column2: GOLDBERG-Mrs. Hiram Charles (Mildred Weinberger), 4,841 Broadway. announces the bar mitzvah of her son, Philip Louis, on Oct. 29, 1938, at Inwood Hebrew Congregation, 111 Vermilyea Ave., 9:30 A. M. Reception at home following services and Sunday afternoon. Friends, relatives cordially invited.

Running in championship form all three times down, Field Trial Champion Hollybrook Abandon, owned and handled by Harry I. Caesar of New York, won the open all-age stake for springers, today's feature of the three-day meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, which will be concluded tomorrow.

Sparked by a dashing set of forwards, Wales defeated England, 4-2 before a record crowd of 55,000, including War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha, at Ninian Park today. Capitalizing on their opportunities in front of goal

The subject of "intermediate credit," which has been under discussion in Wall Street and Washington lately, seems destined, so far as banks here are concerned, to join the classic status of the weather-something that everybody talks about and nobody does anything about.

The University of Delaware is starting this year a five-year course in chemical engineering with the twofold purpose of giving more advanced technical training and at the same time of broadening the course. Since chemical engineering rests upon a thorough training in the basic subjects of chemistry, which take up a large part of the student's first three years, the purely chemical engineering subjects are necessarily crowded into the latter years.

The net improvement in prices in the financial markets last week was comparatively small as followers of the markets came to realize that the gain in general business activity is not being accompanied by a commensurate increase in corporate profits.

Paul Christman's talents as a passer were more than matched by his ability to carry the ball as the University of Missouri Tigers defeated the Washington University Bears, 13 to 0, in an inter-Conference game today.

WE have here the sixth and final volume of Mr. Churchill's life of his ancestor, the Duke of Marlborough. It is as a whole, therefore, that we can now survey the achievement. The work is stupendous in magnitude and mobilization of detail. That is obvious. Also, it is obvious that such an achievement must be either a supreme success or a sensational failure.
The University of California at Los Angeles jolted Idaho out of its Rose Bowl dream today, swamping the erstwhile unbeaten Vandals, 33 to 0, before 25,000 fans.

BOSTON. THIS has been a big week for Boston. Not within recent memory has there been any thing to compare with its list of four openings. Two of them are new productions,, and all of them have quality trappings.

More than sixty-five prominent men and women, including President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt, will discuss national and world problems under the general theme, "America Facing Tomorrow's World," at the eighth annual Herald Tribune Forum on Current Problems.
The Williams and Tuft elevens battled to a 6-6 tie today. Although pass interceptions and fumbles were frequent, a large part of the play was near midfield.

The engagement of Miss Sylvia C. Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weinstein of Brooklyn, to Max L. Shulman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Shulman of Washington, D. C., has been announced by her parents.
Work will commence shortly on the construction of a new 1,000home development on a 120-acre tract of land near the World's Fair grounds in Flushing, L. I., it was announced yesterday.

The fading Big Six title hopes of the Nebraska Cornhuskers virtually vanished today, wafted away by a 14-to-0 defeat at the hands of an Oklahoma football team which met power with more power, speed with more speed, and trickery with Indifference.
The City Council of Cambridge has furnished the students of Harvard University with as inviting an opening for burlesque as has dropped into their eager hands in many a day.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of The Players will be observed on Nov. 6 with a dinner and program of entertainment at the Waldorf-Astoria. It will be the first public event sponsored by The Players outside of their clubhouse on Gramercy Park.

Mr. and Mrs. Percy Milton Chandler of 280 Park Avenue and Brandywine Lodge, Pocopson, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Louise Chandler, to Samuel D. Hughes, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hughes of Germantown, Pa.
These American citizens left Canton yesterday for Hong Kong, Irving N. Linnell, American Consul General, reported to the State Department today:

William and Mary, playing before a homecoming crowd of 5,500, bowed before a highly favored Virginia Military Institute team, 14-0, today. The game was featured by a 74yard run for a touchdown by Ray Ruett, who intercepted an Indian pass on the third play of the second half.

Sidney Lewis, 33 years old, a salesman, of 126 Riverside Drive, was arrested last night, charged with grand larceny, when a woman pointed him out to two detectives at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street as the man who had given her a worthless check some time ago in a store where she was employed.

For the present the matter or tne constitutionality of the - capital stock tax and the excess profits tax has been set at rest. On Oct. 10 the United States Supreme Court declined to review two proceedings in which taxpayers sought relief from erroneous valuations declared upon their capital stocks.

Mrs. Josephine Douglas Halsted, widow of James Maver Halsted, died yesterday at her residence, 583 Riverside Drive, of the effects of a stroke suffered on Friday. She was 78 years old, a daughter of the late Alfred Douglas, New York lawyer.
THE great wind of Sept. 21 struck at so many different angles that the full tale of its doings will probably never be told. One target for the storm's fury was the MacDowell Colony in New Hampshire.

About 500 city folks from New York competed tonight in the annual husking bee of the Kent Grange, disposing, with as much finesse as they could muster, of about fifty shucks of corn in the field outside the Kent Community Hall between the Congregational Church and the graveyard.

In extending her hegemony over Eastern Asia, Japan has been working not only from the coast toward the interior but also from north to south. The northern part of Manchukuo, which she began occupying in 1931, is at the latitude of Labrador;

Complete approval of the principle of transit unification is announced by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, in a statement declaring the union's intention to start at once a vigorous drive for public support of Constitutional Amendment 9, which would allow the city to go outside its debt limit to the extent of $315,000,000 to finance the purchase of privately operated transit facilities.

Japanese military authorities today supplemented their armed action against Chinese guerrillas with an economic blockade against Chinese Communist areas in Northern Shansi and Eastern Hopeh Provinces.

Big Hurry, an aptly named daughter of Black Toney, carried the white and green silks of E. R. Bradley to victory today in the thirteenth running of the $10,000 added Selima Stakes, Maryland's famous mile test for juvenile fillies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What has happened in Europe in the last few weeks, the partition of Czechoslovakia and the way in which it has been brought about, Is a matter of absorbing and awful interest to every small State in Europe.
THE close of the annual metropolitan championships last week left an uneventful season ahead for local bridge players. Apart from the Brooklyn
Sales tax collections for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $9,730,515, compared with $9,396,878 collected in the same quarter in 1937, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday.

Virginia's backs toppled Maryland under a 27--19 score today. Walt Smith trucked 20 yards through a wide-open hole inside tackle for Virginia's final tally in the last quarter. Maryland came right back to count on a 20-yard pass, Hewitt to Devlin, but it was nothing more than a dying gesture, and the game ended with Virginia still battering at the tired Maryland line.

New construction developments, including welded designs for houses, metal for building fronts, colorfused plate, glass, residence elevators and ingenious kitchen units and heating arrangements, are making homes and buildings more livable and decorative, states a research bulletin edited by the structural service department of the American Institute of Architects from data provided by the Producers Council.

Representative Wright D. Patman of Texas, author of the chain-store taxation bill before Congress, and Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing in Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association,

William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for county executive, declared himself unalterably opposed to any extension of Westchester's parkway system at the first dinner of the recently organized Park Association of Westchester County at the Westchester Country Club here Thursday night. ub here Thursday night.
Senator Wagner said today that he believed all Democratic candidates for State office should declare their support of the national New Deal Administration.

Confusion and controversy necessarily have flowed from that passage in Ambassador Kennedy's Trafalgar Day speech in London wherein he discussed his "theory" that democracies and dictatorships should cease emphasizing their differences. The reasons for the confusion and controversy are many, especially in view of the reputation this particular Ambassador has at the State Department of being amenable to its editing.

Hundreds of hobby clubs, social and civic organizations, schools, libraries and retail stores throughout the United States will celebrate National Hobby Week, beginning on Nov. 21, the Hobby Guild of America, sponsors of the demonstration, announces. Locally the Guild will stage a large National Hobby Show during the week at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street.
FROM British sources last week came information regarding the first philatelic results of Germany's acquisition of the Sudeten area of Czechoslovakia.

It has been estimated that fully $10,000,000 has been spent in this country on television research since 1925. Yet until Mr. David Sarnoff announced that by April 30, 1939, we shall see and hear distant theatrical and other performances on the home screen, no radio company would tell us when practical television would arrive, and this though television has been a reality in and around London these many months.
SUNDAY evening short-wave broadcasts from Hungary, formerly heard between 7 and 8 o'clock, have been lengthened, and often run over the former sixtyminute broadcast period.

Declining applications for jobs, indicating that the peak of unemployment in the financial district may have been passed, and a been marked increase in the number of job openings reported, indicating a general pick-up in employment in the metropolitan area, were reported-yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange committee on replacement, headed by Robert P. Boylan.

The eyes of conflicting groups of Dartmouth alumni and of student editors in Eastern colleges are focused this week on a meeting of the Dartmouth trustees, at which action will be taken on the much debated plan for college ownership and control of the student publications.

More than half the Hunter College students admitted into Phi Beta Kappa, national honor fraternity, last semester, worked under the National Youth Administration at the college, according to Mrs. Dean Smith Schloss, in charge of NYA placements.
Two of the forty-nine Chinese students at Cornell, the second largest foreign group in the university, are the children of statesmen and diplomats well known in the United States.

A Federal court jury tonight convicted three men of conspiracy to transport $25,000 worth of stolen bonds across State lines. Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant immediately sentenced the men--Bernard S. Starr of Schenectady, former professional baseball player; John Hyson of New York City and Harry S. Brown of New Britain, Conn.

As their three-day session drew to a close. more than 400 messengers to the seventy-second annual convention of the Long Island Baptist Association adopted a. resolution last week urging New York churchgoers to vote against the first and eighth proposed amendments to the State Constitution on the grounds that the amendments would divert public funds to sectarian uses.

Several issues of water company bonds were called last week for redemption before maturity. Aside from these, the retirements ordered were in comparatively small volume and consisted of a diversified list of municipal, foreign, land bank and public utility bonds.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

CAIRO, Ill.--The new vehicular bridge over the Ohio River at Cairo, which will be completed by Nov. 1, will be formally opened to traffic and dedicated on Armistice Day, according to an announcement by W. H. Vreason, Mayfield, Ky.,

CHEMICALLY, salt water is a purely utilitarian solution; romantically, it is adventure and the stuff of which dreams are concocted. Bruce and Sheridan Fahnestock had a dream of sailing to the South Seas in their own ship, and one day they caught up to their dream and found it a reality. This is their story.
Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, had the endorsement today of groups of Democratic factional leaders in three counties.

EUROPE rearms; Hitler issues a warning; international conferences are held; troops mobilize and de mobilize. After each momentous event scores of newspapers the world over publish-the next morning-wired and wireless pictures of what happened.

THE HAGUE. TO the Netherlanders the Japanese Army and its doings in China are of less permanent interest than is the Japanese Navy. This is not the semi-paternal attitude of an old instructor toward his now grown-up pupilthe Netherlanders supplied the first ships and training to raise the Japanese Navy from its sampan and sailing-junk era;
A memorial room dedicated to the late Edwin Howland Blashfield, mural painter, will be opened with a private view tomorrow afternoon in the Lawrence Art Museum at Williams College.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Waldemar Koehn of this city, formerly of Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Huntington Koehn, to Vandervoort Rand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Rand of North Tonawanda.

Admitting that French aviation was not prepared last month to assume its proper role in case of war, Air Minister Guy La Chambre, in an interview, declared that in the last eight months measures had been taken that would permit France to recover her place in the air by the end of next year.

Stuart Robert Brinkley Jr., a Yale graduate student in chemistry, was probably fatally burned by the explosion of a concentrated silver chlorin compound in the Sterling Chemistry Laboratory today while conducting research experiments.

Little St. Elizabeth's Chapel at Table Rock, the estate of Mrs. Morgan Hamilton here, formed a picturesque setting for the marriage this afternoon of Miss Lydia Blagden, daughter of Mrs. Francis Meredith Blagden and the late Arthur Campbell Blagden, to Seymour Saltus of New York and Morristown, N. J.

Those who are interested beyond the superficial degree in hunting and fishing in New York State should plan to attend the convention of the New York State Conservation Council, to be held on Nov. 17 to 19 at Kingston.

W. O. Burgin and C. B. Deane, rivals in a fight for the Democratic nomination to Congress from the Eighth District, agreed today to let a non-partisan committee of lawyers decide which of them should receive the nomination. Messrs.
Everton's strength in English soccer was clearly indicated today when the Lancashire club, weakened by the absence of three star players called for international duty, trounced Leeds United 4-0.

Europe is still in the middle of a mighty revolution that has blasted away the political system, moral values and borders established at Versailles. The convulsions of this revolution are still shaking the Continent, but out of the din and confusion accompanying it emerges one central fact.

Presidents of many Eastern colleges and universities and prominent men in the fields of education, religion and business will be guests of Hamilton College next Saturday for the inauguration of Dr. W. H. Cowley as eleventh president.

The Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion, first benefit ball of the season, will take place on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf - Astoria. Approximately eighty-five debutantes of the Winwill participate in the cotillion.

District Attorney John T. Delaney said today he would issue subpoenas for nearly a dozen more persons in what he described as "an exhaustive inquiry into all phases" of the escape of three convicted O'Connell kidnappers from the Jamestown jail last November.

Oregon State College came from behind today to down oft-beaten Washington State, 7-6, in a Pacific Coast Conference football game. Prescott Hutchin's point after touchdown left the Beavers with an outside chance of winning the conference title.
Economists scanning the charts, business men studying the balance sheets, government officials reading the reports--all found some signs last week of definite business upturn.
Outclassing their opponents throughout the four periods, Muhlenberg today amassed a 46-to-6 score to defeat Ursinus in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference game.

Mrs. Eleanora A. Iselin Kane, widow of Colonel Delancey Astor Kane, died yesterday at her home, The Paddocks, New Rochelle, at the age of 89. Mrs. Kane was the eldest daughter of Adrian Iselin, New York merchant and banker, and Eleanora O'Donnell Iselin, daughter of Columbus O'Donnell of Baltimore. Her marriage took place in 1872.

LIKE a bolt from the blue and a dream come true, the announcement from the Radio Manufacturers Association that the industry will build hometelevision sets and offer them in the public marketplace next April, electrified the radio field like no industrial proclamation since the advent of the broadcasting "craze."

Miss Gertrude Regan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Regan of 127 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, was married to Dr. Vincent E. Maroney, son of Mrs. Edward Maroney and the late Mr. Maroney, yesterday morning in St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.
Marshall College of Huntington, W. Va., which last week took first place in national scoring lists, was downed today by Toledo University in a 13-to-7 upset.
The Commodity Credit Corporation through Oct. 20 had made loans on 1,391,604 bales of cotton from this year's crop, according to an announcement yesterday through the New York Cotton Exchange.

The thirty-first annual conference on taxation, under the auspices of the National Tax Association, will be held in the Hotel Statler, Detroit, Mich., from tomorrow through Friday. Federal levies, public utility, railroad and industrial taxes and trends in taxation outside the United States will be discussed.
SOME very engaging people have some slightly improbable but thoroughly delightful adventures in Victor Canning's second book on Mr. Finehley. If you read the first
General Shunroku Hata, Commander in Chief of the Japanese armies that are pressing toward Hankow, believes the capture of Hankow will end large-scale Chinese resistance.

A fumble by Springfield College on its own 10-yard line in the third period led to its defeat, 7-3, by Providence College today. It was the first victory of the season for the Friars in five starts. Springfield's points came on a placement field goal in the second period by Tom Anderson from the 20-yard line.
Football history repeated itself in the Baltimore Stadium today when Princeton and Navy wound up in another deadlock, 13-13, in the presence of some 40,000 spectators.
Although still hampered by warm weather, retail trade made a less unfavorable showing last week, when a drop in temperatures brought out some buying of seasonable goods.

Tonight's bulletin about President Kemal Ataturk says the acute symptoms that manifested themselves this week have now completely disappeared. His pulse is strong and regular at eighty, his respiration normal, and his temperature 98.2.

The opening series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx senior high school swimming championship of the P. S. A. L., held yesterday in the 25-yard pool of De Witt Clinton High, were marked by performances which indicate a successful season for the division.

Wagner College crushed the New York Aggies of Farmingdale, L. I., yesterday at Grymes Hill in Staten Island, 27 to 0. to record its second straight football triumph. Last week Wagner defeated Panzer for its first victory on the gridiron in four years.

Mrs. Madeline Tully, 55 years old, of 519 East Eighty-third Street, Manhattan, was brought before Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Kings County Court yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Francis A. Madden.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Lucille Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Loomis Williamson of New York, to Lawrence Richardson Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Livingstone Palmer of Winchester, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

WHAT this department needs is a little Pollyanna in its corner. We try so hard to be optimistic, but it doesn't work. We just keep worrying and seeing the dark cloud on the silver screen and fretting over Darryl Zanuck. This morning's report from Hollywood says that Mr. Zanuck has promised to reform.

Representative John J. O'Connor's charge of political coercion of the needy by relief investigators delivering relief checks in his district was challenged yesterday by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, who said that relief checks were sent by mail and not delivered by investigators.

MADAME CAPET-Tuesday evening at the Cort Theatre. About the French Revolution, this one has been adapted by George Middleton from the French of Marcelle Maurette. Eva Le Gallienne plays the title role, and among her associates are George Coulouris, Frederic Tozere, Blanche Ring, William Post Jr., George Baxter, Harold Gould, Le Roi Operti, Earle Mitchell, Bram Nossen and Merle Maddern.

More than 100 undergraduates at City College were elected to posts in the House Plan, social activities unit of the college, for the Fall semester, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank Davidson, director.

Commander Ambrose Day's New York Power Squadron will combine business with pleasure Thursday evening at the Hotel McAlpin. Under the supervision of Norbert Foerster a members' meeting will be held at 6 o'clock, and, because women are barred from membership in the U. S. P. S., however competent they are as navigators, they will have to wait in anterooms until 7 o'clock for the dinner in the hotel ballroom.

The bristling gridiron rivalry between the New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers will be renewed at the Polo Grounds this afternoon with second place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League at stake and a possibility existing that the winner may vault into the lead.
BARTHA-KAUFMAN-Mrs. William Lewis of Woodside, L. I., announces the marriage of her sister, Ruth Kaufman, to Gene, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. C. Bartha, of Woodmere, L. I., taking place Oct. 23, 1938.
William Fowler, a founder in 1894 of the Fowler Sellars Company, local retail hardware dealers, died suddenly today in his home, 286 Mamaroneck Avenue. His age was 79.

HOLLYWOOD. CLASSICS of the air being scarce-or psychological, like Exupery's "Vol de Nuit" Hollywood has had to hack out its own extrovert sagas without benefit of prosodists, which it has done pretty well so far, and "Men With Wings," or something like it, was inevitable.

The Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic is due today from the Channel ports. Passengers inelude Charles W. Ogden, Miss Mary F. Ogden, Mrs. Lee E. Forrest, Miss Mary Morgan, Professor Henry E. Andrews, Dr. Ivor Euston Brown, Mrs. L. M. Iselin and W. L. Pigott.

Officers representing all reserve units of the army and navy from the Second and Third Corps area received instruction in the use of gas masks here this afternoon from Captain Maurice E. Jennings, First Division chemical officer of Fort Hamilton,

The University of Tennessee's undefeated powerhouse toyed with The Citadel today to win a listless football game, 44 to 0, before 8,000 spectators. Major Bob Neyland used his varsity about five minutes in the second quarter and, apparently deciding that they did not have enough work, kept his first and second string elevens on the field for a signal drill after the contest.

More than 6,000 Boy Scouts and troop leaders from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the largest number in the history of the pilgrimage, marched from Oyster Bay High School to Youngs Memorial Cemetery today to mark the birthday of Theodore Roosevelt by exercises and the laying of a wreath at the iron gate of the tomb high on the hill overlooking Long Island Sound.

Bumble Bee of Delwin, champion Kerry blue terrier from the Knoc Luing Kennels of John Mulcahy of the Bronx took best in show honors at the exhibition of the Queensboro Kennel Club in Flushing yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Bitensky of Far Rockaway, Queens, of the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Ruth Bitensky, to Moses Schonfeld of London, England, elder son of Mrs. Victor Schonfeld of London and the late Rev. Dr. Schonfeld, who was presiding rabbi of the Union of Orthodox Hebrew Congregations of the United Kingdom.

The jubilant hopes with which Hungary greeted the Munich conference have faded away. While the German and Polish banners wave over "liberated" territories, all that Hungary has gained thus far has been a frontier town and a railway station.
State officials who administer the joint Federal-State unemployment insurance program accused the Social Security Board today of exceeding its powers.
Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Peru, sailed yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria, accompanied by his wife and their daughter, Dulcie Ann.

Mr. and Mrs. William Bayard Heroy of this place and Houston, Texas, gave a dinner party at their home here tonight at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Totten Heroy, to Claude James Kirkland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirkland of Leonia, N. J.

Eli Berman, head of the woodworking business bearing his name at 316 East Sixty-fifth Street, New York, died suddenly near here yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while at the wheel of his automobile.

The Mexican Attorney General announced last night that after a careful investigation he had found no evidence that President Lazaro Cardenas's brother, Damaso Cardenas, or any other members of the Cardenas family had anything to do with the contract for 25,000,000peso Mexico City-Guadalajara Road or any other public work undertaken by the present regime.

The University of California's marauding Bears, heading for a second straight Pacific Coast Conference football championship and the Rose Bowl, downed a fighting University of Washington eleven, 14-7, before 25,000 spectators today.

NOT often, it is safe to declare, are exhibitions such enormous successes before ever they open at all. Excitement behind scenes at the Metropolitan Museum has, we now learn, been sustained at an extraordinarily high pitch for weeks.

It is reassuring to learn, from the letter sent by one of Secretary Wallace's assistants to the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee, that the proposal for a two-price system for distributing agricultural surpluses is at this stage only a suggestion offered for discussion.
Bloomfield High School, defending Group IV football champion of New Jersey, registered its second victory, of the season today by overpowering the Dickinson High eleven, 21--0.
JOHN D. LITTLEPAGE is an American engineer who spent ten years, from 1928 to 1937, in the Soviet Union, where he held various responsible positions with the Soviet Gold Trust.
The Trio of New York, which made its Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon in the first of a series of five concerts, is a distinguished addition to the growing field of chamber music.

Mrs. Helen Z. M. Rodgers, candidate for Representative at Large and a member of the Republican caravan, told a group of men and women at the Strand Theatre here this morning that the Democratic claims to liberalism were absurd in view of the surrender of the Legislature's powers to the executive which she termed "reactionary."

Dr. Ura Garfield Rickert, member of the executive committee of the University School of Dentistry, ?? last night of a heart attack in a Chicago theatre. His age was 59. Dr. Rickert was on his way to St. Louis to attend the annual convention of the American Dental Association.
For the first time in the twenty-five-year history of its organization, the UkrainianAmerican Democratic Club withheld endorsement of all the candidates on the Democratic State ticket.

Miss Willette Alberta Ockendon, a descendant of Patrick Shechan, pioneer settler of Peterborough, Ont., was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to B. Gratz Brown, grandson of the late B. Gratz Brown, onetime Governor of Missouri and United States Senator from that State.
Housing authorities in New York City and the larger towns of the State have been invited by Louis H. Pink, chairman of the State Board of Housing, to attend a meeting at the Hotel Astor Nov. 4 and 5.

DETROIT. REFLECTING a much heavier demand for new cars than had been anticipated even a month ago, automotive production was stepped up sharply during the past week, with the to tal running approximately 35 per cent ahead of the previous week.

Strength of next October contracts imparted a steadiness to quotations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but advances in the near-by delivseries were retarded by liquidation of the December and a less active trade demand.
A syndicate to be known as the Paragon Funding Corporation has been formed by William S. Sussman, with the object of acquiring Manhattan real estate.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Josephin Burnham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Dexter Joseph Burnham of Mont clair, to Alexander Cameron Dun can Jr. of Dallas, Texas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan of Glen Ellyn Ill., took place this afternoon in the home of her parents.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Kennedy Kelly, daughter of Mrs. Cornelius F. Kelly of this city and Springfield, Vt.,- and the late Mr. Kelly, to Edward Joseph Kelly, son of Mr. and- Mrs. Edmund P. Kelly of Amsterdam, took place here this morning in St. Augustine's Church.
Governor Lehman asked the voters of New York State today to send Democratic Senators to Washington "to strengthen the hands of President Roosevelt in his humane legislation."

Music has become a part of the daily life of faculty and students at Skidmore College, whether they sing or play an instrument. This has come about through extension use of a library of phonograph records, sheet music and scores given to the college several years ago by the Carnegie Foundation.

Charles Aubrey Grant of Toronto was convicted today of buying jewelry, stamps and various valuables from Vienna Jews with the intention of smuggling them out of the country. He was sentenced to a fine of 120,000 marks or ten months' imprisonment.

TWO lines of "Master series" cars were introduced yesterday by Chevrolet. Powered by six-cylinder engines of eightyfive horsepower and built on 112 1/4 inch chassis, the Master De Luxe and Master 85 have in common six closed body styles of aero-stream design.

Freddie Wilson, 166 1/2, Pompton Lakes, N. J., gained the decision over George Brothers, 161 3/4, Harlem, in a thrilling eight-round bout last night at the Rockland Palace. So keenly was the battle fought that the boxers were rematched for next Saturday.

SAM LEVENE is one man who can take a hint and depart on schedule from Hollywood. He refuses to play the heartbreaking game of waiting and waiting for the producers to insist that he stay with them, and to back up their insistence with a contract.

This afternoon Benjamin Kotlowitz will draw his old praying shawl around his thin shoulders, ascend the altar of the small synagogue in the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Teller Avenue, the Bronx, and deliver a confirmation speech which he says he made at his first confirmation 100 years ago.

CAPE TOWN. SOUTH AFRICA, which leads the world in the preservation of wild life, has just opened another game sanctuary to tourists. This is the bontebok park, near the southern tip of the continent, and 100 miles from Cape Town. A remarkable story lies behind the enterprise.
Army defeated Boston University 40 to 0, today before 10,000 specta tors in Michie Stadium. The Cadets made six touchdowns and were successful in four of their tries for. extra points.

Several striking evidences that the home construction and selling activities in Queens; and adjacent sectionss of Long Island are likely to exceed all former Fall and Winter records were presented last week in the enlarged building programs being made for the coming months in several localities and the well-sustained demand for homes in both the low' and medium-priced ranges.

The $725,000,000 Columbia, Gas and Electric Corporation took steps yesterday, in accordance with the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, to effect write-downs throughout its utility system that may aggregate as much as $195,000,000.

Seven prizes were awarded today for entries in the annual joint exhibition of the Philadelphia WaterColor Club and the Pennsylvania Society of Miniature Painters, which opens to the public tomorrow at 1 P. M. in the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. Represented in the show are 703 works by 371 artists.

A large group of patrons has been enlisted for the annual theatre benefit of United Neighborhood Houses of New York. The performance tomorrow night of the "The Fabulous Invalid" at the Broadhurst Theatre has been taken over for the event.

Columbia High School's eleven took to the air to score a 7-to-0 victory over Westfield High School today. Columbia started from its 19-yard stripe and worked the ball by the overhead route to Westfield's 5. Here a pass from Gregory Hillman to Ed Arnoldt Netted a touchdown. Hillman converted from placement for the additional point.

The dismissal of a Moscow professor this week for teaching such "nonsense" as the. idea that Menshevism was based on the principles of Aristotle and that Plato was the founder of fascism is a trivial incident in itself, but it is another illustration of Soviet distaste for what is termed "vulgarism" and "formalism" in education.

OSSIP GABRILOWITSCH and Mark Twain had some important characteristics in common-a quick temper for one thing but especially a sense of justice and love of liberty. Clara Clemens recalls here an earnest conversation between the young musician and her father on the subject of race prejudice.

As the 1938 Congressional race heads for a finish in hundreds of individual contests Nov. 8, a semifinal survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, shows that the Republican party will cut into the Democratic majority in the House of Representatives for the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt became President.

Long-standing reports that Alexander A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Ambassador, would not return to the United States were revived today upon disclosure that Constantine A. Oumansky, Soviet Charge d'Affaires, would entertain at the embassy's annual birthday party, Nov. 7.

Once again science has extended a helping hand to the gardener--this time in the form of an invisable coating for plants, shrubs, and trees which, by retarding evaporation from leaves and stems, checks the consequent drying out of the plant tissues and the roots.

Criticizing the Court of Errors and Appeals for declaring the Young Assembly committee had no power to investigate Hudson County's election machinery, W. Warren Barbour, Republican Senatorial candidate, asserted tonight that "the major problem of the Republican party in New Jersey today is to assure honest conduct of the Nov. 8 election in Hudson County and to prevent a repetition of the scandal of November, 1937."

MISS. Constance Holme is as deeply rooted in British soil as a Druid oak, and the particular part of England to which she is so attached is the lovely, hilly farm country and cliffed coasts of Westmorland.

With 20,000 supporters of four high schools in the Ebbets Field stands yesterday, the unbeaten football teams from Erasmus Hall and Abraham Lincoln kept their records intact by beating New Utreclit and Manual Training in a double-header. Erasmus outscored New Utrecht,

Failure to convert extra points caused the downfall of the Mount St. Michael High School eleven as the Bronx players bowed to Central Catholic High of Lawrence, Mass., yesterday on the loser's gridiron.

Plans for the organization of a new committee on management practices, which will -concern itself with the entire field of building management, were revealed at a meeting of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York last week in the Hotel Astor.

Miss Mary Park Heuser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Charles Heuser of this city, was married to A. Frederick Nielsen, son of Mrs. Christian Nielsen of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Nielsen, yesterday afternoon in the Gold Room of Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Vruwink of this city.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Whittem of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Huntington Whittem, to Paul Cushing Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph L. Howard of Rahway, N. J.

William Randolph Hearst, in an address broadcast last night over the Blue network of the National Broadcasting Company, urged the United States to remain aloof from the affairs of France and Great Britain and "save our strength, our wealth, our arms" to preserve peace and democracy at home.

The Erskine Hewitt collection of Americana realized $98,615.50 at auction. The sale, which began last Tuesday, was completed yesterday afternoon at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

Politics was with us, unseasonably, during most of last Summer. The primary elections, usually waged on personal and local issues, took on unusual national significance, for on the Democratic side President Roosevelt had given many of the campaigns a common denominator -- the issue of "liberalism," which he defined as loyalty to the New Deal.

THE thirty-sixth annual exhibition of water-colors and the thirty-seventh annual exhibition of miniatures opens today at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. The water-color exhibition includes the work of 315 artists representing twenty-eight States, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, China, France,- Canada, Switzerland and England.

Led by blouses and skirts with a rise of 30.4 per cent, fourteen divisions of local department stores registered sales increases in September compared with the same month last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Scoring a touchdown in the first few minutes of the game and adding the extra point, the Valley Stream Central High School football team registered a 7-6 victory over Baldwin on the loser's field today before 4,500 fans.
After more than thirty years of talk and frustrated planning for a Chicago subway system, actual boring of the city's first underground passenger tunnels will begin in mid-December.

The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants will discuss the emergency taxes of New York City and the Chandler Bankruptcy Act, among other topics, at its sixteenth annual Fall conference at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow Nearly one thousand certified public accountants are expected to attend.

The WPA is no longer regarded by thoughtful business men as a charitable or political agency, but rather as an important element in the industrial life of this city, Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, told 1,200 WPA supervisors yesterday at a meeting in the Adelphi Theatre, 152 West Fifty-fourth Street.
Endorsement of the candidacy of Dorothy Bellanca, American LaborRepublican candidate for representative in the Eighth Congressional District, Brooklyn, was given yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman's balanced budget was attacked here today by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, as a piece of "bookkeeping sleight-ofhand." Juggling, Mr. Dewey charged, had created a paper balance that did not truly reflect the State's financial condition of a deficit of $73,500,000.

Completion of enrollment figures shows the largest undergraduate body in six years at Mount Holyoke College this Fall and necessitates an overflow of freshmen into upperclass houses, beyond the four residence halls especially designated for entering students.

While organizations of women are debating what role they are to play in relieving the condition of the "stateless" population of Central Europe, Miss Emily Greene Balch of Wellesley, Mass., founder and honorary president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, is developing a plan for absorbing a segment of the refugee population.

THE American public has but a hazy notion of the importance of South America in the world of art, particularly as a field for the activities of musicians. The taste of the South American public is admittedly highbrow.

The Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies awaited word from Washington yesterday on their application for exemption of messenger boys from the provisions of the Wage and Hour Act, which becomes effective at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.

After occupying the two-story building at 10-12 East End Avenue, corner of Eightieth Street, for thirty-four years, the Electrical Testing Laboratories has moved to the eight-story building at 2 East End Avenue, corner of Seventy-ninth Street, which it purchased two years ago, and is now utilizing five floors in that structure.

The executivee committee of the recently formed C. I. O. Council of New Jersey sent a peace proposal today to the State executive committee of the American Federation of Labor, suggesting that the two State orsanizations work out a practical program of cooperation, regardless of the war between the national organizations.

The Cortland Teachers College eleven defeated East Stroudsburg State Teachers today, 19-13, before 3,000 in the annual homecoming day game. With the score tied at 13-13 in the third quarter, Kashata, substitute halfback,. tore around right end for the winning touchdown.

Washington and Jefferson spoiled Dickinson's home-coming celebration today with a 14-to-6 victory. Macel swept right end for 3 yards for a touchdown after a 60-yard drive by W. and J. in the second quarter. Grimm, guard,

Major Henry Burnell Faber, consulting chemical engineer and expert on pyrotechnics, who was president of the Driggs-Faber/ International Flare Signal Company of Tippecanoe, Ohio, died at his home here today. Born in Brooklyn 61 years ago, he was graduated from Harvard in 1898.

The rising tide of automotive employment as revealed this week by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors, and K. T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, is construed by those familiar with the workings of the industry as reflecting a much better than anticipated current retail demand for new automobiles.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Helen Wales, youngest daughter of Mrs. Arvine Wales of Saturday Cove, Northport, Me., and New York, and the late Mr. Wales, to Stephen Ailes of Martinsburg, W. Va., son of Mrs. Eugene E. Ailes and the late Mr. Ailes.
THE Sculptors Guild, which made so inspiriting a start last Spring in a vacant lot on Park Avenue, opened yesterday its second show, this time indoors, at the Brooklyn Museum.

ABRAMS-HEYMAN-Mrs. Samuel Heyman of Jersey City announces the engagement of her daughter, Judith, to Mr. Harold Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Abrams of Englewood. BELFER-KRANISH-Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kranish, 98 Riverside Drive, announce the engagement of their daughter, Jean, to Mr. Ira M. Belfer, Brooklyn.

Kansas State's powerful football machine, sparked by the brilliant passing of Melvin Seelye and the long-range punting of Bob Briggs, rode triumphantly over Indiana, 13 to 6, today before a crowd of 20,000.

Notre Dame, off on another march for national championship honors, relegated Carnegie Tech to the ranks of the defeated teams today in the most bruising encounter the Fighting Irish have played this season.

As the scoreboard clock clicked off the game's final six seconds, Stan Mikulka scored N.Y.U.'s only touchdown on Fisher Field today, but the subsequent placement attempt went awry, so that Lafayette's football warriors defeated the favored Violet, 7 to 6.
Trinity's passes clicked against the Coast Guard Academy today for a 26-to-0 decision. Kelly made two touchdowns, Wilcox and Morris providing the other tallies.

Edward M. Hart, president of the Yonkers Civil Service Commission, died today in Washington, D. C., while attending a national convention of civil service officials, according to word received by his family here. He was 70 years old.
thinks Europe, particularly the "fascist States," has imported the high-speed work methods for which America used to be famous and the United States instead has become a nation of serene leisure.

The undefeated, untied University' of Santa Clara, one of the two great football teams of the West Coast, strengthened its bid for national recognition today with a smashing 21-to-6 victory over the University of Arkansas Razorbacks.

Dick Pinck of Paterson, N. J., Washington and Lee sophomore who had been idle all Fall until today, dashed 88 yards in the third quarter to give Washington and Lee a 6-to-0 victory over V. P. I. in the victors' homecoming game.

The first performance this season of Wagner's opera, "Tristan und Isolde," on the afternoon of Dec. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera, will be given in behalf of the Manhattan School of Music, formerly the Neighborhood Music School.

It has been a good many years since Georgia Tech won a football game by a point after touchdown, but it happened today as the Engineers opened their Southeastern Conference campaign by defeating the Auburn Plainsmen, 7 to 6, before 20,000 fans. It was the forty-second renewal of the rivalry between the schools.
A gallant stretch drive gave the Belair Stud's colt, Johnstown, a nose victory over Dixiana's Allegro in the twenty-fourth renewal of the Breeder's Futurity for two-yearolds at Keeneland Park today.

Selecting one of the busiest sections of the Bronx for their crime, five thugs, three of them armed, walked into the Paris Beauty Culture Academy, 2,545 Webster Avenue, at Fordham Road, early last night, ordered twenty-nine women and one man into a rear room and escaped with more than $300.

The annual report of Dean C. Scott Porter of Amherst College shows a trend among students here toward study of the social sciences. Registration in the political science courses increased from 81 in 1931 to 185 in 1937-38; history, from 452 to 560, and economics from 254 to 456.

WE were much flattered last week to be among those invited by RKO-Radio Pictures to attend a private or semi-private showing of an all-Disney program of short subjects, ending climactically with positively the first preview of "Ferdinand the Bull" East of the Rockies. Even Munro Leaf, the author,
The Turkish Government promised to take disciplinary action today against a sergeant of the Turkish Army who killed a French lieutenant at Antioch, Syria.

With only five relatives present, a brief funeral service was held yesterday in the Plaza Funeral Home, 40 West Fifty-eighth Street, for Mrs. Dorothy Hale, who was killed Friday in a plunge from her apartment in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. About twenty floral pieces rested around the white coffin.

Despite all the losses inflicted upon Czechoslovakia, her trials are far from over. The worst at the moment is the complete uncertainty as to the future. Efforts at reconstruction are lamed. by the fact that the frontiers with Hungary and Poland are still fluid. This is still no State,

The former Munson liner American Legion will be offered for sale at public auction on Pier 48 on Tuesday, marking the first step in the final disintegration of the fleet that formerly carried the American. flag into all important ports on the east coast of South America.

Iona Prep triumphed over Tuckahoe High by 7-0 today, Walter Murphy intercepting a pass and carrying the ball 50 yards for a touchdown in the final minutes. Bill Sexton made the extra point on a placement kick without a Tuckahoe player on the field, the losers claiming holding on the touchdown-play.

A quick turnover in the Madison Square section occurred yesterday when the Belhar Corporation sold to a builder the three three-story houses at 105, 107 and 109 East Twenty-fourth Street, near Fourth Avenue.

A gold rush has started to the chateau country around Gex on reports that three unidentified persons found a buried treasure-24,000 eighteenth century gold florins worth $70,000on the grounds of the uninhabited Chateau de Roussillon.

Brown defeated Rhode Island State College, 40 to 21, today, but the outmanned Rhode Island team set a new high for points against the Bruin in the intrastate series. Brown tallied the seventh play of the game and held the Rams at bay until the third period.

The American premiere of Michel Fokine's "Don Juan," to the music of Gluck, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night constituted the ninth and last of the impressive list of novelties on the present season's schedule of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo.

The whole system of police bailbonding methods in Brooklyn was under scrutiny yesterday as high police officials conferred all day in the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn and took further vigorous steps to get at the bottom of the affair that resulted in the arrest Friday of Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan on the charge of stealing 7,200 arrest records from that station.

After the transfer of Ambassador Andre FrancoisPoncet from Berlin to Rome, the French Cabinet announced today a sweeping revision of the diplomatic service, including important changes in the staff of the Foreign Office.
The United States Army team increased its lead over Mexican and Chilean entrants today in the Inter-American Horse Show.

Causes leading up to the recent reduction of 20 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil east of the Rocky Mountains show clearly that the trend of prices for both crude oil and its products will depend almost entirely on the effectiveness of the Various State regulatory bodies In controlling the output of the raw material.

The firm of R. H. Johnson Co. has been formed to transact a general investment business with its main offices at 70 Wall Street. The firm, which has memberships in the New York Stock and Curb and Philadelphia Stock Exchanges, is composed of Rupert H. Johnson, Joseph H. Amy, Joseph D. Euler, Armon D. A. Crawford and T. Reid Rankin.

The former British Concession here, which was returned to China in 1927 under an agreement that retained British administrative participation by means of minority representation on the Municipal Council, has reverted to virtual British control.

The Roman Catholic Church in Austria is facing a very grave crisis. Attacks on the palace of. Cardinal Innitzer on Oct. 8 drew the attention of the whole world to the Cardinal's personality as well as to the differences that have developed among the Catholic priesthood and laity since Germany's absorption of Austria.

The Madrigal Singers, Lehman Engel director, opened their Bach cantata series last night at the Federal Music Theatre before a large and responsive audience. The program began with the motet, "Jesus, My Joy," and was followed by the cantatas "Take What Is Thine" (No. 144) and "Heart and Mouth and Deed and Life" (No. 147).

Miss Helen Tyson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll S. Tyson Jr. of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Louis C. Madeira 4th, son of Mrs. Welsh Madeira of Chestnut Hill and Louis Madeira 3d of New York.

The man and woman who run a decorating shop in midtown act as entrepreneurs for the artists and craftsmen who submit things to them, help with designs and suggestions. These two have been busy as beavers all Summer on new things, and now- have unusual glass and china to offer.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Herbert of Youngstown, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Herbert, to George Clinton Castleman of New York and Atlantic Highlands, N. J., son of Mrs. Samuel Castleman of Atlantic Highlands and the late Mr. Castleman.

Setting a new course record for the second successive year, Carman Bora of Seton Hall Prep paced his team to first place in the third annual Seton Hall College invitation scholastic cross-country meet today. Seton Hall has won the event, including the prep division, all three years. Kearny successfully defended its high school championship.
Cornell's powerful running attack netted three touchdowns today as the Big Red vanquished Penn State, 21-to-6, before 7,000 on Schoellkopf Field.

Professor John Dewey will lecture on "Democracy and Education in the World of Today" at the Meeting House of the New York Society for Ethical Culture at 8:30 tomorrow evening. This is expected to be the first of a series of annual lectures, sponsored by the Ethical Culture School, the Parents and Teachers Association and the Society for Ethical Culture, in honor of Felix Adler.

The dynamite planted in Foraham's new and high-powered offensive exploded with a roar at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a gathering of 26,866 onlookers as the mighty Rams toppled Oregon, 26 to 0, and pointed to Pittsburgh still undefeated.

The New Jersey Bankers Association will hold its tenth midyear trust and banking conference in the Robert Treat Hotel, Newark, on Oct. 27 and 28, it was announced yesterday by George Letterhouse, president of the association.

The War Department has about completed the first thorough and farreaching survey of American industry for the purpose of putting large key industries in a position to function immediately in the production of munitions and other war supplies in any national emergency involving war with a foreign power.

Members of forty-two trade unions affiliated with both the A. F. of ,. and the C. I. O. joined yesterday in support of Vito Marcantonio in his campaign for Representative in Congress on the American Labor party and Republican tickets, in the Twentieth district. The meeting was held in Lexington Hall, 109 East 116th Street.
Proceedings against Plinio Salgado, chief of the dissolved fascist Intergralists party, have been ordered because of evidence just obtained by the authorities. He is believed to be in Argentina.
The Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $6,097,510 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions.

With the Bergen County Home Show scheduled to be opened Thursiday by Governor A. Harry Moore in the armory at Teaneck, N. J., practically all of the 136 booths have been sold, Harry C. Harper, New Jersey Civil Service Commissioner and chairman of the event, announced yesterday.

Intensive self-search of the actual defense status of the United States, spurred by the personal leadership of President Roosevelt, has led to development in the past month of far-reaching agitation for further military preparedness by the United States.
The Japanese have taken Canton, and it is not farfetched to say that Germany contributed almost as much to the victory as did the Japanese Army.

Fifth Avenue and the neighboring streets are in the midst of a revival of building activity "such as the section has not seen since 1928," according to a survey of construction operations there just made by the Fifth Avenue Association.

Miss Julia Matilda Borchers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Borchers of Bloomfield, was married to Archibald William Baird, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Baird of Schenectady, N. Y., here tonight in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leonard P. Nichols.

Leonard S. Gans, Zeckendorf, Morris Company will be dissolved as a partnership on Nov. 1. Leonard S. Gans will maintain his offices and organization at 285 Madison Avenue under the name of the Leonard S. Gans Company, and Kerr-Gans, Inc., of which he also is president, will continue at that address.

Although many courses in theory and appreciation of art, music and drama are available to students at New Jersey College for Women, the college provides opportunities for attending plays, concerts, exhibits and Jectures designed to give students first-hand experience in the arts.

The Yorkville Dinner Dances, which have been conducted for the past twenty-five years under the auspices of the Yorkville Community Association, will be held this season on Dec. 6 and Feb. 7, at the Ritz-Carlton.

A blizzard raged across Michigan, Wisconsin,and Minnesota today, crippling transportation and disrupting power and communication lines. More than eight inches of snow, borne on a forty-mile gale, had fallen this afternoon in some sections.

The correlation of extracurricular interests of students at Bryn Mawr College with the regular academic program is marked this year with developments in several new fields. Many of the changes have resulted from suggestions by students themselves or have been planned by departments to meet increasing needs for diversified programs of study.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Berdan Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Ward of Montclair, to J. Robert Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Adams of Lincoln Park, took place here this afternoon in Grace Presbyterian Church.
The hope of a protest by united religions here against persecution of Jews was expressed by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein at West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday.

MOST persons who achieve the reading of this ponderous volume will be likely, I think, to conclude that while it is a remarkable and in some respects a brilliant performance, its precise contribution to an understanding of history is far from clear.

DAVID MANNES has told the story of his life to his son and daughter. And a wide public should become its eager audience. Among many interesting autobiographies of men who have risen from obscurity to fame in the exercise of a loved art or profession, "Music Is My Faith" holds a completely individual, and quite unusual, quality of its own.
The latest series of bombing raids on Barcelona ceased with the attack at 10:30 o'clock last night. The official casualty figures give twenty-four dead and seventy wounded.

Professors Marcus Nadler and Jules I. Bogen of New York University will conduct a series of six weekly lectures on "The Financial Problems of the United States" on Thursday from 3:30 to 4:45 P. M., commencing Nov. 3, in the governors room of the New York Stock Exchange.

Miss Sara B. Crawford, Republican candidate for Secretary of State in Connecticut, will speak to a number of women's groups this week, among them a rally in New Britain on Wednesday and a victory dinner Tuesday evening at the Hubbard Heights Golf Club with Mrs. David Waterbury chairman.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 8 were announced today by the State Department: Perry Ellis of Riverside, Calif., Vice Consul at Mazatlan, Mexico, has been assigned Vice Consul at Havana.

DURING the last few weeks an almost constant visitor to the offices of John Golden has been Colonel Stoopnagle, former radio partner of Budd, Hearing of this affable friendship, Tecumseh went right up there to find out about it.

MR. MOFFAT, who will be remembered as the thinly disguised head of "The Mott Family in France," turns now from his patient struggles with the Gallic character and customs to the portrayal of a Bostonian. From his special chair in his club, where he manages to catch the eye of the steward and simultaneously avoid that of the club bore, Mr. Pennyfeather, something short of 50,
North Carolina State flashed a! power drive in the second quarter today and Furman matched it nine plays later, causing a 7-7 tie between the teams for the second straight year.

George Gordon. Battle, attorney, and Louis Nizer of the Film Board of Trade will speak at the annual Merchandising Industries dinner to be held in honor of Leonard Ginsberg, president of the Hearn Department Stores, at the Hotel Astor on Nov. 20.

The East won four of seven intersectional games that were among the features of the day's program, Fordham routing Oregon, Pitt overpowering Southern Methodist, Holy Cross downing Georgia and Colgate defeating Iowa.

Opposition is developing to schemes for permissive incorporation of New York Stock Exchange firms. Obsectors assert the real purpose of the plan is to allow commissions to be split with valued customers and that this is being "played down" by emphasis on tax savings, diminished red tape, more stable capital and other alleged advantages.
The Musketeers of Xavier University came from behind today to defeat the Wildcats of the University of Kentucky. 26 to 7.

Since Icarus, men seeking to bring about human flight have studied the birds as possible patterns. While attempts to imitate the flapping wing have been almost completely abandoned, much that has been helpful to aviation has been learned from bird flight since the Wright brothers gave powered wings to man at Kitty Hawk.
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today that farm cash income during September was $764,000,000. This included $27,000,000 in government benefit payments.

Details of the proposed new constitution now being discussed by various political groups were published in evening newspapers today. The reports agree that Czechoslovakia will remain a parliamentary republic, whose President will enjoy more extended powers, including the right to veto bills after their passage.

Princeton's freshman football team defeated the Columbia cub eleven, 6 to 0, at Baker Field yesterday. A 30-yard pass from Bob Peters, substitute Tiger halfback, to Bud Rose, fullback, accounted for the only score in the second period.

Attorney General Cummings appointed two committees today to collaborate with the conference of Senior Circuit Judges to study two problems brought up at the annual session of the conference last month.

The text of Edward Corsi's reply to questions put to Senatorial candidates follows: On Oct. 20 THE NEW YORK TIMES asked the four New York candidates for the United States Senate several questions which have a vital bearing on some of the more vital problems which confront the nation.

Commitments for holiday merchandise assumed major importance in the domestic dinnerware market yesterday as retailers began covering their needs in better price merchandise. Buyers who purchased sample quantities of higher price dinner sets early last month asked for additional goods yesterday and the day before.

Before a large Father's Day crowd the Taft football team lost to the veteran Hotchkiss eleven today, 13-12. The game also marked the dedication of the new Taft field house. Hotchkiss's first score came early in the first period when Green plunged over from the 4-yard line. Taft registered soon after when Captain Moore went over to climax a long march by Guernsey.

THE St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, under Vladimir Golschmann, will open its fifty-ninth season this Friday afternoon and Saturday night in St. Louis with a program containing the Brahms First symphony, Strauss's "Death and Transfiguration," Ravel's "La Valse" and Weber's overture to "Oberon."

A new "high" for the year was registered by THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Oct. 15. All but one of the components advanced, raising the combined index almost three points to 87.7, which compares with 84.9 (revised) for the previous week and 99.8 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Senator Wagner and Frank J. Taylor, former Controller of New York City, discussed with President Roosevelt today the proposed vehicular tunnel from the Battery in Manhattan to Brooklyn, a $70,850,000 project which the Senator termed the "missing link" in New York's shore road traffic system.

MOZART'S "The Marriage of Figaro" will be presented this Friday in Rochester, N. Y., under the auspices of the Civic Music Association. In the cast will be John Brownlee and Josephine Antoine, both of the Metropolitan; Cecile Sherman, Ethel Codd, Warren Lee Terry, Donald Beltz and Abrasha Robofsky.

Although Tufts College is only 86 years old, it has enrolled this year a member of the fourth generation of a family that has been represented in the student body periodically since the Class of 1863 entered.

The Nazi Senate decreed a sort of compulsory military service today for the Free City of Danzig. All youths from 18 to 25 will be recruited in an auxillary police force where they will receive full military training.
LONDON. IT is sometimes said that when the times are ripe, opportunity will produce the man. The say ing is as fallacious as other popular beliefs. But Sir Henry

The marriage of Miss Lucy de Villa, daughter of Mrs. Francisco Luis de Villa of New Rochelle, formerly of Guatemala City, to Harry Christopher Becker of New York, formerly of Mount Vernon, took place here this morning in the Holy Family Church.
A brilliant touchdown drive from near midfield gave Louisiana State a spectacular 7 to 0 victory tonight over previously unbeaten Vanderilt.
LONDON. IN certain quarters some apprehension has been felt of late owing to what is be lieved to be a great increase in the proportion of detective novels to other types of fiction.
(Played at the Hippodrome.) INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE LAST NIGHT'S RESULTS First Game (Doubles)-Angel Iturrino and Jose Pradera, Basques, defeated Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica, South America, 20 to 10.

Earl Oliver, baritone, gave his first New York recital at Town Hall Mast night, where he was well received by a sizable gathering. His program contained arias by Handel and Verdi, and groups of songs in French, German and English.
ONE approaches each new book by Elizabeth Madox Roberts with the certainty that she will not do what she has done before.

Very few flowers, and certainly no other lily, has ever achieved such universal popularity so rapidly as the Regal Lily (Lilium regale). Standing four to six feet tall, with as many as fourteen white blossoms faintly tinged with rose on each stalk, they are not only a delight to the eye but bear a heavenly fragrance for from two to three weeks in June.

The United States and Germany could have been linked in a regularly scheduled overnight air mail service this year had permission from the postal authorities in Washington been forthcoming, according to a Lufthansa statement today.

Boston is going to use ice cream and cake this year in an experiment to curb Halloween vandalism. Police Commissioner Joseph F. Timilty told his men last night to think up novelties for parties in fifteen police stations on the holiday eve.

Transporter, a 5-year-old from, the Burnt Mill Stable, raced to a twolength victory today in the mile and a half Pleasant Valley hurdle ace, opening event of the ElkridgeHarford Hunt Club's Fall season.

New evidence that travel study can be a more powerful teacher than books has just been compiled by the Progressive Education Association on the basis of tests taken before and after a trip to the coal fields of West Virginia by eleventhgrade 16-year-old pupils in the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University.
Vineland will hold its annual Coronation Ball to select a "Miss South Jersey" on Tuesday at the 157th Field Artillery Armory Hall, on Landis Avenue.

Hobart College took a two-touchdown lead in the first half against Kenyon College today to gain a 19-13 triumph. Both Kenyon touchdowns came in the second half as the Lords' passing attack, Olin and Hancock, clicked for long gains.

After the Japanese capture Hankow, as even the Chinese high command concede they eventually will, then what? Will there be a dramatic conclusion of this undeclared war, which has already continued for more than fifteen months, or will the Chinese persist in their policy of attempting to defeat Japan by attrition?

With the nation displaying more interest in the navy than at any time since the World War, elaborate plans for the nation-wide celebration of Navy Day next Thursday are being completed here and in Washington.

Holy Cross's rebounding Crusaders unleashed a devastating offense today and crushed a big, unbeaten University of Georgia eleven, 29 to 6, in a colorful intersectional football war before 24,000 spectators.

Sir Robert Mond of the International Nickel Board died tonight at his Paris residence at the age of 71. He came here recently for treatment of a stomach ulcer and had been in a critical condition for the last week.

IN recent years, and notably in 1937, automobile manufacturers and sales managers were doing a lot of whistling in the dark. A few were realistic, but many sought, for a variety of reasons to express an optimism which was baseless.
In one form or another, prohibition and liquor regulation have become involved in next month's voting in a dozen States.

Mayor Cornelius D. Scully, whose plans to entertain Mayor Fiorello La Guardia here for the world series were upset by Chicago's Cubs, today telegraphed an offer to make a wager with the New York City Chief Executive on the outcome of next week's Fordham-Pitt football game.

Small declines predominated in the foreign-exchange market yesterday. Net changes for the week were highly irregular. with the pound sterling and the French franc higher while some other important exchanges were down. No transactions in gold were reported yesterday.

Harry Stillwell Edwards, whose Negro folk story "Eneas Africanus" exceeded 1,000,000 copies, died here today of pneumonia. He was 83 years old. The dean of letters in Georgia lived only a week after contracting a severe cold.
White Plains High School, defending champion of the W. I. A. A., gained its first league victory and second decisive triumph of the season by defeating Port Chester High, 41-0, today.

With weight removed from high within her hold, the Canadian championship schooner Bluenose was ready tonight to meet the American challenger Gertrude L. Thebaud tomorrow in the third race of a series for the International Fishermen's Trophy.

THAT rumpus in the arroyo? That rattle of musketry profaning the stillness of the mesa? That whiff of Bret Harte? Ominous, you say? Ominous, indeed, for the Kriskys are loose again, defying the canons of George Pierce Baker, Meyerhold and Gordon Craig.

OCRACOKE, N. C. OCRACOKE ISLAND lures the duck hunter in Autumn as well as the tourist who pre fers lonely byways to populous highways at any time. For on this island, part of the outer banks of North Carolina, wild sand ponies roam the dunes, automobiles run without license plates, and youngsters talk a mysterious jargon-an English dialect retained from their forefathers who landed there more than 300 years ago.
Believing that the public deserves to share in the life and culture of the college, Trinity College has outlined three radio programs a week to take in varied fields of college endeavor.
AFTER his brilliant "symphonic synthesis" of "Boris GoduAnoff," an arrangement by Stokowski from parts of Borodin's "Prince Igor" might be expected to attract interest,

Miss Catherine M. Wheelihan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wheelihan of this place, was married to Lieutenant Frank J. McGinity, Air Corps, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McGinity of Denville, in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here today.

LOS ANGELES. SAFETY in the air was strongly emphasized-and sought-at the annual National Aircraft Production Meeting which ended last week in Los Angeles under the sponsorship of the Society of Automotive Engineers, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce and the Air Transport Association of America.

MOTORISTS sampling the Fall foliage along Seven Lakes or Perkins Memorial Drives, or bemused by the brilliant panorama falling away below the Memorial Tower on top of Bear Mountain often are mildly astonished at the sight of a lone hiker under full pack emerging from the underbrush.
GO-BETWEEN: Shuttling by plane between Washington and Mexico City has become part of the job of Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera,

IT is a significant thing that American composers are turning increasingly to native themes when they think of writing operas. In the past the subject was, more often than not, some grandiose story based on the Bible or some tale of blood and thunder that looked as if it belonged to the old-fashioned Italian opera-thriller school.
The State of Washington's sixtyhour law for domestic workers is unenforceable, in the opinion of Mrs. John Boettiger, although she looks for its ultimate success in the education of employers.

A new section at Lake Hiawatha, near Caldwell, N. J., is being subdivided so that approximately 75 per cent of the site will be restricted to four, five and six room all-year homes in about twenty different styles, ranging from $3,000 to S5.000 in price.

Many women of society are acting as patronesses for the series of four music lectures to be given by Olin Downes at the clubhouse of the Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The first talk in the series will take place on Wednesday morning, when Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera will be guest artist.

Fourteen fraternities at Columbia College pledged 157 students last week in the height of the "rushing" period, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes. Pledging by most of the houses will continue until the Christmas season, when new members will be initiated.

Kutz Pa., State Teachers College toppled Montclair Teachers from the ranks of the undefeated by scoring a surprising 21-to-0 victory in a fiercely contested battle today. The invaders led, 7-0, at half time.

May Irwin, famous American comedienne of a generation ago, died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia in her apartment in the Park Crescent Hotel. She was 76 years old. Miss Irwin had left her Summer home in Clayton, N. Y., for the city ten days ago.

Following price reductions in every major line of men's Summer suits for the 1939 season, the most competitive battle that the industry has ever seen will take place, manufacturers predicted yesterday. Latest group to make a downward revision in price are makers of branded spun-rayon suits,

As the superliner Queen Mary came up to her North River pier last Tuesday she appeared strangely bereft. No frowsy-bowed tugs puffed far below her sleek sides, ready to push and pull her into her berth, for the harbor's towboat-men were on strike.

SIR JAMES BARRIE, apparently haunted by visions of Captain Bligh in "Mutiny on the Bounty," told Charles Laughton in 1936 that he did not want him to play Captain Hook, in the annual "Peter Pan" revival, for fear he would terrify the children, But after the actor, looking "very gentle,"

Amid the hurricane-tangled forests of New England is being waged a battle by an army of 40,000 men to prevent loss of life by possible forest fires, and to salvage fallen timber which amounts to ten times the normal annual cut in that area.

DOES John Bull censor broadcasts, even by his prominent citizens, was a question asked during the past week when Winston Churchill, Britain's former First Lord of the Admiralty, broadcast a reply to Chancellor Hitler that was rebroadcast in the United States but was not broadcast in the United Kingdom.

In one of the major upsets of the interscholastic cross-country season, Anthony Maloney, tall and powerful runner from Morris High, came home inches ahead of James Monroe's star, Frank Dixon, to win the Bronx P. S. A. L. championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

QUEENS CANNING, CORA LYON (Aug. 3. 1937). Assets, $204,779 gross; $84,106 net. To husband. Franklin V. Canning, a life estate. Outstanding holdings in real estate, $175,000. J. Read Smith, attorney, 44 Court St., Brooklyn.

In preparation for the centennial celebration of Fordham University in 1941, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president, announced yesterday the institution of the Taaffe Historical Guild, through which the institution's alumni will cooperate in supplying data for a history of Fordham to be published in 1941.

The Vienna edition of Chancellor Hitler's Munich newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, today published a manifesto bearing the purported signatures of several hundred priests in all parts of German Austria which promised "unswerving loyalty to the people, the Reich and the Fuehrer."

GROUP shows of the week included the annual black-and-white exhibition by members at the Salmagundi Club, continuing until Nov. 4. This is one of the best of the club's essays in the field and brings together more than 200 items.

WHEN Eastern visitors began to invade Western ranches, ranch owners and cowboys called them "dudes." The name clung, and today has spread to South Africa where, according to late announcements, the so-called "dude" has taken to the safari idea with enthusiasm.
Scoring both touchdowns in the second quarter, a well-drilled Amherst football team triumphed over Wesleyan, 13 to 0, today in the first contest of the Little Three series.

HERE are reprinted the contents of "In Our Time," "Men Without Women" and "Winner Take Nothing." with four new stories and a three-act play about the war in Madrid that Mr. Hemingway hopes to have produced on Broadway; but, since it reads well, he prints it first.

The marriage of Miss Janie Miller Averett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Averett of Dixiedale Farm, and Sherman Vail Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Vail Allen of Fair Haven, Vt., took place this afternoon in the Averett residence.

Organized labor's leaders, in both the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, are deeply concerned with what they consider a grave threat to the future of the labor movement-the initiative measures to curb labor which will be voted upon next month in California, Oregon and Washington.

Quiet firmness ruled in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Limited activity developed among the lower priced and secondary corporate issues in the domestic section. Most of these loans, as a result, registered furother improvement.
