The Mexican Government today seized the Mexico City headquarters building various subsidiaries of Standard Oil of New Jersey, including the Transcontinental Oil Company, not ?? in President Lazaro Cardenas's expropriation decree of march 18.
THE Christmas holidays will soon be here and photographers who wish to prepare personal greeting cards for the occasion must soon commence production or be left out in the cold.

Starting tomorrow Governor Lehman will make radio speeches every evening except Sunday until the formal close of the campaign on the Saturday before election at the Metropolitan Opera House, it is announced from Democratic State Committee headquarters.

The election of members of the Constitutional Congress will begin tomorrow and will last three days. The voting will be for a single ticket of forty-two principal and twenty-eight substitute delegates.
Northwestern's Wildcats bared their claws for two bruising touchdown drives today and defeated Illinois, 13 to 0, in Memorial Stadium before 37,000 spectators.

Chicago's Maroons outgained Ohio State's husky team, 401 yards to 381, today, but lost a Western Conference contest to the Buckeyes, 42 to 7, as Jim Langhurst, 187-pound sophomore fullback, put on a oneman show.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 22, unless specified: At San Diego: Bagaduce, Cuyama, Osceola, Trinity. At Manila: Black Hawk, Bulmer, Edsall, Paul Jones, Parrott. Stewart.

Traditional football weather means cold, snappy days with here and there perhaps a drizzle or a downpour, and farsighted fans stock up on woolen things for keeping warm in the stands. One can be miserable at a game if the hands get cold. There are several kinds of new warm gloves for keeping them comfortable.

The twenty-seventh annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America will be opened on Wednesday morning and last through Saturday in the Greenbrier Hotel, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. Not since the passage of the Securities Act five years ago has the industry been confronted with more important problems affecting its method of business than at the present time.

From the angle of the lyricist, the librettist, the composer, the publisher, the artist, the music club and the public, American music will be discussed at a luncheon on Saturday at the Great Northern Hotel, where Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober of Norfolk, Va., president of the National Federation of Music Clubs, will be the guest of honor. Mrs. Edmund H. Cahill, president. will be official hostess for the New York State Federation of Music Clubs.
Mr. and. Mrs. George Peabody Gardener Jr. of Brookline have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabella Stewart Gardner, to Harold A. Van Kirk of Falssington, Bucks County. Pa.

Miss Dorothy Catherine Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander of this place, was married here this evening in the First Reformed Church to William A. Caldwell of Ridgewood, son of Mrs. William Arthur Caldwell of Hasbrouck Heights and the late Mr. Caldwell.

Lithuanian Ministers from various capitals in Europe, after their three days' conference here, issued a communique today reaffirming Lithuania's neutrality and suggesting that with Latvia and Estonia new endeavors should be made to improve their relations with the great neighboring powers.

PISGAH FOREST, N. C. RED-CAPPED hunters from all parts of the Eastern United States have begun to appear in the various divisions of the Pisgah National Forest and are oiling up rifles and shotguns for the largest supervised deer and bear hunts ever to be held

Alfred Civisca, 42 years old, of 315 Melrose Avenue, the Bronx, and Joseph Caruso, 50, of 6,007 Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn, WPA workers, were held without bail yesterday for a hearing on Wednesday by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg
FOR the second time this year Belgian Congo (philately's Congo) has issued a souvenir sheet to publicize King Albert National Park, one of the largest game preserves in the world.

Bowdoin opened defense of its State football championship today by downing Colby, 25 to 18. Colby's early first-period lead was quickly wiped out in the same period as Bowdoin, with Karsokas, legate and Haldane running wild, registered twice. Bowdoin put over another touchdown in the second period to lead, 19 to 6, at the half.

As game a team as has worn the Blue of Yale had one of the season's most stunning victories within its grasp today when a penalty for running into the kicker paved the way for its downfall at the hands of Michigan in the last seven minutes of play in the Bowl. The score was 15-13.

The sixtieth annual United Hospital campaign will be started tomorrow night with a dinner at the Hotel Astor. Preparations for a "broad and spirited" appeal have been made by 4,500 community leaders who have enrolled as campaign workers, it was announced yesterday by C. M. Chester, chairman of General Foods Corporation, who is serving as chairman of the campaign.

City College made it seven in a row over Brooklyn College in the gridiron rivalry between the two as the Beavers romped to a 21-to-O triumph before 8,000 persons at the Kingmen's field yesterday. It was C. C. N. Y. all the way, with the outcome never in doubt.

The uprising of Arabs in Palestine which led this week to the military occupation of Jerusalem is the most urgent of the many urgent problems facing Great Britain. The empire on which h the sun never sets consists of a string of troubles and liabilities stretching around the world.

LATE this afternoon the'orchestra of the New Friends of Music, numbering forty players, more or less, according to the demands of the scores, will make its debut in Town Hall. This is an orchestra of young Americans, averaging 25 years of age, who have had previously little or no experience of orchestral routine.

Miss Pauline Wagner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Wagner of this city, was married to Gordon A. Harrison of Springfield, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Harrison of New York, this afternoon a Kenmore, the Summer home of the bridegroom's parents in Richmond, near here.

A radical departure from the traditional policy of sending only the most highly polished debaters into intercollegiate competition and seeking a maximum of decisions is being made by the University of Maine this year.
PARIS.--Lessons of the recent war scare will serve to perfect precautions that have been taken to preserve French art masterpieces in case of hostilities.

A man described by authorities as an engraver for the underworld, whose talent was such that counterfeiters financed his illegal entry into this country, was arrested early yesterday with an alleged accomplice as the man who designed the plates for $1,000,000 in counterfeited currency passed since 1936.

The new Czechoslovak proposals for the settlement of the frontier dispute with Hungarywere handed to the Hungarian Minister, who transmitted it to Budapest this afternoon. Prague expects the negotiations to be resumed early next week.

A complaint that many colleges graduate specialists in one branch of science with only a "smattering" of knowledge of related scientific fields was voiced today by Dr. Norman L. Bowen, Professor of Petrology at the University of Chicago.

HOW to keep alive the charm and traditions of historic Battery Park and adjoining areas in the face of proposed and needed changes along the lower tip of Manhattan, is a problem which has long troubled the guardians of the city's parks and landmarks.

WHEN Mr. Popper, the house painter, wrote a letter to Admiral Drake he little dreamed that it would bring him fame, prosperity and some very embarrassing moments--all of which he accepted with the poise and simplicity

PASSENGERS on the Queen Mary and other luxury liners which arrived last week in New York witnessed a feat rarely seen even by the most constant welcomers of ships--the docking of big liners without the aid of towboats.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 20. Lauman, Capt. P. G., Portsmouth, N. H., to Cavite, P. I., as manager, Navy Yard. Harris, Lt. D. A., New Orleans, La., to Aslatic station. McInthos, J. H., Navy Yard, Boston, Mass., resignation accepted.
Admiral and Mrs. William D. Leahy have arrived at the WaldorfAstoria from Washington, D. C. Mrs. John Hudson Hall has returned from Europe, and is at 130 West Fifty-seventh Street for the Winter.
To the Drama Editor: I should like to air an outraged howl. It is a cooperative outburst from myself and a number of my associates. It is directed against the awards made this week

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Holden of Haverford, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Holden, to Wilbur L. Lafean Jr., son of Mrs. Wilbur L. Lafean of Wynnewood, Pa.

John V. Sheridan, former Democratic State Senator from the Bronx, announced yesterday his support of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, and appealed to all "true Democrats" to support Mr. Dewey as "a champion of liberty in government."

Let us not despair too soon about California. If the $30-Every-Thursday, otherwise known as the "ham-andeggs" plan, seemed at first to spread like a prairie fire, the forces of sanity have been mobilizing rapidly to dash cold water on it, and their cause is far from hopeless.

President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University announced today the appointment of Dr. Harry B. van Dyke, head of the pharmacological division of the Squibb Institute for Medical Research, as honorary Professor of Physiology in the College of Arts and Sciences of the university.

Henry Peartree, one of the oldest members of the American colony here, who died Thursday in his villa near Paris in his eighty-first year, will be buried on Monday in Saint Ouen Cemetery, on his own wish.

The eighty-acre campus of Tufts College, only five miles from the Massachusetts State House but suggesting the surroundings of some of the smaller colleges in New England, will see the inauguration of a new president, the seventh, on Nov. 4 and will bring together for that occasion a group of young and distinguished figures in education.

In an exhibit of models executed by students, the Harvard Graduate School of Design is demonstrating to the lay public a modern architecture based upon "social changes and technological developments."
Wisconsin's Badgers looked like winners over Purdue this sunshiny afternoon until a young man from Massillon, Ohio., named Mike Byelene, got into the football game in the second half.

An auxiliary committee, headed by Mr. and Mrs. George Hopper Fitch, has been organized to aid with plans for the benefit performance of the new comedy, "Yankee Fable," starring Ina Claire, the evening. of Nov. 9 at the Morosco Theatre.

Thirty Jews-men, women and children-are miserably living in a tent near the roadside in a noman's-land south of this city. One kilometer from Pohrlicz, which has become German, this tent was set up in a field to shelter a group expelled ten days ago from towns where their families had lived for generations.
The University of Maine eleven won its third consecutive game of the season by defeating Bates, 23 to 6, in a State series opener before 6,000 fans today.

Miss Madeline A. Haller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph J. Haller of Millington, formerly of Plainfield, was married here this after. noon to Walter S. Zachary of West Orange, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. P. Zachary of Washington, D. C., at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. William Little. The Rev.

With the hour almost at hand for the Wages and Hours Law to go into effect, Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, today issued regulations covering records to be kept by the employers of the 11,000,000 or more workers who eventually will be covered by provisions of the new act.

More than 2,000 persons are expected here for the opening Wednesday of the golden jubilee convention of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association. Sessions are to continue through Friday. Headquarters will be at the Hotel Ambassador, with the overflow crowd going to the Ritz-Carlton and Chelsea.

Completing what they describe as a thorough and dispassionate analysis of the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements program, the tariff committee of the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday announced that neither the optimistic hopes of those advocating the program nor the pessimistic fears of its opponents have been fulfilled.

The 1939 John Fritz Gold Medal, highest of American engineering honors, has been awarded to Dr. Frank Baldwin Jewett, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories for "vision and leadership in science and for notable achievement in the furtherance of industrial research and development in communication."

Captain Sam Weinberg's first-period field goal from the 20-yard line gave a visiting Hofstra College football team a 3-to-0 victory over the Bergen County Junior College eleven before a crowd of 1,500 at Hackensack High School field today.

TRADE rebounded last week from its setback of the previous period, although high temperatures continued to keep down sales volume on seasonal purchases. Toward the close of the week, -however, the advent of cooler weather was immediately reflected in livelier buying.
Wilson College alumnae from all parts of the middle Atlantic States will discuss plans for their first alumnae college when they return to the campus next Friday and Saturday.
AUS DEUTSCHLAND: In Germany, despite the totalitarian regime, jokes about the leaders and the dictatorship circulate, and last week the following anecdote was being told around Berlin.

The Japanese cannot hope to conquer North China with the present strength of their forces there, according to Miss Jean Ewen, a nurse from Vancouver, B. C. She has just arrived in Hankow, en route home after eight months of volunteer work in the hospitals of the Eighth Route Army in Northern Shensi and Shansi provinces.
Francisco Walker will be the secretary of the first American Intellectual Cooperation Conference which meets here in January following the eighth Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru.

On the eve of World Missionary Day Cardinal Fumasoni-Biondi, Prefect of the Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith, and Mgr. Celso Constantini, secretary of the same congregation, issued a broadcast appeal to the American faithful urging them to give generously to missions this year as they have always done in the past.
The Ford Motor Company, which has been employing approximately 53,000 workers, prepared today for a substantial increase in employment with the stepping up of production of new models next week.

Patrolman Franklin L. Hamm, on duty at the information desk in Manhattan police headquarters, looked up at about 8 o'clock last night as a poorly dressed man and woman appeared on the marble stairway leading from the street, moved wearily across the tiled lobby and hesitated before him, as if embarrassed.

Three players and the referee required hospital treatment after a high school football game ended in a free-for-all fight last night. Shirley Lacer of the Miami Beach team was temporarily paralyzed but was expected to recover.

Mrs. Jessie Jordan, who is serving a fouryear prison sentence for espionage and who has been mentioned at the current espionage trial in New York as one of the intermediaries between German agents in the United States and Germany, has undergone a successful operation at the Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.

It was reliably reported here today that German authorities had forbiden a party of Jews to travel from Germany to Southwest Africa because they were unwilling to allow Jews to settle in the former German colonies until settlement of the colonial question.
THE Federal Communication Commission's radio-monopoly probe of the broadcasting industry, scheduled to begin tomorrow, has been postponed until...

Although education as a bulwark of democracy in this country still leaves much to be desired, a markedly increased emphasis on graduate instruction is one of the most significant trends in American academic life, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared in his annual report to the university council, made public yesterday.

A total of $4,964,263 has accumulated in gifts to Mount Holyoke College since 1924, when the office of the field secretary was first organized under Miss Gertrude V. Bruyn, according to a report made to the Central Fund Raising Committee at their annual Fall meeting this week.
Viscount Craigavon, rugged 67-year-old Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, has given vent to an astonishing outburst against Prime Minister Eamon De Valera of Ireland.

Suffolk was one of the original group of eight counties which made up what we are proud to call the Empire State. Its creation as a county dates back to 1683. The county supplied its share of men to each of our country's wars. The hardy whalers who put out of Sag Harbor were a lesson in American initiative to the entire world.

At a continuation yesterday of hearings before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger on an application by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a temporary injunction to restrain Foundation Plan, Inc., from making allegedly false representations in selling of investment certificates, counsel for the corporation assailed the SEC for attempted abuse of injunctive powers.

At its first consumer forum this season, to be held on Tuesday evening at the Town Hall Club, the Advertising Women of New York will hear a discussion of lingerie from both the retailers' and the layman's point of view.

Miss Cecil Loys Melrose, daughter of Mrs. Wilson Melrose of 611 West 111th Street and the late Mr. Melrose, was married to Robert Joseph Humbert, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard Cecil Humbert of this city, yesterday morning in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, 211 West Seventy-first Street, by the Rev. Charles W. Robinson.

The marriage of Miss Charlotte Eliot Leo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton B. Leo of this city and Tuckahoe, N. Y., to David Seabury Henkel of New York, son of Mrs. David S. Henkel of Richmond, Va., and the late Rev. Mr. Henkel, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Under the direction of William P. Bentz of New York, the Haverford College Glee Club will begin practice for its twenty-fifth season tomorrow night. With the addition of new members from the freshman class the enrollment has reached fifty-six members.

Calls for apparel and Winter-type merchandise arrived in greater volume toward the end of last week as cooler weather in various sections spurred retail trade, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Once I passed through a populous city, imprinting my brain, for future use, with its. shows, architecture, customs, traditions, Yet now of all that city, I remember only a woman J casually met there, who detained me for love of me, Day by day. and night by night we were together-All else has long been forgotten by me .

A FEW short-term exhibitions of interest to photographers are now on display at galleries throughout the city. At the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in the Academy of Music a group of photographs by Helen Thompson, F. R. P. S., will be shown until Oct. 30. At the Camera Club,

Although Archie Sparks, Lafayette crosscountry ace, broke the course record and finished first, New York University won the dual meet today, 20-35. Five N. Y. U. harriers followed Sparks to the finish line at Fisher Field between halves of the N. Y. U.-Lafayette football game.

RESPONSES that differ from those that would be made if the animals were alone are regarded as social in Professor Allee's fundamental definition. Since no one has demonstrated the existence of truly asocial animals, the lower limits of subsocial living cannot yet be defined.

The names of fourteen candidates for the presidency of the American Chemical Society was announced yesterday by Dr. Charles L. Parsons, secretary of the society. The nominees will be voted upon in a poll of the society's 23,000 members.

ANY consideration of recent literary events in Latin America must start with the suicide, at a Summer resort on Stumble Island, of Leopoldo Lugones, the great Argentine writer, and with the death of Genaro Estrada, former Minister of Foreign Affairs in Mexico.

Held in check for three periods by an outweighed but tenacious Norwich line, Middlebury's superior power finally asserted itself in the final quarter to enable the Blue eleven to tally its only touchdown in the closing minutes for a 9-0 victory in the first of the annual State series games today.
The Aeronautics Minister announced tonight that Colonel Mario Pezzi had bettered the world's airplane altitude record by reaching a height of 56,016.94 feet.
The army newspaper Red Star disclosed today the death in an air crash of Alexander Bryandinsky, who flew 4,300 miles non-stop from Moscow to Vladivostok last June with Vladimir Kokkinaki.

Miss Kathleen Gillies McEnery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. McEnery of 333 East Sixty-eighth Street, and Amagansett, L. I.; was married yesterday afternoon to Hugh Frederick Gage, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Gage of Upper Montclair, N. J.

After that terrifying interlude during which the threat of actual warfare in Europe dominated the attention of all the world, interest of the United States is returning rapidly to its State and Congressional election campaign which comes to a head in a day of balloting on Nov. 8.
The Austin (Texas) Housing Authority received congratulations today from Nathan Straus, United States Housing Authority Administrator, on its record low cost housing contract proposals.

PARIS. IF the terrible weeks we lived through in September left no appreciable trace on the music sea son, it is only because that season had not yet begun. Had the crisis developed a month later, there would have been a different tale to tell.
Archbishop Chrysostomos of Athens, Primate of the Greek Church, died today of a heart disease. The Archbishop had entered a hospital Oct. 12 for a rest cure. He was 69 years old.
Plans for the erection of a group of six . large garden apartment buildings in Jackson Heights, Queens, under the FHA rentalhousing plan, were announced yesterday.

OMAHA. SANDWICHED in between sighs for the things she wants and cannot have there is a song in the heart of the farm wife out in the wide open spaces. though you might not think so from the volume of quite unmusical sound that comes from this part of the country. But just to prove it here is what one of them writes after a day of cooking, cleaning and mending:

Committees have been formed for the annual Horse Show Ball, principal feature of the round of festivities planned in connection with the National Horse Show. The ball will take place in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 8, that date marking the halfway point in the progress of the horse show, which is to be held from Nov. 5-12 at Madison Square Garden.

THOSE who know the man will be certain that, as the title of this book indicates, Lord Dunsany has set down here only that which is bright and sunny, only what can be recalled without displeasure or pain.

The typical Barnard College freshman is 17 years and 3 months old, weighs 124 pounds and is 5 feet 4 inches tall, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Miss Agnes R. Wayman, head of the physical education department and Dr. Gulielma Alsop, college physician.

Eight hundred officers and 5,500 men, equipped with the army's most modern weapons, demonstrated the new technique of war here this week to the mixed accompaniment of roaring motors and the thud of horses' hooves.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE has been a brief pause in the screen's trend to improve the classics. As a result of unkind words from many sources, particularly the newspaper critics, over the alterations in "Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm" and "Kidnapped,"

The National Labor Relations Board asked the Supreme Court today to determine whether participation by workers in a sit-down strike deprived them of their rights under the National Labor Relations Act. The case is the first of its kind to come before the high court.

Georgetown's football aggregation, composed chiefly of sophomores, remained among the unbeaten elevens by rallying to conquer Manhattan at the Yankee Stadium yesterday by 14-13 before a crowd of 12,000. It was the Hoyas' fourth victory in as many starts.

A correlating agency working in all possible ways to assist students and members of the faculty is the ideal which Miss Blanche Pritchard McCrum, librarian of the Wellesley College library, holds for the library and for the staff of twenty who work with her.
Pennsylvania's gaily uniformed band led a wild snake dance of students under the goal posts of Franklin Field tonight, for the Red and Blue had come back to victory.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight called for election of a Congress that will support and push to "completion" the "greatest program of social and economic reform ever undertaken by a wise and prudent government."

The New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild yesterday listed Magistrate Anna Moskovitz Kross, American Labor party candidate, as "qualified and preferred" among the candidates for justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District.

Albert E. Hurst, bedding buyer for the John Wanamaker Company of New York, died here today at his home after a long illness. His age was 71. Mr. Hurst became affiliated with the Wanamaker company forty years ago and was considered the dean of its corps of buyers.
Cardinal Innitzer made a strenuous denial today of charges that he had been opposing Chancellor Hitler.

A good many people in every country share the sentiment of the Prague editor who discontinued his paper the other day because the world he loved had disappeared. The earth today is full of spiritual refugees.

Like pins on a bowling alley, many scholastic football powers were abruptly toppled from their perches in the unbeaten circle during the past week-end as membership in that select group dwindled considerably to exceed expectations.
Because of a heavy demand the Town Hall, Inc., has leased Carnegie Hall for its special Thursday morning lectures this year, George V. Denny Jr., president of Town Hall, announced yesterday.
One result of the recent war alarms, just disclosed, was that for the first time in a long while savings withdrawals exceeded deposits by 156,700,000 marks in September.

The National Labor Relations Board is asking the Supreme Court to reverse a decision of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals. That decision set aside a board order directing the Fansteel Metallurgical Company of North Chicago to reinstate employes who engaged in a sit-down strike in February of last year, with back pay from the date of refusal to reinstate.

The Boston and Maine Railroad's Fitchburg Division main line from Boston to Troy and Mechanicville, N. Y., crippled since the hurricane and floods of Sept. 21, was reopened for essential freight today and through passenger service will be resumed in a day or two.

Verdi's "Otello" will be the opening performance of the 1938-39 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association on Nov. 21, it is announced by Edward Johnson, general manager. The last two seasons began with music dramas by Wagner.

There are still a good many dirt farmers left in this State and their total crop of complaint about the low state of agriculture is impressive. They will do well to study the crop figures for home-relief farmers.

Mrs. Jane Mitchell, 29, former Broadway actress, was killed and her husband, United States Army Captain Clark Mitchell, was critically injured tonight when their automobile overturned in dodging a horse-drawn cart filled with merrymakers.

Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, told members of the organization today they would have to work even harder now that Chancellor Hitler has achieved the return of Sudetenland to the Reich.

Thomas Mann, Stefan Zweig, Emil Ludwig and Vicki Baum are among the twelve authors represented in the first list issued by the Alliance Book Corporation, a new firm that will publish the work of exiled writers, artists, scientists and scholars.

Football set the stage last Saturday for the sumptuous spread of sport to be offered this coming week-end. It seemed fate contrived in almost every instance to augment the already eager expectancy with which the East is looking to the profusion of big games.

The German wholesale price index on Oct. 19 stood at 105.9, compared with 105.8 the preceding week. The rise was caused entirely by an increase of 0.3 per cent in agrarian prices, the others remaining unchanged.
The rumor has gone round that the Cabinet would be reconstructed along more moderate lines or else be enlarged by the addition of financial experts, but this has been denied.

History repeated itself today when the famous golden-breasted swallows of the Mission of San Juan Capistrano, adhereing to a schedule started 162 years ago, departed early this afternoon for a destination unknown to man, not to return again until March 19, 1939, according to the National Broadcasting Company.
The continued flow of German capital to the United States, which amounted to $13,800,000 in the first half of this year, is represented here not as a flight of German capital,

The opinion that business is "less shy" and is beginning to count boldly on a period of gradual expansion with only minor setbacks is expressed by William R. Kuhns, editor of Banking, the official publication of the American Bankers Association, in the current issue of the magazine.

The charge that Governor Lehman had experienced a last moment change in his attitude toward youth was made last fight by Miss Jane Todd, member of the Assembly and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee. Miss Todd spoke at a tea given by the Colored Women's State Campaign Committee at 175 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

Girls Service League Youth Conference, Hotel Pierre, 10 A. M. Speakers: Dr. Ira S. Wile, Clara Kaiser, Helen Harriss, Katharine Fisher, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, the Rev. Elmore M. McKee. Continues tomorrow.
Sabotage, sniping and arson continued throughout Palestine during the past twenty-four hours.

A plea for the unity of all religious denominations in combating, the forces of destruction in the world today was made by the Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown, Professor Emeritus of the Union Theological Seminary, at the James Memorial Chapel Claremont Avenue and 120th Street, yesterday morning.

A syndicate represented by Dr. J. Alfred D'Onofrio has purchased from James T. Padgett a vacant plot 150 by 180 feet on the west side of Fort Washington Avenue, 662 feet north of 183d Street, running through to Overlook Terrace.

New York City's death rate has been reduced more than one-half in the last sixty years and the infant-mortality rate per 1,000 live births is about one-fourth of what it was in 1879, according to a pamphlet to be distributed tonight by the United Hospital Fund at a dinner at the Hotel Astor opening its sixtieth annual campaign.

Tonight's events: "Traviata," opening of New York Grand Opera Company, Manhattan Center; Efrem Zimbalist and Vladimir Sokoloff, sonata recital, Town Hall; Mischa Violin, violinist, Carnegie Hall; Ernest White, organist, Church of St. Mary the Virgin.
Supply awards valued at $12,747,396 were awarded during the week ended Oct. 15 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Percy Charles Scheuer of 340 West Fifty-seventh Street of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Emily Scheuer, to Charles R. Maxwell Jr. of this city, son of Dean and Mrs. Charles R. Maxwell of Laramie, Wyo.
The pound sterling's continued sharp fluctuations remain the center of interest in financial London. In the rally which began late in the week before last and continued until the middle of last week,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margery Sheffield Atwater, daughter of Mrs. Florence M. Atwater of this place, and of Philip D. Atwater of Glendale, Calif., to Ralph Thompson Crane Jr., son of Mrs. Crane of this city and the late Mr. Crane.
Wiener Grossman, cleaning and dyeing, store at 3,652 Broadway; Ros-Lor Bar Grill, store at 129 E 125th St; Abraham Rosenblum, tobacco store at 50 E 125th St; Porter Co, Real Estate, Inc, brokers.

The liberty we now enjoy under a democratic government will not remain in existence should we sacrifice democracy for a plutocratic, communistic or any other form of rule, Dr. David Sayville Muzzey, Professor of History at Columbia University, declared yesterday morning at the New York Society of Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

A committee headed by Winthrop Rockefeller, son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., will begin work today on a survey of the facilities for training of young people in aeronautics, it was announced yesterday. The committee, to be known as Air Youth of America, will make its headquarters in Rockefeller Center.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell urged support for the unity negotiations being carried on between the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States and the Presbyterian Church, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Tips Manitoba Jake, black and white pointer owned by Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Merion, Pa., won the amateur all-age stake today at the final session of the thirty-seventh annual Fall field trials of the English Setter Club of America.

The Hungarian Government in a communique to day stated that the latest Czechoslovak territorial proposals were unacceptable, while well-informed sources indicated Hungary would wait no longer than Wednesday for a satisfactory reply.

A brochure issued by the trustees of the Berkshire Festival to contributors to the building of the music shed at Tanglewood reveals that 82 per cent of the donations came from people living within fifty miles of the festival site.

A resolution pledging support to Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, and the rest of Republican State ticket today received the signatures of 109 of the 156 Democratic leaders of Allegheny County who supported Lieutenant Governor Thomas Kennedy and his running mates on the Guffey-C. I. O. ticket in the Democratic primary.

In reminding employers that oldage insurance reports for the quarter ended Sept. 30 are due not later than next Monday, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Federal Social Security Board, called attention yesterday to five errors frequently found in previous wage-record reports.

Its "collective sin" has brought the world to the Merge of war, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
More than 200 officials and members of the Methodist Churches in Northern Westchester County attended a Fall convention this afternoon at the Mount Kisco Methodist Church. Dr. Sam L. Hamilton,
The upward movement in cotton prices, which began late last month, continued last week. Active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 21 to 25 points.

Despite the inert condition of the security markets here, there are undoubted signs of a revival in the new capital market. Treasury sanction has been obtained for a big deal in a large line of repatriated British

Leonard Eshmont, the sophomore flash who will carry Fordham's hopes against mighty Pittsburgh on Saturday, rested comfortably in the college infirmary yesterday, impatiently awaiting his release. The Atlas Antelope suffered a twisted knee in last Saturday's Oregon game but has every hope that he will be able to play against the Panthers.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Charles McClarity of this city and Greens Farms, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Marguerita McClarity, to William Joseph Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Joseph Sullivan of South Norwalk, Conn.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Josiah Sherman Mitchell of New Rochelle of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Josephine Mitchell, to William Henry Nicholls, son of Mrs. William Henry Nicholls of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Mr. Nicholls.

An order to cease and desist from violations of the controversial "brokerage clause" of the Robinson-Patman Act has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Webb Crawford Company, a wholesale grocery house, and the Daniel Brokerage Company, both of Athens, Ga., and five concerns which sell commodities to the grocery concern through the brokerage company, the commission announced today.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Howard Elliott Jr. of this place today in the Mount Xisco Hospital. Mrs. Elliott is the former Miss Justine Prince, daughter of Mrs. Charles Barnard Prince of Boston and the late Mr. Prince.

Frederick W. Ritter, candidate of the City Fusion and American Labor parties for Queens District Attorney, made public yesterday a letter he had written to Mayor La Guardia calling for an inquiry by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, into the District Attorney's office, the police and the jails in Queens.

The fact that most of last week was distinguished by stock market reaction did not mean much. Not only had the averages risen 18% points between Sept. 26 and the beginning of last week, giving plenty of opportunity for profit-taking,
The national rankings of the Amateur Fencers League of America were announced yesterday with groups of ten outstanding performers named for each of the three weapons.

Mme. Dusolina Giannini, in Hotel Buckingham, 6th Ave and 57th St. Agda and George F. Von Olzen, Harry D. Wells, Catherine D. McLoughlin, in 352 E 65th St; Madeline Bouard, Edna Hunger, in 54 W 71st St; Andresen Bremer, brokers.

The amazing anomalies of the iron policies which rule Europe today are, emphasized in the "escape" of Dr. Benes from his own country. From whom was the fallen head of the Czech State escaping? Certainly not from the Czechs, who mean him no harm, however bitter they may be over the failure of his quondam friends to protect them, but from the head of another and professedly friendly State.

The New Deal will send half a dozen of its stalwarts into Pennsylvania for the closing two weeks of this State's turbulent political campaign which James A. Farley, National Democratic Chairman, has described as a "special battleground."

Rising tides of hatred emanating from paganism were cited as paramount reasons for missionary zeal among Roman Catholics in a sermon yesterday afternoon at St. Francis Xavier's Church, Sixth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, by Mgr. James H. Griffiths, vice-chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. Bishop Thomas E. Molloy presided.

A rejuvenated defender of the International Fishermen's Trophy, Captain Angus Walters's big salt banker Bluenose, from Lunenberg, N. S., today broke a tie with the American challenger, the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, by scoring her second victory in a three-out-of-five series.

So many "wrong decisions" have been made since the World War that it is impossible to grasp the truth of what has happened to the world, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning.

Applications for the following positions in the city service will be opened Oct. 27 and will close Nov. 21. Details will be available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Municipal Build ing, or in The City Record.
The Fort Jay eleven retained the Cooper Trophy, emblematic of the Second Corps Area football championship, by vanquishing the Fort Hancock team at Roosevelt Stadium today, 20-0.
With the country's business temporarily shaken off its course by the recent war crisis, trade indices covering last month show, as a whole, a further general recession.
Weakened by his seventeen-day fast which ended Wednesday at the direction of his Archbishop, the Rev. Lazar Kirichenkoff was

Extension of the provisions of the Social Security Act to include domestic servants, itinerant farm workers and other groups was advocated last night by Gustav Drews, Republican and American Labor party candidate for Representative in the Sixth Congressional District.

Dollar sales of 140 paint and varnish wholesale establishments, which accounted for 27 per cent of the total business of all service wholesales in the paint trade in 1935, the latest year covered by a regular business census,

Vito Marcantonio, president of the International Labor Defense, announced yesterday the formation under the group's auspices of a committee for political refugees, which will "concentrate on giving aid to political refugees from Germany, Austria and the Sudeten area now stranded in Prague."

Frank E. Owen, who arrived yesterday as purser on the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic, was for ten years senior purser of the Berengaria and held that position in February, 1937, when the ship caught fire and was taken out of commission.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, has added four meetings in Brooklyn tonight to his speaking schedule. These are in addition to his regular Monday evening radio broadcast and are sponsored by the Brooklyn Republican organization, of which John R. Crews is chairman.

Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale School of Law in a report to President Charles Seymour rejects the "unspoken premise" that legal education should aid opposition to the tendency of the government to assume an important part in regulation of business and industry for the public welfare.
J. Stewart Baker, president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, announced yesterday that Peter Grimm had accepted the chairmanship of the foundation's 1938 community campaign.

County Judge Edmund K. Jarecki, Democratic candidate for re-election, was accused today of approving payments of more than $6,000,000 in estate appraisal and expert fees to persons who did not make "the slightest pretext of rendering any service of any kind or nature therefore "

Spencer Tracy has been borrowed from Metro by Twentieth CenturyFox for the leading role, that of Henry M. Stanley, in "Stanley and Livingston." The picture is scheduled to get under way around the holidays. The part originally was scheduled for Tyrone Power.

Phyllis Bottome, author of "The Mortal Storm," which has gone into another printing for a total of 47,500, paid a visit to her publishers, Little, Brown, last week to discuss her forthcoming novel, "Danger Signal," which will be brought out Jan. 21.

The example we give to others when we perform our most commonplace acts has far greater effects than most of us can realize, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks said in a sermon yesterday at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

Commander Hugh Branham, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Branham of Sunnybrook Farm, Chestertown, Md., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jocelyn Margaret Branham, to Charles Otis Vandervoort, son of Captain Benjamin F. Vandervoort, U.S.A., and Mrs. Vandervoort of Chanute Field, Rantoul, Ill.

The purposes of a drive by the Board of Education of the Presbyterian Church to raise $10,000,000 were outlined yesterday morning to the congregation of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge.

The "mass education" of American minds by anti-democratic propagandists seriously menaces our constitutional liberties, the Rev. Peter B. Duffee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi declared yesterday at the eighth annual communion breakfast of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Christian Brothers.

Corn rallied sharply in price last week on the Board of Trade here after a decline which carried all deliveries to the lowest levels since 1934. Short covering and a let-up in hedging pressure are said to be responsible for the upturn, but farmers generally showed unmistakable evidence of holding back their cash grain for higher prices.
Stocks closed irregularly higher on the week; low-priced issues featured; turnover, 11,824,000 shares.

At least 100 men were missing today after storms that caused havoc in the Black Sea port of Constanta. The fate of twelve men aboard the ship Har Carmel was unknown. The vessel, which was to have been scrapped, was torn from her moorings.
The church must save the strong as well as the weak, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning. ., .
The British gunboat Sandpiper. was damaged in an attack at Changsha, China, yesterday by six Japanese bombing planes. A Chinese vessel -was reported bombed, causing 1,000 casualties.

The necessity for the present export drive here is illustrated by foreign trade figures for September. The volume of German trade remained about the same as in the previous month, but values were lower.

A total of 141,210 tons of flaxseed was crushed to produce 98,407,203 pounds of linseed oil by the twentytwo mills operating in the United States in the three months ended on Sept. 30, the Department of Commerce reports.

A thousand residents of Brooklyn attended last night a dinner given to Assemblyman Irwin Steingut by the Brooklyn Citizens Committee of the American Jewish Congress at the Hotel St. George in recognition of Mr. Steingut's fifteen years of service to the people of the borough. The proceeds of the dinner went to the American Jewish Congress.

More than 800 representatives of groups composing the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations, an affiliate of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies; convened yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Sixtyfifth Street and Fifth Avenue, to hear speakers discuss the role the council will play in the federation's forthcoming financial campaign.

The Very Reverend Walter Robert Matthews, D. D., dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, - London, has been appointed Nathaniel W. Taylor lecturer at Yale and. will give four lectures on the general subject "Beliefs in God in the Modern World.".

A parade in Queens in which 40,000 persons were estimated to have marched and an international broadcast in which the United States Navy demonstrated its diverse operations were the forerunners yesterday of Navy Day, which will be. observed on Thursday.
Joseph H. McArdle, a Republican City Committeeman who served four terms in the State Legislature, died today in Jefferson Hospital of a stroke he suffered five weeks ago. His age was 70.

If Czechoslovakia gets peace and time for reconstruction she will rebuild as a democratic nation just as she has since the war, Josef Hanc, Czechoslovak Consul General in New York City, said yesterday morning after commemoration services for the twentieth anniversary of the Republic of Czechoslovakia were held in the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 347 East Seventy-fourth Street.

An offering of $1,894,000 of Cleveland, Ohio, 4 and 4 1/2 per cent various-purpose bonds is to be made today by Smith, Barney Co., Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., R. W. Pressprich Co., the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, Fullerton Co., Inc., and Johnson, Kase Co.
Three members of the United States team were eliminated by South American rivals tonight \as the third round of competition in the Pan-American amateur boxing championships got under way.
The first pictures and first descriptions of the Western line of fortifications that Chancellor Adolf Hitler has named "Limes" are published in the German press today.
St. Mary's Gael's, battered, confused and beaten for three periods, came from behind today to defeat the University of San Francisco, 13 to 6.

The three-and-one-half-story dwelling on a lot 20 by 55 by 100.5 feet at 206 West Seventy-first Street was leased by the Megonko Realty Company to a client of Jones Sullivan, broker. It adjoins the Shernian Sauare Hotel.
A two-goal attack in the last period enabled the Fort Hamilton Officers to conquer the First Division, 9-7, in a polo game between the reservation rivals yesterday at Fort Hamilton.
A large increase in registration in up-State cities and large villages over that for 1934, the last comparable year, indicates that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it was urging voters to support the grade crossing, housing and transit amendments to the State Constitution and to oppose those dealing with the judiciary, labor rights and the ban on proportional representation.

The only diocese of the American Episcopal Church without a cathedral soon is to have one, according to a vote taken today by the parish of St. John the Baptist. which decided to offer a parish pro-cathedral to Bishop Charles Blaney Colmore, Bishop of Puerto Rico, on the twenty-fifth anniversary of his consecration as Bishop next December.

Scholarships totaling almost $16,000 have been awarded to 176 undergraduates in New York University's Washington Square College and School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.
Wendover defeated Vleittown by 5 to 4 in the Emile Pfizer Autumn Cup tourney at the Burnt Mills Polo Club's Schley Field today.

Thirty-eight members of the Gourmet Society, relaxing at their tables yesterday afternoon after having put away heaping plates of savory shish-kebab, murmured in indignant agreement as James B. Pond, widely-traveled lecture manager, charged that various localities of America were making themselves ridiculous by ignoring the types of food and cooking for which they should be famous.

A "cooperative" wedding to the accompaniment of musical "autographs" composed of notes corresponding to letters in the names of the couple was performed by the bride and bridegroom themselves yesterday in the studio of the bride's father, Dr Gustave L. Becker, pianist and composer, in Steinway Hall.

George E. Johnson, for twenty-five years postmaster here, died on Thursday in the State Hospital at Greystone Park, N. J., of a heart ailment. He was 67 years old. Mr. Johnson had served thirty-two years in the postal service before his retirement in 1928.

Danielle Darrieux, one of the film world's most popular finds in France, has been obliged to renounce her Hollywood career. III health resulting from nervous strain has caused her to postpone her departure to the United States this week, and it was announced tonight that on her physician's advice she had decided to remain in France indefinitely.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to your editorial of Oct. 18 on the farm problem, it is probably true that there are as many opinions on this subject as there are authorities interested in it. Nevertheless, certain underlying fundamentals of this problem are rarely touched upon.

While considerable interest has been aroused among exporters in the use of radio advertising in foreign countries, particularly Latin America, exporters who returned last week from those countries strongly advised against it.
The National Council of the National Maritime Union has selected the official organization delegates to the C. I. O. convention in Pittsburgh next month, it was announced yesterday.

Alternating a powerful running attack with a passing game, the Washington Redskins defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 20 to 14, today and retained first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.
Washington will continue to be the least fortified of the major capitals of the world despite the Administration's prospective national defense program, military experts predicted today.

Benjamin Kotlowitz, who says he is 113 years old, was the proudest and happiest "young man" in the Bronx yesterday. So he said, anyway, as he displayed his most prized birthday gifts - congratulatory messages from President Roosevelt, Mayor La Guardia and Governor Lehman.

Four of the six clubs that make up the recently organized Metropolitan Skeet League participated in the second shoot of their championship series over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Westminster Skeet Club yesterday.

The little Roman Catholic Chapel of Notre Dame des Victoires (Our Lady of Victories), here in Quebec, observed today its 250th anniversary. It is the oldest church in Canada and one of the oldest in North America.
ALL THIS, AND HEAVEN TOO, by Rachel Field. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel laid in the New England and New York of 1850 to 1875.

Hidden from the eyes of the "enemy" machine gunners by a dense cloud of smoke, government troops were successful in their "attack" upon a theoretical invader which threatened to capture nearby Wrightstown this morning.

The report of the Phoenix. Securities Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a net asset value of $6,276,951 at the year-end after accrued dividends on the preferred stock.
The recent international crisis found its greatest visible reflection in the Bank of England's circulation, which in the fortnight from Sept. 22 to Oct. 5 increased [pound]26,560,000,

Sales of distilled spirits for the first eight months of this year were less than 8 per cent under those for the corresponding period of 1937, according to Spirits, liquor publication. Sales of rum and brandy showed the greatest decreases.

Merle A. Wilson, Socialist candidate for Representative in the Thirty-fourth Congressional District, made public yesterday a protest against the action of the Binghamton authorities in granting to the Republican party the use of the Binghamton High School for a meeting on Oct. 28,
Mrs. Russell Cruikshank is chairman of the patronesses for this year's Cinderella Dance, to be held on Dec. 23 at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Venezuela, the fourth South American country participating in the World's Fair, has contracted for 25,000 square feet of space, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
The United States Army won the international military team jumping championship today by a scant half point from the Mexican Army in the Inter-American Horse Show at the Meadowbrook grounds.

Clinging to a one point margin through a torrid last half, St. Bonaventure College of Olean, N. Y., repeated its last year's 7-6 conquest of the University of Scranton today before 7,000 spectators. It was Scranton's first defeat in five starts.

Extension of New York City's school program to include health services, remedial teaching procedures, more community centers and residential camps under Board, of Education auspices is recommended as a means of combating delinquency, in the report of the Joint Committee on Maladjustment and Delinquency, made public yesterday.

Completion of arrangements to list on the New York Stock Exchange dollar bonds of the Republic of Chile and the government-guaranteed dollar bonds of the Mortgage Bank of Chile whose holders accept the Chilean plan of debt service will

Ansel's Singing Sam, a dappled, black and gray dachshund dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. Archibald S. Alexander of Bernardsville, N. J., and bred and handled by George McKay Schieffelin of Gladstone, N. J., won the championship today in the tenth field trial meeting of the Dachshund Club of America on Kilsyth Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Moncrieffe Livingston at West Neck.

The Brooklyn Eagles and the Clifton Bears struggled to a 7-?? tie in an American Professional Football Association contest before 4,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was one of the best played games of the season.
Although blanked Saturday, Ev Elkins of Marshall College and Sammy Roeder of Franklin and Marshall continued to run one, two in the Eastern college football scoring.

Prince Arsene Karageorgevitch, father of Prince Paul, the regent, was buried at noon today in the royal mausoleum at Oplenac. He died in Paris last Wednesday. Prince Paul and Princess Olga boarded the funeral train at Slovenia and accompanied the body.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Theresa Moss, daughter of Mrs. James Moss of this city and the late Mr. Moss, former Deputy City Commissioner of Newark, to Thomas E. Colleton of East Orange, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Colleton.
The United States Amateur Skating Union closed its annual convention today by confirming dates and electing officers, installing Winfred P. Hodous of Cleveland as president.

Mrs. Howard M. Chapin, 53, daughter of a former Governor and wife of the librarian of the Rhode Island Horticultural Society, committed suicide today by slashing her throat and left wrist with a safety-razor blade

" Reading maketh a full man," said Francis Bacon and all the copy-books after him. But as far as the reading of books is concerned Uncle Sam is likely to remain as famished a figure as the cartoons picture him, unless the United States changes its postal policies. A national committee, organized to abolish present discrimination against books, emphasizes the need for a revision of the law.

Lieutenant Governor M. William Bray who was denied renomination by the Rochester convention three weeks ago, tonight broke the silence he has maintained since then by an bouncing his unqualified support of Governor Lehman and the whole Democratic State ticket.
The Giants hit a new peak of effectiveness and the Brooklyn Dodgers with the same motion at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the New Yorkers soundly walloped the lads from across the bridge,

John Harlan Amen will go to Albany today to be sworn in as a spe cial assistant attorney general to supersede William F. X. Geoghan, District Attorneyof Kings County, for one of the broadest investigations ever authorized in Brooklyn.

The chief disappointment in the current meeting of the Australian Loan Council was the Commonwealth's failure to induce the States to extend the principle of cooperation to the planning of a policy for the expansion of existing industries and the development of new ones as an integral part of the defense program.

Hotel men gathered here yesterday for the twenty-third National Hotel Exposition, conducted by the New York State Hotel Association and the Hotel Association of New York City, which will open at Grand Central Palace at 2 o'clock this afternoon, to continue through Friday.
The lack of national purpose that holds true in the lives of many individuals has made us as a nation "a jack-of-all-trades and master of none,"

R. C. HUTCHINSON'S "Testament"* is a fine piece of story-telling, the most striking and best sustained novel of the Russian Revolution I have seen in years. The tendency is, if anything, counter-revolutionary rather than pro, since the narrator is supposed to be an ex-Czarist army officer living in Paris, but the point of view is reasonably calm and generally broad-minded. A seventeen-year-old American Negro, John Davies, won the light-heavyweight class world weight-lifting title from the defender, Fritz Haller of Germany, in the international competition at the world congress of weight-. lifters.
The Department of Parks announced yesterday that the winner of its photography contest for amateurs was a 17-year-old student at Hunter College, Martha Berger of 234 East Seventieth Street.
Because Mike Baran, 155-pound substitute halfback, missed a signal today, his St. Vincent College team stayed among the nation's unbeaten football squads by conquering Canisius College, 16 to 14.

Edna Knollys, British opera star of forty years ago, was the central stage figure again today, but her audience did not sit in plush theatre seats as of old; they listened to her in a public ward of Toronto General Hospital.

Sensational runs by Nick Basca and Matt Kuber in the second and third quarters today gave Villanova a lead that a plucky Detroit eleven was unable to overcome despite a last-period rally, Villanova winning, 13 to 6, before a crowd of 25,000 at Shibe Park.
The Jersey City Giants of the American Professional Football Association remained undefeated, untied and unscored upon today, beating the Union City Rams, 27 to 0, before 13,000 spectators.

General Carlos Ibanez, former President of Chile and a candidate in the presidential election scheduled for Tuesday, was absolved today of any connection with the unsuccessful Chilean Nazi uprising of Sept. 5, in which university and public buildings were seized and held for several hours.

A comprehensive survey of this country's present world trade status and the probable trend of its future international commerce is expected to result from deliberations of the three-day convention under the auspices of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc.,
Another British attempt to capture the world's non-stop flight record will start tomorrow when twelve young Royal Air Force pilots will take off for Egypt.

Work made possible with funds from the National Youth Administration not only accomplishes the government aim of giving financial help to needy students at Barnard College, but also has proved valuable to the faculty and administrative employers of the students, Miss Katharine S. Doty, head of the Occupation Bureau, revealed in a report yesterday.
Each day in the life of a modern Catholic is "a challenge to defend your faith," the Rev. Daniel A. McGuire told worshippers at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
Complete returns in today's Senatorial elections announced by the Ministry of the Interior before midnight leave the composition and majority of the upper house unchanged.
Germany's business world currently is dominated entirely by the conviction, backed by official statements and other indications,
During September the combined subway and elevated lines operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company carried 73,794,412 passengers, a decrease of 4,531,014, or about 5.78 per cent as compared

The Federal Wage-Hour Law goes into effect today. It is now, broadly speaking, illegal for any employer engaged in interstate commerce to pay his workers less than 25 cents an hour or to employ them more than fortyfour hours a week. If he does employ them for longer than that time he must pay them at one and a half times the regular hourly rate.

The football pundits in this enlightened area were not surprised that Dartmouth defeated Harvard, but they are not completely sold on the Green line. Even- if the Hanoverian cavalry was still galloping 'to victory when last seen in action, the hint around here is that Dartmouth is riding for a fall.

The Republican caravan spent a quiet day in the Adirondack resort region. Mrs. Helen Z. M. Rodgers, candidate for Representative-atLarge, joined Frederick H. Bontecou, nominee for Lieutenant Governor, at Saranac Lake.

In an address yesterday at founder's day services held by the Christian Endeavor Societies of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Brown of Los Angeles, extension secretary of the International Society of Christian Endeavor, cited the origin of the organization in 1881 and declared that today there were approximately 80,000 societies of the organization.

Queechy Farm, a 241-acre estate at Canaan, N. Y., with a Colonial house dating back to the Revolution, has been bought by Edward Gustave Jacobson, art director of Kenyon Eckhardt, advertising agents, who intends to restore the building for a Summer residence.

Not only were sales of men's clothing by department stores larger in 1937 than in any other year since 1929, but there has been a marked trend in recent years for men to buy their clothes in department stores to the exclusion of men's specialty shops,

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday endorsed 'Henry Vollmer Jr., Republican nominee for District Attorney of Queens County. "Public spirited citizens of all parties should, and I sincerely believe will, supoprt Mr. Vollmer," Mr. Dewey said. "His record speaks for itself."
British naval authorities have drafted a memorandum for- circulation among foreigners here, advising them how to act if the dynamiting of buildings by Chinese begins here.

Miss Lois Mooney Hand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wallace Hand of Elizabeth, has chosen Nov. 15 as the date of her marriage to Franklin A. McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. McCarthy of this city.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Virginia Ann Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Barrett of New York and East Hampton, L. I., to Richard Naville Rand of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. E. Carmen Rand of New York and Nyack, N. Y.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Seiderman of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Beatrice Seiderman, to Stanley David Neubauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman S. Neubauer, also of Brooklyn.

The meeting of the NicaraguanHonduran Boundary Mediation Commission has been postponed until early next year, It is hoped that a solution will be possible at that time despite the unfavorable influence of the failure of the Costa Rica-Panama boundary treaty.

In the name of 6,500 members, Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, called upon Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins yesterday to permit John Strachey to enter the United States.

The improvement of relations between France and Germany is believed to be Chancellor Adolf Hitler's next major objective. Conversations to that end between Berlin and Paris may be expected soon, it is reported in informed quarters.

Complaints from shopkeepers and other citizens against the activities of over-zealous solicitors for charitable causes led Welfare Commissioner William Hodson to promulgate yesterday new rules governing the solicitation of contributions on the streets of this city.

In the far western corner of the State the counties of Chautauqua, Cattaraugus and Allegany, grouped together in the Forty-third Congressional District, are expected to turn in their normal Republican majority, but that is all, according to present indications Republicans have been hoping for heavier leads in the section.
Thomas S. Russo, a banker and lawyer prominent in Italian-American circles here, died of a heart malady yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 55.

In a vigorous and amusing article in our Sunday Magazine Stephen Leacock, himself educated enough to know, complained that our modern education is "eating up life." He drew a picture of our fathers, who, at 20, were already practicing medicine or law,

The Dollar liner President Coolidge, slated to sail for the United States this morning, still was anchored in midstream at 10 A. M., and it was authoritatively reported that Japanese-controlled customs officials had refused clearance papers on the grounds that the vessel was transporting silver valued at $4.500,000.

Charles Poletti, Democratic can didate for Lieutenant Governorg and Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, gave their respective positions on each of the nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution at a meeting yesterday after

As expected, the report of the Bank of France for Oct. 13 shows further considerable improvements in both the monetary and treasury situations. The latter repaid 2,000,000,000 francs on bank loans so that the margin available on the State's maximum authorized credits rose to 3,950,000,000 francs.

The money market here as well as the status of the Reichsbank and other German credit institutions, is dominated largely by the payment on the Reich loan of 1,500,000,000 marks, of which 950,000,000 was submitted for subscription by the public until tomorrow.

Arrangements for further armament for Rumania are said to be the purpose of the visit to London of King Carol on Nov. 1. It is understood that he will try to get the British Government to guarantee a loan of which the proceeds will go to the Vickers Works to finance deliveries to this country in the new rearmament plan.
President Maximiliano Martinez was decorated today with the Grand Cross of the Imperial Order by order of Emperor Hirohito of Japan.
Art exhibitions opening this week in New York include a show of oils and gouaches by Morris Kantor at Frank Rehn's-the first gallery showing of Kantor's work in several years.

May Irwin was always foremost among those ever-effervescing spirits who kept the Gay Nineties gay. The world has saddened since her day, but it is pleasant stili to remember the echo of her wholesome laughter.

The Treasury, acting in its new role of fiscal agent for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, offered today for subscription on behalf of the RFC new 7/8 per cent notes of that agency in exchange for $298,972,000
Soviet school teachers are summoned to intensive anti-religious work among children in an authoritative article today in the Teachers Gazette, the organ of the Commissariat of Education.

An issue of $2,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the Carrier Corporation will be offered to the public tomorrow by Stern Wampler Co., Inc., and Hemphill, Noyes Co. The debentures will be priced at par.

The eighth annual New York State Conference of the National Council of Jewish Juniors was addressed yesterday by Mrs. Benjamin Spitzer, chairman of the executive committee of the National Council of Jewish Women at a luncheon meeting at the Park Central Hotel.
Playing bruising football on the ground, the Green Bay Packers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates at City Stadium today, 20 to 0, before 12,142 fans.

Information received today by State labor authorities indicated that more than 40,000 employes of pecan nut shelling plants in Texas would be thrown out of work tomorrow by the closing down of that industry, due to the new Wages and Hours Law.

A smoldering fire producing heavy clouds of smoke was discovered early last night in the pump room in the basement of the School of Education Building of New York University, 35-41 West Fourth Street. Firemen confined the fire to the basement where it appeared to have started in waste and rubbish.
James R. Watkins, a native of this village, who supplied many Long Island hunters with wooden duck decoys during the last half century, died last night at Freeport, where he had been visiting.

George Billings Gibbons, founder and senior partner of the municipal bond house of George B. Gibbons Co., 49 Wall Street, died yesterday at his home, Hilltop Place, in Rye, after a lengthy illness. He was 54 years old.

The taxpayer containing six stores at the northwest corner of Westchester and Pugsley Avenues, the Bronx, was bought by a client of Alvin J. Sander through Edward J. Kemmy, broker. It is two blocks from the housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The world is facing a dictator who would destroy religion and another who would alter it to suit his purposes, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of the Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, said in his sermon there yesterday.
Gauguin's "Reverie," generally considered a portrait of his native wife, Tehura, has been acquired by the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery and Atkins Museum of Kansas City, Mo.

Mission Sunday, the Catholic Church's tribute to its 266.000 priests and religious engaged in missionary work, was observed here yesterday afternoon with the celebration of the eleventh annual mission vespers in

Alvin C. Cass, S. Bruzza and T. A. Dunst, finishing with totals of 5 1/2-1 1/2, in their respective sections in the preliminaries, qualified yesterday for places in the finals of the annual championship tournament of the Marshall Chess Club.
A second-half rally gave the Paterson Panthers a 19-to-7 American Professional Football Association victory over the Newark Tornadoes today.
ECONOMY SYSTEM, INC., general merchandise, 2,162 3d Ave.-Liabilities $45,939; assets, $19,150. American Merchandise Co., Inc., is listed as a creditor for $28,968.
Members of house parties who came here for the Autumn ball of last night took part in a round of social and sports events today. There are more than two hundred visitors.
All clauses of the General Mobilization Law are expected to be invoked before the end of the year, thus greatly strengthening the government's control of Japan's economic life.
Margaret Tallichet, 23, "discovered" for the movies by Carole Lombard, and William Wyler, 34, film director, were married at the Lakeside home of Walter Huston here tonight.

More than 46,500,000 vehicles have used the-George WaShington Bridge in the last seven years, the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday in announcing that the span's seventh anniversary would occur today Dedication exercises were held on Oct. 24, 1931, and the structure was opened to the public the following morning.

The recent report of the Northern Great Plains Committee recommending "fundamental readjustments in land utilization" for the five States of the affected area has been approved by President Roosevelt, the White House announced today.
The stock market here was rather quiet last week, but wholly confident, and on some days specialties had a lively turnover.

A rally in honor of James (Jeff) Burkitt, anti-Hague crusader, who was released yesterday from the Hudson County Penitentiary at Secaucus after serving a six-month term for attempting to speak in Journal Square in violation of a police ban, was held tonight at Fairmount Hall, near police headquarters here. Close to 300 persons attended.

The warehouse industry's new master contract cleared its last hurdle with ease as more than 2,000 warehousemen roared approval of it in a mass meeting and prepared to go back to work Monday in 138 reopened plants.
The Civilian Conservation Corps has planted 132,564,000 trees in this State in the last five years, according to H. Ferris White, regional director of the National Emergency Council.

Because of its connection "with German-American organizations which are in danger of being called un-American," the word "bund" was removed today from the by-laws of the German World War Veterans in America, Inc.
Rumania was the "fat cat" of the Balkans, with all that that implies. She was prosperous and progressive, just beginning the industrial development of her great internal resources.

The Detroit Lions retained a chance of gaining the Western division title in the National Football League by defeating the Chicago Cardinals, 10 to 0, today. The game, witnessed by a crowd of 17,917, was played in a drizzle.
The series of garden visits being conducted as "Autumn outings" by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be continued on Wednesday and Thursday with visits to the. New York Botanical Gardens.

Thomas E. Dewey is running neck-and-neck with Governor Herbert H. Lehman in the Governorship race, it is indicated in a preliminary State-wide survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director. The institute will continue its tests until the eve of the election.
Beryl Rubenstein's piano recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall once again found that accomplished artist in excellent technical form. His playing was, as usual, ...

The Progressive Ukrainian Societies of Greater New York, at a mass meeting last night in the Ukrainian National Home, 217 East Sixth Street, went on record as opposed to subjecting any part of Carpathian Ruthenia to Hungarian rule.
With the award of numerous trophies, the fifteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association was concluded today.

The Department of Labor announced today that 12,835 placements were made in private industry during September by the State Employment Service, a rise of 20 per cent over August, but a drop of 41 per cent compared with September, 1937.
A new church edifice will be dedicated on Nov. 20 by the Kenilworth Baptist Church at Farragut Road and Kenilworth Place. Brooklyn.

Liquidation developed in the lard market early last week, with prices dropping to a new low level since 1934. Weakness in hogs and grain and a disappointing reduction in local lard stocks in the first two weeks of this month were the depressing factors.
The ten-man golf team representing the Meadow Brook Club was again victorious against the Piping Rock, Nassau Country and Rockaway Hunting aggregations today in the quadrangular competition.
A man and a woman were killed early tonight when the coupe in which they were driving toward Old Bridge from the direction of Englishtown was in collision with a bus of the Gray Line,
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,294,350.

Three thousand persons attended a meeting at Temple Beth-El, Fifteenth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday to protest against the proposed barring by Great Britain of further immigration by Jewish refugees into Palestine.

The appointment and promotion of 178 undergraduate students at City College enrolled as noncommissioned officers in the college unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, Professor of Military Science and Tactics.

A State-wide missing persons alarm was sent out this afternoon for Dean Tripp, 3-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbour D. Tripp of 39 Tulip Avenue, and George O'Connell, 36, of the same address, at the request of Mr. Tripp, who said they had been missing since noon yesterdav.
Every one who has viewed the Tombs either from the outside or the inside will be glad that this monument to

Youth was accused of being passive while world problems called for solution in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, by the Rev. Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchinson, president of Washington and Jefferson College.
The Financial News's index of thirty industrial stocks, based on the average of July 1, 1935, as 100, stood on Oct. 20 at 81.2, compared with 81 a week before, 102.7 a year ago,
Four properties in New Jersey have been sold by Eugune V. Walsh, broker, as follows: ten-acre estate at Washington Corners. near Mandham, for Frederick Kalmbach to Elwood B. Fake;
Construction contracts aggregating $2,099,115 for the new administration building at Bellevue Hospital have been approved by the PWA, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

Young music students In the public schools may have an opportunity to hear orchestral performances of classical works during the current year, according to a plan disclosed last night by Mayor La Guardia.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Pearson of St. George, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Lord Pearson, to Norman Lawson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lawson of Brooklyn.

Colonel Thomas F. Brown of the Ordnance Reserve has been appointed assistant chief of the army's New York Ordnance District, it was Announced yesterday. Colonel Brown succeeds the late Colonel F. W. Roller.
