B. Charney Vladeck, chairman of the American ORT Federation, announced yesterday that Professor Heinrich Neumann, ear specialist, was now aiding the organization in its work in providing technical training for Jews in Vienna.

The International Executive Committee of the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians (C. I. O.) today endorsed the campaigns of Governor Earle and Charles Alvin Jones, Democrats, running respectively for Senator and Governor of Pennsylvania.

Miss Rebecca Ashford Herring of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Herring of Clinton, N. C., was married to Rollin C. Warner, also of New York, on Saturday afternoon in the chapel of Calvary Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Samuel Moore Shoemaker.

An order to cease and desist from either paying or receiving brokerage fees, in violation of the brokerage section of the Robinson-patman act, has been entered by the Federal Trade Commission againt the Webb Crawford Company,

Frederick B. Site, Jr., infantile paralysis victim, who has lain on his back in a 900-pound iron lung for nearly two years, was sitting up today in his River Forest home, able to feed himself and hold a book in his hands.

The Fair Labor Standards (wages and hours) Law went into effect after midnight last night, and Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, in a radio address, hailed the step as a -memorable one for the United States.

The superiority of progressive education over -the traditional practices in elementary schools has been demonstrated by comprehensive testing, Professor J. Wayne Wrightstone of Ohio State University's Bureau of Educational Research reported in a book issued yesterday by Teachers College, Columbia University.

A much firmer undertone prevailed in the world's wheat markets late last week. A considerable part of the strength, however, was attributed to short covering induced by a belief that the government would take steps to bring about higher prices.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace L. Ingersoll gave a tea yesterday at their home, 205 East Sixty-ninth Street, for the Misses Edith Kingdon Gould and Anne Whitmarsh, debutante daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould and Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Whitmarsh.
Dr. John Harper Girvin, physician and surgeon, who for the last sixteen years had been secretary of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, died at his home here today in his seventieth year.
Captain Constantin Badigin of the Soviet ice-breaker Sedoff radioed today that his crew was beginning its second Arctic night in good shape about 500 miles from the North Pole.

Daily shaving leaves many men's faces raw and sensitive. This is especially true of the man who, because of his business and social status, must shave every day. To meet this condition, Williams has now developed a special cream for daily shavers. It's called Glider.

A widespread belief that Mexico has signed or is about to sign a contract with Italy by which Italians will supply Mexico with all the rayon yarn that she uses in exchange for Mexican petroleum was strengthened today.

Truckfreight tonnage in September exceeded that of the same month a year ago for the first time this year that movement of goods by truck exceeded in volume the 1937 tonnage, the American Trucking Association. Inc.. reported today.
The principal business districts of Canton were destroyed by fire today. A shift in the wind saved Shameen, the international settlement.

United Biscuit Company of America and Subsidiaries-September quarter: Net profit after interest, depreciation, provision for Federal taxes, preferred dividends and other charges, $273,629, equal to 56 cents each on 459,054 common. shares, against $221,544, or 44 cents a share, in preceding quarter and $272,519, or 55 cents a common share, in third quarter of 1937. Nine months to Sept. 30:

Cleveland's surprising Rams, who handed Chicago's Bears their first National Football League setback two weeks ago, came back with another stunning triumph today, 23 to 21, to knock the Bears from the Western Division lead. It was Cleveland's third 'consecutive victory.
Mr. and Mrs. John B. Shethar of Milton Point, Rye, N. Y., will give a tea dance on Dec. 29 in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Sylvia Shethar.

The graduate faculty of the New School for Social Research announced yesterday the opening of a placement bureau at the school, 66 West Twelfth Street, under the direction of Mrs. Philip E. Allen, chairman of the placement bureau committee.

John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for Senator, yesterday challenged Senator Robert F. Wagner, his Democratic opponent, to a debate on the question of what should be done to decrease unemployment and whether the National Labor Relations Act, of which Senator Wagner is the author, should be amended.
Net earnings of $5,928,975 are reported by the Municipal Bureau of Power and Light for the fiscal year ended on June 30, despite a reduction in local electric rates amounting to $1,300,000.
Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are:

Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, blessed two "Catholic Action" flags yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Giuditta Guild at the Hotel Biltmore.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Schroeder of Scarsdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Kathryne Schroeder, to William Halsey Johnson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Mount Vernon.
Wage payrolls estimated at approximately $1,000,000 monthly by the Chamber of Commerce will end tomorrow with the application of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

Great Britain cannot achieve the role of "guardian of the peace of Europe" if she "abandons the role of guardian of the conscience of Europe," the Rev. Dr. Solomon Goldman, president of the Zionist Organization of America, declared in an address yesterday morning before the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

A classic example of the practical application of the old proverb, "It's an ill wind that blows nobody good," is to be found in the present jubilation of Republican party leaders in Kansas, over their prospects for success in the election on Nov. 8.

Credit and collection conditions in Latin America showed a mixed trend in the last quarter, the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men reported in a survey yesterday.

Ferdinand Bruckner, whose plays have had a way of being announced often enough but never arriving on Broadway, seems to have had a change in fortune. At least a newly organized Theatre House, Inc., of 25 West Forty-fifth Street announces it will present his "Gloriana," a play about Queen Elizabeth, on Nov. 19. Blanche Yurka has been engaged to portray the Virgin Queen and Tom Powers will also be in the cast.
The country generally, and business especially is awaiting disclosure of the government's fiscal policy for the carrying of the armaments cost. Solution of this problem will be difficult in any case.

An early curtailment of WPA spending leading to a permanent reduction after July 1 because of continued business improvement was predicted today by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator, after the last of a series of conferences with President Roodsevelt.

It was announced at a recent meeting of the board of directors of the Florence Crittenton League at the home of Mrs. J. Nelson Borland that the annual operatic performance in aid of the organization will be the revival of Verdi's "Falstaff," with Lawrence Tibbett in the title role, on the afternoon of Dec. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The Workers Defense League, which has been active in the fight against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, charged yesterday that Herman Matson, chairman of the league's Hoboken branch, could not get a WPA job because "local WPA officials feel they can with impunity discriminate against antiHague leaders now that the Federal Administration has expressed support of the Hague machine by sending Seeretary of War Woodring to speak at a Hague rally."
The Government's long-term debts, excluding debts of States and municipalities, had reached 14,562,300,000 marks on Sept. 1, an increase of 310,400,000 in August.
The French weekly wholesale price index on Oct. 15 stood at 657, compared with 652 a week before and 646 two weeks earlier.

Preparations for the departure of the main International Brigade are already completed and it is expected that the men will be passing through here during the next few days on their way to the towns near the frontier whence they will go directly to France.

An investor bought from the Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn the two four-story apartment houses on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 92 and 94 Brooklyn Avenue, between Dean and Pacifio Streets, Brooklyn. The buildings have a total of fourteen apartments and were sold through the Harry M. Lewis Company, broker.
The Rev. Sturgiss Lee Riddle was formally installed this morning as rector of Caroline Church of Brookhaven.
There follows the text of an explanation by the Department of Labor, for the guidance of employers, of the regulations issued under the Wages and Hours Act for the keeping oj employment records:

Now that the forest-fire hazard is absent in the Maine woods, a number of hunters seem anxious to get up there and try their luck. Many of them want to know the best areas for sport, so we'll run a list of the regions where deer are plentiful, and the men to contact at such places.
Park Drive (18-5652). n e cor of Ed gere St, 100x100; Thomas F. Kearns to Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association. 441 Lexington Ave.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 79.9, which compared with 80.3 the week before, 80.5 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 80.8 four weeks before.

The engagement of Miss Harriet Laura Lock, daughter of Mrs. James G. Lock of this city and the late Mr. Lock, to Samuel Wesley Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Reynolds, also of New York, has been announced by her mother.

Continued warm weather curtailed purchasing of Winter apparel in the New York wholesale market last week, but reports from retailers in sections enjoying lower temperatures indicated satisfactory consumer buying.
During the last few days 1,200 persons have been arrested and 300 of them imprisoned in connection with the murder of Major Gen. Yordan Peyeff, chief of staff, and Major Stoyanoff, his aide de camp.
Miss Julia Grace Keim, who had been active in charitable work in the Murray Hill section for forty years, died yesterday at her home, 145 East Thirty-fifth Street, after a brief illness.

Charles H. Osgood of 24 Bennett Avenue, an associate of the American Agricultural Chemical Company, 50 Church Street, died yesterday in the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital following an operation for an internal ailment. He was 67 years old.
Despite the intense relief that came with the passing of the European war scare, the security markets here have reverted to a state of extreme apathy.

Several dinners were given tonight in the Berkshire Colpnies. Professor Karl E. Weston and Mrs. Weston entertained at Thornwood, Williamstown, in honor of their house guests, Professor Frank Jewett Mather Jr. and Mrs. Mather of Washington Crossing, Pa.

Miss Elizabeth Irving Bartlett was married here today at the home of her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Bartlett Jr., to Lewis Bain Kimball, son of Mrs. Roger Nelson Kimball of New York and Kenosha, Wis., and the late Mr. Kimball.

There was occasion for rejoicing when the new orchestra assembled by the New Friends of Music made its debut, playing three of the Bach "Brandenburg" concertos, at the opening concert of the season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

Edward T. Russell, chairman of the sanitation committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York, charged yesterday, in issuing for publication parts of a report to Mayor La Guardia, that the Sanitation Department had padded its figures on volume of waste collection and disposal to show a low unit cost of operation.

Charlton St. 98; Charlton Builders, Inc. to Albert Blaire, 2,846 W 32d St, Brooklyn; mtg $29,$87 ($2.50). 2d St, 251 E: East River Savings Bank to Seipol Realty Corp, 132 W- 43d St ($8). 82d St, 51 E; Lilian L. R. Franklin to 51 E 82d St, Inc, 4 E 53d St; mtg $40,000 ($1).
E. Jay Edwards, a manufacturers representative who had been associated with several large companies, died suddenly at his home here today of a heart attack at the age of 58.

A visit to the nearest postMunich frontier of Czechoslovakia today suggested that the most fitting description of this country would be "an area in Central Europe inhabited by Czechs and bounded by pieces of string."
Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 49 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from the rate in the preceding week but up 1 point from the rate of two weeks previous.
Members of the College Club or Ridgewood will present "Gaieties of 1883," featuring a melodrama in the manner of that period, on Friday and Saturday evenings at the Ridgewood Woman's Club.

Fifty etchings, lithographs and other prints, the work of artists in the Graphic Arts Division of the WPA Federal Art Project, have been selected from more than 200 now on display at the National Museum and will be sent throughout the country for exhibition at museums and art centers, it was announced today.

St. E,Ann's Roman Catholic Church, of which the Rev. Michael A. Mechler is rector, today began celebration of its golden jubilee. The Pope sent Father Mechler apostolic blessings. Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh officiated at a solemn high mass this morning.

The belief that Yale's chief hope of defeating Dartmouth in the Bowl next Saturday lies in a perfectly conditioned eleven caused the coaches to rest the first team today. They sent the seconds through an hour's grueling scrimmage in a driving rain, however.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 19: A decrease of $16,000,000 in

Fordham gathered her battered football forces on the gymnasium floor 'yesterday as a driving rain soaked Fordham Field, and began preparations for the struggle with unbeaten Pitt at Pittsburgh Saturday. Co-Captain Mike Kochel,

The Securities and Exchange Commission began hearings today on a complaint charging that the Alleghany Corporation's financial statements in registering its securities on the New York Stock Exchange contained false and misleading statements.

THERE is only one thing rarer than a good book about Walt Whitman and that is a poet of Whitman's stature. In the 120 years since his birth we have-had at least 120 assorted poets, but none to compare with him; and in the forty-odd years since his death at least forty assorted biographies, criticisms, explanations, interpretations. A few of the books have been good; some of them have been stupid. Today we have two.*
Governor Lehman put aside tonight the calm attitude in which he had conducted his campaign for re-election and struck out at Thomas E. Dewey in one of the most caustic speeches he ever made.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Joshua S. Koenigsburg of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 374-Erhest Newton Kalb, applt., v. Roscoe R. Luce et al., and 375--Same v. Henry Fuerstein et al. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Per curiam: the appeals herein are dismissed for the want of final judgments.

The lowest price levels since Dec. 24, 1934, were recorded last week by The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices. Declining for the second week, after the rebound that followed the allaying of fears of immediate war in Europe, the index dropped to 79.2 on Saturday from 79.5 (revised) a week earlier and 80.3 on Oct. 8.

Brown varsity work was called oil today. Rain, the need for rest for the bruised members of the squad and the fact that the freshman backfield is riddled with injuries and would offer little opposition for the varsity reserves all conspired to bring cancellation of the drill.
The Treasury's weekly bill offering today brought an average interest rate of 0.026 per cent, compared with 0.018 per cent for the issue sold last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Nomination- by the Democrats of extreme radicals for Governor and Senator, coupled with three ballot proposals focusing long-controverted issues related to union labor, old-age pensions and taxation, makes the election this year one of the most fateful in California political history.

After hearings lasting more than five years, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday that the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company had been ordered to refund about $500,000 to its consumers of electricity on the Rockaway peninsula and in several Nassau County towns.
Preston Delano took the oath of office today as Controller of the Currency and assumed the duties of that office. He was appointed Sept. 23 to succeed Marshall R. Diggs, who had

The 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army has raised a total of $231,697 thus far, Henry W. Taft, chairman of the Army's advisory board for Greater New York, reported yesterday at the Fall meeting of the board, held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The Colgate football team started preparations today for the Holy Cross game in Worcester Saturday with the good news that Hal Lube, ace passer who was injured in the Columbia game, will be ready to play.

A general advance of livestock prices today carried the hog market's recovery 10 to 15 cents higher, restoring the $8.15 top, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Some cattle gained as much as 25 cents while lambs and sheep rose 15 to 25 cents. Curtailed receipts helped markets.

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce will open a membership campaign next month to "enlarge the influence of the organization and make its specific service facilities available to more business and industrial establishments," Cary D. Waters, president of the organization, announced yesterday.

One of the most difficult schedules in history has been arranged for the City College basketball team, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Seventeen games are listed for the court outfit, which will be led by co-captains Louis Lefkowitz and Emanual Jarmon.
An additional 1,000 men will be employed at the Racine, Kenosha and Milwaukee plants of the Nash Kelvinator Corporation this week, R. A. Devlieg, production manager, announced today.

Dmitri Ivanenko, a former captain in the Imperial Russian Army, who became an American citizen, was found dead in bed at the large house on the L. Rutherford Stuyvesant estate at Allamuchy, near here, today.

Before a small but highly baseball-minded gathering, which included Commissioner K. M. Landis, as well as the two major league presidents, Ford Frick and William Harridge, the National League's centennial motion picture, "The National Game," received its preview yesterday at the National Artists' Seventh Avenue studios.

Majority sentiment in favor of the British cooperative movement entering the limited price variety store field on a large scale was expressed at a meeting here this week called by the North Metropolitan District Council of the National Cooperative Men's Guild, which was attended by 246 delegates from local branches and other co-op organizations.

The preliminary draft of the City Planning Commission's proposed capital budget for 1939, calling tentatively for total expenditures of $155,277,472, of which $49,710,518 is provided for new projects, was made public yesterday by the commission.

Two civilians were killed and one was wounded when troops thwarted their attempt to seize the cavalry barracks at San Pedro de Lloc, in the Department of La Libertad, about 350 miles north of here, the War Ministry announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Frankenthaler of 101 Central Park West of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Frankenthaler, to John Edwin Reisenfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Reisenfeld of this city and Beverly Hills, Calif. The marriage will take place here on Nov. 23 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 24, unless specified: San Pedro to San Francisco: Arizona, Nevada, Oklahoma. Norfolk to Guantanamo: Brooklyn, Savannah. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Jacob Jones, Badger.

Indomitable, Henry Lustig's 5 yearold son of Man o' War, who has been a consistently good sprinter all season, found the sloppy going at Empire City to his liking yesterday and was an easy winner of the Fishkill Handicap over the five-andthree-quarter-furlong course.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 15 amounted to 277,001,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

New York City parents and educators must make other citizens aware of the community's educational needs, speakers at the annual Fall conference of the United Parents Association urged last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The War Department approved today the last of the three bridges which figured in the Maryland DemoCratic Senatorial "purge" campaign in which Senator Millard F. Tydings defeated the New Dealer, Representative David J. Lewis, for renomination.

Before evidence had been offered today in six negligence actions against Francis Martin Jr. of the Bronx, growing out of an accident July 16, fatal to two young women, it was announced that a settlement had been reached. The terms were
Gross assets, $23,660; net, $21,866. To Mason S., Varill S. and Franklin M. Chace. children, $3,955 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $21,045. Abraham Berry. attorney, 233 Broadway.
Every member of the Pennsylvania football squad who took part in the victory over Columbia reported today for an hour's work in the rain.
Three officers were drowned today when a seaplane of the Rumanian Navy's Constanta squadron crashed in the Black Sea near Jurilovka. A fourth man swam ashore.

The Bureau of Navigation-released the following orders to, day, dated Oct. 21: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Mee, F. J., New York, N. Y., to the Elied and in command when commissioned. LIEUTENANT Haerlin, F. L., Jr., Washington, D. C., to the St. Louis and on board when com missioned.
The Polish Commissioner here vigorously protested today to the Free City's Senate against the recently introduced compulsory police service which, he said, is disguised military conscription.

Men's wear retailers, particularly in the New York area, have sharply curtailed their buying of men's Christmas gifts because of current slow trade, manufacturers reported here yesterday. With funds tied

The government undertook today to relieve a surplus problem in the citrus fruit industry by a single operation providing for a mass purchase of high-quality fruit and diversion of inferior grades from the market.
Archbishop Joseph Francis Rummel of New Orleans told the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women today that Christians through the world should aid the persecuted peoples of Germany.

As a sequel to "Four Daughters," Warners have scheduled "Four Sons Meet Four Daughters," .with George Brent, Jeffrey Lynn, John Payne and the studio's newest discovery, Eddie Albert, tentatively set an the brothers O'Reilly.

Increases or 8.9 per cent in employment and 7.8 per cent in payrolls were reported by retail firms throughout the State from the middle of August to the middle of September, according to figures released today by Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner. Net gains of 1.2 per cent in

Not long ago the Townsend Plan was thought to be as dead as Huey Long's Share the Wealth scheme. But a Washington dispatch in Sunday's TIMES showed that the doctor's plan or some modification of it is to be submitted to the voters in seventeen States. In Colorado an effort is being

Carefully on the safe and solid rock She knew how wise she builded, and how well; How cunningly she fashioned bolt and lock To seal the portal to the citadel; How smooth and gleaming were the battlements ...

The marriage of Miss Eileen Marie Narizzano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Narizzano of Kensington, and John Chandler Moore 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis de Bebian Moore of Oyster Bay and New York, took place here today at St. Aloysius Catholic Church.

Registrations of new securities, other than common stock issues registered for reserve against conversion of convertible securities which became effective in the three months ended on Sept. 30, were valued at $645,329,000, which was more than $100,000,000 in excess of the corresponding effective in the 1937 period, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

After some five weeks of general th gridiron warfare forty-one college teams with unblemished records are listed in an Associated Press survey. San Jose State of California, one of four teams that have won six straight games, is the high scorer with 215 points to 25 for the opposition. Other six-game winners are Texas Tech, California and Southwestern Louisiana Institute.
The dwelling at 275 Oakwood Avenue, Cedarhurst, L. I., was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to D. Edgar Kalischer through H. Frankfort Son, broker.

J. Hornung's Dubonnet remained the 10-to-1 favorite tonight for Wednesday's Cesarewitch at New Market. In the callover at the Victoria Club, Princesse de Faucigny-Lucinge's Contrevent became the second choice at 21 to 2, replacing Sir W. Burbidge's Solonaise.

Properties along the West Side of Manhattan figured in the majority of the city realty deals announced yesterday. In the Bronx, another parcel in the vicinity of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing project changed hands.
Exploding ammonia tanks and bursting canned goods endangered firemen today as they fought a fire in the Alaska Railroad warehouse here.

" Lehman" was defeated yesterday, and "Dewey" was only the runner-up, in a contest that was not for Gubernatorial honors but for the national championship in the East-West Frog Jumping Derby. The winner, as expected, was the sure-thing world's record holder, Zip, the big black frog from Calaveras County, Calif., the county immortalized by Mark Twain as the home of athletic amphibians.

While Chicago is to remain an important maintenance and operating base for American Airlines, the company's main repair shops and its business offices will be moved from Chicago to North Beach Airport, New York's new $30,000,000 air terminal, by 1940, company officials revealed today.

Pravda, organ of the Communist party, today denounced what it called "an intolerable situation" in Moscow's model department store and accused the manager of dismissing honest workers and protecting thieves.

Projects for which architects filed plans in Manhattan yesterday included a six-story apartment building for fifty-two families at 231-35 Seaman Avenue, estimated to cost about $200,000, and seven-story laboratory, at 428-30 West Fortyfifth Street, costing about $175,000.

The National Association of State Auditors, Controllers and Treasurers will convene in annual session at Biloxi, Miss., Nov. 15 to 18, it was announced yesterday by the Mississippi State Auditor and convention host, Carl N. Craig.

What the United States Attorney's office described as "one of the biggest cases the alcohol tax unit has developed against still operators" came to light yesterday when a Federal grand jury named forty-four men and a woman as members of a liquor ring that is said to have defrauded the government of at least $15,000,000 in taxes from 1931 to 1937 inclusive.

The recent discovery that nicotinic acid, a chemical found in liver, red meats and fish, is a specific cure for pellagra, poor man's disease of the South, is also revealing secrets of fundamental life processes and opening up new vistas toward the understanding of the nature and treatment of other serious diseases, the National Academy of Sciences was told today at its Autumn meeting at the University of North Carolina.

The Schenectady Gazette Unit of the Tri-City Newspaper Guild today went on strike in protest against what an official said was the newspaper's "refusal to bargain with them in good faith." William F. Marquet, president of the TriCity Guild, said the issue was "the refusal of any contract at all, and not any particular terms of the contract." He added that fifteen

A $10,000 gift from the Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was the largest single donation reported yesterday among contributions totaling $43,911 toward the $205,000 needed to balance the 1939 budget of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York.

Alex Rose, State campaign director of the American Labor party, announced last night that the party had arranged for more than 300 meetings during the remainder of the campaign to urge support of its candidates. The principal
A second up-State Mayor was subpoenaed today to testify before the Albany County grand jury investigating the jail escape of three convicted O'Connell kidnappers last November.

Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, met German attacks on British rearmament today with the affirmation that this country needs to back its efforts for peace with a strength equal to that of any other nation.

Edward Senra and Leo Reiter, former stewards on the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company's liner Oriente, were each sentenced yesterday to serve two years in prison, when they pleaded guilty to having accepted from 250 to $300 for stowing away four non-paying passengers who came to this port from Havana in 1937 without passports.

Detectives from Deputy Chief Inspector John Ryan's squad, who have been working for more than a year on a series of truck hijacking cases that have baffled the police, yesterday arrested four men and recovered goods valued at more than $100,000.

President Roosevelt returned to the White House late today for another week of conferences on- budgetary, defense and farm relief problems before going again to his Hyde Park home, from which he is scheduled to deliver a radio address Nov. 4 in support of the State Democratic ticket.
Former President Herbert Hoover visited the art exhibition of Miss Jean Kellogg yesterday afternoon when it was opened at the Ferargil Galleries, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The course of commercial loans does not run smooth. A week ago the reporting member banks in 101 cities showed a smart gain of-$28,000,000 in the item-the best since recovery began. This week a fall

Germany's anti-Semitic laws and their consequences were discussed last night by a Methodist bishop, Catholic layman and a Jewish rabbi over station WMCA. All agreed that the so-called Nuremberg laws, which became valid more than three years ago, marked the beginning of a world-wide program of terrorism against Catholics, Protestants and Jews. The three speakers were:
The Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis season opened last night with last year's winner, the City A. C., bowing to the Yale club on the latter's courts. 3-2.

Automobile production last week expanded to its peak for the year to date, and the adjusted index jumped 20 points to 85.4. The figure was 65.9 for the preceding week and 139.6 for the week ended Oct. 23, 1937.

Advertising Men's Post 209 of the American Legion installed officers for the coming year yesterday. John J. Hall, retiring post commander, reported that during 'his term of office the post membership had increased from 216 to 259 members. He attributed the growth in

Mrs. Ruth Cairns Conne, daughter of Mrs. Robert Andrew Cairns of this city, was married to Dr. Robert S. Buol of New Britain today at her mother's home. The Rev. Dr. James E. Walker, minister of the First Congregational Church of Waterbury, performed the ceremony.

The Federal Trade Commission last week streamlined its administrative processes to pave the way for possible utilization of the great powers over advertising given to the commission by the new Wheeler-Lea act, it was learned today.

The Giants have gained undisputed possession of first place in forward passing figures, according to National Football League statistics announced yesterday. The team has completed 61 aerials in 119 attempts for 51 per cent.
James E. Powers, at 22 Earlwood Dr; George Shrady, at 60 Alexander Ave; E Chishold, at 377 Hamilton Ave, White Plains (Westchester County) leases by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.
A firm undertone was apparent yesterday in most sections of the bond market in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Although there were a few

Although less experienced than last year's team, the current Kent School gridiron squad is considered to be playing better football at this stage of the campaign, despite the fact that the unit dropped its first two games by short scores before leaping into the winning column for the first time last Saturday.

The new regime announces that the Vienna Carnival will be held without modifiction this year. The assistant burgomaster is in charge of preparations for official functions such as operas, balls and a City Hall reception. Each will be limited to 4,000 guests.

Leading electrical manufacturers of the country expect.a sales gain of as much as 25 per cent over 1938 during the coming year, according to opinions expressed here today at the opening session of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 20 totaled 227, as compared with 199 in the same week a year ago and 226 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, will open the junior-senior chapel sessions of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering tomorrow noon, it was announced yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the university college.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, receives one-third of the residuary estate of Mrs. Annie N. Lurie, widow of Morris Lurie, who died Oct. 11. Two sisters, Esther L. Bornstein and Yetta Linenthal, both of Brighton, Mass., share equally in the remainder of the residue.

Mayor La Guardia hailed Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago as "a gentleman and a good sport" yesterday when he was informed that the Chicago Mayor was sending him a pig today in payment of the World Series bet he made and lost.

Japanese here envision an early forcing of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to relinquish his dictatorial powers and his army command and foresee an early peace, which, they say, will be surprisingly generous. After that, they declare, the only problems will be the Chinese guerrillas'and the Chinese and Communist armies holding the far northwest.
Dr. Frank A. Schaefer, Associate Professor of Education at Fordham University, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

JUNIOR ENGINEER, $2,000 a year, optional subjects: Aeronautical, agricultural, architectural, ceramics, civil, electrical, and mechanical, naval architecture, structural steel and concrete. Applications must be on file not later than Nov. 17, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, ,New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington or Wyoming, and not later than Nov. 14 from all other States.

The New York Railroad Club's Fall and Winter educational activities will start this Friday night, when members will hear "The Story of Lumber" in the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. Charles

Two changes were made in the Harvard line-up today. One returned Dave Glueck, who did not play against Dartmouth, to his regular position at right guard. The other placed Win Jameson, a varsity end for the third season, on the right wing in place of Don Daughters.

Fred M. Schanze, vice president of the Montee Publishing Company and associate editor of Turf and Sports Digest, died today at Union Memorial Hospital of complications following an attack of pneumonia four months ago.

Strengthened by yesterday's elections to the Senate, the support of which is assured him, Premier Edouard Daladier is believed to have decided to go to the Radical Socialist party meeting at Marseille this week determined to make the break of the Radical Socialists and the Communists a definite one.

The Dollar liner President Coolidge unloaded a cargo of gold bars, silver bars and coins collectively worth $2,800,000 last night after Japanese-controlled officials had refused to clear the ship unless she sailed without the shipment.

The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday that its net asset value on Sept. 30 was $30,889,384, after bank loans. This figure was equal to $75.99 a share of preference stock and to $1.13 a share of common stock, and it compares with an equivalent of $74.78 and $1.06, respectively, on June 30.

Baron Daresbury, who for many years had been prominent in farming and hunting organizations, died today at the age of 71. He was outstanding as a breeder of pedigreed stock, and was a pillar of the Royal Agricultural Society, which he built up until it was in flourishing condition.
The first American "war baby" to be married in France, Miss Gladys Snowhill, 18 years old, will tomorrow wed Jacques Ponchel, sales manager for a Paris factory in the suburb of Petit-Clamart.

A report by the Commission on the Marketing of Cocoa from West Africa, released here yesterday by the British Library of Information simultaneously with its publication in London, recommended that an association composed of all growers in that area be formed and that all producers be put on a statutory basis for the marketing of their product.

ALIAS THE PROMISED LAND, by S. Gordon Gurwit. (J. H. Hopkins, $2.50.) A novel laid in a small American city. AMERICAN PLAYWRIGHTS, 1918-1938, by Eleanor Flexner. (Simon Schuster, $2.50.) Subtitled "The Theatre Retreats From Reality."
The East Side Chamber of Commerce will hold its first Fall meeting in the auditorium of the Bowery Savings Bank, 130 Bowery, tomorrow evening.

John B. Campbell, former theatrical manager, died of a heart attack yesterday in the offices of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Thomson McKinnon, 11 Wall Street, where he had been employed for many years as a secretary. He was 67 years old and lived at 142 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Rev. Leon M. Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx, will be the speaker on Sunday at the 387th "Bible breakfast" at the William Sloane House of the Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirty-fourth Street. His topic will be "An Undivided Self."

Henry Armstrong, who will defend his welterweight championship of the world against Ceferino Garcia in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 2, will shift training activities from Rockland Palace to the New York Hippodrome today.

Music lovers and other patrons of the fine arts are subscribing to the ninth Town Hall Endowment Fund series of concerts which will be opened the night of Nov. 9 with a recital by Guiomar Novaes, Brazilian pianist. The concerts are given each season to further the educational activities sponsored by the Town Hall.
ALLEN-Monday, Oct. 24, 1938, Mary Williams, wife of Arthur Furmore Allen. Services at Harlem-New York Presbyterian Church, Wednesday, Oct. 26, 1:30 P. M. Please omit flowers.
General compliance with the new Wages and Hours Law, which went into effect yesterday, was indicated by spokesmen for both industry and labor in New York City and elsewhere. Trade organizations

Reports of growing tension in Memel reached Warsaw today. It is reported that a conference of Memel German leaders held recently in Koenigsberg, mast Prussia, decided to submit to the Lithuanian Government a memorandum containing four demands which may mark the beginning of agitation for German annexation of that territory.

Among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday was one for a penthouse apartment of four rooms taken by Lloyd A. French, a director of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., in 470 West End Avenue.

Dr. D. W. Prall, associate professor of philosophy at Harvard University, will give the second lecture in the series, "Lay Approach to the Arts," tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The series is conducted by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences and comprises sixteen lecture discussions. Dr. Prall's subject will be "The Meaning of Form and Style."

George Woolley, general superintendent of the Philadelphia Cricket Club golf courses, died today at his home in Germantown. He was about 73 years old. Born in England, he became associated with the Philadelphia Cricket Club in. 1896 as a cricket professional.

Incensed by interpretations given in France and Britain to his previous editorials, Virginio Gayda in today's Giornale d'Italia writes that it is a misreppresentation to picture Italy as alarmed by the rearmament of the democracies since she is merely noting the intensification of such arming.

Following is the text of the radio address delivered tonight from Station WOL over the Mutual Broadcasting System on the Wage and Hour Law by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act, in a dialogue with the announcer:
Miss Julia T. Coonan, retired chief nurse in the United States Navy, died yesterday at the United States Veterans Hospital, Rutland Heights, Mass., it was learned at her home here today. She became
Eighth Annual Forum on- Current Problems under auspices of The New York Herald Tribune, Hotel WaldorfAstoria, 9:15 A. M. and 2 P. M. Continues tomorrow and Thursday.

New account on the stock market here began cheerfully today when prices in most sections went ahead to the accompaniment of a moderately expanding turnover. The gilt-edge list was firm. On hopes for a truce in the Far East, Japanese issues stood out in a generally rising foreign bond section.

THE weekly huddle was on and the football coaches were being badgered by hecklers. Coach Bill Wood of Army, for instance, was asked whether or not he had changed the Army offense lately and, if so, how. Captain Bill crossblocked that one and then went on down the field, muttering that he forgot to post a letter.

Ford Madox Ford has labeled "premature" the announcement in last Sunday's Book Review that he will be glad to receive letters about fiction written by young Middle Western authors. He will be glad to have them eventually, he says, but at present arrangements are still in a tentative stage.

Major Gen. Robert U. Patterson, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Patterson have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of General Patterson's daughter, Mrs. Eleanor Patterson Roberts, to Osgood Marsh Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Osgood Nichols of Short Hills, N. J.
Othon Friesz, who served as one of this year's jurors at the Carnegie International, is having a one-man show at the Durand-Ruel Galleries. It opened on Saturday and will continue until Nov. 12.

The voters in this and other communities in New York State have a job ahead of them on election day that will test their patience, their sense of responsibility and their intelligence. Not only are they expected to vote on local, State and Congressional candidacies. They must also decide as to

Through blinding rain squalls and a boisterous sea, the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, American challenger, today evened the score with the Canadian defender Bluenose by taking the fourth race in their three-out-of-five series for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic.

The United States and Chilean army teams arrived in New York last night from Washington to complete preparations for the nightly international military jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 5 to 12.

George Zengaras, 134, East Side, gained a close decision over Lloyd Pine, 1323/4, Akron, Ohio, in the main event of eight rounds last night at the St. Nicholas Palace. The bout was hard fought, and the decision evoked mingled cheers and jeers from the crowd of 2,500.
Tonight's events: "Rigoletto," New York Grand Opera Company, Manhattan Center; Dorothy Baker, soprano, Town Hall.

His health restored, Samuel Untermyer completed arrangements today to give a three-day free exhibition of flowers, in which more than 3,000,000 blooms will be displayed, at his country home, Greystone, on North Broadway, Yonkers, opening Wednesday.

Interviewed at Hyde Park, where he had come to discuss with the President various matters pertaining to WPA, Mr. Harry Hopkins ventured on Sunday to predict a majority of 500,000 for the Democratic party in next month's elections in this State. To which he added: "And that means that Sir Galahad will stay home."

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick awarded yesterday an issue of $6,000,000 of New York City 4 1/2 per cent assessment bonds held in the city's pension funds to a banking group composed of Salomon Brothers Hetzler, the Bank of the Manhattan Company, the Manufacturers Trust Company and Barr Brothers Co., Inc.

The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations began its regular Fall session today with reason to believe that its Japanese member, Nobumishi Sakenobe, who was absent, would resign and that the Japanese Government would not send an official to answer the commission's inquiries regarding Japan's Pacific mandate.

Lt. Allan S. MacGillivray, D.-V. (S) U. S. N. R., 33 South Munn Ave., East Orange, N. J., ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Oct. 25, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: Oct. 25. He will revert to an inactive status April 24, 1939.

A report on discrimination against elderly workers, which the International Labor Office will submit to its governing body at the regular quarterly meeting opening tomorrow in London, finds that "in general a hiring policy applying age as a decisive criterion appears unjustified."

The board of trustees of the City Club announced yesterday the club's disapproval of proposed Amendment No. 1 to the State Constitution, the omnibus proposal, and the amendments dealing with the judiciary, labor rights and the ban on proportional representation.

Record gold imports of $743,960,000 in the third quarter of this year were reported today by the Treasury. Newly mined domestic gold acquisitions were $47,220,000, and miscellaneous gold acquisitions $5,250,000, or a total of $796,430,000.

Harvey Harman split the Rutgers football squad today and sent two mixed elevens through a spirited eighty-minute kicking scrim mage on the quagmire of Neilson Field. Due to heavy rain, fumbles were prevalent and the footing insecure.

Captain Jack Wright, Columbia's 193-pound tackle, who was injured in the Penn game last week, will not play next Saturday when -the Lions clash with Cornell at Baker Field. Examination at Medical Center yesterday revealed that Wright has a torn shoulder muscle.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a net income of $8,416,905 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion. amortization
European sales headquarters of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation have been moved from Warsaw to Amsterdam, according to an announcement made here yesterday by agents of the company.
Within the past week President Lazaro Cardenas has decreed final expropriation of 43,237 acres of land belonging to five American companies or individuals.

Vacations with pay for baseball players! That would solve many a manager's problems, declared Connie Mack, 76-year-old head of the Athletics. today. "Vacations would be the greatest insurance against slumps, and slumps are more costly than all ball players' salaries," declared Connie.

The Board of Elections sustained yesterday a number of objections to petitions designating candidates for independent nominations, mostly on the ground that they did not have the required number of valid signatures.

Lower quotations on Russian furs are likely to prove a major influence on the prices and use of American furs in the 1938-39 season, according to J. D. Silberman of the Silberman Fur Corporation of this city.

COHEN, ANNA BELLE (June 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Pearl C. Jacobs, daughter. 503 Huron St., Toronto, Canada, $2,000, jewelry and one-third residue; David Jacobs, brother, 320 Sterling St., Brooklyn, $2,000; Josephine Jaffa, sister, 320 Sterling St., Brooklyn, $1,200; seven varying bequests; Deborah Cohen, daughter, executrix, 129 Lockwood Ave., New Rochelle, N. Y., specific bequests and two-thirds residue.
Mrs. Mahlon Pitney gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius, Mrs. Ansel Phelps, Mrs. Robert E. Tod, Mrs. John W. Davis and Mrs. Arthur Ryle.
Compiling a perfect score, with seven of its runners purposely breasting the tape together, Fordham scored in its annual crosscountry meet with C. C. N. Y., 15-40, at Van Cortlandt Park

Andrew Lenart, 59 years old, of 707 Madison Avenue, Elizabeth, N. J., got a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge Donnellan in General Sessions on his guilty plea last week to a misdemeanor count in the $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy.

If opera cannot go it alone, try swing and see what happens. The formula was initiated last night at the Manhattan Center, which is a slight alteration of the old name of an old but renovated theatre, the Manhattan Opera House.

To help promote fine printing in this country and to honor the Metropolitan Museum of Art as a pioneer in this field, the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirtysixth Street, opened last night an exhibition of printing done by the Metropolitan in the last thirtythree years under the direction of Henry W. Kent, secretary of the museum. For many years the

Millions of dollars now spent on the- importation of foreign species of wild life, a program "as unthinkable as the restoration of Mount Vernon with chromium- and reinforced concrete," should be -spent on the improvement of native habitat, thus preserving the American species, the National Association of Audubon Societies was told yesterday at its thirty-fourth annual convention in the American Museum of Natural History.

Premier Bela Imredy declared tonight that if Hungary's "really conciliatory proposals" should be rejected by Czechoslovakia the. Hungarian Government would "enforce its justice by all means available to the nation."

Agencies that are concerned with seeking industrial jobs for unemployed youth are facing at least two snags, speakers told a conference of social workers at the Hotel Pierre yesterday. The meeting was under the auspices of the Girls Service League.

A new issue of $2,500,000 of tenyear 4 1/2 per cent convertible sinking-fund debentures of the Carrier Corporation, due on Oct. 1, 1948, will be offered today by Hemphill, Noyes Co. and Stern, Wampler Co., Inc. The debentures will be
General Francisco Franco's Insurgent armies opened a surprise offensive on the Madrid front today and claimed to have pushed back government lines in the Clempozuelos sector.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens again issued an invitation yesterday to William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, to conduct an inquiry into the Queens County District Attorney's office. The invitation was

The founder of this Grand River boom town was somewhat upset today by reports that Disney tethered offenders to a tree in lieu of a jail. D. C. Armstrong took cognizance of a letter from Mrs. Mabel Bassett, State Commissioner of Charities and Corrections, protesting that an intoxicated woman was handcuffed to a tree, and demanding that the practice end.

No observer of the European drama since Hitler appeared on the scene has failed to perceive that the ups and downs of France have had more to do with the timing and success of Germany's moves than any other single factor. That is why a special interest and anxiety focus on every swing of the French political pendulum.

Lord and Lady De Ramsey of Abbots Ripton Hall, Huntington, England, are at the Lombardy. Mr. and Mrs. Noah MacDowell Jr. will give a reception on the afternoon of Nov. 23 at their home, 4 East Seventy-second Street, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Annetta MacDowell.

In General Sessions yesterday a pickpocket with a record of fiftysix arrests insisted that, because of "a strange twinge of conscience," he had returned $386 he had stolen from the pocket of a victim.
The engagement of Miss Ann Freshman, daughter of Mrs. Taber Low of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Edward A. Freshman, to Alfred Pach of this city has been announced by her mother.

With the arrest and conviction here today of four men for stealing oysters and lobsters from beds of oyster-growers and lobster fishermen in Long Island Sound the police believe they have put an end to oyster-bed "piracy" that has bothered them for several years.

The national Congress approved unanimously today a bill authorizing flotation of a $6,000,000 "guarantee bond" issue to be subscribed exclusively by banks, public utilities and oil companies in Panama. The measure lacks only the approval of the President to become law.

Colonel re Charles A. Lindbergh spent three hours today inspecting the German Labor Front's Bureau for Vocational Education and Business Management. He was described as having .shown "great interest."
Secretary Morgenthau this afternoon indirectly confirmed reports that the Treasury was concerned over the recent behavior of the French franc and the British pound with relation to the dollar.
Eduard Benes in exile is one of a distinguished and numerous company, today and in the past. If we look

West St. 354, 25x80xirreg; Benjamin Gottfried to Silver Dollar Properties, Inc. 715 11th Ave. Canal St. 336-40, 51x41.7xirreg; Bowery Savings Bank to Silver Dollar Properties, Inc. 715 11th Ave; ($36).

With no serious casualties resulting from Saturday's game, Army's varsity turned out with only two absentees for today's practice against Notre Dame formations. With Bob Stillman's jayvee team wearing green shirts and using Notre Dame plays as reported by Army scouts, the varsity was given a long drill on the offensive.

Alcoholic beverage taxes totaling about $9,500,000 have been turned back to the county treasurers of the State, representing their share of collections during the quarter ended Sept. 30, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced today. Greater New York received $5,245,712.17.

Under cross-examination at the opening of his second week on the witness stand at the trial of two men. and a woman accused of espionage, Gunther Gustav Rumrich testified yesterday that "skeptical" government investigators had deleted from his signed statement his assertion that he entered into a plot to steal military secrets in order to expose Germany rather than betray the United States.

The twelve-family apartment house at 115-117 Twenty-second Street, West-New York, N. J., was sold by the Merchants Trust Company to an investing client of J. I. Kislak Inc., broker. The apartments are of three and four rooms.

A letter from Henry I. Harriman, former President of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urging the re-election of Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, was made public yesterday at Wagner headquarters. In 1935 Mr. Harriman fought the enactment of the Wagner Labor Act.

The British shoe trade is faced with a comparatively new form of competition, offered by the importation from the United States of second-hand shoes. Such imports totaled 19,329 pairs, valued at about $1.10 a pair, in August.

Harry L. Hopkins, head of the Works Progress Administration, said here tonight that "the only thing that will haunt me when I retire to private life is that while I had the power I did not spend more."

The eightieth annual convention of the American Dental Association opened here today with an attendance including representatives of Europe, South America, Canada and the Far East. Officials estimated that the total attendance at the five-day meeting would exceed 6,000.

Both Henry and Edsel Ford, founder and president, respectively, of the Ford Motor Company, expressed strong optimism here today regarding the outlook for business in general and the automobile business in particular at a preview of their new models for 1939. Among these is an

Five little children of working parents from the Wayside Day Nursery, 216 East Twentieth Street, achieved yesterday the dream of all children-complete freedom to play for hours with a whole room full of the newest and most wonderful toys.

Appointment of a paid investigator to study various phases of the furniture industry was recommended last night by Charles Kirchen, chairman of the board of the National Furniture Manufactures Association, as a means of ridding the industry of the evils of false wholesaling and other mutual problems.

Deciding that it might be beneficial to add its bit to publicizing the current upturn in business, Platt-Forbes, Inc., yesterday issued a folder containing a variety of news stories on industrial recovery, with the headline "The Trend's Up." Clippings from eight

Manufacturers of women's better-grade slippers are booked to capacity and are turning away business for preholiday delivery, Norman N. Souther, president of the Shoe Travelers Association of Chicago, said at the monthly shoe exhibit of the association, opening here today.

The Crop Reporting Board estimated today the nation's wheat supply on Oct. 1, including stocks in interior mills, elevators, warehouses and on farms, at a total of 581,564,000 bushels. This compared with 481,260,000 bushels on the same date last year.

Appropriations totaling $858,550 were made in 1937 by the Spelman Fund of New York, the annual report disclosed yesterday. With the exception of $10,000 for the National Urban League, all grants were for activities in the field of public administration. the report said.

Objections to the will of the late Mrs. Esther Hull Tremain of Dobbs Ferry, who left part of her $1,500,000 estate to charity, were dismissed today by Surrogate Charles D. Millard and the will was admitted to probate.
The Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, will place on exhibition today newly acquired paintings and sculpture, both gifts and purchases.

Organizations in this country which are registered with the State Department under the Neutrality Law for the purposes of collecting funds for relief purposes in Spain collected in the period from May, 1937, to September, 1938, inclusive, a total of $1,653,048.80 and expended for relief $1,216,292.59, according to the monthly report issued by the State Department today. They spent. $396,679.93 for administrative and

A fair under the auspices of the Church Guild of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor will be held Friday afternoon and evening at the historic church, now in its hundred-and-first year of service. Mrs. William L. Bradley
Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed firm and mixed; turnover, 1,678,350 shares. United States Government issues lower, other bonds mixed; transactions, $7,498,500.

The Long Island Golf Association held its final tournament of the season today at the Matowac Golf Club, with rain reducing the number of teams in the amateur-pro competition. Young Billy Holloway and

" The Folklore of Capitalism," the muchdiscussed work of Thurman Arnold, recently put in charge of the antitrust division of the Department of Justice, was included today in a list of suggested readings for young officers of the navy.
A new Bureau of Public Service Training was announced today by the Regents of the University of the State of New York to provide training for public employes.

The text of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's radio speech denouncing the O'Connell machine in Albany follows: Tonight we examine a political racket, a political monopoly-the O'Connell machine in Albany. We rip the lid off the vicious mess of corruption which exists within the very shadow of the Capitol of this State.

An improvement in business conditions was recognized as a fact this afternoon by Secretary Morgenthau at his press conference when he stated that the improvement would be taken into consideration in planning the 1940 budget to be announced by President Roosevelt at the end of the year.

Mail order volume picked up here yesterday, reflecting the cooler weather toward the end of last week. Improvement was shown in reorders for coats and suits, with retailers rounding out stocks held down during the recent period of high temperatures.

The contract for the construction of the last unit in the Sheffield Farms Company's new plant at Eleventh Avenue, between Fiftysixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, has been awarded to the White Construction Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday.
Sales in the big herring markets of Yarmouth and Lowestoft were halted today by a strike of 2,400 Sabbath-keeping Scottish girls in the fish-packing plants.

Harry J. Tompkins, a participant in the famous case of Erie Railroad vs. Tompkins, in which the Supreme Court at the last term upset ninetysix years of precedent, failed to obtain today a high court review of an adverse lower court decision in his personal damage suit against the railroad.

Herman B. Delman of the Delman shoe department of the Bergdorf Goodman Company was elected chairman of the new retail shoe affiliate of the Uptown Retair Guild at a meeting yesterday of the organizing committee held at the offices of the guild.

Engagements of $7,700,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They consiste of $3,400,000 which was obtained in England at some previous time and $4,300,000 which was shipped from Canada yesterday. Since July 26, a total of $289,200,000 gold has been engaged in England for shipment here on commercial account. Large additional amounts

The last sixteen years of Marie Antoinette's life, through the days when she sabotaged the French Treasury to her death on the guillotine, is the substance of "Madame Capet," opening tonight at the Cort.
The total registration in New York City, according to an dfficial tabulation made public yesterday by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, is 2,434,137. A table by boroughs,

The books will be closed by the Treasury on its offering of approximately $300,000,000 of 7/8 per cent Reconstruction Finance Corporation notes at midnight tomorrow, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference this afternoon.

Mrs. Fatima Wright, widow of the Rev. Frederick H. Wright, who served some of he largestt Methodist churches in Nova Scotia, died here yesterday after a long illness at the home of her son-in-law, the Rev. David O. Cowles, pastor of the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church. Mrs. Wright was born in
William A. Halpin, founder of the W. A. Halpin Company, general contractors, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Vera B. H. Rolph, after a brief illness.
Thomas H. McDonough, former State Superintendent of Public Buildings and long active in Rensselaer County Democratic circles, died at his home yesterday at the age of 71.

A banking group composed of Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., Van Alstyne, Noel Co. and Eastman, Dillon Co. will offer today a new issue of 60,000 shares of Union Premier Food Stores, Inc., of Philadelphia, cumulative convertible preferred stock, par value $15. The stock, which is entitled to
Railway officials said today that they had agreed to have station porters report their tips and, if they were less than the 25-cents-an-hour WageHour Law minimum, to pay the difference.

An application by the New York Central Railroad for modification of an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission entered on Aug. 29 authorizing the railroad to issue $5,000,000 of notes for certain purposes, including repairs to 1,000 freight cars, was granted today by the commission.
The holocaust in Canton continued unabated today, as a result of the work of determined Chinese incendiaries, systematically operating under cover.

The immediate lay-off of 1,000 Postal Telegraph messengers was announced last night at the same time that it became known that the American Communications Association, a C. I. o. affiliate, had called a "slow-down" of work among employes of the company.

Ball-toting stars from small college teams head the nation's football scoring list, while the leaders of major conferences trail far behind. Everett Elkins of Marshall College, Huntington, W. Va., who led the parade a week ago, was held scoreless last Saturday and found a rival who could equal his point-getting pace in Leroy Fry, a halfback from the Texas College of Arts and Industries. Each has made
A woman and two men were sentenced to death today in a murder case in which three persons were killed by poison and fourteen others made cripples. A second woman was sentenced to life imprisonment.

The recent rains throughout New England and New York have not only quieted the woods but in most areas have resulted in the lifting of the ban on hunting which has been in effect for the past week or ten days.

A lease involving about 18,000 square feet of space in the garment manufacturing district marked the commercial rentals announced by brokers yesterday, when the bulk of the contracts were for quarters in midtown.

Proceedings against four Staten Island lawyers on charges of unlawful and unethical practices will be conducted by Harold M. Kennedy, Brooklyn attorney, it was announced yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

In a radio speech reminiscent of his racket smashing campaign for District Attorney last year, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, last night denounced the O'Connell brothers' Albany Democratic "machine" as a "political racket," a "political monopoly" and a "vicious mass of corruption."

Unaware that his absence over the week-end with his employer's 3 1/2year-old son had caused a kidnap scare, George O'Connell, former marine and a handy man at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Tripp, 39 Tulip Avenue, here, returned by train this morning carrying his week-end companion, Dean Tripp.

A broad and sweeping expansion of the Federal Government's anti-trust division and the granting of new power to the Attorney General to subpoena witnesses and documents without going to the grand jury were urged today by Wendell Berge, special assistant to the Attorney General of the United States in an address before the annual convention of the National Oil Marketers Association here today.

A coroner's jury decided today after hearing testimony concerning the death of Daniel Dodge 21-year-old Detroit millionaire who leaped from his speedboat into Lake Huron last Aug. 15, that the cause was "accidental death by drowning."

Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin and Jack Sharkey Jr., featherweights, will head the card at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight, with Joey Wach listed to oppose Jose Hernandez in the semi-final. Each battle is scheduled for eight rounds.
The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizing Association declined again last week, largely because of drops in the prices of foods and fuels. The association's index,

The movement for tax exemption or preferential tax treatment for small homes, already embodied in the laws of at least a dozen States, has reached New York, and it is considered likely that some proposal of. this type will come before municipal authorities and the State Legislature soon.

New Jersey's Fair Trade Act was declared unconstitutional today by Judge Berthold Vorsanger of the Third District Court of Bergen County. In a lengthy decision Judge Vorsanger held it to be a discriminatory price-fixing measure and contrary to the American concepts of government and economics.
Mrs. Tiemann N. Horn of 1,130 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Adah Howell Horn, to Griff G. Berkeley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison C. Berkeley of Dayton, Ohio.
Solution of "the Jewish question" was demanded today in a resolution by the central committee of the Sokol, the great national athletic organization.

Lessing Julius Rosenwald will retire as chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co. on or before the next annual meeting of stockholders in New York on the last Monday in April, it was reported yesterday in financial circles.
The Two-Hundred Club of this place will sponsor a bridge party Friday night at the Upper Montclair Woman's Club to aid the club's welfare work.

George R. Goodfellow of 466 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, father of M. Preston Goodfellow, a former publisher of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle, and of Roy Goodfellow, now an employee of the Eagle, died at the Brooklyn Hospital last night of a heart ailment. His age was 71.

Business prospects of furniture manufacturers for the balance of this year through the early months of 1939, appear "exceedingly promising," Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants specializing in furniture accounts, predicted yesterday.

Several of the specialty acts from the Madison Square Garden rodeo will be seen at a special performance at 2:45 P. M. today at the playground on Seventh Avenue between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets. Children from the

A government court of inquiry into one of the deepest mysteries of the sea today decided that the British freighter Anglo Australian probably broke in halves "from deck to keel" after her shelter-deck buckled.

Total cash collections of current taxes by the township of North Bergen, N. J., in the nine months of this year amounted to $1,264,252, an increase of approximately 20 per cent over the $1,063,740 collected in the same period of 1937, according to a special report issued by Josiah H. Hewitt, 100 Broadway, to holders of some $5,000,000 of the township's bonds represented by him.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 22, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Cooperation of building and loan associations in liquidating mortgages which form part of guaranteed-mortgage certificate issues will permit greater progress in efforts to return the full principal and interest to investors in the certificates, trustees of the $10,000,000 Series Q. of the New York Title and Mortgage Company reported yesterday in an accounting filed with Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler.

The United States Chamber of Commerce urged today that the approaching Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, take steps to halt inroads of non-American countries into this hemisphere's foreign trade through the use of barter agreements and manipulated currencies.
Failure of a campaign to raise $500,000 today brought abandonment of a plan to move Auburn Theological Seminary to the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School campus here.
Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: "State Finances," Morris S. Tremaine, from Syracuse, WHN, 6:45 to 7 P. M. Thomas E. Dewey, from Albany, WJZ, 8:15 to 8:45 P. M.

A restless German shepherd dog named Toots jumped up on the gas stove-its favorite stepping stone to an exit through the window-in the basement apartment of Benjamin Budesheim at 145 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning and by kicking open two jets almost asphyxiated Budesheim and his six children.

Joint action by retailers and manufacturers to take steps aimed at smoothing out the peaks and valleys of retail trade was urged here yesterday by a retail executive who has been giving close study to this phase of distribution. His view,

William James Finlay, president of the Strathcona Paper Company, died last night at his home in Strathcona, following a stroke suffered two days before. He would have celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday next month.

Further X-ray pictures made at the college infirmary today definitely confirmed the fact that Larry Dilkes, regular 200-pound tackle, would be lost to Dartmouth for a long period. Dr. John Pollard, ba team physician, stated that it was doubtful if Dilkes could play again this year, since he has a fractured fibula of his left ankle.

Notre Dame has the largest and best team it has had since Elmer Layden took over the coaching job. That was the report that Captain Bill Wood, the Army coach, made to the Football Writers Association at the weekly luncheon at Jack Dempsey's yesterday as he sounded a note of foreboding with the West Point-South Bend engagement at the Yankee Stadium only a few days away.
The firm of Norman A. Walker Company has been formed to transact a general municipal bond brokerage business, with offices at 55 Liberty Street.
Professor James Harvey Rogers, Yale economist, who has been a monetary adviser of President Roosevelt, declares that it is silly to demand that the country's budget be balanced every year.
The Class I railroads had 7,459 freight cars on order, under construction or in rehabilitation in their shops on Oct. 1, against 24,345 a year ago and 19,337 two years ago.

Joseph E. Triner, chairman of the Illinois State Boxing Commission, has been appointed national sales director for Joseph S. Finch Co. of Schenley, Pa., distillers of several brands of whiskies, domestic cordials and brandies.

Trading was fair on lamb and pork loins, slow on others in local markets yesterday. Pork loins were higher; lamb carcasses T steady to 50c higher, lamb cuts mostly 50c$1 higher; other classes barely steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

This community, which understands the game of politics thoroughly and is especially familiar with the refinements in those rules which the New Deal has contributed, is watching with unusual interest the bedeviling of Governor Lehman to make a 100 per cent endorsement of the national administration Washington is well aware of the stakes and the motives, the former being high, the latter selfish.

Mal Stevens is disgruntled and angry. That comes under the heading of news, for the N. Y. U. coach is one of the most amiable persons connected with football. Dr. Stevens seldom wears a frown. It was a shock to encounter a different Mal Stevens yesterday.
A Foreign Office spokesman this morning said: "The Sandpiper was not intentionally bombed, but if it happened it was an accident. The Foreign Office is awaiting a detailed official report."

Speaking at a Mercer County Democratic rally in the Stacy Trent Hotel here tonight, William H. J. Ely charged that his Republican opponent for election to the United States Senate, W. Warren Barbour, "doesn't believe that the Federal Government should spend or lend money to benefit the masses of the people," "but nobody," he said, "ever heard Mr. Barbour complain when the government advanced money to the banks or utility companies."

A move for a mistrial because of comment by a woman juror and an attempt by the defense to have Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo disqualify himself as trial judge marked the opening yesterday of the trial in Supreme Court of eleven members of two C. I. O. unions on a charge of contempt of court.

Postmaster General James A. Farley yesterday assumed active direction of the Democratic State campaign in his capacity as Democratic State chairman and expressed surprise at the racketeering issue raised by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor.

The price at which the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's $50,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1948,/will be offered by an underwriting group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Otis Co. was fixed at 99 1/2 by an amendment to the registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A new "honor system" of emergency tax collection, following established British procedure, has been approved by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick for immediate institution as an experiment designed to save a large part of the $2,000,000 currently spent yearly by the city and its taxpayers in settling disputes, Deputy Controller Joseph M. Cunningham announced yesterday.

Several debutantes are contributing their efforts to the success of the preview performance of the Ice Follies which will be presented in Madison Square Garden on the night of Nov. 29 as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund.

William E. Horton, breeder of trotting horses and a grain merchant for more than thirty years, died here last night at the age of 81. He was the son of Joseph and Lucy A. Robinson Horton, and a brother of the late Superintendent of Schools Joseph Horton.

With both sides apparently fearing too much publicity with the election only two weeks away, the motion for a new trial for D. C. Stephenson, former Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan of Indiana, serving a life sentence for murder, did not come up for a hearing today in Circuit Court here.

A regional conference of United States Foreign Service officers from Central America and Panama will be held in Panama late next month and from South America in Lima early in January, the State Department announced today. Two officers of the Division of the American Republics will attend the conferences.

Funeral services for May Irwin, famous comedienne of the American stage a generation ago, were held yesterday morning at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, with about seventy-five of her former theatrical associates attending.

As a distinguished gathering of more than 1,000 leading citizens opened the annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night, David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the fund, revealed that in cooperation with organized medicine it had been making an intensive study of ways to expand the "3 cents a day" hospital plan to include "payment toward the cost of medical care."
Rain has washed out the last of any immediate fire danger in the Adirondack and Catskill forests which were reopened to hunters today by Governor Lehman.

Samuel Null, American Labor party candidate for Justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, as well as Magistrate Anna M. Kross, was listed by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild as "qualified and preferred." In commenting on Mr. Null's candidacy, a Statement by the chapter read:

The French liner Ile de France is due tonight from Havre via Southampton and Plymouth. Her passengers include Paul C. van Zeeland, former Belgian Premier; Shigeru Yoshida, former Japanese Ambassador to Great Britain; A.
Members of the Society of Virginia Women in New York will hold their annual card party in behalf of their philanthropic enterprises the afternoon of Oct. 31 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Trial of a suit to set aside the will of Mrs. Lucy Worth James, former wife of Huntington Wilson, Assistant Secretary of State under William Jennings Bryan, was started yesterday before Surrogate James A. Delehanty and a jury. Mrs. James died on Jan. 20, last, at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street, leaving an estate of more than $2,000,000.
