Dick Cassiano, 190 pounds; John Chickerneo, 213; Curly Stebbins, 207, and Mad Marshall Goldberg, 200. And the Panther line averages 203. .. Which brings to mind the Portland University roster that contains the catch-line "Honest weights, no springs."

Miss Ethel Chamberlain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Chamberlain of Stonesides, Lexington, was married here tonight in the First Unitarian Church to Porter Dietrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Dietrich of Westport, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Gill and the Rev. John Nicol Mark.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Molly Hornsby, elder daughter of Sir Bertram and Lady Hornsby of The Old Rectory in Ifield, near Crawley in Sussex, to William Gardner Miller 3d of New York and Paris, eldest son of Carroll Miller,
The effect of the recent hurricane is reflected in the earnings of the Boston Edison Company for the three months ended on Sept. 30, Frank D. Comerford, president, reported yesterday.
There was a frosty snap in the air, and the Cornell varsity hustled through a light workout tonight in preparation for the Columbia game at New York Saturday.

Major James Pond's complaint to the Gourmet Society that in this country he is never able to get a native dish on its native heath will strike a responsive chord in the digestive apparatus of many wandering Americans. When some local product or recipe is particularly celebrated it is almost certain to be missing from the local bill of fare.
Hankow heard an artillery duel seventeen miles away yesterday as Japanese warships attacked Kotien, one of the last defenses of the city. Invaders were also advancing on this position by land.

In recognition of his work in stimulating and improving American foreign trade the National Foreign Trade Council presented today to Secretary of State Cordell Hull the Captain Robert Dollar Memorial Foundation award.

The day of football's big push is near and no two fans- can get together without breaking out into a rash of ratiocination that ends with their deciding that maybe they are both wrong. Between now and

A syndicate of seventy-six banking houses headed by Dillon, Read Co., the First Boston Corporation, Spencer Trask Co. and the Securities Company of Milwaukee, Inc., will offer to the public today $54,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company due on Oct. 1, 1968. The bonds will be offered at

West Tremont Ave, 147-9 (11-2868); 1,986 Grand Ave Realty Corp to Taunton Realty Corp. 22 W 48th St; mtg $195,200 256th St, 429 W (13-3423); Bridget Mullins to Emma Burke, 8,265 Audley St, Kew Gardens, L. I.
Two leading Democrats were quoted last night in condemnation of State Senator John J. McNaboe by Langdon W. Post, American Labor party candidate for State Controller. Mr. Post, at a meeting

John D. M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, predicted tonight in an address here that the National Administration soon would offer a new farm program "far worse than the miserable failure of the one we have now-unless some one brings Mr. Wallace down to earth."

Ray E. Nimmo, American Legion attorney from Los Angeles, accused Secretary Perkins today of resorting to a "subterfuge to protect" Harry Bridges, West Coast director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, from deportation as an alleged member of the Communist party.

With the Wage-Hour Law in effect yesterday, Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, called it in a radio address a means of stabilizing American industry. Ten States and the A. F. of L. and C. I. O. promised aid in enforcement. The pecan-shelling

Death Reported Retired Engineer of Steamer Thomas L. Steele, formerly a member of Engine Co. 153, residing at 110 Boyd St., Stapleton, S. I., died Oct. 22. Advancements To take effect at 9 A. M., on date specified: 4th to 3d grade, Nov. 17: John P. Dicke, Engine 156.

Vincent Mastroberti, 32 years old, of 240 Clifton Terrace, Lyndhurst, N. J., was exonerated yesterday by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, of a charge of criminal negligence growing out of an automobile accident that resulted in three deaths.

Mary Andrea Martin, 18 years old, a filing clerk employed by the St. Regis Paper Company, 230 Park Avenue, was killed at 9 o'clock yesterday morning when she plunged from a fifteenth-floor inside window at 521 Fifth Avenue to the roof of a two-story extension at the bottom of an airshaft.

Nicholas Fox, 31 years old, of 32 East Sixty-eighth Street, disappeared from the steamer Arrow of the Colonial Line at about 1 A. M. yesterday while the Arrow was en route from Providence, R. I., to New York, Police Headquarters reported in an eight-State teletype alarm last night, on information received from the United States Coast Guard. He was probably attired in

The formation of playground children's orchestras and bands in the five boroughs, under the auspices of the Department of Parks, is well under way and two such groups are already rehearsing, it was disclosed yesterday.
Hugh Buchanan, General Secretary Alexander Bustarnante of the labor unions and S. Kerr Coombs were sentenced today to six months' imprisonment for seditious libel. They were convicted Oct. 3.
Coach Ossie Solem gave his Syracuse squad the day off today for additional rest before starting the drive for the Penn State game Saturday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A short time ago I purchased for 50 cents each at an auction two leatherbound volumes of old verse. In one of them were Whittier's lines on "Indian Summer," with "Eve of Election' printed underneath. A few days later I read your editorial on the season to which those New England lines refer. I had not seen them for years.

Willie Reddish, 189 1/2, Philadelphia Negro, battered Roscoe Toles, 195, Detroit Negro, for ten rounds to win a decision tonight at a boxing show. Reddish took all but one round from the conqueror of Jimmie Adamick, and had him staggering and bleeding at the end.

There is no improvement in conditions in Palestine. Terrorism in all its forms still reigns throughout the country. The British Army here faces the greatest difficulties in its attempt to halt the Arab campaign.

The Republican caravan, which has visited thirty-three towns and villages and traveled 1,250 miles, today swung into the Northern Counties of Essex and Clinton, starting its -second week. Rallies were held
No deaths due to automobiles were recorded over the last twoday week-end, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.

Encouraged by the improved play of the Manhattan football team in its close battle with Georgetown, Coach Herb Kopf started preparations for Saturday's meeting with Canisius at Buffalo by Sending the Jasper squad through a brisk, ninety-minute drill in yesterday's rain.

Representative John J. O'Connor, defeated for renomination on the Democratic ticket as a result of President Roosevelt's "purge," declared last night that he was confident of his election on the Republican and Andrew Jackson party tickets and equally confident that he would be re-elected chairman of the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives by a coalition of Democrats and Republicans.

Dr. Ignatius L. Goodfried, specialist in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, who formerly was chief of the Oto-Laryngological Department at Mount Sinai Hospital, died yesterday at the Beth David Hospital after a brief illness.

An apartment of eleven rooms and five baths at 19 East Seventysecond Street has been leased to Robert A. Magowan, vice president of Merrill, Lynch Co., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. The same broker also
An anti-aircraft tank built in Detroit of welded armor and 2,000 pounds lighter than the present United States Army tank was demonstrated here today at the plant of the American Armament Corporation.

Francis Conrad Elgar, New York builder and real estate operator, died of a heart attack here yesterday in his home at the age of 76. He moved to this city six months ago from 149 West Twenty-second Street, New York.
The first performance this season of Michel Fokine's "Carnaval" to Schumann's music was given last night by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House. The presentation had charm

The campaign for tomorrow's Presidential election ended today with mass meetings, parades and speeches by the two candidates, Gustavo Ross, who is supported by the Right Wing parties, principally the Conservative and the Liberal, and Pedro Aguirre Cerda, who is supported by the Left Wing Popular Front of Socialists, Communists and Democrats.

Complaint that the only tasks which the Episcopal Church provided for laymen to interest them in the church were "sissy" jobs, is made in the report of the Commission on Church Extension to the Synod of the Province of New England, which opens tomorrow in the Cathedral Church of St. Paul. Eight Bishops and 200 clerical and lay delegates will attend.

More than 4,000 health experts on public, welfare and private payrolls are assembling here for the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association, which will open in the Kansas City Auditorium tomorrow.

Turpentine firm, 24 3/4c bid; no sales; receipts 241 barrels; shipments 11 barrels; stock 51,266 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 264 barrels; receipts 1,278 barrels; shipments 15 barrels; stock 273,345 barrels.

Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey, wife of the District Attorney, and wives of other Republican candidates will be the guests of the Woman's Republican Club of Astoria, Queens, at a "Meet the Candidates' Wives" tea and reception to be held in the clubhouse at 31-27 Forty-first Street Thursday at 2 P. M. Heading the committee in charge is Lucie Oerther, Republican State Committeeman and co-leader of the First Assembly District, Queens.
Agricultural cooperative marketing and purchasing associations do an annual business of $2,750,000,000, it was estimated today by S. D. Sanders, cooperative bank commissioner. He made the estimate on

Operations in the steel industry this week are scheduled at 53.7 per cent of capacity, the highest rate in more than a year and a gain of 4.3 points, or 8.7 per cent, over last week, The American Iron and Steel Institute reports. The rate,

The most important provision in the Federal Wage-Hour Act at present, it has become clear, is not in Section 6 (a), which fixes minimum wages per hour, but in Section 7 (a), which fixes maximum hours per week, particularly when this is taken in connection with Section 18. During this first

When democracy does not move on to new victories in the presence of new social conditions it begins to die, Dr. John Dewey said last night at the meeting house of the New York Society for Ethical Culture at Sixty-fourth Street and Central Park West.

The committee for holders of the first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds and secured 4 1/2% per cent bonds of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to include in the record of the hearing on reorganization of the Rock Island new figures just prepared by the road's accounting department. These are said to show that

The text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman at a campaign rally in Albany tonight was as follows: In my campaigns and throughout my public life I have scrupulously kept discussions of issues on the high plane of decency and truth. I have followed that policy in this campaign, knowing' that what the people of the State want are facts and an honest discussion of the issues that affect their interests.

Jerome Ave (12-3318), e S, 200 ft n of 196th St, 125x125; Townlee Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., extends mtg to Oct. 1, 1948, 5 per cent; $190,000. Grand Concourse, 2,842, (12-3304); Joreke Realty Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co, installments. 4 1/2 to 5 Per cent: $50,000.

Asserting that the National Government's spending policy had been a failure so far as reducing unemployment is concerned, John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared last night that the only way to expand business and trade and thereby create more jobs was by convincing people that it was safe to contribute money and labor in turning out more production. Mr. O'Brian, who

Confident of "a normal continuation if not an actual upturn of import and export business" between the United States and Sudeten areas of Czechoslovakia recently acquired by Germany, the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., yesterday announced that it stands ready to "give advice and information on all questions regarding the Sudeten-German districts."
Dr. J. Cayce Morrison, Assistant State Commissioner of Education, offered the "three s's" of education today as a "new alignment of the school curriculum."
Coach Bill Kern of Carnegie Tech today severely criticized Referee John Getchell of Minneapolis for a decision that set up a 7-0 victory for Notre Dame against Kern's team Saturday.
Secretary Wallace suggested tonight that railroads, middlemen and retailers join the farmer in making "sacrifices" so that surplus farm products might be sold to low-income families at cut prices.

The Federal Power Commission, heartened by a favorable Supreme Court decision, pushed today its investigation into the Associated Gas and Electric System by announcing a joint hearing with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to be held on Dec. 1 into certain operations of thirty-five companies and four officials of the utility system.

The Greyhound Corporation applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue about 145,000 shares of its common stock for the purpose of exchanging it for the capital stock of Eastern Michigan Motorbuses.

In a letter to the business news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES referring to the recent trends in personnel practice as reported in these columns, William C. Watt of Larchmont, N. Y., declares that perhaps these developments indicate the beginning of "something of a practical nature." The letter reads in part:
William J. O'Connor, manager of the American-Smelting and Refine ing Company's plant at Murray, Utah, said today a lead furnace employing 300 men would be reopened on Wednesday.

A two-hour conference at City Hall on the Brooklyn police scandal and the swearing in of John Harlan Amen as special prosecutor in a ceremony in Albany set the stage yesterday for the formal opening today of the far-reaching inquiry authorized by Governor Lehman into charges of official corruption in Brooklyn.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,247,400 barrels, compared with 3,271,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 24,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Canadian official circles are now certain that King George and Queen Elizabeth will visit the United States when they come to Canada next June.

Yale's football forces began today careful and thoughtful preparation for still another of the succession of hard afternoons the Blue has faced since the opening of the season. Yesterday, the Monday after the Michigan game, little or nothing was done by the first-string players. Today there was a certain amount of contact work, a good deal of it dummy scrimmage,

An apology to Baron von Hundelhausen, the German Consul, was printed by the Diario Nuevo for comment on photographs that compared the arrogant appearance of Chancellor Adolf Hitler with the calm of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain at their Berchtesgaden conference.

Re-election of Guy M. Gillette, unpurged conservative Democrat, to the United States Senate; a close race for Governor and a possible Republican gain of from one to three seats in Congress-this is the net of political prophecy in Iowa two weeks before the election.

Because of opposition to a plan for permissive incorporation of New York Stock Exchange firms, the committee on member firms of that institution is reported to nave made certain modifications in the plan.

The three-story apartment building containing six suites at 160 First Street, Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to a client of the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, broker in the deal.

Four delegates of the Women's 'Volunteer Committee appeared before the army commission studying the recent mobilization to report on the role women were prepared to play in the national defense in wartime.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, demanded in a statement here today that President Roosevelt declare openly whether the National Administration was "endorsing the record of the Hague machine in New Jersey."

The Dial Press has taken over from Covici Friede the contract to publish Ludwig Lewisohn's novel "For Ever Wilt Thou Love." It will be issued early in 1939 and will have a contemporary American setting.

Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop will fly to Rome Thursday to confer with Premier Benito Mussolini and Count Galeazzo Ciano, his Foreign Minister, on questions concerned with the paralleling foreign political interests of the two governments.

In presenting Katharine Hepburn to the 3,000 clubwomen attending the eighth annual Forum on Current Problems opened by The New York Herald Tribune at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of The Herald Tribune and chairman of the forum, offered the stage and screen actress as "my candidate for Scarlett O'Hara in 'Gone With the Wind.' "

The Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class A team tourney began last night with the three winping teams scoring shut-out victories. The Midston House Squash Club, winner of the event a year ago, triumphed over the Crescent A. C., 5 to 0, on the Midston courts.

Mayor La Guardia, speaking as a resident of New York City, and Senator Perley A. Pitcher of Watertown, giving his views as an up-State resident, led a "discussion". at Union College tonight of the proposed amendments to the State Constitution.
The Sailors Snug Harbor has leased to Mrs. Adella F. Meadows the four-story house at 1 Washington Square and the abutting twostory house in the rear on Washington Mews.

That old Army slogan, "Beat Notre Dame," is very much in evidence at the United States Military Academy these days. It appears over each barracks door, while home-made banners that hang from windows reflect the cadets' belief that their eleven will triumph over the South Bend squad on Saturday.

Captain Charles Otto Toussaint, a retired champagne agent and a veteran of the old Seventh Regiment, National Guard, died on Sunday of a heart ailment, at the Fifth Avenue Hospital, after a brief illness. Captain Toussaint, who lived at the New York Athletic Club, of which he had long been a member, was 76 years old.

A steel cabinet in a patrol wagon yesterday caused considerable excitement among reporters at Police Headquarters when it was noticed that the wagon was from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn, scene of the theft of 7, 200 police records, for which Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan was arrested last week.
Lord Dawson of Penn, physician to the late King George V and to King George VI, was introduced to President Roosevelt today by Dr. Ross T. McIntire, White House physician.

Industrial purchasing agents desiring to be certain their suppliers are complying with Federal wage and hour standards were advised yesterday to require an invoice statement from suppliers stating "we certify that the hours of labor and wages of our employes meet the requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938."

A new four-story apartment house for thirty-two families is to be erected on the southeast corner of Cathedral Avenue and Mulford Place, Hempstead, Nassau County, by Charles R. McLaughlin, as president of the Mulford Realty Company.
George A. Gosselin, paymaster of Arnold Constable Co., will receive today from Isaac Liberman, president of the store, the first "Founder's Day award" for loyal and devoted service.

Mayor La Guardia named a committee of 400 prominent New Yorkers yesterday to assist in raising $250,000 to build a Temple of Religion on a site close to the center of the New York World's Fair in Flushing Meadows.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, met again today with William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange; Edward E. Bartlett Jr., chairman of the board of governors, and Paul V. Shields, chairman of the committee on public relations, in what was described briefly by the commission as a "continuation of the informal round table discussion of Oct. 19."

For six years Herbert Lehman has given the people of New York an honest, capable and progressive administration. Under the pressure of events which have created new and difficult problems he has shown sound judgment, a genuine capacity for party leadership, an unflagging interest in the cause of social justice.
The Rutgers varsity, preparing to meet Lehigh at Bethlehem Saturday, failed to impress today in its weekly scrimmage against the freshman eleven.

The National Oil Marketers Association closed its convention today by going on record against the Connelly "hot oil" law, interstate compacts to pro-rate production and the latest proposal to pro-rate refinery output as playing into the hands of the large oil companies.

When the Holland-America liner Veendam arrived last night at Hoboken from Rotterdam it became known that Mrs. Rose Sonnenschein, 65 years old, a Jewish refugee from Vienna, had disappeared from the ship three days ago.

The Italian liner Rex is due to arrive today from Mediterranean ports. Her passenger list includes Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States; Count Girolamo Debosdari, new Italian consul to New York, Lucrezia Bori, singer;
C. L. Von Egloffstein was elected yesterday president of the Certainteed Products Corporation to succeed Walter G. Baumhogger, resigned. Mr. Baumhogger will continue as a director of the company.

Opposition to German barter trade methods is spreading rapidly through all of Central and South America, foreign traders attending a regular luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania, asserted yesterday.
President Leopoldo Arosemena signed today a legislative bill authorizing a $6,000,000 internal loan and providing for the regulation of banks in Panama.

A LONG the line of scrimmage they are still chattering about the official error made in the Notre Dame-Carnegie Tech game. To run through it again briefly for the benefit of those who came in late, Carnegie Tech had the ball in its own territory, close to midfield, in the fourth period. Score: 0-0. The Skibo quarterback asked-the referee what down it was and the referee said:

Sean Lemass, Minister of Industry and Commerce, told the annual meeting of the Irish Tourist Association here today that the government had decided to make tourism a State industry on the same lines as those of France, Italy and other Continental countries.

Foreseeing a continued expansion of government activity in relief and all types of public service, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson declared yesterday that "the great need of the hour is for the closest kind of cooperation between government and industry, between government, the employer and the employe."

Tonight's events: Elizabeth Wysor, contralto, Town Hall, 8:30; Iso Elinson, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Madama Butterfly," Manhattan Center; Composers ForumLaboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall; Bernard Gabriel, lecture-recital, Sherman Square Studios, 8:15; "Music of the Orient," lecture by Dr. Arthur P. Moor, New York Public Library Music Division, 8:30.

Representative Dies, chairman of the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities, on his return late tonight from New York, said that while he "deeply regretted the President's bitter attack upon a committee of an independent Congress" he would continue to do his duty "undeterred and unafraid."

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and many other city officials are expected to attend the annual memorial service at 4 P. M. Sunday for the deceased members of the Anchor Club, which is composed of members of the Police Department who belong to the Knights of Columbus.

Coach Jack Blott ordered a long offensive drill for the Wesleyan regulars today. The team has lacked scoring power in the last two games and will concentrate on this for the contest with Trinity Saturday. Captain Daddario was back in the lineup as quarterback and called the signals.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, veteran of two State Constitutional Conventions, denounced last night the convention method of drafting a new State Constitution and the resulting system of submitting the whole document to the people in a huge lump, as will be done on election day, Nov. 8.

The University of Pittsburgh said tonight 75,000 tickets have been sold for Saturday's gridiron contest between the Panthers and the Rams of Fordham-assuring the largest crowd ever assembled at the Pitt Stadium.

Total sales of the Borg-Warner Corporation and the American Car and Foundry Company, filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission, were released for publication through the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Investment Bankers Association of America special train left here last night in two secontions carrying some 270 delegates to White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., for the twenty-seventh annual convention of the association, which will convene today at the Greenbrier Hotel.
Ranked as the paladins of the Ivy League at the start of the season, Dartmouth and Cornell invade the Yale Bowl and Columbia's Baker Field on Saturday,

C. Manuel Pereira, Chilean delegate to the New York World's Fair 1939, started the building of the Chik??an exhibit at the fair grounds in Flushing yesterday by pressing a lever releasing a ton of cement into forms for the foundation.

The sale of vacant plots featured the realty transactions reported in the Bronx yesterday. The seven-family dwelling at 4,441 Carpenter Avenue was purchased by Mrs. Albina Vignali from a client of P. C. D'Onofrio, broker, for cash above a mortgage of $10,250.

Wilbur Hall, chairman of the Virginia Conservation Commission, delivered today to Jesse H. Jones, treasurer of the Woodrow Wilson Birthday Foundation, Inc., a check for $5,000 as the first installment of Virginia's $10,000 share in the purchase price of the Wilson birthplace at Staunton, Va.
Mr. and Mrs. Christopher L. Ward of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Ward, to Dr. C. Lalor Burdick.

A string of six jumpers, headed by Blarney Castle, 14-year-old veteran of the Irish Army Horse Show team, arrived on the United States liner American Importer yesterday to compete in the international jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 5 to 12.

Mrs. Ann Hogan Gillespie, the first president of the old Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, died on Saturday in Indianapolis, according to word received here yesterday.
An important step toward German economic hegemony in Southeastern Europe was taken today when a new trade agreement with Germany was signed here after three weeks of negotiation.
Eleven members of the Moyne Commission, on their way to Jamaica on the liner Orbita, had luncheon with the Governor of Bermuda before sailing this afternoon.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
General Arthur Schuschnigg, father of Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, the imprisoned former Chancellor, was buried in Hietzing Cemetery this morning.

Coach Andy Kerr today used Hal Lube, ace passer, and Joe Hoague, fullback, in the backfield he expects to start against Holy Cross in Worcester Saturday. In the same quartet were Bob Johnson, quarterback, and Howard Herman, right halfback.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 24: COLONELS Miller, A. C., Med. Corps, one month and ten days leave, Nov. 23. Baird, R. C., to retirement, on own application.

William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, said last night that as far as he was concernedd workmen could have a one-day week, as long as "the level of productivity is maintained."

A definite, decision to defer consideration of the New York,. Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company's application to list its new 6 per cent three-year notes was reached yesterday afternoon by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran's "university" has fallen upon evil days. In fact, it appeared yesterday, that the founder, dean and faculty of the now studentless university has reached the point where he has expressed a willingness, even eagerness, to enroll his disciples by winning football wagers.
New pneumonia cases in the city increased by ninety-seven last week, it was reported yesterday to Dr. George T. Palmer, acting Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield. registrar of records.

Seven-year-old John E. Rogers, who brought suit against the Betsy Ross Ice Cream Company of Newark after one of its trucks demolished his toy express wagon, was placated today when the company gave him a new wagon.

Mr. and Mrs. Lynford A. Ward of Queens Village, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Diane Ward, to Lyle Cottrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Andrews Cottrell of Center, Col.

The Dies Committee Investigating Un-American Activities was assailed in caustic terms by President Roosevelt today as a forum for disgruntled politicians to air "absurdly false charges" with the deliberats intent of preventing the re-election of Governor Murphy of Michigan.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Before leaving for Albany, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared that "panicky" Democratic leaders had put pressure on Governor Lehman, his opponent, which had caused the Governdr to lose his customary poise and restraint in his Albany speech Monday evening.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some Englishmen and their press, in the stress of recent developments, are demanding that the United States join with Britain to preserve peace, democracy and the political status quo. Americans are called upon to come out strongly on the side of European democracies against the economic and political menace of growing totalitarianism.
Two United States boxers scored knockouts tonight on the fourth night of the Pan-American amateur boxing championships.

Brown opened preparations today for its contest with Tufts here Saturday by staging a long, hard scrimmage for the reserves against a makeshift array of freshmen whose ranks were depleted by injuries sustained last Saturday.
The Department of Agriculture and Markets won its battle today for strict enforcement of a 1937 law regulating truck transportation of coal into the State.

Paul vap Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium, who arrived in the United States yesterday, will make the first lecture of his American tour at the school house of the International Business Machines Corportion at Endicott, N. Y., according to Frederick W. Nichol, vice president and general manager of the company.

The Munich pact marked the disappearance of an era and the beginning of a new one, in the opinion of Paul Van Zeeland, former Prime Minister of Belgium, who arrived last night on the French liner Ile de France for a lecture tour here.

Multiple-unit collective bargaining, as contrasted to the British system of industry-wide collective bargaining, was predicted yesterday as an inevitable trend in this country by John C. Gall, counsel to the National Association of Manufacturers, in an address before the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Trade Association Executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
An eleven-room apartment at 1,113 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Martin F. Reddington through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

The marriage of Miss Helen May Goldsmith of Scarsdale, daughter of Mrs. William Ravner and the late Oliver L. Goldsmith, to Edward J. Grunebaum of New York took place here tonight at the Jewish Community Center.

Mrs. Louise Owens Carter, wartime chief of nurses at several army hospitals during the World War, died here yesterday of a heart ailment. She was taken to a hospital Sunday. Her age was 48. She and her husband, John E. Carter, and their daughter, Phyllis, had been residents of Brunswick for sixteen months. She was a native of Detroit.

Representative J. P. Thomas of New Jersey, a Republican of the Dies committee, tonight termed President Roosevelt's criticism of the committee "an attempt by New Deal bureaucrats to minimize its findings."

The 13,736-ton liner American Legion was sold at auction yesterday to the United States Maritime Commission for $135,000. She was the largest American vessel placed on the auction block in this port in many years.
Steel ingot production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index receded to 71.3 from 73.5. The figure for the week ended Oct. 23, 1937, was 81.3.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo announces several changes in the schedule of its remaining performances at the Metropolitan Opera House. On Saturday afternoon, "Gaite Parisienne" will replace the scheduled "Prince Igor," and on Saturday evening "Giselle" will be withdrawn and in its place will be seen "St. Francis" and "The Seventh Symphony," along with "Bogatyri."
Tony Lazzeri had a free rein tonight to go shopping in the baseball marts even though P. K. Wrigley, owner of Chicago's Cubs, said the ex-Yankee had not been given his unconditional release.

The second weekly Associated Press ranking poll, made up from the ballots of 100 sports writers, leaves not the slightest doubt that the outstanding college football game in the country this Saturday will be the meeting at Pittsburgh of Jock Sutherland's all-conquering Panthers and Fordham's unbeaten Rams.
A German scientific expedition returned here today with six live falcons after four months in West Greenland studying the conditions in which the birds exist.

Following is the text of the speech given by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, here tonight in Harmanus-Bleecker Hall: At last the lid is off in Albany County. At last the truth is coming out. Last night I told part of the story of the political oppression in this, your home city.

The State Unemployment Compensation Department announced today that it had decided to pay benefits to employes of the Seaman Body Company of Milwaukee who were laid off during the shut-down of the Nash-Kelvinator Company plant in Racine.

Dr. Joseph H. Willits has been elected director of the division of the social sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, according to an announcement yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick, the president. Dr. Willits succeeds Dr. Edmund E.

Part of William R. Hearst's collection of old silver, covering the fifteenth to nineteenth centuries, which is being sold in liquidation of the newspaper. proprietor's estate, will be offered. at Christie's on Dec. 14.

Defeat is just around the corner for Choate's football forces, according to affable Jack Maher, head coach; in fact, finis can now be written to the Blue and Gold's enviable distinction of not having bowed in fifteen straight games, if you place absolute faith in Maher's opinions.

The Republican caravan, which has visited twenty-one up-State Counties in the last week, left the North country today to join Thomas E. Dewey, head of the patty's State ticket, in meetings at Albany and Troy.

Following a narrowing of more than a quarter of a cent in the spread between the December and the October 1939 delivery, differences widened again yesterday and near-month contracts on the Cotton Exchange improved 7 points, while the October lost a point.
The text of Senator Wagner's replies to questions on New Deal policies put to Senatorial candidates by THE NEW YORK TIMES follows:

The Postal Telegraph Company indicated yesterday its readiness to abide by the hours provision of the Wages and Hours Law while it began, in line with its previous announcement, to dismiss 1,000 messenger boys because of the minimum wage provision of the law.

Thomas E. Dewey, the-Republican candidate for Governor, continued his attack upon the O'Connell Democratic machine of this city here tonight, charging manipulation of tax assessments to favor the machine's

George C. Buechner of 85-12 Forest Parkway, Woodhaven, Queens. a lawyer with offices at 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Memorial Hospital, Manhattan, after a month's illness. Born in East New York fifty-eight years ago, he had resided in Woodhaven since 1905.

Lewis Beers Curtis, Bridgeport banker, manufacturer and world traveler, whose English ancestors first settled in Stratford in 1684, died suddenly at his residence here this morning as the result of a cold contracted on a European trip from which he returned on Wednesday. His age was 75.

New England manufacturers have been engaged for two years in a large spending program which will continue through 1939, it was disclosed here today by the New England Council and the Engineering Societies of New England, Inc.,
The Women's Hour of the Jewish Theological Seminary reopened its Tuesday afternoon broadcasts yesterday at 3 P. M. from Station WHN and the Empire State network.

Governor Lehman completed a strenuous day of campaigning through the Mohawk Valley with the charge before a campaign rally here tonight that the Republican party on its record and despite its candidate could not be trusted to administer for the people the extensive water power resources of the State of New York.
The Duke of Kent, 35-year-old brother of King George, has been appointed to succeed Lord Gowrie next year as Governor General of Australia.

BURTON, CLINTON FREDERICK (Oct. 20). Estate, not more than $2,000. To Martha Jordon, mother, 400 Convent Ave., residue; one specific bequest. Henrietta Lane, executrix, 452 Convent Ave. DUHIGG, ELLEN (Sept. 23). Estate, less than -$10,000. To Mary Hartigan, sister, executrix, 226 E. 67th St.; two specific bequests.

" Danton's Death," with which the Mercury Theatre had expected to open its season tonight, has been postponed until Friday night. Difficulties with the mechanics of the production and the need for a little

The 4,000,000 young men and women who have come of voting age since 1936 and will be eligible to cast their first vote in a national election Nov. 8 are more in sympathy with the Democratic party than the Republican party in the Congressional contests, according to a survey of "first voters" just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.
Two stakes were completed today during the first session of the fifth annual meeting of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association over the course of the Ingham Hill Game Farm.
Boos and mild applause greeted Gene Tunney this afternoon at the first national conference on liquor advertising when he severely criticized liquor advertising.

A new kidnapping-prevention device for children's bedrooms, made to set off an alarm in any other room or rooms in the home without the use of any connecting wires between the various rooms, is being shown by American Communications Corporation at the National Hotel Exposition at the Grand Central Palace this week.

Selectivity ruled throughout trading yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Although individual issues gained considerable upward momentum, the list in general showed sagging tendencies. Sales rose to $7,900,975 from Monday's $7,498,500.

Present employment figures at the Rock Island Arsenal are the highest since the World War, states Colonel Norman F. Ramsey, commanding officer. Employes total 2,052 now. The previous high figure in 1934 was 2,047.

Three more allegedly fraudulent investment trusts were put out of business yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Valente signed an injunction permanently restraining them from further securities dealings "in and from" New York State.

The thirteen-story apartment house on an irregular plot 90x75 feet at 322-326 West End Avenue was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Greenwich Savings Bank, as plaintiff, bid it in at $500,000.

Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark and Colonel and Mrs. Percy W. Parkinson, who arrived recently from Kintbury, Berkshire, England, will leave the Pierre today to go to Wrentham House, Mrs. Clark's home in Newport.

A red-haired woman of 37, who formerly toured the country as a showgirl, was arrested at 1 o'clock this morning charged with the theft of jewelry valued at $4,000 from the home of I. O. Gulden, a banker, at his home in Rumson, N. J., last Aug. 11, where she was employed as a maid.

Raymond Marien, 45 years old, an accountant, of 24-32 Forty-third Street, Astoria, Queens, in General Sessions substituted yesterday a guilty plea for the not-guilty plea he had enteredd last February on his indictment on a third-degree attempted forgery charge in connection with his mysterious inflation by $1,000,000 in assets of his employers, the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc.

While a few advertising budgets may have been pared slightly by companies to allow participation in the World's Fair here, the average budget of exhibitors for newspapers, magazines and radio will be increased, with particular emphasis put on "merchandising" exhibits to the public, according to comments by advertising managers yesterday.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins was accused of "gross malfeasance of office" in her handling of alien deportation cases by two spokesmen of the California American Legion today before the House committee investigating un-American activities.
The approaching World's Fair already is exerting an influence on activity in various branches of the real estate industry, particularly on Long Island.

There are now 18,500 British troops in Palestine, including the air force. They have general headquarters headed by Lieut. Gen. R. H. Gaining, who is in command, and divisional headquarters under Major Gen. R. M. O'Connor, in addition to military commanders for the various districts throughout the country.

Dr. Rexford Guy Tugwell and' Professor Raymond Moley, two of President Roosevelt's original "brain trusters," debated the Presidential third term before more than 3,000 men and women at the eighth annual Forum on Current Events opened by The New York Herald Tribune yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Formal contracts for the fifteenround meeting between Henry Armstrong and Ceferino Garcia at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night were signed yesterday at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission. Armstrong's welterweight championship will be at stake.

A hard-fought soccer battle today ended with a victory for Yale over Trinity by 1-0. The Elis triumphed in the second quarter with a kick by Erickson. 'Outstanding players for Yale were Bruce, Brown and Captain Raleigh. Bates, Gaboury, Insley and Ferguson played well for Trinity. The line-up:

The art of gathering stars in the far reaches of the universe has made such progress in recent years that the giant 200-inch telescope now being completed on Mount Palmomar, Calif., will have penetrating powers into the vastness of outermost space equivalent to those of the 400-inch telescope ten years ago, it was learned here today at the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at the University of North Carolina.

The Japanese naval spokesman, in discussing tonight the damage to the British gunboat Sandpiper by Japanese bombs Monday, reiterated that the Japanese had not been notified that the Sandpiper. was at Changsha.

Sports Peerless Pride, an English setter owned by Louis M. Bobbit of Winston-Salem, N. C., took first honors today in the $500 All-Age Stakes, first event of the seventeenth annual West Virginia field trials.
A schedule of twelve college basketball double-headers, in which teams from all parts of the country will participate, was announced today by Promoter Clair Hare.

A daughter of Pilate, the erstwhile selling plater Andy Schuttinger campaigned into a stake horse, scored at Empire City yesterday to further support the assumption that the horse will be a greater success as a sire than he was as a racer.
ANDREW TO THE LIONS, by H. W. Freeman. (Morrow, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "Joseph and His Brethren."

The Rockefeller interests have sold another parcel of their holdings in Washington Heights, just south of Fort Tryon Park and north of the former site of The Cloisters, to a syndicate which plans to improve the property with a $2,000,000 apartment project.

After an absence or two years, Eva Le Gallienne has returned in the best part she has had for a long time. If she coveted "Madame Capet" when she saw Marcelle Maurette's play in Paris, it is easy to see why in the beautifully modulated performance which opened at

Although this country's merchandise exports in September, as reported Tuesday by the Commerce Department, were below those of any month of 1937, or of 1938 until June, the imports were so small that the surplus of exports was the largest for September since 1930 and, for the nine months, the largest since 1921.
To the varied collection of lost property recovered by the Police Department was added last night one wooden ferry bridge 60 feet long, 40 feet wide and 12 feet high.

To take the "mystery" out of oral English examinations, the Board of Examiners has Formulated a sixpoint scale to evaluate the speech of prospective candidates for.teaching . licenses in New York - City schools,
Two Tennessee "mountain" women stood unemotionally before Judge W. Joe Hill of Benton today and were sentenced to long prison terms for the hitch hike murder of Felix Shanon, a Mount Erie farmer.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 25, unless specified: At San Francisco: Arizona, Nevada, Oklahoma. Pearl Harbor to San Diego: Cushing, Perkins, Preston, Smith.

It is unofficially reported here that one of his aides will succeed Governor Lawrence W. Cramer here. Governor Cramer interrupted his vacation, leaving Mrs. Cramer at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore to come here for private conferences with the government secretary and other officials.

On their own application. To take effect 12 midnight, Oct. 22: PATROLMEN-Charles C. Michael, 5th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 25, 1913. To take effect 12 midnight, Oct. 31: Felix Martin, Traffic Precinct L, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 13, 1905.

3d Ave (11-2924), w a, 108 ft n of 176th St, 54x92; Francis X. Hennessy, referee, to Edward King Realty Co, Inc, 60 Broadway. 256th St (13-3423B), n e cor of Delafleld Ave, 50x100; Bridget Mullins to Emma Burke, 8,265 Audley St, Kew Gardens, L. I.

The legal procedure was reversed yesterday afternoon in the Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court, Brooklyn, when five men, arrested on charges of vagrancy in the Borough Park section, appeared before Magistrate Mark Rudich.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, who charged in a recent campaign address that corruption existed in the Democratic State organization, became tonight the target of a counter-attack based on charges of Republican misuse of funds in up-State areas.

Addressing the first open meeting of the American Jewish Federation to Combat Communism and Fascism, Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the .House committee investigating un-American activities, urged yesterday that all religious or minority groups unite in an aggressive campaign to fight the inroads of communism, fascism and nazism.

Vsevelod E. Meyerhold, famous producer of eccentric dramatic productions, who was dismissed from his own theatre last January-the Meyerhold Theatre itself was at the same time dissolved--has won his way back to official favor.

Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company called today a special stockholders' meeting for Dec. 1 to approve a new exchange offer of four Edison shares for each of the preferred shares of Western United Gas and Electric Company.

Pledges of active cooperation with the Federal Wages and Hours Law were made yesterday by two more States, while reports. from other centers indicated that the new law was functioning without great difficulties other than the routine of putting it into effect.

French Guiana, the convict settlement on the South American coast, will receive two new shiploads- of "habitual criminals" despite the fact that Popular Front legislation killedd" this penal colony, which is popularly known as Devil's Island.

Japanese announced yesterday that they had entered Hankow, China's provisional capital. But high officials had withdrawn from the city, most of the civilians had been evacuated and fires and explosions were causing vast destruction.
The government has granted the United Fruit Company permission to import and operate two airplanes for the purpose of spraying banana plantations with Bordeaux mixture to fight the "Sigatoka" pest.

The probability of most serious thirdpower complications is foreseen in high official circles here as a result of the expected early Japanese control of the entire length of the Canton-Hankow Railway.

The injury jinx which has been trailing the Brooklyn College football team all season struck again yesterday afternoon, when it was announced that Sid White, backfield ace, would be lost to the team for at least two weeks, and possibly for the rest of the season.
An "$8,000,000" race will be run tomorrow when the classic Cesarewitch is renewed over two miles and a quarter with one Americanowned horse among the twentyeight entries.
City College concentrated on polishing up its aerial offensive yesterday as Coach Benny Friedman pointed the Beavers for the Lewisohn Stadium game with undefeated Lowell Textile on Saturday.

Two operators of a sound truck used by an organization seeking repeal of Colorado's $45 a month old age pension law, most liberal of any such statute in the country, were beaten today on a downtown corner here and the truck was damaged.

Jesse Gordon of Kuhn, Loeb Co. has been re-elected for a third term as president of the Wall Street Riding Club. Other officers elected include G. H. Struckmann of Bank of the Manhattan Company, vice president; Joseph Landsberg, Brickman, Landsberg Co., treasurer,
Edward N. Townsend Jr., an investment and insurance broker, of 99 John Street, reported to the police last night that his chauffeur and an automobile containing luggage and jewelry valued at $200,000

Taking off from the airport here in tow of an airplane, Lewin B. Barringer of Philadelphia today piloted his motorless sail plane to a new American altitude record of 9,000 feet, against that of 6,804 feet by Richard C. duPont, president of the Soaring Society of America.

The Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime, which precipitated the special investigation of law enforcement in Kings County, issued a report yesterday on "Twelve Months of Crime in New York City" that asserted that pleas of guilty dominate the city's criminal justice, that burglary continued to be the most successful predatory crime and that the crime problem was greatest in Manhattan.
John Haynes Holmes, who has been chairman of the City Affairs Committee since its organization in 1930, has resigned that post, it was announced yesterday.

Recommendations for changes in the organization of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., to make it eligible for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Maloney act as a nationwide association of over-the-counter brokers and dealers were adopted here today at a joint meeting of the governing committee and advisory council of the conference in the Carlton Hotel.

A new issue of $50,000,000 of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company ten-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1948, will be placed on the market today by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Otis Co., as syndicate managers and leaders of a group of eighty-six underwriters and of more than 600 dealers.
Mayor La Guardia and Newbold Morris, Council President, warned members of the City Council yesterday to devote their immediate attention to two phases of the city's financial situation.
Central Illinois Public Service Company-Three months to Sept. 30: Net income after expenses and charges, $575,846, compared with a net of $494,582 in 1937 period.

The worst accident in the history of civil aviation in Australia, involving the loss of eighteen lives, occurred this afternoon when an Australian National Airways plane, en route from Adelaide to Melbourne, crashed on Mount Dandenong, twenty-four miles east of Melbourne.

The Welfare Council Committee on Constitutional Convention sent yesterday to the 800 social and health agencies affiliated with the council a report recommending that they support the proposed amendments dealing with housing, rights of labor, social welfare and the general, or omnibus, amendment.

A net loss of- $5,847,791 for the third quarter of 1938 was reported for the United States Steel Corporation yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board, following the declaration of the regular preferred dividend of $1.75 a share.
Rivals in Michigan's Gubernatorial campaign, Governor Frank Murphy and former Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald, acclaimed and attacked President Roosevelt's rebuke of the Dies committee tonight.

Fire Lieutenant Patrick J. McKeon, 63 year old, in charge of Engine Company 224, died at 9:45 o'clock last night while fighting a smoky rubbish blaze at 2,984 West Third Street, Brooklyn. The police and firemen said he had been overcome by smoke.

Two of the major faults revealed by, the New York University football team in its campaign to date have been in tackling and blocking. As a result Coach Mal Stevens promised his charges yesterday that they could expect-to devote a large measure of each workout until the game with Ohio State at the Polo Grounds on Saturday to sharpening their performances in these departments.

Although the soprano Dorothy Baker made her Town Hall debut last night, her professional career has been keeping her busy for some time near and far from West Forty-third Street. For the last three seasons she has been regular soloist at St. Bartholomew's,

A flexible, rather than a fixed, season for shooting waterfowl was urged upon the Federal Government last night by. Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy, president of the National Association of Audubon Societies.
Lessing J. Rosenwald, chairman of the board of Sears, Reobuck Co., said here tonight that he had "no thought of retiring."

AFRICK-Maxwell, of 25 Clark Place, Bronx. Members of Rodfie "Zedek Anschei" Rittover are requested to attend the funeral of Brother Maxwell Africk at 2 o'clock, today, Glassman Memorial Home, 200 Broome St. Interment Washington Cemetery.

Jam sessions and jitterbug "orgies" of "swing" music are wooing young people "along the primrose path to hell," the Most Rev. Francis J. L. Beckman, Archbishop of Dubuque told the National Council of Catholic Women tonight.

Thomas E. Wilson of Wilson Co. in a statement today said that despite declining consumer buying power during the first ten months of the year, meat packers will have paid $1,800,000,000 for livestock bought by them during the fiscal year closing Oct. 31.
The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $3,886,816 after Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion and retirements.

The first group of third quarter earnings statements of principal steel companies appeared yesterday, displaying in general less favorable results than in the second quarter, although the industry, as a whole, operated at 41 per cent of capacity in the third quarter, against 31 per cent in the second quarter, a gain of 33 per cent.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Independent Citizens Committee speaker, in behalf of Governor S Lehman and Charles Poletti (from recording), WNEW, 11:45 to 11:50 A. M. (1,250 Kc.)

A complete revision of plans for sponsoring celebration of a Nationally Advertised Brands Week in the grocery industry was announced yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America.
Negotiations for a British-American trade treaty, which recently have been at a standstill, apparently were resumed today when a communication from the British Government arrived here.
The Rev. Professor Archibald R. S. Kennedy, one of the most distinguished Hebrew scholars of Great Britain, died in Edinburgh today at the age of 78.

Eleven members of two C. I. O. unions were found guilty of criminal contempt of court by a Supreme Court jury before Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo yesterday for picketing Busch Jewelry Company Stores in violation of an injunction issued by

With most of its injured players back in action, the Princeton squad ran through the first of a series of three secret practice sessions on University Field today in preparation for the Harvard contest. Ninety minutes of the workout was spent in scrimmage against the scrubs, who employed Cantab plays.

A 12-year-old Negro boy, Walter Williams, pleaded guilty today to a charge of shooting and killing Hubert Brouillete, 9-year-old white boy, and was sentenced-to life imprisonment in the State penitentiary.

The engagement of Miss Marian Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Phillips of this place, to Edmund A. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Smith of Garwood, N. J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Phillips.

Richard Farnsworth Hoyt, banker, sportsman and former partner in Hayden, Stone Co., left an insolvent estate when he died on March 7, 1935, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday with the State Tax

The Rock Royal Cooperative, Inc., of Rock Royal filed a reorganization petition here today stating that it cannot pay to its producer members the price set by the State administrator for milk and meet the payments of its creditors also.

Miss Martha A. Shannon, writer and lecturer on American Colonial topics, died suddenly at New Haven, Conn., yesterday according to word received here. She was 90 years old. Miss Shannon, for many years a resident of Beacon Hill, was a member of Trinity Church. Recently she had made her home in Hartford, Conn.

Guenther Gustav Rumrich testified yesterday under cross-examination on his seventh day on the witness stand that after agreeing to turn State's evidence in the government's espionage case against his former co-defendants he was transferred from the Federal House of Detention to the Hotel Commodore and occasionally taken to a moving picture show.
The bitter struggle between Estonia's semi-dictatorial regime and the Democratic opposition for restoration of constitutional rights continues unabated in the newly opened Parliament.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, the National and State Democratic Chairman, has received preliminary reports from the five county leaders of the city which indicate a plurality of more than 700,000 votes for Governor Lehman in the city.
Twenty-eight lathing contractors and officials of a lathers' union were indicted yesterday by the Queens County grand jury. The indictments charge the operation of a $1,000,000 conspiracy.
The long-advertised sale of the furnishings of the Van Sweringens' Daisy Hill Farm mansion was launched today in the spacious "ship room."

All France observed today in one way or another the one hundredth aniversary of the birth of George Bizet, the composer. Festivities, however, began some time ago and will continue for some time to come.

For the first time since he was barred from landing in the United States on Oct. 10, when immigration authorities informed him that the United States Vice Consul in London had revoked his visa, John Strachey,

Answers to the six questions put to candidates for the United States Senate in an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Thursday came today from Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democratic nominee for the long term.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Art of Ancient Persia," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; Collection of Roman Art (general tour) 2 P. M.; "American Cabinetmakers: Transition in Architecture, 1700," Alfred Busselle Jr., 4 P. M.
Five saddened members of the crew. of the lost American schooner Pioneer reached New York yesterday on the American Banker of the United States Lines, which rescued them at sea on Oct. 2.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 20 was greater in four groups and lower in one, as compared with a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

The Central Council of Associations, composed of seventeen groups of women in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut which are active in the support of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, will hold its annual get-together this afternoon at the institute building, 25 South Street.
The marriage of Mrs. Charles M. Dickinson of Binghamton to Louis Balog, New York civil engineer, was announced here today. The ceremony was performed Sunday in New York.

Syracuse started its drive for the Penn State game on Saturday, with Coach Ossie Solem making four important changes today. Bill Hoffman, regular quarterback, moved to fullback and Jack Taylor, his senior understudy, called signals from the blocking back position.

Four elms said to have stood since Washington's time, several frame dwellings and metal garages, a warehouse and 100 feet of board fence will be razed on Lawrence Street and on the continuation of Thirty-fifth Avenue, from Prince to Lawrence Streets, Flushing, in connection with the widening and paving of an important approach to Whitestone Bridge by the Queens field office of the WPA, according to an announcement yesterday.
A capacity throng is expected in the Starlight Roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria today at the special luncheon and bridge for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. Mrs. Harold H.
Before a packed court room a mass arraignment was held today for seventy-three persons charged with fraud and political conspiracy through manipulation and organization of the WPA in the State.

Suggested trade practice rules drawn up to eliminate unfair methods of competition in the linen industry won general approval of more than 150 representatives of importers, wholesalers, retailers and consumers yesterday at a conference held by the Federal Trade Commission in the Hotel Astor.
Bernie Friedkin of Brownsville gained the decision over Jack Sharkey Jr. of the West Side in the eight-round main bout before 4,500 at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
Sid Luckman, Columbia's stellar passer, was the central figure at Baker Field yesterday as the Lions sped through a three-hour, aerial drill in preparation for the meeting with Cornell Saturday.

William Lemke, in 1936 Union party candidate for President of the United States and now a member of the House of Representatives, today became the latest American to have property in Mexico expropriated.

Professor Albert Einstein and Mayor La Guardia will participate in the dedication of Congress House for German refugees, maintained at 48 West Sixty-eighth Street by the women's division of the American Jewish Congress, on Saturday at 4 P. M., according to an announcement yesterday.

" The absolute political freedom" of WPA workers was the way Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, today phrased an order assuring them of their right to vote on Nov. 8 for candidates of their own choosing and providing for a readjustment of their working hours, if necessary, to enable them to do it.
Oswald Pirow, South African Minister of Defense, was cordially received here this evening when he arrived by air en route to London.

Sir George Middleton, who as First Church Estate Commissioner was largely responsible for the management of vast estates, holdings of the Church of England, died today during a conference with the Archbishop of Canterbury. His age was 62.

The stock market here was quieter today but its undertone remained firm. Giltedge issues on the whole held to yesterday's closing levels and foreign bonds were equally steady, with Japanese and Chinese issues up slightly on the hope of an early truce in the Far Eastern hostilities.

The outstanding characteristic of the war in the Far East is that it is a war of advances and retreats rather than of battles and defeats. The Japanese have taken one great city after another, but since the siege of Shanghai the Chinese Army has never waited to fight it out with the invaders.
Nine young musicians were chosen from sixty applicants to appear as soloists this season with the City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, Judge Leopold Prince, conductor. Auditions took place yesterday.

In confirmity with now well-established practice, the government announced today that the latest Reich loan of 1,500,000,000 marks had been so well oversubscribed that in order to "meet subscribers' urgent demands" the total had been raised to 1,850,000,000 marks.

One year of war in the Far East caused a shrinkage in the trade between the United States on the one hand and Japan and China on the other comparable only with the declines in the worst years of the depression.

A lot of New Yorkers seem to be interested in the Tennessee boar hunting this year, and those who are planning trips South fpr quail and turkey have asked for additional information on this odd feature.
H. J. Perahia was re-elected president of the executive board of the National Skirt Manufacturers Association, Inc., at the sixth annual meeting of the group in the Hotel New Yorker last night.

With a11 the fanfare concerning the merits of the point after touchdown, Herb Kopf, whose Manhattan College eleven was affected by such a point last Saturday, was sought yesterday for an opinion on the subject.

Dr. and Mrs. J. Willard Travell gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Grill of Rockefeller Center for Mrs. Travell's daughter, Miss Margaret Bates, and Stuart Henry van Saun, whose marriage will take place today in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Resentful over a day's idleness enforced by the race committee, the crew of the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, American challenger for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic, labored long after dark tonight preparing her for tomorrow's decisive meeting with the Canadian defender Bluenose.
Having scored a 400 per cent sales increase from the low point in 1933, the piano industry yesterday set about creating two annual "peaks" of consumer demand.

Frank Hatch of 89-07 Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill, Queens, an actor and stage director who had been associated in both capacities with William A. Brady productions, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Queens General Hospital, Jamaica. He was born in Marysville, Calif., seventy-four years ago.

The voluntary hospitals of this city are indispensable. It is among them that the medical progress of our day has reached its peak in the care of patients, the training of nurses, the development of professional standards and the encouragement of research.

A change in the ownership of the largest natural gas transmission line in California was disclosed yesterday by the Pacific Lighting Corporation in a statement to shareholders. Pacific Lighting reported the acquisition of the half interest

A forty-foot chimney on the site formerly occupied by a lumber yard and mill at Penn Street and Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, yielded to progress yesterday when WPA workers pulled it down as part of the demolition in preparation for construction of the new Brooklyn Crosstown Highway.

On the- basis of a plea by Governor Blanton Winship to New York principals in the needle trade to continue sending work to Puerto Rico pending possible readjustment of the Fair Labor Standards Law, many establishments are continuing operation, with slight adjustment in wages and hours.
Dr. Joel Henry Hildebrand, Professor of Chemistry at the University of California and internationally known for his studies of liquid and solid solutions,
Severe criticism of the management of the French arms industry, which has been nationalized, was heard today by the Army Commission of the Chamber of Deputies in a report by Fernand Laurent.

Miss Vera A. Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Goodman of Dallas, Texas, has chosen Nov. 5 as the date of her marriage to Ross Bond Updegraff, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Updegraff of this city.

Commander John D. Pennington, superintendent of the Pennsylvania Industrial School, was exonerated today of all blame in connection with the death last Christmas of Daniel Lamaurr, a 19-year-old Negro inmate of the reformatory.

Many hostesses entertained at the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop yesterday at the Versailles. Young women of society who acted as manikins in the revue were Mrs. Carl Triest, the Misses Brenda Frazier, Margaret Beadleston, Hope Saunders, Audrey Paige, Mary Louise Wart, Helen Stedman, Anne Wright and Anne Amory.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:

A decision to seek the cooperation of store managers in a proposal to report information on customers who repeatedly seek adjustment of unfair claims was made last night by members of the Metropolitan Retail Store Adjusters at a meeting at 2 Park Avenue.

Asserting that the State government during the administration of Governor Lehman had dealt "grudgingly" with New York City in connection with its relief problem and had plugged a hole in the State budget by taking $12,000,000 in public utilities taxes from the city,

A brand new type of suspended house has arrived in town and was placed on view yesterday afternoon (in the form of a revolving four-bythree-foot model and a set of floor plans) at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Time Signal, owned and trained by L. E. Ogle, overcame a slow beginning to annex the Fayette Purse, today's feature race. Showing a disregard for the heavy going along the rail, the High Time colt ran there most of the way and defeated D. B. MidKiff's Dixieland by a length and a half.

The statement from the -White House late today containing the comment by President Roosevelt on testimony before the House Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities that Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan had been guilty of "treasonable" activities in dealing with sit-down strikes, was as follows:
The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee heard today from its investigators that some WPA workers in Pennsylvania had been solicited for $100 contributions to the Democratic campaign fund.

The Hamburg - American liner Deutschland, with 591 passengers and a crew of 390, was proceeding to New York this morning after having caused tense anxiety last night when she sent out distress messages saying she was urgently in need of assistance about 200 miles southeast of Cape Race, Nfld., following an explosion and fire in her No. 2 hold.

Trading was slow on veal and calf, good on lamb and pork loins, mostly fair to good on others in local markets yesterday. Pork loins were higher; veal and calf barely steady; other classes mostly steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

A $235,000 mortgage on the 2-story business building, containing the Nemo Theatre, at the s e cor of Broadway and 110th St, formerly held by the estate of Josephine DelDrago, has been taker over by the mutual Life Insurance Company.

Forcing the battle all the way Jackie (Kid) Berg, 147 1/4, England, gained the decision over Joey Greb, 145 1/4, Herkimer, N. Y., last night in the feature eight-round bout on the card at the New York Coliseum before 8,000 persons.

An appeal to the State Supreme Court will be taken from the decision handed down yesterday by Judge Berthold Vorsanger of the Third District Court, Bergen County, decaring the State Fair Sales Act it unconstitutional, it was announced here today by Harry Lief, president of the New Jersey Retail Grocers Association.
To strengthen the link between the United States and Latin America, which has become a paramount policy of this government since the Munich agreement, very practical steps are in view.
The Brazilian delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, has been definitely chose. The delegation will be headed by former Foreign Minister Afranio Melo Franco.

Reports issued by two Eastern trunk lines yesterday confirmed previous indications that the increase in the East of the charge for travel in coaches from 2 cents to 2.5 cents a mile had failed to produce additional revenue.

Mrs. Louise Owens Carter, wartime chief of United States Army nurses, died here yesterday of a heart ailment. Mrs. Carter, 48 years old, was taken to a hospital Sunday. She and her husband, John E. Carter, and their daughter, Phyllis, had been residents of Brunswick for sixteen months. She was a native of Detroit.
The Dartmouth football squad swung back into action today after yesterday's lay-off and serious. defensive work predominated as Coach Earl Blaik started preparations for Yale.

Lyle Talbot played a real hero's role today which may blight his screen career. His hands, neck, arms and head were burned so severely in a $50,000 fire that destroyed his home he may never appear again before a camera. He dragged his house guest, Franklin D. Parker, also an actor, from a fiery, smoke-filled bedroom to safety on a second-story ledge.

Extension of-physical examination to all pupils in the New York City school system is recommended by Charles Degan, assistant director of health education, in his annual report, issued yesterday, on-health activities in the vocational high schools.
Domestic wheat markets showed today considerable resistance to selling pressure and weakness in Liverpool and Winnipeg.

The newly developed radiotype machine of the International Business Machines Corporation was used yesterday to record automatically the speeches at The Herald Tribune Forum as they were broadcast over an NBC coast- to- coast network.
When the voter goes to the polls on Nov. 8 he will be asked to vote yes or no on nine amendments to the State Constitution. Eight of these amendments are relatively simple.

The Fifteenth Brigade started its last long trek homeward this morning when the Americans, Canadians and British entrained for their final ceremony as soldiers of the army of the Ebro. This evening they were en route to a town near the border, whence they will pass through Puigcerda into France.

Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, revealed in an address here tonight that the Federal Administration plans to "take the next steps soon in a national health program"

The necessity for success in the United Hospitals'drive was stressed yesterday by speakers before 1,100 persons attending the opening of the Brooklyn appeal for the United Hospitals Fund and the borough's Visiting Nurse Association at a luncheon at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

Miss Sylvia Curtis White heads a group of debutantes who will sell souvenir programs tonight in the lobby of the Metropolitan Opera House where the performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo has been taken over to raise funds for the educational department of New York Women's Trade Union League.

The trustees of the Western Pacific Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a $10,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The loan would bear 4 per cent interest and would be secured by trustees' certificates.

What may be the long-sought answer to New York City's parking and parking-lot problems, a rooftop "parking, station" with stores beneath it, will be opened tomorrow in the theatre district at Sevenh Avenue and Fifty-third Street.
The Council of Defense has decided to order construction of the nucleus of an Egyptian fleet of thirty-six units.
Greenwich Village, the Times Square district, Harlem and Washington Heights were represented in the sales of Manhattan realty announced by brokers yesterday.

On the arrival of the Ruthenian and Slovak Ministers, whom Premier Jan Syrovy of Czechoslovakia summoned to consider the new Hungarian demands, a Cabinet council was held, which lasted the greater part of this afternoon.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by Examiner R. H. Jewell to approve a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad which would reduce capitalization of the company from $671,205,664 to $553,898,000, and to find that the equity of the Missouri Pacific's common and preferred stockholders has no value.
Electoral prospects of Democratic candidates in Pennsylvania were discussed for fifteen minutes today by President Roosevelt and J. David Stern, Philadelphia publisher.
A number of leases for space in buildings in the midtown section marked the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

The Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, dean of Canterbury, married Miss Nowell Mary Edwards yesterday. The bride is the dean's second cousin and since the death of the first Mrs. Johnson in 1931 she often has acted as his hostess.

Madison St. 217, 26.1x100; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 217 Madison St. Realty Corp, 1,154 Manor Ave; p m mtg $18,000 ($18). Carmine St, 30-30 1/2, 25x75; De-Mar Realty Corp to 30 Carmine St. Corp; mtg $11.750 and p m mtg ($8.50).

John Dewey's protest against militarism taught in the schools, as reported in this newspaper yesterday, should be checked by another item in the same issue. This was an A. P. dispatch from Washington about a list of 100 books just issued by the Secretary of the Navy for the guidance of young naval officers in their required reading.

Japan's capital tonight received the announcement of the fall of Hankow without excitement. Japanese leaders indicated that a huge lantern parade would be organized tomorrow to celebrate the victory, but there was no evidence that the celebration would be spontaneous.

Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, will be the principal speaker at the beefsteak dinner of real estate clubs of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish charities tomorrow night in the Hotel Astor.

The first voters' division of John Lord O'Brian's campaign for United States Senator was started yesterday afternoon with a reception at the Hotel Roosevelt. Alfred M. Lillenthal, president of the group, presided.

The New Haven Lawn Club will be the setting for two debutante parties on Friday. That night Colonel and Mrs. Edwy L. Taylor will give a reception and dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Helen Angeline Taylor.
