The younger generation will be scrutinized by two studios. On Monday Universal will launch "Swing, Sister Swing," based on the jitterbug craze, with Frank Jenks, Dorothea Kent, Ernest Truex, Johnny Downs and Ted Weems and his band.
The address delivered by Governor Lehman tonight at a campaign rally in Utica was as follows:
Charles S. Horwood, 72 years old, president of Horwood Co., manufacturers of children's underwear here, attempted suicide in the stockroom of his plant at 1,007 Grand
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold by allotment yesterday $30,000,000 of New York City special revenue bills to twenty-six banks and trust companies at an interest irate of 0.40 per cent.

MANHATTAN AZUZ, MAX (March 5, 1938). Gross assets, $13,901; net, $12,724. To Dora Azuz, widow, $5,000 and one-half residue; Anna Azuz, mother, one-half residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $12,901. Schimer Schimer, attorneys. 25 Ave. A.
Fordham's Rams were running through signals up on Rose Hill yesterday afternoon in preparation for Saturday when they have a little date with Pitt's Panthers out in Pittsburgh.
National defense is the most important topic in the Administration agenda just now,President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference today.

Thomas E. Dewey will do better in Erie County than did William F. Bleakley, the last Republican Gubernatorial nominee, it is contended here by Republican leaders and other observers as well. They predict for Mr.

UP in the Sikorsky plant in Connecticut they are planning an airplane to carry 100 passengers and a crew of sixteen. It will have a flying range of 5,000 miles, a speed of 200 miles an hour, a wing span of over 200 feet and a brake horsepower of at least 10,000.

Pedro Aguirre Cerda, candidate of the Popular Front, was elected President of Chile today, receiving 212,000 votes. while Gustavo Ross, the Rightist candidate, obtained 199,000, it was officially announced tonight.
The city moved yesterday to make the property holders who will benefit by the removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line pay one-third of the cost of the improvement.

Tony Chizmadia of Perth Amboy, who has been a substitute blocking back on the Penn varsity squad, -was shifted to a guard position today. The 215-pounder was regular fullback on the freshman team last year.

Rev. Herbert John Lane, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Long Branch, N. J., for the last eighteen years, died Monday night in PostGraduate Hospital here after a month's illness at the age of 58. He had been in failing health for a year.

Term loans offer a "significant avenue for expansion of the earning assets of American banks,"according to the conclusions reached in a study issued yesterday by the Association of Reserve City Bankers. The study, prepared by the Institute of International Finance of New York University, is called "Term Loans by Commrcial Banks."
The government has issued a decree under which non-resident foreigners in future will pay the same inheritance tax as Peruvians on property inherited in this country.

Seven capable post and rail jumpers have been named to start in the Mount Defiance Cup event which will feature the opening of the annual two-day Essex Fox Hounds Hunts meeting on the Froh-Heim estate of E. B. Schley tomorrow afternoon. The meeting will be concluded on Saturday.
The American way of doing things makes any improvement in the economic and social conditions of the country a long and tedious process, President Roosevelt remarked today at his press conference.

Mayor La Guardia received a 500pound dressed hog at City Hall yesterday in payment of a bet made with Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago on whether the Yankees or the Chicago Cubs would win the recent World's Series baseball championship.

Hog prices continued to advance today, but lambs turned downward and cattle weakened. Lambs reacted from the highest price mark since Aug. 2. The extreme top on hogs was $8.20, paid for short loads, according to the United States Department of Agriculture report.
The sweeping investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn got under way in earnest yesterday when John Harlan Amen, the newly appointed special prosecutor,
Three new six-story apartment house projects were listed among the new building plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

Although somewhat disheartened as a result of last Sunday's game with the Giants, Potsy Clark, coach of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers, is looking forward to Sunday's encounter with the Washington Redskins at Ebbets Field with considerable optimism.
The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against Corn Products Refining Company and Corn Products Sales Company, Inc., of 17 Battery Place. New York,

ALONE, by Richard E. Byrd. (Putnam, $2.50.) The story of Byrd's five months' isolation at Advance Base in Little America. THE BAKER'S DAUGHTER, by D. E. Stevenson. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) A romantic novel with a Scottish setting.

Alfred E. Wheeler of Floral Park, Queens, president of W. E. Marshall Co., seed merchants of 150 West Twenty-third Street, Manhatton, died Tuesday night of heart disease in the Jamaica Hospital. He was born in Worcester, England, sixty-five years ago.

Lieutenant Benjamin S. Kelsey flew a new army pursuit plane from Dayton, Ohio,. to the Buffalo airport today at an average speed of 350 miles per hour, which he said was a record for an Army Air Corps ship.

Chinese officials announced today in Chungking, their new capital, 750 miles from the mouth of the Yangtze River, that they would not surrender and would not accept mediation because 3,000,000 troops were still available for fighting the Japanese invaders.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 24: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Manley, F. J., the Portland; to Naval Hospital, San Dlego. Calif.

When the House of Representatives met yesterday afternoon, the leader of the Labor Opposition, John Curtin, submitted a motion declaring that "by its lamentable lack of leadership regarding urgent national problems the government has forfeited the confidence of this House."

TO hear the breathless scouts coming back from outlying trails, the Indian peril is twofold. The Dartmouth Indians are preparing to descend upon the old New England town of New Haven and the "Washing Done" Redskins, sponsored by that luxurious laundryman, the immaculate Marshall, are getting ready to attack those Autumn inhabitants of Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, the football Dodgers.
President Roosevelt today extended by forty-eight hours the time for his fact-finding board to report on the railroad labor wage dispute.

A letter sent last Monday to Governor Lehman by a Federal grand jury recommending an investigation of the city of Newburgh, where a ring of moonshiners is said to have maintained headquarters, was made public yesterday by Colonel Foulke 0. E. Knudson, foreman of the Federal body.

Leonard St, 52; Fifty-two Leonard Street Corp to Helen Linkraum, 403 Prospect Ave, Hackensack, N. J. ($18). 3d Ave, 297; 297 Third Avenue Realty Corp to Kashar Realty Corp, 31 Union Sq; mtg $22.500 (50 cents). 3d Ave, 502; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co to Brewis Realty Corp, 8 W 40th St. ($30).
The indications are for partly cloudy and slightly colder weather today and fair weather tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

Changes in industrial insurance practice to offset present defects and make this form of protection for workers cheaper and more elastie were recommended in a report by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, issued yesterday.

A new type of fluorescent lamp, which may be screwed into the ordinary. type of electric socket and for which is claimed a saving of 80 per cent in current costs, will be placed on the market within a month or two by the Duro-Test. Corporation, North Bergen, N. J., Maxwell M. Bilofsky, president, announced yesterday.

Both democracy and the system of free capital have been placed definitely on the defensive by the growing trend toward centralization of government and State capitalism, Francis E. Frothingham of Boston, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, told about 700 investment bankers assembled here today for the twenty-seventh annual convention nf the association.

Trading continued slow on veal and calf, fair to slow on beef and lamb, and good on pork in local markets yesterday. Pork loins were higher, calf hindsaddles weak to lower, other classes mostly steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Leonard J. Reid, financial editor of The Daily Telegraph and Morning Post of London, died on Tuesday night of pneumonia in Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.

Plans for improving a corner in downtown Manhattan were announced yesterday when an investor bought from the Phelps estate a plot 44 by 50 feet at 166-167 West Street and 112 Murray Street, the southeast corner. The proposed improvements include a gasoline station, parking lot and lunch wagon.
Defense against Dartmouth plays as reported by Eli football scouts occupied more than an hour of today's scrimmage at Yale, in which open tackling and scoring runs were barred.

Sure Off and Count Arthur scored at Empire City yesterday, giving two Western owners the principal prizes as the New York season drew within three days of its close. Warren Wright owns Sure Off, who carried the Calumet Farm colors to victory in the Nichavo Purse, and John D. Hertz, leader at Arlington Park in Chicago, where Mr. Wright is his colleague, is the owner of Count Arthur, the surprise winner of the Arcturus Handicap.

A lively meeting of the autonomous Diet in Memel, which has a large German majority, was held tonight while Nazi crowds demonstrated outside the chamber despite the fact that the Lithuanian Governor of Memel today handed over to the Germans fresh conciliatory proposals regarding the disputed security bill and his vetoes on legislation passed by the Memel Diet.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 12, reporting on the hearings before the Railroad Fact Finding Board, quotes my friend W. Jett Lauck, economic st of the railroad unions, as saying that,

Improvement in retailer reorders for Fall apparel and accessories thus far this week has been below expectations. Although store stocks are admittedly low, most stores are still waiting for the first real spurt of consumer seasonal demand before increasing commitments.
Roger Graham, a song writer of the "blues" era who composed the lyric for "I Ain't Got Nobody," died yesterday in the Cook County Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 53 years old.
Denial that the market break in the Autumn of 1937 was caused by bear raiding will be contained in the report of the special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc., on short selling.
For the first time as head man, Elton (Tad) Wieman is tuning up the Princeton varsity to march on Harvard, and, mirabile dictu, he is serene and relaxed and enjoying three hearty meals a day.

The most noteworthy feature of the State campaign thus far has been the absence of any sustained attack by the Republican party on the great mass of legislation enacted at Albany during Governor Lehman's six years in office.

It seems a fairly safe prediction that today's Federal Reserve reports will disclose excess reserves of all member banks at a record high.. The old record was $3,304,000.000, established on Dec. 11 1935.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Blight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Howard Blight, to Charles Wesley Michaels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Michaels of New York, took place here this evening at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Dana Street, pastor of the Ridgeview Congregational Church.

The Fortune survey of public opinion announced yesterday that President Roosevelt had not succeeded in selling the New Deal's economic and political ideas to the American people, despite his personal popularity.

There were no traces of optimism in the vicinity of Ohio Field yesterday. "Can you blame us?" asked Coach Mal Stevens, New York University's head football mentor, as he pointed out that Colgate and Fordham are also on the Violet schedule, not to mention Ohio State on Saturday at the Polo Grounds.

Because of a limited quota, Gabriel Bahdo, a Turk, had to wait seventeen years before he could be admitted to the United States legally, but when he arrived here last July with his wife and two children, and with a proper passport, he was taken to Ellis Island and held for deportation.

Exhibits of "artistic confectionery" as well as selected products of French cuisine received the commendation of the French Government and prominent officials here yesterday at the seventieth Salon of Culinary Art held in conjunction with the twenty-third National Hotel Exposition, in session at the Grand Central Palace.

Recommendations for broad liberalization of associate memberships in the New York Curb Exchange were made yesterday to the board of governors of that body. The report, submitted by a special committee appointed by the board on June 7, will be discussed by the governors at a meeting next week and, if approved, will be sent to the members in the form of a constitutional amendment for their approval or rejection.
Business on the stock market remained slack today and prices eased in the absence of buyers. Gilt-edged securities recovered after small declines early in the session.

Reaffirming its stand against the Patman Anti-Chain Bill, the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at a meeting here yesterday, declared the measure, if enacted, "would represent a prostitution of the taxing system of the United States for the purpose of destroying an important segment of American business."

A new industry, Raylaine Worsted, Inc., was organized here today for the manufacture of woolen and rayon products. 'The new concern has leased 30,000 square feet of space in No. 10 Mill of the former Amoskeag Manufacturing Company.

William Allen White called on New Jersey residents today to "destroy the menace of Hague and all his works" by electing W. Warren Barbour, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, who is being opposed by William H. J. Ely, the Democratic and Hague candidate.

Marisa Morel, Italian lyric soprano, arrived yesterday from Naples on the Italian liner Rex. She will make her debut at the Metropolitan Opera House this Winter. The singer made a concert tour here last Year.

Characterizing James "Jeff" Burkitt as a "paid agent of the Communists and Reds, whose sole purpose is to create riot and disorder and to disturb the peace of our city," Director of Safety Daniel Casey of this city denied today a speaking permit for an open-air meeting to the anti-Hague crusader.

George Fleming, chauffeur for Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Townsend Jr. of Syossett, L. I., who disappeared Tuesday with $120,000 worth of their gems, was picked up here shortly before 2 o'clock this morning and held for questioning in the East Fifty-first Street station where, the police said, he confessed taking the jewelry to meet payments to his wife, from whom he is separated.

William Wellman's "Men With Wings," new at the Paramount, is an unmistakably sincere attempt to dramatize the history of aviation from its Kitty Hawk days to the present. Mr. Wellman knows his subject.

The Italian section of the International Workers Order, in a statement issued yesterday, described the Italian Government's new "Aryan" theory as "non-Italian," as putting the government of Rome at the service of Chancellor Hitler, and as trying to divert with a campaign of anti-Semitism the discontent of the Italian people.

For the first time since he assumed directorship of the National Broadcasting Company's Symphony Orchestra, Arturo Toscanini will perform the music of an American composer at one of the weekly broadcasts. On Saturday evening, Nov. 5, he will conduct the world premiere performances of the "Adagio for Strings" and "Essay for Orchestra" by the 28-year-old composer, Samuel Barber.

Julian W. Curtiss, referee of the Poughkeepsie regatta for many years, was honored by the stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association at a testimonial dinner at the Columbia University Club last night.

As a result of a disagreement over casting, Ruby Keeler today ended her contract with RKO. The former Warners star was committed to one more picture at RKO, having appeared in the recent "Mother Carey's Chickens." When she was assigned to a part secondary to that of Lucille Ball in "Beauty for the Asking." she rebelled.
The quartet that probably will compose the Rutgers starting backfield against Lehigh Saturday showed to good advantage today as the first and second teams engaged in a spirited half-hour scrimmage.

After visiting the rural areas of Northern New York, the Republican caravan turned today to the industrial section in Schenectady, where Edward F. Corsi, candidate for the short term in the United States Senate, presented his program of unemployment insurance and attacked Senator Wagner's claims.

An unusual series of triumphs by foreign-bred horses on English turf was capped today when the French-bred 3-year-old, Contrevent, owned by Princesse de FaueignyLucinge, captured the 100th running of the Cesarewitch Stakes.

Less than. twenty-four hours after bench warrants had been issued for their arrest, after indictment on Wednesday by the Queens County grand jury on conspiracy charges, twenty-two lathing contractors and officials of a lathers' union were arrested yesterday by detectives. Six others under indictment are still at large.

Alexander Antonovitch Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, has requested his home government to withdraw him from his American post and station him closer to Moscow, it was learned today.
Filling an eight-month vacancy at its regular meeting yesterday, the Board of Education elected Miss Regina C. M. Burke, assistant superintendent of schools, as an associate superintendent.

Pressure by killers forced prices of strictly good and choice steers, except prime weighty bullocks e downward today, erasing advances scored earlier in the week, the United States Deapartment of Agriculture reports. The hog market opened briskly, but lost ground on the upturn, early top was $8.25 and later $8.05. Lambs worked 25c lower, top falling to $8.75.

Tex Austin, Santa Fe restaurant proprietor, rancher and one-time promoter of rodeos in New York and London, was found dead in his car in his garage here today. Dr. E. W. Fiske reported death was due to carbon monoxide poisoning.

The Federal Reserve Board said today in its summary of business conditions that the volume of industrial production increased further in September to 90 per cent of the 1923-25 average on its seasonally adjusted index, the highest level since October, 1937, when the index reached 102 per cent.

The first twenty-six railroads to report for September showed an aggregate net operating income of 8.3 per cent below the total for September, 1937. The results of this group, with percentage of changes shown and last three figures omitted, are indicated in the following table:

3d Ave, 592, 25.3x100; Brewis Realty Corp to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co; p m. 7 yrs, 4 per cent; $25.000. 15th St, 406 E, 25x103.3; Maybrown Estates, Inc, to Minnle Moscowitz, 878 West End Ave, prior mtg, $33,769, 1 yr, 6 per cent: $2.000.

The dollar value of sales on national securities exchanges in September amounted to $1,054,263,797, a decrease of 4.6 per cent from August and 40.1 per cent less than in September, 1937, when a severe decline occurred in security values on the exchanges, accompanied by unusual trading activity.

In reply today to criticism by Representative Dies of the government's brief in the Julius Strecker deportation case, on which it is waiting a Supreme Court decision before proceeding with deportation action against Harry Bridges, Robert H.
A hint that the people of Bermuda are living beyond their resources was contained in the speech of Governor General Sir Reginald Hildyard convening Parliament for its 1938-39 session.

The General American Transportation Company's request to withdraw its $5-par common stock from listing and registration on the Chicago Board of Trade has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mobilization of the uniformed Park Department employes yesterday morning on the sheep meadow of Central Park made an impressive array as 3,000 men and women reported for the annual inspection by Mayor La Guardia. He marched two miles back and forth along the flag-marked ranks, accompanied by Allyn R. Jennings, general superintendent.
Miss Margaretta van Rensselaer Schuyler has been named acting manager of the retail furniture department of W. J. Sloane. Louis Gorglione nas been named manager of the retail fabric department.
Following is the text of the address at a campaign rally here tonight by Governor Lehman: "The common good and prosperity of the people of the State are dependent upon the prosperity of the farmer."

One of the larger apartment leases listed in brokers' reports yesterday was made with Mrs. Marjorie Harlow Dane, who took a thirteen-room furnished suite in the cooperative building at 1,040 Park Avenue, through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers.

The following film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and less by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools:

The one-story business building at 9-15 Manufacturers Place, Newark, N. J., has been sold by the Rahr Realty Company to the Lane Corporation, through Leo Flaster, broker. The structure covers the greater part of a plot 100 by 100 feet. It is said to be tenanted under a long-term lease by a food distributor.

James F. Reilly, executive secretary of the League of New York Theatres, announced yesterday that the new ticket code, designed to eliminate speculation, was 75 per cent successful. He flatly denied reports that the code "may be abandoned." The code has been in effect for nearly eight weeks.

The Real Estate Board of New York announced yesterday its approval of proposed Amendment 1 to the State Constitution, the omnibus proposal, and disapproval of Amendment 4, the housing amendment, and Amendment 9, the transit amendment.

The rate of steel ingot production advanced this week 3 points to 54 per cent of capacity, which is possibly the first indication of a furtheir rise to result from substantial bookings of sheets and strip, The Iron Age says.

Well after the darkness of an Autumn day had fallen over the stretch above the river where Columbia University's major sport teams practice and play, the eleven which on Saturday will be host to the big Cornell outfit was engaging last night in what was planned as the last really hard work for the game.

Before a wildly cheering audience of 10,000 persons in the Fair Grounds here tonight, Thomas E. Dewey taunted Governor Herbert H. Lehman with failure to answer his speech in Suffolk County last week on the budgetary practices of the State, except by charging "vilification."

A newspaper report here that Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, had been officially invited to Washington for the Armistice Day parade aroused intense interest in view of Cuba's financial crisis and reports that attempts are being made to obtain the assistance of the United States Government in establishing a national bank of issue and a currency system.

The Czech Government agreed today to submit the Hungarian minority problem to German and Italian arbitration, according to a communique that gave the details of Prague's answer to Budapest's last note.

John Lord O'Brian, Republican opponent of Senator Robert F. Wagner, offered yesterday a categorical retort to the Democratic legislator's reply to six questions, put by THE NEW YORK TIMES, before one of the largest crowds to attend the campaign tea series at the Women's National Republican Club.

A heckler's demand that Mayor La Guardia endorse the candidacies of Governor Lehman and Charles Poletti created a brief but noisy uproar last night at a political rally in the New Utrecht High School, Seventy-ninth Street and Sixteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, with the Mayor denouncing the man as a "bum" and the audience booing as the man, who was unidentified, was escorted out of the building.

Commission houses with connections in the East and Southwest which were aggressive buyers of wheat futures recently were free sellers today. Prices T declined about 1 cent a bushel at the extreme under pressure of the sales. Other commission houses were buyers around 67 cents a bushel for the May, which checked the decline.

Dr. Wesley Sturges, executive director of the Distilled Spirits Institute, possibly referring to the severe criticism of liquor advertising made here yesterday by Gene Tunney, chairman of the American Distilling Company, today answered "unfounded" criticism of the industry by quoting the biblical words:

Mrs. Louise Blagden Lord, daughter of Mrs. George Wrenn of this city and Southampton, and of Wendell Phillips Blagden, was married to Robert E. Banks Jr. yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

Mrs. Mary Ray, wife of the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Church of the Transfiguration in New York, better known as the Little Church Around the Corner, died in their country home here today of a heart ailment. She was 48 years old.

Although not expected to show much activity in the trading mart this'Winter, the Yankees, in a surprise move yesterday, actually became involved in the first major baseball transaction of the off-season with the announcement by Business Manager Ed Barrow that the world champions had completed a four-player deal with the Browns.

Harvey E. Eaton of Teaneck, N. J., died Tuesday night in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after an intermittent illness of three years. He was born in Juniata County. Pa., fifty-three years ago.
Several communications tending to minimize reports of large numbers of employes laid off as a result of the operation of the Wages and Hours Law were received by Administrator Elmer F. Andrews today.

A first mortgage of $465,000, with interest at 41/2 per cent for five years has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., with the Equitable Life Assurance Society for the Dillerwood Realty Company, Inc., on the recently completed nine-story apartment house on the northeast corner of the Grand Concourse and 162d Street, the Bronx.

Stocks closed a fraction to 2 points lower despite rally in final hour featuring public utility shares; turnover 1,702,180 shares. United States Government bonds strong, foreign issues mixed, domestic corporation bonds irregular; transactions $8,695,650.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 26, unless specified: Naval Operating Base, Norfolk to Ponta Del Gada: Badger, Jacob Jones. At Miami: Somers, Warrington. Villefranche to Gibraltar: Claxton, Manley.

Despite the efforts of a professional football team and scores of motorists to guide them to a successful landing, two fliers from New York City were fatally injured, in a crack-up at 6:40 P. M. just west of Easton.

Spokesmen of the Federal Government presented an official appeal today to the general meeting of the American Public Health Association to support a newly proposed extension of social security principles which would provide medical care for the public.
The Grand Cross of the Order of Merit was bestowed on Andre Francois-Poncet, the retiring French Ambassador, by Chancellor Adolf Hitler today.

The fortieth anniversary of the Moscow Art Theatre's first production was celebrated here tonight in a gala performformance of "Tsar Fyodor," with which the then new theatre--since become world famous--won instant success on Oct. 27, 1898.

The Electric Power Associates dedared yesterday a dividend payable with about 200,000 shares of the common stock of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc. The distribution will amount to one-fourth share of American Water Works for each common and Class A share of Electric Power Associates outstanding.
Bernard J. Kelly, 43 years old, acting superintendent of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, was crushed to death in the building at 6:20 P. M. yesterday by a falling five-ton metal door.

Organized Endicott business men issued a formal public letter today to the 20,000 employes of the Endicott Johnson Shoe Corporation and 4,500 employes of the International Business Machines Corporation urging them against unionization.

Catherine St (17-5066), w s, 175 ft s of 239th St, 25x100; Albina Vignali to Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, 164 Bush St; installments, 5 per cent; $10,750. Clinton Ave, 1,323 (11-2933); Rose Deninno to Tommaso Massucci, 134 White St; extends mtg to June 19, 1943, at 5 per cent; $10,000.

The most important military problem in the North Baltic, the projected fortification of the Aland Archipelago between Finland and Sweden, which has been the subject of exceptionally lively discussions in all the countries bordering on the Baltic, is now expected to enter a decisive stage.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Everett Rich of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Louise Rich, to Charles D. Donohue, son of Mrs. Frances Donohue of Hartsdale. N. Y.
Registration figures in New York show two women to three men. This is the ratio which has long held for women at the polls.

Roy Greene, consulting electrical enginever of 114 1/2 Earl Street, Pittsburgh, who claims he was acting for the Federal Government and with the consent of President Roosevelt when he asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to organize and operate an interurban, high-speed railroad over the old South Penn Railroad right-of-way from Pittsburgh to Harrisburg, today charged Division 4 of the Interstate Commerce Commission with "conspiracy and fraud."

AT last, four years after the event, Admiral Byrd has written his story of one of the most curious adventures of our time.* In March, 1934, shortly before the long Antarctic night set in, he went down from his expedition headquarters at Little America to a tiny hut sunk in the snow and ice of the Ross Barrier.
Capitalizing on a Chicago fumble the Eagles shoved over a touchdown early in the second period tonight to beat the Cardinals, 7 to 0, in a National Football League game.

Of the total of $55,580,000 for which construction contracts were awarded in Manhattan for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 70 per cent, or $38,957,000, was for work financed privately, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
The twelfth annual Cancer Week fund-raising campaign of the New York Cancer Committee was opened yesterday. Booths were set up in railroad terminals and other points in the city.

Tonight's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Clara Rockmore, thereminist, Town Hall, 8:45; Greenwich Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45; Florence Foster Jenkins, soprano, RitzCarlton ballroom, 8:30.

The election of Pedro Aguirre Cerda, Leftist candidate for the Presidency, indicated by partial returns yesterday, was confirmed today. With almost all returns in, he had obtained 220,892 votes against 213,521 for the Rightist candidate, Finance Minister Gustavo Ross.
The Empire Trust Company has been appointed registrar of the preferred and common stocks of the S. E. Hyman Company.
The Palestine Government announced today that the quota for immigration into Palestine had been reduced to 4,870 for-the next six-month period, which is 1,230 less than for the previous six months.

The police yesterday captured John Hughes, who escaped last Sunday from the Hudson River State Hospital, in a drug store at Fiftyfifth Street and Seventh Avenue. With him at the time, the police said, were his mother, Mrs. Mary Hughes, and two friends.

The declaration that Japan cannot admit the inviolability of third powers' property and is not responsible for any damages inflicted thereon "during actual fighting" in China was made by a Japanese Embassy spokesman this evening.

Earl and Countess Beatty, who arrived on the Ile de France, are at the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. F. de Peyster Townsend are expected to arrive today from Hot Springs, Va. They will be at the Chatham.

Sym bolizing the friendship between French and American World War veterans, French veterans today dispatched a five-foot bronze torch aboard the liner Paris for the United States, where it will be lit by American veterans and returned to France in time to be carried to the annual armistice ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier beneath the Arc de Triomphe.
Millions of Americans suspect a plot "on the part of the Fascist dictators and the Tories of England to sell Spain to fascism," Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan said last night.

Compositions by Charles Haubiel and Lazare Saminsky were performed at the second session of the new season of the WPA Composers' Forum-Laboratory held last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall before an enthusiastic capacity audience.

The appearances of noted artists as soloists and the performances of several works will be features of the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts during November. The concerts of Nov. 16 and 18 will present Jascha Heifetz as soloist in the Tchaikovsky violin concerto, and the first American performances of the Arnold Bax Fourth symphony.

A special Fall appeal for $25,000 was announced yesterday by the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. The appeal was made, the announcement said, "to enable the continuance of its many services to the blind of all ages in New York City."

William F. Burrough, justice of the Union County (N. J.) Court until his retirement six years ago, died in his home here today. Born in New York, he attended Manhattan College and the Catholic University in Washington.
Head Coach Benny Friedman yesterday conceded his City College football team a good chance of overcoming Lowell Textile's undefeated eleven when the Weavers invade Lewisohn Stadium Saturday.

Food exports from the United States during the first nine months of this year were virtually double those exported in the corresponding period in 1937, when measured in terms of value, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Now that it can be told the Supreme German Army Commana revealed today the extent of the military preparations that enabled Chancellor Hitler to conquer the Sudetenland and with it complete Greater Germany without firing a shot at the same time keeping all other powers in check.

Pravda and Izvestia, organs of the Communist party and the government, today printed a long list of Soviet fighters decorated for distinguished service in the "defeat" of the Japanese at Changkufeng last July and August.

It appears the British military authorities are earnestly endeavoring to efface Arab terrorism from every nook and corner of Palestine. Having begun with a siege of the Old City in Jerusalem, which they occupied and searched thoroughly last week, they are now satisfied that that area is cleared of rebels.

The belief that "peace can be attained only by non-aggression, and can be made enduring only by respect for the rights of others and good-will among the nations of the world," was voiced by President Roosevelt today in a proclamation calling for observance of Armistice Day on Nov. 11.

As the drive of the Markets Department against short measure beer barrels widened yesterday, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. said that thirty-one short-measure barrels had been found in seventy-five establishments.

Mrs. Vincent Astor gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 130 East Eightieth Street, for her niece, Miss Peggy Marshall, and for Miss Elizabeth Irion. Miss Marshall is chairman of the junior committee for the Ice Follies, to be held at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 29 for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, and Miss Irion is chairman of the debutante committee.
W. O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a letter sent to J. Fred Brown of Boettcher Co., investment banking firm of Denver, Col.,

A forward pass from Gould to Hallowell, which grew out of a fake end run on the 2-yard line, enabled the Andover eleven to tie the Bowdoin freshmen, 14-14, in the final minutes of their football game today, with Whalen kicking the tying point.
Coach Lou Oshins put the Brooklyn College football team through a two-hour scrimmage yesterday afternoon in preparation for the Kingsmen's game with American International College Saturday.

Planning all sorts of surprises for the Redskins when they meet at Ebbets Field on Sunday, Coach Potsy Clark sent the Dodgers through a vigorous workout at the Municipal Stadium today, the two-hour drill being veiled in secrecy.

The marriage of Miss Mary Grace Wren, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alphonse A. Wren of 800 West End Avenue, to Edward Francis Ricca, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo F. Ricca of 1,230 Park Avenue, took place yesterday noon in the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Joseph H. McMahon. White chrysanthemums and red oak leaves were used in the decorations.
A three-day convention of New York State architects, under the sponsorship .of the New York State Association of Architects, will begin today in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The second annual merged appeal of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, benfiting 116 health and welfare institutions, was started by the Brooklyn division last night with a dinner at the Unity -Club, Bedford Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn.

The old dowager queen of the North Atlantic, Captain Angus Walters's big salt banker Bluenose, retained her crown today by a narrow margin when she defeated the American challenger for the International Fishermen's Trophy, the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud.
Britain's Cabinet decided yesterday to submit the Anglo-Itallan agreement to Parliament for ratification in mid-November as a result of Italian withdrawals of troops from Spain.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $606,908 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, interest and other charges.

After about six hours of running which started at 7:30 o'clock this morning, the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels was decided with the announcement that the winner was the black and white dog Finglen Johnnie of Strawberry Hill.

There are many reports of persecution of Jews and Czechs in German-occupied areas in Zatec, where many Czechs and German democrats were arrested and illtreated. Most of the Czech-owned End Jewish-owned shops have been closed.

Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday net income of $1,887,747 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, after Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges, but before profit and loss Items. The result is equal, after dividend requirements on $4.50 preferred stock, to 13 cents a share on 12,648,108 common shares.
The directors of the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad announced yesterday at a meeting the outlines of a plan for its amalgamation with the Mobile Ohio Railroad, a subsidiary of the Southern Railway.

The navy will play host to the nation today in what is expected to be the most widespread observance of Navy Day in the seventeen years since the Navy League of the United States first set aside the anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt as the annual day for honoring the navy.

In this Autumn of the sixth year of the New Deal, Democratic members of Congress are engaged upon two enterprises which, more than anything that has happened in Congress itself, testify to that body's rising independence of the Executive and the national political organization.

A syndicate headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and including Bacon, Stevenson Co., Jaxtheimer Co., Grande Co., Inc.; Wheelock Cummins, Inc., and William P. Harper Son Company, Inc., is offering at 101 1/2 and accrued interest a new issue of $760,000 City of Tacoma, Wash., 2.80 per cent water revenue bonds of 1938, due Jan. 1 and July 1, 1951 to 1955. inclusive.

Six bus companies operating between New Jersey and Manhattan filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission today objecting to an application by the trustee of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad for authority to operate a bus service from its North Bergen station to mid-town New York by way of the Lincoln Tunnel.

The government's weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday as follows: There were some unimportant interruptions by rain to cotton picking in Tennessee and the northeastern portion of the belt but elsewhere picking and ginning made splendid progress, with good weather prevailing.

For mid-week performance, the Second Avenue Theatre last night presented a new play, in which a new actress makes her American debut. The play, the late L. Malach's "With Open Eyes," is superior to the run of Second Avenue scripts only because it is a little different in dealing with the familiar triangle of boss, designing designer and wife.

For the first time in the eighty-two years of the existence of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, its directors today elected a woman to high executive office. Mrs. Edith Jarvis Alden of Berwyn, Ill., was made secretary, succeeding Charles J. Sturgis, who retires at 78, after fifty-eight years of service with the company.

The development of a comprehensive program of preventive medicine, made possible by an $84,000 grant from the Commonwealth Fund, was announced yesterday by Dr. Currier McEwer, dean of the New York University College of Medicine.

Manhattan Alterations Stanton, St, 290; to 6-story tenement and stores; Berglin Realty Corp, 202 Broome St, owner; H. Wolff, architect; cost, $5.000. 92D ST, 310 W; to 4-story tenement; Birch Realty Corp, 315 W 107th St, owner; Charles N. and Selig Whinston, architects; cost, $12,000.

Leaders of veterans' organizations in Manhattan and the Bronx are actively supporting Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross, the American Labor and Progressive party candidate for Supreme Court Justice, Reuben Hecht, chairman of her veterans' committee, announced yesterday. Among those listed by Mr. Hecht as endorsing Mrs. Kross were Frank Bilsky, Manhattan Commander of the Jewish War Veterans: John J. Colman.

About 100 men and women, most of them members of the Newark-Irvington branch of the German-American Bund, were sequestered by the police in Schwaben Hall for almost an hour and a half late last night and early this morning while crowds milled about in the vicinity in a threatening manner.
The Fascist Grand Council acted today to draw what Italians call their "fourth shore" closer by decreeing that the African colony of Libya should be made an integral part of Italy.

Governor Lehman has agreed to transfer radio networks for his final campaign speech at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 5 so that former President Herbert C. Hoover, making a nation-wide broadcast at the same time, will not be deprived of a New York outlet.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George A. Seligmann of 35 West Seventy-fourth Street and Elberon, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Mathilde Seligmann, to Edward Riem Whitehead Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitehead of 730 Park Avenue.

In recognition of a quarter century's service, Bailey B. Burritt and William H. Matthews were honored by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor at a meeting of the board of managers yesterday in the association's office, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The Wages and Hours Law was described last night by Walter H. Liebman, Democratic opponent of Bruce Barton in the Seventeenth Congressional District, as a "direct aid to underpaid wage-earners and to little business, which needs; more than anything else, plenty of customers with a little more money to spend."

The quarterly earnings of the United States Steel Corporation have so long been accepted as reflecting the status of the steel industry and with it the trend of general trade that Tuesday's statement for the third quarter of 1938 will to many readers be disappointing.

Following is the address made by Thomas E. Dewey last night at the Nassau County Fairgrounds, Mineola: For ten days now I have been up and down the State, talking to the people about our State government.

Vinylate, a substance obtained from. natural gas and from byproducts of petroleum: refining, probably will be the basic element in the new fiber to be produced by Celanese Corporation of America at the $10,000,000 plant which that concern plans to build in Virginia, it was reported among chemical producers yesterday.
Ernest A. Barvoets, president of the J. B. Lyon Company, which does most of the State's printing, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

Governor Lehman carried his campaign for re-election into the control zone of the $2,000,000,000 dairy industry of the State tonight with a recital of the agricultural achievements of the Democratic party and a challenge to Republicans to state their program.

Representatives of real estate organizations warned the City Planning Commission yesterday against committing the city to any extensive capital improvements next year, as the commission opened public hearings on the 1939 capital outlay budget.

N. J. Nassoff has resigned as vice president of Brunswick, Praver Nassof, Inc., after an affiliation of about ten years, and plans to go to California for a study of the real estate possibilities in that State The resignation is effective Nov. 1, upon which date the firm name will be changed to Brunswick-Praver Company, Inc.

Near month contracts touched 8 1/2 cents a pound on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday for the first time since Aug. 20. This represented a rise of more than threequarters of a cent from the low of a month ago, When the December sold at 7.73 cents.

A letter protesting the "swinging" of music by Bach and other classical composers on the air waves and advocating stringent penalties for stations that permit it has been sent to the Federal Communications Commission by Alfred L. Dennis, president of the Bach Society of New Jersey, it was announced today.

Investment bankers, who are assembled here for their twenty-seventh annual convention, turned over the greater part of the first session today to a discussion of the problems surrounding the Administration's proposal for legislative elimination of the tax-exempt feature from future issues of Federal, State and municipal bonds.
Ground breaking ceremonies were held yesterday for the widening, extension and improvement of Cross Island Boulevard in Queens, a link in the city's system of new and projected highways.

A dispute in the American Sons of Italy over recent anti-Semitic decrees in Italy was revealed yesterday in a Supreme Court suit brought by Philip Bongiorno, former supreme master of the brganization, to compel its present officers to hold immediately a convention of its New York State lodges.

Tony Canzoneri of Marlboro, N. Y., former featherweight and lightweight champion, won Referee Whitey Healey's decision over Howard Scott of Washington in a close eight-round battle at the reopening of Braddock Arena tonight. Canzoneri weighed 140, Scott 138.

After an ownership of eightyeight years, the Emma L. Johnston estate has sold the last remaining portion of the old Johnston farm, consisting of about 20,000 square feet on the northwest corner of Broadway and Britton Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, to the Broadway Construction Company, Joseph Perlbinder, president.
Miss Ida Van Feddelen, Dutch swimmer, bettered the world record for the 200-meter backstroke for women today by covering the distance in 2 minutes 40.6 seconds in a swimming meet.

The National Labor Relations Board was requested today to certify the American Federation of Office Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, as bargaining agent for business, office employes of Wilkes-Barre's three daily newspapers, instead of the Newspaper Guild of the C.I.O.

The contests for the world's championship title's in the various events at the Madison Square Garden Rodeo, which will end its twenty-four day run on Sunday night, are getting closer and the standing of the leaders is changing each night.
The police arrested Francois Marek, a Polish butler, and six other foreigners today on suspicion of having stolen $60,000 worth of jewelry from Lady Davis, widow of the Canadian tobacco man.
Following is the text of the formal statement in which Chairman Dies (Democrat-Texas) replied today to President Roosevelt's criticism of the House committee investigatinq un-American activities:
Mrs. Anne Colman, artist and musician, died today at her home here, after a long illness. Her age was 49. Mrs. Colman had spent much time abroad studying both music and art.

In a sweeping condemnation of force, exile and repression as instruments of national policy abroad, President Roosevelt, in an address broadcast from the White House last night, warned that the United States was determined to protect the Western Hemisphere from foreign interference.

A group of Flint citizens tonight adopted a resolution criticizing President Roosevelt for his "scathing denunciation of two highly respected citizens and public officials of Flint and one of our Circuit Court judges because of evidence given before the Dies Committee at Washington."
Joseph J. O'Brien of East Rochester, N. Y., Republican candidate for the National House, reported today campaign contributions of $1,000 and expenditures of $1,990.

Warning that anti-Semitism was spreading rapidly and violently in Europe and that "Jews have no other choice than to fight back," Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the administrative committee of the World Jewish Congress, with headquarters in Geneva, outlined yesterday afternoon in an interview at the Hotel Astor the Jewish situation in eight European countries.

The prospect that Argentina may have a favorable trade balance at the end of this year if a good start is made with the new cereal export season was indicated by Dr. Pedro Groppo, Minister of Finance, in a statement on the fiscal affairs of the country made available here through the Argentine Information Bureau.

Three Syracuse teams today took turns viewing the. Penn State attack as shown by a freshman eleven. Preparations for Saturday's game at State College were intensified by Coach Ossie Solem as he ordered a short scrimmage and drilled two combinations on offensive tactics until darkness.
Depicting Egyptian, Arabic and Romanic days "Herod and Mariamne," a play by Clemence Dane adapted from the German classic by Friedrich Hebel, had its premiere in the Nixon Theatre here tonight.
After more than forty years, the Gerry interests have divested themselves of the valuable land at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street, on which the forty-one-story Hotel Pierre stands.

ARTHUR--Oct. 25, 1938, Sarah Tully, widow of Archibald Arthur and mother of Mrs. S. Earle Saylor and Sarah T. Arthur. Services at her residence, 1,217 Ditmas Ave., Brooklyn, Thursday, at 2 P. M. Corning, N. Y. papers please copy.
The Republican State Committee today accused David L. Lawrence, Secretary of the Commonwealth and chairman of the Democratic State Committee, of a deliberate effort to defraud the Republican

J. Nelson Stuart, until recently advertising and sales promotion manager of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Coal Company, has been appointed director of advertising and sales promotion of the Kelvinator division of the NashKelvinator Corporation, Henry W. Burritt, the division's vice president in charge of sales, announced yesterday.
The War Deapartment released the following orders ton day, dated Oct. 25: BRIGADIER GENERAL Gulick, J. W., retired, effective Nov. 30, at age of 64.

The Assizes Court here today sentenced to death Maurice Goldebarrier, 43 years old, a bank cashier and war veteran, who confessed he murdered his wife and adult son "to spare them dishonor when my employers should discover I had embezzled 70,000 francs."

President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell of the Municipal Court and Municipal Court Judge, Benedict D. Dineen were endorsed last night for the State Supreme Court by the Association of Trial Lawyers of the City of New York at a dinner in the Cafe Loyale, at which the two candidates were the chief guests.

Miss Peggy Bates, daughter of Mrs. J. Willard Travell of 12 East Sixty-fourth Street, this city, and Talcott Farms, Westfield, N. J., and of the late Rev. H. Roswell Bates, was married yesterday noon to Stuart Henry van Saun, son of Mrs. Henry H. van Saun of Hackensack, N. J., and the late Mr. van Saun.
Herman ("Doc") Berlin, trainer of athletes, died in Community Hospital in Perrysburg, Ohio, today of injuries suffered in an automobile collision last night. He was 52 years old.

Burke Ave (16-4760), s w cor of Fenton Ave, 30x100; Rebrau Real Estate-Corp to Ashdale Realty Corp, 6-E 45th St. Mosholu Ave (13-3423), n w cor of 256 St. 67x89; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co, trustee, to Julia R. Murray, 5,615 Mosholu Ave.

Marking what is believed to be the first step of its kind, the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., yesterday sent a notification to 600 paid resident and commission fur buyers, requiring them to register with the trade practice bureau of the organization.

William H. J. Ely,Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, told audiences in, Salem County tonight that the record of W. Warren Barbour toward governmental assistance to the destitute and jobless had been based on a "let them eat cake" attitude.

England definitely asserted its superiority at soccer football today by defeating an all-star European team, 3-0. Apart from the opening stages, when the continental players displayed brilliant work, England had a marked edge in all phases of the game.

The personnel of the teams that will represent the New York City Police Department and the New York State Troopers in the military and police jumping' events of the eight-day National Horse Show, which will open at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday, was announced yesterday.

Amid a flood of manifestoes, declarations and printed appeals, about 30,000 voters in the city of Oxford prepared to choose a Member of Parliament tomorrow in the first electoral test of British public opinion since the Munich agreement.

Gerard Swope and Charles R. Hook, two of the country's leading industrialists, attacked compulsory industrial legislation before more than 3,000 men and clubwomen at the eighth annual Forum on Current Problems held by The New York Herald Tribune at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Sleepy Jim Crowley stepped out of the Fordham gymnasium yesterday afternoon and his jaw dropped. He was staring toward the practice field in stunned disbelief. "Can that fellow throw a forward pass?" he asked, "or can he throw a forward pass?"
The seventeenth annual observance today of Navy Day--anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt--has a somber significance in this year of recurring crises and international tension.

District Attorney John T. Delaney said today lie "believed" that the source of information disclosing issuance of a subpoena before it had been served, in connection with a new investigation of developments following the 1933 O'Connell kidnapping, had been "found."

Long Island Sound will be colored next Summer in other hues besides those the Lighthouse Department inaugurated a few years ago when it deviated from the red and white night warnings and adopted green.

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor in the Brooklyn inquiry into official corruption, announced yesterday that he had named as the first appointee to his staff Deacon Murphy, a lawyer who has served in special capacities under several former District Attorneys.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has signed an agreement with the .Association of Western Union Employes guaranteeing compliance with the hours provisions of the Wages and Hours Law and assuring full-time. workers that weekly earnings will remain unchanged despite a cut in hours, the association disclosed yesterday.

" Leave It to Me!" the Vinton Freedley musical reuniting Victor Moore and William Gaxton, will stay in Boston an extra week, so it will be on Nov. 9, instead of Nov. 2, that it opens locally at the Imperial. Although Boston has shown enthusiasm for the show-to the tune of $22,000 gross last week--it was said that the two stars suggested the additional week out of town.

Hamilton Fish Benjamin, senior partner of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Benjamin Ferguson, 61 Broadway, and a former member of the governing committee of the Exchange, died yesterday morning at his country home in Atlantic Beach, L. I., after an illness of four months. He was 61 years old.

Harcourt, Brace report that last week's sales of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "Listen! the Wind" exceeded 20,000 copies, following the advance sale of 75,000. This week, on Monday alone, the firm received orders for 10,000 copies.

Anxiety concerning the fate of the 591 passengers and crew of 390 on board the Hamburg American liner Deutschland, which was on fire Tuesday night 200 miles southeast of Cape Race, Nfld., was completely allayed yesterday morning.

A change regarded as having for its purpose perpetuation of the Smith dynasty in the reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints was announced today by Frederick M. Smith, president and grandson of Joseph Smith, the founder of the Mormon faith.

Postmaster General James A. Farley accused District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday of attempting to mislead voters of the State as to the part he played in driving racketeers out of New York City.

An efficient navy, "adequate in men and material to insure positive protection against any aggressor," ls the kind of navy which President Roosevelt regards as "imperative" in -the present state of world conditions.

Governor Blanton Winship expects Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, in Puerto Rico in a few weeks for his first visit in three years. The Governor made his announcement this afternoon on his return from a month in New York and Washington.

The fact that he cut a flag in his rush around a sharp turn cost Faction Fighter, from the Rokeby Stables of Paul Mellon, an easy victory in the Mount Defiance Cup, which featured the opening of the twentythird annual meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds today over the Froh-Heim estate of E. B. Schley.

Mayor La Guardia expressed criticism yesterday of superannuated school teachers who clung to their positions after their mental and physical powers had waned, and coupled the criticism with a warning that the city might lower the present age limit of 70 unless these teachers resigned voluntarily.
A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that John M. Schiff had been elected a director.

Special Notice Company Commanders, in making out their hydrant, report for November, shall state therein the number of hydrants they reported as in need of repairs in their October report and the number, so reported, that have since been repaired and the number that have not been repaired.

The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee disclosed today that Edward Noel Jones, vice chairman of the Pennsylvania Democratic State Committee, had acknowledged drafting two fund solicitation letters which the committee charged were circulated in Pennsylvania in violation of the law.

Running 10 per cent ahead of Spring attendance figures, the first day of the Jamestown semi-annual furniture market was off today to a start which led Edward.J. McGee, president of the Jamestown Furniture Market Association, to predict "the best market for two years." The market will continue through Nov. 5.

The thirty-fifth annual congress of the Radical Socialist party, led by Premier Edouard Daladier, opened here today prepared to consider a program that it was hoped would result in another of those recovseries that France has staged so often in her history.
Herman Philips's Fair Stein scored by a length and a half today in the $5,000 added New England Handicap at Narragansett Park.

Training in the graces required in royal courts will become a part of the educational program of the Dionne quintuplets, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, their physician and guardian, revealed yesterday while on a business trip to this city. He arrived on an early morning train from Toronto.

The two-price plan for disposing of agricultural surpluses was strongly defended by Lawrence F. Myers, chief of the marketing.division of the Department of Agriculture, at the annual meeting of the CottonTextile Institute, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, at which Dr. Claudius T. -Murchison, president of the institute, supported the plan.

The American Republics Line announced yesterday that it had been decided to shift the freight service of the line to Pier 60, at West Twentieth Street, which has already been designated as the terminal for the three renovated passenger liners assigned to the fleet.

While Japan was impatiently awaiting the complete capture of Hankow yesterday thousands of citizens thronged to the Yasukuni shrine of the Japanese Pantheon. Otherwise there was no outward manifestation of the tension gripping the empire.

Final agreement in the controversy that led to the recent towboat strike was reached yesterday by the joint conference of representatives of the New York Towboat Exchange and Local 333 of the International Longshoremen's Association. The conference met at the office of the exchange, 17 Battery Place.
Every year thousands of novice hunters take to the woods, fields and waterways of this State and a large percentage of this number seem to make their initial efforts on the duck marshes.

An encouraging expansion in the philanthropic activities of the local chapter of the American Red Cross has been going on for the last year with the result that the prospects for "additional dividends of sympathy and security for suffering humanity are exceedingly bright,"

Experiments in which the kidneys and livers of animals- were trained to resist bichloride of mercury, chloroform and alcohol in doses large enough to inflict serious injury, and perhaps death, to animals not so conditioned, were described here today before the closing sessions of the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at the University of North Carolina.

Paced by Harry Wolf, nine times holder of the national championship, the New York A, C. squash tennis team opened its Metropolitan League Class A season yesterday by blanking the Yale Club on the latter's court, 5 to 0.

Chancellor Hitler's visit to Vienna received only brief announcements in the press, but many photographs were published. Official quarters emphatically deny that Herr Hitler saw either Cardinal Innitzer or Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Chancellor of Austria, before he left at 8 o'clock this morning.

Renewals of leases on office and showroom space in buildings in the garment and fur districts featured contracts for business quarters in Manhattan yesterday. Concerns retaining their quarters in 315 West Thirty-sixth Street include the Senate Embroidery Works, Inc.

The Rev. Dr Herbert Hensley Henson, for eight een years Bishop of Durham and one of the most outspoken British churchmen, announced tonight his retirement on the grounds of his "age and length of active service." He will be 75 Nov. 8. He will leave his office Feb. 1.

The State Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered the reinstatement with back pay of nine waiters of the Stork Club, 3 East .Fifty-third Street, in a decision which found that the men had been discharged because of their activities as members of the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organization Committee. The men were discharged in September, 1937.

A proposal for merger of the Chicago North Western Railway Company and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company was submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by two protective committees for shareholders of the lines.

Scholarships and fellowships totaling more than $19,000 have been awarded to forty-nine students in the Columbia University Schools of Engineering, Architecture and Library Service, it was announced yesterday.

The Art Adventure League will open classes for amateurs on Tuesday evening at the organization's headquarters, 55 Fifth Avenue. The program of study includes six branches of the arts and crafts to be conducted under the direction of William Zorach, Ruth Reeves, Nathaniel Pousette-Dart, Lewis Daniel, Berenice Abbott and Donald Baker.

On the largest turnover so far this week and the heaviest since last Friday the bond market moved contrary to the share list yesterday, and while the gains were not large the majority of the groups held firm.
Brown Harriman Co., Inc., announced yesterday that the subscription books have been closed for the $50,000,000 issue of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company 31/2 per cent debentures, due 1948.

Eager to regain its winning stride after tasting the bitter pill of defeat for the first time last week, the Hill School football squad is now drilling diligently in preparation for the traditional contest with Lawrenceville that will be the sports feature of father's week-end here on Saturday.

MANHATTAN CARPENTER, LILLIAN 'TAYLOR (Sept. 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charity Organization,. one-half residue; United Hospital Fund of New York and Henry Street Settlement, one-fourth residue each; St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette, Ind.,

President Roosevelt, in a letter received today by former Mayor J. Hampton Moore, president of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association, emphasized that in the furtherance of a harbor and waterway improve ment program "funds amounting

The possession of a superior voice, which was used with a degree of skill none too common among youthful vocalists of the day, made it possible for Elizabeth Wysor to make an easy conquest of her large audience at Town Hall last night.

The Clyde-Mallory liner Iroquois, which was chartered by Catholics from New York and other seaboard States for a voyage to New Orleans during the sessions of the Eucharistic Congress, returned yesterday, bringing 350 pilgrims, including 72 priests, from New York City.

The two-price system by which the Department of Agriculture hopes to aid in disposing of surpluses is an emergency action without relation to, and not designed in any manner to supplant, the regular agricultural program, Secretary Wallace said today.

KINGS GOLDEN, BERNARD (Feb. 1, 1936). Gross assets, $138,304; net, $73,923. To St. Rose's Free Home for Incurable Cancer and Catholic Center for the Blind, $250 each; nieces, Mary J. McCourt and Margaret McGee, $500 each; wife, Mary A. Golden, life interest in specific realty and life income from one-third of residuary estate; daughters.

Haile'Selassie I, former Emperor of Ethiopia, still has an agent in the United States. A registration -at -the State Department disclosed today that Publicity Associates, 350 Fifth Avenue, New York City, of which Josef Israels 2d is president, acts as Haile Selassie's agent here...
Secretary of Commerce Roper today asked that business try to stabilize its prices to prevent increases which might cripple the recovery evident in many lines.

A demand that the House Investigating Committee recommend the impeachment of Governor Earle unless he gave "a denial and a satisfactory answer" to charges growing out of the Erie gravel scandal was made today by Representative Elwood J. Turner, a Republican member of the committee.

A hearing to determine whether the registration of the Northwestern Investment and Securities Corporation, Milwaukee, should be revoked or suspended, originally scheduled to be held today in the Securities and Exchange Commission's office in Chicago, has been postponed until Nov. 15, the commission announced today.

Following is the text of President , Roosevelt's speech delivered by radio last night to The New York Herald Tribune's forum on current problems: No one who lived through the grave hours of last month can doubt the longing of most of the people of the world for an enduring peace.

Merger of the land line systems of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and the Western Union Telegraph Company would be in the public interest, Frederick Gallup Coburn, a member of the engineering firm of Sanderson Porter, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe at a hearing on the proposed confirmation of a plan of reorganization for Postal and its subsidiary, the Associated Companies.

Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex to close his affairs in Washington before quitting the diplomatic service to enter the insurance business in Trieste. He expects to be here about a month.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to Sept. 30, which is being mailed to shareholders today, shows a net income of $15,445,215 after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.59 a common share, compared with $19,419,397, or $2.05 a common share, in the preceding twelve months.

Whether the projected television sets will contribute the large expenditures to newspaper advertising that radio sets did in their first years is a question which arose this week in newspaper circles, following announcement that television will be 'available early next year.

The story of how an important member of an alleged German spy ring "talked himself out" of trouble after being caught trying to smuggle military and aviation secrets out of the country was told yesterday in Federal court, where three minor figures in the alleged conspiracy are being tried for espionage.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations made public yesterday the answers of 213 candidates for State office, including candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Controller, State Senate and Assembly, to seven questions covering their public education policies.

Prizes in the amateur photographic contest and children's handicraft exhibition sponsored by the Department of Parks were awarded yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of the Park Association of New York, Inc., in Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History.

That the Guggenheim Committee on the Control of Crime is not devoted merely to abstract studies is amply demonstrated in Brooklyn, where its disclosures of corruption forced the investigation now being conducted by Mr. Amen.
The State Appellate Court today reversed the decree giving the former Merry Fahrney of Oak Park a divorce from her third husband, Baron Arturo Berlingieri of Italy.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Towle of Pelham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maude Sanborn Towle, to Daniel Pierson and Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al- city bert S. Johnson of Swarthmore, Pa.
Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 1: PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to Grand Central Parkway Precinct, assigned to motorcycle duty.
Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Speaker in behalf of Edward Corsi, Republican Senatorial candidate, WOV, 3:45 to 4 P. M. (1,130 Kc.)

Sudden collapse of business recovery after a continued resurgence for not more than twelve months was foreseen here today by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, unless. business men demand, that government regulation take "a saner form."

Miss Liberty, proudly looking out upon New York Harbor in her new finery, which cost Uncle Sam $250, 000, will celebrate her birthday tomorrow, 52 years young, under the auspices of the ladies auxiliary of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the National Parks Service of the Department of the Interior.
Dr. Percy W. Bidwell, head of the Department of Economics at the University of Buffalo, has been appointed to a research professorship at the Council on Foreign Relations, it was announced yesterday.

State Senator Frederic H. Bontecou, Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor, who has just returned from a speaking trip upState, predicted yesterday that the up-State plurality for District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, would be 20 per cent greater than that for William F. Bleakley, nominee for Governor in 1936.

Nazi pressure to force Jews out of business and out of Germany is steadily becoming heavier. Scattered yet significant incidents today gave emphasis to the scope and variety of the anti-Semitic movement.

An agreement whereby the surplus oil produced in Mexico will come to the United States instead of being sold in the Eastern Hemisphere has been entered into by Roy R. Fisher, president of the Argo Oil Corporation of Detroit, and the Mexican Government, it is announced.

Beacon Participations, Inc.-As of Sept. 30: After allowing for all known liabilities, net asset value of the 30,547 no-par shares of Class A participating preferred stock equaled $13.82 a share, against $14.04 on June 30, 1938, and $24.68 on Sept. 30, 1937.
Four new governors joined the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange at its meeting yesterday. They were Carle C. Conway, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, General Robert E. Wood and Howard B. Dean.

Electric power production increased last week, but the gain was slightly smaller than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index eased to 95.1 from 95.2. The figure for the week ended Oct. 23, 1937, was 103.6.

Partisan Reapportionment Representative government, in principle, requires that every voter have as nearly as possible an equal voice in the Legislature with every other voter. Absolute equality in this respect has never been achieved. As in other States, the rural voter in New York is overrepresented, the urban voter underrepresented.
Army's backfield was the center of interest today as Coach Bill Wood and his aides put the Cadets through an hour-and-a-half drill of polishing assignments for Saturday's game against Notre Dame.

Turpentine firm, 26c; sales, 41 barrels; receipts. 938 barrels; shipments. 67 barrels: stock, 52,367 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 87: receipts, 1,946; shipments, 128: stock, 276,100. Quote: B. D, $4; E. $4.30; F. $5.10; G, H, I, $5.25; K, $5.25-.271/2: M, $5.30; N, $5.70; WG, $6: WW. X, $6.50.
Herr Rainer, Nazi district leader for Salzburg Province, made a significant announcement this evening about the differences between Catholics and Nazis, declaring in a public statement:
The Arkwright Club, one of the oldest luncheon clubs in the city, will leave 320 Broadway after nearly half a century for new quarters, in 40 Worth Street.

The Argentine Republic has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of sinking fund external loan 4 1/2 per cent bonds to mature Nov. 1, 1948, fixing the offering date for Nov. 3.

The world of tomorrow cannot get along without religion any more than the world of today. For this reason Mayor La Guardia's appointment of a committee of 400 to assist in raising $250,000 to build a Temple of Religion
Hannes Schneider, the "uncrowned King of Tyrol" and supreme skiing authority, is viciously attacked in the Elite Guard organ, Schwarzekorps.
Changes in New York Stock Exchange procedure with respect to striking issues from the list were announced yesterday, as a result of consultations with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Seventh educational conference under the joint auspices of the Educational Records Bureau, the Cooperative Test Service, the committee on measurement and guidance of the American Council on Education and the commission on the relation of school and college of the Progressive Education Association, Hotel Roosevelt 10:30 A. M. Afternoon session, 2:30 P. M., and dinner 8 P. M. Continues tomorrow.

Manhattan's new backfield combination passed the major portion of a two-hour dummy scrimmage yesterday testing its attack against the first freshman eleven, which represented Canisius, the Jaspers' rival Saturday in Buffalo.

Instead of depending upon a running attack against the Navy, Pennsylvania probably will open its attack, judging by the time spent on for ward passing today. Most of the yardage in the victories over Lafayette, Yale and Columbia was gained on ground plays.

The ranks of the unbeaten, thinned considerably last week-end when Carnegie Tech, Vanderbilt, Syracuse, Georgia, Colorado State, Creighton, Idaho, Brigham Young and San Francisco came off the field with their colors drooping, are certain to be still further depleted this week when football offers its rarest treat in years.
The Most Rev. Matthew Francis Brady today was consecrated Catholic Bishop of Burlington by the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

Two more Rebel attacks on the Jarama River sector, in much lighter form than yesterday, were repulsed today, according to a Spanish Government communique. The attack toward .Ciempozuelos was made with only a few brigades, so the Rebel command could not have had any ambitious plans.

Chairman Dies of the special House committee investigating un-American activities made formal denial today of President Roosevelt's charges yesterday in an attack on the committee's motives and methods, and went on with the investigation.

The Army plebes defeated the Lafayette freshman eleven by a 26-to12 score in the Michie Stadium today. Neither team tallied in the first period but in the second the cadets pushed over a touchdown when Hatch went 10 yards on an offtackle smash.

Governors Island Each of the following Regular Army office cers, on duty at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., is designated as a member of the Corps of Instructors for the Command and General Staff Extension Course for thin 26th Infantry:

Park Commissioner Robert Moses criticized the lack of recreation areas in public and private housing developments yesterday when he asked the City Planning Commission to include additional funds for this purpose in the 1939 capital outlay budget.
A man too modest to reveal his name appeared in the Federal Court House yesterday at a public sale of unclaimed odds and ends left aboard ships by 209 deserting or dead sailors.

New provisions of the extended coverage endorsement for fire insurance policies were explained to the Risk Research Institute, composed of insurance buyers for industrial concerns, by Ralph W. Morrell, vice president of Davis, Dorland Co., at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The Crack Brigade 5-year-old, Bill Farnsworth, who did so poorly at Saratoga, was a decisive winner yesterday at Empire City, where players still complained of the form of the thoroughbreds.
