Closing strongly after a faster beginning than usual, Bill Farnsworth had no trouble winning by a length and a half at the end of the short six furlongs.
Resolutions supporting the National Labor Relations Act, but criticizing labor leaders for their "bickering," marked the close of the annual meeting of the National Council of Catholic Women here.
The general level of wholesale prices dropped last week to the lowest level since December, 1934, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Though the Administration has still to lay before the country its formal program of medical care, the lines on which it is likely to proceed were indicated by Surgeon General Parran and Mr. Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, before the American Public Health Association. It is already clear that we may expect taxation and insurance-probably

The publishing firm of G. P. Putnam's Sons celebrated its 100th anniversary last night at a dinner at the Hotel St. Regis, at which tributes were paid by Dr. Walter Damrosch, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, Dr. John Dewey, Dr. Raymond Moley, Federal Judge John M. Woolsey and Newbold Morris, President of the Council, representing Mayor La Guardia. Franklin E. Parker Jr. presided.

Edward F. Corsi, Republican candidate for the United States Senate short term, tonight advocated a four-point program to "loosen restrictions" on old-age pension payments. In a campaign speech here, Mr. Corsi, urging "old age security in our time, instead of our children's," called for:

The conservative tradition of the Metropolitan Opera House will be. shattered on the evening of Nov. 18 when for the first time in its fifty-five years of existence this exclusive home of the opera and the ballet will offer a motion picture. The picture will be "Sable Cicada,"

The first Premier of autonomous Ruthenia, Andrew Brody, who yesterday was removed from office by order of the Prague Central Government, was placed under arrest tonight. The order to come here reached him yesterday in Slovakia, but he refused to comply.

Representatives of organizations in the cotton trade and government officials considered yesterday at the New York Cotton Exchange a proposal that contracts for the future delivery of cotton on domestic exchanges be changed to allow full premiums for certain staple lengths over seven-eighths inch. Frank J. Knell, president of the New York Cotton Exchange presided.

In the state of flux and confusion of American foreign policy after Munich it is not remarkable that the President and his predecessor, Mr. Hoover, should have approached the question on different roads in their remarks before The HeraldTribune's Forum. And this fluid condition of the policy explains why the President's party members in Congress
The fine Fall weather has made the crop of chrysanthemums at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park, Fifth Avenue at 105th Street, exceptionally beautiful this year,

This correspondent found the new Chinese "puppet regime" for the Wuhan area today. Motoring along the littered Chungshan road south of Hankow this morning between rows of shuttered shops into some of which roving groups of Japanese soldiers had broken in search of food and shelter, I noticed two huge five-barred flags flanked by smaller Rising Sun

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Oct. 26 were announced today: Johnson, Lt. E. B., resignation accepted. Hall, Commander N. B., headquarters, promoted to Captain (engineering). Dagnin, Chief Machinist W. G., the Nike, to the Tampa.

MANHATTAN BERNSTEIN, HENRY (Jan. 13, 1938). Gross assets, $39,730; net, $38,243. To Herbert A. Aaron, Jesse M. Aaron, Helene B. Brill, Lester and Milton B. Seasonwein, nephews and niece, residue equally. Chief assets, mortgages notes, cash and insurance, $21,067. Milton B. Seasonwein, attorney, 350 5th Ave.

A plan for the cooperation and exchange of film material among the Museum of Modern Art Film Library and similar non-commercial groups in England, France and Germany went into effect yesterday with the signing of the articles of federation here by John Hay Whitney, president of the American organization.

Amid extremely quiet conditions, the stock markets here were able to maintain today a firm tone, helped by rallies in one or two formerly weak sections. Gilt-edge issues eased a trifle in negligible dealings and foreign bonds hardly changed under similar conditions.

A new Dodge truck division plant was dedicated on the outskirts of Detroit today as K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, approved the first truck to roll through the end of the assembly line.
Employment in the non-agricultural occupations increased by 440,000 in September, according to an employment report made public today by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

The existing United States fleet, while ready for instant action and with a gunnery record that is "amazing," is nevertheless inadequate for the complete protection of the United States and its possessions, Charles Edison,

In this industrial city, which he lost by only 4,000 votes two years ago, Governor Lehman appealed tonight for his own re-election as a safeguard for the progressive labor laws which he said the Republicans had fought at every turn and probably would sabotage if returned to office.

Longwood Ave, 1,190, 1-story and vacant, 64.7x100xirreg; National City Bank against Tiffany Holding Corp; due $43,677, taxes, etc., $5,776; to plaintiff for $20,000. By HENRY BRADY Eagle Ave, 812, 3-story tenement, 16.6x100x irreg; Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corp against Gustave Simmert, individ exec; due $5,898, taxes, etc., $428; to plaintiff for $1,000.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation, New York City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 37,500 shares of no-par value common stock.
Turpentine firm, 25 1/4c; sales, 69 barrels; receipts, 165 barrels; shipments, 118 barrels; stock, 52,414 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 224; receipts, 1,530; shipments, 346 stock, 277,284.

A demand by the United States that Japan should cease interfering with American rights in China was disclosed in Washington yesterday. A note was delivered in Tokyo Oct. 6 and has not been answered. It insisted on the Open Door and carried an intimation that if satisfaction was not given definite measures might be taken by the United States. [Page 1.]

Williams B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigations, disclosed last night that a complete file of all known data on lawbreakers and their associates was being compiled on the basis of thousands of filing cards on Brooklyn criminals and their connections.
Manhattan's football squad, twenty-six strong, left last night for Buffalo, where the Jaspers will oppose a crafty Canisius eleven at the new Civic Stadium tomorrow afternoon. Two veteran linemen,

A special train left late today with thirty-six Notre Dame football players for Rye, N. Y., where the team will stay before the game with Army in New York Saturday. The squad will stay at the Westchester Country Club, work out tomorrow afternoon and go to New York Saturday morning.
Following is the text of the United States note Ambassador Joseph Grew presented to the Japanese Foreign Minister concerning events in China:

Major Gen. Joseph D. Leitch, U. S. A., retired, died last night in Letterman General Hospital after an illness of a year. He was 74 years old. Holder of several medals, he retired ten years ago after a varied career of service, including a post in Siberia and assignment as secretary of the War College in 1912-13.

Two contracts determining wage and working conditions on piers and harbor craft in New York probably will be signed today by employer and union representatives, assuring peace in these marine fields for another year.
Stockholders of the International Silver Company, at a meeting in Jersey City, approved yesterday a proposed reorganization plan by more than two-thirds vote of each class of stock.
Hugh Wallace Young of Oreland, Pa., Philadelphia representative of the E. W. Bliss Company, heavy machinery manufacturers, died yesterday following an automobile accident, at Glenside, near here.
Herbert Seibert of this city, supervisor of physical education in Bayonne schools for twenty-one years until his retirement in 1935, died today in Presbyterian Hospital here at the age of 74.

The British Government adopted today a general plan for the evacuation-and compulsory billeting in the country--of roughly one-third of the urban population as the most effective form of civilian defense against air raids.

An unprecedented step was taken by the State Labor Relations Board last night when it notified 3,000 janitorial workers, employed in the public schools of this city, that their jobs were safe whether or not they voted in an SLRB election to be held tomorrow to designate a collective -bargaining agent for the workers. The notices were mailed.

Returns to date indicate that net operating income of the railroads in September was about $53,000,000, or the highest for any month since October, 1937. This would compare with an aggregate net operating income of $59,304,948 reported in September, 1937. Predictions are that October earnings will run ahead of September's. The total for August was $45,376.622.

Yehudi Menuhin, 21-year-old vio linist, started today what he described as a fight for his freedom as an artist by refusing to join the American Guild of Musical Artists. In a letter to Mrs. Leiland Atherton Irish, executive vice president of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, he flatly refused to join the Guild as a prerequisite for his appearances as soloist with the Philharmonic on Nov. 3 and 4.

Dayton's 34,000 public school pupils faced today at least six weeks of no studies and no athletics, the city Board of Education having decided yesterday that it could no longer "encumber the future" to keep the schools open in the face of a $61,936 deficit. An order to close the schools after Friday's sessions affects seven high schools, five junior highs, forty-four elementary schools and seventeen kindergartens.

Mrs. Ruth Hanna McCormick Simms suffered a broken hip in a fall yesterday, but she will not permit that to handicap her election campaign activities. Scheduled to make a radio address last night in behalf of the Republican State ticket, she spoke into the microphone from her hospital bed.

The Seminole Club of Forest Hills, L. I., scored a 3-to-2 triumph over the New York A. C. in the opening of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class B interclub matches last night. S. J. Dicketts won the leading contest from C. A. Hardy at the Winged Foot Club courts 15-10, 12-15, 15-11, 15-12.

Walter G. Baumhogger has been elected president of United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Walter S. Mack Jr., chairman of the board. Mr. Baumhogger, who recently resigned as president of Certainteed Products Corporation, has been a director and member of the executive committee of United Cigar-Whelan since 1937, and was elected chairman of the executive committee last July.
Foods and drugs not approved by the American Medical Association may not be advertised over Puerto Rican radio stations, it was learned today.

Governor Lehman will carry the city of Rochester by a reduced margin, compared with his 29,095 plurality here in 1936, according to estimates. The question is whether his plurality will be reduced low enough to permit the Republican strongholds in the rest of Monroe County to overcome the Lehman lead within the city limits.
Aiming at putting Syracuse's running attack in high gear, Coach Ossie Solem today had three teams running in dummy scrimmage, testing the offense to be used against Penn State Saturday.

Joseph H. Bragdon. in 1,215 5th Ave; Conrad Milliken, in 231 E 76th St; Howard Hotchner, in 115 E 90th St; Irene Reeder, in 116 E 73d St; Henry A. Wise Jr, in 166 E 96th St; Magella Cusson, in 49 E 86th St: Culver. Hollyday Co, Inc. brokers.

The demand for low-priced stocks, especially public utility issues, continued yesterday to feature the stock market. The market as a whole closed irregularly higher. The day's business on the Stock Exchange reached 1,995,000 shares, the heaviest volume since Oct. 19.
Michael N. Slotnick, an attorney and a former member of the Massachusetts State Legislature. died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 10 West Eighty-sixth Street. He was 49 years old.
Prince Valdemar, the oldest member of the royal house of Denmark and the brother of the late Queen Alexandrine, today celebrated his eightieth birthday.

Miss Alice MacIntyre, daughter of Charles H. MacIntyre of New Canaan and the late Mrs. Alice Teasdale MacIntyre, was married here this afternoon to George F. Keefer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Keefer of Darien.

Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York and the first German official here to appear on a public platform since the German annexation of the Sudeten territory, attacked such democratic institutions as free press and liberty of worship in a speech last night at a meeting in the Turnhalle, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

President Lazaro Cardenas today promised Washington to publish no more decrees expropriating American-owned farm land during the current negotiations between Mexico and the United States for settlement of the agrarian debt, claimed to be more than $10,000,000.

SERGEANTS-Joseph F. Dunn, from 78th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn-Richmond, assigned to duty in Felony Court, Brooklyn, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 1. John J. Regan, from 104th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad Queens, assigned to duty in Felony Court, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 1.

Three women who attended the first New York piano recital of Moriz Rosenthal fifty years ago in Steinway Hall in Fourteenth Street were the guests of the 76-year-old pianist at a golden jubilee tea yesterday afternoon in his apartment at the Hotel Great Northern, 118 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Mrs. Charles S. Whitman and Mrs. Cornelius Tiers, in behalf of Governor Lehman (from recording), WQXR, 10:30 to 10:45 A. M. (Also WINS, 1:05 to 1:10 P. M., 1,180 Kc.)

Mixing his modeling material with clay taken from the river bed seventy feet below the surface of the East River, Leo Lentelli, sculptor, of 2 East Twenty-third Street, began yesterday his statue of a sandhog which probably will be exhibited at the World's Fair by the New York City Tunnel Authority.

A mural symbolizing the six major American wars, painted by Tom Loftin Johnson for the Second Corps Area Headquarters Building, Governors Island, will be viewed there at. 3:45 P. M. today by. a group of invited guests.

A double-deck parking lot with stores beneath one-third of its 15,000 square-foot roof was opened yesterday for business. Occupying the northeast corner of Fifty-third Street and Seventh Avenue, it introduced to the city a new way to meet the parking problem and to owners of vacant property a new kind of "tax-paying" structure.

The title, itinerary and chief personnel of this year's Princeton Triangle Club show, fiftieth since the musical group's inception in 1888, were announced today by Sanders Maxwell, '39, of Trenton, N. J., president of the club.

A certificate of incorporation for the Henry Cabot Lodge Association of 108 Summit Avenue, this city, was filed with the Hudson County clerk here today by David J. Allen of Jersey City and four other trustees.

Secretary of Commerce Roper announced tonight that national income increased in September for the fourth consecutive month. The department's seasonally adjusted index of income payments to individuals rose from 82.5 per cent of the 1929 level in August to 83.3 per cent in September.

Department store sales in the New York Federal Reserve District for the first three weeks of October showed less than the usual seasonal rise and were about 11 per cent lower than in the corresponding period of 1937, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Fresh buying, particularly in the railroad and utilities sections, produced the heaviest trading volume in two weeks yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange and most groups moved generally higher.

St. John's University will be represented by only two basketball teams during the Winter, it was announced yesterday by the athletic association. Usually the Redmen have freshman, junior varsity and varsity teams, but this season the cub unit has been dropped.

An effort to bar Philippine-born Chinese from Filipino naturalization was launched by the. Commonwealth Department of Justice in court here today, indicating the government is attempting to establish a new exclusion policy.
Irving Beenstock bought, through Edgar Storms Jr., Inc., the English residence containing seven rooms and three baths at 6 Linford Road, Russell Gardens, Great Neck, from the Irving Trust Company.

Robert Moses, New York Commissioner of Parks, and Carter Glass, United States Senator from Virginia, were hailed as outstanding administrators last night at a dinner marking the eightieth anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt when the Theodore Roosevelt Medals for 1938, recently awarded to them, were presented.

Marshall Field Co. and subsidiaries reported yesterday in a statement covering the three months to Sept. 30 a net profit of $485,697 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.
Because transfer facilities are no longer available, the New York Curb Exchange has removed from unlisted trading the common stock of the Continental Securities Corporation, $5 par value.

Coach Lloyd Jordan continued to work his squad today in preparation for the Amherst-Massachusetts State football game here on Saturday, with an intensive drill on defense against the quick-kick and more work on passing marking the session.
Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator, announced today that no exemptions would be allowed under the Fair Labor Standards Act where employes were clearly under the provisions of the law.

A bronze plaque for "meritorious public service" was presented last night to the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women by the New York Lodge 1, B'nai Brith, at the annual benefit concert of the fraternity in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With its film of A. J. Cronin'S "Citadel" just around the corner, Metro stole some of its own thunder yesterday by presenting "Young Doctor Kildare" at the Music Hall. It is a rather fine picture in most respects, quiet in tone and performance, happily free from the cliches of most men-in-white dramas.

Fordham's football forces were humming over the rails last night, headed for Pittsburgh and a rendezvous with the mighty Panthers in the Pitt Stadium tomorrow. The Rams departed from a Fordham campus that still had left some of the hysteria from the night before when some 10,000 alumni and undergraduates stormed the gymnasium for the biggest pre-game rally in Maroon history.
Thirty-five Colgate football players, Coach Andy Kerr and Trainer Jack Rourke left tonight for Worcester, Mass., where the powerful Holy Cross- eleven will be met Saturday in the annual game.

Sales of new passenger automobiles at retail in September, according to unadjusted preliminary figures, were 49 per cent below September, 1937, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Renewed confidence reigns in the Mercersburg Academy football ranks, for with three regulars, who have been out with injuries for several weeks, back in harness, the squad is determined to return to the victory column here Saturday at Franklin and Marshall Academy's expense.

Private business no longer exists, but has assumed the nature of a public utility, Don Francisco, recently appointed president of Lord Thomas, advertising agency, declared yesterday, in urging that each industry tell the public the simple, fundamental truths about its operations.

Morris Park Ave, 634-638 (15-4030); Frank Samson to Mathias Auer, 525 Bergenline Ave., West New York, N. J., installments, 5 per cent; $18,500. Greystone Ave (13-3414C) e s, 100 ft n of 238th St, 100x100 ft; Fanruth Realty Corp. to Investors Syndicate. 250 Park Ave, 1 year, 6 per cent; $135,000.

The attitude of the totalitarian States confronts American education with a serious situation, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared last night in an address at the Roosevelt Hotel before the seventh Educational Conference being held under the joint auspices of the Educational Records Bureau,

Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials were restrained from any further deportation of C. I. O. speakers and organizers and any other visiting speakers they might not like, by a decision handed down yesterday by Federal Judge William Clark in Newark in the suit brought by the C. I. O.

Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman denied yesterday an application for a writ of mandamus which would compel County Judge Charles Colden to execute a sentence he suspended in the case of Mrs. Etta Reisman three years ago.

Industry and capital should cease to stand idly by, waiting for the "old American way" of unobstructed production to come back by itself, and unite their energies in forcing output to the highest degree possible, regardless of the alleged inconsistencies and restricting regulations that hamper the natural processes of production, according to F. C. Crawford, president of Thompson Products,. Inc. of Cleveland.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has petitioned the United States District Court at Wilmington, Del., for permission to intervene in the reorganization proceedings of the Standard Gas and Electric Company in connection with the $1,400,000 claims for fees and epenses sought by persons other than banks and trust companies concerned in the reorganization.
October egg futures slumped 1 1/3 cents today to the lowest price since Aug. 8 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and closed 1 cent below yesterday's close at 23 3/8 cents a dozen.
George Whitney White, president of the National Metropolitan Bank, died there last night, according to word received here. His age was 68. His home was at 2,800 Upton Street, N. W., Washington.

From West Coast naval bases to the Atlantic seaboard and from the Gulf Coast to small inland towns near the Canadian border hundreds of thousands of Americans helped yesterday to make the seventeenth annual observance of Navy Day the largest in the country's history.

Commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Notre DameArmy football game, more than 1,000 alumni of the University of Notre Dame and of West Point will gather at 8:30 o'clock tonight at the Hotel Pennsylvania at a reunion under the auspices of the Notre Dame Club of New York.

Yale finished football practice for the Dartmouth game on Saturday in the secrecy of the Bowl today. Little contact work was attempted, tackling and running out of plays was avoided, but a short supervised rehearsal of the attack was held, along with a more protracted defensive scrimmage against the Green's formations, notably the aerial game

" If they can pitch 'em, we can too," said Carl Snavely, Cornell's mentor, after today's final workout before the Columbia game. Rain, such as is hoped for Saturday by the local element, forced the Big Red indoors, the boys donning basketball shoes and romping through plays in the drill hall.

John Henry Lewis risks his world light-heavyweight title tomorrow in a fifteen-round fight against the veteran Al Gainer, who for years has been chasing champions in the hope of getting a crack at the crown.

Several multi-family dwellings in Brooklyn were sold by savings banks in realty deals reported yesterday. The Williamsburgh Savings Bank sold to an investing client of Isaacs Murofchick, attorneys, the fourstory house for forty-three families at 345 Lefferts Avenue for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $100,000.

Assistant Dean Edmund H. H. Caddy has been appointed acting dean and secretary of New York Law School, according to an announcement yesterday by Archibald R. Watson, New York County Clerk and president of the board of trustees. Dean Alfred E. Hinrichs,
Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman at a political rally here tonight: For years the Democratic party has been the friend of the working man.

Today's major events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Canadian Choir, Town Hall, 8:30. A concert of chamber and swing music will be given tonight at the Washington Irving High School under the auspices of the United Membership Drive, Former Blue Ticket Supporters of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

It was not easy, listening to the program of Handel, Beethoven and Brahms performed last night by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, John Barbirolli conductor, in Carnegie Hall, to dismiss the somewhat melancholy impression that there were musical giants in other days than ours.
Dr. Arthur H. Merritt of New York was named president-elect today of the American Dental Association to take office at the close of its 1939 convention in Milwaukee. Dr. C.

Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff, president of the New Ydrk Tuberculosis and Health Association, announced yesterday that Alfred C. Howell, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, would serve as chairman of the thirtysecond annual Christmas Seal Sale.

The groundwork for an organized effort on the part of architects to combat legislation unfavorable to their profession and particularly to halt the growing trend toward use of government bureaus and agencies in place of private firms in designing public buildings was laid yesterday at the opening session of the convention of the New York State Association of Architects.

Increase of $2,781,000 in deposits of chartered banks was shown in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on Oct. 26, issued today. The statement with changes noted from the previous week (in thousands of dollars):
Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 22 exceeded purchases by 162,590 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Brown today closed contact work in preparation for Tufts with another comprehensive drill on forward passes, the varsity working on both offense and defense. Charles Blount, New York City junior, passed for the "Tufts" team and the varsity had considerable trouble on many of the plays.

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association at its policies division meetings here today approved a budget which carried forward several successful indirect sales promotions and awarded to George C. Thomas Jr., vice president and treasurer of Thomas Betts Company, Elizabeth, N. J., the James H. McGraw Award for the most important personal contributions to progress in the industry.

United States amateur boxers met defeat tonight in the Pan-American championships, Bobby Carroll of Trenton, N. J., and Frank Mullane of Detroit both losing decisions. Carroll was outpointed by the Chilean flyweight, Luis Porteles. Mullane, a featherweight, dropped the verdict to Vital Coccio of Argentina.

William Hard has resigned his secretaryship of the Republican program committee, an office he held since the group was organized last Winter. The resignation was made public today by Dr. Glenn Frank, commitee chairman, who said it was unlikely a successor would be appointed at this time.

Hamilton College is taking no chances on having rain mar the inauguration of Dr. W. H Cowley as president of the institution Saturday. Learning from the Weather Bureau that rain has fallen Oct. 29 in six of the last seven years, Wallace B. Johnson, chairman of the committee on arrangements, visited Utica stores and purchased several hundred umbrellas.

An effective demonstration of the present capabilities of the theremin ether-wave instrument in the hands of a fine musician who has fully conquered its difficult technique was made by Clara Rockmore at her recital last night in Town Hall. What Miss Rockmore accomplished in matters of intonation, legato and staccato playing, accentuation and nuances, must have come as a distinct surprise to any in the house who. entertained false ideas of the theremin's possibilities.

Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged here tonight that the number of civil service employes of the State had been decreased by political corruption to the point where fewer than 50 per cent of the 46,500 State employes were civil servants, ...

The need of a moratorium upon further expansion of retail equipment, systems, frills and all requirements of customer service which increase distribution costs "might well be considered," Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said last night at the first annual dinner of the Consumer-Retailer Relations Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Oct. 25: REAR ADMIRAL Williams, Y. S., orders to Navy Department revoked: to continue treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Flanagan, H. C., orders to Naval Radio. Mare Island, revoked; to continue duty as district communication officer, San Francisco, Calif.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service has raised $85,795 in its campaign for $250,000, Mrs. Grover C. Loening, chairman of the women's division, announced yesterday at a meeting of seventy-five women workers for the drive at the Kips Bay Center, 411 East Sixtyninth Street.

THE first of November is just around the week-end. It is therefore time for the third of the three-times-a-year reviews of reviews. Looking backward over the books that have been discussed in this quadrangle since the beginning of July, here are a dozen-or more-that stand out for a variety of excellences:

Detectives rounded up the last six of the twenty-eight men indicted in an alleged lathing racket in the building trades in Queens Wednesday night and yesterday morning, and yesterday forenoon they were arraigned before Judge Charles S. Colden in the Queens County Court.

The minimum motor carrier rates recently established by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the New England region, the first of their kind ever promulgated by the Interstate Commerce Commission, were modified by the commission in a supplemental order issued today.

Joseph P. McKay, vice chairman of the Democratic committee of Richmond County and former Commissioner of Weights and Measures of New York, died yesterday in his home, 223 Victory, Boulevard, Tompkinsville, S. I. He was 62 years old.

More than 1,500 dealers and salesmen from the Edgewater, N. J., branch of Ford Motor Company had their first view yesterday of the company's 1939 line of cars, trucks and commercial units at a preview at the Casa Mariana.

Contending that peace and cooperation are realizable between the French and German peoples, Premier Edouard Daladier sought in an address this afternoon at the Radical Socialist party congress to give France that new lead for which she has been waiting ever since the Munich agreement.

The new he $850,000,000 annual plan for natioialhealth, now being formulated by to the Federal Government, was endorsed here tonight completely 'by the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association,' attended by about 4,000 health experts in public welfare and industrial service.

The West Side Democratic Club of 2,796 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, voted yesterday to support Isidore Nagler for Representative in the Twenty-third Congressional District, Carl 0. Parsons for the State Senate in the Twenty-third Senatorial District and Magistrate Anna Kross for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District.

If the nation's economic and social ideas are correctly mirrored in Fortune's poll on the subject, then it is a solemn and an interesting thought that the American people is less collectivist-minded today than it was twenty-six years ago when Woodrow Wilson was elected President.

Payment of cash relief to those aided by the Westchester County Department of Family and Child Welfare in place of the present system of voucher relief was recommended yesterday in a report presented by Miss Elizabeth W. Clark, staff secretary of social welfare research.

Mayor La Guardia left last night for a quick trip to the Middle West, where he plans to make speeches in three cities. On Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock the Mayor will speak in Detroit under the auspices of the Michigan Citizens Progressive Committee.

An investing client of the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization purchased from the Hoboken Bank for Savings the nine-family dwelling at 125 Nineteenth Street, West New York, N. J. The house, which contains five four-room and four three-room suites, will be modernized by the new owner. Pierson Brand were attorneys for the bank.

Catherine St, 82; Andrew Fiori to Michael A. Rofrano, 11 Oliver St, one-half interest; mtg $16,000 covering whole parcel, deed dated Jan. 11, 1919 (50 cents). Same property; Colomba Fiori, executor of Andrew Fiori, to Colomba Fiori, 734 E 5th St, Brooklyn; one-half interest (50 cents). Catherine St. 29; Bellifiore Realty Co to Peter P. Bello, 61 Caryl Ave, Yonkers, N. Y. (50 cents).

Contrary to expectations, the excess reserves of all member banks failed to reach a new record this week, although they rose $10,000,000 to $3,280,000,000, the highest ever reached, except the record of $3,304,000,000 Dec. 11, 1935.

Thinking that their gas masks were unnecessary, two firemen entered the cellar of a row of one-story stores at 84-86-88 Mount Vernon Place, this city, to fight a small fire late tonight and were killed by escaping illuminating gas.

The Hon. Arthur Murray and Mrs. Murray of London, who were recent guests of President Roosevelt at Hyde Park, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. James Roosevelt and Sir William Wiseman. The host and hostess are sailing next week for their home in London.

The passing of several large plots of vacant land into new ownership for improvement with an apartment house, a group of small dwellings and a business building was reported yesterday with the sale of sites in Jackson Heights and Elmhurst.

Each of the following Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Division--1st Lt. Donald R. MacKay, Inf.-Res., Inter Ocean Reinsurance Co., 90 John St., New York, N. Y. 1st Lt. Fenner H. Whitley Jr., Inf.-Res., N. Y. University, University Heights, N. Y. 2d Lt. Raymond E. Feuerstein, Inf.-Res., 58 W. 48th St., New York, N. Y.
Stocks closed mixed to irregularly higher in largest trading in a week; turnover, 1,995,870 shares. Bonds steady and mixed with Treasury, rail and utilities higher; transactions, $8,932,000.

For the first time in fifteen weeks awards for engineering construction,this week are lower than in the corresponding period of last year. Off 15 per cent from last year's $62,866,000, the current volume is $53,634,000.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the extension for four months, until the end of February, the effectiveness of Rule 210 under the Securities Act of 1933, and Amendment 32 to the instruction book for form A-2, which otherwise would expire on Saturday.

Fed steers and yearlings were active, strong to 25c higher today with other cattle in limited quota, steady to strong, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs were generally 10c to 15c lower, with top $8. A 25-cent lower trend prevailed in lambs.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stockton Woodward of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Stockton Woodward, to Philippe Magdelain, son of Mrs. Robert Magdelain of Paris and the late Mr. Magdelain.

Cash sales of dwellings on the upper West Side featured realty contracts reported in Manhattan yesterday. Mrs. J. Benita Seligman sold to a physician for his office and residence the four-story dwelling at 35 West Seventy-fourth Street.

Stocks of oil products held by the principal marketing companies in California, except those at sales and service stations, on Sept. 30 amounted to 153,237,753 barrels, an increase of 2,770,114 in the month, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

George W. Hulsart, president of the Bishop's church extension fund of the Newark Episcopal Diocese for twenty years, died this afternoon at the home of his sister-in-law, Mrs. Altana Bull, 45 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

Dr. Lascelles Abercrombie, poet and critic, died today after a week's illness at the age of 57. Nearly thirty years ago he became recognized as a poet of unusual force, originality and power to excite, among other emotions, terror, as illustrated by his drama "Deborah."

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Republican candidate for Attorney General, charged his Democratic rival, John J. Bennett, today with neglect of duty for failure to suppress election frauds in Albany County.

Coach Jakie Todd of Erskine College was injured in an automobile accident today while en route to Deland, Fla., for Erskine's game with Stetson University. Todd was admitted to the City Hospital with possible fractured ribs.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that 160 answers had been received to his nine-point questionnaire, which was sent last week to 289 candidates for the Legislature asking their views on possible legislation affecting the city.

John Lord O'Brian, New York Republican Senatorial nominee for the long term, reported to the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee today $5,625 in contributions and $4,700 of expenditures made by a volunteer citizens committee supporting his candidacy.

We had so many requests for information on hunting and hunting conditions in this area that we decided to run up to Putnam County and find out for ourselves. First of all on the matter of shooting conditions, everything is fine.

Trading was only fair to slow on a11 classes except pork which was fairly active in local markets yesterday. Market on pork ins higher cows lower other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agricultre follow:

Indignant because Republican officials of Westchester County have Ignored his request for a low automobile license number, Village President Howard Dunscomb of Ossining, a stanch Republican for thirty-five years,

Marcel Hoden, French chief of cabinet in the League of Nations secretariat, disclosed his dismissal tonight in what League observers interpreted as the first move of a "purge" designed to pave the way for return of Italy and Germany to Geneva.

Captain Angus Walters, doughty skipper of the Canadian schooner Bluenose, today held the racing championship of the North Atlantic fishing fleet, butThe silver cup, emblematic of the Bluenose's three - out - of - five - race victory over the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, couldn't be found.
Pitt's mighty Panthers worked on their aerial offensive today in preparation for the nation's No. 1 game with unbeaten Fordham in the Pitt Stadium Saturday. Pitt is a 3-1 favorite to win.

During the period from Sept, 4 to Oct. 24, when 10,000 Italian soldiers were withdrawn from Rebel Spain at and the British Government was ket deciding to make the Anglo-Italian accord effective, Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy sent sixteen ships bearing 4,549 men and much war ton, material to General Francisco in Franco, Rebel commander in chief, according to official information of the Spanish Government.
The Cuban delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, in December will be headed by Secretary of State Juan J. Remos, it was announced by the Department of State this afternoon.

A net profit of $5,367,688 was reported yesterday by the General Motors Corporation for the third quarter of 1938. The net, equal to 7 cents a share on the common stock after preferred dividends, compared with $44,412,734, or 99 cents a share, earned in the same period for 1937.

Mrs. Esther Lyons Robinson, former actress and explorer, who was known in the late Eighteen Nineties as "The Klondyke Girl," died late yesterday of a heart ailment in the Elizabeth General Hospital. She was 74 years old, and since the disappearance of the small fortune she made on the stage and as a lecturer, had worked occasionally as a practical nurse here.

The Maryland Racing Commission climaxed a long, secret investigation today with the announcement it was convinced the horse which raced in Maryland as the 5-year-old James A. was really the 4-year-old Play Pal.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdins and te ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Miss Esther Moody Barlow, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. DeWitt Dukes Barlow of this city, will have seven bridal attendants at her marriage to Seymour Perkins Jr., also of Plainfield, which will take place here the evening of Nov. 18 in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John J. Moment will perform the ceremony.

" This Was a Poet, a Critical Biography of Emily Dickinson," by George F. Whicher, which Scribner will publish on Monday, traces the literary achievements of the New England poet. The author is a Professor of English at Amherst College.

Business in the Pittsburgh district moved into new high ground for the year last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The rise resulted partly from a contra-seasonal increase in freight shipments, but primarily from the large gain in the volume of trade.

Water carriers and pipe-line companies with annual operating revenues of more than $500,000 for the last three consecutive calendar years were ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to file quarterly instead of annual reports on the volume of their business.

Peter Lehman, 21-year-old son of the Governor, made the first campaign speech of his career yesterday in an address before several hundred students at New York-University's uptown campus in the Bronx.

With himst owner C. S. Howard and Mrs. Howard looking on and with Jockey George Woolf up, Seabiscuit today worked a brisk mile and three-sixteenths, the distance of his "Pimlico Special" duel with War Admiral here Nov. 1.

Ackman Co., Inc., brokers, secured from a savings bank for Hudson Grove St, Inc, Harry A. Schacht, president, a first mortgage of $102,000 on the recently completed six-story apartment at 2 Grove St. The loan runs ten years, with interest at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent.

Following is the text of the speech made here tonight by Thomas E Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor: Today is the birthday anniversary of one of the greatest of all Americans, one of the greatest Republicans, a great leader of the people, Theodore Roosevelt.

The property formerly occupied by Drake's restaurant at 118-22 West Forty-third Street and 121 West Forty-second Street will be improved with a one-story motion-picture theatre, according to plans filed yesterday by Ely Jacques Kahn, architect.

The Board of Education here voted tonight, 7 to 1, to dismiss Miss Olive F. Jordan, for twenty years a firstgrade teacher in the Wenonah schools, after a hearing on charges that she had "strained" her pupils' nerves by relating "horror stories" to them and that she was professionally incompetent.

WNYC, the municipal radio station, will be the only broadcasting agency furnishing election returns directly from Police Headquarters on election night, Nov. 8, according to an announcement yesterday by Morris S. Novik, station director.

Alma Gluck, wife of Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, and an internationally famous soprano in her own right until her retirement in 1925, died yesterday at 9:30 A. M. at Rockefeller Institute Hospital at the age of 54. She had been ill for a long time and had been taken to the hospital several days ago.
The Navy Day address of Assistant Secretary Edison tonight over the Mutual Broadcasting System was as follows:

Brig. Gen. Evan H. Humphrey of Governors Island, commanding officer of the Second Corps Area, as emissary of President Roosevelt, visited the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemnetery, here today to commemorate the birthday of the late President by placing a wreath on the tomb.

Led by Captain Daniel Corry, members of the Irish Army team that will take part in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, beginning Nov. 5, arrived here last night in the United States liner Manhattan.

Coach Harlow today declared Harvard's workout the best it has had in weeks. There was a distinctly improved drive in the running plays, and both Frank Foley and Austin Harding were on the mark with their forward passes. It was dark when Harlow put away the white ball and sent his team to the locker building, having finished the drill under the lights set on the stadium roof.
Coach Harvey Harman sent the Rutgers eleven through a twohour dummy scrimmage against Lehigh formations today in preparation for the Scarlet's clash with the Engineers at Bethlehem, Pa., Saturday.

The New York Grand Opera Company was forced to close its season at the Manhattan Center because of failure to make back-stage alterations in compliance with the building and fire laws, it was announced yesterday by Amadeo Passeri, general director of the company.
Chancellor Hitler's recepiton today at Nikolsburg, to which he went from Znaim, was the most enthusiastic and picturesque he has yet had in the newly acquired Moravian region.

President Roosevelt was requested yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association to call a conference in Washington at an early date of representatives of government, farmers, labor, consumers, producers, manufacturers and distributors to develop a cooperative program for the disposal of agricultural surpluses.

W. F. Mannagh's Chief Nadi scored a narrow victory today over Mrs. V. Wyse'S Bachelor Dinner in the featured Greystone Purse at Narrangansett Park. Two lengths back of Bachelor Dinner was Mrs. W. Hodson's Mansco, who had a length on the Lewin Stables' Cautivo.

Cannon Pl (12-3263B), e s, 565 ft n of 238th St., 102x121; Lulu Hoffman to Anthony C. Galluccio, 1,956 Crotona Parkway. Walton Ave (11-3181), e s, 48 ft s of 182d St, 75x95; Awol Estate, Inc, to Orsala Seria, 2.825 Claflin Ave. Tibbett Ave, 3,216 (13-3406E), George J. Freedenberg, referee, to Jefferson Title and Mortgage Corp, 1 Stevens Ave, Mount Vernon.

City College closed its heavy work for tomorrow's home meeting with undefeated Lowell Textile with a long drill at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, forward passing being stressed for the third day in a row.
Coach Carl Snavely, for the past three seasons the teacher of Cornell's football teams, said today he planned to remain there "indefinitely."

John P. Noonan, retired secretary and a member of the board of the real estate firm of George A. Bowman, Inc., 100 West Forty-second Street, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old.
Considerable time was spent today by the Dodgers in preparing a sturdy defense against the threat of Andy Farkas's pile-driving runs when they meet the Redskins on Sunday at Ebbets Field.
Postmaster General James A. Farley will canvass the New York City political situation today at a breakfast conference with ,the leaders of the five county Democratic organizations.

Local Republican leaders expressed belief yesterday that the race for the Governorship between District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Governor Herbert H. Lehman was tightening and that-the Governor's plurality in New York City would be held below 500,000.

Mike Frattini, 147, Italy, outpointed Phil Furr, 147, Washington, in the main bout of eight rounds last night at Prospect Hall in Brooklyn. Pete Scalza, 125 1/2, West Side, knocked out Frankie Walsh, 129 1/2, Washington, in 1:02 of the second round of a scheduled eight-round semi-final.

The problem of Rumanian armament, which is proceeding apace, is causing considerable financial difficulties since the ordinary budget can allot only $30,000,000 annually for this purpose, whereas the national defense expenditures envisaged by King Carol would necessarily lead to inflation.

The Middle West Corporation yesterday announced that stock, warrants and scrip having a current value of over $500,000 still await delivery to holders of notes and stocks of the Middle West Utilities Company, predecessor organization.

As Penn concluded preparations today for the Navy game Saturday, Coach George Munger announced four changes in his starting line-up. Those who won places on the first team because of their showing against Columbia last week are Mike Burke, wingback; Ray Frick, center; Balfour Smith, left guard,

Last November certain members of the C. I. O. "invaded" Jersey City for the purpose of distributing leaflets and getting recruits to their organization. Thirteen were arrested. They and a considerable number of their sympathizers were "removed" from the city for the purpose, as Mr. Hague explained, to protect them from the anger of citizens.

A series of lectures on art topics by scholars and critics will be given on alternate Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock at the Frick Collection. 1 East Seventieth Street, beginning next Sunday and continuing through Jan. 22. Admission will be by tickets, given free of charge in order of application.

Inquiry at New York radio stations yesterday on the protest Alfred L. Dennis, president of the Bach Society of New Jersey, sent to the Federal Communications Commission against "swinging" Bach and other classical compositions, revealed that the broadcasters have no plans to stop "swinging" the classics unless the FCC so decrees.

Two St. Simon's Island resort operators were charged today with hiring two Negroes to kill Dr. Charles H. Lee eight months ago so that the rector of Christ Church could no longer oppose illicit gambling.

Mrs. Rembrandt Peale will give a reception at her home, 510 Park Avenue, on the afternoon of Thanksgiving Day for her granddaughter, Miss Patricia Peale, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rembrandt Peale Jr.

Eight United States Customs agents, armed with a Federal court warrant, searched the apartment of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer on the tenth floor of 570 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon and evening for gowns, hats, jeweled slippers,

During the period from Nov. 1, 1937, to March 8, 1938, Richard Whitney of the firm of Richard Whitney Co. negotiated a total of 111 loans aggregating $27,361,500 in a desperate effort to stave off insolvency and prevent the suspension of the firm from the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission stated today in the first section of a report on its investigation of the Whitney failure.

The Princeton squad closed its home practices for the Harvard game with a secret aerial workout on University Field today. In good physical condition for the first time in two weeks, the Orange and Black staged a spirited two-hour drill.

While his parents slept in an adjoining room, the 3-year-old son of a traffic policeman shot and killed his 5-year-old sister yesterday with his father's service revolver in the bedroom of their home at 32-54 Forty-fifth Street, Astoria, Queens. Neither parent heard the fatal shot.

The Missouri Kansas (Mokan) Pipe Line Company filed suit yesterday in the Chancery Court of Wilmington, Del., against the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company for an injunction to restrain Panhandle Eastern from putting into effect a resolution adopted by the Panhandle Eastern board on Oct.

Regulations governing the census of Peru which will probably take place in 1939 have been issued. It will be the first national census since 1876, when the population was placed approximately at 2,700,000.

A joint meeting of yarn and thread producers to act upon a set of fair trade practice rules proposed by the yarn group was voted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Cotton Thread Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, after J. C. Roberts of Gastonia, N. C., president of the Southern Combed Yarn Spinners Association, had explained the rules in detail.
On the assumption that a change b in routine will do Columbia no harm and possibly some good, Coach Lou Little yesterday set a precedent.

Major Foods, Inc., a sales corporation, just formed to distribute twelve food products under the brand name "Guest House," will introduce its new line about the middle of next month and launch an advertising campaign in newspapers and radio, it was announced yesterday.
Coal, air and water were revealed yesterday as the basic source of the material from which E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will produce its new textile yarn, known until now simply as "Yarn 66."

Inaugurating the Class A interclub series of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, the Harvard Club, led by Germain G. Glidden, national champion, registered a 5-to-0 sweep against the Dartmouth Club last night.

Mrs. Marcus A. Rothschild of 49 East Eighty-sixth Street has announced here the marriage of her daughter, Miss Edna Rothschild, to Frederic Royston, which took place in a London registry office on Wednesday.

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 27 unless specified: At San Diego: Arctic, Drayton, Flusser, Lamson, Mahan Porto. Acushnet, Norfolk to Navy Yard WashIngton via Potomac River points, Oct. 26. Bobolink, at Navy Yard Puget Sound, Oct. 26.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, from Bremen and Channel ports, has among her passengers Sir Thomas Brocklebank, Princess Farid Essultanah, Lady Moira Forbes, Maurice Dollfuss, Mr. and Mrs. D. W. Tomlinson, Colonel Robert Fierz,
Former Mayor James J. Walker will serve as director of a Sunday afternoon radio variety show, beginning Nov. 6 from 2 to 3 o'clock, according to an announcement yesferday from WMCA.

Bids for the Treasury's weekly issue of approximately $100,000,000 of ninetyone-day bills were invited this afternoon by Secretary Morgenthau. The bills will be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders and will be dated Nov. 2 and mature on Feb. 1.

Three Soviet women fliers, who reported establishing a women's distance record, come home today to a flag-draped welcome, in which their achievement was characterized as having "immense defense significance."

Miss Betty Jane Scott and Dr. Daniel Bailey Hardenbergh Jr., whose engagement was announced early this month, were married here this afternoon at the home of her sister, Mrs. John Talcott Jr. The Rev. Spencer E. Evans, a greatuncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

Earl Stan hope, a dependable but undistinguished Conservative party wheelhorse, was appointed First Lord of the Admiralty today in succession to the high-spirited Alfred Duff Cooper, who resigned on Oct. 1 because he could not approve the Munich agreement on Czechoslovakia.

Nashville, Tenn., will be in the market on Nov. 15 with $1,592,000 of school construction bonds. Additional details regarding the sale will be announced later. New Britain, Conn. Officials of New Britain, Conn., will consider sealed proposals on Nov. 9 for two issues aggregating $635,000.

MANHATTAN GOLD, CARRIE WEIL (Oct. 8). Estate, about $1,000. To Nathan M. Gold, husband, 145 E. 23d St.; Rosalind M. Levy, niece, 156 W. 86th St., residue. Harold W. Levy, executor, 156 W. 86th St. MAURELLI, MARY (Nov. 23, 1937). Estate, $2,500. To Sebastiano Maurelli, husband, executor, 408 E. 123d St.

MissMary Elizabeth Cobb of Kew Gardens, Queens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Cobb of Rutland, Vt., was married to Cornelius Alfred de Vyver of Mount Vernon, N. Y., yesterday noon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Forest Hills, Queens, by the Rev. R. Thomas Blomquist.

Large Grade A white eggs, an important item in the city person's diet because of their nutritional value, now cost New York consumers more than they have for six years largely because of an artificial marketing situation and not entirely because of the local shortage in supplies of eggs, it was learned yesterday.

Assailing the northeastern walls of the bitterly contested city of Teian, midway between Kiukiang and Nanchang, Japanese storm troopers late Wednesday afternoon finally gained access to the city, whereupon sanguinary street fighting ensued.

Continued demolition of tenements and other outmoded and idle structures has increased the amount of vacant land on the lower East Side of Manhattan to the highest point in more than half a century. The number of vacant parcels in the East Side neighborhood south of Fourteenth Street has reached 559, and the area involved is 1,293,789 square feet.

Separately but with the evident intent of heckling Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, Norman Thomas, his Socialist opponent, and Martin T. Purtell, Democratic chairman of Chemung County, today posed questions for Mr. Dewey on his arrival here.

Coach Mal Stevens had his last chance yesterday to apply the finishing touches to the drastically revised New York University backfield before the team goes up against the highly touted Ohio State eleven tomorrow afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

More than a decade ago the inrease in motor traffic on the highways mde it imperative that intersections of railroads and important highways should be separated. Under Governor Smith's energetic drive two constitutional amendments were adopted, in 1925 and in 1927, creating for this purpose a fund of $300,000,000 and stipulating

Robert R. Crowell, civil engineer, who helped to organize the Queens Topographical Bureau, died yesterday at his home, 153-11 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica. He had been ill for two weeks with bronchial pneumonia and a heart ailment. He was born seventy-four years ago in Newark, N. J.

Insurgent troops were reported massed tonight on a front nineteen miles south of Madrid, leading to a belief that new and heavier attacks were being prepared in an area marked by bitter fighting within the last few days.

The stimulation of State and county programs for the benefit of mountain schools in the Southern areas was advocated yesterday by educational, social and religious leaders attending the annual Fall conference of the Save the Children Fund.

With little or nothing in the news to account for a reversal, the foreign exchanges turned decidedly soft yesterday, after having put on a good show of strength for several days. The franc's decline was ascribed in some quarters to the-influence of passages in Premier Edouard Daladier's speech to the congress of the Radical Socialist party in Marseille.

J. P. Morgan Co., as sinkingfund agents, have drawn by lot for redemption on Dec. 15 at 105 for account of the sinking fund, $277,900 principal amount of Phelps Dodge Corporation convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1952.

The Brooklyn College football team went through a long dummy scrimmage yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's game with American International College. Coach Lou Oshins made five changes in the Kingsmen's line-up after Wednesday's scrimmage and they will probably be carried over for this contest.

The assistant coach stopped to shake the outstretched hand of the visiting Old Grad and exchange greetings. "How's the team look, Ed?" The coach, second in command, chuckled and said, "Well, I don't know. I haven't seen 'em play a game yet."

The police last night raided the headquarters of the Yugoslav National Socialist party and arrested the party's founder and leader, M. Lyotitch. The arrest was made while a secret conference was in session at the headquarters.

Representative Caroline O'Day of Rye was named co-defendant today with her son, Daniel O'Day, in a $10,000 negligence action in Superior Court here as the result of an automobile crash Oct. 2, 1937, on the Post Road at Byram Hill, Greenwich.

Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, carried his $500,000 libel suit against Represetative George Holden Tinkham of Massachusetts to the Supreme Court today. Specifically, the Bishop asked the court to review a decision against him in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals last June.

Mrs. Mary L. Hays, for more than sixty years an active worker in the Baptist Church here, died Wednesday at the home of her son, William H. Hays, 817 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of seven months. She was 93 years old.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 26: BRIGADIER GENERAL Gulick, J. W., to retirement; previous orders revoked. MAJOR Putnam, W. F., Jr., C. A. C., Fort Hancock, N. J., to 13th Coast Artillery, Key West Barracks, Fla., about Jan. 1.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Cook of this place have announced the engagements of their daughters, Miss Jane Mitchell Cook and Miss Nancy Nickerson Cook. Miss Jane Cook is engaged to Eads Johnson Jr. of Morristown and her sister is the fiance of Allan H. McAlpin Jr. of Convent.

The Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society announced yesterday the election of Herman W. Block, long engaged in the textile business and active in Jewish charities, as its president. Mr. Block succeeds the late Adolph Lewisohn.

The promise of durable hosiery, made by the du Pont company, and the forecast of beautifying foods ready. to be served before they reach the kitchen, made by the General Foods Corporation, were enthusiastically applauded as the eighth annual Forum on Current Problems held by The New York Herald Tribune closed yesterday afternoon at the New York World's Fair Grounds.

Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Finlay of Havana have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Finlay, to James Tolman Pyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. McAlpin Pyle of this city and Hunting Hollow, Far Hills, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. James H. Carter of Scarborough, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Gray Carter, to Abbott Abercrombie, son of Mrs. David T. Abercrombie of Elda, Ossining, N. Y., and the late Colonel Abercrombie.
Three protective committees filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a new proposal for reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company.

The ten-story Schilling Building, was bid in for $100,000 by the West Side Savings Bank, plaintiff against the Schilling Press, Inc., at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday. The property, which is on an at 137-9 East Twenty-fifth Street, irregular plot about 45.2 by 197.6 feet, was sold in satisfaction of a judgment of $165,615, and taxes and other liens of $9,996, by Henry Brady, auctioneer.

Forward passing held the spotlight today as Dartmouth concluded its home preparations for the Yale game. Coach Earl Blaik left nothing undone as far as Yale's passes were concerned. He had a backfield composed of Howard Nopper, Colby Howe,

Allocation of a special quota for the importation into Poland of 2,000 tons of American prunes, subject to payment of compensation fees of 52 per cent of their c. i. f. value, was reported to the Department of Commerce today from the office of the American commercial attach, Warsaw.

It seems likely that all American republics will support President Roosevelt in his contention in his speech yesterday that the present activities of the totalitarian States constitute a threat to the democratic governments of the Western Hemisphere.

Two men were fined $25 each, another man was found not guilty and trials of two other men were continued here today when the five men were arraigned before Judge Anthony Bianco of the Fourth Precinct Police Court on charges arising from a demonstration last night

A request from two of the seven members of the special House committee investigating un-American activities that further hearings be postponed until after the election campaigns was rejected today by what was announced as a committee majority.

Continued reduction of commercial loans and expansion of speculative loans, together with a renewed increase in holdings of government securities, constituted the principal changes in the position of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in the week ended on Wednesday.
Mrs. Louise Viau's Rex Flag, after fourteen straight defeats this year, finally found a field he could handle in the Tuscarora Purse, today's feature race at Laurel.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the nation amounted to $5,235,341,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, against $5,846,201,000 in the corresponding period of 1937, a decrease of $610,860,000, or 10.4 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Fritz Kuhn, head of the GermanAmerican Bund, must appear before Recorder William P. Leary here on Nov. 7 to answer charges of passing a red light and disorderly conduct.
Unless the paint industry begins labeling its products with their full formulas, fast-growing pressure from consumer groups will force not only labeling but standardization, Delancey Kountze of.

Business men handling imported goods were assured yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, Wages and Hours Administrator, that the Fair Labor Standards Act was not intended to cover working conditions abroad and that they might use imported materials without fear that the finished article would be barred from interstate commerce.

In an attempt to eliminate bureaucratic tendencies in the New York City school system the Board of Education has voted to change the policy of assigning teachers and supervisors for special duty at headquarters, James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

Wheat markets in the United States showed today stubborn resistance to scattered selling and weakness abroad. Prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent a bushel, with the close on the Board of Trade here unchanged to l/8 cent lower.

A net profit of $446,866 was made by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the three months ended on Sept. 30, compared to $150,305 in the previous three months and to $9,249,560 in the third quarter of 1937, Eugene G. Grace, president, announced yesterday. The directors declared yesterday the regular quar-terly dividends on the preferred stocks.

Miss Tessie K. Scharps died yesterday after a long illness at her home in the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fifty-fourth Street. A native of Newburgh, N. Y., Miss Scharps was the daughter of Simon A. Scharps and Rose Kurtz Scharps.

Another crop of rumors concerning Soviet leaders recently published abroad, including stories that Joseph Stalin was ill or even dead, or that he was parting company with Nikolai I. Yezhoff, Commissar of Internal Affairs, was disposed of this evening when Mr. Stalin,

The following Marine Corps changes since Oct. 26 were announced today: Berkeley, Brig. Gen. R. C., Washington, D. C., about Dec. 1 to home, to retire Feb. 1. West, Major R. E., San Francisco, Calif., ordered home, to retirement. O'Neill, Capt. S. B., San Diego, Calif., to retirement.

Annual Fall Convention, New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. "Protecting Women's Health," Dr. Eric M. Matsner. Afternoon session, 2 P. M. Seventh Educational Conference, Hotel Roosevelt, 10 A. M. Speakers: Professor Francis T. Spaulding, B. Lamar Johnson. Luncheon,

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor in the investigation of official corruption in Brooklyn, will make his first official appearance in that capacity today when he appears in Brooklyn Felony Court to prosecute Police Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan, who is charged with grand larceny in the theft of 7,200 police records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn.

A suit charging that Walter J. Salmon and 11 West Forty-second Street, Inc., of which he is sole stockholder, were attempting by misrepresentations to put through an "unfair, inequitable and illegal" plan of reorganization to the detriment of bondholders was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday when Justice Lloyd Church ordered the defendants to furnish to the plaintiffs a list of the bondholders.

In an attempt to eliminate bureaucratic tendencies in the New York City school system the Board of Education has voted to change the policy of assigning teachers and supervisors for special duty at headquarters, James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

Wheat markets in the United States showed today stubborn resistance to scattered selling and weakness abroad. Prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent a bushel, with the close on the Board of Trade here unchanged to l/8 cent lower.

A net profit of $446,866 was made by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the three months ended on Sept. 30, compared to $150,305 in the previous three months and to $9,249,560 in the third quarter of 1937, Eugene G. Grace, president, announced yesterday. The directors declared yesterday the regular quar-terly dividends on the preferred stocks.

Miss Tessie K. Scharps died yesterday after a long illness at her home in the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fifty-fourth Street. A native of Newburgh, N. Y., Miss Scharps was the daughter of Simon A. Scharps and Rose Kurtz Scharps.

Another crop of rumors concerning Soviet leaders recently published abroad, including stories that Joseph Stalin was ill or even dead, or that he was parting company with Nikolai I. Yezhoff, Commissar of Internal Affairs, was disposed of this evening when Mr. Stalin,

The following Marine Corps changes since Oct. 26 were announced today: Berkeley, Brig. Gen. R. C., Washington, D. C., about Dec. 1 to home, to retire Feb. 1. West, Major R. E., San Francisco, Calif., ordered home, to retirement. O'Neill, Capt. S. B., San Diego, Calif., to retirement.

Annual Fall Convention, New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. "Protecting Women's Health," Dr. Eric M. Matsner. Afternoon session, 2 P. M. Seventh Educational Conference, Hotel Roosevelt, 10 A. M. Speakers: Professor Francis T. Spaulding, B. Lamar Johnson. Luncheon,
Fred A. Victor, temperance worker, who for eight years was New York State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, died of heart disease here today at the age of 64.

Five closings are scheduled for tomorrow night. "Madame Capet" ends its run with seven performances; "Missouri Legend," with forty-eight performances; "Knights of Song" with sixteen; "Lightnin'" with fifty-two and "I Have Been Here Before" with twenty. Thus, out of the season's twenty-eight new shows, eleven have failed to date.

Henry Armstrong, welterweight champion, and Ceferino Garcia, against whom he will defend his title at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday. were examined yesterday by Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, who came away pleased with the condition of both fighters.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 75.3. This compared with 74.7 for the preceding week, and 78.3 for the week ended Oct. 23, 37.

President Roosevelt proved to the satisfaction of at least one White House visitor today that he could relax on the afterdeck of the Presidential yacht as well as in the guarded privacy of his Hyde Park study.
Dr. Addinell Hewson, anatomist, editor and teacher, died at his home in Bryn Mawr today after an illness of three weeks. He was 83 years old.
Senator Wagner caused a roar of laughter from a campaign rally here tonight when his tongue betrayed him into asking fcr his own election, "and my running mates on the Republican ticket."

Early action in negotiating a reciprocal trade treaty between this country and India was advocated yesterday by officials of the India Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., at a meeting in their headquarters at 665 Fifth Avenue.

49th St, 347 W, 25x100.5x irreg; Meier Manheimer and Sidney and Henry S. Manheimer as trustees, Abr Manheimer and Hortense Manheimer, widow of Abr Manheimer, to Emma Falk, 590 West End Ave; 3 years, 5 per cent; $8,000. St. Nocholas Ave, 608, 18.3x89.2x irreg; John O. Garrett to Lawyers Trust Co, 135 Broadway, trustee under deed of trust; p m, 10 years, 4 1/2 per cent; 88,000.

The Jewish Mayor of Tiberias, Zaki al Khadaf, shot this afternoon by Arabs, is in a critical condition. As the Mayor was leaving his office, three Arabs who had been hiding jumped out behind him and fired three shots. Two struck him in the back. The assailants escaped.

An old-fashioned hay-ride down Park Avenue was one of the features of a Halloween supper dance held last night for the benefit of the National Bureau for Blind Artists at Le Coq Rouge, 65 East 56th Street.

Miss Barbara Erstein, who arrived here recently from Paris with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Moyse Erstein, and is residing with them at the Pierre for the Winter, is one of the many debutantes who will participate in the colorful entertainment program at the Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Our Government's note to Japan, presented at Tokyo on Oct. 6 but only made public yesterday, reiterates our traditional position in the Far East. That Japan, for all her categorical as surances that the Open Door would be respected in China, has nevertheless persistently violated American rights and interests is the keynote of the message.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cook Culver of Akron, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia McDonough Culver, to Julian N. Trivers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Trivers of this city.
Robert O'Gorman of Newark, president of O'Gorman Young, one of the largest insurance agencies in New Jersey, died today while playing golf at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield.
The Treasury said today that a fourth of the $828,914,956 national bank notes in circulation when their redemption began in 1935 were still in the hands of the public or had been lost.

General John J. Pershing returned from Europe last night on the United States liner Manhattan after a three months' visit abroad in connection with his work as chairman of the Battle Monuments Commission.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition for Arrangement LOUIS GELLER, haberdashery. 803 and 965 8th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $23,532 and assets of $22,117, exclusive of insurance. A compromise of 40 per cent. payable 20 per cent in cash and balance in notes, is proposed.

JUST think of it. The fellow looked up at the buildings and said: "Pardon me, but what are all the flags flying for today?" Maybe that would have brought a chuckle from General Hugh Johnson, but if "Navy Bill" Ingram had heard it he would have clapped the scoundrel in irons!

Amid a roar of cheers from the lusty-lunged cadet corps following a whooping pep rally in the mess hall, Army's football team left by buses tonight for the Knollwood Country Club at White Plains, where it encamped preparatory to its twenty-fifth anniversary meeting with Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
Quotations on a number of important furs were unchanged from the opening season levels a year ago in the first price list for the 1938-39 season covering the new catch of raw furs by the trappers.
The arrival of Jaachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, in Rome tonight was made the occasion for a minor demonstration of ItaloGerman friendship.

A list of questions and their answers concerning the operation of the Fair Labor Standards Act was made public today by the Wages and Hours Division. Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, said such questions were being answered directly as rapidly as possible;

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your observation in the editorial "The Wage Act Joker" leads me to believe that we are about to return to the confused state of affairs as experienced in the early days of the NRA. Section 18 of the Wage-Hour Bill, which you characterize as a joker, is substantially the same as Paragraph 7

Net earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, reported yesterday, were $6,051,359 after deducting $572,258 blocked foreign net profits, depreciation and estimated Federal income taxes. The result is equivalent to $7.43 a share on 814,674 shares of no par capital stock outstanding.

Edward J. Flynn, for the last eleven years a law assistant in the office of the New York Corporation Counsel, died Wednesday night of a heart attack at his home, 117 West Thirteenth Street. He was 48 years old.

Robert Gregory, the wrestler who married Princess Baba of Sarawak, daughter of the only white rajah in the world, admitted today that they have separated and that she will return to England, leaving Sunday.

Backers of Elmer Benson, Farmer-Labor Governor, in his campaign for a second term in Minnesota are looking hopefully, but as yet vainly, to President Roosevelt for some word or act that will remove the growing possibility of his defeat on Nov. 8 at the hands of a 31-year-old triplethreat "liberal" Republican, Harold Stassen.

In the carefully modulated tone of a debutante trying out for a society play, a comely nurse told a jury in Federal court yesterday that two "fine gentlemen" she met at lunch in Berlin a year and a half ago wanted to cast her in the role of an American Mata Hari.

There are certain broad principles of foreign policy to which the Roosevelt Administration has consistently subscribed. Secretary Hull has stated them many times. The United States advocates faithful observance of international agreements. It advocates respect by all nations for the rights of others.

Brokers reported yesterday numerous store leases in buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan. The lists were accompanied by the names of many concerns that took office and showroom space. A leading downtown lease was made by Bruno Mueller and Irving Kamber, operators of the Garment Centre Capitol Club Restaurant at 498 Seventh Avenue, who leased the store and basement at 115 Nassau Street.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, a great hand for prowling through the dim corridors and unused rooms of City Hall, revealed yesterday that he had found three old dungeon-like rooms in the basement of the building.

While prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday, steady buying by mill interests widened the spread between December and October to 66 points, and the list ended with a gain of 1 to a loss of 5 points on the day.

Of the many leases of residential quarters on the East Side appearing in the brokers' reports received yesterday, the largest was for a duplex suite of thirteen rooms and six baths, occupying the twelfth and thirteenth floors of 4 Sutton Place, taken by Mrs. Samuel E. Pryor of Greenwich, Conn., and Jupiter Island, Fla.

Suspects in jewel thieves had top billing in the line-up yesterday morning at Police Headquarters. The first on the calendar before Inspector Joseph Donovan was George Fleming, 38-year-old chauffeur, formerly employed by Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Townsend Jr. of Syosset,

The keynote of the army-dominated Japanese policy toward China, following the capture of the three Wuhan cities [Hankow area], was sounded tonight by the War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Seishiro Itagaki, when he said in a statement:

Several lists of apartment rentals in buildings in Greenwich Village and lower Fifth Avenue were submitted yesterday by brokers. The leasing of a large suite on the East Side also was reported.
