The latter, a unit of ten rooms and four baths in the house at 4 East Seventy-second Street, was taken by Noah MacDowell Jr., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc, brokers.
Mrs. R. Becker leased to Mrs. A. H. Buxbaum for occupancy the dwelling at 316 West 103d Street through Howard H. Bellows, broker. The lessee also bought the furnishings of the house.

John E. Phelan, who was until his retirement in 1928 head of the construction department of the Kroger Grocery'and Baking Company of Cincinnati, died here last night of a heart attack at his home, 37-44 Sixty-first Street, Woodside, Queens. He was 74 years old.

Canada's September imports were valued at $56,411,727, compared with $70,240,465 in September, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Imports from empire countries amounted to $14,900,089, against $21,653,911, and from foreign countries to $41,511,638, against $48,586,554.

If all the money now lost to the State through underassessment of real estate were given to the schools sufficient funds would be available to carry on the needed educational services, speakers at the annual meeting of the New York State Teachers Association declared yesterday.

Following a day of comparatively mild temperatures yesterday, New York was in for a tussle last night and this morning with strong northeast winds that were expected to reach gale force at times but not to compare with the recent hurricane. The outlook was for continued rain today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has been asked by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to set aside its order authorizing an 8 cent fare from Jersey City and Hoboken to the Hudson Terminal in New York City and permit, for an experimental period, a 10 cent fare.
Ways to strengthen the New York Stock Exchange's supervision over its members' financial affairs will be discussed at an important conference this week-end, officials said today.

The tomb of the Empire's Unknown Warrior lying near the west door in the lofty beamed nave of Westminster Abbey may be altered by Armistice Day, 1939. Already an experimental model carried out in wood has been put in place. The model, on the plain lines of the present granite slab,

Indications are this year will pass without an epidemic of infantile paralysis in any part of the country, according to the Public Health Service. Incidence of the disease in recent months was said to have been lower than at any time in the past decade.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday in a condition statement for the quarter ended Sept. 30, net profit of $1,355,980, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividends paid on the $4 convertible preference stock, the profit is equivalent to $1.61 each on 685,749 shares of no-par common stock.

MANHATTAN APPLE, HERMAN (Oct. 12). Estate, less than $500. To Sadie Apple, widow, executrix, 605 W. 170th St. EDWARDS, CATHERINE (Oct. 19). Estate, less than $10,000. To Sarah A. Jones, sister, petitioner, 529 W. 142d St., and William Edwards, brother, 529 W. 142d St., executor, life estates in one-half residue each; three specific bequests. ERON, JOSEPH E. (Sept. 1). Estate, less than $10,000. To Frances Eron, executrix, 55 E. 10th St.

Democratic leaders of the five counties in New York City reported yesterday to Postmaster General James A. Farley, State and national chairman, at a breakfast conference in the Biltmore Hotel that Governor Herbert H. Lehman would receive in the city a plurality ranging from 865,000 to 875,000 votes

Mayor La Guardia of New York told 4,500 public school teachers here last night that "our problem is not how to educate our children, but what to do with them after they are educated." "We are now in a period of transition," he said, "and some day we will work out our problem of what to do with our surplus mankind. In the meantime, in New York,
Stricken by a heart attack while working in his private laboratory, Dr. George Waller O'Grady, head of the Monroe County Bacteriological Laboratory, died today at the age of 63.

A completely revamped Brooklyn College eleven will see action today against the American International College team on Brooklyn's field. After last week's rout by City College, Coach Lou Oshins made five replacements in the line-up.
From noon today until Sunday night, all Turkey is celebrating the fifteenth anniversary of the establishment of the republic, which falls tomorrow.
Reports from 2,500 wholesalers collected by the Department of Commerce and made public today indicated that wholesale trade last month was 13 per cent under similar trade for September, 1937.

The trade balance between the United States and Egypt, which was favorable to Egypt in the first six months of 1937, reversed itself in the first half of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of advices from Cairo.

Dollar sales of 627 wholesalers of clothing and furnishings in the second quarter of this year were 0.2 per cent under sales for the first quarter and 15.9 per cent less than the second period of last year, the Philadelphia office of the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Miss Elinor Engier, daughter on Mrs. Charles H. Engler of South Orange, was married tonight to William White Hibberd, son of Hayward A. Hibberd of Maplewood. The ceremony, in the South Orange Methodist Episcopal Church, was performed by the Rev. Fred E. Miles.

The efforts of reactionary influences in Czechoslovakia, which first emerged after the country's collapse following the Munich decisions, received their first check today in a celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the republic's foundation, which the reactionaries had attempted to hinder.

The estate of the late Alice G. Vanderbilt, widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt, must pay a State transfer tax on $5,285,572 of the principal of a trust fund left to her by her husband, the Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday in upholding a decision by Surrogate James A. Foley.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday postponed until 4 P. M. on Nov. 15 a scheduled hearing on confirmation of the recent foreclosure sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line to a protective committee of Manhattan Railway bondholders at an upset price of $12,500,000.

Carl L. Peirce Jr. of Hubbard Co., Pittsburgh, was elected president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association at the closing session of the annual convention here today. Vice presidents elected were Matthew Porosky, Walter Robbins, C. E. Swartzbaugh, N. G. Symonds and G. C. Thomas.

The Harvard cross-country team, led by Captain Roswell Brayton, swept to its third straight victory today, defeating Holy Cross 21--39. Brayton finished first, John Haley of the Crusaders was second, Dave Simboli of Harvard third, and Pent Tuttle, also of Harvard fourth.

German airplane factories are organized on "a scale beyond anything even considered in the United States," and could produce more than 3,000 planes a month, if necessary, according to Daniel W. Tomlinson, assistant vice president of the Transcontinental and Western Airlines, who returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

District Attorney Edward J. Neary disclosed here today that a bench warrant had been issued for the arrest of Daniel Hogan, 40 years old, who quit his post as village clerk of Massapequa Park, L. I., last July and was last heard of en route to Ireland.

The Very Rev. Milo Hudson Gates, for the last eight years dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, has resumed his duties of administering the cathedral after a six months' leave of absence due to illness.

Triple-header (Alexander Hamilton vs. James Madison, St. John's Prep vs. New Utrecht, Erasmus Hall vs. George Washington), at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, 10:45 A. M., 1 P. M. and 3 P. M., respectively. Fordham Prep vs. All Hallows, at Fordham Field, Third Avenue and Fordham Road, Bronx, 10.

Turpentine firm, 24c bid; no sales; receipts 255 barrels; shipments 1,040 barrels; stock 51,629 barrels. Rosin firm: sales 36; receipts 1,122; shipments 4,966; stock 273,440. Quote: B, $3.95; D, $4; E, $4.25; F, $5.10; G, H, I, K, M, $5.25; N, $5.65; WG, $; WW, X, $6.45. ; WG, $; WW, X, $6.45.
St. Bonaventure defeated Davis and Elkins, 20 to 13, in a hard-fought football game before 2,500 spectators under lights tonight. The winners chalked up a marker in each of the first three periods.

The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission announced medal awards today to twenty-seven persons in widely separated parts of the land for saving, or trying to save, the lives of others in peril. Ten of those honored, including a 15-year-old girl, lost their lives.

In reply to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's attack on Governor Lehman's civil service record, the Lehman-Poletti Independent Citizens Committee made public last night a letter from H. Eliot Kaplan, executive secretary and counsel to the Civil Service Reform Association, commending the Governor's attitude toward the merit system in the past eight years.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $11,851,720 for the twelve months to Sept. 30. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $2.16 a common share, and compared with $13,289,922, or $2.48 a common share, in the previous period.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's Some Count made good today in the Carney Purse, feature event at Laurel. The victor, a son of Reigh Count, acquired by the Chicago stable through the claiming box, put on a stretch rush that could not be denied to bring a scattered backing a $20.30 mutuel.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, now on leave as commanding general of the Second Corps Area, will be honored at a dinner and review of his old regiment, the 165th Infantry (the old Sixty-ninth), at the armory, Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, tonight.

Industrial payrolls in the United States rose 5.5 per cent and employment went up 2.1 per cent in September, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. Its estimates, based on reports from manufacturers in in twenty-five industries, showed gains of 3.6 per cent from August to September in average weekly earnings and of 5.3 per cent in total man-hours worked.

Seventeen-year-old Pan Pihcheng and his bride of four months began the fifth day of a hunger strike today. They hoped to force his wealthy parents to contribute 4,000,000 Chinese dollars [nominally $640,000] to help the Chinese cause against Japan.

Paintings by more than 100 artists, representing sixteen States, will be on show next Wednesday when the 1938 Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Art is opened to the public at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street.
President Roosevelt today appointed John W. Hanes as Under-Secretary of the Treasury to succeed Roswell Magill, who recently resigned the lost to return to his post at Columbia University.

Irving Williams, Suffolk County Welfare Commissioner and county certifying officer for the New York State Unemployment Service, threatened today to resign from the latter post because he had not been consulted before the WPA began to hire nonrelief labor for the $352,000 WPA forest fire control work started this week in the areas struck by the hurricane.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.:

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., announced yesterday that next Tuesday it would open a new link to the Southwest with service for passengers and air mail between Phoenix, Ariz., and Boulder City, Nev., under an award of route made by the Postoffice Department.
Mrs. Edna Dunham Plant of Greenwich and New York won a divorce today from Philip M. Plant, former well-known Broadway figure, on charges of cruelty. Mr. Plant did not appear in court.

There were indications in the Radical Socialist Congress this morning, before its session was interrupted by the fire in this city, that Premier Edouard Daladier's leadership of the party would be seriously challenged at tomorrow's session.
Francis A. Schmidt, Ohio State coach, guest speaker, explained at the Touchdown Club's luncheon at the Midston House yesterday that deception is the keynote of football today.

A memorial mass for Cardinal Hayes, who died Sept. 4, will be offered this morning at 9:30 o'clock in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent. in the Riverdale section.
The Post-Dispatch and the St. Louis unit of the American Newspaper Guild signed an eighteen-month contract today covering editorial and news department employes.

Velvets of the twentieth century were glorified in a revival of the old fetes of the Louis XIV period in France at the annual Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria last night.

Military and naval detachments in this area joined with representatives of patriotic organizations yesterday in celebration of the fiftysecond anniversary of the erection of the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island. Special exercises, which included the cutting of a large birthday cake, were conducted at the base of the statue,

The Dominguez Oil Fields Company, Los Angeles, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 no-par capital shares to be offered for the account of certain stockholders. Smith, Barney Co. and others to be named by amendment to the registration statement will be the underwriters.
Georgetown's undefeated and untied Hoyas converted two breaks into touchdowns tonight to beat Temple, 13 to 0, for their fifth straight victory.

" An Gradh agus an Garda," or "Love and the Civil Guard," said to be the first Irish play to be given in Gaelic in America for thirty years, will be presented tomorrow night at the Hotel Great Northern by the Irish Foundation. The production was directed by Joseph Campbell.

A George III mahogany bookcase brought $700 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries at the auction of property from the estates of Robert Gould Shaw 2d, Mrs. R. Wasserman, Mrs. J. Percy Sabin and others.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on a total of 5,458,600 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 20, as follows: 809-T--Birdseye, 58x42, 265,900 yards; broadcloth, 102x54, white, 451,200 yards; solid colors, 177,700 yards.

The first lesson in a course of grammar and diction for administrative officers and guards at the World's Fair will be held this morning at 9 o'clock under direction of Dr. Walter 0. Robinson, director of an institute of public speaking in Carnegie Hall and a member of the faculty of St. John's University, Brooklyn.

The separation of the electric and transportation properties of the Milwaukee Electric Railway and Light Company was completed today with the transfer of $70,000,000 proceeds of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company's new bonds and notes to redeem the outstanding bonds of Milwaukee Electric Railway and Light and the Lakeside Power plant.

The public utilities still lack the cooperation of the government in developing the utility industry to a point where it can spend normal amounts for new construction, according to the annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company to its employes.

Campbell Mason, 50 years old, of 4 East Twenty-eighth Street, a clerk employed by Stanley Co. of 37 Wall Street, securities dealers, was arrested yesterday at the office of the Attorney General on a Federal warrant charging him with mail fraud.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Oct. 28 unless specified: At Navy Yard, Washington, D. C., Oct. 27: Cuyahoga, Potomac. At San Diego, Oct. 25: Cushing, Perkins, Preston, Smith. At Gibraltar: Claxton, Manley.

Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, will sail for Rome today on the Rex to make a report to the Holy Father on the proceedings of the recent National Eucharistic Congress at New Orleans, at which he was the Papal Legate.

Dr. Preston Pope Satterwhite, who has been spending Autumn at Preston Hall, his place in Great Neck, L. I., will leave today to pass ten days in Louisville, Ky. On his return, he will go to 960 Fifth Avenue for the Winter.

Business men must maintain and strengthen the economic, political and religious systems or be faced with highly centralized Federal control, amounting to dictatorship, H. W. Prentis Jr. today warned as spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers.

The Canadian Choir of Brantford, Ont., consisting of some fifty mixed voices under the leadership of Frederick Lord, gave a concert last night in Town Hall. This was the second appearance of the organization in this city, which it first visited a year ago.

Chinese porcelains, prints' and other works of art were sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $5,772. A Chinese sculptured stone brush holder, Wei, was bought by the Heeramaneck Galleries for $250. Alice B.

The friendly ties between West Point and Notre Dame were commemorated at a reunion in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Notre Dame-Army football game last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, under the auspices of the Notre Dame Club of New York.
General improvement in the business situation in the month ended on Oct. 15 failed to manifest itself in the index prices of farm products, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Reports of rain at one point in Nebraska and a forecast for showers in the West and Southwest led to liquidation of wheat futures by houses with connections in the East and Southwest who were on the buying side recently.

Trading was only fair to slow on all classes except pork which was fairly active while lamb was slow. Market on pork loins fully steady to $1 higher, lamb lower, other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Commissions representing the Protestant Episcopal and the Presbyterian Churches took a "significant" step yesterday toward the eventual union of the two denominations by adopting a platform for the merger at a joint conference at General Theological Seminary in Chelsea Square.

Clemson completed two daring passes in succession for seventy-six yards to defeat Wake Forest, 7 to 0, in a Southern Conference football game tonight. A crowd of about 7,500 watched the game in a cold, steady drizzle.

The retirement of George P. Gardner Sr. from the board of directors of the General Electric Company, at the close of forty-three years of service, was announced yesterday following the regular meeting of the board.

Given favorable weather, Yale and Dartmouth tomorrow will play the twenty-second game of a series dating from 1884 in a Bowl overflowing with spectators. The Athletic Association tonight announced that only 500 reserved seats and a few thousand general admission tickets of the 71,000 capacity were unsold.
Realty trading in Manhattan yesterday included sales of tenements on the East Side and in Harlem. Savings banks and operators figured as the sellers in some of the transactions.

The decrease in sales volume of furniture and house furnishings in representative retail furniture stores in the principal trading areas east of the Mississippi in the third quarter was 15.0 per cent, as compared with 1937, against 34.5 per cent in the second quarter and 31.3 per cent in the first quarter, Arthur Fertig Co., retail advisory service, reported in a bulletin yesterday.

G. W. V. Shaw has been appointed assistant secretary of the Canadian National Railways, with office in Montreal. He has been with the company since 1916 and has been attached to the office of the chairman and president since 1922.

The Catholic Bishops of the United States sent a message of "profound sympathy" today to Cardinal Innitzer of Austria and other Austrian Bishops. Archbishop Joseph F. Rummel of New Orleans signed the cablegram, which was addressed to Cardinal Innitzer. It said:

Joe Turnesa of the Rockville Country Club and Peter Cassella of Malowac were crowned pro-pro Scotch foursome champions today in the tournament sponsored by the metropolitan section of the P: G. A. at the Fairview Country Club.

The marriage of Miss Bianca Marvin Leale of 130 East Sixtyseventh Street, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Medwin Leale of New York and Glen Cove, L. I,, to Alexander G. H. Cerf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Cerf of Montclair, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts declared in a speech here tonight that the Roosevelt administration was dominated by a "reactionary" group bent on hamstringing progressive legislation at every turn.
The Town Council has arranged elaborate plans to celebrate the arrival of the schooner Bluenose, racing champion of the North Atlantic, in its home port early next week.

A catastrophic fire started in the Nouvelles Galeries, a six-story deapartment store in the famous Rue Cannebiere early this afternoon. Within an hour it had spread to Hotel de Noailles where Premier Edouard Daladier and most of the principal delegates to the Radical Socialist Congress were staying, and caused a dramatic suspension of the work of the congress.
Wholesale trade gained momentum last week as reorders on seasonal goods arrived in larger volume, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

Existence of a "Washington-Jersey City axis" because of support given by officials of the Roosevelt Administration to William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate in New Jersey for the United States Senate, who. also has the support of Frank Hague, Mayor of Jersey City, was charged last night by Mr. Ely's Republican opponent, W. Warren Barbour.
James Parmelee Logan, retired editor of The Newark Sunday Call, died last night at his home here of a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

In the presence of the public officials and representatives of the two candidates in Tuesday's Presidential elections, an examining committee has been formed here to investigate the polling, which gave Pedro Aguirre Cerda, Popular Front candidate, a victory over Gustavo Ross, Rightist candidate, by a small margin.
Thomas L. McFadden, orange grower and attorney, today was named president of the newly organized California Citrus Growers League, a fact-finding body for all growers of the State.
A rare public appearance of the Emperor and Empress, each carrying lanterns, tonight stirred the cheers of hundreds of thousands of their subjects in a celebration of the capture of Hankow.

David Van Gelder, treasurer and a director of the Butchers Mutual Casualty Company of New York, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, died Thursday at the York Hospital after a ten-day illness. Mr. Van Gelder, who had been a leader of several trade organizations, lived at 7,210 Colonial Road, Brooklyn. His age was 54.
Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman at a campaign rally here tonight: In a vain effort to belittle the importance of the management of the financial affairs of the

Good-natured "foul" play marked the eleventh annual freshman-sophomore class rush yesterday on the Long Island University athletic field in Brooklyn, where the first year class shed the traditional fetters of underclass servitude by literally mopping up the field with their sophomore rivals.

With $1,400 they were alleged to have obtained Wednesday night by robbing a horse auctioneer, three Negro boys went on a two-dayspending spree that was halted early yesterday morning by detectives. The boys were arrested in a Harlem drug store when they aroused the owner's suspicions by producing two twenty-dollar gold notes.
A 3-to-2 defeat of the Harvard Club, defending champion, at the hands of the New York Athletic Club featured yesterday's play in the Class C division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.
Today's events: Erika Morill, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Wagnerian Festival Singers, McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30 P. M.

When the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church meets for its annual session next Wednesday and Thursday in Memphis, Tenn., it will act on the resignations of ten Bishops. This announcement was made yesterday at the headquarters of the Communion in the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, this city.
The Back-Stage Club, an organization of theatrical performers and producers, will hold its official opening dance of the season tonight in the Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton.

Infidelity actually accounts for only 1.8 per cent of the divorces of couples living in New York State-whereas 70 per: cent are the result of incompatibility, according to the summary of a survey made public yesterday by the National Divorce Reform League.

Six Swiss Army experts headed by Colonel Robert Fierz, chief of ordnance of the Swiss Army, arrived here yesterday on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line to study American aviation. Colonel Fierz said he did not know whether any American planes would be bought either during or after the visit of the mission.

While no official announcement has been made of the purchase of "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" by Samuel Goldwyn from Robert Sherwood, the indications are that the producer has procured the property. Gary Cooper, the proposed star, will leave for Manhattan within a few days to see the play and then will spend some time in the Lincoln country around Springfield, Ill.

Major Gen. Fritz Loeb, who as chief of the Department of Supplies in the Air Ministry was one of the key men in the creation of the German Air Force before he was later transferred to the Economics Ministry, has been recalled to the Air Ministry.

The Italian liner Rex is sailing today for Mediterranean ports. Passengers include Bishop W. R. Griffin, Bishop S. V. Bona, Mgr. Thomas P. Bona, Mgr. Alberto Mella of the Vatican and Mgr. Robert C. Maguire.

Trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 8 was 20.42 per cent of total volume, compared with 21.75 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Instead of "branding" a child with a life-long stigma by sending him to a probationary school, truants, problem pupils and "bad" boys will now- receive remedial treatment in the regular classroom, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday.
Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Senator Robert F. Wagner, Isidor Nagler, Representative James Mead and Luigi Antonini, WEVD, 10 to 11 A. M.

The formal announcement yesterday by the nation's leading utility executives that the utility industry would embark on a construction program aimed at strengthening the national defense was regarded in the financial community as additional evidence of the intention of the industry to meet the Federal Government more than halfway in an effort to bring the five-year-old utility-government controversy to a close.

The conservation work undertaken by the Camp Fire Girls of the country brought them yesterday an offer from the United States Forest Service to dedicate a memorial forest to their organization. The plan was announced at the national council's luncheon meeting yesterday in the Hotel Lafayette, and accepted by Mrs. Lola D. Williams of Dallas, Texas, national president.

Delegates to the convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs turned a neat trick yesterday by tacitly endorsing Magistrate Anna M. Kross for justice of the Supreme Court, in spite of the fact that individual endorsements are illegal under their by-laws.

Organization of the nation's over-the-counter security business into a self-regulatory body as efficient, closely woven and comprehendable as that yet achieved by any national Stock Exchange was pictured to investment bankers here today by George C. Mathews, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Francis A. Bonner of Blair, Bonner Co., Chicago.

The announcement that American Airlines is moving its main repair shops and business offices from Chicago to North Beach Airport underlines the success of Mayor La Guardia in his long struggle to make this city one of the great air centers of the world.

Funds for the erection of Silliman College, the tenth at Yale University under the college plan for undergraduate residence adopted fifteen years ago, have been provided by a bequest of Frederick W. Vanderbilt, who died June 29, it was announced today by President. Charles Seymour of the university.

Stressing the disastrous effect of truck competition on the nation's railroads and the alleged unfairness of the present rate structure, the railroad securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association urged today the creation of a central truck subsidiary for all carriers and legislation permitting the carriers to adopt the so-called agreed-charge rule of rate-making to enable them to compete more equitably with other forms of transportation.
For the first time this season the New York University football team will take the field on the short end of overwhelming odds when it tangles with Ohio State this afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

Miss Brenda Diana Duff Frazier, debutante daughter of Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss, entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Oak Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Among her guests were the Misses Elvira Fairchild, Anne Wisner, Fernanda Munn, Marion Oates, Jane Will and Helen Stedman;

President Roosevelt told his press conference today that his special fact-finding board seeking to avert a nation-wide railroad strike against a 15 per cent wage cut would file its report with him at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow.

James J. Loftis, Democratic candidate for Congress in 1930 against Frederick M. Davenport, died suddenly today of a heart attack. Mr. Loftis was a coal dealer, a director of the Citizens Safe Deposit Company of Utica, the Citizens First National Bank of Frankfort, a member of Lake Placid Club, Yahnundasis Golf Club of Utica and many other .organizations.
From somewhere beyond the Japanese lines, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek today proclaimed continued Chinese resistance and expressed the hope of "luring" the enemy into Western China.

An investing client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, bought from the Manufacturers Trust Company the four-story apartment house at 39-44 Twenty-fourth Street, Long Island City, for cash above a first mortgage of $59,500.

Bishop William T. Manning will ye make a "statement of great importance" at the 11 o'clock service tomorrow morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine concerning the opening of the interior of the cathedral before the start of the World's Fair.

Lowell Textile's undefeated, but once-tied football team, a 3 to 2 favorite, will meet City College at Lewisohn Stadium this afternoon in the seventh meeting of the gridiron rivalry between the two schools.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, will visit Washington as a guest of the War Department to attend official Armistice Day ceremonies, military headquarters State Department officials may re- that it announced today.

Mrs. Annie Phelps Brown, wife of Frederick L. Brown, a retired executive of the New York Life Insurance Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J., at the age of 74.

The South Shore of .Long Island and several points along the New Jersey coast from Sandy Hook to Barnegat Bay seem to be producing a number of striped bass for the surf casters. Another report comes from Cape Cod to the effect that the stripers are unusually plentiful there.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 22 amounted to 705,628 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,984 cars, or 2.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;

Shipping men and traffic experts from scattered sections of the country will gather here next week to attend the National Foreign Trade Convention, which opens a threeday session at the Hotel Commodore on Monday morning.

Plans of major utility systems operating in the nation's strategic war material centers to place "immediate orders" for new equipment of 1,000,000 kilowatts generating capacity were announced today by President Roosevelt's National Defense Power Committee as the result of a series of conferences it has been holding with representatives of the industry.

The Commercial Travelers Auxiliary of the State Pharmaceutical Association has adopted a resolution of support for the drug industry's participation in the World's Fair. Louis Barish, 92 Liberty Street, has been appointed district representative in this area of the John H. McGowan Company, Cincinnati.

The Hamburg - American liner friend Deutschland, which was hove to at sea from 8 P. M. Tuesday until after 5 A. M. Wednesday because of a fire in her No. 2 hold, two decks below the third-class passenger deck, docked last night at her pier at West Forty-fourth Street with no visible sign of damage.

Elmer F. Andrews, wage-hour administrator, reversed himself today and said that if more than 50 per cent of a department store's business crossed State lines the store was subject to the Wage-Hour Act.
Miguel Lopez Pumarejo, who has been Minister of Colombia here since April 15, 1935, presented his credentials to President Roosevelt today as the first Ambassador of his country to the United-States.
Barklie McK. Henry, president of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, announced yesterday the election of four members to the board of managers of the organization.
Frederic Worthen Frost, assistant attorney of the Third Avenue Railway system of New York from 1924 to 1935, died last night at his home here after an illness of five weeks. He was 68 years old.

While Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain still pondered ways and means of speeding up British rearmament, the National Executive of the Labor party issued a manifesto tonight flatly opposing conscription "for armed forces, for passive defense or industry."

Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for Kings County judge, declared last night in a campaign speech that an alleged highway robber was freed illegally this week in Kings County Court by direction of the judge.
A crowd of 70,000 is expected to watch Penn and Navy play the twentythird game in their fifty-year-old football series tomorrow at Franklin Field. The game will start at 2 P. M.
John Henry Lewis, holder of the light-heavyweight championship of the world, successfully repulsed the title bid of Al Gainer in a fifteenround fight at the New Haven Arena tonight.

A four-day auction of antiques, art objects and home furnishings of the late M. J. and 0. P. Van Sweringen, said to have been collected at an original cost exceeding $1,000,000, ended today with all articles sold for $89,287.50.

AHLES--Henry, on Oct. 28, 1938, at his residence, 1,323 Theriot Ave., Beloved husband of Fredric and father of Robert, Charles, No. 244, F. and A. M. Religious service at his home Sunday, 8 P. M.; Masonic Service 8:15 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery Monday at 2 P. M.

The American Public Health Association closed its annual meeting today leaving to Federal authorities the task of winning the organized private practitioners of the American Medical Association to the new deal in public health which was approved in full here yesterday.

Memel's reawakening struggle for autonomy finds sympathetic support in the German press but official comment so far is extremely cautious. Informed quarters here believe that the Reich government does not intend to precipitate an acute situation in the Memel sector pending

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 27: COLONELS ??arman, S., C.A.C., 15 days' leave. Nov. 1. collins, L. P. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, 1st Corps Area, Boston, Mass., to Assistant Commandant, F. A. School, Ft. Sill, Okla.
Cooler weather brought some seasonal improvement in local retail trade during the week, although the percentage of decline under a year ago probably did not change much from the previous week.

About 900 women attended a reception and tea yesterday afternoon at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, in honor of Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey and the wives of other Republican candidates. In addition to Mrs.

The Anglo - Czechoslovak and Prague Credit Bank has been authorized by the New York State Banking Department to establish an agency in this city, it was announced yesterday by George Boochever, an attorney, who has been designated agent for the bank here.

The 155-acre farm of the late Jesse R. Salmon, in Sandyston, Sussex County, N. J., has been sold by Mr. Salmon's estate to Calvin A. Agar. In the sale Jacob Schmeider acted as attorney for the seller and Wayland Bernard represented the buyer.

French Lane, Chicago Tribune sports writer since 1921, died today in Evanston Hospital at the age of 48. He had been suffering some time from a complcation of ailments. Mr. Lane, who wrote of many sports, had specialized on horse racing.

Legal action was begun yesterday by the Department of Agriculture to force three milk handlers supplying milk to the metropolitan area to comply with the Federal-State milk marketing orders. The government filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York to compel the three handlers to pay

The Red Hook and Queensbridge low-cost housing developments will be completed at about one-quarter less than the original estimated cost, Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, disclosed yesterday.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed New York paying agent, exchange agent and registrar for $80,000,000 Public Service Company of Northern Illinois first-mortgage bonds 3 1/2 per cent series, due in 1968.

The Rev. Leslie W. Sprague, a retired Congregational minister who was regarded as an expert on fund campaigns for institutions, died here last night after an illness of ten months. He was 69 yeas old.

The Adelphi Academy and St. Paul's School football teams, both boasting unbeaten records, met yesterday at the Adelphi Field and the game resulted in a 6-all tie. The former had won four successive contests, while the Long Islanders had triumphed in two two starts.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Vahlsing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Vahlsing of Forest Hills, Queens, to Henry Frelinghuysen Schenck, son of Mrs. Henry F. Schenk of Flemington, N. J., and the late Mr. Schenk, took place yesterday afternoon in the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy, Forest Hills.
The sudden mass expulsion of Polish Jews from Germany came today at a time when from three directions rays of hope seemed to be dawning for other refugees rendered homeless by Nazi persecution.

The fiftieth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners will be held in the Roosevelt Hotel, New Orleans, Nov. 15 to 18. Among the subjects to be discussed will be the natural gas industry,
Big Carl Nery, Duquesne tackle, played a lot in the backfield tonight and as a result his team scored a 14-6 upset victory over the University of Detroit at Forbes Field.

Superior Judge Thomas P. White announced today that negotiations are under way for a post-season football game between Santa Clara and Fordham to be played in the Memorial Coliseum here Sunday, Jan. 1.

Detectives of the Mercer Street station arrested three men early yesterday on charges of assault and robbery as a result of a hold-up Thursday night in which they were alleged to have taken a truck loaded with $15,000 of knit goods from two watchmen at 112 West Twentyfifth Street.

Aubrey Williams, Acting Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, instructed tonight the New York office of the WPA to ascertain from Representative John J. O'Connor facts in connection with his charge that political coercion of relief workers is occurring in his district.

Tonight the Krimsky brothers bring into the American Musio Hall, 141 East Fifty-fifth Street, their latest chrome entitled "The Girl From Wyoming," and otherwise described as "the sultry saga of a Harvard graduate trapped by sex in the purple sage."
ANNAPOLIS TODAY, by Kendall Banning. (Funk Wagnalls, $2.50.) A companion to the author's "West Point Today." BANBURY BOG, by Phoebe Atwood Taylor. (Norton, $2.) A mystery novel.
Farmers' cooperatives did a total business of $2,400,000,000 in the last year, an increase of 14 per cent over the previous year, it was shown today in a survey by the Farm Credit Administration.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Last Saturday THE TIMES printed a letter from Mr. Harold W. Strauss of New Brunswick, N. J., who had written to deplore "the age and physical condition of the officials" handling varsity football games and to tell with dissatisfaction of his feeling "that too many of them just don't like to hang' up their shoes and call it quits when they should."

Francis L. Whitmarsh, president and director of Francis H. Leggett Co., was elected yesterday a director of the Irving Trust Company, it was announced by the bank. Mr. Whitmarsh became president of Francis H. Leggett Co., wholesale grocers, in 1936, succeeding his father, the late Theodore F. Whitmarsh.
Stocks eased and closed generally lower, following irregular gains, in less active trading; turnover, 1.563,010 shares. All groups of bonds closed steady and mixed; transactions, $9,024,750.

Milk delivery men following routes that cover the entire city in the early hours of the day were praised yesterday as "a splendid auxiliary to the Fire Department" by Commissioner John J. McElligott when he pinned Pasteur hero medals of the Milk Industry Foundation on three such drivers who had distinguished themselves in fires.

Manuel Trucco, Ambassador of Chile, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Sefiorita Rebeca Trucco, to Robert Knowlton of Boston, son of Mrs. Richard Burleson of Honolulu and the late Frank Knowlton.

BOXING Ridgewood Grove, St. Nicholas Avenue and Palmetto Street, Brooklyn ......8:30 P. M. CROSS-COUNTRY Quadrangular meet. Columbia, Yale, Dartmouth and Cornell, at Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and 242d Street. 11 A. M.

James H. Fay announced yesterday that the had begun suit to restrain Representative John J. O'Connor, his opponent for Representative in the Sixteenth district, from using the word "Democrat" or any of its variations in his campaign literature or banners.

Immigration Commissioner James L. Houghteling refused today to drop deportation proceedings against fifteen aliens now held at Ellis Island after trying to return to the United States from service in the Spanish war.

Admiral William H. Standley, director of foreign participation in the World's Fair, reconsidered his resignation from that post late yesterday afternoon, following an urgent personal appeal by Grover Whalen, president of the corporation. He will leave the office in Flushing Meadow Park on Monday, as he intended, but now plans to return next Spring.

Showing fine form, Manhattan's football players sped through a signal practice this afternoon at Civic Stadium as they concluded preparations for tomorrow's contest with a threatening Canisius eleven.

Production of automobile manufacturers established a new high record for 1938 this week for the second successive week, Ward's Automotive Reports noted today. Estimating the period's output at 73,335 cars and trucks, Ward's declared that further advances in production were expected because "field stocks were still at exceptionally low levels."

Formation of the Independent Veterans' League for the Re-election of Representative Bruce Barton, Republican, in the Seventeenth Congressional District, was announced yesterday by Harold F. Stone, chairman, and Llewellyn G. Ross, secretary.
The State Banking Department announced today that a license had been issued to the. Bank Polska Kasa Opieki, Spolka Akcyjna of Warsaw, Poland, to operate an agency at 32 Pearl Street, Manhattan.

An application by the Savings Banks Trust Company on behalf of all the mutual savings banks of New York State for permission to invest in certain telephone, oil and tobacco debentures that are not on the legal list has been received by William R. White, State Banking Superintendent, it was announced yesterday.

Barringer High School's eleven scored a 13-to-6 victory over Central High tonight to remain in first place in the Newark High Schools Football League. The Blues scored once in the first period and tallied the deciding touchdown in the final session.

The football play which critics said could not happen occurred today in the annual Army-Yale jayvee game. In the first period Army, after holding for downs on their 1-yard line, kicked. The high wind blew the ball back over their own goal line, where it was recovered by Theirlann of Yale for a touchdown.
Genoa bade farewell today to 13,000 colonists sailing for African Libya, which the Fascist Grand Council this week ordered changed from a colony to a provincial district.

Store locations in retail shopping areas continued yesterday to play an important part in the leasing of business space in buildings in Manhattan. A large shop for the sale of men's shoes will be established in the office building at 400 Madison Avenue, where a store has been leased for a term of years to Lefcourt Shoes.

With cheers of a spontaneous student rally ringing in their ears, Harvard's football players left the Briggs baseball cage tonight and dispersed to a wait tomorrow the renewal of the ancient string of games with Princeton.

An overwhelming majority of Britons not only are against giving back to Germany any of her former colonies but say they would actually fight rather than hand them over, it is revealed in a survey just completed by the British Institute of Public Opinion, affillate of Dr. George Gallup's American Institute.

The Chaco Peace Conference announced today the appointment of a mixed commission to survey and mark the frontier between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco in accordance with the recently ratifled peace treaty.

A spokesman for the State election bureau estimated at $700,000 today the cost of publishing, on a State-wide basis, the abstract of fifty-seven proposed amendments to the organic law on which voters will pass judgment Nov. 8.

The recent hurricane cost the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad $3,386,000 in damages and lost revenue, the company announced yesterday. Property damaged to the extent of about $421,000 included in this total will not be replaced.

A young patrolman from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn pointed to Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday as the man he saw prowling around the station house record room early on the morning the 7,200 arrest records were slit from their bindings and stolen from the store room.

The persistent weakness in sterling exchange, despite its recovery from the panicky price of $4.60 during the September war scare, has generally been assumed, in banking circles, to mean continuing remittance of European capital to this country.

A crowd of 33,000 is expected to pack Baker Field this afternoon to witness the twenty-fifth renewal of the Columbia-Cornell football rivalry. The Ithacans, with a triumph of 14 to 0 last year, also have an edge in the series which goes back to 1899.

Thomas E. Dewey accused Governor Herbert H. Lehman tonight of making political capital out of the milk problem and taking credit for legislation incorporated in the Rogers-Allen law on bargaining agreements between farmers nd distributors, which was inspired "by the farmers themselves," and, he said, "passed by the Republican legislature."
William R. Cantrell, a commission broker and member of the New York Produce Exchange, died last night at his home after two years' illness. He was born in New York.

The battle of zeroes will be resumed in Pitt Stadium tomorrow before Pittsburgh's record sports throng of 75,867 when the Fordham Ram clashes with the mighty Panthers in the fourth game of a series that has produced that gridiron phenomenon, three successive scoreless ties.

College Ave (9-2434). e s, 311 ft n of 166th St. 38x100; Katherina Adam to Julia Kampf, 23-67 Kindred St, Astoria, L. I. Arnow Ave (16-4527), s s, 37 ft e of Bouck Ave, 38x75; Gaetano Noto to Louis Tenore. 674 Rhinelander Ave. Bruner Ave, 3,021 (16-4775); Mary Freese to Harry Jones, 758 E 222d St.

AMHERST VS. MASS. STATE--Amethysts are sometimes found in a mass state, so to speak; in conglomerate huddles. Amethyst is a variety of quartz with a luscious purple tint. A vote of amethystine hue for Amherst.
Oswald Pirow, South African Defense Minister, will fly to Salamanca tomorrow after a "good-will" visit in Lisbon.
Curiosity about Wage-Hour Administrator Andrews continues to gnaw at one. Is that an armchair or a sofa on which he is cuddled up while speaking to the newspaper men, with his feet on the cushions?

The Securities and Exchange Commission has received the following applications from New York for registrations as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market. Symbols: S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation:

" ALL the intellectual curiosity of the Renais sance," Reinach said, "its dreams of glory and of infinite progress, its enthusiasm for science and for beauty, were combined with many other attributes of genius in Leonardo."
Circuit Judge William V. Brothers ordered former Mayor William Hale Thompson today to turn over to the Red Cross $72,794 collected in 1927 for the relief of Mississippi River flood victims.

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday that net income in the three months ended Sept. 30 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges was $1,112,812.

Faith in a science of society has not penetrated to the man in the street, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University declared yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt on the second and final day of the seventh annual conference under the joint auspices of the Educational Records Bureau,

Addressing a vast crowd gathered in the Piazza Venezia to celebrate the sixteenth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome, Premier Benito Mussolini pointed this morning to what he called a patch of blue on the political horizon growing larger and more promising.
The Soviet Government, to safeguard pilots' lives, will be "extremely severe" henceforth toward permitting record-flight attempts.

First Sergeant Chester A. Reinhart, one of the last enlisted members of the Sixteenth Infantry Regiment, who served under General Pershing during the Mexican punitive expedition in 1915, will be accorded a retirement review at 9 o'clock this morning on Governors Island.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The demand for wool has continued of fair proportions again this week and the position of the market is rather better than a week ago, with prices showing a tendency against the buyer, both here and in the country.

Alfred M. Lilienthal, president of the First Voters League, announced yesterday that a suit by the First Voters League of America to prevent use of the name had been abandoned by failure of the complainant organization to file a bond to cover costs.
According to The Daily Express the German Government has decided to encourage British tourist traffic by lifting the order imposed May 21 requiring Visas.

B. Howell Griswold Jr., chairman of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., has appointed a special drafting committee, headed by Nevil Ford, New York, to prepare the conference for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a national securities association of over-thecounter brokers and dealers under the Maloney act.

An increase in labor costs caused by the Social Security Act, the new Wage and Hour Law and other New Deal legislation, has placed such a burden upon the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation that some form of mechanized delivery of messages may have to be devised, Raymond C. Kramer, reorganization trustee of the corporation, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe on a reorganization plan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ever since the commencement of the campaign, I and my family, comprising four votes, have paid strict attention to all being said over the radio by Mr. Dewey. We were firm in our belief that he would conduct a clean and intelligent campaign based solely upon the issues involved.

The John J. Kennedy Building Corporation sold to a client of Henry Benis, broker, the eightroom dwelling at 5,037 Fieldston Road, in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx. The house is on a plot 50 by 130 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $12,000.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that the general level of farm prices remained unchanged in the month ended on Oct. 15, despite general improvement in the business situation. The level stood at 95 per cent of the pre-war mark on Sept. 15 and Oct. 15, compared with 112 per cent a year ago.

Mrs. Isabel Dorney of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabel Rita McCafferty, to William H. Boettger, son of Mrs. Henry W. Boettger of Mamaroneck and the late Mr. Boettger.

New bond offerings this week fell slightly under the mark of last week, which was the largest since June 3, but still held above the $100,000,000 level. Two large public utility and industrial issues combined to swell the total for the week ended yesterday to $125,737,500, compared with $143,222,350 in the preceding period and $18,489,000 offered for the corresponding week last year.

Although holders of December contracts reduced their obligations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the supply proved less than the demand from trade sources and the near months advanced into new high territory.
Fred Kohler, motion picture character actor, died in his sleep of a heart attack early today at the age of 49. He was counted as one of the oldest "heavies" on the screen in point of service.

Harry Bolens, Democratic candiate for Gornernor, today asked the Federal prosecutor to take "legal proceedings" against Governor Philip F. La Follette on the ground of "misuse of the mails" and against those who, he said, had coerced WPA workers to "vote the Prograssive ticket."

Pitt's cross-country team might have been trying to foretell tomorrow's happenings as four blue-shirted Panther harriers swept hand-in-hand like a wave of interference in leading their team-mates to a perfect score of 15-40 in a cross-country run with Fordham today.

John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, pictured the Republican party as the true exponent of political liberalism in a speech tonight before 250 members of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women at the Garden City Hotel. He was introduced by J. Russel Sprague, county leader.

German artillery of all calibers is firing on the former Czechoslovak fortifications around Pilsen and elsewhere in Southern Bohemia to test their strength. For the same purpose German airplanes have been bombing the concrete shelters constructed by the Czechoslovak Army.
Mrs. William Molyneux, for many years active in the Daughters of the Sons of St. George and in Baptist Church circles, died here yesterday at her home at the age of 91.

Mrs. Mary Sullivan, 63, had permission today to continue bag-punching as exercise to help her arthritis, notwithstanding objections of her South Boston neighbors who did not like the noise. Major Peter Borre, a master appointed by Suffolk Court to hear their objections, reported that the noise "does not in fact constitute a disturbance or a nuisance."

Several parcels of vacant land in Bay Ridge were among the Brooklyn properties reported yesterday by brokers to have been sold. A plot 100 by 200 feet on the northwest corner of Eleventh Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street was sold by Mary Blanchard for improvement with six one-family houses to a client of John B. Swift, broker.

Extensive advertising in newspapers throughout the country is scheduled by cranberry packers to dispose of a crop only about half as large as a year ago, which will be sold to consumers at sharply increased prices, it was learned yesterday.

Miss Charlotte McCall of Bayberry Lane gave a tea today for Miss Gwyn Grant, whose marriage to Roland Ruutz-Rees will take place on Nov. 5. Among the guests were Mrs. Coulter D. Huyier, Mrs. Alex L. Dommerich Jr., Mrs. John White, Mrs.

Commencing on Monday, all of the offices and departments of Rockefeller Center, Inc., will be concentrated on the third floor of the new Associated Press Building, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets. The corporation thus will become the first tenant of its twelfth building.

Retailers of anthracite in Manhattan and the Bronx will make a 50-cent increase on the egg, stove and nut sizes and a 25-cent increase on pea coal, effective Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday. Brooklyn and Queens dealers will put similar increases into effect on Nov. 7.
The American destroyers Claxton and Manley arrived this evening from Villefranche. They are expected to sail for America tomorrow, after serving a year in European waters.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By JOSEPH ELMO, foreman. 3,175 Grand Concourse-Liabilities, $4,338; no assets except insurance. PETER L. ENGEL, salesman, 84 W. 188th St.-Liabilities, $2,806; no assets except insurance. SHIRLEY KATZ, resident buyer, 1,450 Broadway, residing at 200 W. 86th St.Liabilities. $4.569: assets. S2,643.

The second of a series of rallies designed to bring football back to Long Island University was held yesterday at the school's University Hall, and 300 enthusiastic students decided to hold a ballot next week asking the student body whether they would be willing to shoulder an annual $5 athletic tax.
Income-tax claims of $55,973 against William A. Hines and of $59,742 against Ernest W. Marlow, Mr. Hines's partner in a New York City law firm, were erased today by the Board of Tax Appeals.
Captain Johnny Drebinger, Penn's sophomore star, won the five-mile cross-country race in 26:49 today as his team lost, 20-43, to a strong Princeton outfit that annexed the next nine places.

Inwood Ave (11-2859); e s, 175 s of Mt. Eden Ave, 80x100; Leonor Realty Corp to Reconstruction Finance Corp; extends mtg to Aug. 15, 1943, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $40,000. Spuyten Duyvil Parkway 4,590 (13-3414c); Carroll Management Corp to Goldie Schack, 100 Riverside Dr; installments, 6 per cent; $15,000.

The housing amendment-No. 4will bring the State of New York into line with what is now a national movement, nonpartisan in its nature, to provide better homes for the-lower income groups in our population.

The Aulick-Johnson Memorial Cup, awarded annually to the fraternity at Columbia College foremost in scholarship, athletics and extra-curricular activities, has been won this year by Zeta Beta Tau, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday. Alpha Sigma Phi was the runner-up.

MANHATTAN CAMPBELL, LOUISE de R. (May 21, 1937). Gross assets, $164,730; net, $128,546. To Ella Porter, sister, personalty and life estate in one-eighth residue; John L. de Ruyter Jr., and Michael ??e Ruyter, grandsons, equal interests in seven-eighths residue and in one-eighth remainder. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $99,649. Albert Ross, attorney, 285 Madison Ave.

Helen Jean Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Truxton B. Pratt of this place, was married this afternoon to John Burns Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Grant of Rutherford, N. J., formerly of Bridgeport, Conn.

Gilbert Colgate, treasurer of the Citizens Committee for the Re-election of Representative John J. O'Connor in the Sixteenth Congressional District, filed yesterday with the Board of Elections a financial statement showing receipts of $8,301.15 and expenditures of $6,773.84.

A plan that may completely change the hitherto hostile relations between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers of America and pave the way for the unionization of 350,000 employes of 6,000 auto parts manufacturers "at one fell swoop" is now being prepared by a union committee and
Naval circles admitted today that the government was speeding preparations for the ordering of two 8,000ton cruisers by the middle of next month.
William Mayo Atkinson, Newark attorney, died here today at the Newark Hospital after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.
The Rev. Joseph A. Sammon, former teacher of Latin, English and mathematics at St. Joseph's College, Princeton, died in St. Joseph's Hospital here today at the age of 49.

Department-store sales during the week ended Oct. 22 were 9 per cent lower than during the corresponding week last year and for the four weeks ended Oct. 22 were 13 per cent lower than for the corresponding period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Treasury Procurement Division today announced awards of contracts from bids opened Oct. 27 on a total of 195,000 yards of textiles, for shipment by Nov. 10, as follows: 808-TW Type A chambray, 45,000 yards, Texas Textile Mills;

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today the allotments in connection with the offering last Monday of an issue of 7/8 per cent three-year notes, Series P, of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in exchange for $298,972,000 of Series K 1 1/2 per cent notes of the corporation maturing on Dec. 15.

The annual meetings of the National and American Baseball Leagues will be held at the WaldorfAstoria on Dec. 13 and 14, it was announced yesterday. The arrangements this year are unlike those of previous sessions when both circuits met on the same days but at different hotels.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 26: CAPTAIN Wainwright, D. B., Jr.. Bureau S. A., Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., to Asiatic Station.

Engagements of $1,505,000 gold in England for shipment here-$635,000 yesterday and $870,000 at some previous date-were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Roughly $27,000,000 gold was understood to have been landed here from England yesterday, of which nearly $25,000,000 consisted of "secret" official shipments from foreign stabilization funds to our fund.

President Roosevelt assured Dr. Hu Shih, who presented his credentials as the new Ambassador of China at the White House this afternoon, that the United States would continue to advocate observance of international law and orderly processes in international relations.

Amendment of the Wagner Labor Relations Act to provide guarantees for industrial management against "continuing industrial warfare" was proposed today by Donald R. Richberg, former National Recovery Administrator, after a luncheon conference with President Roosevelt.

The Feast of Christ the King will be celebrated tomorrow in all Roman Catholic churches. Reformation Sunday will be commemorated in all Lutheran churches. The day is World Wide Temperance Sunday and there will be anti-aleohol lessons in the Sunday schools.
Cotton-mill activity increased last week. Daily average operations declined, however, but less than anticipated on the basis of seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 113.8 from 109.9.

Paul C. Lentz, a sophomore at the American University, Washington, was selected as. winner of the regional finals of the national oratorical contest sponsored by the National Young Republican Federation tonight at the Essex House.

In the eleven years from July 1, 1927, to July 1, 1938, the State of North Carolina has reduced its bonded indebtedness by $85,565,346, including the reserve of $30,771,320 now on hand in its sinking fund, according to the Budget Bureau and State Treasurer's office. This reduction was at the average rate of $7.776.667 a year.

Operators of motor trucks engaged in interstate commerce over New York highways were warned yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, that today is the last day for filing applications for permits or certificates if they desire to continue in business.

Faculty members of the Berkeley Institute, 181 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, give a dinner at the school last night to Miss Elizabeth Musgrave on her twentieth anniversary as head of the lower school of the institute.

George J. Byrne, former vice president of A. Robinson, Inc., once vice president of Harry Thoens Co., Inc., and assistant vice president of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation, has been named vice president of Fish Marvin, effective Oct. 31, 1938.

A contempt of court action will be brought against Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials if they ignore Federal Judge William Clark's ruling upholding the right of the C. I. O. to hold meetings in Jersey City parks and instead deny permits for the meetings on the strength of a recent State Supreme Court decision,

Matthew M. Casey, a captain in the Fire Department, died early today in a twoalarm fire which destroyed the 63year-old City Hall and damaged a neighboring church at an estimated total loss of upward of $260,000.

The championship for the year among the timber-toppers will very likely be decided today with the running of the New Jersey Hunt Cup race at the .final day of the meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds on the Froh-Heim estate of E. B. Schley at Far Hills, N. J.

Lou Ambers, starting his campaign to regain the lightweight title, scored a technical knockout over Steve Halaiko of Auburn in the third round of a scheduled tenround bout before a crowd of 2,000 tonight.

Torrential rains in all parts of Nicaragua have caused the rivers to overflow, damaging plantations and drowning cattle. The Tuma River rose fifty feet after a fall of twenty-seven inches of rain in twenty-four hours.

Mrs. Mary C. Newell, a fullblooded Cheyenne Indian, who was known professionally as Princess Chinquilla, died in her home, 146-12 157th Street, Idlewild, Queens, on Thursday night. She was the leader of the movement that resulted in the establishment as a recognized holiday of Indian Day a few years ago. Her home had been the gathering place of members of an Indian society on that day.
Mr. and Mrs. Evans Dick of Boston have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Dick, to Gardiner Pier, son df Mr. and Mrs. Roy Pier of New York and Hewlett, L. I.

Political organization by employes of State and local governments to insure for them privileges on a par with those accorded to labor in private industry was urged last night by John Brophy, national director of the C. I. O., at a general meeting of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America in Carnegie Hall, preliminary to the opening of the organization's first State convention today.

Cases in downtown Traffic Court since last Jan. 1 passed the 150,000 mark yesterday when Magistrate August Dreyer disposed of 1,203 charges. Only one person was sent to jail, and he for one day in default of a $1 fine.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous alterations in Manhattan and for dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens. The plans follow: Manhattan Alterations 97th St, 154 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Choice Realty Corp, 50 W 158th St, owner; J. J. Gloster, architect; cost, $10,000.

Capitanzing on a break in the first quarter for a touchdown and then adding the extra point, the Poly Prep eleven topped its traditional borough rival, Brooklyn Prep, 7 to 6, at Boys High Field yesterday. It was the seventeenth meeting between the schools in a series Which was inaugurated in 1909.
Real estate taxes for the second half of 1938 are payable not later than midnight Monday, according to a warning issued yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer.

The naivete of Katherine Moog, called by the government as a witness against three prisoners accused of espionage, prompted Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday to declare before the jury that he found it hard "to believe" her story.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced tonight that the Department of Justice and the Canadian Government were investigating an "apparent" violation of the United States Neutrality Law in the transshipment of approximately forty American planes from Canada to Spain.

The candidacies of Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross and Samuel Null for Justices of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District have been endorsed by the Bronx County Bar Association, it was announced yesterday at Mrs. Kross's campaign headquarters.
Joseph Henry Dillon, former member of the Quebec Legislature and Minister without Portfolio in the Taschereau Cabinet, died at his home today after a short illness. He was 58 years old.

Henry Clay Rood Jr., Eastern sales manager for the Northern Engineering Works, with New York offices at 30 Church Street, died last night at his home here after a two-month illness. He was 46 years old.

Specializing in placement of large blocks of securities with foreign and domestic investment trusts, the New York Stock Exchange firm of Arthur Wiesenberger Co. will commence business on Nov. 1. Arthur Wiesenberger, originator and operating vice president of the Allied Stores Corporation and for five years associated with Distributors Group, Inc.,

Looking younger than ever but with her usual exuberance somewhat restrained by Director Carl Boese, the popular Lucie Englisch is back on the screen of the Eightysixth Street Casino Theatre in a mildly amusing, A B C production called- "Der Klapperstorchverband" (The Stork Society). The society has to do with increasing the population of the Reich. and Lucie proves to be its most prolific member by becoming the mother of twins.

Mrs. Doris Kenyon Sills, actress, concert singer and author and former wife of the late Milton Sills, motion-picture star of the silent films, was married here yesterday morning to Albert D. Lasker of Chicago and this city, one time chairman of the United States Shipping Board.

The war that did not break out over the amputation of the Sudetenland from Czechoslovakia is hardly likely to occur over the Hungarian demands for a smaller slice of Czech territory. The claims of Hungary have more justification than those of Germany, but they are not supported by the force or the threat whereby Hitler was able to work his will.

Deaths Announced Retired Engineer. of Steamer William P. Lawless, formerly a member of Engine 51, residing at 407 Woodstock Ave., Tompkinsville, S. I., died Oct. 26. Funeral will take place from Cooke's Funeral Parlor, 190th Street and Jerome Ave., Bronx, at 10 A. M., Oct. 29. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. No escort desired.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that common shareholders of the Richmond Radiator Company will receive the right to subscribe at par to tenyear 5 per cent convertible debentures of the company, due in 1948, in the ratio of $1 of debentures for each common share held.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Medieval Sculpture: The Dark Ages," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; "Durer's Woodcuts and Engravings," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; Medieval painting (survey of collections), Harry D. M. Grier, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

Cheshire Academy's football team, undefeated and unscored upon in its first three games, succumbed to a heavier, harder-hitting Columbia freshman eleven at Baker Field yesterday, 6-0. It was the second victory in three starts for the Lion yearlings.

With the present French and British Governments committed to the proposition of reaching an understanding with the dictatorships and with authoritarian and totalitarian ideas spreading throughout Europe and the world, German propaganda concentrates its fire today on the American Government in general and on President Roosevelt in particular.

Governor Lehman, in a campaign speech here tonight, gave what he called a "lesson in finance" to Thomas E. Dewey to prove that the State budget had been honestly balanced, that the State funded debt increased only $63,000,000 instead of the $200,000,000 charged, and that the State's credit was as good as that "of any political unit in the world."

One issue on which all parties and all candidates in this State are agreed is the desirability of preserving the system of social security which was established in 1935. In no quarter is it proposed to repeal or even to amend, in so far as their essential purposes are concerned, either the national or the State laws providing for old-age annuities, unemployment insurance and other benefits to those in need.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night gave the season's first performance of Michel Fokine's "Petrushka," at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Leon Massine, Alexandra Danilova and Frederic Franklin in the chief roles, and Efrem Kurtz conducting Stravinsky's marvelous score.

Miss Margaret Mesick Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel C. R. Palmer of this city, was married this evening to Charles Everitt Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Duncan, also of New Rochelle, in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Japan warned France yesterday to cease furnishing arms to China by way of French IndoChina, declaring that otherwise China, declaring that otherwise "self-defense." It was indicated that a reply would soon be made to the United States note demanding the Open Door in China. Former Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita, regarded as a moderate on China, was renamed to that post. [Page 1.]

Germany began a mass deportation of Polish Jews yesterday because of a new law in Poland barring re-entry after today to Poles living abroad who had not had their passports revalidated. From 4,000 to 18,000 were said to have been arrested and many were started for the frontier or were put across it.

New York's annual football feast--the Army-Notre Dame game-is just around the corner. A few hours more, and a game that has become a New York tradition will get under way in- the Yankee Stadium as the future generals and the Hoosiers square off for their twenty-fifth game.

A money shortage forced the closing of the Dayton public schools today for an indefinite period, while a delegation of officials and business men urged Governor Martin L. Davey in Columbus to summon a special session of the Legislature to provide finances.

The Republican National Committee reported today campaign expenditures so far this year had exceeded contributions. In a statement to the Clerk of the House of Representatives the committee reported receipts of $419,603 and expenditures of $469,313 from Sept. 1 to Oct. 27.

A rookie fireman early yesterday morning performed a spectacular rescue of a woman patient who attempted suicide by jumping from her window on the fourth floor of the annex of the Regent Nursing Home, 113 East Sixty-first Street.

The New York State Association of Architects yesterday pledged itself to work with other business and professional groups for passage of a constitutional amendment to limit State activities "strictly to governmental functions" and to make it mandatory wherever possible for the State to "purchase the goods and services it requires from the private industries and the professions."

The Empire Sheet and Tin Plate Company will recall 100 additional men next week, James M. Hill, president, announced today. This will increase employment to 1,000. Operations will be stepped up to 60 per cent of capacity, the highest since last Fall.

The New York Federation of Music Clubs will hold the first of a series of forums, slated in preparation for its World's Fair activities, at a luncheon in honor of Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober, president of the National Federation, to be given today at 1 P. M. in the Great Northern Hotel.

Prince Eugenio, Duke of Ancona, and Princess Lucia of Bourbon were married in a civil ceremony today. A religious service will be performed tomorrow by Michael Cardinal Faulhaber, with Crown Prince Umberto of Italy as one of the witnesses.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 1: THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE--William F. Walsh, from 18th Division, 10th Detective District, to 77th Precinct. Designation as Third Grade Detective revoked. PATROLMAN--Harry Taylor, from 110th Precinct to 18th Division, designated as Third Grade Detective.

Football comes up today with the greatest October show ever offered the East. Never within memory has such a bewildering profusion of major attractions vied for the public's attention as are listed on this afternoon's program.

119th St, 309 W, 25x100.11; Gedar Realty Corp to Metropolitan Savings Bank, p m, 7 yrs. 4 per cent; $10,000. La Salle St, 103 25x99.11: Helen Morrissey to John G. Wehmann, 420 W 125th St, 5 yrs, 6 per cent; $2,000. 30th St, 108 E, 20x98.9; 108 E 30th St Corp. 101 Park Ave, to American Baptist Home Mission Society, a Corp. 23 E 26th St, 5 yrs, 5 per cent ; $10,000.

Arthur H. Levine, trading as the Keystone Process Printing Company of 1,755 Broadway, New York, agreed today in a stipulation filed with the Federal Trade Commission to stop using the words "engraved" or "embossed" on stationery manufactured by him under a thermographic process.
Villanova's Wildcats, undefeated since 1936, drew a tartar today in the South Carolina Gamecocks who battled them to a 6-6 draw before 6,000 fans at the Orangeburg County Fair Grounds.
Mortgage moratorium statutes, adopted during the depth of the depression as a means of reducing the number of foreclosures, still are in effect in nearly a score of States.

Miss Margaret Mitchell said politely but firmly today that she had not named Katharine Hepburn or any one else as her personal choice to play Scarlett O'Hara in the movie version of her novel, "Gone With the Wind."

Customs agents examined and appraised yesterday the contents of the four suitcases they removed Thursday evening from the apartment of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer, on the tenth floor of 570 Park Avenue.

If the United States is turning its back on Europe, there is not much evidence of it in Washington. The Old World may be dying of a complication of diseases, but in dissolution it has strength enough to make the New World reel.

The city of Syracuse and the county of Onondaga are going to roll up an oldfashioned Republican plurality on election day, thanks to the smoothworking political machine headed by Mayor Rolland B. Marvin.

New financing scheduled for next week by one State and ninety-four municipalities amounts to $15,608,450, compared with a revised total of $34,910,520 for the current week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer, which puts the weekly average of new offerings for the year to date at $24,160,059.

As a result of reports abroad-particularly in Great Britain--that former German colonies soon will be returned to the Reich as part of the general European appeasement sought by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Premier Edouard Daladier, stocks of German shipping concerns and enterprises in the former colonies Staged today a sensational boom on the Boerse.

Railroad and utility issues again monopolized trading in bonds on the New York Exchange and both groups scored the widest gains as the volume of sales went to the second largest of the month. Total transactions were $9,024,750, compared with $8,932,000 for the preceding session.
