The Hackensack River Bridge on the old Lincoln Highway, Route 25-M, Communipaw Avenue, between Jersey City and South Kearny, will be closed from midnight tomorrow to midnight Sunday to permit repairs, State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner announced today.

The Munich settlement failed to make provision for refugees and others made destitute by the transfer of Czechoslovak territory to Germany. As Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler states, "the Czechs themselves do not know yet either where their frontiers are to be or what their economic future is, or how many people without lodgings or means or nourishment or work may have to be maintained and resettled."
Two college youths were killed and three others injured, one critically, when their automobile crashed into a tree on East Main Street here early today.

Following is the text of the speech that Thomas E. Dewey made here tonight: We are here tonight in a fine industrial community set down in the midst of some of the richest farm country in the State. Here we have an example of the partnership of business and agriculture.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,117,000 bales, against 1,120,000 a week ago, 1,143,000 two weeks ago, 1,140,000 three weeks ago and 771,000 a year ago; of which American 552,000 bales, against 547,000 a week ago, 565,000 two weeks ago, 581,000 three weeks ago and 323,000 a year ago.
The Court of Appeals ruled today that a person bringing a court action in the State as a "poor person" must be put in that category at the outset.

The officials of the American Sons of Italy, through their attorney, Anthony Romano, denied yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook that they had postponed a convention of New York State lodges of the society in order to stifle criticism of recent anti-Semitic decrees adopted in Italy.

Lawrence High's eleven was hard pressed by a fighting Glen Cove squad before preserving its unbeaten record that has extended through twenty-one games in three years, winning, 7-0, tonight at Horn Memorial Stadium. Stocky Pete Ruggieri registered the only touchdown in the first period on a 3-yard plunge.

The Arabs continue to defy the Palestine Government, paying no attention either to the civil or military authorities Arab inhabitants throughout the country are so terrorized and frightened by the rebels that they obey the latter's orders rather than the government's.

A hearing has been set by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Nov. 15 on an application filed by the Consumers Power Company of the Commonwealth and Southern system in regard to the proposed acquisition of utility assets and other interests from *the Citizens Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of Cities Service Power and Light Company.

Logan Pearsall Smith's book of memoirs, "Unforgotten Years," originally to be published this Fall by Little, Brown, will not be brought out until Spring because the book is being held in reserve by the Book-of-the-Month Club as a dual selection for February or March.

Most livestock prices were unchanged in today's clean-up trade. Light hogs sold fully steady, while others returned to mostly steady values, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Spots 5 to 10 cents lower. A slow trade on lambs forced the top down to $8.50, being around steady with Thursday's close, and 50 cents under the week's high mark.

E. W. Beattie, general attorney for the New York Telephone Company, announced today that his company would "vigorously resist" an order by the Public Service Commission for a reduction in short-haul toll charges now in effect.

Thomas B. Moreno, who was "Skyball" Moreno to motion-picture old-timers and fans of the silentscreen days, died Tuesday in the National Military Hospital at Sawtelle, but many of his friends did not learn of his death until today. He was a noted stunt man and "double" in dangerous scenes for many picture stars. His age was 48.

Eventual fulfillment of the bright promises held out for autogiro aircraft, when first introduced in this country in 1929 by its inventor, the late Juan de La Cierva, was predicted here today at the first rotating wing aircraft meeting ever held.

Business in the Spring of 1939 may be as much as 25 per cent better than the corresponding period of this year, according to Harold G. Parker, vice president of the Standard Statistics Company, Inc., who addressed the New Jersey Bankers Association at its closing session today.

Behind - the - scenes experiences while investigating the munitions industries in England and France in 1934-35 are told by Hilton Howell Railey, publicist, in his autobiography, "Touch'd With Madness," published by Garrick Evans, Inc.

Discovery that corroborative evidence was needed to support testimony expected to be given before the special House committee investigating unAmerican activities caused cancellation of the committee's scheduled hearing today.

Proposals made by executives of the coastwise steamship lines for inclusion in a new agreement between the lines and the International Longshoremen's Association will be submitted to locals affiliated with the union for ratification. officers of the A. F. of L. longshoremen's group announced last night after a conference at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

Capt. Lawrence M. Gredinger, Inf.-Res., 136 West 55th St., Hotel Gorham, New York, N. Y. (D), 28th Infantry, is ordered to active duty, Oct. 30, at headquarters, First Division, Fort Hamilton, New York, for training. Date of rank, Oct. 16, 1937; he will revert to inactive status Nov. 12. Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name;

Princeton's 150-pound eleven came from behind today to defeat the Yale lightweights, 19-13. The Elis led by 13-6 at half-time. Two touchdowns by Buster Bedford, one in the second and another in the third period, featured the Princeton attack. George Lord tallied the winning Princeton touchdown late in the third period.

A summary of three years of operation issued by the National Labor Relations Board reported today that 4,081,191 workers were involved in 17,367 "unfair labor practices" and representation cases filed with the board. The board disposed of 13,472 cases, leaving 3,895 pending on Oct. 1.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The Harvard junior varsity eleven defeated the Princeton jayvees, 19-6, today in the first game the two teams have played the Harvard in many years.
Part of the population of Roskilde, near Copenhagen, is protesting against the darkening of the city for three nights in "blackouts" during the anti-aircraft manoeuvres.
The Sydney Morning Herald, in an editorial on the promised appointment of the Duke of Kent as Governor of Australia, says: "It is a move after his father's heart."

An atmosphere of complete discouragement pervaded American trade circles here today following official announcement of large oil barter deals with Italy and Brazil. The Italian deal is said to involve $3,000,000 worth of rayon, yarn and machinery.

Two stake events, aggregating in excess of $10,000 in added money, will ring down the curtain on the 1938 Jockey Club racing season at Empire City today after one of the most lucrative terms for the sport since the liberalizing of the law a few years ago.
DOUGLAS CORRIGAN, the reverse-Irish flier, tells his own life history in "That's My Story," which E. P. Dutton Co. will publish early in December.

The reorganization of the American Association of Junior Colleges and the establishment of a central executive and research office at Washington is expected to have considerable influence in stimulating and guiding the future development of the junior college movement in all parts of the country.
Washington State smashed the four-year Gonzaga football jinx today, 15 to 13, by the margin of a safety after a blocked goal line punt in the final four minutes of play. .

ASIDE from the psychological responses of humanity as a whole, there are basic mental traits in the English, French and German nations which differentiate them and lead, occasionally, to misunderstandings.

THE mandrake root which gives Martha Ostenso the title to her new novel is a plant inhabited with magic Shaped like a human body, it is said to cry out when pulled from the earth; eaten, it gives fertility to a barren woman. In the tale she tells, Martha Ostenso, author of "Wild Geese" and other novels, makes poetic use of this legend.

Bill Davis's successful placement after he had tossed a fourthperiod touchdown pass to Ned Iverson, was the deciding factor today in Davidson's 13-to-12 triumph over Furman's Purple Hurricane. A crowd of 8,000 saw the game.

Alan LennoxBoyd, Under-Secretary for Labor, suggested at the Management Conference of the Institute .of Labor last night that the International Labor Office might be expanded into a new league of nations.
Under the administration of Dr. Eunice M. Hilton the office of the Syracuse University dean of women has become a center for integrating the phases of the woman student's campus environment.

Pledging himself and a Republican State administration to go down the line for the continuance without "skimping" of unemployment insurance, relief and other forms of social aid, but calling for the kind of an administration that would correlate these activities and bring them into a unified system,

The delicately balanced wheels within wheels that make up the Harvard scheme of attack moved with the precision of watchworks today and the Crimson took its first victory of the football season with an impressive 26-to-7 defeat of Princeton.
The sixtieth anniversary of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will be marked by a large dinner party to be given on Nov. 15 in the Exchange Restaurant, 541 Madison Avenue.
Mrs. Stanley K. Greene and Mrs. Walter P. Chandler are co-chairmen of the annual card party in aid of the Willoughby House Settlement in Brooklyn. They have enlisted a large group of aides.

The record of Senator Robert F. Wagner in connection with the defeat of President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the United States Supreme Court was attacked last night by John Lord O'Brian, his Republican opponent.

Back on the track where he scored his first victory, W. L. Brann's Challedon, a 15-to-1 shot, today triumphed in the $25,000 added New England Futurity before nearly 20,000 persons at Narragansett Park.

With delegates present from 150 colleges, a regional conference of the Association of American Colleges in Milwaukee on Nov. 7-8 will consider problems of the relationship between the government and the colleges.

The next German demand, which France feels sure will be the return of the former's colonies, is at present a subject for deep anxiety in Paris. Vital French interests in Africa are involved in this question, and official circles hold the opinion that, if ever the former German Cameroons, now French, is given back to Berlin, it will spell the disintegration of France's colonial set-up in the Dark Continent.

Frank Melowitz, Joseph Anese and Howard Schaeffer of Union College finished in a dead heat for first place as the Garnet harriers defeated City College, 19 to 36, in a dual meet over the five-mile intercollegiate course in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

The exhortation to Soviet school teachers this week to carry on active anti-religious training among children is part of a general campaign directed against all religions - Catholic, Greek Orthodox, Protestant,. Jewish and Mohammedan-which has been especially pronounced in the last two years.
Miss Bettina Sherwood Simmen, a descendant on the maternal side of Captain Matthew Mead of this place, who served in the Revolutionary War, was married here this afternoon to John Herbert Connors,

A scrapping Virginia Tech football team carried the fight to a favored North Carolina State eleven today, scored a touchdown on a sustained drive in the third period, and won, 7-0. Al Miller, sparkling halfback, drove over from the four-yard line and Captain Pierce kicked goal for the 7 points which spelled victory.

IT is a comment on the rapidity of the westward movement that the three frontiers which Mr. Pitzer here recalls-prairie Illinois, Iowa, and Colorado, were all experienced within a period of thirty years.

ONE of countless tiny rocky islands in the Atlantic, a few miles from the coast of Britanny in France, not even marked on the maps of this section, the Island of Illiec, which seems to have been torn off the coast by the fury of the elements, is now the home of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

Declaring that "it is too late now" for a common democratic front against fascism, Nicholas Roosevelt, former United States Minister to Hungary, addressing the Foreign Policy Association yesterday, advocated large-scale national rearmament as protection against potential aggressors and an "awakening of the American people's faith in democracy" to counteract the internal "contagion" of totalitarian ideas.

A "substantial" increase in the cost of construction by next Spring, due in part to possible higher costs of labor and materials, is forecast by William J. Levitt, president of Levitt Sons, well-known home builders.
Several leases have been made of stores in the row of shops being erected by N. K. Winston Co. in connection with Garden Bay Manor, the English garden apartment colonly at Jackson Heights.

THE past week's most encouraging example of healthy skepticism was provided by Milton Vaughn, a young man who was signed four months ago and rushed out to Hollywood to play one of the Tarleton twins in "Gone With the Wind." Mr. Vaughn has returned to his post as elevator boy at the Hotel SavoyPlaza until the David Selznick film goes into production.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 27: COMMANDER Hazlett, E. E. Jr., Washington,' D; C., to Continue treatment in naval hospital and when discharged ordered home, relieved all active duty.
ALTHOUGH this new Crime file is bound like a book, it is in other respects similar to the other items in this series in that it is a complete police record of a murder case.
A smoky fire that started in, a ventilating shaft of a five-story tenement at 328 East Seventy-third Street at 5:45 P. M. yesterday drove sixteen families into the street.
IN an article in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES Magazine I drew attention to the way in which, in my opinion, education is threatening to eat up life.
At least ten Democratic and Republican candidates for State and national office will speak to the Stamford (Conn.) League of Women Voters at a luncheon meeting Friday at the Hotel Davenport.

The city's fire house for Engine Company 295 and the Sanitation Department section station 144, doomed to demolition because they lay in the right of way of the new Cross Island Boulevard being built as an approach to the new Whitestone-Bronx bridge, will be moved from their present sites at 149th Street and Fourteenth Avenue, Whitestone, to a nearby site, it was learned yesterday.

Morton Govern's aged chestnut mare, Sarah B. Mosby, took the championship and otherwise monopolized the hunter classes at the sixth annual Byram River horse show, held in the arena of the Round Hill Club Stables today.

To help "resist the mechanization of mind and morale" resulting from productions of mass entertainment industries, Smith College will continue this year its program of weekly film showings at Sage Hall.
The New York Philharmonic Orchestra, with John Barbirolli conducting, opened Princeton University's 1938-39 concert series in the McCarter Theatre tonight before a capacity audience of 1,100.
SOME slow headway is being made by. retailers against adverse trade conditions, but, with few exceptions; they have still to report a real upturn in volume.

Scoring twice in the final period, the last time 45 seconds before the end of the game, Hempstead High Schoool rallied to gain a sensational 18-18 tie with Baldwin before 5,000 spectators in a Nassau Conference football battle today.
Lafayette went on a scoring spree today to defeat a weak but fighting Ursinus team before a crowd of 4,000 by 39-0.
OVER half a century ago Henry L. Stoddard was beginning life as a reporter and was at once assigned to get news in the field of politics. He kept on in that field.
Port Jefferson's cross-country team pulled a surprise today, taking the eleventh annual La Salle Academy run from a favored Sayville squad.

Five New England States are preparing to elect Governors, three United States Senators and twenty-six Representatives. Maine already has returned a complete Republican slate and will keep all incumbents in office.

" Serious deficiencies" in many of the zoning and planning ordinances thus far adopted in the metropolitan region and a growing recognition of the importance of restricting land uses are emphasized in a survey just completed by the Regional Plan Association on the progress of zoning here.

The death of Sir William Coaker of Port Union, Nfld., former Newfoundland Cabinet Minister and Commissioner of Marine and Fisheries, was announced today by officials of the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 67 years old.

Mary Lombardi, 14 years old, the only girl in the Park Department's whistling contest held yesterday at Roosevelt Playground, Chrystie and Forsyth Streets, took first place among a dozen contenders from all parts of Manhattan.
The engagement of Miss Marian Grote to Dr. Henry Mannix Gahan of Medford, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William D. Grote of this city and Palm Beach, Fla.
ONE of the philatelic fruits' of the Nazi invasion of Czechoslovakia reached New York last week in the form of a stamp commemorating Germany's acquirement of Aussig,. a city in Northern Bohemia.

The first conrete sign of the so-called new coneption of a merely technical and educed League of Nations is evilenced in the sudden removal, effective Monday, of Marcel Hoden, secretary General Joseph A. C. Avenol's Chief of Cabinet.

ELABORATE plans for trans porting members of the American Bankers Association to Houston, Texas, for their sixty-fourth annual convention, Nov. 14-17, have been made by the Pennsylvania and the New York Central.

A program of English and American folk dancing and music will be given the night of Nov. 21 at the Town Hall to mark the twentyfifth anniversary of the Pine Mountain Settlement School in Harlan County, Ky.

WALTZ IN GOOSE STEP--Tuesday evening at the Hudson Theatre. A play by Oliver H. P. Garrett, one which tells of dictatorship in a. country that might just be Germany. The cast includes Henry Oscar, Leo Chalzell, Harold Johnsrud, John Boruff, Mariana Fiory and Barrie Wanless.
Launching drives culminated by touchdowns following an intercepted pass and a fumble, Rutgers defeated Lehigh by 13 to 0 before a house party crowd of 9,000 in Taylor Stadium today.

ADELMAN-Mr. and Mrs. Harry (nee Pearl Koenigstein), are happy to announce the birth of their daughter, Wednesday, Oct. 26, at Beth Israel Hospital. ALTENDACH-Mr. and Mrs. Peter Altendach announce the arrival of a son on Oct. 28, 1938, at the Park East Hospital.

More than 1,000 alumni are expected to attend a confernece on "Education and Peace" arranged by the Alumni Association of the New York University School of Education next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. H. Claude Hardy, superintendent of schools at White Plains, N. Y., and president of the association.
Lyman E. Hurd, former president of the Salem Common Council and a onetime member of the lower house of the Legislature, died here today in Baker Memorial Hospital at the age of 63.

Fully 3,000 persons, mostly children, assembled on pier 92 North River, foot of West Fifty-second Street, yesterday forenoon to bid farewell to George Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, who sailed on the Italian liner Rex.

The Assembly of the League of Nations last October called for a preliminary investigation of measures for raising the standards of living. Professor N. F. Hall, formerly of University College, considers the proposals so far made in a monograph published under the auspices of the League, and stresses among other things the part that mistaken policies of taxation play in holding back human welfare.

Voters, in balloting in the forthcoming election, should avoid the influence of racial and religious prejudice, as a menace to the democratic system of government, rabbis said in sermons here yesterday.

Curfew shall ring tonight on the University of Missouri campus and, if there is any justice, Sophomore Paul Christman, whose willowy right arm pitched the Tigers to a 13-10 Big Six football victory over Nebraska today, should get the first yank at the cord.
THE last few years have brought a huge crop of books intended to clarify the mysteries of medicine for the benefit of the layman.

Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York, made a complete denial yesterday of published reports of a speech made Thursday night at Turn Hall, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, in which he was quoted as having attacked the institutions of freedom of worship and freedom of the press.

THESE are zestful days everywhere in the Midsouth, and nobody with an eye can escape the feel of it. Somnolent Summer is replaced by the tang of Fall, mild and invigorating and lovely as it slips down over Virginia, the Carolinas and Tennessee.

A warning of an incipient debacle in sterling, owing to Britain's continued adverse balance of trade and the mass of "refugee capital" with in its borders without gold for coverage, is contained in a bulletin issued by Delaware Fund Distributors, Inc.

Valley Stream Central High School's football team continued as one of the two unbeaten and untied elevens in Nassau County today by defeating Great Neck, 20-0, before a capacity crowd at Firemen's Field, Valley Stream.

The University of California, defending Conference champion and one of the Coast's two contenders for the Rose Bowl bid, gained a 13to-7 victory over a fighting Oregon State College football team today.
A desperate rally today gave Carnegie Tech a 27-to-13 football victory over Akron University before 8,500 fans. Two quick thrusts in the final five minutes broke a 13-13 deadlock.

Trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra are understood to have voted to send the organization of 110 men under the direction of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, abroad in May for its long-contemplated European concert tour.

Marking the first of a series of supper dances to be sponsored in Manhattan during the Fall and Winter seasons by undergraduates of Georgian Court College here, the annual social of the student newspaper will be held next Friday evening at the Hotel New Yorker.

THE broadcasters swing into November with election specials and programs of Thanks giving being woven into the pattern of broadcasting. A number of the regularly scheduled shows will be missing this week because of political broadcasts, but the
The directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey have voted a distribution of $2,000,000 to all domestic employes, most of whom are participants in the company's thrift plan.

The Fall flower show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which for thirty-five years has been one of the outstanding annual events in-the Eastern States for professional gardeners, is expected this year to become a high spot in the garden calendar of the general public, with the cooperation for the first time of various garden clubs in the vicinity--the Matinecock Garden Club, Neighborhood Garden Guild, Sea Cliff Garden Club and North Country Garden Club.

IT was high time that someone came along and applied the scalpel of common sense to the huge growth of Goya apocrypha, as Mr. Poore has done in this excellent biography, at once so vivid and so well-balanced.

At 7 o'clock yesterday morning the longshoremen at pier 84, North River, removed the covers from No. 2 hatch on the Hamburg American liner Deutschland which arrived Friday night after a fire on board had forced Captain Karl Steincke to stop the ship from 8 P. M. Tuesday until 6 A. M. Wednesday, when it was extinguished.

Mrs. Parsons Simpson of 1,331 Madison Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Cynthia Jacqueline Dechert, to Henry Coolidge Adams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Adams of Springfield, Paget East, Bermuda.
The Emergency Fact-Finding Board appointed by President Roosevelt recommended today that the Class One railroads abandon their proposal to reduce wages of nearly 1,000,000 employes by 15 per cent.
PINEHURST, N. C.-The outstanding event of the Fall season here is the eighteenth annual Midsouth professional golf tournament, which is scheduled to be. held from Nov. 15 to 18.
AS invariably happens about this time of the year, Victor makes a special release of repressings of European recordings for which it has been unable to find place in the regular monthly lists.

Clarkson College's football team went down to a 14-to-6 defeat at the hands of Niagara University today in a game filled with hard and spectacular playing. A crowd of 2,500 saw the Engineers outplay the Purple Eagles during the greater part of the contest.

The costumes of past years and those of today will be the features offered in the fashion show to be conducted by the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work in connection with its annual Christmas sale at the Greenwich Country Club on Nov. 10.

No sport is safe any longer from, women competitors. Now the girls are breaking into ice hockey, heretofore an exclusively male sport. A serious invasion of the ice rinks is planned this season by a group of skaters who call themselves the Gay Blades.

A sentence of six months in the workhouse was imposed yesterday on Joseph Bono, 35-year-old musician, on his plea of guilty to a charge of pasting a caricature of the Statue of Liberty to a pillar in the Fifty-ninth Street station of the Independent subway Friday night.

Ratification by the unlicensed members of ships' crews of the collective bargaining agreement negotiated last Spring by the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, and representatives of American steamship companies operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports was announced yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, will preside this afternoon at the dedication of a new six-story pavilion at St. Clare's Hospital, 417 West Fiftyfirst Street.

Lawrence Tibbett announced today the board of governors of the American Guild of Musical Artists would meet in New York Monday to make "final disposition" of Yehudi Menuhin's proposed appearance with the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra Nov. 3 and 4. Mr. Tibbett is president of the guild.

Harvard and Princeton played two overtime periods today but failed to break a 3-3 soccer deadlock. Mendel tallied twice for Harvard, Williams also scoring. Newbold, Schweizer and Watts were the Tiger point makers.

Hockey will make its bow on the sports calendar when the National Hockey League race begins on Thursday night. Two games are listed for the opening night, the New York Americans opposing the world champion Chicago Black Hawks on the latter's ice and the Boston Bruins tackling the Toronto Maple Leafs in Toronto.

The feeling that Walter Carter long has held as to Clodion's ability to run beyond sprinting distances was vindicated yesterday when his 4-year-old came from behind in the $6,800 Scarsdale Handicap to win going away by a half length at the end of a mile and seventy yards.

Moderate improvement in prospects for the sugar industries now leaves only canning, aviation, transport and silver mining as industries whose outlook is viewed as unfavorable during the next several months, according to the November Industries Service, issued by Fenner Beane.

A survey on some aspects of home loaning conditions just completed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reveals a steady downward trend in interest rates charged by savings and loan associations during the last four years and at the same time a marked increase in savings accounts.

An unusual philanthropic aim is applied to the recital to be given by John Powell, Virginia pianist, on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. Net proceeds from this musical event will-augment a fund for purchasing for the University of Virginia a rare collection of letters written by that institution's founder, Thomas Jefferson.
Thomas J. Mooney has changed his mind and asked his lawyers to continue their fight before the United States Supreme Court to win for him release from San Quentin prison.

THE first physician in the history of motion pictures to advocate socialized medicine will arrive here soon in the person of Dr. Manson, principal character in A. J. Cronin's story "The Citadel," which follows "Stablemates" into the Capitol Theatre.
Troops of the Sixteenth Infantry at Governors Island passed in review yesterday morning before First Sergeant Chester A. Reinhart on the occasion of his retirement after thirty years' service.
In a two-mile-wide no-man's land between German and Czech troops there are several hundred Jews whom the Germans have expelled and whom the Czech authorities have refused to receive.
The tiger's cage is wide open, the tamer has run away and the panic-stricken people fear the worst. Such was the description of Southeastern Europe recently given by a British Member of Parliament.

The realty firm of Tetor Schmults, Ridgewood, N. J., has moved from 1 East Ridgewood Avenue to 9 North Broad Street. The new offices were fitted up under the supervision of the architect Harvey Mather.

THIS is the definitive handbook for commuters. Thoughtfully conceived, lucidly written, and brilliantly illustrated, it should prove as invaluable to commuters as is a watch that gains a few minutes every night.
Some important. dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

The benefit performance under the auspices of the Protestant Big Sisters of New York of the new play, "Yankee Fable," starring Ina Claire, has been changed from the night of Nov. 9 to that of Nov. 30, due to a three-week postponement of the play.

Observant gardeners soon learn that the measures which best serve to keep crabgrass pest in check are cultural. Lawns which from early Spring on are carefully weeded, fed and mown, and in consequence give heavy, healthy stands of grass, are safest from the inroads of crabgrass and other weeds.

While several hundred youngsters and a large sprinkling of adults shouted words of encouragement, youthful roller skaters set a mad pace yesterday afternoon on the Circle Lawn rink at 106th Street and Central Park West.
Michael Cardinal Faulhaber today solemnized the marriage of Prince Eugenio, Duke of Ancoma, and Princess Lucia of Bourbon, whose civil wedding yesterday united two royal houses.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Rutledge Snare, a granddaughter of Frederick Snare of New York and Havana and of William Dulles of Englewood and New York, to Philip Reed took place at her home here this evening.

President Roosevelt, Secretary Swanson, Secretary Morgenthau and other high officials of the government inspected today specimens of practically every type of airplane which the country's fighting services now have.

THAT highly controversial realm of the abstract or "non-representational" or "non-objective" comes to the front in several exhibitions which opened last week and remain current until the middle of November.

As one reads, or tries to read, the official summaries of the proposed amendments which will appear on the ballots or voting machines a week from Tuesday, one may doubt that the convention system is the best means for improving a State Constitution.
On a Ninth Avenue site formerly occupied by two two-story wooden shacks and three "old-law" tenements a modern six-story apartment house has just been completed.

The Agricultural Department's estimate that the world wheat crop this year will reach the all-time record of 4,365 million bushels (excluding China and Russia) shows that the problem of wheat is by no means confined to the United States.
Columbia University finished a thirty-year task of scholarship last week with the publication of the eighteenth and last volume of the first complete collection of the works of John Milton.
Alabama vs. Tulane at Birmingham. Arkansas vs. Rice at Fayettesville. Army vs. F. and M. at West Point. Boston College vs. Indiana at Boston.

Interest in the opening of the Amherst College dramatic season next Thursday is two-fold, for the Masquers will present "High Tor," the first of a cycle of plays by Maxwell Anderson to be given during the year, and with the production will open the new Kirby Memorial Theatre, 'which has been in construction for more than a year.

Miss Madeleine Jeanne Coll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Coll of Elizabeth, was married to Lieutenant William J. Cain Jr., U. S. A., son of former Judge and Mrs. Cain of Bayonne, at St. Genevieve's Catholic Church here this morning.
Secretary Perkins and the Department of Labor were accused today by Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee on un-American Activities,...
THE announcement that Turkey plans to improve the port at Trebizond on the Black Sea has revived interest in that ancient stronghold.
IN the case of Raymond Massey the coincidence goes back a long time-about seventy-seven years, in fact.
An indication that Soviet aviation engineers have developed successful new types of military planes is seen in two small items in the newspaper Pravda, one published today, the other yesterday.
Judge Null M. Hodapp of the Court of Common Pleas issued a temporary restraining order today prohibiting the Dayton Board of Education from closing the city's schools to 34,000 students.

The Purple Wave of New, Rochelle High School extended its winning streak to four games by conquering St. Basil's Prep of. Stamford, Conn., today, the count being 25 to. 0. The locals compiled 19 points in the opening period and coasted the rest of the way.
As usually happens, the garden season, drawing to its close, is "evening up" for the year. After a poor Spring and a worse midsummer we are enjoying a Fall that leaves nothing to complain about.
Hackley completely outplayed a favored and unbeaten Storm King eleven today to win, 25-0, with Charlie Masse accounting for two touchdowns and the Bergeron brothers for one each.
After six months at his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo Pope Pius returned to the Vatican this afternoon.
The University of Buffalo eleven, underdog in four previous contests, displayed a surprising form reversal to defeat Allegheny College, 47 to 0, at Rotary Field today.

The tumult over the operation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act continues in the Middle West as the Congressional elections approach.' The most recent development was the adoption late this week by the Kansas State Farmers' Union at Salina of a resolution opposing the AAA as a permanent agricultural policy and asking the substitution of the domestic allotment plan.

For more than a decade wealthy New Yorkers have been busy converting the old farmhouses of Southern Connecticut for all-year or Summer use or building costly new residences along the shore or in the hills of that State.

Miss Cynthia Sloane Kellogg, daughter of Mrs. Cynthia G. Babcock of Buffalo and Old Bennington, was married to Robert Lindsay Wickes, son of Commander and Mrs. George L. Wickes of New York, this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Norman P. Dare.
About 150 Westchester delegates attended today a consumers' cooperative institute sponsored by the Westchester Federation of Consumer Clubs here.

One of the economic anomalies seen by persons in many quarters these days is the fact that, although industry is believed to have re-employed from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 persons since the upturn began last Summer, WPA relief rolls in the same period also have risen by nearly 500,000.
The Great Neck firm of Edward J. Clancy-Ann Vera Hughes reports one of the most active renting seasons in many years in that Long Island section.
The Coast Guard Academy eleven rallied with a bewildering attack in the third period to down Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 19-7, today. Coast Guard scored all its

Further evidence that the National Democratic Committee regards New Jersey as an important battleground in its fight to prevent Republican inroads in the United States Senate was presented today with the announcement that two more Administration stalwarts would speak in behalf of William H. J. Ely.

Requesting the use of the poundmile method as a basis of payment for transporting. air mail, the United Air Lines Transport Corporation has filed a petition with the Civil Aeronautics Authority asking it to fix fair and reasonable rates.

The Maritime Commission's program for the building of a merchant marine which will cover all the seas and, besides, go far in the direction of solving the navy's auxiliary problem, is proceeding at full speed, and the year 1938 is going into history as the most active since the World War so far as the merchant service is concerned.

Next Saturday in Madison Square Garden, the National Horse Show Association will open its annual exhibition, which will continue through the following Saturday evening, Nov. 12. There will be regular performance every afternoon and evening, with the exception of Sunday, when there will be only an evening session.
An unusually strong Fall demand is being shown for homes in and around Teaneck, Bergen County, according to the alexander Summer Company.
Only two teams remained undefeated after the weekly interclub matches of the New York Women's Field Hockey Association yesterday on the fields at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

The new Schrafft's restaurant and store, a two-story building at 61 Fifth Avenue, corner of Thirteenth Street, will be opened on Tuesday morning.

PARIS. PROFESSOR CHARLES SEIGNOBOS, who taught history forty years at the Sorbonne, has turned to account his vast knowledge to write from materials dispersed in thousands of sources, his Histoire Comparee des Peuples de l'Europe (Rieder. 486 pages, 25 francs).

A PLAIN citizen, a leader a man of business and a lover of music protested last week against the "swinging" of Bach's Toccata in D minor. Did they also "swing" the fugue? A four-voiced fugue, in the best Benny Goodman style, would be something, though just what defies the imagination of man.

Shifts of political power in Europe with their relationship to Jewish persecution have presented problems, to the solution of which the twenty-fourth annual convention of Hadassah, opening in St. Louis at noon tomorrow, will be dedicated.

Fifty Oklahoma high school and junior college students whose families are receiving some form of Federal relief are to be trained in public affairs under a plan for a residence school to be set up at the University of Oklahoma in February.

AN appreciable number of books are published on the subject of neurosis each year for the special benefit of the layman. Most of these are psychoanalytic in cast and the same tune is repeated, at one time transposed an octave higher and at another an octave lower.

AHLES-Henry, on Oct. 28, 1938, at his residence, 1,323 Theriot Ave., beloved husband of Fredrica and father of Robert, Charles and Edith. Member of Hope Lodge, No. 244, F. and A. M. Religious service at his home Sunday, 8 P. M.; Masonic Service 8:15 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery Monday at 2 P. M.

Miss Evelyn Rae Kelser, daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Raymond Kelser of Washington, was married last night to Lieutenant John Andrews Allgair, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Allgair of Somerville, N. J., in St. Luke's Cathedral, Ancon.
Miss Mary M. O'Reilly, whose thirtythree years of service have won her unofficial designation as the "sweetheart of the Treasury," retired today.
The War Department applied a soft pedal on official utterances today, pending completion of President Roosevelt's restudy of national defense needs.

There is no middle of the road in California politics this year, and voters must choose between outright conservatives on the Republican ticket and Democratic candidates who stand to the left of they New Deal.

Reorganization of the alumni program of Cornell University, giving recognition to the importance of their participation in the welfare of the university, will be stressed at the alumni convention in Chicago Friday and Saturday.

Jacques Gordon, leader of the Gordon String Quartet, will receive the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Medal for eminent services in the field of chamber music at the annual Founder's Day concert of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation tonight in the Library of Congress.

WHETHER a room is traditional or modern, there are many new textiles to add to its artistic effect. In those fabrics which are still woven. by hand texture plays a leading part, while others with hand-blocked patterns express a graceful informality of technique. Some of these fabrics.

INSTRUMENTAL and vocal soloists who have yearned to be heard in recital with the gorgeous support of a full symphony orchestra instead of a lonesome piano may indulge their hopes by simply engaging the newly organized "accompaniment orchestra."

Aching back muscles troubled an entire Brighton family today after a hunt through 75,000 discarded telephone books for fifteen $100 bills carelessly hidden in one of them, but they had the money to salve their Pains.

The margin of difference in the number of votes in favor of Pedro Aguirre Cerda, Leftist Presidential candidate, over Gustavo Ross, Rightist candidate, in last Tuesday's election dropped from 7,000 to approximately 4,000 after this morning's examination by a special committee.

The University of Alabama's Crimson Tide swamped the University of Kentucky, 26 to 6, today before a homecoming-day crowd of 10,000. The bright spot in the Kentucky picture was the 71-yard touchdown dash of Halfback David Zoeller, who broke through left tackle in the second quarter.

A Ray Eichen short pass thrown by Everett Kischer, Iowa State's brilliant quarterback, to Martin Boswell, end, resulted in a touchdown which gave the Cyclones their sixth straight victory, a 7-to-O decision over Marquette's football team today.
A powerful and alert Duke University football team rode to a 14-to-O victory over North Carolina today in a game which probably decided the Southern Conference championship.
Under the auspices bf the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, an afternoon of entertainment will be held Nov. 15 on board the new Norwegian-America line flagship, Oslofjord.

Many a home owner whose garden after the first light frosts is almost colorless looks with envy at the gorgeous display of hardy chrysanthemums now to be seen in public gardens, on large estates and in the fields of commercial nurseries.

Two homes in Upper Montclair, N. J., were reported yesterday as having been sold through the Hill, Simpson-Merritt Company, brokers. One was the twelve-room dwelling, on a plot 100 by 160 feet, at 130 Clarewill Avenue, which was purchased from the estate of H. C. Townsend by Arthur Lissner.

LONDON. MANY people, without any discreditable profiteering, must have made pots of money out of the war scare. I am not referring merely to the firms that have supplied timber and other materials for the construction of airraid shelters or to the manufacturers of the forty million gas masks that have been distributed.
Newly enrolled students of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel will receive their emblematic caps and gowns next Thursday evening at the annual investiture exercises of the college.
Mrs. Rope N. Townsend of New York obtained a divorce today from James M. Townsend Jr. on grounds of cruelty. They have one child. Agreement was reached as to custody and support.

BROADCASTING celebrates its eighteenth anniversary on Wednesday. It was on Nov. 2, 1920, that KDKA, Pittsburgh, broadcast the Harding-Cox election returns and started the "craze" on its way across the country, although there were several experimental radiophones on the air prior to that date.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Joan Kaufman Biddle, daughter of Louis Graveraet Kaufman, banker, and Mrs. Kaufman of Short Hills, N. J., this city and Marquette, Mich., to Joseph May Wintersteen, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Wintersteen of Haverford.

Resumption of the flow of capital into industry and a plan for informing the public of the investment banking business were discussed here today at the final session of the convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.by Jean C. Witter of Dean Witter Co., San Francisco, incoming president of the association, and Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance in New York University.

Lebanon Valley rallied in the closing minutes to defeat Pennsylvania Military College today, 15 to 13. A 49-yard pass from Kress to Captain Brown brought the winning touchdown. Brown ran 28 yards after making the catch.
Malcolm Stevenson gave a dance tonight at Two Maple Farm, his home here, for his debutante daughter, Miss Maude K. Stevenson.
THIS is a poignant record of the impression made by the new Palestine on a German-Jewish visitor of acute perception and innate delicacy of soul.

Every lightweight streamlined train operating in this country produced more traffic than other trains and substantial earnings, according to a survey-by Coverdale Colpitts, engineers, for the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of this kind of equipment.
Special services in churches of the city will open the annual Girl Scout Week. The 17,600 Girl Scouts and their adult leaders in Manhattan will attend four services of their respective faiths.

HUNDREDS of thousands of Americans, visitors to the Chicago Exposition in 1934, probably first heard of Jehol, the "holy" city of Manchuria, when they viewed the reproduction of its graceful Golden Temple, which was constructed and placed there under the direction of the Swedish explorer Sven Hedin.

The first for this season in the series of Knickerbocker Assemblies, traditionally inaugurated during the Thanksgiving holidays, will take place on the night of Nov. 26 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Dr. George Jay Smith, who retired on Feb. 1, 1937, as a member of the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education after having served since the original board was named in 1898, died yesterday at his Summer home at Ogunquit, Me., of heart disease, according to word received here.
Into his program speech at the Radical party congress at Marseilles on Thursday Premier Edouard Daladier suddenly thrust a significant reference to France's colonial empire.

As bodies were recovered from the ruins and checks were made of the missing today, the Marseille fire turned into a larger and larger calamity. Close to 100 persons were missing. More than a score of bodies have been found and there are more than twenty in the hospital.

The preliminary celebration of Barnard College's fiftieth anniversary, National Barnard Day, to be observed by alumnae throughout the country and the students on Nov. 19, will include a nation-wide broadcast by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and five prominent alumnae and will be directed by Mrs. John TO HEA Miles Thompson.

The Boy Scouts of America announced yesterday that Daniel Carter Beard, National Scout Commissioner and chairman of the National Court of Honor, had reported three honor medal awards for lifesaving and ten certificates for heroism.

The Kansas election a week from Tuesday will furnish a good indication of the attitude of the farmers of the Middle West toward the New Deal, because it is conceded by observers on all sides that the farm vote will swing the election.

Trailing by 7-6 going into the final quarter, Notre Dame struck twice in rapid succession with touchdown runs yesterday to gain a conclusive 19-7 victory over Army at the Yankee Stadium in their twenty-fifth anniversary football meeting.

With observers of both parties saying that Allegheny County and the adjoining territory is pro-Democratic, leaders of the Democrats assert that their candidates will go over the Allegheny Mountains on Nov. 8 with a surprising majority sufficient to wipe out the predicted Republican lead in Philadelphia and its suburban sections.

Berkshire defeated a stubborn Kent football team, 20 to 6, today. In the second quarter a short kick gave Kent the ball on Berkshire's 15-yard line, and after a forward pass Captain Lyon plunged over for Kent's only score. The point for touchdown was missed.

The first company to avail itself of the provisions of the new Chandler Act was revealed yesterday when E. Edgar Elliott, president of the Haytian Corporation, proposed in a letter to stockholders an arrangement for readjusting $3,000,000 in debenture bonds due on Dec. 31, which it is unable to meet.

THE third-term issue faces the nation. Whether, as discussion of a pivotal Presidential election grows, the President will announce that he has decided to run again or that under no circumstances would he accept nomination for four years more, this issue will. exert a large influence on our national affairs for many months.
Following is the prepared text of Governor Lehman's address tonight before a campaign rally here: My Republican opponent said in a campaign speech a few nights ago-and I quote him:

A sharp increase in the use of market research by industry to the point where it is now costing about $4,500,000 a year was reported here yesterday by Frank R. Coutant, director of research of Pedlar Ryan, Inc., and former president of the American Marketing Association.

Addition of a combination Alumni Secretary and Placement Bureau Director to the permanent administrative staff of Swarthmore College is making possible for the first time in the history of the college an organized opportunity for members of the senior class to receive vocational guidance.

In the most puzzling campaign for many years, Ohio faces the election on Nov. 8 with marked uncertainty. Even bettors appear to have little idea of the trends and wagers are exceedingly scarce this year. In general, the odds appear to be practically even.

The Ithaca College eleven scored its first victory of the season by defeating Panzer at Ashland Stadium today, 26-6. The Panthers scored first on a 20-yard pass from Minowicz to Brownlee, after a recovered fumble had put the team scoring position.
Southern California brought the Pacific Coast Conference's oldest football jinx to Multnomah Field today and, just as it has done at every meeting for twenty-one years, defeated Oregon, 31 to 7.

WHAT is all this sound and furythis babble of discordant voices--now rising in America? Out of a blue haze hovering over the great State of Pennsylvania comes the noise of accusations and counter-accusations of corruption and dishonesty in high public places.
The Republicans in Oregon have swung over to policies and promises which rival in liberalism those of the New Deal candidates.
FOR years Professor Frank furter has rendered valuable public service by his discourses on the merits of the late Justice Holmes.
Brown University paid tribute this week to the memory of one of the university's most distinguished alumni-John Hay, '58, who was born 100 years ago this month.

The New York State Committee of the Communist party announced yesterday that it had purchased from the National Broadcasting Company time for a State-wide radio hook-up next Sunday with the objective of "defeating reactionary Republicans such as Hamilton Fish, John Taber, Bruce Barton, John Lord O'Brian and Frederic Bontecou as well as the entire State ticket headed by Thomas E. Dewey."

FOR SPORT: Field Marshal Hermann Goering likes to hunt and wants to revive medieval falconry in Germany. He needs falcons. Last Summer he sent an expedition to Greenland to study falcons, their likes and dislikes. Last week the expedition returned.

After a joint session of the British and American Chambers of Commerce of Shanghai, W. H. Plant, president of the American organization, sailed today for the United States to assist the government in efforts to maintain the "open door" in China.

A letter from Elisha Hanson, counsel for twelve newspaper publishers' associations, made public here today, asked for a ruling at "the earliest possible moment" on the status of newspapers under the section of the Wages and Hours Law which exempts "any employee engaged in any retail or service establishment the greater part of whose selling or servicing is in intrastate commerce."

Editor The New York Times Book Review : In the book review of "Triumph Over Pain" by Rene Fiilop-Miller I was struck by the absolute dismissal of the claims of the discovery of anesthesia of the man they would deny, Dr. Horace Wells!

A plan to increase the effectiveness of New York City's library resources through cooperative collection agreements by the major libraries, was proposed by Robert Bingham Downs, director of the New York University libraries, in a preface to his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.

Wisconsin remained in the race for the Western Conference football championship today by repulsing a pass-slinging Indiana football team after grabbing a 6-0 lead that did not appear safe until the final gun. A homecoming crowd of 32,000 saw the game.

The extent to which the people of the United States have become prey to propaganda and just how fa?? they can still "balance their emotions with intelligence" is the subject of a study which the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War has inaugurated through a nation-wide survey.
Governor Lehman, taking recognition of the charges of Thomas E. Dewey that he had failed to act against "entrenched, corrupt Democratic political machines" and was their puppet,...

VISITORS to the World's Falt who want to see the newest inventions in automobiles, trains, boats and airplanes, with a glimpse of a rocket-ship, to learn what travel was like in the past and what it may be like in the future, will witness the largest and one of the most spectacular exhibits at the fair when it opens next April

Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose L. O'Shea of Kew Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of Mrs. O'Shea's daughter, Miss Betty Bradford MacIntyre, to William Terrence, son of Mrs. William Terrence of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Terrence.

Colonel John Wesley Miller, one of the Canadians who fought at Gettysburg on the Union side and a veteran of the Fenian raids, died today at the age of 93. He attended last July the seventyfifth anniversary celebration of the Battle of Gettysburg.

Little Bert Marshall, directing a crushing set of backs behind a fast-charging line, led Vanderbilt's once-beaten Commodores to a decisive 13-to-7 Southeastern Conference victory over Georgia Tech before 17,000 spectators today.

George Wallace, formerly president of the New Haven Board of Aldermen and member of the Board of Councilmen, died yesterday at his home in Hamden at the age of 75. He was a candidate for Mayor in the city Democratic primaries thirty years ago.
A truly great filly won, and one of the year's filly sensations broke a leg in the twenty-fifth running of the $15,000 Washington Handicap at Laurel today.

Henry Armstrong, the Los Angeles Negro who created boxing history by becoming the first fighter to hold three regulation ring championships simultaneously, will risk one of his crowns, the welterweight diadem, in a fifteen-round bout with Ceferino Garcia of the Philippines in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

Shelby M. Singleton, who was identified with Chicago reform organizations for the last thirty-five years, died today at the Mayo Brothers Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 71 years old. His home was at 1.104 Forest Avenue, Wilmette, a Chicago suburb.

RAPID and extensive progress in the construction of military aircraft and in the types of materials used has made it possible for the United States Army Air Corps to abandon its practice of completely overhauling and rebuilding its ships at the expiration of predetermined periods.
BRAZIL has issued a new 2,000 reis piece in aluminum bronze. The obverse shows the bust of the Duke of Caxias (1803 to 1880), Marshal and Prime Minister of Brazil;

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than t can publish.
AN old dream is coming true in Athens. Work on the excavation of Plato's famous academy-the center of learning and a tourists' wonder in the ancient days-is being resumed after a lapse of five years.

Funeral services for Mrs. Mary Elmendorf Watson Ray, wife of the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, were held yesterday at that church. Mrs. Ray died last Wednesday in her Summer home at Ridgefield, Conn.

The marriage of Miss Lydia Gray Shaw, daughter of Dr. Charles Gray Shaw of New York University and Mrs. Shaw, to John Howe Bickford, son of Gershon P. Bickford of Berwyn, Md., and the late Mrs. Lulu Buck Bickford, took place here yesterday at noon in the chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church.
The German Minister to Lithuania left for Berlin tonight to report on the situation of Germans in Memel, semi-autonomous territory of Lithuania which belonged to Germany before the war.
Here in the "North Country," in Jefferson, Lewis and St. Lawrence Counties, Thomas E. Dewey should get about the same plurality that William F. Bleakley received two years ago.

The selection of Hachiro Arita as Foreign Minister is held to signify that Japan hopes shortly to be in a position to negotiate peace with China, although still adamant against Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Activity in the redemption of bonds before maturity increased substantially last week, when announcements were not only more numerous than in the preceding period but included also several large issues of public utility bonds.

In view of the fact that scores of inquiries have been received concerning the Pennsylvania shooting season, which opens for upland game tomorrow, we will list some of the areas where the State has set up farm-game sections.

From the outset, expert forecasts of the results of the coming election have conceded a gain of Congressmen to the Republicans. But from time to time the estimate has varied. A poll by Newsweek, based on replies by Washington correspondents and by experienced politicians, has reduced its estimate.

The University of Richmond eleven upset Washington and Lee, 6-0, today. The game was played on a field made dangerous by two days of rain. Stewart Hoskins, substitute half, crossed the line in the third period from his 2-yard mark for the lone tally.

A Brooklyn team that suddenly found itself in the last quarter of last Sunday's game with the Giants will clash with the Redskins at Ebbets Field today, convinced that it has found the right combination for keeping itself in the Eastern Division race of the National Football League.

IT is the greatest joy to feel justified in putting on one side all contemporary world tangles, political and social, to concentrate on a literary work of art brimful of the sort of human interest that never stales or gets out of date and is startlingly original to boot.

After hearing nearly two hours or argument, Justice Joseph B. Perskie of the New Jersey Supreme Court continued today until Dec. 10 the hearing on Asbury Park's plea to regain control of its finances from the State Municipal Finance Commission.

THE forty-ninth annual exhibition of American paintings and sculpture, which recently opened at the Chicago Art Institute, where it will remain current until Dec. 4, includes more than 300 works of art by some 280 artists.

In response to the request of Secretary Woodring, Governor Murphy has named three State officials to confer with the War Secretary Nov. 3 on the proposed Federal flood-control program in New Hampshire.

The first motorcycle championship trials held under thbe auspices of the Army Motor Cycling Control Board were concluded at Aldershot today in the presence of Sir Reginald May, quartermaster general, who awarded prizes. One hundred officers and men competed.

Alumni of the Tome School at Port Deposit, Md., have decided to buy and control this old preparatory institution on the edge of the South. For some years the alumni have had this plan in mind, desiring to add the Tome School to the ranks of other preparatory schools in the East owned and controlled by former students.

To the Drama Editor: I object! I want the road to come back. I don't want to be dangled on a limb with fake advertising. I want "flesh and blood" tramping the boards in my town, and I'm willing to pay for it, but "You Can't Take It With You," for Oct. 28, advertises "Forty Broadway Artists."

Unglamorously but effectively, two feminine factions of those political nonconformists labeled independents are concentrating these days on the "spade work" that materializes on election day into votes at the polls.
A pass-conscious Boston College eleven remained in the dwindling ranks of unbeaten major football teams today by walloping the University of Florida, 33-0, before a chilled throng of 10,000 fans.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's delay in appointing a successor to the late Lord Stanley as Dominions Secretary has revived a report, which springs up periodically, that the government intends abolishing the Dominions Office or merging it with the Foreign Office or the Colonial Ministry.

The strike at the Monterrey refinery of the American Smelting and Refining Company was suspended today Until Nov. 17 by the Federal Labor Board. The purpose is to determine whether the workers and the company can reach an agreement.

Plans for a State-wide contest to find a native American soprano between 16 and 21 years old were announced yesterday at a luncheon forum given by the New York Federation of Music Clubs, sponsor for the event.

THE rugged, heavily wooded stretches of the Cherokee National Forest just back of Tellico Plains, Tenn., will be the mecca of big-game hunters from all parts of the country during the next two months.

Permits by which thirty-four airplanes were shipped out of Canada purporting to be destined for Turkey were issued by the National Revenue Department on application from a Canadian manufacturer, a departmental statement disclosed today.

Skippers of the Staten Island Power Squadron who have passed successfully the elementary instruction course in navigating, piloting and small boat handling will be led upward through the maze and mysteries of--advanced seamanship, beginning tomorrow night.
The new Federal Wages and Hours Law which went into effect last Monday morning without any fanfare raised a host of questions to which the answers will be made slowly in the months to come.
THE semi-annual pair tournament open only to residents of Long Island will be played at the Garden City Hotel in three sessions, Friday night, Saturday afternoon and night.
Mexican petroleum for Brazil is to be handled here by a newly organized Brazilian corporation under the name Pemex, it was divulged today by press dispatches from Mexico.
(All time is P. M. Eastern standard, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycles.) Today 11:00 A. M.-Memorial Church service, Harvard University, WIXAL, 15.13--Boston.
John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O. and president of the United Mine Workers of America, predicted today that Congress would not amend the Wagner Labor Act.

Last-period rallies won for Notre Dame and Pittsburgh in two of the leading attractions on football's biggest Saturday in the East. Notre Dame got two touchdowns in rapid succession at the Yankee Stadium to subdue Army before 79,000 fans, and Pitt, playing in its own stadium, came from behind with three touchdowns to conquer Fordham as 75,867 looked on.
IT is no mean task to make the mere physical preparations for such an exhibition as the National Automobile Show, which will open in Grand Central Palace on Armistice Day.
FIRST LADY: On Eagle Street in Albany, N. Y., is the red, rambling, Victorian mansion that for more than sixty years has been the official residence of the State's Governors.

Calmly disregarding the current slow pace of retail trade, men's clothiers last week embarked on their most extensive buying campaigns in eighteen months, reports from manufacturers and resident buyers indicated.

Paintings by eightenth century British and American artists, works of the Barbizon School and nineteenth century genre examples from the collection of the -late Mrs. Charles B. Alexander and- the late George F. Baker will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Friday evening.

An appreciable increase was noted last week in purchases of goods for holiday selling, but demand for merchandise for current sale was disappointing, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

DIGNATARIES from the city of Montreal, accompanied by a martial escort, are coming soon to Ticonderoga to supervise the erection of a handsome monument, flanked by four cannon, designed to honor the French regiments quartered at the fort more than 180 years ago.

While crossing the street near his home, Jerry Byrd, 7 years old, of 144 West 103d Street, was killed by a Department of Sanitation truck last night, on 103d Street about 200 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue. Witnesses said the boy appeared to have slipped and fallen beneath the truck.

Reservations from 150 authorities on housing and municipal officials from all parts of New York State have been received for the Statewide housing conference to be held at the Hotel Astor on Friday and Saturday under the sponsorship of the State Board of Housing.

Flashing a strong passing attack, the Connecticut State eleven defeated Middlebury today by 13--0. Donnelly swept the end of the Middlebury line to tally in the second period. Kosikowsky took a Middlebury fumble in the end zone in the last period.

Never losing heart although repulsed on several scoring bids, Lawrenceville School's unbeaten football forces finally bagged a last-period touchdown today to gain a 6-all deadlock with the Hill School in the thirty-third edition of their traditional gridiron series.

Phillips Exeter Academy was routed, 25 to 0, by Hebron Academy today. The Maine school played superior football in all departments and scored mainly by the forward pass and long runs by Dolan and Johns.

Three thousand members of patriotic and military organizations will take part next Sunday in the seventeenth annual parade of the Massing of the Colors on Fifth Avenue from Seventy-eighth to Fifty-third a Streets.

Plucky Grinnell fought Drake on nearly even terms for three periods tonight before the Bulldog manpower asserted itself with a twotouchdown offensive in the final period for a 21-6 Missouri Valley Conference victory.
Western Maryland rolled over Mount St. Mary's of Emmitsburg today, scoring two touchdowns in the first period and one in the third for a 21-0 triumph.

Carlos W. Munson, president of the Munson Steamship Company, announced yesterday that as soon as the three remaining vessels of the company's former passenger fleet are sold next month he will call a meeting of the board of directors to plan the company's future operation of freight services.

Milk distributors here were discussing last week a possibility that the committee just appointed by Mayor La Guardia to examine methods of marketing of milk in this area would consider the advisibility of legislation permitting the city to set prices and give franchises to private companies.

Many entertainments were given in this locality today in connection with the running of the second day's program of the twenty-third annual meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds, over Froh-Heim, the estate here of Mr. and Mrs. Evander B. Schley.

Pennington School for Boys will observe its 100th anniversary in a celebration to be held here Nov. 5, 6 and 7. Dr. Francis Harvey Green, headmaster, announced the anniversary program today, which opens on Saturday afternoon with a football game between the school team and Admiral Farragut Academy, followed by an alumni celebration in the evening.

A portrait of the late Hannah J. Patterson, Pittsburgh business woman and civic leader, was presented to Wilson College, her alma mater, at the annual meeting of the Wilson Alumnae Council this week-end.

By occupying the southern metropolis of Canton nine days ago Japan completed her military control over China's "front door"-the row of ports along the Yellow Sea, the East China Sea and the South China Sea.

IT is a vast pleasure to encounter a biography of a great composer which is not a bedtime story or an attempt to reduce the subject to the mental and moral level of the author, but the effort of a sensitive and admirable student who can write vividly and concisely, desiring only to do his humble best to read the lesson of greatness.
The Hobart College football team overwhelmed the University of Rochester eleven, 40 to 0, in the fifty-first renewal of Western New York's oldest gridiron classic today.

Mrs. Louise Russell Cornelius, widow of Charles O. Cornelius of this city, was married to James Watson Over of New York, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Over of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Judge Over, yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Callery of 812 Park Avenue.

Scoring late in the second period on an 8-yard touchdown pass from Bill Jones to Martin Quick, the Bucknell Bisons defeated the Albright Lions, 6-0, before a Fathers' Day crowd of 7,000 at Memorial Stadium today.

Seven new scholarships, ranging from $500 to $800, were announced today by Miss Margaret T. Corwin, dean of New Jersey College for Women. About 100 scholarships will be awarded to members of the class of '43 next year, and both scholarships and loans will be available to upper classmen as in the past.
Iowa's Hawkeyes, heckled on several fronts because of listless traits, replied to their football critics today with a fiery performance which brought them a scoreless tie with heavily favored Purdue.
WITH two additional body types available, GrahamPaige Motors Corporation last week announced its 1939 cars.

Dr. George W. Lewis, director of research for the National Advisory Committee, told the closing session of the rotating wing aircraft meeting today that "windmill" type planes "definitely open the way for a wide expansion of private flying in the United States and abroad."

HONG KONG. for scores of years just a tiny red dot on the map, has become a big question mark in Anglo-Nipponese relations. The change has been wrought by the long deplayed invasion of South China, which has set in motion events threatening eventual disaster for this crown colony and even major setbacks for the British Empire, of which it stands as a political, -strategic and commercial symbol in the Far East.
Investigation into activities of two candidates for Governor rekindled interest in Wisconsin's general election tonight.
Experimental production will comprise a large part of the coming season's schedule of Cap and Bells, student dramatic organization of Williams College.

The Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, Inc., of the State of New York made public yesterday the report of its directors on the nine proposed constitutional amendments which will be voted on throughout the' State on Nov. 8.

Frank Dixon, Negro star from James Monroe High School, wrested the lead from Robert Chisholm of Kearny in the final fifty yards to triumph in the second annual, interscholastic cross-country meet sponsored by the New York University Spiked Shoe Alumni Club at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for the short term in the United States Senate, has submitted to THE NEW YORK TIMES his replies to an editorial, asking that the senatorial candidates outline their position on six questions.

Ronald Clark of Yale strode to an easy victory over representatives of Columbia, Dartmouth and Cornell yesterday in the annual quadrangular cross-country meeting of the squads over the grueling Van Cortlandt Park five-mile course.

With comparatively little excitement--nothing to compare with the furor at the launching of the NRA-the first nation-wide, Federally enforced basic wage scale for industry since the NRA's collapse went into effect last Monday.

Mrs. Joel Chandler Harris, widow of the creator of the "Uncle Remus" Negro folk tales, died here tonight after a long illness. Her age was 84. She had been an invalid since April, 1925, when she was stricken with partial paralysis.

THE season's plans at the OperaComique include five novelties and a respectable quantity of revivals. The new works mentioned are "Sous le Masque," by Georges Auric; "Guignol," an opera bouffe, by Andre Bloch; "La Nuit Parfumee," by Henri Hirchmann; "Le Diable Amoureux," by Roland Manuel and "Comme ils s'aimaient," by Andre Lavagne.

A two-year study of operation and comparative results of public and private management of economic activity, both in the United States and elsewhere, was announced yesterday by Dr. Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Homer E. Capehart, Buffalo phonograph manufacturer who helped start the Republican campaign with a "cornfield conference" on his farm near here, followed that up tonight with another new kind of political meeting-a radio rally for party workers in Indiana.
THE first season of the newly reorganized Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo is unmistakably a success, not alone from the box-office standpoint, bu in other respects as well.

Trailing by two touchdowns late in the fourth period, Union College drove 60 yards for a touchdown and had advanced 40 yards toward another as the game ended, with Williams ahead, 13 to 6. The thrilling contest was witnessed by 5,000.

Class I railroads in the first nine months of 1938 had a net railway operating income of $205,073,657, or an annual rate of return of 1.10 per cent on their property investment, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

THE play is an air raid. The terror will last for thirty minutes. The American radio audience has never had such a horrifying experience, and so the problem of the dramatist becomes more acute. He must make it sound real.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, left for Berlin this evening after another meeting with Premier Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, at which it is understood, an agreement on the Hungaro-Czech problem was finally reached.

After the stock market's closing at noon yesterday, many in the financial. district chose to remain around the financial news tickers for news of the Railroad Emergency Board's report to President. Roosevelt on the rail wage situation.
Western Reserve's Redcats, paced by Johnny Ries and Johnny Lucas, turned on power against Boston University today and smashed out a 47-to-6 victory.

ASTOR-Marie Antoinette: Norma Shearer, Tyrone Power.* BELMONT-Irish and Proud of It: Richard Hayward. CAPITOL-Stablemates: Wallace Beery; The Citadel: Robert Donat, Rosalind Russell, opens Thursday. CRITERION-Touchdown Army: Mary Carlisle; Girls School: Anne Shirley, opens Thursday. 5TH AVE. PLAYHOUSE-The Story of a Cheat: Sacha Guitry.* 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-The Edge of the World;* This'll Make You Whistle: Jack Buchanan, Elsie Randolph, opens tomorrow.

It is an old axiom of, national economy that trade follows the flag, and where the flag does not penetrate "spheres of influence" do as well. National Socialist Germany, which has upset so many axioms, upset that one too, or at least supplemented it with two other axioms:

With Mayor La Guardia, other public officials and a number of Bronx civic leaders expected to participate in the ceremony, the new Westchester Avenue roadway bridge over the Bronx River will be formally opened to traffic Tuesday.

THAT wonder guy of the garment trade and Broadway, Mother's little Harry Bogen of the Bronx, first introduced in his "I Can Get It for You Wholesale," continues his story in "What's in It for Me?" He is to be commended as the most savagely portrayed figure in contemporary letters.
THE MARIAN EXILES. A Study in the Origins of Elizabethan Puritanism. By Christina Hallowell Garrett. IX and 388 pp. Cambridge University Press; New York: The Macmillan Company. $6.50.
The qualifications of several hundred young lawyers are now being scrutinized by John Harlan Amen, who is building up his staff for a searching inquiry into the lawenforcing agencies of Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Miller of New York and Lake Mahopac, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Hughes Miller, to Lieutenant Thomas Charles Compton, U. S. A., son of Warrant Officer and Mrs. Hubert Compton of Fort Lewis, Wash.
Reports recently received from many of the leading builders, developers and realty brokers in Bergen County and other sections of New Jersey indicate, announced Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey
At St. Michael's College, Winooski Park, Vermont, a new policy of the official alumni quarterly known as The Michaelman is attracting attention.

Leslie MacMitchell, former George Washington High School star, now at New York University, captured first place in the freshman triangular cross-country meet in which Manhattan and Columbia representatives also competed at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
Miss Mary A. Judge and John A. Donohue, both of New York, were married here this morning in the Chapel of St. John Fisher in the residence of the Bishop of Rochester.

St. Lawrence University paid tribute this week to Dr. Charles Kelsey Gaines professor of the Greek language and literature and of English literature, emeritus who for sixtyseven years has been affiliated with the university as student or teacher.

Trailing by six points at the half, Vermont unleashed a passing attack and defeated Norwich, 20 to 6, before a homecoming crowd of 3,000 today. Trigilio went 15 yards off-tackle for the first score. Taylor tossed a 33-yard pass to Bill Pye for the second and Dave Jones plunged through tackle for the third.

WEATHER clear; track heavy. The early morning rains had left the Yankee Stadium turf a trifle sticky for the annual ArmyNotre Dame engagement. It hampered the runners, but it proved a nice soft couch for falling bodies, of which there were plenty during the football festivities.

Captain Angus Walters's missing International Fishermen's Trophy bobbed up tonight in a foundling home. The cup disappeared soon after the captain's Canadian salt banker Bluenose won it for keeps Wednesday by beating the American challenzer Gertrude L. Thebaud.

Louis Waldman, labor attorney and candidate of the American Labor party for Kings County Judge, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner tendered to him by a committee of civil service employes at the Towers Hotel, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn.
