HOLLYWOOD has reached the fiddle. Singers were employed first and in abundance; the record includes names such as Lawrence Tibbett, Grace Moore, Lily Pons, Gladys Swarthout, Nino Martini and Kirsten Flagstad.

The stock market was unusually narrow and dull during the short trading session yesterday. The closing was irregularly lower. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 613.000 shares, compared with 1,126,000 the Saturday before, and was the smallest volume since Sept. 10.
The New York University freshmen defeated the Rutgers cubs at football, 13 to 7, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the second loss for the visitors in three starts.

Action on three fronts was brewing at the week-end on the plan of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., to register both paid and commission buyers of furs as a means of curbing unfair returns of merchandise.

A steadily increasing demand for acreage property in the Bernardsville section of New Jersey is -reported by Philip B. Lawrence and Harry T. Miller, comprising the realty firm of Country Properties, Inc.

The annual exhibition and sale of useful and decorative articles, the handicraft of refugee women in the Near East, will be held Thursday and Friday at the home of Mrs. James M. Speers in Montclair, N. J. Mrs. Florence Spencer Duryea, who has traveled extensively in the Near East, will direct the sale.

Miss Suzanne Paris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Andre Paris of Edgartown, Mass., formerly of Princeton, was married in Princeton University Chapel this afternoon to Henry Clay McCormick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hays

Despite the apparent desire of both Governor Herbert H. Lehman and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, to avoid stressing national issues in their respective campaign speeches, it has become obvious that the attitude of the voters toward the policies of President Roosevelt is likely to be a determining factor in the election of Governor and the other New York State officers when the voters go to the polls on Nov. 8.

Although there was a sharp decline in building permits in leading cities during the first six months of 1938 as compared with the same period last year, a decided upswing during the third quarter brought the nine-month total for this year to a point onlyslightly behind 1937.

Dr. Lewis W. Douglas, principal of McGill University and former Director of the Budget, and Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Temporary National Economic Committee, will discuss "Industrial Organization and the American Ideal of Living" at the annual dinner meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor Wednesday night, Nov. 9.

John H. Morris of Far Rockaway was re-elected president of the Long Island Real Estate Board at the annual meeting last week of the board of governors. Walter S. Dayton was elected vice president for Queens Borough and H. Ward Ackerson, vice president for the NassauSuffolk district.
LONDON.-Now that the Czechoslovakian crisis has been "solved" the British Government is faced with the problem of what to do about German demands for the restoration of the old colonial empire.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 29 unless specified: At Guantanamo: Brooklyn, Savannah. Gibraltar to Ponts, Del Gada Claxton, Manley.
1st Lt. William L. Parker, F.A.-Res., 73 Bedford St., New York, N. Y., having enlisted in the New York National Guard, is relieved from his present assignment to the Field Artillery Group.

Trading in wheat futures on domestic exchanges was inactive today. Prices here held within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel, showing stubborn resistance to scattered selling, but there was no follow-up to the buying. Closing trades were 1/2 cent lower on the December and 1/4 to 3/4 cent higher on the deferred months.
Susquehanna University's nomecoming day football game, in which all the scoring was done in the first quarter, resulted in a 13-7 victory for Moravian College today.

During thirty years of showing, the annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York has developed from an insignificant one-room affair into a large and colorful show of over seventyfive competitive events, which, this year, will fill several large rooms at the American Museum of Natural History, Nov. 10 through 13.

THIS book contains more than 350 letters and memoranda by the Prince Consort and most of these miscellaneous papers appear for the first time. The rest are shrewdly selected from earlier volumes and are thus rescued from oblivion.

Holding to a conviction that lifting of tax immunity from future issues of Federal, State and municipal bonds should be brought about only by a constitutional amendment, the Investment Bankers Association of America formally went on record today as advocating adoption of an amendment to permit a form of reciprocal taxation of all future issues of such bonds.

Various proposals in connection with the reorganization program of the New York Stock Exchange, intended more adequately to protect the investor, were scheduled for discussion at conferences over the week-end between William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and William McC. Martin, president of the Exchange.
Veteran organizations supporting Governor Herbert H. Lehman for re-election have arranged a huge reception for him when he returns home this evening for the closing days of his campaign.

The turnover on the Boerse was small today. The principall issues were irregular, fractional gains predominating. Yesterday's boom in shipping stocks and colonial issues on rumors of an early return of the German colonies to the Reich was not continued, although shipping gained up to 1 7/8 points.

Walloping William Osmanski, Holy Cross' brilliant fullback and captain, gave one of his greatest ballcarrying performances today and led the powerful Crusaders to a smashing 21-0 victory over Colgate.

D. Robert Yarnall, chief engineer of the Yarnall-Waring Company of Philadelphia, has been re-election president of United Engineering Trustees, of which the Engineering Foundation is the research organization, according to an announcement yesterday.

THE concerts to be presented in the Library of Congress this season, under the auspices of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, will be inaugurated tonight with the annual Founder's' Day concert, which will enlist the services of the Coolidge and Gordon String Quartets.

By changing the paint in a room homeowners often may obtain three times as much light from the same lamps and fixtures, points out Dr. Samuel G. Hibben, director of applied lighting of the lamp division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

Loss of several of its crack sprint swimmers of last year did not prevent Textile High School, Manhattan-Bronx champion of the Public School Athletic League, from winning its Initial aquatic engagement of the season yesterday.

NOW, three and a half years after its starring debut, it is possible to examine the three - component Technicolor and say that it has not revolutionized the cinema after all. "Becky Sharp" had its premiere in June, 1935. Since then there have been only about twenty-five films in Technicolor, a gayly pigmented drop in the bucket of the 1,500-odd pictures produced in the period.

The formal dedication of the New Salem development on Port Washington Boulevard, between the North Hempstead Country Club and Port Washington Park, Port Washington, L. I., will take place, this afternoon. Walter J. Harter and Cy Williams are the developers.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 28: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Smith, R. C., Inf., one-month leave, Nov. 15.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 22 were announced by the State Department today: These Vice Consuls ordered from their respective posts to the Foreign Service School, effective Jan. 17:
Edward Corsi, Republican Senatorial candidate, speaking in his own behalf, WOV, 2:30 to 2:45 P. M. (1,130 Kc.).
THIS, says Rachel Field in the "letter of introduction" addressed to her novel's heroine, is the story she has always wanted to tell. She tells it superbly. And it is a story: the story of a young
THE House of Krupp was at one time called the Armory of the Empire. At the height of its glory it had a peacetime personnel of more than 80,000 and a wartime personnel of 160,000 employes.

What is said to be the first student sound film with synchronized talking to be produced in this country will be made at City College by the student members of the House Plan, the social activities unit, according to an announcement by Frank Davidson, director of the plan.

The New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold, German-English daily, which also gave a detailed account of Dr. Borchers's speech, reprints the full German text of the address in its issue this morning with an introductory comment, which was translated by an editor of that newspaper, as follows:
Fordham College's Mimes and Mummers, dramatic organization, is planning to widen its scope of activity in order to give the nonactor a greater opportunity to participate.

THERE has long existed a need for a good up-to-date but short history of economic thought. Professor Ferguson has attempted to meet this need in the present volume, and has succeeded in covering a remarkable range in less than 300 pages. He departs to some extent from a strict chronological account, but his exposition gains important advantages by doing so.

The world is changing so swiftly that textbooks cannot keep up with it. "No group of college teachers has confronted so many problems during the last decade as those who teach in our university schools of commerce," said Dean John T. Madden yesterday. He has been dean of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance since 1929, an urbane Massachusetts man whose fifty-sixth birthday fell on Wednesday.
Hun School's big football team, unbeaten for three years and tied only once, still had its victory string intact when its contest with Larry Kelley's Peddie boys ended on Annenberg Field today.

IN most of the discussion of the airplane as a weapon of war comparative air strengths are calculated by the number of aircraft. The mere figure 10,000, when applied to the number of craft that Germany was said to have ready for action, was enough to give noncombatants in large French and English cities cold chills and make diplomats walk warily.

Janitors employed in the city's public schools and colleges selected an A. F. of L. union as their collective bargaining representative yesterday by a margin of more than three-to-one over its C. I. O. rival.

The Republican National Committee put nine rank-and-file party members from various parts of the country, including a relief client, two college students, a grocery clerk, a farmer, a factory worker, a small business man, a physician and a housewife, on the air last night in a nation-wide NBC broadcast in behalf of its candidates.

A new demand for the return of Germany's former colonial possessions "as a whole" was served today on the powers holding them by General Franz Ritter von Epp, leader of the German Colonial League and director of the National Socialist party's Colonial Policy Office.

SOMETHING has gone wrong with our pursuit of happiness and Mr. Herbert Agar, a Southerner fervent in the Jeffersonian tradition, has set out to find what it is, telling "the story of American democracy."

Seven years ago this week the George Washington Bridge was formally dedicated and opened the following day to a public so on tiptoe with expectation that 57,778 cars crossed during the first twenty-four hours. That enthusiasm has not died.

At weekly meetings of various committees, plans are being completed for the annual Carnival on Wheels, the roller skating party to be given by many young women of society on the night of Nov. 11 at Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, as a benefit for the Vocational Service for Juniors.

Mount St. Michael High defeated Edison Tech of Mount Vernon, 6-0, today. The only touchdown of the game came in the first period when Jack Kerwin blocked Ed Codgell's kick and fell on it in the end zone.

Striking suddenly and unexpectedly in the first and third periods, St. Louis University made it two straight over Catholic University of Washington by winning, 13-0, in an intersectional football game today Last year the Billikens won, 7-2.

A $1.50 slump in the price of Southern Pacific stock was the initial reaction on the San Francisco Stock Exchange to the railroad fact-finding committee's request that the carriers withdraw their 15 per cent wage-cut proposal.

Miss Patricia Bull is enlisting the aid of a group of debutantes of this and recent seasons to assist Mrs. George Nichols and members of the executive committee in planning the Miami Biltmore Fashion Show Ball for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.
Dickinson College scored a 6-to-O victory over Washington College today. Padgen scored the touchdown in the opening period after a drive from midfield.
Curtis High School's football team of New York City took a 33-0 drubbing at the hands of Union-Endicott's undefeated and unscored-upon but once-tied Tigers today before more than 3,000 fans.
A crowd of 5,000 saw Bates overpower a bewildered Bowdoin team, 21 to 0, and win its first State series game today. The underdog, Bates, provided the biggest upset in the State.
THE success of Maurice Evans in the full-length "Hamlet" was inevitable. He is an extraordinarily able actor, clearheaded and sincere; "Hamlet" is the great play in the English language.

Eighty-six of the 200 families whom the government took from the Dust Bowl to the Matanuska Valley colony, in Alaska, have left either of their own volition or because the government found them undesirable colonists. The colony's manager, Leo B. Jacobs, also reported today that there were seventeen families in the colony "incapable of becoming or unwilling to be self-supporting." There are now 164 families on the project.

BLONDER-ROTHMAN-Mr. and Mrs. O. Rothman, 780 West End Ave., announce the marriage of their daughter, Ella, to Mr. Saul Blonder, New York. EICHNER-HERZOG-Mr. and Mrs. Harry Herzog, 333 West End Ave., announce the marriage of their daughter, Lucille Silvia, to Mr. Lawrence Eichner, Oct. 28.
TO the lover of nature this end - of - October weather may bring awareness of the pause before Autumn succumbs to Winter.
Retail trade continued last week to struggle with the thermometer, and found the going difficult. In most districts, sales were well below those of a year ago, and high temperatures were blamed.

A government construction program for the Quarantine station on Staten Island, increasing the housing facilities from fourteen to twenty-two families, was announced yesterday by Dr. C. V. Akin, medical -officer of the United States Public Health Service, in charge of the station.

Two performances of Philip Barry's "Hotel Universe," on Nov. 7 and 8, will open an expanded program of The Pennsylvania Players, a 1-yearold organization which now has a monopoly on campus dramatics at the University of Pennsylvania.

Tabor Academy defeated St. George's, 6--0, today for its third triumph of the season. A second-period pass from Captain Brett to Snell climaxed a 58-yard drive for the touchdown. St. George's third quarter drive to the 5-yard line failed as Tabor took the ball on downs.

Oklahoma's aerial bombardment defeated Tulsa University, 28 to 6, before 16,000 football fans at Owen Field today. Unable to dent a Tulsa line that turned out to be as stubborn as their own, the Sooners uncovered an aerial game that rocked the Tulsans.

White House concern and a share of the spotlight of the Dies committee are eleventh-hour developments which have moved the contest of Governor Frank Murphy for reelection in Michigan into the national political foreground.

INTIMATE is the word for Herbert Jacoby's little upstairs room-otherwise known as Le Ruban Bleu-and unique is the word for Morgane, the chanteuse who does for the opera singers what Fanny Brice did for the modern dance when she cocked one foot in the air and cried "rewolt!" Mme. Morgane is French and 50, which may explain her sophistication, but the devastating diva is more than that.
THE silent film, now a rarity on the professional screen, is giving way to the sound picture in the homes and clubs of thousands of amateur movie makers.
The Great takes exhibition opened to the public today in the Albright Art Gallery of this city, where it Will continue through November. Assembled are 165 paintings, oils and water-colors.

The Carroll Club, the center in this city for Catholic business girls and professional women, will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held the afternoon of Nov. 8 at the home of Mrs. Robert Louis Hoguet, 47 East Ninety-second Street.

NOT since "Alice in Wonderland" has the flesh and blood division of the screen dared indulge in the grotesqueries of stories that have proven as enjoyable to adults as to children. But at the moment Metro is being studiously whimsical in creating a film version of L. Frank

Epaphroditus Peck, jurist, author and a leader in the Congregational Church died today at the Bristol Hospital at the age of 78. He attended a legal meeting in Hartford Saturday. Sunday night he entered the hospital and later underwent an operation.
Fred Duprez, American comedian, died aboard the liner President Harding, it was reported today from the liner, which is at sea and which is due at Southampton next Thursday.

AIR express shipments in and out of New York City in September scored an all-time high for any one month since the inauguration of the nation-wide service or Sept. 1, 1927, according to Railway Express Agency.

Increased interest has followed the entry of the Political Union into the debating field. The fear felt by some members of the Yale Debating Association that the support given annually to that unit might be diffused has been dispelled and officials of both organizations today expressed the belief that the successful opening of the season in each group gave promise of joint development.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, speaking yesterday at a luncheon and rally attended by 250 young Republican men and women at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, praised the party's entire State ticket and declared that its high character was a guarantee that its election would sweep from power all corruptive influences in the State.

Premier Juan Negrin made a bitter attack on non-intervention plans and the powers supporting them tonight in a farewell broadcast to departing international troops. Once again, and in stronger terms than ever, he rejected any question of negotiation until all foreigners are withdrawn from Rebel Spain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a well-established tradition in the State of New York that the Constitution should not impose hampering restrictions upon the Legislature in the field of taxation.
An annual charitable event which always has the interest of many members of society is that given to aid the work of the Florence Crittenton League, a shelter for young women.
Before a Founders Day crowd of 3,000, Swarthmore scored in the first and third periods to vanquish Hamilton, 21-6, today.

The University of Maryland's battered football team went down to a crushing Southern Conference defeat at the hands of V. M. I. today. The score was 47 to 14. The Terrapins suffered their sixth loss before 6,000 homecoming-day fans.
Sewanee's hapless Tigers, playing in the favorite role for a change, were upset today :by Tennessee Tech, 7 to 6.

With sealed bids for the paving work on another section of the fivemile easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge in the Bronx scheduled to be opened tomorrow in the Bronx Borough President's office, construction of that thoroughfare is proceeding at a rapid pace and, despite a late start, the greater part of it undoubtedly will be ready in time for the World's Fair, a checkup reveals.
MANY people get their ideas of the Sahara from films, and probably nothing could be more misleading than some which show the desert as holding only ruthless Arabs and sweating legionnaires.

The Rev. C. E. Hill bagged a sevenpoint deer right in his dining room tonight. He shot twice, and the 250-pound beast dropped in his tracks. The Methodist minister, his wife and 4-year-old daughter were sitting at supper when the buck crashed through a window.

A precedent was set in English League soccer today when the King attended the Norwich City-Millwall contest. It was the first time in history a reigning monarch had attended a professional game apart from the cup finals, where royalty usually is represented.
A powerful St. Anselm eleven subdued the University of New Hampshire football team, 26-0, at Lewis Field today. A 30-yard aerial from Sikorsky to Johnson brought the first tally for the Hawks.
The National Lawyers Quild announced yesterday that it had designated Frank P. Walsh, Osmond K. Fraenkel and William Mack to ask Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo for leave to intervene

Coq Bruyere, gray gelding owned by John Strawbridge of Philadelphia, today stamped himself as the best of the timber-toppers for the year as he galloped to an easy victory in the New Jersey Hunt Cup, closing-day feature of the Essex Fox Hounds meet on the Frohheim estate of E. B. Schley.

Minnesota's football empire fell today. No longer are the Golden Gophers the symbol of reigning power in the Western Conference. In their place are the Wildcats of Northwestern, who beat down the Mighty Men of Minnesota, 6 to 3, in one of the most bruising, sensational battles of any season-and a distinct upset.
Elmer G. Fremont of Birmingham, Mich., was elected president and general manager of the Emerson Engineers, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, at a meeting held yesterday in the company's offices.

NOVEMBER rings up the curtain on New York's social season. Things get brilliantly under way with National Horse Show week, which begins on the 5th, and picks up with a big crescendo when, on the 21st, the Metropolitan Opera season starts.
THE way things are in the world at this moment, it's a good deal like starting an argument on religion to write a play dealing with fascism.

Jewish leaders asserted today that Interior Secretary Ignacio Garcia Tellez, formerly President Lazaro Cardenas's private secretary, had told them that nothing could be done toward permitting twenty-one German Jewish refugees, now aboard the liner Orinoco at Tampico, to enter Mexico.

INQUIRY at New York radio stations relative to the protest Alfred L. Dennis, president of the Bach Society of New Jersey, sent to the Federal Communications Commission against swinging Bach and other classical compositions, revealed that
Mr. and Mrs. Gregory McLoughlin of New York and Ipswich, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. McLoughlin's daughter, Miss Cornelia Whitehouse McLoughlin, to Edgar B. Van Winkle 2d.

New York City school officials, unwilling to see capable boys and girls barred from college or university because they did not follow a routine high school curriculum, have started a campaign to liberalize college entrance requirements.
MANY a fond parent has the delusion that the offspring, given a little press and a few pieces of type, is well started to become an important figure in printing history.
President Roosevelt has approved a new list of 521 non-Federal PWA projects, including eight in New York, ten in New Jersey and nine in Connecticut, it was announced today.

Mrs. David Challinor, Roll Call director of the twenty-second Roll Call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, to be held from Armistice Day to Thanksgiving, announced yesterday the division chairmen and vice chairmen. Edward R. Stettinius Jr. is general chairman of the drive.
Edward C. Bolle, for thirty-five years a member of the board of directors of the Mutual Savings Bank Harmonia, died this morning at his home here at the age of 86.

Two sales of English and American furniture, Oriental rugs and other art goods were completed yesterday afternoon, listing receipts of $69,566. The one at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized -$15,496.

ONLY seventy-four more days until "Gone With the Wind" goes before the cameras! There is a piece of news to make the welkin ring and set the Southern hills to rocking with echoes of the rebel yell. For perhaps no cinematic consummation

Whether losses sustained by a taxpayer are deemed to be "ordinary" or "capital" losses may materially affect the amount allowable as a deduction from income. Ordinary losses, like ordinary bad debts, are deductible in their entirety, whereas capital losses are deductible only to the extent prescribed by the revenue law effective at the time the loss is recognized for tax purposes.
SOLOISTS with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this week are Guiomar Novaes, pianist, and Robert Virovai.
Three things have occupied the attention of the farmer during the past fortnight: settlement of the 1937 corn loan by resealing or delivery, politics and corn-husking contests.

Although foreign prices failed to respond in sympathy with the upward movement here and in New Orleans, near months on the Cotton Exchange here strengthened again yesterday and the list ended 2 points up to 1 point down.

Although officially on the ballot, Samuel Fuchs, Socialist party candidate for Kings County judge, does not want the office. He said yesterday at his home, 1,892 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, that he "never sought the job" and that he "didn't want to run."

The fourth annual cookie sale will be launched tomorrow by New York's 17,500 Girl Scouts fbr the benefit of maintenance budgets in the five boroughs The event is one of the many scheduled for Girl Scout Week which over half a million Scouts throughout the nation willinitiate today with special services in churches.

Utilizing a near-by city as their laboratory, Mount Holyoke students in sociology this year will attempt to rub shoulders with reallife social problems through a link between class room theory and coordinated social agencies in Springfield.

Nine prominent financiers, including L. J. A. Trip, president of the Bank of The Netherlands, protested to the government today against the manner in which the budget was constructed and particularly the financial methods of the government.

A regimental review in honor of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, who is retiring from the service tomorrow, took place last night, on General McCoy's sixty-fourth birthday, at the armory of the 165th regiment, New York National Guard.

AXELROD--FINE--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fine announce the engagement of their daughter, Iris, to Mr. Maitland M. Axelrod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman S. Axelrod. CHARNAY-KRAFT-Mr. and Mrs. Max Kraft, 221 West 82d St., announce the engagement of their daughter, Shirley R.,
The Winter Ball, a supper dance that has enlisted the interest and cooperation of many younger members of society, will take place Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery said today before sailing for Europe that he was optimistic regarding Brazil's trade with the United States. He predicted greater improvement in exports from the United States to Brazil.

At the final session of the national convention of the Radical Socialist party today a resolution was adopted expressing the hope that an economic conference would be called at which, in accord with President Roosevelt's suggestions, means for remedying the economic disorder of the world would be discussed.

Representatives of the Saco Aviation Company sailed for New York today to purchase planes and other equipment for the improvement and extension of its service here. The government recently paid the company half of a subscription of $115,000 for placing operations on a sound financial basis.
ONE of the outstanding photographic events of the Fall season will be the opening today of the New York Salon of Photography at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street.
LURAY, Va. - Since Virginia's Caverns of Luray were discovered and opened to the public in 1878 eight other groups have been discovered or developed for public inspection.
Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was dull, with prices firm in all groups and fluctuations confined to fractions.

Verdi's "Otello" started the seven-weeks season of the Chicago City Opera Company at the Civic Opera House tonight. With a cast headed by Giovanni Martinelli, Helen Jepson and Lawrence Tibbett the performance was directed by Roberto Moranzoni.

IN 1828 George Palmer Putnam, a youngster of 15, came to New York and found a job in a Maiden Lane bookshop at $25 a year and his board. Yankee ambition soon led him to better jobs until, a century ago, he founded the publishing house of Wiley Putnam.
Mighty Texas Christian rustled up 524 yards by ground and air to rumble on undefeated with a 39-7 victory over the hitherto-unbeaten Baylor eleven before 25,000 fans today.

The announcement that the United States Government has authorized the importation of stock plants of new variety of elm bred especially for resistance to the Dutch Elm disease will be followed with interest by innumerable tree lovers and home owners in this country.

A new residential community limited to homes costing less than $6,000 is being opened in Valley Stream, Nassau County, L. I., a. few miles east of the Queens County line, by a syndicate headed by David Weisbarth, which has just

The text of Thomas E. Dewey's address at White Plains last night follows: For eight years now I have been working in the administration of criminal justice. The slow process of undermining the powerful forces in the criminal underworld is a familiar story.
Irvington High School, a Westchester Class C leader for the past two seasons, failed to score for the fifth straight game this year while playing Greenburgh High to a scoreless tie today.

A report on foreign trade issued today by the Philippine Commonwealth Department of Commerce indicated that the Philippines will have an unfavorable trade balance in 1938 for the first time in seventeen years.
The Elgin, Joliet Eastern Railway Company and two railroads leased by it asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to merge.

Ohio State's dazzling aerial game enabled the Buckeyes to score a convincing triumph over the New York University eleven at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The visitors packed their most damaging punch into the second period, in which they accounted for four touchdowns, and went on to subdue the Violet by 32 to 0.

Gains in three components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Oct. 22 were offset by four losses, and the combined index remained unchanged at 87.7. This compared with 97.3 for the week ended Oct. 23, 1937.
The midseason lull in new plays seems to have started earlier than usual this year, and the interval before the Christmas rush is singularly empty.

A Fairview hospital benefit ball at Berkshire Inn tonight was the leading Hallowe'en entertainment in the Berkshires. On the auxiliary committee in charge were Mrs. Albert Keep, chairman; Mrs. Delano de Windt, Mrs. Bertha V. Dunn, Mrs. Frank D. Griswold, Mrs. John B. Hull Jr., Mrs. Joseph H. Maloney, Miss Clara Newton and Mrs. Harry Hogan.

Thomas Heatley, retired New York City civil engineer, died yesterday at his home here after a short illness. His age was 73. Mr. Heatley, who retired four years ago after forty years of active employment, was chief testing engineer for materials used in the construction of the Bronx Borough Hall.
The writer of the following is the president of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, a government agency, who has just returned from a ten weeks' air tour of South America.

The opening date of the second merged New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities campaign for about $6,000,000 for 116 affiliated health and welfare agencies in Greater New York will be set this week, according to an announcement yesterday by Walter Rothschild, chairman of the drive.
Southern Methodist's razzle-dazzle kings today blasted their way over and through the University of Texas to open their 1938 Southwest Conference football campaign with a 7-6 victory.

James O. Moore, campaign manager for District Attorney Thomas E Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared yesterday that he was certain Mr. Dewey would be elected but added that constantly increasingly favorable reports made it impossible at this time to estimate his plurality.

Marking large-scale entry of the new two-cycle Diesel engines into road transportation, General Motors truck and coach division disclosed yesterday that it would offer for 1939 twelve new Diesel models-six conventional and six cab-over-engine trucks especially designed for the medium and heavy duty fieldall powered with the new type engines, put into production last Spring by General Motors Corporation in a variety of sizes.

The private library of Richard T. Ely, economist, has been acquired by the Louisiana State University. This library represents sixty years of collecting and is said to be the second most important collection on economics obtained by any American library in this century, being exceeded only in size and importance by the E. R. A. Seligman library obtained for Columbia University.

Raising the Issue of Red riots once more, Daniel J. Casey, Director of Public Safety in Jersey City, denied yesterday the application for an open-air meeting Tuesday evening at Pershing Field at which Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, was scheduled to speak.

In bunting-draped campaign headquarters in hundreds of American cities and towns political leaders and party workers last week speeded up the preelection machinery. There was handshaking, speech-writing and speechmaking. Literature was distributed.

Under the executive chairmanship of Mrs. Hans George Spitzer, the former Princess Dolly Obolensky, plans are now being made for the annual Russian Students' Ball, which will be given on Nov. 30 in the main ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Russian Alumni and Students Association.

An alert Johns Hopkins team managed to eke out a 7-6 victory over Haverford today. After a scoreless first half Charles Rudo, Hopkins quarterback, ran 80 yards for a touchdown and Spilman converted what proved to be the deciding point on a drop-kick.

THE campaign to determine who will be elected Governor of New York State is entering its final and most vigorous stage. The closing days of such a battle are generally interesting but this year they are attracting the attention of voters to an unusual extent because of the vigorous and contrasting personalities of the men involved.

Miss Ruth Jean Hemion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Freeman Hemion of Paterson, N. J., was married here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Verner Albert Johnson, son of Mrs. Emma D. Johnson of Cambridge, Mass.

Justice Peter P. Smith in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, held yesterday that although Albert Helmes, 40 years old, of 304 Covert Street, that borough, was born in Buffalo, N. Y., he was not a citizen of the United States.
American Jewish Congress meeting, Hotel Biltmore, 9 A. M. Luncheon session, noon.Afternoon session, 2 P. M. at which speakers will be: M. Maldwin Fertig, Carl Sherman, Professor Horace M. Kallen, Dr.
Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT-Charles R. Michie, from 5th Division to Emergency Service Division, assignment to desk duty continued, for 15 days, from 8 A. M.. Nov. 1.

Pennsylvanians with or without a flair for politics, whether they follow a professional career in Philadelphia, hold down an up-State WPA job or lounge about the apple barrel in the crossroads general store, are in agreement on one point in this State's political campaign:

The University of California at Los Angeles, staving off a last-minute aerial attack that had the Bruin rooters' hair standing on end, knocked over Stanford for the first time since 1935 today by a score of 6 to 0. A crowd of 37,000 saw the game.

Turkey continued today to pay tribute to its ailing President, Kemal Ataturk, today on the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of his regime. The three-day celebration was planned originally to commemorate Turkey's political westernization but it turned out to be a national tribute to the President, who is confined to his bed with a liver complaint.
Today New York Madrigal Society-Reception, program, Great Northern Hotel. Monday A. W. A.--Meeting. Speakers on constitutional amendments, 8:30 P. M.

Though Erica Morini played no less well than usual at her Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon, the point of distinction was her restoration of the Viotti A minor concerto. One uses the word "restoration" unhesitatingly, for while this work is one of the staples of every violin student's repertory, it is only accasionally brought to the public ear.

Expressing sympathy with the oojectives of the New Deal but criticizing its methods, Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, short term, declared last night that if elected he would work for an integrated system of social security that will embrace adequate unemployment insurance, old-age pensions and other protective social legislation in one unified and coordinated system.
Worcester Tech came from behind in the fourth quarter to defeat Rhode Island State, 19 to 14, on the gridiron today. Ben Lambert, Tech fullback, scored the winning marker from State's 4-yard line.

The New York Aggies lost to the New Britain Teachers today by 21 to 0 before a large home-coming day crowd. The Aggies were unable to break up the flood of Attavi passes nor cope with the hard running of the visitors' backs. Captain French and Schill were outstanding for the Aggies.
The Millersville (Pa.) Teachers College scored an easy 21-7 victory over the Trenton (N. J.) State Teachers eleven at the Hillwood Lakes field today.

Coomb's Pat Boy, owned by Willard Coombs of Temple, Pa., and handled in the field by Harry Campbell, today was declared the winner of the first stake in the fourth annual Autumn meeting of the Long Island Beagle Club.

PARIS. AS Europe still gropes with the problems left in the wake of the recent crisis and ponders what its future is to be, it begins to realize more sharply than ever that that future is likely to be molded by four men--four men who differ widely in their personalities and in their manner of dealing with the gigantic issues that confront them.

The first in a series of Autumn and Winter events celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the Child Study Association of America will be held tomorrow in the cottage of Hampshire House, when a tea will be given for members and friends of the association.

Tulane University's Green Wave showed everything a team should have-power finesse, stamina and confidence-in today's smashing 27to-0 victory over Mississippi State College before 20,000 homecoming fans.

THE first night of a J. B. Priestley play is a fairly common event in our theatre, but it remains an event. This is a tribute to the mental and physical energy which enables Priestley to be prolific without falling below the -standard of achievement that satisfies him as an artist.

Eight thousand Arab residents of Gaza who were suspected of harboring and assisting rebels against British authority were rounded up, searched, questioned and relieved of firearms in a surprise attack at dawn here today by British military forces.
A NEW instrument that is expected to contribute much to safety and economy of airplane operation will be announced soon, according to information from Baltimore, Md.

Pat Crowe, who kidnapped the heir to the Cudahy meat-packing fortune at the turn of the century, died at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Harlem Hospital. The 79-year-old ex-criminal suffered a heart attack last Wednesday in the furnished room at 124 East 128th Street where he had been living on an old-age pension for the last two Months.

WATER-COLORS, prints and drawings all had place in the newly opened exhibitions. Mrs. Sullivan has assembled at her gallery a large group of excellent and' representative lithographs and drawings by Daumier, Fantin-Latour, Lautrec, Rouault,

A Federal district court jury today convicted four Hot Springs residents of conspiring to harbor Alvin Karpis, the outlaw, in 1935 and.1936 and fixed their sentences at two years in the penitentiary, the maximum provided by law.

Erasmus Hall High's football warriors continued their victory march yesterday- when they crushed the previously unbeaten George Washington High eleven, 27 to 6, in the star attraction of a schoolboy tripleheader at Ebbets Field.
Colonists who had been gathering here for the last two days for a mass migration to Libya under the government's new colonization program steamed out of the harbor today on nine ships.

Speaking in Pennsylvania today in the interests of the New Deal, Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, urged voters here to support the Democratic ticket on Nov. 8 to prevent a return "to industrial barbarism and social chaos."
The house of delegates of the western zone, New York State Teachers Association, was on record today, 62 to 16, in favor of Federal aid to guarantee a nation-wide minimum education program.

Cornell's 150-pound football team showed power in defeating the Lafayette lightweights, 13-6, today. Wright Bronson plunged from the 2-yard line to climax a 30-yard firstperiod drive and Bob White raced 67 yards in the third period for the second score.
The Albright College Athletic Council has ratified a basketball schedule of nineteen games, which includes fourteen Eastern Collegiate Conference contests, for the 1938-39 campaign.
A PARTIAL preview of the government's stamp-production program for 1939, as made available by Robert E. Fellers, superintendent of the Postoffice Department's division of stamps,
BEFORE the Nineties were really gay, Eugenia Brooks Frothingham remembers, some Boston matrons hesitated before sending their 16-yearold daughters to an evening dancing class.

WITH television scheduled as a medium of public entertainment coincident with the opening of the New York World's Fair in April, interest is focused on the television stations already equipped to conduct visual broadcasts.

The directors of Newport Industries, Inc., have adopted a resolution proposing the offering to holders of capital stock of record of Nov. 9 rights to subscribe to 103,870 additional capital shares at $10 a share on the basis of one-fifth of a new share for each share now held.

Unable to stop Amherst's strong ground attack, Massachusetts State bowed by 35-0 on Pratt Field today. Amherst scored in each of the first three quarters and made two touchdowns in the final period in taking the forty-third game of the series.

Conceded only a remote chance of gaining a victory, Boys High overcame the hitherto unbeaten Abraham Lincoln football squad, 13-0, yesterday at Boys High Field: The setback was the first in four starts for the losers, who also have a tie in their record.

After a busy night making arrests ??arcotic agents of the Treasury Department brought two groups totaling eight persons to the Fedral Courthouse yesterday for araignment on charges of possession r sale of narcotics.

The Pennsylvania freshman eleven defeated the Princeton cubs in the annual game on River Field today, 21-0. Bob Sheppard made two touchdowns, the first on a 56-yard run in the opening period. Bill Davis tallied on a 40-yard pass by Fred Der inger in the last quarter.

The Broadway office of the East River Savings Bank, at the northwest corner of Broadway and Reade Street, has been completely redecorated and modernized. 'The- site, now one of the branches of the five offices in the city, was formerly the main office of the bank.

Calvert Magruder, general counsel for the Wage Hour Administration, informed the Motion Picture Theatre Owners of America today that it was "very doubtful" that theatre employes not engaged in interstate distribution' of films would come under the act.

Diplomatic circles here have been amused by published accounts that the Duke of Kent was being "exiled" to Australia to serve a fiveyear term as Governor General there. They are waiting to hear the reaction from Canberra, the Australian capital.
The University of Delaware completely outclassed St. John's of Annapolis today, scoring six touchdowns and five extra points for a 41-0 victory.

Joseph W. Catharine of Brooklyn, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will preside at the opening session and at all general sessions during the national convention in Milwaukee opening officially Nov. 9 and continuing through Nov. 12.

Fordham led Pitt by 7 to 3 as these two titans of the gridiron world swept into the last quarter of their thrill, packed drama before the enraptured gaze of 75,867 spectators in the Pitt Stadium today.

The break-even point of the steel industry in the third quarter of 1938 appears to have been closer to 45 per cent than to 50 per cent of capacity. This result is said to be better than was believed possible by most steel executives when prices were reduced on many important products at the end of June without corresponding action to reduce costs.
The mass deportation of Polish Jews, which commenced yesterday and continued all day today, has been suspended pending further negotiations between Warsaw and Berlin beginning early next week.

Addressing the Fall meeting of the Middle States Association of History and Social Science Teachers at the Hotel Dennis today, Professor Louis M. Hacker, lecturer in economics at Columbia University, said that the New Deal had not touched the basic problems of American agriculture.

Premier Benito Mussolini's second son, Captain Bruno/Mussolini, married Signorina Gina Ruberti this morning in the Church of St. Joseph in the parish, in which the Premier resides. After the wedding the couple, accompanied by their parents, visited St. Peter's Basilica and worshiped at the Apostle's Tomb in accordance with Roman custom.

Extra-curricular activities at Hunter College have been organized for the Fall semester with the election of more than 350 officers for thirtyeight clubs and societies. Most of the organizations have branches in the four centers of the college, bringing the total of clubs with their branches to more than seventy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The football game between the University of Delaware and the Pennsylvania Military College will take the spotlight in both sports and social programs in the resort during this week.

With a vigorous attack upon governmental competition, members of the New York State Architects, closing a three-day conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, called upon professional organizations throughout the country to join in resisting the "inroads of bureaucracy."

In an effort to arouse the interest of owners toward better buildings and finer alterations the Fifth Avenue Association is resuming the practice of making annual awards for the best improvements to realty in the section, it was announced yesterday.

A hard-driving, sure-passing Mississippi eleven overpowered George Washington University today, 25 to 0. Until today's defeat, George Washington was unbeaten, untied and unscored on-but it hadn't met Mississippi's Parker Hall, who dominated the day.

THE story of Christ forms the theme of a play--"Family Portrait" is its present title which Martin Broones is thinking of doing. The authors are Mrs. Lenore Coffee Cowen, who used the nom de plume of Rose Graham in writing "The Birds Stop Singing," and William Joyce Cowen.

Far off Australia, which is nearer to the unsettled Orient than to almost equally unsettled Europe, prepared this week to welcome the Duke of Kent, brother of the King, who, as her first royal Governor General, is expected to help strengthen the ties linking, that remote Dominion with Britain and with the throne upon which the Empire rests.
In the eighteenth renewal of a series that began before the turn of the century, Washington and Jefferson College conquered Geneva, 14 to 7, today.
Franklin and Marshall staged a comeback by defeating Drexel Tech, 1937 Eastern collegiate conference champions, today before a big crowd, 21-0. The victory puts the

Sixty-three gunners, the largest field on record for the opening shoot of the season, gathered at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The major event was a registered one at 100 targets. The High-Over-All Cup was taken by Roger Fawcett, who broke every one of the flying targets.
The Alumni Association of Columbia College will hold its fourth annual Autumn luncheon on Tuesday at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, in honor of the seven surviving members of the class of '79.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, chairman of the newly formed American Committee for Relief in Czechoslovakia, announced yesterday the receipt of numerous messages of support and encouragement for the organization.
REVIVAL of the American merchant marine-a topic much discussed in the last two or three years-appears to be emerging rapidly from the discussion stage into the realm of actuality.

Latter Day Saints, waging their thirtieth month of war on unemployment and want within their church, announced today that they were prepared to care this Winter for all needy members who had been willing to participate in the church's welfare program.

Springfield College made a surprise comeback today to defeat Northeastern University, 14 to 7, rolling up a safety and two touchdowns in the final half after the Huskies had completely dominated the picture in the first two periods.

SHORT waves from China now begin to slide over the polar belt into the Eastern United States. Recently, with the international dial pointer swung to the 11.45 megacycle mark, voices in Swatow, calling for response from China's recent capital, flashed into the New York area at 8 A. M.
Harvey C. Sherer, at one time in the telephone business and later a prominent engineer, died at a hospital last night after a long illness. His age was 69.

ITALY AT THE PARIS PEACE CONFERENCE. By Rene Albrecht-Carrle. Bvo. New York: Columbia University Press. 55.25. Published for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in the Series, "The Paris Peace Conference, History and Documents."

SOME of philately's amazing complexities confronted by the new collector interested particularly in Uncle Sam's postal output are strikingly illustrated in the specialized catalogue (Scott's) of United States stamps, the 1939 edition of which was released last week.

The American Cyanamid Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first nine months of 1938 a net profit of $1,400,280 after depreciation, depletion, research and process development expenses, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges.
Starting tomorrow and notcounting Sundays or national holidays, there are just forty-seven days left to get Christmas cards in the mail. The rush is beginning.

PASADENA, Calif. OUT across this country's most forbidding desert there is flowing today a thick, chocolate-colored flood which eventually will become the juice of more abundant cantaloupes for America's breakfast tables. Water is at last running in an All American Canal which will double the productive size of that natural hothouse of the nation, California's Imperial Valley.

Refusal of the Chicago millinery market to affiliate with the newly organized National Council of Millinery Associations will not affect plans to go ahead with the council, which will be pushed at a meeting to be held in Atlantic City next month, it was stated yesterday by Walter K. Marks, treasurer of the council.

Despite the fact that interstate pipe-line systems are common carriers and under the supervision of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the agitation for the divorcement of their ownership from the oil industry has come up with persistent regularity for more than a decade.

Declaring that many rate reductions ordered by regulatory bodies in recent years had produced an "unfair" or uneconomic reduction in the net income of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, J. I. Mange, president of the corporation, in his annual report to shareholders for 1937, made public yesterday, called for a more careful study by utility commissions of the "longterm economic effect" of new rates.
GENERAL comment on the Carnegie International at Pittsburgh appeared on this page a fortnight ago, but, save glancingly, the American Wing was not then reviewed and will be taken up now.

Football's glory road was a rocky and treacherous path today, but the Broncos of Santa Clara cashed in on a second-period break to down Michigan State, 7 to 6, and remain among the nation's undefeated and untied major college elevens.
The Scarsdale Women's Club will hold the first in a series of lecturediscussions on "Parents and Youth in a Changing World," on Tuesday at 10 A. M., when Dr. Edward H. Reisner will be the speaker.

HAIFA. THE minotaur of rebellion has made the little country of Palestine a worse than Cretan labyrinth of racial, religious and political mazes. More deplorable than villages and bridges bombed is the havoc within the personalities of the natives who live among snipers' nests in Galilee and the Judean hills.
Mrs. Mary Hulse Chadburn, widow of Samuel Chadburn, Yonkers wagon and carriage manufacturer, died at midnight last night in the home of her daughter, Mrs. William Roth, in Ossining.

Miss Frances Burke Haley, daughter of Dennis Frederick Haley of this city and the late Mrs. Haley, and Albert Eugene Blomquist, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Albert Blomquist of North Warren, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Miss Isabel Ward, daughter of Mrs. Atwood Ward of 400 East Fifty-second Street and of James Lakeman Ward of this city and Oyster Bay, L. I., was married to Robert H. L. Coogan yesterday afternoon in the apartment of her father at the Sherry-Netherland.

California's campaign for "$30 every Thursday" for every person over 50 who promises not to work is squarely in the national spotlight today as the 1938 elections approach the finish line, according to a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, accused William H. J. Ely tonight of committing acts that "seriously impugn his fitness to sit in the United States Senate" while State Administrator of the WPA.

Room 110 of the new United States Court House on Foley Square provides a serene setting, with its scroll-worked ceiling so high that the room seems cubical, its arched, maroon-draped windows, its black marble and walnut walls, its comfortable furniture upholstered in red leather, and its excellent acoustics that induce soft speech.

The historic Quaker Meeting House, built in 1669 on what is now Northern Boulevard near Main Street, Flushing, Queens, will be a center for all activities of both the Hicksite and orthodox branches of Quakers in connection with the World's Fair, it was decided yesterday at the Westbury Quarterly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.

The Jewish position is becoming worse and Jewish life utterly ruined in conquered areas because the democracies "are in retreat," Louis Lipsky, vice president of the American Jewish Congress, declared last night at the opening session of the congress at the Hotel Biltmore before 400 delegates, elected by 351,674 persons from 187 communities in thirty States.

Repair and modernization loans on properties in the, New York City area insured by the Federal Housing Administration since restoration of Title I to the National Housing Act slightly more than seven months ago have now reached the aggregate sum of $21,000,000, a new high record, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director announced yesterday.
Wesleyan won the important intrastate game with Trinity today, 7-6, Captain Daddario's extra point providing the margin.

A FILE of old magazines was the motivating force back of "The Fabulous Invalid." That and a harrowing attack of insomnia. It was a year ago, when "I'd Rather Be Right" was in the final throes of its rehearsal period.

Cocker spaniel breeders of the United States and Canada are looking forward to the seventeenth annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England which will be held Nov. 18 and 19, once more in Horticultural Hall, Boston.

Holding that a college "is more than a mind factory," Dr. W. H. Cowley declared himself in favor of an educational program embracing the development of the student as a "whole personality," in an address this morning at his inauguration as eleventh president of Hamilton College.

CONTINUING the sharp upward swing which got under way less than a month ago, automotive production during the past week topped the 70,000 mark and is expected to show further gains during the weeks to come.
Idaho defeated Montana State University, 19 to 6, today in a football battle between the "Orphans" of the Pacific Coast Conference.

From thousands of specimens of commercial printing produced last year by leading plants here, 863 examples, produced by 105 firms, have been selected by judges for the fourth annual printing exhibition of New York City,

With the critical point of the Fall coat and suit season at hand, the inventory condition is the "lightest in years," Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

With the new Wages and Hours Law affecting interstate commerce entering its second week, plans already are being laid for a national drive for State legislation which will set up similar labor standards for millions of men and women engaged in intrastate industries.

Frank Wing Holmes, 67 years old, a member of the Brooklyn law firm of O'Dwyer, Holmes and Bernstein, plunged to his death yesterday from the twenty-third story office of his firm at 26 Court Street. Brooklyn.

Striking with massed power and defending well against attacking manoeuvres, the unbeaten and untied Volunteers of Tennessee kept pace with the nation's outstanding football teams today by bowling over Louisiana State's Tigers, 14 to 6, before 36,000 fans, a record local crowd.

Mr. and Mrs. Dana Osgood of Boston have arrived from Narragansett Pier, R. I., at Hampshire House. Mrs. Samuel A. Welldon has left the Waldorf-Astoria for her country place in Hamilton, Mass. Mrs. Charles West Churchman of Jenkintown, Pa., is at the Carlyle.

Piling up its biggest point total since Benny Friedman took up the coaching reins in 1934, City College trounced Lowell Textile by 32-0 at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday to drop the Red eleven out of the ranks of the unbeaten with a resounding thud.

Mrs. Harriet B. Pratt Van Ingen, daughter of Herbert Lee Pratt of The Braes, on the Pratt estate here, and 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, New York, and the late Mrs. Pratt, was married this afternoon at her father's country home to. Donald Fairfax Bush of 29 Sutton Place, New York, a son of Mrs. D. Fairfax Bush and the late Mr. Bush.
Sale of the 7,300-acre estate and ranch in Colorado Springs, Col., known as Glen Eyrie, was reported yesterday by Previews, Inc.

Music Hall of the Air: An abbreviated version of Leoncavallo's two-act opera, "I Pagliacci," will be presented with Viola Philo, soprano, in the role of Nedda; Jan Peerce, tenor, as Canio, and Louis Purdey as Peppe.

It would be hard to overrate the quality and the effect of the performances given by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City. Superlatives have often been used, and exhausted, in discussing the accomplishments of this amazing musician.

Two railroad connections running through Czechoslovakia, uniting Austria with the Silesian district of the old Reich, over which German passengers and freight may be carried duty free and regardless of the usual passport and currency regulations, have been agreed to by the German and Czech Governments.

A COUPLE of seasons back two young gentlemen produced a Broadway stage hit out of what would seem to be the most improbable source material to hand-life in a strict and severely disciplined military college. The production was attended by considerable halloing and hat-tossing among the critics and no little financial kudos for the authors.

From now until the election of 1940 is over, the Republicans, La Follette independents and other mavericks in Congress and the President's Democratie political foes will surely keep watchful eyes on the national defense program. For they suspect that concealed in it are a scheme to perpetuate New Deal political power and a device to obtain new tax money which otherwise could not be obtained.
IN Saint Giles, Cripplegate, where the bones of Milton are lost in dust, arises no sculp tured sarcophagus, embellished with marble columns and recumbent effigy.

The entire question of American superliners to compete in the rich travel field now dominated by express vessels of foreign nations is being reviewed by the research department of the Maritime Commission, it was learned yesterday, indicating that the government has not closed the door finally on the possibility as an important part of the rejuvenated merchant marine.
The Museum of Modern Art in New York recently put on exhibition its newly acquired paintings and sculpture, which will form part of the permanent collection of the museum.

Today's Challenge to Trade Associations: By Roscoe C. Edlund, manager, American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc. The text of a series of lectures delivered before a group of professional trade association executives.

ON the evening of July 4, 1905, John Halliday, rich young boss of the Jumbo Mine in hell-roaring Goldfield, Nev., experienced a personal resurgence of the Spirit of '76. This patriotic manifestation had drastic results.

Miss Eveline Wilbor Williams and Saxon Winston Holt Jr. were married tonight in St. Paul's Church by the Rev. J. Keith Lee before a large assemblage of guests from New York, Baltimore, Richmond and Tidewater, Va.

With the disturbed conditions in Europe and Asia, Radcliffe College is receiving an increased number of students from abroad. This year's enrollment figures show the number of students from distant lands is almost double what it was last year.

Bradley Lewis, New York middleweight, continued to advance through the Pan American amateur boxing championships in the sixth night of competition tonight, but Robert Carroll, flyweight from Trenton, N. J., was beaten, Lewis outpointed Mario Schoub of Brazil, and Carroll lost to Juan Trillo of Argentina.

One of the largest philanthropically conceived theatre parties of the Autumn will be that arranged for the night of Nov. 14 by the managing board of the women's auxiliary of the Union Settlement, a neighborhood house which serves a crowded district of the upper East Side.
The department of stock list of the New York Stock Exchangehas been notified that two issues of the Milwaukee Electric Railway and Light Company have been called for redemption on Dec. 1 as follows:

Mexican gold production in the first half of this year totaled 14,006 kilos, compared with 13,418 in the same period of 1937, the Department of Commerce reports. Production of silver in the same periods was 1,443,995 and 1,411,284 kilos, respectively.

The entry of twenty-seven colleges in the Boston Dinghy Club regatta held on the waters of the Charles River Basin this week-end with the cooperation of Massachusetts Institute of Technology has focused attention on one of the most rapidly growing intercollegiate sports.
Asserting that the "American system" was at stake in the coming election, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg tonight called on the nation to rally to the cause of Republicanism.

The upward trend of business has inspired enthusiasm among the 4,500 campaign workers in the sixtieth annual United Hospital Campaign for a minimum of $2,523,179, It was reported last night by C. M. Chester, chairman.
Brown swamped Tufts, 48 to 0, today before a crowd of 5,000 as an army of Bruin reserves took over most of the play. Tufts reached the Brown 29 in its best advance of the day.

Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator executed a lease today turning over to the Atlantic City, N. J., Housing Authority complete operation and management of Stanley S. Holmes Village, the government's $1,545,000 slum clearance and low-rent housing project there.

Grace Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting for the marriage here this afternoon of Miss Helen Alice Grand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grand of this place and Greenwich, Conn., to Edwin Thorne 2d, a descendant of the Thorne family who settled in Dutchess County early in the eighteenth century.

Plans are well under way for the card party and bazaar in aid of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, which will be held the afternoon of Nov. 17 at the Plaza. Various committees have been formed to facilitate the sale of useful and decorative articles, as well as candy, which will be a feature of the benefit.

Young women of society headed by Miss Mariska de Hedry of Budapest, who, with her mother, Mrs. Etienne de Hedry, is visiting Miss Frances Coleman, are taking an active interest in the plans for the annual bazaar and bridge tournament for the benefit of the Convent of Mary Reparatrix to be held Nov. 9 at Sherry's.

A LINE of Ford V-8 trucks and commercial cars for 1939 equipped with hydraulic brakes and comprising the widest selection of capacities, gear reduction ratios and power it has ever offered was announced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company.

A mural, "The - United States Army. in War,". on the walls of the main entrance of the Second Corps Area headquarters building on Governors Island, was shown publicly for the first time Friday by Brig. Gen, Evan H. Humphrey, commandant of the post, and officials of the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration, under whose direction the mural was painted.

Miss Irene Jeannette Gleason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Gleason of this place, was married here tonight in the West Side Presbyterian Church to Ransom Clayton Talbot of Attica, N. Y., son of Mrs. Gertrude Talbot of Willsboro, N. Y.

What the Cooperative School for Teachers at 69 Bank Street considers a broader opportunity to serve public education is afforded through the recent approval of the school's training course by the New York State Department of Education.

IF I were examining an audience to see whether they understood Sacha Guitry's "Story of a Cheat," I'd ask them to explain the hero's question about his future wife--"I wonder if she can be trusted when she isn't gambling!"
Rose Schneiderman, secretary of the State Department of Labor, declared here that inquiries had been many and complaints almost absent since Monday, when the law went into effect.
Paced by Bennie Babula and Teddy Ciesla, Garfield High School's eleven continued its march toward the State Group 4 title by scoring a 19-to-0 victory over the Bloomfield High team today.
Two scoring thrusts, one through the air and another on the ground, gave Michigan's resurgent football forces a 14-to-0 victory over Illinois today before a homecoming crowd of 41,500.

RAIN from Kansas to the Texas Panhandle; some rain, but not enough in the northern parts of the "Dust Bowl"-these gifts of nature have quieted some of the alarm felt, even in Eastern cities, when Western real estate began to drift overhead four years ago.

Leonard Gerasso, 22 years old, reported to have deserted from the army nine days ago, tried to hold up Philip Pressman and his son, Jerome, in their jewelry store at 1,233 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, according to the police, but his toy gun was unconvincing.

SERGEI RACHMANINOFF will appear as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra, under-Eugene Ormandy, at its concert Nov. 8 in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Rachmaninoff will play Beethoven's First piano concerto and will be represented as composer on the program by his Third symphony, which received its world premiere by the same orchestra in Philadelphia two years ago.

AMERICAN cars carry $300,000,000 worth of batteries, and, with forecast sales of $92,000,000 of storage cells to be added next year, motor vehicles in 1939 will be capable of generating as much electricity as the output of all the turbines in the United States, S. B. Robertson, president

REMEDIAL legislation, which recognizes the differences in the nature of newspaper publishing and broadcasting is needed before the broadcasters can find comfort in regard to libel and slander, according to Representative Emanuel Celler, who in a recent

With her decks almost covered with drums of fuel oil and the little Aeronca scouting plane fastened to the hatch, my ship, the Wyatt Earp, sailed from Cape Town at noon today Greenwich mean time [7 A. M. Eastern standard time].

DRUCKER-Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Drucker announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Carl Sickle, on Saturday, Nov. 5, at Hebrew Tabernacle, 605 West 161st St. Reception following services, Hotel Bancroft, 40 West 72d St., from 1 to 5. No cards.

The professional tennis tournament featuring William T. Tilden and Vincent Richards of the United States and the Frenchman, Martin Plaa, scheduled to start today at the Sporting Club, had to be canceled at the last moment because Richards's right hand was injured when caught in a doorway.

IN 1922 Mr. Stearns edited "Civilization in the United States. An Inquiry by Thirty Americans." Included in that volume were three foreign points of view concerning American civilization, by an Englishman. an Irishman and an Italian.

Rice Institute today found a corking substitute for its injured Ernie Lain in lanky, speedy E. Y. Steakley, who scored two touchdowns to defeat Auburn, 14 to 0, for the Alabamans' third loss of the year. A crowd of 10,000 attended.
For the many humiliations Dartmouth has received at Yale's hands in the past, the Indians took ample revenge in the Bowl today.
Big John Kimbrough, a 211pound cyclone of a man, tore a fighting Arkansas line to shreds today as the Texas Aggies staged a story-book finish to defeat the Razorbacks, 13-7.
The Montclair Teachers College team beat East Stroudsburg today by 7--0, Selvomridge scoring in the first quarter. The losers missed three chances.

Manhattan, held scoreless for three periods by a rugged Canisius defense, rallied and tallied twice in the closing minutes of the last period to emerge with a 13-3 victory before 4,500 spectators today at Civic Stadium.
Japanese domination in China will cost American manufacturers $20,000,000 in annual sales to the Chinese market, in the opinion of exporters conversant with the Far East.

The drawing of names from which will be selected the extraordinary grand jury which is to investigate official corruption in Brooklyn will be held in the Commissioner of Jurors' office in Brooklyn at 10 o'clock Tuesday morning, it was announced yesterday.

Sweden's campaign for an increased birthrate through the establishment of maternity subsidies has resulted in more children in well-to-do families, but has had little effect in reducing birth control among the poorer class, according to Mrs. Alva Myrdal of Stockholm, newly elected vice president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

Raw silk distributors here have made representations to the Japanese Government suggesting that an official delegation be dispatched to the United States to study methods for combating the threat to the silk industry contained in the development of new synthetic yarns by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Malaya, Co. and by Celanese Corporation of America.
Two rapid thrusts at the start of the third period gave the American International College eleven a 12-0 victory over Brooklyn College on the Kingsmen's field yesterday.
Social security laws are laws chiefly affecting and industrial population. The new Wages and Hours Law chiefly conerns the

LONG before Helen's face launched a thousand keels and Ulysses went his roving voyage home to Ithaca and his waiting Penelope-long, long before old Homer twanged his lyremen went down to the sea in ships and the spell of a great adventure was laid upon men who did not. At the same time life afloat began for the mariner.

A 40 per cent increase in home relief allowances, simplified administration of unemployment insurance, inclusion of public employes in social legislation and strengthening of the civil service were urged in the officers' report presented yesterday at the opening sessions of the first State convention of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

APPEL, MOSES S. (Sept. 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To Addie Appel, widow, 305 West End Ave., 75 per cent of residue; Anna Sands Phillips, 12 W. 72d St., executrix; Madie Appel, sister, executrix, Atlantic Beach, equal shares in remainder.
Opening night at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, generally regarded as the inauguration of the Winter social season in New York, occurs next Saturday.
YOUNG men who qualified to carry on the whaling traditions of Nantucket and New Bedford are steaming toward the Antarctic.

Penn State's brilliant running sophomore backs were instrumental in a 33-to-6 victory over Syracuse University today in one of the season's most stunning upsets. Nearly 12,000 spectators watched the charging Nittany Lion forwards completely throttle the passing attempts of-Wilmeth Sidat-Singh.
Eddie Kosko, alert West Virginia Wesleyan end, scooped up a blocked try-for-point in the first period and ran it over the Waynesburg goal line today to give Wesleyan a 7-6 victory.

The story of copper, from its use for spearheads by the early cavemen to its present specialized development for high-tension transmission lines and other industrial purposes, will be told in animated exhibits at the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday.

Princeton University's Theatre-Intime, student dramatic group, will open its eighteenth annual season with the presentation of an adapted version of "Hamlet" in Murray Theatre during the week of Nov. 7-12, it was announced today by Alexander H. Lehmann Jr., '39, of New York City, president of the theatre.

Dates for several of twelve proejected regional conferences on occupational adjustment to be held during the Fall and Winter months in various cities throughout the country have been announced by the National Occupation Conferene.

A big Red team, reminiscent of the Cornell steamrollers that scored decisively over Columbia a decade and a half ago, conquered the Lions at Baker Field yesterday, 23 to 7, before a crowd of 34,000, officially estimated to be the largest gathering that has ever witnessed a contest there.

WILLIAM BLAKE was virtually alone among Englishmen in uniting the gifts of writing and painting in one person. The history of publishing abounds in examples of illustrated books that are the results of collaboration.

One hundred and ten men were named today to the "Who's Who on Rutgers Campus" by The Targum, undergraduate newspaper. The men named were: Student Council-Walter R. Bruyere III '39, Red Bank, president; Grover K. Coe '39 Orange, vice president; Akin Toffey '39, Jersey City, secretary; Ranney G.
Keuka College will be host to the group of fifteen women invited to attend the Council on the Education and Placement of Women in a Democracy by President J. Hillis Miller on Nov. 7.

The first thing to be said about the Japanese victory at Hankow is that it has come six months after it could have been expected on any reasonable calculation, certainly six months after the Japanese had expected it.

West Virginia cashed in on the breaks today, banging across four touchdowns on two blocked punts, a penalty and a fumble to trounce the Youngstown (Ohio) College eleven, 27-6. The Youngstown tally came in the last minute of the game on a pass Heber to Benish.
A new project at Pennsylvania College for Women is a film rental library, under the direction of Dr. James S. Kinder,, head of the Department of Education.
Miss Mary Sampson Horton and John Murray Black were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hudson Reddall, 173 Riverside Drive.

A slender red maple tree that will serve as a landmark for members of the Catholic Daughters of America at the New York World's Fair next year was planted yesterday on Front Street, near the Long Island Railroad station at the fair grounds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The intelligence of the voters of the State of New York will be tested on Nov. 8 as it has rarely, if ever, been tested. A revised State Constitution will be voted upon that day.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance and entertainment to be held the night of Nov. 23 at the Waldorf-Astoria. During the evening there will be a revue by professional entertainers.
Miss Mary edith Lackner, 43 years old, of Cincinnati, was burned to death today when her airplane trashed in flames in a cornfield near here.

Postmaster General James A. Farley predicted last night that the voters of the country would, give President Roosevelt a tremendous vote of confidence on election day By returning huge Democratic majorities to Congress.

The Federal Social Security Board is considering a request from the State Board of Social Welfare for an increase of more than $5,000,000 a year in Federal contributions to the aid of dependent children in this State, it became known yesterday.

The performance of "Leave It to Me," originally scheduled for this Thursday night to aid the Maternity Center Association, has been postponed to Nov. 10, the night following the New York opening of the new Cole Porter show at the Imperial Theatre.

THE beginning of actual operations of the nation-wide system by which every State and every art center in the country will be tapped for "the most comprehensive exhibition of contemporary American art ever staged at one time in this country" was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair. 1939.
Mrs. William Howells heads the fifth annual fashion show and tea to be held the afternoon of Nov. 17 on the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys' Club.

Virginia's eleven turned back William and Mary today by 34-0. The Cavaliers made two touchdowns in the second period, one in the third and two in the fourth. Virginia rolled up eighteen first downs against four for the Indians.

Foreign trade -problems, particularly those arising from recent developments in Europe, will be discussed this week by more than 1,000 exporters and importers expected to attend the twenty-fifth annual National Foreign Trade Convention- opening here for three days tomorrow.
