A tie-up of New Deal Democrats and La Follette Progressives now being effected silently but unofficially in many parts of Wisconsin may yet save the political hide of Senator F. Ryan Duffy and assure the re-election of Philip La Follette for an unprecedented fourth term as Governor of the State.

A reception in honor of William C. Handy, Negro composer, who will celebrate his sixty-fifth birthday on Nov. 16, will be given next Friday afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Delphic Studios, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street; under the sponsorship of the Harlem and Musicians Committees to Aid Spanish Democracy.
Joe Moclair led the Manhattan College cross-country team to a 15-to-40 victory over Alfred yesterday over a five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. Moclair was timed in 28:33.

NORA BURGLON'S story of rural Denmark appears in a thoroughly charming form. It would, indeed, be hard to surpass in distinction and appropriateness this beautifully printed little volume, designed by Helen Gentry and illustrated by Fritz Eichenberg.
A fire, believed to have been caused by a smoldering cigarette, damaged the walls, floor and furniture of a fifth-floor room of the Patton Hall tower on Princeton University campus tonight.
Dormitory students who are not fraternity members have risen to new power in the social life of Lafayette College by the revival of the Marquis Association.
Colby College rose from seeming defeat to score two fourth-quarter touchdowns and defeat a favored University of Maine eleven, 19 to 14, today, before 7,800 fans.
Battered and bruised in a savagely fought contest from which both teams emerged with frustrated hopes, Pennsylvania and Navy rounded out a half century of gridiron rivalry today without a score.

Window boxes and potted plants need no longer be a source of disappointment because of poor, stunted growth. Electrical science has come to the aid of enthusiastic indoor gardeners through research by engineers of the General Electric Company.

Peter Quioness, 40 years old, a Puerto Rican who was leader of the Guardana Democratic Club, Inc., of 133 Adams Street, Brooklyn, was found shot dead in Adams Street, between High and Nassau Streets, last night.

Miss Mary O'Leary, adopted daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Magawly Banon of 81 Riverside Drive and Newport, R. I., was married yesterday at noon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Dr. William P. Whalen, son of William E. Whalen of this city and the late Mrs. Whalen.

Senator William E. Borah said today that the real issue in present relations among nations was the "irrevocable difference between governments which would destroy liberty and governments which would preserve it."

An increase of 100,982 in the boy membership of the Boy Scouts of America in the first six months of 1938 brought the organization's total membership on June 30 last to 1,213,755 persons. This was announced yesterday by Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive.

Patrick Kehoe of 10-159 120th Street, Richmond Hill, a member of the Police Department for thirtythree years, and assigned to the Board of Education for the last nine years, will retire tomorrow. He is 63 years old.

A plea that the courts be kept independent of politics was made by Magistrate Anna M. Kross, American Labor party candidate for the Supreme Court in the First District, at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Belmont Plaza sponsored by the women's division of the party.

The recent trend toward solidcolor carpeting for living room, bedroom or den is reminiscent of the period before parquet floors came into common use for moderatepriced apartments as well as more expensive homes.

It is going to cost Uncle Sam about $9,000 to find out how many street lights and electric poles there are in this city, but Patrick Tumelty, manager of the municipal lighting system, knows the answer right now.

Federal authorities announced yesterday that plans have been made for an early grand jury investigation of the case of Albert N. Chaperau, who is charged with having falsely claimed diplomatic status to smuggle into this country wearing apparel allegedly delivered to the home of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer.
The Works Progress Administration plans to throw open its adult education classes to an additional half million persons during the coming months.

Detectives began an investigation yesterday into the death of Pat Crowe, one-time "bad man" who died Saturday in Harlem Hospital, following the disclosure by an autopsy that he had suffered a fractured skull.

Prospective upward trends in industrial activity and consumers' incomes were the principal bases for a forecast of a better demand for farm products in 1939 made today by the bureau of agricultural economics of the Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. James Vincent Coffey of this city has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Helen Coffey, to Dr. John Houston Sulzman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank- M. Sulzman, also of Troy.
The Fort Hamilton quartet conquered its reservation rival, First Division, 9-6, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton army post in Brooklyn. George Sherman made five goals for the polo winners.

President Roosevelt will meet tomorrow at the White House with George M. Harrison, head of the Railway Labor Executives Association, and John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, in an effort to avert a general strike of the nation's 900,000 railroad employes.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, will close his campaign with meetings in New York City this week. Mr. Thomas will speak today at rallies in Yorkville and the Bronx, at the Yorkville Culture Center, 268 East Seventy-eighth Street;

Interest in holiday-type merchandise improved last week, although sales of goods for current selling were disappointing. All types of apparel and accessories were in demand for gift use, and suitable types in house furnishings, furniture and regulation gift goods sold well.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hungerford Johnston of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Blanche Hungerford Johnston, to Herbert Widener Andrews, also of Westfield, son and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Andrews of Newport, R. I.

Hudson St, 482-86, s e cor Grove St; Old Chapel Properties, Inc, and Hudson Grove St., Inc to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, equal lien with mtg of $100,000; due on demand , $2,000, at 4 1/2 per cent. 19th St, 359 W; Gianbatista Sassarini to Mutual Life Insurance Co.; $9,000.

" Democracy is essentially a spiritual and ethical system and when it relies on force alone to fight the forces of fascism, democracy loses its birthright," the Rev. Charles Francis Potter said yesterday in an address before the First Humanist Society, 113 West Fifty - seventh Street.

The New York League of Women Voters made public yesterday replies it had received to a questionnaire sent to all New York candidates for United States Senator and Representative-at-Large. All the replies expressed support for the extension of the merit system and the reduction of Federal appointments subject to Senate confirmation.

Mrs. Edward W. Morahan of Elizabeth, N. J., has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Ruth Prazak, to Henry Allen Detering, son of Mrs. Henry Detering, also of Elizabeth, and the late Mr. Detering.

Extending their control of China's few unoccupied stretches of railway, Japanese forces have completed their occupation of six miles of tracks southwest of Sienning and are pressing toward the border of Hunan.

Trading in oats and rye futures here last week was restricted. The new rye crop in the Northwest is reported in need of rain. Oats closed 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel lower for the week, with the December position at 24 3/4 cents and the May at 26 cents.

" Hellzapoppin," the Olsen and Johnson revue, has become the new season's unchallenged smash hit. Last week the show played to 350 standees, ranging from twenty-five Wednesday night to 100 on Saturday. Its only serious competition came from the leader in the dramatic field, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," which had 212 standees.

The future of British defense policy overshadows every other issue here as Parliament prepares to reassemble Tuesday and start a new session next week. In the past fortnight the country has been watching the familiar but never inspiring spectacle of its Cabinet Ministers trying to make up their minds.

District Attorney Leo J. Hagerty, a Republican, tonight denied charges that Democratic Governor Lehman had forced him to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate city affairs by threatening to supersede him.

The first week's operation of the wages and hours law and the manifold statements that have been published about the law "have made only a slight progress toward clearing up the fog of uncertainty that exists regarding its application to individual concerns," the Merchants Association announced yesterday on the basis of inquiries addressed to its industrial bureau.

Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, announced yesterday the names of 134 American students who have received fellowship awards for study in other countries during the academic year 1938-39.

Rumblings of the recent crisis are steadily diminishing and now have become so faint that, with one or two exceptions they are not an active factor in Great Britain's financial markets. These exceptions are the nervousness concerning Germany' s colonial claims and the uncertainty over the pound sterling.

Mr. and Mrs. Frances Leggett Whitmarsh and Dr. and Mrs. John Munn Hanford gave a large tea yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Whitmarsh, 1,220 Park Avenue, for their debutante daughters, the Misses Anne Whitmarsh and Nancy H. Hanford.

Bob Pastor, holder of the New York State heavyweight championship, will encounter George (Big Boy) Brackey of Buffalo in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. The fight will mark Pastor's first start in several months, but the layoff is not expected to trouble him.

There is no contradiction between real science and the Bible, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, said in his sermon yesterday. The seeming contradiction is between unproved scientific theories, Dr. McComb said.

A bronze memorial plaque of Guglielmo Marconi, presented to Fordham-University by the Italian Professional Women of America, was unveiled yesterday in Freeman Hall, the physics building on the campus. Executed by Pietro Montana, the plaque bears a bas-relief head of the inventor, supporting figures representing Science and Faith, as well as various symbols representative of his work on wireless telegraphy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his reply to the six questions propounded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, Senator Wagner, referring to old-age insurance, says: "On the question of the reserve account, my answer is very simple. I wrote the 'reserves' into the Social Security Act because that was the recommendation of the best insurance brains of the country."

Immediate reopening of Dayton's public schools as ordered under a temporary injunction appeared doubtful tonight as a member indicated the school board would ask Common Pleas Judge Null M. Hodapp to vacate his order preventing the schools' closing.

Miss Anne Cashman, daughter of Mrs. Michael J. Cashman of 790 Riverside Drive, has completed plans for her marriage to Richard A. Leyendecker, also of New York, which will take place the morning of Nov. 8 in Corpus Christi Roman Catholio Church.

The Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League administered a 7-1 lacing today to the Springfield Indians, International-American League entry, in an exhibition game today before 5,000 persons. The contest was rough most of the way, and in the final session tempers flared into three fist fights.
The value of construction during September was 20.6 per cent higher than the same month of 1937, the Labor Department announced today.

Biblical passages have more living force when considered in their setting, declared the Rev. Dr. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal. Church, in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University.
A survey of up-State New York while as yet uncompleted, shows Thomas E. Dewey to be stronger at this stage of the campaign than any other Republican Gubernatorial candidate in many ears.
A solid Central American bloc at the Pan-American Conference in Lima, Peru, in December was foreshadowed today by the newspaper Diario Nuevo.

Mrs. Luella Bouton Shearn, wife of former Supreme Court Justice Clarence J. Shearn, died yesterday at her residence, 740 Park Avenue, after an illness of several months. A daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman Leslie Bouton of Detroit, Mrs. Shearn first married Harry Beckwith Mason of Grosse Pointe, Mich., former president of Parke, Davis Co., who died in 1929.

Green Bay, leader of the National Football League's Western Division, snapped the three-game winning streak of the Rams, 28-7, today before 18,483 fans, largest crowd in Cleveland pro football league history.

The national figure-skating championships will be held under the auspices of the St. Paul Figure Skating Club of St. Paul, Minn., on Jan. 19 to 21, it was decided at the annual meeting of the United States Figure Skating Association last night at the Hotel Lincoln.

A wave of mass hysteria seized thousands of radio listeners throughout the nation between 8:15 and 9:30 o'clock last night when a broadcast of a dramatization of H. G. Wells's fantasy, "The War of the Worlds,"...

Four officers have been chosen to represent Canada in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show which opens Saturday at Madison Square Garden, according to an announcement by show officials yesterday. On the Canadian squad will be Captain Stuart C. Bate, Lieut. Col. R. S. Timmis and Lieutenants Douglas Cleland and E. W. H. Berwick.

James C. Nugent, real estate mortgage broker for the last thirtyfive years, died yesterday at his home, 527 Riverside Drive, after an illness of five years. He was 64 years old. Mr. Nugent, who conducted his business under his name at 149 Broadway, had been active in the development of Radburn, N. J., and Sunnyside, Queens.

Present-day turmoil in the world is as much a rebellion against God as it is against freedom and democracy, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer said in his sermon at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning.

A dinner was given last night to Monroe Goldwater, New York attorney and law partner of Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, for his leadership in the campaign to raise funds for the American-Jewish Joint Distribution Committee. More than $20,000 was subscribed at the dinner held at the Hotel Commodore.

A "highly organized system of atheism" is breaking down Christian civilization outside the Catholic Church, the Rev. J. Harding Fisher, superior of the Jesuit House of Studies, Inisfada, Manhasset, L. I., warned at a mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. He called for a new consecration to the living Christ.

Professor Abial Brown Davis, founder of the Mount Vernon High School, now known as "the A. B. Davis High School," and for thirtyfour years its principal, died last night at his home here after an illness lasting since July. His age was 80.

The Rev. George A. Trowbridge, rector for ten years of All Angels Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, has accepted a call to St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. He made this announcement yesterday at the 11 A. M. service in All Angels Church.

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor in charge of the Brooklyn investigation into official corruption, devoted his time yesterday to interviewing persons from among whom he will select half a dozen chief assistants. He also worked on his budget, which he will submit to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. within a few days. The budget will then be placed before the Board of Estimate.

Despite adverse business conditions, 82,049 relief recipients in this city found private employment in the last twelve months, records of the Department of Welfare and the Works Progress Administration disclosed yesterday.

Ratification by the membership of the National Maritime Union of the agreement it concluded recently with the major shipowners on the Atlantic Coast was announced by the union yesterday. The vote to ratify was 10 to 1. A total of 13,489 votes were counted.

Japanese interference with United States commercial interests in China, which was the subject of the moat recent note to Tokyo from Secretary of State Cordell Hull, has focused attention on the importance of Japanese-American trade relations.

Twenty-seven gunners took part in the first Sunday shoot of the season over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. J. Stinson won the highover-all cup by breaking 9'l out of 100 targets.

Despite a drop of $416,518 in the value of crude gold bullion produced in Ontario mines in September, compared with the August figure, production in the first nine months of this year amounted to $73,228,132, an increase of 12.4 per cent over the $65,137,357 produced in the same period in 1937.

Louis L. Allen, Clinton T. Revere and P. Lyndon Dodge, formerly partners of Munds, Winslow Potter, will be admitted today as partners in the firm of Laird, Bissell Meeds,' members of the New York Stock Exchange. Offices will be in 120 and 1,775 Broadway, New York; in Wilmington and in Philadelphia.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kilsby Fields of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Estelle Fields, to Harold Ira Haskins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haskins of Cranford.

An operating surplus covering the fiscal year ended June 30, 1938, was shown by New York University for the eighth consecutive year, it was announced last night by Benjamin Strong, treasurer, in his first annual report to the university council.
The New York Rangers and the New York Americans will meet in the last game of their six-game series at Winnipeg tomorrow night, with the Americans still seeking a victory.

Representative John J. O'Connor, defeated for renomination in the Democratic primary but a candidate on Republican and Andrew Jackson party tickets, demanded yesterday that Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, stop "ducking" charges that political pressure is being put on WPA employes in the Sixteenth Congressional District.

Under the banner of liberalism, with State issues and the alleged irregularities of his administration largely ignored in his speeches, Governor Earle is conducting an impressive campaign for the Senate that may easily win despite reported revolts in the Democratic ranks and charges of extravagences in State affairs and abuses in the WPA and general relief.

The one important news announcement last week came after Saturday's stock market had closed. It was the formal disapproval by the President's "fact-finding" committee of the 15 per cent horizontal cut in railway wages. It can hardly be said that railway managers or the market were taken by surprise.

General Marie Gustave Gamelin, Chief of the French General Staff, arrived in Tunis today for an eight-day tour of inspection of the military defenses of the colony. He was accompanied by an escort of Spahis and was received at the residence of the Governor.

The names of forty-three persons, who passed the September licensing examinations of the State Board of Dental Examiners, were announced today by the Education Department. Those who will receive licenses to practice dentistry in this State are:

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, dedicated officially yesterday the new pavilion of St. Clare's Hospital at 417 West Fifty-first Street before more than 1,000 persons. He praised the work of the Sisters of St. Francis and Mother Alice, whose zeal, he said, had made possible the addition.

Passengers due -to arrive today from London on the steamship American Trader of the United States Lines include Miss Kathryn Allison, James W. Davis, George W. Grupp, Noah Dixon and Mr. and Mrs. James R. Preston.

Governor Lehman returned last night from his up-State campaign tour to be greeted at Grand Central Terminal by the biggest crowd and the most tumultuous reception he had received anywhere on his tenday trip, which took him through Central and Northern New York.

The M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company was the broker in the recent sale of the apartment house at 25 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Ninth Street, to Cortland Properties, Inc. The five-story building at 214 Central Park South is fully rented, according to the Burgoyne Hamilton Company, agent.
Upton Pyne bowed to Vleittown by 9 to 8 at the Burnt Mills Polo Club's Schley Field today but gained the first leg on the Emile Pfizer Autumn Cup on total goals in the three-game tourney.
Mr. and Mrs. Jack Denenfeld of this city and Far Rockaway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Denenfeld, to Dr. Eugene Rodin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Rodin of Hempstead.

A certain degree of tension appeared last week in the foreign exchange market here, and the equalization fund was obliged to intervene rather strongly, it would seem, with sales of sterling. The dollar follows here exactly the fluctuations of the dollar rate in London, and it is the British fund that intervenes there to regulate fluctuations.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 54 per cent of capacity, up 5 points from the rate in the preceding week and making the pace the fastest since about the middle of October last year.

Concerning the government's economic recovery program, of which Premier Edouard Daladier has said only that it would consist chiefly of increasing production, no details are known. The Minister of Commerce has, however, put forward in a speech a system of "steered economy" which would differ from the "managed economy" practiced in some countries, in that the State would leave private enterprise more liberty, intervening directly only in certain cases.

Miss Phyllis Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Halsey of this place and Brooklyn, was married here today to Roderick Halsey Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Foster of Southampton, at Old Fields, the home of the bride's parents.

Lester W. Herzog, New York State WPA Administrator, replied sharply in a letter today to charges of Irving Williams, Suffolk County Welfare Commissioner, that WPA funds were being used for political exploitation of the unemployed in Suffolk County.

Representatives James M. Mead, Democratic candidate for the short-term Senatorial seat in the election Nov. 8, today answered in a statement the six questions on campaign issues propounded by THE NEW YORK TIMES to the four New York nominees of the two major parties in an editorial Oct. 20.

Bainsford House, 208 East Sixteenth Street, formerly the Deaconess House of St. George's Episcopal Church, was dedicated yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Elmore Mc?? McKee, rector of the church, ?? residence for young business ?? who will devote part of their time to welfare work in the neighborhood.
Prices of cotton registered slight day-to-day changes last week. In the futures market, the principal feature was the wide fluctuations of the spreads between prices for the various deliveries.

Newark's Tornadoes came from behind in the last quarter today for a 14-to-13 American Professional Football Association victory over the Union City Rams. Red Weiner, Newark fullback, figured in both touchdowns and kicked the extra points from placement. He went over from the 1-yard line following Riccardi's 64-yard run after picking up a Union City fumble in the second quarter.

Hope that the United States and Great Britain will reach a commercial understanding as a result of the trade treaty negotiations, was expressed yesterday by Sir Thomas Brocklebank, a director of the Cunard White Star Line, who is here for his annual Fall visit to the company's American offices.

The Erica Reed, an 8,000-ton freighter chartered by the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, arrived early yesterday morning from New Orleans with a cargo of 5,000 tons of wheat.

Another episode was added yesterday to the many strange happenings that take place at Ebbets Field when the Brooklyn Dodgers came bouncing back from the rout they had sustained at the hands of the Giants the week before to play the champion Washington Redskins to a stand-off in a wildly exciting game.

Asserting that there exists a "lack of order, balance, coherence, continuity and consistency in the city's medical services," Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, urged in a letter made public yesterday, that a municipal department of medical care be created to consolidate the services rendered by the Departments of Health, Hospi??als and Welfare.
The plate was "passed in reverse" today at the first Methodist Church here and the Rev. Grant Robinson, who inaugurated the plan, termed it a "great success."

Dean Jacob G. Lipman of the Agricultural College of Rutgers University, speaking at the annual meeting and Harvard Festival of the National Farm School here today, urged consideration of changing the school from a vocational institution to a junior college.
The "Midland Canal," joining the River Rhine and the Baltic Sea was opened here today by Chancellor Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess, with the terse phrase, "The Midland Canal is open."

Today, when dictators are usurping power that does not rightfully belong to them, it is fitting that the church should set aside a day in honor of Christ the King, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, told worshipers in his sermon yesterday morning.

The new drawbridge over the Bronx River at Westchester Avenue will be opened tomorrow afternoon by Mayor La Guardia, Colonel Maurice E. Gilmore, regional director of the PWA, and James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President. The ceremonies will be held at 4 P. M.

Kicking and screaming, Anna Laura Barnett, 57, widow of the wealthy 'Indian, Jackson Barnett, was led 'today from the. gas-filled. \Wilshire Boulevard mansion which he built, but in which the government has ruled that she-is no longer entitled to live.
The University of Scranton ended St. Vincent's five-game winning streak with a 19-to-7 victory over its previously unbeaten rival before 6,500 spectators today.

Signing of an agreement by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workers Union, Local 334, A. F. of L., and the New York Butchers Dressed Meat Company, an affiliate of Armour Co., was announced last night. The pact was said to be "the first agreement signed by the company with any recognized labor organization in the country."

Moriz Rosenthal, veteran pianist, scored a personal triumph at today's opening concert of the National Symphony Orchestra's eighth season, at which he appeared as guest artist in the first orchestral concert of his "jubilee" tour of this country.
The meadows are brown and sere, but the chrysanthemums are blooming in Central Park; the skies are gray at times and darkness

GOOD books about the matchless Emily Dickinson are rarer even than good books about her robustious contemporary Whitman, the dearth of which we were bewailing the other day. But at last we have one; George F. Whicher's critical biography,' "This Was a Poet."* At last. Mr. Whicher's isn't the ultimate book, but it is sharp, informed and doubtless as nearly definitive as can be expected under the circumstances.

Justo Pastor Benitez, Paraguay's Minister-designate to Bolivia, has withdrawn his acceptance of that post as a result of a decision by the Liberal party not to cooperate with the present government of Paraguay.

The thirteenth annual World's Championship Rodeo ended last night at Madison Square with new champions crowned in a series of hair-raising events that were witnessed by a crowd of 13,000 persons. Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of. the Garden, presented the awards.

Thomas Stewart Brush, a director of the Brush-Moore newspapers of Ohio, died in a sanatorium here today after a year's illness. His age was 42. Mr. Brush, who received his education at Andover and the University of Michigan, worked for a short time on The New York Herald Tribune before assuming a post with the Brush-Moore organization.

It is understood that as a result of the recent conversations here by Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, the arbitrators of the HungarianCzech controversy will meet in Vienna on Wednesday. Italy will be represented by her Foreign Minister, Count Galeazzo Ciano, and Germany by Herr Ribbentrop. It is thought that Dr.

The University of Scranton freshmen defeated the Manhattan College cubs today, 7 to 6. Manhattan scored in the third period, when McNulty went over from the 4-yard line, but the New Yorkers failed to make-the extra point.

Daniel M. Ladd, Director of the Chicago office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced tonight the arrest of George Slade, who was described as the last member of the Edward Bentz gang of bank robbers.

Reports to wage-earners in this State on the amounts credited to their account in the old-age insurance files of the Social Security Board are now being rendered in three or four days from the date application is made, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the board, said yesterday.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 79.9 the week before (reached also on Aug. 20), 80.3 two weeks before, 80.5 three weeks before and 80.4 four weeks before.
Supply contracts valued at $25,913,536 were awarded during the week ended Oct. 22 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

God is the only safe source of liberty, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
GELLIS--COHEN--Mr. J. H. Cohen of 87 Schenck Ave., Brooklyn, announces the marriage of his daughter, Mussie, to Mr. Abe Gellis of Brooklyn, N. Y., to take place on Thursday, Nov. 3, at Savoy-Plaza.

A plan to protect and restore Fire Island at a cost of $6,250,000 less than the estimate of Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, has been completed by Earle W. Andrews, consulting engineer, for submission to the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors at Riverhead on Nov. 14.

The contention that business recovery has been retarded by the refusal of banks to make sufficient loans is challenged by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York in the current issue of its Guaranty Survey.

Charles Zeller Klauder, noted architect, died today in his apartments in the Rittenhouse Plaza at the age of 66. Active until a short time before his death, Mr. Klauder was responsible for the design of many churches, libraries and universities throughout the country, among them buildings at Princeton, Yale and the University of Pennsylvania.

A lower East Side property that had been inherited from Peter Stuyvesant passed to new hands for the first time when it was sold by Winthrop Properties, Inc., to a client of David N. Katz. The property is the five-story tenement on a lot 23.10 by 100 feet at 174 Suffolk Street.
B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party member of the City Council and general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward, died at Mount Sinai Hospital last night at 8:15. He was 52 years old.

Seven of the twenty-three who entered the preliminaries in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club qualified yesterday for the finals, in which they will compete with those who were exempt, for the club title held by Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion.

In a strong northeast wind on the Charles River basin, M. I. T. crews today successfully defended in Boston Dinghy Club's Intercollegiate Challenge Cup in the largest intercollegiate regatta ever held in the United States. Sailors from twentysix colleges competed.

The Federal Government bought for a postoffice in North Bergen from Francesco Romano the onestory store building and two-story dwelling at 964-966 Bergen Turnpike; from Christiana Van Der Knaap the dwelling at 960 Bergen Turnpike, northwest corner of Van Wagenen Place;

The St. Joseph's College eleven marched thirty-three yards for a touchdown in the closing minutes of the fourth quarter to score a 7-to-0 victory over La Salle College today. A crowd of 8,000 witnessed the game.

The full story of the great three-act drama played at Berchtesgaden, Godes berg and Munich will not be known until Mr. Chamberlain writes his memoirs of the most incredible dialogues in history. Even then it will not be known; their will remain the mystery of the motive and intentions of the chief protagonists. Meantime, controversy as to what really took place at and before Munich

The German Academy conferred the Honor Badge "for conspicuous merit in promoting German culture" today upon Professor Emeritus Alexander R. Hohlfeld of the University of Wisconsin. Professor Hohlfeld was born in Dresden, Germany, seventy-two years ago and served as Professor of German at Wisconsin from 1901 to 1936.

Characterizing school officials as a "group of Hitlers," William Johnson, a North Mill River Road farmer, today threatened court action to force. the reinstatement of his three children, expelled from school last Monday for their continued refusal to salute the American flag.
Major Gen. Sir Hugh Perry died today at a nursing home in Bournemouth at the age of 77. He was an artillery officer long identified with the ordnance branch of the British Army.

Philip Maziraka, 22 years old, of 340 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, was fatally burned yesterday morning when he locked himself in a sedan near his house, poured gasoline over the upholstery and set fire to it.

Plans for coordinating the efforts of housing authorities throughout New York State will be discussed at a two-day conference starting next Friday at the Hotel Astor. The program includes an address by Mayor Thomas Holling of Buffalo and a trip to the various State and city housing projects here.

Pittsburgh, Evanston, Ill., and Fort Worth, Texas, were the scenes of football's most significant developments on a Saturday notable also for the huge turnouts in the East, where four games each drew 70,000 or more.

Eddie Mead, manager of Henry Armstrong, is breathing easily for the first time in a month. The portly manager, apprehensive lest a reopening of an old cut in Armstrong's mouth might cause a postponement of the battle with Ceferino Garcia, against whom Henry will defend his welterweight championship of the world in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, was considerably relieved yesterday when Armstrong ended his training in tiptop shape.

Under the light of a bright Autumn sun, the Greater New York Navy Day parade of 35,000 marchers representing military and other organizations from the five boroughs attracted 70,000 onlookers along the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, yesterday.
Representative James M. Mead, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, short term, today replied to questions put in an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES, as follows:

The elements of spiritual progress are the same today as they always have been, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, minister of the North Presbyterian Church, 525 West 155th Street, said in his sermon yesterday, marking the ninetieth anniversary of the church.

The blind are the most cheerful of our afflicted folk, although they most of all need help. Here in New York much can be done for them, especiall for little blind children burdened at the beginning of life. Each year these come in increasing numbers to "The Lighthouse," some in the hope that their sight may be restored, some only in the modest hope that they may be taught to play like other children.

Those actors are here again. Up at the American Music Hall in Fifty-fifth Street they are playing a new rowdy-dowdy, "The Girl From Wyoming," which opened simultaneously with many bottles of liquor on Saturday evening.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, and Israel A. Horowitz, who tied for first place in the American Chess Federation tournament at Boston, met yesterday in the third game of their play-off at the residence of Maurice Wertheim, 33 East Seventieth Street. The result was a victory for Horowitz. Horowitz won the first game and Kashdan the second.

John Barnini, Providence College center, lost his head while sitting on the bench in today's game and raced on the field to tackle a Xavier University runner, but it didn't make much difference, for Providence lost the game, 33 to 7.
The Treasury, having plenty of funds to meet its month-end payments, is now limiting subscriptions to its issues.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Governor Lehman (recording), WQXR, 10 A. M. Governor Lehman (recording), excerpts from his National Democratic Club speech of acceptance of the State nomination, WINS, 1:05 to 1:10 P. M. (1,180 kc.)

Finance Minister H. H. Kung said today that China was in a strong position both. financially and economically for continued resistance to Japan's invasion. Dr. Kung said in an interview that the army had a supply of rifles and ammunition sufficient for two years and that excellent crops this year had yielded enough foodstuffs for the next eighteen. months.

Important commercial negotiations beginning here tomorrow with a German delegation will be accompanied by a week of German propaganda demonstrations. Germany's object is to secure a large share of Rumania's oil and grain.

Lieut. Col. Ramon Franco, brother of the Insurgent Generalissimo, Francisco Franco, and former air attach at the Spanish Embassy in Washington, was killed Friday in an airplane off Palma, Majorca, an Insurgent airplane base.

A group headed by Anthony R. Conti, a well-known restaurant operator, has purchased from the East River Savings Bank the sixstory building at 208 Central Park South, a former brownstone dwelling which was altered about fifteen years ago by the late Deputy Police Commissioner Harriss.

With the veteran Ken Strong accounting for all the scoring with field goals, the Jersey City Giants trounced the Brooklyn Eagles, 9-0, before a record pro football crowd of 15,657 at Roosevelt Stadium today.

Governor Clarence S. Ridley, accompanied by his wife, sailed aboard the Ancon today for his annual appearance before the Bureau of the Budget in Washington regarding Panama Canal appropriations and for the meeting of the board of the Panama Railroad Company in New York.
Stocks irregularly lower for the first time since week ended Sept. 17; turnover, 9,041,300 shares. Treasury bonds at new high levels, other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $45,827,875.

Criticizing the "humanistic trends" in religion today, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, pastor of the John Street Methodist Church, near Nassau Street in the financial district, affirmed his belief yesterday morning that the notion that man is sufficient unto himself was passing, and that soon a renaissance of organized religion would begin.

The Fort Du Pont First Engineers defeated the Fort Hamilton eleven of New York today, 16 to 0. Beckett scored the first touchdown from the 2-yard line in the opening quarter after the local team recovered a fumble on Fort Hamilton's 15.

All lovers of nature are interested in contributions to our nation's record of care for life and for life's surroundings. Man's harmonious adaptation to his environment, whether of a utilitarian, esthetic or religious or spiritual nature,. is one of his most commendable aspirations toward increased largess and happiness.

With eight days left before the election, Democratic leaders are confident, probably overconfident, of the re-election of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, and Republican leaders are hopeful, increasingly hopeful, of the election of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to the Governorship.

APROPOS OF DOLORES, by H. G. Wells. (Scribner, $2.50.) A novel in diary form. BEWAR FAMILIAR SPIRITS, by John Mulholland. (Scribner, $2.50.) A study of spiritism and its exponents in the United States and England.

The Detroit Lions displaced the Chicago Bears as runners-up in the Western Division of the National Football League and Dutch Clark, Detroit's player-coach, became the league's undisputed all-time scoring king today as the Lions defeated the Bears, 13 to 7.

Because of many conflicting influences, the German markets were quiet, although steady last week, awaiting further clarification of the international and domestic situations. All surface developments undoubtedly have caused a more optimistic view.

In a signed article in The Los Angeles Times today Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the old-age pension plan bearing his name, condemned as "impractical and absurd" the "$30 - on - Thursday" scheme on which California will vote Nov. 8.

Benjamin B. Bledsoe, former Federal judge, civic leader and national president-general of the Sons of the Revolution, died today of a heart attack at his mountain home near Crestline. His age was 64. He was appointed a Federal judge of the Southern California District in 1914 by President Wilson and resigned in 1925.

Miss Marie H. Torrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Torrey of this place, and Saunders Lanier Ogburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Clinton Ogburn of Greensboro, N. C., were married yesterday in the Apostolic Church, West Fiftyseventh Street, New York. The Rev.

Mrs. Geraldine McAlpin Webster, wife of Dr. Jerome Pierce Webster, an assistant surgeon at Presbyterian-Hospital, and granddaughter of the late William Rockefeller, died early yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion after the birth of twin sons. The infants survived. Mrs. Webster was 38 years old.

The solution of the problem of strengthening Finland's and Sweden's joint military security in case of war in the Baltic by refortifying the Finnish-owned Aland Archipelago-a measure requiring the revision of the existing internationally guaranteed Aland neutrality pact-has encountered serious obstacles.

A "definite policy of long-run liquidation" of emergency Federal credit organizations such as the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Home Owners Loan Corporation and some of the units of the Farm Credit Administration was urged yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.
The French wholesale price index for the week ended Oct. 22 stood at 653, compared with 657 on Oct. 15, and 652 on Oct. 8.

Corn futures are selling close to the lowest level of the season. The market of late has been feeling the effect of an unprecedented movement of cash grain to terminal markets. It is estimated that more than 50 per cent of the arrivals represented grain obtained by the Commodity Credit Corporation on unpaid government loans to farmers.

Property owners desiring to pay their real estate taxes for the second half of this year must do so by midnight tonight if they are to have their payments accepted without penalty. Taxes for the period were due on Oct. 1 and payable without penalty throughout the month.

The place of a denominational hospital as "a symbol of human sympathy and an agency for exercising religious influence and Christian charity" was stressed in a brief address yesterday afternoon by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn at exercises dedicating the first unit of the new Holy Family Hospital, Dean Street between Hoyt and Bond Streets, Brooklyn.

A. Emmett Adams, composer of popular songs, whose "The Bells of Saint Mary's" has been broadcast from the White House, died here today at the age of 48. "The Bells of St. Mary's" has become the official song of St. Mary's College in California.

A hauntingly fascinating performance of the Chopin piano concerto in F minor was heard from Guiomar Novaes, who appeared as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

In making public its recommendations of candidates for Municipal Court Justice in the Second Bronx District, the Citizens Union held yesterday that all three candidates were qualified but recommended the election of George Salvatore, American Labor and Socialist party candidate.

" Shadow Over Europe: The Challenge of Nazi Germany," by Shepard Stone, is a new Headline Book published by the Foreign Policy Association. It traces the development of the pan-German movement down to the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia and discusses Hitler's further aims in Eastern Europe..

The evacuation from frontier areas of thousands of Polish Jews--8,000 according to official reports and 12,000 according to an estimate by the Jewish Relief Committee-deported from Germany began today after they had been massed at frontier stations up and down the border for twenty-six hours.

Saturday's report of the President's Emergency Fact-Finding Board, appointed in the railway wage dispute when the mediation board had failed to bring managers and labor representatives together in compromise, disapproves positively of the railway proposal for a 15 per cent horizontal cut in wages.
Several huge new fires are raging in Hankow. They were started yesterday when the Japanese started burning down blocks in the slum district and buildings that might have been haunts of snipers.

Two masked bandits entered the country residence of Warren L. Marks, a New York business man, in Dykeman's, Putnam County, at 7:30 o'clock this morning, awakened Mr. Marks, bound his arms and legs with cord and robbed him of $50 in cash and a wrist-watch worth $100. Then, cutting the tele-.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Shirley Ruth Lunitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Lunitz of 230 Central Park West, to Dr. Jacob S. Barb, son of Mrs. Samuel Barb of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Barb.

Plans are being made for a theatre-supper party to advance the health work of the Frontier Nursing Service in the Kentucky mountains. The New York committee for the service has chosen the performance of "The Boys From Syracuse" on Nov. 30 at the Alvin Theatre for the benefit, and is arranging also for a supper dance in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria after the performance.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Post of this city and East Williston, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances L. Post, to Ricardo S. Santamarina of Buenos Aires, son of the late Enrique Santamarina, a former vice president of Argentina, and the late Mrs. Santamarina.

Operations in lard futures were on a reduced scale last week. Prices held within relatively narrow limits. There was some liquidation by scattered longs in sympathy with the easiness in corn and cottonseed oil. Cash interests were fair buyers on the decline.

Maurice Duplessis, Premier of Quebec Province, announced today completion of arrangements with a Canadian syndicate headed by L. J. Beaubien Co. of Montreal to float provincial loans amounting to $30,000,000.

Associated Press photographer Karl J. Eskelund has pictures of the Japanese entry into Canton. He has not got his clothes and his camera is gone, but he has the pictures. Mr. Eskelund walked the rails back to Canton today almost stripped.

Mrs. W. Morgan Churchman of Whitemarsh, Pa., and Edward Walter Clark of Chestnut Hill, Pa., were the honored guests at a dinner given tonight at Mepal Manor, New Marlboro, by Mr. and Mrs. George Greer of Rye, N. Y. Among others present were Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets, Miss Julia B. Scribner and Philip Le Boutellier of New York.

The La Guardia administration and the Transit Commission are confident that the proposed constitutional amendment to permit the city to go outside its debt limit to the extent of $315,000,000 to finance the unification of rapid transit lines will be carried by a safe margin, despite a definite undercurrent of opposition, it was disclosed yesterday.

Certain phases of the judiciary artide in our proposed new State Constitution--No. 5 in the list of amendments--have been in hot controversy since they first appeared in the Judiciary Committee at the convention. One of these, a relatively minor one, is that which creates a tenth judicial district consisting of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. These counties are now, with Queens, Kings and Richmond, part of the Second Judicial District.

Figures just published on Britain's retail trade sales in September reflect a heavy decline due to the war scare, being only 0.9 percent larger than those of a year before, following a series of considerably larger increases in preceding months.

George Godfrey Harrap, London publisher, died last night in a London nursing home where he underwent a serious operation a week ago. He was 71 years old. Mr. Harrap was the managing director of George G. Harrap Co., Ltd. During his career he was instrumental in acquainting English teachers with the educational publications of D. C. Heath Co. of Boston, and was the Londonrepresentative for Thomas Y. Crowell Company of New York.

H. Boardman Spalding, president of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, in reporting yesterday on the progress of the bureau's furid-raising campaign to meet the current budgetary requirements, declared that legitimate business men, in their own selfinterest, must help the bureau continue its efforts to fight within-thelaw swindlers.

John Franklin Fairlamb, retired former general passenger agent of the New York Central Railroad, died today at St. John's Riverside Hospital, Yonkers. Mr. Fairlamb, ill only three days as the result of a hip injury due to a fall, lived at 643 Palisade Avenue, Youkers. His age was 82.

Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., United States P. G. A. champion, today won the Argentine open golf, championship with a record score of 282 for 72 holes. He took a prize of 1,500 pesos, approximately $385.

Mrs. Maxine Corbaley, 38 years old, wife of Thomas B. Corbaley, vice president of the American Institute of Food Distributors at 420 Lexington Avenue, was found dead of gas poisoning at 5:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of her apartment at 156 East Thirtyseventh Street.

Miss Shirley Osborn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fairfield Osborn, has been appointed junior committee chairman for a benefit theatre-supper party to be given on the night of Nov. 28. The performance of 'Herod and Mariamne" at the Empire Theatre will be followed by a 'special supper dance in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Twenty - fifth National Foreign Trade Convention begins at the Hotel Commodore this morning at 9 A. M. and continues Tuesday and Wednesday. Speakers, morning session: James A. Farrell, Louis E. Pierson, Richard C. Patterson Jr., Edgar W. Smith, Dr. E. J. Kyle, Eugene P. Thomas.

An apparently inspired press campaign, which is becoming more violent as it proceeds, is pressing on the Japanese people the idea that Japan is now in a position to pursue her policy in East Asia independently of all other powers.

Jersey City War Veterans gathered yesterday in the basement of the Jersey City Armory to protest against the meeting-already banned by the city-at which Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, was to have spoken in Pershing Field.

Miss Evelyn Lipman of New York, daughter of Harry Lipman of Antigo, Wis., and the late Mrs. Lipman, was married to Dr. George Libman Engel, son of Mrs. Adolph Engel of this city and the late Mr. Engel, by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise yesterday afternoon in his study at 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, in the presence of relatives.

The small stockholders in the country's Investment trusts, although their number has increased tremendously in recent years, have had little voice in the management of such companies, according to conclusions stated by the Securities and Exchange Commission in another chapter of its investment trust study made public today.

Frederick W. Longfellow, well known New York lawyer, died suddenly Saturday night at the St. Andrews Golf Club, Mount Hope, Hastings, Westchester County. For many years he had been president and chairman of the board of the club. His age was 68.

A speedy and consistent little hound was the cynosure of all the experts and the casual spectators in the gallery at the second day's running of the fourth annual Autumn field trial meeting of the Long Island Beagle Club today.

Miss Ann Broadhead Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Durand Freeman of Westfield, was married to Francis Culbert Carney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Carney of Brooklyn, at the home of the bride's parents yesterday.

A crowd of 50,000 attended the final race meeting today at the picturesque Santa Beatriz course, which is to be closed after thirty-six years of operation. A new track, located about ten kilometers from the center of the city. will be officially opened by President Benavides on Dec. 4.

An additional $95,000 will guarantee the completion of the "absolutely necessary part of the work" on the sanctuary and choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in time for the opening of the World's Fair in 1939, Bishop William T. Manning announced at the cathedral yesterday morning.

A military victory for General Francisco Franco, combined with a supposed food shortage in Loyalist Spain and with certain consequences of the Munich agreement that may favor Burgos, are counted on, in official quarters here, to bring the war in Spain to an early end. It is thought that fighting will be over by next Spring at the latest.

Pratt Ave (17-4963), o s. 150 ft n of 2330 St, 50x136; Elste Wolfe to Home Owners Loan Corp. 3rd Ave (9-2363), o s. 81 ft s of 156th St. 55x103; Winston Realty Co, Inc, to 722 E 180th St Corp, 19 e 47th St; mtge, $65.000.

More than 1,000 members of the Anchor Club, composed of members of the Police Department who belong to the Knights of Columbus, attended memorial services for deceased members of the organization yesterday afternoon in St. Joseph's Church, Forty-fourth Street and Grand Avenue, Astoria.

A condemned man will join a Utah scientist tomorrow in an experiment to determine how long a man lives after a bullet pierces his heart. Shortly after dawn in Utah's State prison yard, John W. Deering, 40 years old, will go to his death before a five-man firing squad for the death of Oliver R. Meredith, Jr., Salt Lake City business man.
General Evangeline Booth, head of the Salvation Army, acting on medical advice, canceled today her proposed visit to the Salvation Army Congress to be held beginning next Saturday in Manchester.

Applications are now open for the following positions in the city service. Details are available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission. Municipal Building, or in the City Record. There are physical, residence and citizenship requirements.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander James Cox of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Palmyre Madelaine Cox, to Martin Merson of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Merson of Portsmouth, Va.

The improvident college student soon may be of the past, if figures compiled by the Bowery Savings Bank are taken as indicating the general trend of student savings in the country. The average student account at the bank totals $688, it was announced yesterday.

Amid the fallen, Autumn leaves on one of the Long Mountain trails that he had helped to blaze, a memorial to the late Raymond H. Torrey, botanical authority and writer, was dedicated this morning in the presence of 500 hikers and nature lovers, and, in accordance with his wishes, his ashes were scattered along the path.

E. H. Crump, political chieftain of Memphis, said today that the proposed purchase of the electrical distribution system of the Memphis Power and Light Company by the city of Memphis for $13,500,000 would be held up unless satisfactory arrangements for a "big reduction" in the price of gas were made.

Giles Knight Tinker of Oyster Bay, L. I., a retired insurance man, whose son, Edward R. Tinker, was formerly president of the Chase Securities Corporation, died yesterday in the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 82.
Bremen's cotton stocks rose slightly last week to 247,411 bales. The price of North American cotton stiffened from 10.27 cents in United States money to 10.44 cents.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 70 on Oct. 26, compared with 70.5 a fortnight before, 70.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Yale may be set back this Fall in football, but apparently Is not to be outdone in one fast-growing sport, which appeals to the grads because they can carry on in it after their college days are over. That is sailing.

In celebration of Reformation Sunday, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer asserted yesterday in his sermon at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, that there was a misconception of the true character and function of the Reformation.

The average weekly wage of workers in manufacturing industries in all the States during August was higher than the minimum fixed by the Wages and Hours Law, according to a compilation released today by Elmer F. Andrews, administrator. The average wage was highest in the District of Columbia, with $33.61, and the lowest was in Georgia, with $13.71.

Statements by Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, Warden Lewis E. Lawes, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Rabbi Philip Bernstein, Correction Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick, Sanford Bates, S. C. Mead and others urging approval of proposed Amendment 4 to the State Constitution, dealing with housing, were made public last night by the New York State committee of the National Public Housing Conference.

The striped bass at Montauk evidently are not only plentiful but large, for Lawrence Craufurd of New York came in with a forty-fivepounder the other day. According to Ned Schafer, who has his ear to the ground on all striped bass matters, Craufurd was one of a party of four out with Captain Bill Sweeting.

A survey conducted by Northwestern University reveals that the aviator has displaced the motorman, the fireman, the policeman and even the cowboy as the idol of boys in grammar school. Most of them want to be flyers. This natural hero worship should supply a

In a letter interpreted as an endorsement of the Democratic candidates in Pennsylvania's State-wide election, President Roosevelt has assailed Republican charges that he had refrained from giving formal support to the party's nominees in this State because he was unwilling "to put his hands in that muddy water."

If the fly ball of anti-labor falls between Center Fielder William Green and Right fielder John L. Lewis, then the ball game of progressivism is lost by a home run, Mayor La Guardia of New York told a cheering audience of 6,000 at a rally this afternoon.

Officials of Butler County and Middletown appealed to Governor Davey personally tonight for National Guard troops to aid reopening of the P. Lorillard Company tobacco plant, strike-bound since Oct. 3.

Palestine Jews will observe tomorrow as a national rally day to open an extensive drive for contributions to the Koffer Hayishuv (Redemption Fund). Encouraged by the unexpected success that this fund has met since its inception less than three months ago, the interparty committee in charge has now undertaken a scheme of spending [pound]25,000 monthly for Jewish defense purposes in Palestine, the entire sum to be raised among residents.

Royalty visited Obersalzberg today when the Italian Crown Prince, accompanied by the Italian military attace in Berlin, was received by Chancellor Adolf Hitler here this afternoon. The Italian guests lunched with Herr Hitler and remained almost three hours.

65th St., 170 W; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 170 W 65th St Corp; purchase money mtg. $25,332, and building loan mtg, $19,500 ($25.50). 78th St, 24 E; Everett Jacobs to E. and R. J. Holding Corp, 542 5th Ave (50 cents).

David Bradley Carse, former member of the advisory committee of the United States Steel Corporation, died today at a near-by hospital of bronchial pneumonia. Mr. Carse, who was 74 years old, lived here. Born in Jeffersonville, Ind., he was the son of Thomas Carse, a railroad executive, and Matilda Bradley Carse, temperance and welfare worker closely associated with Frances E. Willard.

Sale of television receivers at the present time would be premature and "unfair to the public," E. F. McDonald Jr., president of the Zenith Radio Corporation, said today. He stated his views in a letter to stockholders.

In a letter to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, John Lord O'Brian Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared yesterday that he already had said in speeches he would advocate amendments to the National Labor Relations Act.

The problem of Jewish education in America has been partly solved by the Hadassah, Miss Susan Brandeis of New York, attorney and daughter of Justice Louis D. Brandeis, told an audience of 400 women here today at the opening session of the twentyfourth annual convention of the Womens' Zionist Organization.
The New York Americans defeated the Trenton Highlanders by 8-2 in an American Soccer League fixture at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 5,000.

THERE they are, still riding high; Pitt, Notre Dame and Dartmouth. But mighty Minnesota went down in the general firing on Saturday. Question: How long is it since Army won a game from Notre Dame ? Answer: Too long.
Further depletion of the undefeated list occurred on a broad scale in the scholastic football world during the past week-end, but in most cases the surprise element was virtually nil.

A new world's record for handlaunched model gliders was set yesterday by Herbert Friedlander, 16 years old, of 2,527 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, when his model craft made a timed flight of 2 minutes 58 seconds at a gliding contest held in Central Park under the auspices of the Metropolitan Model Airplane CounciL The previous record, held by Henry Gerrin of Malden, Mass., was 2 minutes 19 seconds.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Aron Halpert of 530 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Ellen Halpert, to Herbert Bijur, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan I. Bijur, also of this city.
The nationalistic attitude of the National Assembly is indicated by the recent enactment of a law that prohibits the licensing of physicians and surgeons unless they are citizens of Panama.

In the week's recovery here bear covering again played its part, induced partly by revival of talk of dollar devaluation and by the belief that the United States Administration had protested to the British authorities concerning the unsatisfactory trend of sterling.

A public hearing on recent recommendations of the wage board in the confectionery industry for a minimum wage of 35 cents an hour or $14 for a 40-hour week for women and minors employed in the industry in this State will be held at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, at 2 P. M. tomorrow. Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, will preside.

Declaring that fascism and communism alike were enemies of the principles upon which the greatness of this country was founded, President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell of the Municipal Court, a candidate for the State Supreme Court, made a plea for religious freedom yesterday in a speech at rededication services at Temple Beth Sholom of Washington Heights, 390 Fort Washington Avenue.
John Rahkonen of the FinnishAmerican A. C. won the 30,000meter national A. A. U. championship walk yesterday under the auspices of James J. Tappen Post, American Legion, at Clove Lakes Park, S. I.

Greenwich society attended in large numbers a private view, reception and tea this afternoon at the art gallery of the Greenwich Library which marked the opening of the annual Fall exhibition of the Greenwich Society of Artists, to be continued through Nov. 13.

Ev Elkins, held scoreless as Marshall was upset for the second straight week, barely retained the eastern college football scoring lead from the challenge of Sammy Roeder, Franklin and Marshall fullback.

National headquarters for the "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign have been opened at 50 East Forty-second Street, Keith Morgan, chairman of the committee for the celebration of the President's birthday, announced yesterday.

Miss Frances S. Whitall, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Wistar Whitall of Katonah, will give a dinner at the Versailles tomorrow for Miss Isabel Imlay Butterworth and Cabot Ward Low, who will be married in Rye, N. Y., on Saturday.

Pointing out that "truth knows no national boundaries," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, called attention to the internationalism of modern scholarship in his annual report to the board of trustees today.

Except for several important special movements, the Boerse was quiet and virtually unchanged last week. Operations for the Reich loan and month-end preparations produced a slight dip in the middle of the week,

In a measured manner that showed their self-control and courage, but was all the more impressive because of its restraint, twenty-one German and Austrian Jews discussed aboard the ship Orinoco here this afternoon their hope of landing in the New World and their fear of returning to lands of persecution if they are not permitted to enter.

Mrs. Jerome K. Jerome, widow of the author famous for "Three Men in a Boat," died today at Rampstead at the age of 70. Mrs. Jerome, whose marriage to the author took place in 1888, was the former Georgina Henrietta Stanley Nesza, a daughter of Lieutenant Nesza of the Spanish Army.

To increase production capacity the government is expected to loosen its capital control enough to permit the flotation of new private capital issues, of which a fund issue of 45,000,000 marks by the BraunkohleBenzin Company is considered a beginning.

Cecelia Loftus returned last night in her program of impersonations and sketches, this time at the Vanderbilt Theatre under the sponsorship of Martin Jones, in association with Judson O'Donnell and Clay Shaw.

A sharp upcurve in the number of art exhibitions in New York City emphasizes the beginning of the second month of the local season. Nearly thirty shows are on the calendar, ranging from big group attractions at museums to incidental showings at stores, shops and clubs.
The ten-room dwelling, on a lot 17 by 100 feet, at 599 Fifth Avenue, adjoining Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. H. Beebe to Patrick Costello for occupancy. L. L. Yearsley was the roker.

Under the title of "New England Hurricane," the Federal Writers' Project of the Works Progress Administration will publish on Friday a running story of the disaster which visited that part of the country last September.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Marie Ahern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ahern of Brooklyn, to John J. Shugrue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Shugrue of Jackson Heights, has been announced by her parents.

Opposition to proposals that Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, be permitted to fulfill two engagements this week with the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra without joining the American Guild of Musical Artists was voted today by the Western executive committee.

President Roosevelt, former President Hoover and a host of other major party leaders will take the stump in this final week of the election campaign. Their speeches in behalf of candidates for State and Congressional offices are expected to make the President and his policies more than ever the dominant issue in the balloting Nov. 8.

With his own Radical Socialist party solidly behind him and with the Communists definitely shaken from his ranks, Premier Edouard Daladier returned to Paris this morning. He will attempt to complete the preparation of what promises to be a long and severe series of decrees for the restoration of industry and national finance.

A minimum wage of $1,200 a year and a 40-hour week for all government employes was a demand embodied in its constitution yesterday by the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, at the closing session of its State convention at the Aldine Club. 200 Fifth Avenue.

No more Japanese cotton or woolen stockings or socks will be imported into Great Britain for the remainder of this year, it was announced here this week by the Japanese Embassy, following representations from the National Federation of Hosiery Manufacturers Associations.

Ricardo Risatti won the 15,000 pesos Argentine automobile road classic which ended today. He drove the distance of 7,342 kilometers (4,562 miles) from Buenos Aires to La Plata in 88 hours 58 minutes 53 4-5 seconds.

Max Pollikoff, violinist, will be heard in recital this evening at Carnegie Hall. Louis Kievman, viola player, will assist. The annual presentation dinner of the American Guild of Organists will take place tonight in the Florentine Room at 220 West Fiftyseventh Street.
Although rumors of impending mark devaluation as an aid to the export drive have been denied officially, there is talk of the creation of an "export mark" involving the mark's devaluation abroad.

A call for a combination of all patriotic and God-fearing Americans to unite in a common front against communism was sounded yesterday by Representative John J. O'Connor, the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran and Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling at a meeting attended by about 2,000 persons at the Hotel Commodore.

In spite of a substantial shift of 1936 Roosevelt New Deal supporters to the Republican candidates in this State, it is predicted generally that Utah's Democratic Representatives in Congress will be re-elected on Nov. 8.

Unless there is a veritable orgy of political fratricide in Chicago and Cook County on Nov., 8. the Democrats will chalk up another victory .in the once heavily Republican State of Illinois by electing Representative Scott Lucas to the United States Senate and holding their loss of Congress seats to an expected "normal" turnover.
Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Newington of Villa Serena, Field Point Park, entertained at dinner this evening in honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Chaffee and Wentworth Johnson of New York.

The United States wheat markets appear to have been stabilized at around 65 1/2 cents a bushel for the December delivery on the local Exchange. Prices last week held close to that figure, which is the average at which the future has sold in the last three months.

The Bay Parkways bowed to the Reading Rams, 7 to 6, in an exhibition football game before a crowd of 4,200 at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The visitors tallied less than three minutes before the game's close, Bill Smale running 35 yards with a recovered fumble and Dick John kicking the extra point.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, will enter the final stage of his campaign today when he leaves by train for Syracuse, where he will speak tonight at an Onondaga County meeting besides making his regular Monday night broadcast.

It doesn't greatly matter whether the German or the Polish Government is chiefly responsible for the mass deportations of Polish Jews from Germany. Reports from Berlin and Warsaw do not make it clear whether the Poles living in Germany were notified in advance that their passports would lapse at midnight on Sunday, or whether the action of Poland was precipitated to forestall the forced return of thousands of Polish Jews to the country of origin.

The Court of Peace of the World's Fair. where representatives of sixty-two nations will gather at a round table in a spirit of good-will to build "a better world of tomorrow," will be dedicated as a feature of New York City's observance of Armistice Day on Nov. 11.
The German wholesale price index on Oct. 26 stood at 105.9, unchanged from a week before and compared with 105.8 on Oct. 12 and 105.5 on Oct. 5.

Sid Luckman, Columbia backfield ace disabled early in the Cornell contest, had some rib muscles on his right side torn, examination at Columbia Medical Center revealed yesterday. He is not likely to face Virginia next Saturday at Baker Field, but it is virtually certain that he will play against Navy the following week-end.
" Madame Pompadour," popular operetta of the early Twenties, has been purchased by Metro as a vehicle for Miliza Korjus, whose first picture, "The Great Waltz," will be previewed Tuesday night.

The necessity for action by democracies everywhere in a program to resist the spread of dictatorship was emphasized at the second session of the American Jewish Congress yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore, and at a meeting held under the auspices of the organization in the evening in Carnegie Hall.
Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Lent of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lent, to William Curtis Sprong, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Sprong of Glen Ridge, N. J.

Eleven small American independent oil operators, with an investment between $1,500,000 and $2,000,000 in this region, are in danger of being forced out of business, partially as a result of the attitude of the Mexical Federal Government as well as that of the State of Tamaulipas. None of the properties was expropriated outright.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Seward, Alaska, of Derick Lane, a member of an old Troy, N. Y., family who was secretary to the judge of the Federal Circuit Court at Seward. Born in Troy 64 years ago, a son of Derick and Mary E. Thompson Lane, he prepared for college at St. Paul's School,

Because a dog, out without a muzzle, knew enough to run into the house when he saw a policeman, Magistrate Mark Rudich suspended sentence yesterday on the animal's owner in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn.

The reorganization committee for the Brockway Motor Truck Corportion yesterday notified the corportion's creditors and stockholders that the common shares and the warrants to buy the common stock of the Brockway Motor Company, Inc., the successor organization, were ready for distribution.

President Clark Griffith of the Senators signed Stanley R. (Bucky) Harris today to manage the team for another year, putting to an end the rumor that Harris was through at Washington. Griffith added, under questioning, that Bucky would get a slight rise in pay.

The most comprehensive revision of Stock Exchange practices in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, a revision which will fundamentally alter the conduct of brokerage businesses throughout the country,

Harvard University will receive eventually for its Business School a fund of more than $375,000 left by the late Mrs. Sophia E. Williston in memory of her husband, James Richards Williston, who was a member of the New York Stock Exchange.
If the violin recital that Max Pollikoff gave last night at Carnegie Hall did not measure up to expectation, the fault was only partly the recitalist's.

Obituaries in all newspapers in Generalissimo Francisco Franco's zone today recall Colonel Ramon Franco's transatlantic flight in 1926 with Ensign Duran and Captain Julio Ruiz de Aida in the plane Ne Plus Ultra to Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Ample short-term credit for farmers and potentially lower production costs were predicted today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics as a result of surveys undertaken in an effort to discover the trend for 1939.

Another step toward the complete reorganization of the New York Stock Exchange as planned by the Conway committee, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the new administration of the Exchange, was announced yesterday. While the proposals were adopted by the board of governors of the institution last week but not revealed until yesterday, there are still two important plans to be worked out.

The ten-room dwelling on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Stratford Avenue and Brompton Road, Garden City, L. I., was sold by the estate of Mrs. Emma M. Parker to Louis T. Weiss of Brooklyn. The property was reported held at $35,000. William L. Enequist, Inc., was the broker.

Mrs. David Rumsey gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. Frederick Mitchell Gould of Newport. Among the other guests were Mrs. John Adams Mayer, Mrs. Brokaw Dugmore, Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon, Mrs. Roderic D. O'Connor, Mrs. Leslie Bliss Soper, Mrs. E. Martin Michalis, Mrs. John P. Constable, Mrs. Thomas J. Mumford, Miss Janet Coleman, Miss Margaret H. Lawson and Miss Virginia Murray.

Stocks improved irregularly and closed steady and mixed after weakness in rail shares; turnover, 1,093,270 shares. United States Government and rail obligations lower, other bonds firm; transactions, $6,553,500.

Frederick Stuart Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works, replied in a statement tonight to the attack of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, who charged at Binghamton last week that the State's highway system was "going to pot."

Committees representing the American Merchant Marine Institute and the National Maritime Union of America, C. I. 0. affiliate, signed an agreement yesterday at the office of the institute, 11 Broadway, covering wages and working conditions for 20,000 seamen employed on ships of major American steamship companies.

Battered and weary but without a serious injury in the ranks, Fordham's football team took a light workout of less than an hour's duration on Fordham Field yesterday as preparations were begun for the annual intersectional game with St. Mary's at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 26 aggregated $7,992,000,000, or 13 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 12 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The Chilean Navy Office intercepted an S 0 S today from the navy cutter Leucoton saying she was in distress nineteen miles off Constitucion [about 150 miles south of Valparaiso] with a storm raging and her engine room flooded.

The conversion office for German foreign debts has announced an optional offer of exchange to holders of matured bonds of the following issues: Frankfort-am-Main 7 per cent serial bonds of 1925, matured Oct. 1, 1938; Duisburg-Hamborn (Duisburg external 7 per cent serial bonds), maturing today; Municipal Bank of the State of Hessen 7 per cent serial bonds,
Helen Armitage, who said she had done welfare and missionary work for the Rock House Mission in Virginia, received a prison sentence of fifteen months when she pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal

Prices dropped in a sluggish stock market here today although the range of fluctuation was small. Gilt-edge issues and foreign bonds were uniformly lower in restricted trading. United States Steel and International Nickel declined on speculative selling among transatlantic stocks.
