The Federal Communications Commission studied with evident perplexity today the unprecedented problem of the mass hysteria aroused last evening by the broadcast of "The War of the Worlds," but withheld any action pending a meeting at which the members planned to listen to a transcription of the program.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at her home in Schenectady, N. Y., of Mrs. Mary Ellis Yelverton, wife of James Walker Yelverton, chairman of the board of the Citizens Trust Company of Schenectady.

Colonel John Clibborn, one of the best known engineers of his time in India, died in Lyndhurst today. He had played a large part in the development of the great irrigation systems in Northern India and, as principal of the Thomas Engineering College at Rorkee, 1892-1901, he trained thousands of officers for Indian public service.

Police declared yesterday the fracture found in the skull of Pat Crowe, one-time desperado who died Saturday in Harlem Hospital, was received when he fell down a flight of stairs following a heart attack. Detective Fred Schmidt of the East 126th Street station said reports that the 79-year-old man had been stricken while in his furnished room were incorrect.

Germany's announcement of plans for arbitration of the Hungarian-Czechoslovak issues yesterday showed Britain, France and Poland had been excluded from influence in mid-Europe. Italy's role also was secondary as the Reich became committed to the arbitration plan before consulting Rome.
John W. Deering, a convicted murderer, faced a firing squad in apparent calm today, but his heart pounded three times normal, an electro-cardiograph film showed later.
Robert Woolsey, motion picture comedian, died today at his home here after a long illness at the age of 49.

The report of the Hospital Survey, published last year, left no doubt that New York City's public hospital and medical service needs overhauling, consolidating and modernizing. In an open letter to Miss Katherine Faville, director of the Henry Street Nursing Service, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner in charge of the city's Department of Hospitals, indicates the first step that should be taken in this process.

Despite the recent upturn of business, and a slight rise in employment in the last few months, the relief burden in this city continues to mount. Local officials regard this as a customary lag between economic conditions and relief needs.

Duke University emerged from October's last Saturday the only unscored upon, undefeated and untied football team of the country. The Blue Devils, leaders of the Southern Conference, have gone to the wars six times and piled up 79 points.

Brownsdale Chief, owned by Lewis Brown. of Peekskill, N. Y., was the winner in the open all-age stake for fifteen-inch dogs in the third day's running of the Long Island Beagle Club's Autumn field trial meeting today.

Viscountess Mersey and her son, the Hon. Edward Clive Bigham, have returned from a trip in Canada and are at the Gotham. Mr. and Mrs. Pierre L. Barbey are at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. John S. Phipps of Westbury will be at the Ritz Tower for the Winter.

In the lee of the Island of Ventotene, Premier Benito Mussolini, standing in a downpour of rain with his arm raised in the Fascist salute on the bridge of the cruiser Trento, inspected a fleet of sixteen ships carrying 1,800 families of agricultural workers to the Italian colony of Libya.

Even stricter secrecy than usual was observed regarding the deliberations of the Cabinet at its meeting tonight to consider the proposed decrees for restoring the financial and economic situation of the country.

Declaring that he wished to make an example of them for their "flagrant disregard of both law and order," Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo imposed maximum sentences yesterday of thirty days in the county jail and fines of $250 each upon two officials of the United Retail Employes Union, Local 830.

The Child Study Association of America opened yesterday its fiftieth anniversary campaign for $200,000 to be raised nationally to meet its budgetary needs for three years. Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller Co., and Professor Lyman Bryson, of Teachers College, Columbia University, director of adult education activities of the Columbia Broadcasting System, addressed the opening meeting and tea yesterday afternoon at Hampshire House, attended by 200 women workers.

Christmas Club deposits in mutual savings banks in seventeen States reached $54,429,205 this year, an increase of $2,771,844 from last year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks announced yesterday. The total of depositors was 1,326,797, a record and an increase of 99,906 from last year.

Habit and custom have combined to represent each biennial election in this country "as the most important ever held." The same thing will probably be said of the polls of Nov. 8, 1938. It is impossible that electoral importance should be thus cumulative. But there can be no doubt that great consequences will flow from next Tuesday's voting, even though they may not be the greatest ever recorded.

Abraham Segall, Past Grand Chancellor of the Knights of Pythias of New York State, died today of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 43. Mr. Segall, Grand Chancellor in 1935, was a Brooklyn attorney. He ran as an independent Democrat for District Attorney of Kings County in 1933.

The Panama Canal's oldest employe in-point of service, Charles D. Hummer, retired today after more than thirty-four years' continuous service. Mr. Hummer, a native of New Brunswick, N. J., was first employed Sept. 4, 1904, for rehabilitation of excavating machinery left by the French.

Recommendations contained in the Conway report that the retiring nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange present a slate of seven names for the 1939 nominating committee, giving due representation to the various interests represented in the membership, will be followed this year, it was announced yesterday.

Warnings that Americans in foreign trade must find ways of combating trade methods of totalitarian governments or face exclusion from major markets of the world predominated in the remarks of speakers yesterday at the opening day's...

Vacuum cleaners in operation in American homes now number 12,000,000, C. G. Frantz, secretary-treasurer of the Vacuum Cleaner Manufacturers Association, announced today. Mr. Frantz, who is with the Apex Electrical Company of this city, reported that the cleaners were in use in 50 per cent of the wired homes in this country.
Adoption of the grade-crossing amendment, No. 3, was urged last night by Alfred E. Smith, who said that it would provide many jobs without calling for an additional State debt authorization.

AERONAUTICAL OCCUPATIONS FOR Boys, by Captain Burr Leyson. (Dutton, $2.) A survey. ALL ABOUT SUBWAYS, by Groff Conklin. (Messner, $2.50.) Subway building, in pictures and text. As HIGH AS THE SKY, by Norah C. James. (Macaulay, $2.) A new novel by the author of "Sleeveless Errand."

The old saw about being too smart for one's own good was supported yesterday in an psychologist's report contending that an intelligence quotient above 150 menaced a child with loneliness, an inferiority complex and a cynical attitude toward life.

Sharply curtailed wheat acreage for the 1939 harvest was predicted by the Deapartment of Agriculture today on the basis of a nationwide survey of factors governing this crop. The prediction was made on the basis of current low prices. a poor export market and indications that the bad export condition would continue into the next marketing year.

The New York Stock Exchange has already set its machinery in motion for making effective a joint program worked out with the Securities and Exchange Commission designed to give greater protection to the money and securities deposited with brokers by the investing public.

Governor Lehman, Senator Robert F. Wagner, Representative James M. Mead and former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, candidates on the Democratic and, American Labor party tickets, received tremendously enthusiastic receptions at the climax rally of the Labor party at Madison Square Garden last evening.

Municipal officers invited yesterday tenders to be considered at various dates in the future for new issues aggregating in excess of $4,000,000. Leading the list, the city of Phoenix, Ariz., announced that it would receive sealed bids on Saturday for a new issue of $1,175,000 of water, sewer,

Colonial Julgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Arnmy, has accepted the invitation of General Manuel Avila Camacho, Mexico's Secretary of National Defense, to visit that country in the first part of next January.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 28: CAPTAIN Beauregard, A. T., the New Orleans, to duty as chief, naval mission to Brazil, Rio de Janiero, about Dec. 15. COMMANDER Bright, R. M., Navy Yard, Washington, D. C., on Dec. 1 to Asiatic Station.

L. W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager of the New York Central Railroad, announced yesterday that Harry G. Gillis had been appointed assistant general passenger agent. Mr. Gillis has had thirty years' experience with railroads, and heretofore has been chief of the passenger traffic tariff of the company. He succeeds the late Irving M. Taylor.
Seventeen-year-old Pan Pih-cheng and his bride today ended an eight-day hunger strike when Pan's father a wealthy Canton merchant, agreed to donate 1,500,000 Chinese dollars to China's war chest.

The Federal Communications Commission requested yesterday a transcript and electric recording of the radio broadcast Sunday night which dramatized H. G. Wells's 41-year-old novel, "The War of the Worlds," and spread panic among thousands of Americans convinced that fiction in the form of tensely spoken "news" bulletins was stark fact.

The board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board made public today rulings on questions relating to its Regulation T, holding that to protect themselves against withdrawals from general account followed by other transactions on the same day brokers should permit no withdrawals without being certain that trading in the account has been coneluded for the day,

A Thanksgiving tea dance and fashion show will be given under the auspices of the Humane Society of New York on Nov. 18 at Sherry's for the benefit of the society's free clinic for animals. The style display, entitled "Sister Act," will have the participation of sisters prominent in New York society in the role of manikins.
When Judge William Allen in General Sessions yesterday sent two ex-convicts back to State. prison for terms of seventeen to thirty-four years each, he was informed in a report from Irving W.

Dividend declarations by 737 companies in October amounted to $190,783,485, the smallest for that month since 1935 and the lowest figure for any month since last July. In September, 1,167 companies authorized payments of $216,290,830, while in October, last year, 888 companies declared dividends of $304,634.647.

The Appellate Division, Third Department, unanimously refused today to review a Supreme Court decision that Howard C. Hopson and five other individuals must appear before the Public Service Commission in its investigation of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.
The Sudeten German party as a unit was inducted into the National Socialist party today by a decree of Chancellor Hitler.
G. S. Hinkins, vice president of the Dollar Steamship Line, announced last night that the lines will be known hereafter as The American President Line.
President Roosevelt today called upon the railroad industry to accept the recommendation of the Emergency Fact-Finding Board that they abandon their request for a 15 per cent wage decrease.
Wheat futures were traded in today in the world market within a range of about 2 cents a bushel. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were unchanged to 1/8 cent lower.
S. J. Norris's Mr. Blaze today took the Meriden Handicap on a heavy track at Narragansett Park from the Fanfare Farm's Dunade by a neck, the judges calling for a picture.
AlLeach, Cleveland golfer who won the national public links tournament in August, was back on WPA today. Leach, 26, forfeited a job as WPA timekeeper to enter the tournament.

The site of a new American legation building was dedicated at Monrovia yesterday with impressive ceremonies on the seventy-fifth anniversary of the initiation of treaty relations between Liberia and the United States, according to a report received by the State Department today.
William H. Fritz, president of the Berwyn National Bank, died last night in the Windermere Apartments in Wayne at the age of 74.

Tonight I wish in a very calm and sober manner to present certain important facts to the people. I believe it is my duty to present these considerations to you. All this I do in an objective spirit and without any personal feeling.

Announcement in Washington that the Public Works Administration had approved a supplemental loan and grant of $3,279,000 to the Chattanooga Electric Power Board was taken by L. J. Wilhoite, the board's chairman, today to mean that the public power distribution system here will be pushed forward to completion. The loan and grant lifts the total advanced by the PWA to the board to $7,609,000.
It will be War Admiral against Seabiscuit, East vs. West, at historic Pimlico tomorrow at 3:50 P. M.

The little wooden soldier completely ruined the wave in her hair and the charcoal-bearded cossack got water up his nose, but they11-year-old Corinne Daly and George Sikoryak, 12-dipped deep into the. galvanized iron washtub at the Boys Athletic League's Halloween party yesterday and emerged triumphant as city-wide apple-ducking champions.

Neither of the Virginia Senators is running for re-election this year, but the feeling over their positions in the national picture is illustrated by a hunting and fishing privilege issued to Arthur Naul of Bronxville, N. Y., by T. M. Gathright of Hickory Lodge, near Hot Springs. Mr.

General JeanMarie Joseph Degoutte, former commander of the allied armies of the Rhineland, famous for his campaigns in the World War, died today at the age of 72 in his native village of Charney, department of the Rhone.

Sale by the Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company of certain properties in Clarksville, Tenn., to the city of Clarksville for $260,000 cash, in accordance with an agreement to which the Tennessee Valley Authority was a party, was approved today by the Federal Power Commission.
This correspondent flew here from Prague yesterday to see 330 Hungarians who were captured in the course of an invasion of Ruthenia.
John W. Hanes, former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and until today an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was sworn in this afternoon by Secretary Morgenthau as Under-Secretary.

THE weekly huddle was on, with Coach Tad Wieman of Princeton putting the ball in play by telling how good Harvard was against Princeton. After that the comments, queries and retorts courteous were as badly scrambled as an inside tackle play thrown against that Pitt Panther line. This innocent bystander missed some nice passes, but caught the following on the fly:

A $156,000 building and permanent mortgage loan for 10 years at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent on the 6-story apartment house under erection at 206-218 W. 19th St has been arranged for the Seventh Chelsea Corp., owners, by Ackman Co, Inc. broker. Several loans on Brooklyn and Long Island properties were negotiated by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc, broker.

Aubrey Williams, Deputy Works Progress Administrator, announced today that about 228,000 persons left WPA employment during September and that 80,221 of the 173,202 withdrawing voluntarily had gone directly into private employment.
Two buildings of historic interest--one in Sharon, Conn., and the other in Chester, N. J.-have just changed hands. Both of them date back to about the same period of early American realty history.

1st Lt. Alfred F. Tucker, Air-Res., New Providence Rd., Mountainside, N. J., is ordered to active duty Nov. 1, at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, for training. Date of rank, Oct. 4. He will revert to an inactive status Nov. 14. Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Solomon J. Zoller, Inf.-Res., May 8, 1939.

Because of an unexpectedly heavy demand for automobiles, the Buick division of General Motors Corporation is starting the largest manufacturing program in its history, Harlow H. Curtice, president and general manager of Bulok, said today.
J. B. Priestley, British author and playwright, doubled in brass tonight when he suddenly made his debut as an actor.
The details of a number of realty transactions in upper Manhattan and the Bronx were made known yesterday. They involved residential and business parcels, as well as a large parcel of vacant land.

Leroy Fry of Texas College of Arts and Industries took over the national football scoring leadership during the past week, while Everett Elkins, former leader from Marshall College of West Virginia, dropped to third place among the pace setters.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: John Yearwood, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES in opposition to the proposed constitutional amendment excluding $315,000,000 of debt for rapid transit unification purposes, makes a number of inaccurate statements.

The Democratic National Committee reported today that it received $264,060 and spent $238,741 between Sept. 1 and Oct. 27. It filed a statement with the Clerk of the House, in accordance with the Corrupt Practices Act, showing a balance of $25,319 on Oct. 27 and, unpaid obligations of $183,012.

Sales of bottled soft drinks will reach a new all-time peak this year and the outlook for 1939 indicates further substantial gains, according to reports made yesterday at the opening sessions of the annual convention and exhibit of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages at Commerce Hall, Port Authority Building.

An informal conference will be held this afternoon between Edward Fillmore, counsel for the Associted Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., and representatives of the Association of Buying Offices, on the plan of the fur manufacturers' group for the registration of all fur buyers.

Every member of Harvard's varsity squad except Don Lowry, who was excused for classes, reported to Coach Dick Harlow on Soldiers Field today. The Crimson came through the victory over Princeton in excellent physical condition. The first team confined its practice to a signal drill directed by Captain Bobby Green, left end.

Mrs. Carleton Macy gave a tea yesterday at her home, 775 Park Avenue, for members of the debutante committee and chairmen of other groups planning for the Victorian Ball to be given Dec. 16 at the Ritz-Carlton under the auspices of the National Arts Club.

Fatalities dropped sharply yesterday in the tabulated reports of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department covering traffic accidents for the week and week-end, comparedd with those of the corresponding periods of 1937.
The Colonial dwelling on Oneida Street, Rye, Westchester, owned by the Lucetta Ottley Trust, has been sold by the Guarantee Trust Company to Mrs. Clara V. Henshaw, through E. V. Siedle, broker.

Bonds called for redemption prior to maturity in October totaled $217,884,000, the largest amount for any month since July, 1937, when $235,477,000 were redeemed. Last month's prepayments compared with $36,660,000 in the preceding month and with $134,043,000 in October, 1937.
Another Summer having gone by, the Brattleboro Theatre has reopened for a Winter of business at the St. Felix Street Playhouse in Brooklyn.

Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College was host yesterday afternoon to the college faculty at a tea in his office at 2 Park Avenue. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, and Mrs. Walter S. Mack Jr., chairman of the Hunter College Board of Trustees, were present.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 26: Increases of $7,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $63,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities,

Governor Earle announced here tonight that he was prepared to lay before President Roosevelt a plan for "the immediate mining, preparation, transportation and storage" of 20,000,000 tons of anthracite coal as a national defense measure.
Title to uncounted thousands of oysters changed as one result of the hurricane which swept the- coastal region of New England recently, the Bureau of Fisheries reported today.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 27 numbered 251, the largest number recorded in sevtenteen weeks, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compared with 185 a year ago and 227 a week ago.

Modification by Secretary Hull of rules made in carrying out the law requiring registration of propaganda agents of foreign principals so that persons interested only in the importation of merchandise will not be classed as public relations counsel or publicity agents is urged in a report made public yesterday by the committee on foreign commerce and the revenue laws of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

According to S. John Block, New York attorney and a member of the Charter Revision Committee that framed the new City Charter under which the late B. Charney Vladeck was elected to the City Council, the choice of his successor lies entirely in the hands of the City Council.

MANHATTAN ALVORD. NELLIE (Jan. 20). Gross Assets, $28,254; net, $23,217. To Susan G. Theis and Isabel T. Hoskins, sisters, equally. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $25,410. Wingate Cullen, attorneys, 142 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn. BANBERGERM, REBA A. (May 31). Es$579,424; net, $537,528.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest for any month of the year as well as the largest since the corresponding month in 1937. The heaviest day's business was 2,523,960 shares on Oct. 17, and the smallest was 947,780 on Oct. 4.

Mrs. Hayden Channing is entertaining a house party at Valley Head, Lenox. The guests are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sears Lovering and Mrs. Frederick G. B Hard of Bay Shore, L. I.; Miss Phebe K. Thorne of Islip, L. I., and Miss Diane de Pourtales of Geneva, Switzerland.
Courage in the face of one of the darkest periods of Jewish history was the keynote of today's second session of the annual convention of the Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization.

Mail reorders for seasonal apparel and accessories from retailers in many sections of the country increased here yesterday, and buyers and merchandising executives expressed the belief that cooler weather has brought the awaited turn for the better in the Fall season.

The following homes in Brooklyn and Long Island have been leased through Joseph P. Day, Inc.: In Brooklyn, 1,834 East Fifth Street, to A. Romano, 1,947 East Thirtyseventh Street, to J. Pego, and 673 Tenth Street, to V. Neebe; in Ozone Park, L. I., 106-02 Seventy-ninth Street, to M. Silvestro,
Head Coach George Munger of Pennsylvania today received word that Fullback Jim Connell will be able to play against Michigan.

The refusal of a request for a Sunday chicken dinner at Father Divine's "Heaven" at Lenox Avenue and 123d Street led indirectly yesterday to a ten-day sentence for Buddy Jones, 36 years old, a Negro, of 36 West 128th Street, according to testimony before Magistrate Raphael R. Murphy,

A uniformed fireman was shot dead by a hold-up man in front of a firehouse in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday as he returned in his car at 12:30 P. M. from a neighborhood bank where he had cashed the pay checks of twenty-eight other firemen for a total of about $3,400.

In the first half of 1938, German production of motor vehicles continued at record levels, with the building of 286,123 machines of all types, the Department of Commerce reported today. This represented a gain of 16.8 per cent over the comparable period in 1937.
Coach Carl Snavely and his Cornell squad today watched movies and listened to scout reports on Dartmouth, to be met here Nov. 12.

The proposed Sixth Amendment to the State Constitution consists of three parts, two of which belong in the Bill of Rights and one of which has no place in a Constitution. The amendment states, first, that "labor of human beings shall never be construed to be a commodity or article of commerce."

The Harvard Club, playing on its own courts, trounced the Princeton Club, 5 to 0, last night for its second straight victory of the season and remained in first place, tied with the New York A. C. in the Metropolitan League Class race of the National Squash Tennis Association.
The Czech press publishes today interesting details of what is happening on the other side of the new frontiers.

Persistent trade absorption of contracts for the current cotton crop, coincident with moderate selling pressure on the 1939 crop delivery, widened the December-October spread to 80 points yesterday and left prices with a gain of 1 point to a loss of 8.

Henry Armstrong and Ceferino Garcia, who will meet for the former's welterweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, brought their training to an end yesterday. Both fighters survived the long preparatory campaign without suffering injury and are in the best of condition.

Colgate undertook hard work today to prepare for the annual. game with Syracuse in the Salt City on Saturday. Trey Coley, quarterback, returned to the squad and commenced light work but Bob Johnson, veteran signal caller, rested most of the time. He hasn't recovered completely from the injury received in the Columbia game, although he played more than half of the contest with Holy Cross last Saturday.

Instructions to more than 18,000 members of the Police Department, outlining work to be done on election day, Nov. 8, were distributed from the office of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday afternoon.

Governor Lehman charged tonight that Thomas E. Dewey was not qualified to be Governor of New York and that he had broken faith with the people in not completing his term as District Attorney before seeking higher office.
Belgium returned a flat "no" today to suggestions that she might contribute in a general redistribution of colonial territory to meet Germany's demands.

Rejection of the proposed $77,000,000 Manhattan-Brooklyn vehicular tunnel by. the Public Works Administration is a settled matter under the present appropriation, Secretary Ickes said today after a conference with President Roosevelt.

Employers in this State have shown themselves "extremely favorable" to the Wages and Hours Law and eager to be well informed and cooperative in the administration of it, according to a statement issued yesterday by Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner. She stressed the satisfactory results obstained during the first week of the law's operation.

President Roosevelt's letter approving Governor George H. Earle's "Liberal" Democratic administration, was commented upon jubilantly by Republicans today, while Democratic leaders predicted that it made the election of the Democratic State ticket certain.

Utica is the home city of Lieutenant Governor M. William Bray, who was left off the Democratic State ticket this year because of the desire of the State leaders to develop in that post some one of more definite Gubernatorial stature.

The annual sale of Christmas gift articles to assist St. Luke's Home for Aged Women at 2,914 Broadway will be held there on Nov. 16 and 17. Mrs. Percy L. Hance and Mrs. Frederick H. Cone will give a tea tomorrow at the Plaza for the board of managers and those who will assist at the sale.

Now that Deputy Mayor Henry C. Curran has turned his educational activities elsewhere it has fallen upon his most promising student, Borough President James J. Lyons, to carry on his former mentor's crusade for grammatical English.
Most of the Princeton regulars refrained from practice altogether today, although a few played touch football with the coaches.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against HARRY BRIKOLD, haberdashery, 451 E. Tremont Ave.-By Atlantic Shirt Co., for $200; Samuel Krovonet, $400; Fendel Dershowitz. $100. BUDROSE SHOPS, INC., women's specialties, 116 W. 34th St. and Lexington Ave. -By Benjamin Johnes, Inc., for $200; Dainties, Inc., $300; W. B. Foundations, Inc.. S50.

Tonight's events: John Powell, .pianist, Carnegie Hall; Mary Bothwell, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Kolisch String Quartet, New York Public Library, 8:30; John Barbirolli, first of a series of lectures for the Philharmonic-Symphony League, Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, 8:30;

Marking its first change in location in sixty-eight years, John H. Graham Co., Inc., has leased the new two-story and basement building at 105-107 Duane Street, extending through to 14-16 Thomas Street, it was announced yesterday. The firm, which represents numerous manufacturers, was founded in 1870 in 113 Chambers Street and 95 Reade Street, in which buildings it now is located.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,537,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Pitt was playing Wisconsin in a game that some of the experts had picked as one likely to provide an upset Both teams were unbeaten, and out at Madison they thought that Harry Stuhldreher was going to turn the tables on Dr. John Bain Sutherland.

The text of the two speeches made here tonight by Thomas E. Dewey follows, the first speech having been broadcast on a State-wide N. B. C. hook-up and the second delivered at a Republican rally in Lincoln Hall:

After being informed yesterday of a shortage of 1,423 pounds of meat at the Rikers Island Penitentiary Mayor La Guardia ordered the suspension of Abraham Lasher, a butcher at the institution, and referred his case to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx.

Robert E. L. Saner, who was president of the American Bar Association in 1923-24, died here early today at the age of 67. In his younger days he was a school teacher, railroad man, connected with magazines and took part at times in State politics.

Coach Wood let Army's football squad loosen up with a period of kicking and passing, followed by a short signal drill today as he carefully checked the physical condition of the Cadets. After a forty-five minute drill Wood excused all except the placement kickers.

The military today took over control of Jaffa, long a center for Arab rebels who used it as a headquarters for terrorist activities in Southern Palestine. The present disturbances began in Jaffa in 1936 and ever since it has been one of the most troublesome districts.
President Roosevelt, through a proclamation today, reduced the postage on books to 1 1/2 cents a pound for all domestic mail.

In an article published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES describing answers sent by Congressional candidates to a New York League of Women Voters questionnaire it was incorrectly reported that the league supported the proposed so-called "equal rights" amendment to the Federal Constitution.

The influx of gold to the United States, which reached record proportions in September, abated in October. Imports at New York, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank, amounted to $127,247,000 last month, compared with $303,451,000 in September and with $39,598,700 in October, 1937.

Century Shares Trust reports a liquidating value of $21.88 for each participating share on Sept. 30 last, compared with $21.95 on June 30 and $22.58 on Sept. 30, 1937. Investments carried at cost of $13,314,400 had a market value on Sept. 30 of $10,927,099, compared with $13,360,957 and $11,312,840, respectively, a year before. By Oct. 28 liquidating value had risen to $23.12.
The blessed work "science" has covered many a dubious adventure, but we do not often encounter such a questionable piece of business as that experiment in the execution yard of Utah State Prison.

A sharp conflict developed yesterday between Representative John J. O'Connor, seeking re-election in the Sixteenth District, and the WPA administration. Mr. O'Connor charged at a conference in his office with R. C.

In an effort to establish the identity of an Oyster Bay resident who was reported to have said that the village high school was "too good" for Negroes, Italians and Poles attending it, more than 300 students conducted a strike this morning and refused to attend classes until a committee of students had been selected to investigate the source of the alleged statement.

After a patrolman testified that he had seen Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan carrying the stolen police records from the Bergen Street station record room, Magistrate Matthew J. Troy, acting on the request of both Behan's counsel and Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, held Behan yesterday for the extraordinary grand jury to be impaneled in Brooklyn on Nov. 17.
The Fort Pitt Bridge Works has taken a contract for 6,000 tons of shapes for Youngstown Sheet and Tube's new mill construction at Indiana Harbor, Ind.

The newly organized New York Stock Exchange firm of Pedley, Martin Co. formally opens offices today at 634 South Spring Street, Los Angeles, to conduct a general securities business and to act as Los Angeles correspondents for J. S. Bache Co. The new firm will maintain a New York branch at the Bache offices, 42 Broadway.
The Spanish Insurgent command reported its forces in Eastern Spain had advanced to within artillery range of Mora de Ebro, major immediate, objective on the Catalan front.

Bonds drifted to moderately lower levels yesterday in dull trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Railroad issues, which attracted the bulk of activity in the corporate section, experienced a rather severe sinking spell in early dealings, but a late rally reduced the initial declines so that net losses in that list ranged from fractions to about 2 points.

The two four-story apartment houses at 549-51 Park Avenue, West New York, N. J., were sold by the Merchants Trust Company to the Polk Realty Company, Inc. J. I. Kislak, Inc., were the brokers in the deal.

A luncheon at which $250,000 worth of ermine coats will be displayed will be held today at the Hotel McAlpin to select a model who will wear a $25,000 ermine wedding gown, created for National Fur Week, which is to be held Nov. 14 to 19.

A national advertising campaign for electric roasters will be launched some time during 1939 by a newlycreated division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, it was learned here yesterday. Sales of this appliance have spurted sharply this year,

Department stores here will open their holiday toy displays on Saturday, Nov. 19, with the arrival of Santa Claus in town and other publicity stunts. The earlier opening this year is due to the earlier date for Thanksgiving, which falls on Nov. 24.

Charges that the Administration, although highly critical of the manner in which the investigation had been conducted, had repeatedly refused to give departmental assistance to the House Committee on Un-American Activities, even though the resolution of Congress authorizing the investigation directed that such assistance be given, ...

Wells Lewis, a senior at Harvard, has written a first novel, which has been accepted for publication in the Spring by Farrar Rinehart. Its setting is Harvard, New York and Mexico. Its title is "They Still Say No." The author is the elder son of Sinclair Lewis.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. Speakers: Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey, Bruce Barton, Mrs. Frank L. Patterson Jr., Mrs. William Henry Hays, 10:30 A. M.; "Thomas E. Dewey the Administrator," Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Willjam Mertens Jr., Gertrude B. Lane, 8:30 P. M.

Party boat anglers who have been waiting for the cod to arrive can go out any day now and be fairly certain of taking a few fish. Several of the off-shore boats report the cod to be quite plentiful, with enough blackfish, ling and whiting to assure anglers of a good day's sport.

The charter provides a procedure for filling a vacancy on the City Council. The chair now empty will be occupied by a new member chosen by the majority of all the present members. He must be of the same political party as the man who has gone, and a resident of the same district.

Two teams deadlocked in the amateur-pro event with 65s today as the Long Island P. G. A. held its final tournament of the season at the Sound View Golf Club. Stanley J. Harte and Tony Longo of Inwood, Karl Karch of Bayside and Jack Mallon of the Garden City C. C. formed the top combinations.

Governor Lehman was asked yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate what a Federal grand jury reported last week as "reprehensible" conditions in the city of Newburgh and in Orange County.

When Andre Frangois-Poncet, who had been French Ambassador to Berlin since before the Hitler regime, returned to Paris last week, he brought with him, it is said, concrete proposals from Chancellor Hitler for a nonaggression pact with France similar to that signed between Herr Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain at Munich.

President W. J. Tobin of the Black Hawks hockey team announced today that three of the team's most promising youngsters had been farmed to the Providence Reds of the Eastern division of the International American League.
An anti-Fascist play, "Waltz in Goose Step," by Oliver H. P. Garrett, opens tonight at the Hudson Theatre. Henry Oscar has the leading role.

Four able men have been nominated in this State for two places in the Senate of the United States. Mr. Wagner and Mr. Mead, for the Democrats, and Mr. O'Brian and Mr. Corsi, for the Republicans, have all shown competence in public office. They are all progressives.

The project would contemplate a central financial institution to receive deposits of all classes of marketable securities in the same way that commercial banks receive deposits of money. As funds can be transferred in or withdrawn by checks from banks, the central depository would enable depositors to shift their interest in deposited securities from one depositor to another and to withdraw securities by checks.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew called on Vice Foreign Minister Renzo Sawada late this afternoon. While the nature of their conversations was not divulged, it is supposed that Mr. Grew urged that Japan reply to the United States note of Oct. 6.

The death in Fordham Hospital at 4:05 o'clock yesterday morning of Patrolman George W. Perkins, attached to the Morrisania station, from a bullet wound in the abdomen was described as "apparently P a suicide" at the office of the assistant chief inspector this morning.

The campaign for noise abatement in the city begun some time ago by Mayor La Guardia resulted in the warning of 293,088 makers of unnecessary noises and the summoning of 16,356 violators during the first nine months of 1938, records at Police Headquarters showed yesterday.

Chile's highest award to non-citizens, the Al Merito order, established by the country's first President, Bernardo O'Higgins, was conferred -yesterday on J. D. MacGregor, vice president and general manager of Pan American-Grace Airways, for his and his company's work in establishing airlines to Chile in the last ten years.
A total of 5,557,845 persons registered for the November elections, the Secretary of State's office announced today.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, was called upon yesterday to reinstate process servers whose positions he abolished on taking office as District Attornay last January. In a telegram to Mr. Dewey, W. R. Van Wagner, chairman of a committee of civil service process servers, said:
An injunction against the removal of top soil from the Saxon Woods real estate development here to the World's Fair grounds in Flushing was granted today by Supreme Court Justice Raymond E Aldrich.

MANHATTAN BEGNALL, MARGARET H. (Oct. 1). Estate, $18,700. To Maria Morrow, sister, Kilgola, Finea P. O., County Meath, Ireland, residue; William Morrow, nephew, executor, 240 Sheldon Ave., Tarrytown, N. Y., $5,500. CHIAPPARI, MARTA (Oct. 13). Estate, not more than $10,000. To Louis, Emila and Eros Chiappari, executrix, children, 75 Washington Pl., equally.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 56.8 per cent of capacity this week, the best figure recorded since the week of Oct. 11, 1937, and a gain of 3.1 points, or 5.8 per cent, over last week, when operations were 53.7 per cent.

Harrison T. Giberson, treasurer of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company of New York, died Sunday night at his home at 353 Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, of coronary thrombosis after an illness of two weeks. He was 68 years old.

While scores of citizens in all walks of life paid tribute yesterday to B. Charney Vladeckj American Labor party leader and City Councilman, plans were made for his funeral services to be held at 10 A. M. tomorrow at the auditorium of The Forward Building, 175 East Broadway.
Commercial leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday centered on the west side of the midtown district. A number of fullfloor rentals appeared in the lists of contracts announced.

Frank J. Moore, veteran clubhouse commissioner, who had made book at all of the New York tracks since the days of the old Morris Park in Westchester County, died on Sunday at his home, 211 Central Park West, after a long illness. He was about 70 years old.

Financed by a gift from James H. R. Cromwell and his wife, the former Doris Duke, Princeton University is instituting a Study of the simplification and improvement of the New Jersey tax structure, it was announced today by President Harold W. Dodds.

Green Bay is helping toward the establishment of a new scoring record in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday. The Packers have tallied 168 points in their eight games.

The Lafayette Guild, an auxiliary of the Maternity Center Association, will resume its activities today with the opening of its weekly sewing class at Essex House. Mrs. J. Wideman Lee is president of the guild, Mrs. Louis H. Huot heads the sewing class committee, and Mrs. William P. Sears and Mrs. Ivy Lee are assistant chairmen.

A petition signed by almost half the members of Congress and thirty Governors of States urged President Roosevelt today to make representations to Britain to keep open Palestine for Jewish refugees. It was presented at the White House by the Emergency Committee on Palestine.

While the Wuhan cities-Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang-are in many respects assuming more and more aspects of normality, in other ways they are showing increasing evidences of harsh treatment by alien soldiers.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court awarded $40,000 yesterday to Mrs. Esther Shapiro of 115 Division Avenue, Brooklyn, for the death of her husband, Joseph, 37 years old, who was killed by a tire rim hurled by a tire blowout on a dairy truck.

Automobile production continued to increase more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 87.9, compared with 85.4 for the preceding week and 115.9 for the week ended Oct. 30, 1937. Output for the week, as estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports, was 73,335 units. The previous week's assemblies totaled 68,360,

Omnibook, a new literary monthly magazine, which will contain five books in abbreviated form, will be released today under the editorship of Councilman Robert K. Straus, son of the late Jesse Isidor Straus, former Ambassador to France.

The two pension proposals contained in Amendment 1 offer the "only way the pension systems can be placed on a sound basis," the presidents of four organizations of the Police Department declared in a letter to the Citizens Budget Commission, made public yesterday.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, takes the position that the. public relations of a modern industry concern the employes of a company as well as the management, in his introductory message for the Bethlehem Review of Nov. 1, which is a bulletin for employes.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association rose last week after having reached a new low for the year. The association's index, based on the 1926-28 average, was 72.9 for the week ended Oct. 29, compared with 72.3 last week, 73.3 a month ago and 82.2 a year ago.

The Police Department, indicating that the action was taken because of recent criticism of the practice of reducing complaints against prisoners brought into the Magistrates' Courts, moved yesterday to make a record of all such cases in the' future.

Reports of a growing tide of antiSemitism in Czechoslovakia were denied yesterday by Vojta Benes, elder brother of the former President of Czechoslovakia, with the assertion that "it is not possible to convert a nation like Czechoslovakia from a model, democratic republic into a fascist, anti-Semitic nation by a mere stroke of the pen."

This writer made the rounds today of provisional concentration points here of Jews expelled from Germany, of whom about 1,000 have thus far arrived in Warsaw. They are being accommodated in schools and various Jewish institutions.

Two funeral services will be held today for Mrs. Geraldine McAlpin Webster, wife of Dr. Jerome Pierce Webster. The first, at 1 P. M., in the chapel of the Presbyterian Hospital, will be for members of the staff of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where Dr. Webster is an assistant surgeon.

Leading European currencies were moderately lower yesterday in quiet dealings in the foreign-exchange market. Traders attributed the movement more to strength of the dollar in London than to any severe pressure against the foreign currencies The pound sterling closed 1 cent lowe here at $4.75 1/2 and the French franc declined 7-16 point, closing at 2.66 1/8 cents.

Two of Columbia's disabled mainstays limited themselves to light exercise on Baker Field yesterday as Lou Little sent the rest of the squad through a rigorous session correcting the defensive faults of the linemen.

If or when King George and Queen Elizabeth visit Washington, they will be made welcome at the White House by President and Mrs. Roosevelt during their stay in the capital, or another residence will be placed at their disposal, as has been done in the past for .other visiting members of -royalty, Mrs. Roosevelt said today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System made public yesterday the complete script of the dramatized version of "The War of the Worlds," which created widespread panic Sunday night. Here are sample excerpts, all of which followed the introductory announcement and a speech by Orson Welles setting the stage as "in the thirtyninth year. of the twentieth century, near the end of October."

A committee representing the Allied Underwear Association will call on Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Act, tomorrow to ask that a separate committee be named to represent the women's undergarment industry.

Thomas T. McCrosky, director of planning of the Department of City Planning, will discuss housing and planning at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, tomorrow evening. He will replace Jacob Crane, chief of the project review division of the USHA, who will be unable to attend.

James Lord Pratt, proprietor of the famous village smithy, operated by one descendant after another of Lieutenant John Pratt since 1678, dropped dead this morning in a store here. He would have celebrated his seventy-seventh birthday tomorrow.
Any demands for changes in the Adminisration's silver purchasing program should be addressed to Congress, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said this afternoon at his press conference.

According to an official announcement, Chancellor Hitler as supreme commander of the armed forces today dismissed from active army service, on his own application, General Ludwig Beck, first chief of the new German General Staff, and appointed General Franz Halder as his successor.

City College football players started work yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium for their game next Saturday in Providence. Coach Benny Friedman expressed himself as highly pleased with the manner in which C. C. N. Y. ended Lowell Textile's string of victories, but warned the Beavers to expect a hard struggle against the Providence College team.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today Henry C. Little of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4144-U. S v. Pennsylvania Salt Mfg. Co.

The midseason furniture, floor coverings and house furnishings exhibits opening today at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart drew a combined buyer registration that was slightly in excess of a year ago. Buying was spotty.

Emphasizing the growing shortage of men's wear wool goods, advances of 5 cents a yard were made last night on all standard worsted fabrics by American Woolen Company, which also advanced its tropical worsteds 2 1/2 cents.

Dr. and Mrs. Rene H. Huvelle of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street will give a tea dance on Dec. 26 in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Marguerite Amelia Huvelle.

Public utility financing featured the market for new securities in October and contributed greatly in raising the total of all bonds marketed to the highest total for an October since 1927, and the largest for any month since January, 1937.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Mayor John B. Thacher of Albany, in behalf of the Albany County Democratic Committee, WABC, 6:45 to 7 P. M. James A. Farley, at Hackensack, N. J., WOR, 8:30 to 9 P. M.

Edgar Belmont, duplex in 231 E 48th St; Dr. W. S. MacComb, in 130 E 75th St; H. Buxton Price, in 505 E 55th St; Harry Gilbert, Nicholas A. Stavroudis, in 136 E 36th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
The Rangers defeated the Americans, 4 to 3, in overtime tonight before 4,000 fans to sweep the six-game Western Canada exhibition series between New York's two National Hockey League teams.

In a proposed fourth report on the Interstate Commerce Commission's investigation of warehouse practices of railroads in the Port of New York District, Homer C. King, special examiner, today asked the I. C. C. to find that the agreements and arrangements between the Seaboard Terminal and Refrigeration

The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors, by a vote of 7 to 3, rejected today the modified plan recommend by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, for the restoration and protection of the ocean beach in Suffolk County, known as Fire Island Beach, which was so seriously damaged by the hurricane on Sept. 21.

The public will be doing itself a great disservice if it allows the fraud division of the Better Business Bureau to close or be curtailed in any way for lack of funds. The investing public especially will pay many times over for what it withholds now.

Winter flying schedules, with the minimum westward transcontinental journey 48 minutes longer and the eastward trip lengthened 32 minutes, will be effective today for Transcontinental and Western Air transports.

The program for the formal dedication of the new Rutgers stadium on Saturday was made publie today by President Robert C. Clothier as the Scarlet eleven began a week of intensive practice for its biggest test of the season, against Princeton.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Stainken of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine H. Stainken, to the Rev. Henry E. Horn, son of Mrs. William M. Horn of Ithaca, N. Y., and the late Rev. Dr. Horn.

A suggestion that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh ought to go home because of his activities in Europe was made today by Everybody's Magazine, a non-political British "pulp" publication with an audited circulation of 600,000 and an actual circulation closer to a million.

Projects for which the specifications were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings included two six-story apartments on the land recently purchased from the Rockefeller interests, near Fort Tryon Park, Washington Heights, and buildings of six stories in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and in Elmhurst, Queens.
Captain Al Caruso of the Manhattan College football forces has won back his job as No. 1 quarterback, after having failed to make the starting line-up in his team's last three games.

Declines in independent store sales ranging from-7 to 24 per cent in September were shown in the tabulation compiled yesterday of the reports on a State-wide basis issued by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce. Data on twenty-three States are covered in the figures.
The Department of Commerce made known today that a decline in Argentina's exports in the first nine months of this year can be ascribed to decreases in shipments of corn wheat and linseed.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $36,540,210 after operating expenses, taxes and charges.
From chapel to bedside, Knights Templar funeral services for: Frank M. Wheelan, 86-year-old retired building contractor, were broadcast by telephone today to his widow. Mrs.

Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, rode today through the heart of New York State, where he was greeted by rousing crowds at nineteen railroad stops, to deliver in this city a radio speech on political corruption in Brooklyn.

Word has been received here that William Miller Beldon, secretary of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey nearly twenty years, died last night at the home of his son, William R. Beldon, in Clarkdale, Ga. Mr. Beldon, who was 74 years old, had lived at the Marcus L. Ward homestead here since the death of his wife two years ago.

Miss Kathleen Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lord Powers of Red Bank, N. J., was married to Charles Rieley Neighbour of Indianapolis and Beverly Hills, Calif., yesterday afternoon at the home of her cousin, Countess Vincent Orssich, 515 Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church.

Turpentine firm, 24 1/4c; sales, 72 barrels, receipts, 342 barrels; shipments, 2,990 barrels; stock, 49.275 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 107; receipts, $1,88; shipments, 1,617; stock, 274,925. Quote: B, $3.95; D, $4; E, $4.25; F, $5.10; G, H, I, K, M, $5.20; N, $5.65; WG, $6; WW, X, $6.45.
Mrs. Anna Pingree Wheatland Phillips, member of a distinguished Salem family, died here today at the age of 69, after a long illness.

A signed statement in which Otto Hermann Voss, a former employe of the Seversky Airplane Company of Farmingdale, L. I., admitted that he served as a spy untet the orders of Captain-Lieutenant Erich Pfeiffer, head of the German Secret Service, was introduced in evidence yesterday and read to the jury at the espionage trial in Federal Court before Judge John C. Knox.
Lieut. Col. Herbert Franklin French, retired army officer and former postoffice official at Boston, died at a hospital here today at the age of 72.

The Transit Commission approved yesterday an application by the Depreciation Fund Board to permit the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to spend $905,000 of depreciation fund moneys for fifty additional express cars for the Corona line.

Despite a dramatic plea by Common Pleas Judge Null M. Hodapp and a threat of contempt citations, the Dayton Board of Education refused tonight to rescind its order closing the city schools because of a financial crisis.

Franklin C. Spies, treasurer for the last ten years of the Hudson-Harlem Valley Title and Mortgage Company of White Plains and Mount Kisco, died here last night in the Northern Westchester Hospital after a week's illness. He was 42 years old and lived in this village.

Morris S. Tremaine, Democratic State Controller, campaigning for re-election for a seventh two-year term, asserted tonight that he had saved New York taxpayers $40,000,000 in debt-interest charges in twelve years.

What happened on Sept. 28, the critical day of the recent Sudeten crisis, has been the center of much speculation in Europe and this country. Germany was ready to march into Czechoslovakia but, instead, Chancellor Hitler summoned the conference at Munich that averted such action.

A man and a woman, the latter described as "about 18 years old and cute,' robbed the Northwest Security National Bank of between $10,000 and $15,000 today. For two hours, at pistol point, they compelled bank employes to transact business while they waited for the time vault to open and scores of persons passed in and out of the bank.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 3, net profit of $3,066,672 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal and State income taxes and $3,610 surtax on undistributed earnings.

A train with 308 convalescent casualties from the International Brigades in the Spanish Loyalist army was held up tonight at the frontier. The French Government ordered that only sixty-two French veterans were to be admitted.

J. Willets Berry, a contractor here for twenty-fiv years, who also conducted a lumber and a real estate and insurance business, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Jefferson Hospital, Philadelphia. His age was 64.

Negotiations in the last year for a merger of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation with the Western Union Telegraph Company or with the Radio Corporation of America consumed little time, Raymond C. Kramer, reorganization trustee of Postal, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

The value of humor as a factor in teaching children will be emphasized at the annual reading conference of the New York University School of Education and the Association for Arts in Childhood, meeting at 9:30 A. M. Saturday in the auditorium of the Harriet Johnson Nursery School, 69 Bank Street.

The property comprised of the vacant plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street and the two five-story tenements with stores known as 5-7 East Eighty-eighth Street was sold at' auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Bank of New York, plaintiff, bought it in for $1,500,000.

New York University's football team learned on starting practice yesterday for the Lehigh game at Ohio Field on Saturday that it may have lost the services of Bill Helmcke, guard, and Morris Vogel for the rest of the season. Both suffered knee injuries in the defeat by Ohio State last Saturday.

William Brevoort Potts Jr., 36 year-old broker of Red Bank, N. J., who has been on bail since June 20 on charges of leaving. the scene of an accident and assault, was discharged: on both counts yesterday by Magistrate Alexander Brough in Homicide Court.

Plans have been completed by Miss Gail Francisco, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Wellington P. Francisco of Orange, for her marriage to Alan Condit Hood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred R. Hood of East Orange.

Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace replied last night to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's speech dealing with agriculture. In a statement issued through the Democratic State Committee the Cabinet official charged that the Republican nominee for Governor had presented a distorted picture by omitting "inconvenient facts."

Maxie Berger, Canadian lightweight, and Charley Gomer of Baltimore will clash in the star bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight. In the semi-final, also listed for eight rounds, Bobby Wilson will oppose Siggi Lander.

The latest development in the Chicago gasoline price war has been the return of posted prices to the station placards. When Summer motoring was at its height a gasoline jobber group announced that cooperating retailers would remove their price placards as a step to a series of posters announcing anywhere from 3 to 5 cents "off from regular."

Cauldwell Ave (10-2629), e- s, 207 ft n of 156th St, 39x100: Sam Garber to Beckle Krieger, 762 Cauldwell Ave. Bussing Ave. 1,809 (17-5012); Helen F. Golz to Harrison G. Otis, trustee, 131 Woodward Ave. Rutherford, N. J. Creston Ave, 2,315 (11-3172); Susan F. Bannon to Jaysum Building Corp, 565 5th Ave.
Louis Hayward will play the lead In Edward Small's remake of "The Man in the Iron Mask" for United Artists.

Injury and illness of two Yale play ers as well as Brown's strength ?? the gridiron this year prompt?? Yale today to interrupt concentra?? ed practice for the big games ?? the season with Princeton a?? Harvard and prepare carefully ?? Brown's invasion Saturday.

A recommendation that the Interstate Commerce. Commission approve an application by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company to acquire control of the Santa Fe Trail Transportation Company by purchase of a majority of its capital stock from the General Improvement Company was made today by J. Edward Davey, chief of the finance section of the I. C. C.'s Bureau of Motor Carriers.

Charged with forcibly resisting Federal officers in the performance of their duty, Mrs. Anna Laura Barnett, widow of Jackson Barnett, Indian oil millionaire, and her daughter, Maxine Sturgis, were arraigned late today before United States Commissioner David B. Head.
Employment in the steel industry advanced in September, with 431,000 on the payrolls compared with the 427,000 average in August, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Interdepartmental Committee in charge of President Roosevelt's $850,000,000 New Deal in public health met today for eight hours with a committee representing the 110,000 private practitioners of the American Medical Association whose ruling body voted last July to keep the government from interfering with their patients.

The season list of United States players left in Harri the Mexican national amateur golf championship was cut in half today. Four reached the quarterfinals at the Mexico City Country Club and four more were eliminated, two at the hands of their countrymen.
Twenty-two games have been scheduled for the New York University basketball team this season, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. A feature of the N. Y. U.

The government is preparing measures to check the activities of so-called professional bridegrooms-men who contract a legal marriage with a foreign woman for pay giving her Netherland citizenship, which is retained after the divorce.

The Chicago dress industry is split again over the duration of the January market shows held in conjunction with the Interstate Merchants Council meetings and promotions, one group favoring holding down to a week and the other, including a number of New York and other out-of-town houses, urging a twoweek show.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council, predicted yesterday afternoon that Russia some day would offer "the greatest missionary opportunity in the world" and declared "we ought to be prepared."

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York filed a libel proceeding yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to foreclose its preferred mortgage of $4,698,451, including interest and costs, against the Munson Steamship liners Pan America, Western World and Southern Cross.

Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen and John B. Trevor Jr., whose engagement was announced in August, have completed plans for their marriage. The wedding will take place on Nov. 18 in St. James Church. The prospective bride, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Jay Bruen, has chosen her sister, Miss Constance L. J. F. Bruen, for her maid of honor.

Describing himself as "a goodgovernment man," rather than a "good party man," Mayor La Guardia appealed for the re-election of Senator Robert F. Wagner last night in a radio speech over WOR from 11:15 to 11:30 o'clock.

A resolution refusing to permit Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, to appear as soloist with the Los Angeles Symphony' Orchestra on Thursday and Friday because of his refusal to join the American Guild of Musical Artists was adopted yesterday afternoon by the guild's board of governors.

Commodity prices rallied a little in mixed trading last week, and The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices advanced to 79.7 on Oct. 29, from 79.2 the week previous, when the index had touched the lowest levels since Dec: 24, 1934.

The police were triumphantly vindicated today when an eight-foot rock python, which most of the frequenters of Hyde Park and Kensington Gardens had been frantically searching for the last three days, was discovered quietly curled up in an armchair in the Chelsea flat of its owner, who is Arthur Conan Doyle, son of the late author and spiritualist.

Radio ought to act promptly to prevent a repetition of the wave of panic in which it inundated the nation Sunday night by its "realistic" attempt to transfer to the air H. G. Wells's horror story of a mythical invasion by creatures from Mars.

After weakness in railroad shares at the outset and generally lower initial prices for leading industrial issues, the stock market recovered gradually yesterday. The closing was Irregular, with the rails finishing well up from the low levels of the day and the industrials showing a small average net gain.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain put new blood into his Cabinet tonight by appointing Sir John Anderson, for many years one of the most capable civil servants, as Lord Privy Seal with the supremely difficult job of trying to organize civilian defenses in Britain.

Thomas J. Watson of New York, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, arrived here today by steamer and was met by delegations of Portuguese commercial associations and representatives of the principal local banks.

An urgent appeal for $1,000,000 to meet the emergency resulting from the mass deportation of Poles from Germany was made yesterday by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.
Twenty teams turned out in a chill Autumn wind for the final Wstchester pro-amateur one-day tourney of the season at the Dunwoodie Golf Club today, with two duos carding 66s.

Bob Pastor of Washington Heights, New York State heavyweight champion, made his first ring appearance in almost three months last night when he knocked out George (Big Boy) Brackey of Philadelphia in the fourth round of the main bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at the St. Nicholas Palace.
The death of B. Charney Vladeck, member of the City Council, which occurred at 8:15 P. M., Oct. 30, Is announced to the Department.

Democratic leaders of ten upState counties, on a visit to Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, disputed yesterday the results of polls indicating that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey would fare better up-State than Republican candidate for Governor in recent years.

William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey seeking election as a New Deal supporter, declared at a campaign rally last night at Burlington, N. J., that if elected he would press for "adjustment" of Federal farm programs to give consideration to the "peculiar" problems of New Jersey farmers.

The former Case property, about two miles from the heart of Stamford, Conn., and once known as one of the best peach farms in that section of the State, has been sold by the First Stamford National Bank and Trust Company, as executor under the will of Frances Waring Case, to Case Acres, Inc. The property had been held by the Case family for about fortysix years.
William Gladstone Menzies, a leading authority on antiques and all branches of the fine arts, died today at the age of 58. Mr. Menzies was the art sales correspondent of The Times of London.

A blind Negro peddler and an 81-year-old woman were killed yesterday when a truck that was ascending "Duffy's Hill" on. Lexington Avenue got' out of control and rolled backward from 102d to 103d Street, crushing the two, destroying a newsstand and smashing a subway entrance.

Adoption of an amendment to the general policy-of the National Retail Dry Goods Association on returns of merchandise from store to producer to meet the specific problems of the popular-price dress industry was announced yesterday.

In a radio broadcast to the voters of California, Postmaster General James A. Farley, speaking as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, appealed last night for the election of Culbert Olson, Democratic nominee for Governor, and Sheridan Downey, the $30-a-week pension advocate and Democratic candidate for United States Senator there.

Today was wash day-even in the dignified Eighth District United States Circuit Court of Appeals. A dozen washing machines, exhibits in a patent case, swished merrily while attorneys for the General Electric Supply Company of Kansas City and the Maytag Company of Newton, Iowa, argued over the "gyrator" principle of clothes washing.

Mrs. Walter H. Liebman, wife of the Democratic candidate in the Seventeenth Congressional District race, demonstrated yesterday that she had the highest aspirations of any candidate's wife when she took to the air-as a skywriter-in behalf of her husband's campaign.

Executives of wholesale grocery and chain grocery organizations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be guests of the Association of Manufacturers Representatives at a dinner tomorrow in the Hotel Astor. H. B. LeQuattee of the H. B. LeQuattee Advertising Agency will speak on "Could Advertising Dollars Be Better Invested Elsewhere?"

Eight seniors in Columbia College who lead their class in scholarship have been elected to Phi Beta Kappa, it was announced yesterday by Dwight C. Miner of the History Department, secretary of the Columbia chapter.

Ernie Lombardi, ponderous backstop of the Cincinnati Reds, was voted the most valuable player in the National League for 1938, it was announced yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America, whose committee conducted the annual poll.

As far as Father Flanagan is concerned, the motion picture "Boys Town" didn't turn out quite the way it was expected to. Like everybody else, Father Flanagan thought the picture would be a bonanza for his home. It hasn't been.
" Colonel" Martin (Moe) Snyder, who is in jail on charges of attempting to kill Myrl Alderman by shooting in the presence of Ruth Getting, radio singer, today was sued by Alderman for $255,000.

Charles Eldridge Spencer, retired woolen textile manufacturer with mills in Naugatuck, Conn., and New, Brunswick, N. J., died at his home here today at the age of 82. Mr. Spencer had lived here for the last nineteen years, following his retirement, and was a Summer resident of Sea Girt for sixty years.
The Panthers of Pittsburgh again top The Associated Press poll of sports writers. Of the 115 who participated in the third poll, 105 picked the Panther eleven as the best football team in the land.

The Treasury's weekly offering of approximately $100,000,000 of ninetyone-day bills went at an average interest rate of 0.027 per cent today, compared with 0.026 for similar paper last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. As in the last few weeks, there was at least one bid of 100.

John Forsythe Meigs Jr., 21 years old, of Havre De Grace, Md., a Harvard College senior, died at the Nashua Memorial Hospital tonight of injuries suffered in a 50-foot fall down a cliff of Joe English Mountain on Sunday afternoon.

Alfred M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, said tonight that the country must decide in its next two elections "whether we are going to be a democracy or a Fascist State." "We cannot vest too much power in a few individuals as we have now and remain a representative democracy,"

Steers and yearlings sold at steady to 25 cent lower prices in a slow cattle trade today and other killing classes were generally steady, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Light hogs were steady to 5 cents lower and heavier weights cleared mostly 5 to 10 cents, instances 15 cents lower, while fat lambs demand ruled active at strong to 15 cents higher values

President Roosevelt's assistance in finding funds with which to administer the Wages and Hours Law was sought by a group of officials headed by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division, who conferred with him at the White House today.

The Yale varsity opposed the jayvee eleven in a two-hour scrimmage today in which the absence of seven regulars, Al Wilson, Bud Humphrey, Johnny Miller, Captain Bill Platt, Charley Miller, Buck Dyess and Bill Moody, indicated that they were somewhat worn by the terrific schedule. Except perhaps Wilson, all will be ready for the Brown contest in the Bowl on Saturday.

KINGS BRAHE, CLARA L. (March 5, 1938). Gross assets, $47,563; net, $45,015. To nephews, Donald Schaefer and Ralph Buehler and nieces, Evelyn Schaefei and Harriet Woodward, two specific bonds each; nephew. Herbert B. Buehler, life income from two specific bonds; sisters, Bertha Buehler,

After Clement R. Attlee, Labor leader, had expressed gloom in Parliament today over British trade prospects in China, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain indicated he thought the situation would not be so bad.

The stock market here became unsettled today under quiet conditions almost approaching stagnation, but sporadic rallies helped to cover the general weakness. Gilt-edge issues showed small losses and Far Eastern loans continued weaker among the foreign bonds.

The New Jersey hunters, when they take to the field a week from tomorrow, may look forward to one of the finest seasons in years, according to the surveys conducted by wardens and game protectors throughout the State.

" Chiseling" by relief recipients has been greatly exaggerated, John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for the long Senate term, said yesterday in a statement made public at his local campaign headquarters. Men and women want jobs, not relief, he contended.

Further extension of the program for improving the city's shoreline with parks and highways may threaten the industrial and commercial life of the city, according to a letter sent to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Captain James G. Conway, president of the New York Tow Boat Exchange, Inc.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as first assistant in the subjects Indicated in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, as of Oct. 29, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:

Operations of the United Aircraft Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a net profit of $3,564,405 after deductions for expenses, depreciation, Federal and Canadian income taxes and minority proportion of profits of a subsidiary company, according to a report issued yesterday.

The "unwritten code of silence" respecting misdeeds or misconduct of a member, which, it contended, had dominated the affairs of the New York Stock Exchange until the new management came into power, ...
Wary of the Virginia football team scheduled to line up at Baker Field Saturday against the Lions, Coach Lou Little sent his squad through a long, hard offensive drill yesterday.
Each of the following Medical Corps Reserve officers, is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Nov. 1, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y.

The Bituminous Coal Commission asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to investigate the financial structure of the nation's railroads. The request was made in opposition to the carriers' plea for continuance of temporary increases in freight rates on soft coal.

Catalogue, an 8-year-old gelding, starting as the rank outsider at 25 to 1, surprised a crowd of 95,000 at the Flemington course today by winning the Melbourne Cup, Australia's two-mile thoroughbred racing classic.
Injunction proceedings against the Dayton Board of Education were dissolved by Common Pleas Judge Null M. Kodapp late today, clearing the way for reopening of the city's schools.

Albert N. Chaperau, who obtained the freedom of the port last month by representing himself to be an attache of the Nicaraguan Consul General, and who subsequently was arrested for smuggling Parisian finery into the United States, has acted for at least ten prominent New Yorkers in bringing goods bought abroad to this country, the United States Attorney's office has been informed.

Tentative plans for two new housing projects, a Federal development to cost $12,000,000 and a city project to cost about $7,500,000, to be built on adjoining sites in the "heart of the slum district" on the lower East Side of Manhattan, were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Acquisition by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation of 42,500 shares of common stock of its subsidiary, the Dayton Power and Light Company, for $2,550,000 has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

A mass meeting of 2,500 union hotel workers last night authorized the New York Hotel Trades Council to discontinue negotiations with the Hotel Association of New York, unless an agreement is reached by Nov. 15. The meeting was held at the Palm Gardens, 320 West FiftySecond Street.

On the first anniversary yesterday of the start of the United States Housing Authority, Nathan Straus, its Administrator,, declared in an address over radio station WABC that "most of the doubters of yesterday are silenced by a year of achievement."

Running for the first time in the silks of Mrs. Ed McCuan, Hasty Star today raced to a half-length victory in the Narragansett feature. Closest to that filly at the finish of the six-furlong sprint for 2-yearolds was the favorite, Benjamin F. Lister's Grisette, with two and a half lengths on Mrs. J. Walker's Major B.

At least one member of the diplomatic colony in Washington has been cheering a harassed and melancholy Foreign Office abroad with running accounts of the developing story that might be called: "II Duce Didn't Do It.

Each of the three defendants on trial before Judge John C. Knox in Federal court for conspiracy to violate the espionage laws of the United States confessed complicity in the plot voluntarily, without threats or promises,

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Pelley sent out invitations today for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Pelley, to Willem Dirkse-van Schallwyk, attach of the South African Government, formerly in Washington and now in Montreal.

The Federal Communications Commission today granted a temporary renewal license of ninety days to Radio Station WHOM in Jersey City, N. J., instead of the customary six months' license, pending investigation of a program which was "alleged to be against the public interest."
