Dr. Paul D. White, lecturer in medIcine at Harvard, told the Interstate Post-Graduate Medical Association today that "freedom from fear" was the greatest necessity of a majority of sufferers from cardiac ailments.

An injury sustained in the very last gesture of training yesterday forced Henry Armstrong to postpone tonight's fight with Ceferino Garcia. Armstrong was to have defended his welterweight title at Madison Square Garden.

Mrs. Arthur Lehman appealed yesterday for 1,000 foster homes for wards of the Joint Home Finding Committee for Jewish Foster Children, announcing at an institute held in The New York Herald Tribune auditorium that a campaign was planned which would concentrate attention on the better residential areas of all five boroughs.
An intensive workout on pass defense occupied the attention of the New York University football squad as Coach Mal Stevens had his charges out for three hours yesterday at Ohio Field.

President Roosevelt indicated his satisfaction today with reports reaching the White House as to the progress of the political campaign in New York, but beyond the remark that the reports were all right he would not comment.

The Interstate Commerce Commission instituted today a proceeding to extend its regulations for safety and maximum hours of service for common and contract carriers by motor vehicles to private carriers of property by motor vehicle, "if need therefore is found," thus entering what officials concede to be probably the most difficult field reached thus far by the Motor Carrier Act of 1935.
George C. Guggenheim, secretarytreasurer of the Stein-Bloch Company, clothing manufacturers for more than fifty years, died today at his home here at the age of 76. He was ill two days.

Reports by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration showed today that 4,896,352 short tons, raw value, of sugar were delivered to United States markets in the first nine months of this year. Deliveries in the same period last year were 5,336,849 tons.
Justice Minister Paul Reynaud, lawyer, business man and financial expert, became Finance Minister today in a slight Cabinet revision at this critical juncture in French history.

George S. Hobart, Newark lawyer and former Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, died today at his home here at the age of 63, after being ill a few days. He was a member of the firm of Hobart, Minard Cooper.

While hundreds of homewardbound workers waited for trains at 5 P.M. yesterday two thieves shot James MacIntosh, 32-year-old salesman, of 58-77 Fifty-eighth Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, in a hold-up in a washroom of the Grand Street subway station of the B. M. T. In Brooklyn.

With payment of the last note today, the Oliver Farm Equipment Company announced retirement of an indebtedness which at the end of 1930 aggregated nearly $17,000,000 owed to banks in Chicago, New York and St. Louis.

Reduction of the postage rate on books to 1 1/2 cents per pound for domestic mail will "revolutionize" the book industry, Morris L. Ernst, counsel for the committee which urged the reduction, said yesterday.

The mother of Queen Geraldine of Albania received word here today that the Queen and King Zog were expecting a child some time next March. "Needless to say," the Queen's mother said, "the news makes me very happy, and the King has written asking me to come to Tirana early in February.

Sentiment in the share market remained cautious yesterday and the i stock index on the chart continued the now familiar sidewisee" movement. Stocks pointed higher in the early trading but most groups failed to retain the early advantage.

C. M. Chester, chairman of the appeal in behalf of ninety-two voluntary hospitals, members of the United Hospital Fund and of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, announced yesterday that contributions totaling $276,794 had been received to date.

Rear Admiral Yancey S. Williams, veteran naval officer and former commander of the special service squadron in Central American waters, died today at the Naval Hospital from a heart ailment. His age was 62.

Seabiscuit defeated War Admiral today. Amid scenes of frantic enthusiasm, created by a record crowd of 40,000 persons, that simple fact stood high and alone and it will leave its impression on the American turf. Historic Pimlico never had seen anything like it.

Wheat developed a weak undertone today in North American markets. Paced by Winnipeg, prices on the Board of Trade here declined 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel and closed at the bottom, the lowest level since Oct. 5. Heavy selling, which brokers attributed to a professional trader in New York, had considerable influence on the market.

COLLECTED POEMS, 1918-1938, by Genevieve Taggard. (Harper, $2.50.) CRISIS AND DECISION, by Solomon Goldman. (Harper, $2.) A guide to Jewish problems by the president of the Zionist Organization of America.

Four firemen, members of Engine Company 290, 480 Sheffield Avenue, Brooklyn, were assigned yesterday to help the police trace the murderers of Fireman Thomas J. Hitter, who was shot on Monday as he sat in his car about to deliver a payroll of $3,400 to the firehouse.

Charges that utility companies discriminate against Negroes in hiring employes were brought out yesterday at the first public hearing by the New York State Temporary Commission on the Condition of the Urban Colored Population in the old Appellate Division Court room in Brooklyn Borough Hall. State Senator Jacob J. Schwartzwald presided.

Dr. Albert W. Twiggar, president of the New York State Dental Society in 1914 and former public official here, died of pneumonia on Sunday at his home. He was 68 years old and had been an invalid for eighteen months. He practiced here for many years.

Miss Dorrit Merrill, Viennese actress, was chosen "National Fur Bride" at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday to herald the sixth annual National Fur Week to be held from Nov. 14 to 19, inclusive.

The advertising loss in October of the eight New York newspapers was 11.4 per cent, practically the same as that for September, when the drop was 11.5 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Linage last month amounted to 10,263,788 as against 11,581,986 for the like period of 1937.

Cheered by enthusiastic crowds, Governor Lehman carried his campaign for re-election into Staten Island and Brooklyn last night with attacks on the "reactionary" policies of the Republicans on labor legislation and public utility regulation.

A countrywide Arab general strike began today in protest against the government's order that every motor vehicle must have a government permit beginning today and that each male traveling by motor or rail outside municipal areas must have a permit with a photograph attached.

Among other things, Munich gave Germany Mitteleuropa, which has so long been the German dream. The first moral exultation over that has now yielded to a determination not to lose a moment in capitalizing its material advantages.

General satisfaction with last year's rules was expressed at the basketball rules interpretation meeting held last night at the Hotel McAlpin. The only radical change in this Year's court regulations concerns the three-seeond rule.
Several purchases of apartment houses in the Bronx for investment purposes were included in the deals reported from that borough yesterday.

Barcelona today caught air raids coming and going. At 10:10 this morning another British ship, the Gothic, was damaged in an attack that apparently cost the Rebels one bomber, for a government pursuit plane dived right into the attacking air squadron and in the ensuing combat was shot down, but not until it. had torn off part of a wing of one bomber and damaged two others.

The Maritime Commission opened bids today for the construction of three more ships for the merchant marine, bringing the total for 1938 to fifty-two ships, or two in excess of the fifty ships a year which is the construction program of the commission. The new vessels, which will be combination passenger and freight ships, will operate between New Orleans and the East Coast to South America.

Thomas Hitchcock's Annibal probably the best steeplechaser in the country and the winner of numerous stakes at Belmont Park and Saratoga, will have top weight in the Temple Gwathmey Memoria Steeplechase which will feature the meeting of the United Hunts Rac ing Association at Belmont Park next Tuesday.
A large apartment in 320 Park Avenue has been rented by F. Warren Pershing, stock broker and son of General John J. Pershing, through Douglas Gibbons Co. and Douglas L. Elliman Co.

Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced last night that the collections of second-half 1938 real estate taxes up to the close of business were $12,879,051 in excess of the collections for the second half last year.

Harry Benjamin Jepson, Professor of Applied Music at Yale since 1907, university organist and director of the Yale College chapel choir for thirty-two years, will retire in June. He will be succeeded as university organist by Luther M. Noss, who is now at Cornell.

The report of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc, and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $2,046,470 after all expenses and charges.

The Spanish Government accused Italy anew today of lending strong military support to Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco Franco. Pablo de Azcarate y Florez, Spanish Ambassador to London, sent to the British Foreign Office today "certain information"

The Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., directed yesterday distribution to stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company of the warrant held by MissouriKansas (Mokan) to purchase 80,000 shares of the common stock of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company at $25 a share, it was announced here by the management of Mokan.
Engagements of $3,633,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the amount, $1,533,000 is to come from India and $2,100,000 from England.

C. E. Groesbeck, chairman of the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company, said today after a conference with President Roosevelt that the "rapprochement between the utility industry and government" had passed the theoretical stage and presaged an era of cooperation and understanding which should make for solution of the industry's problems.

Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross, candidate of the American Labor and Progressive parties for the Supreme Court in the first district, declared yesterday that "the liberal forces in this city are at present opposing the passage of an illiberal judiciary amendment." She spoke at the Round Table luncheon in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
Coach Lou Oshins decided yesterday afternoon that a rest would be better for his battered Brooklyn College football team than the signal drill originally scheduled.

While Harvard's regulars worked only on signals and on defense against Chicago's running and passing plays today, the substitutes had a vigorous half hour's scrimmage against the freshmen. At first the youngsters were "jittery," but after Mike Cohen and James had made. long runs through their line and around the ends the cubs settled down and made quite a battle of it.

J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced at the Federal Building here last night the seizure of four men in the solving of three kidnappings, one of which resulted in murder, and three robberies, all occurring within the last year.
The Navy team, with two of its firststring backs, Monty Whitehead and Ed Gillette, resting, today rehearsed the plays which will be used against Notre Dame on Saturday at Baltimore.

Joseph Kerr Cass, chairman of the board of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company since 1909, died here today at his home on Riverview Road after a year's illness. He celebrated his ninetieth birthday on Oct. 10.

Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, denied yesterday that he had said that it would "degrade" him to join the American Guild of Musical Artists. The denial was made in response to the resolution adopted on Monday by the guild, refusing permission to Mr. Menuhin to appear with the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra because he was not a guild member.
Following is the second part of the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the investigation of the affairs of Richard Whitney and his partners in the firm of Richard Whitney Co.:
Dr. David Bruce Stewart Bruce-Jones, a skin specialist known on both sides of the Atlantic, died in his sleep in his London home today. Aside from his work in his special field.

An apartment of twelve rooms and four baths has been leased by Dwight Rockwell in the building at 860 Park Avenue, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., who also report the following rentals: Mrs. Holland McKittrick, in 277 Park Avenue; Winthrop P. Haynes, in 170 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Spanish refugee labor will no longer be permitted to work aboard the local fishing fleet, Louis de Chappedelaine, Minister of. Merchant Marine, today told delegates from the Fishermen's Union who protested against the employment of these "cut-rate Spaniards who crowd out natives."
Mr. and Mrs. S. Sloan Colt of Tuxedo Park will be at Hampshire House for the season. Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt have left the Waldorf-Astoria for Sagamore Farm, their place at Glyndon, Md.

The complete list of the extraordinary, grand jury panel follows: David A. Burke, 65 Henry Street, retired. Charles Carlington, 1,910 Kings Highway, manager. Charles Heinrich, 335 Rutland Road, silks.

Ratification of a "basis of settlement" by both employers and unions early today ended San Francisco's fifty-six-day strike against thirtyfive leading retail stores. Striking A. F. of L. union clerks ratified the agreement as the climax of a mass meeting, 1,069 to 1,014.
Trainer Thomas Malone filed suit for $100,000 against the Maryland Jockey Club today for alleged ejection from Pimlico.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/4c; sales, 118 barrels; receipts, 260 barrels; no shipments; stock, 49,535 barrels. Rosin, firm: sales, 194; receipts, 2,114; shipments, 426; stock, 276,613. Quote: B. $3.95; D, $4; E, $4.25; F. $4.8590; G, H, I, K, $5.10; M, $5.15; N, $5.45-50; WG, $6; WW, X, $6.45.

The New York University varsity cross-country team made a perfect score in defeating C. C. N. Y. over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, 15 to 40. Curtis Giddings led four of his teammates across the finish line to give N. Y. U. the first five places, while the Beaver harriers were able to first ten.

Both the Republican and Democratic parties are offering this year platforms in which they take credit for passing laws that originally were proposed by the Socialists and rejected, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, said here tonight.

Daily average crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,237,550 barrels, compared with 3,247,400 in the previous week, a decline of 9,850, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 129,250 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,366,800 daily by the Bureau of Mines for October.

A flip of a coin cost Kenneth Dickinson, 26, his life today. A heavy fog made traffic dangerous on the Schenectady-Albany Road, and Dickinson. who lived in Hornell, N. Y., and Gerald Lee of Canisteo, N. Y., halted their truck in a vacant lot.
Belgium will soon go "wet," for the double purpose of running 200,000 bootleggers out of business and diverting some of their illicit revenue into tax receipt channels.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 1, unless specified: At San Pedro: Arizona, Nevada, Oklahoma. At Manila: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41.

After introducing a resolution in the Board of Estimate yesterday aimed at cutting the pay of 145 members of the bench to $7,500 a year, Mayor La Guardia engaged in a violent row with John J. Halleran, Queens Public Works Commissioner, that reached its climax when the Mayor accused Mr. Halleran of "sticking" the people of Queens whom he represents on the board.

Tom Erickson of Yale carried the ball from deep in his own territory, eluding the Brown halfbacks, and drove it past Goalie Du Comb in the last two minutes of the game to 1 give the Elis a 1-0 soccer victory over the Bruins today.

Plans are under way for a luncheon to be held Nov. 18 in the garden of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Yorkville Unit of the Speedwell Society. A feature of the entertainment will be a fashion showing of the latest costumes.

The five-story apartment house at 220-224 Forty-eighth Street, Union City, N. J., has been purchased by the Vigor Realty Corporation as an investment. The property is valued at $100,000, accommodates forty-seven families, and is said to produce an annual rental of $18,000 J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Francis Greulich, 35 years old, and his wife, Anna R., 27, of 184 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to stealing from the Stanley Gibbs Corporation at 38 Park Row more than $100,000 worth of rare stamps while they were employed there.

APPELL--On Monday, Oct. 31, 1938, of 153-32 41st Ave., Flushing, Augustus Appell, beloved husband of the late Emma Roth, loving father of Walter L., Arthur F. and Thelma Appell Noble. Services at the Hallett Homestead, 147th St. and Northern Blvd., Flushing, L. I., on Wednesday evening, Nov. 2, at 8 o'clock. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Thursday, 11:30 A. M.

A virtual agreement on the issues presented by Mexico's expropriation of American-owned agrarian lands was announced by Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, after a twenty-minute conference late this afternoon with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.

Representative John J. O'Connor, who was defeated for renomination in the Sixteenth Congressional District in the Democratic primary and is running on the Republican ticket, told Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer yesterday that he thought there was "no power, not even a court of equity, which can prevent me from calling myself a Democrat, verbally or otherwise."

Three new lines of automobiles, entirely restyled and with a number of chassis and body innovations, were announced yesterday by the Hudson Motor Car Company. Models on display at the local distributors at Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street cover three price divisions.

Further expansion of the use of glass fiber, notably in industrial fields but to some extent also in consumer-goods industries, was predicted yesterday with the announcement that the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and the Corning Glass Works had formed the Owens-Corning Fiberglas -Corporation to produce a variety of products made from fiber glass.
Syracuse began heavy work today for the Colgate game here Saturday with a scrimmage against a freshman eleven which demonstrated the chief formations of the Red Raiders.

Houghton Mifflin announce the next Lloyd C. Douglas novel, "Disputed Passage," for January publication. The motion picture rights have been acquired by Paramount. A second printing has been ordered for "Lost April" (Crowell), a novel of the stage by the actress, Sydney Thompson.

With Howard Bruce and his followers who are backing Attorney General Herbert R. O'Conor, Democratic nominee for Governor, opposed by the New Dealers and Mayor'Jackson of Baltimore, defeated 'Democratic aspirant for the Gubernatorial nomination, the result of the Maryland primary campaign for State offices has been to project into the election the factional bitterness stirred up by President Roosevelt's unsuccessful opposition to the re-nomination of Senator Tvdinges.

Tossed by the angry, lumpy seas where the strong Agulhas current meets the high westerly winds off the Cape of Good Hope, the Wyatt Earp in her first few hours out of Cape Town pitched and rolled with the nastiest corkscrewy motion I have ever experienced.
October brought further evidence of improvement in business and the indications for the near future continue favorable, the National City Bank says in its monthly business letter, issued yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Gossler will give a reception on the afternoon of Nov. 17 at their home, 14 East Sixty-fifth Street, to introduce Mrs. Gossler's daughter, Miss Marion Oates, to older friends of the family.
Leases calling for store space in buildings in scattered parts of the city marked the contracts for commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday.

Harrington Gates, senior quarterback who led the Dartmouth eleven to victory over Yale Saturday, has resigned from college to enter a New Hampshire religious cult called the Legion of God, also known as "The Holy Ghost and Us."

A survey of the cotton-consumption and crop-production possibilities for next year, made by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and published today, showed little prospect for any material change in the great amount of supplies on hand.

The address of Governor Lehman at Curtis High School, New Brighton, follows: The regulation of public utilities and the development of the water, power resources of this State are matters of deep and vital importance.

Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Senator Wagner and many labor leaders will be among the speakers at the funeral service at 10 o'clock this morning for B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party leader and City Councilman, in the auditorium of the Jewish Daily Forward Building, 175 East Broadway.

Following is the text of the speech made here tonight by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor: For several weeks now I have been describing the effects of corrupt political machines upon the operation of our government.

Drastic revision of the New York City evening school system, to include the establishment of an allday school for adults, provide tenure and pension rights for permanent, instead of per diem, teachers, and lower the compulsory retirement age from 70 to 55, was recommended yesterday in the annual report of the Board of Education's evening elementary division.
Maxie Berger, Canadian light-weight champion, outpointed Charley Gomer of Brownsville in an eight-rounder at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Berger weighed 140 pounds and Gomer 135 1/2.

City College will rely on passing in its football battle with Providence College at Providence on Saturday, judging from the drill yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. The Friars boast a stalwart line and Benny Friedman, the Lavender mentor, is figuring on going over rather than through the bulky Rhode Island forward wall.

Shortly before the War Admiral-Seabiscuit race today members of the prosecutor's staff raided an alleged "wire room" here where they charge bets were being taken on the race. Twenty-one men were arrested. Lieutenant Nathan H. Allyn of the prosecutor's staff headed the raiding party.
A three-way tie among Midston House, Jackson Heights and Bayside continued as all defeated their opponents yesterday in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class A tourney.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 22 totaled 276,652,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 27 was greater in four groups and smaller only in construction, as compared with the same week of 1937, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday. Detailed comparisons are given in the following table:

A not-guilty plea to an automobile-theft charge was entered in Felony Court yesterday by Rabbi William Margolis, 29 years old, reported leader of the United Jewish Community in Ottawa, Canada, although a native of Brooklyn. Magistrate Aurelio released him in the $2,500 bail the clergyman had furnished the night before and ordered him to appear for a hearing Nov. 10.

Winning all of his fourteen bouts, young Austin Prokop of the Salle Santelli took first place in the individual prep foils competition on the strips of the New York A. C. last night as the 1938-39 season of the Amateur Fencers League of America began.

The United States liner Manhattan is sailing tonight for the Channel ports. Passengers are Mrs. Bob Gregory, daughter of the Rajah and Ranee of Sarawak; Mrs. Wilson Cross, Orson Nielsen, United States Consul General at Munich, and Mrs. Nielsen; Ralph Busser.
One-third of the Polish Jews deported by Germany-about 4,000-are still in the small frontier town of Zbaszyn. The Polish authorities refuse to permit them to proceed to the interior.
Sir John Daniel, who for several years after coming here from Wales was able to keep his title secret, died today in his home at the age of 68. Surviving are Lady Daniel, a son and a daughter.

To provide a greater supply of cash for yearly requirments of $195,000,000 for replacement and extension of facilities, the directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey declared yesterday an extra dividend of three shares of capital stock for every 200 now outstanding.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook issued yesterday, on complaint of Attorney General Bennett, an order restraining the New York Endowment Company, Inc., of 12 East Thirty-second Street from doing further business in this State.

IT is pitiful, whenone -stops to think about it, how little most of us know of the country we inhabit. Having satq quietly and duly in school, we are all equipped with more or less of a working knowledge of American history and American geography, and a few of the adventuresome among us have actually gone to see people and places hundreds or thousands of miles away.
Mrs. Florence Southerland Foster of New York, for many years a member of the Manchester Summer colony, died today at the Addison Gilbert Hospital here at the age of 63.

Rejection by the voters of the Fourth or housing amendment to the State Constitution was urged yesterday by the Bronx Board of Trade through its president, Roderick Stephens. Approval of the eight other amendments was recommended.
Following a week's steady advance, the cotton market ran yesterday into more selling by growers and the near months eased 2 points, in contrast with a gain of 2 points by the October.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday several appointments to follow the retirement of J. M. Scott as general superintendent of the Pennsylvania district of the company. The appointments follow:

The Clement Cleveland Medal for outstanding work in the campaign to control cancer" was presented last night to the National Association of Science Writers at the twelfth annual dinner meeting of the New York City Cancer Committee.

Frederick K. Saunders, one of the last two G. A. R. veterans in this section, died at his home here last night at the age of 96. The last survivor here of the Civil War is Thomas Barker of Bellmore, 92 years old.

The action yesterday of the alrectors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in declaring an extra dividend in the form of stock rather than in cash probably will be followed by other companies in need of cash for expansion.

White the Federal Communications Commission today postponed formal study of the broadcast of "The War of Worlds," which sent thousands of persons throughout the country into panic on Sunday evening, there were fairly definite indications that no action would be taken beyond a possible statement of regret that the program was staged in too realistic a manner.

The daily work of the Institute of Family Service of the Charity Organization Society is becoming increasingly that of family and individual counseling, according to a report issued yesterday by Anna Kempshall, director of the institute.

The greatest error in western intellectual culture is the separation of reason and emotion, Professor Harry D. Gideonse declared in an address on "Academic Freedom and Privilege" to more than 400 undergraduates at a Barnard College assembly yesterday.

A middle road between the "New Era" of the early Nineteen Twenties and the present New Deal was pictured by Representative Bruce Barton yesterday as the course the nation should follow toward a better social order.

" The world is at a crossroads. But its power of choice is not lost." This is the keynote of the address made last night by the Secretary of State at the Twenty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention.

Although temporarily in recess, the special House committee investigating un-American activities expects to resume hearings probably on Thursday and to continue until and after the election Tuesday, Chairman Dies said today.

Member banks of this Federal Reserve district were notified yesterday by Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, that Otis A. Thompson of Norwich, N. Y., and Walter C. Teagle of this city had been nominated to succeed themselves as Class A and Class B directors, respectively, of the bank for three years, beginning on Jan. 1.

Rensselaer County is one of the few up-State counties in which Governor Lehman is expected by Democratic leaders to do better than in 1936. Neutral observ ers expect the Governor. to do as well, but no better, while the Republicans predict gains over the excellent showing they made here with William F. Bleakley as their Gubernatorial candidate.

Major Gen. George S. Simonds, retired, former Deputy Chief of Staff of the army, who was a member of General Pershing's staff and subsequently Chief of Staff of the Second American Army in the World War, died today in the Letterman General Hospital, San Francisco.

Solly Krieger, ring-wise bomber from Brooklyn, won the world middleweight boxing championship tonight by taking a fifteen-round decision from Al Hostak, Seattle titleholder. Krieger weighed 160, Hostak 159 3/4.

When early next June the United States and Great Britain meet on the historic turf of International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, it will be possible for this country to place in the field the highest handicapped team in the history of international polo.

The American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $4,670,954 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $1.40 a common share,
The honor of serving as acting captain of the Carnegie Tech Tartans in their efforts next Saturday to upset the Panthers of Pittsburgh was given to Jack (Whitey) Lee, burly fullback, today.

Because of the election on next Tuesday, the Treasury will sell its weekly bills on Friday of this week instead of on Monday, the Treasury announced today. The approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills will be dated Nov. 9 and mature on Feb. 8.

The 1938 annual exhibition of contemporary American painting opened with a preview yesterday afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock at the Whitney Museum. The work goes on public view today and will be shown until Dec. 11.

As the world relaxes from the tension of last September when the peace of one of its most important regions hung in perilous balance, many observers in this country not unnaturally raise the following question:
Of the two protagonists in the recent 4-W radio panic Welles, Wells, and the War of the Worlds--the player Orson Welles is 23 years old

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday that it would oppose a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Corporation Commission of the State of Virginia which charges that rail and water freight rates applicable to Baltimore, Md.,

Fed steers and yearling prices were unevenly steady to 25 cents lower today in a slow trade. Top for 1,240-pound steers was $13.25, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. Hog prices were mostly 5 to 15 cents $20. lower. While fat lambs found an active clearance with bulk sales around 25 cents higher. Receipts, 25,000, including 8,000 directs.
Babe Ruth would like to manage the St. Louis Browns-next year. The former home-run king telephoned last week and asked for the job, President Don Barnes said today.

The first luncheon-in a series under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund will take place tomorrow in the St. Regis Roof Garden. Mrs. William Francis Gibbs is chairman of arrangements and is being assisted by Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer and Mrs. John Aspegren. Miss Peggy Marshall

Two years ago this Fall the citizens of Greater New York adopted a system of proportional representation for the City Council by a vote of 923,186 to 555,217--a larger majority than they gave the new City Charter which was adopted in the same election.
Steel ingot output rose more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 78.3, from 71.3 in the preceding week. The index was 74.6 for the week ended Oct. 30. 1937.

The American Republics liner Argentine returned to its terminal at West Twentieth Street last night after a day's trial test. Leaving Hoboken at 8 A. M., the vessel headed for Asbury Park, then turned to Fire Island.

The teams that have given the impression of having the greatest strength in the East are Pittsburgh, Dartmouth, Fordham, Holy Cross, Cornell and Carnegie Tech. In the South, they are Tennessee, Duke and Alabama. Notre Dame, Northwestern, Minnesota, Michigan, Ohio State and Michigan State are selected in the Middle West, and Texas Christian, Oklahoma and Texas A. M. in the Southwest.

John Powell, not only an American pianist, but a musician and a poet, celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his professional American debut last night in Carnegie Hall. The audience had reason to rejoice in the maturity but also the freshness, the sincerity and the beauty' of his art.

UNITED STATES AIRWAY TRAFFIC CONTROL OPERATOR, $2,000 a year, Civil Aeronautics Authority (for duty at airway traffic control stations in the field). Applications must be on file not later than the following dates: (a) Nov 28, 1938, if received from States other than those named in (b), below. (b) Dec. 1, 1938, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, in one of its few communications concerning the subject to the New York Stock Exchange, informed the Exchange yesterday that 86.7 per cent Df its $14,994,000 6 per cent notes due on Oct. 1, last,

The growing bond of friendship between the United States and The Netherlands, and the prospect of a further increase in trade between the two nations was hailed by speakers at a ceremony yesterday to mark the signing of papers that will create a Netherlands cultural, social and commercial center in Rockefeller Center.
A prediction that the Federal Trade Commission, which through the Wheeler-Lea law has gained wide control over consumer advertising, eventually would scrutinize sales talks,

Mt Morris Park W. 32, 23.11x100x irreg: Theo Haebler to 89 W 134th St, Inc, 217 W 125th St: ($10.50). 14th St, 316 W, 25x103.3; Dona Holding Corp to Jean Brody, 3,109 Brighton St. Bklyn, mtg $12,000 and p m mtg $24,000 ($39).

Here at Rutgers the coaching staff, headed by Harvey Harman, faces a problem which must be solved before Saturday's traditional meeting with Princeton. The solution is not so easy, for the squad has lost the services of its first, second and third string fullbacks.

Further steps to lighten the load on the stock ticker in periods of heavy trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange are in process of formation, it was announced yesterday. The latest plan, which includes further shortening of symbols, has been worked out by the committee on floor procedure.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received the award yesterday of a new issue of $400,000 city of Scranton, Pa., funding and improvement bonds on a bid of 100.165 for 3s. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1938, and due serially on Nov. 1, 1939 to 1968, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.50 to 3.10 per cent, according to maturity.

Death Announced Retired Captain Patrick Toman. formerly a member of Engine Co. 278, residing at 5.313 Sixth Ave., Brooklyn, died Oct. 30., Funeral will take place from his late resldence at 9:33 A. M., Wednesday, Nov. 2, Interment at St. John's Cemetery.
MANHATTAN AHRENS, JEANETTE (Oct. 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To B'nai Jeshurun Temple, $1.000 three specific bequests; Esther Tallerman, sister, executrix, 27 W. 86th St., residue.

A pictorial history of the building of the World's Fair will go on public exhibition today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets. For posterity copies of the record will go into the museum's files as the first of its picture collection of the fair.

Relaxation of tension in the money market caused by the European crisis in September was disclosed by lower average rates on the weekly Treasury bill issues in October, as tabulated yesterday. Five issues of ninety-one-day bills, each amounting to about $100,000,000, were sold in order at the following average discount rates:

W. Warren Barbour, :Republican can didate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, called today upon William H. J. Ely, his Democratic opponent, to say openly whether he favored a sales tax and the placing of an income tax on New Jersey workers with small incomes to pay off the increasing national indebtedness.

Mrs. Kempton Adams of Piermont, Redding Ridge, Conn., and Benjamin Williams of New York were honored at a dinner given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Rodney W. Williams of New York, who are at Dun Romin, New Marlboro, for ten days of bird shooting. Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Braman of Chatham, N. Y., also were in the company.

Mrs. Mary L. Azoy of this city, a social leader, died yesterday at Homeopathic Hospital here after a three weeks' illness. The widow of A. C. M. Azoy, general manager of the Berwind-White Coal Mining Company of New York at his death, Mrs. Azoy was 78 years old.

The Ford Motor Company said today that the price range of its Mercury. 8, its new entry in the lower mediumprice field, would start under $900. The delivered price in Detroit of the sedan model, with two doors, will be $894. Federal and State taxes amounting to $49.70 are extra.

The directors of the Chesapeake Corporation, an intermediary holding organization through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and, in turn, lines controlled by the C. O., will meet tomorrow to discuss the proposal by Robert R. Young, chairman of Alleghany, for dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporatinn.

William Green, president of the A. F. of L., today endorsed Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York for re-election. In a letter to the Senator Mr. Green said that every worker in New York State felt he owed a debt to him for his championing of progressive labor laws in the last thirty-three years.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, former president of Mount Holyoke College and a registered Republican, and Miss Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, were among educators who announced yesterday their approval of Governor Lehman.

A panel of 100 names, including those of five housewives, from which will be selected the twentythree members of the extraordinary grand jury that is to investigate official corruption in Brooklyn, was drawn in Brooklyn yesterday with great ceremony.

Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, advanced himself tonight as a champion of the rights of labor who would "continue to fight for those rights" and advocated the adoption of the labor amendment to the State Constitution, No. 6 of the proposals on the ballot.

A familiar figure came back to the city yesterday afternoon when the smiling Slip Madigan led his St. Mary's football players into town, sent them on a quick tour of New York City and then took them to the Westchester Country Club at Rye, where they are to stay until Saturday's game with Fordham at the Polo Grounds.
Lieut. Gen. Sir Charles Edmond Knox, who led the historic chase of the elusive General De Wet throughout the closing months of the South African war, died today at Putney. His age was 92.

Wilson Shaw Arbuthnot, president of the Arbuthnot, Stephenson Company, a large dry goods concern, died tonight in the Western Pennsylvania Hospital of which he was president and director. He was 74 years old. Mr. Arbuthnot was a trustee of Carnegie Institute and Carnegie Institute of Technology and was a director of the Mellon National Bank.

A time is on its way when all textiles for apparel, home furnishings and industrial use will come from the laboratory, Theodore Wood, advertising director of American Bemberg Corporation and North American Rayon Corporation, told a luncheon meeting of the Boston Advertising Club here today.

Admiral Hermann Boehm, heretofore commander of the North Sea Naval Station, was appointed today Chief of the High Sea Fleet, succeeding Admiral Rolf Carls, who takes over the Baltic Naval Station. These changes are officially explained as the annual Autumn shake-up and without political significance.
George D. Wick Jr. has retired as a partner in Butler, Wick Co. and is at S. B. Chapin Co., the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt opened the Girl Scout Federation's fourth annual cookie sale yesterday when she bought the first box of vanilla and chocolate wafers from a Girl Scout in the federation's headquarters, 14 West Forty-ninth Street.

The Roosevelt Administration, "from the top down," is enthusiastically in support of William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, Postmaster General James A. Farley declared here tonight.

Most classes of bonds participated in a modest but broad upward movement yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative attention continued to center on the New York City traction bonds, which again responded to a brisk demand with substantial gains.

Harry M. Baldwin, 34 years old, of 50 Hunter Avenue, Trenton, wanted to "get it over with," so he went to Judge Frank A. Hendrickson today and asked to be jailed immediately for a second drunken driving conviction. The Court complied and gave him ninety days.

Today's events: Silvio and Isabel Scionti, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Frank Sheridan, pianist, Town Hall, evening; lecture-recital, "The Evolution of Keyboard Music," by Douglas Moore, Town Hall, 5:30; lecture by Roy
Real estate and realty securities usually are rather slow to respond to any quick revival in general business, but during October it was a different story.

Reports of troops landing at Futsing, thirty miles south of the Fukien provincial capital, Foochow, indicate the Japanese plan to seize the few principal coastal cities still remaining in Chinese hands, such as Foochow and Swatow.

Although Coach Bill Wood hopes to give his reserves plenty of service in Saturday's game with Franklin and Marshall College, and the varsity a much-needed rest, the Army coach today ran the first team through a 30-minute defensive scrimmage, which was followed by a long signal drill.

The Rev. John W. Curran, rector of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church here, died of a cerebral hemorrhage early today at the rectory after having been stricken in the confessional box in the church at 5 P. M. yesterday. His age was 54.
Plans for multi-family residential improvements in three boroughs were filed yesterday. They included a six-story tenement in Manhattan, to cost $70,000; two sixstory buildings in Brooklyn,

Twenty-five cadet officers in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at New York University's College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering have been promoted to the rank of first lieutenants.
Guy Stillman, 20, son of James A. Stillman, former head of the National City Bank of New York, was announced today as treasurer and a principal backer of the "Rensselaer Central Railroad."
Collins Judy, owned by Peter DiCristina of Floral Park, L. I., carried off the open all-age stake for fifteeninch bitches in the fourth day of the Long Island Beagle Club's field trials today.

To the fifteen-point program for Stock Exchange regulation, made public by the SEC, there will be little objection in the membership itself. Four or five of the provisions have already been approved by the Stock Exchange governors; most of the others have been recognized informally by members.

Len Barnum appeared well on the way toward a starting assignment at quarterback as the New York Giants drilled yesterday in preparation for their battle with the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds next Sunday.

110th St, 135 E, 4-story tenement, 18.9x 100.11; City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee, against Solomon S. Scharfer: due, $11,046: taxes, etc. $728; to plaintiff for $10,000. By WILLIAM KENNELLY 118th St. 304 E, 3-story tenement, 25x50.5; Central Savings Bank in City of New York against John Distefano; due, $6.149; taxes etc. $296: to plaintiff for $6.400.

The French Revolution, as seen through the eyes of the revolutionists, breaks out tonight at the Mercury Theatre, where "Danton's Death," by Georg Buchner, opens the Orson Welles-John Houseman season, the Martians being willing.
The engagement of Miss Marjorie Louise Sniffin, daughter of Mrs. C. Merwin Sniffin of this city, to H. Graham Hubbel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Hubbel of Tarrytown, has been announced.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany was inspired to maintain the firm stand he assumed during the negotiations over the partition of Czechoslovakia by a favorable conjunction of the stars and planets reported to him by his favorite astrologer, according to reports current in informed circles in Berlin.
Stocks continued to move narrowly, closing steady and mixed; turnover, 1,280,630 shares. United States Government, Japanese and local traction bonds higher, others steady; transactions. $7,387,000.

Christine Isham, the former Viscountess Churchill of England, obtained a divorce today from Ralph Isham, retired British Army officer, on the charge of cruelty. She asked no alimony, and the decree provided that she could use her former name, Christine Viscountess Churchill.

A severe drought on the island of St. Croix during the past year has so endangered the sugar and rum production of the government-financed Virgin Islands Company that relief is being sought through sinking deep wells. This work will begin within a month.

Universal today announced immediate release of an already filmed picture, "Mars Attacks the World," in an effort to capitalize on the Orson Welles radio broadcast. The film, which is a recut edition of their serial "Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars," distributed last Spring was scheduled for
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad filed today a petition in Federal court here seeking approval of a settlement of incometax claims amounting to $2,919,033 for a cash payment of $90,885.

Among the political talks acheduled for broadcast over local stations today are these: Eddie Dowling, George Coulouris, Blanche Ring and William Sauter, actors, "Stage, Arts and Governor Lehman," under auspices of the women's division of the Independent Citizens Committee for Election of Lehman and Poletti, WABC, 11 to 11:15 A. M.
The Argentine Republic filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new amendment fixing Thursday as the offering date for its $25,000,000 bond issue.

The Pennsylvania Railroad issued yesterday to holders of' its securities a letter. urging them to vote for Amendment 3 to the New York State Constitution which would relieve the railroads of most of the expense entailed in grade crossing eliminations.

The property known as the Anchorage, consisting of a twelveroom house with about two acres of land at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., has been sold by Mrs. Charles E. Fritz of Menlo Park, Calif., to Albert F. Blakeslee, director of the Department of Genetics of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, D. C.
Irving Mendelson, one of the smallest players on the Pennsylvania varsity squad, was promoted to left guard on the first team today and will probably start the Michigan game.

The Federal Trade Commission is now considering charges filed under the Robinson-Patman Act by the United Millinery Salesmen against seven commission buyers of millinery, it was announced here yesterday by David English, business manager of the salesmen's union.

Entitled "Let the Buyer Beware," a series of public service broadcasts, designed to help consumers guard against being cheated when making purchases, will be introduced by the Department of Markets on Saturday morning at 11 o'clock over Station WNYC.

Everything is ready for tomorrow's conference that will decide the HungarianCzechoslovak frontiers. All the delegations have arrived with the exception of that of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, whose train is due early in the morning.

Manhattan's football team spent the larger part of yesterday afternoon's three-hour drill developing a new passing attack to be used in Saturday's meeting with North Carolina State at the Yankee Stadium.

Appreciation for courtesies extended to him in this country and a hope for a "return visit" later were expressed by Jonkheer H. M. van Haersma de With, retiring Netherlands Minister to the United States, prior to his departure last night on the Holland-America liner Statendam to assume his new post as Minister in Berlin.

Production of meat in October, reflecting increased marketing of livestock, was estimated today by the Institute of American Meat Packers to have been from 5 to 10 per cent greater than in September, 1938, or in October, 1937.
Mild weather has cut business booked at the current American Toy Exhibit sharply, a check of the exhibitors at the American Furniture Mart showed today.
When exhausted clerks halted counting tonight, applications amouting to more than [Pound]32,000,000 had been checked for 2,200,000 F. W. Woolworth Co., Ltd., 5s ordinary shares at 58s each.

Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth of 812 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Aylesworth, to Robert G. Knott, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Knott of 43 Fifth Avenue and Glen Cove.

East Side realty involved in the trading announced yesterday included buildings in Yorkville, Lenox Hill and East Harlem. An investing syndicate represented by Choate, Larocque Mitchell, attorneys, bought from the 975 Lexington Avenue Corporation the eleven-story apartment on the
Extracts from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement in the House of Commons today follow:

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, fiscal agents for Kingdom of Bulgaria 71/2 per cent stabilization loan of 1928, announced yesterday that Nov. 15 coupons of dollar bonds of this loan, presented with letters of transmittal, would be paid at the rate of $12.19 for each $37.50 coupon and $6.09 for each $18.75 coupon in full settlement for and against surrender of the coupons.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Mohammedan Conquest," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; Oriental Art, the Near East (general tour), 2 P. M.; "American Cabinetmakers: Transition in Furniture, 1700," Alfred Busselie Jr., 4 P. M.

Another attempt has been made to pack some of the brutishness of the Nazi culture into a play. "Waltz in Goose Step" is what they call it; Oliver H. P. Garrett, a laborer in the Hollywood vineyard, wrote it, and it was put on at the Hudson last evening by Julien Chaqueneau as his first Broadway production.

James M. Mead, Democratic candidate for the short term as United States Senator, pleaded yesterday afternoon for the election of a Democratic Congress to support President Roosevelt and the election of a Democratic Legislature as an aid to Governor Lehman. The Buffalo.

Board of Education officials were caught napping yesterday and could not decide whether the pupils at the Seward Park High School annex, in the heart of the lower East Side, had called one or two strikes on them. The change of pace was too confusing.

SOMNOLENT James Crowley of. Fordham has a helpful suggestion to allay planetary war' scares. His serious suggestion is that if Martians are reported moving into your territory, just phone for that Pitt Panther football team and go on with the contract bridge game.

Al Reid, 126 3/4, Bronx, rallied in the last three rounds to gain a hard-earned verdict over Nat Litfin, 127, Bronx, in the feature eightround bout at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 8,000.

A three-in-one evening gown was a big help on her recent lecture tour, says Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. The dress was of uncrushable black velvet with a long skirt. A jacket with long sleeves was added for dinner wear.
The Daily Herald said today that a letter from King George accepting President Roosevelt's invitation to pay a visit to Washington next Summer was en route to the White House.

The motor vehicle accident death rate in New York City in September was 0.11 per 10,000 persons, compared with 0.13 for sixty-five up-State cities and villages and 0.49 for rural New York, it was reported yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

City officials who went to the Bronx yesterday to open formally a new drawbridge over the Bronx River at Westchester Avenue played only a minor part in the ceremonies. They surrendered to a crowd of more than 2,500 shrieking, pushing school children who engulfed policemen, overwhelmed the speakers with shrill chatter and made the formal opening their party.

Taking advantage of the new "rental-sales" plan provided under Section 210 of the National Housing Act, Philip J. Bowers Co., developers, will break ground this week for ten low-priced homes on Hollywood Avenue, between Stone Street and Leland Place, Hillside, N. J.. west of Newark.

The Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, liquidating shell for the assets of the old "Dawes bank," collected $528,000 from liquidations in the three months ended yesterday, Charles H. Albers, receiver, reported today to the Circuit Court. This compared with $991,000 collected in the preceding three months.

The award of the Clement Cleveland medal to the National Association of Science Writers, a group of newspaper men who specialize in the presentation of scientific and technical news, has a double significance.
The Conservatives more than held the ground they gained at their peak in 1935 when today they won twenty more seats in municipal elections from their Labor, Liberal and independent opponents.

In China there is nothing new even under the Rising Sun. Everything has happened before. The appearance may change, but the pattern remains the same. Invaders may come or go, conquerors are absorbed, but life and love among the Chinese continue as they did through all the shadowy centuries.

Regina Gregory, a matronly looking woman, was one of the ten persons chosen last night in Prospect Park to represent Brooklyn in a city-wide whistling contest Nov. 13 in Mullaly Playground, 165th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, Manhattan:

A funeral service for Frederick W. Longfellow, New York lawyer, who died Saturday night at the St. Andrews Golf Club at Hastings, of which he was president, was held yesterday at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, by the Rev. Dr. H. W. B. Donegan, the rector.

Colonel John K. Brown was reelected president of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club of New York at the meeting last night in the Riding and Polo Club, which had just become the group's permanent headquarters.

Princeton began serious preparations for its traditional Rutgers game with an hour and a half of scrimmage on University Field today. The first and second elevens alternated at making substantial gains through a third team.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Frank Moore Colby of 680 Madison Avenue of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Harriet Wood Colby, to Walter William Beachboard, son of Mrs. Walter William Beachboard of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Beachboard.

James St, 58. 25x10; Frank Perez to Michael Greco, 1,515 Jarvis Ave, 5 years, 5-6%; $10,000. Madison St, 151, 30.5x46: Abram Zerenocvitz to Fannie Cohen. 1.534 Selwyn Ave; pr mtg $8,000, install, 6%; $2,700. 14th St, 316 W, 25x103.3: Jean Brody to Dona Holding Corp, 316 9th Ave; p m mtg; pr mtg $12,000; due Nov. 1, 1948, 6%: $24.000.

In supporting Governor Lehman this newspaper believes that it is important to remember that an Administration is not a man but a team. For the three offices next in responsibility to that of Governor the character of this team is vital.

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was slightly less than in the previous week. However, the total was considerably ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Representative Caroline O'Day of New York, a close personal friend of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, reported today that she had received a $100 campaign contribution from Mrs. Roosevelt.

The first published reference to a new and powerful anti-aircraft gun appeared yesterday in an official government report of evidence taken before a select committee of the House of Commons studying estimates submitted by various departments.

Jim Reddick, light-heavyweight from St. Louis and the only North American fighter to see action on the card, outpointed Joaquin Mosquera of Uruguay before 15,000 fans in the seventh round of the PanAmerican amateur boxing championships tonight.

During the last two months a new stream of Jewish emigration has been passing through Trieste. Italian Far Eastern liners are now sailing regularly crowded with third-class and leek passengers, most of whom are Austrian Jews.

The financial condition of municipalities in New Jersey was reported today by Walter R. Darby, Local Government Commissioner, to have improved slightly during the year ended on Sept. 30, while that of counties showed a decided upward trend.

The trustees of the Greenwich Savings Bank, Broadway and Sixth Avenue, at Thirty-sixth Street, presented yesterday a silver service to Charles A. Kimball, a member of the new business department of the bank, in recognition of his completion of fifty years' service with the institution. The presentation was made by Clarence M. Fincke, president.

The Hamburg-American liner Orinoco slipped out to sea from Veracruz tonight, bound for Germany via Havana with twenty-one Austrian and German Jewish refugees who had the door to the new world t slammed in their faces by the Cardenas Government.

To restore Great Britain to her true greatness and create a new chivalry and new spirit of unselfishness among the peoples of the world a large number of British sportsmen tonight issued a call for "moral rearmament through sport."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The bad taste and lack of restraint in the Halloween "joke" broadcast cannot be too harshly condemned. It would appear that radio is in incompetent hands if the studios lack persons with enough responsibility to prevent the sending of such frighltfulness into the homes of a people already jittery from war talk, depression and political uncertainty.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has postponed indefinitely a rule designated as X-10 B-4, which it adopted several months ago, in so far as it would apply the antimanipulative provisions of Section 9a of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to the over-the-counter markets.

The silk market has become buoyant, with prices advancing and the futures market stronger, and as a result Japan has developed greater business optimism, radio and cable reports to the Department of Commerce from its attaches noted today.

Prime Minis- GANG ter Neville Chamberlain reaffirmed in the House of Commons today GANG that his government "intends wholeheartedly to devote itself" to the policy of "appeasement" in Europe, but also declared that Britain would have to spend still more millions on her defenses as a result of what he described as the "warning" of a month ago.

Moritz Rothenberger, 57 years old, a retired member of the New York Curb Exchange and for many years active in Jewish philanthropic activities, ended his life yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the head in his penthouse apartment on the twenty-second floor at the Oliver Cromwell Apartments, 12 West Seventy-second Street.
Maxwell E. Fillet, former head of Schenley Distillers' convention and banquet bureau, was named yesterday as Eastern regional sales manager for Joseph S. Finch Co.

Determined to give the Presidential boom of former Governor Paul V. McNutt, now High Commissioner to the Philippines, such a boost as will leave no doubt anywhere as to its seriousness, leaders of the streamlined Democratic machine of Indi- party ana have undertaken to pile up a majority for the party next Tues- tom. day the like of which has never been seen before in an off-year election in this State.

It is quite natural that Halloween should usher in the month that foretells Winter. November plays the same childish pranks. Like a small boy it creeps up to ring your doorbell in the darkness, pretending to announce the arrival of a cold spell.

Woodlawn Rd (12-3328), w s, 370 ft n of Gun Hill Rd, 150x103; Lislie F. Havender to Havender Realty, Inc. 3,686 Jerome Ave. Bainbridge Ave (12-3344), s e cor of 211th St, 36x100; Marguerite Havender to Havender Realty, Inc. 3,686 Jerome Ave. Bainbridge Ave (12-3344), e s, 36 ft s of 211th St. 50x100; Joseph Havender to Havender Realty, Inc.
Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, wife of the Secretary of Agriculture, held a reception this morning for a preview of the chrysanthemums annually shown in the greenhouses of the department.

Expressing the broad viewpoint that the city's major improvements should meet the requirements of its commercial life, the City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a capital outlay budget for 1939 of $146,022,143, which showed a cut of some $9,000,000 from its October total.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor aided 45,281 persons at an aggregate cost of $1,561,955 during its ninety-fifth fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, according to Barklie Henry, president. The association spent $30,000 more than the year before and served 5,227 more cases.

The present excess bank reserves could support a theoretical maximum expansion of $17,000,000,000 in bank loans and investments, it is calculated by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to c the current monthly review of the bank, published yesterday.
Raymond Sheldon and his wife, Annette, of 198 Washington Park, Brooklyn, who were convicted last month of obtaining loans
Elmer F. Andrews, Wages and Hours Administrator, ruled today that newspapers generally are engaged in interstate commerce and are not exempt from the law as service industries.

Miss Frances S. Whitall of Acorn Farm, Katonah, N. Y., gave a dinner last night at the Versailles for Miss Isabel Butterworth and Cabot Ward Low, whose marriage will take place Saturday afternoon in Christ Church, Rye.
After hearing reports on the plight of Jewish boys and girls in Central Europe, delegates to the Hadassah convention today pledged $125,000 for the relief of the young people.

Those Americans who are carrying on "such a vicious campaign of hatred" against President Roosevelt and the New Deal represent the same forces that brought about the peace of Munich and its consequences, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party and former Communist Presidential candidate, said last night.

A funeral service was held for Mrs. Geraldine McAlpin Webster, wife of Dr. Jerome Pierce Webster and granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller, at 1 P. M. yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital chapel, and another at 3 P. M. in the Webster home on Dodge Lane, Riverdale, the Bronx.

The plan to register all buyers of furs as proposed by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers was discussed yesterday at an informal conference between Edward Fillmore, counsel for the fur group, and a committee representing the Association of Buying Offices, composed of paid resident buyers.

Coach Jack Blott began today pointing a somewhat bruised Wesleyan football squad for its Little Three game with Williams on Saturday. Phelps, the big tackle, who suffered a concussion in the Trinity game, rested, and Gale substituted for him.
A disagreed today on a minimum dis agreed today on a minimum hourly wage for 1,300,000 textile workers to be established under the Wages and Hours Law.

The Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau and the Life Agency Officers Association, both of Hartford, Conn., opened their eighteenth joint annual meeting here today in the Edgewater Beach Hotel with an attendance of several hundred executives of life insurance companies and agencies.
Electric power production last week rose more than anticipated on the basis of normal trends and the adjusted index advanced to 95.8 from 95.1. For the week ended Oct. 30, 1937. the figure was 102.1.

The newest new car of the year, the Mercury 8, added to fill a price gap between the de luxe Ford V-8 and the Lincoln-Zephyr, was formally announced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company. A streamlined vehicle of 116-inch wheelbase with 95 horsepower V-type eightcylinder engine, the new car is offered in four body styles with eight color options.

The Fifth Avenue shop of the Walk-Over Shoe Stores will move two blocks to the north, it was learned yesterday with the announcement that the concern had leased the two-story building under construction at 548 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northwest corner of Forty-fifth Street. The present store is at 510, adjoining the southwest corner of Forty-third, where it has been for almost twenty years.

" Run Sheep Run," a comedy by Raymond Knight, opens tonight at the Windsor. It deals with a columnist who returns to the home town about which he has nostalgically written in New York. Hugh O'Connell plays the columnist, said to have been suggested by the life of the late O. O. McIntyre, and is aided by Ruth Weston, Alan Bunce and Beatrice Herford in the principal roles.

Among prominent persons listed among new apartment tenancies yesterday was J. Andre Fouilhoux, architect, who took a suitein 1,075 Park Avenue through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker. Mr. Fouil??oux's firm, Harrison Fouilhoux, has designed many notable buildings in the United States.

William J. McAuliffe, who retired a month ago as assistant director of the Bureau of Extension Activities of the Board of Education, died yesterday after noon in his home, 372 East 194th Street, of the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered on Tuesday. He was 57 years old.

Jimmy Foxx, slugging first sacker of the Boston Red Sox whose spectacular comeback provided one of the highlights of last season, has been chosen the most valuable player in the American League for 1938, it was announced yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America, whose committee recently completed its annual poll for The Sporting News Trophy.

World gold output for September, excluding Russia, for which there are no figures available, amounted to 2,774,000 fine ounces, compared with 2,766,000 in August and 2,520,000 in September last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The high for this year was 2,808,000 ounces in July.

Praising the aims of safety education, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in a brief ceremony in his office yesterday afternoon welcomed Uncle Robert and eight elementary school children who came bearing S. O. S. (Stay on Sidewalk) messages from their classmates.

Undue centralization of power at Washington and extravagant and wasteful government spending were attacked last night by John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for United States Senator, in a radio speech from Station WJZ and in statements issued at his headquarters in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Edwin D. Ide of Glen Road, Wellesley Farms, associated with Brown Brothers, Harriman Co. of Boston for fifty-one years and considered an expert on financial history, died today of a heart attack while on his way to his office. He was 69 years old.

Charles J. Hildebrandt, veteran vaudeville player known to the stage as Charles J. Hill, a lifelong friend of Robert Woolsey, cigar - smoking comedian, who died on Monday at Malibu Beach, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital here.

Reports on the progress of the Metropolitan Opera Guild were heard by 700 members yesterday in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza, where the Guild held its first campaign luncheon of the season. Mrs. August Belmont, chairman, pointed out that since last season the Guild has increased more than 13 per cent among those living in and near the city and 77 per cent in new radio membership throughout the country.

Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, denounced last night the record of Governor Lehman on power as one lacking in decisive action while the people of the State paid millions of dollars in power rates based on a capital- structure alleged to be 37 per cent fiction.

Officials of the United States Polo Association yesterday announced the names of thirteen men who will be asked to aid in the defense of the International Cup in the matches against Great Britain at Meadow Brook next June.

Among other aspects of the new position of British trade, arising from the aftermath of the Munich accord, the government is studying the question of barter arrangements. Several civil servants on the staff of the Board of Trade have been assigned to make a general survey of the effects of the German barter system upon the Reich's trade with European and other countries.

Justice Minister Paul Reynaud's acceptance of the Ministry of Finance had a good reception on the Bourse, today and, in general, in the press. Rentes rose between 35 centimes and 1 franc 75 centimes. French securities of all kinds were stronger and, indeed, in certain cases, byoyant.

Mr. and Mrs. Earl Blough of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street, this city, and Tiverton, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frani Blough, to Curt Muser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Muser, also of New York.
Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the New York Yankees baseball team, was re-elected today for his seventeenth term as president of the United States Brewers Asssociation.

In addition to the declaration of an extra dividend of 10 cents, together with the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share payable Dec. 15 to stockholders of record Nov. 15, the Standard Oil Company of California made public yesterday its earnings for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, it was learned tonight, have rented a home on the Boulevard Suchet in Paris, facing the Bois de Boulogne. The house, in Louis XVI style, designed and owned by the Countess de Sabini, was built only six years ago.
For the first time since the Navy game, Fullback Jim Connell engaged in practice at Pennsylvania today, and displayed early-season form in the mock scrimmage against the junior varsity eleven.

The directors of the Chesapeake Corporation, intermediary holding agency through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio, the New York, Chicago St. Louis, the Erie, the Pere Marquette and the Wheeling Lake Erie Railways, approved yesterday a plan for dissolution of Chesapeake. This will place Alleghany in direct control of the C. 0. and other lines.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's swept out on the turf of the Westchester Country Club this morning and began their labors for Saturday's game with Fordham at the Polo Grounds after having had similar workouts in Colorado, Texas, Arkansas, West Virginia and Maryland since they left their native California a week ago.

Although the incidence of tuberculosis infection is decreasing in the New York City high schools, many apparently healthy boys and girls with active cases of pulmonary disease attending classes, Dr., Herbert R. Edwards, director of the Department of Health's tuber culosis bureau, disclosed yesterday.

The Bureau of Standards said today that can linings offered the greatest potential new commercial use for silver. The bureau, with funds provided by silver producers, has developed methods of lining cans with a thin coat of silver, which, it said, increases resistance to corrosion and improves the preservation of vegetables, fruits and other commonly canned foods.

Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, told members of the Society of Colonial Wars and their guests at their forty-first annual dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that "we are not trying an armament race, not trying to outbuild any one or even keep up with them."

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of last month was $47,001,767,212, compared with $43,526,688,812 on Sept. 30, an increase of $3,475,078,400, according to a compilation by the Exchange.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $2,824,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at 4 per cent to pay fixed charges and maturing equipment obligations between Dec. 30, 1938, and March 31, 1939.
A silver eagle, wings outspread, today replaced the familiar "$" emblem on the liner President Monroe, former Dollar ship, which became one of the new American President Line fleet.

Delegates to the fifth annual American Trucking Association convention were told today by J. Gordon Gaines of Akron, Ohio, trucking expert, that more than $100,000,000 will be invested in new trucking equipment next year, and a majority of this equipment will be manufactured in Detroit.
Mayor La Guardia has definitely decided to support Governor Herbert H. Lehman in preference to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey in the Governorship campaign.

The report of the Engineers Publie Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after expenses and charges, of $3,701,057, compared with a net of $3,540,656 in the twelve months ended Sept.

Morris.. S. Tremaine, Democratic candidate for re-election as Controller, has saved State taxpayers more than $25,000,000 on the State's borrowings in the twelve years he has been Controller, according to a pamphlet distributed yesterday among business men- by the Tremaine-for-Controller campaign committee.

Payment in September of $41,500,000 in unemployment benefits was announced today by the Social Security Board, which reported also a continued dedine in volume of first claims received and amount of benefits paid.

President Kyosti Kallio today appointed Hjalmar Johan Procope, former Foreign Minister, as Minister to Washington to succeed Eero Jarnefelt, who was transferred to Rome. Mr. Procope is ill and will not go to Washington until Feb. 1.

As rewarding two-piano playing as has been disclosed here in many months was heard last night at Carnegie Hall when a new team, Silvio and Isabel Scionti, gave its first New York concert. This was playing that justified the combination of two pianos by the interpretive results. The instruments complemented and fulfilled each other.

A group of Viennese actors, directors, musicians and writers, formerly associated with the Kleinkunstbuhne, which disbanded when Austria was assimilated by Germany, have organized a Refugee Artists Theatre, which is to present its first production here early in January.

Clutching at Prime Minister Chamberlain's ruling out of industrial conscription in connection with Great Britain's rearmament program, the stock market took on a brighter appearance today to the accompaniment of a small rise in trading.

According to Iron Age, the factors that are counted upon by the steel industry to bring a still higher level of operations in the next several weeks include increasing specifications for sheets and strip as consumers face the possibility of a tight delivery situation,

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer publicly today by means of a prospectus an issue of $25,000,000 of ten-year sinking fund external loan 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the Argentine Republic.

Damage estimated at $30,000 was done by a fire which swept three of four wings of the residence of Samuel W. Meek of Dublin Road this afternoon. Mr. Meek is vice president in charge of foreign affairs of the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Agency.

Prices of wheat moved within narrow limits today, although trading increased. There was no material pressure, and late in the session buying of futures attributed to professional operators lifted prices moderately.
Princeton's football forces, minus most of the first-stringers, overwhelmed Johnny Gorman's freshmen by ten touchdowns to one in their second encounter of the season on University Field today.

Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale's, yesterday announced the appointment of I. A. Hirschmann as director of advertising and sales promotion, a newly created post. Mr. Hirschmann will take up his new duties on Nov. 14. They will comprise the supervision of all of the store's advertising, publicity, display and sales promotion. He will serve as a member of the store operating board.

Sylvia Brema, 19-year-old lyric soprano, returned yesterday on theFrench liner Paris after being barred from opera in Italy, she said, because she is a Jew. The young singer, who lives at 1,350 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx,

There is something soothing in the report, again renewed, that Hitler condescends to take advice from the heavenly bodies through his professional astrologer. Sun, moon and planets would be friendly to him on Sept. 27, his diviner told him. So that was the day chosen for his latest venture.

Accusing the Republican party of sham liberalism, Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight assailed the campaign address recently made in Connecticut by former President Hoover.

The Bayside Tennis Club appears to have a strong team in the Metropolitan League Class A tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association, for it has scored two straight victories since the season opened and is tied with the New York A. C., which has won two straight also.

A general decline of both exports and imports for the United States in September from the totals for September, last year, in the case of all major geographical divisions was reported today by the Department of Commerce in a further breakdown of data issued a week ago.

William A. Eagleson, postmaster of Staten Island from 1927 to 1932, died on Tuesday night at St. Vincent's Hospital in West New Brighton after being ill for several weeks. His age was 66 years. Mr. Eagleson, who resided at 409 Manor Road, West New Brighton, was born in Manhattan and made his home on Staten Island for more than fifty years.

In an effort to ascertain the views of employers and trade unions on the merits of the State and National Labor Relations Acts and on the wisdom of amending them, the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Relations has distributed 4,000 copies of a confidential questionnaire on government activities in the field of employer-employe relations.
