In order to avoid the publication of blatant propaganda or halftruths, newspapers should establish standards for institutional advertising even higher than those for other types of copy, Henry Obermeyer, assistant vice president in charge of advertising of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, yesterday told the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Newspaper Promotion Group at the Advertising Club.

Fireman 1st grade Thomas J. Hitter, of Engine Co. 290, died Oct. 31, in the performance of duty, from bullet wounds caused by bandits, while on messenger duty. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 94-12 103d Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, Nov. 4. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick gave a dinner last night at Larue for Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C. P. Wichfeld and Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Cushing. A luncheon was given by Miss Eileen Haire in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for Miss Eileen Marie McCarty, who will be married to Francis Richard Curry on Nov. 18 in the Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament.
The 114-acre estate of Mrs. Walter D. Worrall in Mount Kisco, Westchester, has been purchased by a New York manufacturer for his allyear home.

Continuing preparations for the visit to Yale, Brown went through an intensive workout today, including scrimmage, kick-offs, blocking and signal drills. As the scrimmage progressed, the improvement in timing was quite obvious.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that the recent conferences between the National Defense Power Committee and utility executives was to him a definite indication that the Roosevelt Administration does not intend to be in any sense unfair to the public utilities or to any other industry.

More than 400,000 Christian refugees have fled. from the Sudetenland because of Germany's annexation, in comparison with 30,000 Jewish refugees from that territory, it was asserted yesterday by the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, 287 Fourth Avenue.

The National Labor Relations Act has established a set-up that is "bound to produce unfair results," Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State and president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, declared yesterday.

A summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders for September, issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that Pierre S. du Pont acquired 5,500 shares of common stock and sold 8,000 shares of debenture stock of E, I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

Evaristo V. de Montalvo, SpanishAmerican War veteran, civil engineer, sugar planter and former New York resident, died on Oct. 20 at his home in Havana, according to word received here yesterday. He had been ill for five years.

Picking up a loose ball on a bad pass from center in the first minute of play tonight, Bill Barnard ran 68 yards for a touchdown and then scored another on a 23-yard pass from Harry Mattos in the third period as the Jersey City Giants of the American Association scored a 21-0 victory over Wilmington in an exhibition game.

Journey's End, the 125-acre estate of C. B. Warren on Journey's End Road, near Kitchawan Road, Yorktown, Westchester, has been sold to a client of Howard L. Auerbach, Inc., broker. Included are a fifteen-room and four-bath main residence, a sports and boat house, eight-room superintendent's cottage, gardner's cottage and other outbuildings.

The Rev. Dr. Harry E. Ulrich was installed this evening as pastor of the Presbyterian Church here. He comes from the pastorate of the Presbyterian Church at West Chester, Pa. Presiding at the installation was the Rev. James W. Butler, Moderator of the Presbytery of Westchester.
William R. Teece has been appointed manager of the central division, comprising twelve Middle West States, for the Seagram Distillers Corporation.
Young automobile drivers are killing three times as many persons as are middle-aged drivers, J. L. Lingo, public safety specialist at Purdue University, today told the annual Parents' Institute.
Japanese planes in an attack on Shekki, fifty-five miles south of Canton, killed fifty and wounded sixty today. Incendiary bombs started a number of fires and houses were damaged extensively.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday gave as poor a performance as did the shares, and trading was the slowest in more than a month, or since Sept. 27. Transactions in bonds fell to $5,931,100, compared with $7,387,000 on the preceding day.
The National Labor Relations Board told President Roosevelt today that in the opinion of its members the National Labor Relations Act did not need amending.

Investing buying of apartment properties in Yorkville featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday. A large parcel changed hands with the sale by the Eighty-second Street Management Corporation of the modern six-story elevator apartment building at 222 to 230 East Eighty-second Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

After a little less than four weeks of spectacular campaigning, Thomas E. Dewey is still running neck-andneck with Governor Herbert H. Lehman in the contest for the Governorship of New York State, according to the semi-final results of a State-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

Alberto Haines, an Argentine newspaper man, on his way to the eighth Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, early next month, conferred today with the Chilean authorities concerning plans for the creation of an inter-American press bureau to provide a regular news service

Mild weather, hampering retail sales last month, was cited yesterday by stores as the chief reason why newspaper linage did not expand as much as had been expected. The continued poor showing of national advertisers in newspapers and magazines was laid partly to the war scare, some lingering business uncertainty and the forthcoming elections.

Following is the text of the letter of Henry L. Stimson on the subject of the National Labor Relations Act: TO THE EDITOR THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has performed an important public service in propounding to the candidates for United States Senator the series of questions which were contained in its issue of Oct. 21.

A colorful selection of about thirty music sheet covers, done through lithograph and engraving mediums and dating to the close of the eighteenth and middle of the nineteenth centuries, was placed on exhibition yesterday afternoon in the showroom of the Pynson Printers on the seventh floor of 229 West Forty-third Street.

Mrs. Rachel Ann Cartwright Lynch of Lakewood, well known for her activities in the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, died of coronary thrombosis today in her Summer home here after an illness of four weeks. She was 77 years old.

Sylvester J. McBride, a leader of the Socialist party here and formerly president for six years of the Boston Typographical Union, died today in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Brighton, after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for Kings County Judge, pleaded last night with the rank-and-file of the American Federation of Labor to support his candidacy because of his long fight in behalf of organized labor. Mr. Waldman spoke at a series of Brooklyn labor rallies and finally over station WEVD.

Aroused by heavy trade losses in Latin America and other markets due to German barter activities, foreign traders, adjourning their twenty-fifth annual National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, moved to spike such competition.

AZOY-On Oct. 31; 1938, Mary L., wife of the late Anastazio C. M. Azoy of East Orange, N. J. The Mary Washington Colonial Chapter, D. A. R., announces with deep regret the death of Mrs. Anastazio C. M. Azoy. Mrs. THADDEUS MERRIMAN, Regent. Mrs. PHILIP GOODIN, Cor. Sec.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today applications by the New York Stock Exchange for permission to delist the $100-par-value capital stock of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Company, and the 6 per cent cumulative preferred $100par and $1-par common stocks of the Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Corporation.

Dayton school teachers voted almost unanimously today to back the Board of Education in keeping the schools closed until enough money was found to pay salaries and expenses, then issued a statement which said that voters failed to "show concern over the school problem" six times in the last six years.
Stocks continued to fluctuate and closed firm and mixed in dullest trading since Sept. 27; turnover, 783,950.

Saul Cohn of New York, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in an interview today that the "two-price plan" sponsored by Secretary Wallace "would not be a durable solution to the cotton problem."

The preservation of private ownership of the merchant marine cannot be solved by "berating the bogy of government ownership," it was declared yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Marine Institute, speaking before the National Foreign Trade Convention in the Hotel Commodore.

A memorial exhibition of work by the late Ernst Barlach, eminent German sculptor, who died on Oct. 24 at the age of 68, will be held at the Buchholz Gallery. Curt Valentin, director of the gallery, who is making preparations for the show, was a personal friend of Barlach's and is thus doubly interested in the project.
Six Harvard students named Murphy are the recipients this year of the annual scholarships given in 1916 by William Stanislaus Murphy, '35, for the "collegiate education of men of the name of Murphy."

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College gave a tea yesterday at the deanery for Mrs. Hooker Talcott, general chairman of the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund of the college, and members of her committee.

The executive committee of the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday issued the following statement: "The very same publishers of New York City who have most bitterly fought the. collective bargaining efforts of their own employes have now, true to form, taken the lead in opposing the re-election of Senator Robert F. Wagner, author of the most important single law enacted in recent times for the freeing of working men and women.
Scotland surrendered its Interleague soccer title to England today. Playing before a crowd of 25,000 spectators on the Wolverhampton Wanderers' ground, the English league eleven won handily, 3--1.

Governor Earle's plan to have the Federal Government buy and store 20,000,000 tons of anthracite in various parts of the country for national defense purposes was called impracticable today by Senator James J. Davis.

The old Montclair Hotel, which has stood for thirty years on Crestmont Road, on the top of Montclair Mountain in Montclair, N. J., is soon to be razed to make way for an apartment house, the first to be erected in the town in more than a decade.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, obtained permission yesterday from Federal Judge John C. Knox to send to Governor Lehman a copy of the minutes of a Federal grand jury that indicted recently forty-five members of a supposed alcohol ring.

The season of 1938 will linger for many years in the minds of quite a few of the gentlemen who spend their Saturday afternoons arrayed in unseasonable white costumes pursuing football players about the fields of various stadia as officials. For exactly 125 of these men, it now appears, the season of 1938 will be remembered as the last one during which they worked in major college games.

Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, wrote this week to Commissioner B. H. Meyer of the Interstate Commerce Commission reminding him of commitments made in 1933 in connection with a loan of $3,390,000 from the RFC to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, it was learned today.

Mysterious activities in a carefully screenedoff section of the'Poets' Corner in Westminster Abbey, involving the clinking of picks and the grating of slabs, gave rise today to reports that Edmund Spenser's tomb had at last been opened, in another effort to prove that Bacon was Shakespeare.
Concluding its practice for Saturday's game in Providence with the Providence College eleven, City College's varsity football squad went through a long drill at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.
The British Government has recently considerably increased an original large order placed in this country for anti-aircraft fire-control directors, it was learned today.

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutorinthe inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn, asked Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday for a special detail of policemen to work under him in the, investigation. The request was made at a Secret conference between the Commissioner and Mr. Amen at a place which neither would disclose.

Following a steady rise in old-crop positions which widened the December-October spread from 47 to 80 points recently, differences on the Cotton Exchange here narrowed sharply yesterday when the October delivery gained 13 points while the December remained unchanged.

A pledge to demand of the next Congress a comprehensive investigation of the political activities of all Federal relief agencies, signed by twenty-five Republican Senatorial incumbents and candidates and 180 members of or candidates for election to the House, was made public today by the Republican National Committee.

The Administration will probably begin its experiment in the two-price program with the manufacture and sale of mattresses at reduced prices to poor persons, Secretary Wallace indicated at a press conference today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today corrected an error of more than $57,000,000 in its Bureau of Valuation's cost figures for the Chesapeake Ohio Railway as introduced in the current proceeding in which the Pocahontas roads seek continuation of the present surcharges on bituminous coal which will expire on Dec. 31.
The Federal Government ended the first four months of the current fiscal year with a deficit of $1,139,537,782. A deficit of $4,000,000,000 has been predicted officially for the year.

The CzechHungarian frontier was redrawn today by the German and Italian Foreign Ministers to give Hungary more than 4,000 square miles of Czech territory, with a population of 860,000. Hungarian occupation is to begin Saturday and end Thursday of next week.

Bids, described generally as "highly satisfactory," for the construction of three battleships, offensively the equal if not the superior of comparable ships in any navy, were opened today at the Navy Department.
Bringing to an end the Long Island Beagle Club Autumn field trials, the Derby Stakes for the thirteen and fifteen inch classes were run today.

Princeton's soocer team scored in every period in overwhelming a weak Lafayette aggregation, 9-0, on Poe Field today. Bob Goheen led the victors from his inside left post with two scores, one in the first period and another in the third. Captain John Landis starred for the visitors at center half.

Mrs. Miriam Ryan Robb of Palm Beach filed a divorce suit here today against Hampton Robb of Hewlett, L. I. Mental cruelty was charged. She asked for custody of their 4-year-old son, Theodore Ryan Robb.

The Navy first eleven worked on the defense today against a B squad group drilled in Notre Dame plays and with the attacking backs wearing the names of the ball-carriers of the Irish, who will be met in the Baltimore Stadium Saturday. Contact was avoided in the practice.

The Millville Board of Trade announced today, with the reopening of the Whitall-Tatum Glass factory here, that every plant in the city was operating and that the recall of men to work would leave an insufficient number still on WPA rolls to complete projects already under way.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due today from Southampton via Cherbourg. On board are: he Countess of Granard, Lord and Lady Duveen, Lord and Lady Forres, Lady Broughton, Lady Bowden, P. M. Broadmeed, First Secretary of the British Embassy at Washington;

Mrs. Oscar Lampland of 2,116 Iglehart Avenue, Merriam Park, St. Paul, has announced here the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Miss Ruth Evangeline Lampland, to Donald Duncan Ross of this city, formerly of Westmount, Montreal, Que. The wedding will take place Nov. 12 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, this city.

Fifteen persons were wounded and Forty were arrested today when Arabs of French-mandated Syria and Lebanon clashed with police luring demonstrations against the British administration of Palestine. The anniversary of the 1917 Balfour declaration, in which the British Government announced its plan to establish a national home for Jews in Palestine, was the occasion for the outbreak.
The Navy Department announced today that a new dirigible airship for "training, experimental and development purposes" would be constructed at a cost of not more than $3,000,000.

A seven-game varsity football schedule for Rutgers for the 1939 season, featured by the appearance of four rivals not met this year, was announced today by George E. Little, director of physical education. An open date exists on Nov. 18, but it is to be filled later.

Debate on a move to censure the government was begun in the House of Representatives today under circumstances unprecedented in Australian politics. For the first time the Prime Ministership of Joseph A. Lyons finds its authority challenged by a Cabinet minority headed by Attorney General Robert G. Menzies, which more than makes good in influence and ability what it lacks in numbers.

The Bronx Borough Taxpayers League announced yesterday that .t had adopted a report of the legisative committee recommending that all of the nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution be "completely rejected" by the voters next week.

THE longest run of the football season was made by a blocking back who didn't have the ball. That was Harrington Gates of the Dartmouth squad, who, after the Yale game, went off to join a little religious group on a farm about forty miles from Hanover.

Following is the text of the speech Thomas E. Dewey delivered last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx: Last week at Utica my opponent took public utilities as an issue of this campaign. Last night on Staten Island he again took up the subject. As your candidate, I accept the challenge.

Trading generally slow on all classes in local markets yesterday except choice and prime hinds and ribs which was fair. Market on pork loins was barely steady to mostly $1 lower; other classes barely steady.

The Army plebes, after trailing through the first half, rallied in the last two periods to defeat the New York University freshman eleven in Michie Stadium today, 20 to 14. Frank scored for the New York team in the opening period and the Violet held its lead in the second quarter when Chada scored on a pass to offset a plebe touchdown scored by Hatch.

Two Communists filed in Circuit Court today a $250,000 suit alleging libel of the Communist party by The Chicago Tribune. The suit, directed against the Tribune Company, Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher, and Edward S. Beck, assistant editor in chief, was based on an article aphearing in Sunday's edition of The Tribune.

Glenairley Rocket, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Gorlock of Barrington, Ill., and handled by Frank Hogan, captured the Derby Stake, opening event today of the eighth annual field trials of the Labrador Retriever Club in the Shinnecock Hills.

Harry G. Bragg, general manager of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, was host yesterday at a luncheon meeting to automobile editors in this area at the Hotel Biltmore. Amendment 3, providing for grade-crossing elimination throughout the State, was endorsed.

Prime Minister Chamberlain carried his "appeasement" policy a step farther yesterday when he won a vote of 345 to 138 in the House of Commons for ratification of the agreement reached last Easter with Italy.

Whipping the Calumet Farm's colt, Bull Lea, among others, 6-year-old Mucho Gusto today won his first New England race of the season in the $5,000 added Aquidneck Handicap at Narragansett Park. He paid more than 12 to 1.
A head-on collision between two eight-oared shells of Columbia and Manhattan on the Harlem River yesterday disrupted the annual Columbia Bangs Cup freshman regatta.

A strike of 120 office workers of the Eastern Steamship Lines, begun last Saturday, was called off yesterday after three days of negotiations between officers of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, which called the walkout, and J. L. Bernard, mediator for the Maritime Labor Board, who came here from Washington on Monday.

The greatest immediate opportunity for extended commercial use of silver is in the field of coatings or linings for containers, according to the seventh progress report of the Research Project on New Industrial Uses for Silver, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The thirty-six senior proctors at Barnard College were guests of honor at a tea, given yesterday afternoon by the student council of the college, at which they received silver keys of the college seal.

Following is the text of the address made by Governor Lehman last night at a Democratic campaign rally in Jamaica High School, Queens: The government of the State of New York is a vast and complex business organization. It ministers to the needs of 13,000,000 people.

The general index of retail sales, as compiled from composite figures for twelve lines of business, gained 16 per cent in September over August but was 3 per cent lower than In September, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

William Green today endorsed Representative James M. Mead, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate short term, from New York. Mr. Mead's record in the House toward labor was 100 per cent favorable, Mr. Green wrote George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor.
CECIL BEATON'S NEW YORK, by Cecil Beaton. (Lippincott, $4.) A record of impressions. CHALLENGE TO THE READER, edited by Ellery Queen. (Stokes, $2.50.) An anthology of detective stories.

A blunt warning was given today by the Senate Campaign Investigating Committee that if preliminary evidence of padding of lists of voters in Hudson County, New Jersey, was "substantiated by further evidence" from its investigators, the winner of the Senatorial election in that State probably would be called upon to face the "tribunal of the Senate" before he could take his seat.

Having recovered from frightening the nation over the radio, Orson Welles is now turning his attention to frightening an audience inside the Mercury Theatre. He is doing it deliberately this time in a tingling revival of Georg Biichner's "Danton's Death," which finally opened last evening.
The fact that the St. Louis Browns change managers quickly has not deterred at least fourteen candidates for the job, including Babe Ruth.

Lippincott will publish soon a new edition of Eugene Young's "Looking Behind the Censorships." It will contain a chapter in which the author takes up the happenings of Europe since the publication of the book last Spring and will include the partition of Czechoslovakia.

Al Hostak's physician said tonight the middleweight fighter probably would be unable to box for three or four months as a result of injuries he suffered last night in a fifteenround bout with Solly Krieger of New York.

A revamped New York University football team went through a hard two-hour workout yesterday at Ohio Field with a scrimmage featuring the activities, and from all appearances Coach Mal Stevens will have a revised line and backfield facing Lehigh on Saturday at the University Heights campus.

Financing to cover the cost of experimental transatlantic flights preparatory to the establishment of a permanent airline to connect the United States with European and African points will be undertaken soon through the sale of stock by a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers, it was announced yesterday.
Six new members were elected to the council of the Authors Guild at the guild's annual meeting yesterday afternoon at Midston House, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Declaring that the proposal would save "years of litigation" that might cost holders of defaulted mortgage certificates "hundreds of thousands of dollars," counsel for holders of certificates of the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company and for the State Mortgage Commission consented yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to the plan of Louis H. Pink, Superintendent ,of Insurance, for an immediate settlement of the certificate holders' trust claims for $1,000,000.

Chairman Dies of the special House committee investigating un-American activities called a surprise session of the committee today for 2 P. M. and then as surprisingly called it off after newspaper men had gathered at the hearing room.

Poland occupies a peculiar and somewhat privileged position in the present European situation, but not the key position, as might have appeared at first sight and as the Poles are-or were-inclined to think.

Mayor La Guardia, in a speech last night declaring Britain was honor bound not to go back on the promise to Jews implicit in the Balfour Declaration, digressed for a brief attack on Adolf Hitler reminiscent of his much-discussed "Chamber of Horrors" speech on March 3, 1937.

Mrs. Constance Spry, who created the flower decorations for the marriage of the Duke of Windsor, opened a shop at 62 East Fiftyfourth Street yesterday under the name of Constance Spry, Inc. Mrs. Spry, who has been in the artificial flower business in London's Mayfair for eight years,

Plans to petition the National Labor Relations Board for a vote on unionization by the 20,000 employes of the Endicott Johnson Corporation were announced today by Joseph O'Boyle of Endicott, a shoe worker.

Japan in a formal statement published today announced her aim to coordinate-politically, economically, culturally and otherwise--China and Manchukuo in the Japanese scheme of things and advised other nations to "adapt their attitude" accordingly. A Foreign Office spokesman expressed dislike of Western "colonies" in Africa as well as Asia.

Statements filed with the clerk of the House of Representatives today disclosed strong union financial support for two American Labor party candidates opposing incumbent Democratic Representatives in Greater New York.

Aside from the election of a Governor, two Senators, members of the House of Representatives and various State officials, the people of this city will be called upon next Tuesday to choose between certain candidates for judicial office.

Thomas E. Dewey made unexpected appearances at two women's gatherings yesterday afternoon and encountered his mother, Mrs. George Dewey of Owosso, Mich., at the first of the two-a tea at the Hotel Roosevelt sponsored by the Thomas E. Dewey Non-Partisan Committee.

Syracuse cross-country runners scored a double victory over Army today, the varsity harriers winning, 25 to 30, and the freshmen by a 15-to-40 score. Southard and Cavileer of Syracuse ran a dead heat in the varsity race, finishing about twenty-five yards in front of Schellman of the cadets.

BECHTEL, JENNY C. (Oct. 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Carl F. Ahlstorm, brother, executor, residue; Carl F. Ahlstrom Jr., Norwalk, Conn., and William Ahlstrom, 410 Park Ave, nephews, $1,000 each; one specific bequest.

Dr. William Lowe Bryan, president emeritus of Indiana University, has sent in his resignation as a trustee of the Carnegie Foundation and. will attend his last meeting of the foundation in New York Nov. 16, he said today.

Twelve alleged members of an investment trust ring and five corporations were named defendants yesterday in a fourteen-count indictment returned by a Federal grand jury charging mail fraud and conspiracy.

Delegates to the Hadassah convention, closing their meetings today, paid tribute to their "No. 1 boy friend," Eddie Cantor, signed a petition to President Roosevelt and re-elected their national officers. The petition urged the President to use "his good offices to keep open the doors w of Palestine to large-scale immigrationn"
Samuel Seabury will make his first speech of the campaign at a meeting tonight at the Manhattan Opera House under the sponsorship of the New York County Republican Committee.

Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Building and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will speak today on the effects of low-rent housing at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. Charles G. Meyer, chairman of the chamber's committee on housing, will present a report on suggested Amendment 4 to the State Constitution.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, assailed District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican 'candidate for Governor, yesterday as a "wanton mudslinger" and charged that Mr. Dewey had personally appeared in Federal court as the defender of stock swindlers.

Thomas E. Dewey, at Advertising Club luncheon, WMCA, 1:15 to 2 P. M. Richard B. Scandrett Jr., Republican candidate for Representative at Large, WABC, 4:30 to 4:45 P. M. Charles Poletti, "Campaign Issues," WEVD, 4:45 to 5 P. M.

President Roosevelt has approved the report of a Marine Corps selection board recommending four officers for the grade of brigadier general of the line-Colonels Clayton B. Vogel of Pennsylvania, Calvin B. Matthews of Tennessee, Holland M. Smith of Alabama and Philip H. Torrey of Utah.

The city's Fusion administration came out strongly last night for adoption of the Constitutional Amendment No. 9, providing for extending the city's debt limit by $315,000,000 so that the city may purchase the I. R. T., the B. M. T. and the elevated lines.
The first meeting of representatives. of the Polish and German Governments to decide the fate of Polish Jews resident in Germany and those already deported to Poland took place here this afternoon.
Attorneys for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation objected today to details of a recapitalization plan of the Pittston Company, which leases coal mines in Pennsylvania from the Erie Railroad.

Francis P. McQuade of 175 Riverside Drive, for the last sixteen years editor of Drug Topics, weekly paper for retail druggists, and editor for the last twelve years of Drug Trade News, a trade paper for manufacturing druggists, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J., at the age of 63.

James A. Spriggs, one of the greatest of circus clowns, died here last night at the age of 65. He had served with the Hagenbeck circus and Ringling Brothers. He retired ten years ago. Mr. Spriggs was the first to caper in the make-up of Jiggs, the George McManus newspaper cartoon character.

One hundred and fifty members of the "Old Guard" from the home office of the America Fore Insurance and Indemnity Group attended the annual dinner last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The "Old Guard" is made up of those who have served twenty-five years or more with the American Fore companies.

Again pledging his services to the State for four full years, if reelected, Governor Lehman told the garment industry yesterday that he had never allowed political interests to sway him and had never been influenced by the lure of any office than that of Governor.
Gold in the amount of $2,390,000 was engaged in England yesterday for shipment to the United States, it was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank here.

The Spanish civil war was brought to Britain's doorstep this afternoon by a naval engagement within ten miles of the Norfolk coast. Rushing to the tops of cliffs at the sound of gunfire, Cromer coast guards saw through a North Sea haze the 5,649-ton freighter Cantabria,

Export orders have been lost and imports have been curtailed because of the uncertainty and confusion over progress of this country's negotiations with Great Britain over a reciprocal trade agreement, the American Tariff League declared yesterday in an open
Saying that he would have voted for Governor Lehman for United States Senator, Dudley Field Malone declared last night for District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor.

Negotiations for a new GermanRumanian trade agreement began here today. It is understood that the German delegation is offering Rumania a barter agreement for the exchange of German manufactured products against Rumanian oil and agricultural products.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 31: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Potter, J. E., Med. Corps, Naval Hospital, Puget Sound, Wash., in January, to headquarters 13th Naval Dist.

Broadening even further than at first was expected, the New York Stock Exchange's proposal for capital requirements for members, the committee on floor procedure, it was revealed yesterday, is now holding conferences with individual specialists regarding their requirements of capital.

Ten Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church have resigned on account of advanced age or physical disability, members of the House of Bishops of that denomination reported here today. Their resignations were accepted.

George P. Merrick of this city, attorney for the Santa Fe Railroad and other large corporations, died tonight in a health resort at Winnetka, Ill., of heart disease after a short illness. His age was 76. Mr. Merrick was born at Manteno, Ill. He worked his way through Northwestern University, received a law degree in 1884 and had been a member of the bar since 1886.
The Federal Housing Administration is considering a new type of housing, designed to meet the needs of persons in the lower income group not heretofore assisted by Federal projects.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has agreed to become honorary chairman of the 1940 American Olympic women's track and field committee, it was announced yesterday. As President Roosevelt is honorary president of the American Olympic Association, this will be the first time both heads of the Executive family have been officials of an American Olympic squad.

Commission resident buyers expressed their conviction yesterday that their operations are within the Robinson-Patman act and expressed surprise at the charges alleging violations filed with the Federal Trade Commission by the United Millinery Salesmen, a union affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Leni Riefenstahl, a plumber's daughter who became a German film star and has been considered one of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's few woman friends, was said today to have left last Saturday for New York to launch her film of the 1936 Olympics.

189th St, 690 E (11-3090); 1,131 Elder Ave Corp to East River Savings Bank; extends mtg to Nov. 1, 1943, at 3 per cent; $105,000. Weeks Ave, 1,761 (11-2796); Congregation and Talmud Torah Beth Hilell, Inc, to Z. V. Holding Corp, 570 7th Ave; installments, $10,000.

Judge William Clark of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals deferred today the signing of a formal decree restraining Jersey City officials from interfering with civil rights and incidentally made it clear that the plaintiffs were the victors in the suit which Mayor Hague had disputed in statements immediately after the decision was handed down.

The Park Association of Westchester County requested the County Park Commission today to appoint without further delay a successor to Hermann W. Merkel, the commission's general superintendent, who died six months ago.

Wertheim Co. have exercised an option issued in the name of Charles B. Nolte to buy 10,000 shares of the Crane Company for $100,000. The unexercised balance of this option, originally for 50,000 shares, is 23,000 shares. Mr. Nolte is president of the Crane Company.

99th St, 10 W; Bonded Municipal Corp to Larpeg Realty Corp, 55 5th Av; purchase money mtg, $15,000 ($1). 172d St, 642-4 W; 172d Properties, Inc, to Jacob Bloch, 810 W 183d St; mtg $65,000 ($16). 19th St, 406 W; Commercial Checkers Lyceum, Inc, to Emily M. Keller, 113 W 23d St: mtg $8,000 ($3.50).

R. H. Marwin Company, Inc., as principals, have sold to the Elbrig Realty Corporation, Elizabeth Goldstein, president, the twenty-four family apartment house. at 125 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, for $20,000 cash above a purchase money mortgage of $30,000 taken back by the seller.
Powell Crosley Jr., president of the Crosley Radio Corporation, announced yesterday the official change of the corporation's name to the Crosley Corporation.

George A. Williams, president, until a year ago, of the Williams Record Company, a steel-equipment concern with offices in New York, died here today in his home at the age of 65. He was born in the United States consulate at Havana, where his father, Ramon O. Williams, was consul general.
Louis Fitch, a Montreal lawyer, was elected tonight to represent Montreal-St. Louis in the Quebec Provincial Legislature as a member of Premier Duplessis's National Union party.

Captain George Gallagher, in charge of the Brooklyn Homicide Squad, yesterday afternoon urged 2,000 students at the Thomas Jefferson High School, Dumont and Pennsylvania Avenues, Brooklyn, to help the police in their effort to capture the thugs who robbed and murdered Thomas J. Hitter, a uniformed fireman, on Monday in front of the firehouse of Engine Company 290, at 482 Sheffield Avenue, near the school.

Oblivious to the current furore over an "invasion of Martians," the World's Fair announced yesterday that a "city" inhabited by weird creatures suggesting the reddishhued planet would be an entertainment feature.
Installation of Edwin Sharp Burdell as director of Cooper Union, Cooper Square, 11 A. M. Speakers: Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Dr. Karl Compton.

Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff of 860 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of Princess Kaplanoff's daughter, Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, to James Abercrombie de Peyster, son of Frederic Ashton de Peyster of New York and of the Countess Bohdan de Castellane of this city and Menton, France..

Pioneering services introduced into agencies of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities by women in recent years were described yesterday by Mrs. Richard Percy Limburg, 1938 campaign chairman of the women's division of the two groups. She spoke at the first rally of the division's fund-raising campaign at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

Allan S. Haywood, president of the C. I. O. State Industrial Union Council, sent a telegram yesterday to the heads of all local C. I. O. unions calling on them to work for the election of Governor Lehman and all his running mates on the American Labor party ticket.

New Jersey is modernizing its "navy." State Purchasing Commissioner Brodesser announced today that the Blue Heaven, built last year at a cost of $37,500 for the late W. W. Trimpi of Newark, has been bought for $23,000 with funds provided by the United States Public Health Service.

All of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's plan for modification of interest charges and extension of maturities of its bonds and notes except that relating to an extension of the road's $72,771,578 indebtedness to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. It must now be submitted to the affected bondholders.

Although William Blake, British artist, poet and mystic, was so neglected by his contemporaries that he was buried in an unmarked grave, his fame is such now, more than a century after his death, that one of his works, "Europe, A Prophecy," brought $13,000 at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

The Greenwich Orchestra and soloists will present a piano concerto of a series this evening at the Federal Music Theatre. Arnold Eidus, young violinist, will be guest artist today at the luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund at the St. Regis Roof.

The trial of Robert Irwin, arrested in June of last year and charged with the murder of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and Frank Byrnes, a boarder in the Gedeon home at 316 East Fiftieth Street, will be transferred from the Criminal Courts Building to the Supreme Court Building, it was announced yesterday.

A Savoia-Marchetti S-81 bombing plane, damaged by anti-aircraft fire during last night's second raid over the Catalan coast, was forced to land soon after midnight at Santa Cristina del Aro, on the coast about fifty miles north of here.
Conscientious citizens who have pretty well trained themselves to say Netherlands instead of Holland, and under no

Some sort of a record for crossing the Hudson River must have been set by portly Steve Owen, coach of the football Giants, early last night. The big fellow was moving fast toward Jersey City, for which he was bound, in an effort to secure an end to replace Will Walls.

Governor Lehman will probably carry his city but lose the county as a whole by about 2,500 votes, according to information here. Enthuiastic Republicans say that District Attorney Dewey will carry the county by 5,000 votes, and equally Enthusiastic Democrats assert that the candidates will just about break even.

President Roosevelt returned to his family home tonight as "a voter of New York State" prepared to make a personal appeal by radio Friday night to voters in the State and nation for the election of representatives pledged to support the New Deal administration.

In reply to a recent campaign assertion by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, that "murder is safe in Brooklyn," William F. X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County, declared yesterday -that Mr. Dewey either "was ignorant of the real facts or he uttered a deliberate lie.

The regular campaign of the National Hockey League will start to- t night, with games listed in Chicago and Toronto. In the Windy City the New York Americans will help the world champion Chicago Black Hawks usher in their season, while in Toronto the fast and youthful Maple Leafs will play host to the Boston Bruins.

The Rockefeller interests control at least 50.38 per cent of the stock of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation, a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and available at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday shows.

The officials of Baldwin Township (Pa.) School District yesterday awarded a new issue of $300,000 of bonds to a banking group consisting of E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and Singer, Deane Scribner, Inc.

Extracts from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement on the AngloItalian agreement in the House of Commons today follow: Since we made the agreement with Italy on the 16th of April last I am glad to think there are no differences between our two countries.

Governor Lehman charged last night in a campaign speech before a Democratic rally in Jamaica High School, Queens, that Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, had shown himself an enemy of civil service by demanding abolition of competitive positions in his own office when he became District Attorney of New York County last January.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 1: MAJOR GENERAL Reed, W. L., the inspector general, one-day leave, Nov. 2. BRIGADIER GENERALS

No official reply has been received to the American note of Oct. 6 demanding an end of Japan's interference with our trade in China. But yesterday's statements by the Japanese Government and the Foreign Office spokesman are clearly intended as an answer to Washington and to other Governments whose interests have been flouted in the Japanese invasion.

Kentucky's 10-year-old child bride, Rosie Columbus Tackett, was ordered to an orphanage today by a six-man hill country jury. At the urging of County Judge Hill and a court-appointed attorney, the girl's mother, Mrs. Grace Columbus, made an "X" on a legal paper giving the court the right to put Rosie, who was married last week to 34-year-old Fleming Tackett, coal miner, in the Children's Home at Lyndon, near Louisville.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, here tonight to speak for the election of W. Warren Barbour, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, made, as he termed it, "one final appeal" to the whole American electorate to vote for the retention of the American system of free institutions and free economy.

Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, said tonight that utility rate reductions during Governor Lehman's administration had saved consumers $46,000,000. In an address at a Warren County Democratic club gathering, Mr. Graves urged Lehman's re-election. Praising his labor policies, he said:

Queen Wilhelmina today visited an exhibition of paintings by William H. Singer arranged on the occasion of his seventieth birthday at Laren, the Dutch painters' village where the American artist and his wife usually pass the Winter. Summers they go to Norway, near Bergen, most of Mr. Singer's works being inspired by Scandinavian scenes.

Thousands of people in this city paid tribute yesterday to B. Charney Vladeck. But perhaps the tribute which would have meant most to him was paid on Tuesday when Senator Wagner, Mayor La Guardia, United States Housing Administrator Straus, Commissioner Rheinstein and Controller McGoldrick sat down on a woodpile at Red Hook and composed the differences which have been holding up slum clearance in this city.

Leon G. Turrou testified yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox at the espionage trial that Dr. Ignatz Griebl, key man of the German espionage ring in New York, who escaped to Germany, threatened to have Johanna Hofmann, one of the defendants, shot when he was told she had confessed, implicating him.

Mayor La Guardia and former Governor .Alfred E. Smith united last night in urging public support of the housing amendment at the election next Tuesday, declaring that. State aid is a necessity if decent housing is to be provided for low-wage earners. They spoke under the auspices of the Citizens Housing Council-from radio station WABC.

That Dartmouth relies on the second team for the Dickinson game here Saturday was made further evident today when again all attention centered around the reserves, while the regulars merely ran through a signal-drill on Memorial Field.

An appeal for aid to the 1938 Community Campaign of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York was made yesterday by Peter Grimm, general chairman, at a meeting of district and divisional chairmen at Cavanagh's Restaurant, 258 West Twenty-third Street. The foundation seeks 25,000 adult "sustaining members" at rates of $1, $5 or $8.

Chairman Harry R. McLogan of the Wisconsin Pension Department said today he would report to Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board in Washington, that Governor La Follette used a departmental list of old-age pensioners' names for political purposes.

In an unprecedented referendum on Long Island, taxpayers of the town of Huntington will vote next Tuesday on whether WPA projects should be discontinued after Dec. 31. The controversy concerning the WPA as a method of providing jobs is overshadowing all other issues in this township of 28,000 persons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So much has been said by Mr. Straus and Mr. Rheinstein about the cost of housing that I am afraid the original and fundamental purpose of slum clearance has been lost sight of. I do not intend to be drawn into the controversy whether State funds or Federal funds should be used for slum clearance and housing projects.

Ben Smith's fine all-around work against Princeton and the speed and power he showed in today's varsity scrimmage resulted in his regaining his old job as Harvard's starting fullback for the game Saturday with Chicago.

Detectives investigating the kidnapping and murder of Arthur Fried, 32-year-old executive of the Colonial Sand Company, discovered early this morning two human teeth, after having found earlier in the night several bones of undetermined origin, a German machine gun in a sinister, bullet-riddled secret chamber, and a liquorcutting plant in the basement of Ukrainian Hall, 217 East Sixth Street, where Fried's body was said to have been cremated in a furnace.

The Federal Communications Commission declined today to rule officially on the right of orchestras to "swing" the classics, but urged that broadcast licensees use "a high degree of discrimination" in their treatment of that type. of composition.

With 500 National Guardsmen ordered to concentrate here tomorrow morning to protect this community from what Governor Martin L. Davey termed "an armed invasion" by the C. I. O., the Pioneer Tobacco Workers Union decided tonight to call off its month-old strike at the P. Lorillard tobacco plant.

Pig iron production for October, according to The Iron Age, is estimated at 2,054,000 gross tons, based on reports which were gathered by telegraph on Nov. 1. This compares with 1,680,435 tons in September.

In the midst of the rapid changes which take place in Manhattan, even in periods of dull trading, it is refreshing to pause and consider the large number of properties, particularly in the older sections, which have been held by the same families, through good times and bad. for a century or more.

Joseph Uihlein of Milwaukee, former vice president and now part owner of the Schlitz Brewing Company, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that in 1924 he had advised Arthur V. Davis, chairman of the board of the Aluminum Company of America, to buy James B. Duke's power interests in Canada.

All 394 stalls in the basement of Madison Square Garden have been reserved, it was announced yesterday by Manager Ned King as preparations neared completion for the opening of the annual National Horse Show on Saturday.

Gilbert Pi (10-2762A), n e cor of Hunts Point Ave, 108x51; Morris Holstein to Huntlone Realty Corp, 1,450 B'way; mtgs $77,500. Clarke Pi (11-2839), s w cor of Walton Ave, 109x95; Hillview Realty Corp to Lena Malzman, 115 McClellan St; mtgs $163,200.

Harrington Gates of Saugus, Mass., listened tonight for an hour to the pleadings of his family and the Chief of Police and Superintendent of Schools of his home town, and then asked for time to decide whether he should return to Dartmouth College, not as one of its football stars but as a young man determined to enter religious life.
Italy hinted today that she was ready to take down her barbed-wire defenses erected along the eastern Libyan frontier with Egypt just before the invasion of Ethiopia in 1935.

George O. Everett, assistant vice president of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica, N. Y., was chosen today president of the Financial Advertisers Association of America by delegates in their annual business meeting here.
According to reports in Confessional Church circles, the Rev. Martin Niemoeller is beginning to suffer pronounced mental depression as a result of his long imprisonment and waning hope of release.

Evidently there are some big bears in Maine, and unless the guides up there have begun to grossly overestimate size and weight, Robert Ellinger of New York City stands a good chance of holding the 1938 record.

The Republican caravan made its final campaign effort outside of New York City in a speedy swing through the normally Republican territory of Orange County today. Candidates spoke at seven town rallies, winding up with a torchlight procession to the City Hall here, where a crowd of more than 1,000 persons heard issues discussed from the balcony over a loudspeaker system.

Little demand for exemptions or exceptions from the Wages and Hours Act has been made by shoe manufacturers, and there has been little call for haste in the formation of an industry committee, Jay O. Ball, president of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, asserted in a statement issued yesterday.

The following film programs, to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public annd private elementary and high schools:

A plan of advertising which embraces specific cooperation with dealers and sales personnel was advanced last night by H. B. LeQuatte, president of H. B. LeQuatte, Inc., advertising agency, as themost urgent present need of sales management. Speaking at a dinnermeeting in the Hotel Astor of 800
War notes-military scrip-are appearing in great quantities in the Yangtze Valley areas held by Japanese troops. The notes are almost the only money in Kiukiang and are already appearing in Hankow.

The appointment of 123 students enrolled as commissioned officers in the advanced courses of the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, Professor of Military Science and Tactics. Roy T. Huntington was named cadet colonel, highest rankink officer in the student corps.

The Liam Holding Corporation sold to an investing client of Arthur D. Goldstein the five-and-a-halfstory apartment house for twentytwo families at 792 East 175th Street, the Bronx, for cash over a mortgage of $30,000. J. J., Boneparth, Inc., broker in the deal, recently sold the adjoining house at 788 for the same corporation.

Averaging $58,975,000 per week for the four-week period, major engineering construction awards in October aggregated $235,898,000, the highest monthly total since June, 1937, and the highest October total since 1929, according to Engineering News-Record. The October weekly average was 2 per cent higher than that of the five-week September and 26 per cent higher than that of October, 1937.

Despite reports almost as terrifying as those that came out of loudspeakers recently when the hobgoblins from Mars played preHalloween pranks, Head Coach Lou Little and his Columbia football warriors appeared calm and collected yesterday as they went on with their preparations for the Virginia game on Saturday.

Preparing for the unusual running and passing plays used by North Carolina State, Coach Herb Kopf sent the Manhattan eleven through a hard offensive and defensive scrimmage yesterday. The freshmen, who had been equipped with the Wolfpack alignments served as opposition to the first-stringers.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and subsidiary companies report net profit for the nine months ended on Oct. 1 of $2,606,158, equal to $1.53 a share, compared with $3,053,417, or $1.79 a share, in the 1937 period.

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 12, bringing dividend distributions for 1938 to $2 a share, compared with $10 a share paid in 1937.

A merit rating plan that will give safe automobile drivers in New York State a 10 and 15 per cent differential in bodily injury and property damage insurance rates was approved yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent.

That home run that Manager Gabby Hartnett of the Cubs hit in the dusk of Sept. 28 not only did its bit in toppling the Pirates out of the National League pennant race but crashed the catcher into a "hall of fame" niche all his own.

The first general price advance on rugs and carpets in about fifteen months was announced, yesterday by three leading producers, to take effect Nov. 15. An advance of 5 per cent was made by Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., covering its complete line. Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., and A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., announced increases of indefinite extent, but it was believed that these also would be 5 per cent.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Levey of this city and Merrick, L. I., formerly of Minneapolis, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Edith B. Levey, to Leon J. Cohen of New York and San Francisco. The wedding will take place on Nov. 27 in San Francisco.

Germany's fortifications on the western frontier will be "wholly completed before the beginning of Winter," according to Major von Wedel, chief of the press section of the army high command in the current issue of the command's magazine, Die Wehrmacht.
Entirely new generic names will be developed for each weave construction produced with nylon, the new fiber to be produced by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., it was learned yesterday.
The undefeated Brooklyn College junior varsity football team scored its third victory yesterday afternoon, conquering the St. John's University Football Club, 12-0, at Brooklyn's field.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman was the overwhelming choice over District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey in the race for Governor in polls announced yesterday by student publications at Columbia University and at the Washington Square center of New York University.

Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black will give a dinner at the Pierre on Dec. 17 for Mrs. Black's debutante daughter, Miss Ethelette Tucker. Mrs. Alton Brooks Parker has returned to 116 East Fifty-sixth Street for the season.

President Lazaro Cardenas today decreed the expropriation of about 100-acres of irrigated land, believed to be coffee property, from an American, Charles Miller. The property is situated near the town of Ometepec in the State of Guerrero.

Robert Virovai, 18-year-old Hungarian violinist, will make his American debut this evening at Carnegie Hall as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony, John Barbirolli, conductor. Mr. Virovai will play the D minor concerto of Vieuxtemps; the rest of the program will consist of the Sinfonia in A by Boccherini, played for the first time by the Philharmonic, and the Sibelius Second symphony.
With the fanfare of opening day and the War Admiral-Seabiscuit race past, the Maryland Jockey Club's stakea-day meeting at Pimlico settled down to a normal tempo today.

Manhattan 3d Ave, 1,671-77, 32.8x22; for 1-story gas station; Junior Ehret Corp, 51 Chambers St, owner; H. Kron, architect; cost, $5,000. Alterations 8th Ave, 2,359; to 5-story tenement and stores; Joseph Shaid, 2,558 8th Ave, owner; C. B. Cali, architect; cost, $8,000. 16th St, 53 W; to 4-story furnished rooms and store; Eva Rosenberg, 301 W 13th St, owner; M. Whinston, architect; cost, $3.000.

99th St, 10 W, 25x100.9; Larpeg Realty Corp to Bonded Municipal Corp. 55 5th Ave; p m, due on demand, 6 per cent; $15,000. Amsterdam Ave, 481, 25.8x100; also Amsterdam Ave, 200, 20.5x65; also Columbus Ave, 269-75, 50x102.2; Thomas Kelly to Just TradingCorp, 204 E 23d St; prior mtg, $207,000, due Sept. 29, 1939, 6 per cent; $3,500.

The State Department reported today that nineteen more persons had registered as representatives of foreign principals, bringing the total on Nov. 1 to 191. The new registrants, mostly advertising or commercial agents, included these from New York:

A Democratic estimate of the lowest plurality Governor Lehman can possibly get in New York City, made yesterday, was very close to a Republican estimate of the maximum New York City plurality that may be expected for the Governor.

The country's outstanding football players, as well as its high-pressure industrial executives, may credit their achievements largely to possession of an oversized coeliac ganglion, or "abdominal brain," said Dr. George W. Crile of Cleveland today in an address before the Interstate PostGraduate Medical Association of North America.

The Guaranty Trust Company yesterday advised holders of Republic of Panama thirty-year 5 1/2 per cent external secured sinking-fund bonds due on June 1, 1953, that it had on hand funds sufficient to permit payment of coupons that were due on June 1, last; and would be ready to make payment from today on.

The proposed eighth amendment to the State Constitution is purely permissive. It will enable the Legislature, as need arises, to place the necessary money and credit behind a broad humanitarian' program. It should be distinguished from the section of Amendment No. 1 which ordains that "the protection and promotion of the health of the inhabitants of the State" and "the aid, care and support of the needy are public concerns."

Unless Senator Bailey of North Carolina is reflecting merely his own views in a recent statement, a formidable group of Democratic Senators will return here bent upon taking relief out of politics and drastically strengthening the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.
On his own application (to take effect 12 midnight, Oct. 31): LIEUTENANT--George P. Lang, 15th Division, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Dec. 2, 1908.

Mrs. Mildred Adams Hosmer of Denver was married today to Harold Kingsmill, vice president of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation of Peru. The ceremony was performed at the home of Alvin P. Adams, uncle of the bride.

In another extended scrimmage today nearly all the Yale regulars were on the attack against the Grays for three-quarters of an hour and then received an equal amount of time on the defense, testing Brown's plays in the last contact work before the Bruins come to the Bowl Saturday.

Coach Andy Kerr spent most of today's practice session drilling Colgate's Red Raiders on the passing attack that will be used against the Syracuse eleven in Syracuse on Saturday. Three backs were alternated in tossing to receivers.

The United States Weather Bureau yesterday issued its weekly report of crop conditions, as follows: Moderate temperatures and continuous fair weather made another ideal week for picking and ginning cotton,

Benefits to the consumer, distributor and manufacturer of textiles would result from "really informative advertising, informative signs and fully informed salesmanship in retail stores," Harold W. Brightman, vice president and general merchandise manager of L. Bamberger Co.,

After her engagement with Fred Astaire in "The Castles," Ginger Rogers will be featured in "Little Mother," by Buddy De Sylva. The film will be produced by the author; it replaces "Perfect Honeymoon" and "She Married for Money" on Miss Rogers's schedule at RKO. The story is described as a melodrama which deals with an unmarried girl who adopts a foundling.

British interests have intimated that they may construct an oil pipe line 1,000 miles from Calgary, Alberta, to Vancouver, B. C., if they find that potential oil supplies in the Turner Valley in Alberta justify it, the Department of Commerce reports.

Funeral services for B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party leader and member of the City Council, who died Sunday evening, were held yesterday in the auditorium of The Jewish Daily Forward, 175 East Broadway, of which he was the manager for twenty years.

Joe Louis will make the next defense of his heavyweight championship of the world in New York on Jan. 27. The Detroit Dynamiter agreed yesterday to risk his crown against John Henry Lewis in a 15-round bout at Madison Square Garden under the promotion of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club
The sum of $325,000 will be sought by the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, in its forthcoming roll-call, according to an announcement yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr.,

An investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, has purchased the three-story apartment at 166-68 Jewett Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., from the Unix Holding Corporation. There are twelve suites of two and three rooms in the house. Insley, Decker Cross were attorneys for the buyer and George Clott acted for the seller.

The directors of the Aetna Life Insurance Company have voted dividends to policyholders to be paid next year at a somewhat lower scale than those the company has been paying in the last three years, it was announced yesterday.

Seabiscuit, king of the turf but no pampered darling of the paddock, will keep right on running after a pot of gold bigger than Sun Beau's record of $376,744 and is willing to race all comers to get it.
Luis Anderson left today for Lima, Peru, to attend the meeting of the commission of experts on international law opening there Nov. 9 in preparation for the Pan-American Conference in December.

Charles H. Weeghman of New York, former owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball club and former Chicago chain restaurant owner, died today in the Drake Hotel, at the age of 64. He suffered a stroke yesterday afternoon.

While admitting there had been some abuses under the Wagner law, William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, endorsed it tonight as an instrument of "genuine industrial democracy." He and Senator Lister Hill of Alabama spoke at a rally of Middlesex County Democrats in the Knights of Columbus Hall here. Senator Hill is the third Administration stalwart to speak for Mr. Ely's election.

The necessity for negotiating an Anglo-American trade treaty that will be "fair to loth sides" was stressed by Oliver Stanley, President of the Board of Trade, last night in replying to questions in the House of Commons about the progress of the treaty.

Opposition to the proposed constitutional Amendment 1, particularly the section which would permit the Legislature to provide transportation for children attending church schools, was expressed yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.
The War Department released the following orders today dated Nov. 2. COLONEL Alfonte, W. A. Inf., Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to home and await retirement.

The Presidential address of Kemal Ataturk to the -National Assembly today disclosed that Turkey, which controls the strategic Dardanelles, has prepared a large program of naval reorganization. The address was read in the absence of the President, ill with a liver complaint.

Jerome A1vord Peck, an attorney in New York and Westchester for the last fifty-four years, died of a heart attack this afternoon while putting on the fourteenth green at the Apawamis Golf Club here. He was 75 years old and his home was on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club in Harrison.

George T. Bunten, retired carpenter, who fifty-eight years ago was the first constable of this community, died tonight at his home at the age of 87. Born in Stanwich, Conn., Mr. Bunten came to Montclair sixty-four years ago.

For the second time this week the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities canceled a scheduled hearing, this time because Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, again begged off from appearing at this time.

The necessity for extending the Y. W. C. A. services in the city in preparation for the World's Fair was emphasized by speakers at a luncheon given yesterday by the organization at the Hotel Biltmore. About 400 volunteers in the budget campaign for $205,000 attended.

The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee disclosed tonight that it had additional evidence of coercion of WPA workers in Pennsylvania and gave details of the reports of its investigators as an answer to the recent denial of Aubrey Williams, Assistant Administrator of the WPA, that such a state of affairs existed.
High army officials and representatives of Harvard University attended today the unveiling of a statue of Artemas Ward, First Commander in Chief of the army in the war for independence.

The Senate Campaign Investigating Committee's statement that it had "preliminary" evidence of wholesale padding of vote registration lists in Hudson County drew the fire of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City yesterday, while the county's Superintendent of Elections and Commissioner of Registration issued contradictory statements as to which would know of fraudulent registration and- voting, if any.

Owing to the inclusion of heavy first-of-the-month settlements in this week's total, bank clearings rose above those of the preceding week. Year-to-year comparisons are also somewhat distorted due to the fact that the election day holiday occurs one week later this year than it did in 1937.

Harris Berlack, member of the socalled Lehman bondholders' protective committee, which is. sponsoring a plan of reorganization for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Coxe that he hoped that the Postal's land lines, after reorganization, would earn enough income. to pay dividends on its securities.

Mrs. Maggie Holloway Fisher, film pioneer and once leading lady for Nat Goodwin, Henry Miller and William Faversham, died today at the age of 84. Inactive since she retired from the screen in 1922, she had been living here on the verge of blindness caused by studio lights.
Sydney E. Martin Jr., University of Pennsylvania student for whom a search had been made for six weeks, was found working as a vacuum cleaner salesman in Richmond, Va.
Directors of the Gatineau Power Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock.
The entire Italian press today is enthusiastic over the arbitration of the HungarianCzech controversy- by Count Galeazzo Ciano and Joachim von Ribbentrop, the Italian and German Foreign Ministers.
Administration of vitamin K, isolated only two years ago, was credited today with having saved many lives since then by stopping hemorrhages following gall bladder operations.

The American Red Cross is undertaking to relieve suffering among Czechoslovaks made homeless by German occupation of the Sudetenland. Five thousand Christmas boxes, filled by American school children with boys' knives, dolls, candy, soap, toothpaste and picture postcards, were shipped to Czechoslovakia yesterday.

A dramatic suicide from the center of Europe's longest bridge was made known here tonight. A. J. Borcher, 46 years old, the engineer of a streamlined- train, stopped it right at the center. of the recently dedicated span over the Little Belt.

It is to be hoped that the interesting plan of a differential in favor of safe drivers, announced for New York by the State Insurance Department, will prove an added stimulus to maintain the year's fine record of reduction in highway deaths.

With Columbia's game against Virginia at Baker Field tomorrow, originally scheduled as a "breather," looming as a hard, close battle, Lou Little drove his Lion squad at top speed in yesterday's drill in an effort to build a stanch defense for the Cavaliers' vaunted attack.

In rurtherance of cooperative effort by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the public utility holding companies, William O. Douglas, chairman of the SEC, has sent a letter to the heads of the utility holding companies assuring them that any tentative plans filed for compliance with Section 11 of the act will be treated as confidential unless the companies agree to their publication.

With the largest citrus fruit crop on record in Florida beginning to arrive 'in New York City markets, oranges and grapefruit fell in price this week to unusually low levels. Oranges are down to less than 2 cents each, according to the citywide average prices computed by the Consumers' Food Guide of the Department of Markets.

Executives of the major railroads will meet here' tomorrow to make a final decision on the 15 per cent reduction in wages set for Dec. 1. It is believed likely that the railroads will withdraw the wage-cut order. They were urged to take this step by the fact-finding committee appointed by President Roosevelt, which made its report last week.

Engineering and optical instruments previously imported from France and Germany will be made in this country by Charvoz, Inc., of 185 Hackensack Street, East Rutherford, N. J., formation of which was announced yesterday.
Members of the junior committee of the Yorkville Dinner Dances were entertained at a luncheon given yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton by their chairman, Mrs. Edward Mathews Latham.

C. Grant Keck, head of the realty organization which bears his name, has purchased the Angell house at 104 Knollwood Avenue, Douglas Manor, in Douglaston, L. I. The residence, in Spanish style, is one of the landmarks in the community, having been built thirty-two years ago for John Woodruff.
The garage at 23-25 East 134th Street has been leased by Olga J. Hilliard to Adolph Thenstead for use of taxicabs. J. P. McCann and Butler Baldwin, Inc., were the brokers.

Colgate's football team was sent through its last hard workout today for the Syracuse game, with Coach Andy Kerr giving the players final instructions about the forward pass defense formation that he hopes will stop the throwing of Sidat-Singh, Syracuse ace.
The will of Mrs. Aureau Balseiro Georgetti, widow of Eduardo Georgetti, once one of Puerto Rico's richest sugar producers, was read in court today. It left approximately $2,000,

Clifford W. Smith, formerly general foreign manager of Electrical Research Products, Inc., was appointed yesterday general manager for the West Coast, a new post in which he will have jurisdiction over all activities of the company in Hollywood.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman accused Thomas E. Dewey last night of "hypocrisy" in charging that he and other Democratic Governors of New York State had condoned crime and corruption and said he was willing to place his own record of law enforcementmade without "fanfare of publicity"--against that of the District Attorney of New York County.

A powerful Boston defense and offense coordinated tonight to mow down the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, in their National Hockey League opener. All three Bruin goals were tallied by defense players as 10,000 fans looked on.

The State started an investigation today of alleged illegal registration in Rochester. Acting on challenge affidavits issued by police authorities, Donald J. Corbett, Deputy Attorney General, moved to check on complaints.

Mrs. Roland C. Hall gave a lunchon today at Kenilworth, her home here, for members of the Junior Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, at which plans were made for the Thanksgiving dinner to be given for the children of the nursery, located at 249 East 117th Street, New York.

Thirteen corporations, members of the Lead Pencil Association, Inc., who allegedly produce more than 90 per cent of all the wood-cased pencils made in the United States, were charged by the Federal Trade Commission today with fixing and maintaining uniform prices for their products.

Automobile traffic on a "peak day" throughout the State decreased 10 per cent compared with 1937, despite a general increase in automobile registrations, John A. O'Donnell, senior civil service engineer of the State Highway Department, said today.

Two lines of Ford cars for 1939 go on display this morning in showrooms throughout the country. They are the Ford V-8 and the De Luxe Ford V-8. Both,. for the first time this year, have hydraulic brakes.
Whether the New York City schools will provide sex education in junior high school children remained unsettled yesterday. Educational authorities have split on the question.
The Provident Institution for Savings sold the six-family flat at 146 Wilkinson Avenue, Jersey City, to the Hex Realty Company, taking back in part payment a purchasemoney mortgage for $6,000.
After running second in his last two starts, Forever Prince, owned and trained by R. C. Groff, today won the Lexington purse, mile and 70-yard feature for 3-year-olds and up at Narragansett Park.
The Riviera was shocked today when police discovered what seems to have been the suicide of an American resident following the "mercy" murder of his wife.

The Farm Credit Administration today announced appointment of Dr. Thomas G. Stitts, formerly in charge of research and service work in the cooperation division in dairying, to head a new subdivision of cooperative research and service of the division of research.

The frequent squabbling of Newbold Morris, President of the Council, and James J. Lyons, Bronx'Borough President, at Board of Estimate meetings reached a more threatening plane yesterday when Mr. Morris, after a stormy interchange, promised that he would bounce Mr. Lyons out of the Bronx the next time he ran for office there.

Sharply criticizing those factories which closed because of reported Inability to pay the 25-cents-an-hour minimum required under the new law, Mayor La Guardia yesterday expressed the hope that the Wage and Hour Law will create greater employment.

The Spanish Insurgents' armed motor ship Nadir, which yesterday shelled and sank the Spanish merchantman Cantabria off the Norfolk coast, was seen speeding down the English Channel today, apparently en route to Spain.

While Fordham's first and second elevens deployed on offense, then took a turn defending against St. Mary's plays as executed by the freshmen yesterday in an intense three-hour workout on Fordham Field for tomorrow's game, a new arrival entered the Rose Hill gridiron picture with considerable fanfare.

The Refugee Economic Corporation, which was organized by the late Felix M. Warburg and associates to help Jewish emigres from Germany and other countries to become self-supporting, has renewed its registration of a $5,000,000 stock issue with the Securities and Exchange Commission at Washington but has no plans for offering the stock to the public at this time, Charles J. Liebman, vice president and a director of the corporation, said last night.

Harold S. Vanderbilt, three times defender of the America's Cup and twice victor over T. O. M. Sopwith in cup matches, is likely to race against him in twelve-meter yachts in English waters next Summer. The "twelves" are much smaller than the America's Cup ones but still are large yachts.
Police Chief Filinto Muller disclosed today that the police had frustrated a plot to assassinate President Getulio Vargas last Sept. 7-Brazil's Independence Day.
Nazis arrested nine Serviten monks and "a great number of other citizens of Innsbruck" today in resumption of a drive against alleged immorality among monks.

It may sound like a paradox, but N. Y. U.'s Violets are not blue. Not even after the Ohio State game last week, in which the Buckeyes were charitable and beat them only 32-0 when, according to observers, it might have been worse.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Major Edmond H. Levy and Capt. Clinton F. Robinson, Corps of Engineers, having been detailed for duty with the Organized Reserves, Second Corps Area, in addition to their other duties at New York,. N. Y., are assigned to duty as Assistant Instructors, Engineers Reserve Section, Second Military Area, and will report to the Executive Officer, Second Military Area for instructions.

Webster Ave (11-3143), w s, 196 ft n of 180th St, 33x100, James J. Daly to Charles G. Schildwachter, 2,097 Webster Ave. mtge, $13,500. Tenbroeck Ave (16-4367), w s, 200 ft s of Astor Ave, 33x100, Schapowal Construction Corp to Bridget M. Tierney, 2,328 Eastern Blvd.
The University of Pennsylvania is the newcomer on the University of North Carolina's 1939 football schedule, announced tonight by Athletic Director R. A. Fetzer.
Ralph A. Butler, Deputy Superintendent of Buffalo Public Schools and presilent of the Empire Outdoor Advertising Company of Rochester, died ast night. He was 51 years old.

Having pleaded guilty to charges of kidnapping a; valuable Boston bull terrier and holding it for "ransom," Mrs. Gladys De Boe, 30 years old, and Charles Lawrence Jr., 26, both of 807 Nassau Street, Bellmore, were sentenced to jail by District Judge Lent today.
