Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban army, has accepted an invitation from the Cuban Chamber of Commerce in New York to attend a dinner in his honor Nov. 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Lawrence Berenson, president of that body, announced here tonight.

With Germany demanding the unconditional return of all colonies and other foreign footholds lost as a result of the World War, there is the liveliest curiosity here as to what is Japan's attitude in view of the Tokyo-Berlin axis.
The Pennsylvania varsity squad of thirty-four players, led by Captain Walter Shinn, left tonight for Ann Arbor, where Michigan will be met in the teams' seventeenth game on Saturday.

Yale will present a revamped eleven against Brown here Saturday. Captain Bill Platt, tackle and center; Al Wilson, halfback, and Gilbert Humphrey, quarterback, still ailing from the grueling Dartmouth battle last Saturday, are unlikely to see service against the Bruins.

Big Bill Edwards, captain of the Princeton football team in 1899, was honored last night at a dinner of the Touchdown Club at the Princeton Club. Eight other members of his team were present. They were L. R. Palmer, Williamson Pell, W. C. Booth, Professor Howard R. Reiter, Edmund S. Burke Jr., Dr. George Lathrope, Marshall Mills and Stephen McClave..

Mrs. Edith Williams of 2 Independence Place, Ossining, reported to Yonkers police today she was robbed of $48 this afternoon by two bandits in a black automobile who forced her car to the curb on North Broadway, took the money from her purse and tossed the bag back to her before they fled.

The New York County grand jury voted its first batch of indictments yesterday in the annual investigation of registration frauds. The number of bills voted was not revealed at the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, but it was reported they involved men and women who falsely registered last month in polling places in the Sixth and Twelfth Assembly Districts on the lower East Side and the Seventeenth and Nineteenth Assembly Districts in Harlem.

With the near approach of the end of the account, the stock markets here were irregular today and business continued to be restricted. The undertone, however, was firm, and there was some investment buying of giltedge issues, among which the War Loan led the general improvement. Austrian and German issues were weaker among the foreign bonds, although Czech securities again were higher.

The establishment of his headquarters in Hankow was announced today by General Shunroku Hata, Commander in Chief of the Japanese Army in the Yangtze Valley. In an interview given to foreign newspaper men, General Hata said his headquarters would remain here so long as military operations warranted.

Edward L. Grimm, retired president of the Peerless Marine Motor Company of Buffalo, N. Y., and builder of racing hydroplanes, died today at his home here at the age of 59. He was builder and owner of the racing hydroplane Miss Peerless, world's record challenger.

Reports that the New York Joint Nov Liquor Conference, formed last light Spring to stabilize conditions in the corn liquor market here, will disband at an early date circulated through R the industry yesterday.
The Japanese Government's note breaking off all relations with .technical. organizations of the League of Natons was published by the League Secretariat today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that its operating telephone subsidiaries had a net gain of about 53,000 telephones in service during the first nine months of this year, compared with a gain of 47,000 in the corresponding period last year.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing on Nov. 22, at Boston, on a petition by the Stock Exchange in that city for authority to delist the consolidated mortgage 5s of 1945 of the New England Railroad Company.

The Ministry of Colonies issued a decree today forbidding the importation of foreign wheat into French colonies. A report accompanying the decree in the Official Journal said this measure would provide a market for about 3,670,000 bushels of French wheat a year.

Railroad stocks were taken in hand yesterday and these shares, as a group, made their best showing in several weeks. The stock market as a whole finished irregularly higher, and the days volume on the Stock Exchange was 1,065,000 shares, compared with 783,000 the day before.

A court order directing executors and trustees of the $10,000,000 estate of John E. Andrus of Yonkers, manufacturer and financier, to resume the distribution of trust fund income to beneficiaries will be sought here tomorrow by John E. Andrus Jr. of Daytona Beach, Fla.

New York State Board of Housing meeting, Hotel Astor, 9 A. M. Luncheon 1 P. M. Address by M. P. Catherwood. Afternoon session 2 P. M. Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11:30 A. M. "Current Events," George Earle Raiuel. .

In a sweeping condemnation of New Deal policies, John J. O'Connor, candidate of the Republican and "Andrew Jackson" Democratic parties to succeed himself in Congress, last night replied to the questions put to the candidates for the United States Senate on the editorial page of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

With the foregoing changes, yesterday's statement of the Bank of France, which represents its actual position at the end of last week, compares as follows with reports for previous weeks, in millions of francs:

An employer may not average a fortyfour-hour week for his employee over a period of two weeks, according to an opinion of the legal division of the Wages and Hours Administration, made public by A. L. Fletcher, assistant administrator, in replying to a Maryland macaroni manufacturer who asked whether it would be possible to base the weekly limit of forty-four hours upon a two-week period making a total of eighty-eight hours.

A Federal housing program on a sufficiently extensive scale to eliminate every New York City slum in ten years will be one of his prime objectives, if elected, Edward F. Corsi, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared last night in a speech broadcast over radio station WABC.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ended its hearings today in the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway reorganization proceedings. Oliver Sweet, finance director of the commission, called for briefs by Jan. 9.

Their arms clasped in death, the bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Chadwick, each 59, were found today in their automobile, parked in a wood road. They had ended nearly forty years of married life in suicide by carbon monoxide poisoning. Their Scottie dog was lifeless beside them.

The open all-age stake of the Labrador Retriever Club, held in the Shinnecock Hills near here today, was won by Nigger of Barrington. This champion retriever of the year, owned by Gordon P. Kelly of Lake Forest, Ill., was handled by Francis Hogan.

Realty and trade organizations appear to be about evenly divided, pro and con, on the proposed Amendment 4 to the State Constitution providing for State aid and a $300,000,000 bond issue to promote slum clearance and low-rent housing.

New York City takes another step toward putting its financial house in order with the publication by the City Planning Commission of the proposed capital budget for the year 1939 and the capital program for the succeeding five calendar years.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion...decreased [pound]53,000 Reserve in bank'g dept.,

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition to Reorganize ROCKLAND COUNTRY CLUB, Sparkill, N. Y.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter X of the Chandler Act, listing liabilities of about $160,000, including a bond issue of $141,000, and assets of $154,523. The debtor is a membership corporation of which J. Du Pratt White is president. A plan of adjustment will be submitted later.

Storm Jameson has been elected to succeed H. W. Nevinson as president of the P. E. N. Club. She is the first woman to hold this office. Miss Jameson's new novel, "Here Comes a Candle," is announced for publication in January by Macmillan.

Controller Morris S. Tremaine, Democratic candidate for reelection, asserted last night in a radio speech that he had saved many municipalities from serious financial difficulties during the depths of the depression by investing State funds in their securities when no private buyers were available and by advising them of steps they could take to rehabilitate their fiscal affairs.

Details of Mexico's policy at the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, starting Dec. 9 are being developed at a series of secret meetings between those selected as delegates and high officials at the Foreign Office.

The beginning of a new cycle of livestock production in which supplies of cattle, hogs and sheep will increase was predicted today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in a series of surveys on the annual farm outlook.

The "unholy alliance" between political judges and the criminal element in Brooklyn was vigorously attacked by Mayor La Guardia last night as he made a strong plea over WOR for five independent judicial candidates.
Today's statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday showed that the bank's ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 50.88 per cent, against 51.17 previously.

The entire German press, radio and semiofficial correspondences are today celebrating the excellence and justice of the historic Vienna arbitration verdict that Joachim von Ribbentrop and Count Galeazzo Ciano, the German and Italian Foreign Ministers, rendered on the Hungarian-Czech dispute, the triumph for the Rome-Berlin axis that it represents and the gain for peace expected from it.

Dollar volume of 2,646 independent men's clothing and furnishings stores, which had aggregate sales in 1937 of $130,637,000, were 16.7 per cent below 1937 in the first half of 1938, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, reported today.

Mrs. Eleanor Lane Mingle Bainbridge-Bell, well known actress of forty years ago, died in the home of her cousin, Mrs. Alden March, 606 West 116th Street, yesterday morning after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

It begins to look as though we may have to wait quite a while for excess bank reserves to go above the record of $3,304,000,00 reached on Dec. 11, 1935. A week ago, with the figures already close to that high point, it was predicted confidently by experts in the subject that a new record would be made;
Dr. John Lawrence Yates, practicing surgeon in Milwaukee since 1907, died at his Fox Point home today at the age of 65. He had been sick only since Monday.

Harold M. Kennedy, Brooklyn attorney, was appointed yesterday to the staff of John Harlan Amen in the investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn. Mr. Kennedy's was the third appointment to be made by Mr. Amen since his designation by Governor Lehman as special prosecutor to supersede District Attorney Geoghan.

A compilation of registered voters in the forty-eight States, made by The Associated Press, gives a total of 54,324,930 who are eligible to cast ballots on Tuesday. The same agency forecasts after a nation-wide survey that about 40,000,000 will go to the polls.

Following a statement that he would rather "go down to defeat than be elected by any votes based on race or religion," Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, made a speech on the "rights of the individual" in which he attacked the Administration of Governor Herbert H. Lehman at the Manhattan Opera House last night.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, at a luncheon at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday which marked the inauguration of its Fall fund-raising campaign, announced that it sought $150,000. The chief subject discussed was the debut performance of the Ice Follies to be given Nov.

Dr. and Mrs. Frederic C. Paffard have presented to Yale University the Jonathan Edwards family manuscripts and portraits, in carrying out the provisions of the will of Eugene P. Edwards of Stonington, Conn.

MANHATTAN BRETT, BRIDGET M. (Oct. 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gertrude King, Elizabeth King and Frances K. Murrary, cousins, all of 3,591 Bainbridge Ave.. Bronx, $1,000 and one-sixth residue each; Grace Barrett, friend, 555 W. 186th St., $2,000 and one-sixth residue; Elizabeth Guilfoyle, cousin. 560 W. 144th St..

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Nov.-1 Were announced today: Roberts, Radio Elec. C. E., Headquarters, to Radio Corporation of America, Camden, N. J., for inspection duty, Nov. 5.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company has exercised its option to purchase 98,000 shares of class B common stock of the American Cyanamid Company at $20 a share on Oct. 31, officers of the latter company said yesterday.

Football is going historical. Last week Army and Notre Dame observed the silver jubilee of the game in which a couple of Lochinvars answering to the names of Knute Rockne and Gus Dorais appeared unheralded on the plains of West Point to sell the United States Military Academy a new,
C. B. Warren was erroneously listed as the seller of Journey's End, 125-acre estate on Journey's End Road, Yorktown, Westchester, in a deal reported by brokers yesterday.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 4005--Lucas Kyrides v. Herman A. Bruson. Argued for appellant. No oral argument on behalf of appellee.

A concert in the piano concerto series sponsored by the Federal Music Project was given last night at the Federal Music Theatre by the Greenwich Orchestra, under Joseph Littau, with Ellen Edwards, Lydia Hoffman Behrends, Sylvia Smith and Earl Maiman, pianists, as assisting artists.
With the exception of the United States Treasury obligations, which were soft, almost all classes of bonds rose quite briskly in more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

New York horse show enthusiasts will have an opportunity this morning to get-a view of Canada's most noted cavalry regiment, the Royal Canadian Dragoons, who will participate every evening and at the four holiday matinees In a pieturesque precision ride to music as one of the leading features of the National Horse Show, which will open tomorrow morning in Madison Square Garden.

More than 350 travel agents attended a dinner last night on board the newly reconditioned American Republics liner Argentina, which sails tomorrow on its first voyage to Rio de Janeiro, Montevideo and Buenos Aires.
Operating without either Captain Bob MacLeod or Bill Hutchinson, the Dartmouth varsity was sent through its first scrimmage of the week today.

The exhibition of paintings by Paul Lewis Clemens, the first New York show of his work, at the Walker Galleries, has been extended through Nov. 12. Maynard Walker, director, announces that nine pictures have been sold during the first two weeks of the exhibition The Clemens exhibition will be followed by a show of paintings by Hobson Pittman of Philadelphia.

The concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, introduced a young violinist of 18, brilliantly gifted, who, on the occasion of his American debut made an immediate and very favorable impression upon the audience.
John E. Devany, a telephone engineer associated with the Bell Laboratories for forty-two years, died yesterday at his home, 1,844 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 60.
Mrs. Alice H. Whaley, 33 years old, of 1,104 Broad Street, Newark, was arraigned today before Common Pleas Judge Edward A. McGrath here on an indictment charging atrocious assault and battery.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday registered its official judgment on six of the nine proposed constitutional amendments for the guidance of its members on election day. It was silent on the others.

Representative James M. Mead defended yesterday the administration of President Roosevelt from charges that it had created a "super-Tammany" through the establishment of Federal jobs exempt from civil service regulations. The merit system has always made greater gains under Democratic than under Republican national administrations, he said.
A new by-law placing responsibility for all advertising literature upon a partner of a firm has been approved by members of the Montreal Stock Exchange.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 71.6. The figure was 75.3 for the preceding week, and 70.9 for the week ended Oct. 30, 1937.

If Newfoundland permits the salmon-fishing public to see the movies taken by Lee Wulff, showing the salmon jumping the falls of the Humber River, there is going to be a steady stream of anglers headed into that area next year.

The Appellate Division refused in a unanimous decision yesterday to stay the payment of fines imposed by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo upon four pickets and the business manager of the Window Trimmers Union, Local 144, in sentencing them for criminal contempt of court for violating his injunction against picketing stores of the Busch Jewelry Company.
A transposition of registrations of agents of foreign principals at the State Department led yesterday to the erroneous listing of several.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, indicated today that the commission would be prepared for public hearings early in January on certain phases of its study of insurance companies and within three weeks or a month for such hearings in connection with solicitations of proxies from stockholders if the monopoly committee,

Turpentine firm, 231/2c; sales, 70 barrels; receipts, 167 barrels; no shipments; stock, 50,002 barrels. Rosin firm; sales. 125; receipts, 922; no shipments; stock, 278,924. Quote: B, $3.95; D, $4; E, $4.25; F, S4.85; G. H. I. K, M, $5.071/2; N, $5.50;
Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 29 exceeded purchases by 146,969 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

An appeal to graduates of New York University for $100,000 to cover a number of "specific pressing needs" this year, including books, scholarships, classroom equipment and continuation of medical research, was made last night by Dr. William M. Patterson, '93, chairman of the university's Alumni Fund.

Ted Balko of Redwood Falls, Minn., won the 1938 national cornhusking championship today. The 33-year-old Minnesotan, who was credited with husking 22.24 bushels during the eighty-minute contest, was more than three bushels short of the 25.78 bushels by which he had previously won the national title in 1934 at Fairmont, Minn.

Letters to several hundred retail trade boards and chambers of commerce throughout the country urging that retailers delay their seasonal clearances until after Thanksgiving Day will be sent out today by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board. No specific date will be mentioned in the request, but the board feels that Thanksgiving Day should the earliest time for clearances to start.

World deliveries of coffee in the first four months of the new-crop year, including July and October, were estimated at 8,936,209 bags, against 7,400,621 in the same period of 1937, an increase of 1,535,588 bags, of 20.7 per cent, according to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Entertainment in advertising has become so important that no large corporation, for reasons of dignity or ethics, can afford to disregard it, William M. Day, chairman of the advisory board and vice president of J. Walter Thompson Company, yesterday told a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Roosevelt. As an example, he said the largest coupon response that his agency ever received came from a comicstrip advertisement.
In the presence of a distinguished group of scholars Dr. Leonard Carmichael will be inaugurated tomorrow as seventh president of Tufts College, from which he graduated seventeen years ago.
The goat mascot of the United States Naval Academy became involved today in an investigation by monopoly experts of the Justice Department.

The Pacific Public Service Company, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of California, announced yesterday that the former intends to reclassify its capital stock. The terms call for conversion of 300,000 outstanding shares of second preferred stock into 60,000 shares of first preferred stock and 280,000 shares of common stock.

The entire blockfront on the south side of East 149th Street, between Austin Place and Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Dollar Savings Bank to the 900 East 149th Street Realty Corporation.

Harold Valan, 13014, Brooklyn, the outpointed Al Ragone, 128%4, Green- ceiwich Village, in the star bout of eight rounds on the boxing program which marked the reopening of the Jamaica Arena last night. A crowd of 2,500 was present.
It cannot be said that with the installation of Dr. Edwin Sharp Burdell as its director Cooper Union enters upon a new phase of its honorable career. In his thoughtful and
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 3 unless specified: Ponta Delgada to Gibraltar: Badger, Jacob Jones.

Senator Robert F.. Wagner and the American Federation of Labor are in "absolute accord" on amendments to the National Labor Relations Act, George Meany, president of the New York State Federation and chairman of its Non-Partisan Committee, declared last night in a radio speech. Mr. Meany did not enumerate any changes in the act which had been agreed upon.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. M. Abbott Van Nostrand of Forest Hills, Queens, on Tuesday at the Lying-In Hospital, Mrs. Van Nostrand is the former Miss Jane Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alexander of Cleveland. The child will be named Pamela.

The Duke of Devonshire warned tonight that the empire must be populated. "If we do not populate our empire within a reasonable time, it will become weaker, more envied, and in a far more dangerous position than it is.,today," the Under-Secretary of the Dominions told the Society for Overseas Settlement of British Women.
The government defeated a motion of censure by a vote of 41 to 28 in the House of Representatives this evening after twelve hours of debate.

In the presence of prominent educators and college presidents, Dr. Edwin Sharp Burdell, former Dean of the Humanities at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was installed yesterday as director of Cooper Union.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 4: PATROLMEN-John J. Dolan, from Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, to 109th Precinct, assignment to duty with Midtown Squad, discontinued. John Curry, from 23d Precinct to Traffic D.

Miss Sally Rand, fan and bubble dancer, was convicted on two counts of assault and battery by a municipal court jury today in connection- with an attack upon Ray Stanford, a candid camera photographer and Miss Hazel Drain, his young woman companion.

Coach Charhe Caldwell spent a large part of today's practice at Williams working out a plan for protection of punt receivers. The team captain and safety man, Larry Durrell, and his understudy, Hary Potter, were catching the ball, while the other backs and the line fell back for interference.
The two apartment houses at 89-91 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the National City Bank to an operating syndicate which immediately resold them to the Annrow Realty Corporation.

Members of the service and maintenange staffs of the Frederick Loeser Co. department store, at 484 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, went out on strike yesterday in a walkout called by nine. A. F. of L. unions for higher wages, working hour adjustments and union contracts.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed his concurrence today with the views of Oliver Stanley, Britain's President of the Board of Trade, when he said yesterday in discussing the pending Anglo-American reciprocal trade agreement that he desired a "treaty which will give advantage to both and be biased toward none."

The economio implications for Northern States involved in the application to the Interstate Commerce Commission by eight Southern States for a lowering of rail freight rates on northbound products which involve industrial competition between the North and South were set forth in a brief filed today with the I. C. C.

A luncheon was given yesterday for Mrs. Robert L. Livingston by her daughter, Mrs. John W. Delafield, in the Oval Room of the RitzCarlton. The other guests were Mrs. Arden Morris Robbins, Baroness Foucaucour, Mrs. John Ross Delafield, Miss Sylvia de G. Livingston and Miss Catherin McCann.

New York State collected 78 per cent more in unemployment insurance taxes in October than it paid out in benefits, an analysis of the monthly report of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department disclosed yesterday.

The week's awards for engineering construction, totaling $71,013,000, are 216 per cent above the figure for the corresponding week of last year, when $22,427,000 was recorded, The Engineering NewsRecord reports.

Several legal problems in the estates of Colonel Henry H. Rogers and that of his father, Henry H. Rogers Sr., were settled yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley approved' a compromise settlement among the executors and trustees of the estates and the legal guardians of heirs.

Public bequests exceeding $400,000 were left by Mrs. Eleanora Iselin Kane of New Rochelle under her will filed today in Westchester County Surrogate's Court. She was the widow of Colonel De Lancey Kane and a daughter of the late Adrian Iselin, New York banker. She died Oct. 22.
The Philadelphia Inquirer Company and E. Z. Dimitman, city editor, were indicted by the October grand jury today on a contempt of court $5 charge.

Commercial loans of local banks fell $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new low level for recent years, it was disclosed yesterday in the weekly statement of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City. Meanwhile, brokers' loans continued to advance.

Harrington K. Gates departed tonight from his hilltop retreat in the colony of the Legion of God after spending four days in meditation over his resignation from Dartmouth College and the football team, on which he starred as a back.

Sweeping gains last week in all important in- fused to dustries and substantial increases in originating freight shipments lifted business in the Pittsburgh district to a new high level for the year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

For the second time within a month, scheduled examinations in the New York City school system for high salaried jobs have had to be postponed because of insufficient interest on the part of prospective candidates.
The English Wholesale Cooperative Society, Ltd., is preparing a scheme for the opening of a limited price variety chain for submission to the retail cooperative societies.

The Old Colony Trust Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the release of the following securities from the collateral held by it as trustee under the consolidated refunding mortgage of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company:

The California Democratic State Committee made public tonight a letter from President Roosevelt in which he said that regardless of his opposition to the $30-everyThursday plan, he considered it of national importance that Democratic candidates be elected in the State next Tuesday.
A new television device designed to aid department store sales promotion was announced yesterday by the American Television Corporation. The device,

The round of festivities arranged in connection with the National Horse Show, which begins tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, was inaugurated here yesterday with parties given for officers and committee members for the. show, exhibitors and others actively associated with the eight-day horse show program.

Mrs. Charlotte P. Johnson, wife of Paul E. Johnson, died here last night at her home at the age of 41. A native of New York, Mrs. Johnson was the daughter of Mrs. Lucia Phillips and the late Dr. Wendell C. Phillips, a surgeon who formerly was president of the American Medical Association.

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., chief city magistrate, announced yesterday that an increase of $414,980 in fines, or 41 per cent, had been collected in the traffic courts of the four boroughs under his-supervision in the first ten months of this year.

THE AMERICAN WOMAN'S COOK BOOK, edited by Ruth Berolsheimer. (Culinary. Arts Institute, $2.50.) A new edition. ART CRITICISM FROM A LABORATORY, by Alan Burroughs. (Little, Brown, $6.) An account of the use of X-rays in the study of paintings and in the detection of their forgeries.

Vince Pimpinella, 149, Red Hook, scored easily over Felix Garcia, 143, Harlem, in the main bout of ten rounds last night at Prospect Hall in Brooklyn. The victor staggered his rival on several occasions with lefts and rights to the head and body.

An Investigation by the WPA has failed to disclose any factual basis for Representative John J. O'Connior's charge that relief workers in his district were being coerced into voting for his New Deal opponent, James H. Fay, it was announced last night by R. C. Branion, field representative in New York and New England of Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator.

Harvard today continued its drive for Saturday's football game with Chicago, the first two teams spending more than one and one-half hours in a defensive drill against passes. The scouts have reported the Maroons' tosses as being particularly dangerous.

William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, asserted in speeches here tonight that thousands of Republicans and independents in New Jersey were flocking to his banner because of the "reactionary record" of his opponent, W. Warren Barbour. Mr.

Navy's chances in the Notre Dame game Saturday shrank today when three outstanding backs-Emmett Wood, who leads all his teammates in gaining; Ed Gillette, ranking blocker, and Cliff Lenz, who has been improving as a plunger, failed to appear at practice and were reported as having serious injuries.
ONCE more it looks dark for En fals. Iuss McLaughry has a good Brown team, after some years in the swamp, and the Brown Bears are hungry for a victory over the Bulldog.

Dean Tristram W. Metcalfe of Long Island University announced yesterday classes would be suspended this morning between 10:50 and 11:45 to permit the students to vote on whether or not they favor the return of football.

Declaring that "United Hospital Campaign workers are setting an example for the community in the support of the 'voluntary health agencies," C. M. Chester, chairman of the campaign committee, announced yesterday a contribution of $50,000 from Mrs. Charles S. Payson, 'co-chairman of the women's division.

The Commonwealth Edison Company announced today plans for the sale of an additional $59,300,000 of new securities. Part of the proceeds will be used to finance the construction of additional electric generating capacity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was a shock to me to read Henry L. Stimson's letter in THE TIMES of Nov. 3 on the New York Senatorial candidates. Mr. Stimson reminds the public that he is president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Their confidence bolstered by decisive victories over Brooklyn College and Lowell Textile, twenty-four City College football players will take the boat to Providence today. Tomorrow they will play Providence College, and for the first time in four visits to Providence the Beavers are rated an even chance to win.

A fund of $850 was raised last night at Vassar College by an entertainment for the benefit of refugees in Czechoslovakia. The performers were Miss Christine Ramsey of the Department of English, Clair Leonard of the music faculty, Alan Porter, assistant professor of English;

Secretary Ickes today reiterated his belief that the government should have the power through control of oil production to safeguard petrol'eum' reserves for national defense and the use of future generations.

Disposal of forty-one decommissioned stations by sale, lease or return to original grantors was ordered today by the Coast Guard as part of a program to increase efficiency of land station life-saving work and decrease the maintenance costs.

Forty-two trade associations and organizations affiliated with the paper industry were asked yesterday by George G. Cobean of Chicago, president of the National Paper Trade Association of the United States, Inc., to organize and attend a conference to consider unemployment in the industry, government intervention and what might be done cooperatively to relieve the unemployment situation.

Frank M. Parrish, general solicitor of the claims bureau of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives and formerly a special assistant to the United States Attorney General, died of meningitis on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital after a ten-day illness that commenced with a cold and developend later into a sinus infection.

Secretary Ickes expressed the belief today, based on his recent tour, that President Roosevelt was "stronger than ever" in the West. "That is not to say that there are no cross-currents out there," he added.

Henry St, 293, Metropolitan Savings Bank to David Geller, 262 Stanton St, purchase money mtg $10,000 ($11.50). Same property, David Geller to Herman Wachtel, 51 Clark St, Brooklyn; mtg $10,000. 97th St, 231 E, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, as liquidator of Mortgage Guarantee Title Co, to Reconstruction Building Corp, 1,819 B'way (50c).

To those primarily interested in politics-and that includes the entire government in Washington-Mayor La Guardia's final alignment in the New York campaign has been one of the most interesting topics of discussion.

Stocks of casings and inner tubes in the hands of distributors on Oct. 1 were at the lowest level recorded in the last three years, according to a quarterly survey of distributors' tire inventories made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
The Federal Reserve Board announced tonight that money in circulation was the largest in United States history, except for the two weeks after the bank holiday declared on March 4, 1933.

Opportunities for increasing trade relations between this country and India were listed by speakers at a dinner given by the Indo-American Association of Commerce last night at the Aldine Club in honor of H. S. Malik, India Government Trade Commissioner to North America.

William A. Oldfield, considered by many to be the best of Australian wicket-keepers, today announced his retirement from first-class cricket. An internationalist, Oldfield celebrated his forty-first birthday on Sept. 9.

Harry Harrison, Penn State's star quarterback, was in uniform today for the first time since the Syracuse game last week. The 150-pound Nittany Lion running ace is expected to be in condition to play, if needed, against Lafayette here Saturday, although Coach Bob Higgins has decided to start his stellar sophomore, Chuc Peters.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for three apartment houses in the Bronx and numerous small dwellings in Brooklyn. Architects also filed for altering structures in Manhattan.

Apparently intending to use a number of reserves against Franklin and Marshall Saturday, Coach Bill Wood excused several Army regulars from practice early in today's session and devoted his time to grooming the second string.

Japan's Foreign Office spokesman disclosed today that Japan considered obsolete the Nine-power treaty, of which the United States is a signatory, guaranteeing the territorial integrity of China, and intimated Japan might denounce it.

Through an error, THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday said that Samuel J. Krinn was Republican nominee for Congress from the Twenty-second district and Arthur D. Fisher and Robert H. Brennen candidates respectively for Congress from the Twenty-third district and for the State Senate from the Twenty-first district.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Nov. 2 were announced today: Howard, Lt. Col. A. F., assignment changed to duty on staff of commander Atlantic Squadron, U. S. Fleet. Phillips, Major C. A., Quantico, Va., to home and await retirement.

Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman last night before a Democratic rally in the Morris High School, the Bronx: Just as I have discussed fully and frankly every phase of State government in this campaign, so tonight I shall discuss law enforcement. I shall not, however,

Eight persons, including a woman and a physician, were indicted yesterday by the October Kings County grand jury in connection with the $427,950 armored car robbery in Brooklyn more than four years ago--the largest cash hold-up in the nation's history.
The American President liner President Adams will sail from Jersey City today for the West Coast and the Far East, marking resumption of the country's only passenger service around the world.

The Daily Mail says it learns on high authority that during the recent crisis the South African Government informed the British Government of its intention to remain neutral as long as possible in the event of a European war.

Ruth Creech Howard, shown by school records to be 12 years old, and her husband, Wilburn Howard, 60, were in the hands of the law today. It was the second legal action concerning a child-bride taken in Kentucky in little more than a week. Rosie Columbus Tackett, 10,

Tennessee, seeking to "modernize" the treatment of its convicts, will abandon prison stripes and lashings as disciplinary measures. Great Cate, Institutions Commissioner, said "discipline cells" would be installed instead.

Dissatisfied with the showing of some of his letter men, Coach Glen Harmeson lined up the Lehigh varsity with sophomores in most places for a long defensive scrimmage against the freshmen and junior varsity, who were groomed in New York University plays.
Auburn's football squad will remain without the services of Stancil Whatley and Max Harrison, stellar flankmen, for the remainder of the season, the two players said today.
Death Announced Retired Lieutenant Charles F. Douth, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 130, residing at 1.745 North Alvarado Street, Los Angeles, Calif., died Oct. 30.

The initial newspaper advertisements In a national campaign sponsored by the League for Fair Trade, Inc., designed to present the "factual story of the chains and to help the public correctly interpret the effect of proposed anti-chain legislation," appeared yesterday in leading Connecticut papers, according to announcement yesterday by R. H. Lee Martin, managing director.

The Quincy, Omaha Kansas City Railroad and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad applied jointly today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a certificate authorizing abandonment of the Q., O. K. C. line between Milan, Mo.,

John Hart McAlarney, assistant treasurer of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., 26 Beaver Street, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in his apartment at the Hotel Wellington, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Mr. McAlarney, who had been associated with the council for several years, had been in charge of arrangements for the twenty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention, which closed its three-day session at the Hotel Commodore Wednesday. His age was 58.

With more cotton being released by growers as a result of the recent advance of about $2 a bale above the government's lending figure, hedging pressure weighed yesterday, on the near months and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended 5 points lower to 2 points higher.
The German passenger and freight steamship Vancouver sank in the Oakland estuary today a few minutes after a tremendous explosion had torn a gaping hole in her starboard side.

Walter Huston and Nan Sunderland, actors, "Governor Lehman and Governor Stuyvesant," under auspices of the women's division of the Independent Citizens Committee for Election of Lehman and Poletti, WABC, 11 to 11:15 A. M.

Ninetytwo dental supply wholesalers' establishments, which accounted for 52 per cent of the total sales of all houses specializing in this business in 1935, the latest year covered by a regular business census, had a dollar volume in the second quarter of this year 18.7 per cent below the second quarter of 1937, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, announced today.

Robert E. Lancaster, securities dealer who has been sought for three weeks by the police, was arrested yesterday by local authorities in Orlando, Fla. At the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., where this information was received, it also was revealed that Lancaster was indicted last week by the New York County grand jury for grand larceny.
Miss Sarah accounted for today's Mocking Bird Valley Purse at Churchill Downs in a driving photograph finish with Friedberg and Axton's Bala Ormont.

The continuing necessity of cooperation between Federal, State and local governments for solving the social and economic problems of the nation was suggested in official circles here today as likely to be the keynote of President Roosevelt's radio appeal tomorrow night for support of the State Democratic ticket.
When the colonial question was raised in the Chamber of Deputies today, Foreign Minister Paul Spaak declared: "The Congo belongs to us. Our rights to it are established, and nobody can contest them."

The Harvard Club, led by Uermain G. Glidden, national champion, captured its second consecu-tive team match in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association interclub Class A series last night, vanquishing the Rockaway Hunting Club team, 5 to 0.

A three-cornered campaign was being made yesterday by the prosecutors of Westchester, New York and Kings Counties for the right to prosecute the three men recently arrested by Federal agents for several crimes, including the kidnapping and murder of Arthur Fried of White Plains.

151st St (9-2441), n s, 200 ft w of Morris Ave, 49x118; Kenwer Operating Corp to Metropolitan Savings Bank; six years, at 3 1/2 to 4 per cent; $9,500. Morris Ave, 2,693 (12-3317); 1,320-28 Grant Ave Corp to Union Dime Savings Bank; extends mtgs to Nov. 1, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent $87,000.
Soaking rains last night and early today effectively broke the Fall drought over a large part of the West and Southwest and resulted in general selling of futures.

Frank M. Gould, eleventh floor in 381 Park Ave; Michael A. McDonald, in 383 Park Ave: Max Meyer. through Pease Elliman, Inc, in 71 E 77th St: Adolph Levy, in 440 Park Ave; Edgar W. Knudsen, in 38 E 50th St; Madison Realty Co, brokers.

Victor Watson, veteran newspaper man and for many years an executive of Hearst newspapers, died yesterday morning when he jumped or fell from an eleventh-floor window of the Hotel Abbey, 151 West Fiftyfirst Street.

The American Dental Association will publish next month a list of products used in the repair of teeth which have been approved by the Bureau of Standards in tests extending over a ten-year period, the bureau announced today.
A 4-year-old boy and an adult entered a ten-day period of suspense tonight to learn whether they would see through the eyes of a Utah slayer who was executed Monday by a firing squad.

Mrs. Catharine Maugham, who was chauffeur for Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig through several battles of the World War and who received three wound stripes, the Croix de Guerre of France and the British Silver Palm for bravery, died here today. She was 52 years old.

The International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $12,850 for the third quarter of 1938, equal to 1 cent each on 924,996 convertible preferred shares, on which arrears, as of Sept. 30, were $5,786,875.

Sidney L. Hellman, a director of Schenley Distillers Corporation, 350 Fifth Avenue, died on Wednesday at Louisville, Ky., after a long illness, officials of the firm announced here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

The noteholders' protective committee of the Haytian Corporation of America has notified all holders of the corporation's 8 per cent notes that it is in substantial agreement with the company's decision to offer the noteholders, under the provisions of the Chandler Act, 60 per cent of the common stock of the company, plus new bonds in the face amount of $333.33 for each $1,000 bond now outstanding.

Howard C. Hopson, former vice president of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, agreed tonight to produce for New York's Public Service Commission the information on his utility interests it sought vainly to obtain from him on the witness stand.

Herbert Marshall, who has not been seen on Broadway since "There's Always Juliet" in 1932, will be returning this season and, in the order of their receipt by this department, here are the latest bulletins on that event: (1)

Private enterprise long ago found tne job of furnishing rapid transit to Greater New York too heavy to perform unaided. As a result a system has grown up under which public funds have been invested in privately operated roads, and these, in turn, have been forced to compete with new subways which are publicly owned and publicly operated.

G. Winthrop Brown, collector of porcelain and early American antiques, and a Boston business man, died today at his home in Chestnut Hill at the age of 74. Mr. Brown was president of the W. A. Wood Company and the Kehem Bradley Company of Boston.

Charging that Federal social security funds were being spent to-pay part of the ordinary Federal deficit, W. Warren Barbour, Republican Senatorial candidate, asked his Democratic opponent today if he approved that practice.

Explaining that it was better to be candid than to conceal the truth, Leslie HoreBelisha, Secretary for War, read to the House of Commons tonight a detailed list of the shortcomings in British anti-aircraft equipment that would have left London almost defenseless if war had broken out last September.

Plans for the match in which Joe Louis will defend his heavyweight championship against John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight titleholder, at Madison Square Garden Jan. 27, were made yesterday in the offices of Promoter Mike Jacobs at the Hippodrome.
Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, implied in an address before the Advertising Club yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had deserted the cause of "good government."
Heavy preparations for Manhattan's intersectional meeting with North Carolina State at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow were brought to a conclusion with a two-hour dummy scrimmage yesterday.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The city of Albany is probably the most politically minded community in the State--first, because of its position as the State Capitol, and, secondly, because it has been dominated for many years by a powerful political machine.

A dramatic midnight race against time by three St. Joseph lawyers saved the life of Oscar Ralph Ashworth, confessed kidnapper, a few minutes before he was to have entered Missouri's lethal gas chamber early today.

Frank Coyle and Ed Linz, home club stars who hold the national championship, met with considerable opposition from J. Rosenman and H. Steinmeyer of the Broad Channel A. C. before triumphing, 21-16, 21-17, in the first round of the New York A. C.'s invitation four-wall handball 'doubles tournament last night on the Winged Foot courts.

In a fireside address to the American people several months ago President Roosevelt said: I am concerned about the attitude of a candidate or his sponsors with respect to the rights of American citizens to assemble peaceably and to express publicly their views and opinions on important social and economic issues.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor of New York, announced in a speech here tonight he had telegraphed a request to Attorney General Homer S. Cummings that he send an observer to a Socialist party rally at Central Avenue and Bowers Street, Jersey City, tomorrow night.

The spectacular rise in President Roosevelt's popularity which followed his peace plea to Hitler last month has been short-lived, according to the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is the director.

Shipments of oil burners in September by 178 manufacturers totaled 26,405, as compared with 15,373 in August and 33,711 in September a year ago, according to figures released today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

In an address before more than 2,000 employes of the garment and fur industries at the Manhattan Opera House, Israel Amter, Communist candidate for Representative at large, accused the Republican State Committee yesterday of having "disseminated anti-Semitic propaganda, which started as a whispering campaign and now is out in the open and has spread throughout the State."

The latest attempt to prove that Bacon wrote Shakespeare's plays-this time by delving around what hitherto had been supposed to be the grave of Edmund Spenser-ended in failure tonight in the immemorial dust of the Poets' Corner of Westminster Abbey.

Trading began today on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange in future contracts calling for delivery in March, 1940. Cotton which ultimately will be delivered on the contracts will not be planted until the Spring of 1939, making one of the longest periods elapsing between sale and delivery in the history of the local Exchange.

The Public Service Commission postponed today to Jan. 1, 1939, the effective date of its order requiring truck operators and brokers subject to the 1938 State Motor Transportation Act to furnish liability insurance on trucks and cargoes.
Harry Reeves, Detroit police officer, made a clean sweep of the South Atlantic regional pistol championship today, winning both the regional and the Georgia State titles.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., today announced that Adolph Zukor, chairman of the board and production chief of the studio, would leave for London shortly to coordinate European production and exhibition.

Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y., will review the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment), N. Y. N. G., at a formal review at 9 o'clock tonight at the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Sales of several houses in Harlem were reported yesterday by brokers. The sellers included a bank, a children's society and a church. A recently modernized apartment house at 227 East 127th Street was sold by. the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Irving Bachrach and Ira Rosenstock, operators.

Mr. George Jessel is going to give us two acres of old New York at the World's Fair. He promises much in little and the picture in yesterday's TIMES of a street in the village which he will construct delights the eye.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation today sold to highest bidders 76,164 of the 107,688 hides and skins remaining from stocks purchased in drought-relief activities. The sales were at prices 1 to 11/2 cents above bids which were rejected on Sept. 8.

The Brooklyn College football team went through a two-hour drill in blocking and ball handling yesterday in preparation for the game with Panzer College. The backs concentrated on running back punts and reverse plays, with Pete Matsoukas as the chief threat.

During the week ended Nov. 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $54,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $52,000,000 in money in circulation and $51,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts,

ONE would not strenuously ask a postman on vacation to rear back and produce a garland of discourses on Plato. Or a sabbatically footloose and pen-free philosopher to take up the postman's burden. So it should come as the mildest of surprises to find Irwin Edman strewing a few crisp and judicious ideas on God, freedom and immortality through the lively pages of his new book.

More friendly cooperation between government and business management and more intensive capitalization of technological progress to achieve a national economy of plenty were advocated by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, in an address here today before the Boston Chamber of Commerce.

Sir John Hanbury-Williams of London, who arrived on the Queen Mary, is at the Ambassador. Mrs. Frank Wheatcroft Frueauff will give a dance at the Pierre Dec. 17 for her debutante daughter, Miss Elaine Storrs Frueauff.
The scholarly Tad Wieman, who handles the fortunes of Princeton football, sat in the window seat at Osborne Field House today and peered at the dark-looking practice field under low-hanging clouds.

Rutgers deserted Neilson Field today and worked in the new stadium, scene of its game with Princeton Saturday. Both the first and second string elevens ran through brisk signal drills, followed by a defensive dummy scrimmage against Tiger plays.

Henry St, 293, 24x77.11xlrreg; David Geller to Metropolitan Savings Bank; p m, 7 years, 4% $10,000. 75th St. 31 W, 20.1x102.2; Clara Malamud to Mae V Sullivan, 20 W 69th St; p m. 7 years, 41/2% and 5%: $10,000. Same property, same to same, p m, prior mtg. S10,000: 7 ears, 41/2% and 5%; $7.000.

The Protestant Episcopal House of Bishops, in its annual pastoral letter, today said that statesmanship and diplomacy, unsustained by Christian convictions, had proved "utterly inadequate" to meet coneditions arising since the World War.

One officer in the Navy Department's board of inspection and survey, which is charged, among other duties, with inspection of new ships, has been transferred and the president of the board, Rear Admiral H. L. Brinser, has requested transfer, it was learned today.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 3,037 telephones in October, compared with an increase of 6,373 installations a year previously. For the first ten months of this year the numerical cumulative net gain in stations was 13,626, against 86,888 correspondingly in 1937.

Appointment of a separate independent industry committee for the knitted outerwear industry under the Fair Labor Standards Act was urged today in a memorandum submitted to a subcommittee of the Textile Industry Committee by Harold R. Lhowe, executive secretary of the National Knitted Outerwear Association.

The directors of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, Inc., have authorized sale of 25,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value, at not less than $4 a share, the New York Stock Exchange has been advised.
Dr. Philip S. Stout, surgeon and otolaryngologist, died in St. Luke's and Children's Hospital today after a month's illness, He was 60 years old.

Edelman Bennett, 29 years old, of 32-86 Thirty-third Street, Astoria, Queens, died tonight in St. James Hospital of injuries suffered yesterday afternoon when he jumped or fell from a moving Pennsylvania Railroad

Miss Elizabeth Cantlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. S. Cantlin of this city and Sea Girt, N. J., was married here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church to Edmond Brehmer Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Bailey of Milwaukee.
American buyers are rushing to get goods out of the Sudetenland before that former Czechoslovak. territory is placed under the higher. tariffs the United States levies on Germanmade goods.

Any comedy in which Hugh O'Connell appears ought to be cheerful and cherubic. He is the somewhat addled clown who, as a police reporter, bobbed and weaved through "The Racket" many years ago with a copy of the American Mercury (Old Style) protruding from his overcoat pocket and pure comedy bubbling out of his wide countenance. In "Run Sheep Run,"

Under the scrutiny of troops ordered here by Governor Davey, the P. Lorillard Company's tobacco plant; resumed operations today after having been closed since Oct. 3 by a strike of the Tobacco.Workers Union of the C. I. O. The strike was called off last night.

Herriman Schnitzer, 48 years old, of the Bronx, died suddenly in an automobile on the WarrensburgChestertown Highway, en route to Glens Falls Hospital. Death was attributed to a heart ailment. Mr. Schnitzer was one of a party of eight men who had been hunting near Indian Lake.

Relief administration should be returned from Washington to the individual localities and every precaution should be taken to insure disinterested and non-political control, John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared yesterday in his daily statement.

Continuance of store leasing was marked yesterday by announcement of one of the highest figures for a retail shop rental in the city. Favorite Drugs and Cosmetics Inc., leased from Simco Investors, Inc., the store at 38 East Fourd teenth Street, in the Spingler-Van Beuren Estates development.

Further gains were made yesterday by the pound sterling and the franc, but the foreign exchange market in general was quiet. No engagements of gold abroad were reported. Imports of $3,661,000 gold were received here, consisting of $1,901,000 from England and $1,760,

The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrives today from Bremen and Channel ports. Her passengers include Mme. Kirsten Flagstad, Wagnerian soprano, arriving for her fifth American opera and concert season; Stephen Sanford,

Stocks closed irregularly higher, with rail shares leading and close to best levels of year; turnover, 1,065,100 shares. Traction bonds steady, United States Government issues lower, other groups irregular; transactions, $8,453,450.

The joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee announced yesterday that they would picket any theatres which showed motion picture accounts of the 1936 Olympic Games produced in Germany by Leni Riefenstahl.

Sir Abe Bailey's Maranta was installed favorite at the Victoria Club call-over tonight for the November Handicap, to be run over one and a half miles at Manchester on the 26th. The odds on the son of Solario-Mispec were 100 to 7.

Meetings of the local General Councils in all French departments today gave the first opportunity for political leaders to discuss France's foreign and internal policies since the Munich accord before provincial gatherings and sound out public opinion on these questions.

Formation of an American campaign committee to help raise $50,000 for the Palestine Hebrew Culture Fund was announced yesterday by Dr. Simon Ginzburg of Tel Aviv, Palestine, who has come to the United States to promote the interests of the fund.

The system of dispensing relief in the United States has been completely "Farleyized," Mrs. Helen Z. M. Rodgers, Republican candidate for Representative at Large, charged yesterday in a statement issued at her headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.
One of the capital's "brilliant" young doctors, who had lately managed to get a following in fashionable circles, has been unmasked as a carpenter who escaped from an insane asylum.

Dante Piccoli, who gave up his own Summer vacation so that one of his friends could enjoy it. welcomed several hundred underprivileged children yesterday afternoon to the new Morosini Boys Club at 209 Sullivan Street.
Jacob August, veteran of the Franco-Prussian War and oldest clothing manufacturer in Rochester, died today at the age of 96. Mr. August was the oldest member of B'rith Kidesh Temple.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corportion decided today to buy up to 40,000,000 pounds of surplus milk in the New York area to assist in maintaining current prices paid producers through November and December.

Trading generally slow on all classes. Veal, calf and pork loins are lower; lamb cuts steady to lower; others mostly steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: BEEF STEER HINDS AND RIBS-Supply about normal;

The address by Thomas E. Dewey at the Manhattan Opera House last night follows: This is a real victory meeting. Already we see the panic and confusion on the other side. The forces arrayed against us are disorganized.

Prior to a national advertising campaign in newspapers in conjunction with dealers, H. Kohnstamm Co., manufacturers and distributors of a new soft drink, will endeavor to promote their product through several novel means.

Fed steers and yearling trade was somewhat slow today, with prices at steady to 25 cents lower levels, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Fat lambs and hogs found an active clearance, fat lambs selling steady, to 15 cents higher, up to. $8.90, while hogs sold steady to 10 cents. higher with top at $7.90.
Fire of undetermined origin early today destroyed three two-story wooden buildings on Main Street. Loss was estimated unofficially at nearly $200,000.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt are going to have a new grandchild next March. The President's daughter, Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Boettiger, revealed in a signed article in The PostIntelligencer tonight that she was expecting a child.

Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, appeared in concert here tonight with the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra despite reports of an agreement between the American Guild of Musical Artists and the Southern California Symphony Association that no non-Guild musicians would play under its auspices.

More work on fundamentals and rehearsals, both offensively and defensively, against Dartmouth plays was the order for Cornell today. In all its operations the aerial game was stressed, especially offensively.

James H. Fay and Walter H. Liebman, Democratic candidates for Congress, and Robert F. Wagner Jr., and Lester P. Doidge, Democratic candidates for the State Assembly, addressed a meeting called last night by the Affiliated Young Democrats at the Hotel Piccadilly, 227 West Forty-fifth Street. About 100 persons attended.
In the first major step toward rehabilitation since the hurricane swept the Eastern seaboard in September, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it would consider bids on Nov.

A tea marking the opening of Lois Shaw, Inc., was given Tuesday afternoon in the concern's shop, at 460 Park Avenue. The firm deals in eighteenth-century French and English furniture, old English and Irish silver, Lowestoft china, small pieces of sculpture, silhouettes, drawings, water-colors, oil paintings and other small objects of distinction. Mrs.
Irving C. Krewson Corporation, resident buying office, has added to its accounts the Arleen Shop, Indianapolis, a new ready-to-wear store occupying the former premIses of the Avon Shop.
Bruce Hobbs, 17-year-old jockey who rode Battleship to victory in the Grand National Steeplechase last March, lay in a hospital today with a broken back.
Jackson Heights triumphed by 4 to 1 over the New York A. C. last night in the Class B competition of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the Winged Foot Club's courts.

Dr. Ignatz Griebl, who is a fugitive from an indictment charging him with espionage, was " an informer" who betrayed not only the United States but Germany as well, Leon G. Turrou, former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation,

Several hundred members of society and the artistic world gathered at dinners and suppers last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for an entertainment marking the opening of that rendezvous for the late Autumn and Winter season.

The Massachusetts Horticultural Society has awarded the George Robert White medal of honor to Robert Moses, New York City's Park Commissioner, for extending that city's park system, planting and preserving trees and "teaching the love of nature to the younger generation."

Because of a technical oversight made by city authorities in the financial crisis in January, 1933, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick withdrew yesterday from sale an issue of $6,000,000 New York City assessment bonds which had been held in the city pension funds.

Eight leaves from a copy of the Gutenberg Bible, one of the monuments of printing, brought $2,500 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries at the final session of the auction of rare books, manuscripts and other items from the library of the late George C. Smith Jr. of this city, a member of the firm of Street Smith.

Union workers asked the Supreme. Court today to examine the constitutionality of a Maine law under which strikers in shoe factories at Auburn and Lewiston were convicted last Winter of criminal conspiracy. The law, the workers said in an appeal from the Maine Superior Court, violated the right to strike and- deprived thom of their liberty without due process of law.

Bruce Boyce, baritone, will give a recital tonight at 8:30 in Town Hall. The Phil Sym Quartet and Yoichi Hiraoka, xylophonist, will give a concertt under the auspices of the Lincoln Square Chapter of the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade tonight at the Riverside Plaza Hotel.
Ending more than a year of hearings and trade discussions, the Federal Trade Commission yesterday promulgated, effective today, a set of trade practice rules for the silk industry.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 24, reported yesterday a consolidated net opereating profit of $4,622,091 after giving effect to all charges, including Federal income taxes.
New York State knows how to elect Governors, and occasionally a President, by narow margins.
Czechoslovakia, despite her recent dismemberment, is going to participate in the World's Fair and will erect its own pavilion,
Walter S. Ball, former Sunday editor of The Providence Sunday Journal and The Journal correspondent overseas during the World War, died at the age of 63 today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Joseph of the Bronx of the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Joseph's daughter, Miss Evelyn Renee Trosk, to Claude A. Sartorius Jr. of this city and Chicago.

Gracie Square was the hub yesterday from which a cavalcade of motor cars spread out fanwise into all the boroughs, carrying flags, loudspeakers and spokesmen on behalf of the top-ranking candidates of the Democratic ticket, Governor Lehman and Justice Charles Poletti.

A. J. Cronin's "The Citadel" has been converted by Metro's British unit into one of the most satisfying screen dramas of the year. Although the film, like the novel, may be criticized for offering little new to those who have read "Arrowsmith,"

A directors' meeting tomorrow morning at which selection of the organization's important senior advisory committee will be announced will end the twenty-third annual convention of the Financial Advertisers of America, in session here this week.
Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould gave a large reception yesterday afternoon in their home at 160 East Seventy-second Street to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Edith Kingdon Gould.

Anything from a close Republican victory to a repetition of the Democratic landslides of 1936 and 1934 can be heard among the political predictions for Ohio five days before an expected turnout of 2,500,000 voters at the polls to make the selections for Governor, one United States Senator, twenty-four members of Congress and several dozen State and local officers.

In observance of the sixty-sixth anniversary of the Bowery Y. M. C. A. at 8 East Third Street, approximately 100 bankers, industrialists, publishers and other professional and business men and women last night were .he guests of that organization at a 25-cent dinner.
Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace described Governor Lehman yesterday as a "100 per cent New Dealer" so far as the Administration's farm program is concerned.

The general level of wholesale prices rose in the week ended on Oct. 29, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Based on the 1926 average as 100, the bureau's index stood at 77.6, compared with 77.3 on Oct. 22 and 84 on Oct. 30, 1937.

" There is no place for bigotry and intolerance in the American way of life," Richard B. Scandrett Jr., Republican candidate for Representative at Large, declared yesterday, in comparing conditions in this country with those in Europe. Mr.
Joseph Goldfarb, a quiet-looking little man, constituted himself a one-man picket line at City Hall yesterday in an effort to regain his license as a barker on a Chinatown bus.

A cooperative attack on the problem of reducing preventable waste in heating American homes by more than $500,000,000 was suggested yesterday by L. R. Taylor, president of the National Warm Air Heating and Air-Conditioning Association, in a letter to twenty-one national associations representing the fuel, heating, air-conditioning and building industries.

War Admiral, defeated Tuesday by Seabiscuit in Pimlico's historic match race, worked out briefly today before boarding a special car bound for Narragansett Park, where the, Riddle star is booked to run in the $10,000 Rhode Island Handicap Nov. 12.

Chuck Barnard, former Edmond State Teachers end, was back with the New York Giants yesterday, having been recalled from the Jersey City Giants by Coach Steve Owen. It is expected that Barnard will see action during Sunday's game with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds.

Roseretter, in the Foxcatcher Farm milks of William du Pont Jr., staged one of her characteristic stretch rushes to emerge victorious by a head in the Lady Baltimore Handicap, mile and a sixteenth test for fillies and mares that topped today's program at Pimlico.

KINGS GOLDEN, MAY E. (Aug. 15, 1938). Gross assets, $25,650; net, $23,495. To Evergreen Cemetery, $300 in trust; Josephine Briggs, specific jewelry and $1,000; Mary C. Magerle, specific Jewelry and $500; Mary T. and Peter Magerle, $50 each; Rusha H. C. and Masle Cooper, specific jewelry each; Elizabeth Jackson, $200; Ann E. and Wallace Perry and Anna G.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Blagden of Willowgate, Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Blagden's daughter, Miss Sarita Blagden, to the Rev. Frederic B. Kellogg, son of Mrs. Frederic R. Kellogg of this city and Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. Kellogg.

The world champion Chicago Black Hawks looked the part tonight, opening their National Hockey League campaign by routing the New York Americans, 6 to 1, before 15,842 spectators, who formed the largest opening night throng in the history of ice hockey in Chicago.

Seventy-five persons, whose activities in the sale of oil royalties and real estate is said to have cost the investing public more than $5,000,000 during the last six years, were named defendants in a sealed mail-fraud indictment opened yesterday in Federal court.

Several prominent New York lawyers yesterday disputed charges that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, is too young and inexperienced for the office he seeks, and praised his abilities as a lawyer.
Walter R. Darby, New Jersey Commissioner of Local Government, disclosed today he had notified prosecutors that 9 counties and 178 municipalities in the State overexpended their budgets last year.
Professor Robert W. Wood of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, will receive the Rumford Medal of the Royal Society in recognition of his work in physics and optics.

Some mills producing men's wear wool goods raised prices an additional 5 cents a yard this week, bringing values to 121/2 cents a yard above opening levels, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly survey.
The Nicholas G. Rutgers property on Route 22, Bedford, Westchester County, has been sold through Kenneth Ives Co. to a client of George Howe, Inc.

The Insurgent right wing reported tonight that it had reached the Ebro River in the neighborhood of the village of Pinell, about four miles southeast of Gandesa, and had split in two the zone covered by the Loylists in the Ebro's bend, where the latter drove across the river on July 25.
Major John L. Griffith, Western Conference athletic commissioner, asserted today critics who accused college football of overcommercialization were hasty and uninformed.

The O. Henry Memorial Award Committee, through its chairman, Harry Hansen, has announced the winners of its twentieth annual award of three prizes for the best short stories published in American magazines during the year.

Twelve squads of city detectives, cooperating with Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, raided the offices of thirteen race-track tipping services yesterday shortly before noon and arrested thirty-nine persons on charges of mail fraud.

Miss Sally Clark, daughter of Mrs. F. Haven Clark, whose marriage to George X. McLanahan will take place in Boston on Dec. 3, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin For Mrs. Archibald McG. Foster and Mrs. William B. M. Hutchinson of Winnetka, Ill.
Having spectacularly advanced northward of Canton, with the Chinese leaving them almost a clear field, the Japanese ran into opposition in their drive toward Wuchow yesterday.

Henri Royer, noted portrait painter and contributor of portraits and landscapes to the Paris Salon for nearly fifty years, died last Sunday. For several years he was a member of the jury of the salon and a member of the Committee of Artistes Francais.
Under the combined pressure of December liquidation and hedging operations, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 3 to 7 points yesterday and the near months closed at low levels for the week.
Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are:

Mr. and Mrs. Fairman Rogers Dick of Glen Head, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Dick's daughter, Miss Elise Duggan, to Edward Putnam Currier Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Currier of Scarborough-on-Hudson.
With the dispatch of the first contingent of 80,000 settlers who will eventually go to Libya, attention has been called here to the possibilities of colonization of Italians. The fact that

The Chemical Industry Medal of the Society of Chemical Industry, awarded annually for valuable application of chemical research to industry, was presented last night to Dr. J. V. N. 'Dorr, president of the Dorr Company, Inc., at a joint

Another tide of refugees is sweeping over Ruthenian and Slovak roads to what remains of Czechoslovakia. Tens of thousands of Czech officials, Slovaks, Jews and those politically compromised are leaving their homes with bundles of their possessions in search of new opportunities in the already overcrowded rump State.

Turnover in wholesale markets was brisk during the week despite limited calls for the replacement of seasonal merchandise, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Price increases in some lines and talk of advances in others was a factor in influencing forward purchasing.

The Mexican Government has increased its oil shipments to Texas from 10,000 barrels daily to 15,000 under the sliding scale permitted by the contract with the Eastern States Oil Company. The increased shipments began Quietly this week.

United States Marshal Arthur Jaeger in Brooklyn announced yesterday that on Thursday, he would sell at auction three former Munson Line vessels, the Southern Cross, the Western World and the Pan America. The sale will take

Giving way to "force majeure," the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday that it had abandoned its proposal for a reduction of 15 per cent in union wages. In view of the Washington Administration's views on wagecutting, this was to be expected.
THE NEW YORK TIMES received the following from the Twentieth Century Fund: "In the Oct. 27 issue of THE TIMES an article appeared written by Burton Crane entitled 'Bears Absolved in Market Break.

The undefeated Dartmouth Indians plan to start their regulars against Little Dickinson tomorrow, but Head Coach Earl Blaik is confident it will be safe to withdraw his first stringers as soon as they are warmed up.

Sir James de Hoghton, landowner and a veteran of the Ashanti War of 1873, died today at the age of 87. He owned Hoghton Towers in Lancashire, in the banquet hail of which tradition says King James I created the expression "sirloin" by knighting a loin of beef. Sir James,
The engagement of Miss Carol Prichitt, daughter of Mrs. James T. Houghton of this city and the late Hugh Kirkman Prichitt, to Edward Godfrey Miller Jr. has been announced by her mother.

In an effort to end street fighting in Harlem between Italians and Puerto Ricans, former Representative Vito Marcantonio brought spokesmen for both groups to a conference with Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.
State police sought today the whereabouts of Miss Martha May Avery, 26, and the Rev. Leonard C. Richmond, 59 both of Union Center, Ulster County, missing from their homes for nearly a week.

The Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries have a net profit of $1,616,449 for the third quarter of this year after deductions for expenses, interest, depreciation, amortization and provision for Federal income taxes, according to a statement to be made public today by David Sarnoff, R. C. A.'s president. Dividend requirements on

Cattle supplies were limited today and steady prices prevailed throughout the list, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs sold on a steady to 10-cent higher basis, with the day's top at $8 being paid sparingly, while fat lambs cleared at mostly 10 to 25 cents higher levels. Western lambs selling up to $9.10.

Mr. and Mrs. William B. Warthman of Burlington, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Julia E. Warthman, to John Austin Stevens Heckscher of Strafford. The marriage is to take place soon.

The joint efforts of the Swedish and Finnish Governments to solve the problem of refortificatlon of the Aland Archipelago, the most important strategical position in the Baltic Sea, entered a critical stage today with the arrival in Helsingfors of Foreign Minister Rickard Sandler at the head of a delegation of Swedish experts to confer with the Finnish Cabinet.
S Arlent Edwards, an etcher of international reputation who revived the art of color printing from a mezzotint plate, died here today in his home at the age of 76.

Colonel Robert S. Henry, president of the Association of American Railroads, will speak on "The Business of Railroading," at the regular meeting of the Home Furnishings Club at the Hotel Imperial next Wednesday evening. The club,

President Roosevelt urged New York State voters, in a radio address today, to re-elect Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Senator Robert F. Wagner and to send Representative James M. Mead to the United States Senate.

Anna M. Kross and Samuel Null, American Labor and Socialist candidates for Supreme Court in the First Judiicial District, have been judged "qualified and preferred" by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild. The guild made public yesterday its Supreme Court recommendations.

Miss Jane Sheppard Patteson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Patteson of this place, was married to James K. Irvin of Irvington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arba J. Irvin of Evanston, III., this afternoon in the Second Reformed Church here.
