As the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service's campaign for $250,000 reached the half-way mark yesterday with a joint meeting of men and women workers at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, it was announced that a total of $128,446or more than 50 per cent of the goal-had been obtained since the drive opened Sept. 26.

American Cyanamid and Chemi cal Corporation has bought from the Seaboard Air Line Railway a seventy-two-acre tract at Georgetown, S. C., -and will build a plant for the production of sulphate of alumina, a product used for water purification and paper making.

A charge that at least 1,500 names had been inserted in the Hudson County registration books yesterday in violation of the registration law was made this afternoon by Superintendent of Elections John Ferguson in a letter to Registration Commissioner Charles F. Stoebling.
The sure Department of Commerce reported today that American shipyards on Oct. 1 were building or were under contract to build 193 vessels for private shipowners, as compared with 158 on Sept. 1.
A Bristol County grand jury com pleted today its inquiry on the municipal administration and in a second and final report returned fortyone indictments against nineteen men. These included three
Vladimir Shavitch, Russian-American conductor, substituted two sound technicians and an intricate recording device for operatic accompaniment and presented Gounod's "Faust" here tonight.

Attorney General Cummings announced today the government was filing an anti-trust suit at Wilmington, Del., against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, one of the country's largest holding companies, and its subsidiary, the Warfield Natural Gas Company.

UnHarry J. beaten California remained the general favorite today to defeat Southern California when the two elevens line up before some 85,000 fans tomorrow in a game that probably will decide the Pacific Coast Conference entry in the Rose Bowl classic Jan. 2.

Columbia College's South Field took on the air of a collegiate movie set yesterday as freshmen and sophomores turned out in large numbers for a bruising melee before 1,000 spectators. The fracas revived a tradition that had met undergraduate indifference for more than a decade.

Cooperating in the drive of the La Guardia Administration for early demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, the Transit Commission has ordered a public hearing at 10 A. M. next Thursday on the question of approving the city's recent request for condemnation of the structure.

Check exchanges at 194 clearing houses throughout the country last month totaled $26,619,143,283. This was the largest turnover in checks since last December and a gain of 10.5 per cent over the September returns. However, by comparison
Leni Riefenstahl, German film star and director, who is said to be one of the few close friends of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Viscount Jules Henri de Sibour, long a popular figure here and an outstanding architect, died early today at the age of 65 in Emergency Hospital. He had been ill since Oct. 26, and died despite an operation performed a week ago.

In telegrams to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday, William B. Bankhead and Sam Rayburn, Speaker and majority leader respectively of the House of Representatives, branded as untrue statements attributed to Representative John J. O'Connor that they would support him for re-election as chairman of the House Rules Committee. Both said they favored

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Every year about Halloween time the critics of the point-after-touchdown play emerge from their respective corners and closets to haunt the lives of peace-loving, football-loving coaches, writers and fans. So, if you don't call the
Two conquerors of the great Seabiscuit, reigning king of the turf, will be highly favored tomorrow in the $10,000 added mile-and-three-sixteenth Riggs Handicap at Pimlico race track.

Fordham University's varsity and freshman harriers scored victories over Seton Hall teams yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The former placed five men among the first six finishers to gain a 19-36 triumph, while the Maroon yearlings triumphed by 24--31, although Charles Macieski of the visitors led home the field.

The compulsory training of youth for defense purposes is strongly urged by two members of the Legislative Council. The Governor, Sir Reginald Hildyard, in his recent speech at the opening of Parliament, urged the building up of local defenses and the Council indicated its willingness to consider a proposal for military training.

BOSTON COLLEGE VS. INDIANA-The old joke is that, when everything else fails, you can always find help in the dictionary. This observer has a dictionary. Thumbing the A section; Abacus, abracadabra, ametropia - ametropia? What's that? Ametropia: an abnorml condition of the refracting parts of the eye, causing confused or imperfect vision.

The Wagner National Labor Relations Act is the chief obstacle to the solution of America's No. 1 problem, unemployment, John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared last night in a radio speech from Station WABC.

Special Sessions Judge Robert H. Davidson today sentenced nine men to a total of 110 years in State's prison on conviction of statutory charges. Eight of the nine, whose ages ranged from 18 to 72, were Patersonians and the tenth lived in Passaic.
Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman last night at a rally in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn:

With the exception of Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, who will not leave Paris until tomorrow, all of the famous chess masters who will participate in the Alg Vereen Radio Omroet, international tournament, beginning on Sunday, assembled tonight to discuss the rules and draw the numbers on which the pairings will be based.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, speaking at a Democratic rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music reminiscent of the Gubernatorial days of Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt in size and enthusiasm, last night accused Thomas E. Dewey of running on a platform of promises which already had been matched by Democratic performance.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Otis Co., syndicate managers, announced yesterday that the selling group formed in connection with the offering of $50,000,000 of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company ten-year 31/2 per cent

The railways, submitting to the conclusions of the President's fact-finding board, withdrew yesterday their demand for a 15 per cent wage cut. With this action all possibility of a strike on Dec. 1 disappears. That in itself is good

After having canceled a dinner he was scheduled to attend, in order to listen to President Roosevelt's speech on the New York campaign, Thomas E. Dewey the Republican candidate for Governor, last night swung into Queens with an address in which he charged Governor Herbert H. Lehman with having failed to meet the issues of the campaign.

The Citizens Committee for the re-election of John J. O'Connor of New York, who lost the Democratic nomination and seeks election as a Republican, reported to the clerk of the House today that it had collected $12,359 from Oct. 24 to Nov. 3 and had spent $10,504.

Without further ceremony than the customary bugle blast announcing the first class, the National Horse Show Association will inaugurate its fifty-fifth year at 10 o'clock this morning, at which hour the annual equine exhibition will be opened in Madison Square Garden.

Now that the hunting season is really under way the stories of "unbelievable" experiences and "wonder" dogs are coming in with unfailing regularity. You don't have to do very much shooting or fishing to realize that the unbelievable often happens, but it is something else again when you attempt to test the credulity of your friends.
The twentyone German Jews to whom entry into Mexico was refused last week arrived here this morning aboard the steamship Orinoco.
" It was magnificent," Governor Herbert H. Lehman said of the radio address last night of President Roosevelt. "It was one of the greatest speeches I ever heard."

EVERY one knows it was Mr. Dooley who said "th' Supreme Coort follows th' iliction returns." That can be found in Bartlett, along with a dozen other sayings from the fountainhead. Yet how many living citizens have read them in Finley Peter Dunne's original essays? Not enough, decidedly; not enough-no matter what number. It is. clearly, a service to life.
John F. Ohmer, president and founder of the Ohmer Fare Register Company, manufacturer of street car, train and motor bus fare regsisters, died today after a lengthy illness.

Meadow Farm Night, owned by Charles L. Lawrance of East Islip, president of the Labrador Retriever Club, today won the amateur stake, closing event of the club's eighth annual meet in the Shinnecock Hills near here. In addition to the
he Pulaski Circuit Court had before it today a petition to shorten sentences of minor offenders-because the county's jail bill is running too high. The petition stated

Miss Barbara Belmont and her fiance, Roberi Livermore Jr., whose marriage takes place today in the chantry of St. Thomas Church, were honored at a dinner given last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre by the prospective bride's sisters and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Felix Timmerman and Miss Alice de G. Belmont.

An agreement for purchase of the electric facilities of the West Tennessee Power and Light Company by twenty-two cities and the Tennessee Valley Authority for distribution of TVA power was consumated today. The price was fixed at

The Rev. Dr. W. Coleman Nevils, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, will preach a series of sermons on the general subject "The Canticle of Charity."

Miss Marie Josephine Oothout, last survivor of the eighth generation of her family in America, died on Wednesday at her home, 26 East Eighty-first Street, after a long illness. A native of New York, she was 80 years old.

Manhattan's rapidly improving football team, which has yet to score a major victory, will meet North Carolina State this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium. The kickoff for this fourth intersectional meeting between the teams will be at 2 o'clock.

A supper dance entitled the Winter Ball was given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza by a committee of young men of society organized as the Bachelors. The subscribers included younger married couples, debutantes of former years and single men.

State Representative Harry Dwight Sisson, onetime Mayor of Pittsfield, died suddenly tonight 'of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home here at the age of 75. Mr. Sisson was nominee for re-election on the Republican ticket and his name is on the official ballot for next Tuesday's election.

Max Marek, the Chicago lad who upset Joe Louis to win the national A. A. U. 175-pound title in 1933, hung up his gloves today after thirty-one professional bouts. He was soundly beaten by undefeated Tony Musto Wednesday night.

Having completed a wave of new corporate bond financing during the two preceding weeks during which a total of $242,000,000 of such loans were marketed, the new issue market turned its attention this week to the offering of $25,000,000 Argentine Republic 41/2 per cent bonds. due in 1948.

Full steam ahead" was the watchword pf the Railway Labor Executives Association today when word was received from Chicago that the railway presidents' conference had decided to abandon the 15 per cent wage reduction proposal.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 two registration statements covering between $25,234,800 and $35,957,200 of 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures, due on July 1, 1958; subscription warrants

Mixing a powerful running game with an aerial offensive, the Fordham Prep football team routed Adelphi Academy, 24-13, yesterday on the loser's gridiron. The victors made three touchdowns in the second session and waged a defensive battle most of the time in the last half.

A young Roman Catholic lay brother, in this country one year from Italy and working with the Franciscan Order, was one of two persons who perished early yesterday morning in a monastery fire at the Church of St. Anthony of Padua, 151 Thompson Street, where seven priests, trapped while aiding one another, were rescued.

New York's architecture has come a long way since Peter Minuit's time. The earliest Dutch houses with their high-pitched roofs seem to bear little relation to the modern skyscraper which makes Manhattan's skyline an awe-inspiring sight.

Miss Edith French, a descendant of Jonathan Treadway, a drummer boy in the American Revolution, was married to Kenneth Charles Doty here. tonight in the West Side Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur M. Hughes.

Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, arrived here tonight for a visit officially described as a hunting party in Barnate. There is little doubt, however, that he will discuss problems mutually affecting Rumania and Yugoslavia with his host, King Carol.

Despite endorsement of a two-market year by big furniture manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing groups at a meeting here Thursday, it seemed probable today that both the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart will continue to schedule four exhibitions during 1939.

The Interstate Commerce Commission instituted today a proceeding to determine the extent of its jurisdiction over the hours of service of employes, other than drivers, of motor carriers, including private carriers. One reason for the move,
As the site for a one-story taxpayer a plot 53 by 96 feet at the southwest corner of Mosholu Avenue and Post Road, the Bronx, has been purchased by Arlington C. Hall from Adrian Burke.

A typhoon of moderate intensity that earlier had threatened Manila and Southern Luzon Island was reported southwest of Mindoro Island this morning and moving slowly toward the China Sea. Weather Bureau officials believed the storm would not touch Manila or Southern Luzon if it continued its present course.

Northwestern's undefeated Wildcats will carry their drive toward the Big Ten football championship against Wisconsin tomorrow in a battle expected to draw 35,000 fans into Dyche Stadium. The game, twenty-sixth of a series which began in 1890, may develop into a battel of lines.

Sewell L. Avery, once known as Chicago's busiest man, on his sixty-fourth birthday, today took another step to free himself from the routine of the business world. He retired from the presidency of Montgomery Ward Co., nation-wide merchandise distributing organization.

The Economists' National Committee has distributed a booklet reviewing our currency situation and recommending extremely necessary changes in the existing status. Its first three recommendations are: (1) That Congress

With both teams below par physically, the Yale-Brown game tomorrow in the Bowl is regarded as a toss-up. A crowd of 35,000 is expected to see the Bruins aim for their first triumph over the Blue since 1932.

For the first time in six years Alabama came to town an' under-dog today, prepared for a bruising encounter with Tulane tomorrow. While the Greenies' two-team system appeared ready to function, Coach Frank Thomas reported a shortage of fullbacks on the Alabama squad and assigned George Zivich, right halfback, to understudy Charley Holm.
William C. Handy, the composer of "St. Louis Blues," was the guest of honor yesterday of popular song writers and band leaders at the Delphic Studio, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

E. A. and Sterling Florian, securities promoters who have been prosecuted several times by State and Federal authorities on charges of sharp practices since 1924, are named again in a suit begun yesterday in Supreme Court by Attorney General Bennett.

John L. McNamee, for the last twenty-five years president of Tyson Co., a theatre ticket brokerage office at 148 West Fiftieth Street, New York, died here today at his home, 126 Irving Place, after a long illness. He was 53 years s old.

The nation's major railroads withdrew today their order for a 15 per cent cut in wages of 930,000 employes on Dec. 1, thus definitely removing the threat of a nation-wide railroad strike and opening the way for legislative action to help the carriers.

Fired with undergraduate enthusiasm over tomorrow's PrincetonRutgers football game, nearly 100 Rutgers students invaded the Princeton campus in three forays last night and early this morning, daubing several landmarks before police caught up with them.

Bruce Boyce, Canadian baritone, who gave his first New York recital at Town Hall last season, returned to that auditorium last night in a program composed of early classics, lieder by Schubert and Brahms, modern English songs and the aria, "Erie tu," from Verdi's "II Ballo in Maschera."

The fiftieth anniversary of the Catholic Kolping Society of New York, a social service organization for young men, will be celebrated Sunday throughout the day, preceded by an informal reception at Kolping House, 165 East Eightyeighth Street, Saturday night.

Business was urged today by S. Clay Williams, chairman of the board of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, Winston-Salem, to cooperate in a stand against too much government influence on business. Addressing
They are on the wrong track when they attempt to dig up graves to prove the authorship of William Shakespeare's works, John Howell, noted book collector and Baconian authority, said here today.

One hundred and fifty alumni of the University of Virginia gathered at the Yale Club last night to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of football at Virginia and to hold a rally for the game with Columbia today at Baker Field.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday of the withdrawal as of Nov. 15 of an offer to exchange one share of Class B 7 per cent preferred stock into 0.4 share of prior preferred 51/2 per cent stock and one share of 5 per cent preferred stock for each share surrendered.

Representatives of the New York State branch of the National Society of the Daughters of 1812 placed a wreath yesterday on the vault of Daniel D. Tompkins, Governor of the State and Vice President of the United States in the early part of the nineteenth century, at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie,
Grand Duke Vladimir, 21-year-old son of Grand Duke Cyril, who died last month, issued a manifesto here tonight announcing his claim to the extinct Russian throne.

The Misses Peggy Twicliell ann Gertrude Vanderpoel Rose were introduced to society this afternoon at a tea dance given at the New Haven Lawn Club by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Burton Parker Twichell and Professor R. Selden Rose of Yale University and Mrs. Rose.

The St. John's Prep football team, outstanding rival of the Horace Mann School eleven, scored a touchdown in the fourth quarter yesterday to earn a 9-7 victory in the seventh annual game between the schools. The contest was played on the loser's field.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as. supplied yesterday by the Textile Broken Association Inc.:

Charles A. Poletti, Democratic nominee for Lieutenant Governor, was accused yesterday by Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Children's Court of "concealing his Roman Catholic background." In making the accusation, Justice O'Brien said he had "no desire to inject any religious question" into the campaign but that he believed the question was not one of religion but of integrity.

Mayor La Guardia, with the cooperation of the Board of Transportation and the Transit Commission, is using window posters in all subway and elevated cars to urge the millions of rapid transit riders to vote "yes" on Constitutional Proposal No. 9 permitting the city to exceed its debt limit by $315,000,000 to help finance transit unification.
The estate of James H. Renshaw has sold to Joseph Topalian the two-family residence at 213 Burns Street, Forest Hills, Queens, assessed for $13,000. William G. Kittelberger was the broker.

Football analogy, often employed in the speeches of President Roosevelt, was used tonight by Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, in an appeal for the election of William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, at a Democratic rally in Convention Hall.

In an order signed yesterday Judge Robert A. Inch in Federal Court, Brooklyn, declared New York Investors, Inc., a holding corporation, which filed a petition seeking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law in December, 1934, to be insolvent within the intent and meaning of Section 77b. He told counsel
The Democratic National Committee and two Republican campaign committees reported today that last week they had spent considerably more than they collected.

The Southern Railway Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to sell $6,000,000 of 4 per cent equipment trust certificates to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at par.

The German-American Settlement League, Inc., operator of Camp Siegfried at Yaphank, L. I., for American Nazi sympathizers, and the league's six incorporators, who were convicted on July 12 in Suffolk County Court of violating the State Civil Rights Law by failing to file documents with the Secretary of State in Albany as required of all oath-bound organizations, were exonerated yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Edna Virginia Hammond, 42 years old, a widow, of 7 Park Avenue, New York City, died at Englewood Hospital at 6:30 o'clock tonight, the victim of a hit-run driver whose car struck her as she was crossing State Highway Route 4 at Broad Avenue to wait for a bus to New York.

President Roosevelt revealed today that he had directed that a complete survey be made of all Federalowned lands and plants capable of being used in the national defense program, with a view to potential economies and to expedite military and naval expansion which will be in full swing next year.

Citizens and taxpayers have become so aroused by increased expenditures and taxation of many counties and municipalities throughout the State that they have declared "an open season on budgets," the newly organized Citizens Public Expenditure Survey of New York State announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia, Police Coammissioner Valentine and Fire Commissioner McElligott were among those who attended the funeral yesterday of Fireman Thomas J. Hitter, murdered in Brooklyn last Monday by a thug during a holdup.

A Polish mob today wrecked a Ukrainian hotel in Lwow, the capital of Eastern Galicia, which has a mixed Polish and Ukrainian population. Windows were smashed in the offices of the Ukrainian newspaper Dilo.

Sales of the storage battery industry for 1938 should top the total for 1929, according to estimates yesterday by S. B. Robertson, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company. Mr. Robertson predicted that 1938 sales would exceed $92,000,000, a gain of approximately 18 per cent over last year.

The Colorado Springs Gazetter said it was informed tonight by a reliable source that Mr. and Mrs. James C. McCoy had been reinstated as superintendent and matron of the Union Printers Home by the board of trustees, which ousted them early last Summer.

Bruce Barton, Republican candidate for Congress in the Seventeentl Congressional District, was called "the paid advertising agent of the largest monopolies in this country" by his' Democratic opponent, Walter H. Liebman, in a radio address last night.

Sherman and Earle Woodfall of Braintree start Sunday to realize their six-year dream of a trip around the world in their own boat. They plan to sail Sunday for Hamilton, Bermuda, on the first leg of a 33,000-mile voyage in their 35-foot homemade, ketch-rigged boat, Volita. Earle, 24, two years older than

Mayor Hague is justly inOur dignant at the Republican Leading accusation that he has 40,Deporter 000 floaters on the registra tion lists. When a man has worked hard and acquired a national reputation for throwing people out of Jersey City, it does seem hard to charge him with importing scores of thousands of people into Jersey City.

there were 1,376 bond issues aggregating $50,224,879,868 par value' listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with a total market value of $45,539,193,999, compared to 1,380 issues aggregating $50,330,816,368 par value and a market value of $44,836,709,443 on Sept. 30.
Prospects of the Navy, underdog in tomorrow's contest with Notre Dame, brightened tonight with the announcement that Emmett Wood, key man of the middle backfield, may get into the game.

Herman Barron of Fenway shot two sub-par 71s to win the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship in the county pros' first annual thirty-six-hole title tourney today at the Gedney Country Club.

Georgetown University's undefeated and untied team, led by fleetfooted, sure-passing Joe Mellendeck, defeated Bucknell tonight, 13 to 0, with a sustained drive in the first period and a touchdown resulting from a fumble recovery in the final minutes. A crowd of 15,000 saw the contest.

The Samuel Henry Galpin Latin prize for the best freshman entrance examination in Latin has been awarded to William McAndrews of Chicago. Honorable mention went to Gerald Harwood of New York City.

The muchpublicized black tomcat of 10 Downing Street, official residence of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, has been rewarded with a gift of fresh fish for his vigilance at the doorway during the September war scare.

For the first time this season Harvard, which has been described as "the best football team that ever lost four consecutive games," will play the role of a topheavy favorite tomorrow when it engages Chicago at the Stadium.

The French liner Paris sails today for Havre via Plymouth. Her passenger list includes Baron and Baroness Amaury de la Grange, Mr. and Mrs. Anibal de Moya, Louis Cochand, Lord H. Michelham, Baron and Baroness Jean de Lustrack and Mr. and Mrs. David Stewart.

Little Franklin and Marshall College will engage Army's eleven at Michie Stadium tomorrow before a crowd expected to include about 14,000 boys and girls. Annually the Army sets aside one game for Boys and Girls Day and a year ago 27,000 spectators jammed the stadium to watch the West Pointers on parade and see a football game.

A slow crystallization of sentiment, increasingly noticeable as the hour for decision draws near, is seen by competent observers here to favor Governor Frank Murphy in his desperate fight for re-election and thus to save Michigan for the New Deal branch of the Democratic party.
The transfer to the Czechoslovak Government of the 10,000,000 credit promised by the British Government immediately after the Munich agreement is now taking place.

William S. Hart, hero of the "Westerns" in the days of silent films, whose first verdict of $85,000 against United Artists Corporation was reversed by the Appellate Division on appeal, won a verdict of $190,484 from a Supreme Court jury yesterday at the close of the second trial of his suit. With interest from
Dr. Francis J. Dweeny leased from Corp., the Bowery Savings Bank the fourstory dwelling at 16 West Eighty third Street through Bracher Hubert, brokers.
Henry Huddleston Rogers Jr. was married secretly eighteen months ago to Diana Taylor, a dancer, he disclosed today at his farm house on Old Pound Ridge Road, here. He is a son of the late
The first changes in stock symbols by the New York Stock Exchange, designed to assist the ticker tape in keeping abreast of actual floor transactions during heavy trading, were announced yesterday.

Students, their parents and members of the faculty at the Friends Seminary on Rutherford Place put on an unusual hobby show as part of the school's fiftieth annual fair that opened yesterday. The proceeds will buy milk for needy children in the area.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, said tonight he had acted favorably on the application for reinstatement by Johnny Broaca, pitcher, who left the Yankees suddenly in the latter part of the 1936 season.

The congregation of St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church, 26 Roosevelt Street, began yesterday a celebration of its fiftieth anniversary, which will end Sunday morning, Nov. 13, with a solemn high mass in honor of Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, who will be beatified at St. Peter's, Rome, that day.

Dick Merle-Smith and Eldredge Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $800,000 of city of Greenville, S. C., water revenue bonds on their bid of 100.159 for 2 3/4s. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1938, will mature on Nov. 1, 1943 to 1970. They were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.75 to 2.80 per cent, according to maturity.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday paid the loser's end of a bet on the Fordham-Pittsburgh football game. He sent a bushel of apples to Cornelius D. Scully, Mayor of the city at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela.

The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee approved today the action of Senator Van Nuys, Indiana Democrat, in turning over to the Indiana Democratic State Committee $2,492.15 contributed to his re-election campaign by thirtyfour Federal employes.

Week- Na ly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,109,000 bales, against 1,117,000 a week ago, 1,120,000 two weeks ago, 1,143,000 three weeks ago and 769,000 a year ago, of which American 536,000 bales, against 552,000 a week ago, 547,000 two weeks ago, 565,000 three weeks ago and 336.000 a year ago.

With European opposition to National Socialism virtually silent, the German press is now concentrating its fire increasingly on the opposition encountered in the United States, and judging from the tenor of the attacks, the United States generally and the Roosevelt administration particularly will be treated as triumphant National Socialist Germany's Enemy No. 1.

Five thousand copies of a speech by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, setting forth his belief that "pumppriming is as American as corn on the cob," are being sent through the mails by the local offices of the WPA, it became known yesterday.
Thomas E. Dewey was the choice of Barnard College undergraduates for Governor of New York State in a straw poll conducted by the Barnard Bulletin, the college newspaper, which closed yesterday.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has developed a stronger tone and prices are showing a disposition to advance furtheir. Interest is keener in all divisions of the trade, which reflects considerable improvement in the market for piece goods.
Plans for small homes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens formed the bulk of building projects submitted yesterday by architects. The plans follow:

Harry Pritchard Gould, newsprint manufacturer and one of the leading lumbermen of the country, died today in his home here, after a year's illness. He was 65 years old. Mr. Gould was born at Moose River, near McKeever, July 22, 1873, a son of C. Henry P. and Elizabeth Pritchard Gould.

Informed persons said today that the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation would file consent decrees at South Bend Ind., Monday, providing for regulation of certain trade practices in the auto financing industry.

From an Ohio American Legionnaire who said he has spent six years as an undercover spy in the Communist party, the House committee investigating un-American activities today heard of Communist activities in that State. They ranged, he said,

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, speaking in reply to President Roosevelt's radio appeal for support of Governor Lehman and the liberalism of the New Deal, suggested last night that the President was also paving the way for a third term. Mr. Thomas

Friends of Will Rogers, including President Roosevelt, notables of the stage and screen, grizzled cowboys and simple homefolk, joined today in an impressive tribute to Claremore's famous son as a memorial was dedicated here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Nov. 21 for a hearing at its offices here on the declaration filed by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation regarding the reduction of the capital represented by its common stock from $194,349,005 to $12,304,282 without reducing the number of shares outstanding.
Justice Alonzo C. Hinkley of the Supreme Court in Buffalo began today the issuance of warrants in Albany County's investigation of alleged false registration.

Nearing the end of its case against two men and a woman accused of espionage, the government called several witnesses yesterday to support the contention of United States Attorney Lamar Hardy, in his opening address to the jury three weeks ago, that the defendants were engaged in a conspiracy conceived in and directed from Germany.

Corn was the leader in the grain markets today and rallied sharply after a small dip early. Local professionals sold at the opening, while houses with Eastern connections absorbed the offerings. When shorts tried to cover they found little for sale, and prices advanced rapidly.

Harold E. White, secretary-treasurer of the Plainfield Automotive Association, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital at the age of 57. He was born here, a son of Mrs. Catherine M. White and the late Edward White.

Alfred C. Busch, former assistant vice president of the New York Yor Title and Mortgage Company, and later vice president of Land Esstates, Inc., is now with the Jamaica, Queens, office of Bulkley Horton Company.

President James P. Baxter an or Williams College announced today the gift of an unannounced amount for the construction of a theatre to be begun this Spring. The building will have modern equipment and an auditorium seating 440, a workshop for Cap and Bells, the dramatic association; class rooms

The marriage of Miss Phyllis Dougherty, daughter of Mrs. Alvin L. Powell of this place and Clarence V. Dougherty of Ridgewood, formerly of Newark, to Donald D. Streit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Streit of East Orange, took place this afternoon in the chapel of the First Baptist Church of Montclair.

The question of whether Mexico will continue its membership in the League of Nations is being agitated in the press and in Congress with increasing force. There is rapidly developing a split between the Left Wing and the Right on the point.

William Carlos Hudson, one of the first Iowa cattle commission men and one of the best known livestock exchange leaders in the country, died on Thursday at his home in Sioux City, Iowa, after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. Mr. Hudson was 79
The Fifth Avenue Bank must return $60,000 to a trust fund created in 1924 by the late Leo Feist, music publisher, for his son, Milton, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIME has given its readers various reasons for opposing the adoption of Amendment No. 1 to the State Constitution. It regards as unwise the proposal in that amendment to make membership in pension systems a contractual obligation of the State.
The bulk of the estate of May Irwin, actress, was bequeathed equally to her husband, Kurt Eisfeldt, and her son, Harry C. Irwin, both of Clayton, according to her will, filed for probate today.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., yesterday estimated earnings in the third quarter at $650,658, including $495,000 direct and indirect net interest in the combined undistributed earnings of partly owned subsidiaries and a $233,000 profit on purchase of debentures of Paramount Pictures.
One of the Department of Agriculture's top-ranking marketing experts was en route to Europe today to try to expand exports of surplus domestic farm products.

Miss Edna Marguerite Dietz, daughter of Mr.t and Mrs. Charles Dietz of this city, was married at noon today at the home of her parents to Nathan Chase Ayer, son of Mrs. Nathan C. Ayer of Bangor, Me., by the Rev. D. K. McPherson.

The Democratic State candidates began tonight the last round of campaigning for Tuesday's election, expressing confidence that their standard bearer, Governor Wilbur L. Cross, would be re-elected even though the plurality might not be more than 10,000 votes.

Paul F. Glaser of Glaser Beverages, Inc., Seattle, was elected president yesterday of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages at the concluding session of the organization's twentieth annual convention and exposition in the Port Authority Building.
Dr. Thomas Stephenson, who won a world-wide reputation as a chemist, editor and Rotarian and was a stanch British propagandist in the United States during the World War, died today at the age of 74.

The New York Curb Echange will remove from listing at the opening of business today Rainbow Luminous Products, Inc., class A and B common stocks of no par value, which were suspended from dealings on July 28. The Securities and

Formal notice of the withdrawal of their support from the New York Joint Liquor Conference was transmitted to Gerald F. Dunne, chairman of the organization, yesterday by the New York-Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., which has furnished the funds for the conference's operations since it was organized last May.

Patrolman John Sullivan, 39 years old, of the Bathgate Avenue Station, was in Fordham Hospital last night suffering from concussion of the brain and possibly a fracture of the skull. Patrolman Sullivan said that he had been attacked by four youths at 171st Street and Brook Avenue, the Bronx.

Harrington K. Gates, star quarterback of the Dartmouth eleven, who spent most of this week at a religious cult ninety miles from Hanover, has been reinstated in the senior class after satisfying the authorities that he is content not to play football here again.

Department store sales during the week ended Oct. 29 were 5 per cent lower than during the corresponding week last year and for the four weeks ended Oct. 29 were 10 per cent lower than for the corresponding period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

A rivalry that has blossomed into a traditional one despite the slight difference of 3,000 miles in the locations of the two schools will be resumed before 50,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds today when Fordham meets St. Mary's for the eighth time in a show that always has been a colorful one.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that more than $300,000 had been received in the last four days in response to the nation-wide appeal for a $1,000,000 emergency fund to meet problems arising from the mass deportation of Polish Jews from Germany and recent events in Czechoslovakia and Austria.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 3: MAJORS Christenberry, C. W., Adjutant General's Dept., two days' leave, Nov. 12. Cole, H. R., Engrs., to duty as a member of the staff and faculty at the Engineer School, Ft. Belvoir, Va.
Far too little is being invested in research for tomorrow, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, declared tonight at the Industrial Research Conference at Ohio State University.

Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Oct. 29 totaled 708,840 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,212 cars, or 0.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 59,184 cars, or 7.7 per cent, less than for the corresponding week last year, and 105,335 cars, or 13.0 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

John R. Longo, political foe of Mayor Frank Hague, was the principal witness here today before the Federal grand jury investigating alleged violation of civil liberties in Jersey City. Longo, who is serving

Thomas W. Dewing, noted painter of portraits and figure compositions, died early today at his home, 333 West Twentieth Street, at the age of 87. Mr. Dewing, who had been in poor health for some time, had been acutely ill only for a few days.

The textile apparel industries for the next several months will enjoy the benefits of continued recovery inspired by more rapid gains in other industries, A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., and Fairchild Publications, declared today at the annual luncheon-meeting of the Philadelphia Wool and Textile Associaion.

Though nothing came of the recent conference in Washington between instructed delegates of the American Medical Association and the Government's Interdepartmental Committee, it is plain that the issue of medical care turns largely on taxation, insurance or a combination of both.

Get-edge issues made a further all-round improvement in the stock market today, when further investment buying found operators short of stock. Elsewhere conditions were quiet under end-of-the-account influences, but the undertone was firm.

Armistice Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all the churches. Some clergymen will refer to the election of Tuesday, especially the proposed constitutional amendments. Many will offer "A Prayer for the World and the Church," which has been issued by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Mrs. Anne Ipp of 1,612 Fortyninth Street, Brooklyn, active in Jewish charitable circles in the Borough Park section, died on Thursday in the Hotel Hamilton, Manhattan, of a heart attack. Mrs. Ipp, who was 56 years old, was stricken while motoring in Manhattan and was taken to the apartment of friends in the hotel.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, Foreign Minister, are going to Paris Nov. 23 for a three-day visit at the invitation of the French Government, it was announced here tonight.

A net profit of $1,120,032 for the nine months ended on Oct. 2 was reported yesterday by the Scott Paper Company. This result makes allowance for depreciation, interest, Federal and State income taxes and other charges and is equal, after dividends of $12,500 on the $4.50 cumulative preferred stock issued on Sept. 1, to $1.92 each on
The Brooklyn College football team will attempt to break a twogame losing streak when it faces Panzer College this afternoon on the Kingsmen's home field.

Minnesota, beaten by Northwestern last week, will attempt to hit the comeback trail in a Western Conference game with Iowa tomorrow. The Gophers will take to the gridiron intent on holding at least a mathematical chance of retaining their Conference title against a vastly improved Iowa eleven which held Purdue to a scoreless tie a week ago.

Francis H. Walsh, Federal probation officer in charge of the North New Jersey District and former Seton Hall College athlete, died of pneumonia here today at the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of three weeks. He was 35 years old.

Approval by President Roosevelt of additional loans totaling $32,632,000 for fifteen low-rent housing projects in eight cities was announced today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers;

The most determined of all Britain's attempts on the long-distance-flight record, 6,306 miles, now held by Russia, was started at dawn at 3:55 Greenwich time [10:55 P. M., Friday, New York time]. Three Vickers Wellesley

William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, accompanied by Edward L. Reed, Counselor of the Embassy, and Captain Thaddeus Thomson Jr., naval attach, left by train this afternoon for Naples, where tomorrow he will receive George Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago,
The prospect of football's return to Long Island University after a seven-year lapse, appeared bright yesterday when the students overwhelmingly voted for its return.
Exeter defeated the Bowdoin junior varsity, 14 to 0, in a slow football game today. Joe Kane scored on an end run in the second period and Don Bowersox kicked the goal from placement.

One of the most brilliant and best dressed audiences gathered in Paris for some time tonight witnessed Jane Marnac's adaptation of Clare Boothe's American stage success, "The Women," which was produced at Paris' most modern theatre, The Pigalle.

The Treasury's offering of about $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury discount bills to meet a maturing issue was sold today at the equivalent of an average interest rate of 0.022 per cent, compared with 0.027 per cent for a similar issue marketed last Monday.

Spanish Insurgents broadcast a radio announcement tonight that their troops had occupied Mora de Ebro, major objective of their Ebro River offensive. The announcement said Insurgent forces advanced all along the Ebro front, reaching the river in several places in a drive to regain the zone west of the stream lost to government forces last July.

More leases of stores in midtown Manhattan were reported yesterday by brokers. The Stork Shop, a concern specializing in the sale of infants' and children's apparel, will locate at 14 West Fortieth Street, where it has rented a store from the Orthopedic Shoe Store Company.
The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today a report modifying a previous report approving a reorganization plan for the Louisiana North West Railroad Company. The changes were made

The completion of the remodeling of the interior of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, will be celebrated by a series of services beginning tomorrow, when there will be an Armistice Sunday sermon by the Rev. Dr. J. Jeffares McCombe.

Ellen Drew, who attracted. attention as the gamin in love with Ronald Colman in "If I Were King," was assigned her first featured role by Paramount today. She. will appear opposite George Raft in "The Lady's From Kentucky," replacing Shirley Ross, who had been scheduled. Shooting will start toward the end of the month.

One man was shot and wounded in a hold-up late today of the Garcia Vega cigar factory in West Tampa by two white men with faces painted black. They escaped with. an estimated $10;000 of the weekly payroll. Maximo Alonso, an employee,

The New York Stock Exchange instructed yesterday member firms to supply data on purchases and sales of stocks, supplied separately for margin and cash accounts and for round-lot and odd-lot transaotions, in the week ending on Nov. 19.

Within two hours yesterday the grand jury returned indictments in three kidnapping, naming the four men accused of having maintained a combination hideout and death chamber for nearly a year in the basement of Ukrainian Hall at 217 East Sixth Street.

Miss Frances Louise Mackie, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William D. Mackie of Greenwich, was married to John Wilton Cain of Atchison, Kan., in the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, this afternoon by the Rev. Daniel Bliss. pastor of the church.

President Roosevelt today directed a rebuke to what he called a small group of American newspapers which, he said, attempted to mislead the publie through editorial opinions based on misrepresentation and deliberate misstatement of fact.

Set upon putting the Giants out of the race for the Eastern division crown, the Cardinals will arrive here this morning for their National Football League test at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. The locals,
ANDREWS, JOSEPH (Sept. 29, 1937). Gross assets, $118,786; net, $81,291. To Theodosia B. Andrews, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $107,879. Emmett, Marvin Martin, attorneys, 48 Wall St.

Harvard's undefeated harriers carried off the first Big Three title of the year by conquering Princeton and Yale in a triangular cross-country race over the five-mile Nassau course today. The Crimson scored 30 points, the Tigers 40 and the Elis 52. In the dual meet
The Kings County Grand Jury returned twenty-nine indictmentfor fraudulent registration yesterday. David Senft, special assistant attorney general, had presented fifty-eight complaints.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $14,540,594, to be represented by seventy-nine municipalities, as compared with the revised total of $17,183,450 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,001,499.
Although Holy Cross has failed to score a single point in three previous football meetings with Temple, the powerful Crusaders rule favorites to defeat Pop Warner's invading Owls tomorrow.
Loft, Inc. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, a consolidated net loss of $407,534 after deprecia??on, amortization and taxes.

The University of Miami football team shoved a weak Oglethorpe outfit all over the field tonight to roll up a 44-0 score before 13,612. Coach Jack Harding used every available player on the Miami squad. Miami was forced to punt only once.

An Immediate investigation as to why Isaac R. Swezey of Suffolk County was nominated for Supreme Court justice over John R. Vunk, former Suffolk County judge, was ordered yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. after Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for Kings County judge, forwarded to Mr. Bennett a published report that "there are 50,000 reasons" why the-choice was made.

Coach Harvey Harman whisked his Rutgers football players away from the campus at 4:15 P. M. today as the highest excitement and enthusiasm ever evidenced in this city prevailed on the eve of the Scarlet's all-important game with Princeton in the new stadium.
The Manufacturers Safe Deposit Company, 55 Broad Street, New York City, has filed an application with the State ,Banking Department for permission to open a branch office in the World's Fair grounds.

B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party member- of the City Council and general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward, who died last Sunday at Mt. Sinai Hospital, left an estate of less than $500, it was learned yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley granted letters of administration to his widow, Mrs. Clara Richman Vladeck of 2. Horatio Street.

Amid the tang and color of the late New England Fall Leonard Carmichael was inaugurated today as the seventh president of Tufts College. Thirty-nine years old and a -graduate of Tufts, his inauguration was attended by the most distinguished group of educators gathered together in New England since the Harvard tercentenary.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's offer to arrange the 1939 Scandinavian Gold Cup races in Europe, accompanied by the suggestion that Finland act as host, has been received here with the greatest appreciation. The Seawanhaka club,

Edda Goering, Field Marshal Hermann Goering's 5-month-old daughter, was baptized today at Karin Hall, her parents' country estate. Chancellor Hitler was godfather and the ceremony was performed by Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller in the presence of members of the family.

Mrs. Taylor McDougall of Santa Barbara, Calif., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean McDougall, to John Kershaw Deasy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Deasy of Wynnewood, Pa.

An easing, and possible eventual abolition, of the legal restrictions on insurance companies, savings banks and trustees which force them to invest in fixed-interest and repayment obligations, such as socalled high-grade bonds and mortgages, is called for in a statement Issued yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund on behalf of its Committee on Debt Adjustment.

A "living example" of the city's new political order was seen by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in the fact that the hall used by Owney Madden as a night club in the prohibition era now helps to house a WPA sewing shop in which 2,574 persons are employed and 236,000 garments a month produced for distribution to the needy.
Sophomores carry the hopes for victory of Pennsylvania and Michigan in their intersectional football game tomorrow. A crowd of 35,000 was predicted by Michigan athletic department officials.
The closing date of the second All-Nations Prize Novel Competition has been moved forward from Jan. 31 to March 31, according to an announcement from Farrar Rinehart.

Benny Friedman's air-minded City College of. New York eleven has been established as a slight favorite over Providence College in tomorrow's clash on Hendricken Field. Coach Hugh Devore has named his fastest backs for the starting line-up in anticipation of the expected aerial attack.

William A. Brady, who apparently believes that-there is room in town for two organizations of the Theatre Guild scope, now proposes the formation of a permanent acting company for his theatre, The Playhouse. The group would be
The PolishGerman commission to determine the fate of Polish Jews resident in Germany, as well as approximately 10,000 of them already deported, held its second meeting here yesterday.

For the second time since Federal Judge William Clark upheld the right of the C. I. 0. and American Civil Liberties Union to hold meetings in Jersey City parks, the Jersey City authorities acted yesterday to stop an open-air meeting at which one of the liberals denounced by Mayor Frank Hague as "reds" was slated to speak.

The Commodity Exchange Administration issued an order today denying trading privileges in all futures contract commodity markets to S. W. Gongoll of Minneapolis and eight affiliated companies. The order,

Secretary of State Cordell Hull today broke his silence on the latest pronouncements of Japanese officials concerning the intentions of Japan in the Far East and let it be known beyond any question that the United States stood on the treaties to which it was a party, believed in international law and fair play, and

In his first reference to candidates for office in this State, President Roosevelt today indirectly reechoed the Democratic charge that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, was seeking to quit his job as prosecutor for New York County before his work was finished.

After eight days of hearing testimony Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe reserved decision yesterday on a motion for his approval of a plan to reorganize the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation. He declared the hearing closed as to further proof, but said he would allow attorneys to present final arguments on Nov. 16.
A recip rocal trade agreement between the United States and the United Kingdom is now for the first time regarded as assured. The treaty may be signed within a few weeks.
Using an air route for the second time in his Presidential career, General Oscar Benavides will leave for Arequipa Sunday for a five-day visit, in which he will dedicate a number of public works.

The Administration's purpose to keep the question of building up the country's national defense in the foreground during the next session of Congress became more clear today when it was learned that Thomas G. Corcoran, adviser to President Roosevelt on legislation has been taking an active part in the War Department conferences with the electric power companies.

A not guilty plea was entered in General Sessions yesterday by George Fleming, 38 years old, on an indictment charging him with the theft of $103,400 in gems on Oct. 25 from Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Townsend Jr. of Syosset, L. I., by whom he was employed as a chauffeur. Judge Donnellan fixed bail

While the annual circulation of sixteen leading national magazines increased nearly 5,000,000, or 16 per cent, during the nine years ended June 30, newsstand sales dropped nearly 900,000, according to a circulation study issued yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers, through its .magazine committee.

Frank C. Love, New York department commander of the American Legion, and Maurice Stember, department adjutant, announced yesterday the receipt of letters from Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, his opponent for the Governorship, each of which pledged that no Communists would be appointed to public office.

Wilson College will observe the seventieth anniversary of its founding by raising in 1939 and 1940 an anniversary fund of $1,000,000 for buildings and endowment, it was announced following the annual meeting of the board of trustees.

The engagement of Miss Faith Barney, youngest daughter of Dr. J. Dellinger Barney of this city and Dublin, N. H., and the late Mrs. Barney, to William Jackson Woodin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raye Palmer Woodin of Flushing, L. I., and Tenant's Harbour, Me., has been announced by her father.
Voters in nearly 150 localities in fifty-three Ohio counties will have the opportunity Tuesday to decide questions involving the sale of beer, wine and intoxicating liquors.
Students at the Asbury Park High School paid 5 cents a half pint for milk at the school cafeteria today after a month-long boycott for a one-cent price reduction.
Cotton-mill activity declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 113.3, comparing with 113.8 for the preceding week and 108.9 for the week ended Oct. 30, 1937.

Robert F. Straub, president of the New York Produce Exchange, announced yesterday that the board of managers of the Exchange had appointed a committee to report on the possibility of trading in soy bean oil futures.

Estate, less than $10,000. To Henry and Evangeline Ritter, Vineyard Haven, Mass., one-sixteenth residue each; Elizabeth H. Hill, Pinehurst Ave., Dayton, Ohio; Alice Robbins, Vineyard Haven, Mass.; Clare Bartlett, 120 Auburn St., Paterson, N. J., one-eighth residue each; Jessie Crandall Oblinger, sister, executrix, Catskill, N. Y., one-half residue.
Rear Admiral Samuel Wood Bryant, U.S.N., retired, died at his home here late tonight after a long illness at the age of 61. A native of Pennsylvania, he had been living here since September, 1937.
New York University will seek its third victory of the season this afternoon when it meets a small but sturdy Lehigh eleven at Ohio Field. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 o'clock.

The text of President Roosevelt's election speech, broadcast from his home tonight, was as follows: On the eve of another election I have come to Hyde Park and am sitting at my own fireside in my own election district, my own county and my own State.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, challenged his opponent today to tell the New Jersey voters how he, as a "rubber-stamp" Democrat, would vote on the Administration's reorganization bill, if the measure is revived.

WYNC, the city broadcasting station, will begin a new series of programs warning purchasers against various unscrupulous trade practices at 8:15 o'clock this morning William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, said the series would continue every week at the same time. Each broadcast will last

The following address by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, was delivered last night at Jamaica High School, in Queens, and broadcast. As I rode here through this great county of home owners there was victory in the air. A victory for the fine people who make up your great county and the rest of our State.

Trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 15 was 19.88 per cent of total volume, compared with 20.42 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Rural sections of New York City may get complete school units soon, constructed on a smaller scale along the lines of the best new buildings, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. Allen Rogers, chemical engineer and supervisor of the department of chemical engineering at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, since 1920, died early yesterday at his Summer home at Hampden, Me. He was 62 years old and lived at 184 Emerson Place, Brooklyn.
The four-engined De Havilland airliner St. Catherine's Bay caught fire, crashed into a field and then exploded just after taking off from here for Southampton today, killing fourteen persons.
Danger of forest fires increased in New York State again today as dry weather continued and temperatures reached new high levels in several up-State sections.

*Wilbur L. Cross, Dem.; educator; born Mansfield, Conn., April 10, 1862; ed. Yale University and honorary degrees from ten American educational institutions; taught English in elementary and secondary schools; joined faculty of Sheffield Scientific School, Yale University, as instructor in English 1894;

The marriage of Miss Florence Dodd Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sullivan of this community, to Edmund Ambrose Lynch, son of Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch and the late Mr. Lynch, took place this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Hewlett. The rector, the Rev. J. Reginald Moodey, officiated.

Dave Allerdice, Princeton's sophomore passing star, was relegated to the sidelines today because of a sore throat. Coach Tad Wieman said he would start Bob Hinchman, a good passer and blocker but a weak runner, in Allerdice's post at left half against Rutgers.

After Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, received yesterday assurances of support from civil service employes because of his attitude toward the merit system, Governor Lehman, his opponent, issued a statement defending his own record and citing commendations he had received from nonpartisan organizations for his defense of the civil service system.
A gritty band of Carnegie Tech tartans reported ready tonight to "do or die" in their effort to block the path of the triumphant Pittsburgh University Panthers on the gridiron tomorrow.
" A stitch in time saves nine," Grandmother said, Holding her needle up To catch the thread, Peering at me above The quaint steel rim Of spectacles as bright As seraphim:

A 1939 community program, designed to provide activities for young people, discourage vagrancy and juvenile delinquency, develop ways to utilize leisure hours and assist institutions in their programs, was completed today by Kiwanis International for its 2,000 clubs in the United Staes and Canada.
Big games are few and far between on football's program today, though New York will be offered four attractions, topped by the Fordham-St. Mary's intersectional fixture at the Polo Grounds.

A number of residential properties in various sections of the borough figured in the Brooklyn realty deals made known yesterday. The Manufacturers Trust Company sold to a client of Hy. D. sold Agar, Inc., the four-story apartment house at 185 East Ninetysecond Street, 100 by 100.
The following reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area, are assigned to units as indicated: 21st Engineers-2d Lt. John J. Gronck Engr.-Res., 615 Union St., Schenectady, N. Y.

Writing under the caption "A Plea for More Anonymity," Stephen Spender, himself a writer of books, deplores in the Literary Supplement of The Times of London the trend in published book criticism toward signed reviews. The tendency is "to
Bobby Cifers, sensational Kingsport halfback, scored 33 points in a high school game tonight to eclipse the 211-point total made last year by Chicago's Bill De Correvont.
An irregularity in price movements was the outstanding characteristic in dealings in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace, however, was stepped up somewhat.

Formal notification that the next zone of intensive fighting will include Changsha, 200 miles south of Hankow, and Shasi, 120 miles southwest of Hankow, was handed yesterday to third power diplomatic and consular officials in Shanghai by Japanese embassy officials.

The Belvedere Palace in Vienna is a haunted house. Franz Ferdinand lived there as heir-apparent of the imperial throne when he went to his death at Sarajevo, where the defeat of Austria began. Schuschnigg left it to go to a
Paintings from the collections of the late George F. Baker, Mrs. C. B. Alexander and others brought $35,845 last night at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

An attempt to assassinate King George of Greece, now on a private visit to t London, was the theory advanced tonight for a sudden knife attack t on a British consulting surgeon in fashionable Bond Street last e Wednesday night.

In the role of educational counselor, Mayor La Guardia stressed the need for a cultural background for young people to prepare them for the life awaiting them outside of school in a "surprise" speech yesterday at the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Tilden Avenue and East Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

Northeastern University, led by Captain Jimmy Connolly, defeated American International College, 28 to 12, tonight before a crowd of 4,000. Connolly was brilliant as he paced the visitors to their fourth victory in a row over the Aces.

Today THE TIMES publishes a Voters' Directory of candidates for State and county offices in New York City and in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau, Suffolk and Fairfield Counties. Tomorrow it will publish in its New Jersey pages similar lists for Union, Essex, Hudson, Passaic and Bergen Counties.

George F. Johnson, chairman of the Endicott-Johnson Shoe Company, announced yesterday that he would vote for the re-election of Governor Lehman and had accepted appointment as a vice chairman of the Lehman-Poletti Independent Citizens Committee. Reuben L.

Columbia, trying hard to get back into the victory ranks for the first time since the sensational overthrow of Army, finished practice yesterday for this afternoon's game with Virginia still uncertain as to whether the injured Sid Luckman or his understudy, Les Stanczyk, would start at left halfback at Baker Field.

The Federal Council of Protestant Churches in Czechoslovakia, representing 1,000,000 Czechoslovak Protestants, sent a letter on Oct. 15 to Viscount Runciman, head of the recent British mediation mission, signed by its general secretary, J. P. Bartak, and explaining the real situation in this country, particularly as regards the alleged bolshevist menace.

The Mendelssohn Award offered by the Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia, in a nation-wide competition to encourage modern works for large choruses, was won by Robert Elmore, organist and choir master of Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, for his "Three Fantasies." Joseph W.

With a capacity crowd of 35,000 in Archbold Stadium forecast, Colgate and Syracuse will meet tomorrow in the fortieth game of their gridiron rivalry. Feeling among the partisan fans was at its highest point in many years, with the Colgate Red Raiders ruling a favorite.
Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated that automobile assemblyline output this week will be 80,030 cars and trucks, compared with 73,335 last week, and 89,770 this week a year ago.

Increased government control of banking and finance alternately was stressed as essential for the welfare of the people and criticized as stifling individual enterprise at the executive session of the ninth New England Bank Management Conference today in the Hotel Statler, under the auspices of the bankers' committee of the New England council.

Baron Manfred von Killinger, German consul general at San Francisco, declared today that criminal sabotage was responsible for the mysterious explosion which ripped a hole in the German steamship Vancouver here yesterday.

Marking the cordial relations existing between West Point and the National Guard, the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) N. Y. N. G., held a formal review last night at its armory, 643 Park Avenue, In honor of Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy.

*Herbert H. Lehman, Dem. and A. L.; banker; born New York City March 28, 1878; ed. Williams College; entered textile business, becoming vice president and treasurer of firm 1906; became partner Lehman Brothers banking house 1908, and 1913 named member commission to revise State banking laws; captain in Reserve

Parade of WPA unions and Workers Alliance from Madison Square Park East, down Twenty-seventh Street, west to Eighth Avenue, north to Columbus Circle, 11 A. M. Speakers: Michael Quill, Vito Marcantonio, Louis Weinstock, Walter Liebman, Dr. Bells Dodd, Willis Morgan, Sam Wiseman and Joseph Dermody.

A large exhibition of art from Czechoslovakia will open with a preview and reception this evening from 6 to 10 in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West. Fifty-seventh Street. Beginning tomorrow the show will be open to the public. It is to continue

Stocks closed irregularly lower in slightly more active trading; turnover, 1,196,240 shares. United States Government bonds lower, public utility issues steady, rail and foreign groups higher; transactions, $8,688,700.

Mr. and Mrs. Gifford Pinchot of Milford, Pa., are at the Ambassador. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell have returned from Hot Springs, Va., to their home at 1 Sutton Place South. Mr. and Mrs. Orville H. Bullitt of White Marsh, Pa., are at the RitzCarlton.

The New England Council's index of general business activity was 80.0 per cent of the estimated normal in September, as compared with 90.7 per cent in August and 96.2 per cent in September. 1937. The temporary

Fireman 1st grade Gedrge Hamilton of Engine Co. 235 died Nov. 2. Funeral will take place from Roemmeles Funeral Parlors, 1,228-30 Bushwick Ave., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Monday, Nov. 7. Interment at Lutheran Cemretery.

Representative John J. O'Connor, who was defeated for renomination as a Democrat and is running as a Republican, must not use the word "Democratic" in his campaign literature in connection with the name of his independent Andrew Jackson party, but he is still at

Mrs. Susan Cleveland Yeomans, a sister of President Grover Cleveland and widow of Lucien T. Yeomans, Republican leader, died yesterday in her home, 631 Delamere Place, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 95 years old.

ANNOUNCEMENT of two V-8 cars for 1939 was made last Friday by the Ford Motor Company. Having hydraulic brakes and wheelbase lengths of 112 inches, the two lines are Ford De Luxe V-8 and Ford V-8. Both carry teardrop fenders, front ends in which the hood begins in a vertical line and relationship in design to the new Mercury and the Lincoln-Zephyr, also made by the company.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest. Queries should be addressed to the Editor of Queries and Answers NEW YORK TIMES.

The Republican party is facing a sharp upturn in strength in Tuesday's nation-wide elections for members of Congress and State officials, according to a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

A more peaceful prospect In Europe and the business upturn-- at home have brightened the outlook for Winter travel according to :the monthly survey and forecast of the American Express Travel Service.
Many members of the Georgia Society entertained parties at the organization's supper dance last night in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador.
Italy's two new fast cruisers, Duca d'Aosta and Eugenio di Savoia, sailed today on a world cruise originally scheduled for two months ago but postponed then because of the European crisis.

An immediate saving of "more than $500,000 a year" for school districts was predicted today if a plan permitting those operating their own buses to purchase gasoline and accessories at "State contract prices" is put into effect.

A crowd of 15,000 saw the Pennsylvania Military College eleven register an impressive 32-to-2 victory over Delaware University in their annual contest on the indoor gridiron in the Municipal Auditorium tonight.

While it is true that the results of the nation-wide elections on Tuesday may have an important bearing on stock market sentiment, it is also true that the present highly developed systems of surveys of public opinion tend to remove the element of surprise.

Muhlenberg defeated Drexel today, 136, in an Eastern Pennsylvania collegiate circuit game. Muhlenberg scored in the first period. Zuzzio blocked Ehmling's kick and Milo Sewards took the ball to race 40 yards for a touchdown.

Colonel William Preston Lane, last survivor of Princeton University's football team which played the first intercollegiate game against Rutgers University, died today of heart disease. His age was 87.
A State Circuit Court here has been asked to decide whether organized medicine can dictate exclusion of non-members from practice in a public hospital.

The election of at least five Republican Governors, two United States Senators and upward of thirty members of the House of Representatives in the nation at Tuesday's election is forecast by political observers in the various States.

A new plan for checking up on students in Colgate University, to find out if they "mean business," has been devised, and now, instead of waiting until the senior year, officials will know at the end of the sophomore year whether the student really wants to do his scholars tic work.

The marriage of Miss Ethel Blake Brown, daughter of Mrs. George Alexander Brown and the late Mr. Brown, to Charles Ellis Mead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Mead of Weston, Mass., took place yesterday at noon at the home of the bride's mother, 277 Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James's Episcopal Church.

Dr. Irvin Abell of Louisville, Ky., president of the American Medical Association, received tonight the fiftysixth annual Laetare Medal of the University of Notre Dame. The medal is awarded to an outstanding Catholic layman.

Robert D. Murray Jr., '41, of White Plains, N. Y., is the winner of the Henry A. Stinnecke Prize for proficiency in the classics, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Duane R. Stuart, chairman of the Department of Classics at Princeton University.

Bela Darwin Eisler, New York attorney specializing in tax cases, advises all property owners to check the recent supplemental record of assessed valuations recently compiled by the Tax Commission to ascertain if their properties have been included.
Instead of one national rear commander, a post being filled by William K. Anderson of Dearborn, Mich., the United States Power Squadrons are on the verge of creating number cf these high rankers.

Dr. Thomas William Edmondson of this city. Professor Emeritus of Mathematics and former acting 'dean of the Graduate School of New York University, died last night in Mount Vernon Hospital after a short illness. He was 69 years old.

Third in last Saturday's New England Futurity, the Wheatley Stable's Gilded Knight came back at Narragansett Park today to win the Wannamoisett Handicap by four lengths from A. E. Silver's Heather Time.
The Official Secrets Act and other legislation being used to put restrictions on the British press were denounced at a meeting here today by the National Union of Journalists,

The marriage of Mrs. Eleanor Pat??erson Roberts of this city, daugh??er of Major Gen. Robert U. Pat??erson, U. S. A., retired, and the ate Mrs. Patterson, to Osgood Marsh Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. ?? Osgood Nichols of Short Hills, N. J., took place here this after??oon in All Souls Unitarian Church.

Counsel for Thomas J. Mooney told the Supreme Court today that the "personal discernment" of the justices "should lead them to the conclusion that either Mooney is an innocent man or that he is the most astounding and arrant hypocrite in history."

George A. Clark of Millburn, N. J., president and general manager of the Rahway Valley Railroad, has purchased the home of H. B. Doland on Woodlawn Road at Lake Mohawk, Sussex County, N. J. New homes are being constructed for Gordon H. Knowles of East Orange and Gustaf Seasberg of Brooklyn.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Governor Lehman, Senator Wagner, Mayor La Guardia and Newbold Morris, discussing the Constitutional Amendments, WOR, 2 to 3 P. M.

A valiant Carnegie Tech band rose today to pull mighty Pittsburgh from atop the nation's football perch and accomplish a feat other teams from coast to coast had been trying unsuccessfully to do for two years.

Garden enthusiasts and other horticulture fanciers of the North Shore communities have been looking forward for weeks to the Autumn Flower Show which will be held at the Pratt Oval here on Monday and Tuesday.

" There'll Be a Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight" was the prophetic tune the Syracuse band played late today after the valiant Orange eleven had driven the home rooters mad by gaining a 7-0 triumph over the ancient foe from the Chenango Valley. Colgate's Red Raiders.

Benny Goodman and his clarinet graced with their presence the concert given by the Budapest String Quartet yesterday afternoon at the hour of 5:30 in Town Hall. In some classic breasts this roused apprehension, but the alligators and the jitterbugs said that Benny would show them! And he did, in the most legitimate matter.

Despite her long personal friendship with President Roosevelt, he never once has "brought pressure" on her to support any measure in which he was interested, Representative Caroline O'Day, candidate for re-election, declared yesterday at a rally of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization in New York at the WaldorfAstoria.

Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, was welcomed with signal honors on reaching Italy today to report to the Pope on the recent Eucharistic Congress in New Orleans and to attend the forthcoming beatification of Mother Cabrini.

Representative George Holden Tinkham of Boston returned on the North German Lloyd liner Europa Friday, only vaguely aware that Tuesday is election day and that he is up for re-election for his thirteenth term.

The program for dividing the property formerly known as the Hotel Victoria, at Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue, into two smaller hostelries, the Victoria of about 600 rooms and the Hotel Abbey, at 145 West Fifty-first Street, with about 430 rooms, was completed last week when the new furniture was delivered for suites in the Abbey.

Mayor La Guardia severely criticized school officials and parents yesterday for painting a gloomy picture of the New York City school system. This city, he asserted, is doing more than any other "in the whole world" for its children.

The Sudeten German party was formally taken into the National Socialist party here today in the presence of Rudolf Hess, Nazi Deputy Leader. Konrad Henlein, chief of the new Sudetenland district, presented to Herr Hess the Sudeten party's flag as a symbol of the amalgamation.

Since the war the political axis of France has turned on the Radical Socialists. Most of the governing coalitions have been formed around this party. When the Government tended toward the Right, the Radical Socialists constituted the Left flank; when the movement was toward the Left, as in the Popular Front, they were the Right wing of the ruling combination.

ALL good Americans are supposed to go to Paris when they die. But before that inevitable transmigration, which has its unattractive features these days, most of the aforementioned citizens go to the Radio City Music Hall-that is, when they're in New York.

Abraham Walt, Yiddish poet and editor, who wrote under the name of Abraham Liessin, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 808 Adee Avenue, the Bronx. He was 66 years old.
