Since 1913 he had been editor of The Zukunft, monthly Yiddish literary magazine, published by the Forward Association, which publishes The Jewish Daily Forward.

Miss Gwynn Grant, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Coulter D. Huyler of Round Hill, Greenwich, was married to Roland Ruutz-Rees, aircraft engineer and adopted son of Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees of Greenwich, in the Round Hill Community Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Harold E. Wilson, the pastor, officiated.

Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor of Austria and former head of the Heimwehr, and his beautiful actress wife, Nora Gregor, are in Paris looking for jobs and it is reported they are considering emigrating to the United States.

Joseph Yulinsky and Paul Futterman, builders. have started construction on a new group of twostory homes on Seventeenth Ave??le. between Sixty-sixth and Sixtyseventh Streets in the Bensonhurst area of Brooklyn.

Members of the New York State branch of the Shut-In Society will meet for their annual session on Friday at 11 A. M. at the Hotel McAlpin to hear reports of the year's work in assisting more than 1,000 men and women beneficiaries. Seven directors will be elected at the business meeting.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clayton L. Jenks of Boylston Center, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Tufts Jenks, to James van Benschoten Dresser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Aytoun Dresser of Brooklyn and Salisbury, Conn.

John W. Caveney, editor of the Royal Arcanum Bulletin and retired superintendent of final disposition for the New York Department of Sanitation, died in his home, 30-04 146th Street, Flushing, Queens, yesterday afternoon. He was 65 years old.

Clarkson College outrushed the Alfred University eleven today to send the Saxons down to their second straight defeat, 13 to 0. Checked in the first half by a driving rain and a strong Alfred line, the Engineers opened their offensive in the second half after Whit Reed had intercepted a Saxon pass and raced 40 yards.

Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, will speak Monday at 2 P. M. in the chapel of Pennington School on the concluding day of the three-day celebation of the hundredth anniversary of the founding of the school.

Governor George H. Earle brought the Democratic campaign in Pennsylvania to a climax at a party rally tonight in a speech declaring the issue in Tuesday's election is "between Roosevelt liberalism and Republican reaction."

RADICAL departures from established convention in the design of motor-car chassis are not found in many of the new car chassis offered for 1939. There are, however, at least an unusual number of alterations in details of design.

Canton fell to the Japanese not through treason but because the Chinese command wanted to spare the civilian populace, according to Dr. Harry Talbot, a Briton, who has just arrived in New York from service with the Chinese Red Cross.

There will be many split ballots in Rockland County on Tuesday. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, is regarded as likely to carry Rockland by a close margin, while Lawrence J. Murray Jr., Democratic candidate for the Assembly, is considered as assured of re-election by more than 2,000, according to prevailing opinion throughout the county.
The marriage of Miss Marie Anna Huff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Huff of South Orange, to David E. Finlay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Finlay of Orange,

The question of prohibition crops up again Tuesday in forty-six towns of twenty-four counties where local option ballots will be cast. Forty-three of the towns will vote, the State Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control said, on whether all alcoholic drinks shall be sold.

Southern California derailed the California Rose Bowl-bound special. today, handing the Bears their first defeat of the football season and taking the inside track to the Pacific Coast Conference football championship.

The possibility that the wool goods industry may eventually be placed under the jurisdiction of the general textile committee under the Wages and Hours Act was discussed in the market last week, and it was believed that this may be achieved by the establishment first of a wool goods committee headed by Donald M. Nelson, who is chairman of the textile committee, and later the merging of the two groups.

Three bombing planes, with which the British Air Force Is attempting to break the world's long-distance flight record, were reported early this morning flying strongly across the Bay of Bengal on their 7,162mile journey from Ismailia, Egypt, to Australia.

TRAVANCORE, the native State at the toe of the Indian peninsula, is unique in that the government offices, including courts of law and schools, start working at 7:30 o'clock in the morning and close at 12:30 in the afternoon.

The Penn freshman eleven defeated Columbia's Cubs in their annual game on Franklin Field today, 7-0. The Red and Blue's score came early in the fourth period, when Fred Deringer tossed a pass from Columbia's 42-yard line to Eddie Allen, who caught it on the 25 and ran to the 4 before he was knocked out of bounds.

Order of Retirement and Dismissal To take effect 12 midnight, Nov 5: PATROLMAN-Frank J. Smith, 28th Precinct, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Nov. 21, 1918. Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate. To take effect 12 midnight. Nov. 5: PATROLMAN-John F. Healy, 61st Precinct. at $1,368 per annum. Appointed Jan. 14, 1920.

Under the supervision of Director William L. Austin, the Bureau of the Census is completing plans for carrying out the biggest assignment in its history, the decennial census of 1940. Because of the many changes that have taken place 'in the industrial, social and economic life of the American people since 1930, the next census, the sixteenth, is regarded as the most important ever undertaken.

One explanation of the rows of empty shelves day after day in some of the most important sections of Mostorg, Moscow's leading department store -State-owned, of course-is given in a vigorous attack on the store's management by the newspaper Pravda.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Paragraph 5, Special Orders 143. dated Oct. 31, 1938, pertaining to Lt. Col. Anson F. Robinson, Inf.-Res.. 99 John St., New York, N. Y., is revoked. Lt. Col. Anson R. Robinson, Inf.-Res., 99 John St., New York. N. Y., assigned to the 77th Division, is attached for training to the 40th Infantry (RAI).
In the first football game between the two schools, Hotchkiss overcame Loomis today by 19-12 under an overcast sky which made conditions almost ideal.

Interceptions paved the way for two touchdowns as Xavier High's eleven vanquished Brooklyn Prep, 12-7, yesterday at Boys High Field. The victors scored in the- first period on Tom Doyle's lateral to-Ed Reberkenny and in the last quarter clinched victory on an aerial from Doyle to James Donohue.

The fifty-eighth annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science will be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor. There will be discussions at three sessions on the general topic, "Monopoly and Competition in Industry and Labor."

Country-wide requests for antiaircraft protection, renewed demands for coastal defenses, inquiries about the modernization of wartime cantonments and the supposed "requisition" of hotels and private buildings as barracks are among numerous similar inquiries being received by the War Department. it became known yesterday.

Propaganda in Great Britain to protect British possessions against German colonial demands was declared necessary today by the Southwest Africa League, which was formally constituted at a mass meeting of residents.

At least a "50-50" chance of removing the tax upon chain stores in Colorado in Tuesday's election was seen in chain store circles here yesterday. A victory at the Colorado polls, following the successful campaign against the tax in California, would help the chains greatly in their fight against the proposed Patman "death sentence" measure for chains in interstate commerce, it was asserted.

The marriage of Miss Betty Ward to Whitney Trowbridge Kelsey took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. W. Lysle Alderson, 31 East Seventy-ninth Street.
The year 1938 promises to become the "most healthful in the city's history," it has been reported to Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records.
Mrs. Mary Tebbetts Rorschach of this city, widow of Lieut. Frank Rorschach Jr., U. S. N., was married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Church to Frederick Addeman Jenckes of 70 Park Avenue.

MANHATTAN BELTON. THOMAS A. (Oct. 27).--Estate, less than $10.000. To Eleanore P. Belton, widow, executrix, 780 Riverside Dr., residue. GUGGENHEIM. ALBERT (Oct. 6). Estate, less than $10,000. To Rheta Mayer, daughter, petitioner, Greenwich; Albert J. Guggenheim Baron, Greenwich, and Maurice B. Baron, London, England, equal shares in residue.

Governor La Follette's personal letter to old-age pensioners, which has been followed by another from Progressive party headquarters asking for votes, did not constitute a violation of the Corrupt Practices Act, the Attorney General's Department ruled today.

A CORRESPONDENT delights us by asking, apropos of THE TIMES'S review of Tos canini's recent performance of Tchaikovsky's Sixth symphony, how a music reporter can find anything new to say about a work which is familiar and often repeated.

Five New England properties were reported yesterday by Previews, Inc., has having been sold. Among them is the 100-acre estate with a twenty-room house formerly owned by Dana Osgood in Hopedale, Mass., which was purchased by Ray C. Johnson of Boston. Guy D. Tobey was the broker.

Return to traditional Suffolk County Republican pluralities is expected in this stronghold of party regularity in the general election on Tuesday. Overoptimistic claims are being put forward by the leaders of both major parties, but it is significant that the 'Democrats, in private conversations, do not go beyond the hope of making appreciable inroads into the normal Republican strength and the claim of a good chance for the election of "at least one Assemblyman."

C. B. Cochran is back in the news after a long absence with a light comedy, "Schottische," by a young actor, Gerard Tyrrell, which is scheduled for as soon as Mr. Cochran can make up the cast. He also is engaged in the preparation of a musical show which boasts a stronger story than most.
DESPITE recent changes within its borders, the purveyors of music and drama in Prague have agreed to serve their public with increased zeal.

A. B. Davis High School remained undefeated in W. I. A. A. competition by scoring on one swift thrust against Port Chester High at Howard Field today, 7 to 0. Ed Fitzsimmons turned the trick with a 71-yard dash down the sideline after a sweep around left end from his own 29.
President Roosevelt, cast aside thoughts of politics today to motor with Secretary Morgenthau over his family estate and around near-by Poughkeepsie.

Massachusetts was the legal domicile of Colonel Edward Howland Robinson Green at the time of his death, and thus that State is entitled to levy a tax of nearly $5,000,000 upon the $36,000,000 estate of the son of Hetty Green, the Supreme Court was advised today.

WHAT are "The Ferrar Papers" and whom do they concern? Dr. Blackstone has given full answer in his scholarly and delightful book, a narrative of Nicholas Ferrar, based on manuscripts copied from the original "Life," by his brother,
Bullion production at Dome Mines, Ltd., for October was valued at $616,263, compared with $609,191 for September, and $625,815 for October, 1937.

The disclosure last week that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will spend $195,000,000 this year on rehabilitating and enlarging its facilities has served to call attention again to the vast sums of money needed by the oil industry in its constant race to keep ahead of obsolescence and to keep pace with with the steadily growing demand for its products.

Garfield High School continued to lead the Group 4 football teams of New Jersey by gaining a 19-to-0 decision over Asbury Park High School in the Passaic Stadium today. Garfield is undefeated this season.

The upturn in the sales of business machines and equipment, which got under way toward the end of August, has been steadily accelerated and this month will witness the year's first gain over the corresponding period of 1937, according to executives of leading companies yesterday.

The struggle for civil liberties in Jersey City seems about to enter a new phase. For years, Mayor Hague has been fond of declaring that when decisions on such questions are to be made, he makes them Now he has been informed with the full force of Federal law that even in Hudson County there is an authority higher than his own.

The Treasury published today a revised table of averages of the yields on long-term Treasury bonds, which showed that the average yield on bonds not due or callable for twelve years was 2.57 per cent for the first ten months of 1938, compared with 3.68 per cent for 1926.

TOMORROW night, weather permitting, amateur photographers will be turning their cameras skyward to record the year's second lunar eclipse; for at least two hours of this unique shadow play, during which the earth comes between the sun and the moon, camera men will have ample opportunity to take celestial photographs.

The Spanish people are reconciled to another Winter-perhaps another year-of war. At least those on the government side in Spain can have no doubts about that, for Premier Juan Negrin's oft-repeated declarations have made that perfectly clear. There are some doubts,
A light and gallant Westbury High School football team today broke Hempstead's ten - game winning streak, gaining a sensational 7-6 victory before a crowd of 6,000.

Bucknell University will put into operation at the beginning of the second semester the Carnegie system of retirement pensions, according to an announcement by President Arnaud C. Marts at the November meetings of the faculty.

Miss Harriet de Benneville Crawford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. P. Wickersham Crawford of this city, was married this afternoon to David Connor Tatman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Skelly Tatman of Connersville, Ind.

Miss Marjorie Ella Whitehead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon D. Whitehead of Chatham, was married to N. Douglas Smith, son of Norwood O. Smith, also of this place, this evening in Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Robert A. Biggerstaff.

Sterling-dollar exchange moved today within the range of only 3/8 cent, closing a trifle less favorable to sterling, at $4.76 to the pound. The spot franc was firmer at 178 3/4 francs, but the discount for three months widened to 4 1/2 francs. Other currencies were virtually unaltered.

An active demand for all types of rugs and carpets was expected to develop in the wholesale market here this week as buyers seek to cover requirements before price advances averaging 5 per cent go into effect on Nov. 15.

The grim drama of an air raid was simulated with such realism throughout the 640 square miles of Hertfordshire early this morning that many war-shocked veterans among the 12,000 volunteers engaged in this most extensive of air raid precautions tests yet held in Britain went about their duties, they said, in actual fear of death.

The twentieth anniversary of the Armistice ending the World War will be commemorated here this week with parades, services and other events under the sponsorship of military, patriotic and religious organizations.
The political campaign which is now dragging to a hoarse-voiced, tongueweary close has been fought upon no clear-cut major issue applicable to all the States alike.

Republican claims to as many as eighty additional House seats were countered today by the Democratic assertion that a Democratic loss of fewer than fifty would break all precedents as party leaders here indulged in their last minute preelection predictions.

Cornell's 150-pound football team defeated the Yale lightweights, 19-0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today, Everts, Nicol and White scoring on drives of 22, 13 and 55 yards. Mathers set the stage for two of the touchdowns by recovering a fumble and intercepting a pass, Everts paving the way for the other by blocking a kick on Yale's 22.
Royalist student demonstrators turned loose a dozen live pigeons in the great hall of the Sorbonne today, breaking up solemn ceremonies at opening of classes at the University of Paris.
Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, A. S. Cornhill was the winner of the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. T. H. Lawrence and B. L. Duke took handicap prizes.
Many evidences are apparent, according to builders and architects, that storm windows will be more freely used in the near future than has been customary in recent years.
Five hundred women's clubs in the State have been asked to vote for Amendment No. 4 "to accomplish better living conditions for people in urban and rural communities."

IDLE tongues in Twenty-one and Grey's Basement, it seems, are. convinced that hell hath no fury like ClareBoothe's hate. Antipathy or sympathy for the hapless souls who have been hoist with her petard, or think they have, simply must be voiced lest it be suspected that one is wearing long skirts this season.

Many of the articles to be sold at the eighteenth annual Christmas sale and tea sponsored by directors of Hope Farm were secured both here and abroad during the past Summer by members of the arrangements committee.

The factory building formerly owned by M. W. Moffat at 185 Hackensack Street, East Rutherford, N. J., has been purchased by Charvos, Inc., a new firm formed in this country by Andre Charvos, president of Manufacture Francais de Compas of Ligney-en-Barre, France, and Samuel Sanders of Teaneck, president of L. Oppleman, Inc., importers of engineering and optical instruments.

WHETHER the recent European war scare and the subsequent rush of many nations to improve and enlarge their air forces was a factor in the recent decision of President Roosevelt to provide the navy with a new dirigible is a matter of conjecture.

THE president or tne Bhush Museums Association thinks that a museum of old horsedrawn vehicles should be the next type to be developed in England. Just to indicate the need of such a museum. he wants to know how many Englishmen could define a victoria, a phaeton, a berlin, a landau, a sociable, a gig, a clarence or a brougham. Most Englishmen, he thinks, could not define half these now obsolete Victorian contraptions.
THIS week's success story involves "Old Bill," the buffalo who posed for the original buffalo nickel (according to a wired release from the Warner Brothers West Coast studios).

Governor A. Harry Moore today proclaimed next week as "American Education Week" and asked that New Jersey citizens take advantage of the occasion to become better acquainted with the needs and accomplishments of the schools.

Information filed in court here today by District Attorney J. J. McGuigan charges three men and one 19year-old girl, all Germans, with a felony in "unlawfully obtaining information affecting national defense."
HOT SPRINGS NATIONAL PARK, Ark.-The Federal Government is in partner ship with the community of Hot Springs in a project designed to turn the spa into a recreation center.

Freshmen today point their studies to a definite end and recognize the college as a vocational laboratory, the results of a survey of 1,114 first-year students at Hunter College show. More, than 1,000 of those questioned said they had a specific vocational aim.
James T. Moore, an assistant engineer in the Newark, N. J., sewer department, died here last night at the age of 54.
Tallying at least one touchdown in each period, the strong Blair Academy football team swept to a 48-tovictory over Morristown School on the losers' gridiron today.
A scheduled auction of a United States one-cent stamp of 1851 was called off today when the dealer announced a New York museum and an unnamed American millionaire had asked to see it.
Mr. and Mrs. William C. Bramhall and Miss Priscilla Bramhall of Boston are at the New Weston. Mrs. Theodore Weld Sterling of Lookaway Farm, Buckingham Valley, Pa., has arrived at the Commodore.

The former country estate of the late Colonel Rhinelander Waldo at Garrison-on-Hudson, Putnam County, has been placed by the present owners in charge of Lawrence Management, Inc., of Bronxville and Mount Kisco for development and sale under restrictions which will prevent any undesirable invasion in the property area.
Allen V. Heely, headmaster of Lawrenceville School, welcomed nearly 200 fathers in Memorial Hall last night to the school's annual fathers' week-end.

Chicago made a gallant start against Harvard today, Bob Wasem scoring a pair of touchdowns by completing long forward passes from Sollie Sherman, but Dick Harlow's Cambridge team gradually regained its poise and made a riot of the football game, which it eventually won, 47 to 13.

Sales of bottling equipment, supplies and transportation units at the of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, held last week at the Port Authority Building, totaled approximately $2,500,000, an increase of about 25 per cent over the New Orleans show of last year, it was estimated yesterday by officials of the association.
A flying postoffice that picks up and delivers mail without landing was demonstrated today to a group of aviators and business men.

A new hotel known as the Essex House is nearing completion in Miami Beach, Fla., on the corner of Collins Avenue and Tenth Street. It is three stories in height with a tall tower on the corner section and was designed by the Architect Henry Hohauser for the owners, Maurice L. Fleischman and William G. Mechanic.

A committee representing New Jersey communities, headed by Frank Hague, Mayor of Jersey City, has filed a brief protesting against the petition of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company to the Interstate Commerce Commission in which the railroad seeks permission to charge a ten-cent fare between points on its line in Hudson County, N. J., and its terminal in Cortlandt Street, New York, for an experimental period.

Their vaunted power stalemated by Temple's fighting defenses today, the Holy Cross Crusaders hurried into the air and soared to a smashing 33-0 victory over Pop Warner's Owls on Ronnie Cahill's perfect passing before 14,000 fans. Cahill, a brilliant little 155-pound halfback, pitched the Owls dizzy.

Rhode Island State's famed spread formation brought a last-minute 21-20 football victory over Connecticut State before an alumni home-coming crowd of 5,000 today. McNamara scooped up a 25-yard lateral pass which Abbruzzi had jumbled, evaded half the Connecticut team and galloped 50 yards for the deciding touchdown.

Great Britain's naval interests in Portugal will be strengthened by the appointment, announced today, of Engineer - R e a r Admiral Rene Charles Hugill as the Portugese. Government's naval Industrial director.

THE Philatelic Division of Canada's Postoffice Department made public last week an advance photograph of the double-size 13-cent ultramarine stamp which will be released on Nov. 15 as an addition to the Dominion's "new reign" series.
St. Paul's School of Garden City downed Stony Brook Academy, 18-0, today, scoring once in the second session and adding two tallies in the last stanza.
Myron St. Clair Burr, prominent in local and State politics and for a half century a local business man, died today at the Manchester Memorial Hospital after a short illness.

The class of 1941 of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and the College of Engineering has been declared the winner for the second time in the annual Freshman-Sophomore Song Contest for the Greenfield-Distler Cup, according to Professor Alfred M. Greenfield, supervisor of chapel music and choir at the University Heights campus.

Chet Conant's 95-yard run after intercepting a forward pass on the 5yard line made it possible for Massachusetts State to chalk up its first victory in six weeks as the Coast Guard eleven was downed on Alumni Field, 7-0, before a large Father's Day crowd today.
Biggest news of the week in the Middle West was the breaking of the long drought that was harming Fall crops and causing prairie fires in Kansas and forest fires in Southern Missouri.

THE Illinois State Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution unveiled recently a monument on the west, or the Illinois, end of the George Rogers Clark Memorial Bridge which spans the Wabash River, forming the boundary between Illinois and Indiana.

STEP by step instruction of juvenile automobile drivers, in a safe driving course that includes actual handling of cars on a "proving" ground and in city traffic, has just begun for the third year at the McDonogh School in McDonogh, Md. An-enrollment of eighty-four boys surpasses the numbers taught in either of the preceeding years.

Billy Mims completed two lastperiod touchdown passes today to give Georgia a 19-to-6 victory over a scrapping Florida eleven. The crowd of 17,000 persons saw the third period end with the score 6-6. Then Ned Barbre intercepted a Florida pass on the Bulldog 33.

A season of plays written by students is the feature of the program planned this year by Masque and Gown, dramatic organization at Bowdoin College. The season will open in December with an original musical comedy, "Take It Away," and, except for the traditional Shakespearean presentation at Commencement, will continue to stress efforts created by its own undergraduate authors.
St. Louis University shower surprising strength but was defeated by the University of Mississippi today, 14-12, in an intersectional game before a homecoming crowd of 8,500.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Bullock of this place and Branford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Bullock, to T. Edwin Andrew Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Edwin Andrew of Methuen Mass.
THIS book might be classified as a combination of autobi ography, biography and philosophy, written in a charming essay style with a delicately humorous twist.

Recent graduates of Bryn Mawr College are continuing a trend away from the strictly educational field for their careers, according to a vocational survey covering members of the classes of 1936, 1937 and 1938.

Walter L. Fry, the country's first "sit-down boss," was ordered today to appear in court Nov. 15 to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the Fry Products Company which he heads. A suppressed bill of complaint was filed in Circuit Court Oct. 26 charging that Mr. Fry falsified reports and diverted assets of the firm.

With their campaigns virtually brought to a close after weeks of oratorical charge and counter-charge, W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for United States Senator, and William H. J. Ely, his Democratic opponent, awaited confidently tonight the result of next Tuesday's election.

The Association for the Study of Negro Life and History will hold its annual meeting here next Friday, Saturday and Sunday, according to an announcement yesterday by Harcourt A. Tynes, chairman of the sponsors' committee.

Four persons prominent in industry and finance will come to Williams College this Winter to lecture on economic problems confronting the business man. William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange; Kenneth F. Burgess, Chicago lawyer and railroad specialist and head of the board of trustees at Northwestern;

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Heft of 225 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Heft, to Seymour A. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Smith of Ridgefield. N. J.

Purdue punctured the Buckeye bubble today, 12 to 0, virtually wrecking Ohio State's Western Conference title aspirations with a pair of last-period touchdown thrusts which left a crowd of 54,365 gasping.

Kept in the running by some mighty fine punting by the 142pound Ted Mazur, Manhattan College made its own break after three and a half periods of lukewarm football and then proceeded to eke out a 3-0 victory over an aggressive North Carolina State eleven before 8,000 persons at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

ROLAND YOUNG, who is a comedian but can be serious. when necessary, has an idea that Hollywood can lend a helping hand to its own. extras with ultimate benefit to itself. And his idea is to establish a "little theatre" in Hollywood, with the talent limited entirely to screen extras.

Gerard Barnett of Bishop Loughlin Memorial H. S. capped three years of trying with a decisive victory in the seventeenth annual cross-country championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday when he covered the two-and-one-half-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in 11:56.

More than 400 performers of stage, screen, radio and opera will take part on Nov. 16 in the annual "Night of Stars" performance at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the United Palestine Appeal. The goal is $100,000 for refugee settlement in Palestine.

John Harlan Amen began his investigation yesterday into reports that there were "50,000 reasons" to account for the naming of Isaac R. Swezey instead of John R. Vunk as the Suffolk County nominee for the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Edgar of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Frances Edgar, to John Stuart Booth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Booth, also of Bernardsville.

The Haverford College football team defeated Hamilton College, 18-7, today. Completely outplayed in the first half, Haverford came back strong and scored three times on runs by Beeler, Derr and Magill.
Referee Alvin Bell of Little Rock was escorted off the field by State policemen today after Rice had won a hectic Southwest Conference football battle from Arkansas 3-0.

A BIOGRAPHY of Neville Chamberlain is announced for publication on Dec. 1 by E. P. Dutton Co. The title is "The Man Who Made the Peace," and the author is Stuart Hodgson, editor of The London Daily News for ten years.

Director American Institute of public Opinion WITH the political campaign racing into the home stretch, observers everywhere are watching for clues to the future trends in American politics. Do the people want Congress to reassert its leadership in legislative matters? Do they want a fundamental realignment in our two-party system of government? What are the chances for the formation of a labor party?
Administration circles heard today that President Rooseveit intended to ask Congress to authorize one of the world's mightiest air fleets, numbering from 7,000 to 10,000 planes, for the army.

Great quantities of bones of Ice Age animals have been dug out of asphalt deposits known as the McKittrick Tar Seeps, about thirty miles west of Bakersfield, Calif., by a party working under the direction of Dr. Chester Stock of the California Institute of Technology, a research associate of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
Michael J. McGowan, chief train dispatcher of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 62. He lived at 319 West 105th Street.

Not since the general election in 1915 when, as in this year, a constitutional convention had met to revise the organic law, have the voters of this State been called upon to approve or disapprove so many changes in the State Constitution as will be submitted to them at the polls Tuesday.

Calling attention to the business growth and shopping activity in the Brick Church commercial area of East Orange, N. J., Frank H. Taylor, head of the East Orange brokerage firm bearing his name, cites the fact that the Hale Building at 519-21 Main Street and the adjoining structure known as 2 Prospect Place at the southeast corner of that thoroughfare and Main Street are both 100 per cent rented.

Representative John J. O'Connor accused Mayor La Guardia yesterday of lending himself to a "petty trick calculated to block my reelection as chairman of the House Rules Committee when I return to Congress."

A total of 17,800,000 bags of coffee will have been exported this year through Dec. 31, according to the estimate of the National Coffee Department, but if exports to Germany are resumed, the total will surpass this figure.

TOMORROW marks the twenty-first anniversary of Soviet Russia's Air Corps. The event will be duly celebrated in Russia, and doubtless will be noted throughout the world. Against the background of this milestone a review of Soviet aviation for 1939 is particularly apropos.

The marriage of Miss Ann Robertson Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Lewis Campbell of 930 Park Avenue, to Donald Howes Gleason of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bemis Gleason of Newton, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent.

The announcement by the Social Security Board that new applications for unemployment benefits in September were only about three-quarters as large as in August is welcome confirmation of other reports of a continued decline in unemployment.

Since August, 1935, when the Social Security Act became the law of the land, the subject has been given much careful thought. Today, advocates of a liberalization of the provisions of the act have a decidedly popular appeal.

MISS FARRAR has, I think, given us the best singer's autobiography in many years. Her professional career up to 1916 Miss Farrar has already sketched for us in her "Geraldine Farrar: The Story of an American Singer."

A plea for the restoration of "economic normalcy" was made here tonight by John Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a radio address intended to answer the radio speech delivered last night by President Roosevelt.

Funeral services for Viscount J. Henri de Sibour,- Washington architect, were ,conducted today in St. John's Episcopal Church, opposite the White House, with many notables in attendance. The services were conducted by Canon Anson Phelps Stokes of the Washington Cathedral, a classmate, roommate and clubmate at Yale University.

Although various classes in vocational and industrial schools have built houses, the house project of vocational building trades class of the Champaign Senior High School, Champaign, Ill., is considered unique.

Niagara's Purple Eagles trounced Waynesburg by 14-0 today, for their first undefeated season at home since 1932. The victory was Niagara's fifth straight and this sixth in seven starts. Dan De Santis and Al Lipinski made the touchdowns.

There is nothing new to Washington in legislative investigations of un-American activities; three of them have been held in the last six or seven years. But none of the previous inquiries ever received the publicity or aroused the antagonism that have developed from the current inquiry being run by Representative Martin Dies of Texas.
Realty buying in the Red Bank and Shrewsbury areas of Monmouth County, N. J., has shown well sustained activity this year and brokers report a growing demand for well-located homes.

ABRAHAMS--BERNSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. M. Bernstein of Brooklyn are happy to announce the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy, to Mr. Mortimer Abrahams. ARENSBERG--SIMON--Mr. and Mrs. Irving Simon of Albany announce the engagement of their sister. Dorothy, to Phillip S. Arensberg, son of Mrs. Sadye L. Arensberg and the late Sydney Arensberg of New York.

THIS book is excellent, What will ever be an amazing story is permitted by an accomplished raconteur to tell itself. With clear lens and accurate focus, the moving camera follows a famous woman of her world from the cradle to the grave.
A son, their third, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. van Loon of Manchester, Vt., on Thursday at the Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Mrs.

A major item in the War Department appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1940, which is expected to carry the largest peacetime appropriation in the country's history, will involve the training and equipment of the National Guard, now a fullfledged reserve component of the regular army.

An up-to-the-minute index of occupations, a vital necessity in placement and counseling, is slowly taking shape under the earnest efforts of a committee drawn from several large organizations of women.

By insuring 625 mortgages, involving $3,098,000, the New Jersey office of the Federal Housing Administration during October attained a new all-time high in its monthly induring operations, Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director, announced yesterday. The previous high mark was set in December, 1936, when 604 mortgages having a dollar volume of $2,936,610 were insured.

Miss Hope Palmer and Ward Lawrence Luther Jr. were married here this evening in a candle-light ceremony performed at the Contemporary Club by the Rev. Alan R. Chalmers of the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale.

Indicative of the increase of interest in music on the Hobart College campus is the 200 per cent jump in enrollment in the music appreciation classes this year and the acceptance of forty-four men for membership in the college glee club.
Jose Gomez Osorio, Civil Governor of Madrid, announced today that permission had been granted to three priests to officiate at baptisms and

The Franklin E..Tyrrell Organization of Forest Hills, L. I., reports an increasing business in mortgage activity. Loans recently placed by the firm on the fifteen-year FHA plan include one for Albert Ackerly on the one-family dwelling at 91-14 219th Street, Queens Village, and one for William Wieser at 68-17 Dartmouth Street. Forest Hills.

Dedication of the new $5,000 stage in Casino Hall auditorium on the campus of Georgian Court College, Nov. 13, by the Rt. Rev. Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, will mark one of the leading events in the history of the local institution.

NEW YORK knows Elmer Andrews well, but he is still something of an enigma in Washington. Round faced, round-headed, he carries his helmet of close-fitting black hair slightly forward of his rounded shoulders, and he does not tell all he thinks.

Federal savings and loan associations, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank board, are receiving the largest volume of funds from savers and investors at the present time than in any previous period since the Federal organizations were authorized.
Realty men from all parts of the country are gathering in Milwaukee, Wis., this week for the thirtyfirst annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The Mexican Government is fighting to keep the peso from rising above 4.90 to the dollar in order to maintain increased mining production and other taxes which automatically increase as the peso falls.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, will give the first of its five pairs of New York concerts scheduled for this season, Thursday night, Nov. 17, and Saturday afternoon, Nov. 19, in Carnegie Hall.

Reporting a marked improvement in the market for reconditioned homes and vacant land, Edwin J. Dunn, manager of the Jamaica branch of the Bulkley Horton Company, reports that sales by that firm in the Jamaica section of Long Island have increased 23 per cent since the beginning of the year.
Before the National Council of the Socialist party here today, former Premier Leon Blum advocated a wait-and-see

The Ithaca College eleven scored a 13-0 victory over Hofstra on the strength of two second-half touchdowns today. -End runs accounted for both tallies, Ray - Lagere turning the right side for 1 yard and the first, while Louis (Ducky) Pond covered around the -left wing for the secand. Hofstra's tricky aerials helped it to an advantage in first downs, 10 to 9.

A white garden of rare charm, giving a succession of bloom from early Spring till frost, may be achieved by a planting almost entirely of bulbous material. This type of garden is most satisfactory in a small space, for a large planting of white flowers gives a cold effect.

Dr. and Mrs. T. D. Walker Jr. of Newport News have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Marie Walker, to Franklin Albright Hardy of Detroit, Mich., son of Mrs. Hazlett Mayo Hardy and the late Mr. Hardy of Detroit.

THERE'S a new dance being launched, the Minuette-inSwing. It looks as incon gruous as it sounds. Yet it is just about as typical as anything could be of the night life of these days-a combination of the sweet romance of yesterday and the jazzy informality of our own speedy era.

AS has invariably been so with each successive issue, Kirsten Flagstad's latest disk is likewise her best. In the exacting "Abscheulicher, wo eilst du hin," from Beethoven's "Fidelio," the superb qualities of her voice are reproduced still closer to the original than in any earlier attempt.

Miss Elizabeth Cass Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry DeWitt Smith of this place, was married to Alfred Fanton Sanford 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Wheeler Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn., here this afternoon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev.

The Virginia Military Institute Cadets and Wake Forest fought to a 6-6 tie on a muddy field today before a home-coming day crowd of 4,000. Paul Shu, All-Southern Conference halfback, scored for V. M. I. on a 54-yard run. Marshall Edwards retaliated for Wake Forest after a last-period march of 60 vards.

A Book Auction Dinner will be held at Hotel Plaza on Dec. 8 for the benefit of the Joint Distribution Committee and the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, of which Thomas Mann is honorary chairman. The committee, headed by Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, includes men and women well known in art, music and literature.

Seven seniors, leaders in campus life and representing all sides of undergraduate activities, will make a survey study of Hamilton College from the student point of view. Their findings will be incorporated into a report which will contain suggestions as to the manner in which the life, activities and curriculum of the college may be extended and developed.

THE Plantation Club in Harlem is one of the few outposts left over from the gaudy Twenties, when worthies from out of town were wont to trek north of 110th Street after the witching hour to lose their inhibitions and grow noisy on the down-beat.

Army caught a tartar in Franklin and Marshall College today, but won a hard-fought and well-played game, 20 to 12. Expected to be an easy opponent for the Cadets, the visitors from Lancaster, Pa., displayed a fine attack and gave the 27,000 spectators, a capacity crowd for Michie Stadium, plenty of thrills.

Two touchdown spurts by Kenny Washington and an 80-yard goal s line run by Chuck Fennenbock, sub halfback, gave U. C. L. A. a 20-to-0 victory over Washington State today before a homecoming day crowd of 8.000.

Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman at the Democratic rally in the Metropolitan Opera House last night: For the last two weeks as candidate for re-election for the Governorship of New York, I have discussed frankly and calmly the real issues of this campaign.

Herbert Hoover "answered" President Roosevelt's Hyde Park address with a scathing denunciation tonight of the New Deal, accusing the Administration of "coercive" tactics and responsibility for the nation's economic woes.

Demanding the right to censor speeches that might result in disorder, counsel for Jersey City today filed with Federal Judge William Clark its objections to the proposed decree entered Wednesday in the injunction suit brought against Mayor Frank Hague and other officials by the C. I. O. and American Civil Liberties Union.

Because of a growing realization that something must be done to prevent declining tax receipts resulting from haphazard growth, many cities are now placing greater emphasis upon planning, zoning and subdivision control measures, Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald reported yesterday.

Johnny Daggett, diminutive sophomore star, made touchdown sprints of 72, 69 and 30 yards to lead Colby to a 38-to-21 victory over Middlebury today. Hatch scored twice on end sweeps and passed to Bubar for another tally.

Against the glittering backdrop of a cosmopolitan crowd of 15,000 that included many of society's leaders and persons prominent in every walk of life, the fifty-third National Horse Show formally opened its eight-day stand at Madison Square Garden last night.
A convention of Bishops of the Greek Orthodox Church today elected Bishop Damaskinos, Metropolitan of Corinth, as Archbishop of Athens and Primate of Greece.

Chairman Sheppard, Democrat of Texas, of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee disclosed today that 208 candidates for the thirty-five Senate seats to be filled at next week's elections had reported expenditures of $1,018,111 in their primary campaigns.

Public interest in adult education schools, designed to furnish new activities to business men and housewives who have tired of card parties, motion picture shows and other evening diversions, is sweeping Westchester County this Autumn following the inauguration of new schools in Pelham and Scarsdale and the continued operation of one in Rye.

Tuning up for a comeback bid against Notre Dame next Saturday, Minnesota smothered Iowa's hapless Hawkeyes, 28 to 0, before 42,000 persons today. The Golden Gophers, still in the Big Ten title race by virtue of losses by Northwestern and Ohio State, won as they pleased, leading, 14 to 0, at the half and using regulars sparingly.

The audience assembled last night for the Toscanini concert of the NBC Symphony Orchestra with the same agerness, and listened and applauded with the same intensity which is customary at this series of events.
The shrinkage of Britain's export markets has grown so serious that it has compelled this "nation of shopkeepers" to go carefully in speeding up its rearmament program still further.

Much like the situation in metropolitan New York, this city is the final battleground in the bitter campaign between former Governor James M. Curley, Democrat, and Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, for the Governorship of Massachusetts.

A definite shift in consumer preference away from the types of garments generally regarded as Autumn staples is revealed in an analysis of October apparel sales just issued by Lord Taylor. This change in interest produced a sharp increase in calls for chiffon evening gowns as opposed to other types and a corresponding drop in sales of velvets.

THE tumult and the shouting of the Blake auction has hardly died down when the embattled collector is confronted with two more sales of major proportions. The third part of the Cortlandt F. Bishop library, comprising the letters R to Z, will go under the hammer at the American Art Anderson

The Princeton 150-pound eleven routed the Pennsylvania lightweights, 330, on University field today for its fourth straight victory. Bedford paced the Nassau attack. He went over in the first and third periods.

The 11,000 women who did yeoman service in more than a figurative sense during the World War, must be absolved from responsibility for the trend away from the home and into industry, in the opinion of Mrs. Irene Melito Brown of Brooklyn.

Columbia enjoyed its biggest touchdown feast of the season as the Lions smothered the University of Virginia eleven, 39 to 0, at Baker Field yesterday. Having tasted defeat in the three previous games, the Blue and White, without the services of the injured star, Sid Luckman, flashed a running attack that routed the Cavaliers while 15,000 looked on.

A peace plan based on a world survey of economic needs will be outlined at a dinner meeting of metropolitan Soroptimist Clubs on Thursday by Miss Elizabeth R. Pendry of Forest Hills. Distribution of questionnaires in preparation for the survey will be made following the dinner at the Hotel Wellington.

MUSIC is the backbone of radio broadcasting. The unseen audience stands on the right and on the left of this vertebral line. On one side are the "lovers of good music"; on the other the moderns, the so-called jitterbugs.
Johns Hopkins University remains in the ranks of the nation's undefeated football teams, but the Blue Jay march of triumph was halted today when Swarthmore College held the lncals to a scoreless tie.
EVEN after most of the bright foliage of Autumn has faded, there is much to be seen in the woods and fields by the careful observer out for an afternoon's hike in November.

With inquiries for capable executives three times greater than they were a year ago and with actual placements increasing steadily, employment agencies reported yesterday that the sharp cessation in the training of men since 1929 Is creating a scarcity of top-grade executives.

Trading in wheat futures today was restricted and prices averaged lower, due largely to scattered selling induced by easiness in Liverpol, lack of export demand and prospects of furtheir rains over the Winter wheat belt.

Two new multifamily buildings are being added to the growing apartment colony in the Riverdale section of New York by N. K. Winston Co., who also are active in housing construction operations in other parts of the city.

NOW that the frenzied roars of yesterday's football enthusiasts have subsided, the hundreds of thousands who either could not gain admission to the local stadia or who were unable to follow their favorite colors out of town will have the opportunity today of witnessing not only one but practically all of the major contests, via the newsreels.

It is an honorable medical principle that before a new method of treating disease is introduced it must be tested not only on animals but on animals closely related to man. To adopt any other procedure is to slip back to the Middle Ages, when even the dissection of cadavers was forbidden.
Any belief that Brazil has flirted with nazism and fascism will be combated by the Brazilian commission to the Pan-American Conference in Lima next month.

The American Federation of Labor earnestly desires an "honorable peace" with the Committee for Industrial Organization, and does not consider such a peace impossible if all parties exert "sincere and disinterested" efforts to that end, William Green, federation president, said today.

President Roosevelt's belated entry into Pennsylvania's complex political campaign, and the means he used for accomplishing his purpose, aroused mixed emotions and produced conflicting comments this week among party leaders in the Commonwealth.
The withdrawal by the nation's major railroads of a demand for a 15 per cent reduction in union wages was a formal gesture which the managements for some months had expected would have to be made.

The Hudson River Conservation Society, organized three years ago to restore the natural beauty of the Hudson River and to prevent further encroachments by business, announced today that the Founder's Fund Award of $1,200 which it received this year from the Garden Club of America would be used to employ a landscape architect to serve waterfront communities.

It cannot be said that the Postoffice Department does not give the public sufficient warning, for yesterday Ambrose O'Connell, second assistant postmaster general, announced the latest closing dates for mail intended for delivery in foreign countries before Christmas.

Scoring in the final period with a 44-yard pass from Ed Clary toFrank Urban, the South Carolina Gamecocks won a 7-0 intersectional victory over the Duquesne Nightriders today before 8,000 fans. The teams, apparently evenly matched, battled hard through the first three quarters and a scoreless tie was in prospect until the Gamecocks flashed their scoring play.

Abbey Inn and fourteen adjoining building plots, comprising what was once a part of the old Jesuit property in Woodstock Park, Yonkers, will be offered at auction on the premises on Nov. 19 by Major William Kennelly.

The cooperation of men and women prominent in society here is being sought for the theatre and supper party benefit to be given under the auspices of the New York committee of the Frontier Nursing Service, Inc., on the night of Nov. 30.

Big Bear, which operates a chain of super-markets, will open three more units before Christmas, it was announced yesterday. The first of the new stores will open on Thursday in Plainfield, N. J.; the second, at 113-14 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, on Nov. 17, and the third in Bergen Square, Jersey City, with the date still indefinite.

Plant-collecting for the Winter garden has an advantage over other forms of hunting in that it provides a living quarry which will give pleasure for many months. The seeker after terrarium material need never return empty-handed.
Conformity in design of a dwelling with other structures in the immediate neighborhood is not considered important by the FHA except when it fails to blend with them harmoniously.

Attorney General Homer S. Cum mings, in a campaign address to night, laid major responsibility for the "recent temporary recession" a the door of the "forces of reaction, which, he charged, waged an "un seemly struggle to sabotage reform."

The Lafayette and Rutgers 150-pounders battled to a 7-7 tie today. Rutgers scored first, Campi going over in the third period after a 35yard drive. Scott tallied for Lafayette after a 78-yard advance in the final quarter. Four passes thrown by Rosendorf clicked in this drive.

A recent survey of the eighty-one families who have purchased homes in the Droesch development in East Floral Park, L. I., since May 1, disclosed the fact that young married couples predominate among the buyers. Frank Droesch,

Responsibility for coping with the critical railroad problem has been shifted by President Roosevelt and the Federal Fact-Finding Board to the shoulders of management and labor. This development, in the opinion of some observers, gives promise of an early Congressional program which, with the support of the Administration, may be the opening move toward the rehabilitation of the embarrassed carriers.

THE catwalk grilles distinguish the 1939 automobiles, not that they are innovations, but because of their more general use. The grilles, placed in the front fender aprons or catwalks, in combination with other changes in the hood design have created markedly new effects in the cars now introduced.
A NEW optimism pervades South Shore villages of hurricane-ripped Suffolk County as residents adopt plan after plan for the rehabilitation of beach areas.

Blending a brilliant passing attack with powerful rushes on the ground, Tennessee's great football team maintained its unbeaten and untied record today, crushing the University of Chattanooga by 45 to 0 before 7,000 spectators.

A protest against the United States attitude on the Palestine question was voiced here today at a meeting of 2,000 undergraduates of the Egyptian University convoked to express the sympathy and solidarity of Egyptian students with Palestine Arabs in their fight in the Holy Land.

The University of Missouri's Tigers cracked a battered Michigan State defense for a touchdown in the fourth quarter and weathered a stormy last minute Spartan attack to gain a 6-0 victory today in their intersectional football game.

QUEENS HERMANN, PAUL (Sept. 17). Assets, $11,994 gross; $11,079 net. To children, Anna Fernandez, Elsie Hermann and Henrietta Kretz. Outstanding holdings in real estate and personal property, $11,994. Burkard Burkard, attorneys, 57-38 Myrtle Ave.. Ridgewood.

A striking demonstration of the more cordial relations which have lately been developed between Wall Street and Washington was provided last week when the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange announced a sweeping program of new stock market reforms.

The annual Armistice Ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, Inc., one of the most spectacular of the many celebrations in this city in observance of Armistice Day, will take place Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Astor.

Klaus and Erika Mann, son and daughter of Thomas Mann the novelist, will speak on "Nazi Influence on German Youth" to members of the Greenwich Woman's Club, meeting Wednesday afternoon at the Masonic Temple.

WHEN Richard Wagner as a very young man paid his first visit to Vienna he discovered that the chief musical interest of the population was Louis Joseph Ferdinand Herold's opera "Zampa," which he detested.
A large and brilliant represents tion of society attended the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Forced transfers of property Manhattan during October set a new low monthly mark for the post-depression period, according to the monthly foreclosure analysis made public yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Department of Commerce has been informed from Alexandria, Egypt, that the Joint Egyptian Cotton Committee agreed t a recent meeting to accept for export cotton with a moisture tolerance of 8.5 per cent.

A powerful Union College eleven captured the thirty-fifth renewal of their rivalry with the University of Rochester today, 27-13. Union scored in the first minute of play and was never headed. Pushed back to their 5-yard line by a Rochester punt,

Carnegie Tech accounted for the outstanding victory of a busy day on college gridirons, handing Pitt's powerhouse its first setback in twenty-three games. Fordham came back into the winning column by beating St. Mary's on a field goal.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 29 were announced by the State Department today: Franklin Hawley of Ann Arbor, Mich., vice consul at Lille, France, assigned vice consul at Hankow, China. NON-CAREER Duncan M. White of Louisburg, N. C., appointed vice consul at Dublin. Ireland.
The Public Works Administration announced today approval of 146 additional non-Federal projects for which the PWA has allotted $7,322,220 in grants and $990,500 in loans.

I. A. Horowitz drew the fourth game of his match with I. I. Kashdan at the Queens Chess Club in Woodside yesterday and held his lead in the play-off for the championship of the American Chess Federation.

City College of New York suffered a surprising 26-to-6 defeat at the hands of an alert Providence eleven today. Starting with a rush which carried to one touchdown and within inches of another in the opening period, the Lavender appeared on its way to a walkaway triumph, but loose play and a fast-changing Friar line combined to turn the tide.

Eugene Gross, 32, who, police say, taught the art of stealing to three 14-year-old boys in a Stamford school where he was employed as an assistant janitor, was arrested tonight by detectives investigating the theft of jewelry valued at $600 from the Stewart Jewelry Company.
The threepence and six pence variety store which Selfridge Co., Ltd., opened here about four months ago on Oxford Street, opposite the big department store, has now closed down.

For the first time since that historic day, sixty-nine years ago tomorrow, when Rutgers and Princeton met here on the gridiron in the initial game of American football, the Scarlet beat the Tigers in an unexpected feature of the opening of the new million-dollar Rutgers Stadium today.

Two pass interceptions and a blocked kick, all in the last period, enabled Hobart College to register a 19-0 victory over the University of Buffalo at football today and conclude its season with three straight triumphs after the first half of the schedule had produced a defeat and two ties.

The fleet will be in-next May, and with $4,000,000 to spend. That is the announcement of the New York World's Fair. The arrival of more than 150 ships of the United States Navy will coincide with the opening of the World's Fair in 1939.

TRADE continued to present an uneven appearance in the week and comparisons were difficult because the elections were a week earlier last year. However, some unexpected increases cropped up in the previous week's figures to show what might be done when weather conditions turned favorable.

New York University has just acquired for its James Arthur Collection of Timepieces a unique clock that shows the relative position of the sun and earth on each day of the year as well as the time of day, it was announced yesterday by Professor Carlos de Zafra, curator of the collection.

Active price-fixing by mill interests brought about a stiffer resistance on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the December contract gained a point in contrast to a 6point loss in the October position.

Official final registration figures for Tufts College have surprised administration officials by bettering last year's total by about 2 per cent, with the Engineering School heading the increase. This contradicts earlier estimates.

Penn State's unpredictable Lions lost, 7 to 0, to a fighting Lafayette team before a crowd of 8,000 at Beaver Field today. The Leopards scored midway in the first period when Don Graff Lafayette left tackle, blocked Craig White's kick. Norbert Weldon scooped up the ball and ran twenty yards for a touchdown. Lentzplacekicked the extra point.
Re-employment in private industry brought jobs back to 600,000 men and women in September, the American Federation of Labor estimated in its November issue of The Federationist, out today.
Los Angeles and San Bernardino County authorities investigated today the finding of a skeleton in Big John Flat with a rusted rifle beside it.

Not long ago, just as the alders were changing color to form a camouflage for the long-billed, russet gamesters that seek their shelter, we skirted a field of shocked corn and stood for a moment looking over the remembered scene. Through a gap in the alders we could see the gleam of sun on the snakelike stream that, despite its slight size, was still the Manasquan.

THE VALIANT WOMAN. By Sheila Kaye-Smith. 386 pages. New York. Harper Brothers, $2.50. SHEILA KAYE-SMITH'S charm as a writer of fiction is much the same as that of those women of charm who delight us by their incalculable variation and content us by their never-failing conformity to a code that has its roots deep-grounded in indestructible truth.

With two minutes left to go in the first half of a bruising defensive battle, an unsung substitute got up from the bench on which he has worn his football pants thin for three years to kick Fordham to a 3-0 victory over St. Mary's yesterday as 44,000 looked on at the Polo Grounds.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Una Kinney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Kinney of this place, to Robert E. Kessler, son of Mrs. James McMenamin of Glen Ridge, took place this afternoon in Grace Presbyterian Church in Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank A. Hunger, the pastor.

The New York Giants will swing into the November homestretch of the National Football League campaign at the Polo Grounds this afternoon against the pass-conscious Chicago Cardinals, entering a stage of the race in which each defeat is exceptionally costly.

Otis Mudge of Amesbury, Mass., has been elected chief of the undergraduate fire department at Dartmouth, one of the few colleges in the country where a student department is officially recognized by the administration as an active unit.
Ar "iron man" Allegheny College eleven, playing without substitu tions, upset Thiel today to spoil a homecoming celebration.
Repulsed at the goal line on numerous occasions, Alabama's Crim-Repulsed at the goal line on nuson Tide scored a field goal in the closing minutes to defeat the Tulane Green Wave today. 3 to 0.
A card party and tea, opening a series to be held on the first Monday of each month throughout the season, will take place tomorrow afternoon at the West Sixty-third Sixty-third Street.

" Politics" was blamed before the House Committee Investigating un-American Activities today for the failure of Secretary Ickes to act on charges of his own investigator that the president of Howard University, a government-supported Negro institution here, publicly praises Russian communism.

The swimmers of Textile High, Manhattan-Bronx senior champions of the P. S. A. L., struck another blow in defense of their title yesterday, defeating Theodore Roosevelt, 49-22, in the twenty-five-yard DeWitt Clinton pool.

Following is the prepared text of Herbert Hoover's address tonight on "The Economic Consequences of the New Deal": A few weeks ago at Kansas City I spoke on the moral harvest of the New Deal. At Hartford I spoke on its peril to representative government and free men. Tonight I shall speak upon its economic consequences and what we should do about it.

WE'RE STILL IN THE COUNTRY. By Frederic F. Van de Water. With frontispiece. 253 pp. New York: The John Day Company. $2.50. WHEN the Frederic F. Van de Waters foundand made-their home in the country, the joys of settling in Vermont rippled gayly and briskly, unsentimentally yet with frank tenderness, through the pages of a most delightful book.

Representatives of the WPA unions and the Workers Alliance held a parade yesterday afternoon to support, among other things, the "New Deal Program for Recovery." The parade, marked by several blaring bands and picturesque scenes, started in Madison Square and ended at Columbus Circle, where a meeting was held.

Essex County Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld today promised an investigation of charges of vote transfer forgeries in the county brought to the attention of authorities by employes in the office of Superintendent of Elections Bert Lamb.

Starting play today at Amsterdam and continuing for the next three weeks, eight of the greatest masters of chess will participate in fourteen rounds of the A. V. R. 0. international tournament, sponsored by The Netherlands Broadcasting Corporation.

Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president of City College, announced yesterday the names of 267 graduates who completed their work at the college during the 1938 Summer session and to whom degrees and certificates were voted last week.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police will train a limited number of reserves from among the staffs of large firms in several cities, Deputy Commissioner Thomas Dann announced today. The first of the reserve units will be formed in Winnipeg and the plan will later be extended to "three or four" other cities.

ALMOST any clear day New Yorkers crane their necks to gape at a tiny dot of an airplane tracing an advertising message in smoke against the blue sky. New Yorkers must be particularly susceptible to this form of advertising because most of the skywriting in the United States is done over New York.

German official quarters and the press continue to disclaim any knowledge of the progress of the negotiations between Polish and German delegates meeting here to determine the fate of Polish Jews resident in Germany as well as 10,000 already deported.

Increased interest in debating already conspicuously evident in colleges and universities has spread to secondary schools to such an extent that the annual triangular debate between the Morristown School, Montclair Academy and the Pingry School which will be held on March 10, 1939, is already a matter of warm discussion.

More attention han ever before, states a builder, is being paid to proper designing of the basement. Years ago it was only a place for waste materials, broken furniture and miscellaneous unused articles, with the furnace taking a major place along with coal and ashes.

A misplaced blinker hood very nearly cost $10,000 at Pimlico, where John A. Manfuso's Aneroid surprised a great many today when he won the $12,175 Riggs Handicap over a slow track to return almost 10 to 1.

Class 18. Hackney Stallions, Mares or Geldings, 3 year-olds and under (shown in hand)-First, Seaton Hackney Farms' b. s. Seaton Promenade; second, Miss E. Gwen Martin's b. s. Killearn Presto. Class 16, Hackney Stallions, over 14.2 (shown in hand)--First, Killearn Farm's b. s. Killearn Magician; second, Seaton Hackney Farm's b. s. Seaton Fromenade; third, Miss E. Gwen Martin's b. s. Killearn Presto.

EVER since Professor Percival Lowell in the Nineties discovered the "canals" on Mars, and other celestial observers caught signs of atmosphere and clouds, the world has been looking for messages from the ruddyfaced neighbor, which, incidentally, is now 236,000,000 miles away.

UNITY and improvement of the seven "national divisions" of the national trucking industry from the viewpoint of operating efficiency were the keynote of the fifth annual convention of the American Trucking Associations, Inc., held from Oct. 31 to Nov. 3 at the Hotel Statler, Detroit.

The Yokohama Specie Bank, Ltd., had a net profit of 6,187,602 yen for the first half of this year, according to the report to shareholders which has just been received here. The amount, added to the Mar.

A suggestion that American producers who have funds tied up in Japan because of exchange restrictions arrange to sell their holdings to Japanese farmers on the Pacific Coast was made here last week by a Japanese business man taking part in a discussion of foreign-exchange restrictions.

A plot to force thousands of Republican city employes to vote Democratic at Tuesday's election under threats of loss of their jobs was charged today by the Philadelphia Civil Service Commission as a series of warrants was sworn to in the midst of what was described as "a real reign of terror."

ON the heels of the newly reorganized Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, there now comes the newly reorganized Mordkin Ballet, which will give a series of six performances this week at the Alvin Theatre beginning Thursday evening.

DISCUSSING television problems at the recent convention of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers at Detroit. I. J. Kaar, design engineer of the General Electric Company, announced that "it may be said with some assurance that the last technical obstacles in the path of commercial television have been removed."

SPINETS, harpsichords and other musical instruments of the past are coming to be as much appreciated for their decorative value as for their historical importance. The larger ones were often similar in decorative style to the furnishings with which they were used, and today they often contribute to the effect of the period room.
Friends of the Giuditta Guild, a recently organized affiliate of the Giuditta Guild of the Cenacle of the St. Regis, have arranged a supper dance in behalf of the guild's chartable enterprises.

The former residence of the late Caleb T. Winchester, long-time Professor of English Literature at Wesleyan, has been turned into an inn for the accommodation of college guests and has been named Alumni House. It is located on High Street opposite the president's mansion.
AN excellent study and review of the air defense problem of the United States is carried in the November issue of Aviation, America's oldest aeronautical magazine.

Trinity bowed to Amherst today, 19-0. Captain Joys, assisted by Firman and Pattengill, was outstanding in the first quarter, making a touchdown on a 67-yard run after intercepting a pass from Rihl. The first score of the second quarter also was made on a 62-yard run by Joys. He then passed to Smart on Trinity's 10 marker, scoring the third touchdown for the visitors.

Mrs. Edwin S. Robinson is chairman of the arrangements committee for a lecture to be held the evening of Nov. 27 in the ballroom of the Plaza in aid of the Winfield Day Nursery. A travelogue, "In the Wake of the. Vikings", illustrated with motion pictures, will be given by Mark Haight.

DOWN in Fredericksburg, in Virginia, where arms were made for our soldiers in the Revolution and a famous battle was fought in the Civil War, is a cherished, patched-up old horsechestnut tree which well fortified tradition says was planted by George Washington 150 years ago.

Confident that they will retain their present firm hold on the Assembly, the Republicans have concentrated in their legislative campaigns both in this city and upState upon recapturing control of the State Senate, lost to them for many years.

The spotlight of national political interest will be focused on New York State on Tuesday when the voters of New York City and upState go to the polls to elect the first four-year-term Governor in the history of the State.
Characteristics an employer should have to meet with favor in the eyes of his employee will be described by five young women at a meeting tomorrow evening at the Women's City Club.

Several home deals in the Chester Hill development at Manhasset, L. I., have recently been closed, according to F. J. McGovern, sales manager. Six dwellings recently completed were sold to William R. Sherwood of Forest Hills, Joseph O. Reither of Malverne, E. B. Aiken- of Westchester, Frank H. Hewitt of Brooklyn, George B. McGowan of New York and Ludwig Lustig of Manhasset.

In making plans for a bathroom, either in modernization or in new construction, one of the first points to consider is the style and location of the bathtub, states the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

Arsenal and Aston Villa may forfeit the right to be termed the most attractive teams in English football unless they show real improvement. Both elevens were beaten at home in today's round of fixtures.

THOSE who remember the Nurse Keete stories will agree that when Mrs. Eberhart writes of doctors and nurses she is at her best. There is no Nurse Keete in this novel, but there is a former nurse named Rue who is the second wife of Dr. Hatterick.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, making his last major appeal for re-election at a Democratic rally in the Metropolitan Opera House, last night accused the Republican party of waging a campaign of racial and religious intolerance and warned that such a campaign, if not repudiated by the voters, was a menace to American democracy.

Several students from the metropolitan area have been selected for the cast of forty-five which the Masque and Bauble Club of Georgetown University will present in its production of John Drinkwater's "Abraham Lincoln" on Dec. 9. These undergraduates include:

THE New Jersey mixed team of-four contract bridge championship-a two-session, one day event-begins at 2:30 this afternoon at the Art Center, East Orange, N. J. The concluding session begins at 8:30 this evening. All teams will play in both sessions.

Increased interest in extra-curricular activities has been noted on the Lehigh University campus this Fall. The dean's office reports formation of three new clubs and continued functioning of forty-seven others; organization of seven living group sections in the new Charles Russ Richards House, and creation of an interdormitory council similar in function to the Inter-Fraternity Council.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 4: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Browne, F. W., Finance Dept., seventeen days' extension of leave. Peabody, H., Air Corps, Maxwell Field, Ala., to office of the Chief of the Air Corps, Washington, D. C.

Detroit snapped a three-game losing streak by overwhelming North Dakota, 38 to 7, before 12,000 spectators today. The Titans scored twice in the first period, once in the second and three times in the third.

The season's first performance of "Tannhaeuser," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior, to be given the afternoon of Dec. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been taken over for the benefit of the Girl Scout Federation of New York and its affiliated Councils in the five boroughs.
FOR more than a quarter century passing New Yorkers have regarded a low building with massive twin pillars on West Twenty-third Street as just another office building or bank.

THE news from the Metropolitan Opera House is bullish this morning. With the subscriptions for the coming season all in, it has become clear that the total number of subscribers represents an increase this season over last.

Morris Dube of 5,502 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, an accountant and lawyer with offices at 10 East Forty-second Street, died Thursday night in the Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, following an operation for appendicitis. His age was 37.

Antique Collections. Newark Museum. Various exhibits, including old-time musical instruments, Oriental art, oldfashioned toys. Also colonial, Victorian and modern nurseries. Room Color Schemes. Pedac Galleries, Rockefeller Center. Carpets and rugs displayed with harmonizing wall colors and upholstery fabrics.

Bond trading was conducted on a firm undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the turnover was the smallest for a Saturday since Sept. 10, sales amounting to $3,259,175, compared with $3,776,000 the week before.

Unfurling a powerful last-minute passing attack, the Wesleyan football team broke a deadlock with Williams on Weston Field today and won the Little Three contest, 13-7. Two plays later Williams completed a 75-yard reverse pass play and was set for a touchdown, but the whistle ended the most thrilling game seen here in many years with the ball on the Wesleyan 3-yard mark.

November may well be put down in the gardener's calendar as the season for planting lilies. They can of course be planted earlier, if one has home-grown bulbs available, but, as many species are not available from commercial sources until late in the season, the operation must necessarily be delayed until bulbs are purchased.

Although law enforcement agencies agreed that fraudulent registration has been reduced this year, they announced completed plans yesterday to assure an orderly and honest election in the city when 2,300,000 or more voters go to the polls next Tuesday.

The marriage of Miss Helen Theresa Matis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Matis of Garfield, to Stephen J. Monchak of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Monchak, took place here this afternoon in the Hungarian St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John GasDar.

Five students from Bard College of Columbia University will go to Cape Cod to photograph the eclipse of the moon tomorrow. Dr. Harold Phalen, Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy, will go with them.

Connecticut College has its first regional scholarship this year, created by the Cleveland Chapter of the Alumnae Association. Ten years ago scholarships at Connecticut College were relatively few. Today ninety-one students, 12 per cent of the student body, are receiving scholarship assistance. The total amount awarded is about $19,000.

The strong Republican organization of Nassau County will give Thomas E. Dewey a plurality of approximately 40,000 votes in Tuesday's Gubernatorial election, according to estimates received here today by J. Russel Sprague, Republican county leader.

Silver anniversary communion breakfast of Chapter Theta Pi Alpha, Catholic Teachers Association, Hotel Astor, 10:30 A. M.. Speakers: Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Mary M. O'Brien. West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, 11 A. M. Address by Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde.

Because of the possibility of securing Federal funds to aid in financing the work, considerable progress is being made toward the improvement of sewerage facilities in Bergen County, N. J., announced M. W. Cowles, vice president of the Bergen County Chamber of Commerce, yesterday.
