A city-wide strike of messenger boys employed by the Western Union Telegraph Company will be discussed tomorrow night at a meeting called by the American Communications Association, a C. I. O. affiliate.

That pluralities in excess of 30,000 will be received in Westchester County by the Republican State and county candidates when the 253,000 registered voters go to the polls Tuesday was the confident forecast at Republican county headquarters here today.
Mrs. Selda Jonas, wife of, Ralph Jonas, banker and former president of-Brooklyn Hospital, died at her home, 129 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning of heart disease. She was 64 years old.
Delicacies with which to stock the pantry shelf have been cropping up in the town's food shops in recent weeks. Any one would think that food, being so basic, would not be a field for discovery.

Glen Cove High School's football team scored its first victory of the season today and put a serious crimp in Mineola's North Shore Conference championship hopes by gaining a 20-14 decision at the losers' field.

With an amazingly mature and virile interpretation of the Brahms violin concerto that would have done credit to any veteran of the bow, Robert Virovai roused the audience at last night's concert of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra to an unusual pitch of enthusiasmn.

A warning that attempts by employers to defeat the purposes of the wagesand-hours act "by various devices" might bring on a more drastic law in the next Congress came today from Elmer F. Andrews, the Administrator, in commenting upon an opinion of the law rendered to members of the National Association of Manufacturers by its counsel.
SPORTING SUBJECTS - The seventh local show of watercolors is here coupled for purposes of convenience with a show of oils, since both are primarily of interest to devotees of bird hunting.
MELODIES, sliding through the evening sky from the isles of Hawaii, have been intercepted of late on a new South Sea short-wave lane near 14.9 megacycles.

The Stevens soccer team, scoring in every period, conquered a visiting Bard team today, 5-1, at Castle Point Field. Stevens, taking control of the ball at the opening of the contest, definitely outclassed the Bard squad.
A new central Chinese Government under Japanese auspices and with the nominal leadership of General Wu Peifu, retired Chinese war lord, is expected to be announced shortly.

A golden concert grand piano, which will be used by Moriz Rosenthal for his jubilee recital at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 13, was dedicated last week at the Hotel Lombardy at a tea for the pianist and. members of the jubilee committee.

An import duty on newsprint paper under the British preferential tariff has been recommended by the Australian Tariff Board and legislation partially adopting this report is likely to be introduced soon in the Australian Parliament, The Commercial Intelligence Journal states in its current issue. The Journal is published by the Department of Trade and Commerce.

Dr. Charles S. Neves, school physician in Montclair for the last seven years, died yesterday at the age of 51 in his home, 281 Park Street. A native of Providence, R. I., he completed work for a Bachelor of Arts degree at Harvard in three years, graduating in 1910.
Preparations are under way at Bordeaux for a transatlantic airline base over the route of Paris, Bordeaux, the Azores and New York. It is hoped the line will be operating next Spring.
People who believe that Lord Bacon wrote Shakespeare's plays hoped to find a specimen of William Shakespeare's handwriting
The shagbark walnut, or hickory tree-like our own native chestnut, strictly an American product-is becoming extinct, but it formerly grew in the East, West, North and South of the United States.
Following is the address :of Thomas E. Dewey last night at the closing rally of his campaign at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn:

TWENTY years ago next Friday the World War came to an end. The story of the armistice is more than what went on in Wagon-Lits Company's dining car No. 2,419D, in which, in the Forest of Compiegne, the terms of the great truce were signed. It is a story which begins in July, 1918, when Germany still had hopes of winning the war. It begins with the story of a cap.

Miss Mary Potter Sturges, daughter of the Very Rev. Philemon F. Sturges, dean of the Cathedral Church of St. Paul, and Mrs. Sturges of this city, was married here today in the Lindsay Memorial Chapel of Emmanuel Church to Montgomery Hare, son of Mrs. Montgomery Hare of New York, and St. James, L. I., and the late Mr. Hare. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father.

Answering President Roosevelt with a plea of guilty to being a young man, Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, turned back last night to his major topic of crime and politics and revealed that when Edward J. Flynn, the Secretary of State, was the Sheriff of Bronx County in 1925 he appointed Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer as a deputy.

THE night of Dec. 19 will be a big one for Labor Stage, for the original company of "Pins and Needles," which has been wandering around the road as far west as the Coast, will come back to its home grounds.

A fourteen-foot bronze monument commemorating the historic naval engagement between the battleships Monitor and Merrimac in the Civil War was unveiled yesterday before 5,000 persons in Winthrop Park, Nassau Avenue and Monitor Street, Brooklyn. The park is in Greenpoint, where the Monitorwas launched as a Union vessel on Jan. 30. 1862.

Only a half turn of the minute hand remained when Joseph Pasqua rose from the far end of the substitutes' bench, jogged out in the middle of the field and swept a 45-yard field goal downfield and squarely between the goal posts.

BOTH the title and the sub-title of this book are misleading. The book is not a history of the development of democratic institutions in the United States during the second quarter of the last century nor is it a record of the Jackson, Van Buren and Tyler Administrations.

An attractive home in the scenic section of South Norwalk. Conn., has just been completed from designs by the architect, Clifford W. Hayes, for his cousin, Miss Posie Hayes, great-granddaughter of the late President Rutherford B. Hayes. The house occupies a plot of about one-half of an acre at 135 Flaxhill Road. On the property are several old trees more than a century old, and the site has been attractively landscaped.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, made public at his headquarters yesterday an exchange of telegrams in which he denied that he had endorsed a chiropractic bill or agreed to sign such a bill if elected Governor. Meanwhile, a committee of physicians, of which Dr. James S. Edlin is chairman, has sent a warning marked "urgent,"

The arrival of a shipment of $1,651,000 of gold from China at San Francisco was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the largest gold import from China since January, 1931. Smaller shipments of the metal have been fairly frequent since the beginning of the SinoJapanese war.

The New York Aggies football season closed today with a 6-to-0 defeat at the hands of Arnold College. A well-executed lateral from Coppola to Izzo, followed by a long forward to Fish, provided the only score of the game.

THE "invisible stripes" are those which a man still wears when he leaves prison; they are also the unseen marks of the convict-to-be. Warden Lawes's sequel to "20,000 Years In Sing Sing" goes beyond prison walls to ask why a convict once becomes a convict again, and, then, what makes a criminal in the first place.
ENGLISH judges, despite their reputation for solemnity often indulge in witticisms from the bench which in the United States might be considered improper.

Aviation's attraction for women lies in the dream of piloting a plane rather than in an urge to understand its internal mechanism, according to the observation of those who have noted the dearth of applicants qualifying for the loan fund which Zonta International has voted as a memorial to Amelia Earhart.

Women have ceased to make headlines, politically. But they still make news. They cannot produce a feminine nominee for Governor of New York, this year of portentous issues, but up New Hampshire way they can and do point to 57 women candidates for the State Legislature, or "General Court."

The Crescent Flying Schools, Inc., of 122 East Forty-second Street was restrained permanently from any securities dealings in this State by an injunction issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.

Port Jefferson and Bellport won team honors in the annual Suffolk County Public High Schools A. A. cross-country run today. The Jeffs scored 29 points in Class A, while Bellport's tallies annexed the Class B. championship.

Competing in a new form of competition that involved working both upland and in the water, Field Trial Champion Banchory Varnish of Wingan, a Labrador owned by Mrs. Kathleen Starr of East Islip, emerged the winner among twelve dogs in the retriever stake today on the estate of President Charles L. Lawrance of the Labrador Retriever Club.

THE indecision of Great Britain's leaders in dealing with recent stirring developments was only a symptom of the country's general condition. For Britain is undergoing rapid change, both in its physical and spiritual aspects.
The last of a series of county-wide bridge parties, sponsored by the Westchester Smith College Club will be held on Monday and Wednesday.

The sound trucks are homeward bound today. On many a road in many a community throughout the United States, many a brightly painted vehicle is rumbling along. Smooth of tire, short of "pep" and with battery exhausted, each is going to its home garage.

MEDICINE came clattering into the cinema last week as "Young Doctor Kildare" paid a visit to the Music Hall, "The Citadel" stormed the Capitol and "A Man to Remember" nailed his shingle outside the Rivoli.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lita Alexander, daughter of Dr. Lawrence D. Alexander of this city and the late Mrs. Alexander, to James Philip Gibbs Jr. of Huntsville, Texas.
Oklahoma's football steamroller spent nearly two periods flattening a stubborn Kansas State team today, and then rambled at will to a crushing 26-to-0 victory, in a Big Six game.

The Chicago Black Hawks, who won the Stanley Cup and world hockey championship last Spring, took a clear lead in the new National Hockey League race tonight by a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
CHARLES M. ANDREWS has rounded out a long life of teaching and scholarship by writing a major history of the American colonial period.
Bordentown Military Institute subdued Peddie School, 7-0, on the gridiron today before 1,500 spectators. It was Peddie's fourth defeat in the seventeen-game rivalry dating back to 1891.

Where the water supply in a house has become unsatisfactory after being in operation for any length of time the cause of this failure, it is explained, can usually be traced to the presence of rust in the piping.
ONCE more the question echoes: "How did California get that way?" This time it is inspired by the Ham and Eggs Plan, some times known as "Life Begins at 50" or "$30 Every Thursday."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If the attitude of the American people toward the nation's economic problem can be simply envisioned, so that it may be viewed in familiar terms, we shall go far toward solving the pressing need of finding jobs for all who wish to work.

Two realty parcels undergoing renovation, one on Mulberry Street and another on East Thirty-fourth Street, are nearing completion and are now available for renting, according to Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, supervising architects for the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Princeton's powerful freshman football team defeated the Yale yearlings, 25-0, in Palmer Stadium today. The game closed Nassau's season with three victories and a defeat and allowed the Princeton freshmen to discard their traditional black ties.

THE National Horse Show is on at Madison Square Garden. It has been a gala annual spectacle in New York for more than half a century-or exactly as long as the Metropolitan Opera. It has outlived two Madison Square Gardens already and is bigger and better than ever.
New Hampshire scored a surprise vic- 1 tory over Tufts on the gridiron today, 10 to 6, although Tufts outrushed the visitors, 186 yards to 102, and made fifteen first downs to New Hampshire's five.

THE wild tribes inhabiting the elevated tablelands in the center of the Mandated Territory of New Guinea, who were visited for the first time in 1933, are no longer isolated from the rest of mankind. Permanent outposts of government and missions have been established there.

A fairly severe earthquake rocked Eastern Japan at 5:44 P. M. today [3:44 A. M Eastern standard time] and it was followed by two lighter tremors. The epicenter of the disturbance was about seventy miles off Matsushima.

The General Welfare Federation of America said today that a poll of all Congressional candidates showed that a "preponderant majority" of the new Congress would "favor larger old age security pensions than now provided."

ONE of the most fascinating and practical of the new photo graphic discoveries, from an amateur's point of view, is a contact printing outfit which enables the worker to make black and white prints in an ordinary lighted room, no darkroom being necessary.

The University of Washington snatched a measure of satisfaction from a disappointing football season by scoring a 10-to-7 victory over Stanford's gridiron squad today. The Huskies, although trounced in three previous Coast Conference contests, kicked off as the favorite to score over a Stanford eleven which had won two and lost two in the league competition.

Mr. and Mrs. Chester T. Burr of this city have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Burr, to Will Charles Oursler of Brookline and West Fal mouth, Mass., son of Fulton Oursler of West Falmouth, formerly of New York.

Under the chairmanship of Miss Ruth Elliott, the Department of Hygiene and Physical Education at Wellesley College not only offers graduate instruction but also sponsors a varied program of undergraduate activities.

Although warm weather continued to hamper retail trade last week, there was distinct encouragement in the sharp gains registered by stores in those districts where seasonable weather developed. Ready purchasing of apparel lines lifted sales figures substantially.

With the number of American young people attending college ever increasing, with practically every college reporting record-breaking enrollment, the time has come, in the opinion of Dr. James L. Meader, president of Russell Sage College, for evolving new criteria for the admissibility of new students to the field of higher learning.

Red, white and blue penny seals, of the size of a postage stamp, will go on sale Wednesday to further the campaign for the adoption of the Equal Rights Amendment. Proceeds will assure continuance of the official organ of the National Woman's party, which is edited by Alma Lutz, Inez Haynes Irwin and Edith Houghton Hooker.
A new forest fire menace prompted New York's Conservation Department today to consider closing the woods for a second time this Fall.

Anthony Maloney, 17-year-old Morris High harrier, running in his fifth race, captured the Publio Schools Athletic League cross-country championship yesterday over the two-and-one-half-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.

Blazing jewels, multiplying a thousandfold innumerable lights. Shimmering satins and silks-Parisian masterpieces. Softer lustre of ermine and sable. Flash of dainty steel-shod hoofs. Jingle of glittering harness. Beauty, brilliance, animation.

Politically appointed candidates for the judiciary were assailed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in a speech in which he endorsed the candidacy of Magistrate Anna Moscowitz Kross for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department.

The. town of Greenwich is taking additional steps toward buying the land needed for the Greenwich Harbor improvement, a project which has been planned for several months. Purchase of two of these tracts, one owned by Augustus I. Mead and the other by the estate of J. H. Knapp, on Shore Road will be consummated, it is said, in a few days.

A card party and Christmas sale to assist the Little Mothers' Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, chill be held the afternoon of Dec. 2 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
IN eight witty pages Irwin Edman-Professor of Philosophy, author, traveler, observer of mankind-apologizes for not writing an autobiography. Opening his book. you read those eight pages.

THE helmetless fullback passes to the 10-year-old right end, the end pivots and flips the ball to the ninety-five-pound quarter, who is shrilly begging, "Here, Joie! Here!" and the quarter dashes the rest of the block for a touchdown, neatly sidestepping three opposition players and an oncoming ten-ton truck on the way.

IT is generally the memory of some man long dust that the Pierrepont Morgan Library delights to honor, so when it celebrates the achievement of one still in the flesh, the urbane and distinguished secretary of the Metropolitan Museum, it is news indeed.
HOWARD SPRING'S peace of mind has been disturbed by a statement in an English paper alleging that he has made enormous profits from his recent novel.
The goldspangled Boston College Eagles today retained their unbeaten status by conquering the hapless Hoosiers of Indiana University, 14-0, in an intersectional classic before 25,000 rooters.

BY a coincidence, the first object that caught my eye when I sat down at my desk to write my London review of Robert Morley's "Goodness, How Sad!" was a batch of clippings from the New York papers celebrating this same Robert Morley's success as an actor in "Oscar Wilde."

Football will not survive as the "great American college game" unless strict amateurism is enforced, President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University warned today in dedicating the university's new stadium between the halves of the Rutgers-Princeton game before 23,000 fans.

The marriage of Miss Inez Monteith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Monteith of 1,225 Park Avenue, to George Brenton Leddy, son of Mrs. Mark Leddy, also of this city, and the late Mr. Leddy, took place yesterday morning in| the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The world is confronted by the fact that in certain nations members of minority political, racial and social groups are ruthlessly persecuted and exiled. In many quarters this situation is indifferently dismissed, but it is one that strikes fundamentally at the whole base of human relations.

BERNSTEIN-WEINSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Max Weinstein, 493 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter, Muriel S., to Mr. Milton H. Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bernstein of 430 Crown St., Brooklyn, Oct. 21.

Taking advantage of two late breaks, the Nebraska Cornhuskers picked up 10 points and a 16-to-7 victory over the Kansas Jayhawks today before a crowd of 16,000. It was the first Husker victory in six starts.

During the coming week the United States and the democratic powers of Western Europe will observe Armistice. Day to commemorate the event which twenty years ago ended the "Warto-End-War," "to make the world safe for democracy," overthrow autocracy, prevent a German Mitteleuropa and halt German progress on the road from Berlin to Baghdad.

The University of North Carolina turned a blocked punt into a scoring advance to gain a 7-to-0 victory over Virginia Tech in the mud and rain today. George Stirnweiss made the touchdown, sweeping wide off his right end for five yards.

THE KENTS. By LeGrand Cannon Jr. 321 pp. New York: Farrar Rinehart, Inc. $2.50. MR. CANNON'S first novel, "A Mighty Fortress," was a New England story of the ministry at the time of the Abolition furor.
Halting Maine's passing attack in the second half, Bowdoin drove 59 yards to score early in the final period to gain a 13-6 victory today. The game was tied at 6-6 at half time.
MOVING UP: Before Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. one afternoon last week stood John W. Hanes. He took the oath

The United Meat Workers Local Industrial Union No. 635, a Commitee for Industrial Organization affiliate, was certified today by the National Labor Relations Board as exclusive collective bargaining agent for processing and operating employesin six of the eight Wilson Co. distributing plants in and around New York and Brooklyn, as follows.

Many millions of American voters of both sexes will give a few minutes of their time next Tuesday to marking ballots or working voting machines. We have lost some of our nineteenth century illusions as to what this process involves.

Despite a loss of ground in recent days a visit to the front today showed that the government substantially retained the bridgehead across the Ebro and that the Ebro battle, which had been raging off and on for fourteen weeks, still continued.

FROM Turkey comes official word that President Roosevelt's portrait is to appear on three stamps of six which Turkey will release, on a date not yet fixed, to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Constitution of the United States.

ABROAD and comprehensive program unprecedented in world postal history is being planned by the Postoffice Department to make America philately-conscious, it was revealed last week by Roy M. North, Acting Third Assistant Postmaster General, who is in New York in connection with the second National Philatelic Exhibition in progress at Rockefeller Center.

With Queens County accounting for most of the sales, the Easy-toOwn Homes Organization sold during the first ten months of this year a total of 109 properties with a sales value of $696,990 in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Westchester Counties, Russell Page, sales director announced yesterday.

Share prices fluctuated within narrow limits yesterday and finished irregularly higher. The volume of trading for the half-day session of the Stock Exchange was only 434,000 shares, smallest since Sept. 10.

Directors of the Coca-Cola Company voted yesterday an extra month's salary to all employes outside the managerial group who have been continuously with the company since Jan. 1. The managerial personnel will participate proportionately in approximately $250,000 additional compensation.

An exhibition of 271 pictures by Slovak artists was opened last night at the galleries of the Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Joseph Husek, national president of the American Slovak League opened the show.

At rare intervals something occurs on the radio which results in a deluge of complaints descending on the Federal Communications Commission and declarations that "something should be done" to control this or that type of radio broadcasting.

While om a tour of the slums of East Harlem yesterday to create last-minute interest in the passage of the Housing Amendment, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, was so appalled at conditions that he announced his intention of asking State aid in "cleaning up" the district.
The result of the State election in Connecticut next week may depend on the size of the vote polled by Mayor Jasper McLevy of Bridgeport as the Socialist nominee for Governor.

Judge George W. Smythe of the Children's Court of Westchester County will address a joint meeting of the civics-education and the international sections of the Woman's Club of New Rochelle on Wednesday afternoon.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, will officiate at dedication exercises this afternoon for the new $750,000 Frances Schervier Hospital and Home for the Aged at 227th Street and Independence Avenue, Spuyten Duyvil.

Miss Isabel Imlay Butterworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Forrest Butterworth Jr. of Rye and granddaughter of Mrs. George F. Butterworth of 540 Park Avenue, New York, was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Cabot Ward Low, son of Mrs. Peter F. Crossman of New York and grandson of the late Abbott Augustus Low and the late Curtis Noble Douglas.

Giving New Yorkers another dish of the spectacular at the National Horse Show, a bit of the glitter and pomp of the British Empire went on display at Madison Square Garden yesterday when the Royal Canadian Dragoons made their first appearance at the exhibition.

Snow lay across many areas of the Western Canada pratries today after the first severe storm of approaching Winter. After twelve hours of snow the fall stopped in North-Central Saskatchewan late yesterday and temperatures tumbled.
WARNING: It's wise not to be too smart. That was the conclusion last week of Professor Leta S. Hollingworth of Columbia University Teachers College. Children with an I. Q. above 150,

Wilson College students of the present favor a non-military alliance of the United States with other democracies against the totalitarian States, oppose this country's entrance into a war on foreign soil, and urge the cultivation of closer economic relations with South and Central America, according to a poll conducted by The Billboard, campus newspaper, and the Wilson Peace Council.

Miss Vera A.- Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Goodman of Dallas, Texas, was married to Ross Bond Updegraff, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Updegraff of Elizabeth, in the University Chapel here today.

The triumph of Chile's Popular Front in the recent Presidential elections may prove an important check to Nazi-Fascist penetration in South America. It promises also to strengthen left-wing, liberal and democratic forces in the whole continent, and correspondingly weaken dictatorial tendencies.

DISCUSSING television probfuture status of television, E. F. McDonald Jr., president of the Zenith Radio Corporation, in a letter to the stockholders, expressed the opinion that the offering of telepicture receivers for sale before the opening of the World's Fair next Spring "is unfair to the public and premature for both economic and technical reasons.

Chinese porcelains and jades, Japanese lacquers, sword mounts and other art objects, including property of. the estate of Robert Gould Shaw 2d of Newton Center, Mass.; Mrs. William B. Leeds and John Jacob Astor, will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

The mortgage insurance business, not including rental housing projects, done by the Federal Housing Administration in the New York City area will reach $100,000,000 before the close of the year, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director, predicted yesterday.
Artloom The Artloom Corporation has declared a dividend of $1.75 on its 7 per cent preferred stock, which is in arrears. A similar dividend was paid on Sept. 1.

Worcester Tech, trailing at the end of the half, 7-0, came back to defeat Rensselaer, 14-7, today and maintained its clean slate for the year. Rensselaer tallied on a 50-yard march in the second quarter, Shako going over from the 2-yard line:

The new ready-to-wear group within the National Retail Dry Goods Association will provide specialty shops with a forum which they can largely dominate and will give organized support to the understandings retailers reach with apparel manufacturers, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday.
The Vikings of Upsala invaded Bethlehem today and trounced the Moravian Greyhounds, 14-0, before a Homecoming Day crowd of 2,400.

A mass attack upon the problem of poor readers has been opened in the eighty-one New York City junior high schools as Board of Education officials prosecute an ambitious Fall program to help the thousands of boys and girls who have not been taught to read properly.
The New York University crosscountry team defeated the Rutgers Harriers, 27 to 28, over the Bucceleuch Park course today.

A marriage combining two prominent families took place in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill, this afternoon, when Miss Julia Rush Biddle Henry became the bride of Philip D. Armour Jr. The Rev. Frederic Kellogg performed the ceremony.

In an effort to determine the status of real estate brokers and salesmen under the Federal Social Security and the State Unemployment Insurance acts, the Real Estate Association of the State of New York is studying the advisability of instituting test cases in the courts, Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights, president of the association, stated yesterday.

Win or lose on Tuesday, the active corps of various woman campaign divisions will get their bulletins en masse. In practically every instance where women workers have centered their efforts for their numerous candidates in a midtown building, they are arranging to gather with the nominees to listen to the election bulletins after the polls have closed.
Miss Harriet Crowell Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Riley Williams of Brooklyn and Sebasco, Me., was married to Henry Auguste Sturm Jr., son of Mrs. Henry A.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Helen Hancock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund W. Hancock of this city, to Thomas Pickering Pooley of Hackettstown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Pooley of Bloomfield, took place this morning in Christ Episcopal Church of Bloomfield and Glen Ridge. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John James Kirkpatrick, the rector.

The British Government plans to demand $10,000,000 indemnities for Britishowned agrarian lands seized by Mexico without payment when Washington completes arrangements for payment of the agrarian debt owed to Americans for recent expropriations. This was learned authoritatively here today.
At this season, when gardeners are busy with late bulb planting and transplanting, experienced growers are not overlooking the importance of the last-minute cleanup before freezing weather sets in.
Army and Navy veterans in the New York Curb Exchange held an organization meeting yesterday for the formation of a Wall Street Post of the American Legion.
Taking warning from the recent crisis, the government is studying what should be done with the thousands of refugees now living here if a war should occur.
Five automobile shows will open next Friday; the most diversified display of automotive equipment which New York has enjoyed at one time.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced awards of contracts for a total of 277,500 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 1, from bids opened Nov. 1 as follows:

Miss Ruth Dicke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Dicke of this city, was married to Harold Walter HoWard of Wilmington, Del., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Howard of Pompton Lakes, tonight at the home of the bride's parents.

Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce, declared here yesterday that the "socalled monopoly investigation" was "only a small fraction" of the task before the Temporary National Economic Committee whose main objective is "a complete inventory of the nation's business and financial structure."

SOME thirty new exhibitions opened to the public in New York last week. Of these several which fell to the lot of this reviewer rose distinctly above the mill run of gallery attractionswater-colors, drawings, engravings and were divided between oils, and sculpture.

FROM humble cottages and gilded mansions, from lowly counting rooms and oak-paneled directors' offices, from farms, factories and even from relief lines, the American people, thirty-odd million strong, will go to their polling places next Tuesday to exercise the highest privilege of citizenship-to vote. Nationally, their chief purpose will be to select the men and women who will constitute the Seventysixth Congress of the United States.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters, whose membership is limited to fifty, will elect four new members at its annual meeting Thursday morning, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, its president.

The Nordacs Club, a charitable organization which distributes seventy-five pound baskets of food at Christmas and at other times during the year, will hold its twentieth annual benefit tonight at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.
" Brush your hair and pull up your socks" is Lord Tweedsmuir's advice to children for the visit of the King and Queen early next Summer.
Texas Christian's power and precision kept it in the select circle of undefeated football teams again today. The University of Tulsa was the Horned Frogs' seventh victim of the season, 21 to 0.

Unable to capitalize on severel promising bids, Lawrenceville School's unbeaten football forces were held to a scoreless deadlock by a stubborn, plucky Choate School eleven today in their seventh annual contest, before 2,500 spectators.

The Brooklyn College football team returned to its winning ways yesterday by defeating the Panzer College eleven, 6-0, on Brooklyn Field before a crowd of 500. The Kingsmen scored midway in the first period when Irv Roth, Brooklyn fullback, grabbed a fumble in the air on the Panthers' 28yard stripe and raced down the sideline behind Mike Bennette and Mike Daub for the touchdown.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, disclosed today that one man was under sentence of death and three others faced imprisonment after trial before the People's Court on charges of "plotting an armed proletarian march on Berlin."

Lucien Besset, a leader of the Independent Radical party, told a party congress today that the Maginot Line must be reinforced and 150,000 men added to the French Army to face "a new and more powerful Germany."

The Red Devils of Dickinson College managed to hold their own with Dartmouth's second team for three periods today, but with the varsity in action only six minutes in the final quarter, Dartmouth rolled to an easy 44-6 triumph.

" Whispering" campaigns on raw cial and religious grounds against several candidates were denounced by rabbis in sermons here yestert day. Another sermon topic was the panic caused by Orson Welles's broadcast of H. G. Wells's "War of the Worlds."

I WAS on a steamboat bound down the Ohio for the Mississippi and St. Louis when I first noticed his billing. In the window of a vacant store facing the new concrete levee in Evansville, Ind., I read: LASSES WHITE ALL-STAR MINSTRELS, FEATURING LASSES WHITE, DIXIE's FAVORITE MINSTREL STAR. HE WILL POSITIVELY APPEAR IN PERSON. A WHITE SHOW--NOT COLORED--IN BIG TENT THEATRE.

A last-period rally earned the Princeton varsity soccer team a 2-0 decision over Cornell on Poe Field today. With the teams scoreless, Bob Ewing, Tiger halfback, and Dick Sylvester, inside right, struck twice in three minutes:

Representatives of fourteen local unions of toy and novelty workers, meeting here yesterday to form a national organization affiliated with the C. I. O. were warned by Allan S. Haywood, regional director of the C. I. O., to keep political factionalism out of their union.

Corporation income taxes are not confined in their application to corporate form of organization; they are applied as well to business associations which function like corporations. A business trust, for instance, whose structure resembles that of the corporation, is taxable as a corporation.

Group chairmen of the annual Red Cross "roll-call" campaign, which opens on Friday, were announced yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., general chairman. The goal of the drive is $325,000. The names of the chairmen follow:

To the 40,000,000 and more Americans who on Tuesday will mark ballots or pull voting-machine levers the nation's parties last week made a final appeal. Hundreds of thousands reached by the press, by radio talk and party handout made up their minds. The midterm referendum was at hand.

THE ENGLISH LANDSCAPE. By Sir William Beach-Thomas. Illustrated. 193 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $4.50. THE English landscape is beautiful, as every one knows. It is also-and this we do not always realize-largely man-made. Sir William BeachThomas, who is described as "one of the greatest living countrymen" of England, stresses that characteristic of his native scene in this interesting and superbly illustrated book.

Pleasanton Laws Conquest Jr., widely known in Virginia for his poems on current topics, "At Large," which appeared daily in The Richmond News Leader, died of a heart attack in his home -here yesterday. He was 56 years old.

WESSEL SMITTER has written a first novel which places him shoul der to shoulder with John Steinbeck and Hans Fallada. While "F. O. B. Detroit" neither derives from "Of Mice and Men" or "Little Man, What Now?" it possesses the same essential quality of strength and tenderness in the portrayal of a man pitted against economic forces he is powerless to control.
DO not be alarmed. We are not slaves. We have them. "At an outlay of $1 a week," says Silas Bent, "the average family in the United States can enjoy the services of eleven slaves."

Four factors contributing to the upward trend in home building were reported by the presidents of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks during their recent semi-annual conference in Washington. The favorable elements developed during the discussion at the conference were:

Prospective home builders are urged by the Federal Housing Administration to use the services of a competent architect in drawing plans for their future home. This serves as a check on individual whims and the desire to include unnecessary decorative items which add nothing to the utility of a home and simply detract from its future value.

A heavy Taft eleven today defeated Kent School, 13-0, live weight providing the edge. After a fairly even first half Taft opened the third period with a drive to Kent's 16-yard line only to lose the ball on downs.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has resumed its advance and, with four components gaining, has moved to 89.0 for the week ended Oct. 29. This compares with 87.7 for the preceding week and 95.1 for the corresponding week last year.
A field goal by left guard Joseph Baruno late in the fourth period gave Springfield (Mass.) College a 9 to 6 triumph over the Baldwin-Wallace Yellow-Jackets today.

Mr. and Mrs. James L. Gerry of Pelham, N. Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clare Gerry, to Charles J. Pieper of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Pieher of Avilla. Ind.
Frank J. Ahearn and Henry Margolis, former associates of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer baron, pleaded guilty today in Federal court to charges of income tax evasion.

The engagement of Miss Helen Bulkeley Leake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Leake 2d of this city, to John E. Goetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edwin Goetz of Fairmont, W. Va., has been announced by her parentss.

Officials of the Maritime Commission declared yesterday that revenue figures on the American Republics liner Argentine, which departed at 1 P. M. on her maiden voyage to South America, were adequate proof of -the popularity of the new service with the American public.

With no bench event scheduled for this week in the metropolitan section, canine activities and interest will continue to center on field competition. Retriever folk will gather at East Islip, L. I., today and tomorrow for the first Jay F. Carlisle Memorial trial for retrievers and Irish water spaniels.

Headed by Peter Grimm as chairman and David W. Kempner as secretary, a group of local real estate men has organized a real estate committee to work for the adoption of the housing measure, or Amendment 4.
Held at bay for the first period, James Madison High's formidable eleven came back with fury yesterday to overwhelm its Brooklyn rival, New Utrecht, 25-7, before 4,000 fans at Ebbets Field.
THE "Ara Pacis Augustae," erection of which was decreed by the Roman Senate to celebrate the return of Emperor Augustus from Gaul and Spain, has been rebuilt in Rome.

A Socialist Senator, Sixto Pacheco, representing the Mayaguez district, was jailed today on eleven charges of falsification and fraud in connection with Senate pay checks that went to persons allegedly performing no service.

Smart football gave Norwich University a 9-0 upset victory over Lowell Textile today. Although the Lowell machine, whose power had already massed 141 points against six opponents, was able to outrush the Horsemen, 155 yards to 61, and to gain, 93 to 5, through the air, the alert play of Coach Don McCallister's cadets gave them two points on a safety in the second quarter and a touchdown in the final minute of the game.

The school exerts a relatively small influence in erucating for peace since it is only a part of many factors which go into the daily life of the pupil, according to Dr. William E. Grady, associate superintendent of New York City schools, who spoke yesterday morning before the annual Alumni Day conference of the New York University School of Education, 41 West Fourth Street.

The discussion, "Sending Girls to College, Why and How," conducted by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and five Barnard College alumnae as a feature of National Barnard Day, Nov. 16, will be broadcast from the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, during the celebration of the New York City alumnae, which will be under the direction of Mrs. Willard B. Stoughton.

A pivotal State in the Republican attick on the New Deal, Pennsylvania presents a problem for the political forecaster, with cross-currents of unpredictable force forestalling attempts to prejudge the election outcome next Tuesday on the strict basis of "the New Deal versus the Old Deal" the Democratic battle cry.

This week has witnessed an acceleration of the readjustment of the policies of the European democracies in deference to the dictators and in conformity with the current theory-which is the basis of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's diplomacy-that there is no reason why the democracies and the dictatorships should not be the best of friends.

The validity of an arbitration award by the State Mediation Board, calling for -the reinstatement of two dismissed employes of the F. W. Woolworth Company, was challenged yesterday by former State Senator Thomas I. Sheridan, counsel for the company.

Speaking as the operator of a farm at Millbrook, Dutchess County, State Senator Frederic H. Bontecou, Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor attacked the farm policies of the New Deal Federal Government last night in a speech broadcast from Station WGY.

Columbia undergraduates, finding themselves too sophisticated for traditional intercollegiate debating, have launched a broader program to Include campus discussion meetings and the production of a weekly radio program depicting university life, Dr. Edward Hodnett, director of the college debate council, announced yesterday.

Elburt Preston Fletcher, the Boston Bees' first baseman, had an error chalked up against him tonight-he forgot his marriage license. Just before he was to meet his bride, Martha Betty Hanson, at the altar of the Church of the Holy Spirit, the Rev. J. Clements Kolk asked "Elbie" for the license.
A THREE-HOUR dedicatory, broadcast on Friday night beginning at 8 o'clock, with celebrate the opening of WEVD's new building at 117 West Forty-sixth Street.

Both Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, and William S. Murray, Republican State Chairman, issued pre-election statements yesterday, each forecasting election of the State ticket of his party.

I. Jerome Riker, president of the realty company bearing his name, calls attention to the fact that Representative Wright Patman of Texas has announced that he plans to introduce in the next session of Congress a tax bill which, declares Mr. Riker, if enacted into law would put many chain stores out of business.

The marriage of Miss Inez Minette Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Phelps of this city, to William MacNeal Chambers, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Duncan Chambers of Cincinnati, took place this afternoon in the Community Church of the Circle here. The Rev. Carl S. Weist, the pastor, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the home of the bride's parents.

All 435 House seats are at stake in this year's elections, but since Maine has already elected three Representatives, 432 remain to be voted on Tuesday. For these seats there are 972 candidates, including 385 up for re-election, who range politically as follows

Miss Barbara Belmont of 155 East Seventy-third Street, daughter of the late August Belmont, was married yesterday in the chantry of St. T?? Church to Robert Livermore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Livermore of Topsfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

Japan took another step in her campaign to win the South American markets when President Alfredo Baldomir, all Cabinet members and other high officials, accompanied by their wives, attended a banquet aboard the Japanese liner Buenos Aires Maru on her arrival here today.

The American exporters' fight against Reich barter deals in LatinAmerican markets will center on the claim that such transactions constitute discriminatory treatment and therefore infringe existing reciprocal trade agreements with this country, it was learned here yesterday.

In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Barbara Elizabeth Lockwood, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Charles Davenport Lockwood of this place, was married to Garrett Bunker of New York, a descendant of George Bunker of Charlestown, Mass., who was the owner of Bunker Hill.
Miss Mildred Elizabeth Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Leonard Warner of Malverne, L. I., was married to Claude Swanson Nunn of Newark. N. J.. son of Mrs.

The volume of United States money in circulation on last Wednesday was $6,706,000,000. This was the largest total ever reported, except for two weeks in the banking holiday of 1933, when literally billions of dollars were being hoarded by the public because of fear of failures of banks.

A total of 17,889 families have registered for Red Cross hurricane and flood rehabilitation assistance, it was announced here tonight by Robert E. Bondy, national director of Red Cross disaster relief.

AN array of thousands of stamps and postal covers valued in excess of a million dollars is on display at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center this week. They comprise the second "Naphex," or National Philatelic Exhibition, held under the sponsorship of the National Federation of Stamp Clubs. This annual show.

IN drawing a balance of the Venetian festival, a first recognition is due its two leading organizers: Goffredo Petrassi, superintendent of the Fenice Theatre, and Mario Corti; commissioner of the Biennial Exposition.

Andover Academy came from behind to defeat the Tufts freshmen on the gridiron today by 26-7. Tufts forged ahead in the first period. Gould scored in the second for Andover, then snared a pass from Towson in the third and dashed 50 yards for the touchdown which put Andover in the lead.

In the contest for election as Governor of New York between Herbert H. Lehman, candidate for reelection on the Democratic and American Labor party tickets, and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee, various crosscurrents, some of them under the surface, seem to have made the result uncertain.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption in November and later months before maturity were more numerous than in any week in the last two months. Bonds of public utility companies were outstanding among the new prepayments, most of which were fer December.

Although outplayed for the greater part of the first half, Coach Len Watters's White Plains High football team staged a brilliant rally to down its old rival, New Rochelle High, 13 to 6, in a Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association contest on the loser's gridiron today.

Educators and laymen willgather Friday at Teachers College, Columbia University, to discuss how a democratic people can provide for the selection and training of leaders in the various walks of life, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the college's Advanced School of Education.

Business men who have been mistrustful of the policies of the Administration gradually are coming to realize that official Washington is not quite the hotbed of "subversive" thinking they had pictured, Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce, asserted in an interview here last week.
The Angriff accuses the vatican of "poorly camouflaged words" in describing the visits of important German Catholic clergymen to the Pope last month as "routine calls."

Alexander King Dickson, banker and lawyer, died of a heart attack last night at the age of 62. He was stricken while driving his automobile in West Philadelphia. Mr. Dickson had been assistant vice president of the Land Title Bank and TruSt Company since 1927.
EVER since his first novel Andre Malraux has been working toward "Man's Hope." Like all French intellectuals for the past fifty years or more-like Bourget and Barres and his master.

THE Galloping Gaels from the Moraga Valley came galloping into the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon and a goodly throng was there to greet them, including the Fordham football team chaperoned by Somnolent James Crowley. It was a summery afternoon, too warm for the upholstered warriors to keep going at top speed out there.

Dr. Ernest Robert von Nardroff of the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn, who was principal of Stuyvesant High School, East Fifteenth Street, Manhattan, from 1911 until his retirement in 1934, died yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital after an illness of three weeks.

A group of business men, to whom the world's far-away places were not geographical curiosities but potential centers of trade, formed in 1911 the American Manufacturers Export Association. Later this group merged with others. into the National Foreign Trade Council, a body of manufacturers, exporters, importers, bankers and shippers.

A pony express backfield from Centre College ran a heavier Washington and Lee team dizzy before 7,000 fans today for a 7 to 0 victory. Bill Harrington, a substitute halfback, led the Centre attack, driving through the heavy Washington and Lee line for repeated gains.

THE annual trek eastward to the New York national show, which will be held beginning next Friday at Grand Central Palace, has just about emptied sales and advertising offices of automobile manufacturers here. Recent unexpectedly heavy upturn in sales, which developed shortly after the introduction of new models to the public, has brought about swift changes in show attendance plans.

Discussion of public affairs is a major activity at Vassar College. In addition to lectures arranged by the administration on the European situation, the Political Association, a nonpartisan organization comprising students, faculty and employes, has brought to the campus Raymond Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, to talk on the position of France since the Munich pact, and from Nov. 17 to 19 it will hold a conference on government regulation of business.

The old folks at the City Home on Welfare. Island have decided the Gubernatorial issue without waiting for the regular election, in which they are not qualified to vote. They lost their franchise when they became officially homeless, but they have not lost their interest in politics and affairs of the State.

BLANCHAARD-ln Barnstable, Mass., Nov. 4, 1938, Huse Templeton. Funeral service to be held at his home in Barnstable, Mass., Monday, Nov. 7, at 9 A. M. Burial service in Blossom Hill Cemetery at Concord, N. H., at 3 P. M.
Leaders in transportation, aviation and other fields will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the aluminum industry on Thursday with a dinner in the: Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

That France was as vigilant as ever in her African empire could be gleaned from speeches delivered in connection with today's unveiling of an equestrian statue to the late Marshal Louis Hubert Lyautey, organizer of French Morocco. The ceremony was attended by Marshal Lyautey's widow, members of his family, Sultan Sidi Mohammed of Morocco, General August Nogues, High Commissioner for French Morocco, and Guy La Chambre.

Mayor La Guardia again came within a microscopic distance of making a public declaration in support of Governor Lehman yesterday at City Hall when he commented on President Roosevelt's radio address urging the re-election of the Governor.

THE program of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Tuesday, in which Rach maninoff is presented as composer and performer, and the beginning of the Town Hall Endowment Fund Series, will mark the coming week in music.
A whirlwind last-period attack led by Joe Guyon and Henry Brostek gave Catholic University of Washington a 14-to-13 triumph over De Paul today.

TWENTY years after the great "Cease Fire" sounded, the war memorials and cemeteries of the old western front are at last complete. The architects, the stone masons and the landscape-gardeners have finished their work and gone home, some of them years ago, some only last Spring.
A conference on health protection through nurses' registries has been called for Thursday by the New York State Nurses' Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Threatened collapse of the New York Joint Liquor Conference, market policing body set up by liquor jobbers, package store owners and bar and grill operators, threw the local market into confusion here yesterday.

Across the map of Europe there stretches today a ragged strip of country which can be compared only with a wellgnawed bone. It still bears the name of Czechoslovakia. Its geographical configuration corresponds as closely as need be to what has been its political fate.

A crowd of 4,000 attended the race meeting at the Pickering Hunt Clut today. The Pickering Challenge Cup, al about three and a half miles ovei timber for amateur riders, was cap. tured by the 10-to-1 outsider, Mrs, Howard Buck's Espadin.

James H. Fay Democratic candidate for Congress in the Sixteenth district, announced yesterday that he had placed before District Attorney Samuel Foley in the Bronx evidence that fake "Communist" letters which voters in the district received on primary day came from the Bronx apartment of J. S. Beckerman,

Georges Urbain, a noted chemist, died today after a short illness. He was 66 years old. Mr. Urbain was one of the discoverers in 1907 of lutecium, a chemical element of the rareearth group which was separated from ytterbium.
After an early defensive lapse, the Boston University Terriers today displayed their best offensive of the season and defeated the University of Tampa, 31 to 7, on Nickerson Field at Weston.

A group of debutantes will act as manikins in the fashion revue to be held on Nov. 16 at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue, for the benefit of the various philanthropic organizations furthered by the proceeds of sales at the shop.

Educators and laymen willgather Friday at Teachers College, Columbia University, to discuss how a democratic people can provide for the selection and training of leaders in the various walks of life, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the college's Advanced School of Education.

HERE it is the first Sunday in November and the theatrical battle between the nations has broken out again. Ivor Brown has fired the first broadside in The London Observer.

MIXED with the cool, frosty air and the piercing smudge of burning wood and leaves, now is borne to the wayfarers in Kentucky a rich, tangy aroma of sage, of pepper and of that indescribable mouth-watering odor of fresh hog meat. A tourist traveling through Kentucky wonders at the number of slaughtered hogs hanging on trees or lying on the frost-covered ground,

THE Galloping Gaels from the Moraga Valley came galloping into the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon and a goodly throng was there to greet them, including the Fordham football team chaperoned by Somnolent James Crowley. It was a summery afternoon, too warm for the upholstered warriors to keep going at top speed out there.

In this little village of 850 inhabitants, formerly a frontier outpost of Czechoslovakia, this correspondent passed the night to see Czechoslovak officials part with mutual good-will today from the Magyar peasantry over whom they had held authority for twenty years.

The "two-price" plan as advocated by Secretaries Wallace and Morgenthau, if put into effect, "would deal a staggering blow to retail trade and employment," Major Benjamin H. Namm, head of the Namm Store Brooklyn, and member of the committee of retailers which has been studying the proposal, said in a statement issued yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. Preparations for the opening of the ice hockey season will get under way here this week when workmen start removing the turf from the floor of the Municipal Convention Hall to make I way for the ice.

The items from the collection of the Comtesse de Chivre which were auctioned Friday and yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries realized $26,492. They were removed from her Paris apartment and her Chateau de la Blache at Pont St. Esprit.

AN APRIL AFTERNOON. By Philip Wylie. 284 pp. New York: Farrar Rinehart. $2. FRANKE, who tells the story, was adopted into the Sheffield family when he was 4, and his paralyzed leg still very bad. It never got quite perfect, but he could swim and ride with the three other children, and their grandmother left him her entire fortune because they had plenty from their father and mother.
Student leaders in debating at Harvard obtained this Fall faculty and administrative support for a new program of intramural debates centered about the seven upper-class residential houses.

That quick evolution of opinion and of policy which is one of the advantages as well as disadvantages of the democratic system of government has during the past week given France an opportunity of trying a new financial and economic program with a new leader.

After "six long years" of looking across the House of Representatives at huge Democratic majorities, the Republicans are counting upon Tuesday's election to give them a working minority, which may become even strong enough at times, with the aid of conservative Democrats, to modify or defeat "objectionable" New Deal legislation.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Irenee du Pont of Louviers, here, and of 1,424 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, .entertained today at their home here at a small tea, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Delphine du Pont, to Taleasin Hayden Davies Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Davies of this city..

The State Labor Relations Board reported yesterday that it had been instrumental in settling ninety-three strikes, involving 6,970 workers, in the four months ended Oct. 31. In 351 other cases, in which 46,100 employes were involved, strike action was withheld pending action by the board, the report said.

An advisory report for reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company, under which capitalization would be. reduced to $631.010,668, of which about 36.6 per cent would be represented by funded debt and in which holders of $117,000,000 of $100 par value common stock of the old company would receive nothing, has been made to the Interstate Commerce Commission by M. S. Jameson, an examiner for the commission.
A slashing 63-yard touchdown march carried Western Reserve University to a 7-to-0 victory before 15,000 persons today in a bruising battle with the Mountaineers of West Virginia University.
The Slippery Rock Rockets, like several of their better-known football contemporaries, were upset today by the Cortland (N. Y.) Normal eleven, which displayed a strong aerial attack to win, 13-7.

DIAMONDS of silver hue are rare, and the specimen of 153 carats found recently by a digger at Gong-Gong, Barkley West, near Kimberley, was considered a superb example. It was sold for [Pound]3,200. "Mongrels,"

The success of two marriage courses, both of which started as experiments four years ago, one at a woman's junior college in Missouri and another at the coeducational State University of Iowa, indicates that the demand for such courses is on the increase, although the form which they take may vary considerably.

Reorganization of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., to comply with the law and become registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission as the nationwide self-regulatory, body of overthe-counter security dealers under the Maloney act is under way.

St. Lawrence University's football team lost its fourth game of the season today, bowing to Vermont, 12 to 0. A pass. Trigilio to Pye, in the third period, and a pass interception and 54-yard run by Taylor in the last quarter accounted for Vermont's touchdowns.

THE sacrifice and courage of those who died in the World War will be honored with special observance here on Friday, as the capital, led by the President, dedicates itself to remembrance on the twentieth anniversary of Armistice Day.

Builders in practically all of the active development communities throughout Long Island report that the mild Fall weather has had the effect of stimulating home buying. The interest in home ownership has also been shown in the large number of visitors who have inspected the latest model dwellings and new housing groups in scores of residential centers not only in Queens but in adjacent localities of Nassau County.

Representative James M. Mead, Democratic candidate for the short term as United States Senator, is the "ideal rubber stamp Congressman," Edward F. Corsi, his Republican opponent, charged last night in a radio speech carried over a State-wide network.

Senator Robert F. Wagner predicted last night that the slums of the country would be cleared within ten years and asserted that the new dwellings must be erected on the site of the present slums. He spoke to 750 persons at a housing rally at Seward Park High School at Grand and Ludlow Streets on the lower East Side.

Undefeated Villanova uncovered a new forward-passing sensation in Sophomore Nick Basca today to humble a stubborn Auburn eleven, 25 to 12, before a crowd of 17,000 at Shibe Park, and stretch their unbeaten streak to seventeen straight games.

Miss Marjorie MacDonald Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Henry Flynn of this place, was married this afternoon to James Creighton McCutcheon of Premier, B. C., son of Mrs. Hugh McCutcheon of Victoria, B. C., and the late Mr. McCutcheon, at the Flynn home here. The Rev. David O. Kendall, rector of the Dobbs Ferry Presbyterian Church, officiated.
Mrs. Frederick B. Davis of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Dyer, to Robert H. Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Clarke, also of Utica.

Hopes of educators regarding the value of motion pictures have gone up and down in the last few years. Many who began as enthusiasts feel that they have been disillusioned. Others, still hopeful, have encountered so many problems that the future is disappointingly vague.

The first in a series of departmental "At Homes," a new experiment in alumnae education, will be held at Woodlawn, the new alumnae house of New Jersey College for Women, on Saturday, Nov. 19, Dean Margaret T. Corwin announced.

Miss Helen Davis Sage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tuller Sage of this city, was married here this afternoon to James Beach Platt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Platt of Baltimore, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. George E. Norton, the rector, officiated.

Gift packages, which need not be confined to the Christmas season, will be offered by liquor companies this year, according to plans made known last week. In previous years the Christmas theme was emphasized on the cartons, with the result that those left over were not usable. While in the holiday spirit,

LONDON. - The Italian Government has rescued from decay the villa which Napoleon Bonaparte built on Elba and is engaged in tidying it up and recovering as many as possible of the treasures which it once contained.

Chairman of the Commission on Human Relations of the Progressive Education Association Were our school-teacher faces red Monday morning when we read of the Hoax of the Century gobbled up by an anxious and literal American public? I wonder how many science teachers said a quiet act of contrition for their sins of omission about inter-planetary affairs.

Norman Thomas, candidate for Governor on the Socialist party ticket, speaking yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, deplored the "present tendencies in the enactment and enforcement of laws for the protection of the old parties."

SOMETIMES one medium, sometimes another, seems to call special attention to itself. Terra cotta, these last months, has taken an insistent position, although actually there have not been many examples of the contemporary use of terra cotta on view.

Why do girls want to be policewomen? For the first time in five years New York City is reviewing women candidates for the police force, and taking its pick of thousands of girls who want the job. Paul Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, says that they represent "the finest group of young women we've ever had on any examination."

The North American golfing tourists, Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., recent winner of the Argentine open, and Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass., defeated the Brazilian pros, Arthur Davidson and Gonzales, 3 and 2, in an exhibition at the Gabea Club today.
Gabriel L. Kaplan, Republican election law expert, made public yesterday what he declared to be definite proof of illegal registration, on a large scale, in Albany County.

Declaring that adoption of State Constitution Amendment 4, or the housing measure, would put the State and city in the housing business with "consequent bond issues, expansion of debt limits and the granting of subsidies," former United States Senator William M. Calder urges the. defeat of the proposal.

MEMBERS of the fabulous Long Island set who go through life with never a serious thought in their. Pretty heads are to see reflected in :he pitiless mirror of the screen the sutility and sterility of their existence as only the righteous and sober-minded of Hollywood can chronicle such goings-on.

Herewith are presented brief biographical sketches of the State-wide candidates of the Industrial Government party to be voted upon at Tuesday's election. This political group is the old Socialist Labor party.

ROME. - Italy's population increased by 310,000 in the nine months between Dec. 31, 1937, and Sept. 30, 1938, and stood at 43,853,000 on the latter date. During that period births amounted to 778,000, or 23.7 per 1,000 of the population, with an increase of 43,595 over the corresponding period of 1937.

More than eighty debutantes have been marshaled under the direction of Miss Sonia Phipps, chairman, and Miss Alison Pyne, vice chairman, to serve on the debutante committee for the December Ball, an elaborately-planned event of the early Winter which will be given on Dec. 1 at the Ritz-Carlton to raise funds for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

With retail store inventories reported as "in good shape" or even a trifle light, any improvement in consumer buying is immediately reflected in reorders, and requisitions arrived last week in the wholesale markets for practically all types of merchandise, according to an analysis of the week's activity prepared

The Carroll Club defeated the strong Cosmopolitan eleven, 4 to 2, yesterday to become the new interclub champion as play in the weekly series of matches of the New York Women's Field Hockey Association was concluded at Prospect Park.
THE publication of the first four volumes in this new series emphasizes the serious attention which is being given to biography for young people today.

The Administration's decision to reopen the New Orleans Navy Yard, inoperative since 1921, gave fresh indication today that the "temporary" Atlantic squadron, created last September, might become a permanent sea force

Thirty-nine of America's leading scientists, including three Nobel Prize winners and thirteen members of the National Academy of Sciences, have sent to Premier Juan Negrin of the Loyalist Government of Spain a package containing twenty-six pounds of nicotinic acid, the recently discovered pellagracuring vitamin, for the relief of 40,000 sufferers of this disease of malnutrition in Madrid.

Work was started this week at Massachusetts State College on a history which will never be finished. Using a movie camera instead of a pen, Professor Rollin H. Barrett, official college cinematographer, has begun the filming of a continuous history of activities at the State College.

Setting a new high mark of $311,826 in building operations in October, Union Township is expected to lead New Jersey towns in new construction as it did for a period last year, according to Committeeman Nelson A. Kieb. The $311,826 total, compiled unofficially, establishes a new monthly record for the last nine Years of building reports.

Capitalizing on a fumble at the start of the second half, Wagner College moved to its third victory of the season yesterday. defeating the New Britain Teachers College eleven, 6 to 0, on the Wagner Field at Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

La Salle downed Albright at football today, 14-6. The winners' touchdowns came as the result of a blocked kick and an intercepted pass. Pilconis blocked Bert Aszman's kick and Lacek fell on it in the end zone.

The President of Liberia and Mrs. Edwin Barclay gave a reception last Monday evening in honor of Henry Villard, the State Department's special representative at the dedication of the new American Legation in Monrovia, the department announced today. Mr. Villard traveled to Monrovia aboard the new cruiser, Boise, which is on a shakedown cruise.

The Dairy Products Marketing Association, Inc., a producer cooperative nanced with Federal funds, today announced a schedule of prices at which it will resell butter about cents a pound higher than it paid in accumulating supplies in the open market in the last few months.

Following are forecasts from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES of the probable results of Tuesday's election in forty-three States. The outlook for the polling in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania is presented in separate stories. Maine held its election in September and Mississipi chooses only members of the House of Representatives, with no doubt as to Democratic victories.

Asserting that the, Republican campaign had been "disgraced" by its "vapidities," Representative James M. Mead suggested yesterday that the institution here of compulsory joint debates between candidates "might prove successful" in eliminating evasions and dodging of issues. Mr. Mead's suggestion was made in a formal statement issued at his headquarters.
Iowa State rolled over Drake, its traditional State football rival, 14 to 0, today to establish' an all-time Cyclone winning streak at nine straight games.

William and Mary rallied in the final period today to defeat Hampden-Sydney, 18-7. A pass, Della Torre to Seamans, clicked and a touchdown following an intercepted pass in the closing minutes put W. and M. in front.
Georgia Tech caged a rip-tearing Kentucky Wildcat, 19-18, today in as tense a football game as was ever lost by blocking a point-after-touchdown try;

Yale made a closing bid for victory against Brown today, and, with the cheers of thousands of hysterical fans lending encouragement, rode that. bid through successfully to subdue the Brunonian eleven, 20 to 14. The deciding touchdown,

" ITALIAN brother of Faust," Michelet called Leonardo. And aptly. For Leonardo had an unquenchable Faustian thirst for knowledge, a Faustian gift for questioning nature, whether she exhibited herself in rocks, birds, flowers or men, and a Faustian way of brooding in solitude over the meaning of the cosmos. But, unlike Faust, the great Florentine approached nature as an empirical scientist. rather than as a mystic or a believer in the supernatural.

More than sixteen hours will pass before the voters in all forty-eight States have cast their ballots Tuesday. An estimated 122,000 voting places will begin opening in the East between 6 and 7 A. M., Eastern standard time.
A rain-soaked crowd of 1,000 looked on today as the Gettysburg Bullets conquered the Presidents of Washington and Jefferson, 6 to 0. Hamilton tallied for Gettysburg in the third period.

Two and a half centuries ago, precisely, John Pratt established a blacksmith shop in Essex, Conn. The business was prosperous. John Lord Pratt, latest to carry it on, died a few days ago, just before his seventy-seventh birthday. Between him and the first John came three Johns, an Asa, an Elias and an Edwin.

Many garden experts, both amateur and professional, and numerous fine estates will be represented in the thirty-first annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which opens on Thursday in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

Minnesota Republicans come down the home stretch of the State campaign confident that President Roosevelt's half-way endorsement of Governor Benson has been without important effect and that next Tuesday they will end the eight-year reign of the Farmer-Labor party in the State Capitol.

Two governmental agencies whose activities are largely concerned with national housing progress revealed in reports made public yesterday that ample funds are available for new home construction. Both agencies-the Federal Housing Administration and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board-were in general agreement on the fact that, owing to the large number of institutions ready to make loans for home building, almost any person desiring to build a home may obtain the necessary financing funds.
PAINTINGS, etchings and architecture are included in the memorial exhibition of the work of Charles Adams Platt, to be held at the American Academy of Arts and Letters from Nov. 11 through April 30.

The Cunard White Star motorship Georgic is due today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Godfrey Haggard, relative of the novelist, Rider Haggard, and newly appointed British Consul General in New York replacing Sir Gerald Campbell; Lady SeyniourLloyd, Mr. and Mrs. Harold E.

Pennsylvania's Quakers turned on the heat to score two touchdowns in the final seven minutes of play today, but Michigan's resurgent Wolverines survived the blast to win a thrilling intersectional football battle, 19 to 13.

AN experiment in automobile liability insurance rating will shortly be tried in New York State which, the Insurance Department believes, may form the basis of a permanent rating practice by companies writing automobile bodily injury and property damage insurance. It will go into effect on Dec. 1.

Business has replaced teaching as the major occupational field of Middlebury College graduates, according to a survey completed by the alumni and alumnae offices. Educational work still leads among alumnae, but the men have swung so far to business that it now ranks first in the combined total of former students in both colleges.

Winthrop Lyon Saville arrived yesterday from Europe on the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines. He said he had served a five-year enlistment with the French Foreign Legion in Morocco and enjoyed it.

Whether Florida will join forty-six other States in conducting the National Guard on a basis of military efficiency or continue to subject it to political whim is to be decided by voters in the general election Tuesday.

Before a tense congregation of more than 5,000 Catholics in the Munich Cathedral this evening, Cardinal von Faulhaber made a vigorous defense of the rights of the Christian individual against the Nazi State's all-embracing regime.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,463,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

A girl was killed and two young men were seriously injured early this morning when an automobile in which they were riding toward Armonk got out of control on the steep Bedford Road hill, two miles east of the Armonk Airport, went down an embankment and rolled over three times.
The Right Rev. Warren Lincoln Rogers, who resigned this Fall as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Ohio, died in a hospital here tonight. He was 61 years old.

St. Frances Schervier Hospital and Home for the Aged, overlooking the Hudson at Independence Avenue and West 227th Street, the Bronx, was formally opened yesterday afternoon after a dedication by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
New Jersey still keeps some traces of that zeal for thrift and economy with which she was infected long ago by Swedish, Danish, Dutch and Quaker settlers.
Continued warm weather broke two records at the Weather Bureau yesterday, as the temperature rose to the highest reading for the date and the average surpassed all previous marks for Nov. 6.

The need of the nation is more Christians who will function as citizens and more citizens who will function as Christians, the Rev. Leon M. Flanders, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street. the Bronx. He said:

The appointment of a new commissar of the Red Navy was disclosed today in a three-line announcement without comment in Pravda. The new commissar, M. P. Frinovsky, of whom little was known until last Fall when, as Vice Commissar of Internal Affairs,
To raise funds for furthering the work of the Maryknoll Sisters, members of the Women's Auxiliary have arranged a card party for Saturday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Samuel James Fisher, who manufactured stained glass windows for the Washington Cathedral and for churches at Princeton and Atlantic City, N. J., Philadelphia and New York City, died today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. William Sparks. His age was 79.
A State campaign, the result of which is more in doubt than any since Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected Governor in 1928 by a plurality of 25,853, will come to a close tonight.
A large and applausive audience gathered for the song recital given by Marjorie Lawrence of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.
The New Haven Eagles, making their debut on home ice before a crowd of 4,000, defeated the Springfield Indians, 3--1, tonight in a rough and tumble InternationalAmerican Hockey League game.

In the light of present world conditions it is increasingly important for the nations of the New World to maintain solidarity and cooperative effort in the interest of common democratic ideals, Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, asserted in a radio broadcast tonight.
Egbert Moxham Jr. scored a sweep in Class B and Allan Clark and Burton Morris tied for Class D honors as the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy fleet opened its season today.
