Predictions of price advances ranging as high as 20 cents a yard on men's wear fabrics for Spring, which have been made in the market for the last two weeks, were supported in a statement prepared last week by Moses Pendleton, president of the American Woolen Company, and released for publication today.
Favored by a summery southwest wind, two Braintree men today slipped out of this old port in a home-made thirty-five-foot ketch in which they hope to sail 33,000 miles around the world in two years.

While all German commentators emphasize that Germany achieved her recent diplomatic victories only because she was armed, and because she was ready to employ this force if necessary, Chancellor Hitler, speaking at Weimar today, called on the world to disarm the "war agitators."

Godfrey Haggard, newly appointed British Consul General to New York and a nephew of the late H. Rider Haggard, English novelist, who wrote "She," "King Solomon's Mines" and other popular works of fiction, arrived from London yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic.

An elderly woman who rented a Winter home here ten days ago under the name of Helene M. Grandspeare of New York was found dead this morning, leaving a small fortune. Police are seeking the heirs. Physicians said her death was due to a heart disease.

A supper dance will be given in the ballroom of the Park Lane after the final performance of "All Around the Town," the annual entertainment of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania, which will be presented the afternoon and evening of Nov. 19 at the Center Theater here.

The good neighbor policy enunciated by President Roosevelt offers the best means of preserving peace in the Americas, Spruille Braden, new United States Ambassador to Colombia, asserted yesterday in an address over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Dr. Andrew Cowper Lawson, 77year-old Professor Emeritus of Geology and Mineralogy of the University of California, has received the Penrose Medal, highest honor of the Geological Society of America, for "eminent research in pure geology and outstanding original contributions and achievements which mark a decided advance in the science of geology," it was announced yesterday.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Satruday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels and Scribner's: FICTION Rebeca, by Daphne Du Maurier (Doubleday. Doran).
Louis Clarence Hill, 'an engineer, died here last night after an illness of six weeks at the age of 73.

In his admiral's uniform and riding a white steed at the head of the main body of advancing troops, Hungary's 70-year-old regent, Nicholas-Horthy, fulfilled today a dream of the last twenty years of his life--that he would live long enough to lead his troops into the territories that Hungary had had to cede to the new-born Czechoslovak Republic in 1918.

From the Berkshire Hills to the lierra Nevadas aged persons with good memories for old songs, say??, customs, tales and beliefs will e asked to cooperate in compiling national collection of native and ?? folklore. The collection of his material is being directed andt coordinated on a national scale by ?? A. Botkin of the University of ??, editor of Folk-Say.
Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein of 420 Riverside Drive, founder and leader of the Jewish Science movement, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 48 years old.

Wilbur McIntosh Baldwin, former president of the Union Trust Company of Cleveland, died at his home in Cleveland Heights shortly before midnight last night of a heart ailment from which he had suffered for six years.

Asserting that the problem of curbing the political activities of civil service employes throughout the nation has become "acute," the fiftysixth annual report of the National Civil Service Reform League describes as "ineffective" the law prohibiting assessment of public employes for political organizations.

Perhaps the stock market's idle swing of values last week-fractionally up and fractionally down, with the averages slightly below the high point reached in the third week of October-indicated redistribution of stocks bought on recovery from Europe's political crisis.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 80.4 the week before, 79.9 two weeks before (reached also on Aug. 20), 80.3 three weeks before and 80.5 four weeks before.
Spanish Government counter-attacks of unexpected strength were reported today to have held back an Insurgent offensive aimed at wiping out the government's salient on the west bank of the Ebro River.

With Joseph Stalin and others of the Soviet great ranged behind him on the vast stage of the Bolshoi Theatre tonight, Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff made the first pronouncement on Soviet foreign policy since the Czech-German crisis.

Three games were decided in the finals of the annual championship at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Herbert Seidman of Brooklyn defeated Alvin C. Cass, Crescent A. C. champion. Sidney Bernstein and K. Darby, Matthew Green and Fred Reinfeld drew.
Making their frist home appearance of the season, the Syracuse Stars dropped a 3-1 decision to the Hershey Bears in an InternationalAmerican League hockey game tonight.

Captain Alexander Papana, Rumanian flier who spent two years in the United States preparing for a transatlantic flight that failed to take place, was taken to a hospital today in critical condition from exposure.

Edward F. McGrady, vice president of the Radio Corporation of America and former Assistant Secretary of Labor, appealed last night in a radio talk for the re-election of Senator Robert F. Wagner, describing him as "a liberal and at the same time a genuine and thoroughgoing conservative."
Business prospects are being viewed more hopefully here, the optimism being supported in some directions by actual facts.

Conditions in the local money market are returning to something of their tone as of before the recent European crisis. Treasury bills now are being issued weekly at the normal rate of approximately one-half of 1 per cent, while market discounts have reverted to within a few pence of that rate.

The third annual dinner of the Builders and General Contractors Division of the Real Estate Club of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will be held Nov. 17 at 6:30 P. M. at the Hotel Commodore. Aaron Simon is the general chairman of the division.

The fifty-eight-family apartment house at 1,151 to 1,155 Grand Concourse, corner of McClellan Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Sara Weisman to the 1,151 Realty, Inc., S. Ginsberg, president. It occupies a plot 127 by 100 feet, opposite the Andrew Freedman Home for the Aged, and was erected in 1923.
Led by Frank Pfeifer, who tallied four goals and excelled on the defense, the First Division conquered Fort Hamilton, 9 to 3, in an interclub polo match played at Fort Hamilton yesterday.

Preaching on the text, "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's and unto God the things that are God's," the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham, yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, deplored the modern tendency to justify an irreligious life by the profession of "good citizenship."

Hailing Mayor Frank Hague as "your leader and my leader," William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, told 3,000 persons gathered in Dickinson High School here today that "he will not find me wanting, when he wants me."

An eclipse of the moon under "highly unusual circumstances" will be visible to residents of the eastern seaboard section of the country beginning at 4:43 P. M. today, the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday.

Further E decentralization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue through establishment of two additional regional offices, one for the New England area and the other for Michigan, Ohio and Kentucky, was announced today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

For the first time in half a century The Players emerged en masse last night from their beloved clubhouse at 16 Gramercy Park and wended their collective way to the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where they celebrated their fiftieth anniversary.

First Game--Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica, South America, defeated Angel Iturrino and Jose Pradera, Basque, 20 to 17. Second Game--Domingo Ugalde and Antonio Andres, Cuba, defeated Armando Ferrer anl Candido Echarri, Spain, 20 to 14.

Albert Thayer, 13-year-old Boy Scout, rescued a man and his wife from their flaming home here today, but failed in heroic efforts to save their two sleeping babies. The boy rushed to the one-room cottage of Harold Watkins, 30, when he heard an explosion.

James G. Blaine, president of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that 380 voluntary health and welfare agencies in the city thus far had been accepted for enrollment in the fund and are now eligible to apply for grants from funds raised in the organization's 1938 appeal.
Prices of cotton moved irregularly last week, with little net change. Reversing their actions of the previous week, near-by deliveries were weak and distant deliveries were relatively firm.

Although his team has lost three straight games and he was shut out in two of them, Everett Elkins of Marshall (W. Va.) College managed to retain a share in the Eastern individual football scoring leadership during the week-end.

A youth, clad in hunting clothes he was wearing when amateur radio operators found him in the Alaskan wilds eleven days ago, arrived at the bedside of his dying mother today after a 4,500-mile dash by boat and plane.

The Socialist Labor party,which appears on the voting machines as the Industrial Government party and styles itself the oldest labor party in America and the only one advocating social revolution, wound up its campaign yesterday at the Manhattan Opera House.
Herman C. Kletzsch, member of one of Milwaukee's leading German families and for more than forty years managing director of the Republican Hotel, died last night at the age of 70.

Confident of a Democratic victory in his own State, President Roosevelt received assurances today from Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, just back from a trip to the West Coast, that New Deaf candidates would be elected in Western States through which he passed.

The golden Jubilee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joachim, 26 Roosevelt Street, was marked yesterday by celebration of a solemn high mass, attended by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the archdiocese.
Elimination of the old-age reserve and other "basic defects" in the Social Security Act should precede efforts to extend the law, the American Association for Social Security asserted yesterday.

The Rev. William Frederic Wunsch was installed yesterday morning as pastor of the Swedenborgian Church of the Neighbor, Clark Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn. The Rev. Charles W. Harvey, general pastor of the Pennsylvania Association of the New 'Church, officiated.

The spread of exhibitions this week, as to type and subject, is even wider than usual, the New York art calendar revealing the names of old Italian masters and modern French and American artists as well as a variety of media, including sculpture, oil painting, water-colors and miniatures, among the nearly thirty new exhibitions.

Playing to 11,477 paying spectators and more than 90,000 empty seats in the vast Municipal Stadium, the Brooklyn Dodgers, paced by Ace Parker and Ralph Kercheval, did a workmanlike job today as they kicked, ran and passed their way to a 10to-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.
Realty transactions in Manhattan reported over the week-end included sales of apartment houses on the lower East Side and in Harlem. Several of the houses will be modernized.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dyer Clyde of Swarthmore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Archer Clyde, to Leigh Williams, son of Mrs. William K. Williams of Richmond, Va., and of the late Mr. Williams, who was Assistant Secretary of War under President Wilson.

Tony Sarausky made an auspicious debut in the American Professional Football Association today by leading the Union City Rams to a 10-9 victory over the Brooklyn Eagles before a rain-soaked crowd of 2,500 persons.

The news of the retirement at the age of 73 of Miss Mary M. O'Reilly, whose thirty-three years of service have won for her unofficial designation as the "sweetheart of the Treasury," suggests a number of things close to the American heart.
Stringent measures were completed today to safeguard Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, when he arrives here Wednesday en route to Washington.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, Charles Poletti, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, and Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, were among the speakers at a housing amendment ratification dinner held last night at the Hotel Astor by the National Public Housing Conference and the New York State Board of Housing.

Line after line of American flags and regimental colors was borne through the rain by nearly 3,000 members of patriotic and military organizations, marching on Fifth Avenue yesterday in the seventeenth annual Massing of the Colors, culminating in religious services at which warning against following the ways of European nations were sounded;

The newspaper Kokumin, considered to be the organ of the army and ultra-nationalistic elements, warned today that Japan would "take retaliatory measures" if the United States attempted to force her to continue recognizing the Nine-Power Treaty.

Jersey City's unbeaten football Giants swamped the Newark Tornadoes, 35-0, today to clinch the championship of the American Professional Football Association. Playing before 7,000 at Schools Stadium, Coach Bill Owen's men annexed their sixth straight, brought their season's total to 114 points and have yet to be scored on.

It was not a figment of the prolific imagination of Mr. H. G. Wells served up in the dramatic style of Mr. Orson Welles. It actually happened, and if the Martians collaborated with Buck Rogers they could hardly put on a more hair-raising, spell-binding show than football offered on a Saturday that was supposed to offer comparatively mild entertainment.

More than 300 members of the combined Methodist congregations of St. Paul and St. Andrew attended the first services of the season yesterday in their newly decorated and remodeled church at West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

A threatened strike of 4,000 employes of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Kearny was avterted tonight when the employes accepted the management's proposal for conferences on the dispute and, it these do not result in a settlement, for arbitration. The conferences are to begin tomorrow.
John L. O'Brian, Republican Senatorial candidate, appealed for balloting Tuesday with the basic principle of liberalism, rather than "the spurious superficial liberalism" of Washington, in mind.
Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street, 11:15 A. M. National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section. Speakers: Albert Kennedy, Louis Kraft.

H. W. Maxwell, for five years buyer of men's accessories for Abercrombie Fitch, has been appointed manager of Countess Mara, Inc., a men's custom-made accessories shop, which will be opened formally at 338 Park Avenue on Nov. 15.
Both Republican and Democratic campaign committees in Nassau County will wind up their drives for votes tomorrow night with rallies' in various parts of the county.

Glenairley Rocket, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Garlock of Barrington, Ill., and winner last week of the Derby Stake at Hampton Bays, added new laurels today by capturing the first Jay F. Carlisle Memorial trial stake of the Labrador Retriever Club held over the estates of Gerald Hollins and Charles L. Lawrance.

Investment buying was the mainstay of the corn market last week on the Board of Trade. Futures, at the bottom, sold within about 1/4 cent a bushel of the season's low level, but a moderate rally followed on short covering and a little buying by cash interests.
To those voters who are still in doubt on the eve of the election the views expressed in THE TIMES this morning by Charles C. Burlingham ought to have special interest.

Managed currency is here to stay and not only is there no desire among monetary authorities in any of the leading countries of the world to return to the gold standard, but under present political and economic conditions the adoption of the gold standard with fixed gold points does not seem to be warranted, Dean John T. Madden,

Van Campen Heilner, who has been doing some more practical research for his coming book on waterfowl, just returned from Illinois, and reports that the first couple of days on the river of the same name were grand, but that he finally had to take off his boots to keep cool.
The Atlanta Constitution said tonight the first all-Negro "bowl" football game in the United States would be played in Atlanta Monday, Jan. 2,

Half a dozen witnesses will go before the Kings County Grand Jury beginning at 2 o'clock this afternoon in connection with John Harlan Amen's investigation of a report there were "50,000 reasons" for the naming of Isaac R. Swezey instead

A 9-year-old boy was slightly burned on the leg and forty tenants were driven from an apartment house at 158 West 101st Street yesterday afternoon when a large gasoline tank-truck that was filling portable tanks burst into flames in front of the Saxonia Garage, 160 West 101st Street.

Mary E. Davis, a 13-year-old schoolgirl who-dragged to safety and applied artificial respiration to her 11-year-old brother after gas fumes killed his dog and made him unconscious, received the President's Medal and certificate of the National Safety Council today from J. S. Boylan, director of the Safety and Sanitation Division of the Continental Oil Company.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh pitched the Washington Redskins to a fourth-period 7-0 conquest of the Pittsburgh Pirates today, strengthening the Warriors' clasp on the top position in the National Football League's Eastern loop.

There are as yet few signs of any discontinuation of the movement of capital to the United States and unless some major favorable event occurs in Europe the exportation of gold will persist, although probably the rate of the flow will slacken somewhat.

Polish-Americans and representatives of Poland and France joined yesterday in commemorating the fortieth anniversary of the discovery of radium and the seventy-first anniversary of the birth of Marie Sklodowska Curie with exercises in City Hall Plaza under the auspices of the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs and the United St. Stanisiaus Societies.
There is great concern in German business circles over the foreign trade situation and the fresh burdens which the new trade drive may impose on commercial enterprise. At Dresden Dr.

The Netherlands is somewhat perturbed by the sharp attack made by nine leading financiers-among whom is the president of the Netherlands Bankon the government's budget policy. Otherwise, this country's financial situation is fairly satisfactory.
An alert Iona Prep football team defeated the Mount St. Michael eleven, 20 to 7, before a crowd of 3,500 that sat through intermittent showers at the losing team's field yesterday.
Morris Ave, (9-2338); s e cor of 150th st, 50x78; Carmine Placente to William H. Steinkamp, executor, 277 Park Ave; installments, 41/2 per cent; $12,000.

Reuben Fine of New York, who with Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, represents North America in the international chess masters' tournament sponsored by A. V. R. O., operators of The Netherlands Broadcasting Corporation, carried off the honors of the first round today.
Charles Leo Cuff, corresponding adjutant of the Nassau County American Legion and adjutant of Baldwin Post, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 47. Mr. Cuff,

Despite the recent international crisis and resultant sharp fluctuations in foreign exchange rates and security prices, "business conditions in this country from early Summer to October showed a general and continuous improvement," according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin for November, issued today.

There is not "one scintilla of truth" in the charges of political activity by WPA workers in Pennsylvania made by Senator James J. Davis, Aubrey Williams, acting works progress Administrator, said in a letter to Senator Shappard,

An appeal for support of Amendments 1, 4, 6 and 8, made by Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, was read yesterday in every Catholic church in the archdiocese, at every mass.

Expressing complete confidence that he would be elected Governor at the polls tomorrow, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate, last night declared at a dinner at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn Heights, that the Democrats had failed to meet any of the issues of the campaign.
The Boerse here presented a rather uneven picture last week, with a weak tendency at the close.
Today's events: Frank Bishop and the American Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Enya Gonzales, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Carroll Glenn, violin, Town Hall, 3.

Important legislation was enacted and tournament dates were announced as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association held the biggest annual convention in its sixteen-year history today. Almost 200 persons, including delegates from sixty clubs in the organization attended at the Hotel Carpenter.

George A. Bahr of 48-09 216th Street, Bayside, secretary and a director of the Stevens-Eaton Company, 1 Madison Avenue, dealers in lumber and building materials, died yesterday in the Parsons Hospital, Flushing, after a three-weeks' illness of leukemia.

Dec. 30- Jan. 2, eighteenth annual Invitation tournament for college men, Sno Birds of Lake Placid Club. Jan. 8. interstate jumping, Bear Mountain S. A.; 8. Lebanon-Dartmouth dual meet. Dartmouth O. C.; 15, Lebanon-Dartmouth dual meet, Dartmouth O. C.; 15, Westchester County jumping, Norswift S. C.; 22, high school meet. Winnepesaukee S. C.; 21-22, Greater Boston tournament,
The Philadelphia Germans were defeated by the league-leading Brookhattans before 3,000 soccer fans at Starlight Park yesterday. The score was 2--0.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, predicted yesterday that although the Democrats probably would lose some seats, the next Congress would be "overwhelmingly Democratic in both Senate and House." He added that in a majority of the States where Governors are to be elected Democratic candidates would win.

The German wholesale price index on Nov. 2 stood at 106.0, compared with 105.9 the previous week. In the first ten months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17.

Charles C. Burlingham, who first recommended Thomas E. Dewey to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for appointment as a special rackets prosecutor and who later served as chairman of Mr. Dewey's citizens' committee in his campaign for the District Attorneyship, came out yesterday for the re-election of Governor Lehman.
Efforts to avoid running down a frightened rabbit led today to the death of Randolph Streeter, 44, who survived the World War as a member of the famous "Lost Battation. "

Ray Blades, a veteran of the St. Louis club's farm system, today was named manager of the Cardinals for 1939. Announcement of Blades's seleetion to replace Frankie Frisch, the last month of whose five-year tenure was filled in by Coach Mike Gonzales last season, was made by President Sam Breadon, who declared.

Hopping off at 8:22 o'clock this morning, President Oscar R. Benavides and a committee arrived at Arequlpa at 11:34 after a 490-mile flight on a PanAmerican Grace Airways plane. They are on a tour to inaugurate various public works.

In the campaign which is now drawing to a close, public interest has been centered on the choice of a Governor and two Senators. This has been inevitable in the circumstances. But there are many other offices to be filled, and in some cases the choice of candidates for these offices deserves the special interest of people of this city.
Funeral services for Victor Watson, former Hearst newspaper executive who died Thursday, were held yesterday morning at the home of his mother, Mrs. Harriet Watson, 36-16 166th Street. Flushing.
The Jewish people have not been left unscathed by dispersion and anti-Semitism, Dr. Ludwig Lewisohn told the congregation of the Free Synagogue yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall.
Discovery of a manuscript of a nineteenth century melodrama--"Metamora" -- was announced today by Dr. Wallace A. Goates of the University of Utah Speech and Drama Department.

Calls for holiday merchandise held the center of attention in the New York wholesale market last week, although cooler weather brought indications of consumer buying in the form of fill-in apparel orders and "specials."

Modern civilization, "living on the principle of 'What is gain to me,'" has been judged and today is "found wanting" when measured by the principles of Jesus, declared the Rev. Arthur M. Crawford, assistant minister of the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, in a sermon there yesterday morning.

The impending election is restraining interest here in United States securities. There does not appear to be any fear that Wall Street will suffer any fresh shocks from the election but there will be relief when the result is known.
" Where Do We Go From Here?" the William Bowers comedy about life in a fraternity house, has been postponed from Thursday night until Tuesday of next week.

Fordham's football team emerged from its game with St. Mary's pretty well battered, but Coach Jimmy Crowley expects all the Ram regulars to be on deck for the contest with North Carolina at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, whose facile wit earned him the title of master of the wise-crack while Mayor, made his professional debut as a master of ceremonies yesterday afternoon in a broadcast over Station WMCA from the Bellevue Hospital psychiatric amphitheatre.

Stocks moved narrowly throughout the week and finished steady and mixed; turnover, 5,853,600 shares. United States Government and corporation loans steady; traction and German and Japanese industrial bonds strong; transactions, $40,272,925.
A large number of reservations have been made for the annual card party in behalf of the Mary Fisher Home in Tenafly, N. J., to be held Thursday afternoon at Hampshire House.
Mr. and Mrs. T. Wendell Prestwich of Malba, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lyda Ann Prestwich, to John Frank Wood, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. William Wood of Chester, Pa.

American motion picture representatives said today that several large American companies probably would abandon the Italian market at the end of this year as a result of dissatisfaction with the Italian Government's film monopoly.

Wray Bevens, chief of the Ohio Division of Aid for the Aged, today accused the Social Security Board of violating Federal law in attempting to "interfere in the selection, tenure of office or salaries of State employes" in his division.

Richard B. Scandrett Jr., Republican nominee for Representative at Large, declared yesterday that "if the election in New York State is won by the Democratic Senatorial and Congressional candidates we will have gone a long way toward abolition of the two-party system of government."

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Catherine S. Hodgkinson, of Torrington, Devonshire, England, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. A. L. Hodgkinson, to Marvin McCord Lowes of this city. The wedding will take place on Dec. 13 in Torrington.
Two United States amateurs won their bouts last night in the ninth round of the Pan-American boxing championship.

Society was well represented in the boxes at the gala performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the counter attraction of week-ending in the country and the fact that it was a non-subscription night, every box was filled.
Six thousand of the Polish Jews expelled from Germany entered today the second week of their stay in the fields near Zbaszyn, at the border, with the end of their ordeal still remote.

Whitestone-W s, 151st P1; 30x61, n of 9th Ave; two 1 1/2-story dwellings; cost $7,000; owner, Cornelius R. Fay, Inc., 33-28 147th St, Whitestone; architect, Arthur E. Allen. Whitestone-N e cor Leggett PI and Ninth Ave; 1 story; cost $4,500; same and same.

Stanton St, 290: Berglin Realty Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; prior mtg $17,628; building loan, on demand, $7,400. Willett St, 99; Pioneer Associates Corp to same; purchase money mtg $16,609. Same property; same to same; prior mtg $16.609: building loan $7,000.

An apartment of fourteen rooms in the building at 550 Park Avenue has been leased by Alexander Eisemann of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Alexander Eisemann Co. The lease was arranged by Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.
The French weekly wholesale price index on Oct. 29 stood at 654, compared with 653 a week before and. 657 two weeks before.

The University of Santa Clara, last of the West Coast's undefeated and untied big league teams, retained its perfect football record today with a 7-0 victory over the University of San Francisco. The game was seen by 30,000 fans in sunny weather.

A dispatch from Helsingfors states that the inhabitants of the Aland Islands are objecting to proposals to remilitarize and fortify their territory. They have been bandied about a good deal in historic time: for centuries they belonged to Sweden;

Contributions to the budget campaign of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York are coming in 'better than they did last year," Mrs. William Fellowes Morgan, chairmann of the drive, said yesterlay. To date $77,328 has been received, compared with $62,068 up to the same time in 1937. This year's goal is $205,000.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, declared tonight that the way to promote recovery was through an increase in business activity and "not through government bounty, sustained by unsound financial policies."
A fund of $50,000 was raised last night at a dinner of a committee for the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, it was announced by Harry Zeitz, chairman.

The Honest Ballot Association announced yesterday that it was assigning 3,000 watchers to the polls tomorrow to prevent voting frauds. The watchers are being sent chiefly to districts which have proved troublesome in the past, Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel for the association, said.

Oak Point Ave (10-2773), s e s, at s w s of Preble St, 50x100; Consolidated Edison Co of N. Y. to John R. Flick, 1,701 Bussing Ave. Esplanade (16-4369), e s, 156 ft s of Waring Ave. 40x100; Esplanade Construction Corp to Elsie Friedman. 390 Jackson Ave.

Fort Jay of New York played to a 6-to-6 tie with Fort Du Pont in their battle for the Eastern Army football championship today. The local eleven tallied in the second period after a sustained march from their own 40-yard line, Binder gaining the final 2 yards through tackle. Fort Jay scored on a pass, Sack to Przybyla, from the 4-yard line in the final quarter.

William Powell will return to the screen in January, when he will resume with Metro under a contract signed yesterday. His first picture will be with Myrna Loy, "The Return of the Thin Man," with W. S. Van Dyke directing. Powell has been inactive because of illness for a year.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 57 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the preceding week, and the highest rate since October, 1937.

Gattnig Pastries and Confections, Inc., store at 1,006 Madison Ave.; William C. Walker Sons and George R. Read Co., brokers. Luigi Guiffrida. voice culture, studio in 109 W. 57th St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co.. brokers.

Fernando Guedes, president of the National Coffee Department, denied today that Brazil would trade coffee for United States wheat. Brazil, he stressed, already sells to the United States all the coffee it wants for cash and that trading coffee for wheat would not increase the United States market.

Despite heavy rain and choppy water which nearly swamped both boats, the East Bronx division of the Voluntary Life Saving Service of the City of New York won easily in the ten-oar lifeboat race with the West Bronx division, held yesterday on the East River off Fort Schuvler. the Bronx.

A rugged hammer-and-tongs aefensive battle for fifty-six minutes in the rain and mud at the Polo Grounds yesterday suddenly became surcharged with electric energy for the final four as the New York Giants slammed over a touchdown that encompassed the defeat of the Chicago Cardinals, 6 to 0.

Miss Jean Louise Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Brush Campbell of this place, will be introduced to society at a supper dance given by her parents on Dec. 27 at the Siwanoy Country Club here.

With considerable reluctance, the Federal Power Commission has granted an application by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey to merge the South Jersey Gas, Electric and Traction Company, the Paterson and Passaic Gas and Electric Company and the Gas and Electric Company of Bergen County, according to a decision announced today.

Twenty-three hundred members of the Theta Pi Alpha Chapter of the Catholic Teachers Association for Weekday Religious Instruction of Public School Pupils After School Hours celebrated the silver jubilee of the organization yesterday with a communion breakfast at the Astor Hotel.

Scholastic football teams adhered rigidly to the form chart during the past week-end. Few upheavals were recorded and only a thin file was taken from the ranks of the undefeated. In the meantime several leading elevens scored in convincing style to continue along the victory path.

From anticipating the reassembling of Parliament with some misgivings, as affording opportunity for a fresh stirring of the muddy European political waters, the local financial markets almost have come to bless the event.

Funeral services were held this morning in the Palmyra Cemetery chapel for Mrs. Susan Cleveland Yeomans, sister of President Grover Cleveland, who died Friday in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Charles H. Rogers of Brooklyn.

James J. Doak, a former Mayor of Cape May and one of the two surviving members of John Mecray Post, 44, of the Grand Army of the Republic, died today at his home on the eve of his ninety-fourth birthday.
Sheridan Downey, Democratic nominee for United States Senator, appearing before a mass meeting of its adherents in Hollywood Bowl today, urged passage of the $30 Every Thursday pension plan.

The three-story dwelling at 608 Fifth Avenue, between Eighth Avenue, and Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has been leased by the Edwin Gould Foundation for Children to John J. Guckian. The Bulkley and Horton Company was the broker.
The world's wheat markets continued depressed last week and all deliveries of futures in Liverpool, Winnipeg and Rotterdam went to the lowest levels of the season.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced tonight the election of new directors of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks, chosen by balloting which began in September and ended tonight.

No sadder commentary can be made upon the run-of-the-mill Hollywood production than our report this morning that Rivoli's "A Man to Remember" is a distinguished and unusual film, for the qualities which distinguish it are merely such elements as simplicity, honesty, dignity and human warmthelements which properly should be found in every film drama, yet so rarely are.
Chicago's world champion Black Hawks won their third straight game of the new National Hockey League season tonight, 3-2, from the Canadiens.

Announcement-has been made of the engagement of Miss Hylah Coley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Tallman Coley of Douglaston, Queens, to Allan Farrand Kitchel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kitchel of Old Greenwich, Conn.
Gertrude Atherton, the still vigorous 82-year-old California novelist, thinks a silent revolution is going on in this country which
Miss Margaret Taylor Collier of this city will become the bride of William H. Wells, youngest son of Judge and Mrs. Harold B. Wells, on Nov. 19 in Christ Episcopal Church.

Voting in a democracy is a sacred duty and responsibility which may be appreciated too late if neglected, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson said yesterday morning in his sermon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, charged last night at a campaign rally in Mecca Temple that both Governor Lehman, Democratic nominee, and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate, had been evading the issues of the campaign.

A new Parliament, which will meet only to pass its own death sentence, was elected in Poland today. The voters chose 280 Deputies from 486 candidates who were nominated by special electoral committees.
Delancey St, 306; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 308 Delancey St Corp, 600 Grand St ($3). 57th St, 211-15 E: Alliance Realty Co to Revere Realty Corp, 111 Broadway; mtg $40,000 ($104.50).

The Cleveland Barons trounced the Pittsburgh Hornets in an International-American Hockey League game tonight, 5 to 1, the identical score by which the Hornets defeated the Barons last night in Pittsburgh.

Mrs. Marshall J. Dodge of Paris is expected Thursday on the Washington, and will be at the Ambassador, where she will be joined later in the month by Mr. Dodge. Mrs. Joseph S. Ely of Scarsdale will give a luncheon on Dec. 19 at the St. Regis for her debutante daughter, Miss Rosamond Ely.

Democracy is the vital form of government, and the calm, clear, thoughtful and faithful devotion to the method of our fathers must supersede all resort to the emotions in examination of current international problems, Dr. David S. Muzzey said yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

W. A. Clifford, executive secretary of the New York State School Board Associationm representing the public high schools of the State, pointed out yesterday that the adoption of Amendment 1 by the voters tomorrow would not give constitutional force to a bill providnig free buses to sectarian schools, as was said in a summary of the nine amendments in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for County Court judge in Kings County, announced yesterday that if elected he would work under a six-point program to eliminate evils in the administration of justice in the county.

IT was during the week of the amateur golf championship over the Oakmont course on the outskirts of Pittsburgh that Judge John P. Egan dropped by of an evening to chat about football. Judge Egan is one of the best football referees east of the Mississippi and he gets around in gridiron circles.

The monthly review of the New York Reserve Bank, commenting on the absence, in a season marked by trade revival, of the expansion of member bank loans for commerce and industry, has an interesting explanation to offer.

Voting will be entirely by machine in all boroughs tomorrow. The illustration shows a typical voting machine ballot arrangement. At the top will be found the nine proposed constitutional amendments. Below them are arranged the eight party tickets.

A dispatch received in Sydney, Australia, today said two Royal Air Force bombing planes had landed at Fanny Bay, near Darwin, at 3 A. M., British time [10 P. M. Eastern standard time, Sunday], breaking the distance-flight record previously held by three Russian aviators.

The marionettes of Harry Burnett, Forman Brown and Richard Brandon, who for four years or so have been barnstorming about the country as the Yale Puppeteers, had their two hours upon the stage last night at the Lyceum Theatre, inaugurating this season's series of Hart Doll Sunday night programs.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and Bronx County Democrati leader, in a reply last night to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's speech in Brooklyn Saturday evening, accused the Republican nominee for Governor of resorting to "half-truths" in "vicious and unscrupulous" attacks on Democratic leaders.

Elections were held today throughout Nicaragua for delegates to the Constituent Assembly. The results will be announced later in the week. The delegates convene next December to change the Constitution.
William T. Morrey of 362 Riverside Drive has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Morrey, to Pierce Edmunds, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edmunds of Weilesley Hills, Mass.

" Too many people have been making fun of Hitler," said James G. McDonald, president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, yesterday afternoon at an Armistice meeting in the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark, Brooklyn.

Assumption by the schools of complete responsibility for sex instruction would amount to "educational totalitarianism," in the opinion of the committee on sex education of the Teachers Alliance of Greater New York.

Nation-wide studies of political sentiment by the American Institute of Public Opinion; of which Dr. George Gallup is director, indicate that tomorrow's election will register an important and dramatic shift toward the conservative viewpoint in national politics.

Because of the All Saints holiday and the usual Saturday closing, the Bourse was open for business on only three days this week. On Wednesday the announcement that Paul Reynaud had changed office with Paul Marchandeau as Finance Minister was hailed by a sharp rise in the Rentes and French stocks generally.

No pride will be paid by the city for rapid-transit properties now operated by the Interborough and the B. M. T. that can not be supported by a five-cent fare after unification, Transit Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig declared yesterday in a radio talk over station WNYC.
Twentynine young Norwegians who attended a party in the studio of 0. Andersson, a court photographer, were burned to death early this morning in the worst fire in Norway's history.

The closing of Narragansett race track in October of last year is haunting Governor Robert E. Quinn, Democrat, tonight. He declared martial law and called out the National Guard to prevent the 1937 Fall opening of the $3,000,000 race track and the repercussions gravely threaten his chances for reelection Tuesday.

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy is expected to end the government's case today when the espionage trial of Johanna Hofmann, Erich Glaser and Otto Hermann Voss is resumed before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition for Arrangement FRATELLI DE LUCA. INC., grocers, 195 Bleecker St.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler Act, listing liabilities of $7,379 and assets of $3,065. A composition of 25 per cent payable 5 per cent in cash and balance in notes of 2 1/2 per cent payable at monthly intervals is proposed.

Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, reported today to Pope Plus on the Eucharistic Congress held last month at New Orleans and walked among the Cardinals behind the Pontiff at the beatification of the Blessed Maria Giuseppe Rossello in St. Peter's.

Roger Fawcett took the highover-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday with a perfect score of 100. Z. G. Simmons gained Class A handicap honors on a total of 98. L. F. Sanman Jr. topped the list in Class B.

For the first time in about five years, Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., will launch an ensemble promotion next April for its various products. A new shirt at $2, underwear of the same material, two matching ties and a handkerchief will be advertised for Easter in a color page in one magazine.

The fifth earthquake in three days shook Tokyo today. All were. of mild intensity and caused no casualties or serious damage. The last shock was felt here at 10:45 A. M. today (8:45 P. M., E. S. T. Sunday).

The Twentieth Century Fund appealed last night for a reform whereby "Federal and State Governments and regulatory agencies should strive to discourage debt financing rather than encourage it as they now do through income-tax policy, regulation of utility rates and control of local government debts."
Supply contracts valued at $13,354,675 were awarded during the week ended Oct. 29 by thirteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

A collection of nearly 100 gowns, many of them imported models, that have been donated by women of society to the Opportunity Shop, will be displayed by a group of debutantes of this season headed by Miss Ruth Young at a fashion showing this afternoon at the headquarters of the shop, 46 West Fortyseventh Street.

While some of the major candidates in Pennsylvania's venom-filled political campaign rested today in preparation for a final election eve drive, others continued their rounds of speech-making, and both sides renewed forecasts of victory by pluralities ranging from 250,000 to "landslides."

Interest on France's defense bonds has been lowered from 4 1/2 to 4 1/4 per cent, and the Caisse Autonome delivers these bonds only in renewal of matured bonds. Interest on armament paper also has been lowered by one-quarter of 1 percentage point.

Robert J. Watt, American delegate to the International Labor Organization at Geneva, who attracted some attention in London when he attended a garden party at Buckingham Palace on Oct. 24 and talked to King George VI with his hands in his pockets, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic.

Miss Lucille Cluxton, daughter of Mrs. Sylvia Cluxton of 290 Park Avenue, this city, and Larchmont, N. Y., was married to Andrew Balconis, son of Mrs. Joseph Baier of Boston and the late Andrew Balconis, yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Margaret Mary, the Bronx.

Adverse business conditions at the close of 1937 tended to level off the trend of growth in retail credit activity which featured the recovery years following 1933, and indications so far this year point to a complete reversal of this expansion of credit sales, Alexander V. Dye, Director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestle Commerce,

Joey Fontana, East Side featherweight, will oppose Paul Lee of Indianapolis in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. In the semi-final, also listed for eight rounds, Chalky Wright of Los Angeles will meet Cristobal Jamarillo, Puerto Rican featherweight.
The Democratic and Republican leaders of Westchester County met today to map plans to get out the greatest vote since a Presidential year, when nearly 250,000 voters went to the polls.
The Holland-America liner Noordam is due today from the Channel ports. Passengers are Mr. and Mrs. Otto Stadlin, Miss Doris Stadlin, Miss Frieda Alt, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Balet and G. E. Tamplin.
Eastbound air travel was cancelled and trains were delayed as the worst early November snow in several years covered much of Northern New Mexico today. Santa Fe had 91/2 inches and Las Vegas 10.

A further race for armaments, widespread unemployment and the divided condition of the Christian church are "menacing strongholds" that must be conquered to permit progress, Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president' of Union 'Theological Seminary, said yesterday in a sermon in James Memorial Chapel of the Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.

Norman Carroll, 48 years old, a brother of Earl Carroll, the musical comedy producer, died of suffocation yesterday in his room on the top floor of the Fanmart Hotel, a seven-story building at 112 West Forty-seventh Street, after his bed took fire.
William Strong Hogan, a pioneer in the automobile and airplane industry, died yesterday in the American Hospital after a short illness at the age of 64.

For our own peace of mind we must believe in life after death, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington told worshipers yesterday at a memorial service in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.
An attack on Thomas E. Dewey as a "front" for reactionary interests within the Republican party was made over a State-wide radio network last night by Israel Amter,
Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson and Mrs. Eliza Keats Young, "Why Women Vote for Dewey", WJZ, 12:15 to 12:25 P. M. Postmaster General Farley, at Advertising C l u b Luncheon, WMCA, 1:15 to 2 P. M.

The Irish-Americans scored their fifth consecutive victory in the American Soccer League today, defeating the Brooklyn Hispanos, 4-3, at Scots Field. At half time the home team was leading by 3-0, and this advantage was increased early in the second period, but then the Hispanos recovered and made their three tallies.
Four persons were dead and six persons injured today as the result of a crash between two automobiles at the ramp entrance of a highway bridge in Bolton Notch.
There is concern here over the increasing unfavorable trade balance with Japan and its possible effect on trade relations with the United States and Britain, Costs Rica's two best customers.

The season's third meeting of the insatiable New Friends of Music, yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, presented the Kolisch Quartet in the first of its six concerts devoted to the sixteen string quartets and the Grand Fugue of Beethoven.

A 63-year-old man who told Federal Judge Tillman D. Johnson that he sold a gallon of wine to Indians because he had no other means of making money, was sentenced "to the Works Progress Administration."
Various virtues of Americanism were reawakened recently when the offspring of the famous brothers, Bob and Alf Taylor, disinterred the former's dust and placed it alongside that of his brother Alf's.
Although numerous troops are stationed in and about Haifa and searches are being made daily for Arab terror- N ists, rebels set fire to a warehouse and robbed the postoffice.
THERE is considerable loose talk about "must" books-so-and-so's comments on foreign affairs "must" be read, or so-and-so's 900page novel, or so-and-so's confessions of a pleasantly misspent youth.

Walter H. Whitehill, who was in charge of the Liberty Loan drives in Orange County during the World War and also served as county fuel administrator, died today in St. Luke's Hospital here after an illness of four weeks.

Racial tolerance for all people was the plea made by the Rev. Edwin Holt Hughes, Methodist Bishop of Washington, D. C., to an audience that overflowed the chapel of the Pennington School during the morning religious services at the 100th anniversary celebration of the school's founding.

The opera "Rosalind" by Florence Wickham of New York received its European premiere today at Dresden's Theater des Volkes. The prologue was sung by a chorus of thirty-eight and was followed by two acts in the Forest of Arden.

Delmar E. Haskins rowed twenty-two miles last night on a one-man rescue expedition when the Ellen Mae, a fishing boat of which he was the crew, became disabled forty-two miles south-southeast of Marthas Vineyard.

Pat Dengis, 37-year-old Welshman who designs airplane tools for a living and wins marathons for fun, today became the National A. A. U. champion for the second time by running a starting field of seventy-six fagged.

In two campaign speeches last night Walter H. Liebman, Democratio candidate for Congress opposing Bruce Barton in the Seventeenth District, assailed his opponent's "work against the undistributed profits tax" and asked how "Barton, as an adviser to some of the largest munitions firms in the country, can work in Congress without bias to keep this nation at peace."

Jaques Scholle is with J. Arthur Warner Co. C. Edmund Fay is with Clinton Gilbert Co. in charge of their sales department. Mitchell M. Friedman is manager of the mortgage certificate department of Loeb, Newman Co.
Plans are under way for a card party, tea and Christmas sale in aid of the Peabody Home for aged gentlewomen, to be held Dec. 1 at the clubhouse of the New York Junior'League.

A lifesized mural caricaturing Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini and one held offensive to the Catholic Church were ordered removed today from the new waiting room of the Mexico City Central Airport.

New York Americans 2, Passon Phillies 2. Trenton Highlanders 6, Baltimore Germans 2. Baltimore S. C. 6, Bethlehem Hungarians 1. Brookhattans 2, Philadelphia Germans O. Kearny Irish Americans 4, Brooklyn His?? 3. Scots Americans at St. Mary's Celtics, postponed.

John L. Lewis, in a statement issued today as chairman of Labor's Non-Partisan League, declared that the real issue to be voted upon in Tuesday's election was whether the gains in social legislation under the New Deal were to be retained and extended.

William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, will win in New Jersey by 32,150 votes, according to the consensus of twenty-two newspaper editors in the State's twenty-two counties.

Recognizing that many visitors to the 1939 World's Fair may enter the city without money to maintain themselves or to buy their tickets home, the State Department of Social Welfare is taking steps in advance to guard against any disproportionate rise in transient relief costs during the period of the fair.

Since the meteoric rise and fall of Napoleon there has been a succession of top dogs in continental Europe. After Waterloo there was Russia; after Russia the Austria of Metternich; after Austria the France of Louis Napoleon;

The 268th anniversary of the First Presbyterian Church here was celebrated today. It is the oldest congregation that has been continually of the Presbyterian denomination in the United States. The commemoration sermon was preached by the Rev. James N. Armstrong Jr., the pastor.

Mayor La Guardia joined Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican nominee, yesterday in deploring the injection of racial and religious prejudices into the New York State political campaign.

The world appears to be lining up definitely for "one terrific struggle," the Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

A political symposium virtually unprecedented in recent Massachusetts history, with Leverett Saltonstall and James M. Curley, Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor, meeting face to face on the platform for a short time, ended in pandemonium today when Mr. Curley walked out of a forum which followed speeches by the two candidates.

Net income of the Pullman Company, sleeping car affiliate of Pullman, Inc., increased in September to $397,366, compared with $215; 136 in September, 1937, George A. Kelley, vice president, reported today.

While eager for peace, the Soviet Union, on the eve of the twentyfirst anniversary of the October revolution, is prepared to resist any aggressor, Constantine Oumansky, Soviet charge d'affaires, declared yesterday after the laying of the cornerstone for the pavilion of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at the World's Fair grounds.

A departure service for four Franciscans who will go as missionaries to the Franciscan Mission Station in Shasi, Hupen, China, was held last evening in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street. Presiding was Bishop Stephen J. Donahue.

Scranton University scored in every quarter today to defeat the St. Joseph's eleven, 27 to 6. A pass from Lefkowitz to Davidson early in the first period caught St. Joseph's flatfooted and on the next play Stephanek scored standing up.

James H. Drummond, 64, farmer, merchant and former State legislator, died today, leaving a special request that "six respectable Negroes" be his pallbearers, "because of my special interest in the welfare and well-being of the colored people in our community."

Royal Kid Regards, international champion owned by Mrs. E. P. Anders of Linden, N. J., was adjudged best of breed today at the forty-seventh annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of America at Horticultural Hall.

The Most Rev. Joseph F. Rummel, Archbishop of New Orleans and chairman of the Catholic Episcopal Committee for German Refugees, attacked Nazi leaders yesterday for exiling patriotic citizens because of their faith.

President Manuel Quezon put two more Provinces under constabulary rule tonight because of election campaign tension and officers prepared for trouble in another - Cavite - after three persons had been seriously injured in a political riot there.

The Detroit Lions clung to a place in the thick of the fight for Western Division honors in the National Football League by turning back the Cleveland Rams, 6 to 0, in a listless game before 31,000 fans today.

Armistice Day services were held yesterday for the deceased members of the old Sixty-ninth Regiment at the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, Second Avenue and Twenty-second Street. The services were conducted by the Rev.
The generally held view here is that the forthcoming elections in the United States will result in slight gains for the Republican party, but that there will be no landslide either way.
General Jan Christian Smuts, former Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, declared today that "back to a reformed League of Nations must be our policy."

The man with a $1,500 a year income could buy in forty-four years a $118 a month annuity on which to retire at 65 with the money he now pays in hidden taxes, a study by the National Consumers Commission showed today.

One swift scoring thrust right after the opening kick-off brought Canisius College a 6-to-0 victory over St. Bonaventure before 16,000 spectators today. Throughout the remainder of the game the Buffalo team balked its Western New York Little Three rival's efforts to retaliate, thereby scoring its first victory after five straight defeats.

The only realistic approach to peace is by repentance and a re-established faith in God, declared the Rev. Dr. John Gass, rector of the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, in a sermon yesterday morning.

Frank Campbell, with his B onedesign craft Felix, and Bill Dodge, with his Class X Moth Ball, were the leaders today in the opening of the "cold weather" dinghy sailing at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Campbell, champion of his class last year, won three out of four races to score 79 points.

John W. Smith, former managing editor of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, has accepted appointment as executive director of the newly formed American Jewish Federation to Combat Communism and Fascism, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Milton Solomon, chairman. Mr.

The Boston Bruins scored their second straight victory of the National Hockey League season by conquering the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to i, tonight. A crowd of 11,000 witnessed the Detroit club's season debut.

The chief honors on the second evening of the National Horse Show went to a United States Army officer, Captain Royce A. Drake, when he rode the grey gelding King Hi to victory in the $1,000 International Military Stake at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mayor La Guardia went to the Cunard White Star Line pier at West Fourteenth Street yesterday morning to meet Mrs. Lynna Stockton, his grammar-school teacher of forty-five years ago, who arrived from Europe on the motor-ship Georgic. Mrs. Stockton, who taught at Prescott, Ariz., where the Mayor was born, is now a deputy assessor in Hollywood.
Sai Shoki, Korean dancer, who was first seen in New York last season, made her second bow to Broadway last night at the Guild Theatre.

Imports into Cuba for the first eight months of 1938 decreased materially from those of the corresponding period last year, the American Commercial Attache at Havana has reported to the Department of Commerce. Exports fell off in about the same proportion.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, condemned the "two whispering campaigns" of anti-Semitism and pro-Semitism which, he charged, were conducted during the present campaign and urged Jewish Socialists not to switch to Governor Lehman just with a view to counteracting the anti-Semitic ballots.

Although German business and production continue at a boom pace, it is becoming obvious that business sentiment no longer responds to continued boom news and prefers to await a further clarification of the problems and issues posed by the forced increases in production.

Current British exports of gold to the United States are running at about one-third of the rate reached during the European crisis, but October's exports of approximately [Pound]67,000,000 were not much smaller than September's of [Pound]75,000,000.

Green Bay stopped a last-minute Chicago Bear threat on its own 7-yard line today to win, 24 to 17, and maintain its position atop the Western Division of the National Football League. A crowd of 40,208 saw the game.

Many persons face perplexing situations because they lack the power to make swift and sudden decisions, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig declared yesterday in a sermon in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.
The Navy squad today began preparations for Columbia with a feeling that the result would have much bearing on the Army game, to be played two weeks later.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld unanimously yesterday the decision of District Judge Robert P. Patterson directing that the Sixth Avenue elevated line be sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings for the knock-down price of not less than $12,500,000, the price bid by one of the bondholders' committees at the recent sale.

Heads of the National, Columbia and Mutual Broadcasting companies, the three largest in the country, agreed with Chairman Frank R. McNinch of the Federal Communications Commission at a conference tonight that such news terms as "flash" and "bulletin" should be used with discretion.
Stocks closed active and strong with industrial shares up 1 to 5 points in largest trading since Oct. 27; turnover, 1,761,880 shares.

Officials of the New York zone of the Buick division of General Motors won praise yesterday from the Flint, Mich., headquarters for what was described as an outstanding year-to-date sales record. According to W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager, Buick registered in second place in the industry in the New York Metropolitan area from January through Oct. 15, being outsold by only one low priced manufacturer.

At a meeting yesterday of directors of the Hunter Steel Company (formerly Independent Bridge Company) J. H. Hillman Jr., Albert P. Meyer, A. M. Kennedy, G. E. Dignan and W. L. Affelder were elected new members of the board.

Since time always marches on, the freshman stars of this season become the varsity stars of tomorrow. Hence it is with considerable interest that a large part of New York's sports population will follow--most of it vicariously--the Fordham-N. Y. U. freshman game at Ohio Field this afternoon.
Will the exception of Harlan Gustafee and Balfour Smith, Pennsylvania came out of the Michigan game is good shape and started work today for the annual clash with Pen State.
For the guidance of voters the State Bar Association made public yesterday an analysis of Section 27 of the proposed judiciary amendment to the State Constitution.

No liquor or beer may be sold at bars, in restaurants or in package stores throughout the State today while the polls were open, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, warned yesterday.

Jack Patroni, Shawnee pro, and A. U. Rodney of Quaker Ridge posted a 65 to win the pro-amateur best-ball honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. at the Scarsdale Golf Club today. One stroke behind came Dan Galgano and Ray O'Brien, Green Meadow combination.

House investigators were told today that Paul Sifton, assistant to Elmer F. Andrews, the Wages and Hours law administrator, once wrote an article urging readers to tell capitalists that "the whole capitalist shell game can sink and be damned."

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 3 numbered 216, as compared with 175 for the corresponding week of 1937 and 251 in the week of Oct. 27, 1938, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The week in 1937 included a holiday.

To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 10: PATROLMAN-John J. Cosgrove. from Motorcycle Precinct 1 to 28th Precinct. Assignment to motorcycle duty discontinued. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-Max Isaacson, 46th Precinct. assigned to foot patrol tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and from 4 P. M. to 12 Midnight, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 8.

Freed Burr, whose run for half the length of the field-turned the tide in Yale's victory over Brown, has been promoted to the first string and will start against Princeton Saturday at right halfback, it was announced tonight by Head Coach Ducky Pond.

An irresistible force is about: to meet an immovable object in today's elections. According to the physicists, the result of such an encounter is certain to be chaos. But that will not be the outcome of the balloting by forty millions of Americans, or less.

A drop last week in the general death rate for the city was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health. The rate was 9.2 per 1,000 population, compared with 9.7 the preceding week.

Plans for twenty new buildings costing $1,969,500 were filed with the Manhattan division of the Department of Housing and Buildings last month, as compared with the same number of structures, estimated to cost $19,596,750 in the same month of 1937, Commissioner Alfred Rheinstein announced yesterday.
Andre Franccois Poncet, the new French Ambassador to Italy, arrived here this evening. His train was about a half-hour late because the electric locomotive had broken down a few miles outside Rome.

The new account began firmly on the stock market here today, although conditions still were extremely quiet. The gilt-edge list again strengthened under the lead of the war loan, but failed to hold the day's best levels. Foreign bonds were promising, particularly the European and Far Eastern issues.

After easing a few points yesterday in the early trading prices on the Cotton Exchange took on a steady tone in consonance, with strength in the stock market and ended with a gain of 2 points to a loss of 3. Despite active December liquidation, mill calling absorbed contracts within a narrow range, while spot houses did relatively little hedging.

The admittance to membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System of the Brooklyn Mutual Building and Loan Association and the Millington Building and Loan Association, Millington, N. J., has been announced by the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
Contributions to the United Hospital Fund now exceed $325,000, excluding Queens contributions reported yesterday, the fund's campaign committee announced last night.

Candidates battled all the way down the home stretch for the favor of the Rhode Island voters at tomorrow's election. Highlight of the contests is that for the Governorship, although this State's two Congressional seats, now occupied by Democrats, are the prizes in vigorous fights.

A special appeal for the election of former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, was made yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, at a luncheon in the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Vonderlin of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Frances Vonderlin, to Eugene Richard Cusker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Cusker of Corona, L. I.
Frederic R. Coudert Sr., one of the founders of the Fusion party, issued a statement yesterday asking for the election of Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor.
Two properties in Staten Island were reported yesterday as having been sold through the John A. Lynch Company. Inc., brokers.

Addressing his speech to the "plain people of New Jersey," William H. J. Ely, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, ended his campaign tonight with a plea to the voters of the State to repudiate W. Warren Barbour "and his reactionary millionaire friends" and to stand by President Roosevelt and the policies of the New Deal, to which Mr. Ely has pledged himself. He spoke over station WOR.
The spectacle of a whole infantry battalion making its entry into new barracks by parachutes was witnessed at Brunswick today.
Spanish Insurgent commanders announced tonight the occupation of Mora de Ebro, main base of government forces on the west bank of the Ebro River in Northeastern Spain.

The Supreme Court decided today that James J. Richman, a Brooklyn lawyer, was not entitled to a $1,500 fee awarded by the New York Supreme Court for services in collecting Federal war risk insurance for the estate of an incompetent veteran.
Realty deals on Long Island as reported by brokers yesterday involved a factory, a large number of homes and three business parcels.

Charlie Brickley, Harvard's peerless drop-kicker of another era, told the Football Writers Association yesterday at its weekly luncheon meeting at Jack Dempsey's, that points after touchdown never should be missed if the coaches spent the time with their kickers that Percy Haughton spent with him.
Disposing of 1,924 cases, Magistrate Aurelio handled the busiest day yesterday that Downtown Traffic Court has had since it was opened on June 14, 1916.

Coincident with the opening of the automobile show here, leading tire producers this week are launching campaigns to promote their products. Those companies whose tires are used as original equipment are advertising them on this basis, while other companies, which sell for replacement only, are urging "change-overs."
Specifications were submitted yesterday by architects for sixty-three new small dwellings in various sections of Queens and for fifty, mostly in Flatbush, in Brooklyn. The details follow:

Evidence as to the complete good order with which the Czechoslovak troops are withdrawing and handing over ceded territory was obtained by this correspondent today in the course of a journey from Budapest through the Hungarian and Czechoslovak lines beyond Komarom to Neuhaeusl, which is to be evacuated by the Czechoslovaks at 4 A. M. tomorrow.
With no game scheduled for Saturday, Coach Herb Kopf granted a respite to Manhattan's football squad as a reward for their 3-0 victory over North Carolina State last week.
Indications of a good automobile sales year in the Eastern part of the United States are reported by R. H. Israel, assistant sales manager of Nash Motors.
Mrs. Lynna Stockton, who was Mayor La Guardia's teacher in Prescott, Ariz., was his guest at City Hall yesterday after arriving here on Sunday with a friend, Mrs. Marvin Hart of Chicago.

State and municipal financing for October aggregaated $130,196,393, as compared with $37,406,392 in October, last year.. The total for the first nine months of 1938 was $1,000,334,232, as compared with $838,494,502 for the same period last year.

The safest and friendliest place for an unattached girl in New York City is in a residence maintained by the Young Women's Christian Association or one recommended by the organization. Next year thousands of girls and women traveling alone will be flocking into New York from all over the world to visit our World's Fair.

Legendary, indeed, have become the tales concerning Marvin Allen Stevens Jr., precocious 8-year-old son of the N. Y. U. coach. In football circles the boy's weekly reactions to the success or failure of the team his father coaches are awaited with great interest.
The Harvard football team again came through without injury last Saturday. Dick Harlow started work today for Virginia and Yale, with every player physically-fit.
The Upper Manhattan Property Owners League has been formed by a group of realty men and owners interested particularly in the section north of Ninety-sixth Street.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has booked orders for 7,500 tons of steel for the Netherlands Building, Rockefeller Center; 5,000 tons for three hangars for the North Beach airport and 3,800 tons for an assembly shop at the navy yard in Philadelphia.

The Theatre Intime, Princeton University's student organization, opened its eighteenth season with a presentation of "Hamlet" by Shakespeare in Murray Theatre tonight. The play will run through Saturday evening.

The Hun School seconds defeated the Princeton 150-pound second eleven, 13-0, on Fitzpatrick Field today. Bill Ziemmer, Hun halfback, scored for the schoolboys on a 33-yard run off left tackle and Captain Jim Fair added another tally on a pass from Langdon Granberry.
Gordon Drillon, Toronto Maple Leaf right-winger, who led the National Hockey League in scoring last season, will be lost to the club for a month, Manager Conny Smythe announced today.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 7 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, Kewaydin. San Pedro to San Francisco:

Mrs. Fannie C. Stover, dean of women at Western Maryland College until her retirement in 1936, died today after a 'brief illness. A graduate of Western Maryland in 1889, Mrs. Stover taught at the college for several years before her appointment as dean of women.
Carnegie Tech turned Pitt's championship "dream" into a "nightmare" today by planting the Panther goal posts on the Tartan campus in a hysterical, boisterous victor celebration.

THE current French interest in novels on the installment plan is generally recognized through the work of Duhamel, Celine and Jules Remains. Less familiar is Louis Aragon's "Real World" series, the second part of which is now available in English under the title "Residential Quarter."*

Weakness in foreign markets, absence of any export buying of importance over the week-end and indifferent outside demand caused, today, a heavy tone in wheat. After mid-day there was a partial recovery and,

In the present state of the nation the ultimate choice that the electorate must make lies between the totalitarian State and the cooperative Commonwealth, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, declared last night in a radio speech closing his campaign.
Coach Andy Kerr experimented with new Colgate backs today as he began preparations for the N. Y. U. game. The Red Raiders tested the attack to be used against the Violets.

With the establishment by the New Deal of a permanent basis for prosperity, the nation is definitely on the way to an era of "sustained recovery," Senator Robert F. Wagner told a group of "little business men" yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

Robert Irving Warshow, New York author, publisher and economist who had been a research editor in Washington for the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1936, died on Sunday at the home of- a brother, H. Thomas Warshow, at 1 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of seven months. His age was 40.

The government completed its case yesterday against two men and a woman on trial for espionage in Federal Court before Judge John C. Knox. Thirty-seven witnesses were called by the government in the trial, which is now in its fourth week.
Fred Haney, pilot of the Toledo Mudhens of the American Association the last four years and a former major league player, was named manager today of the Browns for the 1939 season.

Paul Reynaud, who was appointed Minister of Finance "in extremis" last Tuesday evening, announced today that he had finished the preparatory work necessary and that by the end of this week the decrees he deems essential to restoration of the financial and economic position of the country will be published. His communique read:
The Laclede Gas Light Company petitioned yesterday the Missouri Public Service Commission for approval of an extension of $10,000,000 bonded indebtedness for three years from April 1, 1939.

In an election eve broadcast carried over a nation-wide radio network, Postmaster General James A. Farley urged all Democrats last night to vote in today's elections to express their confidence in the policies of President Roosevelt and to prevent Republicans from getting the opportunity to sabotage New Deal legislation.

Miss Katharine Vanderhoef Morse, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Franklin Morse of New London, Conn., was introduced to society here yesterday afternoon at a reception given by her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef,
A number of properties in the West Side area extending from Sixty-sixth Street to Washington Heights figured in the real estate sales reported yesterday. Several parcels in Harlem changed hands.

On a field of a farm twenty-two miles from Sioux Falls, S. D., a great sporting event was decided last week. The field was in bad shape, muddy after continuous pouring rains. The day was of the bleakest. An angry north wind painted noses and nipped ears. The sky was darkened.
Edward Hamilton Daly, New York attorney and a leader in Catholic charity work, died here yesterday at his home after an illness of two and a half years. His age was 63.

Residents of Riverside Drive want to ask Park Commissioner Robert Moses by what authority he can grant to the Riverside-Claremont Restaurant, Inc., the right to operate a cabaret and bar that "impairs the rest and sleep of residents," they declared yesterday in a motion filed in Supreme Court in the suit brought by Peter N. Peters of 528 Riverside Drive, to restrain the operation of Claremont Inn at Riverside Drive and 124th Street.
Pitt St. 96. 25x100; Morris Schwartz to Parkrose Realty, Inc. 1,450 Broadway; mtg $8,050 ($7). 16th St, 435 E. 25x92; Hyman Schapiro to Reconstruction Bldg Corp, 1,819 Broadway.
Dartmouth's football team began work for Cornell on Memorial Field today with an unusual Monday scrimmage that lasted over an hour and a half.

Following their policy of producing sequels to their successful pictures, Warners today announced that "Life of the Parade," dealing with the characters in "Brother Rat" after their graduation from V. M. I., has been scheduled for January production.

Mrs. Helen Ledyard Birch, a descendant of John Ledyard, died here tonight of a heart attack in her apartment in the Marlborough Hotel. She was 64 years old. She was the wife of Frederick Howe Birch, treasurer of Slawson Hobbs.

The Japanese Government paved the way for reconstruction of war-devastated areas of Central China today when it formed the Central China Development Company, twin of the North China Development Company.

Connecticut approached tomorrow's election with two issues standing out, the New Deal and two recent grand jury investigations. In his latest speech Governor Wilbur L. Cross, Democrat, seeking a fifth term,
