As the strains of "Dulce Patria" echoed through Madison Square Garden last night, 10,000 spectators rose in tribute to the' redoubtable representatives of the Republic of Chile who won the international military jumping competition that featured the third night of the fifty-third National Horse Show.

Trading generally low on all classes in local markets yesterday, with the exception of lamb, which was fair. Hinds and ribs were barely steady to mostly 50 cents lower; pork loins steady to fully 50 cents lower; other pork cuts mostly steady to 50 cents lower; other classes about steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
1st Lt. Herbert Chase, M. I.-Res., 103 Park Ave., New-York, N. Y., is ordered . active duty Nov. 6 at Fort Jay, N. for training. Date of rank, Nov. 6. will revert to an inactive status Nov. 19.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 4: Brown, Capt. W. E., the Utah, to Navy Yard, Washington, D. C. in Dec.

William McFee, former first engineer aboard a British battle cruiser and better known as a writer of sea stories. said yesterday that the average passenger and member of the seamen's union was at a loss when given the usual fourteen-foot sweep used in lifeboats.

Society in glittering gowns and sparkling gems filled the boxes on the third night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. The pageantry of fashion was as notable as on the opening night, with a revival of the elegance in the dress of the Eighties.

Domestic sources bought twentynine locomotives and 2,435 freight cars in October, compared with five locomotives, 1,079 freight cars and eleven passenger cars in September, according to Railway Age. In October, 1937, there was no purchasing of locomotives or passenger cars, and only six freight cars were ordered.

The Rev. Simon Borkowski, held "prisoner" by his picketing parishioners, said today he had written to his superiors stating he wished to be an "obedient servant" but it was physically impossible to leave the St. Barbara's Catholic Church rectory in compliance with their order.

Exercising the prerogative of an independent newspaper, THE TIMES has recommended the election of a Democratic candidate for Governor and of two Republican candidates for the Senate of the United States. In both cases it has been guided by the same consideration: are independent judgment of the course which it believes will best serve the interests of the whole people of the State in the situation now prevailing.

Means to meet competition from the Works Progress Administration in the construction field, and the problems arising from the contemplated national defense program will be considered by the governing and advisory boards of the Associated General Contractors of America at the Fall meeting at Excelsior Springs, Mo., on Nov. 15 and 16, the association announced today.
The observance of American Education Week, known as "open school week," began yesterday in the city's public schools on the theme "Education for Tomorrow's America."

A traditional "battle of the Bronx" will be staged today when the New York University freshman football team plays host to the Fordham yearlings at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus. The kickoff is listed for 2 o'clock.

Although he started the second session of his adjourned game from the first round of the A. V. R. O. international chess tournament with a position that was none too favorable, Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, succeeded today in gaining a draw with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the world champion.

Election returns will not represent the only conflict of Highs and Lows today. The weather forecast, which is a kind of straw vote based on conditions all over the country, indicates that a High, lurking unseasonably around these parts, is going to be badly beaten by a Low sweeping to victory from all points west.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation spent $5,105,000 in twenty-four States in the five weeks ended Nov. 2, the Department of Agriculture announced today. This brought its purchases to $17,981,000 for the period since July 1.

Horace M. Gray, city chairman of the City Manager League of Yonkers, made public today a copy of a written appeal he has made to Governor Lehman to assure a fair election here tomorrow on the City Manager Charter.

A $440,000 mortgage at 41/2 per cent for ten years on the six-story apartment houses recently completed at 155 and 165 W. 20th St. has been arranged by Ackman Co., Inc., brokers, for the owners, a firm headed by Horace Ginsburg, architect.
Improving their efficiency for the second successive week, the Giants maintained their forward passing lead in the National Football League, according to the official statistics released yesterday.
Ferris Faulkner of Pleasantville, former attorney in New York and Brooklyn, died here on Saturday in Grasslands Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

Robert Irwin, 21-year-old sculptor and one-time divinity student, grinned and dozed unpredictably yesterday as he went on trial before General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace in the Supreme Court Building for the murder of Frank Byrnes early on Easter morning, March 28, 1937.

Miss Marjorie H. Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Clark of this place, was married this evening to Kenneth Keith King Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. King of Bloomfield, N. J., in the Community Church of Mount Vernon.

Miss Rosalind Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Gray of the Dorset, was married to Martin D. Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jacobs, also of this city, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents.
Criminal sabotage was blamed today by District Attorney Earl Warren for the blast that foundered the German freighter Vancouver Thursday in Oakland estuary.

The Rev. William F. Wefer of this city, secretary for men's work in the Presbyterian Board of Christian Education, was elected today as superintendent of city missions of the Presbytery of Philadelphia, Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Hollywood, which has been watching the development of television as a possible competitor of the movies, heard an announcement today from Stanton Griffis, chairman of Paramount Pictures Executive Committee, that his studio had entered the television field.

Leading members of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy and others interested in the society's philanthropic aims are making preliminary plans for its eighth annual Allaverdy ball. The event will take place on Dec. 9 at the Plaza,
Lehigh started drills today for the twenty-eighth meeting in Taylor Stadium on Saturday with Muhlenberg, and indications are that the game will attract a capacity crowd.

Plans are going forward for the luncheon and fashion revue which will be held Nov. 18 in the Garden of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Yorkville unit of the Speedwell Society. Mrs. Wilson P. Foss Jr. is chairman and Mrs. Bigelow Watts vice chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements.

No definite trend in commodity prices was apparent last week. The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale prices recorded an unimportant advance, rising 0.1 point to 79.8 on Nov. 5 from 79.7 on the Wednesday previous, and a low since 1934 of 79.2 on Oct. 22.

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn and other borough, State and city officials attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. Selda Jonas, wife of Ralph Jonas, philanthropist, at her home, 129 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn. She died on Saturday at the age of 64.

With steel operations this week scheduled sharply higher at 61 per cent of capacity, against 56.8 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday that the output of steel in October was 3,117,934 gross tons, the highest figure reported since October, 1937.

With the cataclysmic, super-colossal defeat of Pittsburgh, Dartmouth goes to the head of the class in the East, and its meeting with Cornell at Ithaca becomes of paramount interest on this week's football schedule.
The declaration that there is no religious issue in the current campaign was made last night by Edward F. Corsi, Republican candidate for the short-term United States Senatorship.

Mrs. Laura Billings Lee, who had been a member of the council of the Charity Organization Society since 1902 and a member of the association's Yorkville district committee for twenty-five years, died on Saturday at her home, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The Merchants Trust Co. sold the two eight-family flats on a plot 50x97 feet at 549-51 Park Ave., West New York, to the Polk Realty Co., Inc., who gave back in payment a purchase money mortgage for $32,000.

Two thousand of the clergy and laity attended the anniversary mass of requiem for bishops and priests of the New York archdiocese celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of the cathedral, was the celebrant.

"The Madonna and Child," an altar piece by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, eighteenth-century Italian painter, has been given by Mr. and Mrs. Edsel B. Ford to the Detroit Institute of Arts. It is said to be the only example in America of the artist's early work.

Tonight we are on the eve of a momentous election. As we pause for final consideration, let us soberly approach the responsibilities of tomorrow. Looking ahead to the next four years, you will decide how you can best provide clean, progressive and good government.

The Harvard Club strengthened its hold on first place in the Class B division of the Metropolitan League squash tennis tournament by defeating the New York Athletic Club, 4 to 1, on the Harvard courts yesterday.

The estate of Lucy Cotton Thomas, 13-year-old daughter of Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas McGraw and the late Edward Russell Thomas, sportsman and owner of The Morning Telegraph, increased from $1,701,819 to $1,831,121 between Jan. 1, 1934, and June 30 last, according to an intermediate accounting filed yesterday by her mother and the Irving Trust Company, trustees.

The voter going to the polls today will be asked to vote yes or no on nine amendments to the State Constitution, submitted by the recent Constitutional Convention. In previous editorials on this page recommendations have been made as to action on these amendments.
A contribution of $12 was received at the Board of Education yesterday, in an envelope similar to two others addressed within the last three weeks to the "conscience fund."

The world's largest United States flag, 230 feet wide and 90 feet high, will feature the celebration of Armistice Day at the World's Fair on Friday, when Mayor La Guardia will deliver the principal address devoted to "World Peace."

Today, election day, and Friday, Armistice Day, will be observed as holidays by all security and commodity markets and banking institutions in the United States. The Canadian markets, however, will be open as usual on both days, as will the European exchanges.
Erasmus Hall High School and the Barnard School for Boys elevens will risk undefeated and untied records today in two of six scholastic contests scheduled for local gridirons.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 2:

A Philadelphia dispatch states that "the world's first municipal electric lighting apparatus, installed by Thomas A. Edison at Sunbury, Pa.," will be put up for sale tomorrow. It has been on loan at the Franklin Institute since 1933.
Dr. Hickson F. Hart of Peekskill, N. Y., physician, former State Assemblyman and former Village President of Peekskill, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital here after a two-week illness.

Supreme Court Justice Andrew J. McNaught of Stamford, Delaware County, came here today at the call of Presiding Justice James P. Hill of the Appellate Division, Third Department, to preside over an investigation of alleged illegal registration in Albany County.
The world's first municipal electric lighting apparatus, installed by Thomas A. Edison at Sunbury, Pa., in 1883, will go on the auction block Wednesday.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn announced yesterday that the police were searching for three more men in connection with the $427,950 armored car robbery in Brooklyn more than four years ago.

The Conference on State Defense, which has started a campaign against the proposal of the Federal Administration to tax State and municipal bonds without first submitting the question to a Constitutional amendment, announced yesterday that immediately after election the conference would begin a drive throughout the country to roll the members of the new Congress on their position with respect to these three issues:

While orders did not specify large quantities, the volume of mail business received from retailers yesterday was quite heavy. The commitments placed by stores in which lower temperatures were experienced last week were substantial, lending color to the belief that the weather is the major handicap of trade elsewhere.

The most hotly contested Congressional campaign in many years in Manhattan's "gas house district" closed last night with James H. Fay, the Democratic nominee, and John J. O'Connor, Democratic chairman of. the House Rules Committee, who is running for re-election on the Republican and Andrew Jackson tickets, both claiming victory.

The apartment building containing fifty apartments and eight stores, on a plot 125 by 100 feet, on the northeast corner of 167th Street and Grand Avenue, Bronx, has been sold by Sam Minskoff to the 1,212 Corporation.
Although three-horse races are a rarity at Pimlico, the crowd today received a real treat from a trio of Maryland-foaled campaigners in the Heiser Handicap.
Money in circulation on Oct. 31 amounted to $6,699,506,572, or about $51.39 per capital, compared with $6,622,249,018, or $50.83 per capita. on Oct. 31, the Treasury announced today.

A feature of the fashion show to be held in conjunction with the annual Christmas sale of the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work, will be a group of costumes for mother and daughter, which will be shown by prominent residents of this community.
Stephen J. Ardes, Democratic leader of Phoenixville, was sentenced today by Judge W. Butler Windle in Westchester court to serve three months in the county prison and pay a fine of $250.

A salute of thirteen guns boomed across New York Harbor from Fort Jay yesterday as Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum arrived at Governors Island to assume active command of the First Army and of the Second Corps Area, with headquarters there.
More than 3,000,000 Illinois voters, according to estimates made in political camps, will go to the polls tomorrow in an election marked by an intense "off-year" campaign.

With buyers here from all parts of the country to cover requirements in advance of price increases approximating 5 per cent, which go into effect Nov. 15, the wholesale floor coverings market expects this week to be the most active, from a volume standpoint, of any similar period in the last six months.
Battalion Chief Harold V. Kinney, 44th Batt., died Nov. 4. Funeral took place from his late residence. 443 Essex St., Brooklyn, at 9:15 A. M., Monday. Nov. 7. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 2, aggregated $9,336,000,000, or 17 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 7 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt cut short a visit planned here today to make certain she arrived in New York in time to vote in tomorrow's election.
Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, said today that "America's greatest asset" was its student "army" of more than 30,000,000 enrolled in schools, colleges and universities.

The Long Island P. G. A. held an added one-day tournament at the Sound View Golf Club today to conclude its 1938 campaign. The amateur-pro event drew thirty-three teams, with four tying for top honors with 65s.
Records of the Department of Commerce showed today that Canadians bought $4,553,950 worth of tariff-exempt merchandise in the United States in the tourist season from April 1 to Sept. 30.

The New Deal, particularly with reference to President Roosevelt's farm and labor policies, will go before the voters of the nation in today's election. Old-age pensions presented in varying forms will be an issue in five States.

Austin Lewis Babcock of this place, executive vice president of the Morris Plan Corporation of America, at 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, died here today in Lawrence Hospital, at the age of 57, after an ill ness of several months.

In an effort to promote business, the Mexican Government has created a bureau to encourage fishing as a sport, something heretofore practiced hardly at all by natives, according to a report received today by the Department of Commerce from the American commercial attache at Mexico City.

Yearlings and light steers received steady to strong bids today, but the rest of the cattle market was weak to 15 cents lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs declined 5 to 15 cents, while fat lambs were strong to 10 cents higher, choice Colorado and native lambs selling up to $9.15.

Five former Sudeten German members of the Chamber and three members of the Senate, after signing a declaration of allegiance to the Czechoslovak republic, announced today that they had formed a "Club of German National Socialist Deputies and Senators of Czechoslovakia."

A high temperature of 75 degrees at 3:10 P. M. yesterday broke records at the Weather Bureau for the second successive day as warm weather continued for the fourth day. The average temperature for the whole day equaled the previous high record of 68, set for the date in 1924.
Columbia's varsity, at full strength for the first time since the Penn game, two weeks ago, began preparations yesterday for the encounter with Navy Saturday at Baker Field.
ADLER--Augusta, devoted sister of Rachel Polak, Jennie Katz, Elizabeth Schiff and George. Services Central Funeral Chapel, 109 West 87th St., Tuesday, Nov. 8, at 10:30 A. M.

Holders of city of Cordoba, Argentine Republic, 7 per cent external bonds of 1927 have been advised by the bondholders' committee that the City Council of Cordoba passed an ordinance for readjustment of the entire city debt on Oct. 20, providing substantially the same treatment for the bonds as outlined in the committee's letter of Oct. 4.
The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association remained unchanged last week despite moderate rises in the prices of foods, farm products and miscellaneous commodities.

A petition with about 3,000 signatures was presented yesterday to John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, by the American Youth League, an anti-Communist organization, endorsing his campaign and asking that he continue to demand amendment of the Wagner act "to reduce unemployment and to make it possible for the 500,000 young people of New York who have never had a job to have their opportunities restored to them."

Fifteen hundred persons took part here tonight in the annual Republican political rally and parade established as a pre-election custom by the late Theodore Roosevelt when he was President of the United States and maintained a "Little White House" in Oyster Bay.

The first of a series of concerts designed to develop young orchestral players in the routine of "accompanying" soloists in the performance of concertos was given by the American Orchestra, Leon Barzin, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The soloist was Frank Bishop, who played three piano concertos by Bach in D minor, Schumann, and Rachmaninoff in C minor.

Voters in the enormous industrial constituency of Dartford, Kent, yesterday rejected Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's candidate in a by-election that the Conservatives had chosen to fight on the issue.
Mrs. Diego Suarez, exhibiting blooms and vegetables grown in the gardens and greenhouses of Easton, her estate in Muttontown, won sixteen first and second awards, in the first day's judging of the

Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 11 East Seventieth Street, at which plans were discussed for a benefit performance of jai-alai to be given at the Hippodrome the evening of Nov. 30 in aid of the Lisa Day Nursery.

It looks as though the time has come for the codfish anglers to hunt up their earmuffs and get out their tackle, for the big fellows seem to have arrived. Perhaps we can even dispense with the earmuffs for the time being.
New Hampshire's campaign ended tonight with Republican and Democratic machines Centering their attentions on the industrial cities of Manchester and Nashua and the State capital here.

The newspaper Tiempo praises the stand of President Roosevelt and the United States Government against dictators and totalitarian governments and urges a common defense of democracy on the part of those countries where democracy still exists.

Harold LeRoy Moffet, one of Broadway's best-known supporting players, whose last appearance was with the Lunts in "The Sea Gull," died of heart disease early yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 46.

Purchase of the Smith-Terwilliger property on Fowler Avenue, in Carmel, Putnam County, along with several old holdings on the same street which formerly were used for commercial purposes, has brought to light an effort by "civicminded" residents of Carmel to provide low-rent cottages and apartments for worthy families not only in Carmel, but also in the towns of Brewster, the Mahopacs and Cold Spring.

John Jay O'Brien, in 67 Park Ave; Alison McB. Feeny, in 27 E 79th St; Mrs. John Philip Sousa Jr., through Fred F. French Management Corp, in 1,140 5th Ave; Margaret M. Martin, in 152 E 84th St; David Walker, through Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc, in 955 5th Ave; Potter, Hamilton Co., brokers.

Mr. and Mrs. John F. Curry Jr. gave a supper last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Eileen McCarty and her fiance, Francis Richard Curry, brother of the host, whose marriage will take place on Nov. 18 in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament.
A badly battered City College football squad reported to Coach Benny Friedman at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday to start preparation for the Moravian game here next Saturday.

Stacy Smith of Short Hills, -vice president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark and head of H. Stacy Smith, Inc., makers of tanners' materials, died suddenly of a heart attack shortly before 7 o'clock tonight at the wheel of his automobile while driving homeward through Weequahic Park.

Eva Kopilchak, a 17-year-old tomboy who was an honor student in high school and who was released from an asylum for the insane last July, admitted yesterday having slain her mother, Mrs. Christina Piatak, 47, with a sawed-off rifle in their two-room apartment at 310 East Seventy-first Street, Sunday afternoon.

For the first time in his six years at Fordham, Coach Jimmy Crowley has excused his Ram football squad from a Monday practice session with a major game coming up the following Saturday. He declared. a holiday yesterday to reward the Rose Hill squad for its courageous battle with St. Mary's.

The oratory ended last night. Today the voters of the city and State will go to the polls to render their decision in the current political campaign. The polls will be open from 6 A. M. until 6 P. M. Voting machines will be in use in the city in all five boroughs and will be used this year for the first time in all up-State districts.
The two-story garage occupying the block front on the south side of King Street between Washington and Greenwich Streets, has been leased to the Patterson Trucking Company, headed by Theodore Ficke.
Iowa candidates looked to the weather and the mud road farm vote as the joint key to tomorrow's "off-year" election test of the New Deal's farm belt strength.

Mrs. Fannie I. Helmuth Edgerton of Darien, Conn., widow of Colonel Wright Edgerton, former Professor of Mathematics at the United States Military Academy, West Point, died yesterday in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital of a heart attack at the age of 79.
Five and a hale million men and women in this State are entitled to vote tomorrow. I hope that all of them will exercise this highest right of citizenship in a democracy.
A Modern Mart in aid of the Newark Exchange for Women's Work will be presented Wednesday at the home here of Mrs. Edgar W. Heller. Mrs. Henry Young Jr. is general chairman.

Bond prices reflected a firm undertone in relatively quiet pre-election trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest was focused mostly on the local traction issues, which continued in brisk demand at advancing prices. Transactions in all bonds amounted to $7,379,400, compared with $8,688,700 last Friday.

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings the common stock, no par value, of New York Investors, Inc. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York in an order on last Friday declared New York Investors, Inc., a holding company which some time ago filed a petition for reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, to be insolvent within the intent and meaning of Section 7.7b.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 12 to stock of record Nov. 17, compared to payments of 25 cents a share made in March, June and September.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Gerhard R. Gerhard and Thomas F. D. Haines of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 15--Waialua Agricultural Co., Ltd., petr., v. Eliza R. P. Christian, an incompetent person, etc., et al;
172d St (11-2929), n w cor of Fulton Ave, 15Ox155; Hendeesy Realty Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co, 55 Broad St: installments. 41/2 per cent: $36,200.

Pennsylvania's bitterly fought campaign ended tonight with last-minute radio appeals by candidates, with the issuance of further warrants in this city based on coercion charges and with Republicans accusing Democrats of responsibility for handbills injecting racial and religious issues.

Three addresses on inter-American cooperation broadcast from Washington on Sunday draw attention to one of the most interesting and in the long view perhaps one of the most important after-effects of the Munich settlement.
Hitler in his Weimar speech held up before the world two ways of life. One is the way of the sword and the other is the way of the umbrella.
It was announced this afternoon that the first Latin-American congress of insurance companies will take place in Chile from Nov. 27 to Dec. 4.

Consent decrees by which the Department of Justice dropped anti-trust cases against the Ford and Chrysler Motor Companies in return for vital reforms in the conduct of automobile financing by their subsidiaries were entered in Federal Court by the department today.

John R. Vunk, unsuccessful Suffolk County candidate for the Supreme Court nomination, was one of several witnesses called before the Kings County grand jury yesterday-by John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, in the inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the nomination of Isaac R. Swezey for the office.

Automobile production last week increased more than seasonally, for the seventh successive week, and the adjusted index advanced to 92.2, a high since the week ended Nov. 20, 1937. The figure was 87.9 for the preceding week, and 102.4 for the week ended Nov. 6, 1937.

John Ringling North, president of Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey, announced tonight that the circus' labor troubles were "settled" and the "big show" definitely would go on the road next Spring "bigger and better than ever-and air-conditioned."

Senator Robert F. Wagner, in his final campaign address last night, urged the election of Governor Lehman on his record, a repudiation of the racial and religious issue he accused the Republicans of raising and maintenance in office of Democrats, State and national, because of their program of social and economic justice for all the people.

Solwyn Tansey of Allen Winden, a Labrador owned by William K. Dick, came out on top today in a group of twenty-five in the non-winners stake which brought to a close the field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club over the estates of Charles L. Lawrance and Gerald Hollins.
Harper Knowles, witness before the Dies committee at Washington last month, was named defendant in two suits filed in Superior Court here today asking $200,000 for alleged libel and slander.
In a resolution adopted last night the Socialist party council called on the Radical Socialists and Communists to compose their differences and preserve the Popular Front.

The Aerovox Corporation, Brooklyn, manufacturers of radio, refrigerator and automobile condensers, will move on Jan. 1 to New Bedford, Mass., the first company to respond to the campaign of the Industrial Legion of New Bedford to rehabilitate industry there, T. A. Haish, managing director of the legion, announced yesterday.
Dr. Frederick William Steinbock, superintendent of Hazard Hospital since 1924, died at the hospital this morning at the age of 72.

In connection with a decision today by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirming a decree by the District Court for the Southern District of New York in the injunction proceeding of the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Associated Gas and Electric Company and certain affiliates, the SEC commented briefly.
172d St (11-2929), n w cor of Fulton Ave, 150x155; Manufacturers Trust Co to Hendeesy Realty Corp, 21 E 40th St; mtg $234,000.

George B. Finch, at 61 Hall's Lane, Rye, N. Y., from Miss Myra Valentine; E. V. Siedle, broker. Oscar A. Doob, in Kensington Gardens, L. I., from Evelyn Reitenbaugh; Edward J. Clancy-Ann Vera Hughes, Inc., brokers. Harold McCormick, at 401 Bard Ave., West New Brighton; E. Cella, through Herbert Welsh, at 253 Prescott Ave, New Dorp; John A. Lynch Co, Inc. broker.
Manhattan College retained its monopoly of the metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championship, winning the meet at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday for the sixth year in succession.
The "home-town folks" gave Governor Lehman an election-eve party tonight in the manner to which he has become accustomed in his five previous bids for public office.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, asserted here today that William H. J. Ely, his Democratic opponent, had "made public admission of his allegiance to Mayor Frank Hague and thus had established the fact that his whole campaign has been based upon a lie."

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today called upon the candidates and workers of his party throughout the country to watch on Tuesday for "evidence of coercion of relief beneficiaries" at the polls in the national election.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced his reconstructed Cabinet tonight following the issuance of a fresh commission by the Governor General, Lord Gowrie, and it contained surprisingly few changes.

The railroad committee of six, named by President Roosevelt, held two sessions here today and recessed subject to call in order that each member might bring to the next session specific proposals for a legislative program designed to aid the carriers.

Major Gen. Sir Murray Irwin, prominent in the development of the army medical service, died today at Bideford, Devon, at the age of 80. He had held high appointments at the War Office and inaugurated the system of incorporating medical units in troop manoeuvres.

Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, praised the work of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York yesterday in helping to eliminate tuberculosis and venereal disease among women and girls.
The Japanese Government announced today the extension of the zone of hostilities to the westernmost provinces of China proper.

Today's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Roland Hayes, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Barbara Stoll, soprano, Midtown Music Hall, 8:30; Gunnar Johansen, pianist, Columbia University, evening;
The Duke and Duchess of Gloucester may meet the Duke and Duchess of Windsor Friday in Paris as a first step toward reconciliation between the British royal family and the abdicated King.

The Brooklyn College football team rehearsed new plays yesterday for the Armistice Day meeting with Ithaca College. The Kingsmen came through last Saturday's game with Panzer in Good shape, and Coach Lou Oshins hopes to have his squad almost at full strength by Friday.
The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Oct. 31 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation rose to 125.29 from 122.11 per cent on Oct. 15.
Dr. Thomas Mann has completed a short paper examining the background and results of the recent European crisis and giving his interpretation of the events.
Twenty-seven Liberals, eleven Conservative Nationalists and seven Conservative Deputies were elected Sunday to the Constituent Assembly to meet next month to redraft the Constitution.
Israel Amter, candidate for Representative at Large, closed his campaign last night with a denunciation of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and the Republican State organization.

Surprisingly modest predictions of victory came from both major parties today as candidates made final bids for votes on California's long ballot tomorrow. In the intense campaign the Democrats have made a determined fight to capture the governorship, which they have not held for forty years, and the Republicans have fought to regain the Senate seat held by the rival party.
Bishop John Duffy late today ordered all "bingo games and analogous games of chance" closed in the Buffalo Catholic diocese, which includes about 220 Western New York churches.
Joey Fontana, 133 1/4, East Side, gained the decision over Paul Lee, 127, Indianapolis, after eight rounds of fast boxing at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before 2,000.
A "death leap" by a man who invited relatives and police to watch him jump from a two-story village hall had a cheerful ending today because a patrolman was a good "catcher."

William Wray Williamson died here yesterday at his home after an illness of ten years. He was 84 years old. Born in Ireland, Mr. Williamson came to the United States at the age of 17 and later entered the employ of W. J. Sloane Co. He remained with that firm for forty-seven years, retiring as chief accountant twelve years ago.

Miss Sue Victorius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Victorius of 441 West End Avenue, was married to William Haas Bransten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bransten of San Francisco, last evening in the Gold Room of Sherry's by the Rev. Dr. William Rosenblum.

Two men accused of hijacking $13,000 from a man who had just carried out a fantastic scheme with the cashier of a Brooklyn bank whereby they stole $25,000 from the bank's vault were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of kidnapping and assault and robbery.

As soon as "Where Do We Go From Here?" of which he is co-producer, is launched a week from tonight, Oscar Hammerstein (he has dropped the "2nd" after his name) will be concentrating on "Glorious Morning," the Norman Macowan play now in the sixth month of its London run.
A speech by Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop tonight indicated that further German negotiations with the Western democracies for a general settlement would probably be carried on.
The long-awaited plan for disc solving the Chesapeake Corporation, the link through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and other lines, was announced here yesterday.

Introduced by John Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, 'Walter Johnson, former pitcher for the Washington Senators, tonight gave his views on national election issues on a radio program sponsored by the committee.

Expressing the fear that the Pennsylvania Railroad might 'sabotage" the Lehigh Valley Railroad by a series of employee lay-offs, officials of the Lehigh Valley Railroad division of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, Steamship Clerks, Freight Handlers and Express and Station Employes announced here today that a telegram of protest has been sent to George M. Harrison, grand president of the union and chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Board.

Arthur Gibson Morse, vice president of the Morse Magneto Watchman's Clock Company, 17 East Forty-second -Street, and for twenty years a volunteer field speaker for the National Security League, died on Sunday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Maude Townend, at Arlington, N. J. Mr. Morse, who lived at 151 East Eightieth Street, was 83 years old.

A hearing on an application by the Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company for exemption from requirement under the Holding Company Act for filing a declaration in connection with the issuance and sale of $4,000,000 of mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series D, 3 1/2 per cent, due on Dec. 1, 1968, was ordered today be the Securities and Exchange Commission to be held here on Nov. 23.

Scholarships totaling $18,800 have been awarded at Harvard College to fifty-seven high-standing upperclassmen, comprising thirty-two from New York, eight from New Jersey and seventeen from Connecticut. The recipients are:

Gasoline-operated motion picture projection units manufactured in the United States will soon supply a new type of education for 200 Polish communities, as the result of a business transaction concluded in Warsaw and made public here today by the Department of Commerce.

"Professor Mamlock," which was shown last evening at the Cameo, says nothing new about Nazi persecution of the Jews in Germany; but that it says anything at all should be news to the American filmgoer.

The National Gypsum Company of Buffalo, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 60,000 shares of no par value $4.50 convertible cumulative preferred stock and an as yet unannounced number of shares of $1 par value common stock.

Great Britain was reported in well-informed quarters tonight to have instituted a special destroyer and submarine patrol in the North Sea to prevent "incidents" in her own territorial waters following recent activities of Spanish Insurgent armed vessels.

Arthur H. Kopp, a chemist employed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, was burned fatally at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when an experiment he was carrying on in the basement laboratory of the museum, aimed to end deterioration of its bronzes, ended in an explosion.

Mayor La Guardia ordered the Police Department yesterday to use all its resources to prevent illegal voting in the city today. In a 35-minute talk to department commanding officers at police headquarters during the morning, the Mayor told them in no uncertain terms that he expected an orderly and hones election.

Transfer of a factory from Stamford, Conn., to New York was made known yesterday with the announcement that the Keller Dorian Paper Company, Inc., manufacturers of foil papers, has taken an entire floor consisting of about 20,000 square feet in the building at 516-22 West Thirty-fourth Street. The rental was arranged by Henry B. Eppstein and The Cross Brown Company.

The Cabinet this morning approved a decree levying on the capital of all industrial and commercial enterprises owned by private individuals and by companies other than joint stock. [The rate of the levy was not announced, but The Associated Press quotes the newspaper Tribuna as saying it will be 7.5 per cent.]

Robert Lange, German Consul in Hawaii, said today he would ask Governor Joseph Poindexter to. eliminate a "sock Hitler" game proposed as part of the entertainment at the St. Catherine's Catholic Church Fair, Nov. 19 and 20.

Dan W. Quinn, old-time popular song writer, vaudeville tenor and associate of Thomas A. Edison in the recording of early phonograph records, died- yesterday at his home, 312 West Twentieth Street. His age was 78. Since 1910 he had been in the vaudeville booking business.
Mixed weather for voters is expected throughout the State today, according to a forecast prepared by the Weather Bureau last night.

Joseph R. Sheehan, president of the newly named American President Lines, formerly the Dollar Line, announced yesterday at the head offices in San Francisco the names of the newly appointed officials. All were in the old Dollar Line Company.

A committee of retailers will confer with Secretary of Agriculture Wallace on the "two-price" plan on Thursday in Washington, it was stated here yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail. Dry Goods Association.

Instead of the seven capital sins by which unfair and unsatisfactory employers can be recognized, Miss Bess Bloodworth, vice president of Namm's stores in Brooklyn, last night submitted the seven capital virtues by which the best may be gauged.

Edward Florio, a dock foreman, of 317 Washington Street, and Joseph McDonald of 161 Sixth Street, both of Hoboken, N. J., were exonerated by Police Recorder Frank Romano in Hoboken today of a charge of assault and battery made by Herman Matson, Hoboken chairman of the Workers Defense League of New Jersey.
Minnesota's three-cornered Governorship race, enlivened by claims of New
The Polish Government tightened exchange restrictions today by compelling all citizens to declare their holdings abroad, including real estate.

Eleventh hour predictions of Democratic victories in a number of States where New Deal prestige is involved rolled into the temporary White House offices today as President Roosevelt confidently awaited the outcome of tomorrow's balloting throughout the nation.

Work will be started within two weeks on the Shore Parkway section of the Circumferential Parkway, the new thirty-five-mile artery around the southern border of Brooklyn, the Department of Parks announced yesterday as bids were taken on the first three of 200 contracts to be let for the project.

FAIRBANKS, VERA (Nov. 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To William O. Fairbanks, nephew, Saxonville, Mass., $8,000 and residue; Constance F. Piers, sister, 152 Shirley St., Halifax, Nova Scotia; Frances O. MacGregor, niece, Sackville, N. B., Canada;

Robert Gammon, 27 years old, a United States Navy radio operator, was sentenced here today by County Judge Hill to from twenty years to life in Sing Sing on conviction of second degree murder by a jury in the fatal shooting on March 19 of his fellow operator,

Postmaster General James A. Farley, National and State Democratic Chairman, received yesterday a letter from Representative Bruce Barton, Republican, soliciting his vote in the Seventeenth Congressional District. Mr. Farley is a resident of the district.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES looks with disfavor upon compulsory health insurance in view of England's experience, yet criticizes cash-indemnity insurance, proposed by the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, as "impractical," and states that the policy as laid down there "holds out no present promise of true cooperation."

Four youths were arrested early yesterday morning after policemen had surrounded the block bounded by First and Second Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. The prisoners were charged with burglary.

A continued decrease in the number of accidents and fatalities in traffic accidents was shown yesterday for the last week and week-end as compared to tables for the corresponding periods of last year. The table for the week compiled by the safety bureau of the Police Department was as follows:

Wintry weather, with snow and icy highways, brought a new factor today into the Kansas election picture. The weather is likely to affect tomorrow's returns, which will be scanned for a possible farm State expression on the Federal agricultural program.
The breaking up of the old Cunard liner Berengaria will provide work for 200 men for two years in one of Great Britain's worst depressed areas, according to an announcement tonight.

Michigan's Democratic Governor, Frank Murphy, and his Republican rival, Frank D. Fitzgerald, shattered political precedent tonight by campaigning far into the eve of the most bitterly contested State election in many years.
Complaints against employers for violating the minimum wage and maximum hour requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act will be held confidential, the Wages and Hours Administration said today.

The final horse racing event of the year in New York, the annual United Hunts meeting at Belmont Park, will be held today. Six events, all well filled, are on the program, with the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, a two-and-a-half-mile test for 4-year-olds and upward, listed as the feature.
Preston Struges, author of "Strictly Dishonorable" and other stage productions, married here tonight Mrs. Louise Sargent Tevis of Reno.

Sterling Products, Inc., and subsidiaries, pharmaceutical and drug enterprises, showed a net profit for the first nine months of 1938 of $6,752,440 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The Rutgers regulars looked impressive today in an hour workout against Lafayette formations, but Coach Harvey Harman used most of the time to drill the second and third stringers. There was no contact work. There was no contact work.

A loan exhibition containing six paintings by the late fifteenth and early sixteenth century Florentine, Piero di Cosimo, will open today at the Schaeffer Galleries, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, to continue until Dec. 6.

George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor and chairman of the Labor Non-Partisan Committee, made an appeal last night to voters to support Charles Poletti, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor.
A forecast of rain and probable snow

Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for Kings County Judge, declared last night that citizens must "clean house" in the courts to eliminate conditions requiring investigations. He spoke over radio station WOR.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a producer of cotton who paid taxes imposed on ginners by the Bank-head Production Control Law might sue to recover the money. It reversed a decision by the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals that because the tax was imposed on ginners the producers could not bring recovery litigation.

Irate residents of South Yonkers will march soon with axes to the Saw Mill River Parkway and chop down a wooden barrier at the McLean Avenue intersection unless the Westchester County Park Commission orders it removed, Supervisor Francis P. Crotty of Yonkers declared this afternoon at a meeting of the County Board of Supervisors. Mr. Crotty said he would be among the axe-wielders.

The South African Minister of Defense, Oswald Pirow, had a conference with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today which was officially described as concerning South Africa's [pound]6,000,000 rearmament scheme.

Natural differences inherited by birth should be accepted as a challenge to cultivate the habit of appreciating them so as to solve problems that grow out of them, Rabbi Samuel Goldenson of Temple Emanu-El declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting of Protestant Episcopal clergymen of the Diocese of New York and Long Island.

Brokerage commissions paid for the purchase of securities cannot be deducted from income taxes as Necessary business expenses, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in an opinion by Justice Black.

Pravda, organ of the Communist party, published today what it described as as a message from Earl Browder, leader of the Communist party in the United States, congratulating the Russian people on the progress made "under the glorious leadership of Stalin."

The Cabinet met this morning under the chairmanship of Premier Mussolini and approved a decree, conforming with the decision of the Fascist Grand Council, declaring that Jews are ineligible for membership in the Fascist party.

A 22 year-old youth, quoted as saying he had "determined" to kill his schoolgirl sweetheart "if he could not have her," today was charged with first-degree murder in connection with the shotgun slaying of Laura Hazzard, 14.

Geoffrey D. M. Haggard, the new British Consul General, who arrived in this country on Sunday, will be welcomed by the British Empire Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon in the Biltmore Nov. 15 at 12:45 P. M.
In today's State election the American Labor party holds the balance of power, Langdon W. Post, its candidate for Controller, said last night in a radio speech closing the party's State campaign.

The National Administration has said no attention to the problem of work for young people between the ages of 16 and 25 who have not been able to get jobs, John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for the long-term United States Senatorship, declared in his final radio appeal over Station WOR last night.

The theme of world revolution, which has been subordinated in recent years to the theme of building socialism in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, came to the fore again in today's celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of the Bolshevist seizure of power.
Whether the stock market was reflecting election guesses or hopes yesterday, or whether the favorable tenor of the news was sufficient to generate new buying, can only be conjectured.

Ray Miller of Newark, 169, New Jersey's light-heavyweight champion, decisively outpointed Lou Brouillard, 160, of Worcester, Mass., former world welterweight and middleweight titleholder, to take a referee's decision in the feature ten-round boxing bout at Laurel Garden tonight.
Levis Miller Booth, president of the Booth Chemical Company of Elizabeth, N. J., died yesterday at his home here of a heart attack. His age was 60.
A plan to double Great Britain's first-line air strength, giving her 5,000 planes by March, 1940, was reported discussed today by the Cabinet on the eve of the new session of Parliament.
The Civil Service Commission said today that 870,031 persons were employed in the Federal Government's executive branch during September, or 2,490 less than during the previous month.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. Some phases of portraiture (general tour 11 A. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

With both claiming victory after a furious Governorship campaign, Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, and James M. Curley, Democrat, crossed swords tonight in the vote-heavy areas of Greater Boston, where tomorrow's election may be decided.
Federal Judge William Clark signed an order here today permanently enjoining Mayor Frank Hague and other officials of Jersey City from prohibiting meetings of the C. I. O.

The Board of Tax Appeals was asked today to review the government's claim that Benjamin E. Hazelton of Los Angeles received $68,750 from the estate of Ella V. Wendel, wealthy New York spinster who died in 1931.

Active buying of men's wear wool goods, both for spot and later delivery, developed in the market here yesterday, stimulated in part by the prediction of Moses Pendleton, president of American Woolen Company, that prices will be advanced 20 cents a yard from present levels.

White Plains Rd. 2,059-4,061, 32.5x100; East River Savings Bank against Martsam Holding Corp; due, $38,221; taxes, etc, $416; to plaintiff for $1,000. Grant Ave, 1,063; 2-story dwelling, 32x100; HOLC against Anna Abramowitz; due, $15,248; to plaintiff for $500.

Seeking to avenge his "fellow-Jewish sufferers from Nazi persecution and oppression," 17-year-old Herschel Grynszpan, a German-born Polish emigre of Jewish extraction, today shot and seriously wounded Ernst vom Rath, third secretary of the German Embassy.

Jascha Heifetz, violinist, played one of the strangest concerts of his career today when he sat alone for two hours in a tiny cubicle, faintly resembling a padded cell, and demonstrated his artistry on the violin in the interest of science.

Walter Sherman Moody, retired transformer designing engineer of the General Electric Company, died today following a long illness at his home here. He was 74 years old and had been with the company continuously for forty-three years when he retired seven years ago.

White Plains Rd. 2,059-4,061, 32.5x100; East River Savings Bank against Martsam Holding Corp; due, $38,221; taxes, etc, $416; to plaintiff for $1,000. Grant Ave, 1,063; 2-story dwelling, 32x100; HOLC against Anna Abramowitz; due, $15,248; to plaintiff for $500.

Seeking to avenge his "fellow-Jewish sufferers from Nazi persecution and oppression," 17-year-old Herschel Grynszpan, a German-born Polish emigre of Jewish extraction, today shot and seriously wounded Ernst vom Rath, third secretary of the German Embassy.

Jascha Heifetz, violinist, played one of the strangest concerts of his career today when he sat alone for two hours in a tiny cubicle, faintly resembling a padded cell, and demonstrated his artistry on the violin in the interest of science.

Walter Sherman Moody, retired transformer designing engineer of the General Electric Company, died today following a long illness at his home here. He was 74 years old and had been with the company continuously for forty-three years when he retired seven years ago.

A special Federal grand jury was impanelled yesterday before Judge Henry W. Goddard and immediately began an inquiry into the alleged smuggling into this port Oct. 7 of Parisian finery that was later seized by customs agents in the apartment occupied by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer and his wife at 570 Park Avenue.

Chairman Sheppard said today that investigators for the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee had found no evidence to substantiate charges that WPA employes were being coerced for political purposes in Ohio, but that the investigation was incomplete.
Corinne Edith Gramm Heffernan, wife of John V. Heffernan, retired publisher, died in Wyoming Valley Homeopathic Hospital here yesterday from a heart attack. Her age was 43.
Seven prizes, totaling $650, for poems appearing in the last year in the magazine Poetry are announced in the November issue. The winners, the names of the prizes and the amounts follow:
A murder and a suicide resulted from a quarrel over a bottle of soda here this afternoon.
Sales of the smaller retail druggists in the Chicago area have taken a turn for the better in the last few weeks, according to reports in trade circles.
Holding a light practice today after its initial Little Three contest with Wesleyan last Saturday, Williams began pointing for the traditional game at Amherst next Saturday.

Saturday's football cyclone not only smashed football reputations left and right but it sheared The Associated Press list of unbeaten and untied football teams from thirty to twenty-two, with Pittsburgh, smashed by Carnegie Tech, the most noted victim.
Plans for the proposed broadcast under retailer auspices of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra have been dropped, it was stated yesterday by officials of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The coming of age of Russia's Soviet Government was honored today by President Roosevelt with a goodwill message to President Mikhail Kalinin, and by a reception given at the Soviet Embassy here "in celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of the great October Socialist revolution."

Credit men in the women's garment and allied fields will watch the Nov. 10 payments by retailers on purchases of ready-to-wear because of the long spell of warm weather in many areas, which has retarded the normal development of the Fall season by some three weeks, they said here yesterday.

Governor Lehman closed his campaign for re-election last night with a State-wide broadcast in which he rested his case on his record as Governor for the last six years and with 'two brief appearances at neighborhood rallies in Westchester County, where he has his Summer home.

Stockholders of Eno Proprietaries, Ltd., have ratified a merger of the concern with Beecham's Pills, Ltd., and Maclean's, Ltd., it was made known yesterday. Beecham, a world-wide manufacturer and distributor, bought Maclean's, a manufacturing chemists' organization, in August.

Prospects for a resumption of the financing of Broadway plays by motion picture companies were improved yesterday when Robert E. Sherwood, president of the Dramatists Guild, urged that the Guild make "every conceivable effort to find ways and means of reaching an agreement" with the film producers. He spoke at the Guild's annual meeting in the Hotel Lincoln.
Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann heads the committee In charge of the plans for the annual card party for the benefit of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service,

To an audience of nearly 10,000 persons, mostly Italian-Americans, who thronged the streets at his "lucky corner" in East Harlem, Mayor La Guardia hurled last night a challenge for them to compare the freedom of the United States with the dictator-ridden nations of Europe and to be glad they are citizens of this country.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously upheld yesterday an order signed recently by Federal Judge Clancy restraining the Associated Gas and Electric Company from extending the maturity date of outstanding 5 1/2-percent convertible investment certificates from next Nov. 15 without the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Labor violence which beset Oregon for three years and aroused prosecutions which sent more than forty men to imprisonment formed a backdrop for tomorrow's Oregon election.
Arthur O. Cooper, Eugene L. Dunne, T. Burton Tilden and Willson G. Todd have been admitted as partners in Hoyne, Mellinger Co., members of the New York and Chicago Stock Exchanges.

In an Armistice Day proclamation, Governor Lehman today called upon citizens to become "more deeply conscious of the sacrifices the people of all nations have been forced to make in the struggle for peace."
OUR AMERICAN TROPICS, by John E. Jennings Jr. (Crowell, $2.50.) A guide to Key West. THE SCIENTIST IN ACTION, by William H. George. (Emerson, $3.) A scientific study of his methods.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Glendale Hospital, Palatka, Fla., of Dr. Alfred J. M. Lasche, until recently chief chemist and zymotechnologist for the Schenley Distillers Corporation. He was in his late Seventies.
Goals by the Misses Evelyn Horn, Carolyn Chalfant and Henrietta Rasweiler gave Hofstra College a 4-1 field hockey victory over Adelphi College today on Hofstra Field.
A committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. William C. Dickerman, with Mrs. A. Taylor Jones as vice chairman, is being assisted by a group of younger women of society, headed by Miss Ruth Boyd,
10th St, 43-47 E, 6-story loft, 69.10x94.9; Thomas G. Greene against Wm. C. Tobey: due, $141,985; taxes, etc, $8,830; to plaintiff for $65,000.
The international stock market indices for Nov. 5, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

A dance will be given under the auspices of the Youth Guild for Infant Welfare, an affiliate of the Godmothers' League, on Sunday evening at the Peter: Stuyvesant. Proceeds of the benefit will be devoted to the maintenance of the league shelter at 115 East 101st Street,

A full moon rose from the east at 4:43 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the form of a tiny crescent of orange, with its remainder hidden behind a transparent copper-colored veil that soon spread to cover the entire face of the moon, providing New Yorkers and other inhabitants of the United States with the spectacle of a total eclipse of the moon.

The monsoon and blinding tropical rains so delayed the three British Royal Air Force bombing planes that the two that remained up were unable to go beyond Darwin. However, they broke all previous distance-flight records by a wide margin in a flight of 7,162 miles.

Urging the passage of Constitutional Amendments 1, 4. 6 and 8, Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for Governor, closed his campaign last night with speeches in which he reviewed his campaign and charged again that the issues had not been met by his Democratic opponent, Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

Pennant, one of the great sires of modern thoroughbred history, died yesterday at the farm of his owner, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, near Lexington. The 27-year-old chestnut horse, one of the oldest thoroughbred stallions alive, had failed rapidly recently because of his advanced age.

Two men named last week by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as members of a gang responsible for three kidnappings and several robberies in New York and Westchester, were indicted by a Westchester County grand jury today on charges of having kidnapped Arthur Fried, manager of the Bronx plant of the Colonial Sand and Gravel Company, last Dec. 4.

Justice Black, whose long dissents were a feature of the last term of the Supreme Court, disagreed with his colleagues three times today and in one of the cases inferentially criticized the seven other justices for not dismissing what he construed as a needless attack on the rights of State legislators.
The 1938 campaign in New York State came to an end last night, with the rival party leaders standing pat on their respective claims of victory, and with the result hinging on three factors.

The charge that some Democratic clubs in the city are circulating last-minute literature urging favorable vote on Amendment 7, which would outlaw the use of proportional representation, was made yesterday by Charles C. Burlingham as chairman of the State Committee for Home Rule or Proportional Representation.

A city-wide campaign has been started by the Department of Licenses to enforce regulations concerning children in motion-picture theatres, it was disclosed yesterday by Commissioner Paul Moss. Five Harlem theatres have had their licenses suspended temporarily and the owners of five others have been ordered to appear before the Commissioner today.
Challengers made many bids over the week-end for supremacy among the nation's leading football scorers, but most of the front-runners succeeded in holding their places.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Anna Charlotte Strom, daughter of Mrs. Carl A. Strom of this place and the late Mr. Strom, to George Austin Mooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Mooney, also of Floral Park.

The Very Rev. Terence S. McDermott, Provincial of the Eastern Province of the Order of Preachers (Dominican Fathers), has received a special dispensation from the Vatican to continue in that office for a third term of four years, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the province, 869 Lexington Avenue.

The Very Rev. Terence S. McDermott, Provincial of the Eastern Province of the Order of Preachers (Dominican Fathers), has received a special dispensation from the Vatican to continue in that office for a third term of four years, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the province, 869 Lexington Avenue.

The engagement of $5,900,000 gold in England for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It was believed that the metal was bought on some previous date.

Eighty of the nation's best professional golfers fired last practice blasts today at the old white course over which they open the Winter golf trail tomorrow in the first annual $3,000 White Sulphur open.

The liveliest down-stretch run in many years marked Wisconsin's campaign, with the La Follette State Administration and Senator F. Ryan Duffy's allegiance to the New Deal the principal issues in tomorrow's balloting.

Thomson McKinnon, 11 Wall street, will remain open today for Winnipeg and other foreign business. ??. S. Bache Co. will keep their office in the Chrysler Building open to accept orders for transmission to their London office and to supply
The five-story apartment house at 50-60 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by Joseph Chinich, operator, from a client of Charles H. Bellows, attorney.

Investors and operators predominated as principals in the transactions involving Manhattan realty announced yesterday. Samuel Reznick, operator, sold to the Franchise Holding Corporation the six-story elevator apartment at 119-25 Audubon Avenue, through Alfred C. Marks, broker.

During the model year ending on Sept. 30 the automobile industry produced a total of 2,704,992 motor vehicles, Alfred Reeves, vice president and general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, announced yesterday.

The voters, who willingly exposed themselves to a deluge of words during the last four weeks of the campaign, risked a real drenching from the skies to get the election results in Times Square last night.

James M. Mead of Buffalo, Democratic nominee to fill out the unexpired term of the late United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, is a former railroad workman who rose to the presidency of the switchmen's union before he entered politics.

Social events in connection with the National Horse Show reached their peak last night with the annual Horse Show ball, held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria following the performance in Madison Square Garden.

Barnet Shirner, 22 years old, of 135 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, fell between two cars of a southbound I. R. T. White Plains train entering the Allerton Avenue station, in the Bronx, shortly after 11 o'clock last night.

Two patients at the Rockland State Hospital are dead and three others are in a serious condition as a result of having received a wrong drug at a clinic treatment late yesterday, authorities revealed here today.

Severe earthquake damage, greater than yet reported in direct news cables and radiograms, is strongly indicated in a flood of data on Japan's most recent earthquakes that has been pouring into the offices of Science Service here. .

State Senator Edward J. Coughlin of Brooklyn who said several days ago that he would go to the polls yesterday if he had to be taken in a wheel chair did not have to have recourse to that sort of a vehicle. The Senator,

Dollar sales of 220 wine and liquor wholesalers, establishments which accounted for 23 per cent of the sales for all houses specializing in this business during 1935, the latest year covered by a regular business census,

Democrats apparently made a sweep of their State ticket today on the basis of returns from 5,057 of the 8,315 precincts in Illinois. Representative Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, had 987,079 votes to 831,764 for Richard Lyons, Republican, in the race for United States Senator. This was the great contest of the day.
The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday that the average weekly earnings of workers on Class I railroads were 2.2 per cent higher in July, 1938, than in the boom year of 1929.

The major part of the advertising program for Fiberglas, the product of the recently-formed Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, will be concentrated upon industrial fields, using trade papers in those markets where the product already is in use, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Solomon Goldman, president of the Zionist Organization of America, and Louis Lipsky, American member of the World Zionist Executive Committee, sailed on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday for London, where they will discuss Palestine affairs with Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.
Chairman Dies of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, told the National Women's Press Club today that he would move out of the country if Fascists or Communists obtained control.

Many reservations have been received for the card party for the benefit of the Mary Fisher Home in Tenafly, N. J., tomorrow afternoon at Hampshire House. Mrs. David E. Lurch is chairman, and Miss Jane Ogden co-chairman of the benefit committee. Proceeds will be added to the maintenance fund of the home.

After a day of heavy but quiet voting, W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for United States Senator and a former resident of Passaic County, appeared early this morning to have won a majority of its vote from William H. J. Ely.

The War Department announced today that Federal recognition had been given to the following National Guard officers, and that they now were commissioned officers of the National Guard of the United States:

A bust of Thomas G. Masaryk in a Prague University building was damaged today by university students, evidently representing the "new era" of Czechoslovakia. A university professor had lectured on the first President of the country as a philosopher.
Elnathan Meade, Civil War veteran and former custodian of the President's gallery in the House of Representatives in Washington, D. C., died here last night of heart disease.

Responsibility for enforcement of fair-trade contracts in the liquor field in the metropolitan area was thrown back to distillers yesterday, after several months of policing by a joint liquor council.

" We are very grateful if there are statesmen in France and Great Britain who wish to live in good understanding with the German people," declared Chancellor Hitler tonight in a speech on the fifteenth anniversary of the Nazi beer-cellar Putsch.
Prices of wheat advanced moderately today in the principal foreign markets. The Board of Trade here and other markets in this country were closed for election day.

Virtual certainty of parallel diplomatic protests by the United States, France and Britain against Japan's intention to close the Yangtze River to neutral shipping in China was expressed here tonight.

Robert F. Wagner, New York's Democratic Senator, who was renominated to succeed himself, is a loyal member of Tammany Hall, who at the same time has been one of President Roosevelt's stanchest supporters on liberal legislation, especially relief and unemployment measures.
The Dartmouth football coaches used the floodlights for the first time this season tonight as the varsity worked hard in preparation for Cornell.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Van Schaick Mitchell will give a dance Friday night at Pennbrook House, their place in Far Hills, N. J., for their debutante daughter, Miss Sylvia Mitchell, and for Miss Nancy Abbott, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Abbott.

A brisk one-hour scrimmage featured New York University's football workout yesterday morning as Coach Mal Stevens drilled his players in a heavy three-hour session at Ohio Field. Fundamentals, timing and passing were the order of the day as the Violet continued preparations for the meeting with Colgate at the Yankee Stadium on Friday afternoon.
Two rival again Chinese-Japanese factions jockeyed for position today to form the supreme central government of Japanese-conquered parts of China.

In almost unprecedented numbers for an off year and with a minimum of disorder and arrests, the voters of New York City flocked to the polls yesterday undeterred by intermittent showers and unseasonably warm weather which made many of the polling places steamy and uncomfortable.
The newly formed organization of all sections of the German minority in Rumania met Sunday in Temesvar with an attendance of 10,000. The leader of the Germans in this country, Fritz Fabritius,

Inscoelda, stout-hearted filly from the Woolford Farm of Herbert M. Woolf, today turned in one of her games exhibitions to beat the favored Volitant in the thirty-second Walden, a mile and a sixteenth fixture at Pimlico that attracted nine high-ranking juveniles.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today George J. Engleman and Justin N. Reinhardt of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Forty-one propositions concerning changes in name, paying police and firemen's pensions and increasing their salaries, legalizing Sunday movies and liquor sales, putting municipal employes under civil service protection and other subjects were voted upon in local referenda by residents of Passaic, Bergen, Hudson, Essex and Union Counties in Northern New Jersey yesterday.
Aside from finding two liquor-vending establishments open yesterday duping the prohibited hours, Mayor La Guardia reported at the end of the day that the election had been conducted quietly.

Thomas E. Dewey carried Rockland County by 4,984. With the county returns complete Mr. Dewey received 16,652 votes to 11,668 votes for Governor Herbert H. Lehman. All members of the State Republican ticket carried Rockland County.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 8, unless specified; Concord, at Savannah. Henderson, San Diego to San Pedro. Kewaydin, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Nov. 7.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 7: COLONEL Lee, R. E., F.A., London, England, to 5th F. A., Madison Barracks, N. Y., about April 7.

The Brooklyn College football team had a light workout yesterday in preparation for Friday's game with Ithaca College. The Kingsmen went through about an hour and a half of signal drill on new plays, with Milt Silverstein, speedy freshman tailback, running the ball.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts for commercial space was the Frank G. Shattuck Company, which leased the quarters west of the East Fifty-eighth Street entrance of its Schrafft's restaurant at 625 Madison Avenue for use as a new bar and cocktail lounge.

When the King and Queen of England visit us in the Spring they will be warmly welcomed for their own sake as well as for the friendship between the two English-speaking nations which their visit signifies.

The third symposium in the Duke University centennial series for this year, entitled "Law in Modern Society," announced today for Dec. 2-3, will assemble as speakers jurists, political scientists and writers on legal and social problems.

Good Counsel High School's eleven continued victorious today, recording a 13-to-6 victory over St. Mary's of Perth Amboy in rain and mud. The Newark school boys tallied in the first period, driving from the visitors' 45 to the half-yard mark, where Frank Dempsey crashed off right tackle for a touchdown.

The Republican party swept Suffolk County by greater pluralities than ever before today. District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York received 49,948 votes in the 162 election districts of the county, to 24,959 for Governor Lehman, a plurality of 24,989.
A long afternoon session for Columbia yesterday found all hands, or almost all hands, drilling hard at scrimmage and at dummy work, with some outsiders imported to help.

Texas Christian, rated the best-balanced football power the Southwest Conference has ever produced, has ousted Pittsburgh from its three-week hold on the No. 1 position in the weekly Associated Press gridiron ranking poll.

Corporation Counsels Edward J. O'Mara and Charles Hershenstein of Jersey City will go to Philadelphia tomorrow to seek from the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals a stay of Federal Judge William Clark's injunction, which restrains Jersey City officials from prohibiting meetings in the city of the C. I. 0. and the American Civil Liberties Union.

The problem of how to keep unit costs down will be studied by representatives of twelve industries, each with differing production situations, at a symposium which will be a feature of a conference for production executives to be held by the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania today and tomorrow.

The four-story residence, 20 by 100.5 feet, at 207 East Sixty-first Street, has been leased, furnished, by H. Fairfield Osborn Jr., to Mme. Frances Alda, operatic soprano. Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., was the broker.
Anthony Schreiber, president of the Schreiber Brewing Company, died today at his home in East Aurora after an illness of several months. He was 74 years old.
Publication of official correspondence disclosed today that Paul V. McNutt is contemplating leaving the post of Philippine High Commissioner within two months.

The Rutgers varsity in a dummy scrimmage today studied the passing attack it expects Lafayette to use here next Saturday. A mixed team composed of freshmen, alumni and coaches demonstrated the Leopard aerial attack, with freshman Coach Art Matsu doing the passing most of the time.
Roland Hayes, eminent Negro tenor, who gave his first New York recital of the season at the Town Hall last night, is still an expert stylist. He models a phrase with the loving care of a Cellini.
It is pleasant to learn that the labor troubles which struck the Big Top last June have been settled and that, like the robin, the circus will return next Spring "bigger and better than ever."

Never has a Fordham football squad been plagued with injuries like the 1938 Rams. It developed on Fordham Field yesterday morning, as the Maroon went through a two-hour workout, that Jim Hayes, the senior who has been outstanding at right guard, was suffering from a broken metacarpal bone in his right hand and might not be able to face North Carolina's Tar Heels at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Ned Arden Flood, industrial banker and lawyer who had taken part in many large corporation sales and reorganizations in the last twenty years, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 970 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

The State Civil Service Commission today postponed until Nov. 15 hearing of an appeal against the appointment of Edmund R. Outcalt of Trenton, as chief of the bureau of administration of the State Department of Health.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club gave a great demonstration of batting strength in its opening match in South Africa today. Starting a two-day game against the Western Province country districts, the Englishmen hit 589 runs for eight wickets.

Sing Sing's 2,780 prisoners received permission today to hear the election returns by radio until 10:30 o'clock tonight, although from their viewpoint there was little choice between Governor Lehman and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Miss Edith Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Henderson of Philadelphia, was married here today to the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr., vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, New York, in St. David's Protestant Episcopal Church.

DEATH BY MOONLIGHT, by Robert Henriques. (Morrow, $3.50.) Lion shooting in the Sudan. DITHERS AND JITTERS, by Cornelia Otis Skinner. (Dodd, Mead, $2.) More skits and sketches by the author of "Excuse It, Please."

Constance Talmadge, in 115 E 67th St: John S. Kelly, in 108 E 66th St; Alice Stetten, in 4 E 64th St; Annie E. Bowers, in 311 E 72d St: Alice G. Montgomery, Julian Muriel, Margaret Sullivan, Mrs. Gertrude Kemp, in the Buchanan, 160 E 48th St; Pease Elliman, Inc. broker.

Ralph L. Carr. Republican, was elected Governor of Colorado today over Teller Ammono, Democratic incumbent, by 40,000 to 50,000 votes, while Senator Alva B. Adams, Democrat, was re-elected over Archibald A. Lee, Republican, by about 40,000.

A tidal wave of anti-New Deal d anti-C. I. O. sentiment rolled up from the Ohio River territory and central farming districts to engulf this county's Democratic majority and sweep Republicans to victory in yesterday's State election.
