James A. Farley, National and State Democratic Chairman, at the Hotel Biltmore campaign headquarters, issued the following statement last night: "We have just completed one of the most hotly contested Gubernatorial campaigns ever waged in the State of New York. ...
A journalist-aviator, Maner Lualdi, and four companions took off from here at 12:18 A. M. today on a "good-will" flight to Tokyo, on which they hope to set a record.
An erudite Member of Parliament today viewed with alarm what may happen to the King's English now that the King of England is going to the United States.

The United States liner President Roosevelt will sail today for Cobh, Southampton, Havre and Hamburg. Passengers listed are Ernest Swift, William A. Smale, Carl Birkeland, J. P. Davies, Edward H. Ellis, Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Miller, A. Paul Martin, John E. McClung Jr., E. R. Pierce, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Deacon and Miss Elly Carstensen.

Herbert H. Lehman, who has been Governor of New York for the last six years and who under the pressure of his friends and political supporters ran for a fourth term, first came into the arena of politics in 1926 as the campaign manager for Governor Alfred E. Smith.
Miss Louise E. Lacey will sponsor a bridge party Friday at the Beekman Tower for the benefit of the library of the School for Industrial Art, 257 West Fortieth Street.

Former Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald, Republican, piled up a lead over Governor Frank Murphy, Democrat, which appeared to be commanding as returns continued to pour in from out-State Michigan in the election for Governor.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, T. H. Lawrence won the high-overall cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In Class A, N. E. Sprague was high man with a total of 99. W. W. Peabody took the cup in Class B with a 97.

Annual meeting, Academy of Political Science, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Afternoon session, 2:15 o'clock. Dinner at 7 P. M., at which speakers will be: Thomas I. Parkinson, Dr. Lewis W. Douglas, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney.
Erasmus Hall High School's football team remained unbeaten yesterday by vanquishing Manual Training, 26 to 0, in the thirty-first game of their series on rain-soaked Ebbets Field.

Both on land and sea engineers have been steadily increasing steam pressures and temperatures to achieve higher efficiencies. The maxima have been reached with the remarkable Benson boiler, which, in its original form, generated steam at the critical pressure of 3,200 pounds to the square inch at a temperature of 706 degrees Fahrenheit.

Charles Poletti, successful Democratic and American Labor party candidate for Lieutenant Governor, is one of the youngest men ever to be elected to that office in this State. His career in the public service dates only as far as 1930 and his rise to the second highest post in the State government at the age of 35 years is often referred to as a modern success story.
The nine-room house on a plot 150 by 175 feet at 12 Brook Lane, Scarsdale, Westchester County, has been purchased by A. W. Ericsson
Mrs. Caroline O'Day, the former Miss Caroline Love Goodwin of Savannah. Ga., is the widow of Daniel O'Day, son of one of the presidents of the Standard Oil Company.

J. Clinton White, Baltimore Ohio Railroad engineer who had been at the throttle for fifty years, died at Jefferson Hospital yesterday. He was 72 years old. A native of Elkton, Md., he was the oldest -employ in age and service on the Philadelphia division of the Baltimore Ohio. Mr. White had been the owner of several race horses which he bred himself.
A constitutional amendment to repeal Colorado's $45 old age pension law was beaten by a vote of more than two to one today.
The National Textile Processors Guild will hold its convention at the Penn Athletic Club, Philadelphia, on Dec. 7.
A Kwangtung Province official said today that Chinese held General Mok Hingoh responsible for the collapse of the Canton defenses. They said he would be executed before a firing squad soon.

Five youths were trapped in a stolen automobile when it overturned, pinning them in it, while they were trying to escape from a police car at Fifty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning, according to the police none was injured.

Since both political parties nominated for the Senate able and progressive men who believe that Government must move forward with the changing times, no fundamental issues of purpose and objective were raised during the Senatorial campaign.
At 1:30 o'clock this morning Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman gave her brief, official interview signalizing recognition that the election was over. She was happy about it and delighted that it was ended.

The St. John's University basketball schedule for the coming season, released yesterday, consists of twenty games, with eight of them listed for Madison Square Garden. Colleges from almost every section of the country will be met.
Commander Hugh Branham, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. Branham of Sunnybrook Farm here have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary-Gwyn Branham, to Charles Chester Atwater.

" Dulcy," the George S. KaufmanMarc Connelly play which Warners announced prematurely for Marie Wilson, will be made by Metro with Florence Rice. Miss Wilson will be featured in "Horses, Horses, Horses," by Albert Demond and Hugh Cummings; it is an original yarn about a waitress who wins on a sweepstakes ticket and buys a stable of horses.
The Foreign Ministry confirmed this afternoon the appointments of the members of Chile's delegation to the eighth Pan-American Conference, which will be held at Lima, Peru, next month.

The "bombing" of ocean waters two miles off Topanga Canyon Beach remained a mystery today. About fifteen objects, believed to have been dummy bombs, dropped from an airplane within 200 yards of two fishing boats yesterday and scared the anglers.
Dr. Damaso Theodore Laine, retired physician and surgeon, who founded the Anglo-American Hospital in Havana, died in his home in Bryn Mawr today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Cliff Lenz, the 200-pound plunging Navy back, greatly needed for the Columbia game, was ordered to bed in the Bancroft Hall sick bay today on account of -a charleyhorse which developed after the Notre Dame battle of last Saturday.
Wool was moving today somewhat more firmly than last week on the Boston market, but prices were strong, the. United States Department of Agriculture reported. Fine wools were the most active.
Indicating how smoothly the election was conducted here yesterday, the arrests for illegal registration and voting and disorders totaled only twenty-six at 4 P. M. Few arrests were for disorders.

The election of Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat,- as Governor of Maryland, over the Republican incumbent, Harry W. Nice, appeared assured late tonight. Returns from 505 of the State's 1.288 precincts put the vote at O'Conor 146,742, Nice 103.595.

Department stores sales here yesterday, hit by both unseasonably high temperatures and rain, were unofficially estimated at 10 per cent below the figure for election day of 1937, but were about double those of the Tuesday of this week last year.

Robert Lee Dean, former vice president of the Santa Cecelia Sugar Corporation of Cuba and an executive of railroad companies in Cuba and rubber-growing concerns in Mexico, died here yesterday at his home after an illness of four months. He was 69 years old.

The marriage of Miss Anne Cashman, daughter of Mrs. Michael J. Cashman of 790 Riverside Drive, to Richard A. Leyendecker, son of Mrs. Frank Leyendecker, also of New York, took place yesterday morning in Corpus Christi Catholic Church.

Coach Benny Friedman of City College concentrated on his team's forward-passing attack yesterday as he took advantage of the holiday to put his Beavers through a long drill in preparation for the closing game with Moravian College at the Lewisohn Stadium next Saturday.

A 20-year-old youth tentatively identified as Vincenzo Tonzello of 359 Greenwood Avenue, was shot dead tonight by a Negro, who then criminally assaulted and probably fatally wounded Miss Mary Myatovich, 16, of 27 Steamboat Street. The assailant escaped.
A black Australian swan for which the seasons are reversed hatched a brood of five cygnets in a snow bank here. Three baby swans broke out of their egg shells yesterday.

The Republican organization of Nassau County shattered all previous plurality records in today's election. Complete returns from all the county's 283 election districts showed District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey had led Governor Lehman by a plurality of 57,734.
Detective Francis Dunn of the Criminal Alien Squad shot himself with his service revolver early yesterday in his home at 601 West 168th Street and died later in Columbus Hospital.

Eva Kopilchak, 17 years old, a former asylum inmate, who confessed to police she killed her mother, Mrs. Christina Piatak, 47, with a sawed-off rifle in their home at 310 East Seventy-first Street, on Sunday, was held yesterday without bail for hearing in Homicide Court next Tuesday by Magistrate Abeles in Jefferson Market court on a charge of homicide.
The little town of Ithaca in Tompkins County up-State is in the throes of the greatest excitement it has experienced since way, way back, and it's not because of the election. .

Most branches of the realty market have been making a favorable showing for the Fall season, after a rather slow Spring and Summer. This trend is in line with the situation in nearly all branches of industry.

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among the guests were Mrs. David Rumsey, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. Frederick Mitchell Gould, and Mrs. John Adams Mayer.
Election day was a holiday for 175,000 WPA workers in this city, but officials announced that the employes would have to make up the time if they wished full pay.

The rear fifteen rows of seats in the balcony of the State Theatre at 2,852 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, were badly damaged and the ceiling of the theatre was scorched early today by fire believed to have been started by the dropping of a cigarette on the carpet.

Amid the magnificent pageantry of the state opening of Parliament, King George announced in his speech from the throne today that he had been "happy to accept" President Roosevelt's invitation to visit the United States with the Queen next Summer.

The broad court test of the administration's power policy, as represented by the TVA, is set for argument in the Supreme Court next Monday. But government tactics make it possible that decision of this important public question may never be made, that only through a change of political policy as a result of elections can Federal competition with private power enterprise be abolished.
Elza Conner, 72, marked his ballot and fell dead of a heart attack in a voting booth here today. A member of the victim's family handed the ballot to the voting board chairman and it was counted.

Rushing two touchdowns across in the opening quarter and adding another in the fourth, the De Witt Clinton High School football team overpowered its old rival, Stuyvesant High, 19 to 0, in the feature game of a schoolboy twin bill at the Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

A. C. Shire, technical director of the United States Housing Authority, will discuss construction problems in public housing tonight at 8:20 o'clock at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

THE British way of doing things has been subject to criticism in this country for quite a while now-exactly how great a while it is hard to say but somewhere in the neighborhood of 200 years. The most recent of the critics is one of the most bitter and sensational. He is William B. Ziff of Chicago, author of "The Rape of Palestine."

The bandit career of Robert Zlomke, 17 years old, of Grand Island, Neb., died aborning according to a story attributed to him yesterday in Felony Court, because his first prospective victim handed him a ook of religious verses in which the line "Jesus died for you" stood out in his mind.

Contracts amounting to $291,935 have been awarded to the Wood Hagan Company for construction of a roadway between the Harlem River Speedway and the George Washington Bridge approach tunnel, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

Mayor Frank Hague's local Democratic machine ran up a plurality of 83,336 for William H. J. Ely over W. Warren Barbour in yesterday's election and early this morning, final returns showed the Republican candidate for United States Senator had lost Hudson County by 130,581.
Carrying out his threatened shake-up plans, Head Coach George Munger made four changes in the Pennsylvania varsity line-up today.
A record crowd of more than 1,000 persons visited today in the Pratt Oval the Fall flower show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight.

Thomas E. Dewey won Governor Lehman's home district, the 30th Election District of the Fifteenth Assembly District, 435 to 258 votes. In the 1936 State election William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate, carried that district with 509 votes to the Governor's 250.

A banking syndicate headed by Alex. Brown Sons of Baltimore, the First Boston Corporation and B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $6,000,000 State of Maryland bridge revenue 3% per cent bonds, series A, due on Oct. 1, 1968. The bonds will be priced at 99 and accrued interest.
Bernie Friedkin, 1331/2, Brownsville, boxed cautiously as he turned in an eight-round triumph over Johnny Cabello, 132, Puerto Rico, in the main event at the Broadway Arena last night.

Louis Myers, a founder and acting treasurer of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League and former operator of motion-picture theatres, died yesterday at his home at 1,605 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. His age was 52.

Prince George of Russia, a great-grandson of Czar Nicholas I, died Monday morning in the Post-Graduate Hospital of pneumonia, which developed after an appendectomy at the end of August. He was 35 years old and had been a resident of this city since 1929.

The taxpayers of this community voted "no" today, to the question: "Shall the Town of Huntington on Dec. 31, 1938, discontinue sponsoring new WPA projects?" The vote was 2,061 to 1,552, with no returns from four of the twenty-six districts.

W. Warren Barbour, Republican nominee for the United States Senate in New Jersey, was elected by an indicated majority of more than 85,000 votes over his Democratic rival, William H. J. Ely, former State WPA Administrator, on the basis of later returns.
The complete Utica City vote for Governor gave: Lehman 20,503; Dewey 23,006. ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 8 (AP).-The complete Ithaca City vote gave: Dewey 4,282; Lehman, 2,710.

A net gain of at least six seats, and possibly one or two more, in the United States Senate, and addition to its House strength that might go above the fifty-mark were registered by the Republican party in the anti-New Deal swing that marked yesterday's national election.
Joseph C. Cornwall of Westfield, N. J., and Rollin D. Osgood of Birmingham, Ala., won the senior and junior class tennis tournaments, respectively, at Princeton University this week.
Thomas Sawyer Spivey, said-by his widow to have been the original Tom Sawyer immortalized by Mark Twain, died in a hospital last night. He was 82 years old.
The wealthy Milanese noble, Prince Luigi Alberico Trivulzio, was shot and killed tonight by a woman who said he was her lover and that he had abandoned her after fifteen years.

The continuing dispute between the Group Health Association of Washington and a group of private, practitioners and hospitals assumed a new phase today when potential contributors to the District of Columbia Community Chest were urged to affix stickers to their contribution pledges making them effective only when hospitals aided by the Chest ceased discriminating against the Health Association.

Now that the eve of the opening of the New Jersey upland game season is at hand, thousands of hunters are scattering to various points throughout the State in anticipation of one of the best seasons in many years.

The personnel of the committee of thirty-six men designated by the Independent Petroleum Association of America to make a broad study of the oil business was announced today by Charles Roeser, president of the association.
Senator Connally, Democrat, of Texas, said today that the United States should build the "biggest, most powerful ??y in the world" as insurance for peace.
The stock markets here had today a more cheerful tone as inquiries widened, although business still was at a low ebb. Gilt-edge issues fluctuated, but recovered early losses.

St. Michael's High School of this city closed its first season in football today with a record of five victories and one tie by defeating Memorial's eleven of West New York, 2-0, before a crowd of 2,000.

The Cleveland Rams, who will meet the New York Giants in a National Football League game at the Polo Grounds Sunday, will arrive in New York tonight and will work out at the Polo Grounds tomorrow morning. During their stay they will be quartered at the Hotel Lincoln.

Walter R. Darby, State Commissioner of Local Government, today declared he expects county prosecutors throughout New Jersey to present reports of expenditures over 1937 budgets by more than 180 municipalities, to grand juries, in accordance with the law.

A Buffalo labor leader who asked police to investigate two notes demanding $5,000 on threat of death ascribed the situation today to his recent receipt of money for risks incurred when a ship was torpedoed by a German submarine twenty-three years ago.
A memorial monument to the nurses of the United States Army and Navy was unveiled today with appropriate ceremonies in the National Cemetery at Arlington. tery at Arlington.

With earnings of department stores for the current half-year approaching the figure of a year ago, full-year 1938 net income should approximate that reported for the twelve months ended in mid-Summer, although still well short of full-year 1937 volume, according to the November issue, released yesterday, of the monthly analysis of leading industries issued by Fenner Beane, Stock Exchange firm.
Latin-American newspapers are greatly interested in Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles's radio speech on closer cooperation among the

Upon receiving definite news of his re-election at his campaign headquarters early this morning, Governor Herbert H. Lehman pledged the continuation of "humane, progressive, clean and business-like Government" for the next four years and expressed his "deep gratitude" to those who had supported him.
A Republican sweep of Essex County seemed assured this morning as unofficial returns from 420 out of the county's 576 election districts were compiled.

The close margin by which the issue has been decided does not obscure the fact that Herbert Lehman has achieved a feat which no other man in modern times has achieved before him. That feat is to be elected Governor of New York for four successive terms and a total service of ten years.

Yearlings and light steers were active today at strong to 25 cents higher prices, while medium weight and heavy steers sold on a steady basis, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs after an early spurt on reaching $8 closed slow with the advance erased. Fat lambs were 15 to 25 cents higher, best Colorado and native lambs turning at $9.40.

Establishment of a "Nova Scotia Coal Development and Utilization Council" was suggested as a step toward solution of the Province's coal marketing problem at a conference seeking formulation of a national fuel policy here today.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt, seeking a vote of confidence from the State and nation in his Administration and its objectives, went to the polls today to cast his ballot, and tonight received election returns at his home.

Valley Stream Central High School's football team remained one of the two undefeated and untied aggregations in Nassau County today by rallying in the final two minutes to score a 21-18 victory over Lynbrook, its traditional rival, at Firemen's Field.

IT'S a rare thing to meet a Navy man in these waters and it was a stroke of luck when Lieutenant Jean Moreau was encountered at a luncheon table. Up from Annapolis, he was laden with information about the Navy squad and coaches and equipment. Across the table was Herb Kopf,
Jewish refugees who for the last three weeks had camped in a no-man's land between Germany and Czechoslovakia were allowed today to enter this country by order of the Moravian local government.

Winning seven of the eight rounds and holding his opponent even in the other, Maxie Fisher of Newark easily won the decision from Johnny Rinaldi of the Bronx in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. Fisher weighed 1381/2 pounds, one-half more than his opponent.
Two Civil War veterans, who helped elect General Grant President back in 1868, turned out today to cast ballots for the "straight Republican ticket."
The Williams football squad worked out under floodlights long after the sun went down today, spending a long session on defense against a scrub team using Amherst plays.

Punctuating Tokyo warnings to neutrals that Chinese territory up to the very borders of Sinkiang and Tibet is now within range of Japanese aerial attacks, eighteen Japanese bombers yesterday dropped more than 100 bombs on the airfield of Chengtu in the first raid on the Szechwan capital since the outbreak of the Chino-Japanese war.
The complete vote of President Roosevelt's home town of Hyde Park today gave for Govnor: Lehman (D), 949; Dewey (R), 1,296.
Trimly-built, medium-sized 17-year-old Gerard Barnett ran his last cross-country race for Bishop Loughlin Memorial High yesterday and rounded out a scholastic running career with distinction.
The Finance Ministry instructed the Central Bank today to change the official exchange rate from sixteen pesos to seventeen pesos to the pound sterling, a fraction under four pesos to the dollar.
Herewith are presented summarized reports of the results of yesterday's election in more than a score of States, extending from the Northeast to the Pacific Coast:

Fordham's coaching staff, Messrs. Crowley, Walsh, Leahy Co., as well as all of the 4,000 persons who braved yesterday's rain at Ohio Field, cast a solid vote for the Maroon yearlings following a cleancut 190 victory over the N. Y. U. freshmen in their annual election day struggle.

Fairfield County, comprising twenty-three towns with a registration of 187,000 and including Bridgeport, home town of the Socialist Mayor, Jasper McLevy, today gave a big vote to Mr. McLevy in his race for Governor, but gave large pluralities to the -Republican ticket.
The decision of Federal Judge Clark, except in the unlikely event that it is upset on appeal, must profoundly modify the policy of Mayor Frank Hague in Jersey City. The order is a sweeping one.

The greatest Republican sweep in nearly twenty years occurred in the Rhode Island elections today, carrying William H. Vanderbilt, Gubernatorial candidate, the entire State ticket and two Congressmen into office.

The Republican party, a tiny minority of Federal, State and local officials for the past six years, reassumed major political status in yesterday's elections by a series of important victories and narrowly lost contests.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 5: COMMANDER Bowman, D. O., Med. Corps, when discharged from treatment, Naval Hospital, Annapolis, Md., to duty at Naval Academy. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Allan, T. D., Dental Corps, Navy Dept., to Navy Yard. Washington. D.

Sweeping, along on the crest of large up-State majorities, the Republicans in yesterday's election increased their representation by one in the State Assembly and wrested control of the Senate from the Democratic party.

The State Department is very much pleased at the decision of King George and Queen Elizabeth to visit Washington next Spring, but in view of the fact that they will come here as the personal guests of President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Cordell Hull today preferred to withhold any formal comment and stand on what Mr. Roosevelt had to say at Hyde Park.
Many public officials attended a funeral mass for Francis Cotillo, father of Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, 447 East 115th Street, yesterday.

Members of society who were at their country homes on the North and South Shores of Long Island to vote, and many from New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Westchester who are in town for the National Horse Show, crowded the Turf and Field Club and the stands at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon to make the Autumn meeting of -the United Hunts Racing, Association one of the largest in several years.

The Ministry of Transport has accepted a bid. for the construction of a bridge over the River Thames near Leray Lock. The bridge, for which the contract price is f128,000, will form part of the projected Maidenhead by-pass.

Newspapers and trade publications have done "a fine job" in acquainting the public with the rules and background of the Wages and Hours Act, Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the law, declared yesterday as he arrived in this city to. cast his vote for the "New Deal ticket."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Stern of 525 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecile J. Stern, to Robert F. Cohen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Cohen of Brooklyn.

With continued expansion of traffic between Italy and East Africa, it is understood in French circles here that Italy is concerned over heavy dues that her vessels pay for transit through the Suez Canal.

With preliminary estimates putting the total saving of lives in traffic during the twelve months ended Oct. 31 at 7,000, the Automotive Safety Foundation will dedicate its annual luncheon on Armistice Day at the Hotel Commodore to honor public ofifcials for leadership in accomplishing the saving.

In the most closely contested New York State election since 1928, Governor Herbert H. Lehman, running on the Democratic and American Labor party tickets, was re-elected yesterday for a fourth consecutive term, defeating District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee, by a plurality of about 70,000.

The body of James W. Zehner, 23 years old, of 211 Warren Street, here, who had been missing since last Saturday, was found today at the base of an embankment along the Newton Creek, about three blocks from his home.

A strong tone developed late in the session today on the Toronto Stock Exchange and closing prices were around the best for the day. Early trading was hesitant, this being ascribed to the election holiday on the New York market.

Mrs Marion Howard Powel, widow of Harford W. Hare Powel, member of an old Newport family, died here today after a long illness. Mrs. Powel was born in Providence, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ezra W. Howard. She had made her home here since her marriage fifty-two years ago.

It was officially announced tonight that the condition of President Kemal Ataturk took a sudden turn for the worse at 6:30 P. M. today and was showing a serious character. Eight physicians are in constant attendance on the Turkish leader.

Methodist Episcopal Church organizations in Germany and Austria have been cut loose from international ties and thus have kept out of trouble with the Nazi Government, it was reported here today by Bishop John L. Nuelson of Zurich, Switzerland, at the Fall meeting of the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain announced in the House of Commons today that the Woodhead report on the Palestine partition problem would be published tomorrow "with a statement of government policy."

Chile's skilled and colorful horsemen, Major Eduardo Yanez and Lieutenant Hernan Vigil, once more demonstrated their prowess in Madison Square Garden last night, when their brilliant performance as a pair earned them the victory in the second event for the International Low Score Challenge Trophy.
Despite the opposition of city employes, many public officials and the Democratic organization, the voters of Yonkers today expressed themselves in favor of the city manager form of government.
A new eastbound freight service between New York and Scandinavian ports, to be maintained by the Thorden Lines, was announced t yesterday by Lester N. Stockard, president of Stockard Co., Inc.

Charles Ellsworth Dunscomb, owner and publisher of The Berkeley Daily Gazette, died today in his apartment at the age of 70. Born in Illinois,- Mr. Dunscomb was graduated from the Sullivan (Ill.) High School in 1883 and went into newspaper work immediately, first in Sullivan and later as advertising manager of The East St. Louis Journal.
Virgil B. Van Wagonen, president of the Kingston Savings Bank, died on Sunday at his residence here at the age of 77.

The United States Life Insurance Company in the City of New York has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 to cover 70,000 shares of $5 par value capital stock to be offered, in the first place, to stockholders at $5 a share.
With the aid of the greatest Socialist vote in the State's history, the Republicans scored a surprising upset yesterday in one of the hardest fought elections in decades.

Mayors were elected yesterday in 103 municipalities in nineteen counties of New Jersey. In East Orange Mayor Charles H. Martens, regular Republican, was re-elected for his eleventh consecutive term of two years.

The resignations of their positions with the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and other utilities in the Aldred group were announced yesterday by J. E. Aldred and Joseph Walworth. Aldred Co. long have marketed securities for the utilities.

While a police radio car stood at the Bowery and Grand Street two men, each about 28 years old, entered a Postal Telegraph Company branch office at 240 Grand Street at 8:30 o'clock last night and, after threatening a young clerk with what appeared to be a pistol, escaped with $70 in cash.

The closenes of the vote in the Gubernatorial contest was reflected in an order issued early today by Mayor La Guardia through Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, providing for the assignment of police guards to all voting machines pending their removal from the polling places to warehouses by the Board of Elections.
Opponents of pari-muteul betting on horse and dog racing today led in returns from Hampden County, home of the Agawam Park horse race track and the Crescent Kennel Club's dog racing track.
A Canadian veteran and a 22-year-old newcomer from Indiana breezed in ahead of a chilling drizzle today to take a narrow lead at the quarter-way mark of the White Sulphur open golf tournament.
Armstrong County, embracing 339,200 acres, went without an election again today because it did not have sufficient residents qualified to serve as election judges.

An investigation that may lead to application of the State minimum wage and homework laws in the glove industry will begin this morning in Gloversville and the surrounding area, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

California voters, on the basis of available State-wide returns tonight, have turned down the "$30-every-Thursday" initiative measure. The proposal to restrict picketing in labor disputes also seems to have been rejected.
Favorable and unfavorable factors in the week's developments regarding business, as reported by telegraph and radio, were summarized today by the Department of Commerce as follows:

Cotton advanced 45 to 65 cents a bale net here today as the government's estimate of indicated production on basis of condition on Nov. 1 was readjusted slightly lower to 12,137,000 bales and took the trade somewhat by surprise. Operators, in fact, had been looking for a small increase in the indicated yield, with the average of private summaries in the neighborhood of 12,253,000 bales, which compared with the October official estimate of 12,212,000 bales.

Playing in the mud and rain on their home field, the Fieldston School team yesterday moved a little closer to the Metropolitan Athletic- Association of Private Schools championship by defeating the Barnard forces, 19 to 12.

Late returns tonight indicated that Kansas had returned to the Republican fold. Clyde M. Reed apparently has defeated Senator George McGill by a wide margin, and Payne H. Ratner has a safe lead over Governor Walter A. Huxman, Democrat.

More than 1,000 persons attended a funeral service for the Rev. Dr. Morris Lichtenstein, founder and leader of the Jewish Science movement, at the Park West Chapel,. 115 West Seventy-ninth Street, yesterday.

Dr. John McCreary, chief resident physician of the Toronto Hospital for Sick Children, took blood specimens today from the Dionne quintuplets for analysis before removal of their tonsils and adenoids tomorrow.
A dispute over the merits of the New York Gubernatorial candidates of the two major parties ended in the death last night of Joseph Byrne, 35 years old, a printer.

Yale's heaviest scrimmage of the week, almost entirely on the defense, was staged today in a sea mud. The Blues met a dogged Gray attack, which bogged down because of the heavy gridiron when a ground game was attempted.

We Easterners have had no reason to complain of our recent second Summer, but conservatives view with alarm these continual contests between low and high pressure groups and this unequal distribution of weather.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, took his defeat cheerfully but members of the young District Attorney's staff and other supporters who were in his campaign headquarters at 11 East Forty-fourth Street early this morning when he conceded his defeat by Governor Herbert H. Lehman were downcast and made no effort to hide their disappointment.
Preparations for the Pan-American Highway Congress, which opens here Jan. 15, are now well advanced.

Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon's Nacionalista party was winning National Assembly election contests throughout the provinces, it was indicated early today, on the basis of incomplete but conclusive returns of yesterday's balloting.

Steel ingot production rose last week, countering a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index advanced to 84.1. This compares with 78.3 for the preceding week, and 71.0 for the week ended Nov. 6, 1937.

Institutions which have investments in the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad and the life insurance group committee for holders of securities of the Chicago North Western Railway filed today identical objections with the Interstate Commerce Commission to the consolidation of the two railroads as proposed by stockholders of each.

The Iowa election was close in early returns from scattered precincts. Senator Guy Gillette, Democrat, seeking re-election, and his Republican opponent, L. J. Dickinson, were so close that the lead often changed.

Payment on open credit accounts receivable of department stores were made at lower rate in September than in September, 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of studies made with the cooperation of 400 stores.

George B. Cocker, founder and president of the Cocker Machine and Foundry Company of Gastonia, N. C., died today in a Richmond hospital. He was 68 years old. His company sold textile machinery all over the world.

The reunion of Victor Moore and William Gaxton, separated since "Anything Goes" (1934), is tonight's event at the Imperial. "Leave It to Me!" adapted by Sam and Bella Spewak from their comedy, "Clear All Wires," is the vehicle for their stage reunion, Mr. Moore playing an American Ambassador to Russia and Mr. Gaxton the role of a foreign correspondent.

To President Roosevelt will be presented tomorrow a "pump-handle" electric desk lamp, the gift of Massachusetts WPA workers in appreciation of his "pump-priming program" to stimulate business recovery.

Rayon-yarn production in the United States for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled 68,300,000 pounds, according to figures made public yesterday by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The figure represents.

The Forty-second Election District of the Tenth Assembly District, Manhattan, w the easiest one in the city to poll, for only the choices of one voter had to be glanced at, the selections of Rabbi Nathan Wolf of the Times Square Synagogue, 240 West Thirty-eighth Street. It cost the city about $500 to record Rabbi Wolf's vote.
Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, who since 1932 has been first lady of New York, unwillingly played an important role in the history of the campaign just closed.

MISSOURI--4,428 Precincts--Voted for United States Senator, Representatives in Congress, Supreme Court Justices and on constitutional amendments affecting pay of legislators and old-age pensions. Vote for President in 1936: Democratic, 1,111,043; Republican. 697,891.

Reuben Fine of New York, one of the two North American representatives in the A. V. R. 0. international chess masters tournament, repeated his success of the opening day by defeating Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, in the second round tonight at the Zoological Garden in this city.

Resurgent Republican forces apparently scored a clean sweep in New Hampshire tonight, unseating New Deal Senator Fred H. Brown in favor of Representative Charles W. Tobey and re-electing Governor Francis P. Murphy over John L. Sullivan, his Democratic opponent.

Mrs. N. J. Keadle and Mrs. William Williamson, both bedridden, wanted to vote today, so they resorted to the telephone. Election officials waived regulations and let the women telephone their preferences to poll commissioners.
Hopes that Canada's trade with the Orient eventually will be restored to normal proportions by reconstruction in wartorn China were held today in Vancouver exporting circles.

Before one of the largest and most colorful crowds that has turned out in years for-the United Hunts Racing Association meeting at Belmont Park, F. Ambrose Clark's colors finished in front in the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase Handicap yesterday.
Pennsylvania has voted to return to its traditional Republicanism, after trying out the first Democratic administration elected in this Commonwealth in forty-four years.

Today's events: Jascha Heifetz, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; lecture-recital, "Evolution of Music for Wind Instruments," Dr. Carleton Sprague Smith and Blaisdell Woodwind Ensemble, Town Hall, 5:30; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall, 8:45; John Powell, lecturing at Midtown Branch of Federal Music Project, 93 Park Avenue, 11:30; Bernard Gabriel, lecturing on "Great Singers," Sherman Square Studios, 8:15 P. M.

" The Yearling," by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings, has gone into its fourteenth printing, bringing the total to 250,000. "The Oxford Anthology of American Literature," edited by William Rose Benet and Norman Holmes Pearson, which Oxford University Press will publish on Nov. 17, contains much writing which has not appeared before.
The Air Ministry announced tonight that it hoped to be able to start experimental transatlantic air mail service as soon as the Botwood (Nfld.) seaplane base is clear of ice next Spring.
Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany Hall, issued last night the following statement on the election of Governor Lehman:

The individuality, interpretive and creative, of one of the greatest musicians of this epoch, Serge Rachmaninoff, dominated the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr.

The Weather Bureau announced today that a tropical storm of less than hurricane force was centered at 7 A. M., Eastern standard time, over Northwestern Andros Island in the Bahamas (about 150 miles southeast of Miami) and was moving northwestward about fifteen miles an hour. our.

Morris S. Tremaine, Democrat, who has been re-elected State Controller, has already served twelve consecutive years in that post. Starting under Governor Alfred E. Smith in 1926, and continuing under Governors Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, he has contributed a large share to the efforts of successive Democratic administrations to make the financial operations of the State so plain that any ordinary citizen may follow them.

Class 87, Heavyweight Hunters (up to carrying 200 pounds to hounds, Course K)--First, Miss Deborah G. Rood's gr. g. Dublin Venture: second, Isaac H. Clothier Jr.'s ch. g. Twentyseven; third, Crispin Oglebay's ch. m. Hi-Bey; fourth, Mr. and Mrs. E. Gardner Prime's ch. g. Ballela.
British exports of chemicals, dyes and allied products in the third quarter of this year totaled $25,276,650, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Convinced of the success of a Christmas parole system he inaugurated eleven years ago, Governor Bibb Graves said today he would reward nearly 800 State convicts with "good behavior" vacations during the coming holiday season.

The Fifteenth Assembly District became a happy hunting ground for autograph seekers and celebrity hunters yesterday as notables of the city, State and nation visited its polling places to cast their votes.
Alfred Hoare, one-time partner in Hoare's Bank and compiler of an Italian-English dictionary, died today at the age of 88. He was a member of the original London County Council.

In a Republican landslide far surpassing the predictions of Republican leaders, all candidates of that party in Westchester County were elected today and Thomas E. Dewey received a plurality of 56,325, according to unofficial returns. The Republican State and Congressional candidates polled correspondingly high votes.

The government of The Netherlands has demanded immediate payment for the vast Royal Dutch Shell-controlled petroleum properties expropriated March 18 by the Mexican Government or return of the properties, in a note dated Oct. 27 and made public today by the Netherland Legation here.

The shots fired yesterday by a Polish emigre at Ernst vom Rath, third Secretary of the German Embassy in Paris, were answered in the German press today with blazing wrath and a unanimous demand for retaliation against both German and foreign Jews in the Reich.

The Smith College Charity Ball, the first of the three annual dances given at Smith College, Northampton, Mass., will be held on Dec. 3 in the Scott Gymnasium. The dance was established in 1932 to raise funds for the Smith Community Chest.
Because of his speaking engagements this week, Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities announced today that the committee will hold no more hearings this week.

The mural, "The Evolution of Western Civilization," by James Michael Newell, a WPA Federal Art Project painting, will be presented to Evander Childs High School, the Bronx, this afternoon, according to an announcement yesterday.

Letting the world know he favored the election of Thomas E. Dewey, Charles H. Benedict, who is 103 years old and who believes he probably, is Mr. Dewey's oldest active supporter, voted in a fire station at Stockport, N. Y., today. He lives with his daughter,' Mrs. T. C.

Walter Elliot, Minister of Health, tonight told a British Medical Association dinner that the government would introduce a bill at the current session of Parliament for the establishment of a cancer service making available modern facilities for diagnosis and treatment throughout England and Wales.

To keep up their Winter sailing record, thirty-two hardy sailors, five of them women, went out in sixteen boats in a blast of southerly wind and seas today for the election day regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Because of gradually returning normalcy in the interior of Shantung Province the United States Government will reopen its consulate in Tsinan, the provincial capital, about Nov. 15. The consulate has been closed for more than fifteen months.

The Continental Oil Company, New York City, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $21,071,600 of ten-year convertible debentures, due on Dec. 15, 1948, and an undetermined number of shares of $5 par value capital stock to be reserved for conversion of the debentures.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission an answer to exceptions by the Postmaster General to a report by two I. C. C. examiners recommending an increase in its air mail remuneration, but "in the interest of expediency
Six of the proposed amendments to the State Constitution submitted by the Constitutional Convention were adopted by the voters yesterday, while three were beaten.

An old-time Republican sweep was scored in the Bergen County election today, with the county giving W. Warren Barbour almost twice the plurality his managers had claimed for him and electing a Republican in the Ninth Congressional District for the first time since the district was established in 1934.

The final returns in the race for District Attorney of Queens County showed that Charles P. Sullivan, the incumbent, had been re-elected by a plurality of 72,371 over his Republican opponent, Henry Vollmer Jr. The total figures are:

Democratic candidates were making an apparent clean sweep of the major judicial offices under contest in the city. Benedict D. Dineen, at present a Municipal Court Justice, and J. Sidney Bernstein were both elected to the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, which comprises Manhattan and the Bronx.

Larry Gilbert, veteran manager of the New Orleans Pelicans, today was named skipper of the Nashville Vols, succeeding Charlie Dressen, resigned. Fay Murray, president of the Nashville club of the Southern Association, said the new pilot would become a part owner of the club.

The Republicans carried Union County as usual yesterday. Representative D. H. McLean, Republican, was leading his Democratic opponent, R. F. Green, by 41,937 to 27,396 on the basis of 201 election districts out of 278 in the Sixth Congressional District, which is coterminous with the county.

Immediate establishment of the Quebec Government's projected 26,000-horsepower electricity plant on the Upper Ottawa was decided on today during a conference between Premier Duplessis and members of the Province's Electricity Syndicate.
An eleven-year-old bride was returned to the home of her parents in Coffee County tonight while her husband of a day was jailed on a charge of kidnapping by inveigling.

John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New York, will-not be able today either to celebrate victory or to deplore defeat in the election, for he must return to work to defend the conservation policies of the Tennessee Valley Authority before the Supreme Court.

John Bohenen, 32, sought as a suspect in the $7,000 hold-up Monday of the Scottsville (Ky.) Farmers National Bank was shot in his home here early today in an exchange of shots with Kentucky State officers and local police. He was captured and taken to a hospital.

The thrill that only the blind can understand came to a 27-year-old sightless man today when for the first time he was able to distinguish objects through corneal tissue given by John Deering, Salt Lake City murderer.
Returns tonight put Senator Frederick Van Nuys ahead of Raymond E. Willis, Republican.

MINNESOTA-3,374 Precincts-Voted for Representatives in Congress, Governor and other State officials. Vote for Governor in 1936: Farmer-Labor, 680,342; Republican, 431,841. Polls closed at 8 P. M. (9 P. M. New York time).

Governor-elect Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts broadcast a message early today expressing gratitude for his victory and declaring that "honest service and decency" must prevail in the conduct of public affairs" if our form of government is to endure."
Wisconsin, which two years ago gave President Roosevelt a majority of more than 400,000, swung decisively back to the Republican banner in today's election.

Four lines of cars with thirty-three body models are being offered by Packard for 1939, it was revealed yesterday by Lee J. Eastman, president and general manager of the Packard Motor Car Company of New York.

Absecon--Ira L. Giverson, D. * Folsom Borough--Jack L. Eckhardt, R. Egg Harbor City--William Townsend, R. Pleasantville--Scott M. Long, D.* Pleasantville--W. Scott Ireland, R. Ventnor--Harry S. Hodson, R.
Daniel L. Donovan, for many years an attorney in Brooklyn, died at his home, 896 Union Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon at the age of 59. He had been ill for five weeks.
More than 100,000 tobacco package union labels, saved by smokers all over the country in the belief they would provide an artificial limb for an 11-year-old girl, were discarded as worthless today.

E. E. Fogelson's Gray Jack, assigned 108 pounds for Saturday's Rhode Island Handicap, took up 118 today and scored by a neck over the Cosgrave Stable's Bobs Boys in the Stamford Purse, feature event of the election day card at Narrag sett Park.
Frederic H. Bontecou of Millbrook, N. Y., conceded at 1:30 A. M. today the election of his Democratic opponent for New York's Lieutenant Governorship, former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti.

A St. Vincent's Hospital ambulance and an automobile collided at Seventh Avenue and West Twenty-ninth Street soon after 8 o'clock last night, injuring ambulance surgeon Charles Sullivan, 31 years old, of 270 Convent Avenue. Dr. Sullivan was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital. He was cut and bruised on the hands and face.

Representative John J. O"Connor at 9:15 o'clock last night conceded his defeat for re-election by James H. Fay, New Deal Democrat. An unofficial vote tabulation at Mr. O'Connor's headquarters showed him the loser by 2,590 votes, while a similar tabulation at Mr. Fay's headquarters showed the latter winning by 2,316. Both tabulations purported to give the complete figures for the district.

Eric Pape, the artist who founded the Eric Pape School of Art in 1898 and was its director until 1913, died Monday morning in the City Hospital on Welfare Island, to which he was removed on Friday after collapsing from a heart attack while walking on Eighth Avenue near Fortieth Street. He never regained consciousness. His age was 68.

Cornelius E. Mitchell of 350 Madison Avenue, an amateur pilot, brought his Fairchild monoplane to a forced landing on a sand lot baseball field between Cross Bay Boulevard and Jamaica Bay in Broad Channel, Queens, yesterday afternoon. A companion, Miss Marian Blagman of 113 East .

Princeton's alumni soccer team suffered a 7-0 defeat at the hands of the varsity eleven in a ragged contest on Poe Field today. Dick Sylvester, varsity inside right, scored twice to pace the undergraduates to victory.
Subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation reported yesterday as follows for the year ended on Sept. 30:

Lieut. Edward Williams, 30, of Adams Terrace, Dorchester, a member of the National Guard and a hull designer at Fore River, was killed accidentally with his service pistol and a companion was wounded by the same bullet in an automobile in which they were riding to work in Quincy today.

Except for the first official announcement of his visit to the United States, King George's speech opening Parliament today was the usual stiff and formal outline, drawn up by the Cabinet, of government policy during the coming session, which is expected to be the last of the present Parliament.

The new cabinet, which Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons reconstructed yesterday, met this afternoon. Mr. Lyons announced that Brigadier Geoffrey A. Street, Minister of Defense, had been added to the senior cabinet group that will shape high policy.

Turpentine firm, 231/2c; sales, 82 barrels; receipts, 846 barrels; stock, 51,573 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 198; receipts 2,107; shipments 732; stock 284,152. Quote: B, D, $4.50; E, $4.25: F, $4.90: G, H, I, K, $5.12 ; M, $5.15; N, $5.55; WG, $6; WW, X, $6.65.
Eight persons were dead and three reported dying tonight in the most violent election day in Kentucky since 1933, when eighteen were slain.

How the Spanish Rebels broke through in the Ebro sector and occupied part of the bridgehead is a story that could not pass the Barcelona censor, but one that deserves to be recorded as part of the history of the war.

Paragraph 9, Special Orders 258, dated Nov. 4, 1938, relating to lit Lt. Joseph Shapiro, Med.-Res., is revoked. Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Cant. Sloan B. Jordan. CA-Res. (3d M. A.).

Another experimental television transmitter will begin tests on the air next month in the New York area, if present plans materialize, Is was said yesterday by Allen B. DuMont, president of the A. B. DuMont Laboratories of aPssaic, N. J. The second trial of James J. Hines, West Harlem Tammany leader, on the indictment involving him with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and others in the policy racket conspiracy, will not start next Monday, as District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey promised last September. It is not likely to start until after the beginning of the new year.

Engineering construction awards in the current short week, totaling $37,260,000, are 4 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of 1937, when the total was $35,920,000, The Engineering News-Record reports. The Armistice Day holiday reduced the statistical period to four days in both years.

The automobile industry has introduced its 1939 models and is greatly encouraged as a result of the enthusiasm with which they have been received by the public. The young Polish Jew who assassinated the third secretary of the German Embassy, examined today by psychiatrists, was reported to have wept when he learned his act had brought new vengeance against Jews in Germany.

A limited edition of 300 copies of "The Journal of Emily Foster," edited by S. T. Williams and L. B. Beach, is being issued by the Oxford University Press on Dec. 1. The Journal recounts her stay in Dresden with her family during 1821-1823, the period of her friendship with Washington Irving.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 9: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Pickering, C. E., Veterinary Corps, two months and 18 days' leave, Dec. 10. Woodruff. R. B. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, one day's leave, Nov. 12.

Four properties in Monmouth County, N. J., have been sold by Charles E. Sweeney, broker. The newspaper Prensa charges that Ecuador's new labor code was copied from Mexico's and reproduces pages of the latter without a change. It also alleges that the law was passed by Congress without reading it, since it contains Aztec words not found in dictionaries and the meaning of which no one in Ecuador knows.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that the trustees had adopted a plan for a permanent field organization to include chapters in all the 3,071 counties in the country.

Members of the American Finance Conference heard today an attack by one speaker upon types of national advertising as fostering monopoly, a prediction by another that business would see more instead of less government interference and a warning by a third that prevalent abuses in the field of automobile finance insurance must stop.

Looking ahead to Princeton, Army's varsity went through another session of scrimmage against jayvee teams armed with Tiger plays today, although the cadets must meet Chattanooga this Saturday before they play the Big Three team.

He was called simply Mustafa when he was born in Salonika in 1880, the son of a Turkish customs officer. His mathematics teacher at military preparatory school added Kemal, meaning "rightness," to his name. When he fought his way to leadership of the Turks, the title of Pasha was added.

All Jewish families were ordered this morning to leave Munich within forty-eight hours and were instructed to inform the political police by 6 P. M. when they would hand over the keys to their dwellings and garages.

One of the first conclusions to be reached after careful study of the experience acquired in the nation's war on traffic accidents over the last two years is that an imperative need exists for career men both in official circles and among the non-official groups attacking the problem.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange' continued active as sales again topped $11,000,000. Although many of pivotal loans lacked their buoyancy of the preceding day, the market generally maintained a firm undertone, with gains outnumbering losses throughout the list.

An argument developed today before the Bituminous Coal Commission over a proposal to permit "quantity discounts" on coal sold directly by the producer to large consumers. The plan was offered by Charles O'Neil of New York, chairman of the District One producers'

Department store sales showed less than the usual seasonal increase from September to October, partly because of tne exceptionally warm weather, and declined 10 per cent below October, 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Fearful of Armistice Day disorders, the French Government tonight banned any parades except the annual march to the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier, scheduled for tomorrow morning.
Among building projects submitted yesterday by architects was a set of plans for three units of an apartment house development in Annadale Park, Queens.

Thomas E. Dewey, whose run for the Governorship against Governor Herbert H. Lehman made him at least nominally the head of the Republican party in the State, indicated yesterday that he had been particularly pleased with the support the up-State organization gave his candidacy.

The British Government will spend [Pound]200,000,000 on its Air Force in the next financial year, Air Minister Sir Kingsley Wood told the House of Commons today. This will be a 75 per centincrease over the budget estimate of [Pound]120,000,000 for the present financial year, which ends next March 31.

The Italian Cabinet met again today under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship and approved two important decrees in which the principles that the Fascist Grand Council laid down Oct. 6 for maintaining the "purity of the Italian race" are codified and promulgated in the form of organic laws.

In these days of constant hammering at the problem created by our street and highway accidents we cannot afford to lose sight of the absolute necessity of cooperative effort and the coordination of safety activities if anything is to be accomplished.

Unless there is a revival of private undertakings, it is difficult to foresee a continuance of the present favorable trend in steel bookwings and production beyond the peak point, probably about next March, of lettings of governmentfinanced projects, Iron Age says this week.

Estate $3,000. To Frank Dellavalle, 605 E. 138th St., Joseph Dellavalle and John Dellavalle, executor, both of 312 E. 104th St., sons, $833 each; two other bequests. FOSTER, FLORENCE SOUTHERLAND (Nov. 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Glen Varick Foster, son, 950 Park Ave.; Gray S. Foster, son, 1,519 33d St., Washington. D. C.,

The armistice that ended the World War twenty years ago will be commemorated today for the first time as a national legal holiday. President Roosevelt signed a bill to this effect May 14. Cities throughout the country will hold exercises centering about their principal war monuments.

Rescue Company 4 will report at the Fire College, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 10 A. M., Saturday, Nov. 12. A medical officer of the department shall be present while instructions in the use

John Bracken, Premier of Manitoba, left Ottawa for Washington tonight to invite officials of the Department of Agriculture to a conference on agricultural exports, to be held in Winnipeg on Dec. 12 to 16.
Coach Benny Friedman made four changes in his City College line-up yesterday in the final heavy drill for tomorrow's closing game of the season at Lewisohn Stadium against Moravian College.
The volume of bank clearings for the current period of five days dedined sharply from that of the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, which did not include election day.
Paced by Eddie Jordan, who tallied all four of his team's touchdowns, the McBurney School football team swept to a 25-to-0 triumph over Columbia Grammar at Central Park yesterday.
The pound sterling was forced down 17/16 cents to $4.73 3/4 yesterday, carrying with it other European currencies to lower levels in another unsettled day in the foreign exchange market.

In a surge of revenge for the murder of a German diplomat in Paris by a young Polish Jew, all Vienna's twentyone synagogues were attacked today and eighteen were wholly or partly destroyed by fires and bomb explosions.

19th St. 115 E.13.4x70: John T. Quinian to Sol Blankfein, 149-57 14th Ave, Whitestone, Queens; pr mtg $2,000; 1 year, 6 per cent; $1,000. 152d St, 614 W, 100x99.11; West Holding Corp to Henry Sonn Co, Inc, 119 W 25th St; p m, pr mtg $153,341, installments, 6 per cent; $10,000. 151st St, 611 W, 100x99.11; same to same: p m. pr mtg $153,341, installments, 6 perrent: S10.000.

The weekly luncheon of the Touchdown Club yesterday at the Midston House was the most informal of the season, with the members discussing the subject of wholesale substitutions. Sentiment seemed to be almost unanimously against this practice, with the most practical suggestion that no replacements be permitted except at the end of each quarter unless there are injuries.

A wave of destruction, looting and incendiarism unparalleled in Germany since the Thirty Years War and in Europe generally since the Bolshevist revolution, swept over Great Germany today as National Socialist cohorts took vengeance on Jewish shops, offices and synagogues for the murder by a young Polish Jew of Ernst vom Rath, third secretary of the German Embassy in Paris.

The Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor of the Catholic weekly, America, said yesterday he had directed the attention of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull to circumstances surrounding the recent sailing from here of the Erica Reed, an 8,000-ton freighter carrying a cargo of foodstuffs, clothing and medical supplies to Spain.

Longfellow Ave (11-2993), w s, 90 ft s of Freeman St, 41x109; Lestein Realty Corp to Jaydon Realty Corp, 900 Prospect Ave; mtge, $26,250. Faile St, 892 (10-2761B); Clarence E. Noska to Frieda Wertheim, 896 Faile St. Noble Ave, 731 (14-3593); Empire Trust Co, Inc, to Carlo Marzocca, 108 E 109th St. Mott Ave (9-2348, 14-3824), n w s, at n e s of 151st St, 119x119; also Eastern Blvd.

A dead man's vote was counted in last Tuesday's Yates County returns, Fred Rogers, Election Commissioner, said tonight. The vote was the absentee ballot mailed by Elnathan Meade from Battle Creek, Mich., before he died Monday.

Fear of agitation resulting from anti-Semitic decrees in Italy and of the possible effect of the agitation on the State election was chiefly responsible for failure to call on time this year's convention of New York State lodges of the American Sons of Italy, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook held yesterday.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 29 totaled 275,824,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
The stock markets here continued cheerful today under the lead of domestic industrials, although the volume of business declined, compared with yesterday.

In October the United States Steel Corporation shipped 663,287 tons of finished steel products, an increase of 85;621 tons compared with the preceding month's total of 577,666 tons and a decrease of 129,023 tons compared with October shipments last year of 792,310 tons.

General Maxime Weygand, who retired as chief of France's armies in 1936, chose Armistice Eve to warn Frenchmen that their only hope to meet the challenge of Greater Germany was unity and work within the French empire.

Charles Cartnell, former vaudeville actor, died last night at the Brunswick Home in Amityville, after a general breakdown. His age was 56. He was an original member of the actors' colony here and a charter member of the Lights Club.
One man was dead and five were wounded today as New Jersey's small game season opened. Walter Pitierski, 20 years old, of Middletown Township was wounded fatally by a discharge from his own shotgun.
Except for a short Armistice Day drill tomorrow morning the Harvard football squad today concluded its week's work with the hardest session it has had since the Chicago game.

A fashion show with matrons and members of the younger set acting as manikins was a feature of the annual Christmas sale of the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work which was held this afternoon at the Greenwich Country Club.

Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse gave a dinner last night at her home, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, for Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, Mrs. Arnold Whitridge, Mr. and Mrs. Parmely W. Herrick,

Fifth lay conference on educational policies, Teachers College, Columbia University, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Dean William F. Russell, Professor I. L. Kandel, Professor L. S. Hollingsworth. Afternoon session, 2 P. M. Address by Professor Edward L. Thorndike.

One hundred and twenty-six children were placed for adoption in foster homes during the year ended Nov. 1 by the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, it was reported yesterday at a meeting of the committee at its offices, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Many dinner parties will precede the third annual Carnival on Wheels to be held tonight at the Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fiftyfifth Street, as a benefit for the Vocational Service for Juniors During the roller skating party, games and contests will be conducted.

Because John D. Rockefeller Jr. is an "excavation fan," those men, women and children who like to stop and watch while others toil at new construction work won an important concession yesterday. The first "excavating watchers' club" was dedicated at Rockefeller Center.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt signed by ninety-five prominent Americans, urging him to "discourage" any further peace settlement such as the Munich agreement to end the Czechoslovak crisis.

THE BOOK OF BELLS, by Satis N. Coleman. (John Day, $2.50.) The lore of bells. HOCKEY, FASTEST GAME ON EARTH, by Mervyn Dutton. (Funk Wagnalls, $2.) An explanation of big league ice hockey by the manager of the New York Americans.

In retrospect, motor vehicle dealers may view the year 1938 as one in which the industry faced many difficult problems that called for the application of the highest degree of energy, business management and intelligence in order to cope with conditions and operate successfully.

Stocks eased and closed irregular after reaching highest levels since September, 1937; turnover, 2,176,753 shares. Corporation bonds generally higher, second-grade rails strong, United States Government fons generally lower; transactions, $11,397,500.

Columbia concluded its major preparations yesterday for the game with Navy tomorrow at Baker Field. The midshipmen, who arrived last night after a long drill at Annapolis, are quartered at the Westchester Country Club. They will have a light workout at Baker Field at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and the Lions will run through signals after they depart.

H. G. Wells confessed today that he "stole" a hat that he intended to keep, and wrote the owner, "I take off your hat to you." The hat belonged to the retiring Mayor of Cambridge, E. S. Peck, who wrote Mr. Wells after a visit by the author:

Bill Krywicki, Fordham quarterback, will not face North Carolina at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. The signal-caller, who suffered rib contusions in the St. Mary's game, was not in uniform as the Rams went through a two and a half hour workout yesterday.

Two former stars at Howard College, Norman Cooper, center, and Harold Hill, end, will be in the starting line-up for the Dodgers Sunday when the Brooklyn eleven meets Philadelphia in a National Football League test at Ebbets Field, it was announced yesterday by Coach Potsy Clark.

Close by the hulking shadows of the Bowl, Yale's football forces finished preparation for Princeton today. Tomorrow morning the squad will climb aboard special cars and head for the first of their two major objectives of the season.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson approved today a lease which the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, owner of the Bear Valley Colliery in Northumberland County, made with the Bear Valley Coal Company to operate the property.

Miss Elizabeth Laurenson Simpson, daughter of Mrs. Wilson Young of this place and of Colonel W. Sloan Simpson of Dallas, Texas, was married to Carroll Dewey Hipp, son of Mrs. John G. Hipp of Newberry, S. C., and the late Mr. Hipp, this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother.
The Swedish Academy today awarded the 1938 Nobel prize for literature to Pearl Buck, American, author of "The Good Earth" and other novels about China.
A tidal wave apparently caused by a severe submarine earthquake centered near the Aleutian Islands washed shores of the Hawaiian Islands today. No damage was reported.

Trading on lamb fair to good: veal, calf and pork fair; other classes only fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Market on hinds and ribs barely steady; veal and calf steady to mostly S1 higher; other classes mostly steady.
Mr. and Mrs. Courtland Kelsey of Orange gave a supper dance tonight at Essex County Country Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Betty Kelsey.
Attorneys were arguing in a liquor case in Federal court today. The point seemed to be whether the witness could accurately smell a broken jug of moonshine at forty yards.
The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, last night in Carnegie Hall contained two favorite symphonies-the Fourth of Schumann and Beethoven's Seventh.

Throughout the recent campaign in this State there were ugly rumors that the election might be decided on the basis of irrational religious prejudice, and now many people seem to think that the results of the election give some evidence that this was so.

Trouble beset the Long Island Railroad twice yesterday. It started with a power breakdown in the Brooklyn Edison Company at 8 A. M. that resulted in a traffic tangle affecting forty trains carrying fully 30,000 commuters. Nine persons were injured, two of them seriously, on one train that jolted to a violent stop.

Set In a decorative scheme designed to express the automobile industry's relationship with agriculture, manufacturing and the production of mine and forest, the thirty-ninth National Automobile Show will open at 2 o'clock this afternoon in Grand Central Palace.

PATROLMEN-Edwin S. Southern, 103d Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and from 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 13. From precincts indicated to 19th Division, duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 19 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 12: Michael V. Terml, 28; George G. Ossmann, Traffic B.
Holy Cross, one of the East's top-ranking teams, will lead off with its strongest line-up when it faces a twice-beaten but dangerous Brown eleven before an expected crowd of 18,000 tomorrow.

The Transportation Association of America in its annual report said today that hope for balanced, competitive transportation systems depended upon "coordination and consolidations, not only among the same types, but between all forms of transport."
Julius W. Cone of Greensboro, N. C., who has been president of Cone Export and Commission Company, was elected to the new post of chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday.

Through an interpreter, Johanna Hofmann, former hairdresser aboard the German 'liner Europa, told from the witness stand yesterday in Federal Court her story of how, through cajolery and threats, she was made an unwilling tool of Karl Schlueter, a traveling agent of Dr. Erich Pfeiffer of the Reich's intelligence service.

Emphasizing that the main trouble with the oil industry is overproduction, D. van Nymegen Schonegevel, manager of the Royal Schonegevel, manager of the Royal Dutch-Shell refinery at Curacao, Dutch West Indies, yesterday said that "it will improve as business improves." Mr. SchoAegevel,

The frost was certainly on the pumpkin this morning and the opening-day hunters had everything in their favor for the first four hours, although the warm sun made it difficult for the dogs to find birds during the middle of the day.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that applications to list the following securities are pending before the committee on stock list: Edison Brothers Stores, 445,494 common shares; $10,000,000 Crucible Steel 41/2r cent debentures, 28,350 additional National Steel common shares and 393,372 additional capital shares of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Associates and friends of Karl F. Egge, former publicity director of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., who has been appointed assistant merchandising director of the World's Fair, will give him a dinner at the Brass Rail Monday at 6:30.

At the annual meeting of. the American Academy of Arts and Letters held yesterday morning at the Academy, 633 West 155th Street, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president,, announced the election of Willa Cather and Stephen Vincent Bent, authors, both of New York.
The corn market was the center of speculative activity today on the Board of Trade here, advancing sharply while wheat was inclined to lag.

The British Great War Veterans of America, Inc., New York branch of the British Legion, will give their annual Armistice Ball tonight in the grand ballroom of the Astor. The event will be under the patronage of the British Ambassador, Sir Ronald Lindsay, and many other men and women prominent in social, military, diplomatic and patriotic circles. As in the past.

Hilgh waves battered the beaches adjacent to St. Augustine today, causing considerable property damage and threatening some waterfront homes and business property. Part of the big Vilano Casino, built during the real estate "boom days" on Vilano Beach by August

Football fatalities in high school, college, sandlot and athletic club games show a decrease for the second straight year, according to a preliminary report issued today by Dr. Floyd R. Eastwood of Purdue University, who makes an annual survey of gridiron vital statistics for the American Football Coaches Association and the N. C. A. A.

The present board of directors of the Equity Corporation, an investment trust, showed a state of mind "which was lacking in good faith and honest judgment" in failing to bring any accounting suits against former directors of the corporation and its affiliates, except one suit against Wallace Groves, Supreme a Court Justice Noonan declared yesterday, in a ruling on a stockholders' suit.
The general level of wholesale prices declined during the week ended on Nov. 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Dr. Russell E. Blaisdell, superintendent of the Rockland State Hospital, at Orangeburg, N. Y., arriving here today in response to a subpoena to appear before the grand jury, disclosed a third death in the hospital at 6 o'clock this morning as a result of the administration of a wrongly made up prescription to five patients.

In observance of Armistice Day, all the principal security and commodity markets in the United States and Canada will be closed today. The Paris Bourse and other French markets also will observe the day, but those in London, Berlin and Amsterdam will remain open.
California, we begin to suspect, is not quite as eccentric as people imagine. It may turn out to be a dry humor and not bats in the

John Marin's annual one-man show opened earlier in the week at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, there to continue until after Christmas. The gallery is open from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M. weekdays and from 3 to 6 on Sundays.

Methods for meeting home-financing problems and supplying the vast potential demand for new dwellings were outlined by speakers at today's sessions of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Cuba will shortly proceed with the adoption of a permanent Constitution and the election of a constitutional President "in accordance with the principles of a free people," Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army and the leading figure in his country, said here today.
The Southern Conference for Human Welfare announced today it had awarded to Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court its Thomas Jefferson medal for 1938.
The government mouthpiece, the Nacion, reported today that the Socialist militia was being organized rapidly on military lines, with enrollments proceeding throughout the country.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight said that the United States need not fear communism "if our young people and we ourselves make our form of government and democracy meet the needs of our people."

The first reports reached here today of the fate of those Polish Jews resident in Germany who reached the Polish border at Neubentchen but were not sent across in the mass deportation proceedings begun two weeks ago.

Turpentine firm 23c, sales 44 barrels; receipts 195 barrels; shipment 80 barrels; stock 51,870 barrels. Rosin firm: sales 73: receipts 2,171; shipments 300. stock 287.883. Quote: B, D, $4.05; E, $4.25: F, $4.95; G. H, I, K. M, $5.15; N, $5.55; WG, $6; WW, X. $6.65.

Pearl Buck has won the Nobel Prize and she deserved it. There is a little irony in the justice. "The Good Earth," which first brought her to fame, had the misfortune to be a best seller, a class of works which she has roundly denounced. It also got the Pulitzer Prize.

Signs of radical changes in Czechoslovakia are multiplying rapidly. The reactionary press is developing a furious campaign against former President Eduard Benes that goes as far as to demand confiscation of his property.

The Foggiani, an organization of World War fliers who served on the Italian front, held its third reunion since the armistice yesterday afternoon and evening. The reunion began at noon when members of the organization assembled at City Hall to meet Mayor La Guardia, one of their members.

Edward Hodges Brown, a founder of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church here and former director of its choir, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 82. Born in New York, Mr. Brown sang in the choir of Trinity Chapel at 12 West Twenty-sixth Street. As Abraham Lincoln's cortege passed along Broadway in 1865, he tolled the church bell sixty-five times.
Mrs. Ann Liza Gulick, retired missionary, who served many years in the Orient and among the Pacific Islands, died at Honolulu Oct. 9, according to word received here today. She was 105 years old.
