Defense of bankers against the charge of unwillingness to lend and condemnation of proposed changes in the banking laws designed to increase the power of the Federal Government over credit constituted the principal themes in speeches delivered here today before the opening session of the thirty-seventh annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

Perry St. 80-2, 5-story tenement, 40x95.1: City Bank Farmers Trust Co against Carvo Realty Co, due, $50,766; to plaintiff for $44,500. By ROBERT FISHEL 9th Ave, 548, 5-story tenement, 24.6x72; Greenwich Savings Bank against Josephine Gallo, due, $30,007, taxes, etc, $624; to plaintiff for $27,000.

The Federal Grand Jury here investigating the alleged violation of civil liberties in Jersey City questioned today Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, and two of Mayor Frank Hague's long-time political enemies, John R. Longo and James J. (Jeff) Burkitt, guards of the Hudson County Penitentiary, brought Longo to Newark.
Prince Chalermbol of Siam, who said he had come here to study American police and crime detection methods in New York, Washington, San Francisco and Chicago, arrived yesterday on the Normandie.

Two debutantes who will be introduced to society together on Thanksgiving night are Miss Marjorie Vose White and Miss Marion Lesher Everett. A dinner dance will be given for them by their parents at the Pierre.

Scoring twice in a space of 85 seconds in the opening session, the New York Americans downed the Red Wings, 2 to 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight. It was the Americans' first victory and the second straight loss for Detroit.

A jury had been chosen from a blue-ribbon panel of talesmen in General Sessions yesterday for the trial of two former officials of the Excess Insurance Company of America accused of the theft of $80,000 of the concern's funds, when one of the defendants, Harry S. Haines, 37 years old, entered a plea of guilty through his lawyer, James D. C. Murray. Judge Charles C.

Sir Victor Sassoon, British financier, who has large real estate holdings in Shanghai and other cities in China, arrived yesterday from London on the French liner Normandie. He expressed the opinion that the Japanese, needing capital, would have to deal with the United States and Great Britain.

Well supplied with experience letter winners, although not at full strength, Exeter's football squad is awaiting the traditional Andover duel with high hopes of halting the Royal Blue's two-year reign of supremacy when their classic series is renewed Saturday at Andover, Mass.

The United States Realty and Improvement Company has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it sold 60,100 shares of its capital stock during October and on Nov. 1 disposed of an additional 2,900 shares.
Arthur (Dazzy) Vance, whose fast ball made him a strike-out king in National League baseball a dozen years ago, is ill with pneumonia in a hospital here.

Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh announced today that he would sponsor a legislative investigation of Albany County. Thomas E. Dewey, in some of his campaign speeches, singled out Albany County as a center of "crime in politics,"

Miss Jane Baar Celler, daughter of Representative and Mrs. Emanuel Celler of 303 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton to Sydney B. Wertheimer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wertheimer of 225 Central Park West. The ceremony was performed by The Rev. Isaac Landman of Brooklyn.

John Ross and Ray Ruddy of the home club defeated Roy See and B. Martinelli of White Plains, 21-9, 16-21, 21-6, in the invitation fourwall handball tournament which opened at the New York Athletic Club last night.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday that it had received the following cable dispatch from Rio de Janeiro: "Getulio Vargas, President of Brazil, stated today that the government's coffee policy had been so successful that he does not expect a surplus from the next crop.

The appointment of Prince Ascanio Colonna as Ambassador to the United States was officially announced today. The Prince, who has been representing Italy on the international commission for the control of Egyptian loans, has been a distinguished diplomat for thirty of his 55 years.

For the third consecutive month retail prices on the average showed no change, as measured by the Fairchild Index, which was at 89.0 on Nov. 1, the same figure that was reported for Aug. 1, Sept. 1 and Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday.
The commercial agreement governing trade relations between Germany and Chile, which expires next month, will be prolonged for another six months, it was announced this afternoon.

John L. Lewis balked the peace efforts of a special committee of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, which sought to arrange a renewal of peace parleys between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, according to the committee's report today to the members of the garment union's executive board.

The Chandler act amending the Bankruptcy Law, which went into effect on Sept. 22, gives more protection to the creditor class and less to the stockholders, Aaron Rosen of the law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler Houston,
The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Newspaper Guild of Philadelphia and Camden have signed a contract, it was announced today, which includes Guild shop and job security clauses.
The Brooklyn College football team will meet the strong Ithaca College eleven tomorrow in a game moved up one day because of the CornellDartmouth contest on Saturday.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Letts Oliver of Pasadena, Calif., who are staying at the Savoy-Plaza, announced here yesterday, at a reception given at the hotel, the engagement of their daughter. Miss Mary Oliver, to Adrian Foote Shannon of this city and Allenhurst, N. J.

More than sixty paid and commission resident buying offices have now registered with the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., it was stated yesterday by Edward Fillmore, counsel for the organization.
Governor Frank Murphy, New Deal Democrat who lost his re-election campaign this week, said tonight that there was no basis for reports that he would receive a Federal bench appointment.

The names of editors and members of the managing boards of nine undergraduate publications at New York University who have been elected for the current academic year were announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

Some of the details of the plan for the merger of the Methodist Episcopal Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant Church next April were disclosed here today at the Fall meeting of the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the Hotel Dennis.
Although Johnny Dutcher has been selected to play .quarterback for Pennsylvania in the thirty-seventh game with Penn State Saturday, the signals will be called by Jim Coulter, blocking halfback.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Rita Monfrede of 1,730 Harrison Avenue, the Bronx, was named the prettiest girl at City College yesterday. From among 300 photographs submitted to Vincent Lopez, orchestra leader and judge of the contest,

Mrs. Beatrice Humphrey Milligan, wife of John R. Milligan, died here today at her home after a long illness. She was 53 years old. The daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Humphrey of Staten Island, Mrs. Milligan was graduated from Smith College in 1907.
The seven-day period beginning at 7 P. M. Sunday will be the first "International Week of Swells" in the history of the weather service of the maritime nations.

The Treasury ruling yesterday requiring goods shipped from the Germanannexed Sudeten area to bear "made in Germany" markings after today, which was reported to have surprised New York importers, applies only to goods shipped from that area today or hereafter, or to goods from that region held in stock at shipping points outside of the Sudeten area which as of today are not invoiced to the United States, customs officials explained.
Two sophomores, Cliff Wilson and Dick Banger, today appeared as the likely starting halfbacks for Syracuse against Duke here Saturdaiy.
Because 146 city primary ballots were inadvertently burned before they were counted, Port Townsend voters wondered today who, if any one, was nominated for Mayor and what could be done about it.

El Toreador, Spanish night club at 7 West 110th Street, has lost its liquor license, it was announced yesterday by the State Liquor Authority. Action was taken on the ground that girls had been employed in the cabaret to induce patrons to buy drinks, that liquor sales had been made after hours, and that gambling had been permitted in the place.

Frank J. Kappler, former business manager and assistant pubfisher of the Long Island Daily Star, has become associated with the sales staff of Frank O'Hara, Inc. Plottage in Candlewood Knolls, Candlewood Lake, Conn., has been purchased by Edward Pardee and T. Henry Howard, while Charles J. Zeller and Joseph Lee have increased their holdings.

The newly reorganized Mordkin Ballet opened a four-day engagement at the Alvin Theatre last night, presenting three ballets with choreography by Mikhail Mordkin. These were "Trepak" with music by Alexandre Tcherepnine, "Voices of Spring"

The keel of the first of four 8,775ton freight ships to be constructed for American Export Lines' New York-Mediterranean-Black Sea service was laid today at the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation's Fore River plant.

An increase in factory construction in this State outside of New York City is indicated in the monthly report of Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, who announced yesterday that 137 plans representing a total expenditure of $1,610,245 were submitted last month to the State Department of Labor.

Moving slowly with his preparations for Manhattan's intersectional meeting with West Virginia a week from tomorrow, Coach Herb Kopfsent the Kelly-Green football squad through a two-hour offensive scrimmage on Manhattan Field yesterday.
Secretaries Ickes and Wallace discussed the election with the press today but while they started from similar premises they arrived at different conclusions.

St. John's College fraternity leaders were told today by President Stringfellow Barr that their groups contribute nothing to the advancement of the college which justifies their continued use of college-owned buildings as chapter houses. He ordered that the houses be vacated by next September, when the new academic year begins.

The nation's public housing and slum rehabilitation program at last is in "high gear" and beginning next Fall low-income families will start moving into the United States Housing Authority's projects at the rate of 5,000 a month, Nathan Straus, administrator of the Authority, reported today to the convention of the National Association Df Real Estate Boards.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, and Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed the view yesterday afternoon that agreement between management and labor could be brought about best by cooperative effort and collective discussion and that a democratic form of government best promoted these means.

A hearing has been set for Nov. 29 at New Orleans by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by New Orleans Stock Yards, Inc., to withdraw its $100-par-value common stock from listing on the New Orleans Stock Exchange.

Among the lessees of residential quarters appearing in the lists submitted yesterday was Oscar Correia, Consul General of Brazil, who took a duplex of twelve rooms and four baths in the building at 940 Park Avenue, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Art Lewis walked up to the Polo Grounds clubhouse yesterday for the first time in two years and instinctively turned the handle on the door to the Giants' dressing room. The door was locked. A light dawned on the 26-year-old coach of the Cleveland Rams.

Republican party chieftains, flushed by their party's victories at the polls, expressed confidence last night that by combining with Democrats critical of many Roosevelt policies they could block President Roosevelt if he insisted on following a "leftward" course.

Mrs. Martha L. Guernsey of 151 East Fifty-ninth Street, New York City, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to review the government's claim that she owed $51,545 in estate taxes on the estate of her husband, Nathaniel T. Guernsey, a former vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Charges that the Screen Actors' Guild since May, 1937, has collected from its members more than $1,000,000, "most of which has been unlawfully spent save approximately $100,000," were filed with the National Labor Relations Board yesterday by three guild .members.

How will the President respond to the results of this week's elections? Will he modify those courses which met such clear rebuke in many States? Will he return to counselors who have a warrant from the people instead of delegating powers to private aides impatient with the coordinate Federal process? Or will he indicate,

Colgate's Red Raiders will write finis to their season this afternoon when they meet the N. Y. U. football team in the Yankee Stadium. Because it is on Armistice Day and the only major football attraction in the city, it is expected that the attendance will run close to 25,000.

VERY luckily, it was just as the reviewer finished reading a fine new book by Frank Sullivan, the distinguished American satirist, that Mr. Arbuthnot (the noted Frank Sullivan expert), arrived. He took the stand. He was sworn. The questioning began.

In order to obtain greater statistical information on textile invenstories and to devise some type of guidance for controlling them, the United States Institute for Textile Research will undertake a research project entitled "Textile Inventory Policies and Statistical Guides,"

Lieut. Col. Sir Melville Heyman, who organized and commanded the Rhodesian reserve regiment in 1914, died today at the age of 79. Born in Gibraltar, son of the late General Heyman of the Royal Artillery, Sir Melville came to South Africa in 1877 and joined the Cape Mounted Rifles.
Today's events across the Rhine will not make it any easier for Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to win the British people to a policy of friendship and understanding with Nazi Germany.

All doubt as to the success of Amendment No. 1, the omnibus measure providing for home rule, permanent registration, civil liberties, free transportation for pupils in denominational schools and many other articles, was dispelled yesterday.

Major Jasper McLevy, who polled 164,000 votes on Tuesday as Socialist candidate for Governor and thereby brought about the election of the first Republican Governor in Connecticut in eight years, made this statement on the election today:
Today's events: Orrea Pernel, violinist, Town Hall, evening; Georgia Graves, contralto, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Budapest String Quartet, Washington Irving High School, 8:15 P. M.

George B. Wuestefeld; one of the first automobile dealers of this city, died today in New Haven Hospital where he underwent an operation several days ago. He was born in New Haven fifty-two years ago and became an automobile dealer when 20 years old.

Amherst College's football team held its last practice on Pratt Field today as Coach Lloyd Jordan sent his charges through their assignments for a final check in preparation for their last game of the year with Williams Saturday.

Inability of large, over-loaded and under-powered trucks to negotiate even slight grades at a reasonably quick speed is being investigated in a special study undertaken by the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission, William J.
North Dakota voted overwhelmingly against repeal of its 2-year-old Liquor Control Act. With only 413 of the State's 2,260 precincts missing, the vote was 80,479 for repeal, 127,695 against.
The eighth annual Northeast Regional Convention of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations will be held at the Community House of Temple Emanu-EI, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, on Sunday.
Phelps, Fenn Co. headed the successful banking group in the purchase yesterday of two issues, aggregating $3,575,750, of city of Minneapolis. Minn., bonds.

One hundred and four new loans amounting to $2,071,883 were made last month on real estate in Manhattan as compared with 121 loans totaling $1,616,228 in September. The moderate increase in dollar volume was offset by a decline of seventeen in the number of loans, according to the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Coach Carl Snavely expected today to start the same Cornell team on Saturday gut, against Dratmouth as that which mer lined up for the Columbia game. teen The eleven will include-Bill McKee- of ver, 210-pound tackle, who rested to several days with injuries, and from George Peck, veteran wingback.

A decided upsweep in sales and a decline in unemployment in the drug and cosmetic industries was predicted yesterday by Philip M. Dinkins, chairman of the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades Section of the New York Board of Trade, at an executive committee meeting at the Drug and Chemical Club, 85 John Street.

On the twentieth anniversary of Germany's World War defeat, public opinion in the United States and in England is overwhelmingly skeptical of Chancellor Hitler's promise that the new and powerful Reich desires no more territory in Europe, according to surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion in the United States and by the British Institute, an affiliate, in England. Dr. George Gallup is director of the American group.

Charles William Bacon, author of books on the United States Constitution and former assistant United States district attorney in the Southern District of New York, died here yesterday in his home at the age of 82.
The former Munson liners Pan America, Southern Cross and Western World were sold at auction yesterday afternoon and were bought in by the United States Maritime Commission for a total of $256,000.

William H. Ryan, assistant fire chief, died this morning in his home here at the age of 64. He was a member of the volunteer fire brigade until the town organized a fire department in 1912 and was the third man appointed to the paid department.

It is a fact both fantastic and deeply discouraging that on this the twentieth anniversary of the end of the World War sane men living under a democratic government in the safest of all nations should be called upon to recommend a further increase of American armaments.

A rift between the State Department and the Department of Agriculture appeared for a time today to be in prospect over reported plans for the sale of United States wheat to Brazil under the export subsidy policy but Secretary Wallace at his press conference this afternoon indicated that he intended to cooperate with Secretary Hull.

The Republic Steel Corporation informed the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today that within two weeks it would petition for an order directing the National Labor Relations Board to reopen its case against the corporation for the purpose of taking additional testimony from company witnesses.
Three of the eight seeded players survived the opening round of play in the Eastern Association open Fall squash racquets tournament which began on the New York AthWhich Club courts last night.

Foreshadowing a new era of extensive transactions in securities of public utility operating companies, two of the investment companies controlled by Harrison Williams and associates announced yesterday their intention of reducing sharply their holdings in the North American Company.
The giant battle cruiser Repulse, escorted by two light cruisers, will carry King George VI and Queen Elizabeth to Canada next Spring, it was announced today.

The marriage of Miss Marion Moran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Francis Moran of Brooklyn, to William Brendan Mattimore, son of Mrs. James S. Mattimore of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Mattimore, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
McKesson Robbins, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday- for the third quarter of this year a net income of $606,404 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes,

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 10: At Oakland: Chester, Louisville. At San Francisco: Astoria, Indianapolis, Minneapolis, Northampton, Pensacola. Portland. Quincy, San Francisco, Salt Lake City, Tuscaloosa, Vincennes. Asheville, Shanghai to Swatow.

Three motor companies will open exhibits today independent of both the National Automobile and the National Truck shows. This will bring to five the number of such displays beginning today and open to the public for the ensuing seven or eight days.

Declaring that the success of a business man was due chiefly to the work of his employes and that "only a jackass would think differently," John F. Webendorfer of Bronxville completed today the sale of his machinery manufacturing business here for approximately $1,000,000 and immediately distributed $250,000 to his 115 employes.

Luang Bipul Songgram, Minister of Defense, escaped injury today when his valet tried to assassinate him. While the Minister was dressing the valet fired at him twice with a pistol but missed. The servant was arrested.

Secretary Morgenthau invited Federal Reserve officials today to meet him after Thanksgiving to determine the financing to be done by the Treasury on Dec. 15. Unofficial estimates indicate that the Treasury probably will borrow upward of $500,000,000 on that date.

Paul Dillard, cotton merchant and former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, died today of a heart attack at the age of 65. Mr. Dillard served the Federal Reserve Bank for twelve years and at one time was its deputy chairman.
Governor Martin L. Davey, accusing the Federal Social Security Board of "robbing" Ohio, today ordered immediate payment of October pension checks to 112,285 needy aged.

Continued gains in the industrial centers, such as Detroit, Cleveland and Pittsburgh, as production of automobiles and steels continues to rise, was reported here yesterday by finance companies handling installment sales.

Firing a spectacular 32 on the final nine, Sam Snead came through late today with a seven-under-par 273 for the seventy-two-hole White Sulphur open golf tournament to win first prize in the $3,000 event. Two strokes behind was KyLaffoon of Chicago.
Electric power production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 95.6 from 95.8. The figure for the week ended Nov. 6, 1937, was 100.8.
Judge Arthur H. James, Republican Governor-elect, urged Pennsylvania industry today to start its program of rehabilitation "right now" and not wait until he took office.
J. Donald Budge has left the amateur ranks of tennis and the United States has lost the mainstay of its Davis Cup defense sixteen months after the trophy was reclaimed from its ten-year stay abroad.

Air express shipments in and out of New York City reached an all-time high record in October, the Railway Express Agency announced last night. Shipments numbered 35,699, an increase of 11I per cent over October, 1937, and 81/4 per cent over December, 1937, the previous high month.

Princeton's latest strategy of shifting the veteran Jack Daniel from end to halfback was materially aided this afternoon when Johnny Meyerholz, ace pass-receiver, reported on University Field for the first time in three weeks.

With 450 additional gifts to the campaign in behalf of the ninetytwo voluntary member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, contributions thus far have passed the $500,000 mark, it was announced last night by C. M. Chester, chairman of the appeal, headquarters of which are at 370 Lexington. Avenue.
Toronto struck quickly in the second period tonight to score its first victory in three national hockey league games and defeat the Canadiens, 2-0, before 7,000.

Among the arrivals from Europe on the French liner Normandie yesterday was a group of British stage and screen notables. Included were Noel Coward, playwright and actormanager; Leslie Howard, actormanager; Anna Neagle, actress; Herbert Wilcox, director and producer, and Laurence Olivier, actor.

Mrs. Joseph Ferris Simmons will give a dinner on Monday in the Ladies' Annex of the Metropolitan Club for Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems and James Abercrombie de Peyster, whose marriage will take place Dec. 2, and for Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen and John B. Trevor Jr., who will be married Nov. 18. Both weddings will take place in St. James Church.

C. Addison Swift, former judge and a former prosecutor of Union County, died this afternoon at the Elizabeth General Hospital after a brief illness. Born seventy-nine years ago in this city, he was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Swift. He was one of the oldest members of the bar in this section of the State, having practiced law here for more than fifty years.

Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday at a service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine that only $74,000 was needed to complete the interior of the cathedral in time for the opening of the World Fair.
Francis Mullane, Detroit featherweight, was outpointed by Bablio Alvez of Uruguay in a semi-final round bout of the Pan-American boxing championships tonight.

Elmer Gantry, the blind horse that has been taught to race, jump and perform at shows, will be the star of a Warner picture. The studio secured the animal, which was blinded four years ago, from Eleanor Getzendaner of Chicago, owner and trainer.

A series of explosions took place this afternoon at the San Antonio government munitions magazines, located at Punta Blanca, at the back of the harbor, across the bay from Havana. No casualties were reported.
The short position in stocks traded on the New York Curb Exchange was 20,714 shares on Oct. 31, compared to 14,209 shares on Sept. 30, the Exchange announced yesterday.

Ethel Shutta, singer, filed suit for divorce in Superior Court today against George Olsen, orchestra leader, charging desertion. Miss Shutta asked support money for herself and two children and requested that the custody of the children be shared jointly.

Herbie Katz, 1751/2, Brownsville, knocked out Gene Stanley, 173, New York, in the feature eightround contest at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn, last night. Referee Gunboat Smith stopped the bout in the third chapter because of a deep cut over the loser's eye. The combatants had waged a close struggle for two sessions.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad was ordered yesterday to meet payment in full, with interest from Oct. 1, 1938, on $99,000 of its 6 per cent notes by Justice Lewis A. Abrams in the Municipal Court here.

Formation of the Hospital Council of Greater New York to "improve and coordinate the services of hospitals and related health agencies" and to "plan the economical and efficient development of these services in relation to community needs" took place at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the council's headquarters, 370 Lexington Avenue.

With the slogan "Automobiles for America's Progress" as its watchword, the National Automobile Show opens this afternoon. It is the headliner in an automotive week in which the National Motor Truck Show opens its doors in New York for the first time, and the three great group manufacturers, Ford, General Motors and Chrysler, also stage independent or correlative exhibitions in Manhattan.

A colorful display of 500,000 gayly hued blooms were displayed at the American Museum of Natural History last night as the Horticultural Society of New York opened its thirty-first annual Autumn exhibit.

A defense of the League of Nations against charges of failure was made yesterday by Arthur Sweetser, League Commissioner General to the New York World's Fair 1939, as he laid the cornerstone of the League's pavilion at the fair.

While we are honoring our war dead today, we should give a thought to the peace-time toll of traffic deaths, Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, reminded motorists yesterday. He asked special care in driving today and over the holiday week-end because of the increased traffic on the roads.

Business leaders should take their feet "off the brake and put them on the accelerator," Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, said today as the Nation's Business Advisory Council went into its regular monthly meeting.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, which will be mailed today to shareholders, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $8,608,437. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.27 a share on the outstanding common

I note this morning the letter in your columns which protests the recently reported increase in traffic court fines. The correspondent protests the present method of collecting fines for minor traffic offenses. He also implies that this increase in the number of traffic fines is undesirable.

The program for the three-day visit of King Carol and Crown Prince Michael of Rumania has now been completed. They will arrive next Tuesday, crossing the English Channel on the destroyer Sikh. They will be met at Dover by the Duke of Kent and the Rumanian Minister.

Reports that one of the largest suppliers of cotton textiles to the Works Progress Administration received favored treatment from the Treasury's Procurement Division and that goods supplied by this contractor were inferior are the subject of an investigation ordered by Secretary Morgenthay.

The automobile show is a great educational institution. In completing preparations for the thirtyninth National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace today, this fact has impressed itself on the show committee more strongly than any other.

General John J. Pershing counseled the nation today, twenty years after he led the American armies to victory in the World War, to take "prompt and vigorous action" to reinforce its defenses. "The situation in the world today is as menacing as at any critical time in history," the commander of the A. E. F. said in an Armistice Day statement.

The Rutgers football team had its last practice of the season today, Coach Harvey Harman announcing at the conclusion of a drill in the stadium that the squad would not dress tomorrow and would have only skull practice.

During the week ended Nov. 9 member bank reserve balances decreased $140,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $58,000,000 in money in circulation, $104,000,000 in hon-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $2,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve
President J. Edgar Park announces that the trustees of Wheaton College had voted to proceed immediately to the erection of a student alumnae building.

Final details of the protracted negotiations for an adjustment of the controversy over Mexico's expropriation of agrarian lands owned by United States citizens were virtually concluded at a conference this afternoon between Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, and Sumner Welles, UnderSecretary of State.
This is how the party line-up of the next and present Congresses compare after Tuesday's election, with vacancies in the present Congress credited to the party which held the seats last:

Sponsors of a proposed anti-lossleader bill, representing many branches of the grocery trade, are now encouraged because twelve of the members of the State Legislature elected Tuesday had, before their election, committed themselves in writing as being in favor .of the bill and others had expressed support, a spokesman for the Greater New York Retail Grocers Conference said yesterday.

An estimated 10,000 to 15,000 workers dared a pouring rain today to march on the first anniversary of the new regime set up by President Getulio Vargas and acclaim the President, whom speakers hailed as labor's protector.

Governor Lehman, in his first general press conference since his re-election on Tuesday, reiterated yesterday his pledge to serve out his full four-year term. The Governor, at the end of that time, will have been in Albany fourteen years, four as Lieutenant Governor under Franklin D. Roosevelt, and ten as Governor.

1st Lt. Frank B. York Jr., Inf.-Res.. 169 W. 80th St., New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Nov. 12, at Headquarers Trenton District, CCC, North Olden and Breunig Aves., Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: Oct. 29, 1938.

New automobiles driven into Rockefeller Plaza yesterday by representatives of seven manufacturers were televised by the cameras of the National Broadcasting Company as a preview of the National Automobile Show opening today at the Grand Central Palace.
A large representation of society filled the boxes and arena seats at the sixth evening session of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Several hundred persons, including members of the Federal bench, attorneys and laymen met yesterday at memorial services in rooms of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals and heard speakers praise the liberalism, scholarship and human qualities of the late Benjamin N. Cardozo, Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

A committee representing the extract flavoring industry conferred today with Under-Secretary of the Treasury John W. Hanes and urged the establishment of a differential favorable to extracts for taxing purposes.

The Dayton Board of Education voted tonight to reopen the city's schools, closed since Oct. 28 because of a financial crisis, on Monday, Nov. 21, on the basis of a report that $430,000 could be made available for operations.

When the Red Cross roll-call begins today the people of this city are bound to remember gratefully the work of the organization after the September hurricane. It is not often that this community has the opportunity to watch the Red Cross going into action at close quarters.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 22 represented 22.07 per cent of total volume compared with 19.88 per cent in the preceding period, the SEC reported today. Total volume was 13,339,540 shares sold, compared with 10,048,600.

Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee, predicted tonight that Democratic majorities in both houses of Congress would be unified by the increase of the Republican minority as a consequence of Tuesday's election.

Kemal Ataturk, President and creator of modern Turkey, died today at Dolma Baghche Palace at the age of 58. He had survived thirteen wounds received in battle and a number of assassination attempts, but succumbed to cirrhosis of the liver.
The navy started enlistment today of a category of merchant marine cadets, United States Naval Reserve, authorized by the last Congress.

President Roosevelt returned to the White House tonight after a week's stay at Hyde Park to begin a series of conferences on the Federal budget and future legislation. He did not break his silence on Democratic reversals in Tuesday's elections.

Six convicts broke out of the Tennessee penitentiary today in a truck, taking three prison officers with them as hostages, and were shot down in a running gun battle with pursuing officers a mile from the prison on a street in a partly residential, partly business district of the city.
Homer Sylvester, the sheriff who in April of 1937 captured Robert Suhay and Glen Applegate, convicted slayers of a Department of Justice agent, was swept from office in Cass County's election.

William H. Hackett, Tax Commissioner of Connecticut for five years, was found dead today at his residence. He suffered a heart attack two weeks ago but rallied and was at his office in the State Capitol on Tuesday. However, he had been confined to his bed the last two days. His age was 67.

Students and faculty members of New College, experimental unit of Teachers College, Columbia University, were stunned at an assembly in the Milbank Chapel yesterday by an announcement that the institution would be closed next June for lack of funds.
A barograph sent today to Washington for calibration will determine whether Willie (Suicide) Jones has set a world's record for a delayed parachute jump.
Dr. Reuben S. Joffe, for the last fifteen years a practicing dentist in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital after a brief illness.
Coach Jack Blott has decided to start a sophomore Wesleyan line and backfield against Rochester Saturday.
A straight-line instrument panel in which all gauges are mounted horizontally and immediately in front of the driver is used in the 1939 Cadillac and LaSalle models.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved an air-mail rate increase for Continental Air Lines, Inc., contractor on Route No. 29, covering 646 miles from Pueblo, Colo., to El Paso, Texas, and including, also, 104 miles from Pueblo to Denver, Colo.

As a result of the action of the Aluminum Company of America in raising the price of aluminum from 18 cents to 31 cents a pound in 1915, the use of that metal virtually was discontinued in the manufacture of Buick, Cadillac, Oldsmobile, Oakland and other automobiles, Charles W. Nash,

A charge of suspicion of homicide against Rassaele Dano, 42 years old, of 511 West 184th Street, whose truck killed Frank Kelly, 5, of 175 Audubon Avenue, at Audubon Avenue and 174th Street on Oct. 24,

American interests will be protected in the coming round-table conference on Palestine, Colonial Secretary Malcolm MacDonald promised in the House of Commons today. "We are certainly conscious of the great interest of the United States in this matter," said Mr. MacDonald.

A Polish Jew, a boy of 17, receives a postcard from his parents telling him that they have been dumped on the Polish frontier, victims of the sudden mass deportation order by the German authorities to express protest against a ruling of the Polish Government and displeasure against the attitude of Poland in opposing German wishes on the Ruthenian question. The parents cannot go back to Germany; they have nowhere to go in Poland.
The youngest team of chief executives in the nation mapped plans today for administration of the State Government after Jan. 1.

The French press, which was almost unanimous in condemning the Polish-Jewish assassin who shot Ernst vom Rath in the German Embassy here, today just as severely reproves the outbreak of anti-Semitism that has followed this incident in Germany.
If the thirst for victory is any criterion, Colgate and New fork University should provide one of the most fiercely fought games of the season today at the Yankee Stadium.

The big brass drum in the court room where Robert Irwin is on trial for murder spun out the names of sixteen more blue ribbon talesmen yesterday at a short session before Judge James G. Wallace, but only two of them were accepted as jurors.

The C.I.O.'s Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union decided tonight to demand a 60 per cent increase in the minimum hourly wage rate which the president, Sidney Hillman, estimated would affect more than 300,000 men and women workers.

The army and navy toasted the Marine Corps today on its 163d birthday anniversary. General Malin Craig, army chief of staff, wrote Major General Thomas Holcomb, Marine Corps commandant, that the army has "profound admiration" for the service.
An exhibition celebrating the founding of the Moscow Art Theatre in 1898 opened yesterday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Mayor La Guardia, after buying the first membership in the twentysecond annual roll-call of the American Red Cross at City Hall yesterday, issued a proclamation asking the people of the city to support the drive for funds.
Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the new Jefferson nickels would be available to the public starting Tuesday. About 11,000,000 of the new fivecent pieces are being shipped

The Department of Agriculture established today 57 cents a bushel as the rate at which the government would lend Federal funds on corn in the "commercial corn area," basing this rate on a crop estimate as of Nov. 1 at 2,480,958,000 bushels.

Gross assets, $87,435; net, $80,196. To Delia B. Cagney, widow, $2,500 and residue in trust for life. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $77,303. Owen E. Reilly, attorney, 154 Nassau St. KAUFMANN, MOLLIE BAAR (Nov. 10, 1937). Gross assets, $52,605; net, $49.960. To Hermine K. Solomon, daughter, $47,500 and one-half residue; Allan L. Kaufmann,

Premier Edouard Daladier's Radical Socialist party today officially broke up the Popular Front in France. This was done in a formal note to the body that organized the Popular Frontcalled the Assemblement Populaire, composed of political parties of labor and other organizations of the Left.

Mrs. Rosemary Ohliger Anderson, an attorney, died here today at the Mohican Hotel. She was 80 years old. A native of France and former resident of Ohio, Mrs. Anderson came to this city more than thirtyfive years ago.

The nine-room dwelling on an acre plot at 980 Post Road, Scarsdale, Westchester, has been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to Vernon Corell for occupancy, through the Raymond R. Beatty Organization, brokers.

Upon the basis of a stipulation signed by all parties, the National Labor Relations Board today ordered Joseph H. Meyer Brothers, Inc., with a plant in Brooklyn, to disestablish "Collective Bargaining Committee of Joseph H. Meyer Brothers, Inc.,"

Secretary Wallace today assured spokesmen for a group of national associations of retailers that the government would endeavor not to disturb employment or normal business in the conduct of its projected twoprice experiment.

The National Association of Retail Grocers today announced the establishing of National Grocers Institute as a training school for grocers and clerks. The institute plans a program of research and education and will offer instruction in the fundamentals of store operation and in food commodities.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Konigsberg of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Minna Konigsberg, to Victor Whitehorn, son of 4 Mrs. Joseph A. Whitehorn, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Whitehorn.

With vast undeveloped and underpopulated areas of Northern Canada being opened up at a rapid pace, statesmen are weighing the possibility of creating a Canadian haven for political and racial refugees from other countries, Ian Mackenzie, Minister of National Defense for the Dominion of Canada, said in an interview here yesterday.

Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroal agreed today to file briefs and exceptions to an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's report which would wipe out common and preferred stocks of the railroad as part of a reorganization plan.

The partnership of Maurice Evans, Joseph Verner Reed and Boris Said, currently presenting the full-length version of "Hamlet," is understood to have suffered a serious breach. Mr. Evans and Mr. Reed are reported planning to become associated with a new theatrical manager,
Severe fighting raged today in Yochow, gateway to Hunan Province, between Chinese defenders and Japanese troops smashing toward Changsha, the provincial capital.

Walter Reade, large owner and builder of theatres here and in New Jersey, has bought from Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney the Plaza Theatre, a one-story building at 42-44 East Fifty-eighth Street, near Madison Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

When the super-trawler Princeton slid down the ways of Bethlehem's Fore River plant today, General Foods completed the launching of five trawlers within the past fourteen months, representing a cost in excess of $1,300,000. Mrs. Clarence Francis of Bronxville, N. Y.,

Cornelius Simonson, 58 years old, a retired New York Stock Exchange member, was found dead early this afternoon in his automobile near the house of his daughter, Mrs. J. H. Stevenson, on Tory Hill Road, Delafield Island, here.

Gene Mako, advised that J. Donald Budge had turned to professional tennis today, wished his erstwhile doubles partner "all the luck in the world" and announced he would team next year with Jack Tidball, former national intercollegiate champion from the University of California at Los Angeles.

Banking institutions were the sellers in many of the Long Island realty transactions announced yesterday, when properties in Queens and Nassau County changed hands. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to Joseph S. Ward the one-story garage building on the southeast corner of Thirty-first Street and Newtown Avenue, Astoria.

Robert E. Lancaster, securities dealer indicted recently in New York County for grand larceny and who was arrested Nov. 3 in Florida, was revealed yesterday to be a fugitive from justice in California since 1931.

As soldier and statesman Kemal Ataturk ranks high in the history of his country. He was without doubt one of the ablest national leaders of the post-war period. The one dictator who let his works speak for him, he was also the only one who actually created the state he ruled.
S. Hoxie Clark of 1,215 Fifth Avenue has announced the engagement of his daughter, Mrs. Betty Clark Hoster, to Dr. Allen P. Gurganious of Palatka, Fla.

The Michigan Associated Telephone Company, Madison, Wis., has filed, under the Securities Act of 1933, a registration statement covering $2,800,000 of first mortgage Series A 4 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1968. The company is a subsidiary of the General Telephone Corporation.

The Martime Commission opened bids today for the construction of six Combination passenger and cargo ships, each ship to be of about 12,000 tons and to be built to specifications approved by the navy.

19th St, 438 E; Lawrence Maslaw to Nineteen Realty Co, 693 Van Buren P1, West New York, N. J.; mtg $70,500, quitclaim. 26th St., 142-44 W; Joseph N. Schultz, referee, to Seamen's Bank for Savings, foreclosure ($100). 62d St, 113 E; Joseph H. Sears, executor of Anna W. Sears, to Joseph H. Sears, East Main St. Oyster Bay, N. Y.

University Ave, 2.189, 100 by 37.5: City Bank Farmers Trust Co against Louis Goldstein. due. $16.671, taxes, etc, $794; to plaintiff for $15,000. Prospect Ave. 1.375,'2-story dwelling, 21.2x 93.2xirreg: Home Owners Loan Corp against Max Lapin, due, $6,607: to plaintiff for 2,750.

Mrs. Corinne Howell Wiley Strange of Bernardsville, N. J. and this city, widow of Albert Bruton Strange, was married here yesterday to Frederic Bull of Bedminster, N. J. and this city, at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Edwin Lex Bacon, 167 East 82d Street.

Management cannot longer take the attitude that if management itself does not undertake the task of job evaluation and establishment of wage rates on a scientific basis, no one else will, W. W. Finlay,

Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan attempted unsuccessfully yesterday to obtain a reduction of his bail from $25,000 to $5,000 pend ing trial of the grand larceny charges against him, which grew out of the theft of 7,200 police records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn last month.

As Reuben Fine of New York, by drawing with Jose R. Capablanca, maintained his lead in the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world champion, moved within half a point of the American by winning in the third round from Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, his opponent in the last title match.
The Junior Service League of Cranford will sponsor an Armistice Night dance tomorrow evening at the Canoe Brook Country Club for the benefit of its welfare fund.

Employment and payrolls in factories in New York State decreased 10 per cent in October from the figures for the same month last year, Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. Employ. ment rose four-tenths of 1 per cent
The year 1939 marks the fortieth anniversary of the Packard car. J. W. and W. D. Packard, brothers, then living at Warren, Ohio, completed the first "Model Al" in 1899.
John B. Payne, vice president of the Texas Pacific Railway, in charge of freight and passenger service, died yesterday in a Dallas hospital. He was 66 years old.

Lieutenant Ramiro Palafox of the Mexican Army team accomplished the impossible in Madison Square Garden at the sixth evening session of the fifty-third National Horse Show when he completed the special course to win the international military special challenge trophy last night.

A reorganization in the administration of the local WPA Federal Theatre appeared imminent yesterday after jurisdiction over the project's personnel department was transferred from the office of George Kondolf, theatre director, to that of Paul Edwards, administrator of all the Federal arts projects.

The first performance of Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice" in the regular season since 1914, to be given at the matinee on Nov. 26, and the debuts of five singers and four solo dancers new to the Metropolitan Opera will mark the opening week of the season beginning Nov. 21.

Secretary Perkins predicted here tonight that the next great step in industrial management in this country would be made by management and labor working together in the conscious development of scientific methods of stabilizing both production and work in industry.
The House will have four women members in the next session, or one less than in the last Congress.

Many headaches of liquor advertisers may be eliminated and the cost of preparing copy, window displays and others aids reduced considerably, if a plan now under consideration by various State authorities is accepted, it was learned here yesterday.

Led by President Roosevelt, the American people, on the twentieth anniversary of the armistice, will pay tirbute tomorrow to the nation's war dead. From early in the morning until sunset, individuals and organizations will lay wreaths and flowers on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

H. P. Metcalf's High Velocity, which won a Grade C handicap yesterday, came right back today and added another stunning surprise to the long list at the Pimlico meeting by capturing the first running of The Grayson, a mile-and-a-half stake named in memory of Admiral Cary T. Grayson.
Science and personal observation clashed today over the reported presence of an iceberg in tropical waters 900 miles west of Honolulu.
Harlow W. Young of Blyth, Bonner Kimbley, has been elected to membership in the Commodity Exchange.

Designed as a demonstration of the commercial vehicle's usefulness in the life of the nation, the fifth annual National Motor Truck Show, largest display of its type ever assembled, will open at 10 A. M. today in Commerce Hall for a sevenday run.
With output declining less than seasonally last week, the adjusted index of lumber production rose to 72.4 from 71.6. The figure was 72.4 for the week ended Nov. 6, 1937.

Commercial loans of local banks continued downward in the week ended on Wednesday, a decline of $8,000,000 being disclosed yesterday in the weekly statement of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City. Loans to brokers and dealers,

Motion picture films are being shown in Latin America by invitation to Nazi members of German colonies under the auspices of diplomatic and consular representatives of Germany, it was disclosed here today.
Eighty delegates representing Jewish communities in all parts of the world today attended the opening meeting of the Zionist General Council, called to consider the Palestine situation.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Osborn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Conover Osborn of 277 Park Avenue, to George Jackson Pearson, son of Mrs. George J. Pearson of 510 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Pearson, took place last night in the Garden of the Ambassador.

The Dartmouth jayvees defeated the West Point junior varsity today, 13 to 7. Army scored first, when Seaman caught Frawley's pass over the goal line in the second period, and converted with a place kick.

Another chapter will be added to prep school football's blue-ribbon classic tomorrow, when Andover and Exeter meet in the annual renewal of the long-standing gridiron rivalry between the two Phillips academies.

While comparisons are difficult, for a variety of reasons, advertising linage in connection with the automobile show which opened yesterday here will be considerably skimpier this year than a year ago.

Mrs. Helena Ackert, wife Of the Rev. Winfred R. Ackert, minister He M in charge of the Knox Chapel of the Collegiate Reform Church, died fifty yesterday at her home, 352 West Forty-sixth Street, after a long ness. She was 66 years old.

A successful conversion gave Samuel J. Tilden High's football team a 13-12 victory over James Monroe yesterday before 5,000 persons at Tilden Field. The crowd is believed to have been the largest to see a football game at the field.

Funeral services for Police Lieutenant William J. Cassidy, who died in Van Wyck Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, early yesterday morning after a short illness, will be held on Monday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pasquale Baylon, 112 199th Street, St. Albans, Queens, it was announced yesterday.

Coming back with a powerful attack in the second half, the Hill School eleven today defeated Hotchkiss by 26--14. The home team scored twice in the first half only to be overwhelmed by Hill's rushing attack which brought three tallies in the third quarter and another in the last session.

Consumption of crude rubber in the United States in October amounted to 40,333 long tons, compared with 37,823 in September and 38,754 in October, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

High officialdom in the United States Army and foreign embassies was represented among the onlookers at the seventh and next to last evening performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,098,000 bales, against 1,109,000 a week ago, 1,117,000 two weeks ago, 1,120,000 three weeks ago and 781,000 a year ago; of which American 534,000 bales, against 536,000 a week ago, 552,000 two weeks ago, 547,000 three weeks ago and 335,000 a year ago.

Immediate drafting of a comprehensive plan for mobilization of the nation's industries in the event of war was urged by Bernard M. Baruch and other speakers yesterday at a reunion luncheon of former members of the War Industries Board at the Savoy Plaza Hotel. About 100 former members and guests were present.

The apartment house at 277 Park Avenue, covering the square block from Park to Lexington Avenues, Forty-seventh to Forty-eighth Streets, is 95 per cent rented, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., managing agents.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy B. Samek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Samek of 607 West End Avenue, to Leon I. Bedrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bedrick of Far Rockaway, Queens, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
The newspaper Universo reports the resignation of the Cabinet last night but says its acceptance by the President was not confirmed.

Europe's persecution of the Jews and the attempt to revive the ghetto in Germany augurs ill for the future peace of the world, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared yesterday at the Armistice Day service in the cathedral.

Scoring twice in the second period, then intercepting passes for two touchdowns in the closing quarter, Wagner gained a 24-to-0 decision over Bergen Junior College at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S. I., yesterday, with 4,000 in the stands.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chief subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, today reduced by $7 a ton the price of coke tinplate and special coated manufacturing ternes, another tin-mill product. The reduction was viewed here as a leveling off of prices in conformity with earlier decreases in sheet steel and rails;

Feminists disconsolate over election bulletins from Washington, where they will have one less Congressional Representative next session, will find more cheering news in a check of State results, not yet complete.

The American Finance Conference, at the closing session of its convention held here today, commended its special legislative committee headed by E. M. Morris, president, Associates Investments Company, for its work with the Department of Justice in connection with the negotiation of the recently filed Ford Motor and Chrysler Corporation consent decrees.

This nation is in the midst of a new industrial revolution which probably will bring a broad decentralization of population and trade, new types of communities and higher valuations for property in small towns and rural districts, Gustavus W. Dyer, Professor of Economics at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, predicted tonight at the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Commissioner Andrews's report on the unemployment caused by the Federal Wage-Hour Law is candid in its presentation of fact, but strange in its reasoning.
Richard C. Colt, a retired exporter, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after an illness of six weeks. He was 74 years old.
The texts of the radio addresses last night of former Governor Alfred E. Smith and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey denouncing the anti-Semitic riots in Germany follow:

Operators were active yesterday in the Bronx, where they disposed of apartment houses. A resale was made by Joseph Chinich, operator, who sold the fiveand-a-half-story apartment house at 50 to 60 West Tremont Avenue after owning it a few days.

C. T. Jackson won the high-overall cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday by breaking 98 out of 100 targets. In the handicap competition J. G. Forstmann, B. L. Duke and W. B. Miller returned full cards. Forstmann won the extra string.
The Middle West Corporation had higher earnings in the third quarter and the first nine months of this year than in the corresponding 1937 periods, Purcell L. Smith, president, reported today.
The annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping for the year ended on June 30, as disclosed here yesterday, struck a note of uncertainty and pessimism as to the outlook of the shipping industry.

Development and standardization for issue to troops of two new and "highly effective" weapons, one designed to combat aircraft and the other an anti-tank gun, were announced today by the War Department.

Wm. Filene's Sons Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on July 31, a consolidated net loss of $284,133 after all charges and taxes. This compared with a net deficit of $87,587 in the corresponding period in 1937. For the twelve months ended on July 31 the company had a net profit of $515,008, compared with $1,101,557 in the preceding twelve months.
The French and Belgian contingents of Internationals will leave Spain tomorrow morning for France, initiating the mass departure of the Loyalists' foreign volunteers.

The producers who turned thumbs down on Matty Zimmerman's proposal that they offer Armistice Day matinees may be interested to learn that the five shows which had matinees yesterday did what is referred to as "phenomenal" business.
Evidently the little island of Bermuda is continuing to hold its own in the fishing world, for word arrived yesterday that Harry J. Tucker had made another record.

While making it plain he was correctly reported as being a Republican, H. C. Neumann of Watchung, N. J., informed THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that he had been incorrectly listed in returns from Tuesday's elections as having been elected Mayor of Watchung, N. J.
Grant Hultberg, business manager of the board of publication of the United Lutheran Church in America, died today at his Chestnut Hill home. He was 68 years old.

James A. Horan of 47-21 Forty first Street, Long Island City, president of J. A. Horan Co., steamship agents and brokers. and a member of the Produce Exchange, died Thursday in the Park East Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 47 years old.

The Politiken, a liberal daily, says editorially today: "The Munich meeting has been described by German newspapers as a great work of peace by [Chancellor Adolf] Hitler, but events in Germany make one realize the wide gulf between the outlook of Northern and Western Europe on the one hand and of the Nazis on the other.

Since last night Jewish refugees have been pouring over Czechoslovakia's new frontier from the Sudeten areas. Many of them are seriously injured. In Louny women and children, some old and ailing, after being arrested were forced to crawl on their hands and knees across the border.
The nation's capital celebrated Armistice Day today in a more serious mood than has been evident in years before.

Cotton 14,000 bales, including 5,900 American. Limited demand in spot; prices 6 points higher. Quotations in pence: American strict good middling, 5.86; good middling, 5.51; strict middling, 5.31; middling, 5.11;

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States interpreted the election results today as the country's mandate to Congress to concern itself more with promoting recovery and re-employment and less with starting experiments.

New bond financing this week, although restricted to the tax-exempt field, reached $10,418,750 despite the interruption of business activities by two holidays. This compared with $32,443,400 placed on the market last week, and with $1,250,000 in the corresponding week last year.
Leading by 12--0 going into the final quarter, Brown's football team was beaten in the closing minutes by Holy Cross today, 14-12, after police cleared the field to enable the teams to continue play.
Two Cabinet changes were under serious consideration by President Roosevelt prior to Tuesday's elections, usually informed Democrats at the Capitol said today.

A slight improvement in his work against southpaw sparring partners was furnished by Fred Apostoli, Coast middleweight, yesterday in Stillman's Gymnasium as he continued training for his fifteen-round battle against Young Corbett 3d next Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

President Roosevelt said today that he saw no threat to liberal government in Tuesday's election returns. Nor did he expect Congress to develop a coalition conservative bloc to oppose all further New Deal legislation. It was his first public comment on the balloting.

Today's events: Sergei Rachmaninoff, piano, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; Giorgio Ciompi, violin, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Budapest String Quartet and Rosalyn Tureck, piano, Town Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; John Carroll, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.
A "clear majority" of the new House of Representatives was claimed today by Representative Joseph W. Martin to favor an investigation of relief activities by Congress.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Howell, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. Russell Blackwell Howell of Highland Park, N. J., to Charles Eliot Bell of New York took place here tonight in the Livingston Avenue Baptist Church. The Rev. C. Everard Deems performed the ceremony.
Scoring in the first, third and fourth periods, the Locust Valley Friends Academy football eleven today defeated Brooklyn Friends, 19--0, on touchdowns by Jim Kane, Steve Beers and Bill Tweedy.

Dr. and Mrs. Burnham N. Dell of Princeton gave a dance tonight at the Present Day Club in Princeton to introduce their daughter, Miss Louise Shannon Dell, and Miss Cornelia Baldwin Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Sloan, also of Princeton.

Miss Berenice D. Solomons, daughter of Bernard L. Solomons of 910 West End Avenue and the late Mrs. Solomons, was married to Milton Popper, former corporation counsel of Long Beach, L. I., yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza by the Rev. Dr. David Golovensky of Long Beach.

The French liner Normandie sails today for Havre via Southampton, Her passengers include Ahmed Abdel Latif, Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs; Tamao Sakamoto, First Secretary of the Japanese Embassy in Washington;
Gill Dobie's Boston College eleven nipped a lastquarter Boston University uprising today and won, 21 to 14, to protect its unbeaten record before 12,000 football fans.

Displaying the power which had been expected of it since the start of the season, Coach Milt Torgan's James Madison High football team walloped Abraham Lincoln High, 31-0, in the eighth annual struggle between the Brooklyn schools at Ebbets Field yesterday.

A plan to promote the industrialization of the State of Texas was outlined here today by Governorelect W. Lee O'Daniel, whose salesmanship tactics and hillbilly band campaign gave him a sweep for the Gubernatorial nomination in the Democratic Drimarv.
In a game marred by frequent penalties, the University of Richmond and Virginia Tech battled to a scoreless tie today.

An instrument prick in a finger during an operation on a child caused the death today of Dr. Elizabeth O'Hearn of Shenandoah, Pa. Last week, in the course of a routine operation, she gashed the index finger of her left hand, the scalpel cutting through her rubber glove.

Current theories on the way the body makes use of iron for building red blood corpuscles will have to be revised soon, Dr. Paul F. Hahn, University of Rochester research fellow in chemistry and experimental pathology, told a regional meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics here today.
Dr. Albert William Crosby, wellknown orthodontist, died at his residence in this city this afternoon after an illness of eight weeks at the age of 68.

Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the Congressional committee investigating un-American activities, stated today that he would seek an additional appropriation of $200,000 to $300,000 to extend the inquiry for another two years.
Ward's Automotive Reports said today that automobile production this week totaled 86,300 units, making the first time this year that output exceeded the comparable period of 1937.

In a battle that must have shot the blood pressure of some 25,000 spectators up to the bursting point, New York University upset Colgate, 13 to 7, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, and Violet supporters still have not swallowed the lumps in their throats.
Thousands of persons thronged the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday to see a display of the new 1939 automobiles manufactured by the General Motors Corporation.

The marriage of Miss Joan Ketcham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Atherton Ketcham of this city, to DeWitt Clinton Howell Jr., son of Mrs. Ethel Barnum Howell of Pelham, took place here this evening in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. McGregor performed the ceremony.

With Mayor La Guardia and representatives of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps as honor guests the New York County division of the American Legion gave last night its annual Armistice Day Ball at the Manhattan Opera House, the proceeds of which go to its county welfare fund.
To the general public the arched tail of the gaited show horse is the mark of a good breed. Actually it is the result of a surgical operation simple enough in itself but followed by torture.

Britons of all walks of life expressed during the last twenty-four hours intense resentment at the excesses committed in Germany upon the Jewish population in revenge for the murder of a German diplomat in Paris.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 5 amounted to 673,333 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.
Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that busniess had started an upward swing.

Sergius Martin Riis, the American whose five-masted schooner is now being held in Koenigsberg, Germany, declared last night in an interview at the Woodrow Hotel, 35 West Sixty-fourth Street, that the situation had been misrepresented by German newspapers.

Southampton annexed the mythical football championship of Suffolk high schools when it defeated Patchogue, 20-6, today. The winners ran rings around the Red and Black in the first quarter, scoring two touchdowns with the Statue of Liberty play.

Nearly 1,000 persons who had been invited to "swing and sway on roller skates" did so and otherwise made merry last night at the third annual "Carnival on Wheels," benefit skating party at the Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fifty-fifth street.

A minimum hourly wage of 35 cents and a minimum weekly wage of $14 for forty hours' work will become effective on Monday for 6,400 women and minors employed in the candy industry in this State under an order issued yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner.
The American Philatelic Congress opened a two-day program here today with 400 stamp enthusiasts in attendance.
Funeral services for Ernst vom Rath, German diplomat who was slain here by a young Polish Jew, will be held tomorrow in the German Lutheran Church,

Woodmere Academy's football team won its third game in four Metropolitan Private School Association starts by defeating Staten Island Academy, 13-0, at the victors' field today. Rogers Wolbarst was responsible for the Woodmere touchdowns, .passing 10 yards to Joe Kaufman and 25 yards to Harvey Robbins.

An imposing military parade marked today the twentieth anniversary of Poland's rebirth. Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz, inspector general of the army, reviewed the troops, as President Ignaz Moscicki was absent in the newly acquired Province of Teschen, formerly part of Czechoslovakia.
As a salute of 101 guns thundered, General Ismet Inonu was unanimously elected by the National Assembly today to succeed Kemal Ataturk as President of Turkey.

Former President Herbert Hoover, in an Armistice Day speech here, said that "to be respected is the first step to our peace in a dangerous world." "But what we must want," he added, "what we must arm for, is not war, but peace. Ours should be armament for defense, not aggression."
Injured Tuesday night when he fell on a sculptor's chisel in his studio here, Corydon Hine, 25 years old, a sculptor, was in serious condition today in the Dobbs Ferry Hospital.

Held off for three periods by a foe whose courage was little less than heroic, the Brooklyn Poly Prep eleven succeeded in whipping across a touchdown in the fourth session to earn a 6-to-6 tie with St. Paul's School today in the twenty-ninth renewal of a series which started in 1892.

The new Mercury 8, latest product of the Ford Motor Company, occupied the spotlight yesterday at the opening of the special showing of 1939 models of that corporation in its own building, 1,710 Broadway, at Fifty-fourth Street.

One hundred horsemen from nineteen States and one foreign country meeting here in a three-day conference, tonight called for the consolidation of the five principal harness horse racing organizations of the country into a single governing body by Jan. 1.
Military rites were merged yesterday with religious services in two instances, which were expected to set precedents for Armistice Day observances.

A large American petroleum company has received from the Danish Government an exclusive ten-year concession to explore and develop petroleum products from Danish soil, the Department of Commerce reports.

The football rivalry between Peddie and Blair Academy passed its thirty-sixth milestone on Annenberg Field today, and there wasn't a point scored by either team to thrill the homecoming gathering of 5,000.

Undefeated and untied Dartmouth, with high hopes of capturing Eastern Ivy League football honors, meets the last and possibly the most difficult obstacle in that quest tomorrow when the Indians face Cornell before a capacity crowd of close to 30,000 at Schoellkopf Field.

The sectional tournament of the Northeast Field Hockey Association began today on the Wellesley College fields under the auspices of the Boston Field Hockey Association. Final selection of the 1938 AllNortheast first and reserve squads will climax the round-robin series.

Peter Rudnick, 40 years old, of 128 East Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn, an employee of the Atlas Lathing Corporation, 815 Broadway, Brooklyn, was held up yesterday by an'unidentified thug and robbed of a $2,400 payroll he was delivering to employes of his company in various parts of the, borough.

Republican forces in Congress came through Tuesday's election without the loss of a seat. Veteran officials here said today, that as far as they were able to determine, the record was unique for a major party.

Safety campaigns to reduce the hazards of automobile traffic on streets and highways have become as much a part of the public health service as sanitation work and the quarantine sign that warns of contagious disease, William J. Cameron, public relations director of the Ford Motor Company, told about 200 members of the Automotive Safety Foundation yesterday at its annual luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.
The big guns of Admiral Farragut Naval Academy brought down the La Salle Military Academy, 15-0, in the schoolboy prototype of the ArmyNavy football game in Ruppert Stadium today.

War Admiral, the stout little son of Man o' War, attempts a comeback here tomorrow. Making his first start since his defeat by Seabiscuit in a match race, the Admiral races an eighthorse field in the $10,000 added Rhode Island Handicap at Narragansett Park.
The Teachers College of Connecticut football team defeated Montclair (N. J.) Teachers College today, 12 to 6.

Minturn de Suzzara Verdi of this city and Syosset, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Patricia de Suzzara Verdi, to Arthur Freeborn Chace Jr., son of Dr. and-Mrs. Chace of New York.
Fred H. Baldwin, a civil and chemical engineer, died here today at his home, 77 Beverly Road, after an illness of two months. He was 80 years old.

A hard-driving Catholic University eleven today defeated Miami (Fla.) University, 7 to 0. Catholic made the only score of the game in the second period. Miami drove deep into Catholic territory in the first and final periods, but never was able to summon enough punch for a touchdown.

The Lawrence High School football team tonight extended its undefeated string to twenty-two games, made over a three-year period, when it outfought and outplayed a heavier Quincy (Mass.) High School squad, 13 to 0, before 8,000 fans at Horn Memorial Stadium. Bob Pearsall, Lawrence left end, accounted for both his team's touchdowns on end-around plays.

John J. Denning of Lynbrook, L. I., died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital here after an illness of five weeks. He was 57 years old. Mr. Denning, who was born in Ireland, had lived in Lynbrook for sixteen years and was engaged in the jewelry business there.

The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union ended its affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization today and refused to send delegates next week to the C. I. O. convention at Pittsburgh, where a permanent organization will be formed.
An injury-ridden Fordham football team will oppose the University of North Carolipa at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, starting at 2 o'clock.
It is twenty-two years since Montana sent to the House of Representatives its first woman member, Miss Jeanette Rankin. The Federal Suffrage Amendment became effective on Aug. 26, 1920.
The Rev. Dr. W. Theodore Taylor will observe tomorrow the fifth anniversary of his pastorate at the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
The Duke of Windsor and--perhaps more important--the Duchess of Windsor had today their first publicly confirmed meeting with two other members of the British royal family since Edward's abdication.
Fewer deer have been shot in New York's forests this Fall than in several recent years, indicating a total kill considerably below the average 8,000, the Conservation Department said today.

Jamil Bey Beyhum, a wealthy landowner of Beirut, Syria, arrived yesterday on the HamburgAmerican liner New York, accompanied by E. A. Ghory, secretary of the Palestine Arab party, who took a Master of Arts degree at the University of Cincinnati in 1933.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was one of the speakers today before 200 members of the New York State Association of Deans which is holding its annual meeting at Union College.

The first meeting of the Federation of Puerto Rican Societies, which represents twenty-nine social and civic Puerto Rican organizations and 200,000 persons, was held yesterday at the headquarters of the Puerto Rican Employes Association, 2,163 Eighth Avenue.

Offering will be made today by the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, the Northern Trust Company, the First Boston Corporation and Stix Co. of a new issue of $1,052,000 city of University City, Mo., 2 1/4 per cent public improvement bonds, dated Nov. 15, 1938, and maturing serially from Feb. 1, 1944 to 1958.

Irving School's eleven defeated Horace Mann of New York, 3--0, today when Steve McClave dropkicked a field goal late in the final period. A fumble by Horace Mann on its own 20 and a 15-yard penalty set up the score that decided the contest.

Joe Beaton and Gardner Holmes, substitute halfback and end, respectively, were the stars today as Northeastern University trounced Upsala College's eleven at Ashland Stadium, 13 to 7, before 5,000 spectators.
Officials of this city made public today their tentative 1939 budget, calling for expenditures of $8,527,890 and a net tax levy of $5,789,295.

Secretary Wallace has made a detailed arithmetical analysis of the election by belts. In the Corn Belt the Democrats went down nearly 50 per cent, while the Republicans grew threefold. In the Wheat Belt the Republicans went up 50 per cent.
Chinese porcelains and jades, Japanese lacquers and sword mounts brought $13,710 at auction yesterday afternoon at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc.

Traffic was impeded in Times Square yesterday while hundreds of persons lining the curbstones stood bareheaded at a memorial service for the Rev. Francis P. Duffy, the "fighting priest," who was chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Regiment (the Fighting Irish) during the World War.

Chancellor Josiah 0. Wolcott, the highest judicial officer of Delaware's Supreme Court, a former United States Senator and former Attorney General of Delaware, died suddenly at his home today after his return from a fox hunt with Associate Judge W. W. Harrington and others in West Dover. His age was 61.

United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels called at noon today at the Mexican Foreign Office to receive a signed copy of the Mexican note accepting the conditions agreed upon by Washington and Mexico City for settlement of the land indemnities problem, involving more than $10,000,000 in claims.
Maximilian Heinrich von Schinckel, former chairman of the board of the Hamburg-American Line, died today at the age of 89.
