John Cain, former Glen Cove High ace, was clocked at 19:48 in winning the Brooklyn Edison Club's tenth annual three-and-one-half-mile road run around Prospect Park yesterday.

William F. Johnson, who until his retirement last Jan. 1 had been for twenty-four years a member of the staff of the Children's Aid Society of New York, died at his home here yesterday after a year's illness. He was 61 years old.
H. Clay Miller, vice president of a Baltimore drygoods firm, died at Pimlico today just after the third race. st after the third race.

Annual meeting of the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History, American Museum of Natural History, 10 A. M. and noon. Meeting at the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street, 1 P. M. Meeting at the Harlem Art Center, 290 Lenox Avenue, 8 P. M.

Oceanside High School's football team continued undefeated and untied in six games this season by conquering Long Beach, 34--19, today. Oceanside ran up a 27-0 lead before Long Beach could score. Interference with a receiver gave Long Beach a first down on the Oceanside 1-yard mark and Abe Weinberg plunged over the goal line on the first play.
Mrs. Howard Bruce, wife of the Democratic National Committeeman from Maryland, was seriously injured today when her horse fell dead while she was riding to hounds on the estate of W. Plunket Stewart.

The following are some of the books of a religious nature that have been published recently: CHRISTIANITY AND ECONOMICS, by Sir Josiah Stamp. (Macmillan, $2.) An account of the economic world in which Christ lived and of how it influenced what He said.

Investment deals formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday, when houses in scattered sections passed to new control. Some of the properties were sold for cash. Plans for remodeling were announced in connection with a few of the sales.
Waldo Cory Johnston, agent of the Clark Estates since 1914, died today at his home here of a heart attack. He was 55 years old. Born in Cooperstown, he attended Hill School and Yale University.

Over all Britain, which was brushed by the wings of war last September, two minutes of silence fell at 11 o'clock today in remembrance of the million and a quarter empire dead in the war that ended twenty years ago.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I resent the implication that Notre Dame took unfair advantage of Army by making frequent substitutions. Notre Dame does not substitute because it likes to or to obtain any advantage, but solely because of its exacting schedule.

Industry can and will make the hour and wage adjustments required by the sweep of technological improvements and labor-saving machinery, Dr. C. C. Furnas of Yale said today at the closing session of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

Federal agents and Boston police hunted today a roll of sound movie films showing and describing naval secrets, including gunnery data, combat tactics, details of ship construction and manoeuvre plans. Timothy A.

That rarest of voices, a true contralto, even in scale throughout its entire compass, is the enviable possession of Georgia Graves, who gave a song recital before an appreciative audience yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

Women's colleges are failing to prepare their students for present society by disregarding modern problems and intellectual accomplishments and refusing to adopt enlightened curricula, Dr. Clyde M. Hill, chairman of the Graduate Department of Education at Yale University, said yesterday in exercises marking the eighty-fourth anniversary of Packer Collegiate Institute.
A Baylor thunderstorm broke over the luckless heads of Loyola today and drowned the Lions under a 35-to-2 deluge.

Wesleyan University celebrated Armistice Day by placing on exhibition a collection of about thirty prints and drawings dealing with the World War by Kerr Eby, artist and veteran. Mr. Eby brought back from the war some little odd scraps of paper bearing his sketches done at the front.

Edmond Beardsley, former chief clerk of the accounting and auditing division of the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, died here on Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Harold N. Wilson. He was 84 years old.

Taking advantage of the holiday and fine weather, more than 20,000 persons visited the thirty-first annual Autumn flower show yesterday of the Horticultural Society of New York at the American Museum of Natural History.

Fine performances in the water and on land gave Chesdel Joe, owned by M. A. Spear of Camden, Del., an easy victory today in the novice stage which opened the American Chesapeake Club's annual three-day Fall field trials at Penniman's Point.

The stock markets here again were firm today and business showed a further small expansion. Domestic industrials continued to lead in the trading. Steel and aircraft issues were especially prominent on a rise in the output of steel and an increase in estimates for the air force.

Duke's undefeated, untied and unscored upon Blue Devils, possible Rose Bowl nominees, ruled 1-to-2 favorites over Syracuse on the eve of their intersectional game tomorrow. About 20,000 are expected to witness the first game between the two universities.

This week enjoys the curious distinction of being the first in our history in which two holidays have occurred in a single week. The reason is that the election-day holiday, which is fixed by law for the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November, fell this year at the latest date possible under that arrangement, and Nov. 8 was numbered in the same week as Armistice Day, Nov. 11.

Gordon S. Ferris, a member of the circulation department of the Crowell Publishing Company and former Columbia University athlete, died here today in the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 34 years old.
Commodore Thomas D. Griffin, United States Navy, retired, one of the few remaining commodores, died this morning at the Military Hospital at Annapolis at the age of 83.

German spokesmen yesterday openly sanctioned Thursday's anti-Semitic wave of terrorism, but denied it was organized. It was called a "spontaneous reaction" to the murder of Ernst vom Rath. German diplomat, in Paris.

A hope that visitors from other countries to the World's Fair would take back an impression of a country living at peace with its neighbors and itself, racially and religiously tolerant, was expressed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address at the Armistice Day dedication of the Court of Peace on the fair grounds.

IT may be true that neither Japan nor Germany I nor any other nation or any combination of nations would ever in this world dream of touching anything anywhere that belongs to the United States. George Fielding Eliot devoutly hopes so.

John Corcoran, 18 years old, of 39-43 Fiftieth Avenue, Long Island City, was killed at 11 o'clock last night when an automobile he was driving on Borden Avenue at Jay Avenue in Maspeth, Queens, jumped the curb, hurtled into a vacant lot and crashed against three boulders. One of three companions, Thomas O'Grady, 16, of 47-38 Forty-eighth Street, Long Island City, suffered two broken ribs.
Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire sailed on the Grace liner Santa Elena yesterday for what he described as a needed rest.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. John M. Bierer of Waban, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Elizabeth Bierer, to John B. Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ward of Ridgewood. N. J.

Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York is one of the five additional delegates elected today by the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church to represent the denomination at the conference in Kansas City April 26 at which the three branches of Methodism will be united.
Still strongly, under the influence of recent events that have made peace seem precarious, the French today celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the armistice with particular fervor.
Somewhat cooler weather favored Armistice Day sales here yesterday, but the sales volume in general did not quite measure up to expectations, store executives reported yesterday.

Staging a rally after trailing, 7 to O, late in the second half, Providence College defeated Rhode Island State in their annual football game tonight, 19 to 7, before a holiday crowd of 13,000 at the Cranston Stadium.
The actors went through the dress rehearsal today for the sixty-second production tomorrow of a drama that had its first performance 65 years ago-the Yale-Princeton football game.

Raymond E. Willis, Republican candidate for Senator in Tuesday's election, signed petitions tonight for a Federal court investigation of charges that frauds turned the tide of victory away from Indiana Republicans.

Nearly all branches of the wholesale market recorded gains this week over the previous week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary. Chief advances were in goods for Christmas selling,
Texas Tech's Red Raiders successfully protected their untied, undefeated record today with a 7-to-0 victory over the Gonzaga Bulldogs.

About 250 employes of the Bigelow Sanford Carpet Company walked out today in protest against What they said was the refusal of the management to reinstate a worker laid off one week for collecting union dues on company time.
A small bomb, scheduled to be used as a signal to halt an Armistice Day parade for a moment of prayer, exploded on a street corner here today, injuring several persons.
Led by the Misses Janet Runcie, Betty Karr and Henrietta Rasweiler, the Hofstra College field hockey team repulsed an invading New York University eleven, 3-0, today on the Hofstra campus.
In a fine southwest breeze and just lively water, about perfect conditions for the small raft, eighteen dinghies were out today for the third Winter regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.
A letter received by the Mayor of Windsor from the King's private secretary announces that his Majesty has decided to give to the corporation of Windsor eighty acres of land adjoining Windsor castle.

George Edwin Parmenter, president and a director of the American Crayon Company of Sandusky, Ohio, died yesterday at Indian Neck, his estate at Branford, Conn., after a month's illness, at the age of 77. His New York home was the Hotel Astor.
Assistant District Attorney Samuel Goldstein of Brooklyn was severely injured yesterday afternoon by a truck at Franklin and De Kalb Avenues, Brooklyn, after stepping from a street car.

A Bradley filly and a Maryland-bred and owned juvenile were running a photo finish tonight in pre-race talk of the Pimlico Futurity tomorrow, the richest stake of the Fall meeting and one of the country's major prizes for 2-year-olds.

Beginning tomorrow night with the fourth round, a series of four consecutive sessions of the A. V. R. O. international chess masters' tournament will be held at Groningen, Zwolle, Haarlem and in this city without stops for adjourned games.

Colby College racked up all its points in the last half to beat Bates by 21-13 today and tie with Bowdoin for the State title. Art Beliveau's 39-yard run for a Bates touchdown on a fake pass play was the day's feature. The passing and running of Johnny Daggett, haflback, paved the way for Colby's success.
The Rev. George Herbert Dennison, former rector of St. Timothy's Protestant Episcopal Church, Roxborough, died after a long illness today in his home here. His age was 69.

Reminiscences of canteen service in France in the World War, of nursing the wounded, entertaining soldiers on leave and other activities of women in war-time were exchanged yesterday by 200 members of the Women's Overseas Service League at their annual breakfast in the Prince George Hotel.
It was announced here this morning that the second South American conference of insurance companies will begin on Nov. 27 and continue until Dec. 4.
Brooklyn College, hampered throughout the game by injuries, lost to Ithaca College, 20-0, in their inaugural game today.

Dartmouth and Cornell in the East, Notre Dame and Minnesota in the Middle West, Tennessee and Vanderbilt in the South and Southern California and Washington on the Pacific Coast are the stand-out pairings on today's football program, with Santa Clara and St. Mary's headed for another big collision tomorrow.

California passed its intelligence test on health and medicine by defeating by 60,000 votes the humane pound referendum proposition No. 2, one of the twenty-five put before the people in Tuesday's election.

The following reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area are assigned to units as indicated: 513th Coast Artillery (AA)-2d Lt. Stephen H. Randolph CA.-Res., 410 W. Dominick St., Rome, N. Y. 389th Infantry-2d Lt. Elliott B. Cheston, Inf.-Res., 125 Manning Blvd., Albany, N. Y. 2d Lt. Wendell M. Knain, Inf.Res., Y.M.C.A, 13 State St., Schenectady, N. Y.
Argentina won the fourth PanAmerican boxing tournament, which ended tonight, after taking six of the eight individual titles and sharing another with Chile.
Two touchdowns by Ozzie Nelson within three minutes in the second quarter staked the Trenton Teachers to a 12-0 victory over Panzer today.

Members of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate, called off yesterday their eleven-week-old strike against the Aerovox Corporation, manufacturers of radio condensers, as the concern dismantled its plant at 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, and completed preparation for moving to New Bedford, Mass.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some features of the 1938 election seem especially significant to observers not interested primarily in political parties or personalities or in issues cooked up for campaign purposes. After the tumult and the shouting die I expect these will receive more attention.
A daughter was born Thursday at the French Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brietal of 708 West 192d Street.
A committee of Western Union messengers presented a list of specific grievances to company officials yesterday and received assurance that two of the conditions they complained of would be corrected.

The program of uniform standards of banking supervision announced by the Federal banking authorities in Washington last June has been adopted by twenty-seven States thus far, the executive committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks reported today at its convention here.

Expansion of the business of Midtown Chevrolet, Inc., was announced yesterday by Frederick Miller, president, who has leased for the purpose the six-story building at 1,920-26 Broadway, corner of Sixtv-fourth Street.

Egbert Moxham Jr. scored his usual victory in Class B in the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet's regatta today. Finishing second to his father in the first race, he took every one of the five sailed thereafter, to gain a 2 point lead on the elder Moxham in the championship scoring for the day.

Members of the Whiffenpoofs, Yale singing club, gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Among the guests were many Yale alumni, also the Misses Elizabeth Watson, Barbara Gray, Ariel Bryce, Mary Eddy, Patricia Johnston, Barbara Spadone, Barbara Evans, 'Ann Semler and Martha-Charrington.

A plan designed to permit complete dealer participation in sales of Electrolux gas refrigerators has been submitted by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., distributor for Servel Electrolux, to its cooperating dealers.
Dr. Walter R. Pettit of 1,819 Avenue K, Brooklyn, a practicing physician in that borough for thirty-seven years, died early yesterday morning at the age of 66.

In New York for the annual automobile show which opened yesterday, Harry J. Klingler, general manager of Pontiac Motors division of General Motors, said yesterday that his company again had revised its schedules of 1939 car production upward.

While results of the election day and Armistice Day sales were only fair, retail trade this week bettered its comparative showing somewhat. The decline for the week in department store sales was put at about 8 per cent, against more than 11 per cent for the previous week.

James Shewan of New York and Strathmore, Southampton, L. I., now a student at Cambridge University, England, has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Patricia Carrington Shewan, to Edgar L. Newhouse 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Newhouse Jr. of 983 Park Avenue.
The award of the Nobel Prize in literature to Pearl Buck has caused several caustic criticisms by Swedish authors and critics. Some pour scorn on the Swedish Academy.

Holders of Edificio la Metropolitana S. A. first mortgage sinkingfund gold bonds due on Jan. 1, 1945, have been notified by the National City Bank of New York, as trustee, that an interest distribution of $30 for each $1,000 bond, less 2 per cent public-works tax, will be made on Nov. 15 upon presentation of July 1, 1931, coupons.

Secretary Hull in a message to the "Good Will Congress" of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches here tonight praised the congress for its stand on promoting world peace by stressing international economic cooperation.
William J. McGowan bought for occupancy from the Home Owners Loan Corporation the one-family house at 85-36 152d Street, Jamaica, Queens, through Bulkley Horton Company, brokers.
The twentieth anniversary of the end of the World War was commemorated yesterday throughout a world arming for a new conflict yet not wholly despairing of a new peace.

In what has been until now real secrecy, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud has during the past ten days prepared his plan of financial and economic reform and tomorrow he intends to submit it to the full Cabinet, announce its contents in the evening and publish the decrees that he considers necessary Sunday morning.

Air Minister Sir Kingsley Wood told the House of Commons today that the government was planning to take over Britain's two major civil air lines, Imperial Airways and British Airways, and fuse them into a single corporation.

Charles E. Hatfield, widely known banker, one-time Republican leader, a friend of the late President Coolidge, and former Mayor of Newton, died at his home in West Newton last night in his seventy-sixth year.

The Oklahoma Aggies, on the short end of the score for six straight week-ends, beat the Oklahoma City University's Goldbugs, 19 to 12, today in a non-conference football contest before 3,000 homecoming fans.

Although 15,000 Nazi votes and energetic action by the Nazi party were considered decisive factors in the Popular Front victory in the Presidential election Oct. 25-definite confirmation of which is still pending-Socialist masses are celebrating the event as now a triumph over what is called "Right-wing Fascism."
The government's projected two-price program got off to a good start today at a formal conference between Secretary Wallace and Agriculture Department officials, on the one hand,

Miss Marion Isabel Gibbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Gibbs of 45 East Eighty-fifth Street and Woodcliff Lakes, N. J., was married to George Freeman Galland of this city yesterday afternoon at the home here of her parents. The Rev.

President Roosevelt and Colonel Fulgencio Batista met today for the first time. The Cuban Chief of Staff and leading political figure of his country, like almost all other foreigners who see the President for the first time, capitulated to his charm and left the White House chanting his praises.
Thomas Jefferson High School teams of Brooklyn and Elizabeth clashed today with the honors going to the visitors. The score was 25-0.
From The Tribune What is especially significant is that the supposedly all-powerful government has permitted an irresponsible mob to break loose and run riot contrary to law and order.

The Fort Jay football team conquered its traditional rival, Fort Totten, 27-12, on Foley Field today in an Eastern Corps Area elimination game before 3,000 fans. Fort Jay now will play Fort Hamilton for the Eastern championship.

Seton Hall Prep retained the national Catholic prep school crosscountry championship by taking the annual run sponsored by Seton Hall College today. With Coach Harry Coates's team figured a sure winner, there were only five entrants including two Seton Hall teams.
Mary Mallon, the first carrier of typhoid bacilli identified in America and consequently known as Typhoid Mary, died yesterday in Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island.

Charles A. Sumner of Kansas City, secretary of the International Stereotypers' and Electrotypers' Union, announced here today that a run-off election would be held to determine the union's new president.

Post-Armistice Day sermons will be delivered by many clergymen tomorrow and a number of special Armistice services will be held for World Var veterans. Comment will be made in some pulpits on the outcome of last Tuesday's election.
Commenting on modern methods of trying out automobile models, David A. Wallace, president of the Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation, stressed the value of new checking machines.

Miss Jean Margaret Sherwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Sherwood of Yonkers, N. Y., was married to Walter Bennett Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lewis of Englewood, N. J., here yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

James C. Ottipoby, a Comanche Indian, will be ordained to the ministry of the Reformed Church in America on Tuesday evening at 7:30 o'clock in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

It is difficult to write calmly about what has happened in Germany. It is especially difficult for one who has watched the German people in the dark days of revolution and hunger they have endured since the war, who has seen close the hopelessness of the "littie men" described in the novels written in by Hans Fallada and has tried to understand what otherwise would be incomprehensible:

Coming through at the eleventh hour, just as he did on Thursday, Lieutenant Ramiro Palafox last night won the international individual military championship at the fifty-third National Horse show in Madison Square Garden.
Curtis Giddings, N. Y. U. crosscountry star, paced his team to a 16-to-39 victory over Colgate yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. It was the fourth triumph in five starts for the Violet.

Against the background of ornamental draperies, lilting music and newly cut chrysanthemums, the thirty-ninth annual National Automobile Show opened yesterday afternoon in Grand Central Palace before the largest opening day attendance since the boom days of the late Nineteen Twenties.

Mediation of the Sino-Japanese conflict is out of the question despite King George's well-intentioned offer in his speech from the throne Tuesday, according to Yosuke Matsuoka, president of the South Manchuria Railway, who has been many times prominently mentioned as possible Japanese Foreign Minister.

The twenty-second annual membership Roll Call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross was started yesterday. On prominent buildings throughout the city 550 Red Cross flags were hoisted, while 1,600 special window displays were unveiled at stores.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey joined with former Governor Alfred E. Smith and other public men last night in a broadcast of protest against the anti-Semitic riots in Germany and appealed to world opinion to halt "the savagery of barbarism" which he declared inspired "the bloody pogrom."

John J. (Bathhouse John) Coughlin, Alderman of the First Ward here since 1892, died today in the Mercy Hospital at the age of 78. He had been taken to the hospital yesterday afternoon and placed under an oxygen tent after being stricken with pneumonia in his room at the New Michigan Hotel.

News of their mother's death last night was withheld from Charles and Frank Geiger, players on the La Salle Military Academy football team, until after the game this afternoon between the La Salle and Admiral Farragut Academy teams in Ruppert Stadium here.

Lightweight football teams of Rutgers and Yale battled to a 0-0 tie at the Hinchliffe Stadium today. Rutgers had the advantage in ground gained but failed to capitalize on scoring opportunities from the 3 and 15-yard lines.
The stirring strains of "Anchors Aweigh" will be wafted over Baker Field today as Navy mixes with Columbia in the ninth game of a series dating back to 1901.

With appropriate ceremonies, the thirty-eighth annual automobile show threw open the doors at Convention Hall today. Three hundred cars are on display, and the opening crowd filled the aisles to capacity.

Taking little note of Harvard's seven previous victories over Vir ginia, Coach Dick Harlow today primed his Crimson squad for tomorrow's attack on what, his scouts reported to be the best Cavalier team in years.

St. Vincent opened its long-range scoring guns in two periods today to trample West Vriginia Wesleyan, 27 to 0. Strosser, substitute halfback, raced around left end for 65 yards to open the scoring early in the second quarter, and Seni, fullback, and Baran, reserve halfback, recorded three rapid-fire touchdowns for the visitors in the last stanza.

Prospects of an uncontrolled citrus shipping market confronted growers today when it was announced that the California-Arizona Citrus Growers' Agreement, by which crop marketing has been regulated on a prorate- basis for the last five years comes to an end tomorrow.
The Amherst cross-country team sprung a surprise in the Little Three championship meet today by gaining a tie with Wesleyan at 36 points. Williams trailed with 48.

Whether or not Frank A. Theis of Kansas City, Mo., succeeds in selling United States wheat to Brazil he is "persona prominent" in Rio de Janeiro and has made the front page in most of the leading afternoon newspapers.

Battling their way over the walls by moonlight, Japanese troops last night entered Yochow, strategic city midway between Wuchang and Changsha, commanding the approach to Tung Ting Lake from the Yangtze River, according to Domei, the Japanese news agency.

Ferdinand Hepperle, 46 years old, a German-American war veteran, who is a naturalized citizen, and conducts a one-man printing shop here, was at liberty today on $3,000 bail as the printer of a widely circularized sticker caricaturing Jews and bearing the slogan, "Vote Gentile, Buy Gentile."

In the last practice of the year, Amherst's varsity football players today jogged through their assignments in preparation for the Williams game here tomorrow. A crowd of 12,000 is expected for the final Little Three contest of the year with Amherst out for an undefeated season and its third straight triumph over the Purple.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace Green of King's Point, Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Green, to Alvah Woodbury Sulloway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Jones Sulloway of Concord, N. H.
City College will start a radically reorganized line-up against Moravian College at the Lewisohn Stadium this afternoon when the Lavender concludes its 1938 football
Victor Moore, actor; through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. in 115 Central Park West; The Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Walter O'Keefe, radio artist, in Hotel Ambassador.
Lowell Textile brought its 1938 gridiron season to a close today with a 25-to-0 victory over American International College of Springfield.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $42,228,850, to be represented by two States and eighty-seven municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $14,956,241 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date stands at $23,800,494.

Gratitude for peace was expressed yesterday at the Armistice Day luncheon of the Canadian Club in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The principal speakers were Godfrey Haggard, newly appointed British Consul General in New York, and Ian Mackenzie, Canadian Minister of National Defense.

Veterans of the allied armies, wearing their wartime uniforms, commemorated the twentieth anniversary of the signing of the Armistice ending the World War at the annual Armistice ball of the British Great War Veterans of America last night at the Hotel Astor.

President Roosevelt stressed the need for educational radio programs in a message read last night at the three-hour dedication ceremonies which were broadcast in connection with the opening of station WEVD's new studios at 117 West Forty-sixth Street. WEVD was founded in 1927 by the Eugene V. Debs Memorial Fund.
J. H. Oatis, 60 years old, of 32 Morris Street, Everett, Mass., died of a heart attack in his room at the Times Square Hotel, 255 West Forty-third Street, at 12:30 o'clock this morning.
John Knox has resigned as general merchandise manager of John Wanamaker, Philadelphia, according to announcement yesterday. The resignation is effective Jan. 1.

The seeded list in the Eastern Association open Fall squash racquets tournament was broken into for the first time as F. B. Alexander Jr., unranked entry of the University Club, conquered Ralph Sleicher, Midston House star and rated third, yesterday in a. thirdround contest at the New York Athletic Club. The score was 13-15, 18-16, 15-5, 15-12.

The establishment of a revolving fund for the development of tested children who show that they possess high intelligence would be a step toward providing the country with needed leaders and "a new thing under the sun," Professor Leta S. Hollingworth told the Fifth Conference on Education Policies at Teachers College, Columbia University, yesterday.
Cotton-mill activity increased more than seasonably last week and the adjusted index rose to 115.8 from 113.3. The figure for the week ended Nov. 6, 1937, was 103.4.

Miss Nancy Bogue, daughter of Perry D. Bogue of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Josephine Ward Bogue, was married to William Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Townsend, also of Greenwich, this afternoon at the home of the bride. The Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson, rector of Christ Episcopal Church here. officiated.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Van Schaick Mitchell entertained at a double debut dance tonight at Pennbrook House for their daughter, Miss Sylvia Mitchell, and for Miss Nancy Abbott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Abbott of New York.
The second annual Beaux Arts Ball, which more than sixty Barnard College undergraduates and their escorts attended, was held last night in Brooks Hall on the campus.
Clinching the decision with a twotouchdown attack in the third pe riod, the Scarborough School eleven gained a 19-to-7 triumph over the Columbia University freshmen B team at Baker Field yesterday.
The Georgia Court of Appeals went back to the Eve and the apple episode for precedent yesterday to reject a plea based on a charge that officers trapped a man into lawbreaking.

The City Planning Commission has added its weight to the axiom that the way to clear slums is to replace bad housing with good housing. As the commission stated in the letter sent to the Mayor this week, it is time now to turn our attention. from the construction of public housing projects on cheap and unimproved outlying land and to develop such projects in the decaying slum areas.

An exhibition and sale of paintings, sculpture and graphics will open tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at the A. C. A. Gallery. It is being held for the benefit of The New Masses and is entitled "We Like America." The exhibition will continue until Nov. 27.
The press announced today that Oswald Pirow, South African Defense Minister, had accepted the German Government's invitation to visit Berlin and would arrive the middle of next week.

Repeated threats yesterday morning that the German Consulate General, at 17 Battery Place, was to be "blown up" led to the establishment of a police guard at the consulate and at the home of Johannes Borchers, German Consul General, at 55 East Seventy-seventh Street.
"Rozsa Sandor," Robert Neumann's story of Bohemia prior to the reign of Franz Joseph, was purchased today by Metro as Miliza Korjus's second American film.
The president of the Jewish community here was informed today by the head of the secret police that the order to Jews to leave the city had been rescinded.
AMHERST vs. Williams-As far as the eye can see-halt! Just how far can the eye see? Well, it can see the sun and that's, roughly, 93,000,000 miles away. One visionary vote for Amherst.

Bells in all Hungarian churches were rung at 11 o'clock this morning when Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Hungarian Regent, entered Kassa, the most important center in the territory gained from Czechoslovakia.

Sales of 685 independent automotive accessory, tire and battery dealers throughout the country were off 6.3 per cent from 1937 in the first half of 1938, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, announced today.
Refusing to play the fatted calf role in Whizzer White's homecoming to his native State, Los Angeles defeated Pittsburgh, 17 to 6, in an Armistice Day game.

ACKERT--On Friday, Nov. 11, 1938, Helena (nee Van Vliet), wife of the Rev. Winfred R. Ackert, at her late residence, 352 West 46th St. Service at Knox Memorial Chapel, 405 West 41st St., on Monday morning, at 10:30 o'clock. Interment Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Kindly omit flowers.

The gloomy picture of declining United States trade in South America and the inroads of Nazi and Fascist ideologies in Latin-American countries was rejected yesterday by Dr. Leo S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, who sailed on the Grace liner Santa Barbara to attend the Pan American Congress in Lima next month.

Alfred M. Stockman of this town, founder and president of the Stockman Advertising Agency in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack which he suffered in the Cortlandt Street station of the Hudson Tubes. He was 61 years old.

The second program of the Mordkin Ballet at the Alvin Theatre last night consisted of the same two ballets with which the company made its local debut two seasons ago, namely, "Giselle" and "The Goldfish."

Inquiries by a State legislative committee and a Federal agency into the deaths of mental patients through alleged administration of wrong drugs at Rockland State Hospital, Orangeburg, and Harlem Valley State Hospital, Wingdale, which already are subjects of separate grand jury investigations, were promised yesterday.
Mrs. Franklin Chase Hoyt and her debutante daughters, the Misses Constance and Beatrix Hoyt, are at the Beekman for the season.

To add a new stimulus to the purchase of the People's auto on the installment plan, it was announced today that payments of only five marks monthly against the previous minimum of five marks weekly could now be made.
Sixteen floats and five balloons will be featured in the fourteenth annual Macy Thanksgiving Day parade, it was announced yesterday by Paul Hollister, executive vice president of the store.

Class 84, Hunters Under Saddle (not to jump)-First, U. S. Randle's ch. g. Primary; second, Sundown Stable's ch. g. Beau Joe; third, Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke's ch. g. Domir D'Or; fourth, May Top Stable's ch. g. Lord Britain.

Miss Katrine van Herwerden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jan van Herwerden, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to William McCollum Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCollum, also of Rahway, by the Rev. Gilbert F. Van Bever of the Second Presbyterian Church.
Maude Adams, famous stage actress of the last generation, paused .in her routine work as teacher of dramatics at Stephens College here today to celebrate her sixty-six birthday.

Lawrenceville's undefeated foot ball team trounced a hard fighting Haverford School eleven in its final game of the season today, 14-0. The Red and Black, led by Willoughby, drove 70 yards to a tally early in the third quarter. Willoughby scored once again in the final quarter after Ellis had intercepted a Haverford pass.
LAST NIGHTS SCORES First Game (Doubles)-Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica, South America, defeated Angel Iturrino and Jose Pradera, Basques, 20 to 14.

President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders are expected to take up the legislative program within two weeks, after preliminary consideration is given to filling vacancies on important Senate and House committees caused by Tuesday's -election.
Miss Rhetta Louise Walsh and John Emerson Asch, both of Brooklyn, were married there yesterday afternoon in the rectory of the Holy Innocents Church by the Rev. Paul M. Klohr.
William Henry Dolan, a salesman with A. G. Spalding Bros. for the last twenty-five years, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 43.

WICHITA, Kan.; Toledo, Ohio; Obion County, Tenn., and Box Elder County, Utah, have accepted the invitation of their respective State departments of education to cooperate with the Office of Education, Department of the Interior, as demonstration centers for community programs in home and family life education in the United States-the beginning of a program that is expected to develop into one of national significance. John W.

A first mortgage of $435,600 with interest at 4 1/2 per cent, maturing in 1940, has been placed with the Troy Savings Bank on the twenty-onestory office building at 269-71 Madison Avenue by Herbert L. Williams, Inc., broker.
L. Baltazzi's Ad Lib, with J. F. Harrison up, tonight was favored to win the Glenwood National and top money of the $1,000 purse at the Middleburg Hunt races tomorrow.

Facing the Eternal Light memorial to the World War dead as an Armistice Day gathering of 10,000 persons stood in Madison Square yesterday, Mayor La Guardia delivered a vigorous indictment against dictators who "murder in the guise of national policy."

Mr. and Mrs. John B. Trevor gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen and their son, John B. Trevor Jr., who will be married next Friday in St. James Church.

The only chance for world peace is in a new conference of nations to discuss the problem without reference to past experiments or present ideologies, David Lloyd George, war-time Prime Minister of Great Britain, said yesterday in the annual Armistice Day broadcast of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

If any power is determined to dominate the world "by force or fear of force," Canada must be ready to resist that power, even to the risk of war, Norman Rogers, Dominion Minister of Labor, said today.

The present rulers of Germany can have learned nothing from the doom which fell upon their predecessors twenty years ago this week. The Imperial Government, between 1914 and 1918, repeatedly outraged neutral opinion:

Major Ralph Millis, an army officer assigned as an instructor to the 104th Regiment Engineers of Teaneck, killed himself with a pistol shot in the basement of his home at 325 Marlboro Road here this evening.

Frank D. Fitzgerald, who captured the Michigan Governorship from Frank Murphy, Tuesday, told a throng at a home-town celebration tonight that his victory was the beginning of a 1940 Presidential boom for Senator Vanderberg.

LEADERS of the major radio networks, having met with Chairman Frank R. MoNinch of the Federal Communications Commission, and agreed that use of the words "flash" and "bulletin" require more discretion, quickly put the decision into practice, as revealed on election night. The less sensational word "report' was generally used.

Alfred University's strong crosscountry team defeated Army today, 17 to 38. Legasse and Rendell of Alfred led the pack home in a hands-clasped finish in 22:14, which was the best time over the Army course this year.

Dow's Theory Applied to Business and Banking: By Robert Rhea. Contends that Dow-Jones averages are not merely a record of stock market changes, but have forecast 77 per cent of the total primary changes in industrial activity. (Simon Schuster, Inc., 386 Fourth Avenue, New York, N. Y. $2.)

THE automobile empire celebrates again its might and its glory at its annual jubilee, the National Automobile Show. A young empire, still on the sunny side of 40, it hasn't yet outgrown its enthusiastic astonishment at itself. And the world, astonished no less, joins in the cheering. The world, which has seen empires rise and fall these thousands of years,
American Folk Crafts. Brooklyn Museum, to Nov. 27. Old-time weaving, patch work quilts, pottery iron work and furniture, shown with modern revivals.

The first local game of the current National Hockey League race will be played on the Madison Square Garden surface tonight when the New York Americans oppose the Boston Bruins. Although the league campaign already is ten days old, New York followers of the sport have been denied a glimpse of the game thus far, because of schedule complications.

FOR trailer owners, the Autumn and Winter months have their special appeal. One contingent, the largest, hies to Florida, where its members pay fancy parking fees to be sardined among hundreds of the same persuasion. To the other kind of trailerites these are known as "sandwichites" or "sandpappys,"

Eight persons were missing today after a fire which razed a business block in this Northern Quebec mining town. Two hotels, a garage, two stores and a half dozen small frame buildings were destroyed, with an estimated loss of $250,000.

Four hundred and twenty-five dogs were benched today at the fourth annual show of the Harrisburg Kennel Club at the State Farm Arena. The exhibition was the best of the series and drew a large crowd Lady Rowena of Rowanoaks, Bedlington terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Neary of Astoria, L. I., and the Cnoc Luing Kennels' Kerry blue terrier Bumble Bee of Delwin were listed among the winners of breed prizes.

Resolutions favoring the amendment of the Clayton act to permit interlocking directorates of banks within limits and opposing any basic changes in the powers and functions of the existing Federal bank supervisory agencies, were adopted here today at the concluding session of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

The Halstead apartments in White Plains, N. Y., originally financed by the S. W. Straus Company, has been sold by William Jackson, S. H. Scheuer and William Gray, trustees for the bondholders, to an investing client of Robert P. Smith, attorney.

Scoring in all but the first period the University of South Carolina Gamecocks piled up a 27-to-6 triumph today over their ancient State rival, Furman's Purple Hurricane, in a Southern Conference game. A crowd of 12,000 saw the game.

Rolling up the biggest point total in Benny Friedman's five - year coaching regime, City College closed its 1938 season in brilliant fashion yesterday by defeating Moravian College of Bethlehem Pa., 40 to 14. The triumph, the fourth in seven starts this year for C. C. N. Y.,
Washington and Lee showed superiority in every department to defeat William and Mary, 27-0, today. The Generals scored first in the opening period on a 79-yard run by Harrison Hogan.

Morgan College completed its fifty-fourth consecutive football game without a defeat by subduing Hampton Institute of Hampton, Va., 19 to 6, today. It was the first time the local eleven had been scored upon this season.

Senator H. Styles Bridges announced today that he would fight confirmation of Donald Wakefield Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, who has received a recess reappointment from President Roosevelt.

During the four years in which the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation has been insuring accounts, Nugent Fallon, general manager, reports that at the present time the funds of more than 2,000,000 savers and investors are now protected up to $5,000 each through the insurance facilities of that organization.

Bates College co-eds of the three under classes are hosts to nearly 100 mothers this week-end. The occasion is the third annual "Mothers' Week-end," sponsored by the Student Government Board and the Women's Athletic Association.
A play a month is the schedule of the combined dramatic activities of students at Colby College this year, according to plans announced by Professor Cecil A. Rollins, director of drama.

Amos Alonzo Stagg still rules the Midway today-Stagg and his College of the Pacific eleven. The man who went West a second time because he wouldn't quit coaching at 70 came back to the school he directed forty-one years, received "All-Time,

A plan that will provide some remedy for the condition of the south bank of the Thames between London County Hall and the new Waterloo Bridge-long the subject of protest by town-planning specialists and others-will be recommended to the London County Council at its meeting on Tuesday.
Harvey Jackson led the Toronto Maple Leafs to their second National Hockey League victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The score was 4-1.

In the second round of play in the annual Northeast Field Hockey Association tournament on the Wellesley College grounds today, the Long Island Reserves defeated the I. A. C. "B" team, 2 to 1; the Boston Reserves won from Stuyvesant's Reserves, 4 to 0; the New York Reserves downed the I. A. C. "A" team, 5 to 3; Long Island halted New York, 2 to 1, and Stuyvesant blanked Boston, 1 to 0.

Leading horsemen, meeting here in three-day conference, tonight approved committee reports advocating a non-profit organization with a twenty-one-member governing board to rule harness racing. It was probably the most far-reaching action ever taken by supporters of the sport.

Any one who plans to take up , Winter sports might want to shop p now for the trappings for skating and skiing. The shops are full of brand new woolen things from all over the world. The international upheavals in Europe have complicated importing considerably, and the alert importers have developed new sources of supply for bright peasant sweaters, caps, scarfs, gloves and mittens.

PROGRAMS have been mailed for the national championship tournament which will take place in Cleveland the week of Nov. 28. The schedule has been arranged so that the two principal events will be played at the end of the week, the open team-offour tournament beginning Thursday night and the open pair tournament occupying four sessions Saturday and Sunday.

ALTHOUGH America was discovered in 1492 by Christopher Columbus, the New World did not receive its present name until fifteen years later. The godfathers at the christening were a group of international scholars; the date was 1507;

THE features of the new 1939 cars which appeal most to safety-minded people are not their dazzling paint jobs and smart streamlines so much as their good brakes, efficient lights and reliable power plants. The coming of the new models renews interest in the problem of what to do about the millions of old cars, many of them unsafe, which fill the highways.

Student interest in photography has increased by 40 per cent on the basis of the large enrollment in the photography club of Marymount College here, it was announced today. William Freese, director of THE NEW YORK TIMES studio, is giving a series of lectures and demonstrations in the college photography studio.

The New York Stock Exchange has been informed of the proposed formation of the firm of Hartley Rogers, Lyon Co., effective on Tuesday, with offices at 14 Wall Street. Partners will be Hartley Rogers, W. Wallace Lyon, Leo B. O'Meara, member of the Exchange; E. Boudinot Fisher and as limited partners, Heber L. Hartley and Wallace Thayer.

Legislation based on the recently announced national public health program will be introduced at the forthcoming session of Congress and the Federal Government already is bringing considerable pressure to bear for its passage.

Senator Walter F. George warned the Democratic party today toconsider last Tuesday's general election a "danger sing from sober-minded American voters, calling us back to common sense in legislation."
St. Lawrence University's football team retained the championship of the north country today, defeating Clarkson, 7-0, before a crowd of 6,000, one of the largest ever to attend this classic.

Laboratory space at the Rutgers University College of Engineering will be increased by 57 per cent, according to construction plans announced today by President Robert C. Clothier. Work on the project, which is being financed jointly by the university and the WPA will start In several weeks.

ALTHOUGH the Boston Symphony Orchestra's proposed jaunt to Europe is still in the realm of the probable, present substantial activities behind the scenes suggest an early emergence into the world of reality. The organization in whose hands the project in being shaped is the French-American Art Association, with Eduard Herriot (ex-Premier of France and biographer of Beethoven) as honorary president.
Senator William H. King of Utah suggested today that the United States sever diplomatic relations with Germany as a result of the latest anti-Jewish measures adopted by the Reich.

The United States Government has made fresh representations to the Japanese Foreign Office regarding navigation rights on the Yangtze River, Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today. As far as could be gathered from his guarded reference to the matter, Ambassador Joseph Grew presented his government's views anew in Tokyo only a few days ago.

The governing and advisory boards of the Associated General Contractors of America will hold their annual Fall meeting at Excelsior Springs, Mo., Tuesday and Wednesday. More than 100 leading general contractors from all sections of the country are expected to attend.
Invited audiences of about 2,000 volunteer critics, drawn from a crosssection of the population in and around New Haven, will witness this year's major productions of the Yale Department of Drama.

Broad changes in the Federal methods of handling slum rehabilitation and low-rent housing problems were urged today in resolutions adopted at the closing sessions of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

When the Lafayette College Glee Club went on its annual tour forty years ago banjo and mandolin clubs were a part of the musical orgrifzation but today Lafayette is attempting a musical innovation by sending on the road the glee club and the college choir united in one organization known as the Lafayette Singers.

The Personal Finance Company of New York has applied for licenses to transact business as a licensed lender at five locations in the Bronx and Queens, the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department reported today.

TO publicize the International Exposition to be held at Liege next year, Belgium has released four finely executed stamps. Of upright format is a 35-centimes light green picturing one of the fair's buildings;' the other three, horizontals, are 1-franc light red illustrating another exposition structure, 1.50fr brown, with a view of the fair, and 1.75fr blue with another exposition scene and with a portrait of the late King Albert in a trench helmet.

Mr. and Mrs. John Coxe Inge of Ridgewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ruth Inge, to James Wilbur Swihart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Daniel Swihart, also of Ridgewood.

Chairman, Night Accident Committee, National Safety Council FATALITIES in motor vehicle accidents for the first nine months of this year are approximately 20 per cent less than for the corresponding period in 1937. Even on the basis of gasoline consumption, the record is most favorable, and indicates that the intensive safety campaigns of various organizations over the whole country are at last producing definite results.
The South Nassau Communities Hospital celebrated its tenth anniversary here today. Several hundred persons attended the ceremonies. Ten candles on a cake were lighted by Miss Mary Pearson,

Led by Joe Majeske and Art Argyros, Alfred University scored a 120 victory over Hofstra College today before 2,000 spectators in the season's finale for both teams. Argyros tallied for the Saxons in the second period on a pass from Larry Bizet to climax a 70-yard downfield drive.
Texas A. M. routed Rice, crippled Southwest Conference champions, 27-0, today. The big Aggie machine rolled over the institute lads almost at will.

White Plains High School, defending champion of the W. I. A. A., reflected the tutoring of Coach Leonard A. Watters in crushing A. B. Davis High School of Mount Vernon by a 26-0 count before 9,000 persons today in a league encounter which saw it gain the title again.

For men of Rutgers, homecoming day on the banks of the Raritan was a howling success this Indian Summer afternoon. Less than a minute following the opening whistle Rutgers blocked a Lafayette punt, crossed the goal line simultaneously, checked every advance of the Leopards thereafter and eventually left the new milliondollar stadium with a 6 to 0 victory over the visitors from Easton, as 14,000 spectators looked on.

In the Court of Claims of the United States today the following calendar for Monday, Nov. 14, was announced: Call of the November Calendar Rule to show cause: Cong. 17659-Julian C. Smith et al. Cong. 17564-Producers Cotton Products Assn. Cong. 17616-Tyler Cotton Oil Co. Cong. 17446-Friars Point Oil Mill and Mfg. Co. Cong. 17439-Vidalia Oil and Ice Co.

Thinking over the results of last week's elections, many voters may be reminded of the idea satirically portrayed oy Mr. Maxwell Anderson in his song "The One Indispensable Man," in "Knickerbocker Holiday." The truth must dawn upon them that in this country no one in public life and no one aspiring to public office is indispensable.
The Hofstra field hockey team outscored the New College of Columbia co-eds, 5-3, today. Miss Henrietta Rasweiler excelled for the winners, tallying twice in the first half.

Academic honors were won by 106 New Jersey College foroWomen students during the last academic year, Miss Esther W. Hawes, registrar, announced today. A record of 1.8 or better was achieved by 51 members of the class of '39, 28 of the class of '40 and 27 of the class of '41.

AMERICA'S huge grape harvest is flowing to market. Muscats, Concords. Dela wares, Catawbas. Zinfandels, Emperors, firm and luscious, are here in quantity, for New York's appetite is large and grape prices encourage heavy consumption.

INSTALLED in an especially prepared gallery on the top floor of Mason Frangaise, Rockefeller Center (there to remain on view through this week) is the large mural called "The World of Steel," painted by Clara Fargo Thomas for the United States Steel Corporation's pavilion at the New York World's Fair.
Mrs. J. Whitall Nicholson of this place has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Dorothea Nicholson, to Ralph E. Ellis Jr. of Washington, D. C.,

ABRAHAM, JENNIE (Oct. 3). Estate. approximately $20,000. To William de Young Kay, executor, 911 Park Ave., residue. CHURCHILL, FLORENCE ROWE (Oct. 3). Estate, more than $20,000. To Margaret Churchill Le Moine daughter. Montreal, Canada; Florence Jane Churchill, daughter, same address, equal shares in residue. Reginald M. Rowe, Garden City, L. I., and John G. M. Le Moine, Montreal, executors.

ABSTRACTION in its various phases continues to be much with us this season. Lyonel Feininger, an American master of the field, long an expatriate, who reversed the usual procedure and exercised a considerable influence on Eurupean artists, is represented among the newly opened current show s. So is the protean Picasso. So also is work by young Americans of the academy of the left, with a decidedly derivative slant in mulch of it.
APPARENTLY the tide has turned in the traffic safety field. There are many indications of this in addition to the large decrease in traffic fatalities.

The Federal Home Loan Bank board, in calling attention yesterday to the fact that several States have adopted progressive laws for the savings and loan business, announced that the board has just changed some of its own regulations to conform to these State statutes.

While this week's elections did not bring victory for any of the more sensational proposals to increase old-age pension payments in this country, there were many indications that the drive for liberalization of present Federal law made considerable headway.

Labor "won" eleven strikes, "lost" seven and "compromised" four in September, according to a report by Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner. The settlements classed as labor victories involved 3,706 workers, the defeats 139 and the compromises eightyseven, Miss Miller said.
Activity in Colombian oil fields is increasing with the development of the Catatumbo fields, which are expected to produce for export next April.

Plans for the formation of a new women's organization will be outlined at the close of a conference called for Tuesday by Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway at 122d Street. Sessions will be held both morning and afternoon on contemporary Jewish problems.

THE highway user, whether he is in his family car enjoying a week-end or driving his truck in connection with his business affairs, realizes that certain costs incident to the present highways must be paid by him.

Brilliant running by Karsokas, Bonzagni and Haldane behind beautiful blocking today gave Bowdoin a 19-6 triumph over Tufts. Karsokas scored twice on 54 and 35 yard jaunts and Bonzagni on a 31. Griffin, Tufts' chief threat, passed the Jumbas to their lone score. Completing three aerials on a 47-yard march, the final toss to Fiorini carried over.

Michigan State, led by its brilliant triple-threat star, Johnny Pingel, came from behind in the fourth quarter to defeat Marquette's eleven today, 20 to 14. The Avalanche scored twice in the second period, but collapsed under Pingel's great passes. The Spartan halfback threw fifteen completed passes, including three for touchdowns for 219 yards.

Seizing upon the unseasonably warm weather which has been bemoaned by retail merchants all Fall, Lord Taylor yesterday opened a window display which stopped passersby and lined them up before the windows several rows deep all day long.

Mrs. W. Bourke Cockran of 1,136 Fifth Avenue, who by one of the oddest bits of whimsy on record will become today one year older than she was last Nov. 13, but one month and twelve days younger than she actually is, will deprive President Roosevelt of the chance to pick up an extra birthday by having some friends in for a dinner party tonight.
SOON or late in almost every talk by automobile salesmen to prospective buyers "economy of operation and upkeep" is stressed as a major virtue of the vehicle under consideration.

Streams of visitors, freed from routine by a three-day week-end, continued yesterday to throng two of the automobile exhibits being held concurrently with the National Automobile Show. During the entire day and into late evening crowds filled both the International Automobile Salon in the Chrysler
Led by little Sammy Padjen, 155-pound fullback who scored all the touchdowns, Dickinson gained a 19-0 victory over Susquehanna on Biddle Field today before a Father's Day crowd of 3,000.

NEW YORK this week-end is at the flood tide of the annual automobile show season. This period has reached a new high water-mark with the introduction of the 1939 models since five, instead of four, exhibitions of motor vehicles are in progress in Manhattan, at one and the same time.

Defense counsel for Erich Glaser, one of the four defendants in the German espionage trial, filed' in Federal Court yesterday a list of seventeen persons and corporations to be subpoenaed in the former soldier's behalf.

Mrs. Charles A. Perera heads the executive committee for the annual Christmas bazaar under the auspices of the International Institute of the Young Women's Christian Association, which will open Wednesday night at the headquarters of the organization, 341 East Seventeenth Street, and will continue there throughout Saturday.

His Excellency, Senor Dr. Don Francisco Castillo jera, Ambassador of Mexico. Excellency: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of the note addressed by your government on Sept. 1 to Ambassador Daniels.

Society was brilliantly represented at the closing performance of the fifty-third National Horse Show in Madison Squar, Garden last night. The display of fashion in the boxes and arena seats rivaled the glamour of old-time elegance in gowns on the opening night.

THIS is a wonderful book that commenced to live when Mr. Bemelmans was a lausbub--that is, a lousy boy--in Bavaria, and that has matured with him through the twenty-odd years since he was given a choice between attending something rather worse than reform school or emigrating to America.

Michigan and Northwestern fought furiously to a scoreless deadlock before 80,000 fans today, tarnishing the Western Conference football championship hopes of both teams. The Wolverines, with two victories, one defeat and one tie, were left with a mathematical chance of capturing top honors.

-Collision of two "football special" trains, each jammed with nearly 500 persons bound for the Notre Dame - Minnesota game, injured ninety-one of them today. Twenty of these were taken to the hospital for treatment.
A wide-awake Muhlenberg football team, capitalizing on errors, romped to a 20-to-0 victory over Lehigh in Taylor Stadium today. Eight thousand spectators saw the Mules triumph.
The problem of a small home for a growing family may sometimes be solved with comparatively little expense by adding a second story to the garage.

If Japan should eventually win her undeclared war against China, the boatloads of soldiers shown in the photograph below will receive credit for the key tactical manoeuvre in effecting such a victory. The picture was taken at dawn on Oct. 12, as the Japanese were completing the landing of 60,000 troops, supported by tanks and heavy artillery, at Bias Bay, a lonely tropical shore fringed with heavily wooded hills which was once a pirate stronghold..
Tulane ended a three-year succession of football losses to Georgia today when a powerful ground attack ran up a 28-to-6 victory over the Bulldogs.
Mineola High School's football team concluded its season with four victories by riding roughshod over Roslyn today, 46-0, in a North Shore Conference game.

WITH the election out of the way, and the post-Thanksgiving pre - Christmas slump almost at hand the theatre is looking well forward beyond the gloom and to a more pleasant vision. To wit, the holiday season with its climax of New Year's Eve.

The State Department announced today the appointment of the following delegation to represent the United States at the Central American Regional Radio Conference to meet at Guatemala, capital of the Republic of Guatemala, on Nov. 24.

Twenty years ago this morning the cannon halted their hymn of hate along the long and bloody battle line in France which stretched from Belfort to the sea. Nearly four years of carnage ended as suddenly as if the Almighty had stretched out an omnipotent hand and cried "Enough!"

John L. Lewis called upon the Democratic party today to "clean house of its Hagues and Daveys" if it wished to stave off a union of all progressives in one political party. While he declared that "unquestionably the majority of the people of this country are behind President Roosevelt and his general policy."

How to take care of plumbing fixtures so that the original high luster will not be lost is explained in a new booklet, "The Handling and Care of Enameled Cast Iron Plumbing Fixtures," issued by the Sanitary Cast Iron Enameled Ware Association.

One-party government, under the domination of the President as leader of that party-a domination often exercised through young doctrinaires who never faced a poll--was emphatically abolished after trial by the voters of the United States last Tuesday. The average taxpayers, who form what is loosely called the "middle class," shifted their allegiance from the President and the post-1936 New Deal to accomplish this.

A rat and mouse show will be an added attraction of the annual cat show, under the sponsorship of the Empire Cat Club of New Yorkand the Siamese Cat Society of America, at Commerce Hall, Port Authority Building, Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Karl B. Norton, president of the Empire Cat Club.

Part three of the notable library collected by the late Cortlandt F. Bishop will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., tomorrow afternoon and evening and Tuesday evening.

The subject of religion, long a puzzle to college administrators who have wanted to include it in their courses of study But could not figure out a way to do so, can be included in the college curriculum, but the instruction must avoid formalistic treatment and the courses must not be organized into departments of religion, the Rev. Gwylym Isaac stated yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ashton Wyckoff of Greens Farms, Conn., and Stuart, Fla., formerly of Pelham, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Atwood Wyckoff, to Charles R. Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Devine of Pelham, N. Y.

The TIMES published recently a statement by William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, in which he said that "the Reich today was the miracle of the twentieth century." This remark is puzzling to me as a student of economics.

Hundreds of Jews fleeing from Germany were turned back at the French frontier tonight by border guards acting on strict orders from Paris. A new flood of German Jews seeking safety in France had attempted to cross the border after announcement in Berlin of new anti-Semitic measures.

BILLY ROSE continues to be Broadway's most astonishing phenomenon. For Mr. R.is not only a little man with a fat purse (which accounts for some of his magic) but he is also an impresario bursting with big ideas and he knows a good act when he sees it.

The swimmers of Textile virtually made sure yesterday of retaining the Manhattan-Bronx senior high championship of the P. S. A. L. by defeating the powerful De Witt Clinton team, 43-28, in the latter's pool.

Mrs. George L. Heins, widow of George L. Heins, who was a member of the firm of Heins La Farge, architects, which conceived the original design of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, died here this morning at her home after a short illness. She was 84 years old.

A heavy Springfield eleven came through with a little more than a minute left to play and gained a 7-0 victory over the University of New Hampshire today before a homecoming crowd of 6,000. New Hampshire threatened twice in the first half, but was unable to score.

The chart showing how the Rhode Island Handicap was run at Narragansett Park today: FIFTH RACE-The Rhode Island Handicap; $10,000 added; 3-year-olds and upward; one mile and a furlong. Start good from gate; won easily; place driving. Went to post 3:19, off 3:22 1/2. Winner, b. c., 4, by Man o' War-Brushup, by Sweep. Trainer, G. Conway. Value to winner, $8,340; second, $2,000; third, $1,000; fourth, $500. Time--1:51 2/8. Weather clear; track fast.

Influenced by a sharp advance in foreign quotations during Friday's holiday here, and a strong two-hour session in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday rose again to new high levels to close with gains of 2 to 4 points.
ZURICH.--In the Balkans almost everything you buy now is German. Whether you are looking for a pin, a hammer, a radio or an overcoat, it all comes from what is now Germany.

A program embracing some of the more spirited topics of the day has been prepared for the convention this week of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, which will mark the close of the administration of Mrs. Clare J. Hoyt and the election of her successor.

READER, can you remember as far back as the night when Orson Welles terrified the nation over the radio? It was only a fortnight ago; Oct. 30 was the date by the calendar. But folly evaporates so rapidly into the laughing clouds that already the night of the great terror seems like a footnote to ancient history. For Mr. Welles, the Gotham hobgoblin, has gone on to something else,
More than 200 reservations have been made for the New York alumnae celebration of National Barnard Day, which will be held in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, on Saturday.
Daniel T. O'Regan, Jersey City prosecutor, announced yesterday that the trial of Joseph Scutellaro, 36 years old, Hoboken relief recipient, on a charge of murder, had been indefinitely postponed.

PILING is in at Red Hook in Brooklyn, transforming the somewhat slippery land into a solid base for New York's $12,000,000 public project. Concrete is pouring. At least nineteen of the buildings have their foundations finished with floor construction and brickwork started. And while the work goes on the Mayor announces agreement on two more big housing projects' for the city.

Maintaining the brilliant form he has shown since the opening of the A. V. R. O. international chess masters' tournament at Amsterdam last Sunday, Reuben Fine of New York won today for the third time.

Determined to complete the "liquidation" of Jews in Germany, the National Socialist Government today issued a series of proscriptive decrees that confiscate the larger part of the remaining Jewish possessions in Germany and entirely eliminate all Jews from German business life. The police, at the same time, continued to arrest Jews-especially prominent business men-indiscriminately.

The Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, representatives of a membership of 4,669,000, called upon the United States Government today to protest officially to Germany against the anti-Jewish riots.

AS Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis reaches his eighty-second birthday today the National Economic Committee is just getting into its swing in its "inventory of big business." The connection between the two events is not on the surface, but it exists

VERY few of the State Legislatures met during 1938, but the year was important legislatively for the motor car owners of America in that there are many new trends and cross-currents in the air as battle lines are drawn for the 1939 legislative sessions.

I WAS looking the other day at one of those typical "motor ads" that you see in the colored illustrations, motors glistening to an impossible effulgence, a graveled drive impossibly neat, beside wide lawns of inconceivable grass and unachievable flower beds.
Brazil will raise on Monday the trade barriers set up against Germany last June, when deals in cotton and other products in compensated marks were barred by the government.

The little horse with the big heart, War Admiral, bade farewell for the season to his public today when he easily captured the $11,840 Rhode Island Handicap before 40,000 persons. Disregarding his recent defeat by Seabiscuit, the big crowd gave the famous son of Man o' War a champion's reception and sent him to the post at 1 to 5, the shortest price in the history of Narragansett Park, which was opened in 1934.

ASTROLOGERS rejoiced recently to read the report that Chancellor Hitler had consulted his favorite star seer during the crisis over the partition of Czechoslovakia. The report seemed to buttress the position of a group who,

An 18 per cent increase over the 1937 period in the number of family dwelling units provided in urban areas was recorded for the first nine months of this year, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today. New units projected totaled more than 197,000, including 3,085 financed by Federal funds.

Eighth annual convention, Union American Hebrew Congregations, Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon 12:45 P. M. Speakers, Jacob Aronson, Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman, Roger W. Straus, Mrs. Leon L. Watters, Samuel B. Finkel. Afternoon session 3 P. M.
Home buyers, warns an FHA official, should make careful examination of trends and conditions before purchasing a dwelling located in an unzoned area.
A church parade will be held this morning by Squadron C of the 101st Cavalry from Brooklyn to Grace Lutheran Church, Seventy-first Avenue and Olcott Street, Forest Hills, Queens. The pastor, the Rev.

With the profit showing for this year largely dependent upon the business done in the next six weeks, retailers will begin their Christmas promotions in the more confident expectation that holiday dollar volume will range from even with to 5 to 10 per cent above 1937.

As a result of last week's elections a number of Republicans hitherto little known have emerged on the national political stage. Some of them are exceptionally young; few have had wide experience in office. There is a great variety in their personal backgrounds,

Mayor La Guardia will lay the cornerstone of a six-story building for the Lower East Side Health and Teaching Center at First Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street at 4 P. M. Thursday. The city is spending $325,000 to erect the brick and stone structure, which is to be opened next May.

A new residential community in the Rumson section of New Jersey is about to be started by Winfield S. Wainvwright, developer and builder, on a tract of twenty acres which he has purchased from the Charles P. Doelger estate.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

The Pine Mountain Settlement School of Harlan County, Ky., now celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, is sending a group of students to take part in the school's silver jubilee at the Town Hall on Nov. 21.

Maryland's last chance for one of its college teams to go through an unbeaten season faded today when an earnest Allegheny College team downed Johns Hopkins by 6 to 0. The only touchdown came in the third period. With the ball on his 34, Cook slithered through the line to midfield.

Drake University, led by a couple of young men whose names have been absent from starting lineups, stunned Tulsa University with a 27-to-7 defeat today, the first time the Golden Hurricane has been whipped since it joined the Missour?? Valley Conference in 1935.

Lieut. Col. Emmet C. Morton, U. S. A., of the finance department at Governors Island, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Marian Morton, to Dr. Fletcher Pearre Veitch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Pearre Veitch of College Park, Md.

ON the crest of the usual seasonal popular interest in Nobel Prize awarding, a new little volume in English, "The Nobel Prizes and Their Founder," by Fritz Henriksson, is peculiarly timely. For the paradox that Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite and other explosives, was also a pacifist the following sentence in italics seems to be the key:"

Frederick Clemens Zeisberg, president of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and technical investigator for the E. I. Pont de Nemours Company, died today of heart disease. He was 50 years old.
Governor Wilbur L. Cross, who has a flair for issuing lyric proclamations, today proclaimed Thursday, Nov. 24, as a day of public thanksgiving.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Brothers of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriette Ann Brothers, to Daniel Silver Morrell Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrell of Hartford and Grove Beach, Conn.
TWO holidays in the week for numerous cities helped or hindered trade according to whether stores were closed or not. Daily volume, however, showed improvement, according to reports.
THIS narrative poem by Josephine Young Case, or novel in blank verse one may choose to call it, has an interesting, if simple, conception behind it. It is not an entirely original conception.

The brutality of Berlin mobs in last week's anti-Jewish demonstrations, reinforced by new and still harsher decrees from the Nazi government, constitute a chapter in modern history which a short time ago no one would have believed possible. Persistent exaltation of might, however, with the fostering of nationalistic bigotry and the throttling of free speech and press, have done their work.

Charles Brown, end on the Woodrow Wilson High School football team, had scarcely recovered from a play that knocked him out before he was stunned again in a game here today. Stretched on the field, his coach examining him, Brown opened his eyes and yelled:
W. A. Alexander, veteran Georgia Tech football coach, charged tonight that Alabama gained a 14-14 tie with his team today through an illegal "screened pass."

The active interest of the individual in facilities for his health protection, a development of recent years, has become apparent in the United Hospital Campaign which has made the community hospital and health conscious, it was pointed out yesterday by C. M. Chester, chairman of the sixtieth annual appeal.

Virginia halted Harvard's running attack for one period today, but wilted before hard-running ball carriers in the concluding three sessions and went down to a 40-to-13 defeat before 15,000 fans in the final home game of the Crimson season.
Bonds called last week before their maturity dates were in comparatively small volume. The announcements, except for two large public-utility prepayments,

Two touchdowns in the closing minutes, the second just as the gun sounded, kept Iowa State among the nation's undefeated teams today but earned the Cyclones only a 13-13 tie with Kansas State and cost them co-leadership with Oklahoma in the Big Six title race.
The navy announced today that the sword worn by Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry at the Battle of Lake Erie had been presented to the Naval Academy at Annapolis by Perry Belmont of Newport, R. I.

The University of Washington Huskies, who couldn't beat anybody a few weeks ago, tripped the mighty University of Southern California football team, 7 to 6, on a slippery field today before 18,000 fans.
Le Roy Smith, former White Plains (N. Y.) postmaster, died here yesterday just -three weeks after arriving to make his home near the University of California. His age was 54.
Dr. F. Scott McBride, superintendent of the Pennsylvania AntiSaloon League, said in a statement today the next Legislature would have "more sentiment for dry program" than any in more than ten years.
Despite notable Republican victories in Tuesday's elections, there still will be lots of Democrats on Washington's Capitol Hill when the Seventy-sixth Congress convenes next January.

Recommendations from an all-party committee of inquiry that Irish Cabinet Ministers' salaries be increased have been rejected by the government. It proposes, however, that former Ministers should receive pensions of [Pound]300 for three years' services, rising to [Pound]500 for seven years or more.

The Loyalists are being hard pressed both on the Ebro and Segre bridgeheads, but today's developments were favorable, according to tonight's communique, which says that the Rebels failed to gain ground in either sector, despite desperate attacks. In the Segre zone, it is asserted, the government even took forty-five prisoners.
