MORIZ ROSENTHAL has been throughout his career a formidable pianist and a man formidable in thought jest, or argument; a lover of literature; a very serious student of philosophy; a traveler by nature a well as necessity, a man of the world, and, as the years have passed, the more a poet of his instrument.

In his Munich speech on Tuesday Chancellor Adolf Hitler, referring to the British and French Governments, said: "They talk of understanding," but he added, "I really do not know what we should come to an understanding about."
THERE can be no doubt, whatever the reason, that the level of performance in American historical novels has risen measurably in the past few years.

The Lafayette lightweights scored twice in the final period to defeat the Penn 150-pounders, 13-6, on Fisher Field today. Jackson ran 50 yards on a pass from Newman in the third session to give Penn the lead.
Drexel Institute's football team ran wild against the University of Delaware today, scoring by 38-13. The Dragons made three touchdowns in the first quarter, two in the second and one in the fourth.

For the first time in its young but kaleidoscopic history the $1,000,000,000 radio industry of the United States is to be the subject of a sweeping investigation by the Federal Communications Commission. The investigation, scheduled to open tomorrow in Washington, promises to be one of the most comprehensive ever conducted in the communications field.

Wilbur Torpey, 29 years old, a clerk in the city Department of Public Works, has received a municipal graduate fellowship in the New York University College of Engineering, making a total of seven city employes who are "career students" in the college's Department of Sanitairy Engineering, it was announced yesterday by Dean Thorndike Saville..

Following a hearing here today County Police Commissioner Abram W. Skidmore revoked a permit given recently to the German-American Burd to hold a "pro-American rally" in the auditorium of the Nassau County Police Headquarters here on Nov. 16.
Announcement was made her last night of the death on Thursday in Memphis, Tenn., of ?? Bertrand Estabrooke, former Professor of English at the University of Kyoto, Japan,

The champion whistlers of the city will be selected this afternoon at Mullaly Playground, Jerome Avenue and 165th Street, the Bronx, in the finals of the Park Department's first annual whistling contest.
DARK IN VADER: The current New York spy trial, with its testimony of stolen plans, kidnapping and attempts to obtain army secrets, furnished the theme last week for

A distinguished audience, including many noted figures in diplomatic, social and artistic circles, will attend the golden jubilee recital of the eminent Polish pianist, Moriz Rosenthal, tonight at Carnegie Hall. They will pay tribute to the 75-year-old artist, one of the last remaining pupils of Franz Liszt, the associate of Johannes Brahms, Anton Rubenstein.

N. Mansfield Smith of Plainfield, retired director of the AngloAmerican Oil Co., Ltd., of New York, died today in Beth Israel Hospital at Newark of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in that city Wednesday. He was born in Bloomsburg, N. J., and was 63 years old.

Retail trade turned upward in many districts last week, but, in the important cities where stores were open on the two holidays, results were under those of the corresponding holidays last year, and in other cities the stores were closed for the Election and Armistice Days.

Mrs. John Haire Walton of the Milburn, this city, has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Miss Margaret Henderson Walton, to Cornelius Stickley Tucker of Buenos Aires, son of Mrs. J. W. S.

THE San Blas Islands, which stretch along the Caribbean coast of Panama like palm plumed stepping-stones from the Canal Zone toward the Colombian frontier and have been called by those who have visited them "a Tahiti in America," will soon be host to scores of tourists.

The marriage of Miss Helen Pendleton Lyster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Judson Lyster of Tuckahoe, to Francis Stephen Nash, son of Mrs. Emily Branson of Rome, Ga., and the late James L. Nash, took place here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Wendell Phillips performed the ceremony.

Dr. Ellwood Patterson Cubberley, who retired at Stanford University five years ago, having written or edited 100 volumes of the familiar "Riverside Text Books in Education" series and eighteen other education books, presented yesterday to the university, on behalf of his wife and himself, a three-story School of Education building, completed this Fall at a cost of $535,000.

The anticipated metamorphosis of Harrison Williams's group of investment companies from a position of virtual control in large public utility systems to one of "inand-out" trading in public-utility operating companies engaged the interest of Wall Street last week.

With four components higher for the week ended Nov. 5, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 89.5 from 89.0. The figure was 93.2 for the corresponding week last year. Steel ingot production rose to its highest level since the week ended Oct. 16, 1937. This upturn, countering a seasonal decline, accounted for the week's heaviest weighted increase.

Under three committee chairmen, a large representation of society has been assembled to assure a successful subscription to the first performance of the Ice Follies the night of Nov. 29 at Madison Square Garden. A percentage of every ticket sold in the interests of the Musicians Emergency Fund will be applied to the work of that organization in aiding needy musicians.

Secretary and General Manager, Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc. THE 1939 car models have been designed by engineers who looked beyond the bounds of engineering textbooks and laboratory experiments for their vision of what people needed and wanted in the way of automobiles.

Extensive experience in addressing civic, political and religious groups outside the university is being offered to Fordham College upperclassmen by the expanding Lecture Bureau, adjunct of the college Council of Debate.
As a result of many tests, the use of mineral wool insulation as a fire retardant has been approved by the National Bureau of Standards, United States Department of Commerce.

Leon Jourolmon, a member of the Tennessee Utilities Commission, charge tonight that The Chattanooga Free Press, editorially opposed to the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program, "benefited" by more than $75,000 from the Tennessee Electric Power Company.

Three United States Senators sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie for a rest after the recent campaign. They were Millard E. Tydings of Maryland and James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, both of whom were re-elected, and J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois, the Senate Democratic whip, who was not a candidate-this year.

Challedon, a flashy colt owned by W. L. Brann, won the $15,000 added Pimlico Futurity with a great stretch rush today and became the first Maryland bred and foaled horse to take the event in thirteen years. A crowd of 20,000 cheered Challedon on to victory over seven other Kentucky Derby hopefuls in the mile and a sixteenth test for twoyear-olds and he didn't let them down.

To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 16: PATROLMAN-Lawrence F. Ryan, from 102d Precinct to 110th Precinct. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS-From commands indicated to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 16:

Paced by its star left halfback, Johnny Gitsas, who scored both his team's touchdowns, Alexander Hamilton High remained undefeated and unscored upon as it downed its traditional Brooklyn rival, Boys High, 12-0, in the thirty-second battle between the schools at Ebbets Field yesterday.
THE first motor trucks, crude though they were, nevertheless made possible great savings In time and in animal and human exertion as compared to the quadruped-drawn vehicles which they replaced.

The sovereign qualities of a great art were never more manifest in their presence and in their effect than when Sergei Rachmaninoff gave his piano recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. It is a tribute to him and to the reality of his music that there assembled again in the historic auditorium a great audience of the select,

St. Joseph's rolled up a 40-0 score against Washington College today, the game being cut eleven minutes owing to darkness. Flashing a powerful ground attack, with Harry Seltzer and Ted Laux setting the pace, the Hawks crossed the Eastern shore collegians' goal-line in every period.
Reports that furniture manufacturers are prepared to put price advances into effect when the Spring markets open here and in Chicago in January gained ground in the wholesale market last week.

VISITORS attending the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace, New York, often experience something of a mild thrill when they view for the first time certain cars about which they have read in the advertising columns.

WELL equipped as it may be, your new car stands ready to provide new standards in satisfaction if safety and convenience are amplified by the addition of some of the latest offerings in accessories. Accent is definitely on safety in these new devices, with additional interest in an unforeseen but entirely logical trend toward revival of travel equipment used in motordom's earlier history. Much equipment is designed to safeguard the beauty of the car itself.

IS it ever too late to try a new experiment? My eye has just been caught by a paragraph in a morning paper reporting that an old lady of 104 in Northamptonshire recently had her first talk over a telephone, her first ride in an automobile and her first flight in an airplane.

Paced by Salvatore Mirabito, speedy quarterback, Manlius School ran roughshod over Cook Academy today to win, 54-7. Mirabito scored three touchdowns, one on a 65-yard run back of a kick-off, and passed for two more tallies.

Licenses for the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war were issued by the Secretary of State during October to the number of 479 and the value of $7,126,044.46, it was announced today. Actual exports during October were valued at $4,080,810.03.

Notre Dame's unbeaten football forces overwhelmed Minnesota today, 19 to 0, before 56,000 astonwished spectators. The Fighting Irish, superb in open field running, passing and blocking, opened the floodgates of their scoring power in three quick thrusts to achieve their seventh straight victory of the season.

A revival of the activities of the Communist International, which has been moribund during recent years while Moscow was endeavoring to safeguard peace by means of a chain of alliances with capitalist powers, was clearly indicated this week in the course of the celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of the Bolshevist seizure of power.

"KNICKERBOCKER HOLIDAY" was obviously written to make an occasion for Kurt Weill's music, and since Mr. Weill responded by writing the best score in the history of our theatre, and since the public has voted an emphatic approval at the box office, the whole venture would seem to justify itself without further comment.

A request that criminal charges of perjury be made against J. B. Matthews, twice a witness before the House committee investigating unAmerican activities, has been submitted to the United States Attorney's office here by A. J. Isserman, a Newark attorney.

An amendment to the constitution of the New York Curb Exchange has been adopted by the board of governors to include securities as well as commodities under the ruling against reciprocal business. The new section reads:

THIS book undertakes to examine some of the international aspects of fascism, to describe and evaluate the two forms of fascism that have developed in Italy and Germany, and to point out the probable influence of fascism in other countries, including the United States.

Fire, out of control, raged here tonight at the Glenmore distillery, one of the largest in the country. James Pendleton, managing editor of The Owensboro Messenger, said firemen and company officials told him they had small hope of saving the plant from complete destruction.

On the site where once stood the home of Dr. Hosea Ballou 2d, Tufts' first president, the college is building a new home for Dr. Leonard Carmichael, recently installed as seventh president. Officials expect the building will be ready for occupancy in February.
F. E. Spencer, chief animator of Walt Disney's "Donald Duck," died in a hospital today after an auto crash which also injured a movie executive and a film sound technician.
Business was suspended and governmental offices were closed today by Presidential decree as an electoral census, preparatory to Constituent Assembly elections next year, got under way.
The illegality of the sit-down strike "cannot be doubted," the Supreme Court was told today by attorneys for the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation of North Chicago.

"Pepper," a 35-year-old polo pony, was buried today in the Bide-AWee Cemetery here following an attempt to hurdle a fence on the property of Harry Walling on East Avenue, Freeport, where "Pepper" has been boarded since the death of his master thirteen years ago. He broke a leg and was shot.

Amedee J. Van Beuren, former president of the Van Beuren Motion Picture Corporation of New York, died of a heart attack today at his country home, Dreamwold, here. His age was 58. Last July he suffered a stroke but had gradually recovered, although confined to his home.

Soviet newspapers welcome the succession of General Ismet Inonu to the Presidency of Turkey with a cordiality that may indicate Moscow's desire to better relations with Angora. Long laudatory biographies of the late Kemal Ataturk and the new President were published in Pravda and Izvestia today and stress was placed on their friendliness toward the Soviet Union.

The Scarsdale Unit of the New York Junior League will sponsor the presentation of "The Bumblebee Prince," by Rimsky-Korsakoff, on next Saturday afternoon at the Scarsdale High School auditorium, to aid the Westchester Speedwell Unit.

Attired in a Bavarian costume, the body of Mrs. Paul A. Davis 4th, the wife of a young Morristown lawyer, was found on a vacant lot in Chestnut Hill by a policeman early today after she had left a costume party with her husband.

The 1,000-acre property, containing three log lodges and a caretaker's house said to be more than 150 years old, at Lake Mashipacong, N. J., owned by Charles S. Orben of Newark, has been purchased by an anonymous buyer and presented to Life magazine for use as one of that periodical's camps.

Paintings: Groups and Solos--Women painters of the State of Washington are the current exhibitors at the Grand Studios, 175 Macdougal Street. Among the artists well represented are Lilly N. Hardwick, M. Camfforman, Ebba R. Rapp, Louise Gilbert and Mildred D. Schmidtman.

"AMERICA'S TOWN MEETING OF THE AIR," which has opened its fourth season over W-IZ's netowrk on Thursday nights at 9:30 o' clock, is now linked with approximately 4,500 members of 225 self-organized Town Meeting discussion groups in thirty-one States, according to George V. Denny, moderator of the broadcasts.
Scoring in every period, Massachusetts State today triumphed over the Rensselaer eleven by 37-0. The line-up:

The new Anderson Memorial Center given to Boston University's College of Practical Arts and Letters last Winter by Mrs. Larz Anderson in memory of her husband, former Ambassador to Japan, will be formally opened for use of students and alumnae on Tuesday, with a tea and tour of inspection for the university's trustees, faculty and special guests.

A thousand more young Jews were sent from Vienna by train today to undesignated concentration camps. A few Jewish shops were reopened, but all are being liquidated or "Aryanized." Some and or sick Jews who had been forcibly confined to their homes since Wednesday received their liberty.

The Administration's naval expansion program faces rough sledding in the next Congress if the record of the Republicans of the House in the last session can be taken as the basis for prediction. When the Vinson-Walsh $1,000,000,000 authorization bill was passed fifty-seven of the eighty-nine Republican opposed it.

PEOPLE who are interested in handicrafts--and their number is increasing--almost inevitably turn to early American examples for study. Some of the folk arts of this country which have been saved from oblivion by their practitioners in isolated districts are being revived through the efforts of organizations.

With gains recorded for October in all classifications of business transacted, the Federal Housing Administration, as of Oct. 31, had written $1,936,492,437 worth of insurance since its establishment in 1934, Stewart McDonald, administrator, announced yesterday.

SALES of automobile tires in 1938 will be considerably below those of 1937, but when the year ends all factors in the tire industry will nevertheless have a balance on the profit side of the ledger. Conditions in the manufacturning and retailing divisions of the industry have improved so materially during the last six months that even the most conservative tire executives look forward to 1939 to exceed the exceptionally successful 1937.

The Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, a periodical which reflects "low church" opinion in the Protestant Episcopal Church, took issue yesterday with a protest made to President Roosevelt last week by the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor of the Catholic weekly America, against the recent sailing of the freighter Erica Reed with food, clothing and medical supplies for Loyalist Spain.

Amherst routed Williams today, 41 to 0, thereby retaining its Little Three football crown and closing its season undefeated, with only one tie chalked against its record. Before a capacity crowd of 10,000, the Lord Jeffs began their scoring spurt in the first seven minutes of this fifty-fifth game of the ancient series and added to their total in each period thereafter.

If the average person believes the sweeping Republican gains in the Middle West in the recent election signify the end of farm-relief experiments, he will be surprised when the new Congress meets. Whatever effect farmers' dissatisfaction may have had in turning Democrats out of office through this section, it was more a revolt against low prices than against a national farm policy with its subsidies.

THE Nazi Barnums have made a patent medicine circular out of history: before Hitler, darkness and Thomas Mann, Jewish Marxism and bad beer: after, eternal sunlight and Wagner orchestrating God, the Labor Front and Wotan alone knows what promise of greatness.

Wesleyan and Rochester renewed their fifteen-year-old football rivalry today, and the former won, 20 to 13. Both teams scored in the second period. Morningstar intercepted a pass by Bucher and ran 48 yards for a touchdown for Wesleyan. Phelps converted on a place-kick.
St. Francis' Prep's football team, with its back to the wall throughout the game, bowed to St. John's Prep, 6-0, yesterday at Boys High Field.

A stand on the north end of the high school football field collapsed this afternoon during the game between Pearl River and Suffern High Schools, dropping 150 persons to the ground and causing severe injuries to three women and minor injuries to a dozen other spectators.

Clarence Hungerford Mackay, leading Catholic layman and chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and president of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, died just after 11 o'clock last night at his home at 3 East Seventy-fifth Street. He was 64 years old.

The Autumn series of free Saturday afternoon lectures at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park will close with two popular addresses by members of the staff. Dr. A. B. Stout, well known for his work in the breeding of daylilies and of hardy seedless grapes for the Northeastern States, in his talk on "Origin and Improvement of Plants" this Saturday at 3 P. M.

Ceremonies colorful enough to resemble a miniature continental congress will mark the fortieth anniversary of the Manhattan Chapter of the D. A. R., to be observed on Tuesday with a luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria.

Virginia Military Institute defeated Davidson today, 19 to 6, before 5,000 spectators in a game that high-lighted Davidson's home-coming program. Paul Shu scored all three of his team's touchdowns in dramatic fashion.

Funeral services for the Rev. Richard Fagan, who died in Columbus Hospital Wednesday morning from burns received when the rectory of the Church of St. Anthony of Padua. 151 Thompson Street, was burned, were held at the church, 153 Sullivan Street, yesterday. The church was crowded and more than 1,000 men and women gathered in the streets outside.

Another football jinx was toppled in today when Oregon State defeated Stanford, 6 to 0, in a savage game marked by several near fights. It was Oregon State's first victory over the Indians In thirteen tries.

LOCATION-Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue, be. tween Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets. HOURS AND ADMISSION-Opens Nov. 11 and continues through Nov. 18, including Sunday, Nov. 13. Opening day hours: 2 P. M. to 11 P. M. Sunday, noon to 11 P. M. All other days, 10:30 A. M. to 11 P. M. Admission tickets, before 6 P. M., 55 cents, after 6 P. M., 75 cents, tax included.

Georgetown's undefeated football team struck swiftly with two touchdowns in the last eight minutes of play today to defeat West Virginia's Mountaineers, 14-to-0, before a homecoming crowd of 12,000 spectators.
"HIGH IRON" is the railroad's main line, or high-speed tracks, in the speech of the railroaders.

Vallery-Radot, his grandson, credits Pasteur with the remark "a man of science should think of what will be said of him in the following century, not of the insults or the praise of one day." On Nov. 14 the Pasteur Institute will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary. Though a century will not have elapsed

An agreement terminating the longstanding controversy between this government and Mexico over expropriated agricultural lands of American nationals was announced by the State Department today. The agreement was embodied in two notes, the first, dated Nov. 9, from Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, and the order, dated today,

WHILE the American motorist may not have been cognizant of the situation the petroleum industry which supplies him with fuel, lubricants and service has been passing through a year of economic insomnia.

Clothes to suit the personality of individual faculty members and students is the objective of the new Skidmore Clothing Service started this year by students in the Home Economics Department at the college.
Dr. Edward Windsor Southall, Geneseo's oldest practicing physician, is retiring after sixty years of service in the village. He celebrated his eighty-seventh birthday March 5.

Tubercular persons in New York will be the beneficiaries of a theatre party to be held on the night of Dec. 7 under the auspices of the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee, Inc., which was organized seventeen years ago to give immediate relief to sufferers from the disease.

Miss Mary Clare Gibbons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gibbons of Corona, Queens, was married there yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows to Peter J. Donoghue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Donoghue, also of Corona.

Ohio State's alert Buckeyes bolstered their hopes of sharing the Big Ten football championship today with a decisive 32-to-14 victory over Illinois. The Buckeyes, in winning their third conference game against one defeat and one tie, were in command throughout the contest, played before 18,000 spectators.

Purdue University, by a reorganization just completed, has established a School of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering. For many years the university has maintained an active School of Chemical Engineering, the enrollment of which has steadily increased, the 1938 graduating class numbering ninety-one men.

Some of the patrons of the benefit performance on Friday night of the musical comedy "Leave It to Me," at the Imperial Theatre, will conclude the evening with large supper parties. The performance has been taken over by trustees of Madison House, a lower East Side settlement.

Army's football team packed far too much offensive power for a scrappy but light and outmanned University of Chattanooga eleven today and as a result enjoyed pretty much of a romp in rolling up a 34-13 triumph in its last 1938 appearance at Michie Stadium.
Seven hundred truckmen and Knights of Columbus and their guests attended a dinner last night in honor of Hugh E. Sheridan at the Hotel New Yorker.

GREAT secrecy surrounds the aviation phases of the Administration's new national defense program, but inquiries in several well-informed quarters establish that one of the surprise features will be a plan to keep the nation's aviation industry productively engaged and to

Harold Jacobi, chairman of "Night of Stars," a theatrical benefit to be given at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night for the limited Palestine Appeal, made public yesterday a letter from Governor Lehman endorsing the entertainment. The Governor's letter follows:
An attempt to sever the tariff union with Poland is seen in the demand in the Nazi Vorposten today that the Free City be allowed to import commodities now on the Polish prohibited list.

TROPHIES The North Farm Challenge Trophy-Killearn Farm's b. m. Killearn Beauty. The Bowman Challenge Cup-Chilean Army team's b. m. Chilena. The Judy King Challenge Trophy-Dicksfield Farm's b. m. Highland Cora. The Biltmore Challenge Cup-Miss Cynthia Clews Wrightson's ch. m. Kentucky Bloom.

In a departure from more conventional entertainments arranged in behalf of charitable enterprises, several younger members of society are now planning a novel party entitled the Photo Finish Story Contest, which will be held on the night of Nov. 22 with the Cafe Louis XIV as its principal locale.
Several homes are being built in the Glenside tract, recently opened at Lake Mohawk, Sussex County, N. J., according to the Arthur D. Crane Company, developers.

Duke had little trouble keeping its season's football record unblemished today. The Blue Devils from Durham, N. C., not only succeeded in handing a convincing setback to Syracuse, but kept their goal line uncrossed in this campaign.

THERE may be some institution somewhere, some organization or some individual who, or which, will not be aggrieved by this book of Mr. Bell's, with its innocent title. It is doubtful, but there may be. For most readers Mr. Bell will be rough sledding.
Guidance research has received new impetus in the formation of the First Corps Area Guidance Association, composed of sixty-eight educational advisers in New England CCC camps.

IBELIEVE the automobile business will be better in 1939. This is not an idle statement. It is based on concrete factors pointing toward definite improvement. They are: 1. Early Fall business indices exhibit an upward trend, where a decline had set in a year ago.

Motorists were warned yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, to check up on the exhaust, ignition and carburetion systems of their automobiles so as to guard against carbon monoxide poisoning while running their cars this Winter.

The wave of anti-Semitic lawlessness here has now been supplanted by a campaign of violence against the Catholic Church. Following the speech last night by Adolf Wagner, Bavarian Minister of the Interior, in which he attacked Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich, and treated with contempt the Munich church authorities' appeal for

WHATEVER the state of the world or the nation, the Annual Fall Motor Parade Toward Florida has begun with a rush that may end in a record. It is two weeks ahead of schedule,according to the Automobile Club of New York, and the Southland routes are expected to carry 11 per cent more traffic than last Fall.

A junior committee for the sixtieth anniversary dinner of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work has been formed recently under the chairmanship of Miss Lynne R. Russell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Russell.

The American Chemical Society announced yesterday the election of 126 chemists to administrative and editorial posts in the organization. Chairmen of the society's eighteen professional divisions for 1938-39 are as follows:

A plan for encouraging wider student interest in a variety of fields of knowledge is being developed informally at Brown University this Fall through the cooperative efforts of The Brown Daily Herald, campus newspaper, and members of the faculty.

for dance audiences. At the Majestic Theatre this evening, Argentinita will make her first New York appearance in eight years, assisted by her little company of two dancers and two musicians. In the former category are Pilar Lopez and Antonio Triana, and in the latter are Carlos Montoya, guitarist, and Bogelio Machado, pianist.

Miss Eleanor Rose Murphy, daughter of Joseph A. Murphy of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Murphy, was married to M. Edward Neville, son of Mrs. Michael K. Neville, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Neville, yesterday morning in St. Anselm's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Faith Marie Gort, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Gort of this city, formerly of South Orange, N. J., to Ferdinand J. Herpers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand J. Herpers of Millburn, N. J.

Importers and customs brokers looked to a conference they expect to hold with Treasury Department officials in Washington tomorrow, for solution of the difficulties created by the department's ruling classing Sudeten products shipped on or after last Thursday as German.
Further offerings of Jewish-owned securities today marked the week-end session on the Boerse and losses up to 2 points in the principal issues were common.

Albert Robbins, real estate operator who was prominent in the development of this section, died of a heart attack while driving his car into the garage at his home in West Allenhurst near here last night. He was 65 years old and had been engaged in the real estate business here for thirty-seven years.

The Rev. Dr. Krasto Tsenoff, for fifteen years head of the Orthodox Bulgarian Church Missions in the United States and Canada, died in Harrisburg Hospital today. He had been ill for three weeks. Dr. Tsenoff, who was 61 years old, received two distinguished service crosses from King Boris III

While the rest of the world commemorated on Armistice Day the end of a war "to make the world safe for democracy," Germany's National Socialist regime celebrated its final victory over the Jews and prepared to consolidate that victory in new decrees designed to "liquidate" German Jewry as effectively as the Bolshevists did the aristocratic and bourgeois classes in Russia.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Nov. 10: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Crawford, D. M., Signal Corps, fifteen days' leave, Dec. 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Camp, T. J. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, seven days' leave, Nov. 14. Weidner, E., Med. Corps, Army Medical From Center, Washington, D. C., to General Dispensary, Washington, D. C.

LAST year Michael Foster's "American Dream" hit the best-seller list and rocketed his name as an important young romantic able to dream his way through current discontent without sounding like the author of gingerbread legend.
The National Small Business Men's Association today invited all business and professional men and women in the nation to join a mass movement seeking changes in the Wagner Labor Relations Act.
Led by the pound sterling, the principal foreign currencies continued yesterday their decline in relation to the dollar in the foreign-exchange market.

An underdog, George Washington University defeated the University of Kansas football team today, 9 to 7. The winning points were scored on a safety early in the final period. Kansas, scoreless for the first two periods, evened the count in the third.
Automobile manufacturers will join with accessories producers Tuesday in the annual automobile show week luncheon of the Overseas Automotive Club at the Hotel Lexington.

Hartwick College closed its football season with a 13-0 victory over a light Arnold College eleven today. The Terriers made only one threat. Hartwick scored late in the first period when George Redden intercepted Lewis's pass and raced 63 yards. An 84-yard march in the fourth session ended with Joe DiPalma's off-tackle dash from the 10. Savino converted on a placekick.

Governor Cross today declined to foster a legal move to reject the 4,700 votes of the Union party, founded two years ago by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and restored to the ballot by a court order last week.

The Helpers will holds their annual bazaar on Tuesday at Sherry's to raise funds for carrying on various philanthropic projects of that organization. A wide variety of useful and decorative articles suitable for gifts at the holiday season will be on sale. Proceeds will be used to provide care and treatment for the sick poor in their homes, and in carrying on settlement work.
HISTORICAL and biographical novels come and go, frequently as shortlived as they are long-winded; but here is one that I think has come to stay.
THAT long-overdue indictment of Nazi persecution of the Jews has arrived at last. As we might have expected, it has come from Russia, which is beyond Hollywood's anxiety about the foreign market.

(Nov. 13-19) (Time Is P. M. Eastern Standard, Unless Otherwise Indicated) TODAY :00-1:00--Music Hall: Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana"--WJZ. :00-1:20--From Vatican City: Cardinal Mundelein, Describing Mother Cabrini Beautification Ceremonies--WEAF, WOR, WABC.
The renewed anti-Semitic terrorism in Germany was described as "a catastrophe to the world" by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise in a sermon at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, yesterday.

The Daladier government made extensive efforts today to hasten the financial and economic recovery of France by approving more than thirty decree laws, revising labor conditions, by revaluing the gold stock of the Bank of France and by making other moves to avert a threatened economic crisis.

CHAUCER wrote at a time when English speech was struggling to be born. Early Britons, Angles, Saxons, Romans and French had thrown their philological contributions into the melting pot and the language was in as chaotic a condition as oral Chinese is today.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Rothschild of 41 East Seventieth Street will give a dinner in their home for members of the Girl Scout National Mariner Committee and- persons prominent in yachting and sailing on Tuesday night.
Miss Mary Anderson,. director of the Women's Bureau, reporting today to Secretary Perkins on a study of hours and wages in shoe factories, said that the average weekly wage was $21.33.

TERRIBLE days, the worst imaginable. were behind us. In the middle of October, 1918, our division was re lieved and transferred from the bloody Arras sector to the comparative quiet of the Alsatian front. Here the company which I commanded was to rest and fill up gaps in its ranks.
Defeat of a drastic initiative measure to restrict labor picketing and boycotting and in important contingencies to prohibit them entirely, was the surprise and sensation of the California election.

Two shoot-offs were required to decide the handicap shoot at the Bergen Beach Gun Club's Jamaica Bay traps yesterday. Dr. L. F. Knoll finally won the prize, breaking twenty-five straight in the first string, and repeating with twentyfive in the second. Others in the shoot-off were R. H. Helsel, A. Rave, J. K. Voorhees and W. Gilbert.

FOLK music will be featured on the programs planned for the Swiss National Exposition to be held May 6-Oct., 29 at Zurich. Soon after the fair opens, a gala concert will be given on "Swiss Boys' Day." Elaborate programs are scheduled by the Federal Music Association of Switzerland in connection with the exposition.
Headed back for home after twenty years on Mars, a fellow can't help feeling a bit nervous. How will I know the place when I get there? They have had so many New Eras down there,

Only two of the forty-three members of Congress whose defeat was sought publicly by Labor's NonPartisan League failed of re-election. The league is the political affiliate of the C. I. O. Representative Driver of Arkansas was not renominated and Representative Lamneck of Ohio was defeated in the election.

Although the United States recently renounced its right to intervene in the internal affairs of Cuba, which had been reserved in the Platt Amendment, the ties between the Pearl of the Antilles and her big neighbor to the north have remained close ever since the island was liberated by the SpanishAmerican War.

The German team of Heinz Vopel and Gustav Kilian won Chicago's fortieth international six-day bicycle race which ended at the Chicago Stadium at midnight. The Germans captured the grind on points in a close finish with three other teams.

Fifteen hundred members, "relatives and friends of the Czechoslovak Legion, which fought in the World War on the side of the Allies, met last night in Sokol Hall, 525 East Seventy-second Street, to protest against the dismemberment of their country at the Munich conference.
Mrs. Ella Humphrey Foulkes, wife of Henry Foulkes, superintendent of mail transportation of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, died yesterday at her home, 37 Garrison Avenue.

Millions of King George's subjects in this island and in far dominions were delighted this week by the news that the King and Queen would visit the United States during an interlude in their Canadian tour next Summer.

Women who have long taken an active interest in the philanthropic activities of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will assist at the annual Christmas sale to be held at the headquarters of the home at 2,914 Broadway on Wednesday and Thursday. A wide variety of articles suitable for gifts at the holiday season will be offered for sale, including bags, jackets, cushions, aprons, smocks,
The fifty-third annual observance of founder's day will be marked Friday by the administration and cadet corps of the Bordertown Military Institute.
With rehearsals now in the final stages the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania will open its fifty-first production, "All Around the Town," next Friday.

Demand for small homes and other properties held by the borough of Bergenfield, N. J., and which the officials recently announced would be disposed of at private sale and on favorable terms, has exceeded all expectations, announces Real Estate Supervisor B. T. Aschenbrand. The properties are chiefly parcels and tracts of improved and unimproved land either deeded back by owners unable to liquidate their back taxes or acquired by foreclosure.

Brief paragraphs in the Sunday newspapers recording without editoral comment the return of the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester to London yesterday after their meeting with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in Paris seem to be no measure of the public interest and, some may say, of the disquiet that this family reunion has aroused here.

The election last Tuesday has resulted in a divided control of the New York State Government. By the re-election of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Controller Morris S. Tremaine and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and the election of Charles Poletti as Lieutenant Governor,

Not only was Philip F. La Follette defeated at the polls this week in seeking a fourth term as Governor, but his third party, known as the National Progressives of America, appears to have been wrecked.

Delegates continued to arrive today for the first Pan-American Congress of Municipalities, which will open Monday. President Federico Laredo Bru will make the welcoming address. On Wednesday Secretary of the Interior Harold Ickes of the United States is scheduled to speak on municipal methods of relieving unemployment by public works.

BELOW will be found specifications and descriptions in some detail of the 1939 models of passenger automobiles. All, with the exception of the products of the Ford Motor Company -- Ford, Mercury, LincolnZephyr and Lincoln cars--which will be shown during the show period at the company's building at 1,710 Broadway, are on view at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace.

Boatmen around a seaport town are apt to think all yachting is done on salt water. But along come two recognized authorities to prove otherwise. President Henry R. Sutphen and Secretary Ira Hand of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers have been doing some research work, and yesterday divulged amazing figures about pleasure boating on inland waters.

Detroit's Titians defeated the North Carolina State Wolfpack, 7 to 0, in an intersectional football game played before 8,000 spectators today. Ghesquiere scored the touchdown and Pegan added the point from placement to climax a brilliant second-period ground and aerial drive for the visitors.

NEW models on display at the National Automobile Show testify to the most extensive use of plastics yet seen on American motor cars. One model boasts fifteen more plastic interior fittings than it had last year. All cars, from the least expensive coupe to the most costly limousine, have acquired a new richness of appearance through the lustrous colors of plastic appointments.

Officials of the American Electric Bond and Share Company were told today by Mexican Government and labor officials that the temporary taking over by the government of their properties in five States at present affected by the electrical

Technical workers on strike against the Aerovox Corporation, which is moving its plant for the production of radio condensers from Brooklyn to New Bedford, Mass., voted yesterday to end their strike, but to carry on a renewed organizing campaign in New Bedford.
Twenty-two students of the Fordham Law School have been appointed to the 1938-39 editorial board of the Fordham Law Review, Ignatius M. Wilkinson, dean of the school, announces.

A number of Westchester clubs will hear talks this week on current literature, the first of which is a discussion of books and authors by Rosamond Beebe at a meeting tomorrow of the fine arts section of the Woman's Club of Mamaroneck. The current events section, meeting Wednesday, will hear a lecture on Czechoslovakia by Mrs. Gerti Freier.

IN this long, involved story of a disowned heiress restored to her possessions you get a mixture of American gangsters and their pursuers, English nobility on the home grounds, and solid American patriots.

New York State's voters approved six of the nine proposed amendments to the. State Constitution at last Tuesday's election, and cast out the remaining three. As the election slipped into history, persons interested in government throughout the State sat

PRINT tongs so constructed that prints may be picked up from three distinct angles are the latest gadgets to make an appearance in photographic row. Sold in sets of two pairs identical except in color, the tongs are colored red and black.

The engagement of Miss Frances Berenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Berenstein of- 22 East Eighty-eighth Street, to Dr. Irvin M. Fradkin of Freeport, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Fradkin of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.
HOLLYWOOD. WITH even less fanfare than attended his take-off on his wrong-way flight to Ireland, Douglas Corrigan arrived the other day to begin his screen career in RKO's "The Flying Irishman."

The question of how rapidly delinquency is increasing among girls, statistics on which support the most pessimistic views, need not agitate unduly civic groups who have been studying the topic in the opinion of Children's Court officials.

Over a pipe at the Harvard Club of Boston H. L. O. Flecker, headmaster of Christ's Hospital, the famous English school, discussed English and American secondary education with Dr. Claude M. Fuess, headmaster of Phillips Andover and because time was short and education long it was agreed to go on with much talk and tobacco the next morning at Andover.

Colonel Charles S. Caffery, Infantry, U. S. A., and Mrs. Caffery have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Coronel Caffery, to James Godfrey Skinner of Greenville, N. C., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Skinner of Greenville and New York.

The volume of mail orders received in the wholesale merchandise markets here last week declined, according to an analysis of buying activity prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Cornell scored the outstanding victory of the day in the East, defeating Dartmouth before a record crowd of 30,486 at Ithaca. This was the first setback for the Green in twenty-three contests. Princeton meanwhile earned a decisive triumph over Yale in the sixty-second game of their series as 50,000 looked on. Two major contests, the Fordham-North Carolina and Penn-Penn State, resulted in ties. Navy came back into the winning column by rallying to Conquer Columbia.
The prospective home owner is advised to examine carefully the closet space in any house that he may have under consideration.

SOME books, and they are incomparably the finest ones, seem rather to have grown than to have been made. Such a book is "East of the Sun and West of the Moon," a new selection of twenty-one stories from the Norwegian folk tales collected many years ago by Peter Christen Asbjornsen and Jorgen Moe and translated into English by George Webbe Dasent.
Public indignation over Germany's new onslaught against Jews has quickened Britain's drive for rearmament and pushed Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's appeasement goal still further away.

AS tens of thousands of Easterners pack their belongings their cars for the long Florida trip, one out of two, as usual, plans at least a part of his journey along that time-tried strip of macadam and concrete known as U. S. Route 1.

County-wide meetings of the Connecticut League of Women Voters this week will be devoted to the Neutrality Act of 1937. Dr. John W. Brewer, assistant professor of government at Connecticut State College, will speak on the act tomorrow when the Hartford and Litchfield County units will meet at the Loomis School in Windsor.

Renting conditions in this city show every prospect of improving next year, according to Donald Jones, vice president of William A. White Sons, who finds enc6uragement in the fact that the market held up well in the face of the disappointing business outlook early in the year and the unsettled International situation at the peak of the recent renting season.

The marriage of Miss Marie Agatha Stamm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stamm of Brooklyn, to Joseph Purroy de Angelis, also of Brooklyn, took place there yesterday morning in the Church of St. Barbara. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Lannig.

Demontrating further the practicability of cooperating living centers for worthy students, women residing in cooperativee or semi-cooperative houses have led Syracuse Univerity's thirty-eight living centers for women in scholastic ranking for he second consecutive semester, Despite the fact they must spend tart of each day working in their souses.

THIS is an involved yarn that out-Conrads Conrad in its involutions. It is by a fine story teller, our adopted son of letters, William McFee, as doughty a sailorman as ever wiped an engine or put pen to paper.

ON that July day in 1894 when Elwood Haynes first operated his horseless buggy in public on the old Pumpkinville Pike, near Kokomo, Ind., he gave the spectators the thrill of their lives and by the success of his trial run moved one step nearer to the modern miracle which moves over our great highways today. The thirty-seven-year-old inventor

A meeting of the chiefs of the General Staffs of the Balkan Entente nations-Turkey, Greece, Rumania and Yugoslavia-will be held at Athens on Thursday. Great importance is. attached to the meeting in view of recent events in Central Europe.
Harry Karp, builder at East Fiftysecond Street, between Foster Avenue and Avenue D in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn, will celebrate his thirtieth anniversary in the building industry this week.
Twelve hundred persons attended the annual dinner dance of New York Photo-Engravers Union 1 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last night.

SINCE the last automobile shows, Graham has again demonstrated the value of its supercharger as an economy feature by winning, for the third time in succession, the Gilmore-Yosemite sweepstakes award, emblematic of the best economy performance of any car in the competition.

AUTOMOBILE manufacturers are confident of at least a 25 per cent increase in sales during the coming year. The present instance marks the first time in more than two years that the entire automobile industry has looked into the future with strong optimism.
Organ Recital, by Dr. Charles M. Courboin at the American Academy of Arts and Letters: WOR, 12 M.

Yale's varsity and lightweight crews swept to victory over Princeton in two pre-season races on a three-quarter-mile course on Lake Carnegie today. Clocked in 3 minutes 50 seconds, the Eli varsity defeated the Tiger firsts and seconds by a close margin, with the Bulldog jayvees trailing.

BOTH in America and in England widespread campaigns are being carried on with the object of reducing traffic accidents. These are conducted by various safety foundations and kindred enterprises. That all such associations contribute their quota to the general fund of honest endeavor is undeniable.

THE scene is Panama, but the detective is Elisha Macomber, who hails from Penberthy Township, Mass., where he is in charge of law enforcement and pretty nearly everything else. Naturally, he has no authority whatever in Panama, but a little thing like that is not enough to stop Elisha Macomber.

A protest against the "tax burden on Manhattan realty" and the "flagrant and gross over-assessment" of values is contained in a manifesto issued yesterday by a "jury" of prominent real estate men for whom Lawrence B. Elliman acted as spokesman.

With sharp Republican gains in Tuesday's Congressional elections and with Republicans capturing such important States as Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, a knock-down-anddrag-out fight in the new Congress over the Wagner Labor Act is forecast by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

The Tax Department has just completed a reclassification of all real estate in the city, increasing the number of classes from ten to eighty-four, to make equalization of assessed valuations more feasible, William Stanley Miller, president of the department, announced yesterday.

Reviewing the present building situation and its future possibilities, Christian G. Norman, chairman of the Building Trades Employers Association, points out that for the first time this year it can be confidently predicted that the 1938 building volume will exceed that of 1937 for the country as a whole as well as for New York City.

The White House announced tentative plans today for President Roosevelt's trip to Warm Springs. He will be away from Washington about two weeks, during which he will make a formal address at Chapel Hill, N. C., Dec. 5, and possibly an informal speech at Chickamauga Dam,

Construction of public and institutional buildings is becoming an important factor in the present rising building market, points out the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which reports that in the month of October contracts were awarded in the thirty-seven Eastern States for such structures having an estimated cost value of $89,839,000.

Harold Amory, 45, of this town, a cotton merchant, yachtsman and veteran of the Yankee Division, with which he won a citation for bravery, was fatally injured this afternoon when his horse stumbled and rolled on him during a pont-to-point ride of the Norfolk Hunt Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am prompted to write about the editorial relative to the proposals advanced for State legislation to authorize the- establishment of "mortgage banks" or "mortgage debenture companies." Such legislation has been under discussion for the past two or three years, -but has so far failed of enactment.

AcceptOnce by the Ford and Chrysler Motor Companies this week of consent decrees (agreements ending court action) in the anti-trust suits brought against them by the Justice Department served to point up an aspect of national political news that is among the most important developments here in the last year.

CAPITOL-The Citadel: Robert Donat, Rosalind Russell.* CONTINENTAL-The Singing Blacksmith.* CRITERION-Vacation From Love and Titans of the Deep; Illegal Traffic: Mary Carlisle, opens Thursday. 5TH AVE. PLAYHOUSE1-The Story of a Cheat: Sacha Guitry.* FILMARTE-Grand Illusion: Eric von Stroheim, Jean Gabin.*

The German-American Mixed Claims Commission expects to take up again this month the story of spies and bombing plots involved in the Black Tom and Kingsland war-time munitions disasters in New Jersey.
Henry Ford's sixty-seven young partner in a "back-to-the-farm" experiment cut a six-thousand-dollar "melon' this week.

Sir Wilfred Grenfell, whose medical and social service work on the Labrador and Northern Newfoundland coasts has achieved wide recognition over a period of many years, and Lady Grenfell are taking an active interest in the annual opera benefit under the auspices of the Grenfell Association of America. The organization has chosen the performance of "Tannhaeuser" on the afternoon of Jan. 18 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit.
Miss Irene Van Feggelen of The Netherlands bettered her second women's world back-stroke swimming record within a week when she was timed in 1:13.2 today for the 100-meter back-stroke.

Miss Ruth Sherman, 19 years old, of the Rockland Apartments, Mamaroneck, died at the New Rochelle Hospital tonight of injuries received last night when she was thrown out of a roadster when it struck a tree.

Methods of the Health Department in safeguarding the purity of food and regulating the use of drugs will be shown to the public in an exhibition which will be opened at the Mott Haven Health Center, 349 East 140th Street, tomorrow to continue there for two weeks.

The marriage of Miss Ethel Mildred Harlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Harlow of New York and East Rockaway, L. I., to Dr. Thomas M. Mulcahy of New York, son of Mrs. Michael Mulcahy and the late Mr. Mulcahy, took place yesterday morning in St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church, Lynbrook, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael P. O'Shea.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Halleck Brodhead of this City of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Jane Broadhead to Howard T. Heintz, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William T. Heintz, and nephew of Miss Frances Heintz of New Rochelle.

Fifteen hundred persons attended a protest meeting against the anti-Jewish campaign in Germany in Columbus Circle yesterday afternoon, 200 of them paying thirtytwo cents each for telegrams addressed to President Roosevelt demanding an embargo on all trade with Germany.

When the- consumers' program on which three national women's organizations are cooperating is complete, the buyer of department store merchandise may be able to judge its value as accurately as the retail seller or the manufacturer.

The Community Power and Light Company, a registered holding company which, with its subsidiaries, operates in several States, including Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Texas, New Mexico, South Dakota and Nebraska, has filed an amendment to its plan of recapitalization under the Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The Bergen County (N. J.) Chamber of Commerce has embarked on a program designed to bring new industries into its meadowland industrial area, J. W. Binder, seccetary-treasurer of the chamber, announced yesterday.

Tennessee's fondest dream of a football championship and the laurels that go with the crown rallied from a nightmare today in a thrill-packed fourth-period, 14to-0 victory over a stubborn Vanderbilt team before 23,000 spectators.
DURING the early days of the automobile, motorists were forbidden to drive through Central Park in New York City, while operators of "steam" cars had to be licensed engineers.

Ulen Co. have notified the New York Stock Exchange that options have been granted to Thomas F. Devaney and Lockwood J. Towne for the purchase of 2,500 and 7,500 common shares, respectively, at $2.50 a share in whole or in part within three years from Oct. 20, 1938.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

Frank Sullivan. 24 years old, a statistician, made six futile attempts to end his life early yesterday morning in his room on the ninth floor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Sullivan, who lives at 64 Old Broadway, registered at the hotel under the fictitious name Stephen Shand, Dallas, Texas, and at Bellevue Hospital, after several hours of questioning, admitted his identity.

A cycle of the dance, ranging from a conception of Stone Age dances done to "savage rhythms," to the newest dance steps of 1939, will be presented at the sixth annual Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and Charity Ball, which will take place Dec. 16 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Cleveland Rams, a sensation in the National Football League for the past five weeks, will make their first New York appearance against the Giants at the Polo Grounds today and what looked like an easy game when originally scheduled now looms as one of the hardest of the campaign. The Maramen must win to stay in the running for the Eastern crown against the Washington Redskins.

In these last days of an unusually long-lingering Indian Summer, gardeners who have been planning and planting for early Spring effeats may well keep in mind those extremely ambitious perennials that flower almost before the snow is gone.
David F. Greenawalt, founder and president of Franklin Worsted Company, died Thursday at his home in Huntingdon Valley after an illness of four months.

OLD masters moved up into the foreground of the week's art panorama, bringing to a world of contemporary experimentation, of tentative enthusiasms, of often abortive effort, their perennial steadying message of ripe and time-mellowed accomplishment.
PERHAPS the fear of sounding sententious impelled George Frisbie Whicher to give this somewhat infelicitous title to his searchingly critical study of Emily Dickinson's life and poetry when he

REPORTS from various travel sources agree that the tourist to Florida this season will have more time for his trip than has been the case in many years. Time is what most motorists want more of when they roll south along the Southern Appalachians.
Francis De Lancey Robinson, retired New York architect, died here today at his home, Brecknock Hall, at the age of 66. He -had a town house at 121 East Thirty-seventh Street, Manhattan.

Western Maryland demonstrated exactly how upsets are achieved by defeating Wake Forest, 20-13, today. The ingredients were one overconfident opponent, one good kicker, Ed Peters; a covey of ball hawks in the front line and just enough defensive strength to hold a lead.

TELEVISION system which would permit reception of tele-images and accompanying sound in each room of a hotel or ship has won a patent (No. 2,135,577) for Philip J. Herbst of Merchantville, N. J. It is assigned to the Radio Corporation of America.
Dartmouth's dream of national empire on the gridiron and a winning streak that began in 1936 both came to an end today before the largest gathering ever to see a football game here.

The young Polish Jew who killed a secretary of the German Embassy here was said by the police today to have alternately wept and prayed when he learned of the 1,000,000,000-mark fine levied on German Jews because of his act.

The Department of Commerce reported today that imports of gold in October made a new high record for a month at $562,381,561, reflecting the flight of capital from Europe occasioned by threats of war. Much of the gold that arrived last month had been consigned for shipment at the height of the crisis in September.
Relations between the United States and Japan seem to have reached that complete- impasse which only total mutual incomprehension can produce.
THE Automobile Show is dedicated to the glorification of the mechanical and the metallic, and women are not supposed to be interested in such things.
Albright ended Lebanon Valley's fivegame winning streak with a 14-to-7 verdict in today's renewal of a gridiron feud dating back to 1902. The Lions rallied after being outplayed for three periods.

Wisconsin, turning on two blasts of power behind a hard-charging forward wall, defeated the Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles, 14 to 7, in an intersectional battle today before 50,000 spectators.

The recognition by management of its social responsibilities, of which much has been written and spoken in the last several months, has passed beyond the stage of mere public relations, in the view of production executives of a wide range of industrial concerns who conferred here last week under the auspices of the American Management Association.

Weakness in United States Government obligations in the face of modest improvement in other sections of the market was the outstanding development in active trading yesterday in bonds on the New York-Stock Exchange.

The new Norwegian-American line flagship, Oslofjord, will provide an appropriate setting for an entertainment to be given Tuesday afternoon under the auspices of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, largest shore home in the world for merchant seamen of all races and creeds.

ASEBALL'S Bill Terry once wanted to know "Is Brooklyn still in the league?" And literature's Thomas Wolfe once said "Only the dead know Brooklyn." To the derogation implied in question and statement the Borough of Churches can now afford to raise a haughty eyebrow. Brooklyn has been recognized by Hollywood and the results of that recognition will become apparent when "Submarine Patrol" reaches the Roxy Friday.

LEAVING the more or less beaten track followed in their earlier series, the Roths turn to record Albert Roussel's one and only string quartet-in D, Op. 45. The throngs now reviewing the new cars at the National Automobile Show will no doubt focus their attention on handy gear-shift levers, roomy interiors, ventilator grilles in "catwalks" at either side of the hood, safety lights that flash speed signals, electric windshield wipers, foot-buttons that tilt lights away from

Western Reserve University's band 2 went on a modified strike at the John Carroll football game today. The musicians refused to march at half-time in protest, officials said, to being unable to practice their formations on a field.
The forty-sixth renewal of the Union College-Hamilton gridiron classic today ended in a 21-0 victory for the Dutchmen. A crowd of 5,000 thrilled as Union scored three touchdowns on spectacular plays.

The Ministry of Education has appointed a Board of Educational Motion Pictures, which will maintain relations with the International Institue of Educational Motion Pictures, with headquarters in Rome.

A Comanche Indian, just in from New Mexico, became intoxicated yesterday afternoon, took an automobile standing in the street and careened madly through the lower east side, knocking down and injring seriously a woman pedestrian.

Washington, the most political city of the country, was last Tuesday above politics. While from one end of the country to the other citizens went to the polls to decide matters that would affect directly the business of the capital, Washingtonians went about their work. By law they are barred from voting.

Savings, building and loan associations throughout the country lent an aggregate of $71,647,000 for all purposes during September, bringing the total advanced for all types of loans during the first nine months of this year up to $597,000,000, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday.
MOST American travelers gain their impressions of French life, M. Andre Tardieu once declared in a moment of not wholly unjustified severity, "in places where French people never set their feet."

From the time in 1903 when the Lexow committee investigating the white slave traffic in New York City turned the spotlight on foreign-born women whose youth and inexperience made them prey to organized crime, young women have been the particular charge of the National Council of Jewish Women.

With inventories at the lowest point in more than a year and the business outlook considered excellent, purchasing agents of this city are placing substantial commitments for all types of industrial supplies, Harold K. LaRowe, president of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York, Inc., said here last week.

Examinations for licenses in mechanical drafting and trade drafting have been announced by the board of examiners. Applications must be filed by Dec. 5. Twentyone positions are available.

Mrs. David Challinor, director of the 1928 roll-call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday that women volunteers had opened enrolment booths in banks, office buildings, restaurants and theatres.

RIDING in the van of current performance and motivated by modern engineering skill, the motor-truck industry moves along with bright prospects for 1939. Both industry and agriculture are looking to more intensive activity for the coming year.

Plans for the alignment of progressive forces throughout the country under one leadership, with the possibility of a third party being formed, were discussed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan and Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Ohio at City Hall. Governor Murphy and Senator Bulkley were among the New Deal leaders voted out of office in Tuesday's election.

The seventy acres of land, formerly known as the Crane Woods development, a half mile north of the Scarsdale station in Westchester County, have been taken over by the Berkley Hills Corporation, developer of the Berkley development east of the station, and will be completed as a home community under the latter's direction.
Florida added one bright spot to an otherwise disappointing football season today with a 21-to-7 victory over air-minded Maryland.

An order which no longer will permit the conversion of class "A" multiple dwellings into residence clubs or rooming houses recently has been signed by Alfred E. Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Building, Edward B. Bell, president of the West of Central Park Association, has pointed out.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Evangeline Lampland, daughter of Mrs. Oscar Lampland of St. Paul, Minn., and the late Mr. Lampland, to Donald Duncan Ross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Ross of New York, formerly of Montreal, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lynde E. May Jr.

LITHUANIA, in commemoration of the twentieth anniversary of her independence, has issued a ten-litu silver coin. The obverse shows a portrait of Antanas Smetona, president of Lithuania. The reverse bears the inscription "Twenty Years Independence" and "The Power of the Nation' Lies in Unity."
Reports from scattered sections of New Jersey indicate that the shooting for the first two days was all the hunters had hoped it would be, which is quite an unusual state of affairs.

With Mayor Joseph F. Loehr, other municipal officials of Yonkers and several representatives from the Federal Housing Administration expected to attend, the first two units of the $1,000,000 Glenwood Gardens Apartment house development in Yonkers, Westchester County, will be dedicated Nov. 26.

Walter Zell, 36 years old, was locked up at the Hunters Point police station in Long Island City yesterday as a fugitive from justice in Connecticut.

The New York Rovers defeated the Hershey Cubs in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight, 7 to 1. It was a rough-and-tumble battle from the start, with several freefor-alls that threatened to involve the fans. Brownbridge scored in the first period on a shot in front of the net.

Striking evidence that the construction industry, particularly that part of it concerning home building, is definitely on the upgrade is provided in reports received yesterday from two different sources.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Monday Kellogg (Spencer) Sons, Inc. Public Service Electric Gas Co.

ACCOMPANYING an order received by the Packard Motor Car Company for a car destined for an Indian Maharajah was the following note: "The Maharajah weighs 280 pounds. He has two brothers who always travel with him. One weighs 325 pounds and the other 350.

The Weirton Steel Company today turned over its idle $500,000 Clarksburg "birthplace" plant to local Chamber of Commerce. Glen W. Tinsley, Chamber of Commerce president, said that Thomas Millsop, Weirton president, "gave us the plant to do with as we please," and that "we can either rent it or sell it."

Two touchdown passes from Banks McFadden to Gus Goins gave the Clemson College Tigers a 14-to-0 victory today over the University of Kentucky. Six thousand fans saw the Kentuckians lose their sixth straight game.

Miss Evelyn Chambers, older daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Laurance Chambers and a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Taggart, was married yesterday afternoon to Julius Birge of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Birge of Greenwich, Conn. Episcopal Bishop Joseph M. Francis

Among the 5,683 students registered last year in the Columbia University Extension, its branch of adult education, 131 were between the ages of fifty and seventy-five, Professor James C. Egbert, director, revealed in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.
Dominating the play from the start, Wayne University salvaged some glory from a losing football season by overwhelming the University of Buffalo, 35-to-0, before 6,500 spectators today.

Playing its second match in the Union, the Marylebone Cricket Club team today dismissed Western Province for 174 runs, and when stumps were drawn had made 70 for three wickets. Earlier in the week M. C. C. defeated a Western Province country district eleven by an innings and 342 runs.
Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia, today interpreted the American election returns as a warning to President Roosevelt not to plunge too hastily into European affairs.

The New Jersey office of the FHA announced yesterday that the percentage of new construction over existing construction has risen from 32 per cent in June, 1936, to 51 per cent in October of this year.
Chairman Frank R. McNinch of the Federal Communications Commission said tonight that government censorship of radio was "impracticable and definitely objectionable."

Two hundred and sixty-five men and women have enrolled for studies at the new Scarsdale Adult Education School, according to Harold E. Vehslage, treasurer of the committee of citizens conducting the school.

Widely acclaimed for its enterprise in evolving improvements which often seem to be exceedingly radical, the automobile industry nevertheless is closely guided by the tabulated experience and the expressed desires of the consumer,

The Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th Street, was the scene of the marriage yesterday afternoon of Miss Florence Hettema, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Myron Hettema of Angola, Ind., formerly of Passaic, N. J., to Fritz Carl Heynen of this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele, vicar of the chapel.

Japanese leaders are facing the stupendous problem of -again making. a going concern" of an occupied area stretching for 2,000 miles north and south and extend-ing, at its deepest point, 600 miles inland.

WITH the new Jefferson nickel the Roosevelt Aministration makes its first contribution to the American cabinet of monetary coins. Except by special act of Congress, the design of the coin of any particular denomination may be changed only once in every twenty-five years.

Production of gold in Quebec in September amounted to 73,345 ounces worth approximately $2,567,075, compared with 71,475 ounces worth $2,501,625 in August. Production in the first nine months of the year amounted to $641,365 ounces worth $22,447,775, against 516,916 ounces worth $18,092,060 in the corresponding period of 1937.

The People's Mandate Committee will send a delegation, led by Miss Mabel Vernon, its director, to Lima, Peru, to urge on the PanAmerican Conference "disarma-. ment, peaceful negotiation and international agreements to end economic anarchy," it was announced from the committee's headquarters here today.
A resolution demanding Leon Trotsky's expulsion from Mexico was voted today at a meeting at the Hidalgo Theatre by the Mexican left wing

Pennsylvania and Penn State battled to a 7-to-7 football tie before 45,000 on Franklin Field today in the thirty-seventh game of a storied series. After a dull, scoreless first half, highlighted only by Penn's drive to the 4 where it lost possession, the action speeded in the second half, particularly in the fourth period, when all the scoring was done.

Mrs. Lorenzo D. Armstrong will give a luncheon on Tuesday at the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Gloria Armstrong. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roberts and their daughter, Miss Priscilla Kent Roberts, have come from Greenwich, Conn., to 1,133 Park Avenue for the Winter.

As a part of a project to raise $20,000 before the end of the year, directors of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry are sponsoring a benefit theatre party the night of Nov. 30. The play chosen is "Herod and Mariamne," starring Katharine Cornell.

Blessing of the Mother Irene Gill Memorial Library, the College of New Rochelle's new $400,000 structure, which the architects ac-claim as "the last word in library planning," will take place on the campus here next Thursday. Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the Archidocese of New York, will officiate.

The six projected combination passenger-cargo liners for which bids were opened in Washington Thursday, are to be assigned to the reorganized American President Lines for service around the. world, it was reported yesterday after a conference of officials of the company here.

REDUCTION of motor wear to limits never before obtained is promised for the 1939 Chrysler engines and other working parts through the adoption of a "superfinishing" process developed by the production research engineers of the Chrysler factory under the direaction of David A. Wallace,

Dr. Gordon B. Maurer, a surgeon of this village and a former president of the Delaware County Medical Society, was killed early this forenoon while hunting grouse. His shotgun was discharged when he climbed over a stone wall and his head was partly blown off.

Miss Mary Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Flanagan of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning at the home of her parents to Valentine Burling Hammann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Hammann of Huntington, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James P. Smyth.

Transfers of securities or other property in trust are not uncommonly looked upon as having been made in avoidance of estate taxes. Questions as to whether transfers by trusts were made "in contemplation of death" invariably present vexatious problems to the courts and to the Treasury.

Caribbean and South -American countries are giving real, cooperation to American steamship lines, in promoting tourist trade arid commercial exchange, according ' to Godfrey Macdonald, assistant passenger traffic manager of the Grace Line, who returned last week after a tour of Southern countries, where he inspected the company's branch offices and agencies.

Once each year the breeders and fanciers of toy dogs meet in New York for a show that is all their own. This year's event will be the sixth annual exhibition of the Progressive Dog Club and will be given In the Roof Garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania Sunday, Nov. 27. Next sunday will be the deadline for the receipt of entries.
Coming. from behind, Garfield High School's eleven kept its record clear for the season today by scoring a 13-to-7 victory over East Side High School of this city.

LONDON. THE RE has been plenty of activity in the theatres this' week, but nothing to give the critic any excitement. Partly this is because all the plays that have opened have been seen before; partly because only one of them is better than mediocre.

At this season of the year, when garden remaking is in order, planters find themselves confronted by one common problem-the question of soil improvement. Too often the importance of the correct answer is not fully realized, and hence is left pretty much to guess work.

A highway safety campaign believed to be unique on such a scale got under way yesterday in Queens County when 500 Boy Scouts elicited pledges from drivers and fastened stickers on windshields. The drive will continue three more Saturdays.

BOSTON is still going strong. Three openings were chalked up this week, and every stage in town was lighted except the Copley, where the WPA is catching its breath for a fortnight between productions. Even the Majestic, which has been more or less out of the running, was pressed into service.
