Three of ten defendants in a liquor conspiracy case were found guilty today by a Federal court jury and received sentences totaling six years from Judge MacSwinford.

Introduced, within the last month in a few major cities, velvet ties for men have begun to sell fairly well and retailers in many sections of the country are now sending in small orders for them, manufacturers reported yesterday.
TWO sculptors whose work prominently figured in the week's developments expose certain traits in common as well as not inconsiderable divergences of aim and method.
A CITY literally lost for centuries, Macchu Picchu is without doubt the most won derful ancient ruin in the New World.

The Stevens soccer team defeated Lehigh today, 2-1. Pat Rockford converted a penalty kick in a slow first half. Azua scored on a long kick and Craig made Lehigh's point on a short boot, both in the third quarter. A fast final period left the score unchanged.

Miss Margot Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bryan S. Reid of Chicago, was married today to Alanson James Donald, son of Mrs. George Donald of New York, in St. Chrysostom's Church. The Rev. Dudley Stark officiated.

THERE is a great deal concerning food--about eighty pages--in this book. The author does such ample justice to the toothsome viands of the Quaker City that its men, manners and institutions lose body and spirit to the degree that its food gains savor.

For most gardeners there's a feeling of sadness in these crisp Fall days that come with the realization that the glow and abundance of bloom is becoming blackened by frost. One cannot help but think of the care and the time it will take to bring back from seeds planted in the Spring this wealth of bloom--often late June before the seedlings of calendulas, stocks, snapdragons and petunias will be in flower.

Chorus personnel and plans for the an fiftieth annual Princeton triangle show, "Once Over Lightly," have been announced by John Hines Jr., director of the chorus. The production will open in Princeton Dec. 9. The dancers will perform six numbers this year, including two ballets by the entire group.

URBANA, Ill.--Extensive building projects have been announced by the Illinois State Department of Public Works and Buildings, F. Lynden Smith, director, in connection with the preservation of historic and scenic spots in various parts of the State.

The four-family apartment house at 702 Banner Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Rebecca Cohen to Bessie Goldberg for a consideration of $10,500. William L. King of Brooklyn acted as attorney for the seller and Harry Karsh was the attorney for the buyer.

The Class Pin Dance will be held at Georgian Court College here on Dec. 1. A committee of sophomores is in charge of the dance, for which music will be provided by the Princeton Tigers, Princeton University swing band.

Led by a sharp rise in institutional advertising, fourteen departments out of thirty-seven in New York department stores had linage increases in October, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The total for the month was 3,607,654 lines, against 3,808,254 in October, 1937.
Chief Satistictian, National Safety Council MOTOR-VEHICLE accidents have always been the bad spot in the national safety picture.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Dunston, daughter of Mrs. William J. Dunston of this city, to Martin McHale of Hempstead, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McHale of Stoneham, Mass., has been announced.

Miss Katharine Thurston Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Roome Crane of Maplewood, was married this afternoon in the home of her parents to Albert T. C. Peters, son of Mrs. John Peters of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John E. Charlton, pastor of Morrow Memorial Church here.

Renewing their efforts to help to end British rule in six counties in the northeastern part of Ireland, members of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic, holding their eighteenth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, charged that government in the area (Ulster) was of "puppet" variety and demanded its abolition.

A large number of private houses, which can be maintained at prices considerably less than apartments offering approximately the same advantages, are now available in New York City and can be purchased at greatly reduced costs, points out Lawrence B. Elliman, president of Pease Elliman.
Miss Katharine M. Talmage. who had been a missionary of the Reformed Church in America at Amoy, China, for sixty-four years. died here today at Resthaven at the age of 85.

A man running through a hallway of the diamond center, crying "Hold up! Hold up!" while blood from a wound on his head coursed down his face, led to a brief period of excitement in the gem district around Canal Street and the Bowery about 1 P. M. yesterday.
The fact that the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, returning from a vacation in Africa, dined this week with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in Paris aroused some speculation here.

Coming at a time, when a better feeling between business and the administration appeared to be well under way, the attack on large advertising budgets made by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, last week in connection with the Ford and Chrysler consent decrees, not only disappointed but intensely irritated business and advertising men.

PINEHURST, N. C.--A series of sports and social events are on the calendar for the remainder of the month. Leading in prominence is the annual mid-South professional golf tournament, which opens the day after tomorrow and continues to next Friday on the championship No. 2 course.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 974 St. Nicholas Avenue, fronting 127 feet between 159th and 160th Streets, has been purchased by the 974 Realty Corporation represented by Samuel K. Beier, attorney.
A girl of 4 was saved from death today when police thwarted her father's intention to end both their lives by plunging over Niagara Falls.

DEVELOPMENTS expected in the tire manufacturing indus try during the next year are a greater degree of safety and longer life in tire performance, according to a study just completed by the Rubber Manufacturers Association in connection with inauguration of a new season in November for the automotive industries.

The Bergen County, N. J., Chamber of Commerce, at the request of Vincent Murphy, director of housing and welfare of the World's Fair, is now working out plans for the establishment in that county of a trailer camp for use by those expected to visit the World's Fair in trailers.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Kerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clark Kerr of this place, to Charles Edward Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Simpson of Ridgewood, took place here tonight in the Church of the Messiah. The Rev. Robert R. Bryan performed the ceremony.

The Chinese jades and porcelains and the Japanese lacquer boxes, which were sold yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, realized $17,500. This sum, added to that realized on the items auctioned on Friday, brought the total for the entire sale to $31,310.

PITTSBURGH. DESPITE a 3.4 per cent increase this year in the number of automobiles on the streets as compared with 1937, traffic fatalities in this city decreased 28 per cent in the first nine months of 1938.

An 18-year-old youth who said he was Alfred Guido of 4,019 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, the 126-pound champion in the Golden Gloves tournament of 1938, was released in $500 bail by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in the Felony Court yesterday on a charge of violating

Nine persons attended a requiem mass at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church, 623 East 138th Street, the Bronx, yesterday morning for Mary Mallon, the first known typhoid bacilli carrier in America, who died on Friday in Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island. The woman, known as Typhoid Mary, died of a paralytic stroke.

FOR the first time since 1922 a national motor truck show is held in New York City. In conjunction with the show a banquet and entertainment are scheduled to be held at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday evening, Nov. 15.

IN the early hours of a recent Autumn morn the good citizens of Astoria were startled by a caravan of buses carrying a cargo of what were unmistakably convicts. Motorists craned their necks; pedestrians stood still in amazement.

To keep pace with the changing school curriculum and at the same time keep the teachers of the New York City school system alert, the Board of Superintendents has es tablished a series of thirty-four free in-service courses this Fall.
The growth of the soil as studied by Smith College students of botany extends beyond the classroom to actual work in the garden, field and greenhouse.

THE history of mankind records many famous pilgrimages, but not even Canterbury or Lourdes or Mecca could' hold a candle to the prospective drawing power of the 1939 World's Fair at Flushing Meadows. With the fair still five months away, reports from-thousands of communities throughout the United States show that World's Fair fever is swiftly approaching the epidemic stage.

In view of the large amount of stock of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in the names of brokers and consequent difficulties by the corporation in getting in touch with the owners, the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday requested members and member firms holding I. T. T.

Vice President, Plymouth Motor Corporation IT is safe to assume, after a careful look at the new creations for 1939, that again next year the American motoring public will run true to form. Once again, close to 70 per cent of all the automobiles they buy will be in the popular-price field, represented by Plymouth and other high-volume producers.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Isabel Fulton Rankin of Washington, D. C., daughter of John R. Rankin of Sparta, Ill., and the late Mrs. Rankin, to Robert Maynard Crooker of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Crooker of Montreal, formerly of Larchmont, N. Y.

Political circles now regard it as virtually certain that Dr. Frantisek Chvalkovsky, Foreign Minister, will be nominated as President of Czechoslovakia and that the formality of electing him will be passed through within a very few weeks.

Living American artists have received $600,000 from sales of paintings and sculpture exhibited since the beginning of this century at annual shows held by the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, it was announced today by Alfred G. B. Steel, the president.

A GALA concert in celebration of the sixty-fifth birthday of William C. Handy, dean of jazz composers, will be given, Nov. 21, in Carnegie Hall. PROTECTION from noise, heat and cold are provided in the 1939 Oldsmobile "Sixty," "Seventy" and "Eighty" bodies by specific types of insulating material to fit each requirement.

The goal posts toppled with a crash at the Polo Grounds yesterday but it was more from force of habit than anything else, because Fordham and North Carolina battied to a surprising scoreless tie. Sixty minutes of hard, bruising play found the two teams at the same spot at which they started with not a point to show for it.

Princeton University's undergraduate committee on academic affairs, devised by the Undergraduate Council last Spring to give the student body a voice in formulating the college plan of study, has taken definite form with the announcement of a personnel today by Edward W. Hobler, '39, of Stamford, Conn.. chairman of the council.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 12, unless speelffed: At San Diego: Brazos, Gridley. Tucker, Nov. 10. At Norfolk: ClaxtonL Nov. 11 Manley. At San Franclsco: Chester, Louisville. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Owl, Salinas.

Professor George H. Nicholson of the mathematics department at the University of Vermont, has worked out models for several mathematical puzzlers and they have been built by an engineering student, A. J. Taggart.

Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis, who will be 82 years old tomorrow, will be the fourth person to serve on the Supreme Court after reaching that age. The jurist plans no special celebration of his birthday, friends said.

LONDON society has never been noted for being particularly busy, and a hundred years ago time must have hung with accustomed heaviness on its hands. The experiments in animal magnetism by the eighteenth century Swiss physician Franz Anton Mesmer reached England in garbled form about the time of Queen Victoria's accession.

A fighting Navy eleven spotted Columbia 9 points yesterday in the ninth clash of their series and then came rushing from behind to score two touchdowns on long cruises and win, 14-9, much to the amazement of 33,000 spectators who crammed Baker Field to the last available seat.

The gardener who regrets seeing his daffodils and tulips pass so quickly in the Spring may prolong the flowering period by the very simple expedient of making some extra late and extra deep plantings. In the writer's garden last year several varieties of daffodils, planted in December, flowered in late May and early June, weeks after similar sorts had passed by.
Clipper Smith's alert Villanova Wildcats remained in the undefeated class today by shoving over three touchdowns in the first half to beat their arch city rivals, Temple, 20 to 7, before 28,000.

Farmers of the agricultural West-especially the Middle West-may not want to go back to the old order of things. There is much to indicate they do not. But in last Tuesday's voting they voiced, in no uncertain terms, their dissatisfaction with the present order.
ONE of the most familiar sights in London, the two-story street cars speeding along the Thames Embankment in their own separate traffic lanes, will soon be no more.

CONFIDENCE in the future and determination to contribute to a rise in business, employment and optimism are spelled out in the new lines of cars which the automobile manufacturers are exhibiting at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace.
Modern traffic conditions require that an extremely intoxicated person be removed from the streets for his own safety, Magistrate Frank Oliver said yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court.

LONDON. PRACTICALLY all the musical institutions of this city have now resumed their usual labors. The B. B. C. Orchestra gave its first concert with a Brahms evening; the London Symphony Orchestra followed suit with Beethoven;

The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Carlotta Kruse, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Kruse of 145 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Kruse, to John Daniel Allison, son of Mrs. Harry E. Beadle of Crossville, Tenn., and the late John Henry Allison, has jeen announced by her mother. The wedding will take place on Dec. 3.

The swiftepace of the crowded curricular and extra-curricular program at Cornell University will be slowed to a standstill in the relaxing atmosphere of a new "browsing" library to be opened Dec. 1 as a part of the expansion program of Willard Straight Hall, the student union.
Harold H. Shearer, directory manager of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Thursday at his home in Darien, Conn., at the age of 52.

Prominent educators and authorities on child development will participate this week in the fiftieth anniversary conference and institute of the Child Study Association of America, which opens tomorrow morning at the Hotel Roosevelt. A series of lectures, round-table discussions, symposiums and exhibits have been scheduled.

Center for Safety Education, New York University THIS year the pedestrian has become the central actor in the traffic drama. His strong and weak points are under investigation in New York, Connecticut and other States, as well as by safety organizations.

The principals were announced today for the production of Richard Strauss's opera, "Der Rosenkavalier," with-which the Metropolitan Opera Association will open its Philadelphia series of ten performances at the Academy of Music on Nov. 22. They are: Lotte Lehmann, the Princess;

Improvement in sentiment in Wall Street as a result of the nation-wide elections on Tuesday found its clearest reflection, of course, in the stock market. The pre-election gains in share prices on Monday were substantial, but they did not match the post-election rise on Wednesday which lifted THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks 2.52 points in three-million-share trading.

Princeton's band, braying loudly the fact that "In Princeton Town, We Have a Team," paraded through the main street of this college town tonight and then subsided into drum beats as it came abreast of Nassau Hall, for the bell in the tower was clanging out its paean of victory.

Those who are prejudiced against the stiff bunchiness of the bedding hyacinth will be glad to know that this fragrant and colorful harbinger of Spring is now available in the form of a cluster of graceful sprays.

ECOGNIZING the increasing importance of amateur radio, especially in time of emer gency, when domestic communication facilities are out.of operation or curtailed, the Federal Communications Commission has revised its regulations governing home-operated stations. To be effective Dec. 1, the new rules specify higher technical standards to reduce possibility of interference to other traffic as well as improving the amateur service.

ACCORDING to E. Raymond Cato, chief of the California Highway Patrol, determinations have been made of the carbon monoxide concentration in the air breathed by drivers of 1,105 motor vehicles of various types during five minutes or longer periods of actual operation on California highways under varying weather and road conditions.

Miss Vera Virginia Allem, daughter of Princess Stanislas Czetwertynski of Glendale, Ohio, and Warsaw, Poland, and of William Thompson Allen of Kenyon Ranch, Tubac, Ariz., is engaged to James Wilmer Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Parker Jones of Washington, D. C., and Marblehead Neck, Mass.

Fulvio Suvich, retiring Italian Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday on the Italian motor ship Conte di Savoia on his way to Rome. After making his report to the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Premier Mussolini he will go to Trieste.

THIS is a strange book to come from troubled Austria. Readers of "Bambi" will be glad to hear of the recent denial of the rumors that its author, Felix Salten, is in a German concentration camp. But there is nothing in this book of European turmoil; like "Bambi," it is a tale of the forest and its wild
Cornell defeated Villanova in an Eastern Intercollegiate 150-Pound League game today, 13-2, before 3,000 fans. The Ithacans made both their touchdowns in the first half.
WHEN the next session of Congress convenes, in January, it will be faced with several vexatious problems, not least of which is the economic position of the railroad industry.
The Memhard farm on Harmony Road, near Pawling, Dutchess County, N. Y., has been purchased by Reuben A. Lazarus, assistant to the president of the New York City Council. from Allen R. Membard.

LOS ANGELES. WITH at least fifteen foreign countries on their list of customers, major aircraft building corporations in the Los Angeles area face the problem of increasing this number, adding to the per-nation sales, and guaranteeing against a slump in trade once the current race to rearm dwindles.

The widespread work of the Union Settlement will be aided by the performance tomorrow night of "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," at the Plymouth Theatre. Members of the settlement's women's auxiliary have taken over the entire house.
WHERE to go, and when, are questions now being discussed by persons planning Winter cruises. Some have already taken up their passage to insure selected quarters on a favorite ship.

Johnny Clement and Ray Mallouf, sophomores, flipped three touchdown passes today to overwhelm Arkansas, 19-6, and keep Southern Methodist University even with Texas Christian U. in their dash for the Southwest Conference title.

In the old German city of Hannover, around dawn of last Oct. 28, an elderly Jewish tailor named Grynszpan was summoned from his bed by Nazi Elite Guards, given time to pack a few clothes and then herded on a train for the Polish border.

New York State has contributed the greatest number of students to Manhattan College's freshman class, it was announced yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar. The survey shows that 379 of the 413 students came from 111 preparatory or high schools of this State.

John Erskine, author and lecturer, will be the guest speaker before 800 teachers and school administrators from New York and nearby States at the fifth annual Foreign Language Conference sponsored by New York University on Nov. 19, it was announced by Professor Rollin H. Tanner of the university's School of Education, director of the conference.
It was learned today from Danzig that the homes of many Jews were searched early this morning, with many arrests "to prevent disorders."

Sales of household electrical refrigerators during September to distributors and dealers in the United States totaled 57,985, compared with 76,905 in September, 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

It is estimated that about 300 tons of Christmas mail will be flown along British Empire routes in the next five weeks. Something like 17,000,000 letters are expected to leave Southampton by flying boat.
Vice Pres. of General Motors Corp. in Chare of Research OUT of all of the past experiences it is impossible for us, even those in industry, to project industrial developments a few years ahead.

Soviet aviation authorities give full credit to the British bombing planes and pilots who broke the Soviet nonstop record with a 7,162-mile flight from Egypt to Australia last weekend, but they are confident they can win the record back.

Formation of an interindustry committee to serve as a central clearing house for statistics to inform the public of the drug and chemical industry's activities is now under way by the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades Section of the New York Board of Trade and will be completed shortly, it was made known yesterday.

APPARENTLY gentlemen prefer blonds in woodwork, too. At least furniture makers report an unprecedented demand for light-colored woods to go with the shiny metals and geometric designs of the ultra-modern home decor.

The Chillicothe Scioto Gazette, an afternoon daily, announced today the purchase of The Chillicothe News Advertiser, which will become a morning daily, and plans for publication soon of a Sunday edition by the combined concerns.

The application of telegraph companies for wage exemptions under the Wages and Hours Law for about 20,000 messengers was denied today on the ground that payment of the minimum of 25 cents an hour under the law would not curtail opportunities for employment.

ALTHOUGH influence of the chemist in the rubber industry has been notable during the last twenty years, few persons attending the automobile show at the Grand Central Palace are aware that to him belongs much credit for the long life of the tires with which cars of today are equipped.

The Affiliated Fund, Inc., Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $4,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent ten-year secured convertible debentures to be offered at par.

The $1,040,000 mortgage held by the New York Life Insurance Company on the third unit in the Garden Bay Manor development sponsored by N. K. Winston Co. at Jackson Heights, L. I., has been insured by the Federal Housing Administration, Thomas G. Grace, State director, announced yesterday.
Active interest in the store buildings being erected by his firm on Centre Avenue and Main Street, New Rochelle, Westchester County, is reported by I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Company, Inc.

The Hall of Nations, American University's graduate division for foreign students, has just opened its second year with fifteen fellows from eight European countries, Brazil, Honduras, Mexico and Panama. In its first year, twelve fellows were enrolled, most of them from Latin-American countries.

A utilities executive testified today that "threats" following his refusal to pay city officials a $270,000 bribe caused him to publish a full-page newspaper advertisement "to protect myself and my company from racketeering."

The fiftieth anniversary of the Woodberry Forest School of Virginia, one of the oldest boys' preparatory schools in the South, will be celebrated Saturday with what is expected to be the largest reunion of alumni ever held at the school near Orange, Va.
A strong Taft eleven defeated the previously undefeated Berkshire team, 13--7, on the Taft field today. Berkshire kicked off to Taft and Captain Moore ran the ball back to the 50.

THE motorist on the road this week end-off for eighteen holes in the crisp November air, returning from a roaring football stadium, or merely out for a spin with the family-revels in the smooth and effortless performance of his automobile.

Miss Virginia Bethel Wight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Wight of Chestnut Hill, will be married on Nov. 25 to William McPherson Bigelow of this city, son of Mrs. Jay Whiting Bigelow of Easton, Md., and the late Mr. Bigelow.

With a newspaper as textbook and the expanse of the campus from which to draw news stories, features, interviews and editorials, students of journalism at Mount Holyoke College aim to learn to know how newspapers and news values as an accompaniment to practice in Writing technique.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Woodberry Forest School of Virginia, one of the oldest boys' preparatory schools in the South, will be celebrated Saturday with what is expected to be the largest reunion of alumni ever held at the school near Orange, Va.
A strong Taft eleven defeated the previously undefeated Berkshire team, 13--7, on the Taft field today. Berkshire kicked off to Taft and Captain Moore ran the ball back to the 50.

THE motorist on the road this week end-off for eighteen holes in the crisp November air, returning from a roaring football stadium, or merely out for a spin with the family-revels in the smooth and effortless performance of his automobile.

Miss Virginia Bethel Wight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Wight of Chestnut Hill, will be married on Nov. 25 to William McPherson Bigelow of this city, son of Mrs. Jay Whiting Bigelow of Easton, Md., and the late Mr. Bigelow.

With a newspaper as textbook and the expanse of the campus from which to draw news stories, features, interviews and editorials, students of journalism at Mount Holyoke College aim to learn to know how newspapers and news values as an accompaniment to practice in Writing technique.

Tne annual meeting and election of officers of the New York branch of the Needlework Guild of America will be held on Tuesday, together with an annual exhibit of new garments collected. Speakers will be Miss Ollie Randall of the A. I. C. P. and Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-el. Miss Amy Hope Ballard will preside.

A bridge and tea will be given for the benefit of the Appalachian School at Penland, N. C., tomorrow afternoon on the St. Regis roof by the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension. The beneficiary is a country day and boarding school conducted under the auspices of the Episcopal Church.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Boooklyn said yesterday that the injuries received by Assistant District Attorney Samuel Goldstein in an accident Friday will not delay his investigation into the bail bond situation in Brooklyn.
A new penal code to replace the antiquated Spanish code of colonial days, applied in Cuba since 1879, has been put into force in the island.

RECORDING changes in pulse rate, respiration and electrical resistance of the skin of 148 children, Dr. John J. DeBoer, at the University of Chicago, has made a study of the emotional effects of radio programs on children.

A small number of entries enabled the American Chesapeake Club to run off two stakes on the second day of their annual Fall field trials at Penniman's Point today. Chesabob, owned by the Selwyne Kennels of R. M. Carpenter of Montchannin, Md., annexed the amateur handlers' event and Break O'Day Barnacle Bill, belonging to Anthony A. Bliss of Westbury, L. I., captured the top award in the Derby.

The National Motor Truck Show, off to a slow start in its Armistice Day opening, yesterday drew a crowd of visitors larger by several thousand than on Friday. Business men making use of highway transportation and casual sightseers found exhibits of interest at nearly every turn and. spent hours in the great, block-square commerce Hall.
President Roosevelt's coming appointment of a new Supreme Court justice may provide the first test of administration strength in the new Congress.

WOODROW WILSON in his historic Fourteen Points placed before Congress on Jan. 8, 1918, held that one condition for a settlement of the World War was an independent Polish State, to include territories inhabited by Polish populations and having access to the sea.

Builders in all of the development sections of Long Island were again favored last week with mild Fall weather and that factor combined with the two holidays drew a large number of prospective home owners to the low-cost and medium priced residential projects under way in Queens and adjacent areas of Nassau County.

UNFOLDING one's own personality on the printed page is not an easy process if it is done with any degree of candor, but the difficulty has not deterred Mr. Railey, for here he has hewed to the line without any particular regard for the final resting place of the chips.

THE sides of the big stadium have been slowly filling up for the past half hour, the color of the crowd blotting out the gray of the concrete stands. It is the day that brings the climax of the football season, the day of the big game, the traditional final encounter.

Playing before an Old Timers' and Fathers' Day crowd of 5,500, the Ursinus Bears were finally defeated by the Gettysburg Bullets today, 19-12. Fred Hamilton, halfback for the Bullets, starred with all three of his teams' touchdowns.

Seeking to combat fascism, communism and similar trends, Florida Southern College is establishing a Chair of Democracy, with objectives including not only instruction for students but also a bureau of press and radio propaganda for the public generally.

Revival of the so-called truth-infabric bill, requiring the identification of virgin and reworked wool, at the forthcoming session of Congress will again meet strong resistance from retailers, it was stated yesterday by Irving Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

DETROIT. "CLOSED for model changeover." That is a fourword phrase that passes almost unnoticed by millions of patrons of the automotive industry. For the automobile production geniuses, who are the real scene shifters at the National Automobile Show now at Grand Central Palace, this phrase means hours of study, work, thought and afterthought.

Tne annual meeting and election of officers of the New York branch of the Needlework Guild of America will be held on Tuesday, together with an annual exhibit of new garments collected. Speakers will be Miss Ollie Randall of the A. I. C. P. and Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-el. Miss Amy Hope Ballard will preside.

The Middlebury Panthers captured the State football title today by deeating Vermont in the final period of a hard-fought game, 7-0. Standing on his own 25, Mahoney tossed a pass to Captain Kirk on the 15 for the touchdown. Jacques converted the point from placement.

Starting with a nucleus of sixtythree members less than two years ago, the Friends of the Library, an association at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has expanded into a society of more than 250 members and is still growing.

While the Nazis this week were staging the most furious of a long series of pogroms, which will add tens of thousands to the stream of dispossessed refugees that Germany is casting upon other countries, publication in London of the latest report on Palestine showed the whole question of a Jewish national home there was again in the melting pot.

Editor Bus Transportation ALL classes of motor bus companies are expected to gain as a result of the Federal Government's financial pump-priming policies, and the business revival which seems imminent.
Idaho lost to Washington State College, 12 to 0, today. A crowd of 8,000 watched the two teams slip and slide and fumble in six inches of slush and snow which fell this morning.

WHEN audiences in different countries, European as well as American, respond to a film with equal enthusiasm, one may well regard it as having universal human appeal. To see such a reaction aroused by one of his pictures is a great joy to the one who has brought it into being.

HARRY A. OVERSTREET, president of the Cooperative Book Club, Inc., 118 East Twenty-eighth Street, New York City, reports that the members of that club were recently asked this question: "Should the Cooperative Book Club offer selected books at special prices?" Seventy-four per cent of the members replied that they preferred to choose their own books rather than to have them chosen for them.

JOINING the long list of European nations broadcasting daily on short waves for American listeners, Budapest anounces that its 31-meter station will be on the air each night except Saturday at 7 o'clock, Eastern standard time. On Saturday the Hungarian aerials will flash programs eastward beginning at 6 o'clock on the 9.125-megacycle outlet.

Interior woodwork finish will last longer and look better if subjected to frequent and thorough cleaning. It may be kept clean by periodic removal of surface dust and by preventing the formation of grease film.

Bucknell University's annual intramural debating contest will take place soon after Thanksgiving vacation, with thirteen fraternities and six sororities discussing the question: "Resolved, That Bucknell University shall adopt the plan of education introduced at Chicago University by President Hutchins."

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities will launch their second merged campaign for funds tonight with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced, yesterday by Walter Rothschild, chairman for the 1938 campaign.

Pope Pius, in an audience for pilgrims from five continents, today extolled the life of Mother Cabrini, who is to be beatified tomorrow, as a "poem of holiness, activity, intelligence and charity." The Pope told the audience of nearly 2,000 persons, including eighty nuns from the United States, that he particularly welcomed George Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, who will officiate at the beatification tomorrow in St. Peter's.
The Census Bureau reported today that 1,464,564 tons of cottonseed were crushed by mills during October. This compared with 1,930,944 tons during the same month last year.

The trend of American political sentiment today is unmistakably toward the right. It was dramatically manifest in the Democratic losses in last Tuesday's election, which gave the Republicans more than eighty new seats in the House, eight new Senators, and control of the State governments in eighteen States.

The American steel industry is wholly or in large part dependent upon foreign sources for seven of the twelve principal non-ferrous metals used in the manufacture of steel, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, which includes nearly all the chromium, cobait, manganese, nickel and tin and a substantial part of the tungsten and vanadium as imported metals.

Journalism is the field to be honored by the twelfth annual "friendship dinner" to be held tomorrow night at the American Woman's Club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. The Advertising Women of New York will be hostess with a former president, Miss Elsie Wilson, as chairman of the evening.

Miss Mary Kathryn Dilger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Owen Dilger of this place, was married this afternoon to Tristam Walker Metcalfe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Metcalfe of Tuckahoe, in the Hitchcock Memorial Church, Szarsdale.

World stocks of refined copper on Oct. 31 were 424,711 tons, compared with 457,454 on Sept. 30, a decrease of 32,743, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks increased 17,582 tons, making the net decrease 14,891 tons.
FIRST concerts of the season by the National Orchestral and the Beethoven Associations and the first appearance here of the Boston Symphony Orchestra mark the current week.
David O'Brien breezed his unconquered Texas Christians over their eighth straight barrier today with passing magic that mystified University of Texas, 28 to 6.

Because five of the city's neighborhood moving picture theatres were lax in making the required special arrangements for unattended children in their audiences, the licenses of these houses were recently temporarily suspended by Paul Moss, Commissioner of the Department of Licenses.

A change in tabulations in Howard County, adding about 1,000 votes to the Republican total, has apparently put James M. Tucker of Paoli into the Secretary of State's chair, giving the party at least two State offices.
Swarthmore triumphed by 42-0 over a light St. John's team today, making three touchdowns in the first quarter. Tallies were added in the other periods, all cut by five minutes.

OUR Historic Comebacks department, started last week in honor of "Old Bill," the model for the buffalo nickel who was engaged to lead a stampede in a Warner Brothers' production, this week belongs to Charles Edward Gounod, whose composition, "Ah! Je Veux Vivre" has made such a hit, after being plugged by Deanna Durbin in "That Certain Age" (now at the Roxy) that it has been issued by G. Schirmer in a new popular edition.

Brooklyn Woman's Club-Club day program, 1:45 P. M. Clio-Luncheon meeting and program, Hotel Astor. Comoedia Matinee Club-Benefit bridge, Hotel Astor. D. A. R. (Major Joseph Bloomfield Chapter of Bloomfield, N. J.)--Luncheon, card party, home of Mrs. J. Harry Philips, Glen Ridge.

MARGARET SANGER'S father was Michael Hennessey Higgins, an agnostic Irishman with fiery hair and a rebellious mind. Her mother was Anne Purcell, a wraith of a woman who bore him eleven children and died of tuberculosis.

The Oklahoma Sooners engineered three touchdown drives against Missouri today to run their victory string to eleven in a row with a 21-0 shutout that carried them within one notch of their first Big Six Conference title.

A hungry Bulldog against a half-starved Tiger. Only two victories for each as they lined up for this battle in Jungletown. But what are records when the players trot out for a traditional game like this? It's Yale against Princeton. That's enough. The proof of it was the great crowd that flocked into Palmer Stadium and burst into a roar as Karper kicked off for

A group of North Jersey and New York building operators, real estate owners, heads of lending institutions and several representatives of the architectural and construction fields will meet Tuesday at the Irvington Elks Club, Irvington, N. J., to discuss the FHA's rental housing program.
In a dozen different ways the forthcoming visit of King George and Queen Elizabeth to Canada promises to be a momentous event.

Production of Canadian newsprint in October totaled 254,872 tons, compared with 315,477 in the same period of 1937, it has been announced by the Newsprint Association of Canada.. Shipments were 255,100 tons, against 338,215.

LaSalle closed its season today with a 20-0 victory over Pennsylvania Military College at McCarthy Field. Quarterback Leo Deschak of Edwardsville, Pa., accounted for 12 of the Explorers' points. He was aided by the running, passing and punting of Paul Prettyman, who tallied the first touchdown and tossed to Deschak for the second.

AMERICAN cities are in critical need of streamlined streets. If cities are to meet the grow ing challenge of traffic accidents and bring a permanent solution to the ever-mounting burden of traffic congestion, city planners and street designers must apply the same streamlining technique that has been used by the automotive engineers.

Mrs. August Belmont of New York, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, and Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan, will be the honor guests at a luncheon to be given by Mrs. George Horace Lorimer, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association for Philadelphia, aided by Mrs. Randal Morgan, chairman of the Philadelphia branch of the Guild, at the Ritz-Carlton on Tuesday.

Historic and typical examples of early New York architecture are rapidly passing away due to the destruction of many fine old houses in recent years, points out Talbot F. Hamlin, librarian of the Columbia University School of architecture.

THE warm Fall notwithstanding, togs for skiing and skating are in readiness for devotees of these sports. Sports departments are a riot of color in anticipation of Winter. But skaters need not wait for the first flurries of snow, and ice on the ponds, for indoor skating is popular from New York to California.
The Par Construction Corporation, builder on the 312-acre subdivision of the Percy A. Rockefeller estate in Greenwich, has recently completed two houses, which are to be offered for sale.

Four endowed scholarships have been awarded to undergraduates in Columbia College for their remaining years in the school, it is announced by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes. The largest grant given by the college, the Henry Evans Scholarship, went to Theodore de Bary of Leonia, N.J. a sophomore.

THE Diesel engine is stealing the Motor Truck Show over in the Port of New York Authority Building and is making quite a dent over in the Automobile Show in the Grand Central Palace. For the first time the Diesel engine is really coming into its own in the motor truck and bus field.

To all the comment, professional and otherwise, on the outcome of Tuesday's national election there is an overtone of rejoicing that party control and party responsibility have been restored to a more normal place in American government.

Twelve Sarah Lawrence College students will soon choose a Westchester community, of which they will make a study, Already they have decided that economic security is the greatest problem of youth today. The group has made this decision after four weeks of reading and discussing what makes a community, what institutions affect it, what forces shape it, what human problems become community problems, and when and why.

WITH a sweeping plurality which left no doubt as to the intensity of their conviction, amateur photographers recently indicated in a poll conducted by a leading photographic film manufacturer that high-key portraiture is their favorite type of photography.

Marriage parlors were so crowded couples stood in line and one minister took on two assistants tonight as out-of-State residents hurried to take advantage of Elkton's weddings-while-you-wait service which ends Dec. 8.

A tea will be given tomorrow at the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, 8 Pitt Street, to celebrate recent improvements in the school. Invitations have been sent out by Miss Helen Hall, administrator of HenryStreet Settlement; Miss Grace Spofford, director of the school, and Mrs, Lionello Perera, on behalf of the school committee.

Calling attention to the fact that home construction in the Fall and Winter seasons is perfectly feasible, the PHA points out that one advantage is the contractors are usually looking for work that will enable them to keep their organizations intact during the dull period, and material dealers are eager for orders to keep their staffs busy and to pay overhead on their establishments and organizations.
Dr. Wellford Bohannon Lorraine died in his home here today at the age of 58.

The Dominion of Canada has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $40,000,000 of thirty-year 3 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 15, 1968, naming fifty-five underwriters.
Pittsburgh's "dream" backfield, minus the famed Marshall Goldberg, quashed Nebraska's dream of an upset victory by defeating the Huskers, 19 to 0, today in their thirteenth annual gridiron conflict.

The continuous series of programs projected for the Temple of Religion at the New York World's Fair of 1939 will include no interdenominational or denominational services of a ritualistic nature, but instead will be devoted to convocations and meetings, music, and pageants and drama, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors of the undertaking.

Tabor Academy scored a 7-6 upset victory over a powerful Governor Dummer eleven today for their fifth and final triumph of the season. With thirty seconds to play, Captain Brett tossed a touchdown pass to Scales on the fourth down and Daggett drop-kicked the winning point. The line-up:

An interesting example of a cafeteria designed on attractive lines is that recently completed by Riker's at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Forty-fifth Street from plans by J. M. Berlinger, architect.

John Adams Payne has commissioned Eugene Nostrand, Hempstead architect, to prepare plans for the erection of a home on a quarter-acre plot he recently purchased at Seawane Estates, in the village of Hewlett Harbor, L. I. It will be built by Wilfred Stewart.

Speaking at the recent convention in Syracuse of the Refrigerating Service Engineering Society, Dr. Willis H. Carrier, chairman of the Carrier Corporation, pointed out that if, to the heating of homes by warm air, is added the equipment for cleaning and humidifying the air, as well as circulating it,

IN spite of the several acute political crises that have disturbed and are still disturbing the peace of the whole of Europe, activity in the automobile world in the leading countries has not abated in the least since I last wrote in THE NEW YORK TIMES. New designs, new body work and all-round improvement are the keywords of the situation.

The Republic of Ecuador has conferred the national order Al Merito, officer rank, upon G. Butler Sherwell, foreign representative of the Manufacturers Trust Company, in recognition of his services in behalf of that country.

The first American school in Bogota, Colombia, opened this Fall and will continue until June 30. The enrollment is thirty-five students. The need for elementary instruction in English and for preparation for continuing study at home led to the organization of this school for children of American and British residents of Bogota.

After driving twice within inches of a touchdown only to be pushed back by a stiffening Iowa defense, Indiana made good on a third thrust in the last two minutes of play and gained a 7-to-3 decis??on before a dad's day crowd of 12,000 today.

Auburn's amazing Tigers, led by fiery Speck Kelly, who put on a great exhibition for his home folks, completely outplayed the favored Louisiana State eleven today for a 28-to-6 victory before 15,000 fans.

New York City's 17,000 Girl Scouts are having a chance to go in for radio work, little theatre activities, art and literature, as well as dress, make-up and the matter of being hostesses, with the inclusion of these subjects for the first time on a city-wide basis in their Fall program.

George Pye, 19, used the last of his shotgun shells to commit suicide today a few minutes after he had accidentally shot and fatally wounded a hunting companion, Floyd Greenwald, 11. The double tragedy at down on the Pye farm near Waukegan was witnessed by Clarence Vogler Jr., 12, who had never before been on a hunting trip.

Announcement has been made to friends and relatives here by Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Elliott of Milwaukee of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Macpherson Elliott, to Hiram Royal Mallinson of New York, son of Mrs. Hiram Royal Mallinson and the late Mr. Mallinson.

The American Bankers Association faces another internal squabble at its sixty-fourth annual convention, which will be opened on Monday in the Hotel Rice here. Like the celebrated quarrel that rent the association three years ago at its convention in New Orleans, the present dispute concerns, on the surface, a three-cornered contest for the office of second vice president of the association;

Unexpected strength in Liverpool imparted a firmer tone today to the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, but the response was indifferent, and at the close prices were only 1/4 to 5/8 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.

Secretary of State Corell Hull called Ambassador Hans Dieckhoff to the State Department today for a fifteen - minute conversation, which gave rise to reports that' they had discussed the new measures against Jews in the Reich.
In an attempt to show English audiences something of the gayety of French classics, Maurice Sachs, the French producer, has arranged an Anglo-French season at the Apollo Theatre.

More than 10,000 persons, many of them school children, found the halls and corridors of the Museum of Natural History transformed into bowers of Fall blooms yesterday at the thirty-first annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York. The final showing will be conducted today from 1 to 5 P. M.

THIS is the first collection of miners' ballads and songs to be made in America. There have been collections of cowboy ballads and of the songs of the Southern mountaineers, and those compilations of folk minstrelsy,

Alert and smart enough to profit by several breaks created by the opposition's erratic ball-handling, Andover conquered Exeter, 14 to 6, on Brothers Field today to add another exciting chapter to their ivydraped football series.
About 500 of the 832 students at Union College are partly or wholly working their way, according to a survey just completed by Miss Frances Travis, director of the Student Employment Bureau.

Canadian industry made its greatest advance of the present recovery period last month with a gain of about 3 per cent, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. While the upturn in October is traceable partly to the resumption of normal conditions, it was too widespread to be credited fully to lessened political tension, he said.

With a perfect score, the Irish Army team last night won the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy, the greatest competition in the fifty-third annual National Horse Show and the final event in the annual exhibition. In the presence of a crowd of 17,000 at midnight, the international riders completed their title competition in Madison Square Garden. The Irish victory was conclusive.

Mrs. Margaret Sanger, pioneer birth control advocate in this country, voiced her concern yesterday over the low birth rate among "healthy and intelligent couples" and advocated private subsidies to those in this group who cannot afford to bring up a family as a means of "promoting the national welfare."

Ducky Pond, coach of the defeated Yale eleven, paid tribute to the fine play of Princeton today, singling out Captain Tom Mountain for especial praise. "The Princeton team played a very alert and very aggressive game," Pond said.

A generation ago it was the common thing to own a horse; only the affluent could afford the new-fangled luxury of a motor car. Today the multi-horsepowered automobile is the possession of the average American;

Roger Fawcett won the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday with a run of 100. It was his third perfect string in four shoots this season. A. S. Cornhill defeated A. Mullhaupt and E. P. Feeley for Class A handicap honors. O. Wuerz triumphed in Class B.

Ducky Pond, coach of the defeated Yale eleven, paid tribute to the fine play of Princeton today, singling out Captain Tom Mountain for especial praise. "The Princeton team played a very alert and very aggressive game," Pond said.

A generation ago it was the common thing to own a horse; only the affluent could afford the new-fangled luxury of a motor car. Today the multi-horsepowered automobile is the possession of the average American;

Roger Fawcett won the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday with a run of 100. It was his third perfect string in four shoots this season. A. S. Cornhill defeated A. Mullhaupt and E. P. Feeley for Class A handicap honors. O. Wuerz triumphed in Class B.

Despite a balmy Saturday and football games of importance, attendance was excellent yesterday at the National Automobile Show which opened on Friday afternoon ?? Grand Central Palace. Crowds returning from the games increased the attendance in the late afternoon and evening.

Calls for special prayer and intercession next week-end for the victims of "racial and religious oppression" throughout the world have been issued by Catholic, Protestant and Jewish organizations to their constituencies, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

WORK RELIEF: Sir John Jarvis, M. P., steel master, is a native of Jarrow, Surrey, a town whose shipyards once employed 8,000 men. For years they have been idle. To provide work Sir John has from time to time bought old ships and towed them to Jarrow for breaking up.

Any lily expert asked for a list of a dozen easily grown kinds of garden value is pretty sure to include the Nankeen Lily. Certainly it is among the most beautiful of all garden lilies. Most gardeners have a belief that lilies are capricious, needing expert care to insure success.

The best Carnegie Tech football team in years kept step right up front in the national football parade today by roundly thumping its city rivals, Duquesne, with three perfectly pitched touchdown passes for a 21-0 victory. A crowd of 31,000 saw the game.

Dazzy Vance, once one of the greatest pitchers in baseball, tonight was reported out of danger from an attack of pneumonia which has confined him to a hospital here for a week. For several days his condition was critical. He is expected to be moved to his home in Homosassa within a few days.
Rayon, the young industry which has flourished throughout the depression, sprouts a new tooth this week.

The Chickasaw Shipbuilding and Car Company's $20,000,000 shipyards at Chickasaw, a suburb of this city, has been purchased by a newly formed concern, which will resume operations there, according to an announcement today.

Two men, overcome by smoke while attempting to fight a fire in a second-floor bedroom at 315 Madison Street, were rescued last night by Fireman Ferdinand Tassoni, 29 years old, of Engine 15, who was summoned from a near-by firehouse.

One of the prime weaknesses of modern Christianity is the suspicion we hold of one another, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday morning in his sermon in, the cathedral.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,974,167,350.

An Illinois youth told today how he and two companions sailed a leaky eighteen-foot dory through heavy seas on a perilous 1,000-mile voyage from Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic, to the Florida Keys. Bryant Morgan, 23, of Hamburg, Ill., said that the trio slipped out of Puerto Plata under cover of darkness Oct. 15 after authorities

Z. G. Simmons and L. F. Sanman tied with 97 out of a possible 100 for the high-over ?? at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. In the shootoff the rivals again deadlocked with runs of 25.
For the first time in history a citizen of the United States was beatified by the Catholic Church when at services in St..Peter's Basilica this morning Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini was thus exalted.

The proposal for a Federal tax on the bonds of the States and their agencies was assailed yesterday by Aaron Rabinowitz, vice chairman of the New York State Board of Housing, who said he saw in the plan a threat to housing projects for the lowest income groups.

Reaching the highest total since 1929, production of pulp and paper in Canada last year amounted to $226,255,915, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reports. The total in 1929 was $243,970,761. Output in 1937 showed an increase of 22.2 per cent over that of $185,144,603 in 1936, and an increase of 83.3 per cent over 1933, when production touched its lowest level, $123,415,492.

A comparatively simple machine, such as the typewriter, never makes a mistake provided it is in good repair. The type-face will continue to strike the paper exactly as it is directed until it is worn out. Yet mistakes in typewriting are frequent.
The Mexican press and public hailed the land agreement with the United States today as a resounding Mexican diplomatic victory.

Further progress in the attack on the railroad problem by means of merger was recorded by the recent insistence of the Interstate Commerce Commission on liberal separation allowances for displaced labor as a prerequisite for its approval of certain proposed consolidations. The railways'

To counteract the deepening concern in the business world, Burgomaster Krogmann of Hamburg last week published in that city's leading economic weekly, Wirtschafts Dienst, a lengthy article in which he maintained that domestic borrowing by the State could continue indefinitely so long as production increased at the same rate because home creditors and debtors set up an equilibrium-debts have corresponding assets.

The toppling of Dartmouth for the first time since October, 1936, by Cornell; Notre Dame's crushing victory over Minnesota; the damaging blow administered to Southern California's Rose Bowl hopes by Washington and Santa Clara's first setback since 1936, effected by St. Mary's, constituted the weekend's most signal accomplishments

James N. S. Brewster Jr. of Hillside, a New York insurance broker and former president of the board of managers of the Elizabeth General Hospital and the Family Welfame Society of Elizabeth, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital following a long illness. His age was 49.

Gustavo Ross, Rightist candidate for President of Chile, revealed today that he had decided to withdraw from a movement contesting the election of his Leftist opponent, Pedro Aguirre Cerda, because many factors indicated the country was already in a state of revolution.
A courageous Northeast first team gained a hard-fought 3-to-1 victory over the Northeast Reserves at the Wellesley College hockey field today.

Lewis St, 92, Pauline Weissman to Ida Silverman. 1,231 Boynton Ave, and Benjamin Miller, 1,498 Crotona Park E; mtg $6,000. 144th St. 457 W; Marburt Holding Corp to Patrick J. Day, 459 W 144th St; mtg $7,600 and purchase money mtg $600 ($1). 192d St. 569 W; Morrem Realty Co to Kranbro Realty Co, 270 Dyckman St; mtgs $97,120 ($10).

Amsel's Truffles, smooth-haired black and tan American-bred bitch owned and handled by George McKay Schieffelin of Goldstone, carried off top honors in the eleventh field trial meeting of the Dachshund Club of America on the estate of James Cox Brady today. The runner-up was the veteran Adolf v. Ernst, black and tan dog belonging to Fred Ernst of Belle Mead.

Nazi extremists have come into control in Germany and have shaken off the influence of the "moderates." Diplomats believe the revolution is proceeding at an accelerated pace. Measures taken against the Jews so far were called "a warning signal" to be followed by even more 'drastic steps in case of "provo- cation." Many wealthy Jews were believed held as hostages for the "good behavior of Jews abroad."

Pastors of many congregations protested in sermons from their pulpits yesterday against the renewed persecution of the Jews in Germany. The congregation of the Community Church approved a message to the German Ambassador in Washington asking him to inform his government of American reaction.

K. Darby and Matthew victors in the second round, tied for first place in the annual championship finale at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. While Darby won from S. Bruzza, former Brooklyn champion, Green defeated Dr. P. T. Schlesinger.

Colonel and Mrs. Hayden W. Wagner of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Wagner, to Captain Duncan Sloan Somerville, Field Artillery, U. S. A., son of Mrs. H. B. Somerville of New York and Cumberland, Md., and the late Mr. Somerville.

Mr. and Mrs. Fleming Newbold of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Newbold, to John Morris Legendre of New Orleans, son of the late James Gilbert Legendre and the late Mrs. Cora Jennings Legendre.

Employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company of 29 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, were called out on strike yesterday by Local 1,222 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate. The strike call is to become effective this morning. The company employs 1,600 workers.

Roger N. Baldwin, executive secretary of the American Civil Liberties Union, charged here tonight that an investigation of the "suppression" of civil liberties in Hudson County had uncovered violations of the rights of 1,896 persons between 1930 and 1938 and thirty-one types of suppression.

Two men and two women, residents of Toledo, Ohio, were rescued by a Coast Guard picket boat this morning after their 65-foot motor cruiser went aground on Point Democrat beach after drifting several hours in a heavy sea with its motor stalled and its anchor line cut.

The Police and Fire Departments will begin tomorrow their annual collection of toys to be distributed at Christmas time among underprivileged children of the city. Toys of all kinds, with the exception of guns, air rifles and pistols, will be accepted at any police station, fire house of Police Athletic League center. Where needed,
NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Wanamaker's:

EUROPEAN RESTAURANT, INC., cabaret and restaurant, 151 East 57th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler Act listing liabilities of $31,467 and assets of $6,724. John M. Johnnidis is president of the corporation, which formerly operated under the style of Salon Royale and Central Park Casino. The business was discontinued temporarily on Nov. 9, but will probably be resumed as soon as the proposed arrangement of 10 per cent is confirmed.

The Federal Communications Commission, beginning public hearings in its investigation of alleged monopolistic tendencies in the radio industry, is scheduled to hear spokesmen for the National Broadcasting Company tomorrow.

In 1937 rate changes resulting in a reduction of one or more typical residential electric rates were made in 350, or 61.5 per cent, of the 569 New Jersey communities with more than 250 population, according to a report by the Federal Power Commission on New Jersey electric rates, made public today.
Supply contracts valued at $2,387,232 were awarded during the week ended Nov. 5 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

The Jersey City Giants, undefeated, untied and unscored upon in six American Professional Football Association games, were humbled, 7 to 3, by the Paterson Panthers today in a league game before 18,000 fans.

Early returns from cities reporting in the Dow Service survey of construction costs indicate that building costs are steady despite recent figures that seemed to show a general increase throughout the country, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow organization. Syracuse and Omaha are the only two cities where costs have shown a tendency to rise.

Whizzer White and his Pittsburgh Pirate team-mates, beaten two days ago by the Los Angeles Bulldogs at Colorado Springs, Col., held the the Bulldogs to a 14-14 tie today in a pro game before a near capacity crowd of 18,000.

Aaron Gantz, 59 years old, a retired executive of a printing company, plunged to his death early yesterday from a window in his apartment on the fourteenth floor of the Hotel Surrey, 20 East Seventy-sixth Street.
Without being spectacular, the further recovery in the stock market here in the last week has been impressive in the solidarity of its modest advance.

The Kearny Scots-Americans scored a well deserved 1-0 victory over the New York Americans before 3,000 fans in a soccer match at Starlight Park yesterday. Spectacular saves by Goalie Cencia stopped the Scots in the opening half, but after ten minutes play in the final frame Walter Conn intercepted a pass from Brown to score

Encouraged by a Sunday of springlike weather, thousands of prospective buyers and interested visitors were drawn yesterday to the exhibits at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace, the fifth annual National Truck Show in Commerce Hall,

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, to be made public today, shows after expenses and charges a consolidated net income of $9,726,774, compared with $11,382,853 in the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, 1937. Gross revenues for the period were $97,523,179, against $97,046,101 in the preceding year.
Mary Pickford, despite a sprained ankle, went to the World's Fair grounds yesterday and raised the American flag above the drug industry's Hall of Pharmacy.

Total expenditure on advertising and publicity by the British Government departments for the current year was estimated by the Treasury at $3,258,270, it was revealed in the report of the government's Select Committee on Estimates, just issued here. This figure included the cost of operating the press bureaus of the respective departments.

A group of debutantes and other young women in society will be guests at a tea to be given tomorrow afternoon in the Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, in the interest of the annual budget campaign of the Y. W. C. A.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 69.3 on Nov. 9, compared with 70 a fortnight before, 70.5 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain. The current index figure is the lowest this year. The previous low level for 1938 was 69.5 on Sept. 14.

Frank Edward Clark broke a weeklong diet of beans today, grinned through a flowing beard and explained that his solo voyage from England in a battered, 30-foot boat was made "just for the devil of it." In good health after his 4,000mile, three-month journey, but short on provisions and money, the 54-year-old English-American seaman made plans to sell the sailing vessel and return to New York, his former home. He made port yesterday.

A picket march through the fur market today and a mass meeting at Twenty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue tomorrow to protest against persecution of Jews in Germany were announced yesterday by the Furriers Joint Council of New York.

Herbert Hoover, Sinclair Lewis, Bishop Manning, William Green and others yesterday added their voices to American protests against persecution of Jews in Germany in statements issued through the Federal Council of Churches.

In financial straits and without "a soul left in the world," Mrs. Edward L. Bloom, widow of a theatre manager for the Shuberts, took her life this afternoon by inhaling gas in the kitchen of her home on South Country Road here. She was about 55 years old.

A hearing will be held here tomorrow by the Maritime Commission on an application by the Isthmian Steamship Line for a subsidy with which to operate a round-the-world service. It is expected that the application will be opposed by the American President Line, formerly the Dollar Line, which would be Isthmian's competitor in such a service.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under the caption "One Health Department" there appeared in an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES a strong endorsement of a proposal made by Commissioner S. S. Goldwater of the Department of Hospitals, to create a single municipal department of medical care "to absorb all of the medical services which the city is now rendering through its scattered agencies."

Mrs. Joseph Ferris Simmons, who will sail shortly for Europe, will give a small dinner tonight at her home, 28 West Fifty-second Street, for Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems and her fiance, James Abercrombie de Peyster, and for Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen and her fiance, John B. Trevor Jr.

A memorial plaque in honor of the late Major James 0. Green Jr., for six years head of the Department of Military Science and Tactics at Lehigh University, will be presented at drill tomorrow afternoon in the Lehigh R. O. T. C. unit.

Hilbert Rauscher, formerly with the Manufacturers Trust Company, is with Curtis-Johnson, Inc., in the renting department. Extension of the mortgage moratorium will be discussed Wednesday night at a meeting of the Midtown Real Estate Association in the Hotel Newton, 2,528 Broadway, near Ninety-fourth Street.

In a rousing battle which held a crowd of more than 15,000 spellbound until the finish, the New York Americans inaugurated their home season in the National Hockey League last night by defeating the mighty Bruins of Boston at Madison Square Garden.
The scream of low-diving Royal Air Force planes, not the trumpets of Joshua, heralded another capture of Jericho today, this time by infantrymen of the crack British Coldstream Guards.

The proposed Nassau County budget for 1939 is $19,857,149, an increase of $1,107,432 over the 1938 budget, J. Russel Sprague, county executive, reported today. The proposed budget will be submitted to the Board of Supervisors at tomorrow's meeting and will be advertised and subjected to a public hearing Dec. 5, after which it may be amended or adopted as it is.

ONE headline on Saturday evening ran: "Yale Upset." That was putting it with admirable restraint. Upset! The Eli were knocked down and trampled on! What those Tiger forwards did to the incautious Eli invaders of Jungletown was dreadful-simply dreadful.

Members of society interested in the work of the Florence Crittenton League are lending their support to the matinee on Dec. 16 of "Falstaff" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the benefit of the league.

With the Jewish community in Palestine deeply moved over the new antiSemitic acts in Germany, the Palestine Rabbinate has proclaimed tomorrow as a day of mourning. The Rabbinate asked other Rabbinates throughout the world to follow suit.

Fireman Patrick Collins, 42 years old, of Engine Company 242, was seriously injured early yesterday in a fall during a two-alarm fire in the Shore Road Barn, a night club occupying a three-story frame building at 10,019 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Collins,

Unity of labor must be achieved without sacrificing the industrial unions already in existence, according to John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, who stated again today the C. I. O.'s position regarding peace with the American Federation of Labor.

With the election tabulations now showing a gain for the Republicans, as compared with the 1936 elections, of eighty-one seats in the House, in addition to eight Senate memberships, comparisons with other "mid-term reversals" become interesting.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 61 per cent of capacity, up 4 points from the preceding period's level and 11 points in three weeks.

Spanish Insurgents reported today that they had driven more than four miles into government territory on the Ebro River front, gaining domination of all main highways in the area. They said they had gained control of the strategic peak of Paumares, eight miles north of Gandesa.

Stocks advanced to the highest levels since September, 1937, with steel shares leading; turnover, 8,043,093 shares. United States Government bonds lower; others irregularly higher; transactions, $36,133,450.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, dedicated the new St. Joseph's Home for the Aged established by the Carmelite Sisters at 123 Lily Pond Avenue, Arrochar, S. I., at ceremonies in the chapel of the home at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
The twentieth anniversary of the Polish Republic was celebrated here today with a two-mile parade and with addresses at Dickinson High School.

The statement of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, given out for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $5,657,998 after all charges and taxes, but before mine depletion. This was equal to 65 cents each on 8,674,338 capital shares outstanding.
Everett Elkins, Marshall College's point-getting ace, found the road to the goal line smoother against Cincinnati and as a result regained the undisputed scoring lead in th East.

Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the American Social Hygiene Association, announced yesterday that contributions totaling $187,065 had been received in the association's national anti-syphilis committee appeal for $500,000.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.5, which compared with 80.4 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 79.9 three weeks before (reached also on Aug. 20) and 80.3 four weeks before.

Recognition for New York's loyal excavation kibitzers was bound to come. For years these humble watchers of the city's vertical progress have inspected foundation after foundation, in fair weather and foul, sometimes even through knotholes, and nothing has ever been done to make their lot more tolerable. Now, at last,

An offering of $146,000 of 4 per cent refunding bonds of the Borough of Oaklyn, N. J. (Camden County), dated Oct. 1, 1938, and due in various amounts from 1950 to 1954, will be made today by M. M. Freeman Co., Inc. The bonds, which are free from present Federal income levies and taxes in New Jersey, are priced to yield 3.50 per cent.

Sanctioning what is regarded as the largest bond issue of the kind in the history of the State, directors of the Public Service Company of Colorado approved here yesterday an application to issue $55,000,000 in new securities as a refinancing operation.

Conferences among representatives of the city, the Transit Commission and the security holders of the Interborough and B. M. T. systems will be resumed this week in an effort to speed up a general agreement on a plan for rapid-transit unification.

Amsel's Truffles, smooth-haired black and tan American-bred bitch owned and handled by George McKay Schieffelin of Goldstone, carried off top honors in the eleventh field trial meeting of the Dachshund Club of America on the estate of James Cox Brady today. The runner-up was the veteran Adolf v. Ernst, black and tan dog belonging to Fred Ernst of Belle Mead.

Miss Ludmilla Aissa Alihan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Alihan of this city, was married to Dr. Bertram Cecil Eskell, also of New York, son of Mrs. Louis Bertram C. Eskell of London and the late Dr. Eskell, last night in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour at 51 East 121st Street.
Chicago's undefeated Black Hawks swept to their fourth straight National Hockey League triumph tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 16,264.

143d St (9-2306), n w cor of Willis Ave, 106x24; Rinfford Realty Corp to Nehin Realty Corp, 389 E 149th St; mtg $55,717. Stratford Ave (14-3777), e s, 350 ft s of 172d St. 102x100; 1.291 Metcalf Ave Corp to Leahprose, Inc, 1,705 Andrews Ave; mtg $103,000. Eastchester Rd (16-4766) e s, 50 ft s of Hamersley Ave, 50x107; Angelo Letizia to Home Owners Loan Corp.
The effects of the recent crisis on the note circulation of the Bank of England now are past completely.

An 80-yard touchdown dash by Halfback Jim Fremming gave Canisius College a 6-to-0 victory over Mount St. Mary's today. Fremming slashed off tackle in the second period on his own 20yard line and broke into the open behind good blocking for his scoring jaunt. Shortly before Mount St. Mary's had tried a place kick from the Canisius 28-yard marker which was wide.
The Bourse, open only four days of last week, showed remarkable firmness. Only on Wednesday did quotations react unfavorably to the rumor of serious discord within the Cabinet.

Antitank armament is an "imperative need" of the army, and "our present war reserves (in munitions of various types) are far short of requirements in a number of critical items," General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the Army, declares in his annual report for the fiscal year 1938 made public today. It is "a matter of military importance" that reserves be built up, he says.

J. P. Morgan Co. and the Guaranty Trust Company, sinking fund administrators, have notified holders of Kingdom of Belgium external thirty-year 6 per cent bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1955, that $1,475,300 of these bonds has been drawn for redemption on Jan. 1 at par out of sinking fund moneys.

Deprived of a chance to prove his claim to heavyweight distinction by an attack of pneumonia last July, Tony Galento, New Jersey's famed "Two-ton Tony," is scheduled to renew his campaign tonight in a twelve-round battle with Harry Thomas of Minnesota at Convention Hall. Philade1phia.

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today that sales volume among men's apparel stores averaged 13.5 per cent less during the first ten months of the year than for the same period in 1937.
From the pulpit and speakers' platform Britons voiced indignation today at the treatment-of Jews in Germany. The Bishop of Salisbury, Dr. E. N. Lovett, speaking at Weymouth, declared:

The Catholic University of America in Washington, D. C., is preparing new courses in democracy, which will be installed throughout the Catholic educational system in this country, Mgr. Joseph M. Corrigan, rector of the university, announced last night at a dinner of 500 of the university's alumni at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The allure of Latin-American dances for the ballrooms of New York, well established by the current vogue of the tango, the rumba and the conza, was further exemplified yesterday morning by a demonstration of the samba at the November meeting in the Hotel Astor of the New. York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc.
Stanley Hicks, 27, a Burlingame, Calif., aviator, was killed late today when a small plane which he had borrowed stalled 300 feet above the airport here, and went into a spin and crashed.

The drowning of two men wno were overcome by carbon monoxide gas in a thirty-foot well on the estate of Lucian Fairchild here last night led State Troopers to the discovery of a 1,000-gallon daily capacity still. The victims, who, State Police Sergeant James Rose said, were apparently drawing water from the well to use in their still operations, were Tony Sangi of Glasco, N. Y.,

The Playwrights Producing Company, of which Maxwell Anderson, S. N. Behrman, Sidney Howard, Elmer Rice; Robert Sherwood and John E. Wharton are directors, announced yesterday that special performances of "Knickerbocker Holiday" and "Abe Lincoln in Illinois,"
