John Rahkonen of the Finnish-American A. C., New York, who already holds the National A. A. U. 20,000 and 30,000 meter walking championships, added the United States 15,000-meter title to his list today when he led home a field of fifteen anklin Park.

After an absence of eight years, Argentinita returned to New York in a recital of Spanish dances at the Majestic Theatre last night, accompanies this time by her sister, Pilar Lopez, and a male partner, Antonio Triana.
St. Mary's Gaels, playing inspired football, sprang one of the major upsets of the season today by defeating the previously unbeaten and untied Santa Clara Broncos, 7 to 0.
A try midway in the first half and another one minute before the end gave Hofstra College a 10-3 victory over the New York R. C. in a rugby match at Travers Island yesterday.
The question of who will be Representative from the Eighteenth California District will be decided by navy men now engaged in tactical manoeuvres with the fleet.

Statements from Herbert Houver, Alfred E. Smith, Alfred M. Landon and John W. Davis endorsing the annual Christmas Seal campaign of the National Tuberculosis Association were made public yesterday by Dr. Kendall Emerson, managing director of the association. Mr. Koover's statement read:
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen is due to arrive today from the Channel-ports. The list of passengers on board includes Princess Vera Romanoff, Mr. and Mrs. H. H. Elliott, Miss Leuise C. Elliott,

The attitude of the Berlin public toward the government's anti-Jewish measures and the mob destruction preceding them is in the main one of shocked amazement so far as can be judged from talks with individuals. Only a very few expressed complete agreement, and even members of the Nazi party admitted to foreign news men how distasteful they found the measures.

With the nation's capital for his setting, the Most Rev. Michael J. Curley, Archbishop of Baltimore, today denounced Adolf Hitler as a mad man. He labeled the Nazi Minister of Propaganda, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, "the cripple-minded Goebbels."
The death of Kemal Ataturk, dictator of Turkey, was not announced to the public for two hours after it occurred, and by that time arrangements had been completed for assuring the succession.

Japan has taken the lead from the United States in the production of rayon, Emil Rieve, executive director of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee and president of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, told a rayon workers' conference here today.

Under conditions a good deal more strenuous than those met yesterday, W. B. Dodge of Mystic, Conn., sailed five perfect races today against the finest competition Class X dinghies can assemble to win a leg on the George E. Roosevelt Trophy, outstanding prize for the division.

Albert Barnes Weimer, an attorney and, until his retirement six years ago, official reporter for the State Supreme Court, died today in his rooms at the Warwick after an illness of four weeks. His age was 81.

The delegation that will represent the United States at the Eighth International Conference of American States at Lima, Peru, was announced today by the State Department. The conference will meet Dec. 9.
Davis Rowland MacDonald returned today from the "dead" to find that his wife had divorced him, remarried, had him declared legally dead and collected three insurance policies on his life.

The Creighton University Blue Jays turned on a powerful running and passing attack to trounce Loyola of the South, 34-0, today before a Loyola homecoming crowd of 6,000. Don Fleming, 180-pound sophomore halfback for the Nebraskans, scored the first two touchdowns, in the first and third periods, on passes from Halfback John Knolla. Fleming galloped 56 yards on his third-period run.

Chicago's Bears bounced back today from a losing streak that had reached three straight and sent Washington spinning from the Eastern Division leadership of the National Football League by defeating the Redskins, 31 to 7. The Bruins, although still third in the Western Division, advanced to a point only half a game behind the Detroit Lions.

Convinced that industry is now so geared that the volume of business activity-can be expanded enormously without a corresponding rise in employment, the governing board of the old Emergency Relief Bureau set forth yesterday its belief that "a very substantial part of the population" would remain dependent on public support despite future improvements in business conditions.

THE ART OF BUNDLING, by Dana Doten. (The Countryman Press and Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) An account of its nature, origins and practice. As YOU ONCE WERE, by A. S. M. Hutchinson. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "If Winter Comes."
The parish of St. Barnabas, Roman Catholic Church, was praised today by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Long Island diocese as a model for all others on Long Island to follow.

Metro has purchased Sir Malcolm Campbell's "Salute to the Gods," in which James Stewart will be seen as a European road racer. Rosalind Russell has been set tentatively as Nelson Eddy's leading woman in "Let Freedom Ring."

Dr. Wallace Poorman, a physician and surgeon in Oak Park for thirty-two years, died today at the age of 65. Dr. Poorman, who was born in Mattoon, Ill., took post-graduate work in Berlin after his graduation from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1905. He was the author of several medical treatises.

Major Algernon Edwyn Burnaby, a friend of the Duke of Windsor when the Duke was Prince of Wales, died today at the age of 70. He was a veteran of the World War and had served with the London yeomanry in Gallipoli and Egypt.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan expressed the opinion today, after a conference with President Roosevelt, that "progressive forces" must work through the Democratic party rather than attempt to unite in a third party movement.

Demand for gift merchandise maintained its pace last week, but orders for goods of other types arrived in somewhat smaller volume in the wholesale market. New lines of resort and cruise apparel met with good response.

The life of one well-to-do Jewish family today portrayed how many Jews have fared since the start of Nazi Germany's greatest anti-Semitic drive. The father has not been home since Thursday, when Nazis started wrecking synagogues and smashing stores.

Widespread violations of the State Minimum Wage Law by beauty shop operators threaten "a complete breakdown" of the wage scale in that industry unless the minimum wage of $16.50 for forty-five hours' work Is made mandatory, Harry M. Spiro, president of the State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association, warned yesterday in a letter to Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner.
Mayor S. Wilson Davis announced today that he would withdraw his charge of "willful and corrupt perjury" against Jerome H. Louchheim, contractor and former political leader.

The Young American Artists, an organized group of art students from schools throughout New York, will hold their first symposium tonight at the A. C. A. Gallery at 8:30 o'clock, where the "We Like America" exhibition is in progress.
Nineteen Massachusetts Institute of Technology students and guests on a flying tea party escaped injury today when their big plane pancaked while rolling to a stop at East Boston airport.

President Roosevelt worshipped today at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, where he heard Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines deliver an address on peace and preparedness. The service, commemorating the Armistice, was conducted by the Rev. Howard S. Wilkinson in the Normanlike stone church in Northwest Washington.

The weekly German wholesale price index on Nov. 9 was unchanged at 106. In the first ten months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks of June.

Prices of cotton last week reached a new high level for the current upward movement. The government's ?? of the cotton crop issued on Tuesday and the improvement of business sentiment following the elections were two new factors which contributed to the further strength in the staple. The crop estimate was slightly below the average of trade forecasts.
Results of the election last Tuesday should go a long way toward restoring confidence, according to Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association.

Mrs. Thorlief S. B. Nielsen of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eline Nielsen, to Thomas Hooker, son of Mrs. Roland M. Hooker and the late Thomas W. Hooker of Hartford, Conn.
" Herod and Mariamne," which was to bring Katharine Cornell back to Broadway after an absence of sixteen months, will be closed after this week's engagement in Washington.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today charged John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, with fraud and misrepresentation in his report for the convention of the Committee for Industrial Organization on the membership and finances of that organization.
The Boerse continued extremely quiet last week, shares selling sluggishly as genuine investors withheld buying orders and only operators participated in the trading.

The World Council of Churches, organized last Summer by all Christian sects except the Roman Catholic, was hailed by the Rev. William Adams Brown, professor emeritus at Union Theological Seminary, in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
Trading in wheat last week was interrupted by two holidays, and on each occasion foreign markets showed decided strength while the exchanges in this country and Canada were closed.

After reaching new low levels for the season the previous week, the lard market showed a little improvement last week. There was considerable shortcovering at times, and there also was moderate commission support on the theory that the trade agreement between this country and Great Britain would go through and would improve the export trade.

King Carol, Crown Prince Michael and their suite left for London tonight. They were traveling by way of Hungary, Germany and Belgium and the diplomatic representatives of these countries were at the railway station.

Although the 12-year-old pianist, Julius Katchen, was heard here last season as soloist with the Philadelphia and Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestras, his first recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall may be accepted as his real introduction. For it told the rest of a story that had only been excitingly intimated at his previous appearances.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bulkeley van Zile of Chesham, N. H., formerly of this city, have announced the engagement of Mrs. van Zile's daughter, Miss Dorothy Fitch Nutt of New York, to William Alexander Bell Jr., son of Mrs. Maclean Bell of New York and of Judge W. A. Bell of New Orleans.

Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the Supreme Court reached his eighty-second birthday today without special observance of the event. A member of the family said he spent a "very quiet" day at home and had not seen any one. Neither the justice nor Mrs. Brandeis would talk to news men.

30th St. 114 E: Thomas Mott Osborne Memorial Fund, Inc. to Seamen's Bank for Savings; installments, 5 per cent; $10.000. 8th Ave. 201; 201 Eighth Ave Corp to Isldore L. Broadwin, executor of Carrie Mannneimer, 327 Central Park W; purchase money mtg, 10 years, 4 to 5 per cent; $16.000.

Religion, like a lasting church edifice, must be built on the right foundation, Bishop Francis J. McConnell declared yesterday in a sermon dedicating a new sanctuary at the St. Paul and St. Andrew Methodist Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Frank Lloyd, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave and 58th St. Lemon L. Smith, in 580 Park Ave; George Armsby, in 2 Sutton P1, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc; Prince and Princess Seesodia, in 485 Park Ave: Mrs. Carley Hawkins. in 111 E 80th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

The jury that will try Robert Irwin for the murder of Frank Byrnes--one of the three so-called "Gedeon murders" which the defendant has admitted through his counsel-is expected to be completed today when the trial is resumed before General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace in the Supreme Court Building.

Wang I-Ting, philanthropist and aide of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen in the founding of the Chinese Republic, died today at the age of 72. Wang was Minister of Communications, Agriculture, Labor and Commerce in the republic's first year.

BOSTON, Nov. 13.--Captain Ernest H. Pentecost of this city and Topsfield has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Cornelia P. Pentecost, to Browning Endicott Marean Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marean of 277 Park Avenue, New York.

The Inland Steel Company, which resisted the strike of 1937, has been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to bargain collectively with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, and to put its agreement in writing, the board announced today.
The French wholesale price index for the week ended on Nov. 5 stood at 652, against 654 a week before and 653 two weeks before.

The Children's Theatre Committee of the Morristown Junior League will hold a luncheon meeting tomorrow at the Women's Exchange. Plans will be discussed for the league's production in February of the children's play, "Stay-at-Home Rebel,"

The importance of cooperation between the prophets, those who organize ideas, and the priests, those who organize institutions, was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Lee Sullivan McCollester, president of Tufts College, in his sermon at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, which is celebrating the 100th anniversary of its founding.

Among the former students of Dr. David Starr Jordan who came with him from Indiana to Palo Alto to found Stanford University was Professor Elwood Cubberly. There, in a bright valley ringed by crouching foothills, musical with meadow larks and swept by California poppies, he saw a miracle enacted.

Five radium needles capable of seriously burning any one mishandling them were the object of a citywide police search last night after they had been stolen from a Brooklyn physician's office in a 150pound safe.
Efforts of local bull operators. coupled with a more active commission demand, were rewarded last week with a fair upturn in prices of corn on the Board of Trade here. The market gained in activity.

Peter Forget, 70 years old, of 87-56 126th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, an engineer for the Long Island Railroad who had hoped to remain in active service for fifty years, died at the throttle yesterday afternoon, while making up a train near the World's Fair grounds.

Two men were arrested on charges of selling liquor without a license last night after another man had been found dead and still another unconscious in West Nineteenth Street, apparently from the effects of poison alcohol.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Fletcher Huntsman of Plainfield, N. J., of the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Marjorie Huntsman, to Arthur Henry Abernethy, son of Mrs. Grenville Goodale Abernethy of Stoneleigh Park, Westfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Abernethy.
The nineteenth annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute will open at the Stevens Hotel tomorrow and will continue through Friday. About 3,000 oil men are expected to attend.
Eighty-three gifts to Columbia University totaling $72,608 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

The life of Clarence H. Mackay bridged two characteristic periods in the economic development of America--the gold-rush days in California and Nevada, when vast fortunes were literally torn from the rock, and the era of high finance in New York, when money multiplied from a forest of growing enterprises almost as leafage multiplies on the trees.

The report of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net profit of $137,588 after charges and taxes, compared with $127,112 before Federal income taxes in the corresponding period last year. Gross revenues were $4,154,884, against $3,581,485.
The further northward one travels in Manchukuo the more evident becomes the Japanese preoccupation in the Russian problem, which here looms even larger than the outcome of the hostilities in China.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to a client of J. W. Gerrish, broker, the four-story apartment house for eight families at 313 East Eighty-fourth Street. property is 25 by 100 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $17,000 for five years at 4 per cent.

Carl R. Hauers is with Van Strum Towne, Inc., in charge of their estate and trust department. J. Anthony Murphy and C. Richard Gunzer are with Leach Bros., Inc. L. Neil Campbell, Paul Feuchtwanger and William Kuhn have formed L. Neil Campbell Co. at 2 Rector Street.

B. Ogden Chisolm, International Prison Commissioner, and Mrs. Chisolm celebrated their golden wedding at Wicopee Farm, Ridgefield, yesterday. They were married in New York City. She was Miss Bessie Rhoades, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harsen Rhoades.
Tonight's events: Beethoven Association, Town Hall; Elsa Baklor, vocalist, 3 P. M.; National Orchestral Association, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Orclestrette Classique, Carnegie Chamber Hall, 8:30.

Dr. Marvin R. Thompson, a director of the Warner Institute of Therapeutic Research of New York, bought a residence on a large plot of ground at Great Neck, L. I., through the M. E. Baker Real Estate Organization.

The European Golf Association today unanimously accepted the fourteen-club ruling placed in effect in the United States this year and recently adopted by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, the British ruling body.

Flower lovers are on the increase, attendance figures at the Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York at the American Museum of Natural History showed yesterday as officers of the society

Calling the rulers of Nazi Germany "murderers and racketeers," Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, at a dinner last night of the Home of the Daughters of Israel at the Hotel Astor, said:

In a leading editorial tonight the Temps warns the Reich that the violent measures taken against the German Jews may have precisely the opposite effect abroad from that intended and that the result may seriously impair the work of rapprochement that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlin has undertaken.
Two New York men were killed today in a collision of their automobile with a truck on the Lincoln Highway in suburban South Langhorne.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Implications of the National Elections," John Taber. National Council of Jewish Women, New York section, Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway, 11:15 A. M. Speakers: Commissioner Paul Kern, Mrs. Dorothy Rosenman.

Gowns for daytime and evening wear will be shown by a group of young women at the fifth annual tea and fashion show in aid of the Kips Bay Boys' Club on Thursday on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

A boy weighing six pounds and one ounce was born at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Medical Center to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Poletti. The Lieutenant Governor-elect went to the hospital immediately upon receiving the news. Both Mrs. Poletti and her son were reported to be doing well.

King George and Queen Elizabeth will sail for Canada on the battle cruiser Repulse on May 10 and they will leave Canada on their return trip June 10, it was indicated today. The official announcement said that the Canadian tour would start May 15. It was indicated that the date of departure from Canada might be postponed.
The Republican State Central Committee met here today to coordinate efforts to unseat Democratic candidates counted as winning in last week's election.

The "Royal Lesters"--only family on San Miguel Island of the Channel Islands chain--have settled down to a Winter of deep contest. Forty miles off the Santa Barbara Coast, swept by all the winds that blow this sector of the Pacific, the home of Herbert S. Lester, will ride out the Winter in seclusion that will be absolute,

Japan today rejected the represenstations of the United States, Great be Britain and France protesting against the closing by Japan of the Yangtze River to commercial navigation. Separate notes were handed to each of the three Ambassadors. The Foreign Office summary of the replies listed five reasons:
The Supreme Court will hear arguments tomorrow on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority power program.

The "Roaring Forties"-we are now at latitude 48:48 south, longitude 67 east-have lived up to their reputation during our rough voyage of fourteen days across the turbulent Indian Ocean from Cape Town. Most of the time I spent braced in my bunk or clinging to anything for support while nursing mashed fingers and a black and blue arm.

A solemn funeral mass for Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, who died Saturday night at his New York home, will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

This picturesque Blue Grass community teemed today with foxhuntes and foxhounds, awaiting the dawn and the first cast in the forty-fifth annual National Foxhunters Association's field trials. Sportsmen came from far and wide to give chase to the wily br'er fox and to pit the skill and class of their hounds both in the field and on the bench.

Another football season has slipped into the archives of history insofar as many major prep schools are concerned, for the past week brought numerous teams to the end of the 1938 gridiron trail with annual renewals of long-standing traditional rivalries dominating the spotlight.

Induction ceremonies for seventeen newly elected members of the New York University Epsilon chapter of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, will be held Saturday evening in the library of the Bliss Building on the University Heights campus, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Clyde Doane of this city, formerly of Plainfield, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Harriet Doane, to William Michael Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Francis Murphy of Sunnyside, formerly of Flushing.
More decree laws, in addition to the thirty announced yesterday, are expected to be approved by the French Cabinet tomorrow in the drastic moves to speed recovery.

British steel production in October amounting to 854,800 tons fully confirms optimistic forecasts. This represents an increase of 12.3 per cent over September's total which, in turn, was 15 per cent better than the showing in August. Last month's aggregate,

Miss Janet Robertson Luke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Luke of Tarrytown, N. Y., was married here today to Dr. Henry Thomas Burns of 162 East Seventy-first Street, New York, at the home of the bride's cousin, George E. Nelson. The Rev. John A. Ingham.

Jay A. Lederman and J. Melvin Jones, commercial photography, in 24 E 21st St: Manhattan Post Card Publishing Co. in 16 W 23d St: Bronze Craft. Inc, metal produsts, in 476 Broome St; M. L. Hess, Inc, brokers. Abraham Rubin, i n 245 7th Ave through Schuster, Fine Mayleas;
John K. Colgate, formerly with the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, has become a member of the firm of Van Strum Towne, Inc., investment counsel. Leicester W.

The Park Department, which in previous contests has encouraged people to pull rabbits out of hats, play harmonicas and impersonate hillbillies, staged a city-wide whistling contest at Mullaly Playground in the Bronx yesterday afternoon.

A traffic policeman and an automobile salesman, formerly a policeman in Boston, were each held in $10,000 bail in Felony Court yesterday on charges of extorting $150 from a woman under threats to report her as the operator of a disorderly house.

Thousands of Catholics suffered humiliation and were made fiercely indignant tonight when an open-air religious festival was first interrupted by organized Nazi bands and then was dispersed by the the police.
French foreign trade statistics for October show imports valued at 3,878,000,000 francs and exports of 2,830,000,000 francs, compared with 3,533,000,000 and 2,652,000,000, respectively, in September.

AITKIN-Mary, widow of Henry Aitkin, Nov. 12, 1938. Burial Tuesday from her late residence, 21-78 35th St., Astoria, L I. Mass at the Immaculate Conception Church, Astoria, at 10 A. M. ALBERTSON-On Nov. 13, 1938, Mary Albertson. Funeral private in compliance with her wish.

An anti-Jewish campaign in this - city is being intensified and is spreading to other cities, supported largely by small merchants. Bogota merchants, taxi drivers, barbers and students have grouped together to fight Jewish competition.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dana Skinner gave a tea yesterday at their home, 1,035 Park Avenue, for their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Hill Skinner.

Norman Thomas told a Yale audience of several hundred students and faculty members today that the Nazi decrees against the Jews announced yesterday far exceeded in brutality anything medieval or recorded in the history of the Western Hemisphere.
The anxiety caused in Central and Eastern Europe by Czechoslovakia's fate was exemplified today in a speech by Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch to 80,000 supporters of the government party in Novisad.

The autobiography of Berta SzepsZuckerkandl, daughter of the liberal Viennese editor Moritz Szeps and sister-in-law of France's wartime Premier, Georges Clemenceau, is announced for January publication by Knopf.

New York State will have the lowest death rate in its history this year, unless there is a decided upward change in present trends, it was predicted today by Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., Commissioner of Health. He based his prediction on a nine months report by Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the division of vital statistics of the Department of Health.

Two thousand persons, including 1,000 National Guardsmen, Gold Star Mothers and members of veterans' organizations and their auxiliaries, paid tribute to the fallen heroes of the 106th Infantry Regiment at memorial services held yesterday afternoon in the regimental armory, Atlantic and Bedford Avenues, Brooklyn.

Approval of the work this season by Eastern football officials was expressed yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics and commissioner of officials, in a letter addressed to Charles G. Eckles, president of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials.

New York University students, enthusiastic over the prospect of their football team defeating Fordham in the "Battle of the Bronx" at the Yankee Stadium a week from next Saturday, formed a line outside the University Heights ticket office last night.
Stingaree II, sailed by Bud Moxham, led the Class B one-design dinghy fleet in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association racing today and top honors in Class D went to Allan Clark's Penguin.

British gold exports are contracting rapidly, having amounted to only [Pound]3,021,585 in the first week of November, compared with [Pound]12,145,441 the previous week and an average of more than [Pound]7,000,000 for the two preceding weeks.

A 15-degree drop in temperature was predicted for today by the Weather Bureau after yesterday's unseasonably warm weather. The average temperature yesterday was 59 degrees, 14 above normal. The high was 64 at 2:45 P. M., and the low 54 at 6 A. M.

With the present campaign to fight infantile paralysis only three days old, Keith Morgan, national chairman of the Infantile Paralysis Campaign Committee, announced yesterday from headquarters of the Committee for the Celebration of

The third annual "Noble Dog Drive" will begin today throughout the State and continue for a month. Morris D. Solow, organizer of the Noble Dog Foundation, 11 West Forty-second Street, in announcing the campaign yesterday said the aim was to promote safe driving and to acquaint motorists with the law, passed two years ago, that obligates drivers of cars that strike a dog to stop and report the mishap.

In the latest test of sentiment by the Gallup poll it was found that 70 per cent of all the voters giving their opinion asked either for the revision or the repeal of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, while only 30 per cent wanted it unchanged.

The old argument as to whether a black bear will charge a man or run away is no longer a matter for discussion, according to Dwight Wilson of Wilson, N. Y., who banished all theory in a recent hunting trip to Maine.

Charged by police with at least fifty robberies in Brooklyn in the last year, Michael Cedulesky, 32 years old, of 132 East Thirty-second Street, was booked yesterday in the Empire Boulevard station, Brooklyn, on burglary charges. He was arrested Saturday night.

A. J. Pronk, president of the Royal Packet Navigation Company of the Netherlands East Indies, said yesterday that general economic conditions were gradually improving and that the future of shipping in the East was promising. Accompanies by his wife, he is at the begining of a combined vacation

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Franklin McNeil of Chestnut Hill announced yesterday the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet McNeil, to C. Ogden Glass, son of Mrs. L. Gordon Glass and the late Mr. Glass of Montreal.

The new stage in Casino Hall Auditorium of Georgian Court College here was dedicated this afternoon with ceremonies attended by 1,500 undergraduates, alumnae and friends of the institution. The stage, costing more than $5,000, was built with contributions;

Dr. Antonio Lazo-Arriaga, lawyer and diplomat, who was Guatemalan Minister to the United States from 1893 to 1903, died late Saturday night in Roosevelt Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 81 years old.

Martial music and the tramp of marching feet were heard again today in this World War port of embarkation as 3,000 members of the American Legion paraded along River Street, the cobbled thoroughfare which two decades ago led thousands of American soldiers to transports bound for France.

The engagement of Miss Mary Walton MeCandlish, daughter of the late Fairo fax Shield McCandlish and a grandniece of R. Walton Moore, Counselor of the Department of State, to Schuyler William Livingston, formerly of New York, was announced today at a tea given by her mother at her home in Fairfax, Va.
The New York Rangers came from behind tonight to open their National Hockey League championship season with a brilliant 4-to-3 victory over the hapless Detroit Red Wings.

In a rough-and-tumble game which was enlivened by a free-forall among the members of both teams, the New York Rovers ushered in their home Eastern Hockey League season by conquering the Baltimore Orioles, 6 to 2, in the feature clash of an amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The return to Hungary of extensive territory ceded to Czechoslovakia at the end of the World War was celebrated here yesterday afternoon by 2,500 persons at a gathering in the Central Opera House, in East Sixty-seventh Street near Third Avenue.

Lieutenants Lansing C. Holden and Raymond W. Krout, war aces, were killed tonight when a New York National Guard plane crashed near here. A farmer reported that the plane, apparently lost in heavy fog, had circled several times before it hit a hillside and burst into flames. Two explosions scattered the wreckage.

First Game-Melichor Renteria and Julian Ulacia, United States, defeated Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica, South America, 20 to 13. Second Game-Federico Santo Tomas and Ramon Ayastaran, United States, defeated Jose Echeverria and Alejandro Guisasola, Spain. 20 to 14.

The stoning of Cardinal von Faulhaber's windows in Munich, like the stoning of Cardinal Innitzer's palace in Vienna five weeks ago, once more illustrates that when the spirit of lawlessness and savagery is let loose it can be directed against one object almost as easily as against another.
The motion picture "The Growth of the Film in America From 1895 to 1912" will be shown today at the Rock Spring Club, West Orange, at a meeting of the Junior League of the Oranges.

Notable changes in the Metropolitan Opera's "Golden Horseshoe" appear in the list of boxholders for the 1938-39 season, made public yesterday. There are important omissions due to death, bereavement and other causes, but while familiar.figures will be missing the list discloses that there will be newcomers, as well as the usual shifting of occupants from one box to another.

The future encouragement of direct ownership, as opposed to the current economic practice of "debt financing," in this country was strongly advocated in the report of the committee on debt adjustment of the Twentieth Century Fund, made public last night.

The semi-annual report of the German Business Research Institute, issued on Thursday, presents a glowing picture of a phenomenal increase of economic production, signalized by a substantial improvement in supplies of raw materials.
The Green Bay Packers assured themselves of at least a tie for the Western Division championship of the National Football League by overwhelming the Detroit Lions. 28 to 7, today.

Following is the text of the address of Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, after the ceremonies of the beatification of Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini in St. Peter's Cathedral, Rome, as transcribed by the National Broadcasting Company:

A water-plant price difference of $10,000 between the Mayor and Aldermen of Halls, Tenn., and the West Tennessee Power and Light Company ended here today-at least temporarily, but probably permanently-the $1,600,000 deal with the company by which about 20,000 persons in twenty-two Western Tennessee towns would have received Tennessee Valley Authority electricity by Christmas.

Shagwong Gypsy, owned and handled by E. Monroe Osborne of East Hampton, came out on top today at the end of the three-day field-trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club held at Penniman's Point. She gained first honors by winning the open all-age stake in a field of twelve that included the best dogs in the trials.

An application for permission to establish a passenger airline route between Boston and New York City will be filed today with the Civil Aeronautics Authority by the Boston-Maine Airways, it was learned here yesterday.

Ways of helping Jewish immigrants to enter fully into the civic and spiritual activities of the community were discussed yesterday at the eighth annual Northeast Regional Convention of American Hebrew Congregations in the Community House of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Had it been staged by the master minds of Hollywood it could not have been more exciting-yesterday's game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Philadelphia Eagles. What started like a romp for the home club subsequently developed into quite a struggle, catchas-catch-can, with few, if any, holds barred.
A message from President Roosevelt expressing hope for the success of the forthcoming campaign for funds of the United Palestine Appeal was made public yesterday by the organization. The message,

The fiftieth anniversary of Moriz Rosenthal's debut in America was observed by that distinguished pianist last night. in Carnegie Hall with a program of formidable contents before an audience which included in its ranks many of Mr. Rosenthal's colleagues.

Invitations have been sent out by Dr. and Mrs. Alden R. Hoover of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. Hoover, to James Stanley Brooks of Ithaca, N. Y., son of Mrs. Fanny Brooks of Bloomington, Ind., and the late Samuel Brooks.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, head of the Cuban Army, accompanied by a group of Cuban officials, arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon after a visit in Washington during which he was received by President Roosevelt.
The Board of Trade's index of British wholesale prices for October, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 99.1, against 98.4 for the preceding month and 110.6 for October, 1937.
The St. Mary's Celtics triumphed in the American Soccer League match at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday after a stirring battle with the Trenton Highlanders. The score was 6-3.

While in many instances the advertising allowance provisions of the Robinson-Patman law have been disregarded by manufacturers, a complaint last week by the Federal Trade Commission against a Southern company in the food field for violating these provisions among other acts is expected to renew interest in the subject. This is the first complaint in the food field in which the commission has specifically charged discrimination in the granting of advertising allowances.

An application for permission to establish a passenger airline route between Boston and New York City will be filed today with the Civil Aeronautics Authority by the Boston-Maine Airways, it was learned here yesterday.

Ways of helping Jewish immigrants to enter fully into the civic and spiritual activities of the community were discussed yesterday at the eighth annual Northeast Regional Convention of American Hebrew Congregations in the Community House of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Had it been staged by the master minds of Hollywood it could not have been more exciting-yesterday's game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Philadelphia Eagles. What started like a romp for the home club subsequently developed into quite a struggle, catchas-catch-can, with few, if any, holds barred.

While in many instances the advertising allowance provisions of the Robinson-Patman law have been disregarded by manufacturers, a complaint last week by the Federal Trade Commission against a Southern company in the food field for violating these provisions among other acts is expected to renew interest in the subject. This is the first complaint in the food field in which the commission has specifically charged discrimination in the granting of advertising allowances.

Preservation by the Jews of "pure worship of God" through 1,500 years of oppression is one of the most significant facts in the history of the world, the Rev. Charles O'Connor Sloane declared at a mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering's anti-Jewish decrees imposing a levy of 1,000,000,000 marks and excluding Jews from all economic activity in the Reich virtually eliminate Jewish capital altogether from any possibility of recovery.
Company officials today announced settlement of a United Automobile Workers strike at the Budd Wheel Company and the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company, which had affected about 10.000 men.

The beatification of Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini was observed here yesterday in the chapel of Mother Cabrini High School, 701 Fort Washington Avenue, where the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, participated in services in honor of the event.

The writer has just witnessed the bringing into a Czech town of a number of Jewish refugees driven out by the Nazis after the burning of most of the synagogues in the Sudeten areas. Since most of these unfortunates will have to return, the correspondent is requested not to specify which of the many frontier towns he visited.
The inseparable Harbison sisters, homesteaders of a hardy era, are dead here, both victims of pneumonia. Kitty, 66, died Tuesday. While Anne, four years older, lay critically ill,
In THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning a photograph of Stefano de Hedry was published with a caption describing him as the Minister from Hungary to the United States. This was an error.

Peter Olexy of Penn State College, representing the Millrose Athletic Association of New York, captured the junior metropolitan A. A. U. cross-country championship over the four-mile route at Lincoln Park today in 18 minutes 7 seconds.
The Danbury Trojans remained in second place in the American Professional Football Association today when they defeated the Brooklyn Eagles, 14 to 7. The Trojans scored in the second

The campaign inauguarated by the national Bureau of Standards to encourage manufacturers to show on their labels exact specifications of formulas of thier products in making gratifying progress, bureau oficials stated today.

A powerful crusade of faith in love is needed today to save a world that is rapidly becoming a "bestial hell," the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, executive secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Central Church of the Disciples, 142 West Eighty-first Street.

Circular letters to 1,500 wealthy widows in New York, warning them that their names, addresses and financial standing were on a "sucker list" found in the files of Robert E. Lancaster, securities dealer charged with widespread frauds, were sent yesterday by Attorney General Bennett.

The establishment of a powerful Rightist National Council, which in effect would make the Diet and the political parties impotent, is predicted by the newspaper Hochi. It says the plan is Premier Fumimaro Konoye's own and that is why he is indifferent to the movement for the formation of a single national political party.

The fourth victim of the mistaken administration of salvarsan to five patients in the Rockland County State Hospital here last Tuesday died today. The fifth is in a critical 2 condition, according to Dr. Russell E. Blaisdell, superintendent of the hospital.

Armaments will be needed to maintain peace until the day comes when "the hearts of men are changed" under the "leadership of Jesus," declared the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of Grace Lutheran Church, 70-18 Olcott Street, Forest Hills, Queens, in a sermon for cavalrymen yesterday morning.

The Merchants Association of New York disclosed yesterday that it had received a copy of an order from the Interstate Commerce Commission under which the commission will shortly determine whether it shall extend its jurisdiction over the working hours of drivers for motor carriers to other employes of those motor carriers, whether common or contract carriers, or private carriers engaged in interstate commerce.

The spirit of democracy and American ideals is admirably expressed through voluntary philanthrophy, James G. Blaine, president of the Greater New York Fund, and other speakers told nearly 1,000 men and women who attended the

Representative Dies selected today what he called an international team of "purveyors of hate." The Texas Democrat, chairman of the committee investigating unAmerican activities, borrowed the idea from sports experts who pick "all-America" football teams.

Pathetic scenes were reported today from the German frontier where groups of Jews, attempting to leave the Reich, literally went to their knees in imploring Netherland officials to allow them to pass. Netherland frontier guards have been doubled and strict orders have been given to prevent any refugee invasion.
Shops and tobacco stores that were open today had a rush of buyers who were stocking goods before the rise in prices caused by the decree-law taxes that will become effective Tuesday.

The twoscore-mark in numbers of new exhibitions is being reached for the first, but, if other seasons are indicative, not the last time this year. Among the more than forty openings of the present week are a number of shows by wellknown European and American artists and a wide variety of media and subject matter is included.

Mrs. Jessie Wright Cocks, widow of William Willets Cocks, former Republican Congressional Representative from the First District of New York, died at her home here today at the age of 62, after an illness of four months.
Dr. Calvin Derrick, superintendent of the State Home for Boys here since 1927, died at his home today after a brief illness. He suffered a heart attack last Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

In a team match in sailing dinghies an Indian Harbor Yacht Club trio today defeated sailors from the Larchmont Club, 53 3/4 points to 51 1/4. Five races were sailed and Dick Maxwell, in his boat Lei, with Jack Keeshan alternating with him as crew and at the tiller, won two of them for Indian Harbor.
A population census of the heavens which shows that crowding among star families, or galaxies, works exactly the opposite from human crowding, was announced today in the Astrophysical Journal.

Business men in general and the business of installment financing in particular were urged today by Donald R. Richberg, former NRA general counsel, to be less ashamed of the profit motives in their relations with the public.
Announcement is expected to be made within a few days of the conclusion of reciprocal trade agreements with both the United Kingdom and Canada.

Vigorous newspaper advertising campaigns, built up in a manner somewhat similar to those conducted by the motion-picture companies, were urged for insurance companies today by Clinton Davidson of New York, vice president of the Fiduciary Council, Inc.
President Roosevelt today commended the National Conference on Labor Legislation for its cooperation in forming "a progressive program for the raising of labor standards."

In the laboratories of the University of California at Berkeley an 85-ton atom-smashing engine, known as the cyclotron, is bombarding a target of light metal with deuterons of several million volts' energy in the first government-sponsored experiment to see what this invention may hold in store for human cancer victims, the United States Public Health Service announced today.
The mightiest Notre Dame football team since the halcyon days of the late great Knute Rockne yesterday took over the national leadership in the fifth Associated Press poll of sports writers.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 14, unless specified: At San Diego: Memphis, Nov. 13; Antares. San Francisco to San Pedro via Operating Area: Astoria, Chester, Louisville, Minneapolis, Northampton, New Orleans, Pensacola, Portland, Quincy, Salt Lake City, San Francisco, Tuscaloosa, Vincennes.

Automobile output advanced last week to its highest point in a year, but the increase was less than seasonal and the adjusted index eased to 89.8 from 92.2. The figure for the week ended Nov. 13, 1937, was 93.2.

The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices advanced last week 0.1 point to 79.9. A year ago, prices were 88.9 per cent of the 1926 base. The current week marks the third consecutive period of advance.

The grave concern with which the United States views the anti-Jewish campaign in Germany was abruptly and dramatically revealed late today when instructions were sent to Hugh R. Wilson, the United States Ambassador in Berlin, to return forthwith to Washington for "report and consultation."

An $80,000 mortgage for five years on the 12-story loft building at 35-37 W. 37th St. has been arranged for 37 W. 37th St., Inc. (Morris Brukenfeld. president) by Ivor B. Clark, Inc. The North River Savings Bank is the mortgagee.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the five-day week ended Nov.. 10 numbered 208, a compared with 192 in the same week a year ago and 216 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

A fire in a ventilating shaft leading from the stereotyping room of The New York Herald Tribune, 225 West Fortieth Street, filled part of the building with smoke last night, and hampered but did not prevent the issuing of the newspaper's first edition.

Lloyd's signal station at Gibraltar informed London headquarters today that the American relief ship Enrica Reed, formerly the Conness Peak of New Orleans, bound from New York to Valencia, Spain, was intercepted by an unidentified armed trawler about four miles west of Gibraltar.
King Haakon of Norway will arrive in London tomorrow from Oslo to be at the side of his wife, Queen Maud, when she is 'operated on for an internal complaint from which she has suffered previously.

In an analysis of the present "state of the military establishment," an analysis all the more forceful because of its restraint, General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the Army, has set forth the needs of the service in his annual report to the Secretary of War.
Mr. and Mrs. Louis Mohill of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam Theodote Mohill, to Arnold M. Astmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Astmann, also of New Britain.

A special Federal grand jury investigating the alleged smuggling Into this port last Oct. 7 of Parisian finery heard the testimony yesterlay of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer, in whose apartment at 570 Park Avenue customs agents found the supposed.contraband last Oct. 27.

Traffic accidents, fatalities and injuries in the city again declined last week and week-end, compared with the corresponding periods last year, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.

Two plans intended to help stabilize employment in the General Motors Corporation and protect hourly-paid employes in case slack times cannot be avoided were announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation. The plans will be effective throughout 1939.
A Netherland airliner, loaded with Jewish refugees fleeing Germany, crashed in a blinding rainstorm near Amsterdam's airport today, killing six of its occupants.
Antanas Smetona, 64-year-old President of Lithuania, was reelected today for a seven-year term. He was the only candidate considered by the newly chosen 128 Members of Parliament.
Professor George Millett Chase, Belcher Professor of Greek at Bates College, died tonight of a heart ailment at his home. He had been a faculty member for thirtytwo years.
With the unification amendment safely under the wire, three-cornered conferences have been resumed in which the city, the Transit Commission and the rapid-transit companies are represented.

For the first time in four weeks the Fordham football squad came through a major game without suffering more than one injury, it was disclosed yesterday when the Rams held a short workout on Fordham Field. Mike Hearn was the only absentee.

New York City's large-scale improvements up to 1944 must be limited to projects that are either indispensable or self-liquidating, according to a joint statement sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Young matrons and debutantes of this season and recent years, headed by Miss Mary Augusta Kinnan, will act as manikins in the fashion show to be held tomorrow at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue, in behalf of various charitable organizations furthered by the proceeds of all sales at the shop.

A blizzard, complete with swirling snow and howling winds, raged in New York City yesterday. It was confined, however, to the locality of Fifth' Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, and it was manufactured not by nature but by the window display department of Lord Taylor.

French Government securities and others of all kinds rose sharply today in response to the new policy inaugurated by Paul Reynaud, Finance Minister, in the decree laws published this morning and applicable as from tomorrow.
Margaret Speaks, radio and concert soprano, received a scroll of honor yesterday afternoon from the Daughters of Ohio "in recognition of her outstanding achievement in the field of music."
The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, will open to the public tomorrow a new permanent gallery illustrating "The History of the New York Stock Exchange."

Mrs. Orin B. Mitcham gave a dinner last night at the Beekman. Among her guests were Mr. and Mrs. George B. Yeomans, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Caldwell, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Granniss, Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Duff, Colonel and Mrs. Jay E. Hoffer, Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Clinkunbroomer, Mrs. James A. Field, Mrs. John McKesson Camp, William E. Beam and Arthur Staire of London.

Housing needs in the United States are localized needs, with a wide variance in size and character, not susceptible to satisfaction by "any single formula or panacea," and housing advocates fail to take into consideration current changes in the picture, Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation and president of the New York Building Congress, declared last night.
The Loyalists are still holding their Segne River bridgehead in its entirety. Generalissimo Francisco Franco is having to prepare a big counter-offensive in an attempt to reduce it.

George McFarlane Milligan, Princeton senior from Pittsburgh, was injured critically here this afternoon when he fell through a trap door on the stage of McCarter Theatre to the concrete floor of the basement, fifteen feet below.

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in October amounted to 542,778 bales of lint and 72,109 bales of linters, compared with 534,037 and 70,991 in September this year and 524,188 and 73,193 in October of last year.

Manhattan Alterations 54th St, 125 W; to four-story school; Board of Education, 500 Park Ave, owner; A?? Rogers, engineer; cost, $23,000. 47th St, 450 W; to five-story tenement; Anna B. Kirkland, 305 W 57th St, owner; R. Ludwig, architect; cost, $8,000.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a proposal to lease property at the North Beach Airport to Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., for ten years at $55,000 a year.

G. F. Hartigan's Pappageno II tonight was established favorite at 100 to 12 for the Manchester November Handicap to be run Nov. 26. The previous favorite, Sir Abe Bailey's Maranta, fell from 100 to 9 to 100 to 8. Other odds:

Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. of General Sessions yesterday set Jan. 9 for the new trial of James J. Hines, the West Harlem Tammany leader, on the felony and misdemeanor indictment accusing him and others of conspiring with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer to operate the policy lottery racket in Harlem.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kilpatrick Cook of 655 Park Avenue, on Friday, at the New York Hospital.

With purchasing men from all parts of the Eastern seaboard visiting their exhibition yesterday, the New York Association of Purchasing Agents, sponsoring a two-day display of the products of their companies at the Hotel Pennsylvania, last night predicted that more than 4,500 buyers, plant managers, and company executives will have viewed the displays by the time the exhibition clones tonight.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Carl M. Anderson and J. Albert Hultquist of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 2 and 56. Kelplogg Company, petr., v. National Biscuit Co.
Spiro Vlachos, a news service correspondent formerly employed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, committed suicide by taking poison this morning while alone in the clubroom of the Foreign Press Association.

The Cabinet met with President Arturo Alessandri at noon today and devoted all afternoon to consideration of the political situation arising from the recent Leftist election victory and the Rightists' contest.

Johanna Hofmann spent her second day on the witness stand in Federal court yesterday denying any connection with espionage activities and accusing Leon G. Turrou, former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, of wheedling a confession from her with false promises of freedom.
To discover what people are going to do at the polls is the function of the straw vote, a test highly perfected of late by Dr. George Gallup and Dr. Claude Robinson.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, and issued yesterday, shows a net income of $10,822,566, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

One-man shows by two leading European modernists appear on the week's exhibition roster. At the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street, paintings and drawings by Henri Matisse will be shown to the public beginning today, while a group of work (again paintings and drawings, by Karl Hofer was placed on view yesterday at the new Nierendorf Gallery, 18 East Fifty-seventh Street, immediately across the street from the old Nierendorf.

A blustery Autumn wind that swept across the Green Meadow Club's championship course today failed to stop Alex Watson, Hudson River C. C. pro, who toured the par 71 route in 33, 36-69, only three strokes above the course record.

A special committee was appointed today to advise on the future of the $7,000,000 Farr Alpaca Company, Inc., after a Boston broker had appealed for liquidation of the concern and a stockholders' advisory committee had endorsed continuance of the company.

Dr. John Charles Phillips, prominent naturalist and a brother of William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, died suddenly today while on a hunting trip near here. His age was 62. His home was at Wenham, Mass.

Only in a democracy can "full respect" be given to the individuality of a child, Dr. Arnold Gesell of Yale University declared yesterday at the fiftieth anniversary conference and institute of the Child Study Association of America in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $19,432,000 of hurricane and flood-damage bonds to a banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company on a bid of. 100.19 for 0.75s.

The cornerstone of Portugal's pa- as vilion at the World Fair was laid bu in the presence of Dr. Joao de Bianchi, Portuguese Minister to Washington, yesterday afternoon at M: the same time that word came from ne South Dakota that its Fair Com- th mission had met and decided to urge upon the Legislature the need m for an appropriation for an exhibit at the fair.
Mrs. Sophie A. Stein of Grantwood, N. J., where she was formerly president of the Women's Auxiliary of the American Legion, died yesterday in Queens Hospital, Jamaica, at the age of 66.
The New York Rangers will open their home season in the National Hockey League race tonight when they oppose the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

With almost every one of the varsity backs suffering from injuries sustained in last Friday's game with Ithaca, Coach Lou Oshins decided to give the Brooklyn College football team another day of rest yesterday. The squad was dismissed after a brief blackboard session.

After an absence from the screen of several months because of illness which necessitated his withdrawal from the cast of "A Christmas Carol," Lionel Barrymore will return to Metro after the holidays for "Let Freedom Ring," for which Ben Hecht is writing the screen play.

Magenta St (16-4634), s w cor of Colden Ave. 117x101; Mayone Co of N Y, Inc. to Mayone Holding Corp, Saugerties, N. Y. Longfellow Ave (10-2762C), w s, 154 ft s of Seneca Ave, 54x100; Samuel Cohen to Les Jay Realty Corp, 850 E 161st St, mtg $63,500.

Miss Veronica M. D. Hammarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hammarth of Elmhurst, Queens, will be married to Alfred A. Beattie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Beattie of New York and Chicago, on Nov. 24 in St. Bartholomew's Catholic Church, Elmhurst.
The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, gave its season's first concert last night at Carnegie Hall before a large audience.
The annual card party to aid the Chapin Home for Aged and Infirm of Jamaica, Queens, will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 28 in the Starliht Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
House investigators received testimony today that Communist party organizers were concentrating on automobile workers in order to "wield economic pressure" on the construction of armaments.

Retail food prices declined 0.7 per cent between Sept. 13 and Oct. 18, according to an analysis issued today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Fractional declines were general in all groups except for eggs and fresh fruits and vegetables.
Viscount and Viscountess Knollys of London will arrive Thursday on the Queen Mary. They will stop at the Ambassador.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is considering a direct approach to President Roosevelt for Anglo-American cooperation to rescue Jews from Germany.

Stocks reactionary under profittaking, closed with widest losses of month in less active trading; turnover, 1,651,280 shares. All groups of bonds closed moderately lower in second slowest dealings of month; transactions, $6,989,175.

Princeton's plentiful supply of ends again was called on to fill a depleted backfield today as the squad raced through a short, spirited passing session on University Field in preparation for the Army contest that will close the season here next Saturday.
Maximilian A. Rasko, HungarianAmerican portrait painter, received a scroll from the French Government yesterday signifying that he had been made an officer of the French National Academy.

Leslie G. Nunamaker, former major league baseball catcher, died today after an illness of several months. His age was 49. He was in the majors sixteen years, catching for the Boston Red Sox, New York Yankees, St. Louis Browns and Cleveland Indians.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday in his official annual capital budget message that the city planned not only to remove the Sixth Avenue elevated line, but the Second and Ninth Avenue lines in Manhattan and the Fulton Street line in Brooklyn as well.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs was fair to slow in local markets yesterday; other classes were in fair demand. The lamb market was strong to higher; veal strong to slightly higher; bull and cow steady; other classes uneven. Early trading in kosher meats was fair, with lamb higher and other kosher meats about in line with last Thursday's close.

The trial of Robert Irwin for the murder of Frank Byrnes early on Easter morning, 1937, ended abruptly in its third day yesterday when the defendant pleaded guilty in the second degree to slaying not only Byrnes but Mrs. Mary Gedeon and her daughter, Ronnie, 20-year-old model.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES Harold Riegelman, in his letter in THE TIMES today, properly and accurately calls attention to the facts that (1) the recent Constitutional Convention did not act in a partisan spirit, (2) that about 94 per cent of its work has met with the approval of the people.
Albert T. Johnston has been elected a trustee of the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.
Ralph D. Earle Jr., Exalted Ruler of Hackensack Lodge of Elks and foreman of the April term of the Bergen County Grand Jury, died of a heart attack while driving through this borough last night.

The Rev. James A. Mackin of the Order of Preachers, stationed at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, died on Sunday in the New York Hospital of a heart attack at the age of 68.
The International Labor Office announced today that the United States Government had officially registered for the first time its ratification of an international labor convention.

John Burke, president of the New York Chapter of the National Republican Builders, Inc., made public yesterday a letter he had written to Kenneth F. Simpson requesting the latter to resign as Republican national committeeman from New York. Mr. Burke has opposed many of Mr. Simpson's policies in the Dast year.
Turpentine firm, 22 8/4c; sales 59 barrels; receipts 410 barrels; shipments 107 barrels; stock 52,773 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 159; receipts 2,172; shipments 715; stock 292,306.

Mrs. Sarah Leah Goldwasser Bruckman, 112-year-old guest at the Home of the Daughters of Israel, Fifth Avenue and 107th Street, died Sunday at the home after an illness of two weeks. She was the oldest among the several hundred men and women at the home.

To Cecil W. Creel of Reno, Nev., retiring president of the Land Grant College Association, was awarded today the annual highest honor for meritorious service conferred by Epsilon Sigma Phi, national honorary extension fraternity.

BUTLER, WILLIAM O. (Oct. 4). Estate. $10,000. To Elsie C. Butler, widow, executrix, 105 West 72d St. FLEURY, ROBERT (Oct. 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Roger Pelletier. nephew, executor, Ocean Ave., Seaford Harbor. L. I., residue.

An acting High Commissioner of the Philippines not only possesses all the powers and performs all of the duties of the High Commissioner but may use all of his facilities, including the recently built palatial residence, Acting Controller General Elliott ruled today.

Tonight's events: Kirsten Flagstad, soprano, Carnegie Hall; Trio of New York, Town Hall, 8:30; Helen Arden, soprano, Albert Mieff, violinist, 13 East Sixty-seventh Street, 9; chamber music concert, Juilliard School of Musi, 4:30;
Public hearings will be resumed here tomorrow morning in the Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

New Yorkers dug out their topcoats, gloves and sweaters yesterday as a biting northwest wind that at times reached a velocity of fifty-five miles an hour swept the city and brought a low temperature of 43 degrees.

A confidential alarm has been sent out through police channels for nearly a month to recover jewels valued at $4,000 which were stolen from Wanamaker's department store on Oct. 17, it was learned yesterday at Police Headquarters.
A bigamy charge filed ten days ago against Edward Mark Marlay Carolin, 33, an architect, formerly of Johannesburg, South Africa, has been dropped, his attorney said today.

Thirteen persons were injured today during the mass funeral for forty-eight of those officially listed as killed in the Nouvelles Galeries fire. One of the Injured was a Senegalese soldier who had been keeping crowds on the sidewalks, but went insane and with his bayonet fixed charged a Bishop who was walking in the procession.

Shredded wheat is a generic term by which a "biscuit in pillow-shaped form is generally known to the public," the Supreme Court said today in deciding, six to two, that the National Biscuit Company could not prevent the Kellogg Company from selling breakfast food under that name and in that form.

Fires and football games would be brought into the home as spot news by television. The flames would crackle and crowds would roar and the radio listener would see in his receiving set every but of action as it happened, Philip T. Farnsworth, a pioneer in television experiments, said here tonight as he described his most recent invention.

The wholesale price index of the National a Fertilizer Association rose moderately last week, with all of the main groups advancing except that of chemicals and drugs. The index, based on the 1926-28 average, was 73.1 for the week ended Nov. 12, compared with 72.9 last week, 72.7 a month ago and 81.1 a year ago.

Budget requests for 1939 aggregating $20,652,575, an increase of $3,785,514 over the appropriations for this year, were submitted to the Westchester County Board of Supervisors today by heads of county deapartments. The supervisors called a public hearing for the night of Nov. 28.

Thomas Hitchcock's Annibal, champion jumper of the year, today closed his 5-year-old campaign in a blame of glory when he carried top weight of 164 pounds to an easy triumph in the eighteenth Manly Steeplechase Handicap at Pimlioo.

Counsel for two Duchy of Liechtenstein corporations sought today, at a hearing before a Federal court special master, to wipe out an $18,352,577 claim which the Southern Pacific Railroad had made against its subsidiary, the Cotton Belt Railway Company.
Estimates for production and sales of Buick cars were revised upward at a special projection meeting of company zone managers for the Eastern part of the country at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 9:

After falling more than 2 1/2 cents to $4.705-16, the lowest level since the recent war crisis at the end of September, the pound sterling rallied slightly yesterday and closed at $4.71, a net loss of 2 cents from Saturday, in another highly unsettled day in the foreign-exchange market.

The Isthmian Steamship Company told the Maritime Commission today it would be forced to build and operate eight fast new freighters under foreign flag if the Federal Government refused to subsidize its 'round-the-world operations.
Benjamin Grobany, American baritone, who has sung in Philadelphia and at the Metropolitan Opera House, will give his first concert in New York tomorrow afternoon at the Town Hall.
Many organizations and individuals, by resolution or messages to President Roosevelt, added their voices yesterday to condemnation of the campaign against Jews and Catholics in Germany.

Pavel Morozoff, a Young Pioneer boy who exposed his father as a public enemy and was murdered by his father in retaliation, will be immortalized in a heroic bronze statue in Red Square beside the Kremlin wall, it was announced today in the Pioneer Pravda.

Shoe retailers, confident of an active Spring season and prepared to pay advances on lower-priced lines, were nevertheless chary about placing appreciable orders when members of the Shoe Fashion Guild and various manufacturers in the volume brackets exhibited their new Spring lines here yesterday.

It was learned today that contrary to previous reports, the Rev. Fritz Mueller and other ministers of the German Evangelical Church's provisional administration have not been arrested, but proceedings have been started against them for participation in an appeal recommending that an church authorities and brotherhood councils should hold on Sept. 30 intercession services--

An announcement by 'the White House that President Roosevelt will confer immediately with Attorney General Cummings upon about fifteen vacancies in the Federal judiciary system led to belief today that, with the elections over, candidates for many of these posts would be chosen at once.

With the opening today of another chapter in the $9,000,000 William Fox bankruptcy case, it appeared that no one knows exactly the value of the All-Continent Corporation, the trust fund which the one-time film executive set up for his wife, Mrs. Eva Fox, and two daughters several years ago.

Spurred by lower temperatures and brisk winds that suggested Winter was close at hand, both retail and wholesale trade scored improvement here yesterday. While they had fairly good figures of last year to beat, retail executives of a number of stores estimated sales for the day ran ahead of the corresponding day of 1937.

Dr. Michael J. Sheahan, for forty years a physician of this city, died at his residence last night after a long illness at the age of 70. Born in Ireland, he was graduated from the Yale Medical School in 1896.
H. A. Mince, representative for The Times of London, who covered Northern England, died today in Manchester at the age of 66.

Two major upsets were recorded in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association open tournament at the New York A. C. last night as B. H. Ridder of the University Club beat A. H. Barker of the Rockaway Hunting Club, No. 1 on the seeded list, and J. J. Reynolds, University Club, topped Tom Golibart, Midston House player, who was listed sixth.

Despite the fact that theirs is not today the power and the glory thai furnished the inspiration for some of the oldest college songs and cheers, the patriarchal Big Three of football will hold the spotlight in the East on Saturday when they reach journey's end along with the Big Ten of the Western Conference

Frank M. Taylor, retired vaudeville actor, known on the stage as Frank Farrell-Taylor, died on Sunday in Morrissania Hospital, 168th Street and Walton Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 71. He lived at 4,441 Broadway.
Commenting upon the summoning home of Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson, The Newark Ledger tomorrow will urge that diplomatic relations between the United States and Germany be severed.
President Roosevelt today appealed to the convention of the Committee for Industrial Organization to hold open "every possible door to access to peace" in the warring labor movement.

The annual financial statement of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation and subsidiaries covering the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, shows a net profit of $1,265,976 after interest, amortization, depreciation, minority interests, Federal income taxes and $20,000 surtax on undistributed earnings.

The Holland-America liner Volendam is due today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Mrs. George Cabot Lodge, Mr. and Mrs. Johan A. Siegruhn, Mr. and Mrs. Carlos de Negri, Ernst K. Gellichsheimer, German author, and his wife; Miss Anna M. Kennedy, Mr. and Mrs. William Ramsey Heberhart, Mrs. Ethel Morison and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bach.
137th St. 605-09 E; 1-story store, 75x100; Herbert J. Cochran against Kloeffler Machinery Corp; due, $3,850; taxes, etc. $1,000; sub to mtg $9,400; to plaintiff for S9.500.
The Mackintosh of Mackintosh, twenty-eighth chief of the clan Chattan for sixtytwo years and a typical Scottish Highland chief, died today at Moyhall, Inverness, at the age of 87.

The monthly survey of bankers' dollar acceptance outstanding in all of the Federal Reserve Districts as of Oct. 31, 1938, put the aggregate at $269,561,958, an increase of $8,131,017 for the month, but a decrease of $76,684,699 compared with a year previously.

The plans developed to mitigate the hardships suffered by senior employes of General Motors Corporation during a shut-down such as occurs even in good years in the period of preparation for a new model, undoubtedly will be received with widespread interest in business circles.

William Lygon, seventh Earl of Beauchamp, who long was a leader in the British Liberal party, died at 11:55 o'clock last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria after an illness of several weeks. He was 66 years old.

Any objections from the States of New York, Texas and Florida to the proposal that Massachusetts be permitted to impose a tax of $4,947,008 upon the $36,137,335 estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green must be filed by Dec. 12, the Supreme Court announced today.
Manuel Mujica Carassa, Peruvian mine owner, reached Rochester today after a 4,765-mile dash from Lima, Peru, to undergo treatment .for intestinal obstruction at one of the clinics here.

Arthur H. Bunker, a member of the investment banking house of Lehman Brothers, was elected to the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History at the annual Fall meeting last night at the museum.
Governor Lehman returned tonight to the capital for the first time since his re-election with an intimation that economy would be a keynote of his fourth term.
A wide variety of residential properties in scattered sections of the city were included in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

Miss Gene Sternberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Sternberg of 135 Central Park West, was married to Dr. Thomas Paine Saltiel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Saltiel of Chicago, yesterday at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

Paul Sifton, deputy administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, will be the principal speaker at the sixth annual president's day luncheon of the Executives Association of Greater New York at the Hotel Astor on Thursday.
In "Ballerina," which was presented yesterday at the Little Carnegie Playhouse, Jean Benoit-Levy has created a film of tenderness, beauty and dramatic strength.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 10: CAPTAINS Griffin, R. M., Washington, D. C., in Dec., to command of the New York. Barry, J. R., Newport, R. I., in Dec., to command of the Trenton.

The Soviet Government is soon to erect a monument to Pavel Morozoff. Pavel was the 12-year old boy who discovered that his father was concealing wealthy peasants from the authorities and who thereupon denounced him.
Two-Ton Tony Galento, New Jersey's gift to the heavyweight division, bombed Harry Thomas of Eagle Bend, Minn., to defeat in three rounds of a scheduled twelve-round battle at Convention Hall tonight.
Robert R. Houston, a consulting architect to the New York World's Fair, died on Saturday at his New York home, 60 West Tenth Street. He was 70 years old.

Captain Thomas Francis McManus, "father" of the fishermen's races and foremost designer of fast sailing vessels, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the age of 82. He was a friend of Sir Thomas Lipton and President Theodore Roosevelt.

Twenty-two women have been elected to the New Hampshire House of Representatives, which is a record number. The total House membership this year is 427, also a record and due to the fact that towns of less than 600 population are represented in proportion to the ratio that their actual population bears to 600.

Domel, Japanese news agency, said today that Japan would reply Friday to the United States protest against closing the Open-Door in China with a demand for revision of "understandings respecting China made immediately after the World War."
The Princeton Club won its third match in four starts last night when it defeated the Yale Club on the Tiger court, 5 to 0, in a Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis match.

Turkey's world trade in the first half of this year has registered a gain of $22,383,200, or 27.2 per cent, over the same period in 1937, and a resultant favorable balance of $6,900,000 is shown in a summary made public by the commercial counselor of the Turkish Embassy.
John W. Arrington, pioneer Southern textile manufacturer and president of the Union Bleachery of Greenville, died at his home here today after a long illness at the age of 77.
Among the many prominent Jews reported arrested in the recent round-ups is Dr. Fritz Moritz Warburg, former head of the famous Hamburg banking house of M. M. Warburg Co.

If football's penchant for upsets persists the country's only undefeated and untied teams are going to be some unknowns named Joe. At the top of The Associated Press survey yesterday was San Jose State of California, and gone are at least two proud powers of the East and West, Dartmouth and Santa Clara.

Fully rested after a week-end of inactivity, the Manhattan football team launched preparations yesterday for Saturday's intersectional meeting with West Virginia University at the Yankee Stadium. In a hard two-hour practice session Coach Herb Kopf concentrated on developing the Jasper attack.
Despite the country's political and economic troubles, the Palestine Symphony Orchestra gave its first Jerusalem concert of the season tonight.
Mrs. Martha McMahon Wildman was married this afternoon at the Frey ranch here to Samuel M. Bash of New York, official of a steel company, by the'Rev. Reuben Thompson.

A copy of the first folio of Shakespeare's plays brought $7,250 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of Part 3 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

Miss Ruth Pierpont Stephens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ward-Stephens of 132 East Nineteenth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to John Martin Lyden of this city and Youngstown, Ohio, which will take place here on Saturday afternoon in St. James' Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary.
