The West Virginia State Supreme Court invalidated today a municipal bond issue of $1,629,000 for the improvement of streets and the construction of fire stations in Charleston.
Mr. Roosevelt's appointment of Mr. Landon as a delegate to the eighth International Conference of American States, which begins next month at Lima, is more than a compliment to a political opponent.
Amendments to the New York Curb Exchange's constitution, which change commission rates on small transactions, have been adopted by a vote of the members and will become effective today.

The House of Assembly has voted the Trade Development Board [Pound]25,000 for advertising in the United States next year. The board asked for an extra [Pound]7,000 on account of the New York World's Fair, which is expected to boom Bermuda business.

Warfare and the domination of increasingly large areas by the totalitarian governments are steadily reducing the spread of Protestantism and the possibility of maintaining church institutions in mission countries, according to a report of the corresponding secretaries of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church to members of the board yesterday.

These may be disappointing days for the Long Island duck hunters, but the striped bass fishermen are really having a time keeping these scrappers off their hooks, according to that eminent piscatorial authority, Captain Walt Willis.

Despite an increase in unfilled orders for men's wear fabrics and automobile cloths, total unfilled orders of 138 wool goods mills opereating 30,000 looms declined in September and stood at 24,800,000 yards on Oct. 1, compared with 25,734,000 yards on July 2, according to data issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.
The first convicts ordered into exile since France decided to resume sending prisoners to the French Guiana penal colony were assembled today for the trip. to South America.

Owners of estates on North Street near Bryant Avenue in this city opposed- this afternoon before the Municipal Planning Board an application by the Wyte West Building Corporation to divide the thirty-acre estate of the late Daniel Maloney, real estate operator and trotting horse fancier, into seventyfoot building plots for 114 "cheap" houses costing $12,000 to $16,000 each.

A new organization, known as Films for Democracy, which has as its purpose the non-profit-making production and distribution of motion pictures designed "to safeguard and extend American democracy," has been in formation for several months, it was revealed yesterday, and has received the endorsement of many prominent educators, writers, political figures and persons well known on stage. and screen.

Franklin D'Olier, acting president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America since the death of Edward D. Duffield, president, on Sept. 17, was elected yesterday president of the company at a meeting of the board of directors.
Miss Betty Coriell and Miss Rosamond Ely will be introduced to society during the Christmas season. Miss Coriell,
Ralph De, Luca, 70 years old, of 1,011 Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, went on trial yesterday before Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer and a jury on a charge of first-degree murder.
Legislation required to carry out the terms of the housing amendment adopted at the polls last Tuesday will be drawn by a special committee, Mayor La Guardia announced at City Hall yesterday.
Seventeen names were suggested yesterday to the retiring nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange for the seven places on the new committee, which will be elected on Jan. 9.

A $10,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the trustees of the Western Pacific Railroad Company to be secured by trustees' certificates was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The Treasury's weekly bill issue was sold today at an average interest rate of 0.027 per cent, compared with 0.022 per cent for the issue sold on Nov. 4, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

The Mexican rebel leader, General Saturnino Cedillo, who is now in hiding following the collapse of his revolution, has an agent in the United States, according to a registration made at the State Department today under the law requiring registration of agents of foreign principals.

The six-story apartment house at 2,865 University Avenue, Bronx, acquired last Summer by Loomis J. Grossman, operator, from the Manufacturers Trust Company has been resold to a client of Cohen Wonder, attorneys.
High scoring performances were reported from all around the nation in Saturday's football festival and new leaders were established in The Associated Press's compilation of individual scores.

Joseph H. Arnold, from 100th Precinct to 18th Division, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 16. James A. Giattini. from 110th Precinct to 18th Division. duty in D. A. office, Queens County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M.. Nov. 10.
The Orchestrette Classique presented fourteen of its members, assisted by the guitarist, Julio Martinez Oyanguren, in a chambermusic concert last night at the Carnegie Chamber Hall.

The appointment of three committees to explore the possibilities of moving surpluses through regular trade channels was authorized at a meeting of retail executives yesterday at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Formation of a coalition between the 170 Republicans in the next House and conservative Democrats to investigate the "political activities" of the Works Progress Administration will be one of the earliest undertakings of Republican leaders after Congress convenes, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, said today after conferring with some members of his party and anti-New Deal Democrats.

In language of a temper and intensity seldom used in times of peace by citizens of one country in speaking of another, six distinguished Americans last night joined in a nation-wide broadcast protesting against Germany's persecution of racial and religious minorities.

Led by Miss Ella Gulbrandsen, 17year-old Norwegian Olympic skier, a group of New York debutantes staged a ski and cruise fashion show yesterday aboard the new Norwegian-American line flagship Oslofjord under the auspices of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

The Election year. Bureau of the Secretary of State's office finished tabulating returns from last Tuesday's elections tonight and found it still lacked reports from 110 of the 9,055 voting districts. Some of the districts which failed to report were in New York City.
Lincoln Ellsworth on his way to the Antarctic has just spent an uncomfortable fortnight between Cape Town and the Kerguelen Islands;
Joseph P. Crosby died at his home in Yarmouth, N. S., following a year's illness, according to word received here today. Mr. Crosby, who was 83 years old, resided in Greenwich, 1885 to 1936.
The instructions to our Ambassador in Berlin to return at once to Washington for purposes of consultation reveal how seriously our Government regards the present course of events in Germany.

Rose Bampton, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, will replace Rosa Ponselle as the artist at the second concert of the Town Hall endowment series on Wednesday evening, Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday.
Chairman Frank McNinch of the Federal Communications Commission, acting under a mandate from the President, began yesterday an investigation of what is called the "radio monopoly."

Sitting as a board of canvassers, Westchester County Supervisors tabulated and certified today the official vote cast in the county Nov. 8 in the two United States Senatorial contests. The official figures were: Short term, James M. Mead, Democrat and American Labor, 79,282, and Edward Corsi, Republican and Independent Progressive, 137,190;
There appeared to be no abatement of interest yesterday as the National Automobile Show was presented for its fourth day at the Grand Central Palace.

A far-reaching program, establishing standard specifications and tests for oil burners and imposing rigid requirements on dealers, will be voted upon by the industry today, when some 350 manufacturers of oil burners meet this morning at the Hotel New Yorker.
THE CHAMBERLAIN TRADITION, by Sir Charles Petrie. (Stokes, $2.50.) Biographies of Joseph, Austen and Neville Chamberlain.

Contributions of $6,792 were announced yesterday at the fourth campaign report luncheon of city Y. W. C. A. at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue. These brought the total received in the 1939 annual budget drive to $93,404. The goal is $205,000.

Gross assets. $21.415; net, $19,788. To Walter Gigerich, $500; Helen and Charlotte Fink, jewelry; niece, Mildred Degman, diamond ring and one-fifth of residue; husband, William Mac Queen, $2,000 and a dinner ring; niece, Ruth Maurer: nephews, Arthur and Edgar Krapf, and niece.

James A. Waddell, 65 years old, for more than twenty years one of the leading strikebreaker chiefs of this country, but who encountered, financial reverses with the advent of the Wagner Labor Law, received in General Sessions yesterday a suspended sentence for passing worthless checks.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 9, which included only five business days in many of the reporting centers, aggregated $6,688,000,000, or 28 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 16 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Harcourt, Brace will bring out on Dec. 1 a chronicle of forty years of American diplomacy under the title, "The Far Eastern Policy of the United States," by A. Whitney Griswold, Assistant Professor of Government and International Relations at Yale University.

Judge Paul N. Schaeffer today delayed setting a date for the opening of the grand jury investigation of the Earle administration so as to give Attorney General Guy K. Bard a "reasonable" time in which to decide whether another appeal should be taken to the State Supreme Of Court.
Practically all groups of bonds drifted irregularly lower in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Sales were $6,989,175, compared with $11,397,500 on last Thursday.
Columbia's football squad was excused from practice yesterday, and instead spent two hours in John Jay Hall on the campus watching slow-motion pictures of the Navy game.

The front tire of a 1939 Hudson was blown out yesterday with a shotgun as.the car traveled at sixty miles an hour along an open highway in Westchester County, when the motor-car company held a demonstration of a safety feature of its new cars called "autopoise control."

Dr. Walter Gropius, Professor of Architecture at Harvard, will lecture this evening on "The New Architecture" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The lecture will beillustrated and is the fourth in the discussion series sponsored by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Miss Ann Rorke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Rorke of Cleveland, was married here to Herbert Newton Higgins, son of Alfred Higgins of Yonkers, N. Y., yesterday morning in the nun's chapel of the Church of St. Joseph, Monroe and Catharine Streets, by the pastor, the Rev. Raphael Larcher.

The anti-Semitic drive now going in Germany was described last night as "part of the fruits of the Munich pact," by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party and former Presidential candidate of that organization, at a rally in Madison Square Garden.

A group of New York importers led by Curt G. Pfeiffer, president of the National Council of Traders and Importers, conferred today with customs and Treasury officials to obtain an explanation of the customs order of last week which decreed Czechoslovak markings on goods from the German-annexed Sudeten area would no longer be acceptable.

The gold medal awarded annually by the American Woman's Association was presented last night to Dorothy Thompson, special writer of The New York Herald Tribune, for outstanding achievement in journalism.
The Netherland Government is being urged by Jewish and other organizations to consider measures for immediate relief of German Jews.

" Where Do We Go From Here?" a comedy by William Bowers, has its postponed opening tonight at the Vanderbilt. It concerns the life of a group of students at a midwestern university and is presented by Oscar Hammerstein and Dwight Taylor.

Mr. and Mrs. Adolph A. Rubens, Americans arrested here last Winter, are flatly accused of being spies in the article today in Red Star, the organ of the Soviet Army, reviewing the spy trial in the United States.
The Junior Emergency Relief Society will resume its weekly meetings for the season this morning at the Biltmore.
Launching a comeback campaign for Harvard's invasion of the Bowl next Saturday, Yale today staged a long signal and dummy drill that was concluded under the floodlights of Anthony Thompson Field.

Uncle Sam has passed his final tests in Akron, Ohio, and is ready to be sent aloft. Thus did an announcement yesterday by R. H. Macy Co. herald the approach of the store's fourteenth annual Thanksgiving Day parade, for Uncle Sam, in this case, is a 75foot balloon that will lead the procession.

A fast finish in the final round enabled Billy Beauhuld, 138, Jersey City, to gain the decision over Charley Gomer, 136 3/4, Baltimore, in the feature eight-round bout on the card at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,800.

The Long Island Real Estate Board will meet at afternoon and evening conferences today at the Garden City Country Club, Garden City, L. I. Herbert L. Carpenter, chairman of the Real Estate Taxpayers' Federation, will be the speaker this evening.

That substantial recovery has occurred in production and trade activity is plainly indicated by current reports and "index numbers." The Federal Reserve Board's monthly industrial production index places the October achievement at 95 per cent of the 1923-25 average.

The registration of motor vehicles in this State in the first nine months this year reached 2,587,527, compared with 2,563,582 in the corresponding period last year, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, reported Yesterdav.

A resolution declaring the acts of terrorism against Jews and Catholics in Germany "a blow to civilized morality" and calling upon President Roosevelt to condemn officially these "barbaric acts" was unanimously adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, New York City's executive body.

Ladies and gentlemen, I speak as a representative of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ and of my own church. Long ago a Methodist Bishop said, "Methodism never hanged a witch, never banished a Baptist, never persecuted a Jew, never whipped a Quaker."
Funeral services will be held at 10 A. M. today in the Hotel Surrey, 20 East Seventy-sixth Street, for Aaron Gantz, who died there on Sunday at the age of 59.

An accident attributed to a strong gust of wind that swept inshore while. a heavy steel truss was being placed in the roof of a partly constructed hangar at North Beach Airport, in Queens, killed one WPA worker yesterday afternoon and injured five others.

The world-wide communications system of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation will be silenced for one minute today as-a tribute to Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board, who died Saturday night.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, here for a lecture engagement, pleaded today for "racial tolerance." "While I cannot speak for anyone but myself, I hope that we, in our country, will remain as free of prejudice and tolerant as we have been," she said in an interview.
The first Pan American Congress of Municipalities opened here this morning in the salon of the House of Representatives at the National Capitol with delegates of twenty-one countries attending.
The administration that has carried on for the United States Golf Association for the last year has been given a vote of confidence, according to the 1939 nominations announced yesterday.

R. Richard Spira, Eric and Warner Baer, in 236 W 70th St; Harold L. Born, in 55 W 11th St; Emilie Farah, in 15 W 8th St: Albert Lipschitz, in 205 W 54th St; Eleanor Dusten, Anne Sweeney, in 177 E 74th St; Byrne Bowman, Inc.. broker.
The fifty-eighth season of the Knickerbocker Greys will be opened at 3 P. M. today, when a musical drill will be held in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street.

On the ground that license laws for real estate brokers, now in effect in thirty-one States, have proved their merit, realty interests of the nation have started a movement to strengthen these regulations and to extend them to all States.
There is as yet no Administration tax program, because tax plans have not yet "jelled," Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today. He had just come from the White House.

Declaring that nazism and antiSemitism never before reached "such bestial heights" as during the last week, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday for support of the United Palestine Appeal, which tomorrow night sponsors the fifth annual "Night of Stars" at Madison Square Garden.
More than 100 detectives and uniformed patrolmen guarded the arrival of the Hapag-North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday while 150 anti-Nazi demonstrators picketed opposite pier 86 North River.

More active retail trade last week found reflection in a heavier volume of mail orders from out-of-town stores yesterday, resident buyers reported. Coat and suit, dress and accessory volume was substantially better than a week ago, although the improvement could not yet be classed as a rush for goods, buyers said.

Indefinite closing of the factory of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, 43 Hall Street, Brooklyn, was announced by the management yesterday after a strike had gone into effect at the plant, which employs 1,600 workers and occupies an entire block.
Boys of the Blind Institute were guests at a reception given for them yesterday at the club house of the Girls' Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, by the league's Leisure Time Committee.

Mrs. Barbara Porges, co-leader with Christopher D. Sullivan of the Second Assembly District on the lower East Side where she virtually controlled the Tammany vote long before woman suffrage, died yesterday of the infirmities of age in a private hospital at 22 West Seventy-fourth Street. She was 90 years old.

Pierre-Etienne Flandin, former French Premier, who exchanged congratulatory telegrams with Chancellor Hitler of Germany after the "peace of Munich," was slapped publicly today by a lawyer who objected.
49th St. 535 W: 3-story building. 40x50: Title Guarantee Trust Co, trustee, against G. R. N. Co., Inc; due, $8,000; taxes, etc. $600; to plaintiff for $7,000.

A cross-section of the William Randolph Hearst collection, ranging from pre-Christian art to that of the eighteenth century, will be opened to the public this morning in a five-story building leased for the purpose at 46 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Captain George E. T. Eyston, holder of the world speed record for automobiles--he made 357.5 miles an hour Sept. 16 on the Utah salt flats-today was fined $5 in Bow Street Police Court for exceeding London's thirty-mile speed limit.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Finan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Finan of 454 Riverside Drive, has chosen Nov. 26 for her marriage to Frank A. Byrnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Byrnes of Brooklyn. The ceremony will take place here in Corpus Christi Church, 531 West 121st Street.

CALVIN COOLIDGE was money-honest, says William Allen White in "A Puritan in Babylon"*--money-honest, shrewd, resolute, old-fashioned. He was by no means as dull as at times he appeared to be, nor as flinty and crotchety. He was a "second-rate lawyer in a fourth-class town" who rubbed his eyes one day and found that he was living in the White House.

The Chinese Army will not attempt to make another firm stand against the Japanese until the invaders reach the Hunan hills south of Changsha, semi-official British news reports from Chungking, the new capital, indicated.
President Neilson of Smith College said today that his proposal to bring Jewish scholars to this country brought from other college presidents the query, "What about our own unemployed teachers?"

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of the Cuban Army, and his entourage inspected the United States Military Academy at West Point yesterday as guests of Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict, superintendent of the academy. Colonel Batista, attired in civilian dress, reviewed the cadet corps.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. "Current Events," Stanley High, 10:30 A. M.; "The Challenge of the Election," Anna Steese Richardson, 8:15 P. M.

Unless the Green Bay Packers are held scoreless by the New York Giants next Sunday at the Polo Grounds they are certain to break their own scoring mark in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday. The Packers have tied their record of 220 points for an elevengame schedule. The contest with the Giants will be the last.

An all-star metropolitan college team will oppose the Brooklyn Football Dodgers at Ebbets Field on Dec. 3 in a game sponsored by the Sports Committee for Catholic, Jewish and Protestant Refugees From Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Lefft, executive director of the contest.

Voluntary self-regulation of broadcasting in the mutual interest of the industry and its radio audience and us a public service vital to the maintenance of the "new freedom" of the air was urged today by David ??, president of the Radio Corporation of America, at the openingg of the Federal Communications Commission hearings in its investigation of the radio industry.

Miss Ruth Brown Shurtleff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Flavel Shurtleff of this city, will be married on Dec. 23 in the Union Congregational Church here to Robert Leland Crowell, son of T. Irving Crowell. The ceremony will be followed by a reception at the Shurtleff home.

1st Lt. Claudius J. Walker, F. A.-Res., 131 69th St., Niagara Falls, N. Y.. is ordered to active duty with the CCC for a period of six months, effective Nov. 14, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC. Schenectady, N. Y., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: Oct. 16. He will revert to an inactive status May 13, 1939.

Sound State conservation laws for oil production plus interstate cooperation by an oil compact are important steps in stabilizing the oil industry, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said today, in an interview as some 2,500 oil men gathered in the Stevens Hotel for the institute's nineteenth annual meeting.
Indications are for generally fair weather with little change in temperature today and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

A slow and draggy fed steer and yearling trade prevailed today, at weak to mostly 25-cent lower levels, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs were fairly active at 5 to 10 cents higher rates, with the day's top at $7.80. Fat lambs sold around steady, best native lambs reaching $9.25.

Wheat prices held within narrow limits today. Easiness in Liverpool had a depressing effect early as did the decline in securities and foreign exchange when the professionals were on the selling side.
ABRAMS-David, suddenly. beloved husband of Lucille, dear father of Joan "Bunny." Funeral 2 P. M. today, 1,024 49th St., Brooklyn.

The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its refusal of Oct. 10 to review the decision of the California Supreme Court against Thomas J. Mooney, serving a life sentence for the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombings in 1916.
The seat sale for the opening night performance of Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera House next Monday was opened at 9 o'clock yesterday morning and closed within an hour.

The Western Union and the Postal Telegraph Companies both announced last night that they would comply with the wages-and-hours decision under the Fair Labor Standards Act in accord with the recommendation made last Saturday to Administrator Elmer F. Andrews by Dr. William M. Leiserson, whose views Mr. Andrews is expected to accent.

Tennessee Valley Authority electricity was assured to twenty-two Western Tennessee communities today when the West Tennessee Power Light Company agreed to sell its electric distribution system for $1,600,000.

An explosion heard all over this town shattered a house on Bahnhofstrasse this morning. Furniture was blown high in the air. Only one body was extricated from the wreckage, but six persons are missing. Three others were injured.

Montgomery St, 31-3, 45.5x75x irreg; Wm. P. Morris. trustee Geo Graham, to State Engineering Corp, 205 W 34th St; ($6). 94th St. 102 W. 35x98.10; Rose Schechter to Rosart Realty Corp. 102 W 94t St; quit claim.

102d St, 304 W, 25x100.11; Lillian Weitz to Kate Kramer, 151 Hopkins Ave, Bklyn; pr mtg $56,300, 5 years, 6%; $7,000. 144th St, 455 to 9 W, 56.6x99.11; Patrick J Daly to Marburt Holding Corp, 270 Broadway; P m as to No. 457, pr mtg $23,600; due May 12, 1939. 6%; $600.

A shift in the emphasis in Federal spending from work relief as it is now conducted under the Works Progress Administration to job-producing projects under a national defense program was the subject of a conference today between President Roosevelt and representatives of the interested departments, it was learned from those who attended the conference.
Latest census figures of the Matteawan State Hospital for Criminal Insane in Beacon, made public today, show the population is now 1,437 prisoners, an alltime peak count.

Legislative proposals drafted by the Government of Panama would restrict all import business to licensed local dealers, according to a summary of a bill prepared for presentation to the Panama National Assembly by the Department of Commerce.

Restriction of patented devices and its effect on the national economy will be the first order of business of the Congressional-Executive Monopoly Investigating Committee, Senator O'Mahoney, its chairman, said after a conference with President Roosevelt today.
The Beethoven Association opened its twentieth anniversary season last night in Town Hall with performances by Harold Bauer, president of the association;

The fireboat Firefighter will be placed in service at the Battery at 9 A. M. Nov. 16 and will be known as Engine Co. 57. The following changes of location and company numbers of fireboats will thereupon become effective:

Assurance that the government would come to no decision on the question of giving colonies back to Germany without full discussion and presumably a vote by Parliament was given to the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.

Mrs. Edna P. Cowgill, national known social worker and superintendent of the Florence Crittenton Home in Charlotte, N. C., died in a hospital here today. She was stricken ill here a week ago while visiting a sister.

Three students, each 20 years old, were killed instantly at 1 A. M. today when their automobile left Bedford Road near here, plowed 300 feet through underbrush, rolled over and crashed against a tree.
Members of the Southern Medical Association today approved the general principles of the national health program to be presented at the next session of Congress.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Cohen of Cedarhurst, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hinda Leah Cohen, to Dr. Maurice F. Neufeld, son of Mrs. Rose Neufeld of Washington, D. C.

Time schedules for year-end partnership changes have been sent all member firms of the New York Stock Exchange to avoid the usual congestion in the holiday season. Present rules require that proposed new partnerships and names of new partners be posted for fourteen days before final action by the committee on admissions.

Progress in enrolling members of various Exchanges in the financial district in the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, was reported yesterday by Mrs. Francis Warren Pershing, Exchanges division chairman of the $325,000 Red Cross Roll-Call.

After five years in operation the French national lottery has been ordered suppressed by Premier Edouard Daladier and Finance Minister Paul Reynaud, who give their reasons in a letter to President Albert Lebrun, published in the official journal today.
Mass meetings, boycott drives and other activities to protest the persecution of religious and racial minorities in Germany were announced yesterday by several organizations.
Pennsylvania's 1989 football schedule was completed today by the announcement that Lafayette would be the opening attraction on Franklin Field Oct. 7.

The Federal Government was accused before Supreme Court today of attempting unconstitutionally to set up a government power monopoly in the Tennessee River Valley, and thereby to drive privately owned electric utilities completely from that vast region.
Dr. Howard Anderson McCordock, Professor of Pathology at the Washington University School of Medicine, this city, died of heart disease last night in a hospital at the age of 43.

Several Brooklyn properties were reported yesterday as having been sold or leased through John F. James Sons, Inc., broker. Among the properties was the two-family house at 129 Bay Fortieth Street, which was sold by the Corning Bank and Trust Company to a client of the broker.
Continuing the anti-Jewish drive, the German authorities announced today further decrees and orders designed to eliminate Jews from all phases of German life.

Bert Acosta, transatlantic flier, was remanded to the Nassau County jail today in default of $500 bail fixed by Acting County Judge Bertram Newman on a charge of non-support of Acosta's two sons, Bertram Jr., 15 years old, andc Allan, 13.

Mischa Elman, concert violinist, expressed his gratitude to Mount Sinai Hospital last night for the return to good health of his father, Saul, who is 74 years old, by playing a full concert program, lasting more than two hours, for the doctors, nurses, student nurses and internes of the hospital staff.

Four persons, three of them Americans, were injured when their automobile plunged over an embankment when agrarians fired upon them near the town of Tlalhualilpa, in the State of Hidalgo, yesterday evening.

No one is wise enough to know as yet whether this business recovery will prove to be of relatively long duration and vigorous development, or instead comparatively brief and restricted, remarks L. P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, in his latest statement to the press.

H-106-Federal Export Corporation. Petition dismissed; judgment in favor of the U. S.; opinion by Judge Green. H-155--Chippewa Indians of Minnesota. Petition dismissed; opinion by Chief Justice Booth. 42,382-The Farmers Union Cooperative Supply Co. of Stanton, Neb. Plaintiff's motion for new trial overruled; opinion by Judge Green.

To show that the principle of light-weight construction in use for railway passenger equipment may be extended to freight cars, the American Car and Foundry Company will put on exhibition today and tomorrow in the Pennsylvania Railroad's yards at West Thirtyseventh Street a box car and refrigerator car of advanced design.
Fordham Pharmacy School seniors were grateful for the strong northwest wind that blew through the dispensing laboratory yesterday and swept away the last fumes of a disastrous bet.
Spyros Becatoros, retired violinist and music teacher, died on Sunday at his home, 82 Wadsworth Avenue, after a long illness.

The suggestion that banks be required to maintain 100 per cent reserves against interbank deposits was denounced here today by both national and State bankers in the opening meetings of the sixtyfourth annual convention of the American Bankers Association.

Midtown locations predominated in the lists of commercial rentals announced yesterday by brokers. Mark Cross Company, manufacturers and retailers of leather goods and novelties, leased an entire floor consisting of about 15,000 square feet in the building at 136-46 West Fifty-second Street, for manufacturing purposes.

The National Bank of Newport, N. Y., and the Hewlett-Woodmere National Bank of Woodmere, L. I., were on a list of banks whose receiverships were terminated in October and made public today by the Controller of the Currency.

A dummy scrimmage against Fordham formations yesterday marked the opening of the New York University football squad's two-week period of preparation for the twentieth annual meeting with the Ram on Saturday, Nov. 26, at the Yankee Stadium. Coach Mal Stevens sent the N. Y. U. players through a three-hour workout at Ohio Field and devoted a good deal of attention to polishing key plays that have been used during the past six weeks.
A large attendance is promised for the card party to be given in conjunction with a bazaar on Thursday afternoon at the Plaza in aid of the Silver Cross Day Nursery.

The smashed windows of the palace of Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich, have attracted thousands of Munich residents in the last three days. The looks of revulsion and the bitter, though whispered, comments are a symptom of the widespread indignation aroused in Catholic circles by this attack.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler has awarded the German Red Cross honor medal, first class, to the French physicians, Dr. Awedee Baumgartner and Dr. Charles C. Paul for trying to save the life of Ernst vom Rath, secretary in Germany's Paris Embassy, who was assassinated by a Polish Jew.

Charles Ogilby, retired New York banker, died here this afternoon at the age of 79 after a heart attack. While on a visit to his native Carlisle in August, 1937, he was stricken ill and he had remained here ever since.

A court circular announces the engagement of Princess Maria, youngest child of the Italian sovereigns, to Prince Louis of Bourbon-Parma. She will be 24 years old next month and is the youngest of five children.

Many tables have been reserved for the Thanksgiving tea dance and fashion show to be given under the auspices of the Humane Society of New York on Friday at Sherry's to assist the society's free clinic for animals.

Paul Keres of Parnau, Estonia, the youngest competitor in the A. V. R. O. international chess masters' tournament, today accomplished the defeat of Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, in the sixth round.

The Osservatore Romano, Vatican City newspaper, in an article protesting against the recent Italian laws forbidding marriage between Italian "Aryans" and "non-Aryans," revealed today that Pope Pius had addressed personal letters to King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Benito Mussolini begging them not to permit such a violation of the concordat between the Vatican and Italy.

Steel operations are scheduled at 62.6 per cent of capacity this week, a gain of 1.6 points, or 2.6 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. The rate is the highest since the week of Oct. 11, 1937, when it was 63.6 per cent. One month ago the rate was 49.4 per cent.

Some 350 leaders in the world of business yesterday heard Charles F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors in charge of research, declare that never before had there been so rich an opportunity for young men and women in the industrial world;

The British Board of Trade's figures for October show total imports at [pound]79,030,000; exports of British products, [pound]42,550,000; re-exports, [pound]5,440,000; total exports, [pound]47,990,000, and excess of imports, [pound]31,040,000.

Committees representing the Camp Fire Girls met yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Lorillard Spencer, 1,020 Fifth Avenue, to make plans for the benefit premiere performance of the Mexican musical film, "Rancho Grande" on Dec. 1 at the World Theatre.

Crime book technique was used by three loft squad detectives yesterday to frustrate an alleged holdup plot in the Hotel Holland at 351 West Forty-second Street. The prisoners were booked on charges of violation of the Sullivan law and conspiracy to commit robbery.

A Cabinet crisis precipitated by Parliament's rejection of a government bill was settled today by the resignation of Premier George Kiosseivanoff, whom King Boris forthwith entrusted with the formation of a new government.

The stock market here was dull today and sporadic selling brought about losses in all sections. The giltedge list finished lower. Foreign bonds were unsettled, German loans declining, while French issues advanced.

Former Judge Stephen Stone, one of the leading members of the Allegheny County bar, died this morning at his home here at the age of 65. Judge Stone was' the son of the late William A. Stone, onetime Governor of Pennsylvania.
Miss Marie Cummings Jermain, Albany philanthropist, died at her home in Menands last night at the age of 90.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday announced that full share stock certificates when issued on Dec. 15 in payment of the stock dividend will not be exchangeable into scrip certificates.

The health of the nation, judged on the basis of mortality rate, was better this year than at any time in the past decade except 1933, when a record was established, according to a United States Public Health Service report today.
Mayor La Guardia left his office at City Hall yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock suffering a cold. He said he was going home to bed and would not be at his desk today unless his condition is improved.

With warm weather causing a leg in retail trade last month, newspaper linage in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records, proved disappointing after the good September showing. Total linage loss was 15.9 per cent, as against a drop of only 11 per cent in September.
Another rise in prices on the Cotton Exchange established yesterday a new high record for the season on December contracts and the list ended unchanged to 6 points higher.
W. A. Alexander, Georgia Tech head football coach, withdrew today his charge that Alabama gained a 14-14 tie with his team last Saturday through an illegal pass play.

Elsa Baklor, Baltimore soprano, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, relied on a program that was something of a catch-all. She ranged over widely diverse schools, epochs and styles and managed to bring twenty different composers into her scope, not counting the unknown creators of a group of Hungarian folksongs. Mozart was the only repeater on the program;
The engagement of Captain Michael Edward Adeane, assistant private secretary to the King since last year, and Miss Helen Chetwynd-Stapylton of Great Berkhamstead was announced today.

George W. Percy of Westhampton Beach was elected president of the Suffolk County Bar Association at its annual meeting here today. He succeeds Isaac R. Swezey of Huntington, who was elected a justice of the Supreme Court.

The Lafayette junior varsity defeated the Rutgers Jayvees today, 13-7, Farrell scoring both touchdowns for the Maroon in the second period on line plunges after aerials had placed the ball in scoring position. Rutgers tallied in the third period when Foster passed to Omley, who ran 57 yards for a touchdown.
Ely Jacques Kahn, architect, of 2 Park Avenue, New York City, has been appointed a special consultant of the United States Housing Authority.

Mrs. Charles P. Luckey was elected president of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association to succeed Mrs. Burchard Dutcher at the annual meeting of the organization at the New York Junior League Club yesterday.
Ward M. Canaday, chairman of the board of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., said yesterday that "there are sound reasons to feel confident" concerning automotive and general business prospects for 1939.
Germany's, best-known folk song, "Lorelei," has been banned by the Nazi Educational Department because the words were written by a Jew, Heinrich Heine.
With the exception of Pete Holovak, the swift right halfback, all the Fordham injured will be ready Saturday when the Rams face the University of South Carolina at the Polo Grounds.

A group of economists and financial experts conferred today with officials of the Treasury and the Budget Bureau to assist in estimating the Federal Government's income expectancy for the next fiscal year.

John A. Buckley, general chairman of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks for the Lehigh Valley Railroad, tonight declared a request for permission to call a strike vote on the Lehigh was "not in order" until every effort had been made to settle grievances under the National Railway Labor Act.

Edward J. Harding of Washington, managing director of the Associated General Contractors of America, forecast today a 50 per cent increase next year over 1938 in the building program for private industry.

The government's fiscal policies are forcing the country with ever-increasing speed toward some form of national socialism or fascism, it was declared here today by Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association, speaking at the opening general session of the association's sixty-fourth annual convention here.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation called today for bids on thirtynine issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts in twenty States. The bids are to be opened at noon on Dec. 1 at the corporation's offices here.

Miss Janet E. Bardusch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Bardusch of Maplewood, will be married on Dec. 10 to George H. Badenoch, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Badenoch. The Rev. Dr. Melford Brown, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Mount Vernon, N. Y., will perform the ceremony at the home of the bride-elect's parents.
Official figures gathered by the Department of Commerce indicate that German investors possibly have a larger stake in the United States than Americans in Germany.

A committee of five prominent men and women was named yesterday as judges in the $250,000 Movie Quiz Contest launched by the film industry last August in connection with the Motion Pictures' Greatest Year Campaign.

October shoe production was estimated in trade sources yesterday at 34,500,000 pairs, which would be an increase of 18.6 per cent over a year ago, compared with 37,862,000 pairs in September, an increase of 11.1 per cent over 1937.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain had before him tonight concrete proposals for the large-scale emigration and resettlement of German Jews under the auspices of Britain, the United States and possibly other interested nations.

Barring any unforeseen epidemic in the next six weeks, new low death rates probably will be set for 1938, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records.

The Lea act, passed by Congress in June to regulate the transportation and sale of natural gas in interstate commerce, represents an honest attempt of Congress to fill a gap in the regulation of this commodity, Claude L. Draper, a member of the Federal Power Commission, said today in an address before the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners, in convention here.

A unique copy of Voltaire's "La Pucelle d'Orleans" brought $6,100 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the final session of the auction of part three of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

Mrs. Daniel G. MacMillan of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mildred E. MacMillan, to George F. H. Nelson, son of Mrs. George Nelson of New York. The wedding will take place on Dec. 10.
The Penrose Medal, awarded by the Geological Society of America "in recognition of eminent research in pure geology," will be presented this year to Dr. Andrew Cowper Lawson.

A shouting parade of pickets, estimated at from 4,500 to 5,000 persons, gave a noisy send-off to the North German Lloyd liner Bremen at Pier 86 last night with denunciations of persecutions in Germany.

Queena Mario, soprano, yesterday announced her resignation from the Metropolitan Opera Association, to take effect at the close of the coming season, which begins Monday evening. She will devote her time to teaching.

Miss Suzanne Hough Arguimbeau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Charles Arguimbeau of Glenbrook, will be married to William Norris Hubbard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hubbard of 515 Park Avenue, New York, on the afternoon of Dec. 2, in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham, will perform the ceremony, which will be be followed by a reception at the Stamford Yacht Club.

Judge Donnellan in General Sessions sentenced yesterday Francis F. Greeley, alias Greulich, 35 years old, and his wife, Anna, 27, to indeterminate terms in the penitentiary after they had pleaded guilty to the theft of large quantities of rare stamps from their former employer.
Reports were circulated today that the reciprocal trade agreements of the United States with Canada and the United Kingdom would be signed on Thursday.

New contracts for the Fred Apostoli-Young Corbett 3d middleweight bout, scheduled for Friday night over the fifteen-round route in Madison Square Garden, were signed yesterday at the State Athletic Commission marking the first step in the board's plan to establish an undisputed holder of the 160pound crown.
Premier Bela Imredy tendered the Cabinet's resignation to Regent Nicholas Horthy today and immediately received authority to form a new government.

A novel method of expressing tribute to a guest of honor resulted, last night, in the raising of $12,000 for the relief of distressed persons in Europe. The occasion was a dinner in the Metropolis Club, 105 West Fifty-seventh Street, to Elihu W. Kleinbaum, partner in the brokerage firm of Albert Fried. Co., 120 Broadway, who had served two terms as president of the club.

Moving the business of selecting officers a day ahead of the original schedule, the Professional Golfers Association today re-elected George Jacobus of Ridgewood, N. J., president for a seventh consecutive term.
The small boy was telling his younger sister the story of how the animals in the Garden of Eden got their names. The very little girl wondered why Adam called the elephant an elephant.

The series of "natural science evenings" being conducted at the American Museum of Natural History in the interests of that institution's ten-year development program was continued last night with a dinner and entertainment at which Mr. and Mrs. Harold Benjamin Clark were hosts.

To the homeless and harried men and women who seek refuge from tyranny in Europe there will come fresh hope in the news that Prime Minister Chamberlain is considering a. direct approach to President Roosevelt in the matter of meeting a situation which grows more critical with every day that passes. As the President said yesterday,
The Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, meeting until early yesterday morning in the Capitol Hotel, ratified by the necessary two-thirds majority the new constitution for the union.

Sixteen seniors were elected today to the Harvard College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. At the same time James M. Tobin of Champlain, Ill., one of the junior eight elected a year ago, was selected as first marshal of the honorary scholastic society.
Stocks improved and closed steadier but at irregularly lower levels; turnover, 1,465,980 shares. Traction bonds strong, United States Government and other issues lower; transactions, $7,276,000.

Department store and resident buying executives will seek clarification of some of the proposed regulations of the Department of Agriculture under the new Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act at the hearing to be held in Washington tomorrow, it was indicated at a conference held here yesterday in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

As part of a plan for the retirement on Jan. 1, 1939, of its ten-year 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation purchased $1,703,700 of these obligations in the open market during October, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
" Lorelei," the Jacques Deval play which first planned to open last Monday and then shifted to Thursday, has taken a bigger jump for its next postponement-from tomorrow until Nov. 29.

More than 2,000 students and members of the faculty and staff of Hunter College gathered at meeting yesterday in response to a college-wide call to reassert the American traditions of liberty and humanitarianism in protest against the persecution of minority groups in Germany.

Japanese forces are within sixty miles of Changsha, the Hunan Province capital, and are continuing their steady advance in the face of only occasional resistance, according to a Japanese Army spokesman in Hankow.
AMERICAN PROBLEMS OF TODAY, by Louis M. Hacker. (Crofts, $3.) A history of the United States since the end of the World War. DEATH IN A WHITE TIE, by Ngaio Marsh. (Lee Furman, $2.) A mystery novel.

Evidence that the president of the Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation had been in the pay of Hiltz Co., Inc., the concern's underwriters for a 244,863-share stock issue, was placed on the record yesterday in the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop-order proceeding against the oil company.
Joey Fontana, 131, Bensonhurst, outpointed Vince Dell'Orto, 127 1/4, Italy, in the eight-round feature bout before 4,300 fans at the Broadway Arena last night.

Local traction issues stood out as conspicuous exceptions in a declining bond market yesterday. Re- ist spending briskly to a statement by Controller McGoldrick that unification of New York City's transit facilities appears nearer now than ever before, the traction bonds jumped 1 to 4 points to new high levels for the year.

Despite important Republican gains in last week's election, President Roosevelt is approved by a majority of voters throughout the nation and continues to be more popular than the Democratic party itself, Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, declared yesterday.

Charles F. Kettering, vice president of the General Motors Corporation in charge of research, told members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon held yesterday at the Bankers Club that the United States had a surplus of money, materials and men, which consequently means, in his opinion, only that the country is lacking projects.

The Chesapeake Corporation, a holding company intermediary between the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $571,706, against $1,875,054 earned in the same period last year.
Scenes of a fire on Wards Island yesterday were transmitted by the mobile television unit of the National Broadcasting Company to Radio City where observers pronounced them "amazingly clear."

A detailed defense of British decisions in the recent European crisis prefaced yesterday a request by Godfrey D. N. Haggard, new British Consul General, to Britons here to support Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in his domestic and foreign policies.

Henry Young Jr., Newark attorney, was sworn in today as Sheriff of Essex County by Common Pleas Judge Walter D. Van Riper. Mr. Young, a Republican, was elected last Tuesday. His term, starting at midnight tonight, is for three years.

The American Republics liner Brazil, the first vessel of the government's new "Good Neighbor Fleet" to complete the round-trip voyage to Buenos Aires, returned last night with 141 passengers, including the good-will mission that carried President Roosevelt's personal greetings to South Americans.

Elevation of Henry S. Sturgis of the Rockaway Hunting Club to the presidency is the main change that will be made- among officials who will guide the destinies of the Metropolitan. Golf Association in the coming season.

Hamilton Ter, 52, 18x100; Kath Prach to Rexhold Realty Corp, 45 Nassau St; mtg, $14.450 ($8.50). Houston St, 287 E, 25x100; Wm. B. Sandler, referee, to Metropolitan Savings Bank; foreclosure ($2). 116th St, 364 W, 25x100.11; Walter M. Langsdorf. individual and trustee Helen R. Langsdorf, to Gedar Realty Corp, 17 E 48th St: ($12).

The idea of killing two birds with one stone is always a tempting one, and the conference called by the President on Monday to consider whether WPA workers could not be transferred from the projects on which they are now working to job-producing projects under a national defense program is understandable on that basis.

The marriage of Miss Lois Mooney Hand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wallace Hand of this city, to Franklin Alexander McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. McCarthy, also of Elizabeth, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
The Hershey Cubs defeated the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 4 to 2, and moved into a first-place tie with the New York Rovers in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.

A onetime cup winner, lately fallen on bad times, turned back ranking favorites in the twenty-sixth running of the $12,400 Bowie Handicap before 12,000 spectators today when Mrs. John D. Hertz's Count Arthur scored by a neck and left the favored Esposa and Aneroid out in the cold on the closing day at Pimlico.

Warren Kelly, in 141 E 88th St; Dr. Hilton H. Stothers, Robert H. Brown, Bernard Fields, Mrs. Edgar A. Ward, in 245 E 72d St; Clara Schork, Mrs. Isabel Willard, Emllio Levy, in 140 E 81st St: Mrs. Ruth Rozaffy, in 24 W 59th St; Arthur E. Wilson, A. R. Montgomery, James Driscoll, in 60 Gramercy Park N; Douglas Gibbons Co. Inc, broker.
Having once served as "hasher" in a college fraternity house, William Bowers has turned his memorybook into a comedy, "Where Do We Go From Here?" which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening.

Attendance at the largest show of commercial vehicles ever held anywhere, the National Motor Truck Show in Commerce Hall, Port of New York Authority Building, increased yesterday to the best point since the exhibition opened last Friday.

Transfer of title to the five-story house at 29 West Fifty-fourth Street, a few doors from the Rockefeller Apartments, from John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the 25 West Fiftyfourth Street Corporation, whose address is 22 West Forty-eighth Street, was recorded yesterday.

An audience of about 20,000 is expected to attend the performance tonight of the "Night of Stars," a procession of artists of the radio, stage and screen, at Madison Square Garden in behalf of the United Palestine Appeal.

Stressing pass offense, Lehigh went through a long scrimmage today for the closing game against Lafayette at Easton on Saturday. This method of attack was weak against Muhlenberg and interceptions aided the Mules in scoring their three touchdowns.

The first real signs of the approach of Winter, which shuts down over this home of the student officers toward the end of every football season, were in evidence today at the United States Military Academy.

In memory of Clarence Mackay, chairman of the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, who died Saturday night, the Philharmonic-Symphony has added the "Liebestod" from "Tristan and Isolde" to its program tonight at Carnegie Hall.

Manufacturing operations in plastics for use on automobiles have been increased sharply by ThermoPlastics, Inc., a subsidiary of the Standard Products Company, following announcement of two awards for its development of such use, the company announced yesterday.

Thirty-four indictments returned last December by an Essex County grand jury against Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark, two members of the City Commission, two former members and numerous other individuals, charging conspiracy to make corrupt and unlawful payment of public funds in land deals, were upheld by the Supreme Court today.

The Pennsylvania Athletic Commission today revoked the license of Harry Thomas, Eagle Bend, Minn., heavyweight, for what it said in a statement was Thomas's "unsatisfactory performance" in a fight against Tony Galento.

According to information from German aviation and American diplomatic quarters, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is contemplating transferring his residence from his French island-Illiec, off the coast of Brittany--to Germany and Mrs. Lindbergh is now looking for a furnished apartment in Berlin.

The Alumnae Association of St. Luke's Hospital Training School for Nurses will give its annual Autumn dance and entertainment on Friday night at Sherry's. Arrangements for the event, the proceeds of which will be used to further the organization's various philanthropic enterprises, are under the direction of the Misses Helen Wysong and Vivian Ahl.

On the eve of a well-earned two weeks' vacation Governor Lehman announces that he wants his inauguration on Jan. 1 to be "just a simple ceremony" and expresses the opinion that he will be able to cooperate with the Republican majorities in both houses of the Legislature.

CALDER, EDWARD VICTOR (Oct. 28). Estate, less than $1,000. To Michael Fruhling, executor, 958 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, residue. HAYS, JEROME (Oct. 26). Estate, less than $500. To Frances Gallagher Hays, widow. executrix, 10 Monroe St.

The Savings Bank Women of the Metropolitan Area will hold their monthly meeting and dinner tonight in the Colonnades of the Essex House. Paul R. Taylor, Deputy Superintendent of Insurance in charge of Savings Bank Life Insurance, will address the gathering on that subject.
Herbert Howard Rice, 68, former Detroit automobile executive, who came here to hunt deer, was found dead today of an apparent heart attack on a roadside in the woods country.

Problems faced by the Jews of the world as a result of Adolf Hitler's new anti-Semitic measures were discussed yesterday by the first Women's Conference on Jewish Affairs at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

Although no hope is held for the continuance of New College, 6year-old educational experiment of Columbia University's Teachers College, beyond next June, an attempt will be made to carry its essential features into the program of its mother institution, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College declared yesterday.
Confined to her home because of a severe cold, Kirsten Flagstad, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was obliged to cancel her recital appearance scheduled last night at Carnegie Hall.

The eight local unions and 6,000 members comprising the Providence and Woonasquatucket Woolen and Worsted District Council today severed their disputed membership in the C. I. O. and were formally received into the American Federation of Labor, Joseph Sylvia, business manager, announced.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,243,250 barrels, compared with 3,628,550 in the preceding week, a fall of 385,300, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

" Concentration Camp," announced by Warners last July but shelved because of political complications, was revived today by the studio and is scheduled to go before the cameras within six weeks. It will treat with European conditions.

Leaders in business and finance, in society and in music were among the thousands who attended funeral services for Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The 50 per cent decline in automobile sales for the 1938 season will be considerably reduced by the end of the year, Leroy Kurtz, sales promotion manager of General Motors export division, said yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A goal by Max Goodman in the second of two five-minute overtime periods broke a deadlock to give Thomas Jefferson High School's soccer team a 2-1 triumph over Manual Training on Commercial Field yesterday.

The only real way to advance toward prosperity is to increase production and adjust prices so that consumers can absorb the full output, George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, told a dinner meeting of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Sculpture of India," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; Medieval Collection (general tour), 2 P. M.; "French and English Cabinetmakers: The Jacobean Period," Ethelwyn Bradish, 4 P. M.
Clarke Hinkle, Green Bay Packers star fullback, has gained the scoring lead in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday.

Projecting an innovation into the field of security underwriting-particularly as applied to utility financing-the United- Corporation revealed yesterday that, although it will continue to operate as an investment company, it has decided, as opportunity permits, to diversify its portfolio and participate in the financing and underwriting of new capital issues in the public utility and other fields.
Rembrandt's "Portrait of Maarten Looten" was sold for 102,000 guilders [about $55,000 at the current rate of exchange] at an Amsterdam auction today to an unidentified American collector.

The Spanish Insurgent command at Irun announced tonight that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops had driven government forces back across the Ebro River in Northeastern Spain with the capture of the important towns of Asco and Flix and domination of the Ribarroja Heights to the west.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Povla Frijsh, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Benjamin Grobany, baritone, Town Hall, 3:30; Joseph Franco, violinist, Labor Temple, Fourteenth Street and Second Avenue,

House committee Investigating unAmerican activities took under consideration today a proposal supported by two members to determine if "well-known Communists" were instrumental in bringing about the investigation by the Senate Civil Liberties Committee.

France prepared today to arrange a bargain with Chancellor Hitler that would, in effect, give Germany a free hand in Eastern Europe. In return France would demand a Nazi guarantee of her Rhineland frontier.
Following are the thirty-four corporations and sixty-three individuals named in indictments charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in milk and ice cream industries:
Seymour Van Santvoord, a former Public Service Commission chairman, dean of the Rensselaer County Bar Association, a banker and an author, died here early today. He was 80 years old.

The old Horsemen of Notre Dame are riding strongly fourteen years after they galloped into national fame. Elmer Layden, Harry Stuhldreher and Jimmy Crowley had a lot of clippings to show back in 1924, and the public prints have been giving a big play to their teams during the campaign now drawing to a close.

The Brazilian press condemns the German attacks on Jews and their property. The Correlo da Manha, which is most bitter, characterizes the German "brutality" as a retrogression to conditions of 500 years ago. It deplores the inhuman treatment of a national minority.
Martin Andrus, for the past eight years with Armishaw's, Ltd., Portland, Ore., has been appointed sales manager of Babers, Ltd., distributor of Church and Alan McAfee British shoes.

The body of Ernst vom Rath, slain attache of the German Embassy here, accompanied by Baron Ernst von Weiszacker of the Berlin Foreign Office, left by special train for Duesseldorf, Germany, at midnight.
The trial began at Salzburg yesterday of three high officers of the former Austrian army for attempted murder and incitement to murder.
James A. Roe of Flushing was named chairman of the Queens County Democratic Executive Committee at a meeting last night in Democratic headquarters, Woodside.
Eight railroads were called upon by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to pay to the State of New Jersey $50,000,000 of disputed taxes on their properties.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 14: MAJOR GENERAL Ashburn, T. Q., Chairman Advisory Board, Inland Waterways Corporation, to retirement; previous orders revoked.

The Pittsburgh Stock Exchange at public hearing today pressed the Securities and Exchange Commission to grant it unlisted trading privileges in thirty-three stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, several of them securities in which there usually is considerable trading in active markets.

George Colyer, retired postal clerk, who in 1927 discovered the murdered body of Albert Snyder, died in his home, 222-06 Ninetythird Road, Queens Village, yesterday morning after an illness of one week. He was 79 years old.

The story of the Child Study Association of America in preserving the family as the basic unit of society, in binding together Catholics, Jews and Protestants and thus strengthening democracy against "new isms from abroad" was broadcast last night from the association's fiftieth anniversary dinner, at which a drive was started for $200,000 to operat the organization for three years.

Automobile owners who still have no anti-freeze solution in the radiators of their cars and pedestrians who have not yet got out their overcoats are directed to the forecast of the Weather Bureau, which warns that temperatures will probably be down to freezing tonight.

American farmers must plant no more than 275,000,000 of their 365,000,000 cultivated acres to cotton, corn, wheat, tobacco, rice and other soildepleting crops next year if they are to obtain $712,000,000 in subsidy payments authorized by Congress.

President Ismet Inonu's desire to reassure Great Britain that Turkey under his leadership will maintain the cordial relations existing under the Ite Kemal Ataturk's rule is believed to be behind the sudden return to London of Fethi Okyar, Ambassador there.

An aerial attack occupied the New York University football players' attention in a three-hour workout yesterday at Ohio Field. The first two hours were spent in drilling outdoors, while the session ended in the gymnasium because of the wind and cold.

The United States training ship Illinois, which is moored in the Hudson above 125th Street, will receive $64,000 worth of repairs in the next few weeks as part of a continuing program for the overhaul of Naval Reserve armories and training ships.

With two major games remaining on the schedule, the none-too-optimistic maestro of Columbia football, Lou Little, thinks "it's about time" for the Lions "to click" on Saturday when they meet Syracuse.

Civilization, some people are beginning to believe, is not all it is cracked up to be, or perhaps it is more accurate to say that it is cracking up into everything it was supposed not to be. This may account for an increasing tendency among so many to get away from the center of things.

After a day of intensive analysis of the competitive position of the lumber industry, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association was urged today at its annual meeting to underwrite a $2,500,000 annual promotion campaign for the industry. The proposal was broached by James G. McNary, president, at the president's dinner.

President Roosevelt announced today that his son James had presented an informal resignation as a mem ber of the White House secretariat but expected to return in the Spring if strong enough to resume work.

The United States Military Attache, Lieut. Col. William Freehoff, called at the War Department today to request the arrest and punishment of about twenty armed Agrarians who late Sunday fired upon an automobile containing three Americans and one Mexican, forcing it off the road near Tlalhualilpa in the State of Hidalgo.

The body of Lieutenant Lansing C. Holden, who was killed on Sunday at Sparta, Tenn., in an aircraft accident, arrived in New York yesterday. He will have a military funeral in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street, at 2 P. M. today.
Charles K. Heebner, a construction engineer, died in Germantown Hospital yesterday in his fifty-fifth year. He was construction manager of United Engineers and Constructors, Inc.

Miss Emma Josephine Twitchell, daughter of the late portrait painter, Asa Weston Twitchell, died yesterday after a long illness. She was 82 years old and had lived at a convalescent home since moving from the farmhouse near Albany where her father had his studio.
A large one-man show of paintings by the distinguished American artist, Guy Pene duBois, opened yesterday at the Kraushaar Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue, to remain current until Dec. 10.
In an effort to combat opposition to resale price maintenance laws, The American Fair Trade Congress, new name of the American Fair Trade League, will issue today a magazine, Fair Trade Review.
Repulicans in the Western New York district today advanced Representative James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo as the next minority whip in Congress.

The idea of an "annual wage" for workers now subject to irregular employment has received a great deal of attention in the last few years, but the problem of working this out on a practical basis is not an easy one.

With thirty-nine players listed in the draw the annual Fall invitation squash tennis tournament opened on- the Princeton Club courts last night. Six first round matches were run off, in which two of the eight seeded players, Frank R. Hanson, Columbia, No. 2, and Willard K. Rice, :Harvard, No. 5, emerged the winners.

Opening of a Broadway display and salesroom for Graham cars at 1,709 Broadway, at the corner of Fifty-fourth Street, was announced yesterday by Walter F. Wright, vice president in charge of sales of Graham-Paige Motors Corporation.

Mrs. Elsie Maud Haviland Gaskell, active in the Westchester Country Club here, died of pneumonia today at her home on the club grounds. She was 59 years old, the wife of Frederic P. Gaskell, president of the firm of shipping agents of that name at 1 Broadway, New York.
Manchukuo desires a treaty of commerce and friendship with El Salvador. the only American country recognizing that government. The proposal was made through Leon Siguenza, Consul in Tokyo.

President Roosevelt voiced the condemnation of the American people and their government of Germany's attacks on the Jews today in one of the most vigorous statements that it was possible to make in protest of the events of the past few days.

Despite the fact that this is the height of the hunting season, there are angling matters that are just as important, for they will have a great significance when the time comes to again take up the rod and reel.

This country will provide two camps for Jewish refugees from Germany, according to a statement made by Premier Hendryk Colijn in the lower house today. Describing recent events in Germany as "the most distressing tragedy in our times," the Premier said that from the first moment of acute danger for German Jews the government had been actively seeking means of giving aid.

The deliberate action of Secretary Hull, after full consultation with the President, in giving public notice of the summons home to Ambassador Wilson in Berlin was a diplomatic method of expressing our high displeasure with what is going on in Germany.
Small dwelling properties, among which was one held in one family for about fifty years, comprised the bulk of the properties in Manhattan changing hands in deals announced yesterday.
President Hoberto M. Ortiz by decree today pegged the price of gentine wheat at 7 pesos a hundred kilos, the equivalent of 21 cents a bushel.

A review of recent campaigns against unsightly billboards along American highways and discussion of proposed roadside control legislation to be introduced in various State Legislatures next year got under way yesterday at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twentysecond Street, with the opening of the annual two-day joint conference on roadside improvement.

Miss Lydia Mortimer Forest, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Story Forest of Minneapolis, was married to Louis Clark Grinnell, son of Mrs. Maurice W. Grinnell of New York and the late Mr. Grinnell, here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

The wheat market is in a rut and prices on the Board of Trade here held within narrow limits again today. They managed, however, to hold slightly above yesterday's close due largely to sympathy with Winnipeg.

The $10,000,000 estate which John E. Andrus of Yonkers, manufaoturer and financier, bequeathed to friends and relatives by his will may be entirely wiped away by inheritance taxes, attorneys told Surrogate Charles D. Millard today.

President Roosevelt, conceding frankly the possibility of attempts at foreign aggression in the Western Hemisphere, proclaimed the continental solidarity of all the Americas today and this nation's determination to expand its defenses to the extent required to repel any threat of invasion from any country beyond the seas.

By unanimous vote delegates to the convention of the Committee for Industrial Organization accepted today "the goal of unity in the labor movement" as their objective but insisted that peace must be attained without compromising the principle of forming powerful industrial unions and protecting their members against dismemberment by craft unions.

Montclair, first municipality in New Jersey to apply for Federal funds under the United States Housing Authority program, will abandon its project for a $1,000,000 low-cost housing project, it was announced here today by Mayor William E. Speers.

The National Association of Sales Finance Companies at the concluding session of its convention here today approved standard automobile sales terms for the territory east of the Rocky Mountains calling for a minimum down payment of 331-3 per cent on all classes of new and used cars and a maximum of eighteen monthly installments on new models and used cars not older than models of two years previous.
Coach Ossie Solem sent the Syracuse football team through a heavy practice in a snowstorm today emphasizing pass defense.

Four young musicians were chosen as winners of the seventh annual Young Artists Contest, sponsored by the MacDowell Club of this city. They are Evelyn Gray and Sidney Foster, pianists, of New York; Mara Sebriansky, violinist, of Brooklyn, and Martha Lipton, contralto, of New York.

Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, has endorsed the campaign of the Noble Dog Foundation, 11 West Forty-second Street, to acquaint motorists with the law penalizing the driver who runs down a dog and fails to stop and report the accident to the owner or to police authorities in the vicinity.

Joseph H. Appel, formerly executive head of John Wanamaker, New York; Professor Arthur H. Cole, librarian of Baker Library, Harvard, and Assistant Professor Ralph M. Hower of the Department of Business History at Harvard, discussed the development of department stores in this country at the annual meeting of the Business Historical Society today in the Faculty Club of the Harvard Business School.

Lamb business was fairly active and prices were stronger in local markets yesterday. Demand for veal and calf was fair with calf higher and veal strong to higher. Trading in other classes was mostly fair. Fresh pork prices were uneven and other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated veal and calf to be steady, other classes stronger. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The condition of George McFarland Milligan of Pittsburgh, Princeton University's Triangle Club stage manager, who was injured when he fell through an open trapdoor, showed slight improvement today, but he was reported to be "not completely out of danger."

William Benson Mayo of Detroit, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, testified yesterday as a government witness in a Sherman anti-trust action against the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

Mrs. Lorenzo D. Armstrong gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Gloria Armstrong. Miss Armstrong, who is a provisional member of the Junior League, attended Miss Hewitt's Classes in this city and the Foxcroft School in Virginia.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 15, unless specified: Balch, at San Diego. Bridge, San Diego to San Pedro. Concord, at Navy Yard, New' York. Cormorant, at Lower Potomac River, Nov. 15. J. D. Ford, Hong Kong to Shanghai. Kewaydin, at Navy Yard, Norfolk,

Mrs. John T. Pratt and Governor Herbert H. Lehman were elected to the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society yesterday afternoon at the season's first meeting of the board, held at the offices of Marshall Field, president of the society, at 250 Park Avenue.

Sullivan St, 58-701; 24x10.8; for 1-story office and motor truck scale; Department of Public WorRs, City of N. Y., owner; R. H. Gould, engineer; cost, $20,000. Alterations 33d St, 343 E; to 4-story tenement; Sangro Corp, 12 E 41st St, owner; H. Z. Harrison, architect; cost, $5,000.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Murdock Ward and Miss Joyce Ward, a debutante of the season, will be at the Beekman for the Winter.

A German editorial, published here yesterday in the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold, formally abandons as "false" any hope it has held out to its German-language readers of "decency" from the leaders now in power in Germany.

Charging William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, with violation of several sections of the City Charter, Councilman Abner C. Surpless of Brooklyn said in yesterday's Council meeting that he would press for an official investigation of Mr. Carey's department.

A proposal that the Pan-American Congress of Municipalities, now meeting in Havana, recommend to American republics the indemnified expropriation of all public services, such as electric light and power, waterworks and telephones, was made today by Julian Devis Echandia, delegate from Bucaramanga, Colombia.

Mrs. Elizabeth A. Doyle, former president of the Catholic Big Sisters of Queens and former vice chairman of the Democratic County Committee, died yesterday morning in Brunswick Hospital, Amityville, L. I. She was 63 years old.

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The total for last week was 881 as against 827 in the previous week and 723 in the same period last year.

Turpentine firm, 22%c; sales, 72 barrels; receipts, 442 barrels; shipments, 15 barrels; stocks, 53,200 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 451; receipts, 2,121; shipments, 428; stock, 293,999. Quote: B, D, $4.05; E, $4.25; F, $4,90; G, H, I, K, M, $5.073; N, $5.50; WG, $6; ww, X, $6.65.

Canadian trade recovery during October, though still below expectations, was stimulated somewhat by the heavy wheat exports, according to a summary of radio and wire reports of the week's trade developments in various parts of the world, issued today by the Department of Commerce.

A rotund baldish Russian appeared in Federal court yesterday and in idiomatic testimony which brought smiles to the face of Judge John C. Knox and guffaws from the spectators, contradicted the denial of Leon G.
