Turrou, former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that he once was a patient in the psychopathic ward at Kings County Hospital.

Issuance of an executive order by President Roosevelt authorizing the committee of Congress that is investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority to inspect income and excess profits tax returns of utility executives and companies was revealed today as the utilities began the presentation of their case against the TVA yardstick rates at public hearings of the committee.

Three important posts in the Wages-andHours Division were filled today by Elmer F. Andrews, administrator. Ralph J. Watkins, director of the Bureau of Business Research at the University of Pittsburgh,

President Anastasio Somoza today named Dr. Vincente Vita, former manager of the Nicaraguan National Bank; Dr. Emilio Pereira, president of the Tribunal of Accounts, and Dr. Eulogio Cuadra, former Minister of Finance, as members of a commission to prepare new banking laws.

Dr. Alcinous Burton Jamison, a physician who specialized in proctology, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a seven-week illness. His home and office were at 175 West Eighty-eighth Street. His age was 87.

A Department of Agriculture committee reported today rayon was "very definitely" competitive with cotton. The committee, named by Secretary Wallace to study developments in synthetic fibers, said a considerable part of the expansion in rayon consumption had been at the expense of cotton.

Bayuk Cigars, Inc., has reported to the New York Stock Exchange that 4,000 shares of 7 per cent cumulative first preferred stock of record of Nov. 5 have been selected by lot for redemption on Jan. 15 at $110 a share, plus accrued dividends of $1.75 a share.

Leaders of Polish Jewry have sent an urgent appeal for refugee aid to Jewish welfare organizations in the United States, Argentina, South Africa, Great Britain and France and also to Malcolm MacDonald, the British Colonial Secretary, and George Lansbury, chairman of the recently formed Polish refugee fund in London.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the five-day week ended Nov. 10 declined in three out of five trade groups as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation issued by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Southern California's hopes of playing in the Rose Bowl soared today with the announcement that the Pacific Coast Conference would select its representative before the Trojan-Notre Dame football game Dec. 3.
Alfred G. Wathall, composer and arranger for radio station WGN, died last night of a heart attack in his home here, at the age of 58.

Sales reported by subsidiary store companies of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for thirteen weeks ended on Oct. 29, were $13,705,928 against $14,382,097, in corresponding weeks last year, a decrease of 4.7 per cent.

Thirty-four corporations, scattered from coast to coast, and sixty-three individuals, including business executives, labor leaders and important public officials, were named in two Federal indictments, made public today, on charges of violating the anti-trust laws in the milk and ice cream industries.

A friendly letter from King Victor Emmanuel of Italy to Pope Plus, assuring him that efforts would be made to meet the Vatican's objections to the new Italian marriage laws, was reported today by the Osservatore Romano.

The thousands of visitors at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace were. joined yesterday as they circulated among displays on three floors by several hundred automotive executives from abroad and representatives of American motor companies in foreign lands.

Washington Fayette Norton, one of the founders of the Babylon National Bank and Trust Company fortyfive years ago and for many years chairman of the board of directors, observed his ninety-fourth birthday at his home on Fire Island Avenue here today.

Premier Jan Syrovy today issued a summons in the name of the government to both houses of Parliament to meet Thursday. The summons followed the reaching of a partial settlement with the Slovak delegation, which has been negotiating here for the embodiment of the Slovak autonomist demands in the Constitution.

Colonel Richard V. Read, Great Britain's military attache to the United States, will visit the Sixteenth Infantry at Fort Jay and view the barracks and other installations on Governors Island at 9:30 A. M. today.
The large apartment and store building on an irregular plot 46 by 80 feet at 1,231 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Edbro Realty Company to a client of Jay A. Gilman, attorney.
Breaking a precedent of 317 years standing in this town, where the first Thanksgiving was held, a Jewish rabbi will preach the sermon in the Church of the Pilgrimage Thanksgivine morning.

Fire Department Deaths Announced Retired Lieutenant James P. Toher, formerly a member of Engine Co. 42, residing at 16 7th St., Providence, R. I., died Nov. 3. Retired Fireman William A. Teaz, formerly a member of Engine Co. 235, residing at 630 Hancock St., Brooklyn, died Nov. 5.

The city of Boston and the Boston Port Authority are ready to go to the Supreme Court of the United States with a major case involving controversies which Boston has with the Port of New York and the trunk-line railroads.

THE revolution ruins in Germany, Mr. Chamberlain prays, Stalin is ominously silent, Mussolini blusters,'France blesses the franc, Spain bleeds along the Ebro 'and China in Hunan. And all for what or why ? No three authorities agree, some saying one thing,some another, and all so sure of themselves that they cancel one another out. Read them and, as it may be,
A banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank won yesterday the award of $1,592,000 of school construction and improvement bonds of Nashville, Tenn., on a bid of 101.92 for 2 1/2s.
Flying Eagle, 3-year-old WalKer hound owned by J. R. Parker of New Albany, Miss., won the National Foxhunters Association championship last night by being judged the best hound in the bench show.

A brilliant round by the veteran Tommy Armour of Boca Raton Fla., whose individual 67 was so low that even such an accomplished partner as Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., could help him only one stroke, gave the ArmourCruickshank pair a tie for the lead today in the first 18 holes of the 36-hole Mid-South professional golf tournament. They turned in a 33, 33-66.

All the medieval pomp of royalty was trotted out by the ruling family of Britain today to welcome their distant cousins, King Carol of Rumania and his son, Crown Prince Michael, on a state visit, which will last until Friday.

Firms engaged in the apparel and textile industries appeared in a majority of the commercial rental listings announced yesterday. The Brooks Costume Company, theatrical costumers, took five floors comprising 30,000 square feet of space in the building at 1,146-50 Sixth Avenue for five years, commencing about Feb. 1.
The Cleveland Rams professional football team asked waivers today on Tackle Primo Miller and Backs Dick Tuckey and Nelson Peterson.
Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets in October amounted to 27,015 units, a decline of 5.5 per cent from sales in October, 1937.

It was said today at authoritative sources that a special meeting of all general chairmen of Canadian railroad unions had been called to discuss proposals of Sir Edward Beatty, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, for amalgamation of the C. P. R. and the Canadian National Railways.

Four of the greatest actresses of the last generation-Bernhardt, Duse, Rejane and Fiske-will perform in the same theatre this evening. Eleonora Duse will be seen in "Cenere," Mme. Rejane in "Madame Sans- Gene," Sarah Bernhardt in "La Dame aux Camliag" and Minnie Maddern Fiske as Becky Sharp in "Vanity Fair."

The French liner Ile de France, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, has among her passengers Henri P. Cassou, Miss Eva Turner, Malcolm Davis, George V. Riley, Mr. and Mrs. R. L. Prain, Xavier de Pompignan, Eloise Tournon, Mrs. Lydie Saillens, Count Christian de Dampierre, Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Jennings, Major Keith Travor and Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Tilbury.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Corporate Reorganizations ASSOCIATED GAS ELECTRIC CO., 61 Broadway-Involuntary proceeding filed under Chapter 10 of the Chandler act by Blanche F. Creamer, C. Raymond Durling Jr. and Charles C. Johnson, debenture bondholders.

On the editorial page of THE NEw YORK TIMES this morning it is announced that Charles Merz has been appointed Editor, in charge of the editorial page. He succeeds Dr. John H. Finley, who, according to a prearranged plan, becomes Editor Emeritus at the age of 75.

The Treasury Procurement Division on Saturday awarded contracts for a total of 5,446,300 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 20, from bids opened Nov. 7, as follows: 809-T--Birdseye, Erwin Cotton Mills Company, 52,350 yards; Superior Duck clothing Company. 213,550 yards; broadcloth, bleached, white, Eddington Fabrics Corporation, 451,200 yards; solid colors, Eddington 177,700 yards.
The lately organized Trio of New York gave their second Town Hall concert last night before a considerably larger audience than had attended their recent debut-which is as it should be.

Insurance companies are permitting billions of dollars in life insurance to lapse each year, Karl Ljung, assistant secretary of the Jefferson Standard Life Insurance Company, Greensboro, N. C., told the sixth annual convention of the Life Advertisers Association at the Hotel Traymore here today.

While icy winds from Long Island Sound blew over the New York Athletic Club diamond at Travers Island and the thermometer waged a losing battle in its efforts to retain a respectable level, the massive men who form the Green Bay Packers yesterday went through their training paces for Sunday's important game against the Giants at the Polo Grounds without a worry in their collective mind.

NEVER mind Apostoll and' Young Corbett 3d and the whole middleweight muddle. The concern in this corner is over Two-Ton Tony, the gallant and globular Galento. The massive master of merriment is now in a sad mood. His public in Philadelphia booed him when Harry Thomas sighed and sank to the canvas.
Frank T. Warburton, a retired lawyer and a leader in religious and welfare work among merchant sailors in New York, died here today at his home after being ill for eight months. His age was 72.

New York's first strictly singlefamily residential zone becomes a reality tomorrow. Fieldston, adjoining the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has the distinction of being the first neighborhood to which the new "G" rating of the city's zoning regulations will apply.

Praising the trade agreements program for the part it has played in rebuilding this country's foreign trade, Pyke Johnson, vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association and in charge of the Washington office of the organization, yesterday told members of the Overseas Automotive Club that the program has suffered some temporary losses in support in Congress as a result of the recent election.
The Blaw-Knox Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission its acquisition of control of the American Gas Service Company of Ohio and the American Gas Service Company of Michigan.

The Columbian Carbon Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $1,944,459, including $3,726 profit on sales of securities and after deductions for Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion and minority interests.

Fifty Postal Telegraph boys, thirty of whom had been dropped from the payroll two weeks ago when the Wages and Hours Law became effective, have been called to work to handle an expected seasonal increase in business, it was learned yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had become a party to four additional reorganization proceedings under the amendments to the Federal Bankruptcy Act incorporated in the Chandler Act.

A block of 75,000 snares of no par capital stock of the Dominguez Oil Fields Company, formed in 1925 by the late Ogden Mills and his associates, will be placed on the market today by a banking group comprising Smith, Barney Co.;

Mrs. Winifred Bushing, wife of Theodore C. Bushing, died today in the Parsons Hospital, Flushing. Mrs. Bushing was a charter member of the Great Neck Garden Club, a former president of the Great Neck Woman's Club and an authority on flowers.
Governor Lehman directed the appointment today of a special term of Supreme Court and a special grand jury to investigate alleged violations of the Election Law in Albany County.
Half of a four-point program to establish standards in the oil burner field was adopted yesterday at an industry-wide meeting held at the Hotel New Yorker.

Mrs. William A. Green, known to the music world many years ago as Mme. Marie Van der Veer Green, contralto soloist, died here today at the age of 77. Born in Brooklyn, she began her singing career in New York in 1888.

Five important administrative positions in the New York City school system are to be filled soon, it became known yesterday. Because the positions are civil service exempt, a controversy has arisen as to the best way to fill them.
Four Manhattan varsity football players and one freshman have been dropped from their respective squads, it was announced yesterday by Herb Kopf, head coach of football and director of athletics.

Bill Platt, captain of this year's football team at Yale; Malcolm Farmer, director of athletics at the university, and Ducky Pond, coach of the eleven, will be guests of honor at the annual barn party of the Yale Club of Montclair, which will be held in Nick Roberts's barn there Dec. 3.

Substantial gains in American automobile exports were forecast by William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Corporation, in an address before several hundred representatives of foreign automobile interests at the International Day Dinner held at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton last night in connection with the National Automobile Show.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court returned a verdict yesterday awarding $37,6837 to Mrs. Rachel Schlacter of 632 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, mother of three children, in her suit against receivers of the I. R. T. subway system for the death of her husband, David, a tailor, on Nov. 11. 1933.

One hundred and ninety-nine shops which employed 27,457 persons before last Oct. 24, when the Wages and Hours Law took effect, are now working with 6,246 employes, according to a report by the Department of Labor here to Robert I. Claiborne, representing Administrator Elmer F.

Army plays underwent serious study in a two-hour drill for the Princeton -squad on University Field today. Both ground and aerial tactics were rehearsed as the first and second teams took their turn against Ned Poe's scrubs.
Walter Paul Temple, founder of Temple City, Calif., and member of the family which built Temple Block and Temple Street in Los Angeles, died last night at his home here. His age was 69.

On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 15: PATROLMEN-Thomas J. Doyle, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 1, 1904. Wilbur J. Kennedy, 18th Division, 12th IY. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 3, 1909.
Glenn L. Martin, manufacturer of airplanes, announced tonight the contemplated sale to shareholders of additional stock "to take advantage of the anticipated demand for aircraft."

The tremendous increase in the work of the National Coordinating Committee of the National Council of Jewish Women since the antiSemitic campaign in Germany came to a climax last Thursday was described by Cecilia Razovsky, director of that organization, last night, before 500 guests at a dinner of the council at the Hotel Commodore.

Ananda Mahidol, 13-year-old King of Siam, returned from school in Switzerland today for a threemonth visit with his people. The boy King's frail condition was given as the reason for restricting the visit to three months.

Raymond Keyes has been elected president of the freshman class of Manhattan College, it was announced yesterday by Vincent R. Fitzpatrick, president of the Student Council. Keyes, who is a graduate of Xavier High School and a student in the School of Engineering at Manhattan, will head the Class of 1942 until the Sophomore elections in May.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club today won the second match of its South African tour, defeating Western Provinces by eight wickets. A week ago the Englishmen whipped a team representing Western Province country districts by an innings and 342 runs.
Miss Wuanita Smith, 72, widely known artist, was badly injured tonight when a purse snatcher struck her on the head and knocked her down as she was walking near her home in the central city district.

Professor Clyde R. Miller of Teachers College, Columbia University, in a speech last night at White Plains, N. Y., called upon Colonel Lindbergh and Henry Ford to return the decorations recently conferred on them by Germany. Professor Miller,

In a statement this afternoon President Arturo Alessandri dispelled all rumors of his impending resignation, declaring he would not abandon his office until he handed it over on Dec. 24 to President-elect Pedro Aguirre Cerda.

Political uneasiness again weighed down on the stock market here today and prices dropped. Gilt-edged issues were marked down sharply and in the foreign bond section all European issues except the French were dull.

Steel ingot production continued its upward movement last week, countering a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index rose to 92.9. This compared with 84.1 for the preceding week, and 63.2 for the week ended Nov. 13, 1937.

Mayor La Guardia explained yesterday that the city's plans for acquring the Second and Ninth Avenue elevated lines in Manhattan for demolition were part of a longrange program that might take many years to complete.

As a result of a radio appeal to Christians in behalf of Herschel Grynszpan, who assassinated Ernst vom Rath, third secretary of the German Embassy in Paris, Dorothy Thompson, special writer for The New York Herald Tribune, unexpectedly found herself yesterday the leader of a national movement that will seek an open trial for the young Polish Jew.

Midston House continued in a deadlock for first place with Bayside as both teams scored victories last night in Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class A matches. On its home courts Midston blanked the New York A. C., 5 to 0, while Bayside visited Jackson Heights to win, 5 to 0. The leaders have swept three encounters each.

Three creditors who are represented by George Gordon Battle and who have claims totaling "more than $5,000," filed yesterday a petition in Federal court seeking reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company under Chapter 10 of the Bankruptcy Act.

A proposal to send a message of thanks to President Roosevelt for his statement explaining the return to Washington of Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Berlin, was made last night at a dinner of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, in its fortyfourth annual convention at the Hotel Astor, and will be formally considered at a business session today.

Sid White, Brooklyn College backfield ace, who led the East in scoring last year, practiced with the Kingsmen yesterday afternoon for the first time since he injured his ankle in the City College game a month ago.

Daily average sales by variety stores in the United States approached within 3 1/2 per cent of the average for October, 1937, and were higher than for any previous month this year, according to a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announce that an order for fifty reconnoissance bombardment airplanes with Wasp engines placed by Australia has been confirmed by the British Commonwealth.

A $96,000 suit over a Frans Hals painting brought In Supreme Court nearly two years ago by Arne Quisling against three art dealers was discontinued yesterday by a stipulation among the parties to the suit and charges of misrepresentation made against the three dealers were withdrawn by the plaintiff.

Spaulding Frazer, counsel for the C. I. O. in the Jersey City civil liberties case, said today that he and Morris L. Ernst, counsel for the American Civil Liberties, Union in the same litigation, might soon ask the Supreme Court of the United States for a writ of certiorari that would take the case, now in the hands of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, directly to the Supreme Court.

The pound sterling continued under pressure yesterday, but the intensity of the drive slackened somewhat from that of Monday. The pound fluctuated nervously, ranging as high as $4.71 5/5 and down to $4.69 3/16 for another new low for the current movement. At a closing price of $4.70 1/2, it showed a net loss for the day of 1/2 cent.

President Roosevelt announced today that Homer Cummings would retire from the post of Attorney General in January. His statement, made at a press conference, was not unexpected. Reports that Mr. Cummings would leave the Cabinet have been current many times in the last two years and they have been accentuated in recent days.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 27-The Tennessee Electric Power Co. et al., applts.; v. Tennessee Valley Authority et al. Appeal dismissed as to applt., West Tennessee Power and Light Co., on motion and stipulation signed by counsel for- all applts. and the government. Argument concluded for both.

The producer price for October milk at handlers' plants in the 201210-mile zone from New York City was $1.91 per hundredweight of 3.5 per cent butter fat and represented an increase of 4 cents per hundredweight over the announced price for September, it was disclosed yesterday by E. M. Harmon, administrator of the Federal-State orders regulating the handling of milk in the New York metropolitan area.
The steer and yearling trade today was more active than Monday and at fully steady prices, especially on yearlings and light steers, cording to the United States Department of Agriculture.

With sales of the more expengive radio sets, priced at $150 and above, finally beginning to be adversely affected by publicity about television, dealers are complaining vigorously over what they consider premature announcements.

One must have loved to penetrate This bland costume of light on stone, Or in the universal violet Perceive a private skeleton. The dead are lost in every leaf That trips the gutter. They are alone In every hawk, in every beacon. The dead are quiet in every stone.

The contractual relations of radio entertainers with the National Broadcasting Company were explored at today's continuance of the investigation of the Federal Communications Commission. into alleged monopolistic tendencies- in the broadcasting industry.

Participation of a third large automobile manufacturer in the New York World's Fair next year was assured yesterday when K. T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, signed a contract for Chrysler exhibit space. Ford and General Motors already have buildings at the fair.

The story of the attempt of Cuba to wipe out tuberculosis was told last night by Colonel Fulgencio Batista, leader of the country, at a dinner given in his honor by members of the faculty of the Cornell Medical College at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr. and William S. Knudsen, chairman of the board and president, respectively, of the General Motors Corporation, visited Trenton today for the dedication of the new plant of the Ternstedt division of the Fisher Body divisions of the General Motors Corporation, a modern factory employing 1,500 persons in Ewing Township, West Trenton.

Puerto Rico is as important in the Atlantic defense scheme of the United States and the Panama Canal as Hawaii is in the Pacific, in the opinion of Representative G. Heyward Mahon Jr. of South Carolina, a member of the House Military Affairs Committee, who is en route to Panama.
The Bruins opened their fifteenth National Hockey League home season by holding the Maple Leafs to a 1-1 overtime tie tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.
The Scranton Miners returned to the Eastern League today when the Hazleton Club decided to transfer its franchise next year.

Peter J. Berry, executive vice president, has been elected president and a director of the Security Insurance Company of New Haven and its affiliates, the East and West Insurance Company and the Connecticut Indemnity Company.

According to the considered estimates of men who direct the progress of the automobile industry, 1939 promises to see a cash volume of new-car sales which will reach about $2,500,000,000, W. C. Cowling, vice president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., told company dealers at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Physicians today prevailed upon Lieutenant Sabiha Gokcen, 24year-old woman flier, to leave Dolma Bagtche Palace, where since last Thursday she had fasted in mourning for her foster father, the late President Kemal Ataturk.

Mr. and Mrs. Alan Theodore Schumacher gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Miss Evelyn L. Bruen, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Jay Bruen, whose marriage to John B. Trevor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Trevor, will take place Friday in St. James Church.
Mrs. Chester B. Melius of this place has made known the engagement of her niece, Miss Mary E. Mooney, to H. Russell Nostrand. Miss Mooney is the daughter of Mrs. Ethel Mooney Burris

Mayor La Guardia told 250 young business executives yesterday that the continued non-political conduct of the city's affairs precluded any reduction at the present time in the cost of local government.

Unsettled prices in the markets abroad tended to increase pressure on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and prices declined 3 to 10 points. With only six full and one short session prior to first notice day, liquidation of December obligations became more active although buying power proved adequate to maintain a 70-point premium on the near month over Optober, 1939, contracts.

The pilot of a plane identified as Luther Martin 4th of Morristown, N. J., crashed to his death tonight on rough prairie land near Lisle in Du Page County. For fifteen minutes he had circled low over western suburbs trying to find his way to the Chicago Airport.
Directors of Penick Ford, Ltd., Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share, increasing payments this year to $3 a share, compared with $1.50 distributed in 1937.

Mrs. Jennie King Mellon, widow of Richard B. Mellon, banker, industrialist and brother of the late Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, died in her home here this morning after a short illness.
A new display will open this morning at the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street, As usual, four groups are represented, three of which were organized by the Artists Union.
The International trade of Argentina for the nine first months of the current year totals 2,138,644,000 pesos (the peso is currently quoted at about 25 cents), excluding gold and silver transactions.

After an absence of several months due to severe illness, Dr. John H. Finley, restored to health, returns to this page today as Editor Emeritus. Charles Merz becomes Editor, in charge of the editorial page.
The Rev. Dr. Arthur R. McKinstry, rector of Christ Episcopal Church of Nashville, was elected Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Delaware today at a special convention.
Eliphalet Remington, retired engineer and builder and member of a distinguished central New York family, died Sunday at the age of 77, and funeral services were held for him today.

British insurance companies and Lloyd's underwriters will probably seek the British Government's advice over the German decree that all insurance claims for Jewish-owned property destroyed in Germany must be handed over to the Nazi State.
A new use of insulin in the treatment of delirium tremens and similar mental disorders was reported today to the Southern Medical Association.

Planning on a county or regional basis and the administration of proper zoning laws will insure permanent progress in the home development field on Long Island, and the building of planned developments should receive adequate financial support from large private money-lending agencies,

With sixty recruits reporting for duty, the Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet organization, held its first drill of the 1938-39 season yesterday at the 107th Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The legal fate of the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program was committed to the Supreme Court late today as all argument and preliminary moves were ended in the suit of fourteen private companies to enjoin this part of its operation. A final decision is hardly expected In less than six weeks.

Two former world champions, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, clashed tonight in the seventh round of the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament, and Capablanca, who met his first reverse at Haarlem yesterday, scored his initial victory in forty moves.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. John F. Rogge of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean A. Rogge, to Robert H. Haines Jr. of White Plains, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haines of this city.

Vigorous defense of the Constitution was urged yesterday by Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, who spoke before 200 members of the Manhattan Chapter of the D. A. R., which had its fortieth birthday party yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Fifth Avenue "blizzard" that has raged since Saturday is playing its last stand today in the windows of Lord Taylor, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. It has been deemed unethical on three counts by the Fifth Avenue Association.

Two goals within three minutes were made by the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League clash with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night, and these tallies enabled the Rangers to open their home campaign with a 2-to-O triumph.

CRAWLEY, ANNA F. (May 20, 1938). Gross assets, $17,557; Net, $16,081. To Hazel C. Frueauff, daughter and George E. Crawley, son, one-half each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $15,457. Frueauff, Burns, O'Brien Ruch. attorneys, 60 Wall St.
The International Rubber Regulation Committee fixed today the export quota for the first three months of 1939 at 50 per cent of the basic quota, compared with 45 per cent in the present quarter.

Trophies for finding new ways of using plastic materials in industrial manufacturing were presented at a dinner in the Hotel New Yorker last night to prize winners in six divisions in a competition sponsored by Modern Plastics Magazine.

It has been rumored for some time that the Nazi authorities were considering subjecting all Catholic preachers, Including Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, to censorship of their sermons.
Rear Admiral Wat T. Cluverius, commandant of the Philadelphia Navy Yard, relinquished his post today to Rear Admiral Julius C. Townsend, who has been serving with the general board at Washington.

Editorially this morning the Comercio of Lima comments favorably on President Roosevelt's nonpartisanship in nominating Alfred M. Landon as a member of the American delegation to the Pan-American Conference.

Former President Herbert Hoover and Mrs. Hoover became grandparents for the fourth time today when a son was born to the Allan Hoovers. It was Mr. and Mrs. Allan Hoover's first child. The mother is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Coberly of Los Angeles. Allan Hoover operates several ranches in the San Joaquin Valley.

As a result of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's published instructions to Hugh R. Wilson, the United States Ambassador, to go to Washington for report and consultation on the clouded relations between the United States and Germany, Mr. Wilson announced today a change in his original vacation plans and will now leave Berlin tomorrow and sail on the liner Manhattan from Havre Thursday.

Federal Judge Thomas W. Slick of the Northern Indiana District Court approved today the consent decrees offered Nov. 7 to end the Department of Justice's anti-trust cases against the Ford and Chrysler motor companies.

The story of the looting of the old museum of Cooper Union on Astor Place on the night of Oct. 8 when more than 200 pieces of antique jewelry, worth possibly $100,000, were stolen, was related last night at District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office after the arrest of a youth as the burglar.
Canada's economic outlook has "brightened considerably" after a year of recession, A. A. Magee, president of Barclays Bank (Canada), told shareholders at their annual meeting here today.
The publication date for. "This Peace," Thomas Mann's examination of the recent European crisis and its outcome, has been set for Nov.. 21, according to an announcement by Knopf.

United States Consul General Paul R. Josselyn strongly protested yesterday to the Jananese consul general an attack on Dr. Logan Roots, Harvard-trained American Church Mission Hospital superintendent, while the physician was attempting to prevent Japanese soldiers from driving Chinese refugees from St. Michael's Church at Wuchang, where they had taken shelter with the commission's permision. Dr.

A reorganization plan for the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway Company which would reduce the company's capitalization from about $80,500,000 to $61,000,0000, wipe out the equity of holders of the present common stock and reduce the voting power of the Mid-America group to 12.4 per cent was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Governor Bibb Graves today denied pardon applications of five Scottsboro case convicts, all serving long-term sentences. Four of the original nine Negro defendants were freed last year when the State dropped charges against them. The nine were accused of attacking two young white women aboard a freight train near Scottsboro, in 1931.

A concrete project has been worked out by Germany, Japan and Italy to transform their anti-Comintern pact into an outright military alliance, it is asserted editorially today by the Journal de Moscou, a French-language paper whose editorials usually reflect the Soviet Foreign Office viewpoint.
Viola Tree, the actress, died in London tonight of pleurisy after an illness of many months. She was 54 years old.

The Chilean army team of Major Eduardo Yanez and Lieutenant Hernan Vigil won the international army officers' jumping event at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight, with a total of 16 faults against 19 for the United States team of Captain R. A. Drake and Lieutenant F. F. Wing Jr.
Arthur Kirk, 32 years old, of Franklin Avenue, Oakland, died today in Hackensack Hospital of injuries suffered yesterday when he was crushed in a slide of trap- i rock and loam in Oakland.

BECATOROS--Spyros, Nov. 13, 1938, devoted husband of Aspasia, beloved father of Coula, Mary, Dennis and John. Funeral Bunnell's, 1,250 St. Nicholas Ave., Wednesday. Services 1:30 P. M., St. Spyridon Church. BENNING-At Montreal, Canada, on Sunday, Nov. 13, 1938, Mamie Donaghy, widow of the late James William Benning.
From both Right and Left, and even, under cover, from the Center, attacks have begun against both the matter and manner of Finance Minister Paul Reynaud's decree laws.

Head Coach Ducky Pond indicated today that At Wilson and Gil (Bud) Humphrey, veteran ace backs, would be replaced in the Yale backfield by Ray Anderson and Fred Burr as part of a sweeping line-up change for the game with Harvard here Saturday.

John D. Biggers, president of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, announced yesterday that the salaries of 563 employes who had accepted 10 per cent reductions in pay this year will be restored on Dec. 1, and that refunds covering the entire amount of reduction will be made before Christmas.

Mrs. Annie Laurine MacDonald Dodge, 21-year-old widow of Daniel G. Dodge, filed a petition in Probate Court here today for a widow's allowance of $33,000 a month during litigation over her husband's $10,000,000 estate.

Mainly because of the great inventions and improvements in recent years, the United States has become a nation more united now than at any time in its history, Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio told 200 members of the Ohio Society of New York at ceremonies at the World's Fair grounds in Queens yesterday afternoon.

The League of New York Theatres has turned over to the United States Attorney's office the case of an unaccredited ticket broker who allegedly failed on four occasions to stamp the final selling price on the back of tickets, Milton R. Weinberger, league attorney, said yesterday.

A ring of distributors that sold $3,000 worth of narcotics a week was said to have been smashed yesterday with the indictment by a Federal grand jury of eight women and four men, who, according to Abel I. Smith, Assistant United States Attorney, made up "one of the major narcotic rings in the East" and supplied "dope users in the Texas underworld."

Mainly because of the great inventions and improvements in recent years, the United States has become a nation more united now than at any time in its history, Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio told 200 members of the Ohio Society of New York at ceremonies at the World's Fair grounds in Queens yesterday afternoon.

Bartolo Pagano, chief cashier in New York of the present Italian Line since its formation in 1932, died yesterday at his home in Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., from the effects of a heart attack suffered on his way home from business the evening before. He was born in Liverpool sixty-nine years ago.

William Ballou Jr. has been appointed an assistant secretary of the Bank of New York. The special stockholders' meeting of the Lamson Sessions Company called to consider recapitalization, was adjourned because of lack of a quorum.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Peter Irving, secretary of the New York State Medical Society, writes you in praise of cash-indemnity insurance. By what magic is a medical society to perform a feat in which experienced private industry has failed?
The extent to which Europeans are hoarding United States currency, that is, actual American Treasury notes, is illustrated graphically by figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank here.

The restraining effect of taxation upon the philanthropy of donors and the evidences of a disinclination on the part of some donors to establish perpetuities are "two important factors mentioned as a basis for concern about future increases in endowments," a coming report of the Financial Advisory Service of the American Council on Education will say.

The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today its, final report on its long investigation of railroads' relations with forwarding companies, finding many violations of the law by the railroads and recommending that the roads cooperate to handle directly the traffic now billed by the forwarders.

How petroleum research is developing new products to bring greater returns from each barrel of crude oil was told today by Dr. Gustav Egloss, head of research for the Univeesal Oil Products Company, at the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute.
The Holland Tunnel, the eleventh anniversary of which occurs this week, has retained its popularity as a traffic facility, the Port of New York Authority revealed yesterday.

Paintings by living American artists; lent through the courtesy of the Whitney Museum, are being shown at the Museum of Modern Art Gallery in Washington until Dec. 4. Canvases by four Washington artists are included in the show, as are also ceramics by Carl Walters.

Governor Earle asked permission today to appear before the House Investigating Committee to reply to the graft and corruption charges that have been pending for more than six months against him and thirteen fellow-Democrats.

Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio denounced the National Labor Relations Board as the "left arm" of John L. Lewis in an address before the Ohio Society of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Several debutantes are serving with Miss Anna Glen Butler on the junior committee for the annual Christmas sale in behalf of Hope Farm, which will open this afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre and will continue there throughout tomorrow.

Stockholders Approve $4,000,000 Sinking Fund Debentures The stockholders of the Sunray Oil Corporation, at a special meeting held in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, approved the issuance of $4,000,000 convertible sinking fund debenture shares without fixed maturity to be retired by the operation of a sinking fund.
Fritzie Zivic, 150, Pittsburgh, easily outpointed Frankie Blair, 155, Camden, in the featured eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 7,000 per-sons.

Gisela Werbezirk, Viennese comedienne, who said she had played on the stage in Europe for twenty-five years, arrived yesterday as a refugee from Germany on the French liner Ile de France. She was accompanied by her husband, Johann Piffl, a dramatic critic, and her son, Harry, who is a composer.

On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 15: PATROLMAN-David F. Morrissey, 60th Precinct. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 5. 1906. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-For 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 16:
William George Zepf, former cashier of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, died Tuesday night of a heart ailment, his home at 203 Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old.

Mrs. A. J. Abel's Honey Cloud, a graduate of the claiming ranks, raced to his second straight stake triumph today when he easily defeated a dozen other crack sprinters in the W. P. Burch Memorial Handicap.
If the Loyalist Government wins the war, political refugees and those persecuted because of their origin or creed will receive an offer of asylum in Spain, the Council of Ministers decided today.

An official protest of the Catholie Church in the United States against Nazi persecution was carried over the nation last night, jointly by the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Emigre Handicrafts, an organization formed to help political and racial refugees from Germany to market merchandise, is holding this week an exhibition and sale of art, textiles and handicrafts at the Westbury Hotel, Sixty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue.

The directors of the Gruen Watch Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, have approved an agreement with F. Eberstadt Co. covering the public offering of 150,000 shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin S. Katz, president of the watch company.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 16 unless specified: Acushnet, Norfolk, to Navy Yard, Washington, via Potomac River points, Nov. 15. Cormorant, Norfolk, to Yorktown.

Another effort in the long series of attempts by France to pull herself out of her economic morass began with the recent publication of thirty decree laws. The mixed reception that seems to have greeted these measures is perhaps not surprising in view of the lack of unity which is evident in France today.
Historical and literary autographs and manuscripts from the collection of William Randolph Hearst brought $13,710 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries at the first of two auction sessions.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh ruled today that the Murray Hill Restaurant Corporation of New York had exclusive rights to the name "21 Club" for a night club it operates on West Fifty-second Street and that a "21 Club" here must change its name. The New York. concern waived claims to damages.

The announcement yesterday of the resignation of Attorney General Homer S. Cummings was followed today by a renewal of assertions that Postmaster General James A. Farley contemplated leaving the Cabinet soon.

A solemn high mass of requiem was celebrated at 10 A. M. yesterday in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer,- Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, for the Rev. James A. Mackin, a missionary of the Dominican Order for the last thirty-six years. Father Mackin died Sunday in New York Hospital.

Seven million Christmas Club members will share in the distribution of $330,000,000 by 4,500 banking and financial institutions and other organizations during National Prosperity Week, beginning Nov. 28, according to. an estimate made yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, founder and president of Christmas Club, a corporation, sponsor of the week.

The pattern of A. A. Milne's comedy, "Gentleman Unknown," presented at St. James's tonight, closely follows the changing character of the central figure, a young silk stocking salesman played by Barry K. Barnes.
John Edward Wagner, who for twenty-two years had been treasurer of the Cudahy Packing Company, died today in the Lakeview Hospital after an illness of twelve days. He was 67 years old.

A special police squad was created yesterday to protect German officials and German property in this city during the period of public demonstrations against them; and the squad turns out to be manned by Jews.

At Oklahoma City Dr. G. Wilse Robinson Jr. told the Southern Medical Association that insulin, now widely inproduced to shock schizophrenics back to sanity, has its uses in successfully treating delirium tremens and mild mental disorders. Dr. Tom Spies folslowed him with an account of studies of pellagra which he has made

Dr. J. A. Retty, chief geologist for the Labrador Mining and Exploration Company, today announced the discovery in Labrador of what may prove one of the world's most important deposits of high-grade iron ore.
Richard H. Sullivan of Marietta, Ohio, president of the Harvard Student Council, has been named to receive the Francis H. Burr Scholarship, one of the major honors in the college.

New residential tenancies reported yesterday included several leases for large suites on the East Side. Theodore J. Eliasco, president of the Bank of Athens, rented an apartment of eleven rooms in the building at 755 Park Avenue from the estate of Emily S. Hornblower, through Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc., broker.

With the intention of creating a fund and centralizing organization on a firm footing to finance attempts to find a solution of the Jewish refugee problem, several prominent Jews here held a meeting of the Foundation International Colonization Fund.

A woman identified from cards in her purse as Miss Madeline Fellerman, 33 years old, of 2,071 Seventy-fourth Streeet, Brooklyn, employed by a charity organization, was seriously injured yesterday afternoon when she fell or jumped eight stories from a fire-escape of the Russell-Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.
Circuit Judge Paul V. Gadola, issuing a temporary injunction, forbade the management of Hamady Brothers' grocery chain here today from making deductions from employes' wage for union dues.

After a week spent in New YorK during which he has made a close study of the crowds attending the auto show at Grand Central Palace and the special exhibit of his own and other General Motors cars in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel ballroom,

Warners announced today that they had purchased Maxwell Anderson's "Elizabeth the Queen" for Bette Davis and Errol Flynn, and Edward Charles Carpenter's "The Barber of New Orleans" for Flynn. Miss Davis will be seen in the title role in the Anderson piece, with Flynn playing Essex.
The University of Mississippi triumphed today, 20-14. over a fighting Arkansas University eleven in neutral Crump Stadium in a game which ended in a small riot.

President Roosevelt's criticism of the acts of violence in Germany at his press conference yesterday was intended to apply to persecution by the Nazis of Catholics and others as well as Jews, it was announced at the White House today by Stephen T. Early, secretary to the President.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: Cases submitted without argument: 44,035--Norman Hussa.

Navy Department opened bids today for 250,000 yards of blue meltons, used mainly for overcoatings. There were three bidders, the American Woolen Company of New York, the Kent Manufacturing Company of Clifton Heights, Pa., and the Portland Woolen Mills of Portland, Ore.
Minus seven members of the varsity squad, who are engaged in practicing teaching work in Johnstown and Altoona, Penn State today continued its preparation for the Pitt game.

The New York. Rovers came from behind with a six-goal barrage in the final period tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 8 to 3, and register their third straight victory in the Eastern Hockey League.

The Rev. Dr. William Morton Pickslay, who was rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church at Warwick from 1898 until his retirement as rector emeritus in 1920, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. E. H. Kerter. He was born in Brooklyn eighty-six years ago.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

An erratic 6 on the tenth hole cost Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Jack Grout of--Chicago first place in the thirty-six-hole mid-South professional best-ball golf tournament, the second half of which was completed on the Pinehurst No. 2 course today.

Labor must first learn to bargain collectively within its own. ranks before attempting to obtain collectivebargaining agreements with capital, William Collins, national representative of the American Federation of Labor in New York, declared last night at a dinner of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, holding its forty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Astor.

The statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that the Fifth Avenue Association considered unethical the "blizzard" that has been staged in Lord Taylor's windows for the last several days was made in error.

Large trees and a jungle of shrubs, which the Westchester County Park Commission planted here six years ago beside the Bronx River Parkway Extension, have grown until this hamlet of thirty merchants and 550 -families is virtually blotted from the view of passing motorists and is rapidly becoming a "forgotten village," the merchants declared today at a meeting in North Tarrytown of the Mount Pleasant town board.

Formation of retail shoe guilds in cities throughout the country, to work for elimination of design piracy and establish uniform opening dates, was recommended to about 800 retailers by Herman D. Delman, head of the Retail Shoe Guild here, at a luncheon and fashion promenade sponsored by the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, Inc., at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Preparing for their battle with the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds Sunday, the New York football Giants brushed up on their pass defense yesterday. Coach Steve Owen indicated that he would start Ed Danowski, Hank Soar, Ward Cuff and Leland Shaffer in the Giants' backfield.
A post-election survey of twenty-four States showed today that on the unofficial count Republicans polled 51.5 per cent of the vote, compared with 40.1 per cent in 1936 and 46.1 per cent in 1934.

Beattie Feathers was back in uniform yesterday as the Dodgers, leaving their regular training quarters at Freeport, L. I., for a few hours, reported at Ebbets Field for a lengthy workout in preparation for Sunday's encounter with the Bears.

A children's book fair was opened yesterday by the John Wanamaker department store. It will continue the rest of the week. Following the pattern of other book fairs, it will include motion pictures and speeches by authors.

With a victory over Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world chess champion, Reuben Fine of New York today crowned his brilliant work in the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament. The young American master bent his energy to the task of finishing the game adjourned from the sixth round.

Michael I. Rogers, 62 years old, of 27 Stegman Place, Jersey City, an employee of the Pennsylvania Railroad for twenty years and captain of the company's ferryboat Chicago, collapsed and died in the Chicago's wheelhouse shortly before 6 o'clock last night while the boat was in midstream en route from Jersey City to its Cortlandt Street dock.

The purpose of this program is to repeat a truth, a timely truth, that man made to the image and likeness of God has an intrinsic dignity which must be respected by governments and by rulers. In a sense, the world is growing smaller every day. Means of communication strengthen the bond of unity arid' the human race.
Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Lee Ward of 1,035 Fifth Avenue and East Hampton will give a dinner dance on Dec. 2 at the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Ward.
October earnings of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad ran slightly ahead of those in September, an official of the company said yesterday. The company's statement for September and the nine months follows:

Public offering of $40,000,000 of Government of the Dominion of Canada thirty-year 3 per cent bonds will be made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The bonds will be priced at 974 and accrued interest, to yield 3.14 per cent.

A Federal subsidy for railroads was recommended in resolutions adopted yesterday by the Railway Business Association at its annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel. The members of the association are manufacturers and others who sell equipment or supplies to the railroads.

The Public Service Commission moved today another step forward in its investigation of the accounting methods of the New York State Gas and Electric Company with receipt of requested information on "five or six" corporation officials.

Captain Harry Wooding, Mayor of Danville for the last forty-sixyears, died this afternoon at his residence. He had been in poor health since he returned from the Gettysburg reunion last July. His aze was 94.

Bermuda's Assemblymen regard the honor of serving in Parliament as sufficient payment. This afternoon the Assemly re. ejected a motion to increase the members' fees from 8 shillings to sixteen a sitting. Only four members supported the motion.

The financial statement of the Imperial Bank of Canada for the year ended on Oct. 31, shows profits of $961,343, compared with $967,977 in the previous year, after provision for increased Dominion and Provincial taxes and an increase in the contribution to pension and guarantee funds.

The militant anti-New Deal, anti-branch bank, anti-big city clique within the American Bankers Association, which seized control of the organization three years ago, received a decisive defeat here today when P. D. Houston, chairman of the board of the American National Bank of Nashville, Tenn., was elected second vice president at a general session this morning of the convene tion.

The Glenn L. Martin Company, Middle River, Md., manufacturer of aircraft parts and equipment, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 156,097 shares of $1-par-value common stock to be offered to stockholders at $20 a share, the aggregate amount of the cash offering being $3,121,940.

John W. Mudroch, City Treasurer since 1932, lied of a heart attack in his City Hall office this afternoon at the age o 61. Dr. Mudroch, a practicing dentist, was elected on the Socialist ticket In 1932.

Both in fighting trim, Fred Apostoli and Young Corbett 3d yesterday concluded training for their fifteenround middleweight ring battle in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, which will be recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as a championship encounter.

A fire that swept through the four-story. brownstone house of Mrs. James Henry Parker, widow of a former president of the New York Cotton Exchange, at 18 East Sixtyninth Street, killed a Negro maid and painfully injured a painter and a fire captain yesterday. Furnishings valued at $30,000 were destroyed.

The election of H. L. Brooks as president of Coty, Inc., was announced here yesterday by B. E. Levy, chairman of the board of the corporation. Since 1934 Mr. Brooks has been general manager and treasurer, and in conjunction with his new title will also retain that of treasurer. The office of president has not been filled since 1933.

The Inland Steel Company stated today that it would fight an order issued Nov. 12 against it by the National Labor Relations Board. The board ordered the company to negotiate a written collective bargaining contract with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. 0. organization.

Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, in a letter to the Most Rev. Antony Bashir, Archbishop of the Syrian Antiochan Archdiocese of America, made public yesterday, denied that the council had taken official action in support of Zionism. The letter read:

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that of $14,988,750 of 6 per cent notes of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Nickel Plate Railroad due on Oct. 1 last, $2,293,000 remained undeposited under a plan for their extension for three years. Of $89,500 deducted in the week ended yesterday from the total of undeposited notes outstanding, $11,500 represented notes deposited in assent and $78,000 notes "surrendered" to the company.

The intensified crsecution of German Jewry has stirred Palestine Jews to he utmost and they have turned to prayer ?? charity. This week Jews here, the religious and the irreligious, have filled place ?? worship in response to calls by rabbis.

It may be coincidence that the AngloItalian agreement goes into effect at the very moment that plans for understanding between Great Britain and Germany recede. Then, again, it may not be coincidence. Berlin has,not looked with favor on the conclusion of an accord between her Mediterranean partner and the Power

Judging of more than 500 new uses of glass in architectural construction, decoration and design completed during the year has begun at the Pedac Galleries, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in the 1938 competition of the Pittsburgh Glass Institute. The judging is done by means of photographs.

Additional regulatory measures to curb over-production in the oil industry were urged today by Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in his annual address at the convention of that organization here.

There is a chance of a second vacancy on the Supreme Court before the new year. At four score and two, Louis Dembitz Brandeis has lived the great life. In his youth, he competed with the best in the bustling market place.
Total tonnage carried on New York State's multimillion-dollar barge canal system, which closes Friday, decreased 350,000 tons during 1938 compared with last year.

Mrs. Nancy Lee Sears, born a slave on the plantation of General Robert E. Lee's family in Virginia, died in the home of a daughter here today. Her age was 102. She had been living in the North since 1898, when her husband, Woodson Sears,
The annual fair and turkey dinner of the Methodist Church Home, 4,499 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, will take place there today and tomorrow. This will be the eighty-eighth

Plans for small houses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens were among the projects submitted yesterday by architects. The leading construction operation in the Bronx calls for the erection of ten two story dwellings at Boynton and Story Avenues.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today George T. Barker and Henry H. Shepard of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

At first we thought we'd got into the wrong place, but it wasn't, as developed a moment or so later when Sleepy Jim Crowley, Fordham's head coach, explained everything.
Unbeaten in their last two skirmishes of the hockey season, Red Dutton's Americans tonight will seek their third straight conquest on the ice at Madison Square Garden.

Fire of undetermined cause destroyed three buildings on Terry Street, near South Ocean Avenue, here this morning .and sparks from the burning structures ignited awnings or roofs of a dozen other commercial buildings and dwellings within a half-mile radius.

Edward Johnson's engagement as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association was extended for two additional -seasons, carrying his contract through the season of 1940-41, at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday.

Premier Edouard Daladier today repeated, in reply to a request by the Colonial Commission of the Chamber of Deputies, the assurance given some weeks ago that the French Government would oppose any dismemberment of the French Empire and "would resolutely maintain the integrity of its possessions as they had been constituted at the end of the World War."

Officials of New York City are working on plans for early offering of two bond issues aggregating $40,000,000, it was reported yesterday. Although details of the offerings have not been completed, it is understood that they will consist of $25,000,000 of one to thirty-five year

Predicting that 25,000 miles of new four-lane highways would have ?? be built within the next twenty-five years to accommodate the automobile traffic of the nation H. S. ?? airbanks, chief of the Division of information of the United States Bureau of Public Roads, told delegates at the closing day of the ?? improvement conference

The Nationally Advertised Brands Week, conducted last week by variety chain stores, will become an annual event, as a result of the excellent response to it, Godfrey Lebhar, editor of Chain Store Age, which sponsored the promotion, said yesterday. The event will be held at approximately the same time of the year.

Harry F. Wolf and Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A. C., A. H. Marckwald of Short Hills and E. G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club, four of the seeded players in the Princeton Club's nineteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament, swept through second-round matches yesterday without the loss of a single set.

The directors of the Central Railroad of New Jersey will meet tomorrow to discuss what a director described yesterday as a "serious" situation caused by the decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia against a petition by railroads against taxes levied by New Jersey.

While Germany observed the Day of Atonement, a festival of the Lutheran Church, and crowded Confessional churches were offering prayers "for all those being persecuted in this land," Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson left for the United States tonight in response to President Roosevelt's summons for report and consultation on the German situation.

It is something better than a mere coincidence that the annual conference on roadside improvement should take place during this week of the National Automobile Show. The motor car has long since passed out of the category of a luxury and become a necessity. Yet a large part of its ever-expanding use properly belongs in the realm

Miss Patricia Eugenie Jones, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Alexander Symington, was married to Lieutenant Thomas Joseph Gent Jr., U. S. A., son of Thomas J. Gent of New York, in St. Luke's Episcopal Cathedral here last night.

Data on America's radio audience, the largest in the world, against a statistical background showing the nature and extent of broadcasting abroad, were presented today by Hugh M. Beville, chief statistician of the National Broadcasting Company, at the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of network operations in this country.

Mrs. Arthur Brisbane, widow of the newspaper editor, has requested local officials not to name a new street for her husband because she felt sure he would not have wanted it done. She suggested that the road be designated as "Richard's Lane" in honor of Richard Harding Davis, war correspondent and author, who was an intimate friend of the Brisbanes.
A letter from Governor Lehman to the director of the press and information department of the Republic of Poland Exhibition at the fair was made public yesterday. It follows:

An ordinance adopted by the town of Harrison on Sept. 28 to prevent property owners from selling topsoil ;to the World's Fair except by permission of the Building Department was declared unconstitutional today by Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson.

Word was received here last night of the death on Tuesday in the Laconia Hospital, Laconia, N. H., of Harry Grant Dart, a well-known newspaper cartoonist, whose work had appeared in The World, The Herald and other New York newspapers.

Descriptions of alleged Communist party tactics to gain influence or control in various organizations were given before the House Committee investigating un-American activities today by witnesses asserting first-hand experience both within and without the Communist party.

The population of the United States as of July 1 was estimated today at 130,215,000 in preliminary figures made public by the Bureau of the Census. This total indicated an increase of 0.7 per cent over July 1, 1937, but emphasized a decline in the rate of increase which is expected to have far-reaching effects on American economy in future years.

The British Cabinet is understood to have given tentative approval today to a plan for opening thinly settled parts of the British colonial empire as a sanctuary for some of the oppressed Jews and other "non-Aryans" in Germany.

Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles since that post was created fourteen years ago, was held in $5,000 bail by Judge Cornelius Collins in General Sessions Court yesterday on charges of extortion and of receiving a bribe as a public officer.

The AngloItalian agreements of last April, settling the problems outstanding between Italy and Britain, were put into force this afternoon by a declaration signed here by Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and the Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador.

Mrs. Caroline Mae Quigley Horne, wife of Dr. William D. Horne of Clewiston, Fla., and Beech Creek, Pa., died today in Nashville, Tenn., it has been learned here. She formerely resided in Yonkers, N. Y., where her husband was a consulting chemist in the sugar industry. A brother, Richard S. Quigley

Although his team finished last, Frank Abbate of Newark Arts High broke the meet record in winning the individual crown in the twenty-sixth annual Newark High Schools crosscountry championship run, held over a course of approximately two and one-half miles at Branch Brook Park today.

Without referring by name to be Chancellor Hitler of Germany, Mayor La Guardia "apologized" last in night before 20,000 persons in Madison Square Garden for not having fr "adequately described the brutality of this man and his government."

The Union County Board of Taxation dismissed today the appeal of the Linden division of the General Motors Corporation for reduction of the assessed valuation of its land, buildings and personal property from $6,114,525 to $1,882,468.

Although the Reynolds Spring Company had called its 1,200 employes to return to work, citing Michigan laws as their protection, nearly 2,000 pickets, 20 per cent of them women, prevented the reopening of the plant today.

Here is the constitution adopted today at the convention of the. Committee for Industrial, Organization: Preamble The Committee for Industrial Organization formed in November, 1935, presented a program to the unorganized workers of this country.

Eddie Shore, the Boston Bruins' all-star defenseman, today ended the longest hold-out siege of his National Hockey League career by signing a contract that called for the circuit's maximum salary of $7,000.

Initial steps to unite all regional consumer cooperative purchasing associations into a single national association are under way, it was announced here yesterday. It was disclosed that at recent meetings Chicago, the directors of the National Cooperatives, Inc., and the Cooperative League of the U. S. A. had accepted in principle a policy of coordination looking toward unifiction of the regional groups.

President Roosevelt's statement of his attitude toward the persecution of Jews in Germany was officially endorsed today by the Congress of Industrial Organizations (C. I. O.) after the rules had been suspended by unanimous consent to permit notice of the convention action to be telegraphed immediately to the White House.
Electric power production rose last week, countering a seasonal easing, and the adjusted index advanced to 96.6 from 95.6. For the week ended Nov. 13, 1937, the figure was 99.0.

GOLDSCHMIDT, FRANCES (June 17). Gross assets, $48,240; net, $44,549. To niece, Mina P. Goldschmidt, $250; Claire and Estelle Diamond, $250 each in trust, principal at 21; brothers, Daniel Goldschmidt, life income from one-fourth of residuary estate; Sidney H. Goldschmidt,

A new, era in Cuban-American relations will result from the visit to this country of Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of the Constitutional Army of Cuba, and his discussions. with President Roosevelt in Washington, it was indicated last night.
Stocks weakened and closed down 1 to 3 points, erasing all gains of the month; turnover, 1,794,880 shares.

Not long ago an attempt was made to introduce firearm legislation that not only would have wrapped the purchase of any type of gun in a maze of red tape, but would have resulted in the application of an additional tax on sportsmen.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey applied today. to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abandon about four and one-half miles of there road's line between Bowentown Junction and Greenwich Pier, Cumberland County, N, J. The line was built to serve the oyster industry at Greenwich Pier but the traffic has been diverted to the highway, according to the application.
Drilling under floodlights, Princeton's football team continued preparations today for its final game of the season against an opponent that the Tigers have not met in thirty Years.

Several deals involving houses on Washington Heights were announced yesterday. Two were of properties on Hamilton Terrace. Other realty activity included deals in Harlem and the sale of a town house in East Seventieth Street.

There are no boundaries to grief; No rod, no compasses, no gauge Delimits its diameter Or circumscribes its acreage. We measure only by the scales That tremble, mount, and vacillate; And grief, a scruple yesterday, Tomorrow is a hundredweight.

Campus talk of an "ultimatum" by Pittsburgh freshman football players in connection with a muddle over tuition payments brought a statement of a firm stand tonight from the school athletic authorities.

Frank D. Jackson, former Governor of Iowa, died oday at his home here at the age of 84. Mr. Jackson a Republican, served as Governor Iowa, 1894-95, after being Secretary of the Senate and Secretary of State. He came here fourteen years ago, after being in the insurance business in Des Moines. Mr Jackson was a native of New York.

Herman Bergholtz, Mayor of Ithacafrom 1930 to 1934, died here today after a long illness at the. age of 74. He s survived by a daughter, Mrs. H. B. Hopkins of Ithaca, and a son, Herman Jr. of Reading, Pa.
It is more than a happy coincidence that traffic fatalities have shown decreases averaging 21 per cent during each of the last ten
Mayor Joseph F. Loerhr announced today the appointment of a World's Fair committee of Yonkers to coordinate activities of the city in an effort to make Yonkers "the gateway to the World's Fair."

Formal condemnation of the Sixth Avenue elevated line was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate under conditions which, in the opinion of Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan, will enable the city to begin tearing down the structure some time next month.

Unsettled by weakness in the stock market and reports that a reduction in tariff rates on highgrade textiles would take place under the new trade treaty with Great Britain, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to losses of from 1 to 5 points.

Local traction issues were among the few groups of bonds that pushed forward in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but late selling caused the transit securities to recede so much that most of them closed lower on the day.

Charles Mogull, 39 years old, owner of one of the largest retail film and camera concerns in the country, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions as he was about to go on trial before Judge Collins for criminally receiving part of the 2,500,000 feet of film stolen last year from a corporation in a series of night burglaries.

The Committee for Industrial Organization, on this, the third day of its convention, formally adopted the constitution which established the body of affiliated unions, committees and councils as the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The Long Island Railroad has filed protests with the Village Boards of Lynbrook and Valley Stream against assessment for tax purposes of improvements made in grade-crossing elimination.

Mark Sullivan, political commentator, came back to West Chester today to serve as guest editor and write the leading editorial for The Daily Local News, on which he began his journalistic career fifty years ago.

When pitted against Dr. Alexandre Alekhine in the opening round of the A. V. R. O. chess tournament Samuel Reshevsky, United a States champion, had a close call, but succeeded in drawing the game, as is shown by a perusal of the official score, which has reached here.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The program follows:

The Federal- Government, in its effort to provide jobs for the unemployed, could find useful work for at least 2,000,000 persons over a period of twenty or thirty years, in the opinion of Harry L. Hopkins, National Works Progress Administrator.

Creation of a Federal Department of Transportation and organization under it of an authority to coordinate all forms of transportation and preserve the usefulness and assets of existing agencies, was recommended today by Walter M. W. Splawn, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a discussion of the railroad problem at the convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners here.

The New York Life Insurance Company, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of New Jersey were permitted today by order of the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene as parties to the reorganization of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad.

Walenta, wife of the Rev. Edmund Joseph Walenta, rector of St. Mary's by-the-Sea Episcopal Church here, died in the Point Pleasant Hospital today after a short illness. She was 64 years Other survivors are two sons, Edmund J. Walenta Jr. of Newark and Harold F. Walenta of this place and a brother Albert D. of York, Pa.

A fashion show in behalf of the Family Thrift Shop will be held the afternoon of Dec. 2 at the headquarters of the New York Kindergarten Association, 524 West Fortysecond Street. Mrs. Frank J. Foley, chairman of the shop committee, is in charge of the arrangements for the event.

George Haydock Brooke, Philadelphia insurance broker and once an all-American football back at the University of Pennsylvania, died in his home here today. He was 64 years old. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Marie Brooke; a sister, Mrs. Edward Carlton Stone of Lexington, Miss., and a brother, Robert J. Brooke of New York.
Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, who last season set something of a precedent by publicly apologizing for appearing in "Yr Obedient Husband," will appear together in "The American Way,"

Exeter's all-class team defeated Andover's all-club combination, 22 to 0, on the gridiron today. Exeter took the offense at the start and a 40-yard run by Dick Noyes put the home eleven in a scoring position. Noyes scored on the next play.

Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, new Commanding General of the First Army and of the Second Corps Area, paid a formal call upon Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward, Commandant of the Third Naval District, at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn. yesterday morning.

Aroused by the recent intensification of attacks on Jews in Germany, the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church adopted yesterday a resolution in which the members expressed themselves as being "profoundly shocked by the unspeakable persecution" and offered their sympathy to the Jews and "the millions of men of good-will in Germany."

The reciprocal trade agreements of the United States with Canada and with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the Colonial Empire will be signed in the East Room of the White House at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

Government dispatches said tonight that militia attacked this morning after artillery preparation in the Tremp sector, forty miles north of Lerida on the Catalan front. The new offensive apparently was intended to recapture Tremp power plants on the Noguera Pallaresa.
Fordham College's freshman class elected four class officers yesterday under the student council's direction, with a special run-off election to decide a tie for the treasurer's office.

After an all-night search for an airplane that had been missing since it took off from Suffolk Airport late yesterday afternoon with two young men in the cockpit, police found the machine near the field early this morning.
The investigation into charges of official corruption in Brooklyn will get under way today with the selection of the special grand jury.. authorized by Governor Lehman.

Arthur Colegrove, Public Utility Commissioner, one of the thirteen men accused with Governor Earle in graft and corruption charges, led the Earle administration's counterattack on Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, at sessions of the House Investigating Committee today.

Brazil has always defended and will continue to defend the principle of continental solidarity and PanAmericanism, it was stated this afternoon by a government spokesman. He quoted President Getulio Vargas's declaration of Nov. 10, 1937, to foreign correspondents that, without hostility to nations of other continents, Brazil recognized the predominance of the American policy over others and the complete unity of the twenty-one American republics.

Two severe blows were dealt today to the plans of Premier Edouard Daladier and Finance Minister Paul Reynaud for restoring the economic and financial situation of France by economies and extended working hours.

Turning his back on the tradition hat Yale seniors are likely to prove hore reliable in the Harvard game han players who are inexperienced against the Crimson, Head Coach Pucky Pond today selected a tentaive line-up for the season's climax ame in the Bowl Saturday.
