Capitalizing on the announcement of County Executive J. Russel Sprague of Nassau County that only one copy of the 1939 county budget would be available for taxpayers to inspect, John S. Thorp, Democratic county leader, purchased a copy here this afternoon for $27.50 and ordered a number of reprints for free distribution at Democratic headquarters next Monday.

New York's latest fire-fighting boat, the 134-foot Fire Fighter, went into service at 9 o'clock yesterday morning at the department's marine station at the Battery. Faster and larger than any fireboat in the service,

J. P. Roney, general manager of the marine department of the Texas Company, was installed yesterday as chairman of the Atlantic district marine section of the National Safety Council, at a meeting in the New York Marltime Exchange, 80 Broad. Street.
A "good" crop yield this Fall due to "almost ideal" harvest weather was reported for New York State today by the State Department of Agriculture.

E. F. BENSON'S "Queen Victoria's Daugh ters"* is actually not so much about Vicky, Alice, Helena, Louise and Beatrice as it is about their formidable Mama. There are several reasons for this, not the least important of.which are that Louise and Beatrice are still alive and that Mr. Benson is the son of an Archbishop of Canterbury.

The British Government published tonight pro. posals for prison reform that are regarded as the most sweeping in a century. The dreaded punishment of flogging with cat-o'-nine-tail is to go except for attacks on prison guards. Hard labor," second division and other divisions of imprisonment are to be merged into simple imprisonment, and criminal lunatics are to be termed "State mental patients."
American trade with Germany continued at a low ebb during the first nine months of this year, according to figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

231st St (13-3408B), s s, 100 ft w of Fairfield Ave, 50x119; Colcan Holding Corp to Anders Jordahl, 15 Elwood Pl, Greenwich, Conn. Pauling Ave (15-4268), w s, 275 ft s of Neil Ave. 100x100; Sophie Steinfeld to Lulu Hoffman, 1,745 President St. Bklyn.

The Brooklyn College football team tried a novel method of gaining the support of students for the Kingsmen's last game against Susquehanna when they went on strike during chapel hour yesterday afternoon against lack of cooperation by their classmates.

Turpentine firm, 22 3/4c; sales, 52 barrels; receipts, 307 barrels; shipments, 1,620 barrels; stock, 51,887 barrels. Rosin firm, sales, 247; receipts, 1,931; shipments, 1,382; stock, 294,548. Quote: B, D, $4.05: E, $4.25: F. $4.85: G. H. I, K, M, $5; N, $5.50; WG, $6; WW X, $6.65.

The Narragansett Park record of 1:101-5 for six furlongs was threatened today when Paul Andolino's Gay Balko went that distance in 1:102-5 in winning the featured Albany purse, a sprint for 3-yearolds and upward.

James A. Donegan, a member of the New York bar for fifty-one years, who had been Register and Clerk of New York County, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, 106th Street and Central Park West, after a long illness. He was born in the old Fourth Ward seventv-four years ago.
The Spanish Children's Milk Fund will be augmented by an exhibition of ten portrait busts of leading its Spanish personalities by Jo Davidson. The exhibition will open today

The President has issued an executive order authorizing the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority to inspect income and excess profits tax returns of utility companies and their executives. So far as tax returns of the,companies are concerned, there may be relevance in such an order.

The first step in a move by the Metropolitan Controllers' Association to reduce costs of retail distribution has been completed, it was made known last night at the monthly meeting of the group in the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street.

By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER Golden Ave, 1,654; dwelling, 40x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Filippo Falcigila; due, $9,915; taxes, etc, $166; to pilantiff for $8,600. Morris Ave, 531-3; 1 and 2-story store, 33.3x100; East River Saving Bank against Flamount Realty Corp; due, $60,985; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Three fishermen tonight rowed a dory bearing their dead captain to the lightship forty-four miles off Nantucket Island and reported that their 48-foot schooner, the Valencia, out of New Bedford, had foundered in a northwest gale yesterday. The lightship reported the survivors as Jack Knutsen, George Jacobson and Nels Adland, all of New Bedford.
The Finnish Foreign Minister, Dr. Rudolf Holsti, resigned today and President Kyosti Kallio immediately appointed as a temporary successor Commerce Minister Vaino Voiomaa.

Mexicans are watching with intense interest developments in United States-German relations culminating in the return of Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson and President Roosevelt's declaration condemning the Nazi anti-Semitic campaign.

The rises in ingot production and scrap steel prices to new high records for 1938 are largely a reflection of the more rapid consumption of steel by the automobile industry, with government spending a secondary factor but of growing importance, Iron Age says this week.

Trading in steer beef was only fair to slow in local markets yesterday; veal, calf and lamb fairly active; other classes fair. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to slightly lower: veal strong to higher; fresh pork steady to lower; other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be stronger; veal and calf steady: lamb steady with Tuesday's late decline. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
John M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad and chairman of the World's Fair committee of the Eastern Presidents Conference.
General Gerardo Machado y Morales, former President of Cuba, was critically ill yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He will be operated upon soon and has had several blood transfusions in preparation.

An amusing bit of homespun, much in the manner of the old Will Rogers films, is "The Arkansas Traveler," which dropped into the Paramount yesterday. It bears a dedication to William Allen White, the sage of Emporia, and it features the homely philosophy of Bob Burns, the sage of Van Buren, Ark.,
Full cooperation in enforcement of the Wages and Hours Law was pledged today by delegates to the fifth annual Conference on Labor Legislation, most of whom are State Commissioners of Labor.

Richard Cummins, Chief Clerk of Surrogate's Court, announced yesterday that Surrogates James A. Foley and James A. Delehanty had promoted George Loesch from Special Deputy Clerk of the court to the position of Clerk of the Court at a salary of $9,000 a year. The vacancy arose through the death last Spring of Charles P. Sheridan, Tammany leader.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 14: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Jennings, H. L., VF-6, the Enterprise, to continue duty the Enterprise. Shelter, E. J., Med. Corps, Pearl Harbor, T. H., to Naval Air Station, San Diego, Calif.

A military funeral service for Lansing C. Holden, World War ace, was held yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue- and Fifty-first Street. The Rev. Cornelius P. Trowbridge, dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, Boston, a friend of Mr. Holden, officiated.

A crew of the Department of Water Supply, Gas. and Electricity prevented a water shortage for thousands of office building occupants and hundreds of storekeepers in the vicinity of Union Square yesterday afternoon when a thirty-sixinch water main broke at the southwest corner of the park.

TIME out from football! There should be breathing spells occasionally during the feverish Autumn campaign. A baseball umpire was recently encountered; probably the youngest umpire in organized baseball. He is Thomas Edward Humphreys, a genial, brown-haired young fellow who has yet to cast his first vote. Thomas Edward is a grandson of the late Joe Humphreys, the famous announcer at old fistic festivities.

Akron's three major rubber companies announced today that some 16,000 white-collar workers, half of whom live here, who received cuts of 10 to 15 per cent in pay on April 1 would be restored to full rates, effective today.

Otto Hermann Voss, one of three defendants accused of espionage, testified yesterday at his trial before Federal Judge John C. Knox that he would "lie to gain freedom" but he insisted that the testimony he gave in Federal court in his own behalf was the "whole truth and nothing but the truth."
Metropolitan Museum of Art; "Classic Myths: Loves of the Gods," Stuart M. Shaw, 11 A. M.; Chinese bronzes (general tour), 2 P. M.; "French Decorative Art," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.

Dr. Floyd E. Keene, a specialist in women's diseases who held professorships in gynecology in the School of Medicine and Graduate School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, died last night at his home in Wynnewood. He was 57 years old.

Seventy-seven amendments ,to the constitution, by-laws and general and athletic rules of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States will be considered at the A. A. U.'s golden anniversary convention in Washington Dec. 24.

Drastic changes in the organization of the New York State. public school system that. would abolish outmoded procedures and introduce extensive new policies are proposed in the three-year $500,000 Regents Inquiry into the character and cost of education.

An appeal for donations of clothing to be used by the residents of Boys Town, Neb., a community for homeless boys near Omaha, was made here yesterday by a representative of the Rev. E. J. Flanagan, director of the community.

A public works program as a means of relieving unemployment and bracing up national economy during a depression has proved highly successful in the United States, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes told the first Pan-American Congress of Municipalities here this afternoon.

A scheduled presentation here tonight of "Faust" by the Operaon-Tour company was canceled today by the Montgomery Concert Course because of what it described as union difficulties encountered by the company.
The annual dinner for the members of Fall sports teams.at Wesleyan was held this evening, follow-. ing which captains were elected for next year.

Returning on the H de France yesterday from a European tour, George V. Riley, manager of the Hotel New Yorker, was appointed national organizer of the sixth annual "Fight Infantile Paralysis campaign, which will end Jan. 30 with the national celebration of the President's birthday.

James McGregor opened the doors of the garage behind his residence here this morning and discovered that in the dark last night he had driven home in someone else's automobile, identical to his even to the ignition lock. The car, he explained, must have been near his in a New Rochelle parkinc lot.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his policy of "appeasement" won an unexpectedly sweeping by-election victory today in the big leather goods center of Walsall in the heart of the industrial midlands.

A mural depicting the early use of anesthesia, believed to be the only painting of its type, will be unveiled tomorrow as part of the ceremonies in the homecoming-class May exercises of the New York University College of Dentistry. The programm will include a luncheon,

Mayor Thomas M. Eaton, Republican nominee for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District, was declared today elected over the Democratic incumbent, Byron Scott, as the counting of the absentee ballots indicated Mr. Eaton led by 228 votes at the final count.

The general cattle market was more active today with steers and yearlings selling steady to 25 cents higher, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Top for 1,264-pound steers was $13.35. Hogs continued fairly active at steady to 10 cents higher rates. Top was $7.80. Fed lambs closed fairly active at fully steady prices, closely sorted lots selling up to $9.15.

Mrs. Henry Austin Clark of Flushing, Queens, and Southampton, L. I., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Versailles for Miss Mary Wilmerding Sprague, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Buell Sprague.

New York City had its coldest weather this Fall early yesterday morning, when the mercury dropped to 33, one degree above freezing, at 4:15. The cold wave promised by the Weather Bureau for `last night missed the city, and the forecast for today is rain and warmer.
Members of the Arab High Committee who fled from Palestine issued yesterday a statement in Bairut, Lebanon, in reply to the British Government's White Paper on Palestine, publshed last Wednesday.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, bought yesterday thirty lemons, twenty-nine heads of. garlic and twenty-seven paper bags from Alphonse Puma, 66 years old, of 510 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, after he had found Puma guilty of peddling without a license.

Japanese fishing concessions on the Mexican west coast have been extended temporarily for two months, a Mexican official revealed today. Coincidentally it.was learned that the Department of National Economy had approved a year's renewal of Japanese fishing rights and that' only President Lazaro Cardenas's signature.was yet to be obtained.

With the elections out of the way, it appears that industry generally is in for a rather long period of anti-trust investigations. Yesterday it was announced that the Department of Justice is conducting "a widespread general study" of the building trades industry.

Seated at a desk on the apron of North Beach - Airport; Queens, Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday leases- with three of the nation's major domestic. airlines for the rental of hangar space in the $28,000,000 municipal airport which will be opened on April 30.

Members of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association today re-elected James G. McNary, president, urged the amendment of the National Labor Relations Act to provide equitable treatment for employer groups, and asked that export markets for American lumber be - expanded through provisions in -the trade treaties negotiated by Washington.

After several weeks in Detroit, Sir Malcolm Campbell, racer of speed boats and cars and a director of the Ford Motor Company of Great Britain; said yesterday on his arrival at the Hotel Biltmore that the United States was fortunate in. having a sound demand for new cars now being introduced at shows throughout the nation.

The Joint Treasury-Postoffice Committee accepted today property offered by Attorney General Cummings and C. F. Maguire for extension and remodeling of the postoffice at Stamford, Conn. The land, in two parcels, is west of the present site and has 157 feet on Federal Street and is 140 feet deep. Mr.

Today's events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; piano concerto series, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45; Sergei and Marie Radamsky, vocal recital, Temple Emanu-El, 11 A. M.; Harold Morris, pianist, Juilliard School of Music, 5 P. M.;

Realty men are watching with interest the outcome of the experiment now getting under way in Baltimore, Md., where an organized effort is being made to rehabilitate forty blocks embracing hundreds of old homes and other outmoded buildings.

Louis Newman bought for occupancy from Fresh Meadow Homes, Inc., the recently completed onefamily residence at 69-42 180th Street, Flushing, Queens, on a plot 40 by 100 feet, for cash above a first mortgage of $5,400. Irving Honigsberg was attorney for the buyer and William Adelman acted for the sellers. J. Halperin Co. represented the mortgagee.

The Swarthmore College soccer team blanked Stevens Tech today, 2-0. The Garnet's first score was made midway in the second period, when Captain Gary White sent the ball into the net on a pass by Crothers. Swarthmore tallied again within the first minute of the second half, Thatcher booting in a cross 'by White.

B. H. Ridder of the University Club gained the semi-final round of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Fall tournament last night when he defeated R. S. Rothschild of the Downtown A. C., 15-10, 18--16, 12-15, 12--15, 15--10, at the New York A. C.
Scientists attended a dinner at the Athenaeum Club tonight to Sir Richard Gregory to mark his retirement from the editorship of the weekly journal Nature.

The $11,470 that Masjoe Joseph Ison, former Harlem policy banker, had in his possessionwhen he was arrested on Jan. 13, 1937, will go to his lawyer and not to the Federal Government to satisfy income tax claims, according to a judgment filed yesterday in Supreme Court
Lieutenant John Stack of the Irish Army team captured the military jumping event on tonight's program at the Royal Winter Fair, riding Blarney Castle.

Central Park W, 294-5; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co to Norwest Realty Corp, 36 W 44th St ($115). 1st Ave, 333; Helen M. Armstrong to Wemay Realty Corp, 302 W 86th St ($2.50). 2d Ave, 340: Elizabeth J. K. O'Reilly to John F. Brown, Sylvia St, Glenwood Landing, N. Y.; mtg $14,500 ($17.50).

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 a net income of $22,335,103 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges. The net was equal, after preferred dividend charges,

The need for a well-worked-out and practical credit plan for reciprocal commerce was stressed last night for furtherance of trade with Latin America by Jorge Gosalvez, Consul General of Bolivia, who spoke before more than 400 members of the Foreign Commerce Club at the Hotel Astor.

Felix Lilienthal Co., Inc., resident buying office, has closed sample rooms on the thirteenth floor at 119 West Fortieth Street because of preparation for moving to 50 West Thirty-fifth Street. Salesmen will be seen on the fourteenth floor. The concern expects to be in the new quarters by Dec. 1.

A direct demand that the trial of Harry Bridges on charges that he was an "undesirable alien" and subject to deportation because of his activities in this country proceed without delay has been made by Stephen F. Chadwick, national commander of the American Legion, in a communication addressed to Miss Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Dowd, daughter of Thomas Anthony Dowd of Livingston and the late Mrs. Dowd, was married here this morning in St. John's Church to Benjamin Raymond Geraghty of Jersey City by the Rev. Boniface McConville of Winsted, Conn.

A client of Harold M. Silverman, broker, has purchased from the trustees of Bronx Certificated Mortgages, a certificate issue of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, the one-story taxpayer at 3,125-31-9 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.

In several of his campaign speeches, and notably at Albany, Mr. Dewey charged the O'Connell Democratic machine of Albany County with political corruption, fraudulent registration of voters and other violations of the election and penal laws. For several weeks Attorney General Bennett and his assistants have carried on an investigation,

Independent tire retailers are suffering from the "unfair" competition of the chain stores operated by the leading tire companies, George J. Burger, secretary and general manager of the National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, Inc., asserted here yesterday. Mr.
Local committees of the Popular Front held a special meeting today with a view to protesting anti-Jewish activities in Germany. Resolutions were adopted providing for the following:

The most impressive moment of the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, and the finest interpretation of the evening, was that of the "Liebestod" from Wagner's "Tristan," performed at the beginning of the concert in memory of Clarence Mackay,

Chinese guerrillas on Sunday recaptured Taierhchwang in Southern Shantung Province, the scene of the first important Chinese victory in the war, according to official Chinese news reports from Lovang.

Coach Mal Stevens decided yesterday to follow the precedent he established last year and allow his New York University football palyers to choose the starting line-up for the meeting with Fordham at the Yankee Stadium Nov. 26.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was under Chancery Court order today to defend a suit by which the Howard-Vaughan Company, Inc., of Buffalo, N. Y., seeks to collect the profits from the formula for ethyl gasoline.

A number of leases for store quarters in buildings in scattered sections of the city .marked the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Among those said to have leased such space was the Lustra Sales Distributing Company, Inc.,

Eight hundred and fifty-seven tins of smoking opium, with a wholesale value estimated officially at $255,000, fell into the hands of customs agents yesterday afternoon aboard the British ship Silveryew, docked at the foot of Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, after a search that had lasted since Sunday.
The annual general meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union will be held at the Harvard Club at 4 P. M. Friday, Jan. 6, it was announced yesterday by Philip J. Roosevelt, president.
Aiming to make its spasmadocally powerful attack more consistent, Columbia drilled at top speed at Baker Field yesterday, with the timing of the intricate aerial and running plays carefully checked.

The new German demands for territory, presented to Slovakia, seem likely to be fulfilled. These demands concern territory that before the war never belonged to Germany but to Hungary--the old Slovak town of Theben, on the Czechslovak bank of the Danube north of Bratislava;
A new scholarship for graduate study at Wheaton College, which is to be offered alternately to the Departments of Romance Languages and Classics will be sponsored by Dr. Helen W. Cole.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Stiles McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mason Murray McDonald of New York, to Edwin Russell Maslen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robert Maslen, also of this city, took place last night in the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church.
The National Motor Truck Show; which ends today in Commerce Hall, may be held in Chicago next year, it was announcede yesterday. by John F. Winchester, president of the show corporation.

E. C. Baltz of Washington, president ot the United States Building and Loan League, said today that unless persons with incomes of less than $3,000 a year could own their homes, the future of all private ownership was threatened.

Speculative operations in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here were somewhat larger today. Prices declined 1/2 to 3/4 cent in the early trading in sympathy with Liverpool, and easiness in securities, only to rally later on short covering, and closing trades were unchanged to 1/4 cent lower, the latter on the December.

The Soviet desire for closer relations between the United States and the Union.of Soviet Socialist Republics is the theme of cordial commentaries on Soviet-American relations in the official press today on the fifth anniversary the American recognition of the government.

Realizing that its ground attack will meet ample resistance from the heavy West Virginia line at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday, Manhattan prepared an aerial attack in a ninety-minute drill yesterday.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the Girl Scout Federation, and other directors of that or- a ganization are sponsoring a benefit' performance of the opera "Tannhauser" for the afternoon of Dec. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The United States had under construetion, as of Nov. 1, naval combatant vessels and auxiliaries of a total tonnage of about 400,000. Included were six battleships of a total tonnage of 210,000.

Miss Cecilia Razovsky, director of the National Coordinating Committee for Aid to Refugees and Emigrants Coming from Germany, said yesterday that her statement, reported in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES, that it was not safe for American relatives of German Jews to send money to Germany applied only to requests for unusually large sums. In this case, she said, organizations here should first be consulted.

With forward passing stressed in practice this week, indications are that Lehigh bases its hope of victory against Lafayette on aerials. There was -a defensive scrimmage against freshmen and jayvees using Leopard plays today,

Denunciation of anti-Jewish violence in Germany was voiced today in a formal resolution by Governor Charles F. Hurley and his Executive Council, at mass meetings of students of Harvard and other Greater Boston colleges, and at an assembly of more than 500 women church workers in St. Paul's Cathedral.

The old Indian on the nickel has started to lead his buffalo down the long trail of oblivion, retreating in this city before an invasion of several million bright and shining Jefferson nickels from the Philadelphia Mint. The new coin has all the virtues of the old one except familiarity.

The English Speaking Union last night gave a dinner in the Plaza Hotel in honor of Godfrey Haggard, newly arrived British Consul General in New York. John W. Davis, president of the English Speaking Union of the United States, presided and assured Mr. Haggard of his "hearty and cordial welcome."

Army's plebes braced in the fourth period of a hard-fought game with the Fordham freshman eleven today and rallied to win by a 20-to-16 score in a game that was all but lost. The battle was started in Michie Stadium, but was finished under flood lights on adjoining Howze Field.
Queen Maud of Norway, sister of the late King George V of Great Britain, underwent an abdominal operation today. Tonight there was anxiety because of her age. She will be 69 Nov. 26.

BEAUCHAMP--William Lygon, K . G., the 7th Earl, on 14th November. Funeral service at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall St., at 3:30, Thursday, 17th November Burial at Madresfield, England, 25th November. BERLS--On Nov. 16. 1938, Magdalena, widow of Robert Beris. Funeral private. BUCK--Fred E., devoted brother of Mrs. Mary H. Norden and August Buck. Services at the residence 616 Riess Place, Bronx, Thursday, 8:30 P. M.
The Catholic daily Italia of Milan has published the text of a sermon by Alfred Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, in which he denounced "so-called racism" as an "international danger."

The stock market here had a more cheerful tone today, attributed mainly to the imminence of an Anglo-American trade pact, but business still was slack. The decline of gilt-edge securities was checked and a general rise took place.

The foreign exchange market was nervous again yesterday, but the trading was considerably under that of previous days. While the pound sterling showed a loss, it held above the previous low and closed at $4.69 7/8, off 5/8 cent.

Secretary Perkins tonight appointed four arbiters on the Pacific Coast to adjudicate any disputes which may arise between longshoremen and employers under the agreement recently signed, which covers about 18,000 workers and runs until Sept. 30, 1939.

German office appliances, sent to Mexico in exchange for oil taken from expropriated American and other foreign wells, are crowding competitive American products from 75 per cent of their former market there, manufacturers of typewriters, adding machines and similar goods complained here yesterday.
Estate, less than $10,000. To John C. Bryant, 4,406 Newport St., Richmond, Va.; Gladys B. Lord, 1,302 E. Capitol St.. Washington, D. C., one-half each. Henry M. Stevenson. 45 Park Ave.. executor.

Three options for 50,000 shares of Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation common stock at 75 cents a share were injected yesterday into the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop-order proceedings against that company.

John Howell Lewis, retired assistant secretary of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died yesterday in his home here. He was 64 years old. Mr. Lewis was born in Canada, but came to the United States in 1896 and was a naturalized American citizen.

Dartmouth College made a gallant gesture toward the jayvee team to day when it was announced by the athletic council that Richard S. Jackson of Plandome, N. Y., would be taken to California with the varsity for the Stanford game Nov. 26.

Amendment to Official Action Guide The Official Action Guide is amended by adding the following new section: Sec. 32-44--Company commanders shall see that a sufficient quantity of blank application forms for permits and certificates is kept always on hand.

The Algonquin Hotel Company, 59 West Forty-fourth Street, obtained a judgment in City Court yesterday against William T. Tilden 2d, former tennis champion, for $2,329 on a claim for unpaid rent. The rent due amounted to $2,045, but interest and court costs brought the total to the amount of the judgment.

At a meeting yesterday of the board of the International Salt Company directors authorized an extra dividend of 50 cents a share to common stockholders in addition to the regular quarterly of 37 1/2 cents.
An exhibition of oils, water-colors and prints by members of the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation opens today in the Academy Room at the Fine Arts Building.

Fifty faculty members of the University of Puerto Rico today cabled an appeal to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, to take the lead in the formation of an association of universities of the Western Hemisphere "for the defense of civilization's humane standards against the brutal aggression the German Government has displayed in its conduct toward Jewish citizens."
Formation of the first collegiate unit of the American Red Cross by students of New York University was announced yesterday. Major Gen. Robert C. Davis,

The Colgate football schedule for 1939 was completed today with the announcement by William A. Reid, director of athletics, that St. Lawrence had been booked for an open date Oct. 21. Seven other contests had been scheduled previously.

The appointment of ninety-seven men and women to the instructional staffs of New York University was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase. Included in the additions to the faculty were a new chairman of the department of speech and dramatics in the University College of Arts and Pure Science. and two distinguished foreign scholars to the College of Medicine and the Graduate School of Arts and Science.

Mrs. Bernhardt.Wall, wife of the etcher, died here last night the home of her brother, William A. Hunter. She was 70 years old. Mrs. Wall was on her way to Houston with her husband from their home in Lime Rock, Conn.
Dr. Joao Antonio de Bianchi, Portuguese Minister to the United States, and Mrs. de Bianchi, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Marguery. Among their guests were

Lord Tweedsmuir, who writes books as John Buchan, now says he has written too many. The record credits him with more than fifty, of which the first book was published at the age of 21. Since the Governor General of Canada is now 63,

The North and South will meet on the gridiron Jan. 2. Mayor William A. Gunter announced tonight teams would be selected from either side of the Mason and Dixon line, professionals or seniors whose college playing days were over, for a game "which will be different."

A net profit of $1,352,893 was reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year by the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries, after deductions for depreciation, interest, amortization of experimental expenses, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges.
Laura Krey's best-selling novel, "And Tell of Time" (Houghton Mifflin), is to be published soon in Germany by Hyperion Verlag of Berlin and in Denmark by P. Haase of Copenhagen.

Dean Edward L. Moreland of the Engineering Department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, today that the highest possible gross annual revenues from the sale of electric power by TVA when it is completed and operating at full capacity, probably some time after 1946,

Looking out upon "Tomorrow Town" from the shelter zone of the World's Fair grounds, the Johns-Manville Exhibit Building was dedicated there yesterday. A feature of the occasion was the announcement by Lewis H. Brown, president of the corporation, that it would open three new plants expected to give work to 1,000 persons between now and early next year.

The plan of reorganization for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation will have to be revised because of provisions of the new Wages and Hours Law, Eustace Seligman, representing two bondholders' committees, indicated yesterday when he asked for adjournment of a scheduled hearing on the Plan before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

If New York City paid all its bills every year out of current revenue it would need only one budget--an expense budget. Since it actually spreads the cost of many permanent improvements over a period of years, it keeps an additional set of books--the capital budget.

Miss Sally Pierce, daughter of Major and Mrs. Stephen Franklin Pierce of Toms River, N. J., and great-greatgrandniece of President Franklin Pierce, was married tonight to David Brown,. son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Brown, at the home of the bridegroom's parents. The Rev. Andrew W. Keener officiated.
THE AGE OF REFORM, 1815-1870, by E. L. Woodward. (Oxford University Press, $6.) The thirteenth volume in the Oxford History of England.
The Professional Golfers Association decided today that all past P. G. A. champions in good standing shall be allowed to compete in its national championship without qualifying.

Percentages by which the Republican and Democratic parties shared the major party vote in twenty-four States for the years 1938, 1936 and 1934; based for 1938 on unofficial returns from Congressional or-Gubernatorial races; for 1936 on the Presidential vote, and for -1934 on the -vote for Representatives by- districts are as follows:
Brooklyn Cathedral Prep rallied in the closing minutes to defeat New York Cathedral Prep, 36 to 32, in their annual basketball game on the victors' court yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Peoples Light Company for approval of its acquisition for an estimated cash price of $346,700 of all of the electric utility assets
Storming around the Irish goal for virtually the entire game, England trimphed, 7-0, over Ireland in an international soccer match before 40,000 spectators at Old Trafford today.

The logically essential course to the balancing of the Federal budget lies in a compromise between reduction of expenditures and substantial increases in taxes, according to Roswell Magill, Professor in the School of Law at Columbia University and former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, who addressed the Municipal Bond Club of New York at a luncheon at the Bankers Club yesterday.

Contributions to the fund for the construction of the Temple of Religion at the New York World's Fair have reached $67,500, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon of the women's division of the cam- been paign in the Hotel Astor.

A memorial mass for Cardinal Hayes will be celebrated under the auspices of the Ladies of Catholic Charity Saturday morning at 9 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The mass will be offered at the Holy Family Altar. The Cardinal was the honorary president of the organization. All the members have been requested to receive holy communion. The invitations were signed by Lady Armstrong, the chairman, and the Rev. Vincent J. Brosman, the Moderator.

Joseph Buerckel, commissioner for Austria, announced today that Field Marshal Hermann Goering had authorized him to say that the person "who makes the next attempt to smash property or to pillage must count on being put against the wall." He made the threat of shooting in referring to anti-Jewish attacks in an address to factory workers in Steyr.

The ideal university is a Catholic university because it is a spiritual as well as an intellectual center, Dr. Francis M. Crowley, dean of the School of Education at Fordham University, said last night at the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the United States Catholic Historical Society at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

Senator Albert J. Brown, lawyer and Representative of Wellington in Parliament since 1932, died here early tonight at the age of 77. Mr. Brown was a native of Windsor, Que. Besides being head of the legal firm of Brown, Montgomery McMichael here,

Miss Mildred Blackney, a city nurse in Ward CI-E of the CancerNeurological Hospital on Welfare Island, shocked members of the Board of Estimate yesterday by describing the institution as verminridden.

If New York City paid all its bills every year out of current revenue it would need only one budget--an expense budget. Since it actually spreads the cost of many permanent improvements over a period of years, it keeps an additional set of books--the capital budget.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, and Dr. Frank B. Jewett, president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, will be among the speakers to address the annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Dec. 1 and 2.
Acting under the procedure set up recently, the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday to remove three closely held securities from its list. They are the common stock

Although a committee appointed by Governor Lehman is still trying to restore service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, which has been closed since January, employes of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad began today to tear up the rails of the New Rochelle-Port Chester spur which the line had used under a lease.

It was increasingly evident yesterday at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace that the percentage of buyers among show visitors has been larger than in any other recent year. No attendance records were broken during the first three days, but the evening crowds on Monday and Tuesday night were heavier than had been expected and this interest continued last night. Today and tomorrow will be the last days of the show.
A new method of healing broken necks by boring holes in the skull and attaching wires through them to pull the head up was described today before the Southern Medical Association.

Listing of 393,372 additional shares of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey capital stock has been approved by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange. The issue is being made in connection with the stock dividend recently voted which gives three shares to holders for each 200.

Donat J. Levesque, Mayor of Lewiston, was indicted today on a charge of accepting a bribe in connection with the appointment of a municipal health officer. He pleaded innocent and was released on $5,000 bail for appearance Monday.

Harvard and Yale stand on the edge of the renewal of one of the game's oldest rivalries. Each will finish the hard work for the season today, and Harvard, tomorrow, will head for New Haven and the scene of action.

Many high school students rack even the rudimentary knowledge of sex information, various speakers declared yesterday at a meeting of the Institute of the Child Study Association of America at the Hotel Roosevelt. Peculiar notions about sex are prevalent indicating a lack of training in the home and in the school. it was held.

The Public Utility Commission of Pennsylvania in effect was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to permit rail carriers in Pennsylvania to raise their freight rates for anthracite coal to the level prescribed by- the I. C. C. in its so-called 15 per cent case, in which it recently granted a general increase in rates to railroads.

Rear Admiral James H. Dayton, U. S. N., retired, died last night in his home here where for nineteen allyears he had lived virtually as a recluse. He had been ill for several months. His age was 92. Born in South Bend, Oct. 25, 1846, Admiral Dayton was appointed to the United States Naval Academy in 1862.
Army defeated Massachusetts Institute of Technology in a well-played soccer game today, 4-2. Dessert and Odom starred for the cadets, scoring all of Army's goals between them.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Nov. 15:

A report on the balance of international payments for the first half of 1938, issued today by the Department of Commerce, showed for that period a greater increase in the merchandise exports balance, compared with 1937, than for any other year since 1921.

A provision in a liquor license making the proprietor of a rural inn subject to the special condition that he would not operate a "Fancist, Communist or Nazi camp or bund on the premises" was overruled today by D. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey Alcoholio Beverage Commissioner. "in the name of tolerance."

I. A. Benediktoff, formerly Vice Commissar of Agriculture, today was named Commissar in succession to Robert Eikhe, whose removal was persistently rumored months ago but until now was not officially confirmed.

Oliver H. Payne of the law firm of DeForest, Cullom Elder was elected chairman of the board of the Kirkham Engineering and Manufacturing Corporation, Charles B. Kirkham, president, announced yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting in Farmingdale, L. I. Raymond V. V. Miller of Robinson,
Smithsonian Institution scientists are trying to shape a picture of the civilization of a long-headed, shortstatured race of Indians who lived along the lower Missouri River many centuries ago.

Samuel G. Rea, vice president of E. the Standard Railway Equipment Company, 247 Park Avenue, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his residence, 151 East Seventy-ninth Street. He was born in Marietta, Ohio.
Miss Edith English gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy.

A card party for the benefit of the Walter Scott Free Industrial t School and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children will be held on Tuesday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Kingsboro Mortgage Corporation, as principal, has made building loans totaling $550,000 in Brooklyn as follows: On the six-story apartment under construction on the northeast corner of Falmouth Street and Hampton Avenue to the C. F. L. Realty Corporation, Morris Leichter, president; $120,000; to the Tehama Building Corporation,

The home of Herman Von Busch, Essex County leader of the GermanAmerican Bund, was stoned about 11 o'clock tonight by persons who are believed to have thrown the missiles from an automobile or to have jumped into a machine afterward. Police found no trace of them.

Mrs. Charles Thaddeus Terry of 850 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beatrice Terry, to A. Broughton Avent, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Avent of Seaton, Devonshire, England.

Republicans were urged yesterday by Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel in Mayor La Guardia's first term, to undertake at once a revision of the State Labor Relations Act in order to separate the judicial and prosecution functions of the State Labor Board.
Joining the parade of Ambassadors to Washington, William C. Built, United States Ambassador to France, will leave for Port Washington, L. I., on the Bermuda Clip per tomorrow.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due today from Europe. Among the passengers are William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy; Viscount and Viscountess Knollys, Sir Keith Price, Baroness Pauline Garibaldi, Lieut. Col. G. P. Pollitt, Eugene Goossens and Herbert L. May.
THE AMIERICAN THEATRE, by John Anderson. (Dial, $5.) An illustrated history of the American stage.

More than 150 representatives of the food and drug industries met today with officials of the Department of Agriculture to make preliminary studies of projected regulations under the new Food and Drug Act which will become operative next June.

Colonel Daniel Lane Howell, retired United States Army officer, who fought in campaigns against the Indians, took part in the Spanish-American War and served in the Philippines and on the Mexican border, died yesterday in Walter Reed Hospital, Washington, after a long illness. He was 85 years old.
William Swan McLean, soldier and jurist, died at his country estate on the North Mountain today after a prolonged illness. He was 61 years old.

Mrs. Constance Dessar Spiegelberg of this city, widow of James E. Spiegelbarg, and daughter of the late Judge and Mrs. Leo Charles Dessar, was married here last night to Abraham Baer. The ceremony was performed at Mr. Baer's home, 941 Park Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. B. Benedict Glazer.

The 1938 Nobel Peace Prize of about $30,000 was awarded today to the Nansen International Office for Refugees at Geneva, an organization that collects information on the material and moral welfare of refugees and gives general directions to relief institutions.

Mrs. Bessie Wiesen, for many years a welfare worker in New York, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 73. Mrs. Wiesen, who lived at 680 West End Avenue, was the widow of Elias Wiesen, who died twenty-nine years ago.
Hormone treatments which restore the minds and bodies of many sub-normal children were reported today to the Southern Medical Association.

Ernst vom Rath, the third secretary at the German Embassy in Paris, whose murder by a young Polish Jew unloosed the most far-reaching antiSemitic outbreak of modern times, was buried at Duesseldorf today following state funeral services attended by Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop and many other representatives of the National Socialist party and State.
Albany's Democratic administration, assailed by Thomas. E. Dewey as "a ruthless political monopoly," was the target today of two requests for a legislative investigation.

James D. Francis, president of the Island Creek Coal Company, announced today that it had acquired a "substantial majority" of the stock of the Carnegie Coal Corporation, a Pennsylvania corporation, owning the Carnegie Dock and Fuel Company, which has docks at Duluth, Minn., and Superior, Wis.

Mrs. Mina Louise Mann, wife of Dr. Frederick J. Mann, died of a heart attack at her home yesterday at the age of 65. Born in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., she attended Vassar College and kept up an interest in art throughout her life. She was active in church and garden work.

Mrs. Anne Hollifield Briggs, wife of Frankland B. Briggs, the vice president and gene al counsel of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, died yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital, New York City. The Briggs home is at 560 Mt. Prospect Avenue, Newark, N. J.

54th St. 19 W; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co to 25 W 54th St Corp, 22 W 48th St ($110). 64th St, 144 W; A. Broida, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp, foreclosure. 109th St, 58 W; Rodney Realty Co to 720 West 172d St Corp, 110 W 424 St; mtg $30,423 ($5.50).

The Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop maintained for charitable enterprises, will celebrate its tenth anniversary with a tin shower on Tuesday afternoon at the headquarters of the shop, 1,175 Third Avenue.
Coach Carl Snavely of Cornell University announced tonight he had declined an invitation for the Cornell football team to play Santa Clara in the Los Angeles Coliseum on New Year's Day.
Judgment for $843,283 was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office in favor of Central American Mines, Inc., and against the company's subsidiary, Compania Minera del Divisadero Sociedad Anonima.

The report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges of $3,916,114.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain revealed to the House of Commons today that the former German colony of Tanganyika was being considered among the places where Jews might find a refuge from persecution in Germany.

The first for this season of the Starlight dinner dances, a series of subscription parties under the direction of Miss Jessie Fanshawe, took place last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Economists of the National Industrial Conference Board, asserting that the $500,000 Government Monopoly. Investigating Committee "could not give a rounded picture of American business," said today that they would conduct an independent study of business enterprise during the next two years.
The most powerful Diesel-electric locomotive in the world left the plant of the Electro-Motive Corporation at La Grange, Ill., today for delivery to the Seaboard Air Line.

G. M. Wolkenberg, Inc., brokers, have arranged mortgages on two groups of dwellings in the Bronx as follows: $28,000 on the five one-family houses on Kingsland and Mace Avenues, for John Faley; and $41,000 for the Schapowal Construction Company on six one-family homes on Waring and Woodhull Avenues.

The Division of Simplified Practice of the National Bureau of Standards has announced that Simplified Practice Recommendation R 53-32, steel reinforcing spirals, has been reviewed by the sponsoring organization, the Concrete Reinforcing Steel Institute, and reaffirmed without change.

A prayer jointly composed by a Protestant clergyman and a rabbi, "for the victims of racial and religious oppression," will be offered tomorrow in thousands of synagogues and Sunday in thousands of churches all over the United States. Tomorrow and Sunday have each been designated as a "Day of Prayer for the Oppressed."

With Lenny Jordan and Irv Roth, varsity fullbacks, nursing leg injuries, Coach Lou Oshins made several experiments in his Brooklyn College backfield yesterday during a dummy scrimmage for the home game with Susquehanna tomorrow.

Charles A. Harnett resigned today from his post as State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, twenty-four hours after he had pleaded not guilty to charges of accepting $67,000 in bribes from taxicab companies.

The week's volume of $58,780,000 in engineering construction awards is 69 per cent above the $34,753,000 reported in 1937, and raises the cumulative total for the year to date to $2,402,711,000, or 10.9 per cent more than for the same period of last year, The Engineering News Record reports.

The New York Steam Corporation's first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1963 and Scott Paper's $4.50 dividend no-par preferred shares will be admitted today to the list by the New York Stock Exchange.

During the week ended Nov. 16 member bank reserve balances increased $181,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $32,000,000 in money in circulation, $34,000,000 in ..Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $16,000,000 in Treasury cash, and $6,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and increases of $71,000,000 in gold stock and $21,000,000 in Reserve bank credit.

Herb Kopf, Manhattan football coach, will have a team ready for West Virginia at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow that has survived a series of setbacks and injuries. One of the chief Jasper threats will be John Supulski, who has been gaining speed in practice during the past two weeks and has successfully graduated from the "one-legged" stage.

Mrs. Sarah Corelia Palmer Adelman, wife of Henry Adelman, one of the oldest residents of Old Greenwich, died today at her home, 11 West End Avenue, following a long illness. She would have been 81 years old on Nov. 25.
The creation of a permanent committee to facilitate the return of Italians residing abroad was announced today.

Controller James Hushion of Yonkers, N. Y., announced yesterday that the Common Council has authorized him to borrow $1,000,000 on short-term paper, the proceeds if which will be used to pay part of the Westchester County taxes for 1938 owed by the city and for meeting city operating expenses.
Sir James Barr, vice president of the British Medical Association and a lifelong crusader for the reform of English prisons, died Wednesday at the age of 89.

Through a confusion in figures, it was erroneously reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that direct investments by Americans in Germany at the end of 1937 totaled $228,000,000 compared to German investments in this country of $365,000,000.

The new Anglo-American trade agreement is warmly welcomed not only because of its stimulus to British exports but because it is believed here that the compact will do much to strengthen the ties of friendship between Great Britain and the United States.

Mrs. Nat S. Brown, Democratic National Committeewoman from Missouri and a leader in civic and charitable organizations for more than twenty years, died of pneumonia early today in her home. She was 67 years old.
After running second in two previous starts here, the Cosgrave Stable's Bob's Boys today won the featured What Cheer Handicap at Narraganesett Park.

Valhalla, a little unincorporated village of great name beside Bronx River Parkway Extension, complains that it is "a forgotten village." Trees and a wilderness of shrubs hide it from the motorists humming along the parkway.
Typographical errors and misplaced commas caused yesterday an unexpected delay in the passage of the new constitution of the New York Curb Exchange.

"Footsteps in the Dark," by Ladislau Fodor, was announced today by Warners as Edward G. Robinson's next vehicle. It is the story of a lawyer who dabbles in mystery writing, and is said to be on the order of "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse."

Total national lumber stocks at the mills on Oct. 1 were about 8,560,000,000 feet, as compared with 8,430,000,000 feet on Oct. 1, 1937, 9,000,000,000 feet on Jan. 1, 1938, and 8,672,000,000 feet on July 1, 1938, the Lumber Survey Committee reported today to the Department of Commerce. Stocks declined 4.5 per cent in the first nine months of 1937 and 1.3 per cent from July 1 to Oct. 1.

Guenther Gustav Rumrich, star witness in the government's case against two men and a woman accused of espionage, testified yesterday when recalled for further cross-examination that he was fond of romancing and not unfamiliar with the uses of marijuana.
A point not mentioned in either the British or the Canadian trade agreements is expected officially to prove one of the most important factors of both.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 15: COMMANDER Gilmore, W. W., Norfolk, Va., Naval Operating Base. to Norfolk Navy Yard.

Dr. Paul von Schwabach, senior partner of the internationally known private banking house of S. Bleichroeder of Berlin, died Wednesday night of a heart ailment at his Berlin home, it was announced here yesterday by S. Bleichroeder New York, Inc., at the firm's offices, 25 Broad Street. He was 72 years old.

The fastskating, hard-checking New York Rangers handed the Black Hawks their first defeat of the season tonight and remained the National Hockey League's only unbeaten member by scoring a rousing 1-to-0 triumph before a crowd of 12,404.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, replying to an appeal from the University of Puerto Rico, declared yesterday that he would do "everything which is practicable to make plain to the whole world the sense of horror and grief with which all Americans regard the cruel and barbaric treatment of Catholics and Jews now going on in Germany."

St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, was named residuary legatee and two charitable institutions and a church were among the other legatees in the will of Mrs. Annabella Curtis filed in the Surrogates' Court yesterday. Mrs. Curtis died Oct. 31, last. was the widow of Dr. B.

Another round in Great Britain's "miniature general elections" was decided today when the Labor party succeeded in holding its parliamentary seat in the big coal-mining and railway center of Doncaster in Yorkshire.

Eleven Republican candidates defeated for State offices and Raymond E. Willis, beaten for United States Senator, charged fraud and error today in last week's election and planned to broaden their movement for a recount from 5 to 21 of Indiana's 92 counties.

Gerard Ave, 1,229-31 (9-2489), Julius Lewy to Winfred M. Stern, 25 Ft Washington Ave. Gerard Ave, 1,227 (9-2489), Julius Lewy to Winfred M. Stern, 25 Ft Washington Ave. Fox St (10-2707), w s, 200 ft s of 156th St, 100x100, Gli-Sol Realty Corp to H F Equities, Inc, 349 E 149th St.

The unrivaled Boston Symphony Orchestra, with Serge Koussevitzky, the conductor whose catholicity of taste and brilliancy as leader have made that orchestra what it is today, gave its first New York concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall before an audience which packed the house and comprised the musically elect of the city.

Grover Whalen, without the flower he usually wears in his lapel, went to James Monroe High School yesterday to accept an award from the student body for his "distinguished contributions to the cause of world peace." But he failed as a diplomat and was roundly booed by 1,500 students.

Felicitations on the signing of the United Kingdom reciprocal trade agreement were exchanged today among Lord Halifax, British Foreign' Secretary; Oliver Stanley, President of the British Board of Trade, and Secretary Hull.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

As a result of the drastically curtailed capital outlay budget allotted to the Board of Education, the New York City school building program will be paralyzed and the building bureau may be disbanded, school officials declared yesterday.
Small tenements and private dwellings made up the bulk of properties figuring in Manhattan realty trading yesterday. Several of the purchases were made by investors.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sails today for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Southampton. Among her passengers are Lord Perry, Lady Moira, John Bigham, Sir Malcolm Campbell, Lady Edward Gleichen, Viscountess Mersey, Lady Norton-Griffiths, Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, Henry Oscar, Lieut. Col.

In the twelve-months ended Aug. 31, Canadian imports of glycerine in all forms totaled 3,121,429 pounds, valued at $416,583, against 2,750,245 pounds, valued at $487,102, imported in the twelve-month period ending Aug. 31, 1937, the Commerce Department reports.
Not only are automobile sales sharply higher here, but the shifts in positions of the various makes are reflecting a significant improvement in general buying power.
Treasury figures disclosed today that the public debt had reached a new high record of $38,527,824,089 on Nov. 15, an increase of $1,363,083,774 since July 1.

According to K. M. Schaefer, general sales manager of the Federal Motor Truck Company, domestic and Canadian orders for October were 8 per cent better than September and indicate a good start for the final quarter.
Lord Chalmers, a distinguished civil servant and colonial administrator who after retirement became master of Peterhouse, Cambridge. died today at Oxford at the age of 80.

Testimony at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing into the affairs of the Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation brought yesterday a partial answer to the question that Ralph T. McElvenny of counsel for the commission had been asking since the stop-order proceedings started.

Linking all the Latin-American capitals in a continent-wide aviation network for the first time, a northbound Pan American-Grace Airways plane left here this morning on a regular schedule and will reach Quito, the capital of Ecuador, Saturday morning.

The "misplaced ingenuity" expended in devising bookkeeping schemes for juggling purported regular hourly rates, by which employers hope to be able to work men in excess of forty-four hours weekly without increasing their total wages, not only is dangerous legal practice, but should be considered in the light of its possible effect upon Congress, business was warned today by George A. McNulty.
Miss Nancy Newbold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fleming Newbold, was married here today to John Morris Legendre, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Gilbert Legendre of New Orleans.

Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Middleweight title bout. fifteen rounds, Fred Apostoll vs. Young Corbett 3d. First bout ........8:15 P. M. Broadway Arena, Halsey Street near Broadway, Brooklyn. Amateur bouts. 8:30 P. M.

Statistics issued here this week by the London Employers Association regarding the imports of women's and girls' apparel into Great Britain for the first nine months of this year showed that Germany and Austria are sending less of this merchandise and that the United States and France are, to a certain extent, making up the deficiency. The comparative figures for that period are:

Two severe earthquakes, which must have caused serious damage if they occurred on land, were recorded here late Wednesday night, the Rev. Joseph Lynch, director of the observatory at Fordham University, said yesterday.

10:30-10:45 A. M.-From Geneva: Judge Michael Hanson, Head, Nansen Refugee Bureau, Discussing the Bureau's Work-WJZ. 2:00-3: 00 P. M.-Music Appreciation Hour; Dr. Walter Damrosch-WJZ. 3:00-4;00 P. M.-National University Extension Debate: "United States Should Establish an Alliance With Great Britain," Dr. Pennington Haile of League of Nations Association; John T. Flynn, President Board of Higher Education. and Others-WJZ.

Directors of Loew's, Inc., authorized yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents, in addition to the. regular quarterly distribution of 50 cents, on the common stock. Including these dividends, disbursements for 1938 total $3 a share.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $2,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to pay taxes due on Dec. 1.

Corporations maintaining "paper" offices in New Jersey are "leaving the State in droves" because "certain municipalities keep scaring them out with personal property demands," J. H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, said today in proposing that miscellaneous corporation taxes be reduced to prevent further loss of revenue.

The fog hung heavy over the navy yard in Brooklyn and the driving rain added to the poor visibility at 6 o'clock yesterday morning when Andrew Rose, taxicab driver, was blindly plowing his way through the yard's streets with Second Class Fireman Bruce Albertson of the destroyer Manley as a passenger.

William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, returned yesterday on the Queen Mary for his first visit in a year. He said his trip was "purely personal" and that he was going to Boston to attend the funeral of his brother, John C. Phillips.

Harry L. Brown, assistant secretary of agriculture, said today a "vigorous effort" would be made by the next Congress "to substitute another act for the Agricultural Adjustment Act, or to drastically amend the present legislation."

Announcement has been made of the engagement and forthcoming marriage of Baroness Militza von Goertz of 19 East Ninety-eighth Street, daughter of Baroness Anna von Goertz, also of this city, and the late Colonel Vladimir von Goertz of the former Imperial Russian Army, to Wilhelm Meyerweissflog of Zurich, Switzerland.

At the conclusion of the first half of the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament, the scene of action was shifted to this city for the eighth round, where four games were contested tonight at the Tivoli Restaurant.

The investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn, regarded as the most sweeping inquiry of its kind ever authorized in the history of the State, got under way yesterday with the selection of five members of the extraordinary grand jury which will hear evidence and the dramatic arrest of a prospective juror on a charge of perjury for denying that he had been convicted of shoplifting fifteen years ago.

An exhibition of paintings by contemporary American artists has been assembled for the opening today of the new Sutton Gallery, 358 East Fifty-seventh Street. Work by Anne Goldthwaite, Grace Swank, Mark S. Jaffe, Lawrence Lebduska, Raphael Soyer and Nathan Hoffman will be shown through Nov. 30.
The American textile industry, employing about 1,300,000 workers is the most important field affected by concessions in the trade agreement negotiated today with the United Kingdom.

Former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg probably will not be tried, after all, an official spokesman said today. Thus far no preparations have been made for such a trial, he added. Rumors that a jury had already been appointed were categorically denied. Not even a bill of indictment has been prepared, nor has Dr. Schuschnigg been examined.

The opening of the raw fur season has been featured by advances on mink and a rise of about 12 1/2 per cent on muskrats suitable for mink dyeing, according to a report prepared yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by J. D. Silberman of the Silberman Fur Corporation of this city. A larger supply of skunk than a year ago is holding down prices on that fur.

Experts from the Reich Chamber of Culture, accompanied by members of the Secret Police, today made a tour of homes of former wealthy Jews and removed works of art. They were taken in trucks to the National Museum here.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Lee of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lee, to Charles W. Goulding of Culver, Ind., son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Goulding of Providence, R. I. The wedding will take place on Dec. 24.
Homer S. Cummings, who will retire in January from the post of Attorney General, described his five and one-half years' association with President Roosevelt today as "perfect and beautiful."

Grand Concourse, 3,224 (12-3323): Maffer Realty Corp to Jacob R. Schiff, 575 Park Ave: $25,000. Muliner Ave, 2,026 (15-4295); Adolph Katz to Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn. 441 Lexington Ave; installments, 5 per cent; $10,500.

Accelerated buying of automobiles is indicated in retail delivery reports for the first ten days of November received by the Packard Motor Car Company, according to M. M. Gilman, vice president and general manager.

Miss Rosemary Warburton and Miss Innes Kane Drury will be introduced to society today. Miss Warburton, daughter of Mrs. William Kissam Vanderbilt and the late Barclay H. Warburton Jr., will make her debut at a supper dance

Henry Armstrong, lightweight and welterweight boxing champion of the world, agreed today to defend the latter title at The Cleveland News Christmas fund show Dec. 5. His opponent will be Al Manfredo of Los Angeles.

The formal resolutions on financial questions of the day, always adopted at the close of the American Bankers' annual conventions, avoided yesterday at Houston any sharp attack on the Administration's fiscal policies, present or prospective.

Replying yesterday to criticism of conditions in the city-owned Cancer-Neurological Hospital - on Welfare Island, Mayor La Guardia said that within a short time patients would be removed from the seventy-five-year-old building to a new $7,500,000 hospital on the island, which is now being completed.

Four utility companies have filed applications under the Holding Company Act seeking exemption from the requirement of filing declarations in regard to the issue and sale of an aggregate of $65,250,000 of bonds, $10,000,000 of debentures, $1,375,000 of notes and 5,000 shares of common stock, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Production of crude oil in South America by the International Petroleum Company, Ltd., in October amounted to 2,981,061 barrels, compared with 2,851,708 in September.

Ever since the patent claim on personalized mailing of the Harry Latz Service was upset some months ago, the direct mail field has become embroiled in a battle between advertisers and users of direct mail on one hand and the companies, which specialize in devising unusual or trick mailing devices, on the other.
J. P. Muller, creator of the Muller system of gymnastics, which stressed the importance of daily exercise and became a world cult, Is dead in Aarhus, Denmark, at the age of 73.

A demand that railroad bondholders put the rehabilitation of lines and equipment ahead of their own interest for the time being in order that the government may have security for a loan of $500,000,000 to bring the American railroads up to date was made by Senator Burton K. Wheelers at the conference of the New England council today.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales,- 70 barrels; receipts, 203 barrels; shipments, 350 barrels; stock. 51,740 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 287; receipts, 1,570; shipments, 120: stock, 295,998. Quote: B, D, $4.05; E, $4.25; F, $4.80; G, H, I, K, M, $4.971/2; N, $5.40; WG, $6; WW, X, $6.65.

Irked over repeated delays in getting a small appropriation for work connected with the yacht basins at the World's Fair, Park Commissioner Robert Moses angrily told the Board of Estimate yesterday that he was "through" with the project.

Norman E. Oliver, vice president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., 119 Fifth Avenue, and president of the Hermetite Corporation, Nutley, N. J., died of a heart attack on Wednesday night at his home, 1,016 Fifth Avenue.

Gustave Natapoff, 27, of New York, a graduate student in the Harvard School of Engineering, was drowned late this afternoon while trying an underwater swim in the university pool in the indoor athletic building.

Opposition to a section in the proposed new State insurance code that would prevent life insurance companies from paying dividends on policies after only one year of effectiveness was expressed yesterday by spokesmen for the companies at a hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

The ceremony of signing the reciprocal trade' agreements between this country; Great Britain and Canada was staged in a manner sufficiently impressive to emphasize the great importance American officials attach to them.

Leave of absence for four days, effective on or about Nov. 24, 1938, is granted Major Carter R. McLennan, Cavalry. Major Milton S. Mead Jr., Sig.-Res., 1,410 Regent St., Schenectady, N. Y., is detailed as assistant instructor, for the purpose of correcting Signal Corps Extension School courses, for the Schenectady office of the Albany Military District.

Frank Coyle and Edward Linz of the New York A. C., national A. A. U. champions, last night defeated Sol Goldberg and Harry Haught of the Trinity Club in the semi-final round of the New York A. C. invitation championship handball doubles tournament on the club's courts. The score was 21-3, 21-7.
President Roosevelt's committee of three railroad officials and three rail labor officials began yesterday a series of conferences here to make a thorough Study of the carriers' problems.
Not content with his Victorian biography of last season, Herbert Wilcox has produced a Victorian chronology which he modestly calls "Sixty Glorious Years."

The bottleneck in the Henry Hudson Parkway between 105th and 121st Streets has been satisfactorily eliminated with the opening of the new southbound three-lane road along that stretch, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Chief Inspector James J. Sheehy, in charge of traffic.

Assumption by the State and Federal Governments of half the cost of caring for dependent children in this city has made it possible to increase the child relief fund 80 cent within actual saving to New York City taxpayers, Dr. Paul E. Fusco, executive director of the Board of Child Welfare, disclosed yesterday.
The struggle for the west side of the Ebro River, which lasted more than three months and was one of the most costly episodes of the Spanish war, has ended.

With the adoption of resolutions reaffirming its stand in favor of balanced budgets for Federal, State and other governments and against the extension of branch banking across State lines, the American Bankers Association brought its sixty-fourth annual convention to a close here today.

The State Utilities Commission struck at the Tennessee Electric Power Company today for the second time within a week for what it described as "discrimination" in favor of the Chattanooga Free Press and Chattanooga Home Stores, a grocery chain.

Regaining his best form after two failures at Pimlico, Indomitable, in the Longchamps Farms silks of Henry Lustig, won the fifth race of six furlongs today. This event was the best offering on an ordinary program.

Billy Fiske, driver of American four-man bobsleds to Olympic championships in 1928 and 1932, yesterday announced he would compete for a place on the 1940 team at the final Olympic bobsledding tryouts at Lake Placid on Feb. 10 to 13.
A meteor streaked across the skies or California, Arizona and Utah last night. Here and in Salt Lake City scores of excited residents mistook the meteor for an airplane falling in flames.

Another drop in commercial loans of local banks for the week ended on Wednesday, which brought the total down to the lowest level in several years, was disclosed yesterday in the weekly statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve system in New York City.

Twenty men and women accused of being members of an international ring of narcotic smugglers that supplied Chinatown with large quantities of gum opium and used the-mails to distribute heroin and cocaine to addicts in other parts of the country, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

Professor Philip Drinker of Harvard University said today that the Air Hygiene Foundation of the Mellon Institute had established two graduate fellowships at- Harvard to train men in industrial hygiene.

A. H. Marckwald Jr. of the Short Hills Club paced the field to the quarter-final round in the nineteenth annual Princeton Club squash tennis tournament last night when he conquered Arnold Wood Jr. of the home club, 18-15, 18-15, in a third-round encounter. The match was hard played.

A. P. Giannini, chairman of the board of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, in California, who has been the foremost advocate of nationwide branch banking in this country, declared here today that under present conditions he would not favor extending the branches of his bank across State lines.
Dr. Jane Harriett Walker, who introduced openair treatment of tuberculosis in England, and who was one of the oldest practicing women physicians in this country, died here today at the age of 79.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the threshold of what we sincerely hope is the start of improvement in business should we not subject to far more critical analysis than it has yet received the effect of the extensive use of installment buying on the nation's purchasing power?

Denials of graft and corruption charges against members of the Earle Administration were spread upon the records of the House investigating committee today by more of the accused men, who followed Arthur Colegrove, Public Utility Commissioner, to the Witness stand.

Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, is opposed to the suggestion of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs that the administration of relief should be turned back to the States and that they should conduct their own home and work-relief programs with the aid of Federal grants.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. C. G. Wyckoff of Great Neck, L. I., and this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Wyckoff, to W. Dallas Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Baker of Philadelphia.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 17 unless specified: Acushnet, Mathias Point to Navy Yard, via Quantico, Indian Head. Badger, at Villefranche.

The new Canadian-American trade agreement, according to explanatory material issued here today, is, from the Canadian point of view, "a more comprehensive agreement than the one it replaced and one which provides wider and more favorable export opportunities for both Canada and the United States."

Freddie Apostoli of San Francisco and Young Corbett 3d of Fresno, Calif., will clash tonight in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden for what the New York State Athletic Commission declares is the middleweight championship of the world.
Two New England Governors tonight attacked the trade treaties with Great Britain and Canada.
Detroit crushed the Canadiens, 7 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League contest. Neither team had won a game in four starts previously and both managers made desperate efforts to salvage this one.
Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today he saw a definite need for coordination of the chartering of various kinds of financial institutions.
Winston Churchill, at one point almost breaking down with emotion, failed in the House of Commons tonight to rouse back-bench conservatives in revolt against the government.

The court has ruled that the Messageries Maritimes Steamship Company's 6 per cent Canadian dollar bonds of 1927 will have to be paid in gold according to the gold value content of the Canadian dollar on May 1, 1927.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that the Peruvian Telephone Company, a subsidiary, would provide an extensive speech-translation and public address system for the delegates to the forthcoming Pan American Conference at Lima, Peru.

Two were killed and forty injured following a dispute between strikers and loyal workers in the Titagarh jute mill area, about thirteen miles from Calcutta. Two European police officers were slightly injured.

Exporters, importers and other foreign trade interests yesterday described the, signing of the trade agreement between this country and Great Britain as an "economic victory" in the long struggle toward world recovery and as an event which will have a deep influence on future world trade.

New concessions on $80,000,000 worth of this country's exports to Canada and on $73,000,000 worth of the Dominion's exports to the United States, based on last year's figures, were granted in the trade agreement signed today with the Dominion, according to a summary of the reciprocal trade treaty made public by the State Department.
Secretary Wallace told cotton and tobacco growers today that they must keep their Agricultural Adjustment Administration programs "if you want to save your economic life."

Abraham and Clara Grynszpan, uncle and aunt of the assassin of Ernst vom Rath, third secretary of the Germany Embassy here, quarreled with their nephew, Herschel Grynszpan, on the night before the crime, they told a magistrate today. In despair he had talked of joining the French Foreign Legion and of committing suicide, they said.
Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of the Constitutional Army of Cuba, was the guest of honor yesterday at a "speechless luncheon,"
Prince Paul, chief Regent of Yugoslavia, left here today for a surprise visit to London. The possible political implications of this unexpected royal journey are manifold.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today Henry G. Waltery Jr. of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
Midtown traffic on Sixth Avenue was snarled, about 150 telephones were put out of service and the fire alarm system along Sixth Avenue was endangered soon after 9 A. M.
