President Roosevelt continued to give consideration today to the question of removing Jews from Germany, but in the face of rigid quotas, which were disclosed to have been filled for months to come, there apparently was little hope that this country at present could do other than help finance the movement proposed in London by Ambassador Joseph P.Kennedy.
Harvard today finished a hard four-day drive to put its football team back on its toes after the easy going against Chicago and Virginia.

Coach Ossie Solem sent the Syracuse football squad through its final workout of the season today minus Bill Hoffman, varsity fullback, as the spirited squad prepared for Columbia. Hoffman-has been troubled with an infected foot all week, and the starting fullback likely will be Walt Zimdahl.

IN the beginning, "All That Matters" * is a serene love story of young, post-war generation Germans enjoying themselves under the Riviera's sun. They have very little money, these two-Christina, the girl, and the man who is telling the story-but they have great hopes, and, in time, they are married. Life stretches ahead wonderfully.

William H. Kreider, former president of the Philadelphia Civil Service Commission, died at his home here tonight at the age of 64. A graduate of Yale University, he came to this city as a young lawyer and eventually was elected to the old Common Council.

Fordham will attempt to loose its best forward passing attack of the season when the Rams meet the University of South Carolina on the Polo Grounds gridiron tomorrow. This was indicated yesterday at Fordham Field when Coach Jimmy Crowley sent his charges through a taxing two-and-a-half-hour workout in which aerial manoeuvres in a dummy scrimmage were stressed.
Agriculture Department experts said tonight that the British and Canadian trade agreements should benefit American agriculture, but not to the extent of greatly relieving existing surpluses.

Paul Roth, who is erecting small homes on the fifty-acre Klein farm in Flushing, L. I., has bought a tract of seventy lots opposite the development. He has acquired the lots, each of which is 20 by 100 feet, from John Boggs of Philadelphia.
Stocks rallied and closed higher in second smallest dealings of month; turnover, 994,580 shares. United States Government and other bonds firm; transactions, $5,710,150, smallest since Sept. 27.

Trading In steer beef and fresh pork loins was slow in most sections in the local markets yesterday; cow and bull business was only fair to slow; and other classes fair. Steer beer weak to slightly lower; fresh pork prices uneven; other classes mostly unchanged in price.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Theodore Jones of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Du Noyer Jones, to Alfred E. Fountain 3d, son of Mrs. Alfred E. Fountain Jr. of Bayside, Queens, and the late Mr. Fountain.

Pronounced contra-seasonal gains in industrial activity and moderate increases in the volume of originating freight shipments boosted business activity in the Pittsburgh district to a new high level in this recovery period last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The Pastime Theatre Building, a three-story structure at 140 Forty-eighth Street, on the corner of Broadway, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to the Colony Real Estate Company.
The Treasury's weekly issue of approximately $100,000,000 of bills was offered for bidding today by Secretary Morgenthau.
Annual cat show of the Empire Cat Club of New York and the Siamese Cat Society of America, Commerce Hall, Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

James Dalhover, 32, known as the "trigger man" of the Al Brady gang, died in the electric chai at Michigan City State Prison here early today for the slaying of Paul V. Minneman, a State policeman, who was shot from ambush on May 25, 1937, after the $2,500 robbery of the Goodland (Ind.) State Bank.

Sebastian Mueller, senior vice president and director of the H. J. Heinz Company, died today at his home after an illness of several months. His age was 78. He was a native of Germany. For many years he was in charge of the company's manufacturing operations.
Relief and taxes were the center of discussion at today's opening session of the twenty-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey League of Municipalities in the Hotel Traymore here.
On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 15. INSPECTOR Charles N. Stilson, 14th Division. at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Dec. 30, 1902.

A recommendation by the first Pan American Congress of Municipalities, new in session here, to place before the coming Pan American Conference in Lima, Peru, proposals aiming at the termination of private ownership of public utilities in the nations of the Americas was agreed upon by the congress's third commission today.
Plans for houses in the Bronx, Brooklyn- and Queens formed the bulk of building projects submitted yesterday. The plans-follow:

Commercial loans of banks in this city apparently are headed for lower levels, and unless some unforeseen development occurs in the business and industrial world which would tax the cash reserves of the larger corporations, there is little likelihood that an appreciable rise will be indicated before the Spring demands set in.

A step to make theatregoing less onerous is being taken by the League of New York Theatres in support of the new ticket code. The league makes known in an advertisement this morning that it will refund any excess charge on tickets bought through one of its accredited brokers.

Suit for divorce on the ground of desertion was instituted in Chancery Court here today by Mrs. Olive Ganong Conklin of Neptune City against her husband, William S. Conklin, former publicity aide to Governor Harold G. Hoffman and now employed in an official capacity by the State Unemployment Compensation Commission.
A $6,000,000 expansion program for Cornell university was announced today by Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, university president.

The Merchants Association of New York has been informed that a new type of consular invoice must be used for freight shipments to Venezuela leaving this country on and after Nov. 23. The new form contains a special column to indicate the country of origin and will be sold exclusively by the consulate.

Demand for almost all types of wool goods continued to be active this week, but volume slackened from the previous week, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

It is now confirmed that within a short time, probably before Dec. 14, General Wu Pei-fu, one of the old-time Chinese warlords, will officially announce his emergence from retirement to assume office as titular head of the new Central Government of China, with headquarters at Peiping, which has been chosen as the permanent capital.
Sheik Abdul Rahman el Khatib was shot and seriously wounded while walking on a street here this morning. There is little hope for his recovery. His Arab assailant escaped.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 12 exceeded sales by 53,082 shares, and the value of the shares purchased was $4,498,671 greater than the value of those sold, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Norwest Realty Corporation, of which Samuel Rudin is president, purchased the seven-story New Windsor Apartments at 294-295 Central Park West, near Ninetieth Street, from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company. L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers.

A ninety-pound, eight-foot mounted marlin was presented to President Roosevelt today by a group of fishermen from Ocean City, Md. They said it was the first marlin of the Summer season caught at the Point, and was hauled in by Dodd Shuster of Wilmington, Del.

The efforts of New York's Mayor La Guardia and other liberals toward forming a national third party in politics, says the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director come at a time when the public is not particularly receptive to the third party idea. a.

In an unprecedented decision that may affect many physicians throughout the State, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn held yesterday that a doctor who maintains his office in his home is entitled to the residential rate for his telephone and not the business rate, which is $2.35 a month higher.

Pearl White, heroine of the old silent movie thrillers. who died in Paris last Aug. 4, was disclosed today to have left an English estate valued at [pound]50,500. Death taxes will amount to [pound]7,560.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
This is a story of reunion, the little saga of a Polish father and his sons and daughters, with a beginning twenty-four years ago in the peasant scenes of Stolin, Russia, and ending in New York.

Dr. Muier C. Hill, in 11 E 68th St: Mrs. H. Lyons Hunt, in Southmoor House, 230 Central Park South; John E Siegel, in 540 Madison Ave: Raymond Parker, in 71 Washington Sq South; Mrs. P. A. S. Franklin, in 955 Lexington Ave; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.
The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Magadieu, Capt. Walter J., 105th Inf., .assigned to Company M. Brown, 2d Lt. Charles R., 369th Inf., assigned to Company M.

Mrs. Harry Maurice Jones of Bryn Mawr, formerly of Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Linlo Jones Calloway, to Nathaniel Ewing, son of Judge and Mrs. Samuel Evans Ewing of Gwineffen, Bryn Mawr.
Leasing of space for business was featured yesterday by deals for store locations. Cushman's Sons, Inc., bakers, took three new retail locations in Manhattan and renewed their lease on another.

What is considered here as the outstanding diplomatic achievement of the Roosevelt Administration was consummated with the signing this afternoon of reciprocal trade agreements with Canada and with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Newfoundland and the British Colonial Empire.

Dollar volume of 2,205 furniture stores throughout the country totaled $67,493,000 in the first six months of 1938, compared with $89,135,000 in the same period of 1937, a decline of 24.3 per cent, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, reported today in connection with the census survey of business for 1937-38.

In a decision protesting against further delay in the final fixation of general claims against the New York Title and Mortgage Company, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler overruled objections of stockholders yesterday and granted an application of Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, for consolidation into one proceeding of all cases on valuation of the claims.

Bank clearings of the leading cities throughout the nation amounted to $5,047,483,000 for the five-day week ended on Wednesday, against $5,192,521,000 for the corresponding period last year, a loss of 2.8 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Underlying companies of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit today petitioned Federal Judge George A. Welsh for authority to seize the transit system if a reorganization plan is not adopted within "a reasonable time."

The Chinese are applying the torch to still more towns in the line of the Japanese advance southward of the Yangtze, Japanese aerial observers report, according to information given out here yesterday. Siushui and Santu, Western Kiangsi centers, were said to be in flames as Chinese troops fell back from positions along the Sui River.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that "with the permission and authorization of the company," field agents of the SEC were making a survey of certain records of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in connection with the collection of data for public hearings on various aspects of the life insurance companies by the monopoly committee.
Miss Rosemary Thacker of Winnipeg, Canada, former national junior titleholder, made her American debut at a private session of the Skating Club of New York last evening.

After Andrew Zawalik, 30 years old,- had pleaded no defense today to a disorderly conduct charge filed against him in connection with the egging of Norman Thomas in Military Park June 4, Mr. Thomas charged that the plea was a ruse of the "Hague machine" to keep the "true facts" of the disturbance from the residents of Newark.

The executive board of the Raw Materials National Conference has decided to name one committee chairman each for agriculture, forestry, mining, industry, chemistry, fisheries and labor, after consultations within the industries, and have the chairman name his committee.

An appeal to the United States Supreme Court appeared today as the next step in the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission's fight to forbid railroads from increasing their rates for hauling anthracite.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point the year to date.
The new trade agreement with Canada was criticized tonight by John D. 'Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, made public yesterday statistics intended to refute the charge that WPA construction activities had been cutting into the private contract field.
Lumber output declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 65.8 from 72.4. The figure was 65.7 for the week ended Nov. 13, 1937.

Announcement by the Republic Steel Corporation that all its outstanding $1,408,000 of Series A 4 1/2 per cent general mortgage convertible bonds due in 1950 would be redeemed on Dec. 30 at 105 and accrued interest resulted yesterday in a decline of 17 points in these obligations in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Sales of 19,006 independent grocery stores throughout the country, 60 per cent of which sell meats with groceries, were $225,269,000 in the first six months of 1938, as compared with $241,498,000 in the same period of 1937, a loss of 6.7 per cent, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, announced today.

Martin, chief passport officer at the Foreign Office since 1916, whose activity in the Boy Scout movement, in the words of international headquarters here, had made him "next to Lord Baden-Powell the best known Scout in the world," died today at the age of 59.

J. P. Morgan returned from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after his usual Summer holiday in England and Scotland, where he followed his favorite sport of grouse shooting. In August he was host to the King and Queen at Gannochy Lodge.
Educational leaders of the United States, in radio addresses and statements, added their voices last night to the nation-wide protest against what is going on in Germany.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for October were higher than for any previous month of 1938 but about 12 per cent below October, 1937, the Commerce Department reports.

The three-story building at 948 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank to the Rosengar Realty Corporation for investment through M. C. O'Brien, Inc., brokers. The property is assessed for $20,000.
Mrs. William Henry Young has left her home, Aloha Lodge, in Tuxedo Park, and, with her debutante granddaughter, Miss Ruth Young, will be at the Beekman for the season.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Nov. 5 amounted to 275,217,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines.

he real crisis facing the oil industry is the threat of governmental control in the guise of helpful regulation, J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, said today in an address at the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute here.
Ninety-six works of art distributed last night among ninety-six lay members of the Grand Central Art Galleries at the annual drawing, at the galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

The American Medical Association won what was described as a limited victory today when Justice James M. Proctor of the local district court quashed two-thirds of a subpoena which had ordered the A. M. A. to produce a variety of records for the grand jury investigation of alleged anti-trust activities against Group Health Association, Inc.
Blyth Co., Inc., announced yesterday that an issue of 90,000 shares of common stock of the Line Material Company, offered at $15.75 a share, had been sold and the books closed.

Credit collections from retailers for the important Nov. 10 due date were better than expected, according to a report given yesterday on behalf of the Garment Credit Conference, composed of forty executives of producing concerns in dress, coat and fur lines' which do an annual volume of business of from $75,000,000 to $100,000,000.
The Cuban Government has set up a registry of importers and exporters which will be a unit of the Cuban Department of Commerce, the Commerce Department reports.

The new Anglo-American treaty which was signed yesterday in Washington represents a goal which Secretary Hull has long been seeking to achieve. He is to be congratulated on his success in reaching it.

Reports from 92 per cent of the country's Class I railroads for October show that in that month they had estimated operating revenues of $287,915,128, compared with $306,731,524 in the same month a year ago, a decline of 6.1 per cent, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Rev. William H. Meegan, a leader in Catholic charity work, died here today after a long illness. His age was 43. Father Meegan, who was a former director of Catholic Charities of Buffalo, Inc., was a former chairman of the Diocesan Directors of Catholic Charities of the United States and a member of the executive committee of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

High points in the AngloAmerican and Canadian-American reciprocal trade agreements signed today are as follows:. The British signatories acted on behalf of the United Kingdom, Newfoundland and more than fifty non-self-governing colonies of the British Empire. .

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Nov. 16 were announced today: CAPTAIN Prall, W. M.. San Francisco Division, to Gulfport Boiler and Welding Works,, Port Arthur, Texas, in connection with construction of Harbor Cutters.

The tramp, tramp of marching soldiery will be heard in historic Princeton tomorrow. Army is invading the countryside hallowed by action in the War of the Revolution, and General Tad Wieman has fortified his defenses against possibly the strongest assault to be directed against his forces since the Dartmouth Indians came down from the hills of Hanover.

If the United States does not "wake up soon" and rebuild its commercial status in South American countries the nation's prestige will suffer irreparable damage, M. L. Wilcox, director of operations and traffic of the Maritime Commission, declared yesterday in an address before the Propeller Club.
Following are the remarks made at the signing of the Anglo-American and Canadian-American reciprocal trade agreements today:

The two-story business building known as 3-51 1/2 South Fourth Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester, on a plot 55 by 105 feet, adjoining the corner of East First Street, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to a client of Kadel, eils Weiss, attorneys.

The Ernest Kempton Adams Research Fellowship has been awarded to Professor Henry A. Boorse of the Physics Department of Barnard College for the year 1938-39 by Columbia University, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of . Barnard announced yesterday.

Street fighting broke out in Paris tonight for the first time in many months when police broke up a Communist demonstration against Finance Minister Paul Reynaud's decree laws and in favor of aid for Loyalist Spain. The government had forbidden the demonstration.

At the annual convention of the New York State Conservation Council, now in session at Kingston, a paper written by J. Paul Miller of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, on the subject of "Farmer-Sportsmen Relationships" was read.

J. Donald Kelly, who formerly was associated with the Kingsway Realty and Mortgage Company and the Kingsway Construction Corporation, has joined the Sullivan-Kushner Company, Inc., as vice president in charge of property management.

A huge demonstration in opposition to any increase in the Westchester County budget for 1939 was planned tonight at a meeting of delegates from eighty taxpayer, civic, real estate and service organizations in fourteen communities of the county.

Seymour Ave, 2,439; dwelling, 40x100; HOLC against Jack Ansalone; due, $8,633; to plaintiff for $500. Sommer PI, 2,913; dwelling, 25x100; HOLC against Hugo Haase; due, $7,345; to plaintiff for $500. Fteley Ave, 1,269: dwelling, 28.5x100; HOLC against Vincenzo Lentini: due, $11.473:

Net profit of the Monsanto Chemical Company and its subsidiaries for the September quarter was $731,353 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions, but before minority interest in an American subsidiary and British subsidiary preference dividends, according to a report issued yesterday.

The Polish Government has informed London, Washington, The Hague and Brussels that it will not allow its interests to be overlooked when the problem of finding an outlet for Jewish refugees is discussed and that Poland's emigration requirements must be taken into account.
Nazis here intimated today that Catholic convents and monasteries would soon suffer the fate of Jewish synagogues.
While the Anglo-American Trade Agreement is regarded as the premier document of this character concluded by Secretary Hull, it was No. 19 on the list of reciprocal trade treaties.

Covering of a block of December obligations stiffened old-crop deliveries during yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange here and widened out the October spread to 88 points, compared with 52 recently.

President Roosevelt today approved an allocation of $6,300,000 of public works administration funds to the Civil Aeronautics Authority for the construction of the Gravelly Point Airport designed to give Washington one of the finest airports in the world.

The policy and practice of the National Broadcasting Company in providing its radio audience with a program service involving an annual expenditure of more than $100,000,000 was described at today's fourth session of the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of network operations by John F. Royal, NBC vice president in charge of programs.

An appeal to the "moral conscience of the democratic world" to help the starving population in Spain both on the side of the Loyalists and the Insurgents was made yesterday by Ernst Toller, exiled German author, who returned on the Queen Mary from a European trip of four months to England, France, Spain and the Scandinavian countries.
As a result of a vote conducted among the New York University football players yesterday, fourteen were selected to start for the Violet in the game with Fordham at the Yankee Stadium on Nov. 26.
E. Carlton Turnbull, head of an insurance agency here, died of a heart ailment last night in his home. after an illness of two years. He was 47 years old.

Rear Admiral A. L. Parsons of the Civil Engineering Corps, U. S. N., who retired on Nov. 1 as Public Works Officer of the Third Naval District, was honored last night at a testimonial dinner given by civilian public works employes of the district at the Hotel St. George Brooklyn.

A resolution of solemn protest against the bombardment of civilian populations from the air in recent hostilities was adopted yesterday by the trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at their semi-annual meeting in the offices of the Carnegie Corporation, 522 Fifth Avenue.

Representatives of the buying offices appealed last night to the Garment Salesmen's Guild at a meeting in the Hotel Piccadilly for closer cooperation in improving relations between salesmen and buyers.

Henry Giegold, State commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars was reported recovering in St Elizabeth's Hospital today from a head and leg injury suffered last night when he was struck by an automobile here. Mr. Giegold is 41 years old and lives at 22 Cooper Street, Dumont.
The Twentieth Century Fund announced yesterday that it would undertake a "nonpartisan" appraisal of the relation of the Federal Government to the electric power and light industry.

At the third report meeting yesterday of the Women's Committee of the United Hospital Campaign at the Hotel Biltmore, Mrs. Charles S. Payson, co-chairman, announced that a total of 4,084 gifts, amounting to $491,796, had been collected to date by the campaign's women workers.

A goal by Regis (Pep) Kelly early in the third period enabled Toronto to subdue the New York Americans in a slashing National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The score was 1 to 0.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today Alfred E. Page, New York City, was admitted to practice and the following Proceedings were had:

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, returned from Bermuda yesterday on the Bermuda Clipper, arriving at the Pan-American air base here at 1:51 P M. He said his return from a vacation at this time had no significance.

An autograph of Button Gwinnett, signer of the Declaration Independence from Georgia-one the rarest signatures in America history-brought $7,500 last night a the Parke-Bernet Galleries at the final session of the auction of William Randolph Hearst's autograph and manuscript collection.
Lou Salica, 117 1/4, former world bantamweight champion, scored a ten-round decision over Katzumi Morioka, 115, Canada, in the feature bout at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn, last night.

Led by K. B. Murphy, who accounted for a four-game victory over M. Selinger, the New York Atheltic Club turned back the City Athletic Club, 3 to 2, at City in one of the three Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class B matches played last night.
Dr. Gerardo Machado, former President of Cuba, now an exile in the United States, yesterday underwent a monor operation at Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street.
Terrell Jacobs, a youthful lion trainer with the Al G. Barnes-Ringling Shows, was attacked and clawed during an afternoon performance. here today by a 475-pound lion.

The Fall showing in New York of new cars that in the past week has occupied the attention of many thousands of visitors to Grand Central Palace, will end tonight at 11 o'clock when the National Automobile Show closes its doors after a season of eight days.

Officials of the Yale Club of Montclair announced today that the Montclair "Yale Bowl," annual award of the club here, would be presented this year to Associate Justice Stanley Reed of the United States Supreme Court. The award is granted to the Yale alumnus "Who has made his 'Y' in life."

At the first meeting of Parliament since the beginning of the crisis that ended with the partition of a great part of Czechoslovakia, Premier Jan Syrovy today delivered a speech that was cautiously worded, as everything must be that is said in Czechoslovakia today lest her all-powerful neighbor Germany take objection.

Raymond E. Marien, 45-year-old certified public accountant, whose strange manipulation of a hosiery company's books caused a fictitious increase of $1,800,000 in the concern's book value and resulted in a series of fantastic consequences, was sentenced yesterday to two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing prison on a forgery charge.

54th St. 25-9 W, 85x100.5: 25 W 54th St Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co; due Oct. 1, 1939, 4 per cent; $106,500. 99th St. 313-5 W. 75x100: 315 W 99th St Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co: pr mtg $188,100, installments, interest per bond; $9,975. 114th St, 213 E. 25x100.11: Michael Acierno to 5th Ave Bank and another, executor William C. Orr; p m mtg, 5 years, 4 per cent: $10,500.

The stock markets here were quietly unsteady today. Although they closed on a firmer tone, many issues still were lower on balance. Gilt-edge securities followed the general trend, improving after a quiet start. Foreign bonds were dull, with South Americans weaker.

The general level of wholesale prices continued to rise during the week ended on Nov. 12, largely as the result of higher prices for farm products and foods, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Leonard Shure, piano, and Paul Tortelier, 'cello, Town Hall, 3; Marie Safonoff, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Oliver Stewart, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30.

The Metropolitan Lutheran Inner Mission Society of New York celebrated last night its fiftieth anniversary with a dinner at' the Hotel Astor. The dinner also -marked the Lutheran Church's seventy years of work among the immigrants in New York Harbor, the thirty-fifth anniversary of the dedication of its chapel at 422 West Forty-fourth Street and twenty years of missionary activity among seamen in New York.

Oswald Pirow, South African Defense Minister, arrived here tonight for a short visit at the invitation of the German Government. He will go to Berchtesgaden Monday night and will visit Chancellor Hitler on Tuesday at Obersalzberg.

Demotion of Normie Smith, veteran goal tender of the Detroit Red Wings, to Pittsburgh of the International American League was disclosed today by Louis J. Giffels, general manager of the Detroit Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Green Gossler gave a reception yesterday at their home, 14 East Sixty-fifth Street, at which they introduced Mrs. Gossler's daughter, Miss Marion Saffold Oates, to older friends of the family.

The United States and Great Britain reached an agreement today regarding access to each other's raw materials, a question of great potential importance in event either country became engaged in a war.

A proposal that farmers be permitted to liquidate their mortgage indebtedness to the Federal Government by payments in kind was laid today before President Roosevelt by William Thatcher, an official of the Farmers Union.

Emphasizing the advances made by the city toward the reduction of infant and adult mortality, Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone yesterday for the new six-story Lower East Side Health and Teaching Center at Twenty-fifth Street and First Avenue.

Only Captain Wally Shinn, left tackle, and Jim Coulter, blocking halfback, are sure of starting positions against Cornell, according to head coach George Munger. The statement was made after a spirited two-hour practice session at Pennsylvania today.
The United States Trust Company of New York, as executor, yesterday disposed of $3,816,000 of New York State fully registered bonds of various coupons and maturities to three banking groups.
THE timorous already are bolting the doors and closing the shutters. The Green Bay Monsters are on the fringe of the town, getting ready to advance on the Polo Grounds, rain or shine.

Funeral services for Dr. John Charles Phillips of Wenham, associate curator of the Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology, who died suddenly Monday while on a hunting trip in Southern New Hampshire, were held today in Emmanuel Church. His age was 62.

The efforts of New York's Mayor La Guardia and other liberals toward forming a national third party in politics, says the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, come at a time when the public is not particularly receptive to the third party idea.

The old elevated lines must have shivered when the first subway was put into successful operation. As the years have passed, the questions regarding them have been not whether they should ultimately come down but when and at what cost to whom.

In a game marked by rough play throughout, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, defending champion, downed the New York A. C. skaters, 6-1, in the New York Amateur Hockey Association opener at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Captain Fred Moseley led the attack for the winners, scoring twice.

Princeton tapered off in its Army preparations with a light passing and kicking session on University Field today. Due to examinations, the practice started late, and ended under lights for the last time this year.
Two pennies is the price of admission to a Penny Carnival tomorrow at the Girls Service League Club, 138 East Nineteenth Street, to raise funds for the club's Christmas party for children.

With Chancellor Hitler's drive into Southeastern Europe bringing nearer the danger in his announced ambition to have the Ukraine, the Soviet press declared today in the strongest language yet used that the Soviet Union, if attacked, would immediately carry the war into the enemy's country with clouds of bombing planes and thousands of tanks.

Word has been received here of the death in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Monday of Frederick Berg, former president of F. Berg Co., once one of the largest hat-manufacturing concerns in this city. Mr. Berg would have been 78 years old on Dec. 27.

There will be plenty of turkey for every one this Thanksgiving, although the question of its quality and price is still a matter of considerable doubt, according to the Consumers' Division of the Department of Markets. Past experience shows that a stretch of mild weather before the holiday results in a fairly high price and in birds that are not too plump, market experts say.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations (C. I. O.) threatened today to boycott products of the Ford Motor Company if it persisted in its "refusal to bargain collectively with the united Automobile Workers of America."

With "Danton's Death" closing tomorrow night after twenty-one performances at the Mercury Theatre, Orson Welles and John Houseman expect to start rehearsals in mid-December of "The Five Kings," which they will present in conjunction with the Theatre Guild.

In an Osservatore Romano dispatch dated Freiberg, Germany, giving the Catholic version of the assaults on Cardinal von Faulhaber's residence in Munich last Friday, it is said that the affair was organized and was not a spontaneous manifestation.

Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada came here today for a short visit to President Roosevelt in the hope that they could speak "quite frankly of things which may benefit the two countries without being catechized afterward."

Yale fellowships for graduate study fine arts at New York University have been awarded to Edmund Haupt Chapman of 90-1 Sixty-third Drive, Forest Hills Queens, and William H. Pierson 01-121 East Eight-second Street, in was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of N. Y. U.

The first penalty for the looting of a Jewish home since the start of Germany's new campaign was handed down today by a Nuremberg court, which sentenced Wilhelm Johann Klein, 21, to eighteen months' imprisonment.

The signing of the Anglo-American trade agreement was the signal for a strong rally in the pound sterling yesterday in the foreign exchange market. Earlier the market had shown some hesitancy, but as the afternoon progressed . the pound gained in strength and at the close showed a gain of 1 cent on the day to $4.70 7/8.

Plans for a national "red tag" promotional campaign in the retail stationery trade during the first week of March under the auspices of the Wholesale Stationers' Association of the U. S. A. will be acted upon by the directors and merchandising committee of that organization at a meeting here next Monday.

The wheat bounty approved by the Commonwealth Government last September has raised the question of how growers not harvesting their wheat because of a bad season and consequently needing help most urgently can participate.

When Evanston's new postoffice opened for the first time yesterday the suburb's forty mail carriers found a fleet of eight taxis to take them to and from their routes. The carriers make two round trips a day. There will be no waiting for buses and lugging of heavy sacks to the first house on the list.

The reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Great Britain, which was signed here today, may well have sounded the death knell of the empire preference theory of trade among the members of the British Empire.
The Civilian Conservation Corps has begun its annual shopping to provide an old-fashioned Thanksgiving Day dinner for 300,000 men, Robert Fechner, director, announced today.

A daughter was born early this evening to 17-year-old Queen Farida at Montazazah Palace here. This is the first child of the 18-year-old King Farouk and Farida, who are the world's youngest reigning monarchs.

Messenger boys employed by the Postal Telegraph Company in this city got their first pay checks yesterday since the company decided to comply with the minimum wage provision of the Federal Wages and Hours Act.

Edward Parmelee Morris, classics scholar and Professor of Latin Language and Literaure at Yale University from 1891 until his retirement in 1919, died Wednesday in the Irving Hotel, 26 Gramercy Park, after a brief illness. Professor Morris, who was 85 years old, lived in Saybrook, Conn.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Nov. 15 were announced today: Howard, Lieut. Col. A, F., when discharged from treatment at Norfolk Naval Hospital, detached as member of Staff of Commander, Atlantic Squadron. U. S. Fleet and ordered to Quantico, Va.

In the next to last practice on Memorial Field this season, the Dartmouth first team today was driven through a hard scrimmage session by Coach Earl Blaik. Tomorrow a squad of thirty-five will entrain for California to meet Stanford week from Saturday.

We are all too much inclined to take the public schools for granted, like the weather or the Bill of Rights. The report just issued by the Board of Regents, under the directorship of Dr. Luther Gulick, should jolt us out of this complacency.

Penn State's football squad went through its final home practice session of the season today before leaving for the Pitt game. The Nittany Lion squad of forty-two players will hold a light workout at the Pitt Stadium tomorrow afternoon.

William Francis (Bill) Cordner, left end on the Amherst eleven for two years, was elected captain for the 1939 season today. Cordner succeeds Jack Joys, whose quarterbacking led the Jeffs to their first undefeated football season in the history of the college.

Mrs. Frances McKee of Muscatine, Iowa, took the $1,000 Wood Roadster Stake at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight when her Playboy was selected over Society Lady, owned by R. C. Flanery of Kansas, Ill. The victory meant $300 to the winner.

Two par-shattering streaks over three successive holes on each nine enabled Gene Sarazen, former United States open, British open and American P. G. A. champion, to tie Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond Va., in the first half of the thirty six-hole Mid-South open golf tournament on the Pinehurst No. course today.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, returned yesterday on the Rex from a three month business tour of Europe on which he visited England, France, Switzerland, Italy, Greece, Turkey, Rumania and Portugal. Mrs. Watson accompanied him.

Skiers of the metropolitan area and others interested in Winter sports gathered at the first of a series of open meetings last night at Wiles Restaurant, where plans and proposals for the coming season were discussed. Oscar Naumann presided.

A no more sorry looking football team ever marched off the Polo Grounds gridiron than the New York Giants at the conclusion of yesterday's practice. Mud caked their hands, their uniforms and their faces. More mud was plastered on their heads.
With a grimness that was accentuated by the strict secrecy of the practice, Yale's football forces put the finishing touches on preparations for Harvard today.

The world's political ills will wreak more harm on music than on any other art, Eugene Goossens, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, declared yesterday on his return from Europe on the Queen Mary.

Postmaster General James A. Farley said yesterday he had "no comment" to make on reports from Washington that he was planning to retire from President Roosevelt's Cabinet early next year. Friends of Mr. Farley in New York were convinced that there was no immediate prospect of his retirement although it has been no secret to them that he would like to re-enter private business if a profitable opportunity presented itself.

Gross assets, $52,183; net, $47,327. To Edna L. Sherman. daughter; Ernest A. Linburn, son, and Irma R. Linburn, daughter-in-law, one-third each; one specific bequest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $43,377. Riegelman, Hess, Strasser . Hirsch. attorneys, 160 Broadway.
George C. Mathews of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that there had been "profoundly significant" improvements in the financial housekeeping of the public utilities.

Spirits and wines dumped for rectification in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, July through September, amounted to 9,286,869 proof gallons, as compared with 10,111,552 proof gallons in the same period last year, the Alcohol Tax unit announced today.

It was learned yesterday that Alfred L. Loomis's twelve-meter sloop Northern Light, which won the class championship of Long Island Sound and was looked upon as a certainty to be sent abroad next Summer for racing in English waters, probably would not be sent after all.
Its intricate aerial and running plays clicking, Columbia concluded major preparations yesterday for the Syracuse game tomorrow at Baker Field.

Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, here, recommended today the expansion of facilities for physical education to care for increasing undergraduate enrollment in a report to the trustees at their annual meeting at the college.

The attention of all officers is directed to the provisions of Section 148, Rules and Regulations, 1937, which, in the future, shall be strictly complied with. Two copies of General Order 52, promulgated Nov. 17, shall be furnished to each company, one for the office copy of the Official Action Guide, and one copy for the General Order book.

Simon Schuster will publish next Friday "We Saw It Happen," in which thirteen correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES chronicle the news behind the news of their most memorable assignments. The contributors include Arthur Krock, G. E. R. Gedye, F. Raymond Daniell, Frank Nugent Douglas,

Mrs. Marie Ballard, wife of John H. Ballard, president of the Bulova Watch Company, died Wednesday her home, 90 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 45 years old. Mr. and Mrs. Ballard, who were married twenty-three years ago, had a Summer home at Atlantic Beach. Beach.

Ernest Neill of Manchester, Conn., regular tackle on the Colgate football team for the past two seasons, today was elected captain of the team for next Fall to succeed John Lucy and Don Wemple, the retiring co-captains.

The Citizens Union, through its chairman, William Jay Schieffelin, announced yesterday a twenty-two point legislative program, adoption of which it will urge on both houses of the Legislature. Much of the legislation suggested is designed to implement the constitutional amendments approved by the voters, but the proposals also call for six new constitutional amendments.
Mrs. Edith Marcy Sperry, widow of a former commander of the United States Atlantic Fleet, died of pneumonia at her home here today. Her age was 84.

As a result of alleged interference by members of the musicians' and stage employes' unions with the first presentation of "Faust" by Opera-on-Tour, Inc., in Birmingham, Ala., last Tuesday, officials of that organization announced last night that they would seek relief in court to prevent further interference with their performances.
Following are the official tabular statements by the Department of Commerce and the Tariff Commission of the concessions made by both sides in the Anglo-American trade agreement:

Mrs. Edwin L. Oliver Jr. entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for her sister-in-law, Miss Mary Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Oliver of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel and Piedmont, Calif., whose engagement to Adrian Shannon has been announced.

Wheat futures on the Exchanges in the United States dipped a small fraction of 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today, but rallied about 1 cent from the low point on short-covering and commission-house buying.
Thoroughly recovered from the illness that kept him out of the line-up practically all of last season, Burgess Whitehead will be more back at second base for the Giants next Spring.
Under the changing methods of realty financing and investment which have developed within the past few years, industrial properties again are attracting loans from insurance companies.

Describing the drunken driver as a potential murderer and a public enemy of highway safety, State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh announced yesterday at the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor that he would introduce eight highway safety bills at the forthcoming legislative session.

Railroads and users of transportation were urged yesterday by James F. Bell, chairman of the board of directors of General Mills, Inc., to join hands in a fight to overcome the present crisis of the railroads lest the roads fall under government control. He spoke to 1,000 members and guests of the National Industrial Traffic League in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska said here today that the liberals got a setback in last week's election and "we probably deserved it." "We got a jolt," Mr. Norris told interviewers. "I don't think it was a bad thing. It will make us stop, consider and listen."

The Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday announced yesterday the personnel of the executive committee for the 1938 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign which will reach its climax on Jan. 30, President Roosevelt's fifty-seventh birthday.

The Harvard and the University Club teams continued in a tie for first place in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association inter-club Class A series as each accounted for triumphs last night. The outcome of the tests gave each of the squads records of three decisions in as many starts.

The first television broadcast from the World's Fair was made yesterday after the arrival of the two trucks that represent the "telemobile" unit of the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company, designed to begin public television distribution with the public opening of the grounds.

The Near East Foundation has proved a vital force in furthering peace, good-will and understanding between nations. Dr. Harold B. Allen, director of education for the foundation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Friends of the Near East. at the home of Mrs. George W. Perkins Jr., 6 East Ninety-fourth Street.

Roger Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, who was to have given a talk at the Norwalk Y. M. C. A. Friday and whose permission to speak was withdrawn, will give his address at the Moose Home instead.

Fed steers and yearlings, grading good and better were active today at 15 to 25 cents higher levels, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Nothing strictly choice or prime was available. Light hogs sold steady, but medium weight and heavy butchers were as much as 10 cents lower.

The board of directors of the Commercial Solvents Corporation today approved the sale of 98,900 of o1 ordinary shares of the capital stock of Commercial Solvents (Great Britain), Ltd., to the United Molasses Company, Ltd., for $729,588, according to Theodore P. Walker, president of the corporation. Shares have been delivered and payment received.

John Anthony (Tony) Weir, one of the better-known bartenders and hosts of three eras--the Gay Nineties, the tense War days, and the "dark days" of prohibition, died yesterday in the Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 69 years old.
A prominent Federal economist injected a note of caution today in the frequent optimistic business forecasts for next year.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following trial cases were argued and submitted:

The general level of wholesale prices in October was 0.7 per cent higher than in September, the index numbers for the two months being 99.1 and 98.4, respectively, the Board of Trade announced here today. Prior to this rise prices had fallen almost uninterruptedly since July, 1937, when the index was 111.5.

No special all-night liquor permits will be issued by the State Liquor Authority for this New Year's Eve, it was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority. No liquor may be sold, therefore, at bars and cabarets after 3 A. M. on Jan. 1.

All our items, today will National be dedicated to statistics, Round with a thin obbligato of Numbers comment more or less worth while. Persons who hate statistics, as practically who of us does not, are thus forewarned in time. They can turn instead to the front page. nt page.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 16: MAJOR GENERAL Lynch, G. A., chief of infantry, one month leave, Nov. 20.

President Roosevelt's aid in bringing about an international conference for the reduction and limitation of armaments and removal of other causes of war was sought today by a delegation of Protestant Church leaders who conferred with him.

The TVA power program will cost the taxpayers of the United States $10,352,000 a year to meet the deficit it will produce when the proposed eleven-dam system is completed and in full operation under the present TVA yardstick rates and under a proper allocation of costs, according to testimony given before the Congressional investigating committee today by Edward L. Moreland, dean of the Engineering Department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Miss Jean Mandeville Pascall, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Myrick Pascall of this city, was married this evening in the home of her parents to Ruel Stuart Dally, also of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Dally of Bemidji, Minn.
The committee of railroad and union officials appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the railroad problem concluded yester?? a two-day session in the Pennsylvania Station.

Washington clubwomen who molest workmen transplanting Japanese cherry trees to make way for the Jefferson Memorial may be transplanted themselves, President Roosevelt said today in commenting on the "cherry tree rebellion" now in progress.

The Public Utilities Commission received authority today to appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States a ruling by a Federal court declaring unconstitutional a section of the State Utility Law permitting the commission to fix temporary rates.

Unusual but practical innovations in details and trimmings,, rather than any major change in silhouette, were characteristic of the garments selected by local manufacturers at the recent Paris openings, an examination yesterday of collections which arrived Thursday on the Queen Mary revealed.
Lieutenant Ramiro Palafox rode Azteca to victory tonight in the Military Jumping Stake at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show for the Mexican Army team's first triumph of the show.

Animbalance between skills and tastes, between knowledge how to do and lack of wisdom in choosing what to do, threatens to rock the very foundation of civilized humanity, the American Philosophical Society was told tonight.
Philadelphia's first team routed Washington's first team, 8 to 0, in the opening round of the women's Southeastern field hockey tournament today.

Colonel Henry D. Lindsley, chairman of the first American Legion convention, died here today after a career as banker, insurance company president, real estate man, army officer and public official. He was 66 years old.

Miss Eileen Marie McCarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. McCarty of 262 Central Park West and Hewlett, L. I., was married here yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament to Francis Richard Curry, son of John F. Curry, former leader of Tammany Hall, and Mrs. Curry of 101 Central Park West.

Columbia Pharmacy vs. Alumni, at Columbia U. gymnasium, 116th Street and Broadway .................8:30 P. M. Union Temple vs. Prospect Y.M.C. A., at Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn......................... 9 P.M.

Influenced by a lower stock market and the closest approach of the New York contract level to Southern spot quotations to date this season, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 3 to 6 points yesterday.

This is Big day for football. By nightfall champions will be crowned in the Big Three, the Big Six and the Big Ten, and after the cheering and the wailing have subsided a big silence will fall upon the Three and the Ten until another season rolls around.

If New York State can advertise the World's Fair on automobile license plates, Westchester County is entitled to advertise itself on the large manila envelopes that are used to distribute the plates in Westchester, County Clerk Harold Mercer said today.
A far-reaching enabling bill which virtually invites Parliament to commit suicide was introduced today and immediately produced difficulties that resulted in an adjournment until Monday.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Huntington Gas Company of West Virginia, have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application under the public Utility Holding Company Act for approval of a plan of liquidation of the subsidiary in furtherance of the program for
After many weeks of unexplained inactivity, Chinese planes are taking to the air again, striving to assist the defense of Changsha, Hunan Provincial capital, and the attack on Japanese-held Canton.

Members of the Zion Evangelical Church here, the oldest Lutheran parish in New Jersey and one of the oldest in the United Lutheran Synod of New York, gave a reception this evening to welcome their new pastor, the Rev. John Henry Munnich and Mrs. Munnich, formerly of Mount Vernon, N. Y. The church was founded in 1714.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Rowland Ewing of 66 East Seventy-ninth Street and High Island, South Bristol, Me., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Valle Ewing, to Alfred Pope, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carlyle Pope of Milton, Mass., and Christmas Cove, Me.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 12 amounted to 636,710 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Federal grand jury that has been investigating charges that Mayor Frank Hague and other officials of Jersey City conspired to suppress civil liberties under the pretext of law enforcement voted today against returning any indictments.
Harvard today won its first New England Intercollegiate Soccer League title by defeating the unbeaten Yale team, 2-1, Mendel kicking both goals for the Crimson in the second period.

The Rutgers lightweight eleven defeated the Penn 150-pounders, 14-6, on Franklin Field today. Rutgers' first score came in the opening quarter when Carlton Dilatush hit center from the 1-yard line after Bernie Reiser had blocked Bill McLane's punt on the 10. Tom Finnie tallied the second touchdown on a 4-yard thrust off tackle.
Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., yesterday reported consolidated net profit of $6,360,964 for the three months ended on Oct. 31 after deductions for depreciation, amortization,

The Harlem Savings Bank has sold to Walselm Estates, Ltd., the property at 3,787-89 Third Avenue, the Bronx, for cash above a first mortgage of $36,000. The buildings are on a plot 50 by 100 feet on the corner of 171st Street and Third Avenue, and contain twenty-five suites and five stores.
Mexican fiesta, New York League of Women Shoppers and National Committee for People's Rights, Mecca Temple, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, 11 A. M.

The council of the Advertising Association considered this week a draft code of advertising practices which was drawn up by a committee of the association on the basis of the code recommended by the advertising committee of the conference of the International Chamber of Commerce at Berlin in July of last year.

Women interested in the work of the Speedwell Society entertained parties yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador where a luncheon and fashion show was given under the auspices of the Yorkville unit of the society.

Joseph Kennedy, retired architectt and builder, died last light at his home here at the age of 73. Born in Ireland, Mr. Kennedy was a resident of West Hud;on and North Arlington for fifty Tears and had engaged in building cork for more than forty years.

Trading in steer beef was slow in local markets yesterday. Veal, calf and lamb business continued good. Pork loins continued to move slowly and some lots will probably be carried. Other fresh pork cuts moved fair to good.

Resolutions asking better cooperation between dealers and producers in the coal industry were passed at the closing session of the sixth annual convention of the Retail Fuel Merchants Association of New Jersey here today.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Royal A. Graves of Ogdensburg, N. Y., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Madeline Lenore Graves, to Roy Hunter deBrauwere, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. deBrauwere of St. Albans, Queens, and Islip, L. I.

President Roosevelt announced at his press conference today that he was appointing a temporary advisory board to canvass fiscal and monetary problems relating to production and national income. It was a fresh approach to the problem of leveling the nation's economic peaks and valleys.

The Jo Davidson exhibition at the Arden, 460 Park Avenue, opened to the public yesterday and will continue through Dec. 3. It is being held as a benefit for the Spanish Children's Milk Fund, under the chairmanship of Dorothy Parker.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain suffered a damaging electoral blow today when Vernon Bartlett, newspaper correspondent and former radio commentator on foreign affairs, captured the parliamentary seat in the Bridgewater division of Somerset from the government. The seat was regarded as a government stronghold and many of Mr. Bartlett's own supporters did not dream he could win it.

At a recent monthly meeting of the board of governors of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, J. Frederick Talcott was elected president and Dan Everett Waid was chosen chairman of the executive committee.
The Lehigh soccer team defeated Lafayette today by 2-1 in the last game of the season for the old rivals, Lehigh making both its goals in the final period.

In line with the Park Department's program to provide more restful, shaded areas along the bustling sidewalks of New York, Rockefeller Center yesterday planted the first of 150 large trees which will beautify the midtown streets around the commercial and amusement center.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Snyder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John I. Snyder of this place, to John W. Scott, son of Mrs. John W. Scott of Collingswood, N. J., took place this evening in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Robert Gardner MacGregor, the pastor, performed the ceremony.
Japanese-American relations have entered upon a new phase with the delivery yesterday of Japan's reply to our Government's note of Oct. 6 protesting against Japanese discrimination in China.

Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, Fifth Avenue and Thirtyeighth Street, will propose an amended ruling on the question of motion in window displays on Fifth Avenue, he announced yesterday following the recent objection of the Fifth Avenue Association to "the simulated blizzard" used in the windows of that store from Saturday to Wednesday.
Eric Coy of Winnipeg, shot put and discus star, today was awarded the Norton H. Crow Memorial Trophy by the Amateur Athletic Union of Canada as the Dominion's leading amateur athlete of 1938.

Mrs. Alice De Blois Stone, a descendant of John Langdon, president of the first United States Senate and Governor of New Hampshire, and a great-granddaughter of John Haven, who once owned the property now in Fort Washington Park, New York City, died Thursday at her home here. Mrs. Stone, a native of Louisiana, was the widow of Ralph Stone, former Buffalo lawyer.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company filed yesterday plans for two additional units in its housing development on the site of the Catholic Protectory in the Bronx. The units will be eight stories high and one will cost $975,000 and the other $400,000.

Henry M. Pease, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and administrative vice president of its worldwide manufacturing and sales organization, was honored yesterday at a luncheon in the I. T. T. Building at 67 Broad Street, celebrating the fortieth anniversary of his connection with the telephonemanufacturing business.
The cornerstone of the new edifice for the Brick Presbyterian Church which will rise at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street will be laid on Friday afternoon at 3 o'clock.
King George and Queen Elizabeth will spend three days in Washington as the guests of President and Mrs. Roosevelt at the White House, and one day in New York visiting the World's Fair.

Trading by members for their own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchiange in the week ended on Oct. 29 represented 20.36 per cent of the total volume, compared with 22.07 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
The Department of Agriculture reported today that deliveries of sugar by refiners, beet sugar companies and importers totaled 576,063 short tons in October, compared with 372,409 a year before.
Many prominent business men and labor leaders are to testify before a Senate finance subcommittee on profitsharing systems in American industry at sessions starting Monday.

Walter Haefeli, New York architect with offices at 140 Cedar Street and former special building inspector of this village, died yesterday in the Memorial Hospital in New York after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived in this village.
Mayor La Guardia arrived here at 9:45 o'clock tonight after his plane from Newark Airport had been delayed by head winds and fog for almost three hours.

Two of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's Cabinet colleagues-Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the Marquess of Zetland, Secretary of State for India-promised in speeches today that Britain would do her utmost to find new homes for German refugees in the British colonial empire.

While cotton textile and fishing interests of New England today continued to protest the new Anglo-American trade agreements as harmful to their interests, shoe manufacturers generally agreed that their business would be little affected, according to official statements.

The Internal Revenue Bureau issued today regulations covering amendments made to the last Revenue Act upon recommendation of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the nonrecognition of gain or loss upon exchanges and distributions made in obedience to orders of the commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company fAct, and the basis of property acquired upon such exchanges and distributions.

As deep in pessimism as his Green Bay Packers were in the soggy field at Travers Island yesterday, Coach Curly Lambeau appeared to have little hope of winning tomorrow's important battle with the Giants at the Polo Grounds.

Canada's reaction today to the new Canadian-American trade treaty was on the whole highly favorable. Only from textile, automobile and shipping interests, and not from all of them, came criticism. Farmers, fishermen and lumbermen expressed approval.

Limited supplies of cattle sold at. generally steady price levels In a clean-up trade today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Nothing strictly choice or prime was offered in the fed steer and yearling division.

Alexander Hamilton vs. Manual Training and Erasmus Hall vs. Boys High, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, 12:45 and 2:45. Stuyvesant vs. Theodore Roosevelt and De Witt Clinton vs. High School of Commerce, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, 12 and 2.
Ante Trumbitch, fo mer Yugoslav Foreign Minister, who was known as "the treaty maker," died today. He was 76 years old.

Edward C. Bolsover Sr. of this community, who retired sixteen years ago as teller of the United States Mortgage and Trust Company of New York, since merged with the Chemical National Bank, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital following an operation.
Hugo George Roboz, foreign edior of The Daily and Sunday Mirror, lied of a heart attack at his home, 25 East Ninety-ninth Street, last light. His age was 51.
ALKER--Edward P., beloved husband of Ernestine Sierck, suddenly, Nov. 18, at his home, Great Neck, L. I. Funeral services at his residence, East Shore Road, Sunday, Nov. 20, at P. M.

Extension of fair-trade practices, greater uniformity in advertising control and prevention of erection of trade barriers between States were recommended by State Liquor Administrators from ten Eastern States, at the second Regional Liquor Control Conference yesterday in the Park Central Hotel, Fifty-sixth Street at Seventh Avenue.

Complexities of the trade agreements with Canada and the United Kingdom deterred most domestic manufacturers and foreign traders yesterday from making specific comments upon the pacts and the effect they were likely to have upon industrial and agricultural interests here.

Ralph E. Ward Jr. of Plainfield, N. J., halfback of the Exeter eleven, today was elected captain for next year. Because of an early season injury, which re-occurred in the Hebron game, he was unable to play against Andover.

Prices of the recently announced 1939 line of Dodge trucks were given out yesterday by J. D. Burke, director of truck sales. The prices show reductions from those of corresponding 1938 types. For the new one-half-ton series the price reductions range up to $24.

Fourscore and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. Now we are engaged in a great civil war, testing whether that nation, or any nation so conceived and so dedicated. can long endure.

A promise from Colonel Fulgencio Batista, commander-in-chief of the Cuban Army, that Cuba would cooperate in providing a haven for refugees from Nazism was given yesterday to the Committee for Political Refugees, which held an hour's conference with him at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

The plan of liquidation of the Pathe Film Corporation is expected to be completed formally over the week-end, it was learned yesterday. Directors have been in conversation with the Securities and Exchange Commission for ten days in working out their plan, which is intended to eliminate Path6 Film as a holding company.
The effect on Bermuda of the financial set-up of the British-Amercan trade pact is a subject of speculation here, but, in the absence of definite information, comments have been reserved.

A Yale team new in personnel and, according to those who have been close to it all week, new in spirit and execution, will try to come back tomorrow at the end of the season's trail. At 1:45 P. M. the Elis will trot out on the field of the Bowl to face Harvard in their fiftyseventh meeting.

Secretary Hull expressed gratification today that the reaction in this country to the reciprocal trade agreements with the United Kingdom and Canada had been marked by a broad visualization of the objectives of his trade program.

A number of special events for next year, one a distance race in the eastern part of Long Island Sound, were decided upon last night at the annual meeting and dinner of the Atlantic Class Association in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

" Crooked people" in the theatre are blocking the success of the theatre ticket code, Brock Pemberton, producer, charged at a discussion meeting of the Actors Equity Association yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.

Columbia University commemorated the 900th anniversary of the introduction of Christianity into Eastern Europe by St. Stephen, first King of Hungary, with exercises last night in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street.

Retail trade improved here this week, with estimates putting volume at about 2 to 3 per cent under a year ago. Active shopping today would put the week's figures ahead of the comparative period a year ago.

Performing with all the grace of a veteran campaigner, My Own Counsellor, solid black 18-month-old cocker spaniel owned and handled by H. E. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., won the biggest share of the $1,000 Big Four Nov Stake today as the seventeenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England opened at Horticultural Hall.

A 70-year-old man protected a $500 payroll yesterday morning by fighting off an armed thug who fired one shot that pierced the victim's hat. The gunman escaped after hitting the payroll carrier on the head with a revolver butt.

Sixtyone individuals reported net income of $1,000,000 or more in 1936, on which taxes were payable in 1937, as compared with forty-one in 1935, an all-time high of 513 in the boom year of 1929, and a depression era low of twenty in 1932, according to the Treasury today.

Summonses Due to the temporary closing of the Third District Magistrates' Court, located at Beach Channel Drive, between Beach 90th and Beach 91st Sts., Rockaway Beach, the following procedure will temporarily govern the issuance of summonses for alleged violations of law or regulations occurring within the boundary of the said court district:

A new employes' retirement plan will be considered at a special meeting of stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana in Whiting, Ind., on Dec. 22, Edward G. Seubert, president, announced today. The policy with respect to similar plans that may be proposed by subsidiaries of the company also will be settled.
A long line of business men was waiting when the government stationery office opened this morning and the "White Paper" containing the text of the Anglo-American trade pact soon became a best seller.

Merton Reynolds, supervisor of dog licensing in the State Agriculture Department, announced today the collection of $1,010,971 in dog licensing fees outside of New York City and Buffalo in the first ten months of 1938.

Vincent de Moro-Giafferi, renowned criminal lawyer, who once defended Henri Landru, famed "Bluebeard," announced today that he had accepted an American request to defend Herschel Grynszpan, 17-year-old Polish Jew, whose slaying of a German Embassy secretary loosed Nazi vengeance on German Jews.

What followed Munich in Germany we have already seen, and it is not either the celebration or the consolidation of a diplomatic victory. It is much more like the conduct of an army in full and disorderly retreat. We begin to see signs of other consequences southeast of Germany.

A reliable report indicates that the Theatre Guild is bestirring itself once more. So much so that Judith Anderson, who last was seen hereabouts in "The Old Maid" in 1935, will be returning to the Broadway stage under the Guild's banner in the John W. Gassner dramatization in blank verse of "The Tower Beyond Tragedy," the poem by Robinson Jeffers.

The New York Social Register for 1939 was published yesterday, and is now being distributed to its subscribers. A few changes are noted among the prominent families of New York, largely as the result of marriage and divorce, with several deletions.

Reporting field stocks still far below normal, with buying "generally good," Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today the current week's output of the automotive plants at 96,735 cars and trucks. Assemblies last week totaled 86,300 units;

King Carol of Rumania and his son, Crown Prince Michael, left for home today after a state visit almost openly devoted to attempts to obtain financial and commercial concessions from Britain as counterbalances to the German trade drive in the Balkans.

The 1939 license plates for private and commercial automobiles will go on sale on Jan. 3 at all issuing offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Carroll E. Mealey, Deputy Motor Vehicle Commissioner.

Two gunmen, lurking in the shadows of a large Queens apartment courtyard at 48-19 Forty-third Street, Sunnyside, shot and killed John F. O'Hara, 27 years old, an analytical reporter for Dun Bradstreet, as he walked beneath the entrance archway shortly after 6 o'clock last night.

MANHATTAN ALSBERG, IRVING (Oct. 9). Estate. not more than $3,000. To Edith Alsberg, widow, executrix, Hotel Alexandria, 103d St. and Broadway. BERGEN, THOMAS (Oct. 15). Estate, about $2,400. To Rev,. Walter G. Moran, St. Vincent Ferrer's Ghurch. Lexington Ave. and 66th St., S500; St. Vincent's Hospital, 11th St. and 7th Ave., residue. John T. Magan. attorney, 102 So. 11th St Mount Vernon.

Looking in better health than for some time past, Cardinal Innitzer walked briskly alone this morning from his palace past the cathedral to a building where a small exhibition of religious wood carvings is being held.

The Netherland Minister called Premier and Foreign Minister Paul Spaak today to discuss with him some plan of collaboration between the Netherland and Belgian Governments in behalf of Jewish refugees from Germany.

The Brooklyn College football team will be trying to balance its record for the season at four games won and four lost when the Kingsmen end their season this afternoon against Susquehanna University at the Kingsmen's field.

Dr. Paul A. Zahl of the Haskins Laboratory in Union College will leave tomorrow on the steamship Lady Drake from Boston for British Guiana, where he will lead an aerial expedition that will attempt to fly to Conan Doyle's "Lost World" in the Mount Roraima region.

The Supreme Court opinion of April allowing the Federal Government to tax salaries of Port of New York Authority employes logically permits New York State to tax salaries of employes of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation, John J. Bennett Jr., New York State Attorney General, declared in the Supreme Court today.

The changing character of the population of the United States may double the average annual commitments to insane asylums two decades hence, without change in the incidence of the disease, according to Dr. Harold F. Dorn, statistician for the United States Public Health Service.

After three stormy days spent in Royal Sound, Kerguelen Islands, we are now heading direct for the Antarctic pack ice. The day after tomorrow we will pass McDonald and Heard Islands and if the weather is fine we will go ashore on Heard Island, the most southerly island in the Southern Indian Ocean.
Charles W. Lapp, assistant secretary of the United Advertising Corporation of Newark, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 43 years old.

Publication yesterday of the items affected by the Anglo-American Trade Treaty, so far as can be determined, had no important bearing on the course of markets here. In England and Canada the markets were up a bit.

Bernard Becker of Brooklyn, N. Y., received the freshman first honor prize at the Fall meeting of the Graduate Council of Princeton University tonight for the highest scholastic standing in the Princeton class of 1941 during its first year.

Scenes of murals and statues at the World's Fair, as seen by the radio cameras of the National Broadcasting Company, were sent by television yesterday across sevenand-one-half miles from- the fair grounds to Radio City.

The Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's was filled to capacity yesterday afternoon for a tea dance and "Sister Act" fashion show presented for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. The style revue featuring the entertainment drew the participation of pairs of sisters among young women of society.
A marital readjustment, through which two couples, after living together for two years, exchanged spouses, became known here today.

Edward P. Alker, former president of the Bank of Great Neck, a leading figure in the State cement industry and for many years one of the most active Democratic leaders in Nassau County, died tonight at his home here of a heart ailment. He was 51 years old.

President William Green of the American Federation of Labor asked today for the resignations of two Pennsylvania Federation officials because they "opposed the political policies of the A. F. of L. in the last (election) campaign."

Bedford St, 76-80, and 65 Barrow St; Barford Realty Corp to Josephine Agolia, 564 60th St, Brooklyn. p m mtg, pr mtg, $75,000, 5 yrs, 6%; $10,000. 2d St. 171 E. 24.9x105.6; 171 E. 2d Corp to Margaret Folsom Corp, 55 Liberty St, p m mtg. 5 yrs, 4%; $13,000.

A hearing scheduled for yesterday on the general plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, Inc, submitted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the compe.ny's largest creditor, was adjourned by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal court, Brooklyn, until Dec. 2.

One of the State officials accused with Governor Earle in graft and corruption charges offered the first public disclosure today of a "quota" plan used by the Democratic State organization in raising its campaign funds.

Secretary Perkins reported today that a survey by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the cost of living for families in the lower-salaried brackets had dropped 0.7 per cent from June 15 to Sept. 15, 1938.

The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that it had omitted dividends on its 6 per cent and 7 per cent preferred stocks. The action became necessary, the company stated, because of the damage to property resulting from the recent hurricane and also because of a need for preserving its cash position.

Plans for the purchase of agricultural and other machinery on a large scale from the United States are being studied by officials of the cooperative Union of Sweden, the commerce Department reported today.

The cost of living in thirty-two large cities of the country dropped 0.6 point from June 15 to Sept. 15, the Department of Labor has reported. The drop in the cost of food was larwly responsible for this decrease, the report said.

Rolling P. Dickerson, sportsman and boxing fan, who made Stanley Ketchell, one-time world's middleweight and light heavyweight champion, his special protege, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

Thomas A. E. Weadock, credited with being the dean of the American Bar Association, former Michigan Supreme Court Justice, former Congressman and author and historian, died at his home here today. He was 88 years old.
