Claims for the constancy of the intelligence quotient. in growing children, recently put forward by a professor at Teachers College, Columbia University,-were questioned yesterday by Dr. Karl M. Bowman, director of the division of psychiatry of the Department of Hospitals, who asserted that he had often seen. I. Q.'s change as children developed.

A meeting of the Astoria Branch of the German-American Bund, proNazi organization, which was devoted to anti-Semitic propaganda, was picketed by 250 men and women last night. The pickets maintained a double file outside the Astoria Turn Hall, Forty-fourth Street and Broadway, Astoria, Queens, where the meeting was held.

Hofstra co-eds defeated the Rhode Island State girls by 3--1 today on Hofstra Field to extend their string at field hockey to six games. It was the first setback in seven intercollegiate tests this year for the visitors.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Thomson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet P. Thomson, to J. Scott Kurtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Kurtz of Altoona, Pa.

" The Fortune Hunter," which as a play starred both John Barrymore and Frank Bacon, and which has reached the screen tw?? in silent form, has been put on Warner's schedule as a vehicle for rick Powell. Production will start after the holidays.
The following tabular statements of concessions made by both sides in the Anglo-American trade agreements are supplemental to those that appeared in the Late City Edition of THE TIMES yesterday:

Over the falls the frenzied waters slide Like maddened time into eternity. Foaming, surging, eddying toward the sea. A hundred miles from where their fury died These weary waters will be purged as souls, Pulled up and blown and tossed about in air By sun and wind, and scattered everywhere On earth again, until once more there rolls The thunder of a thousand waterfalls.
The Central Illinois Public Service Company, Springfield, Ill., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation,

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. St. Anselm--To a man up a tree it is important whether or not the tree is garnished with thorns. This looks like one well furnished with thorns, practically a honey locust in a football way. St. Anselm is one of those stunning "small teams" like Western Reserve, which also is undefeated. Going out on a limb, one wavering vote for Boston College.
Nearly 400 delegates to the American Automobile Association's annual convention were told today that traffic surveys in forty-six States indicated a doubling of present-day traffic volume by 1960.

Dr. Alfred F. Allman, assistant director of the municipal Department of Health and a former member of the State House of Representatives, died of pneumonia last night at his home here in his seventy-third year. He had been in ill health since he was stricken with a heart attack in February.

After sampling the speed of horses like Bull Lea and Jacola in stake events at Pimlico and Laurel, W. L. Brann's Aethelwold today raced in more suitable company and managed to eke out a head triumph in the Meadows Purse, a mile-andseventy-yard event at Bowie for 3-year-olds.

Mr. and Mrs. Loring Washburn of Riverdale and Greenwich, Conn., entertained with a supper dance last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Washburn's daughter, Miss Mary Aylett Royall, who celebrated her birthday, and for her fiance, Thomas K. Chalmers. Earlier in the evening Mr.

A 46 per cent increase in bookings on Palm Beach trousers and slacks for 1939 over last year was reported here yesterday by L. S. Goldsmith, who directs advertising for the Goodall Company, makers of Palm Beach clothes.

The Misses Constance M. and Beatrix C. Hoyt, debutante daughters of Mrs. Franklin Chase Hoyt of Wappingers Falls, N. Y., and the late Judge Hoyt, were the guests of honor last night at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. William Willis Reese in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

When we put out of here at daybreak this morning, with Captain Kep Verbeke to sample some of the duck shooting that we have been hearing so much about, all the weather portents were good. There was a brisk southeast wind and the skies were overcast, so it looked like a good day for sport.

Stephen T. Dunn of 1,376 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, head of the trust department of the Lawyers Trust Company at 185 Montague Street, died on Wednesday night in the Brooklyn Hospital of pneumonia.

Charges that two witnesses committed perjury while testifying in an action brought by eleven electrical manufacturers against Local 3 of the International Electrical Workers Union, were made yesterday by Walter Gordon Merritt, attorney for the plaintiffs, who asked John Kirkland Clark, Special Master, to hear testimony on the subject.

The marriage of Miss Frances Eugenie Mathey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Clarence Mathey of Maplewood, to Arthur Felix von der Linden, son of Mrs. William von der Linden of East Orange, took place this evening in St. George's Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Francis H. Richey, performed the ceremony.

Fred Apostoli, San Francisco middleweight, mowed down Young Corbett 3d in the eighth round of their scheduled fifteen-round battle last night in Madison Square Garden and established himself as the outstanding candidate for the world middleweight title now claimed by himself and Solly Krieger, Brooklyn veteran.

The proposed new service of the Hapag-Lloyd Lines between Key West, Fla., and Havana, which would have been the first of its kind to be operated in the American steamship field by a foreign concern, has been abandoned, it was learned yesterday. John Schroder, general manager of the German lines, confirmed reports that the service would not be started.

Officials maintained silence or a noncommittal attitude today concerning the summoning home of Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, to report on the "singular attitude" of President Roosevelt and other American officials concerning Germany.

The apparent intention of Harry L. Hopkins and other Administration officials is to turn the WPA into a permanent government department engaged in all types of construction work, Christian G. Norman, chairman of the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers Association, declared last night.

A tie for third place in the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament was brought about today between Mikhail Botwinnik of Moscow and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, when the Soviet expert won his adjourned seventh-round game from Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, Russian expatriate and present champion of the world.

Cotton-mill activity was unchanged last week, although the seasonal trend was upward, and the adjusted index eased to 118.7 from 119-2, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Nov. 13, 1937, the index was 99.5

The will of James B. Dobbins of Old Greenwich, retired cotton broker, who died Sept. 6, aged 88, disposes of an estate of $165,000 in personal property. The will was admitted to probate today by Judge Harold L. Knapp in the Greenwich Probate Court.

Drastic revision of the present complicated Unemployment Insurance Law to speed payment of benefits to relieve employers of cumbersome clerical work, and to ease the pressure on the placement work were recommended by Herman A. Gray, chairman of Governor Lehman's Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council, in an address here last night.

Nine members of Premier Edouard Daladier's own Radical Socialist party voted against the government's decree laws and fifteen out of a total of of 105 present abstained when the Premier today explained and defended his action at a party meeting.
Bronko Nagurski of Chicago, recognized in Pennsylvania and several other States as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, lost his title tonight to Jim Londos of Greece.

The University of Miami overwhelmed a heavier Duquesne football team, 21 to 7, on power and finesse tonight before 13,296 spectators, including Mayor La Guardia of New York and Fred Snite Jr., America's most famous invalid.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Frequently before and always after Notre Dame has beaten Army, newspaper writers become sympathetically apologetic for the cadets and point out that it is Notre Dame's manpower and reserve strength that prevailed.

Samuel Leon Parcher, an instructor in physics at Phillips Exeter Academy for twenty years, died yesterday at Lakeview, N. C., where he was visiting relatives, according to word received here today. He was 69 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of this city and Wheatley Hills, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Justine Bayard Cutting, to Alexander C. Cushing, son of Mrs. James Denison Sawyer of New York and Newport, R. I., and the late Howard Cushing.

Asserting that the army's present goal bf 2,320 defense airplanes by 1940 was "far below our immediate needs," Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, told the annual Conference of the New England Council and six Governors today that this total might have to be quadrupled "to meet the tremendous pace the rest of the world is setting."

The appearance of the second major foreign government dollar loan lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $50,839,750. This compared with only $10,418,750 in new bonds marketed last week and with a total of $38,721,500 offered during this week last year.

Sir Earle Page, Minister of Commerce, reviewing the Anglo-American agreement, said the Empire preference changes were made with the full agreement of the Commonwealth and would not adversely affect Australian industries.

Representatives Wolverton of New Jersey and Jenkins of Ohio, both Republicans, attacked. at a hearing today President Roosevelt's Executive Order authorizing the Congressional committee investigating the TVA to inspect income tax returns of utility executives and companies.
Pre-Thanksgiving sermons will be preached tomorrow in churches and today in synagogues, several clergymen discussing the question "For What Have We To Be Thankful?"

After a run of eight days the thirty-ninth National Automobile Show closed last night in Grand Central Palace. Although the attendance for the period did not equal that of 1937, the show was declared by the management to have been the most successful in years from the standpoint of selling cars.

Intercollegiate athletic competition was ordered abolished at St. John's College today by President Stringfellow Barr in a statement which termed the American collegiate athletic system "semi-professionalized."

Miss Elizabeth Feldmeier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Feldmeier of this place, was married this evening to Frank Melville Libby, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Libby of Chappaqua, N. Y., in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. The Rev. George Hugh Smyth performed the ceremony.

Miss Esther Moody Barlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt D. Barlow of this city, was married tonight to Seymour Perkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Perkins of Plainfield. The Rev. Dr. John J. Moment, officiated in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, A reception followed at the Barlow home.
MANHATTAN Gross assets, $360,968; net, $324,299. To Lillie A. Berbecker, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $239,502; Smyth Smyth Jr.. attorneys, 25 Broad St.

The Railway Express Agency, Inc., has filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for authority to issue $16,000,000 of serial notes to be used to retire a like amount of 5 per cent gold bonds, Series A, which will remain outstanding on March 1, 1939, as part of an issue of $32,000,000 of such bonds issued in March, 1929.

Three college graduates competent in the field of research are wanted by the city school system to accept lifetime jobs in the New York City school system at salaries of $7,500. Added inducements are vacations, tenure and pension rights.

Olive J. Gregan of 75-41 113th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, heads the new civil service list for policewomen, according to official ratings made public yesterday by Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

Barclays Bank (Dominion, Colonial and Overseas), 54 Lombard Street, London, England, has applied to the State Banking Department for permission to open an agency at the United Kingdom pavilion on the World's Fair grounds in Flushing, it was announced today.

In friendly but firm tones, and with the hint that there now are improved ways for handling commerce by "other agencies," a representative group of shippers and traffic managers in this country and Canada will ask the railroads to put more intelligent and sympathetic efforts into the adjusting of their rates and services.

A virtual embargo against Japanese and Italian imports has been established by direction of President Leon Cortes Castro to the Exchange Control Board to give preference in the purchase of foreign exchange to countries with which Costa Rica has a favorable trade balance.

Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy took time off today to attend a sale at Christie's of paintings by old masters removed from Rufford Abbey, the home of the Savile family in Nottinghamshire, which also is in the market with the estate.

Mrs. Ray Smith of 2,728 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, an organizer and former national president of the Women's Auxiliary of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, died Thursday in the Brooklyn Cancer Institute after an illness of six weeks. She was 67 years old.

The Jetter Dairy Company, Inc., of Oriskany Falls charged in a suit filed in Federal Court today that its business was being interfered with by the Dairymen's League, Bordens and the Sheffield Company through the Federal Milk Marketing Law.
Italian children may follow the antics of Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck in their funny papers but must give up other foreign comics.

The Rev. Otho Stephen Beaumister, pastor of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Glenville, Greenwich, for the last fourteen years, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport, of high blood pressure and a heart ailment. He was 54 years old.

Department store sales for the week ended Nov. 12 were 1 per cent lower than for the corresponding week last year, and for the four weeks ended Nov. 12 were 6 per cent lower than for the corresponding period of 1937, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Harry Hubbard Pittinger, assistant solicitor of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, New York, died yesterday at the Paterson (N. J.) General Hospital after a four-day illness. Mr. Pittinger was 60 years old.

Replying to the United States demand for Open Door rights in China, Japan denied today that there had been discrimination against Americans. The Japanese note was handed to the United States Ambassador, Joseph C. Grew, by Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita at 6 P. M. after its approval earlier in the day by the Cabinet and Emperor Hirohito.

The suit sponsored by Mayor La Guardia in an attempt to block investigations by the City Council into the operation of radion station WNYC and into relief expenditures lost in the Appellate Division yesterday when the court upheld
The discovery of the only early Islamic paintings ever found in Iran proper (Persia) is announced by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the report of its 1937 Iranian Expedition.

Bond prices receded moderately yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with the trading stepped up. Even the local tractions, which have been rising since before the election, reflected a considerable volume of profit-taking and reflected a substantial paring of listed values at the close.

Robert Branham, 38, Works Progress Administration worker, gave his life here last night for that of his 10-year-old son, Robert Jr. An electric interurban caught them on a 160-foot-long trestle over Eagle Creek as they crossed to hunt.

This country's trade agreement program cannot make, at any time in the near future, any substantial contribution toward a solution of the cotton problem, but benefit to cotton from trade agreements must come through an increase in American imports, Secretary Wallace said here tonight.

According to the Department of Commerce, the United States imported during October $562,381,000 gold. This exceeds the $520,907,000 imported in September, before and during the Czech crisis, and is the largest amount ever sent to us in a single month.

Proposals to decrease the number of Jews in Hungary were considered today at a government party committee meeting attended by Premier Bela Imredi. The principal suggestions discussed were encouraging emigration of Jews and providing special taxes to make rich Jews pay for emigration of those who could not afford to move.

Concord Ave (10-2641), s e c of 150th St. 123x94: Jaydee Garage Co. Inc, to Saul M. Dash, 499 Ft Washington Ave. 146th St (9-2290), n s, 150 w of Brook Ave. 50x100; D. Robert Kaplan, referee, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
Stockholders of the Ward Baking Corporation approved yesterday the proposal to merge their company with its wholly owned operating subsidiary, the Ward Baking Company; under the name of the latter.

Specific opportunities for the sale in foreign countries of a diversified variety of American products ranging from heavy industrial machinery to figsaw puzzles are listed in the current issue of Commerce Reports, published by the Department of Commerce.

Excellency: I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your Excellency's note dated Oct. 6, addressed to the Minister of, Foreign Affairs, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, concerning the rights and interests of the United States in China.

Edward L. Bartley, 59 years old, of 217 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was held in Ocean County Jail here today in default of $25,000 bail on a charge of having misappropriated $262,252 from the estate of his late father, William S. Bartley of New York City.

Maria Safonoff, who appeared in piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, offered Glazounoff's Sonata in B flat, Op. 74, as the most elaborate work on her program. She played the score with a relish of its curve and sentiment.

Bishop William T. Manning has received all but $66,000 of the $435,000 required to start work to c6mplete part of the interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in time to put another section in use when the World's Fair opens in April.

A powerful finish enabled Howard Bachman of Port Jefferson to come from behind and defeat Richmond Van Wagoner, Sayville ace, in the fourth annual Edward J. Burlingham memorial interscholastic twomile cross-country race today at Argyle Lake Park.
Foreign silver coin amounting to $11,152,000, and believed to be Chinese, arrived in the United States in the week ended on Nov. 11, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday the State Labor Relations Act and orders of the State Labor Relations Board, which were challenged by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

J. MEYERS STATIONERY AND PRINTING CO., INC., 315 Broadway-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $21 846 and assets of $40,112. A settlement of 60 Per cent, payable 30 per cent in cash and balance in notes, is proposed.
Turpentine firm, 221/2; sales, 47 barrels; receipts, 293 barrels; shipments, 1,071; stock, 50,962. Rosin, firm; sales, 398; receipts, 1,303: shipments, 814; stock 296,487.

A surprise in the election of the executive committee of the General Confederation of Labor tonight defeated all the Communist candidates and nearly broke up the meeting of the National Confederation Committee.

The first performance of the twenty-seventh annual varsity production of Hunter College, "Stage Door," was held last night at the Heckscher Theatre, 104th Street and Fifth Avenue. Other performances will be held tonight and tomorrow evening with a special matinee tomorrow afternoon.
Major William I Shuman, president of Shuman Co., investment brokers, has been appointed State organizer of the American Federation of Little Business, Inc.

The marriage of Miss Janet Lansing Wicks, daughter of Dean and Mrs. Robert Russell Wicks of this city, to Dr. William Ernest Gillespie, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Gillespie of Exeter, N. H., took place today in the Princeton University Chapel.
German exports to the United States promise to drop to a lower level this year than at any time since 1919, according to estimates by the Department of Commerce.

Millard Whited, who received $1,000 of the $25,000 reward given by New Jersey for the conviction of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the Lindbergh baby kidnapping, was returned today by State police to Hunterdon County, where he is charged with issuing a worthless check for $23.99.

An attempt to outlaw from New York State any activity or representation in behalf of an insurance company not licensed to sell policies here-Lloyd's of London, for example-was made yesterday by spokesmen for the locally authorized liability companies at a hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law.

The James Ferris High School eleven of this city captured the scholastic football championship of Hudson County at Roosevelt Stadium tonight by vanquishing Memorial of West New York, 20-0. It was Ferris's fifth victory of the season over county rivals.
The names of the winners of the second Pittsburgh Glass Institute contest for "outstanding examples of the application of glass to architecture and design" were made public yesterday.

President Roosevelt's plan for American continental solidarity against Nazi and Fascist penetration was attacked editorially today by Mexico's largest and most influential daily, the Universal, as really a program for conquering Latin American markets.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will be chief guest and speaker at the twenty-fifth annual bankers forum dinner of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking on Dec. 1 in the Hotel Astor.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Jeanne Levison, daughter of Mrs. Lois C. Levison of 50 East Seventieth Street and the late Mr. Levison, to Adrian C. Israel, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Cremieux Israel of this city, formerly of New Orleans, has been announced by her mother. The marriage will take place on Dec. 15.

T. Grant Caldwell Jr. of Brooklyn, filed suit here late today against Edward Mark Maclay Carolin asking $250,000 damages for loss of affections of his wife, the former Elizabeth Greve Caldwell, who is now married to Carolin.
Thomas B. Stoel, 60, superintend?? ent of schools of the Third Supervisory District of Jefferson County died today of a bullet woun?? while being taken in an ambulance to a Watertown hospital.

The William C. Orr estate sold to a client of James Felt Co. the five-story tenement at 213 East 114th Street, subject to a first mortgage of $10,500. The house is on a lot 25 by 100.11 feet, between Third and Second Avenues. The Fifth Avenue Bank represented the seller.

Mrs. Leona Hurd Pierce, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lee Maidment Hurd of this city, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Stevenson Pinney, also of New York, at the home of her parents, 39 East Fiftieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman performed the ceremony.

Staving off two touchdown bids in the fourth quarter, Tome School's football team battled the Horace Mann eleven to a scoreless deadlock in the season's finale for both schools on Horace Mann's gridiron yesterday.
A treaty with Canada for the development of the St. Lawrence River Basin appeared today to be an early goal of the Administration.
William H. Bade, a member of the New York Stock Exchange with offices at Scholle Brothers, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 2 East Seventieth Street. He was 41 years old.

Leopold Loevin, treasurer of the Loevin Liquor Store Company in New Rochelle and chairman of the New Rochelle Board of Health twenty years ago, died Thursday night in the Sydenham Hospital, after an illness of three months. His age was 76.

Five former officers of Local 118 here of the United Automobile Workers of America, who were ousted last Summer for supporting international officers removed by Homer Martin, international president, have been suspended for six years from union membership, it was announced today by the local.

Statistics on traffic accidents in the first ten months of 1938, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, indicate that it will be a "banner year for safety." The Mayor's statement, made public at City Hall soon after his departure for Havana, stressed the fact that the figures showed a decline in accidents to children of school age, as compared with the same period in 1937.

Like his two co-defendants who preceded him, Erich Glaser, former private in the Air Corps, took the witness stand yesterday at the espionage trial before Federal Judge John C. Knox and denied that he had helped Germany get American defense secrets.

The Rev. Canon Sidney Gould, general secretary of the missionary society of the Chureh of England in Canada and internationally known leader in church circles, died here today. Dr. Could, 69 years old, failed to rally following an operation a month ago.

WHILE Mr. Atkinson and Mr. Nugent are out today--no doubt watching some one or other roll up a clutch of touchdowns in the Bowl--this department will take the chance to prowl over into their- domains of the drama and the shouting pictures.

SUBMARINE PATROL, from a screen play by Rian James, Darrell Ware and Jack Yellen based on a book by Ray Millholland; directed by John Ford; produced by Darryl F. Zanuck for Twentieth CenturyFox. At the Roxy.

Monday a selection by David Garnett from "The Letters of T. E. Lawrence" will be published. Few characters among the famous have been more complex. Even his closest friends disagree in their estimates.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired and will place on view this morning in its room of recent accessions an early landscape by Corot, portraying "Hagar in the Wilderness."

Fordham's still badly battered football forces will engage South Carolina at the Polo Grounds today, play starting at 2 P. M. It will be the last intersectional meeting for Coach Jim Crowley's men, who have defeated Upsala, Waynesburg, Oregon and St. Mary's; lost to Pittsburgh and tied Purdue and North Carolina.
Thousands of poor received new clothes and free meals from the government today as Egypt celebrated the birth of a princess to 17-year-old Queen Farida yesterday.

Mrs. Aldo Nadi, wife of the famous international fencer, won the annual Van Buskirk prep fencing competition in a fence-off with Miss Ruth Maxwell of Hofstra College at the Fencers Club last night. The fence-off was necessitated when each came through keen competition with six victories and one defeat.

The first painting by an American woman to be included in the permanent collection of the Museum of Living Art at New York University will go on exhibition today in the museum's headquarters at 100 Washington Square East, it was announced yesterday by A. E. Gallatin, director.

Epsie M. Kinard, in 156 E 52 St; Mrs. Georgiana P. Sillcox, in 19 E 65th St; Alexander Orr, in 157 E 72d St; Joseph N. Siegel, in 139 E 94th St; Fred Hugli, in 59 E 96th St; Mrs. Irene M. Smith, in 1,039 Madison Ave; Duff Conger, Inc. brokers.
End-of-theaccount considerations restricted today the stock markets here. The undertone was firm on satisfaction with the Anglo-American trade pact, in which textiles and distillers gained most.

Warning against hysteria as well as complacency on the part of the American people, Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, in an address here yesterday, said a more active participation in government was necessary to preserve democracy in this country.

Bernard R. Le Fort of Scarsdale, an executive of the Bernhard Ullman Company of New York, dealers in yarns and needlework, died last night of a heart attack in St. Agnes Hospital here. He was 55 years old.

The mice and the rats were unable to make their scheduled appearance yesterday at the opening of the twenty-fourth annual Cat Show. However. a silver tabby Persian named Bo-Peep appeased disappointed spectators by turning up with an orphaned white Pekin duckling which she had adopted as a companion for her kitten.

Play in the annual Public Schools Athletic League ice hockey tournament started at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night with six teams swinging into action. Textile High appeared as one of the more formidable sextets as it swept to a 4to-O victory over Manual Training, while in the other tests Brooklyn Tech blanked Jamaica, 1 to 0, and Andrew Jackson held Boys High to a scoreless tie.
One of the navy's pioneer long-range bombing planes crashed at high speed into a boathouse during practice landings at Pearl Harbor, killing two and injuring its other five occupants late last night.

Jimmy Wilson, for five years manager of the Phillies, was named a coach of the Reds today. Wilson arrived here today and signed a contract with General Manager Warren C. Giles to succeed Eddie Roush, who announced yesterday he would not renew his contract with the baseball club.

The treaties which the United States has just concluded with Great Britain, Canada and the British Colonial Empire are in striking contrast to the foreign trade methods pursued by Germany. The new treaties, like the eighteen treaties preceding them, are on a "most favored nation" basis.
Netherland Axe (13-3409a), n w cor of 232d St. 200x100; 232d-Netherland, Inc, to Institutional Securities Corp. 60 E 42d St; due Oct. 1. 1949, at 5 per cent; $210,000.

An investing syndicate has purchased from the Union Square Savings Bank the five-story garden apartment house at 208 Center Avenue, New Rochelle, . Westchester, for cash above a purchase money a mortgage of $160,000.

Six more persons, including Mrs. Ellen Jane Palmer Schaeffer, 84 years old, were arrested today in connection with an alleged attempt to obtain fraudulently the $20,00,000 estate of Mrs. Henrietta E. Garrett, for which there have been more than 20,000 claimants.

Selection of the extraordinary grand jury that will hear evidence in the investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn was completed with unexpected swiftness yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Francis D. McCurn, exactly twenty-nine days after Governor Lehman formally ordered the inquiry that is regarded as the most sweeping of its kind in the history of the State.

Germany summoned Ambassador Dieckhoff home from Washington yesterday as a counter to the summons to'Ambassador Wilson. He will report on "public sentiment in the United States and the singular attitude toward domestic affairs in Germany manifested in various declarations by President Roosevelt and other important United States personalities."

Herr Goebbels need only call atention to the story of the demolitionof the Sixth Avenue "L" to show the sloppy way in which the miserable democracies go about doing things. The Sixth Avenue elevated line, as another columnon this page pointed out yesterday, was "doomed" nearly ten years ago.
Four firemen were burned on the face and hands when they were caught in a burst of flame while fighting a twoalarm fire in a two-story brick office building at 232 Broadway, here, this afternoon.

Complete plans for the exhibition of contemporary American art at the New York World's Fair 1939 were announced yesterday afternoon at a reception for artists given by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, at his city home, 48 Washington Mews.

Mr. and Mrs. Waiter Maynard Drury gave a reception yesterday at their home, 969 Fifth Avenue, for their debutante daughter, Miss Innes Kane Drury. The debutante, who received the guests with her parents, wore a frock of blue velvet, made with a long, full skirt, long sleeves and heart-shaped neckline.

Cinar Spot of Earlsmoor, who won the Sportsman's Cup last year as the outstanding field trial puppy, rose to new honors today as he captured the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels on the inaugural card of the Monmouth County Spaniel Field Trial Association.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 29, 1938, a defense of the Children's Court by its presiding justice, John Warren Hill, in reply to the criticism of Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division as follows:

A resolution addressed to Dr. Hans Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, warning that, unless Nazi persecution of Jews is "made to cease," it will result in "a mad, universal reign of terror," was drawn up here today at a meeting of the Board of Home Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Premier George Kiosseivanoff made a statement on foreign policy yesterday in Parliament. He said that Bulgaria was anxious to continue on the friendliest relations with both Turkey and Yugoslavia, to which countries she is linked by a special treaty.

Mrs. Charles D. Dickey, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sloan and Mrs. Richard Colt, owing to mourning, have recalled invitations to the dinner they had planned to give for Miss Mary Sloan Dickey, Miss Marion Mason Colt and Miss Catherine Sloan Colt on Jan. 6 at the RitzCarlton before the second Junior Assembly of this season.

The Italian liner Rex is due to sail today for Mediterranean ports. Passengers are Axel Jonsson, president of the Swedish-American Line; Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Norman, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Curry, George W. Green, Miss Helen L. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter, the Rev. John J. Brady, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pollak and Miss Ethel B. Richardson.
Tint Champlin of this village, former president of the American Cutlery Manufacturers Association, died yesterday in a Bradford, Pa., hospital at the age of 72.

Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen and John B. Trevor Jr., both of whom are descendants of distinguished Colonial families, were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church by the rector, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

Mail orders received in wholesale markets were heavier last week for seasonal as well as for holiday merchandise and buyers who had been doing little more than sampling goods for Christmas sales increased the size of their orders on individual lines, at the same time covering a wider variety of merchandise, Dun Bradstreet, Inc.,. reported yesterday.

Last year the United Hospital Fund raised a little over two million dollarsabout 10 per cent more than the year previous. This year it needs about two and a half million dollars. It speaks on behalf of ninety-odd voluntary hospitals, which operate on a non-profit basis and which receive no public funds except in return for services rendered.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $39,161,976, to be represented by two States and seventy-six municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $42,250,850 for this week.

The Rev. Chester J. Hoyt, retired Methodist minister, who had held pastorates in several New Jersey communities, died yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn after a three weeks' illness. He was 70 years old.

A shabby and penniless old man who was identified through papers found on his person as Jimmy Martin, 73, a famous jockey of the Nineties, who once rode for Queen Victoria and "Diamond Jim" Brady and W. C. Whitney, lay near death in a Miami hospital tonight.
A small boy and an elderly man stood among a handful of townsfolk in this community tonight and paid tribute to Abraham Lincoln's immortal address of seventy-five years ago.

The Pictorial Coat and Dress Company, Inc., 411 Fifth Avenue, New York, has agreed to cease using in advertising matter or in any other manner the word "wholesale" to describe its business or the prices at which it sells garments, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

President Roosevelt has taken steps to insure that between 12,000 and 15,000 political refugees from Germany who are now in this country as visitors shall' not be forced to return to their own country at the expiration of their visas, he said today.

The new national planting goal established by Secretary Wallace for the 1939 program calls for a reduction of 7,500,000 acres in cotton, corn, wheat, tobacco, rice and other "soil-depleting" crops. American farmers, if they hope to obtain subsidy payments, must plant no more than 275,000,000 of their 365,000,000 cultivated acres to these crops.

The eight-room residence at 19 West Fifty-fourth Street, Bayonne, N. J., has been sold by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, for Walter V. Sutherland to Rodrigo Rama. who will convert the building for two-family use.

Uniformed Storm Troopers today rounded up the Jewish population of Nuremberg and marched them to the Labor Front office. There they were "persuaded" to accept a plan for releasing their property, under which the Labor Front retains 90 per cent of the realizable value.

Miss Mary-Clinton Spencer, daughter of Mrs. Clinton James Spencer of Stony Brook Farm, this place, and the late Mr. Spencer, was married here this afternoon to William Dennison Brooke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brooke of Englewood, in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Bronxville High School completed its third undefeated season in the twelve years that Dan Matthai has been football coach, by turning back its traditional rival, Scarsdale High, 10 to 0, before 2,000 today.

John L. Lewis was unanimously elected today as first constitutional president of the newly created Congress of Industrial Organizations, successor of the three-year-old Committee for Industrial Organization.

Harry F. Wolf, national champion, gained an easy victory to advance to the quarter-finals of the Princeton Club's nineteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday, but other seeded players were not so fortunate.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The Anglo-American trade treaty has been the factor which has overshadowed all other considerations in the wool market trading this week.

Leo E. Archer, who retired last July after forty years in the passenger department of the International Mercantile Marine Company, has been appointed general passenger traffic manager of the MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., operators of the American Republics Line, according to an announcement yesterday by Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the company.

Clarence M. Woolley has resigned as president and chairman of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation. Henry M. Reed, president of the subsidiary Standard Sanitary Manufacturing Company, has been elected president of the parent company to succeed Mr. Woolley.

Columbia and Syracuse, two teams that have had as many ups and downs this season as a department store elevator, will meet at Baker Field this afternoon before some 25,000 spectators with the outcome of the struggle balanced on a question mark. Trying to figure out the Light Blue or the Orange on any particular day is an almost impossible task.
Donald B. Gillies, vice president of the Republic Steel Corporation t was elected yesterday president. of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

Harvard today won all three housecollege games played as preliminaries to its varsity football meeting with Yale tomorrow.. Lewis took Whitman's long forward pass in the end zone to give Adams House a 7-0 football victory over Saybrook College, aided by Whitman's place goal for the extra point.

Clients of the Martin Fuchs Company, brokers, have purchased two four-family tenements in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The house at 711 Bristol Street, accommodating four families, on a plot 26.6 by 100 feet, was sold by the Home Owners Loan

The trade treaty between Great Britain and the United States signed on Thursday should be a substantial stimulant to advertising of those products on which duties have been cut, advertising agency executives, said yesterday.

Clients of the Martin Fuchs Company, brokers, have purchased two four-family tenements in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The house at 711 Bristol Street, accommodating four families, on a plot 26.6 by 100 feet, was sold by the Home Owners Loan

The trade treaty between Great Britain and the United States signed on Thursday should be a substantial stimulant to advertising of those products on which duties have been cut, advertising agency executives, said yesterday.
The signing of the Anglo-American trade treaty fell flat today so far as its effect on the domestic wheat, corn and provision markets was concerned.

41st St. 318 W; K. P. Repair Corp to Ambro Realty Corp, 35 W 45th St; (50c). 44th St, 15-17 W; Excelsior Savings Bank to Gladiton Realty Corp. 15 W 44th St; ($2.50). 160th St, 655 W; Hudson View Construction Co to Bessie Handler, 1,491 Macombs Rd; (S2).

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Raymond W. Saunders. Inf.-Res., 337 St. Ann's Ave., Bronx, N. Y., 18th Infantry (lst Division) (D), is ordered tc active duty, Dec. 4. at Fort Wadsworth New York, for training. Date of rank Nov. 13, 1936. He will revert to an inactive status Dec. 17.
Tommy Armour, former United States open, British open and American P. G. A. king, won the annual thirty-six-hole Mid-South open golf tournament today on the championship No. 2 course.
British imports from the United States in the first nine months of 1938 were higher by [Pound]14,500,000 or 14 per cent, than in the corresponding period of 1937.
Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt gave a supper dance last night in the roof-garden suite of the St. Regis to introduced to society Mrs. Vanderbilt's daughter, Miss Rosemary Warburton.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, in the first of the season's Young People's Concerts, Carnegie Hall,; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Gerald Tracy, piano, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Budapest String Quartet and William Primrose, viola, Town Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Adolf Vogel, bass-baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.

The stamp collection of President Roosevelt, "America's No. 1 philatelist," will shortly receive additions in the form of blocks of four of postal adhesives of Argentina, Brazil, Trinidad and Tobago, and Uruguay, as a gift from Captain Harry Sadler of the American Republics liner Brazil, it was announced here yesterday by the steamship company.
By-I. LINCOLN SEIDE Greene St, 10, 5-story lofts and stores, 28.1x100; Thomas B. Walker et al, against 12 Greene St Corp, due, $16,245, taxes. etc. S1.396; to plaintiff for $20,000.

The marriage of Mrs. Hope Norton Stevens of Hillcrest, Darien, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hope Norton of Hacienda San Miguel, Milagro, Ecuador, to Paul T. Iaccaci of 25 Sutton Place South, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The pastor, the Rev.

Of the group of New York City firms of underwriters, the First Boston Corporation led all others in the third quarter of 1938 (July, August and September) in the amount of purchases in group participation of security flotations of $1,000,000 or more, including purchases in those managed, taking $34,913,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in a statistical analysis.

Nathan Lans, proprietor of the Lans Galleries, dealers in furniture and decorations, has subleased from Richard W. Lehne, Inc., the entire five-st building at 422 Madison Avenue, near the southwest corner of Forty-ninth Street.
The plan of the Central Railroad of New Jersey for a temporary reduction in its interest rates may have to be revised as a result of the decision of the Federal Court

Gertrude Lawrence decided today to relinquish the leading role in -Lenore Coffee Cowen's new play, "The Birds Stop Singing." Her present role in "Susan and God" is too demanding to permit her to rehearse another part while playing this one, she said.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York and Mrs. Lehman arrived here today for a few days' visit. The Governor declined to discuss any public issue except the situation in Germany, which he called "indescribably horrible."

Dr. John A. Harriss, former Deputy Police Commissioner and traffic expert, who died on Oct. 11, last, left an estate of less than $5,000, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate. Dr. Harriss named his widow, Mrs. Lucille L. Harriss of the Hotel Savoy Plaza his sole legatee.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Daniel A. Caputi of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 118-Princess Lida of Thurn and Taxis, et al, petrs., v. Gerald Purcell Fitzgerald, individually, etc., et al. Argued for both. Leave granted petitioners to file an additional brief by Monday next.

The first step in disposing of a utility property in the Utilities Power and Light Corporation system developed yesterday with the disclosure that Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., had entered into an agreement with Charles Adams, trustee for Utilities Power and Light, looking toward the sale of the Newport Electric Corporation.

A frank statement of the grave distress that will confront Spain unless food is sent by other countries was made by former Premier Diego Martinez Barrio before the congress of the National Committee for Aid to Spain, which opened yesterday. The situation had never before been put so openly or in such dark colors.

Scoring their first touchdown in the first three minutes of the game, the Harvard jayvees turned back the Yale junior varsity eleven, 146, today. Arthur Row's pass to Sherman set the stage for the initial tally, then Hoar and Row drove goalward in three line plunges, Row making the six points.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has sold two of the twelve high-speed tankers now under construction to the United States Navy at the contract price, which is about $3,130,000 each. The tankers, although not yet completed, have been christened the Cimarron and the Neosho.
In clammy weather more reminiscent of Spring than the week before Thanksgiving, Princeton and Army today finished preparation for their game here tomorrow.

The China Night benefit program scheduled for last night, in the Metropolitan Opera House under the joint auspices of the Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China and the Church Committee for China Relief was postponed yesterday until some time next month.

Manhattan's football team, at full strength for the first time since early in the season, will seek its second consecutive major victory this afternoon when it meets a strong West Virginia eleven at the Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 10,000 is expected to witness the kick-off at 2 P. M.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 17 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The right of a holder of an Albany to New York railroad ticket to a seat on the train was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in affirming a verdict for $45 won by Philip Davis, an attorney, against the New York Central Railroad last March in Municipal Court.

American historical Staffordshire ware and early American furniture from the collection of William Randolph Hearst brought $23,522 yesterday afternoon at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, making the total for the two sessions to dat $42,325.

A criminal court 'jury tonight acquitted Mayor Robert R. Williams, City Commissioner John W. Dubose and Thomas E. Grady, rate expert, of a charge of soliciting a $250,000 bribe from the Florida Power and Light Company.

The Workmen's Sick and Death Benefit Fund has made a loan of $123,500 through John F. Bottomley, Inc., on the recently completed six-story apartment house at 34-35 Seventy-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, to Spitzer Werner.

The slight flurry that the signing of the Anglo-Canadian-American trade agreement occasioned in the foreign exchange market here on Thursday failed to carry over yesterday and trading throughout the day was dull.

P. Jackson's Bughtrig by Winalot from Skipper's Slip today won the Derby Cup over one and three-quarter miles, defeating H. de Vere Clifton's Golden Martlet by one and one-half lengths. The same distance separated Golden Martlet and W. Carr's Flagg, who ran third in the field of ten. Bughtrig started at 5 to 2, Golden Martlet at 11 to 2, and Flagg at 7 to 1.

Daphne Du Maurier's "Rebecca" (Doubleday, Doran) has gone into a ninth printing, bringing the total to 195,000 copies, including the Litterary Guild edition. The publishers report that they have received orders for 87,500 copies within the last thirty days.
Nazism was denounced in vigorous terms by spokesmen for organized labor tonight, who called for vigorous measures to meet the conditions existing in Germany.

Norwich University has established a bureau of industrial research to cooperate with Vermont manufacturers and business enterprises. The director of the bureau will be Major Douglas E. Howes, Associate Professor of Electrical Engineering.

Receptions and parties will be eld today in all States to listen to broadcast by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and four prominent ??lumnae in celebration of National Barnard Day, a preliminary observ??nce of the fiftieth anniversary of Barnard College.

Miss Margaret Taylor Collier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Collier of Bordentown, became the bride today of William Heisler Wells, son of Judge and Mrs. Harold B. Wells of this city. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church by the Rev. Alfred L.Banyard, pastor.
THE annual Winter national championship tournament, which the American Contract Bridge League will conduct in Cleveland beginning Monday night, Nov. 28, will be well attended by New York players.
Frank C. Huyck, chairman of the board of F. C. Huyck Sons, Rensselaer, N. Y., textile manufacturers, died today at his home here after a month's illness. His age was 64.

IT was some forty years ago that John Dewey wrote his "'Studies in Logical Theory" -- a book which won serious attention to pragmatic philosophy even before William James delivered and published his famous lectures on pragmatism.

The Little Gardens Club of New York City will be the beneficiary of two performances of Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "Patience" to be given Nov. 30 and Dec. 3 at the Heckscher Theatre by the Village Light Opera Company under the direction of Allan C. Hinckley.
Despite our traditional policy of isolation, recent events have brought important developments in the foreign policy of the United States along five international fronts:
Conservation officials and legislators of eleven Eastern seaboard' States approved yesterday a proposal for joint State control and conservation of the Atlantic marine fisheries.

Henry Stafford, superintendent of the Masonic Home, died there today at the age of 78. He was a former State Representative and former Sheriff of New Castle County. He was the first superintendent of the Minquadale home and served for six years.

Armed with authority to exceed the city's debt limit by as mush as $315,000,000, if necessary, in order to help finance the cost of acquiring rapid-transit, street car and bus lines now in private operation, the La Guardia administration is about to enter the final stages of its newest drive to bring about the unification of transit facilities under municipal ownership and control.

LISTENERS in tune with sixty. to eighty stations scattered from coast to coast will be within range of the Metropolitan Opera matinees on Saturdays beginning this week when von Gluck's "Orpheus and Eurydice" will be revived.
Big Rebel, owned by H. E. Talbott, won the $1,000 Noel Laing Memorial Steeplechase handicap brush race in the rain on the Montpelier estate of Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott today.

The bright flowered brooms are abundantly enjoyed in European gardens and on-the West Coast, but in the Eastern United States they are used only sparingly, probably because gardeners are unfamiliar with their sterling qualities.

SINCE the last bulletin about musical comedies was posted on this Sabbath notice board, "Knickerbocker Holiday" and "Leave It to Me!" have established permanent residence in the Forties. Probably they will be at home to World's Fair itinerants next Summer. "Leave It to Me!"

One of the finest performances ever recorded in a local schoolboy competition was given by the Brooklyn Tech first team yesterday as it shot a 1,089 score to win the annual New York Stock Exchange invitation interscholastic rifle shoot on the range of the Manhattan School of Firearms.

INNUMERABLE have been the books, the plays, the films that portray the inexhaustible Victoria. She has been shown to us as a secluded but impetuous Cinderella playing with her multitude of dolls in Kensington Palace, as an adoring wife, as an inconsolable widow.

IN a time when personal liberties are being trampled under foot and when personal vengeance is not only con doned but encouraged by totalitarian leaders, the great democracies must look again and with new concern to their Bills of Rights. In such documents lives the sum of man's victories over the forces of barbarism and oppression, and in their preservation lies the hope of man as a free individual.

-A dazzling display of speed by Lou Brock and Jack Brown brought Purdue's Boilermakers a 13-to-6 victory over Indiana today before a crowd of 32,000 in the forty-first game between the two Hoosier Big Ten schools.

ONE of the most important salon announcements of the year -- that of the Pittsburgh Salon for 1939-has been received. Photographers throughout the world are invited to send their prints, modern or orthodox, color or monochrome, to the exhibition.

Consumption of Lake Superior iron ore in October totaled 2,780,585 gross tons, the highest since the corresponding month last year, when 4,203,873 tons were burned, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today. Blast fur.

Formation of a Penn State association which will include all students, members of the faculty and the administrative staff, alumni and former students of the Pennsylvania State College is being considered by the Penn State Alumni Association.

The resignation of Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti, whose stanch democratic political conceptions and faith in the League of Nations remained unshaken by recent events, has evoked a wide controversy in the Finnish press.
Victory in the $1,500 Jamestown Handicap, feature event of the closing day of the 1938 racing sea-. son in New England, today went to Garrett Watts's Silverette, an 8-year-old mare by Vandergrift.

In a game in which both teams constantly punted and waited for breaks, Bloomsburg Teachers scored over Panzer Teachers, 12-6, today. Bloomsburg tallied first, followIng recovery of a fumble deep in the visitors' territory with Hopper going over.

At the conclusion or an unusually hard test that was finished in a downpour, Dalshangan Gold Digger, owned by the Clarion Kennels of Charles H. Toy, was named the top dog among the twenty-three starters in the open all-age English springer spaniel stake which closed

FOR upward of forty years Mr. Powys has traveled widely in the realms of gold, and his individualistic and penetrating appraisals of their States and goodly kingdoms have won him the confidence of hosts of readers.

THE intense activity in television is reflected by the granting during the past week of nine patents for new devices in this field to various inventors here and abroad. Constant improvement appears to be the keynote of the inventors.
A sharp decline in steamship travel of all classes during the year is reported in a survey of passenger carrying between New York and European ports.

The proposal to raze the Fulton Street elevated road in Brooklyn, as proposed last week by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, was' criticized yesterday by George S. Horton, president of the Bulkley Horton Company, Brooklyn and Queens brokers.
Mr. and Mrs. Aaron H. Haskell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Haskell, to Alan Kirschberg, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Kirschberg of Montreal.

Los ANGELES. DIGGING deep into the gray granite heart of old Mount San Jacinto, workmen have now turned a daring fifteen-year-old dream into a splendid engineering reality-a tunnel which will carry water from the Colorado River to 1,400,000 thirsty acres of Southern California.

In connection with the application of the recent press law, the government has suppressed forty-five publications, mostly Jewish-owned magazines or weekly economic papers. Among them is the theatrical weekly Szimhazi Elet, with a worldwide circulation of 250,000.

In a setting of rain, mud and sullen, low-hanging black clouds like that for a movie of a lost primeval world, the Yale and Harvard elevens fought it out today in the Bowl for the fifty-seventh time, and at the end Crimson flares burned through the wet twilight in a symbol of victory, which brought with it the Big Three title.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Roosevelt expressed the sentiments of all friends of labor in his message to the convention of the C. I. O. when he said, "Continued dissension can only lead to loss. of influence and prestige to all labor."

The annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind, under the auspices of the New York State Commission for the Blind, will open on Nov. 28, and continue through Christmas Eve. The sale will be held this year on the first and secqnd floors of the building at 601 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets.
An exhibition of arts and crafts by instructors teaching in the settlement houses of New York will be opened on Tuesday at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

In the program of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs for the next two years the study of proposed legislation will take precedence over all activities. This is the decision of its new presidentMrs. Allen H. Moore of Albany, whose neighbors customarily refer to the legislative chamber as her "second address."
The Pennsyl?ania Military College eleven defeated St. Joseph's by 7--6 on a rain-soaked field today. P. M. C. scored in the opening period, Vince Hartnett dashing around left end for 50 yards.

With several officials of the Federal Housing Administration and a number of Queens county executives in attendance, the Hillcrest Gardens home development between Grand Central Parkway and Horace Harding Boulevard, Jamaica Estates North, L. I., was officially opened yesterday.
Henry Armstrong, sensational little ring warrior from the Pacific Coast, returns to action Friday night in Madison Square Garden.
The oldest outstanding mortgage investment of the Bank for Savings in the City of New York was paid off a few days ago after having been on the books of the bank for eightysix years.

A rally and entertainment in behalf of the $250,000 campaign of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will be held this evening at the Music Box Theatre, 239 West Forty-fifth Street. Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of the College of Medicine of New York University, will be the principal speaker.

The question "Can the United State Retain Latin-American Trade and Cultural Relations Against German, Italian and Japanese Competition?" will be the topic for discussion at the Winter conference of the InterAmerican Center of George Washington University Dec. 6, 7 and 8.

The jewelry trade is prepared to put into effect next Friday the new commercial standards for the marking of karat gold merchandise, it was reported yesterday by Charles T. Evans, secretary of the American National Retail Jewelers Association.

With undisguised relief in private, if little open expression, the Canadian public this week welcomed President Roosevelt's announcement that his air-defense plans would include the protection of Canada's coasts against foreign aggression.

The WPA Federal Theatrre Project's three-ring circus will open its Winter tour on Thursday afternoon at the 102d Medical Corps Armory, South Broadway and Mitchell Place, here. Performances also will be given on Thursday evening and in the afternoon and evening of Friday and Saturday.
Missouri scored a touchdown a period today for a 26University. The Tigers drove across the first tally six minutes after the kicknl-off. Christman counting.

Kansas State scored two touchdowns in each of the first three periods to trounce Washburn, 41 to 14, before 6,000 today. Elmer Hackney, Kansas State fullback, tallied twice in the first period; Melvin Seelye, quarterback,

Dr. Jose A. Lopez Antongiorgi, a Puerto Rican who had practiced surgery in this city for many years and was formerly associated with the Polyclinic Hospital, died here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 55.

An entirely new squad of detectives, replacing the one that has been assisting John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor appointed to conduct an investigation of charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, will be selected tomorrow, it was learned yesterday.

The Evian refugee conference's projects to facilitate the emigration of German Jews with at least part of their possessions, which would enable them to make a new start in a new land, appeared today to have been definitely wrecked by the new German policy of "liquidating" the Jewish question by the Germans' own methods.

DETROIT. CONCURRENTLY during the past week automobile shows were held in eighteen major cities throughout the United States. Leading in this mass selling effort, of course, was the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace.
With three sister combinations in the line-up, the Matinecock field hockey team upset Hofstra College, 3-1, today on Hofstra Field. The game was well played despite a steady downpour.

Those who have observed the deliberation of the national and State realty conventions for a decade or so have been struck by the growing attention being paid to the subject of housing, and particularly to government-sponsored projects in this field.
New Hampshire looked over the threeyear record of its Unemployment Compensation Act this week and observed the law's ability to withstand a depression.
The mild Autumn has been a boon to geology students at Vassar College, for it has enabled them to carry on continuous field work. Sixty-one students have elected this subject.

The New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold, commenting editorially yesterday on the recall to Germany of Ambassador Hans Dieckhoff, expressed the hope that he would be able to impress upon the German Foreign Office the seriousness of the situation, and that his report would "receive the attention it deserves from the Foreign Office." It noted that hopes for a German-American trade treaty have received a severe blow.

The marriage of Miss Doris Estelle Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Loyal Herbert Powers of East Orange, to Albert William Petrikat, son of Mrs. Theresa Petrikat of Pelham, N. Y., took place this afternoon at Marlboro Inn, Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James A. Monk, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Bloomfield.

LONDON. SHAKESPEARE begins his "Hamlet." "Scene 1: ElsInore; a platform before the castle." Scene 2 is a room of state in the castle, and so on. Most of the twenty scenes of "Hamlet" are laid in "the castle"-i. e., Kronborg Castle at Elsinore in Denmark.
There is a marked trend toward educational activity on the part of the rural librarian, according to Marion Humble, whose study, "Rural America Reads," has recently been published.

Too much homework and no time off to play are likely to make Jack and Jill dull students, school officials have discovered. For that reason, several New York City high schools are devising ways and means this Fall to learn if they are overburdening their pupils with study assignments.
A musical will be given by Mrs. Borge Rohde at her residence, 1,016 Fifth Avenue, on the night of Nov. 30 to augment the Founders Memorial Fund of Delta Gamma Sorority.
Once more the incentive of a coveted appearance on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House is animating the young people of the ballet school attached to that historic institution.

GERMAN pocket battleships and fast cruisers, strikingly new in design. are keeping the seas. The German submarine fleet is rapidly increasing in numbers. Cruisers flying the-swastika visit foreign ports to inform the world that the Third Reich has a fleet in being. All this is a phase of Germany's

Despite the changeable business conditions which prevailed during a good part of the Fall season, apartment house rentals in the larger East Side houses was maintained at approximately the same level as one year ago, reports Richard C. Hollyday, president of the Culver, Hollyday Co. firm.
DR. CHAPMAN'S air castle is a substantial affair of some 4,000 acres that rises more than 450 feet above the waters of Gatun Lake;
As more seasonable weather brought better apparel sales and early Christmas promotions met good response, increases in retail trade figures over last year became more widespread.

GENEVA. TO study the advisability of adopting international regula tions to safeguard the rights of interpretative artists in radio broadcasting and phonograph recording, a committee of experts representing the various interests concerned, has been appointed by the International Labor Office to meet on Nov. 28 and 29 at Geneva.

The "gross overassessment" of realty in New York, which last week drew the fire of a "jury" of realty men headed by Lawrence B. Elliman, can be corrected through the creation of a State board of tax review in line with the new taxation article in the State Constitution, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday.

The Rangers, the only team In the National Hockey League with an undefeated record this season, will oppose the Canadiens in Madison Square Garden tonight. In meeting the Frenchmen from Montreal the Rangers will be skating against the lone team in the loop that has failed to win a game, the invading stick-wielders having been defeated in each of their five starts to date.

Two "encouraging" conclusions were drawn from the favorable response to the openings of medium and better grade houses last week by Morris Kolchin, executive director of Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc. The first, he said.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rauschkolb of this city and Belle Harbor, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Rauschkolb, to Albert Medetsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Medetsky of New York, formerly of Paterson.

Home building in October increased 118 per cent over October, 1937, in the number of homes and 78 per cent in the value and also showed a gain over September of 28 per cent in the permits isued for homes and of 20 per cent in their value, according to the survey of suburban building in the Chicago region by the Greenebaum Investment Company.

The glee club of the New York Junior League has begun rehearsals for its seventeenth season, which will be climaxed by the annual concert in the Great Hall of the league clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Kruge of Palisade, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Mildred Kruge, to William Henry Triest of Philadelphia, son of Mrs. Hans Triest of Stapleton, S. I., and the late Mr. Triest.

The Rev. Henry E. Payne, rector of the Church of the Good Shepherd here, and for twelve years rector of the Church of the Epiphany in Brooklyn, N. Y., died today at a Venice (Fla.) hospital, where he had been confined for six months with a heart ailment. His age was 60. He was a native of England.
THE following survey was recently conducted for the National Safety Council at the request of the secretary of its aeronautics section, Jerome Lederer, chief engineer of Aero Insurance Underwriters.
The pictorial section of the eighty-third annual international exhibition of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain will be shown here next week, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Mary Stanley Brown, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Roscoe C. E. Brown of 164 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn, and Seal Harbor, Me., to Alfred Milton Payne Amey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Amey of 31 Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, took place yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity,

My Own Brucie, 24-year-old from the Poughkeepsie, N. Y., kennels of H. E. Mellenthin, gained the best-in-show award tonight at the concluding performance of the seventeenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England.
THE difficulty in recruiting emigrants for the Swedish settlement in America 300 years ago speaks well for the attractions of life in the mother country.

Members of the junior committee of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery of which Mrs. Samuel A. Thompson Jr. is president are making plans for a bassinet dinner dance to aid the nursery, Dec. 2 in the Roof Garden of the Hotel St. Regis. The executive committee for the benefit is headed by Mrs. Vincent Booth Hubbell.
The Lodi High School eleven, New Jersey's only unbeaten, untied and unscored upon school team, kept its record clear today by gaining a 7-0 decision over Harrison High School on a muddy field.
TURKEY'S short-wave beam, which since the recent death of the President of the re public has been laden with eulogies for the late Kemal Ataturk, is now heard regularly during the afternoon.

A collection of fifty original Paris blouse and suit creations has been imported by the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., for a style show to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 9, it was announced yesterday by B. H. Lerner, executive director

Notre Dame's Fighting Ir sh, striving for national championship honors they last achieved under the late Knute Rockne in 1930, cleared the semifinal hurdle in their path by conquering a stubborn Northwestern eleven, 9 to 7, today before a sellout crowd of 48,500 in Dyche Stadium.

Amid rain and mud, the Blue Jays of Johns Hopkins gained a 25-to-7 victory over American University on the gridiron today. The Jays registered a pair of touchdowns in the first period and added 13 points in the third.

The place that Serge Koussevitsky and the Boston Orchestra hold in the esteem of the New York public was shown again yesterday afternoon by the audience which packed Carnegie Hall and testified after each performance to its enthusiasm.

In celebration of its twenty-first anniversary, the Pasadena (Calif.) Community Playhouse will present tonight in its theatre the program of four one-act plays which formed its first presentation in the old Shakespeare Clubhouse at Pasadena.

The New York School for the Deaf concluded a highly successful gridiron campaign by routing the Children's Village eleven, 28-0, today. The visitors finished with a slate of five triumphs and one reverse. William- Anderson excelled for the winners.

Two additional apartment house sites in the Forest Hills section of Long Island have been sold by the Cord Meyer Development Company. One is a plot 200 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Seventy-seventh Avenue, which was purchased by Lester Contracting, Inc.,

HERE we have a preview of the World Fair with a couple of murders thrown in for good measure. The story starts out as a slapstick farce comedy and continues in that vein, with a few tragic interludes. almost to the end.

Councilman James A. Sandford of this borough died today at St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, after a brief illness. His age was 37. Born in Harrison, Mr. Sandford was a resident of East Newark for twenty-eight years.

The advantages of a college education for women were emphasized by five Barnard College alumnae in a discussion, "Sending Girls to College, Why and How," conducted yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard.

Actual expenditures for building construction during October were $197,814,000, according to the recent issue of Building, The National News Review of Chicago. That amount, with one exception, was greater than was spent in any one month since the start of the recovery period in 1933.
William Rocks, 17, a star football player at West Catholic High School, died at Misericordia Hospital today six hours after he had been hit by a bullet fired by State Patrolman Richard Crane.

Organized labor in Oregon this week looked to the courts in a final attempt to thwart an initiative measure strictly regulating labor union activity. Nearly final election returns show that the law passed by a majority of 50,000 votes in an election in which about 350,000 votes were cast.
The general executive board of the United Automobile Workers of America voted tonight to abolish the Detroit District Council, accused by Homer Martin, union president, of being Communist-dominated.

The NewYork Americans moved into a tie for third place in the National Hockey League at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight when they downed Toronto, 2 to 1, in an overtime game. The victory placed Red Dutton's men even with their intracity rivals, the Rangers.

FRANK R. McNINCH, to whom, thirteen months ago, President Roosevelt presented the opportunity and the challenge to help guide the development and use of radio, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission,

Harvard, making an 80-yard drive in the last period for the only touchdown of the game, defeated Yale before 62,000 in the New Haven Bowl and won the Big Three championship. This was one of several titles decided during the day. Minnesota retained the Big Ten crown by downing Wisconsin, Duke won in the Southern Conference by topping North Carolina State and Oklahoma triumphed in the Big Six when it subdued Iowa State.

A dinner dance to mark the centennial year of Duke University, founded as Trinity College in 1838, was held last night in the Silver Room of the Ambassador. Dr. William H. Wanamaker, dean of the university, was guest of honor.

Duke's Blue Devils-the nation's only undefeated, untied and unscored-on major college football aggregation-kept its record clean today with a 7-to-0 triumph over North Carolina State's Wolfpack. Thus Duke clinched the Southern Conference title.
George W. Rogers, 41 years old, suspended Bayonne (N. J.) policeman and one-time radio operator of the steamship Morro Castle, will be placed on trial tomorrow before Common Pleas Judge Thomas H.
Appointment of Professor John S. Badeau as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences of the American University at Cairo has been anflounced by Dr. Charles R. Watson, president of the university.
The Greek Catholic Metropolitan of Lwow, Andreas Szeptyckyi, and a score of other prominent Ukrainian leaders issued today a strong protest against Polish "repraisals" in Eastern Galicia.

Reports from many builders in the Long Island suburban centers throughout Queens and Nassau Counties indicate the erection thus far this year of a larger number of homes than had been provided for in the original construction programs last Spring.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Quicksall MacDonough of this city and Langhorne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Isabel MacDonough, to Richard Palmer, son of Mrs. Leslie R. Palmer of New York and Irvington-on-the-Hudson, N. Y.
Today A. A. U. W. (Northern Valley, N.J., Branch) - President's reception, Englewood Women's Club, 4 P.M. Hackensack (N. J.) Woman's Club--Vesper service. Dr. A. Powell Davis. speaker.
Speech education is new to the curriculum at the Women's College of the University of Rochester, but it is fast nearing the top in popularity.
Pitt bowled over a dazed Penn State football team to win, 26-0, today, with Dick Cassiano, lone junior in the "dream" backfield, racing for three toucrhdnwns.

Alton Bennett, 168-pound guard, ended his college football career by place-kicking the extra point in the third period, which gave Tufts a 7-to-6 victory over Massachusetts State and its first triumph of the season today.

Stanley Mikulka, star quarterback on the New York University football team, has earned the distinction of being the first gridiron performer at N. Y. U. to be elected to Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity.

ONE observes here, and not by any means for the first time, that the work of Kathleen Norris displays a consistency which in itself amounts to genius. Very few writers have outstripped her in point of quantity.

IN the history of modern Europe the first quarter of the nineteenth century was a mo mentous period in comparison with which even the extraordinary developments of our own era, appear somewhat colorless and almost petty, although the latter may. in their ultimate social and political consequences, prove to be more permanent and far-reaching.

19.-Twenty-five Williams basketball aspirants reported to Coach Charlie Caldwell today as the Purple commenced preparation for a fourteen-game season which will begin shortly after the Thanksgiving vacation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.

Only four all-breed dog shows remain on the 1938 calendar. Thereafter there will be a respite until the annual exhibition of the Maryland Kennel Club opens the intensive campaign in February in the Eastern section, this merging into the strenuous round of Midwestern events.

Walter Fairchild, chairman of the graded tax committee, in analyzing the recent assessment reports issued by the Tax Department, declares that nearly 60 per cent of the Manhattan building sites as grouped by the Tax Department are under-improved. This situation, he holds, reveals the extent of urban blight as it affects Manhattan Island.

RIO DE JANEIRO.-Brazil, like the countries of Europe, though on a smaller scale, is going in for armaments. She is strengthening her army, navy and air force, and in doing so is looking to a number of nations for assistance.

Italian residents of Brazil are cool to Premier Benito Mussolini's decree inviting all Italians abroad to return to the motherland. The Italian consul at Sao Paulo said he had not received official notification of the decree. He doubted that it applied to the Americas.
A quarrel over a drainage ditch in the near-by village of Highland brought death today to two men and injury to a third.

A 98-yard touchdown dash by John Schulep of Stuyvesant through the rain and ankle-deep mud featured yesterday's scholastic football double-header at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island as his team and De Witt Clinton registered victories.
THE story of how "Oscar Wilde" came to be written--or very nearly was not written at all-might have provided a theme for my favorite short story writer, who happens to be O. Henry.

CECIL ARDEN, soprano, assisted by Paul Larey at the piano, will give a soiree Tuesday night, Nov. 29, at the Beethoven Association, to honor Arturo BuzziPeccia, well-known song composer and pedagogue, on the occasion of his eighty-fifth birthday.

Native leaders from all parts of the French Empire are meeting in Paris with the intention of drawing up a petition to the French Government asking a wider share in the administration of their countries and equal treatment with whites. An African Negro is presiding. The delegates declare they are not Communists or extremists.

Upsala and Albright battled to a scoreless tie in the mud at Hinch cliffe Stadium today. Albright recovered a fumble on the Upsala 33 in the first quarter and carried the ball to the 2-yard line with two downs to go but was stopped.

As the result of the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia a whole Pandora's box of minority problems has been flung open throughout Europe.
