Those naive enough to believe that Hitler could not sleep nights because 3,500,000 Sudeten Germans were under foreign rule might ask themselves why his sleep wasn't far more disturbed by the similar subjection of a million Germans in Poland, 1,500,000 in France

To take the overnight boat from Osaka for Beppu means to enter Kyushu through its back door, for the face of this southernmost of the four big Japanese Islands, at least in normal times, is turned toward the west.
THE chief function of an economic system is to provide a livelihood for the population. In recent years the system of "free enterprise" has fallen down in this respect.

Veronicas, because of their showy flower spikes, varying periods of bloom and easy culture, are among the most satisfactory plants for the perennial border. Through selection of different species, the gardener may obtain a succession of bloom from May until Fall.

Acting Governor M. William Bray pointed to this year's celebration of the 150th anniversary of the ratification of the Federal Constitution in his proclamation calling on the people of the State to observe Thanksgiving Day on Thursday.

More than 20,000 independent retail grocers in the five boroughs will close their stores from noon until 1 P. M. on Wednesday as a mass protest against persecution of the Jews and other minorities in Germany, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association.

Republicans improved their relative position in thirty-one States in the recent elections, while electing eighteen Governors and eleven United States Senators, according to a post-election survey, summarized in a table herewith.

SINCE this is the season of thanksgiving, it becomes the duty of this habitually cynical corner to call to mind the benefits, rather than the punishments, of being a persistent filmgoer. If it is a role we fill awkwardly, blame it on lack of practice.
Two rabbis will assist the Rev. W. Harold Weigle, the rector, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the East Chester section here at the annual harvest home festival tomorrow at 8 P. M.

A series of lectures on marriage will be given at Simmons College this year for the first time as part of a program arranged by the undergraduate social activities committee with the authorization of the administration.

Councilman Albert D. Schanzer will introduce in the City Council Tuesday a resolution calling for the use of murals, sculptures and other decorative features to improve the appearance of the stations on the city's Independent Subway System, it was announced yesterday by the Committee on Public Use of Arts.

Miss Jean Elizabeth Hogenauer was married to Robert Adolf Andrew Hentschel of Bridgeport and Ridgewood, N. J., here this evening at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Alphonse Hogenauer. The ceremony was performed by a cousin of the bride, the Rev. A. Stewart Hogenauer, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Newark, N. J.

Mrs. Henry V. Raymond will be hostess at a tea at her home, 461 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday afternoon, to members of the executive committee assisting her in plans for the annual card party and tea to be given by the Woman's Advisory Board of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Miss Katherine Marie Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Augustine Bennett of East Islip, L. I., was married here to Edward John Martin, son of Thomas Martin of Utica, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Martin, yesterday morning in the Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James M. Gillis.

Debutantes who are assisting in plans for the preview dinner dance to be given Nov. 30 in the new Queen Elizabeth Room of the Park Lane will meet Tuesday afternoon in that room to discuss final preparations for their participation in the entertainment and to inspect the newly decorated rendezvous.

Col. Harold Lee, deputy general manager in charge of property management of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, will speak at the twenty-second annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards to be held Dec. 8, 9, and 10 at the Hotel Traymore, Atlantic City.

Former rivals for premier honors at chess and still waiting for a return match, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, titleholder, and Jos6 R. Capablanca of Havana met again tonight in the ninth round of the A. V. R. O. international tournament.
" Open-market" transfers of Manhattan real estate numbered 199 during October, a seasonal increase over the previous month, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.
In the midst of all the confused and contradictory interpretations of the Congressional elections last week, there appears one reasonably important result from the Republican gains.

Speaking at the thirtieth annual members' dinner of the National Press Club here tonight, President Roosevelt praised the help that prominent newspaper men have been to public leaders, including himself.

An intensive drive for peace among Spaniards in the hope of uniting them for the purpose of driving out the "foreign invaders," as the Germans and Italians are viewed by the Loyalists, and of frustrating any attempts on the part of foreign powers to force their own kind of peace upon Spain by the methods used with Czechoslovakia, is now under way at Barcelona.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Rothschild of this city, formerly of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caryl Helene Rothschild to Albert W. Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Feldman of New York.
OUT of the welter of socalled "fictionized biography." so much in vogue in recent years. there now and again emerges a book which justifies the form.
Although the British duties on automobiles remain at the same level as before, the automotive industry, centered in and near Detroit, hailed the signing of the British-American trade treaty.

A study of investment portfolios of thirtynine endowed institutions of higher education by the financial advisory service of the American Council on Education shows that the earnings of the institutions of smallest endowment, contrary to an earlier trend, have increased more than those of the institutions of large endowment.

" One of the best newspapers in the world," H. G. Wells once called the British journal Nature. A scientist in any university or industrial laboratory would go further and designate it "the only scientific newspaper of its kind." He would no more miss it than he would breakfast.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey sailed yesterday on the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda for a vacation with friends in Bermuda. He will return in two weeks, he said. During his absence Sewell T. Tyng will be Acting District Attorney.

The Merritt Parkway has served to stimulate interest in Connecticut real estate near that new highway, according to Mrs. Howard A. Barker, realty broker of South Wilton, who reported several deals in that area last week.
Above is a little Vermont village, typically New England even to its church steeple, photographed before the hurricane. Inset are two storm-struck areas:

IT was a notice in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May Morris's death at Kelmscott Manor on Oct. 17 he that started this investigation. Reading the terse paragraph about May's death brought to mind, and therefore to life, her illustrious father, William Morris.

Mrs. Willylou Chalfant Levy, wife of Lionel K. Levy, architect, died yesterday at their residence, 310 East Forty-ninth Street, after a long illness. She was born in Los Angeles twenty-four years ago, a daughter of the late Lucille Chalfant, concert singer.

The disregard of religion among college students is the cause of much of the uncertainty and unrest that is evident on many campuses and in the nation at large, Dr. Irving H. Berg, dean of the New .York University College of Arts and Pure Science, declared in the preface of his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.
The Duke of Atholl angrily resigned as president and member of a club of his wife's constituents today when it refused to renominate her for the House of Commons.

Elmira College is now completing an experiment which promises to change the class in required freshman English composition from a drill room into a "sanatorium" where grammatical ills are cured not by discipline so much as by relaxation and exercise.

The American Institute of Architects is planning to make an intensive study during the coming year of certain features which originated in the PWA program for subsidized housing and which, it is pointed out, if not modified may become crystallized as a standard to the detriment of the work under the United States Housing Authority.

BALBOA. THE last of the United States 30c stamps (Buffalo design) over printed "Canal Zone" have been issued to local postmasters and it is announced here that no more will be ordered. Virtually all the remainder, about 2,300, have been transferred to the postoffice at Balboa Heights, for sale by the Canal Zone Philatelic Agency.

In its report of last April upon that section of the Revenue Act of 1938 which deals with capital gains and losses, the Senate Finance Committee concluded its recommendations with the following statement:
The Springfield Indians tonight gained undisputed possession of second place in the International-American Hockey League by defeating the Cleveland Barons, 4 to 3, before 4,800 fans.
Oregon's Webfoots, defeated in four major games this season, turned up rejuvenated today to whip the University of Washington Huskies, 3-0, before 20,000 fans.

Buster Bedford, fullback. placed Princeton's undefeated 150-pound football team to a 26-0 triumph over the Lafayette lightweights on University Field today. He scored all four of the Nassau touchdowns.
Previews, Inc., reports contracts for sale of two Massachusetts properties. In Newtonville, the fourteen-room house formerly owned by Donald E. Rust was purchased by the Federal Realty Corporation.

Varied divertissements have been planned for Ye Olde English Faire under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, which will be opened formally the afternoon of Nov. 30 at the Biltmore Hotel by Godfrey Haggard, recently appointed British Consul General at New York.

Ground will be broken Tuesday for the National Advisory Committee Building at the World's Fair, designed as a center for some 6,000 men and women who have assisted the fair in an advisory capacity in all sections of the United States, according to an announcement yesterdav.

The marriage of Miss Mary Frances Wills, daughter of Mrs. Frances Johnson Morin of this city and of Van Leer Wills of Grand Rapids, Mich., to Richard Francis Barrett of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Francis Barrett of Brockton, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Villanova's weather-proof Wildcats reached the portals of their second consecutive undefeated season today by overwhelming the Boston University Terriers, 39 to 6, in the rain and mud before a crowd of 5.000.

The Red Raiders of Texas Tech battered at the University of New Mexico's goal for nearly four periods today and in the final seconds of play turned a tie into a 17-to-7 victory to remain unbeaten and untied.

Savings of from 10 to 15 per cent in the cost of examinations made into the condition of Federal-chartered savings and loan associations and State-chartered associations insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation will result from the adoption by the examining division of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of.a new and simplified form, announces John W. Ballard, chief examiner.

Miss Winifred Harper Bonnell will give a dinner on Dec. 9 at her home, 18 Gramercy Park, for Sydney R. Montague of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, whose lecture, "Under Northern Lights," on the night of Dec. 14 in the ballroom of the Plaza will be presented as a benefit for the National Cathedral- in Washington.

A dance under the auspices of the Junior League of Cliff House will be held Wednesday night at the Biltmore to assist the Up-State Catholic Summer School. In charge of the arrangements for the event are Mrs. John Kearney, Mrs. William Reardon, Mrs. Robert T. Groh and the Misses Mary Catherine Parker,

The week of tragic happenings in Germany seems at last to have awakened Britain and a large part of the nonGerman world to the immenseness and urgency of the refugee problem. The outlines of the five-year-old problem have been sharpened so that even the best friends of Germany in this country can see them.

The Star said today that it had learned that Charles E. Johnston would retire on Jan. 1 as president of the Kansas City Southern Railroad to become chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives with offices in Chicago.

The annual report of Secretary of the Navy Swanson, published this morning, is a concise and interesting summary of the navy's activities during the past year. There are, however, some notable omissions. Mr. Swanson makes only inferential mention of two of the most important naval problems-now before the nation.

The Lyceum Theatre, famous for more than a century as London's home of melodrama, is to be pulled down. Built in 1809, it has one of the largest seating capacities of any in the city--about 2,800-and with its even more ancient neighbor, the Drury Lane, marks the eastern boundary of the entertainment and theatre district, which long since moved farther west.

Henry Brady will sell at auction in the Vesey Street rooms tomorrow the four tenement properties at 279283 Tenth 'Avenue and 505 West Twenty-sixth Street, a plot 59.3 by 104 feet, at the northwest corner of those thoroughfares.

Quito, the last capital in Latin America to get airplane service, rejoiced today on the arrival this morning of a passenger plane from Lima, Peru, en route to Cristobal, C. Z. It is believed airplane communications will improve inter-American commercial and cultural relations.

Stout-hearted Eddie Brink, Bronx welterweight veteran, pounded his way to victory over Maurice Arnault, French ring warrior, in the eight-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove S. C. in Brooklyn last night before a crowd of about 4,000.

TRADE came to life in the week and many centers reported small gains over a year ago. On the average for the country it was considered likely that volume had drawn even with last year. Colder weather was a prime factor in this improvement, along with the passing of the election.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Battey of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Crawford Battey, to H. Hawley Myers of New York and Shawondasee, Sharon, Conn.
LONDON. "A BOLISHINGthePedestrian" is the phrase being used to describe the novel efforts of London's traffic experts now busily seeking to reduce the city's heavy accident toll.

The coming into effect of the so-called Easter agreements of April 16 of this year between Italy and Great Britain passed off comparatively quietly. The press had blown its trumpets so enthusiastically when the agreements were signed that it found itself rather short of breath now that after a seven-month interval they at last have become operative.
Sir Victor Sassoon, British banker and head of several industrial companies in India and China, sailed yesterday on the French liner Ile de France after spending ten days here on business.

With one of the largest Industrial bond retirements in more than two years included, the volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity showed a substantial increase over the preceding week. Most of the new prepayments are scheduled for December.

THE big news on this November day-big, anyway, for the Theatre Guild's scattered children-is that the subscribers will be seeing on Dec. 28 their second play of the season, barring a change of plans, of course. It is "The Merchant of __:
THE doctor was a delicatelooking young New Yorker, who weighed 110 pounds and knew nothing whatever about the Wild West to which he betook himself with $15 in his pocket, fifty years ago.

A native plant well worthy of cultivation in gardens is the Closed or Bottle Gentian-Gentiana clausa (G. andrewsi). Several characteristics make it valuable for either the wild garden or for use among the more formal horticultural varieties.

Michigan State's Spartans closed their 1938 football season today by trouncing, 10 to 0, a Temple eleven which consistently outgained the Spartans but failed to deliver a scoring punch. A crowd of 12,000 saw the Owls yield to superior strategy as Johnny Pingel, playing his last college game, excelled for State.

A large delegation of city officials and representatives of realty and trade organizations will go to Albany on Tuesday to present a plea to the State Tax Commission for "more favorable" tax equalization rates for New York City.

VALENTIGNY," in this book by an English traveler in Frande, is a town in the Rhone Valley, roughly midway between Lyon and Avignon; and "Chalutles-Flots" is a seaside resort--French, not cosmopolitan-to the west of Marseille.
Proper home and land planning was stressed in statements issued yesterday by two governmental agencies interested in improving housing standards and conditions.

Dr. Phillip G. Hood, roentgenologist and head of the X-ray department of Newark City Hospital, Newark, N. J., for the last seventeen years, died early this morning in his home here at the age of 57. He had been ill for five months.

Since the early part of the year, when the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets launched a drive against misleading advertising here under a statute little used previously, it has handled 800 cases and obtained convictions in approximately 98 per cent of prosecutions, according to officials of the bureau, yesterday.

WASHINGTON. HE new Civil Aeronautics Authority, which less than three months ago took over com plete regulation of the nation's adolescent air transportation industry, has been so busy keeping the present operations moving that it has not yet had time to give expression to some of the trail-blazing rate measures which may be expected in the near future.

After a futile effort to rescue his wife, who was trapped with her brother in an automobile that hurtled over the bulkhead between Piers 1 and 2 the Battery and plunged into the North River, Harry Gardner, 51 years old, of Wilmington, N. C.,

Paced by Bob Bastress, star left halfback, the Susquehanna eleven handed Brooklyn College a 14-6 setback at Brooklyn Field yesterday. Limited by the muddy field to straight line play, the Crusaders scored in the first two periods, then stood off several determined rushes by the Kingsmen. The Susquehanna victory broke a seven-game losing streak.
Several single-family dwellings owned by the Home Owners Loan Corporation in the Jackson Heights and Forest Hills areas of Long Island have been sold through the office of Frank O'Hara.

Following numerous articles of protest against German anti-Semitism in the, Right Wing press, the Leftist parties have decided to stage an important mass meeting tomorrow to establish the wide scale of the protest.

Modern home design is steadily increasing in popularity, according to The Architectural Forum, which publishes in its current issue details of the eight houses recently sponsored by Life, in cooperation with the former magazine for four typical American families with incomes ranging from $2,000 to $12,000 per year.

A memorial mass was celebrated yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Cardinal Hayes. It was the annual mass of the Ladies of Charity, a group of Catholic women founded many years ago. The members of the organization work among the poor of the city, visiting and caring for the sick.

A blocked punt gave Southwestern a 7-to-3 victory over Mississippi State today. Bill Little, alert Lynx end, threw himself in front of Sonny Bruce's kick in the second period and then grabbed the ball as it bounced over the goal line.

Seventy-five years ago yesterday Abraham Lincoln delivered "a few appropriate remarks" setting aside the first seventeen acres of the memorial cemetery to the Northern soldiers who fell at Gettysburg. He thought that what he said would be little noted or long remembered.

Modernization work on the old Mercer Street police station is proceeding rapidly and the structure is expected to be ready for occupancy again by the eighth precinct about Jan. 1, a check-up reveals. The eighth precinct is now temporarily housed in 300 Mulberry Street.

Change in the Roosevelt Cabinet as the result of resignations, although a subject of frequent discussion and rumor almost since the administration came into office, has finally come to actuality, but only after more than -five and a half years of the New Deal have passed.
Sophomore stars led Creighton University eleven to a 38-to-0 victory over North Dakota State today, ringing down the curtain on the Bluejay's best football season since 1927.

Reactions to the findings and recommendations of the three-year study of the public schools of New York State which has just been completed by a committee of the Board of Regents are expected to spread soon from educators to the general public.

A program of supervised construction has been inaugurated by ten Westchester County savings and loan associations which have announced that they have more than $8,000,000 available for small home building, points out George L. Bliss, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.

Members of the Brooklyn Branch of Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help in the Diocese of Long Island have arranged their annual card party in aid of that organization for Dec. 1 in the Parish House of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

The unfavorable European political developments last week overshadowed reports of business improvement and the signing of the new trade treaties with Great Britain and Canada, so far as the stock market was concerned.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Doris Berenice Zagor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman I. Zagor of 1,095 Park Avenue, to Michael D. Goldsmith, son of Mrs. Samuel W. Goldsmith of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Goldsmith.
King Farouk, opening a new session of Egypt's Parliament today, dedicated his nation to an extensive rearmament program as a sequel to the September European crisis.

In the white and gold East Room of the White House, a room rich in memories of the American past, history was made last week. Under the great crystal chandeliers gathered President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Hull,
The government, using a fleet of second-hand ships, today began its own attempt to end the partial eclipse of the Stars and Stripes on the Seven Seas.

HOLLYWOOD. TELEVISION, considered by some as a boon to the picture industry and by others as a menace, was pressed to the fore again following a discussion the other day by Stanton Griffis revealing Paramount's interest in the new medium.

Admitting to detectives he had been arrested ten times in the last nine years on charges of fraud, Carl Scheland was held in $30,000 bail for Special Sessions, when arraigned yesterday afternoon on a charge of petit larceny before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio

AFTER making what Norman H. Davis, National Red Cross chairman, has called "one of the most amazing disaster recoveries this organization has ever known," a proud New England approaches Winter with exuberant confidence of a man who has known real trouble and has triumphed over it.
The American Automobile Association ended a four-day convention this afternoon by adopting a sixteenplank platform for advocacy

Ending the uncertainty which has prevailed among domestic manufacturers and foreign traders for the last year, completion of the AngloAmerican trade treaty last week is expected to release millions of dollars' worth of orders for both American and British goods before the end of the year.
Wee Davey O'Brien played his game of games today, an incredible performance that helped unbeaten Texas Christian ride to a 29-to-7 conquest of Rice Institute's ill-fated but battling warriors.

Developers and builders in the renafly and Teaneck sections of Bergen County, N. J., are experi:ncing unusual activity for this sea;on of the year reports Arthur R. Storm, agent for several of the newer home communities.

What is believed to be the largest single fresco panel in the United States will be dedicated today at the 11 A. M. services in the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street, just west of Broadway.

Building costs are not too high at present, according to W. S. Lowndes, director of architecture for the International Correspondence Schools, but he declares many families invest too much for housed-in space. They buy, he points out, a place that is too large and find no budget left for internal comfort.

The growing participation of women in realty affairs has prompted the formation of a national group through which they may have a united voice in expressing their views on problems confronting the industry.
Taking advantage of breaks, fighting Oceanside High School team won the Nassau County foot ball championship today by defeat ing Valley Stream, 6-0, before 7,000 damp spectators.
Southern Methodist torpedoed Baylor University's fine aerial machine today, 21 to 6, and demolished a 22-year-old jinx under which the Mustangs never had defeated the Bears in Waco.

The recent advent of a pure white gayfeather, which has attracted much attention at Fall flower shows during the past year or two, has brought renewed interest in this very useful group of Summer and Autumn flowers.

TOMORROW night, under the auspices of the Harlem Committee and the Musicians Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, a program of Negro music will be given at Carnegie Hall. The occasion will be in honor of W. C. Handy's sixty-fifth birthday.

IN answer to the growing need for more mechanics adequately equipped for promotion-a need which would seriously endanger the nation in the event of war-the Glenn L. Martin Company has authorized twenty representatives from its engineering and tool design departments to serve as instructors of Saturday morning classes in blueprint reading at the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.

EAST AFRICA has a hotel built in the top of a tree. For its two bedrooms the charge is $50 a night. Used by tourists who want to sit up all night watching big game in its natural state, the place overlooks a drinking pool much frequented by game, and is so well concealed in the treetop that the game does not know it is being watched.

Once again battle is being joined between the two great factions in the New York Stock Exchange,. the 20 per cent of big firms which do 70 per cent of the business and the 80 per cent- of small firms which do the rest. The issue is semi-weekly settlements, installed on Sept. 1.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has topped the 1937 figure for the first time this year. The margin is slight, but for the week ended Nov. 12 the index stands at 90.3, against 90.2 for the corresponding week last year. The revised figure for the week ended Nov. 5 is 89.6.

A new factor in American cultural education, seeking to instill an appreciation of opera, the ballet, music and other entertainment in school children from kindergarten age through high school, is discussed in a report by Mrs. Dorothy L. McFadden, director of Junior Programs, Inc.,

Members of three faiths, 3,000 strong, gathered here tonight in a mass meeting to adopt and send directly to President Roosevelt a resolution asking relaxation of immigration laws to aid immigrant Jews from Nazi Germany and commending the President's stand in regard to Nazi anti-Semitism.

Mrs. Bessie Burdick Rathbone, wife of Robert C. Rathbone, head of the New York insurance brokerage firm of his name, died at their home here today. A daughter of the late Captain Russell E. Burdick of Cleveland, Mrs. Rathbone was a classmate at school of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, then Elizabeth Cutter.

Penn and Princeton played to a scoreless deadlock in their Middle Atlantic International Soccer League game today on River Field. It was the final game of the season for both teams. Neither threatened to score at any time during the Fame.

WHAT with the war scare and a rather unusually prolonged hangover from the Summer orgy of bad pictures, the new film season in London has been late in starting, but proves to be a gay one, now that it is with us.

THE history of the Italian na tion from the founding of Rome in 753 B. C. through the conquest of Ethiopia in modern time is chronologically pictured on stamps which, received from Rome last week, are adorned with significant inscriptions from the writings and oratory of Benito Mussolini, each wording being followed by an "M" in his flourishing script.
One of baseball's grand old men-Clark Calvin Griffith, president of the Washington Senators-will be 69 tomorrow.

Whether the recovery in finance and trade during the past six months is or is not destined to be interrupted again, there is no doubt of its character. The Federal Reserve's "industrial production index," for example, fairly indicates the course of trade in general.

THE first Thanksgiving dinner, which the Pilgrims spread on their boards in 1621. was a wholly native American feast. Game, native berries and Indian vegetables made up its substance for the simple reason that the Pilgrims had nothing else.
Lord Astor's Observer, in an editorial note under the heading, "The German Muddle," writes concerning the recent German onslaught against the Jews as follows:

Plans for a million-dollar theatrical plant at Dartmouth and the acceptance by the Dramatists Guild of New York City of the college's invitation to sponsor an annual Summer Drama Festival has spurred the Dartmouth Players to undertake the most extensive program in their long history.

Mr. and Mrs. I. Parker Martin of Portsmouth have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Allison S. Martin, to David tedpath Rough Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rough of Newport, formerly of New Rochelle, N. Y., which took place here last Saturday.

PARIS. IN a moment of discouragement Bizet once said that a composer, to be properly appreciated, ought to be dead a hundred years. No musician ever had less cause for such pessimism. "Carmen" is probably the most popular opera in the world and, in spite of the old, exploded legend that it was a failure at first, few lyric dramas ever conquered the globe so completely, rapidly and deservedly.
AFTER an unpredicated delay which benefited the interested collectors, the Will Rogers-Wiley Post Memorial Expedition covers mailed on Aug. 15 at Barrow, Alaska, reached their destinations last week.

LIMA, Peru. EXCAVATIONS being carried out at Pachacamac, Peru, have resulted in the laying bare of the remains of a monumental stairway, which was probably one of the main approaches to the Temple of the Sun,

Liquidation developed today in-December wheat futures on the Board of Trade and prices declined 1 cent a bushel to lose at the bottom. The drop was acceleratedd by reports that 3,000,000 bushels of No. 2 yellow hard wheat night be delivered on December contracts.

STILL a place where homesick White Russians may sit and dream of bygone days, and Prince Obolensky may be seen on occasion whirling one of the current season's debs to the strains of "The Blue Danube,"

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

Home repairs, points out a builder, requiring concrete work, neglected during the Summer, can be made safely in cold weather. If there is danger of freezing, quick-setting cement should be used. This will reduce the time during which the work must be protected against low temperatures.

Cornell's freshman football team completed its season by defeating the Penn Cubs, 20-12, in snow and mud today. Lou Buffalino scored twice for Cornell, on an 85-yard pass interception run and a 23-yard dash n off tackle. Jack Lewis tallied from the 20 by catching a fumble in the air.
The Federal Power Commission has announced its receipt of the first application filed under the Natural Gas Act seeking authority to import natural gas into the United States.
St. Anselm and Boston College battled to a scoreless deadlock on a muddy field today before 12,000 rain-soaked fans.
The New Hampshire eleven recorded a 10-0 victory over Connecticut State today in the season's finale for both colleges.
Seventyseven foreign newspapers were seized today and their sale forbidden. Among those banned were the Nov. 6 and 7 issues of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A resolution condemning the antiJewish persecutions in Germany and expressing "unsparing condemnation" of the Nazi excesses was approved yesterday by 2,700 New York City teachers, attending the annual luncheon of the Protestant Teachers Association, at the Hotel Astor.

Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the National Federation of Press Women, announces that the organization will award four prizes of $50 each next year to women regularly employed on newspapers or magazines. The prizes will be awarded for a signed feature article, an editorial, a column and a news article.

The marriage of Miss Helen Alethia Mead of New York and Lake George, daughter of Mrs. George J. Mead of Lake George and the late Mr. Mead, to Dr. Edgar William Warren 2d of New Haven, Conn., took place today in the Union Presbyterian Church.

Renovation work on Loew's Theatre in White Plains, Westchester County, has been completed at a cost of $100,000. Among the improvements was the erection of a new marquee and sign and the installation of new balcony beams to accommodate extra seats.

THERE might appear to be some question as to whether a re-recording of Sibelius's Symphony No. 5 in E flat, Op. 82, is required at the present time. Though the set is by no means new, it is not long since the release of the domestic re-pressing from the excellent Sibelius Society set.

Resuming its victory march, which was interrupted Friday by Hofstra College, the Rhode Island State girls' field hockey team defeated the New York University eleven, 3 to 0, at Prospect Park yesterday.

A different approach in the training of social welfare workers for public service is being introduced this year at Bryn Mawr College in a graduate project of the Carola Woerishoffer Department of Social Economy and Social Research, using a technique of training emphasizing Studies in Community Organization for Child Welfare, further developed in a seminar of twelve graduate students.

P. Hopple, president of Mill Associates, Inc., 40 Worth Street, in conjunction with J. H. Boston Jr. and Thomas J. Brown of Mount Alto Bedspread Company, Calhoun, Ga., has organized a new company, the Georgia Textile Corporation for the production of Fruit

More than $700,000 has been raised to date in the United Hospital Campaign, C. M. Chester, chairman, announced last night in making public more than 780 additional contributions. The gifts to the Hospital Fund go to the support of ninety-two institutions and the Brooklyn Visiting Nurses Association.

FOR a note of distinction in an interior, a professional decorator almost invariably turns to something hand made. whether it be silver. pewter, brass, copper, pottery or textiles. Fine machine products can of course be had, but they lack the individuality which an article closely associated with its maker possesses.

How best to get the garden in order for the onslaught of Winter is one of the problems facing the home owner at this season. Denuded trees, sharp morning air, chilling winds from the North or West, all warn us that most plant life is ready to go into its annual period of retirement from obvious activity.

TWO dramatists, Katriona and Elisabeth Sprigge, have produced at the Garrick Theatre a play on "Elisabeth of Austria" which sets criticism one of its more ticklish problems. Briefly stated, the problem, for me,

Rodney Dutcher, for the last eleven years Washington political columnist and Washington bureau manager for the Newspaper Enterprise Association of Cleveland, was found dead at his desk here about midnight last night. He apparently had died of heart disease about 8 P. M.

An independent labor federation rivaling the American Federation of Labor was born here this week. The Committee for Industrial Organization, formed three years ago to further the movement to add industrial unions to the A. F. of L., adopted a constitution,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy M. Burk, daughter of Mrs. Harry A. Burk of this place and the late Mr. Burk, to Norman E. Fisher, son of Mrs. Clarence A. Fisher and the late Mr. Fisher of Jersey City.

Damp basements, which are frequently encountered in houses, are often due to improper back filling, points out the FHA. When a foundation is dug and later refilled, rubbish is sometimes used in the fill. Water running down the walls of the house collects in pools' and seeps through pores or cracks in the' walls and into the basement.

A potential 15,800 worth of silver foxes went on the loose here today. Seventy-nine of them dug their way out under a fence at the William B. Erekson farm and searchparties went to work with rifles and clubs.

Mayor La Guardia delivered an explosive attack on the "wolf in sheep's clothing" policies of the dictator countries in the Pan-American republics here tonight and warned an audience of officials from . southern countries that their best interests lay with the United States and with each other.
Joseph Klein, a patrolman, saved a middle-aged woman from death here today by grasping her as she waded knee-deep in the swirling Niagara River just above the cataract.

A. L. Malumet of Philadelphia has purchased the first completed house in the new group of ten dwellings being built by Sussex Homes, Inc., headed by Paul M. Jeffrey, on Sixty-sixth Road in the Cord Meyer section of Forest Hills, L. I.

An order of President Friedrich Werner of the Supreme Evangelical Church Council, who' has authority only in North Germany, provided today that the name of the God of Israel, "Jehovah" and the names of the Jewish prophets must be erased wherever displayed in Protestant churches.

The Townsend Harris Medals, given each year by City College, were awarded to five alumni at the annual dinner of the college's alumni association at the Hotel Roosevelt last night. Four others received the Alumni Service Medals.

IF they served only as vehicles for her lovely pictures we would be grateful to Mrs. de Angeli for her books, but happily she has something to say and she knows how to capture in her stories the essence of youth.

Mrs. Thomas Henry Alison of Bayonne, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Lowery Alison, to David Stokehill Hunter of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hunter of Stamford, Conn.

Britain's Prime Minister Chamberlain in his eighteen months of power has followed a thorny path marked "peace by pacts." Believing that democracies and dictatorships can learn to live side by side, he has sought to remove causes of irritation and disagreement that might lead to war.

Which Is "Modern Music"? To the Music Editor: In regard to Ashley Pettis's leter of last week, will Mr. Pettis please give his meaning of "modern idiom"? Must there be in art one "modern idiom"? Because there is a Gertrude Stein, must we condemn a Thomas Mann? Isn't the field of music vast enough for opposing currents to flow together?

IT should come as no surprise in our day, when the need for safeguarding democracy against reaction is so evident, that large sections of the movie-going public are hopeful that the powerful influence of the American screen may be thrown into the struggle against intolerance and reaction.

Malcolm Farmer, chairman of Yale athletics, the nearest approach Yale makes to having an athletic director, fairly embraced Head Coach Raymond (Ducky) Pond when they met in the Elis' dressing room after today's game with Harvard.

An estimated 350 to 400 persons, several of them dressed in mourning and carrying black-bordered signs denouncing the persecution of racial and religious minorities in Germany, picketed the German Consulate at 17 Battery Place for two hours yesterday.
R. W. Frick, farmer, had his land posted today by a newspaper advertisement which read thus. "Be a good sport, gentlemen.

The thirty-first annual convention of the National Home for Jewish Children in Denver was opened last night at the Hotel Commodore with a dinner dance for which guests paid $50 a couple. It was attended by more than 1,000 persons.

RADIO leaders and their lieutenants in broadcasting have started a three months' march under the glare of the Federal Communication Commis- a sion's spotlight of investigation. Freedom of speech has become one the keynotes coupled with pledges to uphold American principles of democracy.

Mrs. Blair Reiley, chairman for the production of "Beauty and the Beast," to be presented by the Newark Junior League's children department in the Newark public schools after Christmas, has chosen the following staff to assist her: Mrs. James D. Winans, production manager; Mrs. Robert Hoag,

The refusal of some mills and manufacturers to certify to their customers that they are complying with the Wage and Hour Law on the grounds that such guarantee is not required by the law was challenged yesterday by Mortimer Fishel, counsel to the National Work Shirt Manufacturers Association.

The Navy soccer team in its last game on the home grounds played four regular periods and two five-minute extras against Cornell today, with neither team scoring. Dick Parker, Navy outside right, excelled on the attack. Goalie Wood of Cornell did well defensively and Nicholls and Padriski led the Red attack.

The successful assimilation of adolescent German refugees in the country's schools was attested last week by Miss Marion M. Miller, executive director of the National Council of Jewish Women, at a session of the fiftieth anniversary meeting of the Child Study Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

A. B. Davis High School of this city played to a scoreless tie with New Rochelle High in their last W. I. A. A. football game of the season today. In the opening period the Purple Wave advanced to the Davis 10-yard line, but to no avail.
The Plaza Art Auction Galleries on Thursday, Friday and yesterday sold a collection of furniture and decorations of several owners, including Elsie de Wolfe, Inc. It realized $21,730.

From England comes an idea which seems worthy of adoption here. More than 350 garden owners have banded together to share their flowers with invalids, shut-ins, schools, orphanages and hospitals. The result Is the League of Flower Givers.

St. Peter's College of Jersey City will begin a twenty-game basketball schedule next Saturday when the quintet meets the Alumni at home, it has been announced by the Rev. Thomas A. Fay, S. J., director of athletics.

Lebanon Valley defeated Juniata College today, 6-0, in the closing game of the season for both teams. Lebanon Valley won six games in the campaign and today marked the twelfth victory in eighteen years over Juniata.

Trinity College students have organized a new medium for the expression of the creative literary spirit in the form of The Trinity Review, plans for which were broached by the new Trinity College Literary Society.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday that it would extend use -of its Federal Home Service Building Plan, making it available not only to the 4,000 member institutions but to "every- sound local cooperative movement for better construction of small homes," in an effort, to restrict further the building of "shoddy" houses.

In a murky mist, spattered with rain, the Yale band marched out defiantly-on the soggy turf of the big Bowl blaring the stirring strains of the Bulldog song. A few minutes later the bigger Crimson-coated Harvard band spread all over the field, doing literary stunts and playing "Hit the Line for Harvard."

Underlying the recommendations for a sweeping reorganization of secondary education throughout New York State in the Regents' Three-year Inquiry into the Character and Cost of Public Education made public last week is a study officially submitted to the regents but as yet unpublished which shows how high school girls and boys go out into the world maladjusted to life conditions.
This resort is busily preparing Special programs for the host of visitors expected here over the four-day Thanksgiving weekend.
The Federal Employment Service reported today that during October it made the highest number of placements of jobs for any month of 1938.

The leadership of the American Soccer League will be at stake today when the Brookhattans meet the Irish-Americans at Starlight Park. The Americans are only a few percentage points behind the Brooks, who are setting the Dace.

" TELEVISION will be an important part in our exhibit at the World's Fair," reports a representative of the General Electric Company. Receivers of the latest design will be available for the reception of all television programs broadcast by transmitters in the New York area during the fair.

Mrs. Frank Sheldon Fosdick of Buffalo has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Sheldon Fosdick, to Rufus Horton Jones Jr. of this city, son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Rufus Horton Jones of Portland. Me.

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton-spinning industry had operated during October at 81.9 per cent of capacity, on an eightyhour-week basis, compared with 76.1 per cent in September, and 77.7

The perilous game of retaliating for the Soviet treatment of Manchukuoan consulates in China and Blagoveschenck, Siberia, played in Harbin recently, was won by the Manchukuoan Government in a gigantic game of diplomatic bluff.
The final "liquidation" of the Jews in Germany in the name of retribution for the murder of a German diplomat has surprised and shocked the world as a new manifestation of "Furor Teutonicus."

A reorganization of the system of selecting freshmen for Rutgers fraternities was announced this week by the Interfraternity Council. Under the new system firstyear men will fill out questionnaires and specify which fraternity they wish to join.

Reorders declined in volume last week, since store stocks are generally sufficient to supply current needs and holiday requirements, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

While members of eighty taxpayers associations and other civic groups in Westchester County were circulating petitions today in protest against a proposed increase of 22 per cent in the county budgets for 1939, fiscal experts were scanning the tentative figures of $20,652,575 in search of items they could ask to have cut when the Board of Supervisors conducts a public hearing on the night of Nov. 28.

In the cold, dismal setting of Memorial Stadium, Auburn and Georgia produced heart-warming football fireworks for a shivering crowd today, but the Plainsmen from Alabama fired too many barrages and won handily, 23 to 14.

For his NBC Symphony Orchestra concert last night at Radio City, Arturo Toscanini reached back to about a hundred years ago and chose five composers who, though their lives spanned the better part of the nineteenth century, were contemporaries for some three decades.

Rain brought an armistice today in the controversy over Washington's famous Japanese cherry trees. Workmen, due to the inclement weather, could not resume their excavations for the new Thomas Jefferson Memorial.

Early toy activity in retail stores was good last week, presaging December gains in volume, in the opinion of retail executives who are watching the trends in this division of the gift field closely. In a number of instances the increases were notably heavy, rising well above last year on several days of the week.
The dollar closed firm against the pound here today at $4.70 1/8. The pound weakened on the absence of any provision in the Anglo-American trade treaty for a fixed rate.

The engagement of Miss Peggy Lane Valentine, daughter of Mrs. Marie L. Valentine of 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, to Philip H. Lustig 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. Lustig of the Lombardy, has been announced by her mother.
Frederic Pruyn, retired Albany banker and business man, died today of pneumonia at a hunting lodge at Newcomb in the Adirondacks, friends in Albany were advised tonight.

For gardeners who are interested in growing and studying herbs and in sixteenth century knot-garden designs, a trip to the new herb garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is well worth while. A recent leaflet lists the herbs according to their medicinal, culinary and poisonous qualities.

The trustees of Bradford Junior College announced today, through George A. Parker of Boston, chairman of the building committee, that contracts had been let and the construction of two new college buildings would start immediately.

The possibility that the city may operate the Sixth Avenue elevated line for a while before it starts to tear it down was indicated yesterday when it was disclosed that the Municipal Civil Service Commission has invited the Board of Transportation to send representatives to a conference to discuss "the taking over by the city of operation of the Sixth Avenue line."
Tulane ran up 31 points on the litthe Sewanee football squad in the first half today and coasted through the final two quarters to a 38-to-0 victory.
